title: Too Many Cooks?
description: Jeff Burger, a junior from Cedartown, Ga., will start the season at quarterback for Auburn, and boy, is he getting a lot of advice on how to play the position.

title: PERU MAY ASK BANKS FOR MAJOR DEBT CONCESSIONS
description: With the atmosphere already clouded by the International Monetary Fund's recent suspension of new loans to this country, Peru plans to seek sweeping concessions from its commercial creditors when debt-rescheduling talks resume shortly in New York.

title: FILLY FIRST AT BELMONT
description: Funistrada, the only 3-year-old and the only filly in a field of stakes-winning older sprinters, scooted through on the inside under low weight to score a major upset in the $114,400 Fall Highweight Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: TROUBLED YANKEES LOSE TO MARINERS
description: The results had brought only moderate satisfaction. Lou Piniella was relieved that one more day had gone by without disaster, that he had taken certain calculated risks and survived. But even as the Yankees wound up a five-game, four-day stay here tonight, losing the finale by a 6-2 margin, there were still serious deliberations left for their rookie manager.

title: U.S.-Seoul Air Talks Fail
description: American-Korean talks on expanding air service ended in failure Friday. Korean Air Lines, which flies to Honolulu, Los Angeles and New York, wants to add Anchorage, Oakland, Calif., and Chicago.

title: Japan Lowers Growth Goal
description: The stronger yen has forced the Japanese Government to cut its real annual growth-rate forecast to 2.8 percent, from 4 percent, for fiscal 1986-87, reports said today.

title: NEW NAME AND IMAGE FOR HARRY ROTHMAN
description: For 60 years, it was Harry Rothman's, a store legendary for quality men's suits at discount prices. Next week it will be Rothman's, a streamlining of the name that, its proprietor hopes, will signal a trendier image and attract a younger, more affluent crowd.

title: NEW GOAL IS TO TRAIN TEACHERS
description: As schools in the metropolitan region prepare to open for the new school year, many districts, responding to a national move for more professional teaching, are encouraging teachers to take extra training on how to perform in the classroom.

title: TUGGLE, EX-GIANT, DIES OF CANCER AT 25
description: John Tuggle, who made the Giants football team in 1983 despite having been the 335th and last player chosen in the National Football League draft that year, died Saturday after a two-year battle with cancer. He was 25 years old.

title: Off, Off Off Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: 1919 Peace Conference
description: WILSON AND HIS PEACEMAKERS:

title: SEX SHIRTS AND SIGNS; POTION, TOO
description: The medium is a black billboard emblazoned with huge letters asking ''What's an orgy?'' But the message is sex education, not titillation.

title: RED SOX TRY TO SHUCK THEIR LOSING LEGACY
description: LOU PINIELLA recalls September 1978, vividly.

title: Nicole Mock, Reporter, Weds Philip Leibovitz
description: Nicole Mock, the daughter of Belle Perron of London and Robert C. Mock of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Philip Leibovitz, a son of Col. Samuel Leibovitz, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Leibovitz of Silver Spring, Md., and St. Thomas, V.I. Rabbi Richard Block performed the ceremony at Mr. Mock's home.

title: NEW YORK SUBURBS OFFER JOBS BUT A DAUNTING COST OF LIVING
description: After five years of steady business expansion, New York City's suburbs face a quandary: thousands of jobs wait to be filled, but the soaring cost of suburban life is making some newly arrived workers sorry they came.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Factory Orders July Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment

title: Student Pilot Dies in Crash
description: A student pilot was killed this morning when his small airplane crashed in the yard of a home in a residential area, the authorities said. Sgt. John Burke of the Egg Harbor Township police identified the victim as James Spade, 22 years old, of McKee City, N.J. A Federal Aviation Administration duty officer, Jacques Astre, said investigators were trying to determine what caused the 11:41 A.M. crash of the plane, a Cessna 152.

title: A VOLCKER TRADE GAP WARNING
description: The widening United States trade deficit is ''simply unsustainable'' and may lead to global economic instability, Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said tonight.

title: PIRATES CHASE KNEPPER TO DEFEAT ASTROS
description: Jim Morrison had two hits and knocked in two runs, and Bob Walk allowed seven hits in seven innings today to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Houston Astros, 8-2.

title: Oman Cuts Oil Output
description: Oman announced today that it would cut 50,000 barrels a day from its 600,000 barrels-a-day oil production from Sept. 1 until further notice.

title: Peggy Silberthau Is Bride Of James Edelson, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Peggy Diane Silberthau, a marketing representative for ESI/Morgan Stanley in New York, to James Irwin Edelson, an associate with the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hayes & Handler, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silverman, performed the ceremony.

title: Not a Benign Method
description: To the Editor:

title: GAMBLER SEIZED IN TWO SLAYINGS AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: A Georgia commercial fisherman described by authorities as a well-known gambler was being held today in the poisoning deaths of two college students found in his casino hotel room.

title: Laurie E. Morrison Is Wed To Joshua Mitchell Baskin
description: Laurie Ellen Morrison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leslie Morrison of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joshua Mitchell Baskin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Baskin of Poughkeepsie. Rabbi Irwin Zimet performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El, assisted by Cantor Joseph Wieselman.

title: VALENZUELA DEFEATS DARLING AND METS
description: Every now and then, somebody like Fernando Valenzuela will come along and give the Mets a shot of reality, and that's what happened yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium.

title: C. H. BUTCHER ACQUITTED OF 25 COUNTS
description: A Federal jury found C. H. Butcher Jr. innocent on Saturday of charges that he had lied to investors and covered up insider loans that led to the 1983 bankruptcy of his finance company.

title: Extraordinary Fan Mail
description: When Ed Walker, a Washington radio personality, returned to station WRC after a stint at the competing WMAL, he got a fan letter from a listener who shared Mr. Walker's enthusiasm for big bands, Frank Sinatra and Nat (King) Cole.

title: NEW PRODUCTS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: Manufacturers are discovering that products for the elderly can make them money as well as fill a need.

title: Cram Defeats Coe
description: Steve Cram of Britain retained his European 1,500 meters title today by beating Sebastian Coe on the last day of the European track and field championships.

title: Gangster Killed in Naples
description: A suspected boss of the Naples Mafia was shot dead today in a crowded fish market, the police said. The man, Matteo Vezzi, 41 years old, died instantly when an unidentified man on a motor scooter fired a pistol at him from close range.

title: FOR EX-HORMEL WORKERS, NO FORGIVE AND FORGET
description: If there is one thing that Cindi Bellrichard knows she will never forget or forgive, it is seeing workers cross union picket lines last January to get jobs at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company meatpacking plant here.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Stefan Edberg vs. Dan Goldie Second Match - Martina Navratilova vs.

title: THE TRAIN TO THE CITY, A NIGHT OF ADVENTURE
description: Armed with a subway map, the Michelin guide and less cash than many Manhattanites spend on lunch, Sot Johnson set forth from Highland Park, N.J., for the Emerald City. It was the last week of August and he and his friends were enacting one of the great summer rituals, a voyage chronicled from ''Act One'' to ''Saturday Night Fever,'' the teen-ager's discovery of New York City.

title: Unions Absent on Sunday Are Dead on Monday
description: Most union activists are not in a celebratory mood on this Labor Day. In addition to recalling that Ronald Reagan, the most explicitly antilabor President since Herbert Hoover, was re-elected with the support of 49 percent of union members, they see that decisions by the National Labor Relations Board would warrant its changing its name to the National Association of Manufacturers. Meanwhile, union membership has declined to 19 percent of the workforce.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1986
description: International

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE: Eyesore and Earsore; Peer Pressure
description: A year ago, New York City barred loud radio noise in Central Park's Sheep Meadow and at four city beaches. Skeptics notwithstanding, the noise ban has worked, and the success now leads the city to decree silence for 10 more park sites.

title: Senators Get Ratings On Conservative Votes
description: The American Conservative Union has given perfect scores on its annual ratings to five Republican Senators.

title: JERSEY CURBS SMOKING IN ITS OFFICIAL BUILDINGS
description: The smoke-filled room and government have come to a parting of the ways.

title: DRIVE-IN: TRADITION BENEATH THE L.I. STARS
description: On one 80-foot wall, a bedraggled woman was shrieking in terror. On another, cars sped wildly through city streets. On yet a third wall, a skinny man was turning into a slimy insect. And in the middle of all this, in a high-gloss red Corvette, a young couple noshed on nachos and nuzzled. It was a typical evening at the Westbury Drive-In Theater, the last drive-in picture show in Nassau County.

title: HULBERT GETS BIRDIE ON 18TH FOR VICTORY
description: Mike Hulbert sank a one-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to beat his childhood friend, Joey Sindelar, by one stroke in the St. Jude Classic.

title: Kaiser Steel Reports Loss
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation has reported a $13 million loss for the second quarter, in contrast to a $1.2 million profit a year earlier.

title: Selecting Wedding Guests
description: KATHY MEYER and Dr. Donald James of New York City have a big job ahead of them this fall: paring their preliminary list of 280 wedding guests to a manageable 100.

title: CRASH FOLLOWS PATTERN FEARED BY SAFETY AIDES
description: The collision today between a Mexican airliner and a small private plane in southern California was the first serious accident in the nation this year, when crowded skies and an understaffed air traffic control system have caused concern about air safety.

title: SLUR AGAINST KING SPURS THAI CRISIS
description: Less than a month after taking office, a new Thai Government has been forced into a political crisis over charges that a Cabinet minister defamed the monarchy.

title: EMERSON'S PUSH TO EXPAND
description: Whenever the nation's top corporate executives are asked who is the best manager among them, Charles F. Knight, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Emerson Electric Company, ranks in the top five.

title: W. B. Crenshaw And C. C. Hauge Exchange Vows
description: Caroline Clark Hauge, an account executive at J. Walter Thompson USA, and William Bradford Crenshaw, a fourth-year student at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, were married yesterday in Jackson, Wyo. The Rev. Frank Johnson, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Gabriel Hauge.

title: PENN STATE STILL TOP CHOICE
description: EMPHASIS, deemphasis and status quo are all represented in the spectrum of college football in the East this year.

title: DANNY (THE GREEN) HATCHES SURPRISES
description: He is 41 now, still impish and boyish-looking with freckles and a shaggy mane of red hair. But Daniel Cohn-Bendit, firebrand of the 1968 student upheavals that shook the Continent and even the world, is getting almost respectable, musing, with a touch of what he calls ''megalomania,'' about becoming Foreign Minister of West Germany.

title: How Labor Could Lead
description: Recently on the ''Today'' show, workers at a company that had adopted a four-day workweek talked enthusiastically about the change. The advantages, they said, far outweighed the drawbacks. In a discussion that followed, a spokesman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. opposed the four-day week.

title: One Dead as Gunman Opens Fire on a Van
description: A gunman opened fire on a van carrying 14 Vietnamese people home from a dance in Chinatown early yesterday morning, killing the driver and wounding a passenger, the police said.

title: 150 Flee Chemical Spill
description: A freight train carrying hydrochloric acid derailed in north-central Ohio early today, forcing the evacuation of about 150 people as the chemical spilled from a ruptured tank car. No injuries were reported. The evacuated people, mostly residents of Willard, spent the night at a junior high school.

title: E. F.Hutton to Seek Reprieve
description: It has been more than a year now since the overdraft scandal hit E. F. Hutton & Company. And for almost a year, the giant New York brokerage firm has been seeking to get out from under a particularly omnious legal cloud.

title: Texas and North Carolina Raise Drinking Age to 21
description: Starting Monday, people under 21 years old will not be able to quench their thirst with alcoholic drinks in Texas and North Carolina as those states become the latest to raise their legal drinking age.

title: Susan Landsman Wed To Ethan E. Silverman
description: Susan Joy Landsman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Landsman of Montreal, was married yesterday to Ethan Elijah Silverman, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. David Wolf Silverman of Philadelphia. The bridegroom's father and Rabbi Wilfred Schuchat officiated at the Shaar Hashomayim Synagogue in Westmount, Quebec.

title: Gen. Sherman's 13 Years of Smithing Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Cloud in Cameroon Preceded by Explosions
description: The cloud of volcanic gas that burst from Lake Nios and killed more than 1,500 people was preceded by a series of explosions heard by villagers a few hours earlier, an Italian scientist said today.

title: Brett's Shoulder To Be Examined
description: George Brett flew to Los Angeles today to have his right shoulder examined by Dr. Frank Jobe, the Royals said. The third baseman reported soreness in the shoulder joint after diving for a ball Friday night during a game against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: A Labor Day Sampler
description: Labor can do nothing without capital, capital nothing without labor, and neither labor nor capital can do anything without the guiding genius of management; and management, however wise its genius may be, can do nothing without the privileges which the community affords. $$- W. L. Mackenzie King, Montreal, 1919

title: U.S. PLANS ANTI-SOVIET MEASURES IF AMERICAN REPORTER IS NOT FREED
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States would retaliate against the Soviet Union unless a U.S. News & World Report correspondent arrested in Moscow Saturday was freed promptly.

title: U.S. BORROWERS LURED ABROAD
description: Major American companies are lining up to tap the emerging market overseas for short-term loans. At a time when business borrowing in the United States has remained sluggish despite the decline in interest rates, some 240 American corporations now have more than $25 billion in short-term loans outstanding with overseas lenders.

title: Mortgage Rate Below 10%
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said Saturday that its nationwide average for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 9.93 percent in the latest weekly survey, down from 10.04 percent the week before.

title: FRENCH REBEL AND LYRICIST REMEMBERED
description: For two years Marguerite Eckert has been waging a campaign from her home in this medieval town to persuade the French Government to honor the centennial of her grandfather's death.

title: Labor Day Observance
description: In observance of Labor Day, the stock markets and commodity exchanges and most businesses in the United States and Canada will be closed today. Federal, state and local government offices will also be closed.

title: Paul Brickfield Is Wed To Nancy Scappaticci
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great in Harrison, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Jean Scappaticci, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mario L. Scappaticci of Harrison, to Paul Boyton Brickfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Brickfield of Brooklyn. The Rev. William E. Williams performed the ceremony.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECOLLECTING

title: A Weaker Net Under Workers
description: A century after the founding of the labor movement and five decades after the New Deal inaugurated legislation protecting workers, the nation should celebrate the tremendous progress in workers' lives. Wages and working conditions have improved dramatically, with a huge assist from Federal policies that have helped the unemployed find jobs, established a minimum wage and working standards and insured that retired older workers have enough income to live in dignity. But in the 80's this web of protections has weakened. Congress has retained basic laws that protect workers, but budgetary cuts and inadequate legislative oversight have undermined the support the laws provide.

title: OUTDOORS: MIXING FALL PURSUITS
description: SUMMER'S lease was challenged by tropical storm Charley's recent sideswipe of the Northeastern Seaboard, and although seasonable warmth will return, he who both hunts and fishes will be enmeshed in the ambivalence that the first hint of fall engenders.

title: Japan Yields a Bit on Airport
description: Sometime in 1993, if everything goes as planned, an airport will open in central Japan on a man-made island about to be built in Osaka Bay.

title: Chile Loan Postponement
description: Warnings by the Reagan Administration that it would oppose further World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank loans if Chile's leaders did not improve their human rights record, appear to have shaken the ruling junta a bit. According to the Center for International Policy, Chile asked that final consideration of some $250 million in multilateral development bank loans be postponed until November.

title: QADDAFI SAYS U.S. ATTACK WOULD BRING RETALIATION
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in a speech that lasted nearly three hours before it ended early this morning, ridiculed reports that there was a power struggle in Libya and said that if there were further American hostilities against his country he would form and lead an ''international army'' to attack American interests everywhere.

title: German Archives Bombed
description: A bomb exploded early today at a Government building that houses files on resident aliens in West Germany. The 1 A.M. blast caused up to $100,000 in damage to the facade of the documentation center, the police said. No one was hurt, they said.

title: HENRY MOORE, SCULPTOR OF AN AGE, DIES AT 88
description: Henry Moore, a sculptor pre-eminent in 20th-century art and a particular and longtime favorite in the United States, where he was represented by carvings, bronzes and drawings almost beyond number in both public and private collections, died early yesterday at his home in Much Hadham, England. He was 88 years old. No cause of death was given, but he had been ill with arthritis and diabetes.

title: Lloyds Sale Completed
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said Friday it had completed the sale of its Lloyds Bank of California subsidiary to the Golden State Sanwa Bank unit of Sanwa Bank of Japan for $263 million. It said the combined bank would have assets of about $4.5 billion and operate under the name of Sanwa Bank California. As of June 30, Lloyds Bank of California had assets of $3 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1986
description: Companies

title: New Approach By Texas Air?
description: WHEN the Transporation Department rejected the Texas Air Corporation's bid last week for Eastern Air Lines Inc., the message seemed simple: Give Pan American World Airways a few more takeoff and landing slots at New York's La Guardia Airport and the deal will be approved.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 1, 1986: MONDAY None Reported TUESDAY Albertson's Inc WEDNESDAY Alaska Air Group Pennwalt Corp Allen Group Inc Premier Industrial Browning-Ferris Starrett (LS) Co Louisville Gas & Elec THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Planning Research Atlantic City Elec SPS Technologies Brown Group FRIDAY Bay State Gas Disney Productions

title: JOHN BIRCH GROUP HAS MONEY WOES
description: The John Birch Society, the group that has crusaded for 28 years against big government and what it views as a world Communist conspiracy, has come upon hard times.

title: A Soupcon of Montmartre On West 42d Street
description: A glimmer of Gay Paree will soon emerge from Chez Josephine, at 412 West 42d Street. A homage to Josephine Baker, the world-renowned chanteuse who died in April 1975, it is an evocation of the night spot that the legendary entertainer ran in Montmartre in 1926, and in New York 10 years later.

title: Tax Bill Summary for Sale
description: What is likely to be one of the best-selling books in Washington this week is an 80-page summary of the new tax bill, prepared by the Joint Committee on Taxation.

title: Gelco's Founder Makes A Crossroads Choice
description: When N. Bud Grossman formed the Gelco Corporation in 1958, he entered a growing truck-leasing industry. Now Gelco has reached a crossroads. Deregulation, coupled with overcapacity and wide swings in the nation's economy, has forced Gelco's earnings down. The price of the company's stock fell so low that a potential takeover loomed.

title: Canada Growth Shows Upturn
description: The Canadian Government has reported stronger-than-expected economic growth in the second quarter, sparking optimism about the rest of the year.

title: A Message for Dukakis
description: To the Editor:

title: LIST OF CASUALTIES ON DC-9
description: Following is a list, released by Aeromexico, of passengers aboard the jetliner. From Mexico ESPINOSA, Clemente CARO, Aurea From Guadalajara PENA, Oscar PENA, Maria C. PENA, Maria G. PENA, Elizabeth LEANOS, Raul LEANOS, Elba From Laredo GARCIA, Mrs. P. GARCIA, L. HARMELING, Sher KAPTOWSKY, Robert WINLACK, Don WONG, Dr. D. WONG, [ initial unavailable ] WON, J. CROSNO, Mrs. H. CROSNO, Mrs. R. MALIS, Mrs. R. HENDRICKS, Sharon HENDRICKS, Wendy RUSH, Mr. FREDERICK, RUSH, Mrs. Donald SICAIROS, Mrs. D. SICAIROS, G. SICAIRIOS, George, (age 7) SICAIRIOS, Gabriel, (age 10) BARRERO, Carmen HUERTA, Gregorio GUZMAN, Manuel CORELIA, Mark CORELIA, Frank GUZMAN, Robert BASLEY, Tom GUZMAN, Joe BOOKER, Dyron NAVIS, Mrs. G. NAVIS, R. WINLACK, Georgia From Tijuana ECHEVERRIA, Juan REYES, Jesus LOPEZ, Carlos LOPEZ, Guadalupe LOPEZ, Carlos (child) GONZALEZ, Dinora OJEDA, Rosa Maria AVILA, Andres (child) AVILA, Andrea (child) FERRUFINO, Israel FERRUFINO, Luz GUTIERREZ, Hector GUTIERREZ, Teresa VENTURA, Jaime STEIN, Sandy STEIN, Stanley KNIGHT, P. KNIGHT, R. KNIGHT, R. LIST OF CREW MEMBERS LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (UPI) - Following is a list released by Aeromexico of crew members aboard Flight 498: The Crew VALDEZ PROM, Capt. Arturo VALENCIA, First Officer Hector SANCHEZ, Alma DIAZ, Rosalia TRILLO-LOPEZ, Palma BALLESTEROS, Laura

title: INJURED HAJI-SHEIKH MAY LOSE HIS JOB
description: Ali Haji-Sheikh's career as a Giant may be over for the season, perhaps forever.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Reaping a Profit
description: Hundreds of Nebraskan farm families are facing foreclosure this harvest season, and, had it not been for the popularity of Cornhusker football and their own ingenuity, Don and Anne Grubb might have been among them. The Grubbs moved from Colorado in 1972 and began working a 200-acre spread in Sutherland, Neb., while Don, a 51-year-old former Denver and Los Angeles policeman, taught criminology at the local community college. ''We farm for additional income,'' Mrs. Grubb says, ''but with the farm prices the way they are, we just kept falling farther and farther behind, and we were afraid we'd have to give it up.''

title: IRANIANS INCITE LEBANESE SHIITES TO MILITANCY
description: Increasing activity by Iranians in Lebanon appears to have further radicalized local Shiite Moslem militants, undermining new moves by the Government to bring an end to the 11-year-old civil war.

title: UNITED PILOTS' CHIEF FENDS OFF CRITICS
description: Roger Hall, the head of United Airlines' pilots, is a man without many admirers these days.

title: Bank Bill Gains In California
description: California lawmakers, under intense lobbying pressure from New York banks, have passed legislation that will open California to interstate banking.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS, at Shea Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 1:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1:30 P.M.).

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE: Eyesore and Earsore; Behind in Brooklyn
description: The renovation of Brooklyn's once-stately Borough Hall will recall much of the 140-year-old city landmark's glory. But so far the project recalls only city construction fiascoes like the Wollman skating rink.

title: A.M.I. Chief Pursues A Slimming Program
description: Walter L. Weisman, president and chief executive of American Medical International Inc., sees the restructuring of the for-profit hospital chain as similar to his own fitness regime.

title: DETROIT'S SYMBOL OF REVIVAL NOW EPITOMIZES ITS PROBLEMS
description: Nearly 10 years after it opened as a symbol of this city's renewal efforts, the Renaissance Center has become emblematic of Detroit's inability to sustain a thriving retail district.

title: Trade Mission Minus Jet
description: Signaling unusually great interest in one contentious trade issue, the White House has given a group of American business officials permission to travel to Japan soon as a Presidential delegation. It is the first time in recent memory that an export group has been so designated.

title: China Cites Shortages
description: Shortages of gasoline, power and credit are hampering rural factories, the fastest-growing sector of the Chinese economy, The China Daily said Friday.

title: CONCERT: BRITTEN'S 'WAR REQUIEM'
description: Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem'' was composed in 1961 for the rebuilt cathedral in Coventry, of which an agonized Churchill had made a tactical sacrifice in World War II. Britten wrote it for three soloists who were nationals of old or new antagonists: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau came from walled West Berlin to join Peter Pears for the premiere in 1962, but Galina Vishnevskaya was not permitted to travel from Russia (she arrived for later performances and a recording). The work reached the United States the following year, at Tanglewood, where the Boston Symphony Orchestra took it up again in a moving performance that closed the current season here this afternoon.

title: FORM OVER FUNCTION: MINIMALISM'S DEAD END
description: ''Break It Down,'' Lydia Davis's new collection of fiction, just out from Farrar, Straus & Giroux, gives us 34 stories in 177 pages. Half a dozen of these ''stories'' are no more than a page - or a paragraph - long. The one called ''Safe Love'' reads in its entirety:

title: Ellen Leslie Fox Becomes a Bride
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday Ellen Leslie Fox, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Fox of Roslyn, L.I., was married to Dr. Jeffrey David Spiro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Spiro of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony.

title: An Orchard St. Merchant Hits the Airwaves
description: Who needed commercials?

title: MUSIC: FANIA ALL STARS AT THE GARDEN
description: Labor Day weekend salsa concerts at Madison Square Garden, featuring the Fania All Stars, have become a New York tradition. The audience at the Garden on Saturday was as vociferous in its enthusiasm as any salsa crowd one can recall. If the New York Latin sound is in danger of losing its younger audience to funk and rap, as some observers have suggested, the crowd at Saturday's concert did not seem to be aware of it.

title: HOLMES JOINS JETS AND IS HURT
description: It took more than two years for Jerry Holmes to rejoin the Jets, and only 73 minutes today for the cornerback to become a victim of what Coach Joe Walton ruefully called ''the ankle disease.''

title: Fans Boo Decision to Bar Favored Walking Horse
description: Fights and booing erupted among 28,000 fans at the Tennessee Walking Horse National Celebration when the favored championship contender was disqualified because it might have been intentionally injured.

title: 3d Crash for Mexico's Airlines
description: The fatal crash today was the third this year for Mexico's airlines.

title: AT LEAST 69 DEAD
description: An Aeromexico jetliner approaching the Los Angeles International Airport collided with a small private plane today, raining destruction on a quiet residential neighborhood as bodies and fiery debris hurtled to the ground.

title: L.I. CANDIDATE CONCEDES HE GOT TAPES ON A RIVAL
description: A Democratic candidate for Congress from Long Island paid female investigators to meet his opponent, Representative Raymond J. McGrath, in a Washington restaurant and to secretly tape-record conversations with him.

title: What, No Cotton Candy?
description: Washington's newest tourist attraction is not a museum or a Government building. It is the Willard Hotel, rescued from the wrecking ball and now restored to its old splendor.

title: U.S. SKIPPER HOPEFUL DESPITE LATE START
description: Warren Luhrs, the American skipper who was forced to return to shore for repairs Saturday at the start of the BOC solo yacht race around the world, set sail again today more determined than ever.

title: AIR COLLISIONS: TERROR ALOFT
description: Previous major international and domestic air collisions include these:

title: 2 Thrift Units Are Acquired
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has approved the acquisition of two Ohio thrift units by the Transohio Savings Bank of Cleveland.

title: MARE VICTOR IN MILLION
description: Estrapade, a 6-year-old mare, took the lead at the far turn and raced to a 4 1/2-length victory today to become the first female winner of the Budweiser-Arlington Million.

title: War on Drugs May Justify Abridged Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WANTS AQUINO TO TOUGHEN STAND ON THE INSURGENTS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were increasingly concerned by what they consider President Corazon C. Aquino's lack of effectiveness in handling insurgencies by Communists and other groups in the Philippines. They added that they wanted her to take tougher measures against them.

title: WHITE HOUSE ATTACKS DISCLOSURES BY OFFICIALS ON ARMS-TALKS STAND
description: The White House issued an unusual and sharply worded statement today deploring the actions of Reagan Administration officials in disclosing Washington's intention to relax its nuclear arms negotiating stand in talks with the Soviet Union.

title: AIR FORCE WEIGHS WING COMPETITION
description: In a highly unusual move, the Air Force is making plans to open the bidding for the contract to manufacture the wings of the C-17 aircraft, even though the project's prime contractor, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, plans to produce the wings itself.

title: Tanks For the Memories
description: When a supporter of William Jennings Bryan proudly claimed that his candidate made 16 speeches in a single day's campaigning, an opposing politician wondered: ''When does he think?''

title: Two Iranian Airmen Are Said to Defect to Iraq
description: Iraq said today that two Iranian airmen defected with their American-made F-4 Phantom jet fighter and landed safely at an Iraqi air base.

title: Damaged Hospital Inspected
description: A hospital closed after a transformer fire will remain shut at least until Tuesday while experts try to determine whether smoke from the blaze carried toxic chemicals inside, officials said Saturday. Lightning touched off the fire Thursday in a transformer outside the 228-bed John C. Lincoln Hospital and Health Center. The transformer contained 450 gallons of cooling fluid with polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, which have caused cancer in laboratory animals.

title: HORROR ON A QUIET BLOCK UNFOLDS WITH A BOOM
description: Rigo Uribe was inside his house at midday today when he heard a loud roar ''getting closer and closer.''

title: ELITE SWISS SCHOOLS SAY CURBS COULD FORCE THEM TO CLOSE
description: The Swiss Government has proposed regulations that would drastically cut the number of foreign students at private secondary and finishing schools. Educators say the move could seriously threaten the schools' existence and end a tradition of elite international education.

title: A 'SOAP' CELEBRATES 6,000th EPISODE
description: Will Monica, who is having an affair with Sean, decide to visit her boys in Switzerland after her fight with Sean? Will Tiffany and Edward be successful in their scheme to drive a wedge between Monica and Sean? And, in the meantime, will Alan, who is believed to be dead, leave the lovely Charity and return to picturesque Port Charles to clear Sean's tainted name?

title: LIFE IN MIAMI: WHERE HOLIDAY AND WEATHER MARCH TO A DIFFERENT DRUMMER
description: About the only common Labor Day elements people in Miami share with the rest of the nation are television programming and the task of getting children ready to start school on Tuesday.

title: A Rosy View of the State of Labor: Bill Brock
description: How is American labor doing? On the eve of Labor Day, Labor Secretary Bill Brock talked about some of the issues facing American workers.

title: Deborah Surnamer Married
description: Deborah Jane Surnamer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Surnamer of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Goldhair, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Goldhair of White Plains. Rabbi David B. Kahane officiated at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Mrs. Goldhair is a financial supervisor of Ogilvy & Mather Promotions in New York City. Her husband is president of Milton Goldhair Associates, a New York office products company founded by his father.

title: Unclear How Widely The Drug Will Spread
description: As public officials and government agencies react to crack and cocaine use in the United States, drug abuse experts are still struggling to define the full dimensions of the crack problem and whom it affects.

title: CONNORS FALLS TO WITSKEN
description: He has refused to acknowledge that his time may have passed. He wags a finger at the skeptics in protest, the way he does when lecturing a linesman or chair umpire. But it has been 22 months now since Jimmy Connors last won a grand prix tournament, and yesterday, he was soundly defeated on the hardcourts of New York, in the stadium that has been a second home. There are signs of autumn in the air and Connors chooses not to notice.

title: DIAGNOSTIC KITS BURGEONING
description: Ever since the first home testingkit for pregnancy was marketed about 10 years ago, the nation's big drug companies have had high hopes that they could develop an array of kits that test for everything from cancer to strep throat. The goal was to sell the kits not only to patients for use at home but also to doctors, who often have to wait for laboratory results.

title: EMPLOYEES ARE UPBEAT ON UNIONS
description: Union memberships have plummeted, organizing is more difficult and nonunion jobs have multiplied, labor experts say, but as the nation celebrates Labor Day, they see a basic resiliency within unions, where members still view the future with optimism, labor experts say.

title: Joey Heatherton Arrested
description: Joey Heatherton, the entertainer, was charged today with stabbing her drummer in the hand with a steak knife and with cocaine possession, authorities said. Miss Heaterton, who is 41 years old, was released on $1,500 bail after pleading not guilty here at her arraignment. Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz said the stabbing stemmed from a ''professional dispute'' with the drummer, Jerry Fisher.

title: Dr. Maria L. Buttolph Weds Dr. Robert I. Tepper
description: The marriage of Dr. Maria Lynn Buttolph, a second-year resident in the department of psychiatry at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, to Dr. Robert Ira Tepper, chief resident in the department of medicine at the hospital, took place yesterday. Rabbi Gordon Richards and the Rev. Douglas Phillips, a Presbyerian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. David D. Buttolph, in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dutch Chemical Giant Adapts
description: When Aarnout Loudon joined Akzo N.V. in 1969, its corporate feet were planted firmly in the business of chemical fibers. And that, the company's executives now agree, was like standing amid quicksand.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We saw the two planes, but what we could really see was the tail on the big plane.

title: Nurses in Boston End Their 48-Hour Strike
description: Eight hundred nurses at three city-operated hospitals ended their 48-hour walkout as scheduled today after they were found in contempt of court and their union was fined $20,000 for missing two shifts.

title: SOVIET REPORTS CASUALTIES IN EUROPEAN QUAKE
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass reported today that an earthquake that rumbled across southeastern Europe had caused casualties in the Soviet republic of Moldavia, without specifying how many or the type of casualties.

title: Charlotte Ford Wed to Edward Downe Jr.
description: Charlotte Ford, a daughter of Henry Ford 2d of Detroit and Mrs. Deane F. Johnson of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married last evening to Edward Reynolds Downe Jr., the son of Mrs. Edward D. Lane of New York and the late Edward R. Downe. The Rev. John Twiname, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Miss Ford's Southampton home.

title: Farmers, Not Prices, Need Cash Support
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'ORESTEIA,' AESCHYLUS' TRAGEDY
description: In the history of theater, the Greek tragedy entitled ''The Oresteia'' remains a towering achievement both as magnificent drama and as a seminal work in that crucial period when a member of the chorus, in what was essentially a religious pageant, stepped forward to become a curious new phenomenon called an actor. For better or worse, show business was born.

title: LLOYD WINS IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: Like many young women before her, Mary Joe Fernandez makes no secret of her admiration for Chris Evert Lloyd. In style of play, dress and manner, she resembles the player she calls her idol.

title: 4 STATES HOLD KEY TO CONTROL OF SENATE
description: When the intensive phase of the struggle for control of the Senate opens on Monday, nine weeks before Election Day, the Republicans will be watching developments in four states with special interest: Louisiana, Missouri, Colorado and California.

title: TAX BILL WILL MOVE UP DEADLINE ON STUDENT AID
description: New details of the tax revision bill, including an earlier-than-expected effective date for student scholarships that would be subject to taxation, are contained in a Congressional report scheduled to be made public this week.

title: CITY INCREASES ITS ASSISTANCE FOR DISPLACED ARTS GROUP
description: In an effort to help the scores of small arts groups that are suffering as a result of New York's rapidly rising real-estate prices, the city's Department of Cultural Affairs has doubled the budget for a year-old program of technical assistance, to $50,000.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Just how many shortstops has Willie Randolph played with in his years as second baseman for the Yankees?

title: V.I.P.'s Don't Get V.I.P. Treatment at Broadway Box Offices
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shoe Challenge For Bass Leader
description: In recent years, the Bass division of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. has suffered from the same competition as most of the rest of the shoe industry: from discounters, foreign manufacturers, excess inventory of other domestic manufacturers and even its own excess inventory.

title: U.S. PROSECUTES FARMERS SELLING LOAN COLLATERAL
description: The Reagan Administration has begun prosecuting hundreds of farmers on charges of selling crops and livestock that were used as collateral for loans from the Government or Government-regulated farm lenders.

title: PRAYERS AND SERMONS MARK SOLIDARITY ANNIVERSARY
description: Worshipers in many Polish churches marked the sixth anniversary of the Solidarity labor movement today with prayers and sermons recalling hopes that were raised with the union and dashed with its suppression.

title: Briton Winner In Pursuit Cycling
description: Tony Doyle of Britain defeated the two-time world champion, Hans-Henrik Oersted, tonight to capture the professional individual pursuit title at the World Cycling Championships.

title: INSTINCTS STEER GRAF TO TOP
description: Those who consider themselves the prognosticators of women's tennis have always been quick to anoint the young and gifted ones, to label each as the heir apparent to the crowns Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd will someday surrender.

title: Barbara Alvina Baxter Married to Marc Postman
description: Barbara Alvina Baxter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Willard E. Baxter of Newark, Del., was married yesterday to Jonathan Marc Postman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Neil Postman of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. David Kaplan, a Lutheran minister, officiated with Cantor Shelley Rakofsky at D'Ignazio's Nottingham (Pa.) Inn.

title: K.G.B. SAYS U.S. NEWSMAN WAS SPYING
description: The K.G.B. said today that the Moscow correspondent of U.S. News & World Report had been ''engaging in an act of espionage'' when he was detained on Saturday.

title: Poll of South Africans Omits a Key Point
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN'S DR. WHO CAPTIVATES FANS IN U.S.
description: The convoy of rainbow-colored vehicles that was to bring the traveling ''Dr. Who'' exhibition to the parking lot at the Ingleside Shopping Mall was several hours late. About 30 fans who had turned up early one recent stormy afternoon to greet this latest spinoff of their favorite, BBC-produced, science-fiction television show were not about to leave. They were certain that Dr. Who, interplanetary voyager and champion of good over evil, would not let them down.

title: JAYS TOP TWINS, 7-5, TO WIN 8TH IN ROW
description: Lloyd Moseby hit a grand slam and Willie Upshaw hit a home run and doubled today as the Toronto Blue Jays won their eighth straight game, beating the Minnesota Twins, 7-5.

title: Let the Air Controllers Return
description: On this Labor Day, Congress might begin to think about one simple step it could take to make our skies a safer place to fly. And that would be to lift the ban on rehiring the air traffic controllers who were fired during the 1981 strike of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

title: Suspected War Criminal Dies in Argentina
description: A man believed to be the Nazi war criminal Walter Kutschmann, accused in the deaths of 1,500 Polish Jews, has died of heart failure nine months after his arrest on a West German extradition request, officials said today.

title: EX-PRO WINS AMATEUR
description: Buddy Alexander took the lead on the 16th hole of the morning round and never relinquished it in capturing the 86th United States Amateur golf championship with a 5-and-3 victory over Chris Kite today.

title: The Monarch, the Mexicans and Us
description: That blur of tawny orange that streaks by on a summer afternoon is a monarch butterfly. It flies fast, having far to go, and though it's gone in a flash, it has ruled America for millennia. But now the monarch is in grave danger as builders and loggers encroach on its winter sanctuaries.

title: Richmond First In Southern 500
description: Tim Richmond passed Bill Elliott with seven laps remaining today to win the rain-delayed Southern 500 Nascar stock-car race at Darlington International Raceway.

title: STRAWBERRY HEARING IT
description: EVEN with a huge lead, there is still room for a little rancor at Shea. With the Mets rolling toward a division title, more than a few fans have decided to turn the George Foster Memorial Boo over to Darryl Strawberry, and the young right fielder is not amused.

title: Subway Clean-Car Program Continues Apace
description: Only in recent city history could such a thing be contemplated as a milestone, but a milestone it is.

title: GUEST OF SOVIET BACK WITH PLEA FOR MORE HOMES
description: Joseph Mauri, the New Yorker who has been visiting the Soviet Union in the last month to publicize the problem of homelessness in America, returned home yesterday and said he would resume his part-time job.

title: MOROCCANS ARREST 4 AS TERRORISTS
description: Four foreign Arabs, accused by the Government of planning terrorist attacks in Morocco, are under arrest, the Government said today. The development comes a month after the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, held talks with King Hassan II.

title: For Queens: Claire Shulman
description: Democrats in Queens vote next week to nominate a candidate for the three remaining years of Donald Manes's term as Borough President. The winner is almost certain to win in November.

title: Rahal Wins Race; Garza Is Injured
description: Bobby Rahal slipped past Danny Sullivan 10 laps from the end today and went on to his second straight victory here as the Escort Radar Warning 200 Indy-car race finished under a caution flag following a crash in which Josele Garza of Mexico suffered a broken leg.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Weekender Guide in Weekend on Aug. 15 about the film ''The Liberation of Auschwitz'' incorrectly described the World War II death camp in Poland. Auschwitz was operated by the German SS.

title: 1984 ATTEMPT TO FRAME DANILOFF REPORTED
description: A Soviet emigre said today that his father had refused a request by the K.G.B. two years ago to give Nicholas Daniloff ''some documents'' so that it could frame him.

title: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
description: * American Medcenters Inc., Minneapolis, named Loren N. Vorlicky chairman and chief executive to succeed Glen D. Nelson, who resigned.

title: Bridge: Impact of Puritan Tradition May Linger in Today's Game
description: The Puritan tradition, which labeled playing cards as the ''Devil's tickets,'' may account for one aspect of modern tournament play: Catholic priests often compete, Protestant ministers rather rarely.

title: Examining the Testers
description: When the Equine Drug Testing Program at Cornell University reversed itself three weeks ago on the finding of a banned medication in a horse that had run fourth in the Breeders' Cup Turf last November, virtually everyone in New York racing was suddenly asking the same question: If a mistake had occurred in post-race testing of one of the year's premier events, could the testing done on tens of thousands of other races in the state annually be trusted?

title: HOW TO BRUSH UP SHAKESPEARE WITH A LEAN PURSE
description: It sounds like such stuff as nightmares are made on, but British theater professionals have begun warning of an emerging shortage of the very grace and sinew of the British stage - gifted young actors and directors rooted in the plays of Shakespeare.

title: Newsmaker
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATIONARY RELAPSE DISMAYS ARGENTINA
description: Dismayed by the resurgence of inflation over the past two months, the Government of President Raul Alfonsin has gone on a search for the means to halt it. So far, a new central bank president has been named and tighter monetary practices promised.

title: STAKES MAY RISE FOR HUNTS
description: The stakes in the pitched battle between the wealthy Hunt brothers and their major banks appear certain to climb much higher than the $2.2 billion in assets the Hunts shielded from bank foreclosures last Friday in three bankruptcy filings.

title: DAIRY QUEEN'S BLIZZARD IS HOT
description: Hard-core ice cream fanatics may discuss the butterfat content of Haagen-Dazs, the vanilla beans in Ben & Jerry's, the chocolate that coats the Dove bar. But in America's soft ice cream underbelly, the bestseller this summer has been the Blizzard: a super thick, soft-serve ice cream shake, mixed with chopped-up Heath Bars, Snickers, M & M's, Oreos and the like, that is sold at Dairy Queens.

title: ACCOUNTING SHIFT WOULD ENHANCE BALANCE SHEETS
description: Corporate financial statements would be altered dramatically and companies would appear a lot healthier under new accounting rules to be proposed this week by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: ROBERT WILSON'S VISION OF THEATER AS SPECTACLE
description: Robert Wilson, the 44-year-old director and mastermind behind some of the most extravagant theatrical spectacles of modern times, has been turning his energies increasingly toward classical theater and opera.

title: CREDITORS PLAN TO ASK COURT SHIFT
description: Lawyers for 18 major lenders to the Placid Oil Company said today that, after working through the Labor Day weekend, they were prepared to ask a Federal district judge to relocate bankruptcy proceedings for Placid to Dallas from New Orleans.

title: The Bike Patrol
description: A cheer to the New York City Police Department for finally acting to tame bicycle messengers who plunge through traffic and pedestrian crowds in midtown Manhattan.

title: Louis Phillips Is Wed to Miss Saltzman
description: Jacqueline Saltzman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Saltzman of Sayreville, N.J., and Louis Michael Phillips, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Phillips of New York and Los Angeles, were married yesterday. Rabbi Judah Nadich and Cantor David Lefkowitz officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Liberian Forces Put on Alert On Rumors of Coming Unrest
description: The Liberian Elwa radio said today that security forces had been placed on full alert because of what the Justice Ministry described as ''rumors of impending upheaval and public civil disobedience.''

title: AQUINO ADMINISTRATION PUZZLED BY CRITICISM FROM U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Philippine officials reacted with puzzlement and irritation today to what they said were unfair criticisms by Reagan Administration officials of the Manila Government's approach to combating insurgency.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS WARN PUBLIC ON LYME DISEASE
description: State and local health departments across the New York metropolitan area have had a busy summer warning outdoor enthusiasts of the risks of Lyme disease, which is carried by some ticks, and they say their efforts will not end with the onset of cooler weather.

title: Careers; Fall Season Arrives for Job Hunters
description: LABOR DAY is over, and the fall job-hunting season has begun.

title: BARNEYS UNVEILS WOMEN'S STORE (AT LAST)
description: In 1981, on the night Barneys New York opened its small Women's Duplex, Fred Pressman, Barney Pressman's son and president of the family-owned men's fashion store, first broached the idea of a women's store at Barneys.

title: Market Place; Future Growth In Dividends
description: PROSPECTIVE changes in the nation's tax code promise to place the after-tax return from dividend income virtually on a par, percentage-wise, with the return from capital gains. It's no wonder then that investors have been combing the market recently for stocks that pay hefty dividends.

title: 498 Steelworkers Walk Off Jobs
description: The Carpenter Technology Corporation was struck today by 498 members of the United Steelworkers of America Local 2215, who rejected a three-year contract proposal.

title: Border Vigilante Group Ousts Arizona Leader
description: The Arizona leader of a paramilitary group that detained 15 illegal aliens near the Mexican border in July has been ousted because he planned more border patrols, a spokesman said today.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Gary Donnelly vs. Boris Becker Second Match - Martina Navratilova vs.

title: Pitfalls in a Cash-Only Proposal to Aid the Poor; Worth a Try
description: To the Editor:

title: McDOWELL WINS
description: Sid Fernandez may be fat, and he may be silent, and he may throw with a strange delayed hitch of his left arm. But nobody on the Mets wins more often or strikes out batters more often, and yesterday afternoon before 44,272 fans in Shea Stadium, he was striking them out at a record rate.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: VALUATION OF CONRAIL IS DISPUTED
description: Wall Street investment bankers and analysts doubt that a public sale of the Consolidated Rail Corporation's stock, under current market conditions, would bring anywhere near the $3 billion-plus it was valued at last week in a Congressional Budget Office study.

title: Class Operation
description: The last time Fred Stolle had played the United States Open, people like John Newcombe, Bob Hewitt, Frew McMillen, Bette Stove and Billie Jean King were competing there, too. The other day, after an absence of seven years, Stolle returned to Flushing Meadows - at age 48 the oldest player in the draw - but less because he had missed the action than because he simply wanted to teach. His pupil was Mary Joe Fernandez, at 15 the youngest in the draw, and the classroom was the outer courts of the National Tennis Center, where the team of M. J. Fernandez-F. Stolle played mixed doubles.

title: L.I. Local Strikes Garbage Haulers
description: Union members working for private garbage collectors on Long Island struck today, according to a management announcement, but effects of the walkout were not felt immediately on the Labor Day holiday.

title: Further Assessment
description: At the recent meeting of the American Political Science Association here, much of the talk among those attending concerned how well the Republicans were doing. That prompted Kevin Phillips, author of ''The Coming Republican Majority,'' who spoke at a panel meeting, to observe that ''when academics talk about how smart the Republicans are, it's the blind lauding the bland.''

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS VS. METS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Army Officer Among 3 to Flee East Germany for the West
description: An East German Army officer, a border guard corporal and a bricklayer defected over the weekend, reaching West German territory unharmed, the West German border police said today.

title: HARVARD ALTERS RECRUITING OF FACULTY
description: As Harvard University celebrates its 350th anniversary this week, it has begun an important shift in its tradition of recruiting senior faculty members largely from other schools.

title: LOW PRICES SEEN FOR HEATING OIL
description: Despite the possibility that crude oil prices could continue their sharp rise from the depressed levels of the early summer, oil analysts in the United States say that heating oil prices during the fall and winter months are likely to be at their lowest level in years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LATE BLOOMERS The British passion for gardening is not only rooted in the present but also attested to in the collection of the British Museum, which is the source of a new exhibition that starts today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street (685-0610).

title: CRASH INQUIRY SAID TO FOCUS ON ERROR BY PRIVATE PLANE
description: The small private plane that collided Sunday with an Aeromexico jetliner was not authorized to fly in the zone near Los Angeles where the crash occurred, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: Texas Senate Votes To Allow Bets on Racing
description: The Texas Senate today approved a bill that could legalize parimutuel gambling on horse and dog racing.

title: LOS ANGELES SKIES HEAVILY TRAVELED
description: The midair collision Sunday of a Mexican jetliner and a private aircraft occurred in skies that are the most heavily traveled in the nation and that have long been considered the ultimate challenge to aviation safety experts trying to reduce the risk of such collisions.

title: LABOR DAY: SPIRIT SANS THE PARADE
description: No one waved banners, tooted horns or shouted slogans on Fifth Avenue yesterday. No brawny boilermakers or pipefitters or plumbers marched shoulder to shoulder; no politicians campaigned for their votes.

title: Asian Group Delays Move
description: Economic ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations have postponed making a commitment to form a regional common market, saying the proposal needed further study. The proposal was taken up

title: Dickey Released
description: Lynn Dickey, the quarterback who was the key to the Green Bay offense for more than a decade, and Paul Coffman, the tight end who played in three Pro Bowls, were released by the Packers. Dickey, the Packers' long-time starter, had been cut in June when he could not reach contract agreement and was re-signed after training camp began.

title: Business and the Law; Book Errors And Liability
description: A MAN was badly injured when a tool shattered as he was following instructions in a how-to book. He sued the publisher for negligence in Illinois. In doing so, he raised these unsettling questions about where product liability law intersects with the First Amendment:

title: BUYERS RUSH AS DRINKING AGE IS RAISED TO 21 IN FIVE STATES
description: Laws raising the legal drinking age to 21 went into effect in five states yesterday, triggering last-minute buying sprees and a rampage by students at the University of North Carolina.

title: FIGURES SHOW 3% RISE IN NEAR COLLISIONS
description: The number of incidents in which aircraft nearly collided in midair has increased by about 3 percent in the first six months of this year, although actual collisions have remained steady at between 20 and 30 a year for the last decade, according to Federal aviation officials.

title: JAPANESE CYCLIST DOMINATES FOR A DECADE
description: Koichi Nakano has been too busy winning world cycling championships year after year to worry about Ralph Waldo Emerson's observation that foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds.

title: McCONKEY AND 2 OTHERS CUT
description: The Giants got down to the 45-man limit today with a series of moves that seemed more of a beginning than an end.

title: Double Ceremony
description: The wedding date had crept within six months and counting, and the groom had been spared from much of the dirty work. Kevin Elster was in Jackson, Miss., with the Class AA Jackson Mets, two steps from Shea Stadium and far removed from his fiancee, Jennifer Pizzata, in Huntington Beach, Calif.

title: Coercion Sanctioned By the Conservatives
description: To the Editor:

title: WEARY DETROIT BLOOMS AS JAZZ FILLS THE TOWN
description: Raw licks in B flat and G minor bounced off a stage along the Detroit River, wafted past the listeners eating falafel and popcorn and then joined the nearby riffs of a Finnish quartet speaking the unfettered diction of jazz.

title: Gordon Webber Dies; Author and Executive
description: Gordon Webber, a retired advertising executive with four novels to his credit, died Saturday of leukemia at his summer home in Montauk, L.I. He was 74 years old and also kept a residence on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

title: A Left-Wing Senator Is Killed in Colombia
description: Gunmen shot and killed a left-wing Senator today. He belonged to Colombia's guerrilla-backed Patriotic Union party.

title: OLDER STAFF IN FAST-FOOD JOBS
description: Ever since the first hamburger was put in a Styrofoam box and set under hot lights, fast-food restaurants have been a teen-ager's employment haven. But now, according to statistics, an increasing number of older Americans are working in franchise restaurants nationwide.

title: OGYGIAN TAKES JEROME IN A CLOSE FINISH
description: Ogygian remains an enigma. The 3-year-old colt, who keeps flashing brilliance but fails to confirm it, did it again yesterday, running down Groovy but then tiring and barely holding off Mogambo to win the Jerome Handicap for 3-year-olds at Belmont Park.

title: Token Swaps Program Begins at 6 Sites Today
description: Today through Sept. 30, the Transit Authority will exchange solid brass subway tokens for the new bull's-eye variety that went into circulation last June.

title: Advertising; Rates Flat For Sports Programs
description: FOR sports fans, this may be the best time of year. In baseball, September brings pennant races, playoffs and World Series fever. Professional and college football teams are set to do battle. And the basketball and hockey leagues are preparing to open their long seasons.

title: VW Stock Plan For $1 Billion
description: Volkswagen announced plans today to raise $1 billion in what dealers said was West Germany's biggest stock market sale.

title: Poker With Libya
description: The current campaign of agitation about Libya is stranger than a political thriller. Reports from Washington say that the United States Air Force and naval moves, the carefully leaked hints of trouble ahead, are White House efforts to send a ''message'' to Colonel Qaddafi that there will be heavy retaliation for renewed terrorist acts.

title: Dollar Falls and Gold Gains
description: The dollar fell against all major currencies in European trading today, affected by a record United States monthly trade deficit and the Labor Day holiday, dealers said. Gold prices rose sharply.

title: FREDERICK P. GARRETT
description: Frederick P. Garrett, the former administrative director of the Negro Ensemble Company, died Friday of a heart disease in Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Dolphins Trim Defense
description: Kim Bokamper and Jay Brophy, once big parts of the Miami defense, were waived yesterday. Also cut by the Dolphins was Lyle Blackwood, a 35-year-old safety.

title: SENDING REUNIONS TO ALUMNI
description: Alumni who do not make it back to their class reunions may now find the reunions coming to them - on videotape.

title: QADDAFI, APPEARING HEARTY AND CONFIDENT, REVIEWS A BIG PARADE
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, continuing a forceful re-emergence in public, today celebrated the 17th anniversary of the coup that brought him to power by reviewing a parade of Libyan troops and weapons.

title: World Airways Plan Reported
description: World Airways is planning to end all scheduled flights by Sept. 15, according to The Oakland Tribune.

title: 194 ACCIDENT SURVIVORS MEET TO PROMOTE SAFETY-BELT USE
description: Helen Brady is not sure why she buckled her seat belt after leaving a restaurant on prom night last spring, but today she said that doing so saved her life.

title: OLD FRIENDS DIVIDE IN OLD DISPUTE, WATER IN WEST
description: When Ronald Reagan, then Governor of California, and Paul Laxalt, then Governor of Nevada, shook hands in 1968 on an agreement for their two states to divide up the scarce water resources along their common border, one of the country's longest-running battles over Western water rights appeared to be drawing to a peaceful close.

title: EIGHTH ST. ENCOUNTERS SPIELBERG
description: It's hard to tell where the rubble of the Lower East Side leaves off and the rubble of the movie set begins. Even the sanitation men are confused. They've been emptying the prop garbage cans.

title: Japan Pledge On Airport
description: Japan's Transport Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, assured American and other foreign companies today of a fair chance to bid for work on an $8 billion airport to be built on a man-made island in Osaka Bay in central Japan.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA BRAVES (NL) - Named Eddie Mathews minor league batting instructor and special assignment scout.

title: Ceco's Board Backs Buyout
description: Ceco Industries, a leading supplier of concrete-construction services, said yesterday that its board of directors had approved a proposed leveraged buyout of the company by senior management. The buyout is valued at roughly $210 million.

title: Good Sign in Pregnancy?
description: ''Morning sickness,'' or nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy, may be a good sign, according to researchers at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.

title: SHULTZ SENDS AIDE TO OFFER MIDEAST A U.S. PEACE ROLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has sent a top aide to the Middle East to set the stage for a possible new American effort to encourage closer Israeli-Egyptian relations and to stimulate dormant peace efforts, State Department officials said today.

title: MOVE FROM TAINTED HOMES PROMPTS DEBATE
description: More than a year and a half after 487 families were hastily evacuated from a housing development thought to have been contaminated with mercury, the Federal and Commonwealth governments are quarreling over whether the evacuation was justified.

title: AUTOPSY SHOWS PILOT OF 2D PLANE SUFFERED SEIZURE
description: The Los Angeles County Coroner's Office said tonight that the pilot of the small private plane that collided in midair with an Aeromexico jetliner Sunday had suffered a heart attack minutes before the disastrous collision.

title: Bridge: Regency Club Resumes Play After a Long Summer Break
description: Following a summer break, members of one of the world's oldest bridge clubs return today to the ease of their rubber-bridge chairs. It is the Regency Whist Club, 15 East 67th Street, which has had a reputation for sociable comfort and fine food since it was founded exactly half a century ago.

title: PUBLIC FOUND READY TO SACRIFICE IN DRUG FIGHT
description: Sharply rising concern over drugs has led two-thirds of Americans to say they would pay more taxes to jail drug sellers, and three-fourths of full-time workers to say they would be willing to take a drug test, The New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Jorge Alessandri, 90, Former Chilean Leader
description: Jorge Alessandri Rodriguez, President of Chile from 1958 to 1964, has died, his family said today. He was 90 years old. Mr. Alessandri died Sunday night at Santiago's military hospital.

title: ELECTRONIC PUBLISHING ON RISE
description: The looming changes in Federal tax law have created a special challenge for Accountants Microsystems Inc., a Bellevue, Wash., maker of software for accountants. If Congress passes the tax revision bill, the company must revise its software packages and nearly six dozen support documents, including both graphics and text. And next year will require more product changes, according to Ole Kvern, the company's publications specialist.

title: Small Dance Companies May Apply for Grants
description: Individual grants of up to $40,000 per year will be available for small dance companies of exceptional artistic quality, the National Endowment for the Arts has announced.

title: FOR NEW YORK, A BONANZA OF SUMMER VISITORS
description: On the Fourth of July weekend, a family of Rumanian immigrants in Cleveland watched the brightened face of the Statue of Liberty flicker across their television. And their vacation plans were quickly decided.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Crazy Eddie Inc., Brooklyn, named Mitchell Antar chief operating officer, and Sam E. Antar executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FRENZY OF RENOWN. Fame and Its History. By Leo Braudy. Illustrated. 649 pages. Oxford. $27.50. SOCRATES is famous and Pia Zadora is famous, and anyone who sets out to write a history of fame, as Leo Braudy has done in ''The Frenzy of Renown,'' is committed to surveying an immense and immensely varied territory. Admittedly Mr. Braudy, who teaches at the University of Southern California, doesn't try to be comprehensive, which would have been attempting the impossible; he is primarily concerned with the idea of fame, the ways in which it has been defined and the ways in which it has evolved. But that still leaves him with an enormous subject on his hands.

title: Experts Propose Anesthesia Plan
description: Establishing mandatory standards for monitoring patients under anesthesia could save thousands of lives and reduce the number of malpractice claims, according to a report in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Hawaii Editor Resigns; Reveals He Has AIDS
description: G. William Cox has resigned as managing editor of The Honolulu Star-Bulletin and gone on disability leave after writing an editorial column disclosing that he has AIDS, the newspaper said today.

title: Rate-Cut Hopes Are Growing
description: Expectations of weak economic growth - and another Federal Reserve move to encourage lower short-term interest rates - were bolstered late last week by reports of a record trade deficit for July and a decline in home sales.

title: CHINA SAYS IT PLANS MANNED SPACE FLIGHT 'BEFORE LONG'
description: China has begun choosing a team of astronauts and will launch them on Chinese space flights ''before long,'' The People's Daily reported Sunday. It did not say when the flights would take place.

title: Atlantic Balloonists Over the Netherlands
description: Three Dutch adventurers buoyed by swift winds were sailing over the western Netherlands early today in a helium-and-hot-air balloon toward a new record for a trans-Atlantic crossing.

title: WOMAN IS KILLED IN PALISADES FALL
description: A 24 year-old woman who had climbed beyond a safety barrier at Palisades Interstate Park to get a better view slipped off a cliff and fell 150 feet to her death today, park police officers said.

title: Indonesia Aircraft Deal
description: The Indonesian Government has signed an agreement to buy 12 F-16 fighters from the General Dynamics Corporation for at least $432 million, spokesmen for the Indonesian military and the United States Embassy said today.

title: Iron Mike
description: These are the longest current regular-season skeins:

title: A Fairer Chance for School Riches
description: New York City's high schools offer a wealth of enriched programs, but getting into them often resembles a cruel game of chance. Some people think that the game is rigged against minority groups and closed to all but the highest achievers. Now the Board of Education wants to make the process fairer, and well it should.

title: Bombs Explode in Portugal
description: Four terrorist bombs shattered the facades of buildings at three seaside tourist complexes before dawn today in apparently coordinated attacks, the police said.

title: A Gift Refused And Received
description: Here is a new twist on the old story of the cat burglar who preys on summer vacationers. Rather than stealing, this Brooklyn intruder left something behind.

title: RED SOX WIN, 6-4; STILL LEADING BY 3 1/2
description: Tony Armas hit a three-run double and Jim Rice added a bases-empty home run tonight as the Boston Red Sox rallied for their third consecutive victory, a 6-4 decision over the Texas Rangers.

title: A MIDTOWN MARKETPLACE FOR ANTIQUES PLANNED
description: ''Welcome to Place des Antiquaires.''

title: U.S. AIDES VOICE CONCERN FOR DETAINED REPORTER
description: President Reagan was described today as ''disturbed and concerned'' about the arrest of a U.S. News & World Report correspondent in Moscow, and Administration officials said efforts were under way to free the reporter.

title: Pitfalls in a Cash-Only Proposal to Aid the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Arrested in Riot At California Beach
description: Thousands of people watching a surfing contest went on a rampage Sunday after the police tried to rescue several women whose bikini tops had been torn off, and 13 people were arrested before order was restored.

title: Raiders Waive Van Pelt
description: Brad Van Pelt, the former Giant who was a five-time Pro Bowl linebacker, was among players waived yesterday by the Los Angeles Raiders. Van Pelt, 36, was a Giant from 1973-83 and a Pro Bowler from 1976-80.

title: Primary Choices for Civil Court
description: Here are our recommendations for Civil Court candidates in the Sept. 9 Democratic primary, in those contested races where victory is tantamount to election.

title: 6 Hurt as Car and Cab Crash
description: Three passengers in a taxicab and three pedestrians were injured, none critically, when a taxi and a car collided at the intersection of Third Avenue and 14th Street yesterday afternoon, the police said. The accident occurred just after 5 P.M. as a car traveling north on Third Avenue attempted to make a left turn at 14th Street and collided with a cab, which was traveling south.

title: THE ROOTS OF TERRORISM ARE FOUND IN BRUTALITY OF SHATTERED CHILDHOOD
description: THE route of the terrorist from childhood to a specific violent act is emerging in rich detail from new research. Researchers have found the making of a terrorist involves a unique interplay between the beliefs and dynamic of the terrorist group and the psychological makeup of its members.

title: WORRIED PARENTS HOPE CHILDREN ARE FREE OF DRUGS
description: Most parents - especially those who have ''long talks'' with their children, who ''set a good example'' and ''watch who the kids hang out with'' - are certain that none of their children have experimented with drugs. They may be deluding themselves. In the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, parents of children from the age of 10 to 17 were asked to rate, from 1 to 5, how certain they were that none of their children had used illegal drugs; 1 represented ''certain,'' and 5 meant they knew a child had tried drugs.

title: THE OLDEST OIL EVER FOUND
description: MOST of the world's oil comes from geological sediments laid down since the time when animals and plants had already evolved to highly advanced forms. But a recent discovery in Australia may not only enhance scientific understanding of primitive life forms but may also disclose hitherto untapped sources of oil.

title: PURCHASERS SAY ORDERS PICKED UP IN AUGUST
description: The economy improved considerably in August, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Managers.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Said to Raid Soviet Bases
description: Moslem guerrillas fired rockets at Soviet military installations in the Afghan capital of Kabul over the weekend, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1986
description: International

title: FLORIDA RACE UNDERSCORES CHANGES
description: A look at two candidates who are among the Democratic and Republican front-runners for Governor Tuesday in Florida's primary underscores the changing politics of a state in transition.

title: Laws Alone Won't Stop Crack
description: Politicians and citizens who have advocated severe antidrug legislation in response to the epidemic of crack, the highly potent and addictive form of cocaine, apparently have short memories. Much of the discussion is strikingly similar to that surrounding the Rockefeller drug laws passed in New York State in 1973.

title: YANKEES REVAMP, BUT LOSE
description: One more day passed, and the Yankees continued their slow and painful fade from the American League East race. Tonight, they started four players who had been in the minor leagues until last week, and there was no relief.

title: Sikh Gunmen Kill A Judge in Punjab
description: Sikh gunmen assassinated a judge in Punjab State today, and in New Delhi alert passengers foiled a Sikh attempt to blow up a bus with a briefcase bomb, officials said.

title: Fire Truck Injures 13 at Competition
description: A fire truck went out of control today at a demonstration of firefighting skill and injured several people, the authorities said.

title: THE HUNTS' BID TO BUY TIME
description: When crashing oil prices forced the Placid Oil Company to default on a $1.2 billion loan last spring, the company's owners, the Hunt brothers of Dallas, were true to the brash gambling legacy of their father, H. L. Hunt: They told bankers that instead of paying them off, they wanted to sink more money into drilling for bigger-than-ever gushers.

title: Maryland Defeats Pitt on Late Kick
description: Dan Plocki's 29-yard field goal with 2 minutes 10 seconds to play and Maryland's dominating defense gave the Terps a 10-7 college football victory tonight over Pittsburgh, ruining the debut of Coach Mike Gottfried.

title: CITY EARMARKS A RECORD SUM FOR REBUILDING
description: For the first time in the city's history, more than $2 billion has been committed to capital spending in a fiscal year, according to a report released last night by Mayor Koch.

title: ANDREW S. ROSCOE
description: Andrew Stephen Roscoe, retired president and chairman of the board of the Equitable Federal Savings and Loan Association of Brooklyn, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: New Wage System for Soviet
description: The ruling Soviet Politburo has approved a new pay system that will increase industrial wages by an average of 25 to 30 percent and is tied to workers' performances, the official news agency, Tass, said today.

title: The Year Our Century Lost Its Innocence
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW LEADERS THINK THE UNTHINKABLE
description: One day in August 1980, President Carter gathered his senior advisers on national security around the elliptical table in the Cabinet Room of the White House to assess the implications of a buildup of Soviet military forces north of Iran.

title: THIRD-WORLD BLOC PRESSED ON APARTHEID
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe called today on the nations professing nonalignment to adopt selective economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: 2 SHOWS OF COMEDY FROM HBO
description: SHADOE STEVENS, according to Home Box Office, is a West Coast radio and television personality who, after receiving Billboard magazine's Progressive Personality of the Year Award in 1975, went on in the 1980's to create ''unpredictable, fast-paced'' commercials for a home-entertainment chain that then watched its sales jump more than 500 percent. All of which still leaves me puzzled as to why Mr. Stevens has been given a comedy special on Cinemax, a pay-cable service of HBO. ''Cinemax Comedy Experiment: Shadoevision,'' which can be seen this evening at 9:30, is indeed fast-paced (though hardly unpredictable) but no more substantial than, say, a commercial.

title: Two More Years
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1986
description: Companies

title: JAILED NICARAGUAN SAYS HE GAVE DATA TO U.S.
description: A Nicaraguan businessman, arrested two weeks ago and accused of espionage, said today that he had provided economic information to American officials but that none of the information was secret.

title: VENICE FILM FESTIVAL FEELS TV'S GROWING IMPACT
