description: When the Venice Film Festival opened this year, Gina Lollobrigida, resplendent in white sequins, was enthroned in the VIP section of the loge, much to the delight of the papparazzi, who are often star-starved at this event.

title: WILKISON ADVANCES BRISKLY
description: The occasional shouts of ''Come on, Chesnokov'' did not influence Tim Wilkison. The Grandstand crowd was solidly in his corner. Wilkison wasn't fooled by Andrei Chesnokov's blond hair, wispy Borg-like whiskers and two-fisted backhand from the baseline, either, all as distinctively Swedish as a Volvo.

title: BOMB WOUNDS 18 IN DURBAN STORE
description: A bomb left on a counter exploded today in a supermarket in a white working-class neighborhood of Durban, wounding at least 18 people, the Government reported.

title: AUDIT SAYS CITY MISMANAGES SALE OF FORECLOSED PROPERTY
description: New York City is doing a poor job of managing thousands of commercial properties it has taken over through tax foreclosures and condemnations, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: FOR TRAVELERS AND REVELERS, SEASON ENDS
description: For many, Labor Day is summer's last hurrah, a chance to barbecue one last steak before burying the grill behind the deck chairs in the garage. It is the consummate summer day, colored with nostalgia for the season already being consigned to memory.

title: A PROGRAM TO KEEP PEACE AMONG THE OTHERS
description: ONE of the most disastrous experiences I ever encountered in personal computing occurred at a time when I had a whole series of memory-resident programs, primarily keyboard enhancers and desktop utilities, stored on my hard disk. What distinguishes these programs from all other applications is that they reside in the computer's active memory, even when not in use. This enables the user to call them up instantly, rather than having the computer spend time locating them on the hard disk or the user having to insert a floppy disk.

title: Samuel K. Anderson Wed To Dr. Greta M. Rainsford
description: The marriage of Dr. Greta M. Rainsford and Samuel Kenneth Anderson took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of Freeport, L.I. The Rev. Reginald Tuggle officiated. The bride is the daughter of Gertrude Eleanor Rainsford of East Rockaway, Queens, and the late George Maurice Rainsford.

title: SOUTH AFRICA A PROBLEM FOR CALIFORNIA OFFICIAL
description: Basil J. Schwan, assistant executive director of the Public Employees' Retirement System in California, says that the recently passed legislation requiring state pension and university funds in California to sell off their holdings in companies doing business in South Africa will have a profound effect on the pension fund and others like it.

title: OPEC OUTPUT CURBS GO INTO EFFECT
description: The agreement by members of OPEC to curb production for two months to raise prices took effect today.

title: CREATIONISTS ASSERT THEY HOLD A SCIENTIFIC VIEW
description: THE battle over the place of creationism in the public schools has entered a new phase. When the issue comes before the Supreme Court in the fall, creationists will argue that they represent science and not religion. The aim is to get the biblical version of creation past the Constitution's prohibition against the establishment of religion by the state.

title: GERMAN VOICES DOUBTS ON QADDAFI TERROR ROLE
description: A senior adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that there were no indications that Libya was plotting ''spectacular terrorist actions'' and cautioned that another American raid on Libya could ruin the chances for a Soviet-American summit meeting.

title: Bag It!
description: To the Editor:

title: Transworld Loses Restaurant Devotee
description: Charles J. Bradshaw saw his first Hardee's franchise operation in 1961, liked what he saw and became a staunch believer in restaurants as investments, acquiring a growing chain of Hardee's before joining the Transworld Corporation. So when he resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director of Transworld last week in what was described as a difference of opinion over expansion, a company spokesman said it was a ''fair assumption'' that he wanted to acquire restaurants once again.

title: Gun Owners at Work
description: Ardent pro-gun groups have never been particularly fond of the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, whose job it is to enforce Federal firearms legislation, but lately the friction appears to have gotten worse.

title: Korea Air Orders 747's
description: The Boeing Company announced today that it had received an order worth about $400 million from Korean Air Lines for three 747-400's for delivery starting in April 1989. The order included spare parts. The company said Korean Air also planned to buy five more of the long-range wide-bodied planes.

title: MANILA WON'T TRY A TOP MARCOS AIDE
description: The Justice Minister dropped rebellion charges today against a leading aide to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos in connection with a revolt at the Manila Hotel two months ago.

title: Regulation's Rebirth
description: After an eight-month hiatus, the scholarly conservative journal Regulation has resumed publication. Its first issue under new proprietors will be distributed in a week or so.

title: From Russia: Faces
description: It sounds familiar. Pierre Cardin sweeps into town with 92 new fashion designs, Yves Saint Laurent on his heels. The Foreign Ministry spokesman is on the tube again, must be his fifth announcement this week. The First Family is on TV too, and a team of scientists is off to Vienna to report to experts from around the world. Is this London? Tokyo? No. It's Moscow. For decades, the Soviet Union offered the West no more public faces than Mount Rushmore. Khrushchev, Kosygin and Gromyko, for instance, and one or two other institutional visages. Now, suddenly, the papers are full of officials: Valery Legasov announcing reactor modifications . . . Yuli Vorontsov on verification of nuclear tests . . . military Chief of Staff Akhromeyev on the testing moratorium . . . Leonid Ilyin on radiation in Pripyat.

title: Taking a Series More Seriously
description: The Mets aren't the only people in town who are already looking ahead to the postseason. So are the powers that be in winter baseball, and their bash, the Caribbean World Series, doesn't even begin until the first week in February.

title: RECENT MARITIME DISASTERS
description: Reports of the sinking of a Soviet passenger ship in the Black Sea with up to 1,000 people aboard indicated substantial loss of life. Here are some notable maritime disasters of the last three decades. July 26, 1956 - The Italian liner Andrea Doria sinks, a day after colliding with the Swedish liner Stockholm off Cape Cod. Fifty-two people are killed, most of them on the Italian vessel.

title: NEWSMAN IS GIVEN 10 DAYS OF WAITING
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff's wife said today that the Soviet authorities had told the U.S. News & World Report correspondent that within 10 days he would either be charged with spying or released.

title: Mexico Calls Austerity Effort Permanent
description: President Miguel de la Madrid told the Mexican people today that the economic austerity that has marked their lives for the last four years must become a permanent feature.

title: Kaiser Steel Tightens Belt
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation says it has a ''severe liquidity problem,'' which includes being in default on its main bank loan, and is restructuring itself to restore its financial vigor.

title: Australian Auto Plants
description: Australia's car factories reopened today after strikers at a parts supplier returned to work. More than 8,000 workers were laid off last week because no more axles were coming from Borg-Warner's Sydney plant, where 87 ironworkers had struck over the size of the work force. Details of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: MANDLIKOVA, DEFENDING CHAMPION, FALLS TO TURNBULL
description: She was just beginning to shed the label that has dogged her throughout her career, to dispute the critics who claimed that she could never be a true, consistent champion. But during one cool evening at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Hana Mandlikova, the defending women's champion in the United States Open, undid virtually all of that.

title: SEPT. 2, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, plenary and Special Commission 1 - 10:30 A.M.

title: ISADORE ILLMAN
description: Isadore Illman, a lawyer for more than 50 years and a former member of the American Arbitration Association, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 75 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: When U.S. Trade and Foreign Relations Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: British Unions Accept Secret Ballot on Strikes
description: Britain's organized labor movement voted today to abide by legislation requiring secret ballots before strike action.

title: Books: 2 Theater Lives
description: THE FABULOUS LUNTS: A Biography of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne. By Jared Brown. Illustrated. 523 pages. Atheneum. $24.95. COMPLETELY devoted to the art of live performance and to acting with the other as partner, Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne felt an almost messianic duty to bring theater to the people. As Jared Brown indicates in his comprehensive biography, their entire life was the theater. Each was the other's strongest critic and greatest fan. With both of them, there was a continuing quest for perfection (perhaps more so in Lunt's case). The two were famous for improving their performances even after the Broadway run had ended and they had taken the play on tour.

title: Reorganization At WCRS-U.S.
description: The WCRS Group P.L.C., which in the past several months has acquired Della Femina Travisano & Partners and HBM/Creamer, said it would reorganize its United States operations to set up two independent agency networks. WCRS said Friday that the

title: COOPERVISION AT CORE OF A SHRINKING EMPIRE
description: Thanks to some fancy financial footwork and a flurry of acquisitions over the years, Parker G. Montgomery has put together a small health-care empire whose crown jewel, Coopervision Inc., is the nation's leading eye-care company.

title: Bankruptcy Filing Follows Pattern
description: In seeking Chapter 11 relief last week for their Placid Oil Company before creditors could foreclose on its assets, the Hunt family followed a growing trend in bankruptcy: waiting until the last minute before filing for protection from creditors.

title: PUBLISHING NEWSLETTERS BY COMPUTER
description: MILLIONS of despondent youths will soon begin work on dreary essays entitled, ''What I Did on My Summer Vacation.'' Some of them will struggle with leaky pens and spiral notebooks, while others will tap their essays into personal computers. Odds are that both methods will yield turgid prose, but the computer-printed version is almost certainly going to be easier on the teacher's eyes, and such considerations occasionally mean the difference between a D-minus and an F. That is this year's tip for students. Now, two software tips for teachers. The Newsroom

title: Teachers Vote to Strike In 2 Michigan Districts
description: Teachers in two Michigan school districts voted last night to strike and join walkouts that already have stopped classes for 15,000 students in another Michigan district and in Illinois and Pennsylvania.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ ACCOUNTS DIFFER
description: Iran said today that its forces had captured seven strategic hills in the northern Gulf war front and had pushed ''deep inside Iraq'' in a new offensive, killing or capturing hundreds of Iraqis.

title: Devaluation In Poland
description: The Government today devalued the zloty by 17.6 percent against the dollar to increase its flagging exports, the official PAP news agency reported.

title: RADON: THREAT IS REAL, BUT SCIENTISTS ARGUE OVER ITS SEVERITY
description: NEW warnings about radon in homes, which Federal officials said last month may cause 5,000 to 20,000 lung cancer deaths a year, have touched off a row among scientists over the true extent of the hazard.

title: DUST DULLING THE COLOR OF DA VINCI'S 'LAST SUPPER'
description: Dust is threatening ''The Last Supper,'' and experts hope a dust-absorbing carpet will help protect the colors of Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece.

title: COLLISION VICTIMS ON DC-9
description: Following is the list of passengers aboard Flight 498 as released today by Aeromexico.

title: SOVIET CRUISES: LOW-COST, EFFICIENT AND POLITE
description: The Soviet Union maintains one of the world's largest passenger ship fleets, with scores of liners in the international cruise trade and hundreds of domestic vessels plying rivers and coastal waters like the Black Sea where the Admiral Nakhimov sank.

title: 1.40(f)-1(d)(1), or Maybe 408(n)
description: Lawyers and accountants secretly fear that the much-heralded tax overhaul will result in unemployment among their ranks. This fear is simply unfounded, for what seems to have been overlooked in all the hoopla over the new tax bill is that it leaves much of the existing tax code intact.

title: New York's Beacon Theater Has Been Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICAN FAMILIES SEE HOPE IN ILLEGAL EMIGRATION
description: After 12 years of scrambling to keep food on the table for his wife and four children, Baltazar Valerio Dimas is giving up on Mexico and its troubled economy. He has decided to take his family across the border, illegally, and make a new life in the United States.

title: Baby Who Got Heart Implant Dies as His Body Rejects It
description: A 1 1/2-year-old child who underwent one of a series of pioneering infant-to-infant heart transplants died after his body rejected his implanted heart, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: TOLL UNREPORTED IN 'REAL TRAGEDY'
description: A Soviet passenger ship collided with a freighter in the Black Sea last night and sank, with an unspecified loss of life, the Soviet Union announced today.

title: Goffredo Parise Dead at 57; Published in Italy and U.S.
description: Goffredo Parise, whose writings exploring alienation helped make him one of the best-known contemporary Italian writers, died Sunday. He was 57 years old.

title: Navy Missile Test Successful
description: The Navy successfully fired an unarmed Trident I missile Sunday from a Poseiden submarine cruising off Florida's Atlantic coast, Navy officials said.

title: LONG WEEKEND IN FLUSHING
description: Too much sun, too much baseball, too much tennis, too much traffic have combined to fry your faithful correspondent's brain. Please bear with him as he tries to sort out his tangled notes and jumbled mind from all the events of the past weekend at Flushing Meadows, where he trod the boardwalk between Shea Stadium and the National Tennis Center.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We saw the two planes, but what we could really see was the tail on the big plane.

title: Wendy Gliedman Wed To Mordechai Beizer
description: At Temple Israel in White Plains yesterday Wendy Lynn Gliedman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe M. Gliedman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married to Mordechai Marcus Beizer, a son of Samuel Beizer of New York and Dr. Ruth R. Bohrer of Yerucham, Israel. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony.

title: RANDOMNESS OF DISASTER LEAVES AREA IN SHOCK
description: Jeffrey McIllwain had borrowed his mother's car to go to church on Sunday.

title: ATTIRE FOR SCHOOL, WHERE YOU ARE WHAT YOU WEAR
description: Ghislaine Fanuzzi started shopping for back to school as soon as school got out last June. ''That was the bulk of her summer,'' her mother, Carol, said, ''except a few trips to the beach.''

title: Vuckovich to Start
description: Pete Vuckovich, the 1982 Cy Young Award winner who announced his retirement last March, will return to the Milwaukee Brewers' starting rotation tonight. Vuckovich, 33, who has been plauged by arm problems for the last three seasons, re-signed with the Brewers in July and was playing with their Vancouver farm team when he was recalled. . . . . Bret Saberhagen, who won the American League Cy Young Award last year, was taken off the disabled list by the Kansas City Royals.

title: TAIWAN AGREES TO LIBERALIZE INSURANCE MARKET
description: Taiwan, embarrassed by its large and growing trade surplus with the United States, has quietly acceded to Washington's demands that American insurance companies be given greater access to its $1.5 billion-a-year insurance market.

title: Start With 4,937,775
description: From one of the more whimsical frontiers of number theory comes a report that some mathematicians are investigating the properties of a new kind of number - a Smith number.

title: Woman Regains Sight But Has to Leave Job
description: A woman who regained her eyesight after a lens transplant has lost her job operating a snack bar in a Federal building because she is no longer handicapped.

title: Japanese Hold Quake Drill
description: About 6.5 million people took part today in Japan's annual drill for coping with a major earthquake. The drill marks the anniversary of the Great Kanto Earthquake, which leveled Tokyo and Yokohama in 1923.

title: Judith Block Marries
description: Judith Miriam Block, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Block of Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to David Gilman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Avrim Wallace Gilman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I. The bride is a consultant in the management of nonprofit organizations. The bridegroom is manager of public relations for Pepsi-Cola International in Purchase, N.Y. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: ONE DEAD IN MOLDAVIA QUAKE
description: The Soviet Union said today that one person was killed and hundreds were injured in an earthquake Sunday in this southwestern region.

title: MUSIC: LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL ENDS
description: MORTON GOULD'S ''American Salute'' - a rousing, expertly made fantasia on ''When Johnny Comes Marching Home'' -began the American Symphony Orchestra's free outdoor concert in Damrosch Park Sunday night. The program served as a grand finale to the three-and-a-half-week Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival, and a capacity audience filled the little concrete park behind the New York State Theater to bid the summer adieu.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock markets and commodity exchanges and most businesses in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. Federal, state and local government offices were also closed.

title: The Kauls Are Everywhere
description: India's new Ambassador to the United States has arrived in Washington, and it will be understandable if there is some confusion over names back at the Foreign Office in New Delhi for a while. India's new man in Washington is P. K. Kaul, and at about the same time that he was appointed, T. N. Kaul was named Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

title: KING WINS IN PLAYOFF
description: Betsy King, who tied the course record with a final-round 63, sank a six-foot birdie putt on the fourth hole of a sudden-death playoff today to win the $200,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Rail Charity Classic.

title: HIGHER FARES, REDUCED SERVICE EXPECTED IN DENVER
description: For airline passengers accustomed to using Denver's Stapleton International Airport, the closing of Frontier Airlines will produce a number of changes, including higher fares and reduced service, according to industry analysts.

title: Q&A
description: Q Can we modify our weather?

title: 5 Killed on Illinois Lake In High-Speed Collision
description: Two powerboats collided at high speed early this morning on Fox Lake in the northeastern corner of the state, killing five people and injuring one.

title: A Lull in Treasuries, Tax-Exempts
description: A light supply of new issues is expected in the Treasury and tax-exempt markets during the next few weeks, while activity in the corporate market may remain brisk.

title: ATLANTA CONTEST PUTS STRAIN ON TIES THAT BIND
description: At 1 o'clock Sunday afternoon, as State Senator Julian Bond walked down the aisle of a black church, his seventh one of the day, the pastor, the Rev. Larry H. Williams, beamed down at him from the pulpit. ''Brother Bond, a fine young man,'' Mr. Williams said. ''God bless him! Strong and tall and young and handsome and fine and ready. God bless him!''

title: PIGEON SHOOT: A BARRAGE OF CHARGES
description: For more than half a century the men of this tiny Pennsylvania Dutch town have mined coal, grown grain and shot pigeons on Labor Day.

title: Operations Chief Named Head of British Telecom
description: George Jefferson will relinquish his post as chief executive of British Telecommunications P.L.C., effective Oct. 1, the company announced last week. The 65-year-old Sir George, who will continue as part-time chairman, will be succeeded by Iain Vallance, 43, British Telecom's chief of operations.

title: Ship Held in Canaries Now Flies German Flag
description: The Aurigae, the Honduran-registered vessel suspected of abandoning 155 Tamil refugees off Newfoundland last month, is now flying the West German flag, witnesses said today.

title: The Lower East Side, Month by Month
description: Curious, affectionate and unflinching, a child's-eye view of the Lower East Side begins to unfold this month in a school-year calendar that chronicles East Broadway and Essex, Henry, Madison, Market and Mulberry Streets.

title: SEA TURTLE'S BREEDING GROUND IS OVERWHELMED BY TOURISM
description: Around midnight, the lumbering reptile emerged from the Ionian Sea. Slowly dragging her weight of about 200 pounds across the beach on flippers more suited to swimming than crawling, the turtle reached a spot about 50 feet from the water's edge.

title: NICARAGUA CLINIC AMERICAN-MADE
description: For James Pfeiffer, a 26-year-old printer and contractor from Providence, R.I., spending two months helping to build a clinic in this poor town was a way ''to do something more than just protest.''

title: A BLOW TO RIGHTS IN ZAIRE
description: The United States has begun to deliver approximately $15 million in covert aid to Jonas Savimbi's Angolan rebel forces. Evidence indicates that these weapons are being delivered through Zaire, which has a long border with Angola and a history of allowing such deliveries. Yet, to date Washington has shown little concern for the consequences of its decision to aid the Unita rebels.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: AFTER he showed his first collection here last year, David Cameron, the California-born designer, was hailed as the hottest thing to hit clothes since the electric iron. His designs were innocent, optimistic yet sophisticated. But following his second collection of fall clothes, a badly lighted presentation, haphazardly staged to resemble a beach party, there were those who were left wondering whether Mr. Cameron was suffering from a fashion version of sophomore slump.

title: Susan Seligsohn Weds Stephen Dana Howell
description: Susan Leslie Seligsohn and Stephen Dana Howell were married yesterday at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club by Rabbi Arthur Schwartz.

title: NEW POWER LETS COMPUTER DEPICT IMAGES INVISIBLE TO EYE
description: RAPID progress in the computer enhancement of photographs is aiding such fields as publishing, weather forecasting, failure analysis, medical diagnostics, law enforcement and surveillance from space.

title: Computer Tracks Hospital Infections
description: The Latter-day Saints hospital in Salt Lake City is using a computer to monitor infections and the use of antibiotics among its patients, a procedure done by staff personnel at most hospitals in an effort to control the infections that strike about 6 percent of all hospital patients.

title: DINKINS PLAYS A STRONG ROLE IN BOROUGH JOB
description: It was nearly 11 P.M. on a recent evening at City Hall, and after a long day and night of public hearings and private meetings, the Board of Estimate finally was ready to vote on a disputed proposal to expand Lincoln Center.

title: AFTER CHERNOBYL, IT'S SCHOOL BELLS
description: Children filled the streets of this Ukrainian capital today as they returned to school for the first time since fallout from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in late April forced an early end to their last academic year.

title: Chess Championship To Resume Tomorrow
description: The world chess championship match between the defending champion, Gary Kasparov, and the former champion, Anatoly Karpov, will resume play tomorrow in Leningrad.

title: Fall from Cliff Kills Woman
description: A Canadian woman slipped while walking in heavy fog along a mountain road and fell 150 feet to her death, the Glacier National Park authorities reported. Yvonne V. Waslovich, 34 years old, of Calgary, was walking Sunday near Logan Pass when she fell down a cliff, Chief Ranger Chuck Sigler said. She died about an hour after a paramedic reached her.

title: Who Will Judge the Judges in Election Cases?
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What our children need are lessons that explore unfamiliar possibilities, that play on their imaginative capacities while teaching core democratic values like respect for persons, property and truth.'' - Secretary of Education William J. Bennett. [ A1:5. ]

title: TOMATO'S ABUNDANCE CAN BE A PROBLEM
description: IT has arrived at last: the one time of year when tomatoes taste like tomatoes. Through August and well into September, consumers are excused from the inexcusable, gas-unripened specimens that offer themselves in other seasons, and can relish the real thing. Or at least until, like so many of summer's bounties, they insist on piling up in the kitchen, daring the cook to do something creative with them. Those who have gardens are picking faster than we can eat. Those who have friends with gardens are getting fresh deliveries every time anyone shows up at the door.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Long-term ratings for $23 billion of debt of the General Motors Corporation and its finance subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, are under review for possible reductions, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WELL, another year has gone by and still the Nobel Prize has not been awarded to the inventors of the Snugli baby carrier. I can't figure it. Here you have someone (I prefer to think that it's a woman) who has come up with an invention that takes literally hundreds of thousands of people who have lost the use of their hands and gives them a new lease on life. They can pick up oranges in the supermarket, they can flip through magazines, they can smear lipstick on the backs of their hands in a test try, and all this despite the fact that they have babies.

title: Saffer Changes Name
description: Saffer Cravit & Freedman Advertising, a Canadian retail ad agency with $100 million in billings, is changing its name to Saffer Advertising. It will be known as Saffer/U.S.A. in Chicago and Publicite Wallace/Saffer in Montreal.

title: Bridge: Players in World Olympiad Are Starting to Arrive in U.S.
description: Players from some 60 countries will soon gather for the World Bridge Federation's Olympiad, scheduled to begin in Miami Beach on Sept. 13.

title: OFFICIALS SAY 18-20 ON GROUND DIED AFTER 2 PLANES COLLIDED
description: The death toll from Sunday's air disaster was placed as high as 90 today as Federal air safety officials confirmed that 18 to 20 people from a residential neighborhood here died beneath the wreckage of an Aeromexico jetliner.

title: HAIGHT PUT ON INJURED RESERVE
description: The Jets, who chose 11 players in last April's National Football League draft, have none left on their 45-man active roster. The last remaining draftee, Mike Haight, an offensive lineman from Iowa taken on the first round, was placed on injured reserve yesterday.

title: AUTHOR HELD DEPORTABLE BECAUSE OF WRITINGS
description: A United States immigration judge has ruled that Margaret Randall, an author and advocate of women's rights, is subject to deportation because of her pro-Communist writings, officials said today.

title: Encore for Pele
description: Edson Arantes do Nascimento, a k a Pele, will interrupt his retirement one more time for the good of soccer. He said he would play one game this January in Brazil in a Seniors Mini-World Cup tournament appropriately called the Pele Cup.

title: More Tests on Brett
description: After a round of tests on his injured shoulder Monday proved inconclusive, George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman, was in Los Angeles yesterday to undergo a bone scan and be examined by Dr. Frank Jobe, an orthopedist. Brett, who missed 14 games in July with a strained rotator cuff, was injured Friday night while diving for a ball against the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: BOUNTIFUL HARVEST: URBAN WORKERS LEND A HAND ON FARMS
description: ALMERICK DOLAN looked perfectly at home as he unloaded the 50-pound bales coming off the hay elevator at the Doyle Brothers Farm here. The only thing that gave him away was his accent.

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gas Victims in Cameroon May Have Died Quickly
description: Victims of gas exploding from a volcanic lake in Cameroon probably died within seconds of contact with the gas, a medical team sent there by the Agency for International Development said today.

title: LEADER OF ANTI-APARTHEID GROUP IS READY TO MEET BRITISH OFFICIAL
description: The head of the African National Congress, the political movement seeking to overthrow the South African Government, said today that he was ready to meet with Britain's Foreign Secretary to voice his concern over what he described as Britain's role in perpetuating apartheid by opposing economic sanctions.

title: FAIRFIELD COUNTY IS KEY TO G.O.P. IN CONNECTICUT
description: With varying approaches, the three Republican candidates for Governor are devoting increasing attention to the voters in Fairfield County, who often hold the key to elections in Connecticut.

title: Panasonic Ads On Automation
description: For the first time, the Panasonic Industrial Group will advertise its office automation products on television with a three-month, $10 million campaign beginning Saturday. The blitz, bearing the theme

title: FOODNOTES
description: New (to U.S.) Cooking Oil Procter & Gamble has announced the reformulation of Puritan Oil, which had been made with polyunsaturated corn and sunflower oils. Puritan is now 100 percent canola oil, also known as rapeseed oil, and contains less saturated fat than the previous formula and most other vegetable oils (6 percent compared with 10 to 15 percent). It has a higher proportion of monounsaturates than any other oil except olive oil. Scientists now believe that monounsaturates may be beneficial in reducing the levels of unheathy cholesterol (low-density lipoproteins).

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include a $1,819,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: MUSTANG COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Thrift Units' Deposits Up
description: Deposits at the nation's federally insured savings and loan institutions exceeded withdrawals by $3.7 billion in July, the largest increase this year, the Government reported today.

title: ZACCARO TOLD TO PAY $20,000 TO AN ESTATE HE USED TO MANAGE
description: John A. Zaccaro has been ordered to pay about $20,000 to an elderly woman's estate for what a judge says were Mr. Zaccaro's improprieties and lapses in handling her financial affairs as her court-appointed conservator.

title: ABC STARTING CAMPAIGN ON ILLITERACY
description: ABC tonight begins an honorable campaign: to abolish, or at least alleviate, illiteracy.

title: DEADLINE GIVEN TO THE SUSPECT IN PARK SLAYING
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., the 19-year-old Manhattan man who has been charged with murdering an 18-year-old woman in Central Park last week, has until the end of today to decide whether he will tell a grand jury his version of how the woman died.

title: FOOD EXPLORER KNOWS NO BOUNDS
description: MARGUERITE MARGASON was unlike the other girls attending Blessed Sacrament parochial school in Seattle in the early 1950's and it went beyond the beret and sandals her mother insisted she wear. ''Here comes Fish Eggs,'' the girls would say at lunch. As they peeked under the corners of their peanut-butter sandwiches for reassurance that all was in order, Marguerite would unwrap a sandwich of salmon roe, tomato and freshly made mayonnaise.

title: Trump Helps Reclaim Georgia Suicide's Farm
description: Donald Trump, the New York real estate tycoon, helped prevent foreclosure today on a family farm whose owner had committed suicide to try to save his land.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $284,000 and $484,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLAY, MATE? Part of the Midtown street scene, on the canvas of a local Hogarth, would certainly show at least one curbside chess game. Today, a mass chess exhibition will be held in Bryant Park, between 40th and 42d Streets at the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Busing Ends in Norfolk For Elementary Pupils
description: For the first time in 15 years, elementary pupils walked to neighborhood schools today as busing to achieve racial integration came to an end.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After a loss of $1,657,000 from discontinued operations and a charge of $9,300,000 from a provision for the sale of a unit.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $629,000 for the quarter and $658,000 for the year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $175,000 and $535,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and year results include net charges of $535,000 for estimated losses on the disposal of discontinued operations. The company said about $2,732,000 of income for the latest year is attributable to the receipt of life insurance proceeds on Paul A. Johnston, who died Sept. 18, 1985, net of provision for retirement and related settlements. He was formerly chairman and chief executive of the companys's textile subsidiary, Johnston Group Inc.

title: Token Trade: Few for New
description: Token Exchange Month began yesterday with what amounted to a dribble - given the magnitude of the transit system.

title: Nabokov Was Glad 'The Enchanter' Survived
description: To the Editor:

title: Chairman Leaves Gould
description: William T. Ylvisaker, who orchestrated Gould Inc.'s transformation into an electronics company, has retired as chairman, Gould said today. No successor has been named.

title: Inside the Baseball Cap
description: Tim Wilkison is big in Auckland and Sydney and Vienna and Nancy, all the places where he has won tennis tournaments - ''very big in Nancy,'' he says with a smile. But he never knew what big was until the last few days at Flushing Meadows.

title: Semi Tough
description: If Chris Evert Lloyd gets past Manuela Maleeva today, she'll have reached the semifinals of the United States Open for the 16th straight year.

title: I.B.M.'S NEW REPLY TO 'CLONES'
description: In its recent efforts to ward off a raft of low-cost competitors in the personal computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation has slashed prices, tossed in free software and touted its tradition of reliability - all to little avail.

title: TREND TO COOPERATION HAS EASED MANY TOWN-GOWN FRICTIONS
description: When you operate a free public transportation system, it is easy to handle complaints, says Roy H. Lopata, planning director for this college town of 26,000 people near both Pennsylvania and Maryland.

title: Digital Hires Dr. Hopper
description: Dr. Grace Murray Hopper, who retired last month as the Navy's oldest officer on active duty, began a new career yesterday at age 79 with the Digital Equipment Corporation in Washington.

title: Newspaper Advertising Increase Is Estimated
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has released its estimates for June newspaper advertising volume. Expenditures for national advertising came to $309 million, an increase of 10.3 percent over June 1985.

title: AIDS-RELATED VIRUS SUPPRESSED
description: A vaccine has protected monkeys from a deadly AIDS-like monkey virus for more than a year, according to researchers at the University of California at Davis.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,044,000 for the quarter and $3,050,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Girl Expelled by Priest Enters Another School
description: An 11-year-old girl who was expelled from a Roman Catholic grade school because she supports abortion is to attend sixth grade at a another private school, her mother said today.

title: MINORITY STUDENTS INTERN ON WALL ST.
description: LAST June, Terrycina A. Sewell walked away from Princeton University with a diploma in hand. She had graduated with honors in urban affairs and planned to study at Oxford in the fall. Investment banking never entered her mind.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALL NEW DETECTIVES FOR CITY MUST SUBMIT TO DRUG TESTS
description: New York City police officers who apply to become detectives must submit to drug tests under a departmental order that took effect last week.

title: In Chile, Rivalries Create an Illusion of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Morgan State May Drop a Class
description: Unable to raise enough money to sustain a major college athletic program, officials at Morgan State said today that the school may drop from Division I-AA to Division II in football.

title: JARUZELSKI PLAN TO VISIT ROME ON HOLD
description: Talks between Poland and Italy that would have allowed Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski to visit Rome and the Vatican this month have reached an impasse, according to sources close to Pope John Paul.

title: Argentine Loan Outlook
description: Argentine officials are confident of receiving about $2.5 billion in new loans from the International Monetary Fund and creditor banks in talks that start Wednesday in Washington, banking sources said today. One banking source said that Buenos Aires would be helped by the recent agreement between the I.M.F. and Mexico, which relaxed some of the lending agency's usual stringent conditions. Argentina, with $50 billion in foreign debt, is the third largest debtor in the developing world.

title: Double Trouble
description: Scott Ostler, columnist for The Los Angeles Times, on Martina Navratilova's report that one of her dogs was missing: ''Martina was beside herself, which, come to think of it, would make a hell of a doubles team.''

title: LEBANESE CABINET BACKS POLITICAL PACT
description: The Moslem and Christian members of the Lebanese Cabinet, meeting for the first time in nine months, announced agreement today on the establishment of a new political order for the country.

title: 3 OF 4 AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS TEST POSITIVE FOR OFF-DUTY DRUG USE
description: Three of 34 air traffic controllers being investigated by the Federal Aviation Administration for off-duty drug use have tested positive for amphetamines, cocaine or marijuana, an agency official said today.

title: SCHOOL PROGRAM ASSAILED AS BIASED
description: Four parents of students at a Brooklyn public school argued in court yesterday that the local school board had instituted ''segregated classes'' by blocking off a section of the school for remedial courses for 400 children from a private Hasidic day school.

title: AIR CONTROL DATA SHOW SMALL PLANE SENT RADAR SIGNAL
description: The small plane that collided with a Mexican airliner in California Sunday was transmitting radar signals that were recorded by the traffic control computer, the director of the Government inquiry said yesterday.

title: FLORIDA RUNOFFS SEEM LIKELY FOR NOMINEES FOR GOVERNOR
description: The top vote-getters in the Democratic and Republican primaries for governor were headed tonight for runoff elections when none failed to win a majority in campaigns that had been dominated by law-and-order issues.

title: XTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE wrinkled look may be popular in clothing these days, but it remains as unfashionable on the skin as it was in the days of Nefertiti. Widespread worry about wrinkles and other cosmetic signs of age is a luxury afforded by affluence. And worry we do, not just those whose facial lines make them look older than they really are, but also those who don't want to look their age.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Recalled Jeff Sellers and Steve Crawford, pitchers; Dave Sax, catcher; LaSchelle Tarver and Kevin Romine, outfielders, and Pat Dodson, first baseman, from Pawtucket of the International League.

title: New Jersey Tribe Plans A Museum for Artifacts
description: The Powhatan-Renape Indians are completing plans to build a $1 million, two-story museum for the display of thousands of Indian artifacts, according to Chief Roy Crazy Horse, the leader of the 8,000-member tribe.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CITYWIDE CRACKDOWN TO BEGIN AGAINST UNDER-AGE DRINKING
description: In a crackdown against under-age drinking, undercover investigators will begin spot checks of New York City's thousands of bars this week, state and local officials announced yesterday.

title: World Airways Disputes Rumors
description: World Airways Inc. said that it is significantly stronger, both financially and operationally, than it has been in the recent past, contrary to rumors that arose recently.

title: Garbage Strike On L.I. Is Ended
description: A strike against private garbage haulers on Long Island ended on its second day today when union members voted overwhelmingly to accept a new three-year contract.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUILDER SUES TO CONTINUE PROJECT KOCH WITHDREW
description: A developer contends that Mayor Koch, by withdrawing a controversial plan for a private housing project in the Clinton section of Manhattan, actually guaranteed the plan's approval.

title: Production Down at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said its American car production declined 35.4 percent in August from the 1985 month, to 210,811 units.

title: MCDOWELL AT BEST UNDER PRESSURE
description: Nobody is more amazed than Roger McDowell when he gets to thinking about it. Two years ago, he was a 23-year-old pitcher in the Texas League, he had just had an operation on his right elbow and he didn't know if he'd ever pitch again. Today, he is the best relief pitcher on the best team in baseball, and he has won or saved 31 of the Mets' 88 victories.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $585,000 and $2,104,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $6,000 for the quarter and $803,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,699,000 for the quarter and $3,975,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary gains of $265,000 and $1,565,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. IS CUTTING OFF AID TO ZIMBABWE
description: The United States said today that it would provide no new economic aid to Zimbabwe because of what it called that country's lack of ''diplomatic civility.''

title: Higher Standards In Schools Sought
description: New Jersey's Education Department is seeking to impose tougher graduation requirements on the state's 350,000 high-school students, officials said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: AND now for the results of the American Wine Competition. According to its promoters it was, in 1983, the first such contest to invite every winery in the country to participate. This year's judging was held in New York City last month, and the results were released last week.

title: Accounts
description: * Country Living, a Hearst magazine, to Shaw & Landy, to promote the publication as an advertising medium.

title: U.S. AIDES REJECT DEAL FOR NEWSMAN
description: The State Department today rejected any attempt by Moscow to link the release of an imprisoned American correspondent with that of a Soviet physicist arrested on spy charges in New York 10 days ago.

title: 'DEMAND FOR EXCELLENCE'
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of Education William J. Bennett's report on the condition of the nation's elementary schools:

title: SUN TRUST SET TO ACQUIRE MAJOR NASHVILLE BANK
description: In a move that would create the 24th-largest banking organization in the nation, SunTrust Banks Inc. of Atlanta yesterday reached an agreement to buy the Third National Corporation of Nashville.

title: ROBBERY AT EMPIRE STATE
description: A supervisor of the Empire State Building's observatory was arrested last night and charged with falsely reporting the theft of $80,000 in ticket receipts from the Labor Day Weekend.

title: A FRESH LOOK IS CREATED AT 33D ST. DESIGN CENTER
description: When the owners of the former New York Furniture Exchange converted their building at 200 Lexington Avenue from a marketplace for retail stores to a showroom for designers and decorators a few years ago, the idea was to display not just furniture but a full range of home furnishings and accessories as well.

title: A Classic Carousel
description: He is a professor of classics at the graduate school of the City University of New York. So he sometimes talks in academic terms of a calling that has nothing to do with his profession.

title: HALMI, ROBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Goetz's Lawyers Win a Delay In His Trial for '84 Shooting
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday won another delay in Mr. Goetz's trial in the shooting of four young men on a subway train in December 1984. The lawyers said they would be unavailable to represent their client until at least late October or early November because of other court commitments.

title: PLANE CRASH KILLED 4 FROM L.I.
description: A young couple and a father and son from Long Island were among the victims of the collision of an Aeromexico jetliner and a private plane near Los Angeles on Sunday.

title: Beer and the Military
description: Excerpts from recent floor remarks by Senator Phil Gramm on an amendment to require military bases to buy alcoholic beverages from wholesalers in the state where the base is:

title: IN TENSE FRENCH TOWN, THE MELTING POT BOILS OVER
description: In mid-August, the calm of a late Sunday night in this Mediterranean port was shattered when an Alfa Romeo sedan blew up on a narrow, seedy street, killing its four passengers and destroying two floors of a nearby concrete apartment block.

title: Butcher Facing New Charges
description: C. H. Butcher Jr. and James E. Steiner, acquitted Saturday of 25 counts of mail, wire and securities fraud, were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to commit income tax fraud.

title: POLICE SAY TWO SECURITY GUARDS WITNESSED COLLEGE RAPE-SLAYING
description: Two security guards at Clarkson College of Technology here witnessed a rape-slaying but did nothing because they thought the couple were engaging in consensual sexual relations, according to the police.

title: EAST GERMANY STEPS UP CONTACTS WITH CHINA
description: With a visit to Peking planned next month by its party leader, East Germany is stepping up a reconciliation with China that appears to have the cautious blessing of the Soviet Union, according to scholars and Bonn officials.

title: U.S. Tax Plan Reduces Cuomo's Payment 23%
description: Governor Cuomo's Federal taxes would be cut 23 percent under the tax-revision plan tentatively agreed to in Washington, according to an analysis of his returns by the state's Department of Taxation and Finance.

title: Dial-a-Joke Zapped
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development recently installed a new telephone switchboard and seized the opportunity to include a device that keeps employees from dialing numbers that provide the time, the weather or dirty jokes. According to Rod Hiduskey, a department spokesman, these calls cost the Federal Government, and thus, of course, taxpayers, a fee every time they are dialed, so it was decided to block frequently called numbers that were not business-related. Workers who continue to dial them now get nothing but a busy signal.

title: COUSINEAU WAIVED; TRADE EFFORT FAILS
description: After an unsuccessful effort to trade Tom Cousineau, the 29-year-old linebacker, the Cleveland Browns waived him yesterday to reduce their roster to the regular-season limit of 45.

title: DETOMASO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOR SMART STUDIES
description: THE September arrival of school days can send parents into a shopping daze. There are always clothes to buy, for last year's wardrobe has surely been outgrown by now. And there is always a long list of essential supplies to assemble, from lunch boxes and book bags to notebooks and pencils. Stores around town have a wide selection of back-to-school items to fill those needs. 1.Schoolgirl's Duffel The style-conscious girl will keep warm in this yellow wool duffel coat by Christian Dior. It has a hood and is trimmed with black leather and natural wood toggles. The coat comes in sizes 4 to 6X for $152, and is available in turquoise or sapphire in larger sizes. It can be found in K.I.D.S. on the eighth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street and all branches. 2.Glowing Night Sky A child can turn a bedroom into an exciting planetarium with Lights in the Night. This educational kit contains an illustrated color poster of the solar system, along with 234 luminescent appliques of the stars and planets that a child affixes to designated places. With the appliques in place, the poster glows when the lights go out, revealing the excitement of the night sky. The kit also comes with a comet information booklet by Dr. William Gutsch, chairman of the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium. It is for children ages 8 and up and costs $19.95 at Mythology, 370 Columbus Avenue, between 77th and 78th Street. 3.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Net income

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income tax benefits of $592,000 for the quarter and $4,900,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes income tax benefits of $1,929,000 for the quarter and $2,986,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months' net is also after an extraordinary loss of $1 million.

title: Santa Fe Petitions I.C.C. on Merger
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said that it had petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen its proposed merger case. Santa Fe said it had new evidence that addresses the I.C.C.'s concerns on the anti-competitiveness of the merger between the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railways.

title: Seeing Stars, U.S.F.L. Style
description: It's too bad that Joe Peters didn't get his brainstorm a couple of years ago, when the likes of Herschel Walker, Kelvin Bryant and Jim Kelly were still wearing their United States Football League uniforms. Back then, the idea of staging a U.S.F.L. all-star game might have had a certain logic. Now, however, with the league dormant, its revival far from certain and its stars gone to the National Football League, the idea of putting on such a game the week before next January's Super Bowl seems, well, a shade quixotic.

title: WILBUR STREECH
description: Wilbur Streech, an artist who specialized in serigraphy, died Friday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Palisades, N.Y.

title: Citicorp Paper Rates Decline
description: Interest rates declined for the fifth consecutive week at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING ADVANCED 0.5% IN JULY
description: Construction spending advanced five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the best performance since April, as strength in single-family homes helped offset declines in office buildings and apartments, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Alexandra H. Clark, 52, Dies; Folk Artist and Art Historian
description: Alexandra H. Clark, a folk artist and art historian, died of cancer Saturday at her home on Bainbridge Island, Wash. She was 52 years old and had moved from Branford, Conn., to Washington in 1983.

title: LUGAR, AFTER VISIT TO MANILA, PRAISES AQUINO
description: After returning from an extensive Asian trip, Senator Richard G. Lugar praised President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines today and said she was taking the right tack in trying to control the Communist insurgency in her country.

title: 3 GRADUATES EYE FUTURE
description: AS Americans learn to celebrate food and those who prepare it, the food industry is attracting students whose backgrounds, opportunities and aspirations are more diverse than ever. Witness, for example, these three recent graduates of the Culinary Institute of America. BONNIE CALABRESE, 23, said she knew as a child growing up in Manhattan that she wanted to be a chef. But as a student at a prestigious private school, she said, her friends and family admonished her: ''There's no future in cooking. What kind of goal is that for a bright young girl?''

title: KRUKOW STYMIES METS FOR FOURTH TIME
description: Mike Krukow of the San Francisco Giants became a man of utter distinction last night when he outpitched Dwight Gooden for the second straight time this season and beat the Mets for the fourth straight time.

title: GOLD BUG REVIVAL AS RALLY CONTINUES
description: Some of the investors who for the last few years have sunk billions of dollars into stocks and bonds now seem to be catching the gold bug.

title: TEAR GAS DISRUPTS SOVIET DANCERS IN PERFORMANCE AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: Three minutes into the first performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company in this country in 12 years, tear gas, from a canister apparently thrown from the standing-room section at the Metropolitan Opera House, sent nearly 4,000 patrons streaming out of the hall at Lincoln Center last night.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Stockman Redux
description: David A. Stockman, who said and wrote a number of unflattering things about the Reagan Administration as budget director and thereafter, is back at it. In an article in the current issue of Omni magazine, Mr. Stockman contends that those who differ with President Reagan have not had the courage to take a stand in his presence.

title: Prince Charles in Boston For Harvard Celebration
description: Prince Charles arrived today on his first visit to Boston, where he is to speak at Harvard University's 350th anniversary celebration.

title: New Deaver Quarters
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House official, has moved the office of his lobbying and public relations concern to smaller but possibly more modish quarters. Over the Labor Day weekend, Michael K. Deaver Associates moved from 1025 Thomas Jefferson Street N.W. in Georgetown to 3050 K Street N.W. The new site is actually just across the street, in the large new Washington Harbor development on the Potomac, whose chief active tenants at this point are restaurants.

title: BENNETT URGES OVERHAUL OF ELEMENTARY CURRICULUM
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett called today for a ''major reform'' of curriculums in the nation's 80,000 elementary schools.

title: ALLEN CASE
description: Allen Case, an actor who appeared on stage and in television, died of a heart attack Monday at Truckee (Calif.) Forest Hospital.

title: Sutherland Drops Gala, Citing Injured Eardrum
description: Joan Sutherland has a perforated eardrum and has dropped out of a gala performance with Luciano Pavarotti tonight.

title: RESEARCH ON BIOLOGICAL WARFARE IS CHALLENGED
description: A lawsuit filed today seeks to block the Defense Department's research into biological weapons and antidotes, charging that the military has not complied with environmental laws.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Woman and the Rat
description: The first time I ever saw a sewer rat, it was running across my kitchen radiator. My daughters, whose supper I was supervising, were babies, and my first thought was that I mustn't panic and frighten them. My second, addressed to the rat, was ''How dare you?''

title: 'ONE RIVER, ONE COUNTRY,' ON CBS
description: BILL MOYERS appears tonight in what is, presumably, his last big documentary for CBS News. Mr. Moyers reportedly is leaving to go on to other things, and ''One River, One Country - The U.S.-Mexico Border'' seems to mark his departure. It is provocative and worth watching. Mr. Moyers uses the documentary, on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock, to make a foreign-policy case.

title: FLORIDA SLAYER GETS 2 LIFE TERMS
description: The tobacco heir Steven Wayne Benson was sentenced to two consecutive life terms today for killing his mother and adopted brother by blowing up the family car with pipe bombs.

title: MECIR TOPPLES WILANDER IN 4 SETS
description: There are times when Mats Wilander looks as if he would rather be anywhere than on a tennis court. It is an impression he has left often during the years he has played in the United States Open. He is the best of a band of dispassionate Swedes performing in an emotional cauldron called the National Tennis Center. That is a conflict he and his teammates have not yet been able to resolve, and now, the two who remain must seek an answer without him.

title: Median Home Price Declines
description: A $200 drop in the median price of existing homes in July meant that more than half of American families could afford to purchase an average home, a trade association said today. The National Association of

title: China Party Plans Session
description: The next full session of the Communist Party's Central Committee will be in late September, according to Hu Qili, a senior Politburo member, who was quoted today. Mr. Hu made the disclosure Monday at the opening of China's National Defense University, the official English-language China Daily said. General Secretary Hu Yaobang of the Communist Party has said the session will set the agenda for the 13th National Party Congress.

title: EYE CARE CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Year to June 28
CHILDREN'S CLOTHES GROW UP
description: DON'T blink when you pass schoolyards this fall. Little learners will be wearing little versions of styles first fashioned by the likes of Donna Karan and Azzedine Alaia. At all prices and for all ages, children's clothes are no longer clothes; they're fashions. And those fashions are mimicking adult styles.

title: Wickes Sells Last Of Owens Stake
description: The Wickes Companies said yesterday that it had sold the last of the stock it held in Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation. The company said it had made a profit of more than $30 million from the unsuccessful takeover bid.

title: SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTRY ENDORSES SPY CHARGE AGAINST U.S. REPORTER
description: The spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry said today that an American reporter detained since Saturday had been caught ''red-handed'' in espionage activities.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $6,209,000 on early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 15.

title: A Bitter Pill for Epileptics
description: I have been taking drugs every day of my adult life: phenobarbital and Dilantin in my 20's, Mysoline in my 30's and 40's and now Depakene. They are anticonvulsants that control seizures for me and hundreds of thousands of others who have epilepsy. They also show up in the urine, if tested for.

title: Market Place; The Strategies Of 2 Top Funds
description: THE hottest new issue of 1986, Home Shopping Network, still figures prominently in the portfolios of two of the nation's top-performing mutual funds.

title: New Gillette Product
description: The Gillette Company said today it would introduce a disposable twin-blade razor with a strip that releases a lubricant for smoother shaving. The ''Good News Plus'' razor is Gillette's latest attempt to protect its 62 percent share of the $700 million American shaver market.

title: 27 Lose Party Cards For Chernobyl Roles
description: Twenty-seven members of the Communist Party in the region of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant have been expelled for misconduct related to the April 25 disaster, the party daily Pravda said today.

title: YANKS STUN A'S WITH RALLY IN 9TH
description: The Yankees were within three outs of another downfall tonight, but they scored three runs in the top of the ninth inning and beat the Oakland A's, 9-8. Dave Winfield's single scored Rickey Henderson from third base with the deciding run.

title: RESEARCHER LINKS PICTURES TO ABUSE
description: A Justice Department study has found that three popular adult magazines have frequently depicted sexual images of children, and the chief researcher said today that the depictions might be linked to child abuse.

title: Jackson a Hit In First Game
description: Bo Jackson of the Kansas City Royals recorded an infield single tonight in his first time at bat as a major leaguer. Jackson, the 1985 Heisman

title: Iran Reports Capturing Iraqi Radar Platform
description: Iran said today that marines led by frogmen had seized an Iraqi radar platform in the Persian Gulf 25 miles south of Fao that directed air raids on oil tankers.

title: CYCLISTS SHIFT GEARS FOR THE OPEN ROAD
description: As the United States team still sought its first gold medal, the focus of the world cycling championships shifted today from the track to the road.

title: CHURCH SEEKS END TO STATUS AS LANDMARK
description: A church on the West Side of Manhattan is petitioning the United States Supreme Court to revoke its status as a landmark, arguing that the financial hardship of such a designation interferes with the church's religious liberty.

title: For the New York Assembly
description: In some New York State Assembly districts, victory in next Tuesday's Democratic primary will be tantamount to election. Here are our endorsements for such contests in New York City. MANHATTAN 62d District: Sheldon Silver, the incumbent, is preferable to a perennial challenger, John Bal. 67th District: Jerrold Nadler, whose judgment does not always keep pace with his intelligence, warrants re-election. 68th District: Thomas Santiago makes a favorable impression as an intelligent challenger, but after 11 years in office, Angelo Del Toro is established in the Legislature as a Hispanic leader. 69th District: Despite the interesting challenge by Lancelot Fletcher, we endorse Edward Sullivan, able advocate for libraries, for a fifth term. 70th District: Geraldine Daniels, completing her third term, continues to receive our endorsement over George Miller, whom she defeated in 1980. 72d District: John Brian Murtaugh, a lively legislator familiar with ethnic intricacies of this district, has served capably, offering realistic assistance to privately sponsored housing rehabilitation. BRONX 76th District: Agustin Alamo, a teacher, stresses educational equality and housing issues, but it is not clear that he could do more for the district than Aurelia Greene, an advocate of job training and adult education who has held the seat since 1982 and whom we endorse again. 78th District: We endorse Gloria Davis, the incumbent, believing that her three-term seniority gives her an advantage over Mary Brumby, a former ally and an energetic and determined candidate, and Roberto Ramirez. 81st District: It's hard for outsiders to understand why Eliot Engel, the incumbent in this largely Co-op City district, has so often shifted positions.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,916,096 and $4,092,702 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $320,789 for the quarter and $66,417 for the 6 months.

title: DR. GEORGE D. CANNON
description: Dr. George Dows Cannon, chairman of the board of trustees of Lincoln University, the oldest black university in the United States, died Sunday at his home in New York City. He was 83 years old.

title: Ominous Ghosts in Moscow
description: What explains the frame-up that has landed Nicholas Daniloff, an American correspondent, in a Moscow jail amid dark talk of espionage? There are several possible answers but none speak well of the Soviet Government. The incident serves, rather, as an ominous reminder of how pendular may be the ''openness'' promised by Mikhail Gorbachev's new regime.

title: ANITA BAKER AND HER MUSICAL ROOTS
description: IN the last three months, Anita Baker, a 28-year-old pop-soul singer from Detroit, has attracted such intense critical admiration that a new term, retronuevo, had to be invented to describe a style that fuses gospel, jazz and pop. The term, which was coined by the black music historian and critic Nelson George, evokes not only Miss Baker's singing but a broader reaction against overly mechanized music. Miss Baker, who is playing two sold-out shows this Saturday and Sunday at Radio City Music Hall, represents only one of many artists, especially singers, who are scrutinizing vintage jazz, doo-wop, soul and funk styles for artistic inspiration.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Liquide, Paris, said the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information, under the Hart Scott Rodino Antitrust Improvement Act, about its proposed acquisition of Big Three Industries.

title: GREEK CLASSICS COME TO THE MASSES
description: Some argue that Aristophanes would be amused, others that he would turn in his grave. The controversy is over whether popularized adaptations of ancient Greek plays should be performed by popular Greek movie stars in renowned ancient theaters that, until now, have been the preserve of classical artists.

title: IN A SWITCH, DYSON AND GREEN FOCUS ON D'AMATO IN DEBATE
description: Two Democratic candidates for the United States Senate took time out from criticizing each other yesterday to spell out what they said were their fundamental differences with the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: FINDING THE PARK SPACE FOR FUTURE MEMORIALS
description: The first 210 years of United States history produced more than 100 monuments and memorials here. Officials now wonder where the heroes of the next two centuries will be enshrined.

title: GRAIN-BEAN PROTEIN
description: WITH summer just past its peak, and gardens in farmers' markets full of ripe and flavorful vegetables, this is the time to combine these vegetables in hardy main-course salads. Adding whole grains and beans to salads will increase their protein impact and make them more filling and satisfying - and less like rabbit food.

title: FACTORIES' JULY ORDERS GREW 2.2%
description: Factory orders, propelled by a 44.7 percent increase in demand for military equipment, climbed 2.2 percent in July for their best performance since 1984, the Commerce Department said today.

title: New Creative Director At McCann-Erickson
description: After a five-month search McCann-Erickson/New York has chosen John Nieman as its creative director responsible for 25 clients handled by the agency.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1986
description: International 398 people appeared to have drowned when a Soviet passenger ship sank in the Black Sea on Sunday, the Soviet Union announced. The ship sank after colliding with a cargo vessel. A Soviet shipping official said at a news conference that the Admiral Nakhimov, which was carrying 888 passengers and 346 crew members, sank 15 minutes after it was hit broadside by the freighter about eight miles outside the Black Sea port of Novorossisk. He said there was no time to launch lifeboats. [ Page A1, Col. 6. ]

title: JERSEY LANDFILL TO BECOME AN ARTWORK
description: A 57-acre landfill in northern New Jersey, only four miles from the Holland Tunnel in a highly trafficked area best known for its industrial complexes, smokestacks and fumes, is being transformed into an earth sculpture and park by the artist Nancy Holt.

title: THERMODYNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Pollen Count of 23 Is Measured in Jersey
description: The pollen count yesterday, as recorded at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., was 23 - 23 particles of pollen per cubic meter of air.

title: TECH DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: CULINARY CLASS OF 1986: NEW STATURE, NEW VISTAS
description: A PORTRAIT of this year's graduating class at the Culinary Institute of America is a reflection of the revolution in the way Americans eat.

title: Kodak Products
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced 17 new products for professional photographers and photofinishers, including a faster Kodachrome film and the industry's fastest color print processor. The products were displayed in Cologne, West Germany, at Photokina, the world's largest photographic trade show. They brought to 56 the number of photographic products introduced since January, the most the company has ever had in a year, said Wilbur Prezzano, who runs the photographic products group.

title: Southern Living Plans To Increase Rate Base
description: Southern Living magazine expects a rate base increase of 100,000 by January, which would bring its circulation to 2.3 million.

title: Hartford Surplus Put at $350 Million
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill announced today that the state had a $350.3 million surplus in the 1985-86 fiscal year and expected a $55.8 million surplus for 1986-87.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $156,000 for the quarter and $359,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,000 and $17,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: NBC REBUTS POLL RESULTS ON DRUGS
description: NBC network officials, stung by a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll in which 11 percent of those queried named ''Miami Vice'' as a program that glamorizes drug use, said that network standards prohibited the glamorization of drugs and denied that the program did so.

title: DONOVAN TRIAL DELAYED BY CO-DEFENDANT'S SEVERANCE REQUEST
description: Jury selection in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan was delayed yesterday as a dispute erupted over a request by another principal defendant for a separate trial on the ground of ill health.

title: Dome Petroleum To Meet Creditors
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it planned to meet with its unsecured public debt holders in Europe in late September and early October to urge them to waive interest and principal payments to allow adequate time for carrying out its recapitalization plan.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,300,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also includes a gain on investment of $2,158,000. c-Includes a loss on investment of $266,000 for the quarter and a gain on investment of $14,000 for the 6 months, and losses from discontinued operations of $142,000 and $268,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PROGRESS OF LOVE. By Alice Munro. 309 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. FOR the people in ''The

title: PUBLIC FUNERALS BARRED FOR VICTIMS IN SOWETO
description: South African authorities imposed severe limits today on how Soweto can bury victims of clashes with security forces, two days before a mass funeral planned in the black township for 20 blacks killed last week.

title: LOCAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the previous year net is after a gain of $292,000 from a Federal Home Loan Bank Board preferred stock dividend. Corrected from Saturday, Aug. 30, editions.

title: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
EXECUTIVES
description: * Cabot Corp., Boston, has named Robert A. Charpie chairman, succeeding Louis W. Cabot, who is retiring. Mr. Charpie will continue as president and chief executive.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,904,000 from venture capital investment. c-Net income and after a gain of $2,298,000 from venture capital investment.

title: Lady Bird Johnson's Brother
description: Tony Taylor, 82 years old, a merchant here who was the brother of Lady Bird Johnson, died Sunday at St. Vincent Hospital after heart surgery. Mr. Taylor, a philanthropist and civic leader, opened a shop in downtown Santa Fe in 1927 at which he sold imported Mexian honorary vice consul to Spain by President Johnson.

title: NATIONAL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1986
description: Companies

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,543,000 for the quarter and $750,000 for the 6 months.

title: Henry Moore Will Be Buried In a Private Rite in England
description: Henry Moore will be buried Thursday in a private ceremony near his home in Much Hadham, England, it was announced today.

title: TEACHER STRIKES IN NATION SPREAD
description: Teachers seeking higher wages and improved benefits went on strike in 16 school districts in seven states yesterday, joining colleagues in walkouts that have extended summer vacations for 77,000 pupils.

title: WARRIORS APPEAL TO WORRIERS
description: There is a picture of Magic Johnson in one of the National Basketball Association team brochures, but it is not Los Angeles's. The Laker guard has been enlisted as a ''Golden State Warrior Worrier.''

title: NOVA PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BILLBOARDS ON HIGHWAYS: A TWICE-FOUGHT BATTLE
description: One of the major environmental battles of the 1960's, the effort to restrict advertising billboards along the nation's highways, is being fought again, and with a vengeance.

title: PRIVATE FLYING SAFETY DEBATE FLARES
description: It happens about 50 times a week: Somewhere in the country a private plane or helicopter has an accident. Close to half the time, it happens on a weekend. And about one out of every five times someone is killed.

title: WHO WILL JUDGE THE JUDGES IN ELECTION CASES?
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTHUR PETER CATALANI
description: Arthur Peter Catalani, former president of Breon Laboratories, died Aug. 23 in Middlesex Hospital Hospice, Middletown, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Lyme, Conn.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $188,000 and $286,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $635,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: AMERICAN MIDLAND reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,230,000 and $1,441,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $86,000 for the quarter and $312,000 for the 6 months. The company said its year-ago figures reflect its former drugstore operations being accounted for as discontinued operations.

title: War Criminal Loses Appeal in Yugoslavia
description: The Nazi war criminal Andrija Artukovic lost an appeal today to stop his execution by firing squad. His lawyers said they would try new ways to delay the death sentence.

title: Economic Scene; Alleviating Tax Bill's Drag
description: HOW will the tax revision bill, which Congress seems bound to pass and the President to sign in the weeks ahead, affect the economy?

title: When the Yen Leaves the Sky It May Capture the Earth
description: Tokyo has always been one of the world's most expensive cities, but American visitors today find it shockingly so. The $7 cup of coffee, the $6 magazine and the nearly $100 airport taxi ride are but a few surface encounters the foreigner finds with ''yen shock,'' the phenomenon of a Japanese yen that has appreciated as much as 40 percent against the dollar during the last year.

title: AIRLINE AIDE KILLED IN BOGOTA AFTER FINDING DRUGS
description: The chief of security for Avianca, Colombia's biggest privately owned airline, was shot to death Monday, two days after he led an operation that turned up $5 million of cocaine aboard an Avianca cargo jet bound for Miami, the police said.

title: U.S. Says Airport at Manila Now Has Adequate Security
description: Security measures at Manila International Airport have improved to the point that they now meet international standards, the United States Government said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FUN AND GAMES IN YUPPIELAND LUNCH hour on Wall Street. Louis B. Wolfowitz was heading back to his office when he saw that a crowd had gathered around something or other. This is not an uncommon sight in Manhattan, of course, so Mr. Wolfowitz chose to ignore whatever was drawing such a crowd. He was walking around the milling mob when he noticed two men in business suits - young Yuppie types - struggling to see over the heads in front of them. Suddenly, one of the young men put down his attache case, handle-side up. Then, leaning on a parked car for support, he proceeded to stand on the briefcase.

title: KEY RATES
The Federal Karloff
description: Here is another movie in which the U.S. Army carries on as though nobody with a brain ever put on the uniform. It is ''Starman,'' a pretty good sci-fi flick until it collapses into cliche about the villainy of the U.S. Government.

title: HAY FEVER TIME WORSENS, GRAIN BY GRAIN
description: The sticky glass rods that revolve on the roof of St. Barnabas Medical Center here pick up everything from mold spores and dust particles to an occasional unlucky insect.

title: Robertson Gears Up
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson has scheduled a news conference in Washington two weeks from today to disclose his political plans, and there is some pretty strong evidence afoot that the television evangelist will become an active candidate for the 1988 Republican nomination for President.

title: 25 Hurt in Rail Mishap In West Virginia
description: A Chessie System coal train diverted to the wrong track slammed into a line of sleeping cars used by railroad crews tonight, injuring 25 people, the authorities said.

title: LAWYERS DEFEND HUNT FILING
