description: Lawyers for the Hunt brothers today denied they had violated a Federal judge's order by making a bankruptcy filing in New Orleans rather than Dallas.

title: Devils Sign Adams
description: Greg Adams, the center whose 35 goals and 42 assists in his first full National Hockey League season established team records for the Devils, has signed a three-year contract with an option year, according to Max McNab, the general manager.

title: EASTERN AIR WILL LAY OFF 1,534 AS PART OF A DRIVE TO STEM LOSSES
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday announced plans for one of its deepest cutbacks in an effort to stem its losses.

title: Trilogy Official Chosen As President and Chief
description: Trilogy Ltd. said yesterday that it had appointed Peter Appleton-Jones as president, chief executive and a director, replacing Gene M. Amdahl, who remains chairman.

title: Foolproof Pie Dough
description: CERTAIN kitchen techniques seem so obvious that many home cooks fail to pay them much attention - and thus wind up performing them incorrectly.

title: Through the Hospital Looking Glass to the World of D.R.G.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: 398 FEARED DEAD ON RUSSIAN LINER IN THE BLACK SEA
description: The Soviet Union said today that 398 people appeared to have drowned when a passenger ship sank in the Black Sea on Sunday night after colliding with a freighter.

title: ARMS GOALS: FLEXIBILITY AND FIRMNESS
description: The Administration's tentative modifications to its position on strategic arms suggest that it is prepared to be flexible on the overall levels of strategic arms but is keeping firm to its basic goal of forcing deep reductions in land-based missiles, the principal area of Soviet advantage.

title: NAVRATILOVA BEATS SHRIVER BY 6-2, 6-4
description: It's easy to talk about beating Martina Navratilova. Pam Shriver talked about it before their match yesterday, saying she felt as if the latest renewal of the rivalry between these doubles partners and close friends would be ''her day.'' But she learned once again that such talk is not so easy to defend.

title: G.E. Names Lineup For Financial Unit
description: The General Electric Company yesterday disclosed a new executive lineup for its financial services operations, with no surprises.

title: Books of The Times
description: For the people in ''The Progress of Love,'' storytelling is a way of seeing and remembering, a mundane but necessary art. In the title story, the narrator recounts how her father watched her mother burn her unwanted inheritance in the kitchen stove; though probably untrue, the story serves as a testament to what she believes about them and the nature of love. Another woman tells a story about how she met her first husband while singing madrigals at college, a neat story of destiny between ''a skinny innocent bit of a lad with a pure sweet tenor'' and ''a stocky little brute of a girl with a big deep alto.'' And a third speaks of how she and her husband ''invented characters'' for their children, casting each daughter in a specific role. <TD WIDTH=2

title: Elizabeth Coatsworth, Author, Is Dead at 93
description: Elizabeth J. Coatsworth Beston, author of children's stories, novels, short stories and essays, died in her home at Chimney Farm here on Sunday. She was 93 years old and had lived here for 57 years.

title: TEXAS LEGISLATIVE IMPASSE PERSISTS IN FISCAL CRISIS
description: With three days remaining in the state's special 30-day legislative session, legislators appear to be deadlocked in their attempt to deal with the state's fiscal crisis.

title: CUTS IN FILM 'LOST HORIZON' RESTORED
description: New Yorkers will have a chance this week to see an early, 132-minute version of Frank Capra's ''Lost Horizon'' for the first time in almost 50 years. The restored version of the film about the earthly paradise called Shangri-La will play at the Museum of Modern Art tomorrow and will open a regular theatrical engagement at the Regency Theater on Friday.

title: B.F. Skinner Didn't Put His Child in a Box Ann Arbor, Mich., Aug. 24, 1986
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERIWEST FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $597,000 from a Federal Home Loan Bank Board dividend.

title: Connecticut Fire Kills Boy, 9
description: A 9-year-old boy was killed in a fire at his home this morning, while his father and two older brothers jumped to safety from second-story windows, fire officials said.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YOUMANS WINS 2-HITTER, 1-0
description: Vance Law hit a two-out homer in the ninth inning, and Floyd Youmans pitched a two-hitter tonight to lead the Montreal Expos to a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE textures of foods are almost as important as their tastes. Take porterhouse steak, for example, considered the ultimate cut of beef - and justly so to my mind. A porterhouse consists of two varieties of meat of different textures, with a single connecting bone: the filet mignon, which is the most delicate, softest-textured part of the beef, and the strip shell steak, which is a bit denser yet admirably tender.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. Aide in France On Anti-Libya Tour
description: Vernon A. Walters, the special American envoy, met with President Francois Mitterrand today and afterward denied that the United States was making any ''demands'' on France in the fight against terrorism.

title: Boeing, McDonnell Get Several Orders
description: The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, two of the world's largest manufacturers of commercial jetliners, said yesterday that they had received orders for several planes.

title: Moses Is Winner Of 47.38 Hurdles
description: Edwin Moses ran the year's fastest 400-meter hurdles at an international track and field meet on today, extending his unbeaten streak to 118 races, including 101 finals.

title: A Merger In Public Relations
description: AS a byproduct of last week's mega-merger of three major advertising agencies, a mini-merger of two well-known public relations agencies was announced yesterday, creating the third-largest of its kind in the country.

title: INJECTING BELUSHI WITH FATAL DRUGS BRINGS A 3-YEAR TERM FOR WOMAN
description: A judge sentenced Cathy Evelyn Smith to three years in prison today, saying that she had supplied ''the poison'' that led to the death of the comedian John Belushi from a drug overdose.

title: Bond Investors Gets Aaa Rating
description: Bonds insured by the Bond Investors Guaranty Insurance Company, the smallest of the four major concerns specializing in backing tax-exempt issues, are now rated Aaa, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: DRUG TESTING SET FOR MORE WORKERS
description: At least a dozen of the largest employers in the New York metropoltian area test new workers for drugs, and experts say many more plan to begin drug screening programs over the next few months.

title: A Kennedy's Views
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, Plenary and Special Commission 3 - 10:30 A.M.

title: AT 35, SOAP OPERA 'SEARCH' TRIES TO ADJUST TO CHANGES
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago today, in a 15-minute live broadcast from New York's Liederkranz Hall, ''Search for Tomorrow'' set out to make soap-opera history. It is now television's longest-running daytime drama, hardly missing a beat when it switched from CBS to NBC in 1982. The show's pivotal character is Joanne Tourneur, played by Mary Stuart since that very first day. Her neighbor and best friend is Stu Bergman, still portrayed by Larry Haines, who joined the cast two months after the premiere. In today's half-hour episode, on NBC at 12:30 P.M., Jo and Stu will browse nostalgically through an old photo album, offering viewers a well-intentioned but skimpy retrospective of ''landmark'' moments.

title: Wrong Time for Old Times
description: A ''social visit'' yesterday between Federal Judge Robert W. Sweet and former Federal Judge Harold Tyler resulted in Judge Sweet's disqualification from an election law case.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter is after a gain of $2,445,000 from the sale of nine stores less the clossing of one store.

title: Smell of Success
description: Joe Kapp, the football coach at the University of California, grew up in Salinas, Calif., just south of a little town named Gilroy that considers itself the garlic capital of the world. Early in life, Kapp came to appreciate the distinct and pungent qualities of garlic, and to this day he applies it generously to his homemade salsa (Mexican hot sauce), of which he is so proud.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
U.S., ANSWERING UNUSUAL REQUEST, SEEKS ILLEGAL ALIENS IN WESTCHESTER
description: In an unusual move, officials of this Hudson River village have called in Federal immigration agents to help with what they perceive is a problem with illegal aliens.

title: Grievance on Gossage
description: Don Fehr, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, said the union may formally file a grievance on behalf of Rich (Goose) Gossage in the next day or two. Gossage was suspended last week without pay for the rest of the season by the San Diego Padres for criticizing the team's management in a newspaper interview.

title: Denials on Dawson
description: A report that Andre Dawson had turned down a two-year, $3 million contract was denied by both the Montreal Expos and the outfielder's agent, Dick Moss. The report, in The Montreal Gazette, said Dawson had rejected the deal because it would have meant a ''too drastic reduction.''

title: Continental Begins Paying Off Debts
description: The Continental Airlines Corporation began paying the first installment of about $925 million owed to creditors, a company spokesman said in announcing that the airline had emerged from bankruptcy. Continential will pay nearly $140 million within 10 days in the first stage of a reorganization plan approved this summer by a Federal judge, the spokesman, Bruce Hicks, said.

title: DOW DROPS BY 27.98, TO 1,870.36
description: After a quiet start, stocks fell sharply yesterday on the first day back from the long Labor Day weekend, as the market ran headfirst into higher precious metal prices and a number of uncertainties about the economy.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS VS. METS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: EX-COLLEAGUE UPSETS JULIAN BOND IN ATLANTA CONGRESSIONAL RUNOFF
description: In a stunning upset, John Lewis defeated State Senator Julian Bond today in a Congressional contest that pitted two legends of the civil rights movement against each other.

title: FLORENCE B. MARSTON
description: Florence Brady Marston, former Eastern and Midwestern regional director of the Screen Actors Guild, died of Alzheimer's disease on Thursday at a nursing home in Southbury, Conn. She was 82 years old and lived in Newtown, Conn.

title: Margaret Grant Plumb, 100, A Longtime Hunter Librarian
description: Margaret Grant Plumb, an archivist who was associate librarian of Hunter College for 44 years, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100 years old.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell sharply yesterday, with most of the decline coming in the last few hours of trading when traders and speculators were heavy sellers.

title: DECISION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $81,000.

title: THE MONEY'S NOT HOT, BUT THE TELLERS ARE
description: THE Greater New York Savings Bank on the corner of Broadway and 79th Street has 32 fans: 4 tall floor fans, 10 large table fans, 4 square floor fans, 7 small teller-window fans (5 of them on and 2 off), 3 small customer-service table fans, 1 medium-size customer-service table fan and 3 safe-deposit vault fans - a square floor fan in the reception room, a short one in the vault room and a square floor fan pointed into customer room No. 1. I asked the vault man, Mr. Selterman, why the bank had so many fans. He said because it was hot. I asked him why the vault didn't have air-conditioning. He said it did; it just didn't work. I asked him why they didn't fix it. He referred me to the manager, Mr. Walker.

title: Koch System Stymied
description: Last week, this column reported an odd new Lotto system that had paid off for its developer, Edward I. Koch, with four winning numbers.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
MAFIA 'SOLDIER' SECRETLY RECORDED TALKS WITH GOTTI OVER TWO YEARS
description: A ''soldier'' in the Gambino organized-crime family became an informer and wore a secret recording device during clandestine meetings with John Gotti and others in the crime group for more than two years, according to court papers that were unsealed yesterday.

title: A COLLEGE TRAINS WOULD-BE 'SUPERS'
description: FOUR years ago, David Gorman was laid off after 23 years of working for a trucking company. A short while later he enrolled in a training program for superintendents at New York City Technical College, attending classes three evenings a week for 10 months.

title: BAKER J INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,038,000 for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $1,596,000 for the 6 months. The company went public June 5, after 11 months as a privately held concern.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON GLASS African art of a sort completely different from the art we have come to associate with that continent is on exhibition, in colorful profusion, at the African-American Institute, 833 First Avenue, opposite the United Nations at 46th Street (949-5666).

title: A Journal Meant for Scientists
description: UNDAUNTED by hard times at a number of science publications, The Scientist, ''the newspaper for the science professional,'' will make its bow Oct. 15. It is aiming at an initial controlled circulation of 30,000, which the publishers hope will quickly become 80,000 all-paid subscriptions.

title: Rehnquist Opposition
description: A coalition of civil rights groups will present a case against the confirmation of William H. Rehnquist as Chief Justice of the United States at a public forum in the Senate Office Building today.

title: Bamberger's Shift
description: Bamberger's confirmed that its 24 department stores would be called Macy's, effective Oct. 5.

title: Judge Rejects Kendavis Motion
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has rejected a motion by lawyers for the ailing Kendavis Industries to throw out a reorganization plan offered by banks that are owed more than $500 million by the Fort Worth conglomerate.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
New Counsel for von Bulow
description: Another name has joined the list of lawyers who have worked for Claus von Bulow - a list that includes Alan M. Dershowitz, a professor at the Harvard Law School, and Thomas P. Puccio, the former Abscam prosecutor.

title: LLOYD ADVANCES TO OPEN SEMIFINAL
description: There is a place in tennis few players ever venture, a locale of such excellence and bliss that only the most talented among them can describe what happens there. It is a place where every serve intimidates, every volley lands out of reach and every ground stroke hugs the line. Most importantly, it is a place where every opponent is beatable. Players call it ''the zone.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Doctor's World column in Science Times on Aug. 5 about shock treatment for snake bites incorrectly described lithotripter machines, used to break up kidney stones. The machines use electronically generated shock waves to smash the stones.

title: A Congressman Carries the Ball
description: Back on July 21, when Representative Thomas A. Luken introduced a bill to create a commission on collegiate athletics, not even he felt that it would evoke a sense of urgency. Indeed, nobody thought it had much of a chance of reaching the floor before the House's adjournment in October.

title: British Aerospace
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it had won orders worth about $65 million for six Jetstream 31 airliners and seven 125-800 business jets.

title: CITY PRINCIPALS REPORTED TO DENY USE OF CRACK BY THEIR STUDENTS
description: One of the most experienced drug counselors in the city's school system said yesterday that many public school principals denied that their students were using the drug crack for fear that their school's reputation would be hurt.

title: STOCK WINDOWS: CUSTOM LOOKS, EVERYDAY PRICES
description: IT used to be that most doors and windows in special shapes and sizes - octagonal or fanlight windows, wood-framed french doors -were synonymous with custom millwork. Requiring time-consuming hand labor, they were expensive to make and often took months to complete. But lately, major millwork manufacturers have begun to offer a wider selection of stock windows and doors that have a custom look at much lower prices.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press article Tuesday on a radio program featuring Abbie Hoffman gave an incorrect location for the taping of the show tomorrow. It will be taped at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

title: Bridge: Messages Not Always Clear From Long Suit in Dummy
description: Every defender knows that he must keep a careful eye on dummy's long suit. But the conclusions are not always obvious.

title: B'nai B'rith Leadership
description: The election of Seymour Reich, a New York lawyer, as president of B'nai B'rith International may signal increased emphasis by the Jewish service organization on the condition of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Stewardship
description: St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish, the oldest and one of the most venerable public buildings in Manhattan, is closed.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: BISHOP GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax benefits of $91,000 for the quarter and $326,000 for the 9 months.

title:
GARDENING: WHAT TO DO IN SEPTEMBER - CITY;
Preparing for Frost and Also for Spring
description: THERE are plenty of opportunities and rewards for the city gardener this month.

title: ALL VICTIMS WERE HANDCUFFED
description: Two men and a woman, their hands cuffed behind their backs, were slain in a Washington Heights apartment building yesterday in what appeared to be drug-related shootings, the police said.

title: FOR HASIDIN, SCHOOL BUSES STIR A DISPUTE
description: About 600 boys who attend a Hasidic school in Orange County - following their religious belief that the sexes should be separated -yesterday refused to board school buses driven by women.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Sri Lankan Soldiers Battle the Guerrillas
description: Heavy fighting broke out today between soldiers and separatist guerrillas on a northwestern island after the rebels destroyed a bridge to the mainland, military sources and residents said.

title: Bullets Get Vincent
description: The Dallas Mavericks traded Jay Vincent, a veteran forward, to the Washington Bullets for a first-round draft choice in 1990. The 6-7 Vincent, who played for the Mavericks five years, averaged 13.8 points as a reserve last season.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Martina Navratilova-Pam Shriver vs. Steffi Graf-Gabriela Sabatini.

title: BATTLE FOR DATE IN ZIP 20515
description: The National Taxpayers Union would like to do a little checking on some Government records. The Post Office would prefer not.

title: Sale to SunTrust Hailed By Third National Chief
description: Interstate banking is coming to Tennessee, and that pleases Charles W. Cook Jr., president and chief executive of the Third National Corporation of Nashville.

title: Jersey Mob Figure Arrested
description: Saul Kane, described by law-enforcement agents as one of New Jersey's top organized-crime figures, was among five people arrested during drug raids Tuesday night and early today. In the raids, the authorities seized $15 million worth of a substance used to make methamphetamine or ''speed.'' The authorities said Mr. Kane, 51 years old, of Margate, was a ''trusted operative'' of Nicodemo (Little Nicky) Scarfo, whom they called an organized-crime leader.

title: U.S.-Made Toyota
description: The first Toyota automobile assembled in the United States is scheduled to come off the assembly line Thursday at the northern California factory of New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., a joint venture of the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation. The Corolla FX-16, a sporty version of the Corolla subcompact, will be priced between $9,000 and $13,000, depending upon options. It is expected to be available to buyers in October.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF: USING 'BULLY PULPIT'
description: Public education in the United States has historically been viewed as a matter for state and local government, so the role of the country's top education official, a position currently held by Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, has over the years been an uncertain one. Congress created the

title: Son Leaving the Firm Of Rogers & Cowan
description: A father-son split has developed at Rogers & Cowan, a public relations firm in Los Angeles, over ''philosophical differences.''

title: Reagan Approval Rating Declines Slightly in Poll
description: Public approval of President Reagan's job performance has declined slightly, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: POPE REINFORCING CLERICS IN DISPUTE WITH SANDINISTAS
description: A senior Vatican official said today that Pope John Paul II had given his full backing to Nicaraguan church leaders in a confrontation with the Managua Government over what critics says is harassment of the church and violations of human rights.

title: Bethlehem Sells a Unit
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has sold its Buffalo Tank division to a new company headed by a Chicago industrialist, K. J. Hathi, who owns metal fabrication operations in Illinois and Alabama. The price was not given.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TIGHTENS PRESS CURBS ON THE EVE OF FUNERALS IN SOWETO
description: The South African authorities imposed new and tougher measures today barring reporters from covering any actions of the security forces.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1986
description: Companies

title: G.M. and Daewoo
description: The General Motors Corporation and South Korea's Daewoo Group formally opened a plant to produce a new front-wheel-drive car.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALL carpets need regular cleaning in order to maintain their original brightness and color. The amount of cleaning needed will, of course, depend on the amount of traffic the carpet receives, as well as on the general conditions in the area - how dusty the home is, how dirty the neighborhood air is, and how much dirt is carried in from outdoors.

title: REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.M.C. ADDS FREE FINANCING
description: The American Motors Corporation, taking a dramatic step in the interest rate competition among Detroit auto makers, is offering consumers interest-free financing for up to two years for most of its 1986 products. Free financing is virtually unheard of in retail sales except for loans of shorter duration for furniture and large appliances.

title: Reluctant Report
description: Gerald Riggs, the National Football League's second-leading rusher last season, will report to Atlanta Falcons, ending a holdout that cost him $42,000 in fines, but he remained unhappy.

title: FOR A RETURN TO MUSICAL SIMPLICITY
description: NOT long ago at the Library of Congress, while doing research on musical performance styles of the 18th and 19th centuries, I jostled for time on the photocopying machine with John McGlinn, a conductor who has been doing the same for the 20th - in particular, on American musical comedy in the teens and 20's. Our conversation reminded me how delightful his concert revivals of some of those shows had been, and how fascinating the reconstructive efforts behind them were.

title: 37 GOVERNORS' RACES BUOY UP G.O.P. HOPES
description: Thirty-seven states will elect governors this year in contests that Republicans say may offer their party its best opportunity to extend ''the Reagan revolution'' to the state level, where Democrats remain dominant.

title: MCKELLEN RELISHES A SCOUNDREL
description: How and when the play was written, why it was unknown for decades and then discovered under murky circumstances, what it was originally called - all are facts shrouded in mystery, endlessly debated by scholars but perhaps never to be known for certain. When an early play by Anton Chekhov (possibly the first full-length work he ever wrote) was finally unearthed in a Moscow safe-deposit box in 1920, 16 years after the playwright's death, its title page was missing - as was any record of its origins.

title: Preparing for Frost and Also for Spring
description: SEPTEMBER is planting month - for everything: perennials, shrubs, lawns and even a few cold-tolerant vegetables. About the only exceptions are hardy bulbs, which are planted in October, and herbs, which need the summer to form scented leaves. But pick and dry or freeze them now.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $2,102,423 from the sale of land and $880,000 from the settlement of a claim for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1985 second quarter and 6-month figures include extraordinary income of $17,000 and $37,000, respectively, as a result of the utilization of a net operating loss carryforward.

title: Second-Half Standings
THE WILLARD IS RESTORED AS A JEWEL OF PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE
description: After nearly two decades of neglect and continuing threats of demolition, the Willard, the capital's legendary hotel, has been returned to its former glory.

title: More of the Mentally Ill to Join Homeless Wanderers of the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: GETTING VARIED HELP IN EMERGENCIES
description: On Monday, Aug. 25, President Paul Biya of Cameroon notified the American Ambassdor that the country would need international assistance to help meet the aftermath of the poisonous gas eruption at Lake Nios that had killed 1,200 people.

title: Chicago Panel Rejects Mayoral Vote Change
description: In a move that sets the scene for a prolonged court fight, the Chicago Board of Elections voted 2 to 1 Tuesday against putting a referendum on the November ballot that would change the city's mayoral election to a nonpartisan one.

title: 'SOLDIER BOY' FOLLOWS LIFE IN THE SOVIET ARMY
description: DO Soviet G.I.'s ever go on KP? If they do, the viewer won't find them peeling spuds or scrubbing pots on ''Soldier Boy,'' tonight at 9 on Channel 13. Doesn't somebody have to do the dishes and wake the bugler in the Soviet Army, too?

title: DURATEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 6 months and year-ago losses are before interest expense on advances from National Patent Development Corp. Duratek, which is 59-percent owned by National Patent, went public in February.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''If these charges on Watergate were true, nobody would have to ask me to resign - I wouldn't serve for one month.

title: CBS ON 'CRACK STREET'
description: CBS News overdosed on its own production Tuesday night.

title: 'REALISM AT ANY COST' CAUSED MOVIE DEATHS, A JURY IS TOLD
description: The chief prosecutor in the trial of John Landis, director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' told a jury today that the director had put his desire for cinematic realism ahead of safety, leading to the deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children four years ago.

title: SHULTZ MAY SEE SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said here today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would probably meet soon with Oliver Tambo, leader of the African National Congress.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: The Advertising Column of Business Day on Friday misstated the new title of John B. O'Neil at Vance Publishing in Lincolnshire, Ill. He is vice chairman.

title: MARWICK, KMG PLAN TO MERGE
description: In a move that would create the world's largest accounting firm, Peat Marwick International, one of the Big Eight, and Klynveld Main Goerdeler announced yesterday that they intend to merge.

title: COURT RULES ON DISPUTED JUDAICA
description: A consortium of leading Jewish scholarly institutions will receive a collection of rare Jewish books and manuscripts that was auctioned at Sotheby's in 1984 and later recalled, the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday. The books and manuscripts were returned after Mr. Abrams sued the auction house, charging it with ''persistent fraud and illegality'' in the sale.

title: RULING TODAY ON HUNTS' BANKRUPTCY FILING SITE
description: A Federal judge said today he would rule Thursday on whether bankruptcy filings made by the Hunt brothers should be transferred to his jurisdiction in Dallas from the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Orleans.

title: DANCE TROUPE RETURNS TO MET AMID SECURITY
description: Amid beefed-up security, the Moiseyev Dance Company performed without incident last night, drawing a standing ovation from a capacity crowd at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: U.S. AIDES ARE LOOKING TO GAINS AT A-TEST TALKS RESUMING TODAY
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they hoped the Soviet Union would use the next round of talks on nuclear testing to explain its technique for measuring the size of nuclear explosions and its assertion that a test ban could be verified.

title: Origins of Two Songs That Americans Sing
description: To the Editor:

title: SAKHAROV IN A PLEA ON PRISONERS
description: The dissident Andrei D. Sakharov has written to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, appealing for the release of political prisoners, including Dr. Sakharov's friend Anatoly Marchenko, who was reported today to be one month into a hunger strike.

title: LITTLE ROCK FIGHTS DREAM OF A SODA MACHINE IN EVERY YARD
description: Like a growing number of residents here, Ezekiel Kinchen Jr. thought he was onto a good thing: you take a used vending machine, chain it to a tree in your yard and start selling soda.

title: May in Move To Ease Deal
description: May Department Stores said today that it would be willing to divest itself of assets to insure the completion of its planned acquisition of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

title: A CHAMPION IN ANY LANGUAGE
description: Sinistra. Left hand. Destra. Right hand. Avanti. Forward. Dietro. Back. At the beginning, the student and the teacher were both learning.

title: RECYCLING BACK IN FAVOR IN METROPOLITAN REGION
description: Recycling of bottles, cans and newspapers, which became popular in the 1970's at the height of the environmental movement but has since waned, is enjoying a resurgence in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Alabama Supreme Court Rules for Democrats
description: Alabama's Supreme Court refused today to order a new Democratic gubernatorial runoff between Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley and Attorney General Charles Graddick.

title: Legionnaires' Disease Linked to Cooling Tower
description: A factory cooling tower was the primary source of bacteria responsible for a fatal outbreak of legionnaires' disease, state officials said today.

title: Former ABC Producer To Head CBS Program
description: Bob Shanks, an Emmy Award-winning producer and a former vice president of ABC Entertainment, will be the executive in charge of a new CBS morning program, CBS officials announced yesterday.

title: Official Quits Over Gun Deal
description: The Connecticut State Library's director of reader services, accused of lax supervision of an employee who traded away pieces of a valuable antique gun collection, has resigned. The interim State Librarian said today that the resignation of the official, Arlene C. Bielefield, would take effect Oct. 31.

title: 45,000 HOMES ARE DAMAGED
description: About 4,900 apartment buildings and 45,000 private homes were damaged in Moldavia by an earthquake and a strong aftershock this week, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: More of the Mentally Ill to Join Homeless Wanderers of the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bears of Summer
description: A friend who has been spending the summer without electricity in a house in the country remarks on how comforting a candle is at night, even when he's suffering from insomnia - as soothing as his battery radio. He has spent so many summers in this mountain notch that even indoors he recognizes the howls of owls training their young, the chatter of chimney swifts swirling in a flock, the giggle of a loon or the dubious comments of a cruising raven.

title: POP: THOMAS BOGDAN SINGS
description: THOMAS BOGDAN, a young tenor who made his name as an interpreter of the Baroque repertory and has recently branched out into the pop arena, represents a striking departure from the normal run of ''classical crossover'' singer. Mr. Bogdan, who appeared at the Horn of Plenty last Thursday evening, does not attempt to forge a pop identity that is sharply distinct from his classical self. Instead, he locates a middle ground between the formal refinement of the Baroque aria and the more freewheeling, idiomatic manner of contemporary pop.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1986
description: International

title: Juice Account Moves
description: The Bloom Agency in Dallas has won the $4 million Nestle's Juicy Juice account. The line of fruit juices had been handled by Chiat/Day, which introduced it four years ago.

title: SANDWICH CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The per share earnings are not meaningful since the bank converted from a mutual to a stock organization in July.

title: People
description: * Dennis L. Dunlap and James G. Oates have been elected executive vice presidents at Leo Burnett, U.S.A.

title: Liberated Woman Meets Uncommitted Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Storage Proposes Reorganization
description: The Storage Technology Corporation has filed a reorganization plan in Bankruptcy Court that would repay about $800 million in debt to 8,500 creditors. Under the plan, the maker of computer memory storage devices would repay the debts with $140 million in cash, $285 million in 10-year notes and 196 million shares of newly issued stock valued at $375 million.

title: AMENDMENT TO ALASKA LANDS LEGISLATION STALLED
description: A move to keep land in the hands of Alaska's Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians has met delays in the dying days of Congress that may prevent its approval.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $900 million of 7 percent debentures due 1991 at a price of par through various securities dealers. When the interest rate was announced yesterday morning, the new five-year agency issue yielded about 32-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes of comparable maturity.

title: U.S. Special Envoy Confers With Kohl on the Libya Issue
description: Vernon A. Walters, the American delegate to the United Nations, discussed Libya with Chancellor Helmut Kohl today but gave no hint that there were ''unpleasant things ahead,'' such as another air raid, a West German official said.

title: Sale of Moore Sculpture Sparks Seattle Dispute
description: An eight-ton Henry Moore sculpture that has been a city landmark since 1971 can be removed only if the seller replaces it with another artwork, city officials say.

title: 101 MEMBERS OF NONALIGNED MOVEMENT
description: Following is a list of the 101 members of the Nonaligned Movement who are attending the conference here: Afghanistan Algeria Angola Argentina Bahamas Bahrain Bangladesh Barbados Belize Benin Bhutan Bolivia Botswana Burkina Faso Burundi Cape Verde Central African Republic Chad Colombia Cameroon Comoros Congo Cuba Cyprus Djibouti Ecuador Egypt Equatorial Guinea Ethiopia Gabon Gambia Ghana Grenada Guinea Guinea-Bissau Guyana India Indonesia Iran Iraq Ivory Coast Jamaica Jordan Cambodia Kenya North Korea Kuwait Laos Lesotho Liberia Lebanon Libya Madagascar Malawi Malaysia Maldives Mali Malta Mauritania Mauritius Morocco Mozambique Nepal Nicaragua Niger Nigeria Oman Pakistan Panama P.L.O. title: YIELDS FALL AGAIN
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell for the week ended yesterday. The decline is now into its eighth consecutive week.

title: COMMUNISTS WARN MANILA OVER PEACE TALKS
description: Communist negotiators accused Philippine Government officials of bad faith today and warned of a possible failure in cease-fire talks that began a month ago.

title: True Blue
description: It is Kentucky and not Idaho, of course, that is known as the Bluegrass State, but we're not really talking grass here. We're talking Astroturf, blue Astroturf, if you can believe it, or Boise State Bluegrass, as the first blue football field known to man is officially called.

title: U.S. CALLS IN DEBT COLLECTOR FOR DELINQUENT FARM LOANS
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it had turned over the pursuit of 6,500 delinquent Federal farm loans to a commercial bill collector.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $31.2 million for the quarter and $81.6 million for the 9 months.

title: CAPITAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1985 share earnings were not available because it converted to stock form in November 1985.

title:
TO PROMOTE PHILIPPINE DEMOCRACY;
Provide Aid and Investment
description: On his recent visit to the Philippines, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said, ''I am bullish about the Philippines,'' but our Government and the private sector must go beyond mere praise. Without vigorous assistance for this fledgling democracy, the hope I sensed on a visit last month may not survive. The country is on the edge of economic and political recovery after a brutal era of repression and disintegration. This critical transition period requires all possible support and encouragement.

title: A TEXAS-SIZE LEGAL BROUHAHA
description: Like everything else about the Hunts, their legal battles are being played out on a giant scale, involving a horde of lawyers from firms in Dallas and across the nation.

title: DONALDSON CHIEF QUITS SUDDENLY
description: In a surprise move, John K. Castle resigned yesterday as chief executive of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: A NEW THERMOSTAT YOU SET AND FORGET
description: WHEN it gets cold, the simplest way to cut heating bills is to turn down the thermostat when no one is home or when everyone is asleep.

title: PRODUCTION DEFECTS STILL PLAGUE NAVY MISSILE
description: Deployment of the Navy's most advanced missile for aerial combat is being delayed by persistent production difficulties, Navy officials said tonight.

title: JAZZ: JIM HALL TRIO IN VILLAGE
description: JIM HALL, who is at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street) with his trio through Sunday, plays like a man who knows the whole story but only wants to tell you the good parts. On the sort of tunes that inspire most jazz guitarists to be exhaustive, Mr. Hall is selective.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Karpov Gets a Timeout In World Chess Match
description: The challenger Anatoly Karpov, who is trailing the champion Gary Kasparov by a point in the World Chess Championship, was granted a timeout today.

title: Weinberger Criticizes Efforts to Cut Military
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, resuming his attack on Congress, said Tuesday that the Pentagon's budget request was vital for national security and was not a ''wish list.''

title: BRIBERY IS CHARGED TO GUAM GOVERNOR
description: Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo of Guam was indicted today on Federal charges that he accepted or solicited more than $100,000 in bribes, some of it delivered to him in a brown paper bag.

title: HISPANIC POVERTY RATE NEARS THAT OF BLACKS
description: The poverty rate among Hispanic Americans may soon overtake that of blacks, according to a study released Tuesday. The study showed that 5.2 million Hispanic people lived below the poverty line last year.

title: Gorbachev's Hostage
description: When the Ayatollah Khomeini seized American hostages in Iran, the waffling and timorous Carter Administration reaction caused such a wave of revulsion here as to carry Ronald Reagan to the Presidency.

title: Dairy Farmers Today Are Not in Clover
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK MEN SHOW GAIN IN EARNINGS
description: A new study by the United States Commission on Civil Rights says that the earnings of black men have improved dramatically over the last 45 years but that it is impossible to determine how much of this gain is a result of Government civil rights programs.

title: Reform in South Korea Off to a Poor Start
description: To the Editor:

title: WALKER TO SEE LIMITED ACTION
description: Three weeks ago, the Dallas Cowboys signed Herschel Walker for $5 million over five years. They want him to run with the football, but he may not run much when the Cowboys and the Giants meet Monday night in Irving, Tex., in their regular-season opener.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Reactivated Tom Niedenfuer and Jerry Reuss, pitchers, and Pedro Guerrero and Ken Landreaux, outfielders.

title: JACKSON GETS VISA TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he was given permission to attend the inauguration Sunday of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu as Anglican Archbishop of South Africa, but only under unacceptably severe restrictions.

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The company said the 1986 results reflect a loss from the sale of a subsidiary of $2,018,600. The operating loss in fiscal 1986 was $4,035,900 and included non-recurring charges of approximately $1.2 million.

title: Big Red Machine
description: Terrorism is understandably a matter of some concern in the capital, and today the District of Columbia Fire Department is to unveil what it describes as ''the nation's first antiterrorist armored firefighting vehicle.''

title: AIR CONTROLLER WAS DOING 2 CHORES, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The air traffic controller who was handling the descent of Aeromexico flight 498 characterized air traffic as ''light'' when the jetliner and a small private plane collided Sunday, the head of the Federal investigation into the crash said tonight. And because of the light traffic, the controller was performing two job functions at the same time, he said.

title: Second Arson Fire In Los Angeles Library
description: An arson fire burned briefly tonight in the historic Central Library, which was severely damaged last spring in a similar blaze that destroyed or damaged more than a million books, officials said.

title: Agent Orange - Let It Lie
description: The vexed case of Agent Orange has been laid almost to rest by a solution that is almost a lie. But now, at the last minute, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit seems poised to overthrow Federal Judge Jack Weinstein's elegantly contrived solution with a narrow insistence on the truth. That would be an error that would fruitlessly prolong Vietnam veterans' tormented search for solace.

title: Lord Maybray-King, Ex-Commons Speaker
description: Lord Maybray-King, the first Speaker of the British House of Commons from the Labor Party, died today as the result of a stroke, a hospital official said. He was 85 years old.

title: Merger Lawyer Joining Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company has hired Dennis J. Friedman, a corporate lawyer at the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, to join its mergers and acquisitions department. Mr. Friedman will be a vice president, Kidder said Tuesday.

title: Putnam's President Quits to Start Firm
description: Walter Oechsle has resigned as the president and chief investment officer of Putnam International Advisors, one of the largest managers of mutual funds, to start his own firm. Ten others, including senior Putnam representatives in London and Tokyo, joined him late last month in offices almost across the street from Putnam's headquarters in Boston.

title: OJEDA DEFEATS GIANTS FOR VICTORY NO. 16
description: When the Mets got him from the Boston Red Sox last winter, Bob Ojeda was a luxury: the No. 5 man in a five-man rotation, almost an ''extra'' pitcher on the deepest staff in baseball.

title: 4-YEAR FIGHT IN FLORIDA 'JUST CAN'T STOP DRUGS'
description: Four and a half years after Vice President Bush established the South Florida Task Force, the most ambitious and expensive drug enforcement operation in the nation's history, the Federal officials who run it say they have barely dented the drug trade here.

title: U.S. Bars an Oxfam Shipment Of Farm Tools to Nicaragua
description: The United States has rejected a request from Oxfam America, the relief agency, to ship farm tools to Nicaragua.

title: Rates Continue to Advance
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, creating consternation in the credit markets where traders and investors are wondering if the two-year-old trend to lower interest rates is finished.

title: MILDRED A. GUTWILLIG
description: Mildred A. Gutwillig, a New York social worker and pioneer in the settlement house movement, died Monday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., of a stroke suffered earlier in the week. She was 87 years old and lived in Harriman, N.Y.

title: Soviet Diplomat In Bangkok for Talks
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry has sent the head of its recently created Southeast Asia department to the region for discussions in advance of the annual United Nations General Assembly, according to Thai officials. Thailand is a member of the Security Council.

title: HERS
description: INTO my cedar and canvas canoe goes everything we will need for five days: food, clothes and shelter jammed into big backpacks. We set forth, paddles dipping and pulling, under a high blue sky dappled with marshmalllow clouds. There is no sound but the music of wood on wood, paddle on gunwale, and the canoe leaps forward at every stroke. A canoe carries you across water with grace. Its turns (in the right hands) are balletic, it rides waves and slices into headwinds. It has neither motor to break down nor gizmos to comprehend. Every time your arms pull water, the canoe responds. When the lake narrows into impassable creek, or ends, you put the canoe on your shoulders and carry it to the next water. It is a marvel of self-propelled travel.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The British Government began a $4 billion borrowing program today, the largest issue ever in the international bond market, setting off a hectic morning in the Eurobond market.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AGREEMENT REACHED IN THEATER TALKS
description: Negotiators for the Actors Equity Association, which represents about 37,000 actors and stage managers across the United States, and the League of American Theaters and Producers, which represents most of the country's ''first-class theaters,'' including Broadway theaters, have tentatively agreed upon a new three-year contract.

title: N.C.A.A. PENALIZES 60 NEBRASKA PLAYERS
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eligibility Committee has suspended 53 Nebraska football players for one game and seven others for two games.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL REDRAWS DISTRICT OF MEMBER WHO DIED
description: The Los Angeles City Council tentatively approved a plan today that would reshape council districts by carving up the district of a councilman who died last month to preserve the political careers of two incumbents.

title:
TO PROMOTE PHILIPPINE DEMOCRACY;
Help Win The Leftist Guerrillas
description: Considering Washington's notable lack of success in using military means to deal with third world insurgencies, it takes astonishing hubris to press Corazon C. Aquino to follow this failed strategy. Yet that apparently is what President Reagan and others plan to do when the Philippine President visits in mid-September.

title: THE METHODS, OPEN OR QUIET, OF SPECIAL COUNSELS
description: Criminal investigations of high Government officials and former officials pose a problem acknowledged by most prosecutors: How to generate enough publicity to encourage unknown witnesses to come forward without creating a circus atmosphere that jeopardizes the rights of the accused?

title: Stake Is Raised In Jet America
description: Alaska Air Group Inc. said it had bought an additional 520,000 shares of Jet America Airlines Inc. at $3.25 a share, bringing its total holdings to one million shares, or 18 percent.

title: Oil Meeting Set in London
description: The British energy secretary, Peter Walker, and the Norwegian oil minister, Arn Oeien, plan to meet next week in London to discuss the oil situation, according to British and Norwegian officials.

title: ITALIAN TEAM PAID BALDI'S $11,000 FEES
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's stringent penalties against Marco Baldi stemmed not only from his acceptance of air transportation from an Italian basketball team but also for the tuition, room and board that the Milan-based team paid when the St. John's center attended high school both in Italy and on Long Island.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We mounted our air-conditioners in the living room and bedroom at the tops of the windows, instead of the bottom. I notice that both units tend to ''short cycle'' by going on and off every few minutes. Adjusting the thermostat and turning the louvers has no effect. Is this normal, or are we doing something wrong? A. Most of the time when this happens it is because the units are too large for the rooms being cooled and they have more capacity than is needed. As a result they lower the temperature quickly, then kick off.

title: PUSH ON HIRING BIAS IN ULSTER
description: Encouraged by the success of the campaign to get American investors to pull out of South Africa, a coalition of Irish human rights advocates and politicians is mounting a drive to prod American companies doing business in Northern Ireland to combat discrimination against Roman Catholic workers.

title: RECRUITING GOALS MET BY MILITARY SERVICES IN 1986
description: The nation's military services managed to meet or exceed their recruiting goals in the first nine months of the fiscal year 1986, but the Navy continued to lag behind the other services in signing up high school graduates, a new report shows.

description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation elaborated yesterday on the financial impact of the recapitalization and restructuring plan it announced last Thursday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rorer Rumors Heat Up Again
description: TAKEOVER speculation has kept Rorer Group Inc.'s stock percolating for years, but yesterday the shares reacted like never before to news that the Dow Chemical Company, often considered the concern's protection from a hostile takeover, was bailing out.

title: Kodak Plans Drug Tests
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will require all job applicants to take drug tests and will ask current workers suspected of drug use to take a test or face suspension, a company spokesman said today.

The event, scheduled for tonight, will be conducted by the Home Box Office network, not the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

The Yankees know only that they are scheduled to play through Oct. 5, when they finish the season in Boston.

description: Frank Brady, a writer and professor of English at the City University of New York Graduate School, died of cancer Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a subheading in some copies of Metropolitan Report last Saturday about the funeral of Jennifer Dawn Levin, who was slain in Central Park, reversed a phrase from Rabbi Joel Goor. Speaking at the service, he said: ''We cannot force infinite questions into finite answers so, like Judaism, we must be pragmatic. There is no choice but to turn from death to life, as Jennifer would have wanted.''

description: Atlanta woke this morning to find that yesterday's political assumptions were today's trash. And standing in the midst of the litter, in a city known for the power of its black establishment and black oratory, was the short, inelegant, stubborn man who had taken on that establishment and broken the mold: John Lewis.

title: JOHN AND HENDERSON INJURED
description: The news that Lou Piniella delivered this afternoon was grim. The defeat was one thing, but now the Yankee manager had to contend with two more untimely injuries - one of them to Tommy John, who sustained a thumb injury to his pitching hand in a freakish accident before the game and may be lost for the remainder of the season.

title: BRITOIL LAYOFFS
description: Britoil said it would dismiss almost one-third of its work force, or 750 employees, because of the decline in oil prices. David Walker, Britoil's chief executive, said the layoffs would occur in Scotland, with 600 jobs to be eliminated at the company's Glasgow headquarters and 150 in Aberdeen, the base for the North Sea oil industry. Earlier this year Britoil reduced its work force from 2,700 to 2,480. Mr. Walker said the layoffs would cost about $22.5 million in compensation payments but would save $45 million annually.

description: A murder charge has been filed against the son of John Edgar Wideman, an author who made a family trail of violence and trouble the raw material of a critically acclaimed book.

title: CNW Job Plan
description: The CNW Corporation said that it would offer an early-retirement incentive program to 1,200 nonunion employees at its rail subsidiary, the Chicago and Northwestern Transportation company. CNW said the incentive payments would range from 3 months to 18 months of salary. CNW said it plans to cut its work force by another 250 jobs by the end of the year.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: German Unemployment
description: The West German unemployment rate in August was 8.5 percent, down from 8.6 percent in July and 8.9 percent a year earlier, the Government reported today.

title: Banks' Merger Encounters Snag

On Friday, the Comptroller of the Currency approved the conversion of Westchester Financial's savings and loan unit to a national bank, and the acquisition by Marine Midland for $53 a share in cash.

description: As part of its 350th anniversary celebration, Harvard University announced today that it had created a program to provide public schoolteachers from Boston and Cambridge with a year at Harvard.

description: Sears, Roebuck & Company is offering 9 million shares of common stock at a price of $44.25 a share, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: TO REBUILD CITY, BUFFALO STARTS WITH A FISH REEF
description: Standing on the bow of a 37-foot vessel, James R. Spotila spoke over the radio today to a tugboat captain a dozen yards away. ''Go ahead and drop it,'' he said. With that, huge slabs of concrete splashed into Lake Erie.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: The Gillette Company plans a $20 million ad campaign for its ''Good News Plus'' disposable razor, beginning with TV commercials next Jan. 1. The agency is BBDO/New York.

title: Dance Macabre
description: Dancers don't wage wars, don't jail dissidents and don't grant exit visas. So besides the natural revulsion at the tear-gassing of an opening-night audience at the Metropolitan Opera Tuesday we feel revulsion at the psychotic deviltry of blaming the Moiseyev Dance Company for Soviet emigration policy - if indeed a caller told the truth in claiming ''This was done by Russian members of the Jewish Defense League.''

title: ARCHDIOCESE TO BAR DISSIDENTS FROM SPEAKING IN ITS PARISHES
description: Those who disagree with the official teachings of the Roman Catholic Church should be barred from speaking in parishes in the Archdiocese of New York, the Vicar General of the archdiocese said in a directive to all pastors.

title: U.S. DECISIONS CLASH ON BALLOT CASES
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday affirmed state court decisions invalidating the designating petitions of two leading black Democratic legislators, Assemblymen Albert Vann and Roger L. Green, both of Brooklyn.

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Overseas Role for TDX
description: The Federal Communications Commission has given TDX Systems Inc. authority to offer telephone service in 140 foreign countries. TDX, owned by Cable and Wireless P.L.C., already provides long-distance service within the United States and to Canada.

title: HOME BEAT
description: UNDER the tutelage of the furniture designers James Hong, Carmen Spera and Richard Snyder, concrete telephones that work have been designed by Alex Locadia. ''I wanted to design a series of appliances that were art pieces,'' he said.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A Moscow dispatch on Aug. 19 reported an announcement by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Soviet Union would extend its suspension of underground nuclear tests until Jan. 1. Western diplomats were quoted as saying the Soviet authorities had told a private American group that it would have to turn off its test-monitoring equipment if Moscow decided to resume testing.

title: KEY RATES
GREEK PREMIER MAY DEMAND REMOVAL OF A-ARMS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has told his Socialist Party's central committee that he has ''personally informed'' the United States that Greece may at some unspecified time demand the removal of nuclear weapons stored here.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cleveland Browns claimed Brad Van Pelt, the linebacker, on waivers from the Los Angeles Raiders. . . . The San Francisco 49ers picked up Tom Cousineau, a linebacker, on waivers after he was cut by the Browns. . . . Tim Green, the linebacker from Syracuse who was the Falcons' No. 1 draft pick, suffered a ruptured calf muscle that will sideline him three to six weeks.

title: Conable and GATT
description: Signaling a closer link between international trade and loans for international development, the president of the World Bank, Barber B. Conable Jr., plans to attend the meeting of trade ministers in Uraguay in two weeks.

title: Late Rally Pushes Dow Up by 10.97
description: A spurt of buying in the last hour yesterday helped Wall Street rebound somewhat from Tuesday's big loss. But the recovery was confined to blue-chip and transportation issues, and gainers and losers in the broader market were at a virtual standoff.

title: Animal Rescue Planned
description: Efforts will begin next week to rescue sea mammals trapped in an Alaska inlet that has been closed by a rapidly advancing glacier, organizers say. Howard Rosenfeld, director of the Whale Museum in Friday Harbor, who is director of the rescue effort, said Monday that Russell Fjord has been turning into a lake since about June 1, when Hubbard Glacier surged across its mouth, leaving about 170 seals, 50 porpoises, sea lions and other animals with a dwindling supply of food.

title: DIGITAL'S SURPRISING REVIVAL
description: In the giant red-brick woolen mill where the Digital Equipment Corporation moved in as a start-up company nearly 30 years ago, the chatter in the hallways and offices keeps returning to one question: How long can Digital's remarkable revival last?

title: WILKISON LOSS PUTS ALL AMERICANS OUT
description: The crowd that weathered a rain delay to root for the last American hero had dwindled to a precious few. The baseball cap that had helped make Tim Wilkison an overnight celebrity after 10 years on the tour, and appeared to give him some mystical power on the court, was often removed between games as Wilkison placed a towel over his head in frustration.

title: DRUG CHECKS OF MOTORISTS PLANNED AT THE GEORGE WASHINGTON BRIDGE
description: Law-enforcement authorities plan to set up police checkpoints on the George Washington Bridge exit ramps in New Jersey in search of motorists driving under the influence of drugs, the Bergen County Prosecutor said today.

title: Public Relations Firm Is Acquired by Bozell
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has acquired Robinson, Lake & Lerer, a communications company that specializes in corporate image-making.

title: WORLD AIR TO CUT SERVICE AND STAFF
description: World Airways will end its scheduled passenger service as of Sept. 15, causing it to lay off 1,500 employees, or 57 percent of its staff, the carrier announced yesterday.

title: Santa Fe to Sell Timber Unit
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation has agreed to sell its southern timber subsidiary, Kirby Forest Industries, to the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation for $315 million.

title: U.S. to Seek Sweater Talks
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that he hoped to open talks with China and Macao in 60 days to curb the rising imports of sweaters made from such fibers as ramie and silk blends.

title: Kodak Printer
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, in an effort to penetrate the office automation market, has introduced a high-volume electronic printer for the electronic publishing market.

title: 2 Are Hurt on Sidewalk When Cab Jumps Curb
description: A taxi jumped a curb in Greenwich Village yesterday, injuring two pedestrians and smashing into the door of a bank, the police said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Recall of G.M. Cars Urged
description: Citing 1,500 driver complaints, an automobile safety group has asked two Federal agencies to order the General Motors Corporation to recall six million of its cars and repair what are said to be power steering problems without charge. The Center for Auto Safety said Tuesday that it had filed a petition with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration seeking an investigation of safety problems caused by the reported sudden loss of power steering in 1980-84 front-wheel-drive A-, J- and X-body cars.

title: 3 ARTISTS WHO WORK IN WOOD, FIBER, GLASS
description: Ed Moulthrop's lathe-turned, polished wood bowls, Diane Itter's fiber art and John Nygren's fanciful glass creatures make up a new show, ''Three Media - Three Masters,'' that will open Saturday at the Heller Gallery in SoHo.

title: City Aides Urged To Screen for Lead
description: Children in poor areas of the city who are at high risk of lead poisoning should be medically screened for exposure as a requirement for admission to school, the City Comptroller and a Brooklyn Representative urged yesterday.

title: Two Devils Sign
description: The Devils announced the re-signing of Mark Johnson, a left wing, and Peter McNab, a center. Johnson, 28, agreed to a multiyear deal, and McNab, 34, agreed to a one-year pact. Johnson scored 21 goals last season and McNab had 19. . . . The Islanders signed two free-agent goaltenders, Marty Wakelyn of Colorado College and Roydon Gunn of Prince Albert of the Western Hockey League.

title: BAKER COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Avian Invalids
description: The patient admitted Tuesday was a migratory hummingbird that was almost done in by Manhattan's glass towers.

title: RED SOX WIN FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: Wade Boggs doubled home LaSchelle Tarver with one out in the ninth inning to give the Boston Red Sox their fifth straight victory tonight, a 4-3 decision over the Texas Rangers. The Red Sox maintained their four-and-a-half-game lead over Toronto in the American League East.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on sale of securities of $2,425,000 and $26,365,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax benefits of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $8,603,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits relating to utilization of loss carryforwards of $68,000 for the quarter and $954,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss

title: SIDNEY TANENBAUM, EX-PLAYER
description: Sidney Tanenbaum, a former all-America basketball player who starred at New York University in the 1940's and went on to play for the Knicks, was stabbed to death yesterday at his metal-stamping shop in Far Rockaway, Queens, the police said. He was 60 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: U.S. WEIGHS MOVES AGAINST MOSCOW IN REPORTER CASE
description: Administration officials said today that they were drawing up a set of graduated measures against the Soviet Union - including a personal statement by President Reagan - to be used if an American reporter held in Moscow on suspicion of espionage is not freed promptly.

title: Unexpected Events Aren't Subject to Edict
description: When the Presidential helicopter, Marine One, landed at an isolated park area near here recently, President Reagan suddenly found himself in the middle of a wedding reception. Mr. Reagan, who was on his way to an annual press party nearby, did not go unnoticed, with some in the wedding party later complaining that the event had been disrupted.

title: Tall Tales and All
description: A group of friends and former co-workers of Eugene Patterson, editor of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida and Congressional Quarterly, are holding ''an evening of good fellowship and tall tales'' in his honor at the National Press Club Sept. 13. Before assuming his present responsibilities in 1972, Mr. Patterson worked as a reporter and editor for United Press (1948-56), editor of The Atlanta Constitution (1956-60) and The Atlanta Journal (1960-68), where he won a Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing, and as managing editor of The Washington Post (1968-71).

title: ARGENTINA SEEKS I.M.F. LOAN TIED TO CROP PRICES
description: Argentina's treasury minister, Mario Brodersohn, said today that his Government was seeking a loan from the International Monetary Fund that would insulate Argentina from future falls in world agricultural prices.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represents gross revenue.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LAST year Maxwell's Plum, the rococo all-American restaurant on First Avenue at 64th Street, jettisoned its dated steak, burgers and eggs Benedict menu and leaped into the forefront of California cuisine by hiring two rising stars from the West Coast, Mark Peel and Nancy Silverton. Their revolutionary menu - for Maxwell's at least - caused quite a stir among longtime customers and lured a cadre of new customers. However last May, nine months after the California duo arrived, they suddenly left, saying the restaurant was too large to suit their style of cooking.

title: Dining Out Guide; For Enophiles
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE FOUR SEASONS, #99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - ***(Nov. 22, 1985) For those to whom selecting and imbibing a fine wine to complement a meal is almost as important as the meal itself, the city has a number of restaurants whose cellars offer a comprehensive array of good wines. The Four Seasons, for one, has a size and scope to satisfy almost any taste. The wines are fairly priced with an exceptionally strong selection of American labels. As for ambiance, the Pool Room is done on a palatial scale, allowing for the privacy of well-spaced tables. Starter choices include breast of pigeon with figs; lobster ravioli, and corn and tomato chowder. Main-course options are snapper baked in salt; breast of free-range chicken with shrimp; duck au poivre, and filet of veal with crab meat and artichokes. Dinner entrees $29 to $40.

title: Difficult Task Faces Kaiser Steel Chairman
description: ''We never thought Kaiser would be easy,'' said Monty H. Rial, whose group has been trying to reshape the West Coast company, the Kaiser Steel Corporation. But it has turned out to be a difficult task and Kaiser Steel announced this week that it was trying to work out a restructuring of payments to deal with a severe liquidity squeeze.

title: U.S. PLANS FIRST SPACE-BASED ANTIMISSILE TEST
description: The United States is ready to conduct the first space-based experiment involving the advanced technology that would be used to defend against ballistic missiles, Government officials said today.

title: CORONER OFFERS TO PERFORM SECOND AUTOPSY OF PILOT OF SMALL PLANE
description: The Los Angeles County Coroner has offered to perform a second autopsy of the pilot of a small plane that collided with an Aeromexico jetliner Sunday.

title: Gas Stations in Europe
description: Kuwait's state oil company announced plans today to expand its European retail network. Products at its 2,700 service stations in Europe are to be marketed under a new brand, Q8.

title: Philip Feldesman Dies at 67; National Champion in Bridge
description: Philip Feldesman, winner of many national bridge titles and a member of the United States team in the 1966 World Championship, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: JAPAN PLAN FOR ELDERLY: GREEN PASTURES OVERSEAS
description: Japan is giving serious thought to exporting one of the few natural resources it has in abundance - elderly Japanese.

title: FILM: A DOCUMENTARY, 'SHERMAN'S MARCH'
description: AT the beginning of Ross McElwee's ''Sherman's March,'' the film maker tells us that he had originally planned a documentary about the aftereffects, which are still to be found in Georgia and the Carolinas, of the ''total warfare'' waged by Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman during the final months of the Civil War.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: The Sharp Electronics Corporation has announced a $20 million television and print ad campaign for its consumer electronics and office equipment products.

title: CYANIDE DEATH IN JERSEY CALLED ISOLATED INCIDENT
description: A death caused by cyanide in an instant soup mix probably was a random, isolated case of murder by ''a kook'' who tampered with the product at a grocery store, the Camden County Prosecutor said today.

title: WEST SIDE CONGRESSMAN IS FACING HARDEST PRIMARY FIGHT IN 10 YEARS
description: Representative Ted Weiss, one of the most liberal members of the House, is facing his most serious challenge for renomination in 10 years from a candidate who argues that Mr. Weiss is too liberal even for the West Side of Manhattan, which he represents.

title: Legion Commander Elected
description: James P. Dean of Corinth, Miss., was elected today as national commander of the American Legion. Mr. Dean, a Korean War veteran who holds a doctorate in law from the University of Mississippi and has served in both houses of the Mississippi Legislature, will lead the nation's largest veterans organization until its annual meeting next September in San Antonio, Tex.

title: RHYMES AMONG THE WRENCHES
description: ''The'' New York hosts and hostesses of the 80's, it has been said on more than one occasion, are the city's department stores. The likes of Lord & Taylor, Macy's and Bloomingdale's are frequently the after-store-hours scene of cocktail parties, dinners, fund-raising benefits, award presentations and salutes to all four seasons as well as to practically every country in the world.

title: ART: FLOWER COLLAGES FROM THE 18TH CENTURY
description: MARY DELANY (1700-1788) was born a Granville, the daughter of minor British aristocrats loyal to the Stuart cause. Since the then monarch, Anne, was a Stuart, the young Mary was groomed to follow in the steps of an aunt who had served as a Maid of Honor at the court of William and Mary. But of course Anne died without issue (in 1714) and the Whigs rushed in her distant relative, the Elector of Hanover, George I, preferring a Protestant who didn't speak English to a Catholic who did.

title: CUOMO AT ODDS WITH ARCHDIOCESE OVER POLICY ON DISSIDENT SPEAKERS
description: Governor Cuomo, declaring that ''we lay people have a right to be heard,'' took issue with the Archdiocese of New York last night over a directive that prohibits those who disagree with the Roman Catholic Church's teachings from speaking at parish events.

title: SUSPECT IN PARK SLAYING WILL NOT TESTIFY TO JURY
description: The attorney for Robert E. Chambers Jr., the 19-year-old Manhattan man charged with the strangulation of a young woman in Central Park last week, said yesterday that his client would not appear before the grand jury to describe his version of the events that led to the woman's death.

title: THE PROFITABLE ROAD TO NATURAL BEEF
description: The concept was so simple that Mel Coleman knew right away it would work.

title: THEATER: BECKETT'S STAGING OF 'KRAPP'S LAST TAPE'
description: IN Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' a disintegrating 69-year-old man sits in a dark cell of a room, randomly reviewing taped journals of his life at age 39. As Krapp's life unwinds, we survey the detritus of a painfully familiar existence - the death of parents, the loss of love, the defeat of noble aspirations and resolutions, the eternally losing battle against the allure of drink and the unruliness of the bowels. How small and pointless the life of the 39-year-old Krapp looks, both to us and to the utterly defeated Krapp of 30 years later. ''The earth might be uninhabited,'' says Krapp - and so it might, even with him inhabiting it.

title: HUNTS LOSE ON SITE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: In a setback for the Hunt brothers, a Federal judge today ordered them to transfer their bankruptcy cases to Dallas from New Orleans.

title: Musical version of original 'Dracula' is being prepared.
description: IT isn't going to be a rock musical, although it will have some rock rhythms, and it's not going to be camp or a parody, although the subject matter has invited such treatment. That takes care of what it isn't. What it is is a musical version of ''Dracula'' - and it's very likely that the show will be produced on or Off Broadway next spring. If plans proceed as expected, it will be called ''Possessed'' and cost more than $1 million.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI PROPOSES TAX RATE RISE IN FUTURE
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that future revenue increases needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit should come from raising income tax rates. His remarks came less than three weeks after Congressional conferees reached agreement on a sweeping tax bill that would sharply lower income tax rates.

title: METS BEAT RED SOX, 7-3, JUST FOR THE FUN OF IT ALL
description: It may have been a preview of the World Series, the way some people were saying, or it may have just been an exhibition game for charity, the way it was billed.

title: MOYNIHAN VIEW OF POVERTY
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, last night at a Harvard symposium on the poor:

title: TV WEEKEND
description: NEAR the middle of ''Yuri Nosenko, K.G.B.'' - a Home Box Office ''Showcase '86'' presentation making its debut on the pay-cable service Sunday at 10 P.M. - a C.I.A. agent observes that ''this business is a wilderness of mirrors.'' The same could be said of this film, which is based on a true story bearing on the assassination of John F. Kennedy and the role of Lee Harvey Oswald. The ostensible hero is an American agent named Steve Daley (Tommy Lee Jones). We are told the story through his eyes and vested interests. Yet Stephen Davis's script, based on the real-life defection of Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko in 1964, uncovers enough sliminess on all sides to leave most objective observers appalled by just about everybody involved, not least Steve Daley.

title: 4 GUNMEN IN PAKISTANI CITY SEIZE A PAN AM JET WITH 400 ABOARD
description: Four men dressed as security guards and firing machine guns seized a Pan Am jumbo jet filled with nearly 400 people at Karachi airport early today, and at least four people were wounded, officials in Pakistan said.

title: A FESTIVAL ON 125TH ST.
description: A free festival, with music, dance and other activities, is planned tomorrow, from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. on 125th Street, from Broadway to the Hudson River.

title: Arms Control Is in President Reagan's Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Louisiana Officials Charged in Bribery Case
description: A ranking state legislator and the chairman of the State Pardon Board were indicted today on charges of accepting a $130,000 bribe to pardon a convicted murderer.

title: Litton Net Falls 60.6%
description: Litton Industries said today that it earned $30 million, or $1.07 a share, for the fourth quarter ended July 31, down 60.6 percent from $76.1 million, or $2.06 a share, a year earlier.

title: Marietta Signs Satellite Pact
description: In a breakthrough for the American commercial rocket business, the Martin Marietta Corporation said today that it had signed a reservation agreement to launch a commercial communications satellite for the Federal Express Corporation.

title: THREAT TO LEAVE VIRGINIA BASE MAY WIN FALWELL A TAX WAIVER
description: In the space of less than three weeks, by threatening to leave Lynchburg, Va., and move here if the property of his enterprises continue to be taxed by Lynchburg, the Rev. Jerry Falwell appears on the verge of outflanking the law, the courts and more than a century of church tradition in Virginia.

title: O'Rourke Establishes Conditions for Debate
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke responded yesterday to Governor Cuomo's conditions for a gubernatorial campaign debate by setting his own conditions.

title: HANK GREENBERG, TOP HITTER AND MEMBER OF HALL OF FAME
