description: Hank Greenberg, the boy from the Bronx who grew up to become a Hall of Fame slugger, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Cup Program Finds Cash Goes Begging
description: Breeders' Cup Ltd., which sponsors the seven Cup Day races each November and subsidizes more than 100 other races, has a problem: In its attempt to give money away, it has found few takers, leading to some unusual situations.

title: U.S. and Soviet Resume Chemical Arms Talks
description: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed talks today at an unannounced location in Bern, the Swiss capital, on halting the spread of chemical weapons, an American Embassy spokesman said.

title: VATICAN MOVES TO CURB POWER OF A LIBERAL PRELATE IN SEATTLE
description: Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen of Settle said today that the Vatican had directed him to turn over authority to Auxiliary Bishop Donald Wuerl in five areas, including such moral issues as birth control and homosexuality.

title: Bridge: A Venture Into Five Spades Is a Trip to No Man's Land
description: Those who cross the street without looking are not always injured, but it is not a recommended procedure. The same is true for bidders who voluntarily play in five spades or five hearts: they have nothing to gain and a lot to lose.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IF an artist decided to write a piece of music instead of painting a picture, what would the work sound like? If there were lyrics, what would they say? Jeff Gordon, a New York artist-turned-pop-music-composer-and-record-producer, has spent the last year pursuing answers to those questions.

title: Festivals And Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Steel Pulse, Pier 84, 12th Avenue and 45th Street (ticket and weather information: 249-8870). One of Britain's finest reggae bands, from Handsworth, Birmingham, Steel Pulse was one of the first English reggae bands to become popular outside of England. Powered by the drummer Steve Nesbitt and the bassist Ronald McQueen, the music has a streamlined polish, which integrates funk elements into an accelerated reggae format, matched by its passion. The lead singer David Hinds's keening, plaintive vocals are underscored by the keyboardist Selwyn Brown's and the percussionist Alphonso Martin's backup vocals. Show time is tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. and tickets are $15.

title: TANGSTAD SEEKS ACCEPTANCE
description: When Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, first heard that his opponent here this Saturday would be Steffen Tangstad, he asked a simple question:

title: Hot Hotel Competition
description: Now that the Park Hyatt Hotel has opened at the northeast corner of 24th and M Streets N.W., the hospitality war in Washington's West End can be considered officially on. The Westin Hotel, it should be explained, opened on the northwest corner of the intersection a few months ago, preceded a year earlier by the Grand Hotel (originally the Regent) on the southeast corner.

title: HUDSON VALLEY HARVEST
description: A Harvest Festival, a Polish Festival and a host of farm stands offering raspberries, peaches, early apples, pears, tomatoes and sweet corn await visitors to the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: Weather Update
description: Weather Update, the 80's version of the seminal jazz fusion band Weather Report, will perform at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street) this evening on a double bill with the Mahavishnu Orchestra, featuring John McLaughlin.

title: L.S.U. Football Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has placed the Louisiana State University football program on one year's probation for recruiting violations. But L.S.U. will not be forced to sit out any bowl games, lose television revenue or forfeit scholarships, Chancellor James Wharton said today.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on sale of businesses of $2,425,000 and $26,365,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary tax benefits of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $8,603,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax benefits relating to utilization of loss carryforwards of $68,000 for the quarter and $954,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: SPECIAL PRE-SUMMIT U.S.-SOVIET ARMS CONSULTATIONS RESUME TODAY
description: American officials said today that they hoped the Soviet Union would respond to President Reagan's arms control proposals in a meeting opening Friday.

title: Palmer, Littler Help U.S. Lead
description: Arnold Palmer teamed with Gene Littler today to beat the international team of Gary Player and Bob Charles, 1-up, and help the United States take a 10-6 lead after the opening round of the Chrysler Cup.

title: Some Caution On Tandem
description: DESPITE a generally hostile environment for technology issues, Tandem Computers Inc. has emerged as a major success over the past year. The stock has performed so handsomely, in fact, that some analysts lately have taken a more cautious view of its prospects, simply on a price basis.

title: Contract for Polynice
description: Olden Polynice, who lost his scholarship at Virginia following a conviction for shoplifting, has signed a one-year contract to play for Rimini of the Italian League.

title: ALLIED STORES RECEIVES $2.4 BILLION CANADIAN BID
description: The Campeau Corporation, a Canadian real estate developer, offered yesterday to buy the Allied Stores Corporation, one of the largest American retailers, which owns such well-known stores as Bonwit Teller, Brooks Brothers, Ann Taylor, Jordan Marsh and Garfinckel's, among others.

title: An Exercise For the Heart
description: Running may not be so lonely a pursuit as the cliche cracks it up to be, but when their day's jog is done, even those who get winded after a couple of solitary laps around the reservoir can find themselves panting for some compatible companionship.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OPERATION GARBO: The Personal Story of the Most Successful Double Agent of World War II. By Juan Pujol with Nigel West. 205 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $17.95. DURING World War II, British intelligence set up a body known as the Twenty Committee to coordinate its use of double agents. (''Twenty'' was a little joke - in Roman numerals it is XX, a double cross.) In 1972 the former chairman of the committee, Sir John Masterman, published a history of the double-cross system in which he singled out for special praise the work of the agent known as Garbo, and since then other accounts of deception during the war have confirmed Garbo's importance. But until 1984 his identity remained a closely guarded secret.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Have no fear, ladies and gentlemen, I am used to being regarded as an anachronism.'' - Prince Charles. [ A1:6. ]

title: JOHN MAY DELAY RETIREMENT
description: Tommy John's season ended Wednesday morning on a pitcher's mound in Oakland, but today he left open the possibility that he might return to the Yankees for at least one more year.

title: THE SCREEN: 'HEIMAT,' AN EPIC ON GERMAN LIFE
description: ''Heimat'' was shown as part of the 1985 New Directors/New Films Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times April 6, 1985. The film opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Avenue, and will be shown over four weekends. EDGAR REITZ'S ''HEIMAT'' is a cinematic event, if not quite a masterpiece. It's a massive, nearly 16-hour chronicle of life in Germany, from 1919 to 1982, as reflected in the fluctuating fortunes of the members of one family, initially peasant-farmers, in the fictitious village of Schabbach in the Rhineland. As literature, ''Heimat'' bears the same relationship to Rainer Werner Fassbinder's magnificent, equally long adaptation of Alfred Doblin's ''Berlin Alexanderplatz'' that Herman Wouk's ''Winds of War'' bears to Thomas Mann's ''Buddenbrooks.''

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REAGAN EXTENDING LIMITED SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan today extended for one year a series of limited sanctions against South Africa and held out the possibility of further moves aimed at its Government.

title: REAGANS PLAN SPEECH TO START CAMPAIGN BY ADMINISTRATION AGAINST DRUGS
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will make a nationally broadcast address against the use of illegal drugs, the White House announced today.

title: JORDAN SINGS WITH DIRECT, DEEP FEELING
description: SHEILA JORDAN sings, more often than not, with her eyes closed, projecting an intense concentration. Many jazz vocalists arrive at their own interpretation of a tune and then repeat that interpretation night after night, with minimal variation. Miss Jordan gives the impression that she is feeling her way into a tune as if it were brand new, exploring it with a sense of wonder and a probing curiosity, even if she's been singing it for years. And the urbane, slightly detached ironies that many jazz vocalists bring to their interpretations have no place in Miss Jordan's musical world. Her interpretations of a song are always deeply felt; she communicates emotion directly, with a commitment that genuinely merits the overused adjective ''soulful.''

title: How Dry I Am
description: Bob Stanley, the Boston reliever who hadn't won a game since June 30, when asked after getting his 100th victory Wednesday night whether he had any champagne on ice in the clubhouse: ''Yeah, but it's frozen.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 16 HOURS OF GERMAN HISTORY ''Heimat,'' directed by Edgar Reitz, is a gargantuan film epic examining the course of German history from 1919 to 1982 as reflected in the life of one family. Divided into four manageable installments, the 16-hour ''Heimat'' will be shown over four weekends at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street (review on page C18). Part I, devoted to the years between 1919 and 1933, will be shown today, tomorrow, and Sunday at 3:30 P.M. Series tickets are available at $15 for the four Fridays; $20 for four Saturdays or Sundays. Individual admission is $6; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 598-7150 after 1 P.M.; for a recorded film schedule, the number is 598-7171. BERNSTEIN PLUS 3

title: A LOOK AT A TURBULENT ERA IN CHINESE ART
description: NO period of Chinese art speaks to us with more urgency than the 17th century. It was a century of profound instability and upheaval - much of it triggered by the Manchu conquest in 1644, which brought a sudden end to the 300-year Ming Dynasty. There was a sustained tension between tradition and innovation, style and nature, self-consciousness and expressive freedom that fueled the creative imagination, but also left Chinese art divided and exhausted.

title: Yamani Scans Oil Price Future
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, predicted today that oil prices between now and 1992 would average about $18 a barrel, an increase in price that he said was crucial if world markets are to reach ''equilibrium in the long term.''

title: BECKER REACHES SEMIFINAL
description: It wasn't until the crowd began booing that Boris Becker let his mind wander for the first time during last night's match. He had been too preoccupied with Milan Srejber, the 6-foot-8-inch Czechoslovak who was standing in the doorway leading to the semifinals of the United States Open, to notice that the fans thought Srejber was actually trying to step aside - in effect saying, ''After you, Boris.''

title: ALEXANDER'S PLANS $150 MILLION MALL FOR REGO PARK
description: The Alexander's department store chain announced yesterday the details of a $150 million indoor shopping mall it is seeking to build at the site of its existing store in a bustling commercial area of Rego Park, Queens.

title: JAPAN WARNS SOUTH AFRICA IT MAY ADOPT NEW SANTIONS
description: The Japanese Government warned South Africa today that it might impose new punitive sanctions unless Pretoria moved quickly to change its apartheid policies.

title: AUCTIONS
description: CHARLES W. GASQUE lived as a boy near the railroad tracks in Marion, S.C., and later would recall the excitement he felt every time the Raleigh and Charleston roared through that quiet town. He saved his toy trains and when he was in his 30's, and a personnel manager of a bank, those memories caught up with him and he purchased a Washington collector's mammoth holdings of 10,000 pieces. That collection, acquired in the late 1950's, was edited down and then substantially enlarged by Mr. Gasque in purchases made until shortly before his death in Columbia, S.C., last April. The 4,000 toy trains he owned will be sold at Christie's East, 219 East 67th Street, on Nov. 8 and 9.

title: CITY AGAIN BOASTS A SCIENCE MUSEUM
description: New York City has a science museum again, and although it takes 40 minutes to reach the new New York Hall of Science from midtown Manhattan, a traveler is amply rewarded for the inconvenience.

title: WAGNER PRAISES BOARD'S CHANGE ON AUDIT POLICY
description: The Board of Education's decision to allow state and city audits of its programs might reveal some inefficiency and some failures, the board's president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: No Border in Berlin
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE RACE IN NEVADA IS SEEN AS CLOSE AND VITAL
description: The political stakes are high in Nevada this fall. The state's tiny electorate, a mere 375,000 voters, could decide not only who controls the United States Senate for the next two years but also whether Senator Paul Laxalt, who has long been Nevada's most powerful politician, pursues his Presidential ambitions in 1988.

title: People
description: * Valentine Appel has joined Ted Bates/New York as senior vice president and research director.

title: Trump Stake In Holiday
description: The Holiday Corporation, operator of the Holiday Inn chain, said that Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer, had acquired between 2 percent and 5 percent of the company's stock.

title: Walls Stages Boycott
description: Everson Walls, a cornerback with the Dallas Cowboys, walked out of camp yesterday and said he would boycott Monday night's opener against the Giants unless his contract demands were met. Walls said he would not return until the Cowboys fulfilled a 1983 promise to renegotiate the 1986 and 1987 years of his existing five-year contract if he met specified performance goals.

title: The Goose: Country Hardball
description: If Rich Gossage were not a living, breathing, fireball-slinging, blunt-talking real person, his friend and idol, Willie Nelson, would have invented him, right down to the thick, droopy mustache.

title: Resignation is Delayed
description: Donald I. Hovde, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that he was remaining in his post past the Aug. 31 resignation date he had set earlier. He said he would remain on the board until a successor was chosen by the White House and seated on the board.

title: Glaxo Subsidiary Gets New President
description: Dr. Ernest Mario has been named president and chief operating officer of Glaxo Inc., a North Carolina pharmaceutical company that is the largest subsidiary of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. in London.

title: DANCE: FOLK ENSEMBLE, THE MOISEYEV TROUPE
description: NOT to worry, Mayor Koch assured last night's audience at the start of the rescheduled opening performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company, ''You are each sitting between two police officers.''

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased by $95.2 million, to $233.24 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: RIGHTS LEADERS SAY SENATE COULD REJECT REHNQUIST
description: The nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to become Chief Justice of the United States can be stopped on the Senate floor next week despite predictions of confirmation, civil rights leaders said today.

title: Tax Bill Could Die With Vote On Rule
description: Sometimes the final vote is not the most important vote on Capitol Hill.

title: BOOK TELLS OF U.S. DATA ON DOWNING OF KOREAN JET
description: The Soviet Union shot down a South Korean airliner at a time when American intelligence had a vast array of listening devices directed at that area of East Asia, including installations in Japan unknown to the Japanese Government, according to a new book.

title: MAN TELLS THE POLICE HE MURDERED FAMILY AFTER TAKING CRACK
description: A Bridgeport, Conn., man walked into the city's police headquarters yesterday and told detectives he had murdered the woman with whom he was living and her two children after using the drug crack, the Bridgeport police said.

title: NAVY SAYS PRODUCTION FLAWS ARE DELAYING MISSILE
description: Deployment of the Navy's most advanced missile for aerial combat is being delayed by persistent production difficulties, Navy officials said Wednesday.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Tribute to Tuggle
description: When Rob Carpenter played fullback for the Giants, he wore No. 26.

title: BLACKS IN SOWETO TRY TO DEFY CURB ON A MASS FUNERAL
description: The black township of Soweto was seized by chaos and violence today as thousands of militant blacks sought to defy a Government curb on a mass funeral for blacks killed in clashes last week.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: J. PATRICK BARRETT'S business card gives his office address as Garden City, L.I. But for the past two weeks, Mr. Barrett, who is chairman and chief executive officer of Avis Inc., has relocated to the United States Open where he has traded his pin stripes for a natty blue blazer and the title of Perle Mesta of the tennis tournament.

title: The McCarran-Walter Mischief
description: The McCarran-Walter Act, passed in 1952, is a mischievous vestige of the McCarthy era that each year bars dozens of controversial foreigners from visiting the United States. The especially embarrassing case of Choichiro Yatani makes clearer than ever the need to overhaul the law.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1986
description: Markets

title: NEW POLITICS EMERGING OUT OF DEMOGRAPHIC CHANGES
description: Republicans say the rapid demographic changes since Ronald Reagan was elected six years ago are working mostly in their favor.

title: FERRY'S SET TO SWING
description: The Staten Island Ferry, the venerable New York attraction and commuter workhorse that provides one of the city's most scenic rides, will metamorphose into a floating entertainment hall, starting today.

title: Dow Confirms Sale Of Rorer Stake
description: The Dow Chemical Company confirmed that it had sold 2 million common shares of the Rorer Group Inc., a 9.4 percent stake, to Steinhardt Partners, a New York investment concern, and its affiliates for $39.50 a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dow also disclosed the details of an agreement with Steinhardt concerning the possibility of a takeover of Rorer.

title: A Son but No Contract
description: The contract Dan Marino was supposed to sign to make him the richest player in the National Football League has been put on hold. Marino did not attend practice yesterday because he was with his wife, Claire, who gave birth to their first child.

title: Borrowed Time
description: There has been a change in the assessment of world economic prospects, clearly reflected in an Aspen Institute conference here. Participants were a high-level group, from government and business in a wide range of countries. Their outlook was so gloomy that some American Democrats wondered out loud why candidates in their party were trying so hard to take over responsibility for the Reagan legacy. Remarkably, there was almost complete consensus on what is wrong and what should be done about it - so, little new on diagnosis and prescription.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: SEPT. 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MARTIN MAY START AT DALLAS
description: Of the Giants' left ends on defense, George Martin is 6 feet 4 inches and 250 pounds and Eric Dorsey is 6-5 and 280. The Dallas Cowboys who will be blocking them Monday night are 6-3 and 293 (Crawford Ker at guard) and 6-5 and 274 (Jim Cooper at tackle).

title: U.S. AIDE ASSAILS TV SERIES ON AFRICA
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, Lynne V. Cheney, has criticized a new public television series on Africa that received Federal money on the ground that it is anti-Western and lacks balance, which the endowment's guidelines require.

title: Ted Bates Gets New President
description: Ted Bates Worldwide Inc., which last month was acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi of London to form the world's largest advertising agency, said yesterday that its vice chairman, John Hoyne, would succeed Robert E. Jacoby as president and assume the new position of chief operating officer. Mr. Jacoby, who is 58 years old, remains chairman and chief executive. The promotion of Mr. Hoyne, 48, makes him the heir apparent to Mr. Jacoby, industry analysts said.

title: Israeli Test Flight Is Off
description: The maiden test flight of the Israeli Lavi warplane will be postponed for an undetermined period because of late delivery of a crucial part by an American subcontracter, according to a senior Israeli military source. The flight had been planned for late September.

title: Skipper Rescued As Yacht Sinks
description: One of 25 sailboats competing in the BOC Challenge, the singlehanded yacht race around the world, was reported sinking early today after hitting a submerged object in the water 131 miles northeast of Bermuda.

title: Fitch Joint Venture On Korean Ratings
description: Fitch Investors Service, one of five rating agencies recognized by the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday announced a joint venture with Korea Business Research and Information Inc. to expand the Korean concern's ratings of securities issued by local companies in domestic and foreign markets.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Helena Sukova vs. Chris Evert Lloyd. Second Match - Andres Gomez-Slobodan Zivojinovic vs.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Tommy Flanagan, Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). Tommy Flanagan has quietly managed to be sitting at the piano when earthshaking jazz albums were recorded for the last three decades or so. He was with John Coltrane for ''Giant Steps'' and with Sonny Rollins for ''Saxophone Colossus,'' and from there the list just gets longer and longer. Lately he has become one of the outstanding interpreters of Thelonious Monk's music. He is getting sterling support at Whippoorwill from George Mraz and Al Foster. There are three sets nightly through Sunday, beginning around 10. There is no cover charge or minimum for patrons who have dinner, which is served beginning at 8 P.M.

title: SCREEN: '90 DAYS,' CANADIAN COMEDY
description: THE usual boy-meets-girl niceties are replaced, in the earnest Canadian comedy ''90 Days,'' by one plot about a sperm donor and another, parallel story about a mail-order bride. Both these tales take place at the far end of the courtship spectrum, where connection between the sexes can be achieved in the most impersonal ways. From this, the director, Giles Walker, appears to have worked backward. After fastening on his subject, Mr. Walker, who also co-wrote the film with David Wilson, has constructed the loosest of storylines, created two mild-mannered male protagonists and given each a problem with which to grapple. He has then cast nonprofessional actors in the roles and let them improvise their way home.

title: HARVARD, 350, GETS PRINCE'S WARNING AND JESTS
description: With pomp and wit and an eloquent speech by the Prince of Wales, Harvard University formally began its 350th anniversary celebration today on the grounds where the first American college students met more than three centuries ago.

title: INMAN TO RESIGN AT M.C.C.
description: Bobby R. Inman, the former intelligence agency chief who created the Microelectronics and Computer Technolology Corporation to do battle with Japan's electronics giants, will resign as head of the consortium at the end of the year, the company said today. Confirming industry rumors, the Austin, Tex., consortium, popularly known as M.C.C., said Admiral Inman told the venture's board of directors today that ''he does not intend to renew his contract as chief executive'' when it expires in December. No successor has been selected, and Admiral Inman has not yet decided what he will do next, according to William Stokesbury, a spokesman for M.C.C.

title: Workers in California Strike 2 More Wineries
description: Workers struck two more wineries today and threatened to shut down California's $5.5 billion wine industry after rejecting the latest employer proposal.

title: Quentin Crisp Show
description: The actor and raconteur Quentin Crisp will appear tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

title: WEEDEND FREE FOR ALL THROUGHOUT THE CITY
description: THINK of it: New York on no dollars a day. Watch brave Irishmen collide in a Gaelic football match, or watch the even braver ones eat Irish blood pudding. Hear ''the 60-second novelist'' pound out a story in one minute. Taste a chunk of a 12-foot pizza with ''I Love New York'' emblazoned in peppers, mozzarella and pepperoni. And all scot-free.

title: Two in the 50's, East and West.
description: BRIVE is the sort of eccentric restaurant that evokes pro and con reactions popping with exclamation marks, like abstract art. This softly upholstered new dining room in a town house on East 58th Street is the domain of Robert Pritsker, who operated the nouvelle-cuisine Doudin-Bouffant in the same spot between 1979 and 1982. While Mr. Pritsker has moved from the kitchen to the dining room, the food turned out by his crew still reflects his devotion to quality ingredients leavened with a puckish attitude about haute cuisine. If you can get over Brive's relentless case of the cutes on the menu, some arresting food is to be had.

title: 'ZONE' IS WINNING TERRITORY
description: Studies by sports psychologists and close students of tennis are taking much of the mystery out of why Ivan Lendl or Boris Becker or the world's other great players always seem to win the big points.

title: Cutty's Bid To Leave Last Place
description: CUTTY SARK has fired the first shot in what soon may be called the Scotch Whisky wars. Battle lines have been drawn from New Jersey to Maine.

title: Musical Comedy
description: Gotham, the musical-comedy trio, is performing the revue ''There's No Business in Show Business'' at Backstage at Hisae's Cabaret (318 West 45th Street) this evening at 11 o'clock. There is a $10 cover. Reservations: 489-6356.

title: Ford Plans to Shut Ohio Forge Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would begin closing its forge plant in Canton, Ohio, shutting it for good by late 1989 or early 1990. The company said it would begin helping the 826 hourly and 158 salaried employees find new jobs and that about 250 of them would be idled over the next six months.

title: CONDOMINIUMS IN PARK AVENUE VICINITY
description: ''We do not have a view to sell,'' said Renata Coleman of the Claremont House, a new apartment house at 52 East 72d Street, between Park and Madison Avenues. ''We have the quality, the address, but we don't have the view.''

title: Sid Tanenbaum Killed
description: Sid Tanenbaum, who played basketball for New York University and the Knicks in the 1940's, was stabbed to death in Queens. Page A20.

title: Dr. Armin C. Braun, 74, Dies; Researched Cancer in Plants
description: Armin C. Braun, a plant biologist and a leading researcher on plant cancers, died of a lung infection Tuesday in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. SAN DIEGO PADRES, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Fed Inactive On Dollar
description: Foreign central banks intervened to slow the decline of the dollar by making sizable purchases of the currency between May and the end of July, but the Federal Reserve Bank stayed out of the currency markets, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. The dollar fell 9 percent against the yen and the Swiss franc and 5 percent against the mark and other currencies in the European Monetary System during those months, according to the bank's quarterly report. It remained stable against the Canadian dollar and rose 3 percent against the pound.

title: QADDAFI CALLS THIRD WORLD HELPLESS
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, told other leaders of the Nonaligned Movement here today that they had proved helpless against the West. He raised the possibility that Libya might leave the organization.

title: DOW SOARS 38.38 POINTS, TO 1,919.71
description: Oil and technology stocks came to life yesterday, spurring the Dow Jones industrial average to a record close, and producing the strongest trading volume in six months. With its oil components having a particularly strong influence, the Dow rose 38.38 points, to 1,919.71, coasting past the 1,909.03 record set on July 2.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Consumer Saturday column of the Style page on Aug. 23 misstated the Federal Government's position on the installation of automobile front-seat belts. If states do not require them, the Department of Transportation could require auto manufacturers to install air bags or similar restraints. States would not, however, face a loss of Federal highway funds.

title: 3 FRENCH SOLDIERS KILLED IN LEBANON
description: Three French soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon were killed today in the explosion of a roadside bomb, a spokesman for the force announced.

title: Jewish Groups Support South Africa Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: AVANG-GARDE ANTICS FOR THE ADVENTUROUS
description: AS the city's fall season in the performing arts gets under way, there is a sense within the avant-garde community that the climate has never been more hospitable toward experimental work that asks hard questions about art and society.

title: The Earl of Air
Kodak to Delay Electronic Camera
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said that it would delay introduction of an electronic still camera for consumers until it felt the market was ready. The announcement comes after the recent introduction of several still consumer cameras at Photokina, the international photographic show, in Cologne, West Germany.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about Pee-wee Herman's new television series on CBS misidentified a co-producer. It is Broadcast Arts, not Broadcast Video.

title: FROM UTAH TO NEW GUINEA, A LESSON IN TRANSITION
description: A couple of years ago, Eva and Lee Robertson could have spent a comfortable evening at home in their four-bedroom, three-bath, air-conditioned ranch house in Springville, Utah.

title: Regents Exams Should Be Given Only in English, True or False?
description: To the Editor:

title: RUTGERS FOOTBALL IS PROGRESSING SLOWLY
description: Given the rate of recent visible progress, it may take Rutgers until the 21st century to achieve its goal in football: a major team that fills stadiums and accepts bowl bids.

title: Pitcher Loses Suit
description: Score another one for the Chicken. A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Don Schulze, the Cleveland Indians pitcher, is not entitled to damages for injuries he said he suffered in a collision with the entertainer portrayed by Ted Giannoulas that was formerly known as the San Diego Chicken.

title: Polish Church Drops Plan for Farm Fund
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Church has abandoned its four-year campaign to raise a fund of dollars to aid private farmers, citing Government efforts to dominate the project.

title: AUG. 21-31 AUTO SALES OFF 12%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles, largely unaffected by the latest interest rate incentives, fell 12 percent in the August 21-31 period from record-breaking sales at that time last year, the major auto companies reported today.

title: AQUINO ASSERTS SHE WON'T BOW TO U.S. PRESSURE
description: President Corazon C. Aquino, defending her approach to combating the Communist insurgency in the Philippines, said today that she would not submit to the sort of pressure from Washington on this and other issues that she said her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos, had been subjected to.

title: 'ASYLUM' MYSTERY AT CAPITOL BEGINS WITH A FAMILY PLEA
description: A family of 11 Rumanians made what appeared to be a dramatic appeal for ''political asylum'' today at the United States Capitol.

title: Regents Exams Should Be Given Only in English, True or False?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 IN LEVINE CASE PLEAD GUILTY
description: Two 32-year-old former investment bankers from top Wall Street firms pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal felony charges for illegally providing stolen inside information about pending takeovers or buyouts to Dennis B. Levine.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allied Security Inc., Pittsburgh, has named its chief operating officer, Steven B. Stein, to the added post of president, succeeding Neal H. Holmes, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: THEATER: ALL-MALE, JAPANESE 'MEDEA'
description: THE Toho Company production of ''Medea'' is an evening of primal theater, an interweaving of Eastern and Western performance techniques cohering in a cross-cultural version of a seminal work of Greek tragedy. Deeply influenced by Kabuki and Noh theater, the production acts to transform Euripides into a Japanese classic. As directed by Yukio Ninagawa, the work is related to the films that Akira Kurosawa has made from Shakespeare; it is true in spirit to the source and rich with its own demonic Oriental character.

title: Rehnquist Vs. Rights
description: William H. Rehnquist, a man of undoubted scholarly attainment, has been a Supreme Court Justice since 1971. No one has produced hard enough evidence of unsavory past activities to prevent his confirmation as Chief Justice.

title: Employment Data Day: One Figure Is the Same
description: The nation's unemployment rate swings up and down, but one thing about the official Government report does not change: Janet L. Norwood will be on the job the first Friday of every month to explain it to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: 100 Are Detained in Chile As a Protest Strike Starts
description: A 21-year-old man was killed in the seaside town of Vina del Mar today, and about 100 demonstrators were arrested in Santiago on the first day of a two-day work stoppage called by the Communist Party and other leftist groups.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 5,1986
description: International Blacks in Soweto clashed with security forces in the township as militants sought to defy a Government curb on a mass funeral for blacks killed in clashes last week. Sources said several of the victims had been buried in separate and sometimes abrupt ceremonies. All attempts at a mass burial were reported broken up. [ A1:6. ]

title: FITZGERALD HAS SURGERY
description: Ella Fitzgerald has undergone open-heart surgery and is making ''good progress'' in her recovery, a spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center said today.

title: Philip Siegel Is Dead at 85; Owner of Belmore Cafeteria
description: Philip Siegel, who owned the Belmore Cafeteria in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cutting Off Noses in Zimbabwe
description: A chain of events begun by the rudeness of a Cabinet minister in Zimbabwe has now brought the Reagan Administration to a decision that threatens long-term damage to American interests.

title: Daniloff Testified in '78 Against Spying Efforts
description: The American journalist being detained in Moscow on spying charges told Congress in 1978 that he opposed Government efforts to use journalists for espionage.

title: Archives Nominee Transcends Party Labels
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,756,000 on the sale of businesses for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest quarter net reflects a special charge of $17 million to operating earnings for a settlement related to the U.S. Government's action against the Special Devices division of Clifton Precision.

title: SOVIET SEIZES SHIP CAPTAINS OVER SINKING
description: The captains of a Soviet passenger liner and a freighter that collided in the Black Sea on Sunday night, killing nearly 400 people, have been arrested, a Soviet official said today.

title: MOTORIST SKIRTS CLOSED GATES AND DIES WHEN HIT BY TRAIN
description: A 25-year-old Freeport, L.I., man was killed last evening when he drove his car around closed gates at a railroad crossing in New Cassell, L.I., and collided with an oncoming 12-car passsenger train, the police said.

title: Beethoven Festival In Oyster Bay, L.I.
description: Friends of the Arts will present a Beethoven festival this weekend at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. Tonight at 8, Peter Serkin will play the composer's Sonatas (Op. 79 and 81a) and the Diabelli Variations (Op. 120).

title: Iran Is Reported to Free Soviet Ship After Search
description: Iran released a Soviet freighter today after forcing it to an Iranian port and searching it for goods that might aid Iraq's war effort, shipping executives said.

title: No Certainty On Inflation
description: BOND prices have been falling as a result of anxieties about a resurgence of inflation.

title: Justice Department Rejects Appeal for Rehnquist Inquiry
description: The Justice Department has rejected a request by four Democratic senators for a renewed investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into allegations that Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court mishandled a trust fund for his disabled brother-in-law.

title: NEBRASKA SUSPENSIONS PUT OFF
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday granted Nebraska a five-day postponement of its order that the Cornhuskers suspend 53 football players for one game and seven more for two games. The postponement will allow Nebraska to open its season tomorrow night against Florida State in Lincoln, Neb., with a full complement of 100 to 105 suited players.

title: GOTTI INFORMER SAYS HE WAS MAFIA 'HIT MAN'
description: The organized-crime ''soldier'' who broke the Gambino family's code of silence to become a government informer was an admitted ''hit man'' for the mob, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: FOR SCARSDALE TEACHER, NEW TERM'S A FRESH CHALLENGE
description: Even after 24 years, and 24 opening days, Eric Rothschild still slept fitfully the night before. By 5:30 A.M. today, he was wide awake and getting dressed in his light blue suit. Over the morning newspaper, he had his usual breakfast, a bowl of Grape Nuts and raisins and a cup of decaffeinated coffee.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 9
description: b-After tax credits of $333,000 for the quarter and $723,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $223,000 for the quarter and $718,000 for the 6 months.

title: Webster Streak End
description: Mike Webster, the Steelers' center, who suffered a hyperextended left elbow in last week's preseason loss to the Giants, has been placed on the injured-reserve list and will miss the next four games, starting with Sunday's opener in Seattle, ending his consecutive-games streak at 177. Dan Turk, a second-year player out of Wisconsin, will start instead of Webster, the center for 12 seasons.

title: G.E. Credit Plans A Write-Down
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation said that it would take a $50 million charge on third-quarter earnings for a write-down on repossessed oil drilling equipment.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL RIMINI (Italian League) - Signed Olden Polynice, center. COLLEGES

title: TUTU'S TITLE IS NOW ARCHBISHOP
description: Desmond M. Tutu has formally become the Archbishop of Cape Town, head of the Anglican Church in southern Africa, in a brief, private ceremony at St. George's Cathedral.

title: RAPE AND MURDER SCAR INNOCENCE OF POTSDAM
description: Until a few days ago, this bucolic college town, close to the Canadian border and far from almost everywhere else, enjoyed a kind of innocence.

title: DR. HERBERT D. WELTE
description: Dr. Herbert D. Welte, former president of what is now Central Connecticut State University, died Tuesday at his home in Simsbury, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: Addenda
description: * A new direct marketing agency, Shain Colavito Direct, has opened in New York.

title: Lionel Hampton on the Run
description: Lionel Hampton is 75 years old and yesterday, smiling with enthusiasm and as eager as ever, he said, ''I like to be on the run and play everywhere.''

title: Civil War, Sherman and 1980's love.
description: WHEN Ross McElwee set out to film ''Sherman's March,'' he planned to make a documentary about the present-day repercussions of the Civil War in the South - particularly the damage and devastation of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman's march to the sea. But the film maker was abandoned by his girlfriend shortly before he was to begin and, feeling damaged and devastated himself, he returned to his home in North Carolina to sort things out. When he picked up his camera again, he aimed it at himself - and his personal quest for love. His film, a picaresque journey in search of what he calls ''a romantic relationship - one that lasts more than two weeks,'' presents portraits of the Southern women Mr. McElwee met in four continuous months of shooting and his wryly noted, ill-fated relationships with all of them. The movie opens today (review on page C12).

title: F.D.I.C. PLANS PAYMENT IN GOLDEN PACIFIC CASE
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that it would make a partial payment - 65 cents on the dollar - to holders of high-yield savings accounts, known as ''yellow certificates,'' from the failed Golden Pacific National Bank in Chinatown.

title: MUSEUM'S DESIGN IS BASED ON PROMISING CONCEPT
description: Museums are always sensitive design problems for architects. But a museum of Jewish heritage that includes a memorial to the Holocaust carries a special weight.

title: Treasury Rates Up a Bit More
description: Treasury note and bond yields rose for the third consecutive day, but the size of the increase was much less than the previous two days.

title: CHARLES ON USES OF SCIENCE
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Prince Charles of Britain at the Harvard convocation yesterday:

title: JUDGE ON U.S. COURT FOR 45 YEARS
description: Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr., a profound legal thinker who served on the Federal District Court in Massachusetts for 45 years and formerly headed Harvard University's Board of Overseers, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 80 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Share Offerings By Global Growth
description: Global Growth and Income Fund Inc., a closed-end, dual-purpose investment company, is offering five million capital shares and five million income shares, both at $10 a share, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: NASA CUTTING WORK FORCE AT SPACE CENTER IN FLORIDA
description: The space agency today announced a new round of layoffs at this sprawling center, where major activity in past months has come to a virtual halt because of the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger Jan. 28.

title: U.S. Seeks Talks On Imported Steel
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that he had requested immediate consultations with Canada, Sweden and Taiwan to remedy what he said were steel import surges that could not be permitted to continue.

title: CANDIDATES RULED OFF PRIMARY BALLOT
description: A Federal appeals court issued a series of brief rulings yesterday preventing several candidates from running in the Democratic primary election in New York next Tuesday.

title: AGENCY RETHINKS COLLECTION PLAN
description: The Farmers Home Administration said today that it was reviewing a decision to hire private collection agencies to recoup some of the $630 million in delinquent loans owed by 6,500 borrowers.

title: Tight Formation
description: Ever since Grantland Rice was spurred to poetic hyperbole after watching Knute Rockne's Four Horsemen trample Army at the Polo Grounds in 1924, Notre Dame football has proved a magnetic attraction for the nation's peripatetic press corps. To accommodate the hordes of writers, photographers, broadcasters, technicians and assorted hangers-on who gravitate to South Bend each fall, the three-level press box at Notre Dame Stadium is one of the nation's largest, with room, though not necessarily elbow room, for close to 500 people.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a television review of the ABC program ''At a Loss for Words: Illiterate in America'' misidentified the university where an adult literacy class was conducted. It was Pennsylvania State, at the Beaver County campus.

title: Salming Suspended
description: The National Hockey League has suspended Borje Salming, a Toronto Maple Leafs defenseman, for eight regular-season games and fined $500 because he used cocaine several years ago, the league announced yesterday.

title: A New G.M.A.C. Entry Into Eurobond Market
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is turning to Salomon Brothers Inc. to distribute its first offering in the Eurobond market of securities backed by auto-loan receivables. Previous domestic offerings of similar securities by G.M.A.C., totaling about $3.8 billion, were made through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Continental Reduces Fares
description: In an effort to increase ridership, Continental Airlines sharply reduced ticket prices yesterday on many routes, including a $99, one-way transcontinental fare on flights booked 30 days in advance. American Airlines, United

title: KELLY TO POSE TEST FOR JET SECONDARY
description: Beginning with the release of Bobby Jackson, the veteran cornerback, this summer, the Jets' secondary has gone through a a series of transitions through the preseason. And as the Jets prepare for the season opener, Sunday at Buffalo, the secondary -Russell Carter and Kerry Glenn at the corners, Johnny Lynn and Harry Hamilton at safety - is being cast as the weak link on the defense.

title: KEY RATES
Ziegfeld Memories
description: In another time, they danced for Florenz Ziegfeld. In recent years, they were co-presidents of the Ziegfeld Club. On a Friday evening not long ago, the two women stood arm in arm in the club's office on Park Avenue and 64th Street.

title: Texas Lawmakers to Get 2d Chance to Fix Deficit
description: State legislators, unable to balance the budget in a 30-day special session that ended today, will get another chance beginning Monday when a new special session starts.

title: Diplomatic Switch
description: In normal diplomatic protocol, heads of state who come to Washington and are entertained by the President respond by inviting him to lunch or dinner a few days later, often at the country's embassy here or in a larger place like a hotel ballroom, under the auspices of the embassy. Such exchanges of festivities are planned well in advance.

title: Mondale to the Fore
description: Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President and 1984 Democratic candidate for President, is resuming a more active role in public affairs. Today the former Senator from Minnesota will be named chairman of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs. He is expected to play an active personal role in the organization's efforts to foster democratic parties and systems of government around the world.

title: Violin-Piano Duo
description: The violinist Elliot Rosoff and the pianist James Gemmell will present a program of works by Leclair, Beethoven, Saint-Saens and Karen Khachaturian at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday afternoon at 3. Tickets are $8. Information: 362-8719.

title: POLICEMAN ARRESTED
description: An off-duty transit police officer shot a Brooklyn man early yesterday in the East Village after a confrontation with the man and his two companions in which racial slurs were exchanged, authorities said.

title: IN CRASH'S WAKE, A NEW TEST FOR PILOTS' LOBBY
description: ''We're still carrying the image of guys in baseball caps, called 'Ace,' who bore holes in the sky around airports,'' lamented John L. Baker, president of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, the major lobbying organization for private pilots and the $20 billion-a-year noncommercial aviation industry.

title: Article 707686 -- No Title
description: The Federal budget deficit will be at least $4 billion higher in the fiscal year 1987 than the official Government estimate of $163.4 billion released last month, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Adopting a Neighborhood
description: For a group of New Yorkers who just spent two months with hundreds of deprived children in Israel, this was a summer of giving.

title: Ex-Senator Gets Transplant
description: Former Senator Paul Tsongas was in good condition and ''excellent spirits'' today after undergoing a bone marrow transplant in his battle with cancer, officials at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute said. Mr. Tsongas, 45 years old, a Democrat from Massachusetts who left the Senate in 1984 after learning he had non-Hodgkins lymphoma, will be confined to an isolation room for at least two more weeks, the hospital said.

title: Arms Control Is in President Reagan's Power; In a Cold War Rut
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Deficits: A Global Failure
description: America's trade deficit set another record in July, dashing hopes of a quick turnaround based on the depreciated dollar. Big deficits don't spell doom - foreign creditors aren't about to foreclose on the Liberty Bell. But chronic deficits are a symptom of serious imbalance, created by the failure of the economic powers to resolve conflicts on growth, agriculture and third-world debt. The longer America, Japan and Western Europe act as if each can go it alone, the greater the risk to economic stability.

title: The Simplest Way to Fight Drugs
description: What do the traffickers themselves think of all this drug hysteria -President Reagan's urinalysis, the first blockade of New York harbor since the War of 1812, proposals to seal the Mexican border with a 2,000-mile cocaine curtain? In a fortified mansion in Bangkok, in a Mexico City prison, in homes, hotel rooms and restaurants on four continents, I have spoken to a few of the men who run the international narcotics industry, and I am certain their reaction to the war on drugs is the same today as when I met them. They are laughing. With each desperate new response to the drug dilemma, we move further and further from the real solution, and give the narcotics tycoons every reason to celebrate.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
E.P.A. PLANS NEW CURB ON RADIOACTIVE WATER
description: Naturally occurring radioactivity in drinking water poses a serious health threat around the country and requires stricter regulation, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Drugs After Cancer Surgery
description: Giving breast-cancer patients drug treatments after surgery postpones cancer relapses and prolongs their survival, according to a study.

title: Chiat Day Gets Arrow Account
description: The Arrow Company, the Cluett-Peabody subsidiary, has moved more than $4 million in billings from AC&R, New York, to Chiat Day.

title: DETOUR FOR DOUBLES PRODIGIES
description: Ask any doubles player to list the most critical components of a succesful doubles team and such elements as the second serve, return of serve and quickness at the net will all be noted, but perhaps the single most important factor is communication.

title: Leave Fair Hiring Rules Alone
description: Welcome the Reagan Administration's postponement of any changes in the affirmative action requirements for Federal contractors. The postponement deserves to be permanent.

title: Researcher Reports Success For Workplace Smoking Ban
description: Banning smoking in the workplace helps employees stop smoking without prompting them to quit their jobs, researchers say.

title: Supreme Court Blocks Execution in Louisiana
description: The Supreme Court today blocked the scheduled execution of Willie Watson Jr., the convicted killer of a Tulane University medical student.

title: HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL TO RISE NEAR BATTERY PARK
description: Survivors of the Holocaust, urging the world to remember the horrors that befell them, joined with government officials yesterday to dedicate the site for a new museum in Battery Park City that is to serve as a memorial to the Holocaust and to the destroyed Jewish culture of Europe.

title: Bomb Wounds 45 At a Rally in Sri Lanka
description: A bomb exploded today at a crowded pro-Government rally in a Colombo suburb, wounding 45 people, 10 critically, officials said.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $6,456,000 for the quarter and $8,793,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $469,000 and $1,162,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the 1985 results have been restated to reflect the discontinued operations of Lamination Technology Inc., and Qualitron Corp.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
FOR 1940'S STAR, A VIOLENT END IN ROCKAWAY
description: Sid Tanenbaum gained fame on the basketball court, throwing two-handed set shots for New York University in the mid-1940's. The ultimate New York basketball player, he was called.

title: Ella Fitzgerald Gaining After Heart Surgery
description: Doctors treating Ella Fitzgerald reported today that the 68-year-old jazz singer ''is doing very well'' and is improving steadily after open-heart surgery.

title: State Dept. Lauds Pakistan
description: The State Department said today it applauded the resolve shown by Pakistan in acting ''boldly and decisively'' to deal with the hijacking of the Pan Am airliner.

title: CELLCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GULF CANADA-ALLIED PACT SPLITS UP HIRAM WALKER
description: The wealthy Reichmann family and Allied-Lyons, the British food conglomerate, agreed today to stop fighting and divide the liquor business of Hiram Walker Resources.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: TV: LAURIE ANDERSON PERFORMS
description: If you haven't yet caught up with Laurie Anderson, otherwise known as a ''high-tech one-woman show,'' you can make the acquaintance tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 31 or Sunday at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 13 in the Public Broadcasting System's series ''Alive From Off Center.'' Most of the half-hour multimedia entertainment that she has made her specialty is given to ''What You Mean We?,'' in which Miss Anderson, who wrote and directed it, plays herself, her undersized male clone and his oversized female clone. The small joke is that Miss Anderson is so busy being a pop personality that she no longer has time to write, so her clone does it for her, and he comes up with such promising ideas for movies as ''Rambo Meets Rocky,'' which makes him so famous that he has to get a clone to do the work while he's doing the talk-show circuit.

title: Ferguson and Butler
description: Maynard Ferguson and his band, High Voltage, are appearing tonight at the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street) on a double bill with the New Orleans-born pianist Henry Butler, who will play a solo concert. Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M., and tickets are $10. Information: 228-6300.

title: To the Bronx, With Love
description: ''The Bronx has never left my mind,'' said Jeffrey Silber, a real-estate investor who has just returned to the borough after a 15-year absence.

title: 2d LIVERY DRIVER IS FOUND DEAD NEAR PARKWAY
description: A driver for a Manhattan car service was found shot to death beside the Henry Hudson Parkway near 88th Street yesterday, two blocks from where another livery driver was found fatally shot last month. The police said the incidents may be connected.

title: KEY RATES
DOW FALLS 19.96 POINTS, TO 1,899.75
description: Stock prices pulled back in frenzied trading yesterday, just one day after investors celebrated an improving economy with record stock prices.

title:
PATENTS;
2 Aircraft Control Systems
description: THE Safe Flight Instrument Corporation of White Plains received a patent this week for an aircraft guidance system that controls a plane's angle at takeoff during unsafe air disturbances. Leonard M. Greene, president, was granted patent No. 4,609,987.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 20
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. WANTS TO EXTRADITE HIJACKING SUSPECTS FOR TRIAL; F.B.I. SENDS TEAM TO PAKISTAN
description: The Justice Department said today that it would seek arrest warrants for those responsible for the hijacking of the Pan American World Airways jet.

title: 15 DEAD, SCORES HURT ON HIJACKED U.S. JET; 300 ARE SAVED AS PAKISTANIS KILL 2 GUNMEN
description: At least 15 people were killed and scores wounded Friday night when the Arabic-speaking hijackers of a New York-bound Pan American jumbo jet suddenly began shooting and detonating grenades inside the darkened passenger cabin.

title: 22 HURT IN POWER PLANT FIRE
description: An equipment fire caused an explosion at a coal-burning power plant today and 22 employees fighting the blaze were injured, two seriously, the authorities said.

title: Keith Clearwaters, 45, Dies; Key Official in A.T.&T. Case
description: Keith I. Clearwaters, a senior Justice Department official in the Nixon Administration who was a key figure in one of the nation's largest antitrust suits, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 45 years old.

title: Holly Sugar Proxy Contest
description: An investment group led by the New York-based Brookehill Partners Inc. said it was planning a proxy contest to seek control of the Holly Sugar Corporation.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET END SESSION ON SPREAD OF CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United Staes and the Soviet Union concluded a second round of talks today on ways to halt the spread of chemical weapons and control exports of substances that could be used to make them, United States Embassy officials said.

title: MR. STEAK INC reports earnings for 13wks to June 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $177,000 for the quarter and $310,000 for the 39 weeks.

title: S.E.C. Grants Hutton Plea
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a staff recommendation to grant the E.F. Hutton Group and its subsidiaries an exemption from Federal securities laws that would have barred Hutton from the managing or underwriting of mutual funds.

title: A LOOPHOLE LETS FIBER SURGE
description: As recently as five years ago almost no one - except, perhaps, students of the ancient Orient and dedicated botanists - had heard of ramie, a natural fiber, much like linen, that comes from plants grown mostly in China and Brazil.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cincinnati Microwave Inc., Cincinnati, said James L. Jaeger, its chief executive, had offered to buy about 5 million shares at $11.25 a share, or the shares in Cincinnati Microwave he did not already own.

title: INDIA SUES CARBIDE IN BHOPAL
description: The Indian Government filed a civil suit today in Bhopal against the Union Carbide Corporation, seeking compensation on behalf of victims of the December 1984 toxic gas leak at a subsidiary's pesticide plant in the central Indian city.

title: CITY'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IS LOWEST FOR AUGUST IN A DOZEN YEARS
description: The unemployment rate for New York City fell last month to its lowest August figure in a dozen years - 6.9 percent - while rates for New York State and New Jersey remained relatively stable, Federal officials reported yesterday.

title: LAND OF LINCOLN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $455,000.

title:
PATENTS;
System Improves Use Of Nuclear Plant Fuel
description: A nuclear reactor with a mechanical drive system for moving its fuel was patented this week by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The inventors named in patent No. 4,609,522 are David E. Boyle, a manager in the company's Generation Technology Systems division, and Albert C. Davidson, an engineer.

title: Change in South Africa Needs Encouragement
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI SOLDIER KILLED IN RAID IN LEBANON
description: Israeli troops raided a Moslem Shiite village in southern Lebanon today, and an Israeli soldier was killed in an ensuing battle with local gunmen, according to an Israeli military spokesman and Lebanese radio stations.

title: Allied Stores Stock Dips $1.125 a Share
description: The common stock of Allied Stores dipped $1.125 a share yesterday, closing at $58.25 in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading, and analysts continued to be skeptical that the retailer would accept the $58-a-share offer announced Thursday by the Campeau Corporation, The stock had risen $10.75 a share Thursday after Campeau. a Canadian real estate developer, announced its bid. Allied owns a variety of department and specialty stores including Brooks Brothers, Bonwit Teller, Ann Taylor, Garfinckel's, Jordan Marsh and Stern's.

title: Which Side of the Net?
description: Perhaps when she plays the match over again in her mind, Chris Evert Lloyd will conclude that what happened at the National Tennis Center yesterday was pre-determined, a fait accompli. For someone who has never quite grown accustomed to the taste of defeat, it is easier, sometimes, to curse fate than face reality.

title: SOME REAL INTEREST IN THIS BALLET
description: The San Francisco Ballet Association has come up with a novel way to finance a new production of ''The Nutcracker'' - it is selling bonds.

title: AMERICAN CABLESYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter results includes a pre-tax loss of $10,000 and the year includes a pre-tax gain of $31,917,000 from the sale of assets. The company said the year-ago quarter and year results includes pre- tax gains of $2,442,000 and $4,278,000, respectively, from the sale of assets.

title: ANNA NEAGOE
description: Anna Neagoe, an artist and author, died in Sarasota, Fla., on Aug. 19.

title: 7 CZECH CULTURAL DISSIDENTS SEIZED IN PRAGUE
description: The leader of an independent cultural organization in Czechoslovakia and six members of his group have been arrested in the last two days, according to sources in Prague.

title: Air Alaska Adds To Airline Bid
description: Air Alaska Group Inc. said that it had raised its offer to acquire Jet America Airlines Inc. to $4.50 a share, or $19.9 million, from $3.25 a share.

title: SALE TALK FOR RCA RECORDS
description: RCA Records may be for sale, according to several record industry sources. RCA Records is now owned by the General Electric Company, and a source close to Marvin Davis, the Denver oil entrepreneur, said that there had been a meeting between Jack Welch, chairman of G.E., and Mr. Davis in recent weeks about the possible sale of the record operations.

title: Westburne Offer
description: Westburne International Industries said it had agreed to sell its United Westburne Industries Ltd. unit to Dumez S.A. of Paris for $23 (Canadian) a share, or $217 million. The company, which owns 94 percent of the unit, indicated that it would receive $203 million for its interest. The transaction is subject to approval by Investment Canada and other regulatory agencies and Westburne International shareholders and a favorable tax ruling, according to Westburne.

title: TEXAS TOWN LEADING IN EXECUTIONS IN A NEW U.S. ERA OF DEATH PENALTY
description: The rowdy crowds and solemn vigils that were part of state executions when they resumed four years ago are long gone now. Instead, only a handful of reporters were on hand when three men received lethal injections in one week recently in the pale-blue death chamber here.

title: Riggs Is Eager
description: Gerald Riggs, the running back who didn't report to the Atlanta training camp until Wednesday because of a contract dispute, said he wants to play in the Falcons' season opener tomorrow.

title: INTELOGIC TRACE INC reports earnings for Year to July 26
description: The company said the year-ago figures are pro forma, since the company was spun-off from Datapoint Corp. in July 1985.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1986
description: Markets

title: JUDGE REJECTS HUNT BID, REFUSES TO LEAVE CASE
description: Reacting swiftly to a challenge from the Hunt brothers, a Federal judge refused today to disqualify himself from the Hunts' legal battles with their 23 banks.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ SPEECH AT HARVARD'S 350 ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's speech today at Harvard University's 350th anniversary convocation:

title: Bond Prices Sharply Lower
description: A Government report on stronger-than-expected employment conditions during August sent bond prices sharply lower yesterday.

title: INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $36,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $156,000 and $372,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 33 Americans Injured In West Berlin Blast
description: Thirty-three Americans were injured when a document-destroying machine blew up during a training exercise at a radar installation in West Berlin today, the United States military said today.

title: Baker to Meet Japan Official
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the Japanese Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, will meet in Washington this weekend, a Treasury Department spokesman said today.

title: REAGAN BRANDS HIJACKING OF JET A COWARDLY ACT
description: President Reagan today condemned the seizure of a Pan American jet as a ''cruel and sinister terrorist act,'' and he accused the hijackers of ''a despicable and cowardly crime.''

title: CHERNOBYL DISASTER LEAVING A LONG TRAIL OF LISTS
description: Here in the capital of the Ukraine, and elsewhere in administrative centers of this Soviet republic and neighboring Byelorussia, the Chernobyl nuclear disaster is leaving a legacy - of lists.

title: Fredrika Rhodie, A Singer, Marries
description: Fredrika Rhodie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Rhodie of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Gustavo Enrique Brillembourg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arturo J. Brillembourg of Caracas, Venezuela. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: THE DEAL FOR DEALER'S DIGEST
description: When Theodore Cross decided to buy Investment Dealers' Digest in 1983, he was sufficiently skeptical about its future to hedge his bet by taking in two partners.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GOTTI DENIES KNOWING MOB INFORMER
description: The lawyer for John Gotti said yesterday that his client ''doesn't know'' and had ''nothing to do'' with the organized-crime member who became an informer and reportedly told of Mr. Gotti's criminal activities.

title: N.Y.U. BASKETBALL STAR IN 40'S
description: Sid Tanenbaum, a former New York University basketball star, was fatally stabbed Thursday in the metal-stamping shop he owned in Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 60 years old.

title: Larger Stake Sought in Caesars
description: The New York investor Martin T. Sosnoff said he had filed for permission under Federal antitrust laws to raise his stake in Caesars World Inc. to more than 15 percent, from 13.9 percent, which is 4.1 million shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sosnoff said that his plans were subject to various factors, including his ''assessment of the value of Caesars' business, operations and assets.''

title: Time Runs Out For Dime Parking Meters
description: The last of the dime parking meters in New York City disappeared yesterday.

title: POLICE SEEKING 2 MEN LINKED TO SERIES OF ASSAULTS
description: A team of detectives is seeking two men believed responsible for four assaults and robberies of couples in the last month in Central Park and on Wards Island in which three women have been raped, police officials said yesterday.

title: 'New Moon,' 5 Times
description: Sigmund Romberg's ''New Moon,'' with a book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Frank Mandel and Laurence Schwab, is being presented this weekend by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

title: Arthur P. Upgren Dies at 89; An Economist and Professor
description: Arthur P. Upgren, an economist, author and professor at four universities or colleges for 50 years, died Monday at the Andrews Estates Medical Center in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SKINNER DRIVES IN FOUR RUNS
description: Reggie Jackson, the unwanted Angel, stroked two home runs against his former club tonight, but the Yankees had an offensive weapon of their own: Joel Skinner, who drove in a career-high four runs in a 7-4 victory over the California Angels.

title: Is Andrew Wyeth's Art Too Easy to Understand?; Veronese's Case
description: To the Editor:

title: SUKOVA STUNS LLOYD, 6-2, 6-4, IN SEMIFINAL AT OPEN
description: Helena Sukova knew what might happen if she looked up, what emotions she might feel if she glanced at the scoreboard at the National Tennis Center. After 14 losses without a victory, she was finally serving for the match against Chris Evert Lloyd. So rather than risk a sudden attack of nerves, she looked downward, calmed herself and went on to accomplish the most surprising triumph in women's tennis this year.

title: FRANKLIN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEMORIAL SERVICES FOR CRASH VICTIMS
description: Nearly 1,000 people gathered Thursday to remember three members of one family who were killed last weekend when two airplanes collided over their home in a Los Angeles suburb.

title: Eliminate Taxi Tips
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND SOVIET START WASHINGTON ARMS TALKS
description: Soviet and American officials began two days of arms-control talks here today.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
License Issue Goes Away
description: Since its establishment in 1934, the Federal Communications Commission has been responsible for overseeing the country's broadcasters to assure minimum standards of fairness, keep the airways clear of obscenity and make sure they are not used to promote violence. The commission's chief enforcement tool is licensing of transmitters.

title: DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: No True Miskito Revolution in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sense of Peril
description: THE LOVER OF HORSES. By Tess Gallagher. 184 pages. Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Philip Feldesman Was Force In Many National Contests
description: Two decades ago a group of New York City experts noted for table presence and card-playing skill rather than for scientific bidding was a strong force on the national scene. Most of them later retired from the game, and one of them, Philip Feldesman, died on Monday at the age of 67.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. LOCAL TEAMS Merchant Marine (0-0) vs. Pace (0-0) Mariners begin defense of Liberty Conference title. EAST Boston College (0-0) vs. Rutgers (0-0) Last year was disappointing for both, so one may now forget. (TV - Channel 11).

title: END LIFE TENURE FOR JUDGES
description: The names William Rehnquist and Antonin Scalia strike terror in the hearts of liberals across America. Because Supreme Court justices are appointed for life, both men will probably affect the direction of our jurisprudence well into the next century.

title: MARINO WILL GET $9 MILLION CONTRACT
description: After more than a year of wondering how badly the Miami Dolphins wanted him for seasons to come, Dan Marino has been assured of a new contract that will make him one of the best-paid players in the National Football League, if not the best.

title: California Wine Strike Spreads to Almaden Sites
description: Workers walked off the job today at three plants operated by Almaden Vineyards, making it the ninth winemaker struck over the past three weeks by about 1,200 union members.

title: JLG INDUSTRIESN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EUROPEANS SAY U.S. ENVOY WAS VAGUE ON QADDAFI
description: Officials in various European capitals say that during a West European mission that concluded today, Vernon A. Walters, acting as a special envoy for the Reagan Administration, made only perfunctory suggestions for tightening sanctions against Libya and offered no new proof of terrorist plots by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: LEADER OF LIBERIA BACKS WASHINGTON
description: The Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, defended the United States here today at the meeting of nations professing nonalignment. Washington has been the target of fierce criticism during much of the meeting of the Nonaligned Movement.

title: CUOMO AND AIDE TO O'CONNOR CLASH OVER ABORTION DISSENT
description: Governor Cuomo and the Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York traded strong words yesterday over the responsibility of a Roman Catholic to adhere to church teaching, particularly on the question of abortion.

title: UNMANNED ROCKET ON SECRET MISSION LAUNCHED BY U.S.
description: An unmanned Delta rocket carrying a secret payload for an antimissile system was fired into space today, marking a major United States success in a year plagued by catastrophe and mishap.

title: CLERIC PRAYS FOR DEATH PENALTY
description: Delegates to the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association convention luncheon at the Concord Hotel in the Catskills Thursday applauded when the union endorsed Governor Cuomo for re-election, despite his opposition to the death penalty.

title: Peggy Cornell Benline Dies; Dancer Became Ziegfeld Girl
description: Peggy Cornell Benline, a former Ziegfeld girl and co-president of the Ziegfeld Club, died of pneumonia last Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after having had an operation for cancer. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GROUP NAMES PANEL ON TEACHER CERTIFICATION
description: The Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy today announced the creation of a panel to establish a national board that would test and certify the professional qualifications of teachers.

title: KASPAROV AND KARPOV PLAY TO DRAW IN GAME 13
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger Anatoly Karpov reached a draw today after 40 moves in the 13th game of their title match.

title: DOUBTS RAISED ABOUT ORIGIN OF WALKER'S SPY RING
description: John A. Walker Jr. failed recent polygraph tests and prosecutors are concerned that the Navy veteran is lying about the origins of his career as a Soviet spy, law-enforcement officials and others familiar with the case said today.

title: A SCARE IN PARIS PROMPTS WARNING
description: A failed bombing attempt in the Paris subway Thursday night prompted the Government to call today for vigilance in the face of possible new terrorist attacks.

title: BACK TO THE SWEATSHOP
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to legalize industrial work at home in industries in which the Labor Department banned it almost a half century ago. The Administration would have us believe that restrictions on such work are a relic, but sweatshop conditions that Federal regulations seek to prevent have returned - with a vengeance.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Evelyn H. Murray Becomes a Bride
description: Evelyn Hardart Murray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Murray of Greenwich, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., and Frank A. McGowan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGowan of Bronxville, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Walter Wagner performed the Protestant ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPECIAL MILITARY FORCES: CONGRESS SEES ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT
description: In separate measures passed recently, the House and Senate have put the Reagan Administration on notice that Congress feels proposals by the Secretary of Defense to strengthen the military's special operations do not go far enough.

title: CREW SAVED 3 DAYS AFTER SHIP'S SINKING
description: A 135-foot full-rigged ship that sailed in New York's Liberty Weekend in July capsized and sank in a freakish squall off the coast of North Carolina last Sunday, according to the ship's captain. But he said all five crew members were rescued by a fisherman after drifting three days in a life raft without provisions.

title: 'A Raisin in the Sun' Is Extended 2 Weeks
description: The run of the revival of Lorraine Hansberry's ''Raisin in the Sun'' has been extended for two weeks at the Roundabout Theater and is now scheduled to close Sept. 21, the theater has announced.

title: Is Andrew Wyeth's Art Too Easy to Understand?; In Chadds Ford
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government of Pakistan acted boldly and decisively to bring this nightmare to an end, and we applaud Pakistan's exemplary resolve in the handling of this incident.'' -President Reagan. [ 5:1. ]

title: PRESS LETTER TO GORBACHEV
description: Following is a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, from 29 American journalists based in Moscow. The correspondents, who signed as individuals, are accredited to 17 news organizations, including newspapers, news agencies, television networks and news magazines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1986
description: International

title: Little Red Book (USA)
description: In the category of things that were bound to happen, a little red book called ''Quotations from President Ron'' has appeared in the capital's Politics and Prose Bookstore.
