The book is filled with some things President Reagan probably now wishes he had never said - or tried to say - or that lend themselves to some pointed fun-making and partisan ridicule.

title: A MODEL PUBLIC SERVANT
description: In his haste to accumulate wealth, the former White House aide-turned-lobbyist Michael K. Deaver may have displayed poor judgment or worse. If so, however, his excesses are a matter of degree. For the past 25 years, no right has been more inalienable than the right of White House aides to cash in on proximity to power. Some decorate corporate boards, some are given instant Wall Street partnerships, some remain in Washington on big-buck retainers.

title: 3,500 Workers Go Out At Armco Steel Plant
description: An independent union of steelworkers struck the Middletown Works of Armco Inc. tonight after last-minute negotiations broke down. The Armco Employees Independent Federation said members voted 3,592 to 247 for a strike in a vote taken over three days.

title: What's Happened to Playgrounds Since the 30's
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP MATCHES FOR TODAY
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Ivan Lendl vs. Stefan Edberg, men's semifinal Second Match - Martina Navratilova vs. Steffi Graf, resumption of rain-delayed women's semifinal Third Match - Boris Becker vs. Miloslav Mecir, men's semifinal

title: DIAGNOSTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $199,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: First Commodity's Expulsion Sought
description: The National Futures Association has moved to expel the First Commodity Corporation of Boston on fraud allegations, an action that could prohibit the company from selling commodity futures to the public. Lawyers for the association, a federally approved regulatory group, notified First Commodity on Thursday that they would seek to revoke the company's membership.

title: 'Hunger' Premiere
description: Coney Island, Brooklyn, will be the location for the premiere this weekend of a new play by the Bread and Puppet Theater.

title: East German Family of 4 Swims River to West
description: An East German family of four climbed over border fences and swam across a river to reach West Germany early today, West German officials said.

title: INTERNATIONAL H.R.S. INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,663,137 for the latest year and $344,123 for the prior period. c-Net income The company said the decline in earnings was primarily attributable to reduced income from U.S. oil and gas operations and a writedown of $4,706,401 in the carrying value of U.S. oil and gas properties.

title: Worst Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: Among the most severe traffic trouble spots facing motorists this weekend in the metropolitan region, according to the city Department of Transportation are these:

title: SAGE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
TV: THE KIROV BALLET OFFERS 'GISELLE' ON BRAVO
description: ''Giselle'' is not merely one of the most historically important ballets of the Romantic era, it is dramatically well-nigh indestructible. Since its premiere in 1841, it has moved audiences with its tale of how Giselle, a peasant girl, is driven to madness and death when she learns that her lover is both an aristocrat in disguise and betrothed to a noblewoman.

title: RED SOX WIN, 12-2, INCREASE LEAD TO 5 1/2
description: Jim Rice drove in five runs with a grand slam and a single, and Marty Barrett hit a three-run homer tonight, leading Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox to a 12-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: RE: THE LAWYER-CLIENT RELATIONSHIP
description: With roots that trace back hundreds of years to the British common-law tradition, the lawyer-client privilege remains a vital part of the practice of law in the United States.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John (Blue Moon) Odom, a former major league pitcher who had been convicted of two counts of selling cocaine to a co-worker, was sentenced by a California court yesterday to five years' probation and 90 days in jail. . . . The Hartford Whalers have signed two veteran defensemen, Tim Bothwell and Mike McEwen, to multiyear contracts. Both are former Rangers.

title: Brooklyn Man Seized In Stabbing of Dancer
description: An unemployed security guard has been arrested in the stabbing and robbery of the dancer and choreographer Diane Boardman in her Brooklyn home last May, the police said.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $1,503,000 for the quarter and $5,664,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $1,313,000 for the quarter and $1,447,000 for the 6 months.

title: SOME PARENTAL TAX BREAKS
description: SOME of the ways that parents have shifted income to children to reduce the parents' tax bite will no longer be available under the proposed new tax bill. But estate lawyers and accountants have identified some techniques that will keep the old tax breaks or, at least, lessen the impact of changes in taxing the way that income from property is transferred to others.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRAZIL DAY

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A NEW HERO RESURRECTS THE CIVIC PRIDE IN BUFFALO
description: As a notch on the Rust Belt, this city has not always enjoyed a sparkling image. Its population has been shrinking for more than 25 years. Its old steel mills have gone silent. Many office buildings downtown are vacant.

title: VLADIMIR VASSILIEFF
description: Vladimir Vassilieff, a pianist and arranger for several top entertainers, died Wednesday at Indiana University Hospital.

title:
PATENTS;
Safety Jump Suit
description: Michael Brumfield, who operates a chiropractic clinic in Lewisburg, W. Va., was granted a patent this week for a safety jump suit intended for miners, workers in heavy industry and military personnel. Patent No. 4,608,716 describes a garment covering the body from foot to neck, with a helmet and strong gloves. A shoulder cover can be made of material that gives protection from projectiles such as bullets, shrapnel and rocks.

title: VATICAN CHANGE IN SEATTLE PROTESTED
description: A large group of Roman Catholic priests, nuns and lay members, angered by a Vatican decision to strip Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen of Seattle of his authority in five key areas, today demanded a explanation for ''this injustice.''

title: A.E. Meyerhoff, Ad Executive And Critic of U.S.I.A., Dies
description: Arthur E. Meyerhoff, a Chicago advertising executive who was a critic of the United States Information Agency in the 1960's, died Aug. 29 at his home in Rancho Sante Fe, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: Close the Pentagon's Revolving Door
description: The Pentagon auditor charged with keeping things honest at a Boeing plant retires. The next day he goes to work for Boeing.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
TENNIS'S FICKLE FANS
description: One thing is clear this weekend as we take our places in the stands of the National Tennis Center to watch the U.S. Open finals: unlike baseball fans who swear lifelong allegiance to the home team, tennis fans are a fickle bunch who turn traitor the moment either player wins an advantage. They want nothing more than to get their money's worth by seeing every match end in a dramatic tie-breaker.

title: A Critic Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Suspended At Tennessee
description: Ten Tennessee players have been suspended for Saturday night's opening game against New Mexico for violating an N.C.A.A. rule governing complimentary tickets, the athletic director, Doug Dickey, announced today. Two starters among the 10 -

title: Dome Seeking Revised Debt
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., Canada's largest oil company and its banking system's biggest corporate borrower, is seeking to reschedule its huge debt, and analysts say its creditors face little alternative but to accept its proposals.

title: POREX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOCAL SUPERMARKET: A DECLINING BREED
description: For Florence and Bill VanFelix, a retired couple living in Greenwich Village, bargain hunting is a way of life. They said they had found the Pioneer Supermarket at Bleecker Street and Minetta Street to be the best place for specials on food and dry goods. Two years ago, the supermarket chain lost its lease and pulled out. A boutique selling safari-style clothing occupies that space. The couple travel a little farther and pay a little more for their groceries.

title: TAX BILL'S BROAD EFFECT ON MULTINATIONALS
description: The proposed revision of the Federal income tax system is not just an internal American affair. The prospect of the sweeping tax changes is being evaluated from the board rooms of multinational corporations to the finance ministries of foreign capitals.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $148,440 and $193,702 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: 600 POUNDS OF COCAINE SEIZED IN JERSEY
description: An investigation into an illegal money-laundering scheme known as ''smurfing'' has led to the seizure of more than 600 pounds of cocaine in Bergen County, the largest such haul in New Jersey's history, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: THE DANCE: PETRONIO AND SKAGGS IN THE PARK
description: Light rain fell from time to time on Thursday night when Sarah Skaggs and Dancers and Stephen Petronio and Dancers shared a program at the Central Park Band Shell as part of the Summer Stage series of dance performances. But the evening's real inundations were choreographic, for both Ms. Skaggs and Mr. Petronio offered floods of steps.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7.2 million for the quarter and year and tax credits of $12,000 and $851,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $62,387,000 for the quarter and $74,735,000 for the year. d-Net loss The discontinued operations in both years represent the divestiture of Reeves' direct marketing businesses.

title: REPORTERS IN MOSCOW FACE NEW ANXIETY
description: For Western journalists in Moscow, the detention of a U.S. News & World Report correspondent by the Soviet authorities has created both a wave of anxiety about being arrested themselves and concern that bartering for the reporter's freedom could set a dangerous precedent.

title: Champion Cyclist Has Modest Hopes
description: Nobody ever accused Joop Zoetemelk of being overconfident and he is not about to start now, at age 39 and holding the record of six second-place finishes in the Tour de France.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16.

title: Washing the Election-Law Laundry
description: Ask most New York voters about cover sheets, and they will point to the linen closet. Yet 1986 should be remembered as another year in which court battles over cover sheets - the pages of ballot petitions that summarize information about the signatures - robbed them of a fair primary election.

title: SHULTZ DEMANDS THAT SOVIET FREE U.S. JOURNALIST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, expressing growing Administration impatience with the Soviet detention of an American journalist, demanded today that the Soviet Union ''find the wisdom'' to release the reporter quickly.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN SECURITY STANDS BY AS SOWETO FAMILIES BURY VICTIMS
description: South African security forces stood by in the black township of Soweto today as families buried victims killed in clashes there last week.

title: INVESTIGATORS SEEK TO DETERMINE GUNMEN'S IDENTITIES AND AFFILIATION
description: With the hijacking of the Pan American plane at Karachi International Airport in Pakistan ending in carnage, the next problem will be for investigators to determine the identities and political affiliation of the gunmen who seized the plane.

title: Starting Dates Set for Playoffs
description: The major league playoffs will begin with the American League Championship series at the Eastern Division champion's park Oct. 7, the office of the baseball commissioner said yesterday.

title: Guerrillas in Suriname Attack Army Post for a Second Time
description: Anti-Government rebels attacked an army post at Albina on the French Guianese border today for the second time in three days, the Suriname press agency reported. There were no reports of casualties.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $1,800,000 provision for revaluation of inventories due to reduced manufacturing costs in 1986. c-Net income

title: AEROSPACE ADVISER IS NAMED NASA DEPUTY ADMINISTRATOR
description: President Reagan has named Duke Myers, an aerospace consultant, to be Deputy Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Adminstration.

title: BIOASSAY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CSI TELE-MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,000. c-Net loss

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes after-tax dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company of $37,891,000 for the quarter and $75,782,000 for the 6 months and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $58,995,000, or 62 cents a share, for the quarter and $106,201,000, or $1.11 a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes after-tax dividend income from Du Pont of $37,681,000 for the quarter and $75,249,000 for the 6 months and equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont of $27,978,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and $16,517,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 6 months. Seagram has a 22.5 percent interest in Du Pont.

title: Glass Unit to Be Sold
description: The National Gypsum Company says it has entered into a letter of intent to sell substantially all the assets of its Binswanger Glass subsidiary to ACI International Ltd. of Australia at an undisclosed cash price. Binswanger, based in Memphis, distributes glass in the South and fabricates mirrors and thick glass for tabletops and furniture.

title: F.A.A. DISTRIBUTED RECENT TERROR ALERT; FOUND AIRPORT SAFE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued a ''general alert'' for possible terrorist acts to all United States airlines 10 days ago, a Pan American World Airways executive said last night.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified Eugene Patterson's positions at The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times and at Congressional Quarterly. He is chairman and chief executive officer of The Times and chairman of Congressional Quarterly.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a provision for discontinued units of $22 million. c-Includes a provision for discontinued units of $5.5 million for the quarter and year. The latest quarter and year consisted of 13 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 12 weeks for the year-ago quarter and 52 weeks for the previous year.

title: MILLICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said net income in the latest periods includes gains on the sales of U.S. cellular interests of $5,795,000.

title: AUTOPSY CONTRADICTS SUSPECT IN PARK SLAYING
description: The young woman found dead in Central Park last week was killed by pressure applied to her throat for at least 20 seconds, according to law-enforcement officials who reviewed autopsy findings yesterday.

title: Is Andrew Wyeth's Art Too Easy to Understand?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN INTRODUCES 3 PROTEGES
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN had it better, when he made his New York Philharmonic debut 43 years ago, than the three young conductors who led the orchestra under his sponsorship Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. He had been called in to save the show on practically no notice when Bruno Walter fell ill, and can hardly have had time to think about the impression he would make, let alone to get scared.

title: WEINBERGER DENIES ANTIMISSILE SHIFT
description: The Secretary of Defense today disputed charges that the Reagan Adminstration was quietly reorienting its strategic defense plans to protect missile sites instead of people.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: GERMAN BOOK SETS OFF NEW HOLOCAUST DEBATE
description: A book published last spring by a West German historian suggesting a link between the collapse of Germany's eastern front during World War II and the Holocaust has touched off a new dispute in the nation's press about the Nazi mass killing of Jews and whether German intellectuals have sought to minimize it.

title: Pilot Missing Off Norway
description: A United States Navy pilot is missing in stormy seas off Norway after his attack jet crashed during NATO exercises Thursday, the Navy said today. The pilot of the plane, which was operating from the aircraft carrier Nimitz, was identified as Lieut. Donald Matson, 28 years old, of New York City.

title:
PATENTS;
Artificial Tree Machine
description: Hudson Valley Tree Inc. of Newburgh, N.Y., which sells artificial Christmas trees, received a patent this week for the method and machine used to form the branches. Patent No. 4,609,989, granted to Larry Squarci, a vice president, explains that tips of natural tree branches are wrapped with filament and wire to form the artificial limbs. Operation is controlled by a computer.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: METS AND PADRES RAINED OUT
description: The opening game of the Mets' three-game series with the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium was rained out last night, briefly delaying the Mets' march toward the National League East title.

title: AZTECH INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dining Out: Recital of Specials No Treat
description: ''Every restaurant reviewer has his or her pet peeve,'' says The Gallup Monthly Report on Eating Out. ''It might be iceberg lettuce, overcooked vegetables, tables too close together or any one of a hundred other annoyances. But the one peeve many reviewers have in common is the practice some restaurants have adopted of having daily specials recited by the servers, often without benefit of price.''

title: Nicaragua Lifts Its Ban On Political Gatherings
description: Nicaragua's Government temporarily lifted a ban today on unauthorized political rallies and partly suspended press censorship in response to calls from the opposition for a more democratic debate on the country's new constitution.

title: 'Arts of Adornment'
description: ''Arts of Adornment: Contemporary Wearable Art From Africa and the Diaspora,'' a display of clothing, jewelry and other items by African and American artisans, will be on view through Oct. 12 at the Lehman College Art Gallery, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx.

title: O'NEILL IS HONORED AT HARVARD'S FETE
description: In Cambridge, where relations between the town and Harvard University have often been strained, a native working-class son was honored today as the university marked the second full day of its 350th anniversary celebration.

title: VW to Lift Prices An Average 4.2%
description: The suggested retail price of Volkswagen cars will rise an average 4.2 percent in the 1987 model year over 1986, the auto maker said.

title: FIRE DEPT. TEST DECLARED INVALID
description: The city's most recent test for fire lieutenant, taken by more than 4,300 firefighters in May, was ruled invalid yesterday because of evidence of cheating, city officials said.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after the utilization of the company's tax loss carryforward of $143,000 for the quarter and $233,000 for the 6 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Diner's Journal column in Weekend on Aug. 29 gave an incorrect address for the Pasta Pot Restaurant. Its address is 521 West Street, at Horatio Street.

title: A FAIR FOR CHINA BIBLOIPHILES
description: China's first international book fair opened today in Peking, offering something for bookworms of all tastes - if they could get in.

title: PAUL SANN, AUTHOR AND FORMER EDITOR OF NEW YORK POST
description: Paul Sann, who joined The New York Post as a copyboy in 1931 and stepped down in 1977 after 28 years as executive editor, died of complications from a heart ailment yesterday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 72 years old and had moved from Manhattan three years ago to devote himself to writing.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $124,000.

title: BRITANNICA COMPUTER FOILS TAMPERING WITH FACTS
description: A disgruntled employee who was being laid off from his job as an editor of The Encyclopedia Britannica secretly rewrote parts of history articles in computer files for forthcoming editions, company officials confirmed here today.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $899,000 which resulted from the completion of the initial public offering of CCC Franchising Corp., a partially owned subsidiary of Cosmopolitan Care Corp., for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the share earnings calculations for the latest quarter and 6-month periods are based on 5,733,000 shares outstanding, including incremental shares from common stock equivalents of 933,000 shares, as compared to 4,800,000 shares for the year-ago quarter and 6-month periods.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. SAN DIEGO PADRES, at Shea Stadium, 2:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050, 2:15 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: GUILTY VERDICT IN MURDER CASE IS OVERTURNED
description: The murder conviction of a man linked to organized crime in Manhattan was overturned yesterday when prosecutors said that they believed another man had committed the crime - and that the identity of the real killer had been known by the convicted man's defense attorneys throughout his trial.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $139,000 for the quarter and $155,000 for the 6 months.

title: The Hunts' Misfortune
description: The children of billionaires often turn to philanthropy. Not those of H.L. Hunt, the Texas speculator and oil baron. The brothers Bunker, Herbert and Lamar have been concerned to increase their inheritance by the same means by which it was made. Yet now they have lost much of it, again by speculation. Last week they sought to protect their major asset, Placid Oil, by filing for bankruptcy.

title: DISTINCT STYLES CLASH IN FINAL
description: They could be the Bjorn Borg and Jimmy Connors of the 1990's, or perhaps the Borg and John McEnroe. All the elements for a long-running rivalry are there. Boris Becker is fire, Stefan Edberg is ice. Becker pumps his fist and plays to the crowd; Edberg coolly and quietly overpowers his opponents. Becker enjoys the bright lights of New York City, taking in Broadway shows, eating fettuccine Alfredo at Yannick Noah's restaurant. Edberg fades into the background once his matches end.

title: STAGE: 'DIXIE DEWDROP,' PORTRAIT OF UNCLE DAVE
description: ''I'm just a billy from the hills where the land is so poor you've got to put fertilizer around the telephone poles before you can speak,'' announces Uncle Dave Macon, the jovial country-music legend who is fondly remembered in the musical, ''The Dixie Dewdrop.''

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ALFIN FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
POLITICAL PRISONERS IN CUBA ARE TO BE ADMITTED TO U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had cleared 68 Cuban political prisoners for admission to the United States and that the Cuban Government would probably release them by the end of this month.

title: A NEW SHORT SHAPE IN DENIM
description: Blue denim jackets in substantial numbers have shrunk to new proportions, almost resembling the bolero. The new look in abbreviated jackets was introduced last spring in Paris by Jean-Paul Gaultier, the designer.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, Nadine Hack's article Thursday, ''To Promote Phillipine Democracy: Provide Aid and Investment,'' misstated the size of the debt left by the Marcos Government. The correct figure is $26 billion.

title: Karachi's Day of Madness
description: When zealots strike at civil aviation and are willing to forfeit their own lives, there are no certain rules. Each grisly episode is distinct, but experience has taught a few guiding principles: talk with hijackers, yes, but yield nothing that might spur emulation.

title: Tribble Issues Denial
description: Brian Tribble, who was indicted on drug charges by a grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias, said in a televised interview tonight that he did not supply the cocaine that killed the Maryland basketball star.

title: St. John's Wins
description: Paul Koster threw three touchdown passes, including two to Tony Sas, to lead St. John's to a 24-0 victory over Iona tonight in the opener for each team. Despite heavy rain throughout the game, Koster completed 8 of 16 passes for 112 yards.

title: New Chief Is Sought In Search by M.C.C.
description: The search for a new leader for the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation began today, after the announcement Thursday that Adm. Bobby R. Inman would resign at the end of the year.

title: Change for Expos
description: The Montreal Expos replaced their president, John McHale, yesterday in an attempt to solve the organization's financial troubles.

title: FIRST VICTIM WAS A PROUD NEW AMERICAN
description: Rajesh Kumar, the 29-year-old Californian who was killed by the hijackers of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet in Karachi, Pakistan, became an American citizen only two months ago.

title: Japan to Aid U.S. Arms
description: Japan has agreed to provide the United States with technology for a surface-to-air missile homing device and for warship building, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Complaints On Buying By Mail
description: CONSUMERS complain more about mail-order companies to Better Business Bureaus than about any other companies, according to the Council of Better Business Bureaus in Washington.

title: D'Rivera Quintet
description: Paquito D'Rivera, the Cuban alto-saxophonist, is appearing this weekend with his quintet on a double bill with the Makoto Ozone Trio at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street). Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with a third set tonight at 1:30 A.M. Admission is $12, with a $5 music charge at tables. Information: 475-8592.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $653,000 for the quarter and $1,087,000 for the 6 months.

title: Hotel Fire in Norway Leaves 14 Dead
description: Fourteen people died and more than 50 were injured early today when a fire swept through a crowded hotel in this southern Norwegian resort, the police said.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $436,000 and $981,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $492,000 for the quarter and $1,197,000 for the 9 months.

title: AQUINO MEETS WITH GUERRILLA LEADER AND TRUCE IS EXTENDED
description: President Corazon C. Aquino met here today with a Moslem separatist chieftain and agreed to open peace talks to resolve a 14-year-old insurgency that has taken more than 50,000 lives.

title: EXPERTS SAY CHEMICALS PERIL FARM BELT'S WATER
description: Every year farmers like Gary J. Wegman apply hundreds of pounds of fertilizer and pesticide to their crops, hoping to improve yields and profits.

title: Fishing for Japan's Technology Data
description: Want to know the latest developments in Japanese high-performance ceramics? How does Japanese labor react to introduction of automation in Japanese offices? What is the accident rate in Tokyo from robots gone berserk?

title: Connecticut Museum Chief Is Dismissed for Gun Trading
description: David O. White, director of the Connecticut State Library Museum, has been dismissed because he supposedly traded away priceless pieces of the state's Colt firearm collection without approval, interim State Librarian Suzanne J. LeBarron announced today.

title: A New Focus On Fort Greene Park
description: ''Despite being an Olmsted and Vaux park it is often ignored, even by us,'' said Julius Spiegel, the Parks Department's borough commissioner for Brooklyn, talking about Fort Greene Park.

title: Surgery for Outfielder
description: Gary Ward, the Texas Rangers' outfielder, underwent abdominal surgery yesterday and is expected to miss the rest of the season, the team said.

title: JOBLESSNESS IN SLIGHT DROP, ENCOURAGING SOME ANALYSTS
description: The nation's unemployment rate eased one-tenth of a point to 6.7 percent in August, the third successive month of decline, the Labor Department reported today.

title: MERRILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EXCERPTS FROM THE BRIEFINGS BY WHITE HOUSE AND STATE DEPT.
description: Following are excerpts from a briefing in Santa Barbara, Calif., yesterday by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, and in Washington by Charles E. Redman, a State Department spokesman, on the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways airliner in Karachi, Pakistan, as recorded by The New York Times: WHITE HOUSE BRIEFING

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid in April.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,157,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: AS THE SHOOTING BEGAN, VISIONS OF A 'HOLOCAUST'
description: It all happened in the dark. Suddenly gunfire and hand grenades erupted in the cabin of Pan Am Flight 73 as 398 passengers and crew members screamed, wept and fell to the ground.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A BUNGLE IN SHEEP'S CLOTHING
description: Modern times breed modern phobias. Until the present age, for example, it has been impossible for any woman to suffer crippling fear of artificial insemination.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
In the Face of a Plague, A Party
description: All seemed right with the world. At 3 A.M. on a weeknight, downtown, the Pyramid Club on Avenue A was jammed with revelers, hooting with laughter and applauding the performances of Jean Caffeine, Wendy Wild, Lady Bunny, John Sex and many more, then dancing toward dawn to sternum-thumping recordings of ''Body Slam'' and ''Jungle Fever.''

title: Pointing the Finger
description: Ordinarily, in the early stages of preconvention manuevering, Presidential candidates tend to concentrate their fire on leaders of their own party who are also seeking the nomination; that is, the immediate competition. But here is Representative Jack F. Kemp, the upstate New York Republican, already attacking Democratic 1988 contenders, in what is likely to be seen as a display of confidence in his own nomination.

title: Rail Crash Victim Identified
description: The Nassau County police today identified the victim of a rush-hour train-car collision Thursday evening as 25-year-old Derrick Shuford of Freeport. The accident occurred at 6:05 P.M. at the Urban Avenue crossing, said a police spokesman, Officer Robert Wheeler. Mr. Shuford pulled his 1986 Chevrolet around the gates blocking the tracks and moved into the path of the Long Island Rail Road train, Officer Wheeler said. The accident caused service delays of up to three hours.

title: NRBQ TO PERFORM
description: NRBQ, the popular upstate rock-and-roll band, is performing tonight on the South Street Seaport Museum's Party Boat concert series. Cruises start at the seaport on Pier 16 at 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $17.50 and are available through Ticketron and Teletron outlets. The number for information is 406-3434.

title: PORTRAIT OF A MEDIEVAL CITY
description: In 1896, Leopold II, King of the Belgians, cut a canal through the flat Flemish countryside, 10 miles from Bruges to the sea. Completed in 1907, the canal brought new prosperity to Western Flanders. But for this city it was 400 years too late.

title: Nancy Loves Adolfo
description: Nancy Reagan has agreed to act as honorary patron at the second annual Hispanic Designers Fashion Show and Benefit to be held at the J. W. Marriott Hotel on Sept. 14. It will be part of the celebration of award made to her own favorite, the Cuban-born designer Adolfo, who will present his fall collection. Other designers appearing and showing their creations include Carolina Herrera of Venezuela, Carlota Alfaro of Puerto Rico, Miguel Osuna of Mexico and Fernando Pena, also of Puerto Rico.

title: DATA UPDATE: September 7, 1986
Whalers Sign McEwen
description: The Hartford Whalers signed two defensemen, Tim Bothwell and Mike McEwen, to multiyear contracts, but won't have a compensation wrangle.

title: A MAKER OF MAGIC SOUFFLES
description: SAINTS AND STRANGERS By Angela Carter. 126 pp. New York: Viking. $13.95.

title: 'Problem Solvers' in the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Poll Raises Questions For TV
description: The results of a New York Times/ CBS News Poll released last week showed sharply rising public concern about drugs and caused some consternation at the television networks, too.

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN had it better, when he made his New York Philharmonic debut 43 years ago, than the three young conductors who led the orchestra under his sponsorship Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. He had been called in to save the show on practically no notice when Bruno Walter fell ill, and can hardly have had time to think about the impression he would make, let alone to get scared.

title: QUIETER LOOK FROM JAPAN FINDS A PLACE
description: SINCE first exploding on the Western fashion scene about five years ago with dramatically torn and tattered fabrics, the Japanese look has settled into a less provocative mode. It has also taken its place among the most influential forces in international design.

title: A Correction
description: An article about Brooklyn politics in The Region section last Sunday incorrectly described the political situation of Roy Innis. Mr Innis, a candidate in the 12th Congressional District Democratic primary, has said that if elected to Congress, he would sit on the Republican side of the House

title: PORTLAND, ORE., GETS NEW RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: More than a decade of planning, political negotiation, controversy and construction has ended with the opening of a light rail line linking downtown Portland to its eastern suburb, Gresham.

title: AT HARVEST TIME, WAR IS DECLARED ON GARDEN ROBBERS
description: Thanks to electric power, I've rescued most of my corn this year from raccoons.

title: Mariners Beat Pace
description: Ken Bonkowski, a sophomore making his first start at quarterback, passed for one touchdown and ran for another as the Merchant Marine Academy opened its season with a 21-3 Liberty Conference victory over Pace yesterday at Tomb Memorial Field at Kings Point, L.I.

title: SHAFFER'S PASSING ROUTS TEMPLE, 45-15
description: John Shaffer vindicated Coach Joe Paterno's vote of confidence tonight as he threw for three touchdowns and ran for another in Penn State's 45-15 victory over Temple in the first night game ever at Beaver Stadium.

title: IN QUEENS, CITY SCANDAL IS MINOR ISSUE
description: The city's corruption scandal may have toppled the Queens Borough President and rocked the Queens Democratic organization, but it certainly was not the first thing brought up by questioners at the Macedonia A.M.E. Church in Flushing on a recent night.

title: 'Upper-Income' Couple
description: To the Editor:

title: Vancouver
description: To the Editor: Being a New Yorker fairly recently transplanted to Seattle, I have wondered how others who attended the 1963-64 World's Fair felt about Expo 86 in Vancouver. Robert Lindsey has confirmed some of my beliefs and impressions in his ''A 'World in Motion,' a Wait in Line.''

title: DECISIONS WITHIN NETWORK NEWS
description: To the Editor: In considering Peter Boyer's article ''TV Network News Finds the Rules Have Changed'' [ Aug. 17 ] , readers may want to know the following:

title: Troubled Times Are Continuing On the Tarmac
description: Edward J. Daly, who started World Airways in 1950 with $50,000 won in a poker game, was an early champion of deregulation. When route and fare controls were lifted in 1978, his airline was one of the first to set off a price war with its low fares. But by 1982, two years before his death, Mr. Daly was calling for reregulation, warning that the fierce competition in the skies was ''disastrous.''

title: Despite a Truce, 4 Die in Lebanon
description: For the 191st time since the Lebanese civil war began in 1975, a truce was declared last week.

title: B.Y.U. ROLLS, 52-0, AS PASSER GETS 369
description: Steve Lindsley, a 24-year-old senior who rejoined the team after completing his Mormon mission, threw for 369 yards and two touchdowns as Brigham Young routed Utah State, 52-0, in the opener for both teams today. He completed 24 of 37 passes.

title: Topics: Gifted Athletes; Strokes of Luck
description: Not everyone shoots a hole-in-one on the same hole two days in a row, as Arnold Palmer did last week. But consider: He has shot only two of the more than 40,000 holes-in-one that will be recorded by the time this year ends.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: GANDHI CRITICIZES PAKISAN ON HANDLING OF HIJACKING
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India today sharply criticized Pakistan's handling of the hijacking of a Pan American jumbo jet at the Karachi airport, charging that the Pakistani security forces had ''bungled'' the rescue mission ''very badly.''

title: TO ATTRACT WORKERS, PAY THEM MORE
description: The Opinion Page article by Jon F. Weinstein about the shortage of semiskilled and unskilled workers [ ''Worker Shortage Is Bad Business,'' Aug. 24 ] was full of wonderful platitudes about the problems of running a successful business in the suburbs.

title: MECIR UPSETS BECKER; Lendl Sails Unhindered to 5th Final
description: Boris Becker was wary of Miloslav Mecir, a reluctant visitor from Czechoslovakia who said he would rather be home fishing instead of playing tennis in the United States Open. Mecir expressed his feelings to Becker two weeks ago when the tournament began, and Becker believed him - until he noticed that Mecir had reached the Open semifinals. It suddenly sounded like a setup.

title: NEW TROUBLES IN THE N.F.L.
description: OUR BASIC PROBLEMS are still there, and they're still internal,'' Commissioner Pete Rozelle says about the future of his National Football League. ''The next 12 months worry me,'' says Art Modell, owner of the Cleveland Browns, one of the league's 28 franchised teams. ''We've got our work cut out for us.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: I'M NOT SLEEPY Written and illustrated by Susanna Gretz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press/Macmillan. Board, $2.95. (Ages 18 months to 3) READY FOR BED Written and illustrated by Susanna Gretz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press/Macmillan. Board, $2.95. (Ages 18 months to 3) HIDE-AND-SEEK Written and illustrated by Susanna Gretz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press/Macmillan. Board, $2.95. (Ages 18 months to 3) TOO DARK! Written and illustrated by Susanna Gretz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press/Macmillan. Board, $2.95. (Ages 18 months to 3)

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HARD CHOICES: Mixed Blessings of Modern Medical Technology. By B. D. Colen. (Putnam, $18.95.) B. D. Colen, the author of several books on health matters, has written a most disturbing book on the ethical, medical, legal and financial issues arising from advances in medical technology.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 34 ESTABLISHMENTS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 34 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: COMPUTER LISTING VOLUNTEERS
description: ''A VERY valuable communications link'' is how Walter Jakes of Scarsdale describes The Westchester Skillsbank, a computerized file of skilled volunteers who are available for short-term projects. Mr. Jakes, a semi-retired consultant who has worked with computers for 16 years, is a volunteer who helped select equipment and set up the program for the county's Volunteer Service Bureau of United Way.

title: BETTING ON NEWS, COMEDIES AND SEASONED STARS
description: This season brings the first example of network television's ''New Reality,'' which isn't a programming philosophy but an economic discipline, born of the hard times confronting the networks. In a video world abundant in alternatives for viewers and advertisers alike, the networks, facing stalled revenue growth, have been streamlining their operations, a slimming manifest most noticeably so far in the form of job layoffs and tough cost controls. Now comes streamlined programming, in the form of ABC's ''Our World'' - perhaps the first network television series conceived on a ledger sheet.

title: ARCHBISHOP'S U.S. FRIENDS ARE LEGION
description: DOZENS of Desmond M. Tutu's American supporters were in South Africa this weekend to celebrate his installation as Archbishop of Cape Town, the head of the Anglican Church in South Africa. He has attracted a widening circle of admirers -and lately a few vocal American detractors. He found many of his friends first in the church and later in black political and civil rights circles. More recently, show business personalities such as Stevie Wonder and Harry Belafonte have joined his supporters.

title: Soviet Moves Against Videos Spreading 'Cult of Violence'
description: The Russian Republic, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 states, has enacted legislation declaring the making, storing, distribution or showing of films propagating ''the cult of violence and cruelty'' a criminal offense punishable by up to two years in prison.

title: GRAZING MEALS
description: THE MOST IMPORTANT TREND in American restaurant dining seems somehow un-American. These days, a whole meal often consists of a series of little dishes brought to the table, one or two at a time, for everyone to share. Called ''grazing'' or ''modular eating,'' this new trend is a far cry from having one's own slab of meat, some vegetables and a fork and a knife in each fist to fend off stray intruders.

title: DENG HINTS AT GORBACHEV TALK
description: The Chinese leader, Deng Xiaoping, has told an American interviewer that he is ready to meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev if the Soviet Union withdraws its support for Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Jennifer Shapiro Marries
description: Jennifer Sonya Shapiro and Dr. Neil Howard Hyman were married last night at the North Woodmere (L.I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Raphael Miller and Cantor Yitzchak Lefkowitz. The parents of the couple are Andrea N. Shapiro of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Dr. Sidney J. Shapiro, and Mr. and Mrs. Abraham M. Hyman of Oceanside, L.I.

title: PROSPECTS
description: AUTO ECONOMICS

title: Dentist Given 42-Year Term In Philadelphia Cocaine Case
description: A young dentist who masterminded a $5 million-a-month cocaine ring that catered to lawyers, stockbrokers and other professionals was sentenced Thursday to 42 years in prison and fined $240,000.

title: PHOTOGRAPHERS WHO SEE BEYOND THE FACT
description: Part of what makes photographs so fascinating is the complexity of information they store within their seemingly bland, placid surfaces. The same could be said of the coming exhibition season in photography. While it offers something for every conceivable taste, from Edward Weston classicism to the post-punk, revolte expressionism of Nan Goldin and Joel Peter Witkin, this is merely surface. Beneath the veneer of pluralism lies evidence of a wide, if unacknowledged, gulf between two radically different conceptions of the medium.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AN AMERICAN MUSIC: The Search for an American Musical Identity. By Barbara L. Tischler. (Oxford University, $24.95.) It's difficult to define what qualities make a piece of music sound ''American,'' so American composers gradually abandoned the quest for a musical nationalism in favor of helping to create an international modernism.

title: New Season Under Way
description: Winter? Christmas? Sept. 9 - It started in Cambridge, Mass., 16 years ago, a celebration of the winter solstice, of life and death and of Christmas, a masque of traditional and ritual music, drama, dance and processionals. Nine years ago ''The New York Revels'' was first presented here, and this year the pageant will be performed from Dec. 18 to 21 at Symphony Space. A benefit reception for the nonprofit group that presents the revels and a preview of the performance will be held from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. at the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Tickets, $15 for individuals or $25 for families (children are welcome), from 212-484-1562 or 914-337-4227 or at the door. Worldwide Goal Sept. 9 - The Better World Society has the lofty aim of instilling ''in citizens of all nations a sense of common responsibility for the fate of life on earth,'' the group says. To further its goals, the society will hold a benefit cocktail party and dinner in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, starting at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $125, from 212-582-4055. Party at Bloomingdale's Sept. 10 - The 95-year-old East Side House Settlement in the South Bronx will be the beneficiary of a black-tie buffet dinner party at Bloomingdale's, which is celebrating its 100th annivesary. The evening will begin with cocktails at 8 P.M. Tickets, $200, from 212-665-5250. Premiere of 'Otello' Sept. 10 - Founded in 1974 as an affiliate of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Very Special Arts creates opportunities in the arts for people with disabilities in 40 countries.

title: Trilby Holmes Is Wed To Parker C. Barrett Jr.
description: At St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn., yesterday Trilby Hollingsworth Holmes, the daughter of Joan S. Holmes of Ridgefield and Frank E. Holmes Jr. of Vero Beach, Fla., and Fort Lee, N.J., was married to Parker Corning Barrett Jr., a son of Elizabeth Payne Freet of Ridgefield and Mr. Barrett of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Al Nyman performed the ceremony.

title: Margaret Segal, David J.Topper Exchange Vows
description: Margaret J. Segal, a daughter of Dr. Robert L. Segal of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Sydney Joelson Segal, was married yesterday to David J. Topper, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Yale J. Topper of Rockville, Md. The ceremony was performed at the Central Synagogue in New York by Rabbi Stanley Davids.

title: Santa Fe Trail Exhibit, New England Fair
description: WAGON TRAINS ACROSS PRAIRIES AND DESERTS

title: Deprived Grandparents
description: Today is National Grandparents Day, but Representative Mario Biaggi says he fears it will be meaningless for a lot of grandparents. Mr. Biaggi, a Bronx Democrat, is urging the Senate to join the House in encouraging states to develop a uniform law for grandparents to see their grandchildren.

title: LAYING THE BLAME ON BRITAIN
description: THE IRON CURTAIN Churchill, America, and the Origins of the Cold War. By Fraser J. Harbutt. 384 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: AN AIRBORNE DISASTER REVIVES OLD QUESTIONS
description: AMID the bodies, gutted homes and wreckage in a middle-class neighborhood devastated last week when a Mexican airliner and a single-engine private aircraft collided overhead was the logbook, faithfully kept up to date, of the smaller plane's pilot.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LONG-TERM SCHEDULES FOR CONSTRUCTION NEED LONG-TERM FINANCING
description: THE original intent of the Transportation Trust Fund, enacted by the Legislature in 1984, was to produce $3.3 billion in state and Federal funds for transportation construction through mid-1988.

title: RECALLING VIEW FROM THE BACK OF THE BUS
description: LAST spring, the state and local governments here pledged $8.8 million toward turning the aging Lorraine Motel into a National Civil Rights Center. It was at the Lorraine that Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., standing on a balcony, was cut down by an assassin's bullet in 1968.

title: Don't Touch That Dial
description: A NEW LANGUAGE is being pounded into our ears. It is called dialect - not the regional speech understood by speakers of the same general language, but the arcane argot of the radio dial.

title: MANILA AGAIN TALKS WITH COMMUNISTS
description: Government and Communist negotiators resumed their stalled peace talks today, and at the direct urging of President Corazon C. Aquinio, the Communists agreed to consider an immediate 30-day cease-fire.

title: HARVARD GROUP PONDERS POVERTY TOLL
description: Welfare officials from Massachusetts and New York, meeting to compare notes two decades after the opening of President Johnson's ''War on Poverty,'' agreed this evening that there were still steps to be taken by government and private agencies to reduce welfare dependence.

title: EXPERTS TO BEGIN MAMMALS' RESCUE
description: Early next week a team of experts on marine life from around the world will set up camp on a barren beachhead in southeast Alaska to start a monthlong mission to save more than a hundred mammals.

title: SECRETARY BENNETT PRESCRIBES THE THREE R'S
description: SINCE becoming Secretary of Education nearly two years ago, William J. Bennett has provoked controversy over everything from his contention that some college students receive too much Federal aid to his call for the teaching of religious and moral values in public schools. One topic on which he has been conspicuously silent, however, is the school reform movement.

title: JUDGESHIP PRIMARY IS CHALLENGE TO BAN ON ENDORSING
description: 9412>LONG ISLAND will have one of its quietest primaries in years on Tuesday. But the campaign has been far from quiet for two Nassau County Democratic judges who have been ringing doorbells of Conservative voters in the last month in an effort to save their posts.

title: Digital VCR's Figure in the Future
description: In a field where, as a rule, mere gadgeteering passes for progress, a genuine advance seems doubly welcome. This fall, video takes a momentous step with the introduction of the first digital VCR's. Without question, this marks a turning point in the development of these devices.

title: Mr. Reagan's Myopia on Arms Control
description: Two significant facts about American-Soviet relations stand out.

title: Is the U.S. a 'Bully'?
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, opening the meeting of nonaligned nations in Harare, charged the United States with ''international bullyism.'' That overstated a case that may be stronger than some Americans want to believe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1986
description: International Arab terrorists threw hand grenades and fired submachine guns at a Sephardic synagogue congregation in Istanbul, Turkey, killing at least 21 worshipers, including 7 rabbis, and wounding others. The terrorists posing as photographers entered the newly refurbished synagogue and locked the doors with iron bars. The gunfire and explosions set the synagogue on fire. The bodies of two of the gunmen were found in the carnage. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Calls for increased vigilance against terrorism came from governments and religious groups around the world in response to the terrorist attack on the synagogue in Istanbul. The United States and Israeli Governments, in separate statements, labeled the attack ''cowardly.'' [ 1:3. ] The four hijackers of the Pan Am 747 in Karachi are alive and in custody, the Pakistani authorities said. Contradicting an earlier report that two of the gunmen in Friday's hijacking had died, law-enforcement officials also said that one of the four was seriously wounded. They said that of the four, one was from Syria, one from Bahrain and one was a Palestinian. But other sources said that four gunmen were from Beirut and had entered Pakistan last month on false Bahrain passports. [ 1:2. ] Six Karachi airport security officers were suspended for negligence in allowing the hijackers of a Pan American World Airways 747 to drive on the tarmac in a van disguised to look like an official security vehicle, official sources at the airport said. According to reports in Karachi, three of the hijackers wore security personnel uniforms.

title: N.F.L.'86
description: NEW COACHES Buddy Ryan, Philadelphia Eagles; formerly defensive coordinator of Chicago Bears. Jerry Burns, Minnesota Vikings; formerly Vikings' assistant head coach and offensive coordinator. Jim Mora, New Orleans Saints; coach of U.S.F.L. Baltimore Stars Gene Stallings, St. Louis Cardinals; defensive backfield coach of Dallas Cowboys Jerry Glanville, Houston Oilers; defensive coordinator under his predecessor, Hugh Campbell, and interim coach for two games after Campbell was fired Hank Bullough, Buffalo Bills; successor to Kay Stephenson for final 12 games last season Notable Absences Joe Theismann, quarterback, Washington Redskins John Riggins, running back, Washington Redskins Lynn Dickey, quarterback, Green Bay Packers Earl Campbell, running back, New Orleans Saints Lyle Alzado, defensive end, Los Angeles Raiders Doug English, defensive lineman, Detroit Lions Lee Roy Selmon, defensive lineman, Tampa Bay Buccaneers Jan Stenerud, kicker, Minnesota Vikings Joe DeLamielleure, guard, Cleveland Browns Switching Teams Joe Cribbs, rb, San Francisco (from Buffalo Bills) Gary Hogeboom, qb, Indianapolis (from Dallas Cowboys) Steve Bartkowski, qb, Los Angeles Rams (from Atlanta Falcons) Mark Hayes, cb, Denver (from Giants) Dennis Thurman, db, St. Louis (Cowboys) Tom Cousineau, lb, San Francisco (Cleveland Browns) Brad Van Pelt, lb, Cleveland (Los Angeles Raiders)

title: THE GOOD, THE BAD AND THE GLITZY
description: ALL that's missing at the Claridge in Great Neck is the floor show. The glitzy, overdecorated, rose-plush dining room with its curved, tufted banquettes, shimmering icicle chandeliers, smoke mirrors and chrome trim could be in a Las Vegas casino hotel.

title: 'PUMP BOYS' STAGED WITH GOOD CHEER IN BRIDGEPORT
description: THE hooting and the hollering you hear at Bridgeport's Downtown Cabaret Theater is coming from both sides of the footlights where ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' is now playing.

title: COMPLEX PLAY IS DOMINANT IN 13TH GAME
description: Complex, demanding tactics by Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov resolved the 13th game of their world championship chess match in Leningrad into a draw after a hard fight on Friday.

title: THE WILD MAN OF VIENNESE ART
description: OSKAR KOKOSCHKA A Life. By Frank Whitford. Illustrated. 221 pp. New York: Atheneum. $21.95.

title: Movie Memorabilia
description: To the Editor:

title: Kyle Hallsteen Marries David McRobie
description: Kyle Thais Hallsteen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Hallsteen of Kenilworth, Ill., and David Stuart McRobie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. McRobie of Montreal and Nantucket, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Gilbert W. Bowen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Church in Kenilworth.

title: SOVIET CAPTAINS IGNORED COLLISION WARNINGS
description: The ship collision in the Black Sea in which 398 people apparently died occurred after the captain of a cargo vessel refused to heed warnings for 45 minutes that his ship's course would bring it dangerously close to the passenger liner Admiral Nakhimov, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

title: Edward Leh Wed To Miss Worthing
description: Karen Elizabeth Worthing and Edward Kline Leh, who received M.B.A. degrees from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Reformation in Washington. The Rev. Arnold F. Keller Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Joan Alexandre Clark Weds B. J. Kegelman
description: The marriage of Joan Alexandre Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Adams Clark of Cooperstown, N.Y., to Brian Joseph Kegelman, a son of Harry J. Kegelman of Jersey City and the late Mary Routh Kegelman, took place yesterday. Judge Joseph A. Mogavero Jr. of the Otsego County (N.Y.) Court officiated at the Farmers' Museum Church in Cooperstown.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Nenow set an American record in the 10,000-meter run at a track meet in Brussels when he finished in 27 minutes 20.56 seconds, elcipsing the four-year-old mark of 27:25.61 set by Alberto Salazar. Nenow's time was 6.75 seconds off the world mark held by Fernando Mamede of Portugal.

title: A FIND AT A TOURIST ATTRACTION
description: PRIME tourist attractions are not usually noted for fine dining, but Mystic is fortunate to have at least one such place, the Flood Tide restaurant, situated on a hill overlooking Mystic Harbor. To compound the improbables further, Flood Tide, though in a separate building, is part of a motel and inn complex - The Inn at Mystic - not always a promising place to find a good restaurant.

title: NEW YORK'S LITTLE CAPE COD
description: The North Fork doesn't seem to belong on Long Island. Somehow this tiny wedge of land, one of two forks that jut into the ocean on Long Island's east end, has remained unscarred by the urban clutter to the west. There are no expressways, no exit ramps, no fast-food restaurants and only one shopping mall. The Hamptons are just a few miles away on the South Fork, but their stylishness has made few footholds here. Today, the North Fork is still rough-cut and unpolished, a place where you are more likely to see tractors than limousines, where overalls are always in style and where farms sprout potatoes and broccoli, not condominiums and million-dollar homes.

title: Faust Makes Winning Debut
description: Gerry Faust enjoyed a 35-0 victory over Salem College of West Virginia tonight in his first game as the Akron coach before a crowd of 35,202 in the Rubber Bowl, where Faust had won four state high school title games.

title: Two Soviet Ships Collide in the Night
description: The two Soviet ships, a liner with 1,234 people aboard and a freighter carrying a cargo of oats, were supposed to pass in the night last week as they sailed in the Black Sea off the coast of southern Russia The pilot of the liner, called the Admiral Nakhimov, said the crew had spied the freighter off Novorossisk and radioed a warning, to which the freighter responded: ''Don't worry, we will pass clear of each other. We will take care of everything.''

title: CHALLENGE IN THE PACIFIC
description: THIS SUMMER, IN THE BLACK waters north of Japan, the Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet staged one of its biggest sea and air exercises of recent years. Outsiders were not allowed near the maneuvers, but American naval intelligence concluded that more than 30 surface ships and submarines were involved. The Soviet forces moved with ease in and around the Sea of Okhotsk, which stretches from the main Siberian land mass to the fingerlike protrusion that is the Kamchatka Peninsula. Overhead, fighter planes creased the skies.

title: THE MARBLE MOUNTAINS OF THE GARFAGNANA
description: The first time I saw the Apuane Alps, from a packed beach by the polluted Mediterranean, somewhere between Spezia and Viareggio, I thought I was hallucinating: a range of high mountains seemingly blanketed in snow above all that heat. They must be much higher and more distant than they look, I thought, or subject to some climatic quirk. How else could they be covered in snow when the beach felt like a microwave oven, baking me from the inside?

title: PLAN FOR GROTON MANSION OPPOSED
description: AT Avery Point in Groton, developers plan to turn a historic but deteriorating granite mansion and two neighboring buildings on the branch campus of the University of Connecticut into a conference center and hotel. But a group of Groton residents is trying stop them on the ground that the conversion would limit public use of the mansion's scenic lawns.

title: Gender Benders
description: Jack Rosenthal underestimates the necessity of eliminating sexist words from our language (''Gender Benders,'' On Language, Aug. 10); these efforts, he claims, can be superficial and cosmetic. To create real change, Rosenthal argues that it is the culture itself that must be altered.

title: FILMS FOR VIEWERS WHO THINK FOR THEMSELVES
description: In the legitimate theater, the phenomenon can be described as preconditioned laughter. The preview audience, seeing a new Off Broadway comedy about which there's been no advance word, responds with more dutiful applause than unrestrained pleasure. One week later, after the rave reviews have come in, the audience, which now knows it's about to experience what some wordsmith has described as ''the year's biggest mirthquake,'' will begin to laugh at its first sight of the set.

title: U.S. Navy Searches Off Egypt For Sunken Israeli Submarine
description: A United States Navy airplane criss-crossed Egyptian waters north of Alexandria today in search of an Israeli submarine that sank 18 years ago, airport sources said.

title: 'I DON'T BELIEVE IN KINDLY HUMOR'
description: ''Button-cute, rapier-keen, wafer-thin, pauper-poor is S. J. Perelman,'' wrote the humorist, caricaturing both himself and Time magazine style. ''He raises turkeys which he occasionally displays on Broadway.'' This comic disingeniousness is charming enough to forgive Prelman anything, and it was intended to. Perelman's specialty was intellectual burlesque, and his literary high jinks allowed him, like the great performing stage clowns he so admired, to admit his infantile emotions in public and make a good buck in the bargain. In life, as Dorothy Herrmann's frumpy biography, ''S. J. Perelman: A Life,'' amply documents, the writer was also narcissist-nice and erudute-empty.

title: SUBTLE CONTRAST IN CONNECTICUT G.O.P. CANDIDATES
description: In the final days of campaigning before their primary election on Tuesday, the three Republican candidates for governor have sharpened some of their differences on issues.

title: Megan Lynch Marries
description: Megan Maria Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Lynch 3d of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Harrison Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Green of Baltimore.

title: 16 ARE SLAIN, SCORES HURT AS TERRORISTS SPRAY AIRLINER WITH GUNFIRE
description: ARABIC-SPEAKING gunmen took control of a Pan American jumbo jet in Karachi, Pakistan, Friday, and after holding it on the ground for 16 hours, shot scores of passengers and set off grenades in the cabin. Of the 384 people aboard, at least 15, including three Americans, were killed and 127 were wounded, at least 50 of these seriously.

title: Andrew Walter Weds Susan Furman
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday Susan Jane Furman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Furman of Katonah, N.Y., was married to Andrew Wallace Walter, a son of Mrs. J. Gordon Walter of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Mr. Walter. The Revs. Dr. William E. Foley and Arthur W. Hargate performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; The Zaccaro Case
description: A State Supreme Court judge ruled last week that when John A. Zaccaro went looking for a cut-rate loan in 1983, he found it in forbidden territory - an estate for which he was conservator. Judge Edwin Kassoff, saying the lawyer had improperly borrowed $175,000 from the estate of Alice V. Phelan, ordered Mr. Zaccaro to repay an extra $20,000.

title:
ART;
FREILICHER'S INNER VISIONS
description: TO most observers, Jane Freilicher's paintings are realistic studies of landscape or still life. To the artist herself, however, a painting is ''an exploration of how one sees, a representation of the process of seeing,'' rather than a record of the thing seen.

title: IT'S NOT JUST STUDENTS WHO GET FIRST-DAY-OF-SCHOOL JITTERS
description: IT is 8 o'clock on a weekday morning in September, just after Labor Day, and I know I'll soon have it - moderate to severe stage fright as I face my first Introduction to Anthropology class of the fall semester.

title: A LIVELY RACE FOR LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR, TOO
description: REPUBLICANS planning to vote in their gubernatorial primary election Tuesday for Richard C. Bozzuto, Julie D. Belaga or Gerald Labriola will also have another choice to make - Dennis J. Murphy Jr., E. Clayton (Skip) Gengras Jr. or Leo J. Redgate.

title: The Sullivan Campaign
description: Win or lose in his campaign for a Long Island Congressional seat, Michael T. Sullivan seems to be one politician who wants the voters to know what his opponent has to say. Mr. Sullivan, a Democrat, disclosed last week that he had paid four female investigators to meet his Republican opponent, Representative William McGrath, in a Washington bar and secretly record their conversations with him. He said the recordings of Mr. McGrath's chats with the women raised questions about his behavior. Mr. McGrath, who is separated from his wife, denied any wrongdoing and denounced the surveillance as improper and possibly illegal. Representative George C. Wortley of Syracuse, a friend of Mr. McGrath's who turned up on one of the tapes, assailed the Sullivan tactic as ''disgraceful, cheap, back-alley kind of stuff.''

title: Turkish Police Arrest Bahais
description: Turkish police detained 150 people today after halting a convention of believers in the Bahai faith at a hotel in western Turkey, the independent Hurriyet news agency said. The rooms of 10 Iranian Bahais living in Turkey were searched and books and pamphlets taken away. The constitution of Turkey enshrines religious freedom but activities of non-Moslems often come under pressure.

title: WARNING OF URBAN SCHOOL DECLINE
description: Problems facing urban schools will worsen unless more money is spent to feed hungry children and nurture their intellects in the early years, the educator Ernest L. Boyer says.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: LEONID KOGAN: INTERPRETATIONS With Nina Kogan, piano, Kultur, 60 minutes. $29.95

title: The Tax Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: The Revival of the 'Can't Lose' Stock
description: The notion that some stocks are too wonderful to part with - at any price - has been out of favor since the early 1970's, when the favorite overpriced growth stocks of institutional money managers collapsed. But the case for so-called one-decision stocks - growth companies that money managers should only decide to buy, and never decide to sell -was revived in a recent strategy commentary by a prominent technology analyst.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THE worst of the weekending season is over, dormant until next spring, when it will again burst into bloom. The most relieved people are not, as one might imagine, either hosts or guests, who often return to the city more exhausted than when they left. The most relieved people are the men and women who reject bids to spend ''pure air'' weekends in the country, in the mountains or on the water. These people, and their numbers are not minuscule, can now look forward to the blissful months in which they will not be forced to lie to hospitable friends and acquaintances, or in which they will, at least, have one less lie to tell.

title: AWAITING THE 'NEW' CARNEGIE AND LOTS OF GUEST CONDUCTORS
description: The season in classical music will be distinguished by a place and a person who won't be there, at least part of the time. Carnegie Hall, a focal point of the city's concert life, is still being refurbished and will only reopen in mid-December, thus dispersing some key events to other halls in the fall (for instance, the Berlin Philharmonic on Oct. 19 at the Metropolitan Opera House) and making for an especially dense Carnegie Hall schedule in the winter and spring, with some traditional events (for example the hall's own concert-opera series) squeezed out altogether.

title: D. B. Coggeshall And Ms. Christy To Marry Oct. 5
description: Arthur Hill Christy of New York and Muriel H. Christy of St. Michael, Barbados, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Christy, to David Bayard Coggeshall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bayard Coggeshall of Mendham, N.J. An Oct. 5 wedding is planned.

title: DANGERS FORESEEN IN HOST-LIABILITY LAW
description: The true aftermath of the state Supreme Court's host-liability decision is yet to be felt, and passage of such a bill in any form, as is now being deliberated in the Legislature, shall surely cause havoc beyond our comprehension.

title: Notre Dame Spirit Builds For a Fresh Start
description: AT 8 o'clock in the morning, in the fog of the beginning of her first football Saturday as a student at St. Mary's College, Lisa Pycik of nearby Granger, Ind., received a formal introduction to the Notre Dame experience that was as subtle as a blindside tackle.

title: Van Cliburn's Career
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVER-FATTER BUSINESS OF THINNESS
description: ''THOUSANDS of Women Get Back Girlish Figures on Incredible Super Diet.'' . . . ''New Medical Breakthrough! Lose Up to 50 Pounds Without Dieting.'' . . . ''All the Figure Toning of 3,000 Sit-Ups Without Moving an Inch.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IT doesn't hurt when writing a popular biography of a captain of industry to relieve the solemnity of the list of achievements with scandalous tales of the captain's private life.

title: JESUS IN THE CONFUCIAN TEMPLE
description: CHINA AND THE CHRISTIAN IMPACT A Conflict of Cultures. By Jacques Gernet. Translated by Janet Lloyd. 310 pp. New York: Editions de la Maison des Sciences de l'Homme/ Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $49.50. Paper, $17.95.

title: 'MOUSETRAP': KILLINGLY CLEVER
description: ''THE MOUSETRAP,'' Agatha Christie's perpetually running play, is based on a radio sketch written to commemorate the 80th birthday of Queen Mary. The play made its debut in London in 1952 and has been breaking theatrical records ever since at the same theater where it opened.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CABALIST. By Amanda Prantera. (Atheneum, $12.95.) Amanda Prantera's second novel examines the final weeks in the life of Joseph Kestler, a magician and scholar in the occult arts of the cabala.

title: Prosecutors Say They Have Tapes Condemning Gotti
description: The defense cried foul, but law enforcement experts were admiring: For more than two years, according to court papers unsealed last week, a ''soldier'' in the Gambino organized crime family cooperated with the New York State Organized Crime Task Force by wearing a secret recording device in the company of other organized crime figures.

title: WHY A DIAMOND CARTEL IS FOREVER
description: SOON after Cecil Rhodes showed up on the diamond fields of South Africa in 1871, he seized on the business concept that still drives the diamond industry worldwide: monopoly.

title: TAOS
description: Visitors to Taos are often surprised at how small it is, and at how quickly the streets of art galleries and boutiques run into green fields and expanses of silver-green llano. To the west extends the high desert plain, interrupted only by the jagged gash of the Rio Grande Gorge; to the north and east abruptly rise the Rockies: Taos Mountain, Wheeler Peak, the three Truchas peaks. Over this wide expanse stretches an even wider sky. As if in response to the overwhelming setting, Taosenos over the centuries have put down strong cultural roots. Today's community of 4,500 retains a composite identity as Indian Pueblo, Spanish Colonial outpost, frontier village, art center, resort and small Western town. Getting There Most visitors arrive from Albuquerque where major airlines offer round-trip fares from New York starting at $258. From the airport to Taos, Faust's Transportation (505-758-3410) runs a daily shuttle at 5:30 P.M. and returns at 9 A.M. ($30.75 one way; reservations necessary).

title: U.S. ISSUES THREAT IN TALKS ON TRADE
description: A senior Reagan Administration official warned today that the United States would pull out of planned new global trade talks this month unless other nations gave priority to freeing trade in two key areas for the American economy.

title: LIBRARY FIRE IN LOS ANGELES IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: As book specialists picked through the brittle remains of a fire at the Los Angeles Central Library, investigators tried today to determine whether it had been set by the same person who set a disastrous fire there in April.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: DICK CLARK: THE BEST OF BANDSTAND. Vestron Music Video, 60 minutes. $29.95

title: LADY'S SECRET TAKES MASKETTE
description: Lady's Secret, the best filly in the country and perhaps the best of this decade, trounced five rivals while blazing a mile in 1:33 2/5 to win the $112,600 Maskette Stakes by seven lengths yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Going Away
description: To the Editor: The article reminds me, along with a number of other articles and letters this year, of the typical Midwesterner's mistrust and fear of New York and New Yorkers: ''Watch your purse,'' ''Count your change,'' ''Don't ride the subways,'' ''Take a taxi after 6 P.M.'' ''Never go anywhere alone,'' and so forth.

title: HOPE DIM FOR RUSSIAN ACCEPTED BY BOSTON U.
description: Boston University officials say they harbored no illusions last spring that 18-year-old Boris Lifshitz of Leningrad could accept the university's offer of admission. He was, after all, the son of a Soviet Jewish dissident and therefore had little chance of securing an exit visa.

title: Paul Larkin Harchett Marries Diana Adams
description: Diana Woodman Adams and Paul Larkin Hatchett were married yesterday by the Rev. James C. Blackburn at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Timothy J. Adams of Washington and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Jones Hatchett Jr. of Yazoo City, Miss.

title: JOHN PAUL'S ECONOMICS OF COMPASSION
description: IT was the last night of Pope John Paul II's first pontifical journey abroad. For most of a week he had been traveling through Mexico, a very poor and very Catholic country. That night, according to a close aide, the Pope stayed awake rewriting a speech he was scheduled to deliver the next day before a crowd of workers in the industrial city of Monterrey.

title: IN THE AUVERGNE, CLASSIC POTATOES
description: Potatoes have long been a specialty of the cuisine of the rugged Auvergne region of central France.

title: SANCTIONS TEST METTLE OF LEADERS AT HARARE
description: HEADS of state and other officials of the 101 members of the Nonaligned Movement celebrated the organization's 25th year last week in this well-tended southern African city, amid congratulatory statements mixed with strident calls to self-destruct.

title: G.G. Pardun Wed To Anne Stearns
description: Anne McArthur Stearns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stearns Jr. of Haddam, Conn., and Point O'Woods, L.I., was married yesterday to Gary G. Pardun, a son of Mrs. Clyde Leasure of North Brunswick, N.J., and George Pardun of Bricktown, N.J. Bishop John S. Spong of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony at the Church at Point O'Woods.

title: Teachers Can Still Learn a Few Useful Things About Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICAL GAINS FOR BLACKS LAG IN STATE LEGISLATURES
description: THE announcement last month of another substantial increase in the number of black elected officials in the United States has renewed speculation that the Irish record of entering politics as a means of overcoming poverty and discrimination will soon be rivaled. But the figures also pointed up a major barrier to black political achievement that other ethnic groups did not face - the unwillingness of the white majority, except in unusual circumstances, to vote for blacks running against whites.

title: CYCLING STATURE IS SOUGHT
description: REMEMBER Frank Kramer? The Top Athlete?

title: WHY WE WERE IN INCHON
description: THE KOREAN WAR Challenges in Crisis, Credibility, and Command. By Burton I. Kaufman. Maps. 381 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $34.95.

title: 6 SUSPENDED AT KARACHI AIRPORT
description: At least six members of the Karachi airport security force have been suspended for negligence in allowing the hijackers of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet to drive onto the tarmac in a van disguised to look like an official security van, official sources at the airport disclosed yesterday.

title: Adults or Young Adults
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW PONTIFICATE MEDAL IS ISSUED FROM THE VATICAN
description: The Vatican has issued an unusual medal to mark the eighth year of Pope John Paul II's pontificate. The medal also commemorates the 20th anniversary of the closing of the Second Vatican Council.

title: Jersey City Is Shaping Vast Project To Its Needs
description: OF all the developments proposed for New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront, none is bigger, brasher or busier than Newport City, the 250-acre complex atop the Holland Tunnel in Jersey City.

title: OIL INDUSTRY IS PRESSING FOR CALIFORNIA DEPOSITS
description: Despite depressed prices, a world petroleum surplus and other problems, the oil industry is pressing to gain access to what it says are billions of barrels of oil off California before the Reagan Administration leaves office.

title: No Headline
description: FOR many years, the process of having a development approved on the East End was a routine one, often completed within a few months. But a recently approved project that took over three years to complete illustrates that things have changed.

title: MAJOR DIRECTORS OFFERING THEIR WARES
description: The brew of films that Hollywood has cooked up for fall and winter is thick with the talent of major directors. Martin Scorsese, Francis Coppola, Roland Joffe, Peter Weir, Bruce Beresford, Sidney Lumet, Blake Edwards and Franco Zeffirelli all have new films opening this season. In addition, there are adaptations of Broadway productions, screenplays based on best-selling novels and a number of interesting independent American films, several of which are opening at the New York Film Festival, which begins on Sept. 19. There is also the usual full complement of the staples of Hollywood - mysteries, romantic comedies and escapist adventure stories.

title: TRACKING SCENTS
