description: Men discover fragrance in different ways. Some inherit an attachment to a scent from their fathers. Others first received their favorite blend as a gift from a woman - and women continue to be the big purchasers of men's cologne. However, now more men are buying it for themselves. Advertising also has its effects on men and their choices. One cologne is for the man ''who lives on the edge.'' Another is ''where gentle strength triumphs.'' And yet another offers ''the confidence behind the image.''

title: Dance
description: ''Do you suppose they do that for a living?'' a man murmured incredulously at a performance by the Vanaver Caravan. The musicians and dancers of that folk arts company, which opens the season at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Thursday, do look as if they are having too much fun to be working.

title: HAZEL GLUCK: SPECIALIST IN GENERAL
description: WHEN Hazel Frank Gluck walked into the Commissioner's office of the state Department of Transportation late last May, she was about to preside over the first major about-face of Governor Kean's second term.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HORSES AND CHARIOTS

title: Vivian Blumenthal to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Ingrid Blumenthal of Forest Hills, Queens, and Max Blumenthal of Auburn, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Vivian Kate Blumenthal, to Brian Michael Elba, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Elba of New York. Miss Blumenthal is an associate director for WNBC-TV News in New York and her fiance is a news photographer for WBNG-TV in Binghamton, N.Y. The wedding is planned for November.

title: YORKTOWN'S SNAPPING-TURTLE BATTLE
description: YORKTOWN'S Sparkle Lake has always been a popular swimming spot despite considerable algae, but when members of the family Chelydridae showed up in the swimming area last month, the other swimmers dashed for the safety of the beach.

title: DEEP BASS WITHOUT THE BOOM
description: ''If you are going to make predictions, you had better make them often.'' That's what the economist John Kenneth Galbraith used to tell his students. His point was that long views are risky ventures. So, while peering into the future of audio, we will forgo the grandeur of extended prophecy and stick with the short-term forecast.

title: Piniella's Job Is Endangered by Steinbrenner's Bottom Line
description: ''He knows what the deal is. He knows the bottom line.''

title: REAGAN WRITES TO GORBACHEV ABOUT REPORTER
description: President Reagan has sent a message to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, urging the immediate release of an American reporter held in Moscow on suspicion of espionage, Administration officials said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HOUSE OF KANZE. By Nobuko Albery. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The stately, ritualized Noh plays of Japan are not for theatergoers who succumb easily to the fidgets.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: THE LAVENDER HILL MOB: Starring Alec Guinness, Stanley Holloway, Sidney James, Alfie Bass, John Gregson; directed by Charles Crichton, 1950, HBO/Canon Video, 78 minutes. $39.95.

title: PARKING UNIT AIDE REPORTED CORRUPTION IN '82
description: A key official in the city's Parking Violations Bureau warned the Koch administration in 1982 of corruption in the agency, four years before such corruption was discovered independently by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to senior investigators.

title: NONALIGNED ALWAYS LEANED LEFTWARD
description: SEEKING strength through numbers, Yugoslavia's maverick Communist leader, Josip Broz Tito, joined with Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and Sukarno of Indonesia in summoning 21 other leaders, most of them African and Asian, to Belgrade in 1961. The Soviet Union saluted this founding meeting of the Nonaligned Movement by detonating a nuclear test, thus ending a moratorium that leaders of nonnuclear countries had lauded.

title: EUROPEAN AIDES AGREE TO ADOPT PRETORIA SANCTIONS
description: European Community foreign ministers decided today that the 12-nation group should impose sanctions on South Africa because of Pretoria's lack of progress toward the dismantling of apartheid, community diplomats said.

title: Islanders Await Ruling
description: When the Islanders signed Brian Curran to a three-year contract late last month, the deal for the 22-year-old free-agent defenseman left one key point hanging: Who would Curran's former team, the Boston Bruins, get in compensation? After a week of negotiation the matter is still hanging.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the actress who will play the title role in the forthcoming Broadway musical ''Raggedy Ann.'' She is Ivy Austin.

title: Edwin H. Albano, Ex-Coroner
description: Dr. Edwin H. Albano, who was New Jersey's first state medical examiner, died Thursday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Wave of Thefts Of Surgical Suits
description: AS the Hospital Central Services Corporation of Allentown, Pa., sees it, the television serial ''M*A*S*H'' may have touched off a fashion craze for ''scrub'' suits - the loose-fitting green garments that surgeons wear in the operating room.

title: Marta Bouzas Varela Weds Fellow Lawyer
description: Marta Bouzas Varela, a lawyer of the New York law firm Seward & Kissel, and William P. Barbeosch, a lawyer of the New York law firm Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by the Rev. Charles M. Whelan, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Bouzas of Hempstead, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Barbeosch of Dix Hills, L.I.

title: U.N.'S FIRST DAY COVERS AND OTHER NEW ISSUES ON THE SCHEDULE
description: Seldom does the design of a first day envelope overshadow the new stamp. But that will be the case Sept. 19 when the United Nations issues its seventh set of flag stamps and the World Federation of United Nations Associations (Wfuna) releases covers featuring a drawing by Italian film director Federico Fellini.

title: NEW SHOREHAM EVACUATION SITE HUNTED
description: IF the Shoreham nuclear power plant were to go into commercial operation and a major accident occurred, where would people living within the required 10-mile evacuation zone go?

title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS URGE A BIGGER WAR ON TERRORISM
description: Governments and religious groups around the world condemned the attack on a synagogue in Istanbul, Turkey, yesterday and called for increased vigilance and international cooperation to combat terrorism.

title: SINGER STEALS SHOW
description: ''THE East End music scene had practically evaporated,'' a longtime observer, Clyde Ripka, said recently, attributing the situation in part to declining patronage of bars, traditionally an important income source for musicians. ''But,'' he added with the wisdom of hindsight, ''I also think it needed a shot in the arm.''

title: THE IMPERIAL ACADEMY
description: THE HARVARD CENTURY The Making of a University to a Nation. By Richard Norton Smith. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Texas Bans Oyster Fishing
description: The Texas Health Department on Friday banned until Nov. 1 the harvesting of oysters along 115 miles of the Gulf coast near Surfside, which has been plagued by a widespread growth of marine microorganisms, or red tide.

title: NAIL AND MAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Rich Friends
description: WE ALL MOVED TO the neighborhood about the same time - time of year and time of life. Young couples with first houses, planning families to fill them.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: The Merchandise Is Horse-Related Salem Saddlery in North Salem has tripled its former space for displaying equipment and clothing for horses and for riders of all ages and stages, from the backyard beginner or occasional rider to the show circuit. The store is a distributor for Miller's, the Manhattan retailer and wholesale supplier of horse-related merchandise, and supplies owners and commercial stables with hardware, barn supplies and grooming equipment -buckets, soaps, shampoos and hoof dressings.

title: WAR HITS HOME IN SRI LANKAN TOWN
description: For the people who try to go on living here, this picture-postcard port is Sri Lanka's most sensitive barometer of war and peace.

title: HAS LOU PINIELLA DONE THE JOB FOR THE YANKEES?
description: Next Sunday The Times will begin a weekly feature which will appear on the Views of Sport page. The feature will provide a forum for readers to express their opinions on a specific sport issue or topic.

title: THE EVOLUTION OF AN ISLAND OF ACADEME
description: I READ recently that Jackson Pollock's East Hampton house and studio may soon be entrusted to the State University of New York at Stony Brook Foundation. This struck me as a fine example of the marriage of art and academia.

title: CAPE MAY'S DESIGN FOR FALL
description: Autumn softens the scene at the New Jersey shore. The sun's rays, which have been beating down harsh and white through the summer, turn golden and oblique. In the marshes between mainland and barrier islands, the Spartina and Phragmites grasses take on the same warm hue, especially at sunset. Children have returned to school, siphoning off the summer crowds. Life moves more slowly and quietly. This is an ideal time to explore the town of Cape May and its environs at the state's southern tip.

title: Art
description: The Whitney Museum of American Arts's juxtaposition of ''James Rosenquist Paintings: 1961-1985'' - through Sept. 21 - and ''Shaker Design,'' which closed recently, was as instructive in its own way as the Whitney's juxtaposition earlier this year of exhibitions of Eric Fischl and Alex Katz.

title: Another Dispute Between the Pope And U.S. Catholics
description: The Vatican and the American Catholic Church, already on uneasy terms, have a new point of contention. Last week Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen of Seattle announced that, after a two-year investigation ordered by Pope John Paul II, he had been stripped of his ''decision-making power'' on such moral issues as birth control and homosexuality. The next day 140 Catholic leaders demanded an explanation.

title: RESORT PLANNING VETERANS REUNION
description: FORTY-FOUR years ago, Atlantic City officially became the Army Air Force's Basic Training Center. Its hotels were transformed into barracks, Convention Hall became a training and parade center, and Haddon Hall Hotel was turned into the country's largest military hospital, England General.

title: FREDERICK EBERSTADT: ECLECTIC CHOICES
description: Frederick Eberstadt does not believe that a stylish man must pay his dues in front of a mirror.

title: SEPTEMBER: THE MOST BITTERSWEET MOF MONTHS...
description: COULD it be September already?

title: DRUG TRAFFICKERS TURN TO THAILAND
description: As marijuana production in the Western Hemisphere gradually drops through crop eradication, American drug traffickers are turning Thailand's poor farmers into new suppliers, according to Thai and international narcotics officials.

title: MIAMI BEATS FLORIDA AS PASSING FIZZLES
description: It has been traditional in football that most offensive linemen toil in obscurity while quarterbacks and receivers reap the fruits of their labor. Usually, this is a sore point for linemen. But today, obscurity may have been a blessing for Florida's offensive line, which was thrashed relentlessly by Miami's defensive front as Miami won, 23-15.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WATERCOLORS OF HOMER The Yale University Art Gallery will commemorate Winslow Homer's 150th birthday with an exhibition of more than 90 of his watercolors, opening Thursday and running through Nov. 2. Organized by Helen A. Cooper, curator of American paintings and sculpture, the Yale showing is the only stop in the Northeast on an I.B.M.-sponsored tour. The exhibition opened last March at the National Gallery of Art in Washington and was seen at the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the season's forthcoming movies misidentifies the screen writer of ''Square Dance'' and two actors in Jim Jarmusch's ''Down by Law.''

title: Alex Weiss Goldstein Married to Amy Sue Berns
description: At the Harrison (N.Y.) Jewish Community Center yesterday Amy Sue Berns, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald S. Berns of Albany, was married to Alex Weiss Goldstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin I. Goldstein of Atlanta. Rabbi Moshe Bomzer, assisted by Cantor Usher Fogel, performed the ceremony.

title: Tennis Logic Doesn't Hold
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dolphins Ban Charles
description: Mike Charles, the Miami Dolphins' nose tackle, was suspended yesterday for four games for being late to practice for the second time in a week, Coach Don Shula said.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: A BANNER held by a winged figure on the municipal seal of Milledgeville, Ga., became the focus of a court dispute when a teacher objected to one of the two words on the banner: ''Christianity.'' The other word was ''Liberty.''

title: JAZZ RESURGENCE CONTINUES
description: On stage and on records, jazz has been gathering momentum through the 1980's. Young, well-trained players, who might have been drawn to pop-jazz or fusion, are returning to straight-ahead jazz, while musicians who scraped through the 1970's have begun to establish themselves, and players who emerged in the 1950's and 1960's are returning as elder statesmen.

title: BLACK LEADERS SEEK CHANGES IN EDUCATION
description: BLACK leaders from around New Jersey, meeting here last week for the fourth annual Black Issues Conventin, called for the state to more closely monitor and improve education in urban public schools.

title: RUTGERS SETS BACK BOSTON COLLEGE, 11-9
description: All the elements of an upset came together for Rutgers today as the Scarlet Knights defeated Boston College, 11-9, their first victory over the Eagles after five straight defeats beginning in 1981.

title: Virginia Finch Becomes the Bride of Scott Taylor
description: At Grace Church in New York yesterday Virginia Courtney Finch, the daughter of Mrs. Harry Clinton Finch of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Mr. Finch, was married to Scott Frazier Taylor, a son of Mrs. Robert Frazier Taylor of Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Taylor. The Rev. Ross Wright performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS TO MARK '46 U.S. ARRIVAL
description: There is a sense of urgency to Benjamin Meed's words - every day more witnesses are being lost.

title: TEAM AIDS CHILDREN WITH CHRONIC PAIN
description: LISA GIAMALIS, an active 10-year-old, came home from school one day last spring complaining that her right arm hurt. By morning she could barely lift it.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
For Morristown, Up Is the Way to Go
description: WHEN Interstate 287 was constructed more than a decade ago, it cut through a residential portion of Morristown, resulting in the razing of many stately old homes and clearing the way for developers to build office buildings beside the roadway.

title: SCHOLARS TACKLE 'WHODUNITS'
description: CURLING up with a cunning mystery novel used to be a clandestine affair for them.

title: Bombings Rock Chile After Mass Protest
description: Dozens of bombs blew up overnight in Chile after two days of protests against the military Government in which three people died and more than 20 were injured, police sources said.

title: Going Anyway
description: To the Editor: In response to ''Going Anyway - the Decision Not to Cancel'' (Travel, Aug. 10): I should like to add our own adventures. We too were unwilling to cancel our yearly European vacation since it had been set since January and we were the proud possessors of soon-to-expire free international vouchers on T.W.A. Despite pressure from our usually blase older children and worried parents (friends even accused us of having a death wish and I was asked to clear up everything on my desk at work) we left for Greece, landing at Athens Airport May 24th, not long after the Chernobyl disaster.

title: LEIGH AND LESLIE KENO: CLASSIC CLOTHING
description: At 29, identical twins Leigh and Leslie Keno do not, of course, dress identically. That, they will tell you, they stopped doing when they entered adolescence. Still, similarities in style abound between the two brothers - both of whom live on Manhattan's Upper East Side and work in the American antiques market - right down to their taste for Hermes ties and bright suspenders, which they both prefer to belts. Their suits - classic, discreet and perfectly fitted - are cut by the same tailor, and when they recently purchased new eyeglasses, they independently picked out the same frames from the same shop.

title: Peat Marwick Finds a European Partner
description: The biggest accounting firm in the world would be formed in the proposed merger of Peat Marwick and Klynveld Main Goerdeler, the big European firm. Ernst & Whinney, Arthur Andersen and Deloitte, Haskins had all approached KMG about a merger, but analysts say the fit with Peat Marwick, which was No. 2 behind Arthur Andersen, made for better economies of scale and was more complementary. Although talks had gone on for more than a year, details still must be worked out. The chairman of Peat Marwick's American operations, Larry D. Horner, would be chairman of the combined American operations; the chairman of KMG's American subsidiary, Main Hurdman, would be vice chairman.

title: RHODE ISLAND MOVES TO CURB U.S. FUNDS IN PAROCHIAL SCHOOLS
description: Parochial schools here would be barred from using Federal money for religious purposes under the settlement of a lawsuit against education officials.

title: PARKINSON GROUP'S PLANS FOR HELP
description: Re the article ''Helping Parkinson's Families Cope'' on Aug. 17:

title: DEVELOPMENT PROMPTS HUNT CLUB TO SEEK A MOVE
description: MORE and more now, the meadows where brightly clad hunters ride tall horses, accompanied by packs of hounds, are dotted with newly built houses. The fields are bordered by cars whizzing along Route 25, their noise drowning out the early-morning singing of the crickets and muffling the blare of the huntsman's horn.

title: BEARS' NATURAL ENEMIES: INJURY, COMPLACENCY, FATE
description: IT wasn't vintage iambic pentameter and the jingle didn't win any Grammys, but it spoke rhythmic volumes of what the Bears were all about. We are the Bears' shufflin' crew, Shufflin' on down, doing it for you. We're so bad we know we're good, Blowin' your minds like we knew we would.

title: MINGLING THE TRIVIAL AND VITAL OF THE DAY
description: MY family and I spent a week in Maine this summer, and while we were planning the trip, we racked our brains trying to remember the name of the inn at which we stayed several years ago. Finally I thought to check my diary.

title: PRODUCTION DAZZELS IN CANDLEWOOD'S 'SUPERSTAR'
description: THE Candlewood Playhouse producers know how to give audiences the old razzle-dazzle. Look at ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' for a flash of rather new-fangled pizzazz.

title: POOLS, HILLS AND SO-SO SKILLS
description: IT is time to disabuse the hunting and fishing public of the notion that those who write about these sports are highly skilled in their practice.

title: Tax Law Alters Use By Elderly
description: TWO concepts that enable elderly people to raise cash on the equity in their homes will probably be affected by proposed changes in the Federal tax code.

title: Powerboat Market Is Surging
description: The availability of low-interest financing and inexpensive fuel has been a boon to powerboat manufacturers, who are stocking the fall boat shows with yachts of every description.

title: FIFTEEN MINUTES IS NEVER ENOUGH
description: THE FRENZY OF RENOWN Fame & Its History. By Leo Braudy. Illustrated. 649 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50.

title: TEEN-AGE PROSTITUTION ALARMS LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS
description: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials in and near this resort city are concerned about the growing involvement of adolescents in prostitution.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BRADFORD PEAR: TREE FOR THE CITIES
description: THE callery pear has shiny, deep green foliage and is resistent to fire blight, a bacterial disease that can destroy most pears. The callery pear bears white flowers in the spring, although the flowers are somewhat hidden among the leaves that emerge before they bloom. Its modest 20- to 30-foot height makes the pear well adapted for small gardens and other sites with limited space. Many individual plants produce a striking fall color that may range from crimson to wine purple. The fruits are small and insignificant, so they do not make a mess that must be cleaned up.

title: Dean Paul Baquet Marries Miss Landis in Larchmont
description: The marriage of Dylan F. Landis to Dean Paul Baquet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Baquet of New Orleans, took place last night in Larchmont, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Landis. Rabbi Edward Schecter officiated.

title: A 'NICKLEBY' THAT FULFILLS OUR GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: To understand why the Royal Shakespeare Company's new ''Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' is different, more entertaining and even more Dickensian than the version that first played Broadway in 1981, don't bother to draw up a checklist of the 200-odd characters in the eight-hour-plus piece and compare the two casts' merits in the roles. In fact, such a strict accounting might slightly favor the original troupe, some of whose performances (David Threlfall as the battered orphan Smike, Edward Petherbridge as the tipsy clerk Newman Noggs) will haunt the public memory forever. But the alchemy of theater is not a matter of mathematics. Sometimes the alteration of a few elements in a large stage production, or a change in cultural climate inside or out of the playhouse, can have a disproportionately catalytic effect. While the ''Nickleby'' that slipped into the Broadhurst during the August dog days often looks like a conscientious duplicate of the original rendering, it turns out to be a fresh and unforgettable achievement of its own.

title: Recent Sales
description: Little Falls $120,000 51 Woodcliff Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old split-level; hardwood floors, wood-shingle exterior; taxes $2,157. Livingston $267,500 7 Stonewall Drive 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; family room, fireplace, dining room, garage; taxes $3,692.

title: THE WELL-MADE SUIT
description: The style of the suit has varied through the years, but the standards for judging quality have remained remarkably consistent. Good fabrics and fine tailoring are the enduring distinctions, and comfort is the result.

title: Lawyers Get $6.3 Million In Buck Trust Fund Case
description: Lawyers who successfully fought a move to spread the $435 million Buck Trust fund among charities outside Marin County have been awarded $6.3 million in legal fees.

title: COMMUTER IVAN EXPLAINS
description: HOW fitting, on the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, to have the huddled masses of European tennis congregating at center court of the United States Open. Is Miss Liberty really holding a torch, or preparing a forehand smash?

title: AT LONG LAST, FOCUS RETURNS TO THE FIELD
description: THE trial is over. The other league is gone. The police blotter is clean.

title: XENOPHOBIC RUSSIANS ARE LOATH TO MEET THE PRESS
description: SOVIET authorities, hypersensitive to their country's image abroad and the inheritors of a centuries-old xenophobic tradition,have long made it difficult for foreign journalists to work here.

title: IMMIGRATION AIDES SEEK MONEY TO STOP TERRORISTS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is proposing major new programs in two areas: to prevent terrorists from entering the United States and to capture and expel aliens who sell illegal drugs or commit other crimes in this country.

title: Velazquez and the Centuries
description: To the Editor:

title: READERS, WRITERS AND LITERARY MACHINES
description: This essay was adapted from a lecture by Italo Calvino delivered in Italy in 1967. Mr. Calvino died in Siena, Italy, last September.

title: POSTINGS: Saving Time; Passaic Modulars
description: The modern technology of building modular homes is invading two neighborhoods of large, traditional single-family houses in Passaic, N.J.

title: SHOPPING AROUND FOR GOOD HEALTH
description: Each year, more attention is being paid to keeping travelers healthy when far from home and to providing competent emergency assistance in case of accident or illness. Throughout the United States, numerous clinics and private companies have emerged to advise on what precautions to take before going abroad and to promise help when it is urgently needed. In fact, so much advice and promises of protection are available that it can take careful consideration and shopping around to determine what you really need.

title: PRIEST AIDS HISPANIC COMMUNITY
description: THE Rev. Francis McQuade traveled to the Dominican Republic several years ago, when he was in the seminary, to improve his Spanish at the request of his bishop.

title: Iran Intercepts Russian Vessels
description: The Iranian Navy seems to rule the waves in the Persian Gulf.

title: REAGAN SAYS NATION'S SCHOOLS HAVE IMPROVED CONSIDERABLY
description: President Reagan said today that after years of ''serious trouble'' the nation's schools had improved dramatically in his years in the White House.

title: Music
description: There is currently much discussion - pro and con - about the ongoing search for ''authentic'' performance styles of music up to and including works of the Romantic era. Complete agreement about so iffy a subject will probably never be realized, but even those who think they would rather keep everything sounding the way they first heard it have to admit on occasion that some musicologically informed approaches have resulted in pleasant performance surprises.

title: POSTINGS: New From Sweden; Aquavit on 54th
description: A landmarked town house at 13 West 54th Street, long owned by the Rockefellers and now a magnet for Swedish interests in New York, will become the city's newest Swedish restaurant next spring.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BAD KARMA: A True Story of Obsession and Murder. By Deborah Blum. (Atheneum, $17.95.) This is a routinely written account of the disturbing events that led to the 1969 shooting and stabbing death of Tanya Tarasoff, a freshman at the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Margaret Warner Weds John R. Reilly
description: Margaret Garrard Warner, a White House correspondent for Newsweek magazine, was married yesterday to John Richard Reilly, a senior partner in the Washington office of the Chicago law firm of Winston & Strawn and a former Federal Trade Commissioner. The ceremony at St. Peter's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Ogunquit, Me., was performed by Bishop William H. Marion, who is retired from the Diocese of Southwestern Virginia.

title: Peruvians Seize 288 After Guerrilla Bombings
description: Paramilitary policemen arrested 288 people in an overnight sweep after leftist guerrilla bombings rocked the Peruvian capital, killing two watchmen and damaging a gambling casino.

title: Cynthia Manson Wed in Riverdale To Jeffrey Faville
description: Cynthia Ann Manson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Manson of the Riverdale section of the Bronx and Santa Monica, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey James Faville, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Faville of Portland, Ore. The Riverdale Presbyterian Church was the setting for the ceremony, performed by the Rev. David D. Cockcroft.

title: MORE PEOPLE GIVING BLOOD FOR SELVES
description: WHEN Anne Stabile of Larchmont was informed that she would need an operation for an aortic aneurysm - a blocked coronary artery - she chose to donate a pint of her own blood that would be required during surgery.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BRADFORD PEAR: TREE FOR THE CITIES
description: THE callery pear has shiny, deep green foliage and is resistent to fire blight, a bacterial disease that can destroy most pears. The callery pear bears white flowers in the spring, although the flowers are somewhat hidden among the leaves that emerge before they bloom. Its modest 20- to 30-foot height makes the pear well adapted for small gardens and other sites with limited space. Many individual plants produce a striking fall color that may range from crimson to wine purple. The fruits are small and insignificant, so they do not make a mess that must be cleaned up.

title: Janice E. Major And John Battle Exchange Vows
description: Janice Eileen Major, a lawyer, and John Durham Battle, an architect, were married yesterday at St. Martha's Chapel in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Robert C. Franklin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Lend to Prosper
description: America's trade deficit in July was $18 billion, $2 billion higher than the previous record in January. . . . Despite a 30 percent decline in the dollar, sales abroad in 1986 are no better than in 1985. . . . Clayton Yeutter, the U.S. Trade Representative, foresees no improvement soon and warns of further depreciation in the dollar.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A PASSION FOR FRIENDS: Toward a Philosophy of Female Affection. By Janice G. Raymond. (Beacon, $22.95.) This is an unsentimental, playful yet sobering look at female friendship through the ages.

title: DISCARDING TRICKS TO AVOID AN ENDPLAY
description: Some 60 years ago, in the Canal Zone, a nameless young woman marched into the history of the game by gatecrashing the first recorded session of contract bridge. She gave Harold Vanderbilt the word ''vulnerable'' and disappeared, to his relief.

title: MAO, NIETZSCHE AND UNCLE SVEN
description: STORIES OF HAPPY PEOPLE By Lars Gustafsson. Translated by Yvonne L. Sandstroem and John Weinstock. 134 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: Building a 'Taxi Meter' Into the PC
description: I HAVE a vision of a large taxi meter sitting beside the telephone on the expansive mahogany desk gracing the office of Margaret Farrell, my attorney. Having visited her office on a number of occasions, I am fully aware that my mental image in no way jibes with reality. All the same, every time I pick up the phone to present my lawyer with yet another of the curious conundrums that seem to tie my legal life in knots - horse thieves and subsequently state troopers overrunning our farm, or South Florida dope smugglers absconding with one of my leased airplanes - I hear that meter ticking, at a billing rate capable of making a cab trip from Manhattan to the Hamptons seem cheap by comparison. Then again, I wouldn't trust a cabbie's advice on matters the likes of which I refer to my attorney.

title: CONSTRUCTION CALLED ILLEGAL ALIEN 'MAGNET'
description: THE words carved in the benches of the detention rooms at the Immigration and Naturalization Service office here tell the story: Mexico, Colombia, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Ecuador, Peru, Uganda.

title: MYSTERY WRITERS DISSECT THEIR CRAFT
description: ALL of the tables in Adam Adamo's elegant Upper East Side restaurant are rectangular except one. This one, nestled in a corner in a back dining room, is Adam's Round Table, and its uniqueness lies less in its shape and possession of a name than in its regular patrons.

title: LIVING FOR CHILDREN: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: It would be interesting to know what Joan Baum [ ''Living for the Children Isn't Living,'' Opinion Page, Aug. 24 ] thinks is worth living for, if not one's children.

title: VISITORS, ANNIVERSARIES AND PREMIERES GALORE
description: This is the dance season in which the Russians return, with the Moiseyev Dance Company now at the Metropolitan Opera House and the Bolshoi Ballet following in June. It is a season of anniversaries, among them birthday celebrations for the Erick Hawkins Dance Company and the Joffrey Ballet and its resident choreographer, Gerald Arpino. There will be some interesting dance festivals, and an unofficial, three-venue celebration of the choreographer Mark Morris.

title: Article 142786 -- No Title
description: Vice President Bush's political action committee raised $8.2 million in the 18-month period ended June 30, several times what any other prospective Presidential candidate raised, according to figures made public today by the Federal Election Commission.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AS THE AIRLINES MERGE;
AN INDUSTRY STILL AS COMPETITIVE AS ANY
description: RECENT mergers and bankruptcies in the airline industry have led some experts to call for renewed Government regulation of fares and routes. This reaction comes despite numerous studies showing that deregulation has produced more efficient airlines, substantially lower fares and improved service for most cities. This has been achieved despite restrictions on air traffic, a deep recession followed by sluggish growth and wildly fluctuating fuel costs.

title:
ART;
WORKS BY SULTAN AND GERMAN EXPRESSIONISTS AT WESLEYAN
description: DONALD SULTAN is one of the fabled young American artists on top of the heap, both artistically and financially. To get to that position these days one must be audacious, but Mr. Sultan's brand of audacity is a quiet one. In the last 10 years, his work has revealed a steady growth, but it is mainly a growth in seductiveness. His modus operandi has stayed the same.

title: Jennifer Watson Wed in Scarsdale
description: Jennifer Kathryn Watson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Watson Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and New Suffolk, L.I., and Domenic A. Marino, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan D. Marino of Thornwood, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd performed the ceremony at St. James the Less Episcopal Church in Scarsdale.

title: HOFSTRA AND JETS: GOOD TEAMWORK
description: INCONSPICUOUS among the road signs on the Hofstra University campus is one that reads simply ''Weeb Ewbank Hall.''

title: DISAFFECTION WITH QADDAFI IS REPORTED RISING IN LIBYA
description: Popular disaffection with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is growing inside Libya, threatening to undermine his regime, according to many Libyans and foreigners here.

title: LAKE TO LAKE IN MINNESOTA
description: About half an hour outside Minneapolis the countryside gets wide and green, speckled with wild flowers. Full fields of daisies and dandelions and thistles shimmer in lonesome display. The sky opens up to a huge dome of blue, punctuated with puffy cloud formations. The feeling of space and order is striking, especially in contrast to the city we had left behind.

title: A RENEWED LAKE ERIE AGAIN ONE OF THE GREATS
description: TWENTY years ago, the western end of Lake Erie was choked with foul-smelling algae, and dead fish littered the shoreline. Some scientists predicted that the lake's death was imminent. But as Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio proclaimed in a ceremony on an excursion boat in this South Bass Island port last week, Lake Erie has made a comeback. As if in testimonial, dozens of boats bobbed nearby, filled with fishermen.

title: PANDICK'S STRANGE SLIDE
description: Pandick Inc., the nation's largest financial printer, usually rides high when a strong stock market bolsters demand for new-issue prospectuses, tender documents, proxies, and other financial paper. But the company's shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, were changing hands last week at around $15, near the 52-week low.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TO HELP UNDOCUMENTED ALIENS SEEKING ASYLUM
description: Massachusetts is about to spend $250,000 to help undocumented aliens obtain political asylum or prevent their deportation.

title: Greenberg: A Kind of Beacon
description: ONE afternoon about 10 years ago, Hank Greenberg, in tennis togs, stopped beside the pool of a Las Vegas hotel to chat with friends. Greenberg, then 65 years old and still vigorous at 6 feet 4 inches and 220 pounds, was there to participate in a celebrity tennis tournament.

title: Both Parties Face Runoffs in Florida
description: In Florida, where economic growth has been propelled in large part by an influx of retired people and white-collar workers from other regions, politics often reflects national as much as regional trends. It did so again in the Republican and Democratic gubernatorial primaries last week.

title: Miami Archbishop Offers Absolution for Abortions
description: Archbishop Edward A. McCarthy of Miami has issued a pastoral letter offering absolution to people who have had abortions or assisted in performing them.

title: THERE'LL ALWAYS BE A FIJI
description: ON FIJI ISLANDS By Ronald Wright. 257 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: JETS' CAST IS FAMILIAR; Defense Gets A Lift From Six Draftees
description: THE pro football draft is an annual gamble, and most teams think they have done well if four or five of their dozen or so draft choices survive each year.

title: Katherine Wise Is Wed in Maine
description: Katherine Pharibe Wise, a commercial banking officer of the Marine Midland Bank in Wilmington, Del., and the Rev. Donald Jeremiah Hannan 3d, assistant rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del., were married yesterday in Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BRADFORD PEAR: TREE FOR THE CITIES
description: THE callery pear has shiny, deep green foliage and is resistent to fire blight, a bacterial disease that can destroy most pears. The callery pear bears white flowers in the spring, although the flowers are somewhat hidden among the leaves that emerge before they bloom. Its modest 20- to 30-foot height makes the pear well adapted for small gardens and other sites with limited space. Many individual plants produce a striking fall color that may range from crimson to wine purple. The fruits are small and insignificant, so they do not make a mess that must be cleaned up.

title: ITALIAN MILITARY SCANDALS SPUR CALL FOR CHANGE
description: First there were several suicides in barracks and revelations of violent hazing. Then a general cursed at his troops. And now three soldiers are dead after an accident during maneuvers.

title: Shift in Work Force Goes With Rising Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: NICARAGUA FINDS C.I.A. BEHIND EVERY MISHAP
description: THE rains were late this year, and the pro-Sandinista newspaper Nuevo Diario said it knew why. Under a banner headline Aug. 10, the paper said the drought had been created artificially by United States agents working out of a secret American base at Tiger Island in the Gulf of Fonseca, which borders Nicaragua, Honduras and El Salvador.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We are at one of those critical points in economic history where we will either take some steps together to move forward or we will risk sliding backwards.'' - Paul A. Volcker, Federal Reserve chairman, on need to stimulate growth worldwide.

title: ARTIFACTS OF THE MACHINE AGE
description: The explosion of technological creativity that occurred between 1840 and 1940 dramatically altered the look of what most museums and collectors explore these days, including Navajo blankets, Victorian jewelry, bentwood furniture, metal toys, weathervanes and Bakelite radios. The extraordinary results of this activity - and how artists and designers reacted against industrialization - are the subject of eight museum exhibitions and two fairs that will focus this season on this our innovative and turbulent century.

title: FRANK CASHEN: THE MAN
description: Frank Cashen may be the front office genius Bruce Weber paints, but he is also the general manager who pulled the most monumental boner in the history of major-league baseball. This, of course, was Cashen's failure to protect Tom Seaver in the compensation draft in January 1984.

title: Dr. J. R. Boscamp Weds Dr. Kimura
description: Dr. Yukiko Kimura, a pediatrician, and Dr. Jeffrey Richard Boscamp, a fellow in infectious diseases at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Ralph Dorre performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THREE thousand six hundred and forty-nine days later, Paul thought, and here I am back in a bar listening to a drunk telling me everything I want to hear, but I'm looking at his glass and thinking how easy it would be to pick it up and drink all that Scotch down.

title: 2 GUNMEN KILL 21 IN SYNAGOGUE; BAR DOORS AND THEN OPEN FIRE AT SABBATH SERVICE IN ISTANBUL
description: Two Arab terrorists invaded a Sephardic synagogue during Sabbath services in the Jewish quarter here today and, after locking the doors with iron bars, attacked the congregation with submachine guns and hand grenades.

title: HUMAN FACTOR NOTED IN CORPORATE TAKEOVERS
description: More than 400 years ago, Machiavelli outlined the way to deal with a conquered state: First, replace officers of the old regime with officers loyal to the conqueror.

title: A METAPHOR IS A TERRIBLE THING TO WASTE
description: Anthony Hecht introduces his collection with a figure-in-the-carpet gambit. Though each of its essays was written for a separate occasion -- the earliest in 1962, the most recent year this year -- the volume displays, he says, ''an unexpected coherence, the more surprising in that it was not planned. As to what this coherence consists in,'' he adds, however, ''I had better leave it to others to say.''

title: FALL ARRIVES, BRINGING STRIKES
description: This fall is comparatively peaceful, much better than last year, but the week after Labor Day nonetheless brought teacher strikes that canceled or disrupted classes for more than 120,000 pupils around the nation.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Development's office of business advocacy will offer an eight-week course beginning Sept. 22 on how to obtain state construction permits.

title: LEGITIMATE DEGREES PUT TO ILLEGITIMATE USES
description: Although the word is definitely out about ''self-styled'' nutritionists,'' many people still do not know what questions to ask to evaluate the credentials of the practitioners they encounter. The Bustany article helped, but it would be much easier if legislation were passed in New Jersey to license nutrition professionals so one could just look for the designation ''licensed nutritionist.'' ROBYN L. FLIPSE

title: Houseboats Emerge as a Cheaper Form of Housing
description: IF you are looking for a home away from home for recreation and investment, you might do well to consider buying a houseboat. And, if some people can be believed, having a houseboat as a primary residence is the only way to live.

title: METAMORPHOSIS OF A MUSICAL BEING STAGED WAY OFF BROADWAY
description: WANTED: 15 to 20 alien visitors to earth. Singing and dancing a must.

title: Miss Eyster Married To Hart Woodson 3d
description: Jenifer Nelson Eyster, producer of Earl Ubell's health and science reports on WCBS-TV, was married yesterday to Anthony Hartswell Woodson 3d, a corporate banking officer of the capital markets group of the Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank in New York. The Rev. J. Thomas Kort performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Maumee, Ohio.

title: DEALING WITH BIAS-CRIME VICTIMS
description: ONE muggy October evening, a longtime resident of a suburban New Jersey community about 25 miles from New York City found on her garage door hate messages left by some unwelcome visitors.

title: Cable TV
description: Two outstanding movies have cable premieres this week on Bravo. In ''Secret Honor'' (1985), an actor named Philip Baker Hall portrays Richard M. Nixon, seated at a White House desk and taping his candid thoughts on a wide variety of subjects. That's the whole one-man show. Directed by Robert Altman and written by Donald Fried and Arnold M. Stone, the project originated Off Broadway. Vincent Canby of The Times called the film version ''fascinating, funny, imaginative and unsettling.'' It's showing on Monday at 9:30 P.M. and 2:30 A.M.

title: PLEASURE BEACH, LUSTER LONG LOST, AWAITS ITS RENEWAL
description: THE blacktop roadway, veined with grass and mined with potholes, winds through a collection of abandoned structures that were once the components of a glittering waterside amusement park. They are solidly covered with graffiti.

title: YUGOSLAV CAPTAIN IS CHARGED
description: The captain of a Yugoslav freighter has been charged with negligent homicide after an accident involving the freighter and a commercial fishing tug in northern Lake Michigan. All three crew members on the 30-foot fishing boat were killed.

title: Cuomo Clashes With Archdiocese
description: The Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York named no names recently when he directed parish priests to bar speakers who disagreed with official Roman Catholic teachings. But Governor Cuomo, a Roman Catholic who has been at odds with leaders of the archdiocese, apparently felt compelled last week to try on the shoe. If it fit, it pinched. In a rapidly escalating exchange of increasingly personal comments on the directive and its implications, the Governor referred to the order as a ''restraint of intellectual activity'' and declared, ''we lay people have a right to be heard.''

title: Steel Workers Picket Armco Factory in Ohio
description: Steel workers picketed Armco's Middletown Works today in the first walkout in the 86-year history of the company's Eastern Steel Division, with no contract negotiations scheduled, officials said.

title:
FOCUS: ST. LOUIS;
A Phoenix In Flight Downtown
description: UNTIL the last 10 years or so, this city -which once gloried in the reputation of being first in booze, first in shoes and last in the American League - was fighting the widespread notion that it had become last in everything. More semi-obituaries had been written about it than any other ''Rust Belt'' city, with the possible exceptions of Cleveland and Newark.

title: Stanley Mitton Weds Ruth Richmond Ray
description: Ruth Richmond Ray, a mezzo-soprano who sings professionlly, was married yesterday to Stanley Mitton, a consultant to the United Nations Disaster Relief Organization and the Church World Service of the National Council of Churches, of which he was formerly the director. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony at the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: ARCHITECTURE THRIVES ON AND OFF THE STREET
description: With buildings being demolished, altered, constructed and finished all around us, the streets of New York themselves are among the best of the many architectural exhibitions this fall and winter. The season offers an instructive display of architecture around town, both outdoors - from Battery Park City to the East Side's Belgravia apartment house - and indoors from the modernist Mario Botta at the Modern to the Cooper-Hewitt's ''Berlin 1900-1933.''

title: INSTRUCTOR AT L.I. COLLEGE AMONG HIJACK VICTIMS
description: Syed Nesar Ahmad, who was killed by Arab terrorists in the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jet in Pakistan Friday, was depicted by a colleague at a Long Island campus where he taught as an ''extremely loving, very compassionate'' person and scholar ''continually searching for a rational means to resolve conflict.''

title: HEIRS TO LONG TRADITION, TURKEY'S JEWS HANG ON
description: Turkey's Jews have had good relations with most Moslem Turks for years, and the Turkish Government has stressed that Jews enjoy ''full rights and citizenship.''

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BACK TO SCHOOL
description: BACK to school. Say it: ''Back to school.'' For some, the words have a nasty tone -like the sound of a door closing. To others, ''back to school'' isn't so bad: it means new beginnings, a new routine - and new clothes.

title: TENSIONS ON RISE AT LEBANON PORT
description: Tension has been rising in the southern Lebanese port city of Sidon between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen since a Palestinian died while in the custody of Amal, the mainstream Shiite organization.

title: LEGISLATURE RETURNING WITH EYES ON '87 RACE
description: THE New Jersey Legislature returns to work tomorrow from its summer recess with a collective eye on the 1987 legislative elections. The Democratic-controlled Senate and Republican-led Assembly have their own agendas for the fall session and each party hopes its performance will play well next year when all 120 legislative seats are contested.

title: THE AMERICAN CLASSROOM FROM A JAPANESE PERSPECTIVE
description: MANY Japanese students are now attending American schools in Westchester, and the number is increasing rapidly. And as this population grows, local school administrators and faculty - as well as Japanese parents - are becoming more aware of the ''communication gap.''

title: THE BIG -- AND ILLEGAL -- BUSINESS OF INDIAN ARTIFACTS
description: ON a warm afternoon early in May, special agents from the United States Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management raided 17 homes and trading posts in Colorado and Utah, and seized 325 American Indian artifacts that they insisted had been stolen from archeological sites on public lands in southeastern Utah.

title: HOW THE MIND LOST ITSELF
description: DEATH OF THE SOUL From Descartes to the Computer. By William Barrett. 173 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: WAYS TO SAVOR THE TASTES OF A LATE-SUMMER GARDEN
description: THIS is the time of the year when the neighbors try to give away their tomatoes.

title: A TIGHT RACE IN THE EAST, AND NO RACE FOR THE BEARS
description: The following conference preview was prepared by Michael Janofsky. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish, with the Giants picked to finish second in the East. EAST: Washington Redskins

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TWO WOMEN IN ONE. By Nawal el-Saadawi. Translated by Osman Nusairi and Jana Gough. (Seal Press, $14.95.) This short, impressionistic novel provides glimpses of the life and feelings experienced by its 18-year-old heroine, Bahiah Shaheen, who rejects her everyday identity.

title: Protesters Enter British Base
description: Fourteen antinuclear campaigners entered the Molesworth base for cruise missiles in central England today before being detected, the police said. One demonstrator said the group was dressed as laborers. Ten demonstrators were arrested after climbing a water tower and hanging antinuclear banners from it.

title: MARRIED FOR HIS MAID?
description: SINGULAR REBELLION By Saiichi Maruya. Translated by Dennis Keene. 412 pp. New York: Kodansha International. $19.95.

title: ALABAMA TROUNCES VANDERBILT
description: Gene Jelks, a sophomore running back, raced 75 yards for a touchdown, and Derrick Thomas blocked a punt and returned it for another score today as Alabama routed Vanderbilt, 42-10, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: Miss Rothe Marries Bruce Allan Meberg
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Kirsten-Elisabeth Rothe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tyge E. Rothe of Greenwich, Espergaerde, Denmark, and Singer Island, Fla., was married to Bruce Allan Meberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Meberg of Old Tappan, N.J., and Kvinesdal, Norway. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: The Belushi Case
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith was sentenced to three years in prison last week for administering the drug overdose that killed the comedian John Belushi in 1982.

title: U.S. Aide Meets Mubarak On Egypt-Israel Talks
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy met with President Hosni Mubarak today on a proposed Egyptian-Israeli meeting.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
COMMON RAZOR CLAM
description: Ensis directus Size: To 10 inches.

title: Elizabeth Gail Harris Weds Patrick Hayes Baird
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Gail Harris, a vice president of Mabon, Nugent & Company in New York, to Patrick Hayes Baird, who expects to graduate in December from Brown University, took place yesterday in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Richard Dannenfelser performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lazarus of Providence, R.I., and Stockbridge.

title: Nail and Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: HIJACKING WASN'T FIRST TRY
description: The seizure of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet at the Karachi airport Friday was not the first attempted hijacking in Pakistan.

title: SEVERAL WITNESSES TESTIFY AGAIN IN INQUIRY ON CABLE TV FRANCHISE
description: A grand jury investigating the awarding of cable television franchises in Queens called back several witnesses last week to hear again their accounts of the roles played by Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President; John A. Zaccaro and State Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Smith, lawyers said.

title: WITT'S 7-HITTER STOPS YANKS, 9-2
description: This time, the Yankees may have finally slid out of the race. Tonight, they were held to seven hits by Mike Witt and the California Angels, whose 9-2 victory likely crushed the Yankees' hopes of crawling back into the American League East race.

title: FRANK CASHEN: THE MAN
description: Your recent article on Frank Cashen was indeed correct in coming to the conclusion that he deserves a lion's share of the credit for the New York Mets' rousing revival. But the piece did not give enough credit to the considerable skills of Davey Johnson, the Mets' manager, who is, by any measure, the best field boss in baseball.

title: SOONERS ROLL PAST U.C.L.A. IN OPENER
description: Oklahoma opened its drive for a second consecutive mythical national championship with such ease today that the Sooners' 38-3 victory over highly regarded U.C.L.A. even surprised the winning players.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SHAKER COMMUNITIES, SHAKER LIVES. By Priscilla J. Brewer. (University Press of New England, $24.95.) The Shaker movement that came to America with Ann Lee in 1774 was descended from a French medieval sect that settled in England after 1688; the shaking dance they practiced originated with the Huguenots.

title: LAST 'RED TAG' REMOVED FROM SUBWAY TRACK
description: The last of the ''red tag'' restrictions, limiting trains to 10 miles an hour on dangerous sections of subway track, has been lifted, according to Transit Authority officials.

title: HARVARD'S BOK SEES PERIL TO SCHOLARS IN LURE OF MONEY
description: Speaking on the final day of Harvard University's 350th anniversary celebration, its president, Derek Bok, cautioned today that some professors were becoming increasingly caught up in the contemporary pursuit of affluence, undermining the mission of the university.

title: Miss Principato Bride in Capital
description: Deborah Ellen Principato, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerold J. Principato of Chevy Chase, Md., and The Plains, Va., was married yesterday to William Brinkley Lindsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Haynes Lindsey of Tallahassee, Fla., and Lake Nanthala, N.C. The Rev. William Sydnor performed the ceremony at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.) Mrs. Lindsey, a member of the class of '87 at the Tufts University Medical School, graduated from the National Cathedral School and cum laude from Princeton University.

title: Going Away
description: To the Editor: Anita Shreve's article mirrored my experience last month. Although my husband and I had been planning for a year for our first trip to Italy, we hesitated because of the international situation.

title: Kyle Conroy Has Wedding
description: Kyle Ann Conroy and Raymond Alan Dargan were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Ambrose Eckinger performed the ceremony.

title: When Executives Hawk Their Ideas
description: EVEN executives who are loath to endorse products often feel O.K. about lending their names and faces to concepts - particularly if they get to write their own scripts.

title: We'll All Pay Corporate-Tax Hike in Higher Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieut. A. P. F. Schmidt Marries Miss Bollman
description: Elizabeth Louise Bollman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. McWilliam V. Bollman of New York, was married yesterday to Lieut. Anthony P. F. Schmidt, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Schmidt of McLean, Va.

title: SPINKS WINS BOUT ON KNOCKOUT IN 4TH AND RETAINS TITLE
description: The big punch that Michael Spinks was supposed to lack as a heavyweight materialized tonight.

title: TOPICS
description: SOMETHING happens when I sew. I don't mean the dress that's made.

title: POSTINGS: Gwathmey Design; Parti in Parsippany
description: Charles Gwathmey, a partner in the internationally known architecture firm of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, says his philosophy in designing suburban office buildings is ''to take the inherent parti'' - or basic plan - ''and make it unique.''

title: ARABS AND JEWS IN ISRAEL
description: I have been dealing with the Arab-Israeli conflict for 27 years as a student and a Foreign Service officer, and I believe firmly that the work done at Neve Shalom and Van Leer is as important to Middle East peace as the formal peace plans drafted in Washington or any other world capital. There are great psychological tasks to be accomplished before a conflict as tragic as that of the Arabs and Israelis can be resolved.

title: Consultant Wed To Miss Connell
description: The marriage of Brenda Murray Connell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brendan Connell of Pocasset, Mass., to Hugh Foster Beckwith Jr., the son of Betsy Beckwith of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and the late Mr. Beckwith, took place yesterday in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. John Culloty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Houghton Memorial Chapel of Wellesley College.

title: SMALL BATTLES, IN THE WAR OF NOT GOING TO SCHOOL
description: THE signs are telling us to drive carefully, to shop for back-to-school specials, to stock up on notebooks and paper. Last week I already had a replay of that classic dream where I'm sitting down for a final exam in a course I never attended. My husband, meanwhile, tossed in his sleep and complained when he awoke that he couldn't remember his locker combination. We all seem to be feeling a hint of tension as summer vacation winds down.

title: Pantelleria
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from Pantelleria where I rented a house for the month of May (before the mosquitoes arrived).

title: A NEW BREED OF IMPORT, MADE IN THE U.S.A
description: THE sporty white FX-16 subcompact that rolled off the assembly line at Fremont, Calif., last week was the first of a new class of made-in-America Japanese cars. No other such vehicle is the product of a joint venture between a Japanese and an American automaker, and none other bears a union label.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 7, 1986
description: FICTION 1 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $3.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 2 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 3 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.50.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 4 SAN ANDREAS, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett, $4.50.) A British hospital ship with a deadly secret, adrift in the North Sea after a Luftwaffe attack. 5 LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The heiress of a crime lord versus the heiress of a shipping tycoon. 6 PALM BEACH, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A poor but beautiful woman finds her way in the town of the superrich. 7* THE TRAIL TO CRAZY MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Three long Western stories that the author later turned into novels. 8 HELLFIRE, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.50.) Fury and vengeance pour out when a long-abandoned mill is reopened. 9* THE RIDER OF THE RUBY HILLS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Four frontier stories that were later expanded into novels. 10 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 11 AFTER THE REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Dell, $4.50.) The surprises that befell four Radcliffe women in the five years after their 20th reunion. 12 THE RED FOX, by Anthony Hyde. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A thriller in which a journalist goes to Russia, seeking the father of a woman he loves. 13 THE FOURTH DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $4.50.) Which of six suspects murdered a saintly New York psychiatrist? 14 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Bantam, $4.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 15 SKELETON CREW, by Stephen King. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) Twenty-two tales of horror set in contemporary America. NONFICTION General 1 ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Berkley, $4.50.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband and father. 2 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $4.95.) How the son of immigrants rose to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 3 YEAGER, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $4.95.) The test pilot's autobiography. 4 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Inspiration. 5 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvin Kinder. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) Modern women's efforts to find good men. 6 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and Nancy Austin. (Warner, $10.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 IT CAME FROM THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 3 BLOOM COUNTY BABYLON, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) Five years of comic strips. 4 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1986. 5 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Help for victims of others' compulsive behavior. 6 THE ONE MINUTE SALES PERSON, by Spencer Johnson and Larry Wilson. (Avon, $5.) How to increase selling skills. 7 WHAT THEY DON'T TEACH YOU AT HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL, by Mark H. McCormack. (Bantam, $8.95.) ''Street-smart'' tips. 8 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Revised edition of the handbook used in Scientology. 9* WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed Press, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1986 edition.

title: OF GREEK GODS AND 'MURRAY THE FURRIER'
description: ''YOU see the form of a lovely female swathed in furs,'' said Barry Harman, describing the television commercial for ''Olympus on My Mind,'' the musical he is directing and for which he wrote the book and lyrics.

title: Drink Is the Curse of the Classless Society
description: To the Editor:

title: School Sued in Fatal Climb
description: The parents of one of the seven students who died with two faculty members on Mount Hood in a school-sponsored expedition last May have filed a $2 million lawsuit against the Oregon Episcopal School. Frank and Linda McGinness, the parents of 15-year-old Patrick F. McGinness, filed the wrongful death suit Thursday in Multnomah County Circuit Court. They charged that the school was negligent in not providing sufficient training, planning and equipment for the climb.

title: BEST SELLER: September 7, 1986
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 6 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 2 2 8 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 3 3 10 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 4 5 3 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two men, passion and power brokering in Washington. 5 4 13 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 6 6 27 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 7 10 20 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 8 12 4 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. *9 11 15 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. *10 8 12 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 11 9 17 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 12 1 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's coming of age in 18th-century England and France. 13 13 42 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 14 7 20 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 15 14 14 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 18 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 26 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 4 13 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 4* 3 17 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 5 6 20 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 6 5 11 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life written with his cooperation. 7 7 12 FORD: The Men and the Machine, by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 8 8 8 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation by the film director King Vidor of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 9 9 21 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 10 10 23 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 11 11 8 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. M. Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 12 15 173 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 13 1 THE NIGHT LIVES ON, by Walter Lord. (Morrow, $15.95.) New discoveries and thoughts about the Titanic disaster. 14 1 STRANGER IN TWO WORLDS, by Jean Harris. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The recollections of a prep school headmistress who killed her lover and is now serving a prison term. 15 14 8 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by James Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged - and is being stymied by diplomats and bureaucrats. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 16 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 2 55 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 4 63 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 3 41 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 5 5 8 MEDICAL MAKEOVER, by Robert M. Giller and Kathy Matthews. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) A ''no-willpower program for lifetime health.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) God and sex are again on the fleshly, Protestant minds of Mr. Updike's characters, but this challenging, educative (and highly educated) novel adds science, mathematics, computers and a fierce, honorable bout with natural theology. THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Bizarre comedy, flat Middle Western facts and vigorous tragedy meet in the four women whose lives define Ms. Erdrich's second novel, set, like her first, ''Love Medicine,'' in North Dakota. THE FIFTIES: From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period, by Edmund Wilson. Edited by Leon Edel. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) There are puny and trivial thoughts as well as great ones on the mighty critic's mind from the ages of 55 to 65, but it's a profoundly incurious reader who won't want to know them all. DOSTOEVSKY: The Stir of Liberation 1860-1865, by Joseph Frank. (Princeton University, $29.50.) The third installment (five are projected) of Mr. Frank's distinguished life of the great novelist. THE CHIMPANZEES OF GOMBE: Patterns of Behavior, by Jane Goodall. (Belknap/Harvard University, $30.) The culmination of 26 years of meticulous research, this book brings together an unequaled amount of detail on the biology, ecology and culture of animals eerily like ourselves (they even tell lies). SICILIAN UNCLES, by Leonardo Sciascia. (Carcanet, $15.95.) Four long stories, published in Italian in 1958-60, in which tightness and narrative immediacy support frank political and ethical purposes. TONGUES OF FLAME, by Mary Ward Brown. (Seymour Lawrence/Dutton, $15.95.) There is nothing Gothic in this first collection of short stories by an Alabama native - just a lifetime's knowledge of regular folks exposed to irregular circumstances.

title: A Small-Business Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: RED SOX TOP TWINS, 3-2, ON RUN IN 9TH
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd lived up to his promise today and the Boston Red Sox responded to the pressure of September with their seventh straight victory.

title:
MUSIC;
A GALA, 4 WINNERS AND A PREMIERE
description: MORE than 500 guests are expected at the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's largest fund-raising and social event of the season, its second annual ''Legend in the Park'' gala Tuesday night.

title: AT LEAST 21 ARE SLAIN IN ATTACK ON SYNAGOGUE
description: TWO men described as Arabs entered the Neve Shalom Synagogue in Istanbul, Turkey, during Sabbath prayers yesterday, fired submachine guns, detonated grenades and killed at least 21 of the 30 worshippers. Ten others were injured. Officials said the gunmen also died after the police forced them back into the building and there were more explosions.

title: 2 Bartenders Are Cited In Minors' Liquor Sales
description: Undercover investigators, as part of a crackdown on under-age drinking, entered 18 Manhattan bars Friday night and yesterday morning and issued summonses to two bartenders on the Upper East Side, the police said yesterday.

title: For Jets and Bills, a Rush to Get Started
description: Rarely have two teams been so eager to start a season - and for different reasons - as the Jets and the Buffalo Bills.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
COMEDY, NEWLY MINTED AND REJUVENATED, ABOUNDS
description: From sweeping historical overviews to uninhibited comedy to original films -not to mention pop-music galas and naturalists' fare and ventures into a kind of speculative politics - cable's abundance of ambitious premieres over the coming months gives ample evidence of the industry's growing liveliness. Yet, even after more than a decade of heady development, cable largely remains a stepchild of broadcast television, with significantly slighter viewership and, thus, slenderer resources for production. Within the last two seasons, moreover, the VCR has usurped cable's position as the first home-viewing outlet for theatrical films.

title: FEHR POSTS 67 TO LEAD
description: Rick Fehr used accurate putting to take the lead today with a four-under-par 67 after three rounds of the $400,000 B.C. Open.

title: ...WHEN IT'S REALLY MOTHER'S DAY
description: IT makes little sense: Mother's Day is celebrated with flowers and cards on an inappropriate Sunday in May.

title: MORE GRATITUDE THAN MONEY
description: NO EARTHLY NOTION By Susan Dodd. 216 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: SUBWAY INCIDENT ENDS IN DEATH
description: A 39-year-old man, apparently trying to flee from a group of teen-age attackers, was killed yesterday morning when he fell beneath a moving subway train, the transit police said.

title: Insurance Programs Persevere in H.U.D. Cutbacks
description: WITH the all-but-complete withdrawal of Federal rent subsidies to build new or gut-rehabilitated rentals for low-income people across the country, the Federal role in housing production is hardly what it used to be in New York City.

title: They Jumped Ship and Landed
description: Former U.S.F.L. players now on active rosters in the N.F.L. NATIONAL CONFERENCE: East Washington - Kelvin Bryant, running back; Derek Holloway, wide receiver; Angelo Snipes, linebacker; Doug Williams, quarterback Dallas - Herschel Walker, running back; Nathanial Newton, guard St. Louis - Bob Clasby, tackle Philadelphia - Joe Conwell, tackle Giants - none Central Green Bay - Paul Carruth, running back; Greg Feasel, tackle Minnesota - David Evans, defensive back Tampa Bay - Mack Boatner, running back; Leonard Harris, wide receiver; Vito McKeever, defensive back Chicago - Larry Rubens, center Detroit - none West New Orleans - Chuck Commiskey, center; Antonio Gibson, defensive back; Mel Gray, running back; Vaughan Johnson, linebacker; Sam Mills, linebacker Atlanta - Joey Jones, wide receiver San Francisco - none Los Angeles - none AMERICAN CONFERENCE: East Buffalo - Jim Kelly, quarterback; Kent Hull, center Indianapolis - Victor Jackson, defensive back Jets - none Patriots - none Dolphins - none Central Cincinnati - Kiki DeAyala, linebacker Cleveland - Mike Johnson, linebacker; Gerald McNeil, wide receiver Houston - Jay Pennison, center; Don Maggs, tackle; Malcolm Taylor, defensive end Pittsburgh - none West Kansas City - Irv Eatman, tackle; Kit Lathrop, defensive tackle San Diego - Gary Plummer, linebacker; Dave Martin, defensive back Seattle - Kerry Justin, defensive back Los Angeles - Chris Riehm, tackle Denver - none

title: HELP WANTED, AND KELLY FITS THE BILLS
description: JIM KELLY is back in uniform. It fits, even up here.

title: WOMAN CHOSEN TO HEAD JAPAN SOCIALIST PARTY
description: In this country where politics is virtually an all-male preserve, a woman was chosen today for the first time to head a major party.

title: SEXUAL EQUALITY IN COURT IS GAINING, REPORT FINDS
description: THE sponsors of a program to encourage equal treatment of women in the judicial system and legal profession in New Jersey say that their efforts have begun bearing fruit and that the program has become a model for other states.

title: MECIR UPSETS BECKER; SHE GAINS FINAL, 6-1, 6-7, 7-6
description: It took more than 24 hours to complete, with emotions that ranged from exultation to disappointment. In between, two players tested and stretched one another and provided a sellout crowd at the National Tennis Center with the most dramatic match of the tournament.

title: NOT EVERYONE'S CUP OF TEA
description: ''By their works ye shall know them,'' the saying goes. But for how much longer will different nations preserve their distinctive characters?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ANNA DELANEY'S CHILD. By John Thorndike. (Macmillan, $17.95.) ''Lord keep my memory green!'' pleads Charles Dickens's hero in the story ''The Haunted Man,'' after his wish to forget all ''sorrow, wrong, and trouble'' has been granted.

title: IS THE MIDDLE CLASS DOOMED?
description: MOST OF US ARE ''MIDDLE CLASS,'' or so we like to believe. But there are signs that America is becoming a more divided society: over the last decade, the rich have been getting richer; the poor have been getting more numerous, and those in the middle do not appear to be doing as well as they used to. If America is ''coming back,'' as President Reagan reassured us in the wake of the economic malaise of the early 1980's, it may be coming back in a harsh and alien form.

title: A WRITER DISCOVERS THE CLUES TO CRAFTING THE MYSTERY NOVEL
description: ''I THINK the mystery has a form,'' said Robert Upton of Manhattan and Sag Harbor. ''It's more action than introspection, whereas you can do almost anything with the general novel; and that kind of freedom can be intimidating when you're writing your first novel.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LANGUAGE IMMERSION
description: Language immersion - learning a language in a short intensive program - has grown increasingly popular in recent years. This fall, Manhattanville College in Purchase will join the growing number of schools nationwide using this technique when it offers its first Language Immersion Weekend.

title: CLUES TO ATTACKERS POINT IN CONFUSING DIRECTIONS
description: Responsibility for two terrorist acts in the Middle East within 24 hours - the attack on an Istanbul synagogue and the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways airliner in Karachi, Pakistan - remained unclear this evening.

title: POSTINGS: Park Slope Conversion; Elegant New Life for Tenements
description: By late 1978, the four old-law tenements on Garfield Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn were completely vacant. As part of the early gentrification of Park Slope, a developer had bought the structures as well as five others across the street, hoping to convert them into more luxurious apartments.

title: WHO STAYS UP WITH THE SICK COW?
description: THE CAPITALIST REVOLUTION Fifty Propositions About Prosperity, Equality, and Liberty. By Peter L. Berger. 262 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: RUN FOR VETERANS It's billed as the ''Five-Mile Run for Veterans,'' but today's event at the Mitchel Park complex in Uniondale is actually much more. In addition to the race, which gets off at 9:30 A.M.
