(late registration at $12 begins at 7 A.M.), there will be an interfaith service at 7:30 A.M. honoring those killed and missing in action, a fly-over of World War II planes and the release of 4,000 balloons representing Long Islanders who lost their lives in Southeast Asia, at 8:45 A.M. In addition, a one-mile Fun Run will be held at 11 A.M., and, starting at 2 P.M., there will be an afternoon of family entertainment from such groups as the New Image Drum and Bugle Corps and the Emerald Society Pipe and Drum Corps. Except for the race fees, which benefit the Vietnam Veterans Resource Center in Hicksville, a counseling service, everything is free.

title: Texas Struggles To Pay Its Bills
description: Plunging oil prices have brought Texas, a state accustomed to plenty, the personal agonies of rising unemployment and the fiscal pain of shrinking revenues, the travail that once afflicted Northern industrial states.

title: Jane S. Appleyard Weds R. A. Roel, Magazine Editor
description: The marriage of Jane Sharp Appleyard, the daughter of Bishop and Mrs. Robert B. Appleyard of Weekapaug, R.I., to Raymond Allen Roel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. Roel of Woodbury, L.I., took place yesterday at the Weekapaug Chapel. The Rev. Robert B. Appleyard Jr., the bride's brother, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: FACES OF THE OTHER AMERICAS
description: THE FOCUS SHARPENS. THE STARK PANORAMA OF POVERTY in which millions of Latin Americans live suddenly blurs and faces appear. They are dark faces, the faces of Indian peasants and black settlers, in the main - and on them are etched the resignation, patience, faith and hope that make survival possible in the barren sierras and deserts of the ''other Americas.'' These are not the faces of despair, but the faces of solitude, peering at a rapidly changing world that both calls out to them and rejects them.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Cracking of the Doors Moral indignation flourishes in prison writing. Here Jean Jarris, the conVicted mruderer of Dr. Herman Tarnower, describes a prison ritual that she finds particularly grim. This is from her ''Stranger in Two Worlds'' (Macmillan).

title: Behind the Mask
description: I'm wary of books that scrutinize Hollywood myths; they have a sinister tendency toward psychobabble and sociological truisms. Luckily, HOLLYWOOD: Legend and Reality, edited by Michael Webb (N.Y. Graphic Society/Little, Brown, Cloth, $39.95.

title: 2 HOMERS FOR CARTER
description: Visions of October may be dancing in their heads, but the Mets kept rolling through September with all of the old flair yesterday, including two home runs by Gary Carter and an eighth-inning rally that sank the San Diego Padres, 4-3.

title: Biting Fund-Raising Hand
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, has run into a barrage of criticism from an unlikely source, the campus of Pennsylvania State University, which he has promised to help with a five-year, $200 million fund-raising drive. Mr. Regan is planning to speak at the university next Saturday to help kick off the the campaign, but student leaders are protesting.

title: HAIR-TRIGGER SUMMER RAISES WORRIES AND QUESTIONS IN DETROIT
description: Detroit, which for years has been battling the image of ''murder city,'' is struggling to stem a wave of summer shootings, and officials say they are particularly concerned about a proliferation of pistols used by and against teen-agers.

title: Stock Buybacks
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHERS CAN STILL LEARN A FEW USEFUL THINGS ABOUT TEACHING
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Sutherland Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Ann Sutherland, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Sutherland of Winchester and Chilmark, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Virden Patterson, a son of Henry S. Patterson 2d of Princeton, N.J., and West Tisbury, Mass., and the late Suzanne Virden Patterson. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Dr. John E. Wallace, a retired Congregational minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE EXPOSURE METER'S MEASURE
description: NO matter how sophisticated, virtually all exposure meters see the world as a dreary blanket of gray. This bit of insight comes as a real shock to many tyros, who naively suppose that meters are adjuncts of the human eye. If they only were, there would be far fewer exposure errors.

title: THE EDUCATIONAL CONSCIENCE
description: NOW that September has rolled around again, the battles for educational reform will intensify. I hope we have all had a restful summer because excellence, both the quest for and the delivery of, takes a lot of energy.

title: Stock Buybacks
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: DADDY MAKES THE BEST SPAGHETTI. Written and illustrated by Anna Grossnickle Hines. Clarion/Ticknor & Fields. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 6) In this family, after daddy picks up Corey at day care they are in charge of the evening meal.

title: SENATE RACE TESTS DEMOCRATS' WINGS
description: THE Democratic primary contest Tuesday between John S. Dyson and Mark Green will do more than settle the matter of who gets to oppose the strong Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in the November general election. It also will answer some questions about the Democratic party, such as whether it has moved to the right.

title: MODERN MASTERS, ANCIENT TREASURES AND NEW QUESTIONS
description: The 1986-87 New York museum season is filled with provocative shows, particularly on modern masters and contemporary art. It is limited on Old Masters, however, and weak in sculpture.

title: In Scarsdale, Corey Tessler Marries Lauren Beth Klein
description: The marriage of Lauren Beth Klein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Klein of Rye Brook, N.Y., to Corey A. Tessler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Tessler of Lawrence, L.I., took place last evening at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Klausner officiated.

title: Sarah Foster to Wed Gregory Wetsone
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Foster of Belmont, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Anne Foster, to Gregory Scott Wetsone, a son of Janet Wetsone of Sarasota, Fla., and Richard Wetsone of Miami. The wedding is planned for Oct. 18.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SUSPECTS. By William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) To most of the world, Lieut. Joseph P. Gallagher is the ultimate cop, a hard-driving, glad-handing Irish-Catholic gumshoe who's everybody's pal.

title: Jerusalem
description: To the Editor: As a frequent visitor to Israel, with considerable time spent in and around Jerusalem, I would like readers to know about the following places, in addition to the WIZO shop mentioned in the article ''In Jerusalem, Gifts With Tradition'' (Travel, June 29).

title: DECISIONS WITHIN NETWORK NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MY LIFE WITH GOYA. By Andrew Potok. (Arbor House, $17.95.) ''My Life With Goya,'' is a novel rich in elegance and butchery, lucidity and insanity, love and cruelty.

title: CRIME
description: Ilie Nastase is one of the great tennis players. It now turns out he also is a more than competent writer. At least, no ghost writer or assistant is mentioned in his big, sprawling novel, BREAK POINT (St. Martin's, $15.95).

title: Rats in the Warehouse
description: DESPITE WHAT YOU hear, this is not a service economy. It is an insurance economy. Or haven't you noticed that no matter what your favorite shop claims to be selling nowadays, what it's really selling is insurance? For instance:

title: AT 350TH ANNIVERSARY, THE U.S. UNIVERSITY IS A VAST BUT UNFOCUSED INSTITUTION
description: Three hundred and fifty years after it came into being to provide an educated native clergy for the new Colonies, American higher education has evolved into a huge enterprise with a new strategic role in the nation's economy amid widespread doubt about the academic values that hold it together.

title: U.N. ENVOY IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: A special United Nations envoy arrived in southern Lebanon today for consultations on measures to improve security for the United Nations peacekeeping force there.

title: TIME IS RUNNING OUT FOR THE COIN-OPERATED PARKING METER
description: WHILE New York's parking meters fill with quarters almost as fast as they can be emptied, city planners are studying such alternatives as meter credit cards and even voucher systems that would do away with meters entirely.

title: MOB'S RULING 'COMMISSION' TO GO ON TRIAL IN NEW YORK
description: A major racketeering trial scheduled to begin tomorrow will concentrate on charges that a ''commission'' of top crime leaders ruled the Mafia with ''threats, violence and murder.''

title: MAINE'S WEALTH OF ART
description: The varied resources of Maine's small art museums have largely gone unnoticed, overshadowed by the natural glories of the landscape. Yet that landscape has been drawing artists for centuries, and much fine work has either stayed in or returned to the state.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We share as a nation the grief and pain of all the families of our fellow citizens who have died because of this odious assault, and express our deepest sympathy to them.'' - Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, of Turkey. [ 12:1. ]

title: PROJECT HURTS PHILADELPHIA'S MAYOR
description: As part of an effort to clean up the city, 2,000 teen-agers were hired this summer to sweep up garbage, scrape away graffiti and paint murals.

title: LOW TURNOUT SEEN FOR SENATE PRIMARY
description: Democratic politicians are predicting an abnormally low turnout in Tuesday's Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination from New York, despite a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign and a heated contest.

title: PROFESSIONAL TITLE TO ITALIAN CYCLIST
description: Moreno Argentin, a 25-year-old Italian rider who was among the favorites, easily won the professional road race in the World Cycling Championships today.

title: Why Greenspan Stumped for Apple
description: LAST year, from March through July, Apple Computer ran a series of TV and print ads focusing on two ''achievers'' who used Apple computers. For one of those achievers, the connection to Apple was clear-cut - she was Barbara Blackborn, a secretary who set the world speed typing record on an Apple IIc.

title: Energy Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Manley Activated
description: Dexter Manley, the defensive end who led Washington in sacks last season, was activated by the Redskins just in time for the season opener against the Philadelphia Eagles. He had not been counted on the preseason roster because of a contract holdout that ended 10 days ago.

title: THE PRIZE OF COUNTS AND KINGS
description: Flanders is a Lilliputian land, smaller than Massachusetts, tucked between the North Sea and the Scheldt River between Holland and France. But for nearly 20 centuries, it has been a battlefield on which has been woven the fabric of European history, from Caesar's conquest of Gaul to the fall of Hitler's Third Reich. The record is one of strife, bloodshed, political intrigue, conflict, subterfuge, dynastic rivalries and arranged marriages, religious discord, persecution, economic turmoil and revolutionary upheaval. Domination of Flanders was the goal of the Romans, Franks, Vikings, French, Spaniards, Austrians, Germans, Dutch and even, in the Middle Ages, the English, who wanted free access for their wool in the great Flemish commercial and manufacturing centers, ports, waterways and rivers. Throughout the tumultuous centuries the Flemings have struggled for independence, often skillfully, sometimes deviously, playing predatory conquerors, suzerains and would-be rulers against one another. In the process they left an indelible stamp on the world with their industriousness and the greatness of their art.

title: ART AND CONSTRUCTION
description: Guenther Reiss, an Austrian-born artist whose studio is a loft in Port Chester that was once a dressmaking factory, gets his inspiration from buildings under construction.

title: Walls Faces Suspension
description: The Dallas Cowboys warned Everson Walls, the cornerback, that he can be suspended if his walkout over a contract dispute continues.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CHICAGO IN PHILADELPHIA

title: DEMOCRATS SELECTING DIOGUARDI'S CHALLENGER
description: A SUMMERLONG struggle by four Democrats for the right to challenge Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi as Westchester's 20th District Congressman will end Tuesday when 20,000 to 25,000 Democrats make their choice in a primary election.

title: DRUG TESTING FOR ATHLETES IS WEIGHED
description: SEVERAL Connecticut colleges are considering testing student athletes for drugs, and at least one - the University of New Haven - appears certain to start a drug-monitoring program, possibly this fall.

title: TWO FINALES SIGNAL START OF FALL SEASON
description: IT'S already time to make concert-going plans for the fall and winter, but not before the finales of the summer series sponsored by the South Shore Music Club and the Silvermine Guild.

title: New Chagall Drawings
description: To the Editor:

title: AS WEST RISES, BRONCOS LOOK TO TOSS OFF PATRIOTS
description: The following conference preview was prepared by Michael Janofsky. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish, with the Jets picked for third in the East. EAST: New England Patriots Last season was a happy if not unexpected romp that ended with an embarrassing if not unexpected loss in the Super Bowl. Until then, the Patriots showed what can happen when a young team and a relatively new coach, Raymond Berry, find strength and comfort in each other. The more tangible results were an 11-5 record, followed by victories in the playoffs on the road over the Jets, Raiders and Dolphins. They return this season solid at almost every position with two major questions: Will Paul Fairchild be an adequate replacement for the retired John Hannah at left guard? (He probably will, judging against Hannah's last few seasons.) And can Tony Eason, the fourth-year quarterback, forget his 0-for-6 performance in the Super Bowl?

title: NORWOOD
description: A SURGE of urban renewal has seized Norwood, a neighborhood in the northwest Bronx that in the late 1970's feared urban blight. Now, its residents and merchants say they worry less about the quality of life than about the cost of living there.

title: PRACTICAL POINTERS FOR SEASIDE GARDENERS
description: As the fall equinox approaches with heavy rains and the possibility of a hurricane, it seems timely to share what I've learned about gardening on the seacoast.

title: SPINNING TALES OF URBAN ANGST
description: During one of his radio shows, Mike Feder got a telephone call from a psychiatrist. She said she wanted to thank him, because she listened to him as the warm-up for a whole day of disturbed patients.

title: CASHEN'S LAW: EVERYTHING GOES RIGHT
description: IT is Murphy's Law that if anything can go wrong, it will. It is O'Toole's Commentary that Murphy was an optimist. It is Goldberg's Commentary that O'Toole was an optimist. It is Nagler's Commentary that Murphy's Law was propounded not by Murphy but by another man of the same name. It is Cashen's Corollary that whoever that other Murphy is, it can't be the Bob Murphy who does the Mets' games on radio. That Murphy by now has a law of his own: Whatever goes wrong goes right.

title: A FURNITURE MAKER DISPLAYS HIS CRAFT
description: WHEN James Schriber left Boston University seven years ago with a degree in furniture design, he chose a path different from the one that many of his fellow students took. They went on to establish names for themselves among the country's leading craft galleries and museums; he moved to rural New Milford to set up a design and construction business, which seemed considerably less exciting by comparison.

title: WHEN FILM MAKERS PLAY IT BY EAR
description: If much of contemporary romance is improvised, so are two new movies on the subject by a pair of independent directors whose unstructured style is a metaphor for the uncertain situations they depict. Carrying spontaneity to a creative extreme, both films evolved from the documentary form and ended as whimsical comedies.

title: NEW TACK FOR JURIES: ONE DAY, ONE TRIAL
description: STARTING Tuesday, a pilot program at Middlesex Superior Court in Middletown will try to make jury duty less time-consuming and less burdensome.

title: WHO CAN REACH WHAT IN '86
description: Walter Payton of Chicago needs 662 combined yards to become the first player to reach 20,000 yards by rushing, receiving and returns. He currently has 19,338 - 14,860 by rushing, 3,939 receiving and 539 on kickoff returns.

title: From Alley Cat To Celebrity
description: IN Woodbury, Conn., Fred was a curiosity and a controversy. Fred lived in the public library. At least one library patron objected strenuously.

title: 3d-GENERATION HORSE FARM CONTINUES A VOORHEES TRADITION
description: IN among the housing developments, shopping malls and office complexes of Camden County, three brothers still raise and train pacers and trotters as their grandfather did in the early 1900's.

title:
ANTIQUES;
2-SEASON GUIDE TO INSTRUCTION
description: FOR showgoers, sometime shoppers and collectors, the opportunity to acquire or add to one's knowledge of antiques can make the difference between reasonable certainty and justifiable caution when making a purchase.

title: BYZANTIUM COMES TO PRINCETON
description: CAST into limbo by renovation and construction, Princeton University's art museum has passed the torch to its Firestone Library. Which means that the current exhibition, ''Byzantium at Princeton,'' hangs not in the usual premises, but in the library's Gallery of Rare Books and Special Collections, where it will remain through Oct. 26.

title: Should Ted Turner Join Actor's Equity?
description: THREE years ago, Ted Turner became the first executive to don an eye patch and play ''the man in the Hathaway shirt.'' John Connally, former Governor of Texas and Secretary of the Treasury, and J. W. Marriott Jr., head of the Marriott Corporation, followed. Next month, Pepsico chief Roger Enrico will take his turn.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NEWER INUIT ART

title: Beth Stanley-Brown Becomes Bride Of Peter Garrett Horan on Nantucket
description: Elizabeth Powell Stanley-Brown, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Garfield Stanley-Brown of Ridgewood, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Garrett Horan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Leo Horan of Rehoboth, Mass. The Revs.

title: HERE AND THERE, CITY REPAIRS AND RENOVATIONS START TO SHOW
description: CITY Hall boasts a brand new set of stone steps out front, and refurbished rooms inside. Straphangers are actually seeing new subway cars glide up to the platform. Traffic is snarled daily by repair crews on the East River bridges. Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn is scheduled for renovations this year.

title: SMITH SETS PRIORITIES ON A VETERANS' CLINIC
description: REPRESENTATIVE Christopher Smith, Republican of the Fourth District (parts of Burlington, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth and Ocean Counties) says that although the construction of a veterans outpatient clinic in Vineland, Cumberland County, is an excellent idea, it should be considered only after the Veterans Administration proceeds with a new clinic in Bricktown, Ocean County.

title: ONE MAN DISCOVERS HOW PLANS GO AWRY
description: THE thin young man with sad eyes sat at a small table in the detention center of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Manhattan. There was little he could do but wait patiently as bureaucratic wheels turned to send him back home to Mexico.

title: GEORGE MONAGHAN, 85, DEAD EX-HARNESS RACING OFFICIAL
description: George P. Monaghan, a former prosecutor who went on to become New York City Fire Commissioner, Police Commissioner and ''czar'' of harness racing for the state, died yesterday at the Frances Schervier Home and Hospital in the Bronx. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LITTLE CAESAR, by W.cR. Burnett. (Carroll & Graf, $3.50.) W.cR. Burnett's tale of the rise and fall of a Chicago gangster came to epitomize the hard-boiled realism of life in the underworld, while its hero, Rico, played on the screen by Edward G. Robinson in 1931, became something of a prototype of the brutal racketeer. In 1929 our reviewer found the style clipped and swift, and said ''the sentences are as hard and abrupt as the bullet shots that clear the way for Rico's rise to gang dominance and his downfall.'' LABYRINTHS OF IRON: Subways in History, Myth, Art, Technology, and War, by Benson Bobrick. (Quill/ Morrow, $10.95.) This history of the subterranean railway examines the subway systems of London, Paris, New York and other cities and puts them in their sociological context.

title: BLANCHE SWEET, FILM ACTRESS
description: Blanche Sweet, one of the earliest motion-picture stars, died of a stroke yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: FOR SOME SCHOOL DISTRICTS, CROWDING IS A PROBLEM AGAIN
description: WITH the arrival of the new school year, officials in some communities are being greeted by overcrowded classrooms, a problem they thought was gone forever.

title: Elizabeth Miller Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Page Miller, the daughter of E. Dean Miller of Omaha and the late Barbara Miller, was married yesterday to Bruce Mark McGuire, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. McGuire of St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Susan Harris performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. Mrs. McGuire is director of special projects for worldwide marketing and communications for American Express in New York. Her husband is a psychologist with the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: IN THE NEW HAITI, SMUGGLERS FIND A PARADISE
description: The little harbor here on the north coast of Haiti used to be a favorite hangout for pirates. Then, farther back than anyone can remember, it became a haven for smugglers. Lately, business has been booming. When President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile last February, the 15,000 Tontons Macoute, the security men who had protected him and plundered as they pleased, also fled or dropped out of sight, leaving something of a power vacuum.

title: CINEMATIC REFLECTIONS ON JEWISH LIFE IN 15-WORK FESTIVAL AT 92ND STREET Y
description: THE title of the film series that starts today at the 92d Street Y is almost self-explanatory: ''American Jewry: Looking at Ourselves.'' As the title indicates, the series is not so much a festival of 15 films that give a portrait of the nearly six million Jews in the United States and Canada as it is a vision of how they live as seen through the eyes of movie makers.

title: Frank Cashen: The Man
description: Bruce Weber's article ''The Man Who Built the Mets'' (Aug. 3) left out one major point about Frank Cashen -he happens to be a nice guy.

title: FOR SALE: KEY WEST'S 'WHITE HOUSE'
description: The exterior of the white, two-story clapboard structure is as plain as the Navy's official name for it: Quarters A. Built in the last century on the Navy base at Key West as a residence, it has been shuttered for years.

title: A Conversation With Mitterrand
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France was sitting on a straight-backed couch in Elysee Palace talking quietly the other day about what he called ''the galloping horse of history.''

title: DOTS ON A SINAI MAP SPOIL THE VIEW FOR EGYPT
description: AN American official who has spent one too many hours dealing with the Egyptian-Israeli dispute over the Taba border region greeted the news of the latest snag in negotiations with the cynicism that only a problem blown totally out of proportion can produce. Taba is a 700-yard stretch of sand in northern Sinai with a five-star hotel and a topless beach.

title: A Lebow Play to Open Season in Philadelphia
description: A new play by Barbara Lebow, titled ''A Shayna Maidel,'' about a Jewish woman from Poland who survived the Nazi concentration camps and was reunited with her sister and father in the United States after World War II, will open the Philadelphia Drama Guild's 16th season on Oct. 10, the guild has announced.

title: A Middle-Class Approach to Civil Disobedience
description: Before she went out for the evening, Audrey Wells fried up some pork chops and left them in the oven to warm for when her husband got back from work.

title: Steps to Combat Crack Announced by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill has announced an educational and legal campaign against the drug crack, including legislation requiring sentences of up to life in prison for sellers of the potent form of cocaine.

title: WHAT VOTES CAN'T BUY
description: REAPING THE WHIRLWIND The Civil Rights Movement in Tuskegee. By Robert J. Norrell. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: CONCERTS AND ALBUMS FROM ROCK PERENNIALS
description: John Fogerty, Tina Turner, Chuck Berry, Elvis Costello, Lou Reed, Bonnie Raitt, Paul McCartney - these are some of the pop artists who will be clamoring for the public's attention this fall. Though they are a hetero-geneous group, they have at least one thing in common. They are pop music perennials, talented artists who have proven their staying power. Their hearty vitality, and their continuing commitment to something more satisfying than pure profit-seeking, are evidence that rock-and-roll can no longer be considered the domain of the very young. Many of them have found in rock's roots - the soul, gospel, country and blues that underly pop's rapidly changing trends - the musical equivalent of a fountain of youth.

title: THE NEW SUBTLETY
description: It begins with details: a richly woven necktie, a pair of French cuffs, a fabric whose fine crosshatching creates an illusion of texture and depth. These are some of the elements that comprise a more nuanced approach to dressing for fall, a polished but relaxed style that invites inspection at close range.

title: EDWARD N. NEY: AN ELEGANT EXECUTIVE
description: Edward N. Ney moves in a world of dark blue suits, and manages to look elegant in tan gabardine.

title: Mary Greene Marries
description: Mary Margaret Greene, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lynn Greene of Newport, N.Y., and Dr. Paul Stuart Davis were married in Bridgehampton, L.I., last evening at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Davis of New York and Bridgehampton. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony. Dr. Davis is a son also of Laurie Feuerman of New York and Becket, Mass.

title: LITERARY PRIZE FOR BLACK FOE OF APARTHEID
description: When she first thought of documenting the misery of fellow blacks through the pages of an autobiography, Ellen Kuzwayo said, she found that she was burdened by a legacy of her skin color.

title: FALL IS THE SEASON FOR SUMMER'S READING
description: YOU took six paperbacks and two library books to the shore this summer - with the best of intentions to read; what did you do? The library books are now in the bottom of the laundry bag. The paperbacks are tattered, grainy with sand and greasy from fried fish. What you didn't do was read. Each June you make a summer reading list, determined that this finally will be the year when you catch up.

title: THEORY ASIDE, THE KING SAFETY IS FOREMOST
description: No matter how pertinent to the course of a game positional factors such as a strong pawn center or the bishop-pair may be, they must take a back seat to an elemental value like king safety.

title: STAGE DESIGNER BECOMES THE SHOW
description: SEEING his work on exhibit for the first time in an art gallery had a profound effect on Tony Walton.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BRADFORD PEAR: TREE FOR THE CITIES
description: THE callery pear has shiny, deep green foliage and is resistent to fire blight, a bacterial disease that can destroy most pears. The callery pear bears white flowers in the spring, although the flowers are somewhat hidden among the leaves that emerge before they bloom. Its modest 20- to 30-foot height makes the pear well adapted for small gardens and other sites with limited space. Many individual plants produce a striking fall color that may range from crimson to wine purple. The fruits are small and insignificant, so they do not make a mess that must be cleaned up.

title: BOK'S OUTLINE OF RIGHT ROLE FOR ACADEMY
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Derek Bok, the president of Harvard University, to a convocation in Harvard Yard this afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS ALL GUNMEN SEIZED IN AIRPORT ATTACK
description: The Pakistani authorities, revising the details of the capture of a hijacked Pan American jumbo jet on Friday, said tonight that all four gunmen who had seized the plane were alive and had been taken into custody by Government security forces.

title: LABELING THIS ERA MAY BE EASY AFTER ALL
description: When the time comes for the art historians to choose a label for the declining years of this century, what will it be? Perhaps in light of the quality of the paint we are using and the messiness of the picture we are painting, they will decide to duck the question. Maybe the final quarter of this century will simply be ignored as of no cultural consequence, an era without a Zeitgeist to call its own. How humiliating.

title: D. S. Weil to Wed Hope B. Wickser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Chapin's daughter Hope Baldwin Wickser to David Scott Weil, the son of Nancy Erkes Weil of Philadelphia and Fredrick Stuart Weil of New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption last sunday on billboard art in Hartford misidentified a graphic design titled ''Summer 1986'' at 489 Main Street. The work is by William Wondriska.

title: A COOLER, TOUGHER WOMAN
description: AN ACADEMIC QUESTION By Barbara Pym. 182 pp. New York: E.cP. Dutton. $15.95.

title: More Defiance In South Africa, And Quiet Burials
description: Militants defied South Africa's stringent security controls again last week, but the protests were largely contained.

title: WASHINGTON VOICE FOR DAIRY FARMERS
description: When Lloyd (Pat) Patterson rises at 4:30 each morning he has a lot on his mind.

title: Early Primary Returns Show Guam's Governor in the Lead
description: Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo, who was indicted on Federal charges, a few days before the Democratic primary, led in early returns today.

title: LUNACY AMONG THE TEACUPS
description: LILIAN'S STORY By Kate Grenville. 227 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: INDIANS KEEPING GEM TRADE WITH DE BEERS GROUP
description: India, which has been demanding sanctions against South Africa, conducts trade worth hundreds of millions of dollars every year with the subsidiary of a South African mining company, according to official sources.

title: FOR BRAZILIAN, U.S. TRIP MARKS SURGE IN STATUS
description: President Jose Sarney will visit Washington next week as the leader of a nation that has recovered its traditional self-confidence and is now seeking United States recognition of its new status as an influential third world democracy and a growing economic power.

title: CAMPUS DAY CARE
description: WESTCHESTER Community College has opened a child-care center in a new, one-story building that it will share with the athletics department on its Valhalla campus. Constructed as a fieldhouse, one half of it will be used by the teams only after the children, in the other half, have gone home at 3 P.M. The day-care portion of the building has been suitably renovated and equipment for play and learning activities has been installed indoors and outdoors.

title: 16 Hours of Terror: The Pakistani Account
description: At a news conference in Karachi yesterday, the Pakistani authorities gave an account of the hijacking Friday of Pan American World Airways Flight 73. Here are the key developments; all times are approximate. 6 A.M. (9 P.M. Thursday, New York time.) The hijacking begins as four gunmen speed onto the tarmac at Karachi International Airport in a blue van. Firing into the air, they clamber aboard the Pan Am jumbo jet, taking it over. The two pilots and the flight engineer, hearing the shots, flee through an emergency hatch over the cockpit.

title: Steam Buffs' Alert
description: If it were not for the current low price of oil, the country might be on the way toward bringing the steam locomotive out of retirement. The Department of Energy has conducted a year's study on the feasibility of replacing diesel engines with a modernized form of the old iron horse, using new technologies to covert coal into motive power and reduce smoke pollution drastically.

title: Joan Salzman Is Wed
description: Joan M. Salzman, an assistant general counsel of Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. in New York, was married last night to Michael I. Grant, an assistant vice president of Citicorp in New York. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Mrs. Grant is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Salzman of Scarsdale. Mr. Grant is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grant of Cranston, R.I.

title: DAKOTA SENATOR SEES HIS LEAD SLIP
description: Like his Democratic opponent, Senator Mark Andrews has called for a Federal investigation to try to dispel a mystery surrounding some political snooping that some North Dakotans believe went a step too far into private lives.

title: U.S. REPORTER SAYS MOSCOW INTERROGATORS HINT AT A POSSIBLE TRADE
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American reporter being held here on suspicion of espionage, told his wife by telephone today that interrogators had hinted he might be freed in a prisoner exchange, but that the indications ''were very fuzzy.''

title: FRANCE REPORTS TWO IRAQIS CITED BY MILITANTS MAY RETURN
description: France's Foreign Minister said this week that two Iraqi students, whose return to France is being demanded by Moslem extremists holding French hostages in Lebanon, are free to return to this country whenever they choose to.

title: STATE APPLE CROP LOOKS GOOD FOR MOST BUT NOT ALL GROWERS
description: As the annual apple harvest started this week, Jeffrey Crist and his wife, Joy, looked across an orchard on the 600-acre Crist Brothers Farm here in Orange County and watched a team of migrant workers busily picking bright red Johnamac and McIntosh apples and loading them into huge wooden bins.

title: U.S. SENDS A TEAM TO AID PAKISTANS
description: The Reagan Administration sent a team of American investigators to Pakistan today to help in learning the identities and affiliation of the hijackers of a Pan American jumbo jet in Karachi.

title: Q AND A
description: Absentee Tenant Question: I have been granted power of attorney for my elderly aunt, who lived in a rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan for 40 years before her confinement two years ago to a nursing home. It is unclear whether she will ever return to the apartment to live on her own; the landlord is aware of the situation and I have been paying the rent. Since the apartment is unoccupied and her belongings are still in it, I am worried about its vulnerability to burglars and vandals. May I allow someone to stay in the apartment either as a sublet or house-sitting arrangement? And if my aunt dies in the nursing home, will I have any rights to the apartment? . . . L. K., Port Washington, L.I. Answer: According to Thomas Viola, a spokesman for the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, a rent-controlled tenant needs the permission of the landlord to sublet even if the original lease allowed it. Matthew Shafit, a laywer with the firm of Roseman, Colin, Freund, Lewis & Cohen, said your aunt's landlord might refuse because of the potential economic gain if the unit were to lose its rent-controlled status.

title: Linda R. Widmer Wed to a Lawyer
description: Linda R. Widmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Widmer of New York and Perth, Australia, was married yesterday to Paul Louis Bressan, the son of the late Nance Bressan Mildner and the late Louis Bressan of Garden City, L.I. . The Rev. William F. Guido performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York.

title: Arabs and Jews In Israel
description: Given the tremendous amount of attention focused on Israel's problems, it was particularly illuminating to read David K. Shipler's article (''Arabs and Jews in Israel,'' Aug. 10). Not only does Mr. Shipler address the problem of reciprocal prejudice and stereotypical negative images between Jews and Arabs but he also presents attempted solutions at coexistence.

title: THE WIDER HORIZONS OF SISSY SPACEK
description: ACTING,'' SAYS SISSY SPACEK with a tilt of her strawberry-blond head, ''is a funny thing.''

title: ASTRONOMER, 24, FINDS COMET
description: Christine Wilson, a 24-year-old graduate student in astronomy, has discovered a new comet that is said to rival the size of Halley's comet.

title: PAINTING INTERIORS: MORE THAN JUST A BRUSH WITH THE WALLS
description: REPAINTING rooms is not as simple as it might seem. To avoid creating a mess, a room must be properly prepared and the work must follow a logical sequence to avoid smearing paint on surfaces that have already been finished.

title: RESULTS DISPUTED IN INQUIRY ON FORMER SAFETY COMMISSION MEMBER
description: The General Accounting Office has issued a report on allegations of misconduct made against Stuart M. Statler when he was a member of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, and the two sides in the dispute have drawn diametrically different conclusions from it.

title: OFF TO THE MARKET, FROM NOWHERE
description: I LIVE in the middle of nowhere. But I still need to eat - although there are purists who say living with the trees, hills and river is food enough.

title: Cynthia Katz Is Married
description: At Temple Israel of the City of New York last night Cynthia Ann Katz, a freelance writer, was married to Dr. Mark Charles Steckel, a resident in ophthalmology at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The bridegroom's father, Cantor Harold Steckel, performed the ceremony. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Jean Katz of New York and the late Joseph H. Katz. Dr. Steckel is a son also of Mrs. Steckel of Bayside, Queens.

title: More Than Brodsky
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW ORCHESTRA EXPANDS ITS SEASON
description: IN only three seasons, the New Orchestra of Westchester has carved a major place for itself in county music circles. Its success has been such, in fact, that a Sunday afternoon series has now been added to the original Saturday evening cycle, the back-to-back concerts held at the Arts Center on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: SETTLING INEXORABLY INTO AN OLIGOPOLY
description: WHAT does the recent rash of airline mergers tell us about the future of the industry? Will it come to be dominated by a few giant carriers that set prices and service with a damn-the-consumer arrogance? Or will competition, abetted by judicious antitrust enforcement, continue to keep fares down and service up?

title: BETRAYED BY A GORGEOUS CAD
description: THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY By Karleen Koen. 743 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: ARABS AND JEWS IN ISRAEL
description: Peace with the Arabs does not depend on interaction between Jews and Arabs, otherwise we could have accomplished that decades ago. It depends primarily on two factors.

title: PIPELINE TERMINUS IS A THRIVING CITY
description: On Monday night, just before the Arctic sun sets on the frozen plain at Prudhoe Bay, a noteworthy 42 gallons of petroleum will gush up from one of the scores of wells that dot the oilfield.

title: Swedes Report Progress In Palme Investigation
description: The Swedish police said this week that they were making progress in the investigation of the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme and hoped to see arrests in the next few months.

title: The Fading Allure of Incorporation
description: LAST year, James and Marnie Tynen incorporated Wet Paint Inc., their two-year-old alternative greeting card company in Pittsburgh. The Tynens found that the corporation was a better form of business for raising capital, and it forced them to be more organized - which in turn made the company more profitable. But when the board of directors meets in November, one item on the agenda will be whether to dissolve the corporation and run Wet Paint as a partnership instead.

title: Topics: Gifted Athletes; The N.C.A.A. Tigers
description: Those enforcement tigers at the National Collegiate Athletic Association have pounced again. This time they landed on the University of Nebraska, suspending 60 football players for misusing the four free game passes given to each player.

title: Harvard Gives Itself a Party
description: At its 350th anniversary celebration last week, Harvard University marked its illustrious past but paid at least as much attention to the concerns of the present.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Bergen County community of Paramus, home to half a dozen shopping malls, is facing a test of its blue laws. This came about after the borough police issued summonses last month to a Shopright supermarket and one of its employees for selling a roll of paper towels on a Sunday.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bellevue, Wash.; Bringing Back The Pedestrian
description: THIS onetime Seattle bedroom community, now the fourth-largest city in the state, has long been known as the city without sidewalks. It is virtually impossible, as a local reporter documented a few years ago, to walk continuously from one part of downtown to another.

title: ANIMAL GROUP UPSET WITH MYSITC
description: AN animal rights group is campaigning to get the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium to change the way it collects and keeps marine animals.

title: VERMONT'S UBIQUITOUS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: They've played Tchaikovsky next to moose tracks in Lewis, Bach in the ghost town of Glastenbury and jazz in a one-room schoolhouse in Lemington.

title: LOOKING FOR 'THE PLACE JUST RIGHT'
description: '' 'Tis the gift to be simple, 'Tis the gift to be free, 'Tis the gift to come down Where we ought to be.'' - ''Simple Gifts,'' old Shaker song BY 8 in the morning, it was so humid I had to turn on the air-conditioner so I could put on my makeup without having it slide off my face.

title: Miss Mangan Wed to John Murtagh Jr.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday Margaret Mary Mangan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Mangan of Bronxville, was married to John Martin Murtagh Jr., a son of Mrs. John M. Murtagh of Bronxville and Lake Winola, Pa., and the late Justice Murtagh of New York State Supreme Court. The Rev. Robert J. Sweeney performed the ceremony.

title: TOO ECUMENICAL
description: AS this biography makes clear, Hanna Sheehy-Skeffington, born Johanna Mary Sheehy in 1877, was a remarkable woman and a figure of considerable importance in the cause of Irish nationalism. She can join the list of female political leaders who were insufficiently regarded while alive and, dead, have been forgotten.

title: FINDING A MIDDLE BETWEEN FAIRNESS AND EFFICIENCY
description: WHATEVER the incidence of drug abuse among Americans, the incidence of testing by their employers is rising rapidly. More than a dozen of the New York area's largest employers test new workers for drugs, and many more are planning to do so. In a New York Times/CBS News Poll released last week, 44 percent supported such testing, and 44 opposed it. Proponents say the exams, usually urinalyses, are a reasonable requirement and effectively deter drug use. Critics contend that the tests are invasive and unreliable. Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, discussed the issue with Rear Adm. Paul J. Mulloy, who retired as head of the Navy's anti-drug program in 1984 and is a consultant to businesses on drug abuse, and Dr. Robert G. Newman, president of Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, who opposes routine screening of workers. Excerpts follow. Adm. Mulloy A REASONABLE DETERRENT

title: WANTED: HELP FOR A DIOCESE
description: THE Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre wants to double the number of Spanish-speaking priests in parishes across Long Island.

title: Dire Straits
description: Individuals living in poverty * (in percent)

title: Greek Art, Modern
description: Washington is no stranger to classical Greek art forms, but modern works are rare. It will thus be something of an event tomorrow when an exhibition of 55 modern paintings from the collection of Ian Vorres, a Greek business executive and collector who two decades ago established the Vorres Museum of Contemorary Greek Art, opens on Capitol Hill. Sponsored by Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, the show will hang for four days in the rotunda of the Russell Senate Office Building.

title: Dr. Arguimbau Becomes Bride
description: Dr. Mariette Carmen Arguimbau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent C. Arguimbau Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Seville, Spain, was married yesterday to Edward Barton Scott 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Alexander Barton Scott 5th of Guatemala City. The Rev. Elwood Stark performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., assisted by the Rev. Timothy Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: MUSIC: ELODIE LAUTEN
description: DANSE MIRAGE THEATER, located one flight above street level at 153 Mercer Street, began a four-week series of concerts entitled ''An Artist's Fall'' Friday night, with a performance by the pianist and composer Elodie Lauten.

title: THUGS WHO KNOW THEIR GREEK
description: HIGH ART By Rubem Fonseca. Translated by Ellen Watson. 345 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: A VICTORIAN SETTING IN BREWSTER
description: THE forbidding chain link fence surrounding this once dilapidated building that had featured a dingy topless bar remains, but now within these gates, bright flowers and formal shrubbery gently edge a proper 19th-century manse, renewed by more than just a fresh coat of paint.

title: LEGITIMATE DEGREES PUT TO ILLEGITIMATE USE
description: Laufey Bustany's Aug. 3 Opinion article on nutrition quackery and unaccredited degrees prompts me to comment on the widespread misuse of legitimate degrees; people with legitimate doctorates in a discipline speak with the authority of ''doctor'' on subjects remote from their specialities.

title: Q AND A
description: Lap Swimming Question:We want to do daily lap swimming during a Rocky Mountain holiday. Please suggest resort hotels above an altitude of 7,000 feet with a warm-water pool larger than 60 by 30 feet. - R. A., Houston Answer:Several resorts offer lap swimming, although they may not meet the precise needs described. The indoor, heated pool at Copper Mountain, the ski and golf resort in Colorado, for example, is 75 feet long with four lanes to a total width of about 20 feet The pool, which is in the resort's athletic club and open year round, may be used without charge by guests lodging with Copper Mountain Inc., which manages many condominiums. The base of Copper Mountain is 9,600 feet above sea level. Copper Mountain (Post Office Box 3001, Colo. 80443; 303-968-2882 or 800-525-3878) is near the resort town of Dillon, about 80 miles west of Denver.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Broward Co., Fla.;
Near Dade, But Not in It
description: FOR many of the people who have been moving out of Dade County in recent years, Broward County, 30 miles to the north, has been the destination. Some developers estimate that as much as 30 percent of the new housing in Broward is being sold to Dade residents, many of whom say they are trying to avoid the drugs, crime and other urban problems in Miami.

title: FARMERS IN OVERALLS BATTLE THOSE IN SUITS
description: A LONG-RUNNING battle between big investors and many farmers over who can own agricultural land in Nebraska threatens to heat up anew later this year.

title: Verbatim; Costly Esthetics
description: 'When esthetics threatens the life of a congregation and threatens the free exercise of religion, it does harm.

title: ARCHBISHOP RITES HONOR TUTU TODAY
description: The outdoor communion service Sunday that will mark Desmond M. Tutu's enthronement as the first black person to become Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town is to end with the singing of ''Nkosi Sikelele Africa,'' or ''God Bless Africa.''

title: Affordability vs. the Building Code
description: WHILE most nonprofit housing developers are struggling to build houses for less than $90,000, one organization, the East Brooklyn Churches, is building more than 1,000 brick houses for $53,000 apiece. The Nehemiah Plan Homes, as the Brownsville project is known, can be built so inexpensively because the 50 churches in the group finance the project themselves and use some innovative construction techniques.

title: THE PRE-SUMMIT PATTERN SEEMS REVERSED THIS YEAR
description: THE prospect of a Soviet-American summit meeting usually puts both superpowers on their best behavior. They tone down the hostile rhetoric, avoid abusive actions and intensify their search for areas of accord as the date approaches. As one of President Reagan's advisers observed some years ago, it is most fruitful to be ''always on the verge of a major undertaking'' with the Russians; in such a moment, the Kremlin is about as amenable as it ever gets.

title: FABI GETS POLE POSITION
description: Teo Fabi of Italy beat the lap record by more than one second in qualifying today to win the pole position for the Italian Formula One Grand Prix.

title: CONDUCTORS ARE IN THE SPOTLIGHT ON NEW CLASSICAL RELEASES
description: Record companies in recent years increasingly have been stressing performers rather than fresh repertory in their approach to classical recordings, and in the months ahead the performers that seem most in evidence are the conductors, with a number of major stars of the podium represented with an unusually long list of entries in all formats - compact disk, LP and cassette - while major singers and instrumentalists appear to be somewhat less in evidence than in previous years.

title: NEIL SIMON, ARTHUR MILLER, AND A DAVID HARE MUSICAL
description: In the theater, the promises of September can turn out to be the foreclosures of winter, and, on the other hand, shows unmentioned in the fall may become the most talked about plays by the end of the season. Broadway, in particular, is a leader in the wait-and-see game, as questions linger in the air. Can we sign [ Madonna, Kathleen Turner, Kevin Klein ] ? Is the [ Golden, Music Box, Mark Hellinger ] available? Has [ John Guare, David Mamet, Tom Stoppard ] finished his new play? And, most important, can we raise [$500,000, $2.5 million, $5 million ] ? A look at this year's prospects reveals a full round of ifs, maybes and buts, yet some things are (fairly) certain.

title: Kuwait Belittled
description: To the Editor:

title: For Congress From New York
description: It's rare for New York Republican races to be decided in the primary, and then it happens only upstate - as in Utica's 25th Congressional District this year. The incumbent, Sherwood Boehlert, a moderate with a fine conservation record who deserves re-election, is threatened by the far-right zeal of Robert Barstow. But in New York City, dispositive primaries come only on the Democratic side. This year, three races for Congress will be settled in Tuesday's Democratic primary. MANHATTAN

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Battle Lines Forming on Rents in Nassau
description: TENANTS and owners of the declining number of rent-stabilized apartments in Nassau County agree that the rental-housing situation is grim and getting grimmer.

title: Proud to Be From Flushing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE BUBBLE AND BOUNCE OF PARIS
description: THEY ARE MADE from bits and pieces of superfluous stuff: a froth of lace and veil, a provocative bow placed just so, a lariat of pearls undulating in an unexpected location, a skirt flouncing over a ruffled petticoat, a luxurious fabric scrunched into sumptuous folds or poufed into a bustle or bell-shaped sleeves.

title: IN KENNEDY TERRITORY, A NOT-SO-EASY HOUSE RACE
description: Is an upset in the making here? Is it possible that Joe Kennedy will lose? There are two answers to this, the conventional wisdom and Tip's wisdom.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS IS MOVING TO COUNTY
description: IN the spring of 1987 when American Savings Bank FSB, with assets of $3.7 billion, completes its move from 280 Madison Avenue in Manhattan to 99 Church Street in White Plains, it will become the second-largest savings bank in Westchester County, topped only by Dollar Dry Dock, with assets of $5 billion, which moved its headquarters to White Plains from the Bronx two years ago.

title: ELECTIONS COMMISSIONERS SEEM HEADED TO COURT IN DISPUTE
description: ON the eve of the New York State Primary, Westchester's Democratic and Republican Elections Commissioners are in a battle of their own.

title:
DINING OUT;
4-VISIT BOX SCORE: 3 HITS, 1 ERROR
description: REVIEWERS usually give a restaurant more of a chance than does the average restaurant-goer. We visited a 16-month-old French restaurant in the Bucks County town of Newtown, Pa., four times. Three of the visits were delightful, but one was really not very good.

title: No Headline
description: An article about Herschel Walker in the Sunday Sports section Aug. 31 misidentified a highway near Walker's hotel in Irving, Tex. The highway is Interstate 635.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE REBURYING INDIANS

title: DESPITE TEACHER'S MANUAL, SPIRIT OF OPTIMISM PREVAILS
description: IT'S time to turn my attention from sun and sand, to sit at my desk surrounded by books, pens, pencils and pads, to prepare the course I will begin teaching this month. This year it's college freshmen, something brand new for me. In years past, it was elementary school, then high school students. The course is new and I can't wait to open the shiny red student text.

title: A CORRECTION
description: William Sheinkopf, who wrote the Speaking Personally column of Aug. 24, lives in Hoboken.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: REFLECTIONS IN A WRITER'S EYE: Travel Pieces. By Angus Wilson. (Viking $15.95) With the poised irreverence for which some have likened him to E.M. Forster, the British novelist and critic Angus Wilson knows in words how to capture a place by the gullet.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Legislature returns from its summer recess tomorrow with several major environmental issues high on its agenda:

title: WHAT'S NEW AMONG EXECUTIVE PITCHMEN
description: EXECUTIVES and economists are not only gracing board meetings and Congressional hearings these days. They are also showing up on billboards, on television and in magazines, hawking clothing, computers, liquor, all kinds of products made by companies other than their own.

title: Well Gas Kills 4 in Spain
description: Toxic gas leaking from a water well near Almenara in eastern Spain killed three members of one family and a policeman who went to look for them Friday, a local official said today.

title: Waterbury Finally Coming Into Its Own
description: WATERBURY, a hilly community of 28 square miles in the heart of the Naugatuck Valley, was long considered one of the shabbier, more economically depressed of Connecticut's older smokestack cities.

title: YOUR DOG IS SIZING YOU UP
description: ADAM'S TASK Calling Animals by Name. By Vicki Hearne. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: The telephone number for the Oakland Group Inc. was incorrect in last week's Executive Computer column. The correct number is (800) 233-3733.

title: Say Yes to Reform
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
Making Sears More Friendly
description: ONE million people visit the Sears Tower every year, but until recently the retail tenants in the world's tallest building saw very few of them. Sightseers en route to the skydeck squeezed through the same maze of narrow corridors that office tenants used. Meanwhile, the 26 retail stores totaling 200,000 square feet on five levels were foundering.

title: Nebraska Stops Florida State
description: Steve Taylor, a sophomore quarterback starting his first game, had a part in four touchdowns tonight as Nebraska routed Florida State, 34-17.

title: GRANTS TO AID HISTORICAL AREAS
description: THE state will issue grants this year totaling $1 million for the historic restoration and economic revitalization of five selected downtown districts.

title: THOUGHTS ABOUT HOME, WHILE FLIPPING DIAL ABROAD
description: With another new season poised to begin percolating on television, battle-scarred observers will be forgiven an uneasy feeling of dread. While indefatigable - and in some cases shameless - publicists offer promises of memorable dramas and diversions, broadcasting veterans know full well that as much as 90 percent of the new shows are doomed to failure. Then, assorted watchdogs will begin warming up their computer terminals to churn out fresh batches of absolutely convincing essays about television as a trivializer of great issues or a corrupter of young minds, while industry hacks will dig up incontrovertible evidence proving that television broadens the mind and elevates the spirit. Lost in the yearly ritual of sound and fury is the fact that television has now evolved to the point where, with sensible handling, it can perform the role of old, comfortable and welcome companion.

title: Single Older Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Challenge in the Sky ''COURAGE is not being fearless,'' says Michael G. Conway of Garden City. ''It's having fears and mastering them.''

title: William G. Leahy Marries Pamela Ann Scott on L.I.
description: The marriage of Pamela Ann Scott and William G. Leahy, 1986 graduates of Ohio State University, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Southampton, L.I. The Rev. William J. Remey performed the ceremony.

title: 2d Valve Mishap Shuts Down Nuclear Plant in Connecticut
description: The Millstone 3 nuclear power plant shut down this morning after the second malfunction in two days, Northeast Utilities reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 31 with the ''Our Towns'' column misidentified the location of a skateboard ramp in South Windsor, Conn. It was at Route 5 BMX, a sports shop.

title: Nicole Nicholas Is Engaged to Marry Charles Edward Hambro in December
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. James A. Nicholas of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Nicholas, to Charles Edward Hambro, a son of Charles Eric Alexander Hambro and and Rose Evelyn Hambro, both of Cheltenham, England. The wedding is planned for December.

title: GORBACHEV FINDS AN ALLY IN CAPITALISM
description: PARTLY stymied in his straightforward attempts to reform and modernize the Soviet economy, Mikhail Gorbachev has recently begun to unveil a backdoor strategy. While still in its earliest stages, the plan seems to involve exposing Soviet enterprises to the international economy through joint ventures with Western companies and through greater Soviet participation in the international economic establishment. By exposing Soviet industry to the ways of the capitalist world, Mr. Gorbachev hopes to stimulate productivity growth and the speedier mastery of world technology.

title: David Andrews Wed To Lisa Montgomery
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Lisa Marie Montgomery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Roger Montgomery of Old Greenwich and Siesta Key, Fla., was married to David Stafford Andrews, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lynwood Andrews of Alpine, N.J. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony.

title: JETS' CAST IS FAMILIAR; Only Two New Players On Roster
description: IN an unusual series of events -some misjudgments, bad luck and good luck - the Jets start the 1986 season today without suiting up any of their 11 draft picks. That never happened to them before, and they wind up as the only team in the N.F.L. this year that didn't place a draft choice on the opening-day roster.

title: A CONNECTICUT MALL TO COMPETE SOON
description: MOST of Westchester's shopping malls are about 95 percent occupied by stores and, judging by their crowded escalators, busy cash registers and the assessment of their managers, very successful. But soon the county's malls will have competition. The Danbury Fair Mall, hailed by its developers as the largest shopping mall in New England, is to open later this month with four major department stores and hundreds of small stores on 1.2 million square feet.

title: Shakespeare Library Getting A Facelift
description: The Folger Library is one of Washington's beloved institutions. On Capitol Hill just a short distance from Congress, it is the repository of the largest collection of Shakespearean works in existence, a testament to the civilizing world of the scholar in midst of the combative world of the politican.

title: SHAKESPEARE (ET AL) AT DREW
description: IN response to age-old speculation about who really wrote Shakespeare's plays, Charles Ludlam, the outrageous playwright-producer-director and star of Off-Off-Broadway's ''Ridiculous Theatrical Company, settled the question once and for all.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. SAN DIEGO PADRES, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050, 1:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Fighting Scandal at Lockheed
description: EACH day, for up to 18 hours at a stretch, Lockheed Corporation officials paraded through a hastily prepared conference room in the company's headquarters. Their interrogator was merciless: He grilled them about security on a top-secret project, believed to be the new Stealth fighter plane. He took them painstakingly through every detail of how documents are accounted for at Lockheed, and how it could happen that hundreds of papers appeared to be missing.

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS SEEK ORDERLY OPENING DAY
description: COMMUNITY leaders and education officials in Yonkers last week predicted a peaceful and orderly school opening tomorrow as court-ordered integration of the city's public schools begins.

title: UCONN PRESIDENT RETURNS TO HIS ROOTS
description: AT the University of Connecticut, English 109 is an introductory course, usually taught by graduate students.

title: LIVING FOR CHILDREN: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: After reading Joan Baum's article, ''Living for the Children Isn't Living,'' I am reminded of one of life's responsibilities; I am a mother, but just what are my limits of parental obligation?

title: THE JAPANESE BANK THAT IS NOW NO. 1
description: Nobuya Hagura, the president of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, smiles when he remembers his years in New York City in the mid-1960's, when he was manager of the New York agency of the Kangyo bank, a predecessor of his current bank. In those days, he used to regularly make the rounds of leading American banks to borrow money to swell his bank's relatively small reserves.

title: INDEPENDENT OR FLEET DRIVER, A CABBY IS ALWAYS MISUNDERSTOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT FISHERMEN BEGIN LEGAL ACTION TO CHECK SEWAGE SPILLS IN SOUND
description: Thousands of people descended on a sun-splashed waterfront park here this weekend for the ninth annual Norwalk Oyster Festival.

title: Preparing A 'Pop-Up' For Time
description: THE Transamerica Corporation's nine-inch high, full-color ''pop-up'' advertisement that appeared in last week's Time magazine was the culmination of more than 10 months of preparations, technical problems and hand assembly in Latin America requiring 420,000 worker-hours. It also involved suspense up to the last moment as to whether the magazine might be harmed in mailboxes or crumpled in readers' pockets.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENCHANTMENT. By Daphne Merkin. 288 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: ALLIED'S SURPRISE CHOICE, MACIOCE HAS PAID OFF
description: When Thomas M. Macioce was elected to head the Allied Stores Corporation in 1972, the move was generally regarded with skepticism by people within the retail industry. Mr. Macioce, who had little experience in merchandising and marketing, was one of the first chief executives of a major retail chain to have primarily a financial background. Apparently, the move paid off. ''He has steadily improved return on equity and profit margins,'' said Edmund F. Johnson, the director of Johnson Redbook Service in New York, a division of Prescott, Ball & Turben. ''People condemned him for not having a merchandising background, but he's plugged and has grown his sales nicely. He has been highly successful.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1986
description: International

title: DANGEROUS LENGTHENING OF LATIN RECESSION SEEN
description: Latin America's economic recession is ''lengthening dangerously,'' because of huge capital outflows to pay international debt, and will not be reversed until the resource drain is cut ''significantly,'' the Inter-American Development Bank said today.

title: Acquisition by Doner
description: W. B. Doner & Company, a Baltimore advertising agency, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Lou Beres & Associates, a full-service Chicago agency.

title: Hildy Gottlieb Is the Bride Of Walter Hill, a Director
description: Hildy Gottlieb, a talent agent at International Creative Management in Los Angeles, was married in New York yesterday to Walter Hill, the director whose films include ''48 Hours'' and ''The Warriors.''

title: DANGER'S HOUR WINNER
description: The nation's grass division, which all year has looked like the weakest in racing, has come to life in the last 72 hours. On Friday night at the Meadowlands, Manila, a 3-year-old, thrashed older horses impressively, and yesterday Danger's Hour looked tough winning a stretch-long duel from Premier Mister to take the Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: TENNESSEE WINS DESPITE BAN
description: The one-game suspension of 10 Tennessee players Saturday night for improper distribution of tickets seemed totally out of proportion to the nature of the violation, according to Johnny Majors, the Volunteers' coach.

title: Scranton Concedes He Used Drugs When He Was Younger
description: Lieut. Gov. William W. Scranton 3d, the Republican candidate for Governor, says he used ''recreational'' drugs when he was younger but does not any more.

title: Washington Watch; Curbing F.S.L.I.C. Defectors
description: As the Federal Home Loan Bank Board wrestles with the problems of the battered thrift industry, one of its biggest fears is that healthy savings and loan associations will defect from the savings and loan insurance system, preferring that their deposits be insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. This could leave the already hard-pressed Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation with a group of weak sisters.

title: FINAL STEPS MAPPED ON TAX BILL
description: When Congress reconvenes Monday after its three-week summer recess, the stage will be set for the last act of the long-running drama on tax revision legislation.

title: THE SOVIET LAW ON SPYING
description: Following is the text of Article 65 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic under which Nicholas S. Daniloff was accused of espionage. It is taken from the 1972 book ''Soviet Criminal Law and Procedure'' by Harold J. Berman.

title: BRONCOS OVERCOME RAIDERS BY 38-36
description: John Elway threw two touchdown passes and caught one today to lead the Denver Broncos to a wild 38-36 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: Books: On Baseball
description: ME AND DIMAGGIO. A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods. By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. 303 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. ''WHAT are you doing here?'' Red Smith asks The New York Times book reviewer Christopher Lehmann-Haupt at spring training in 1979.

title: Staying Afloat
description: Yacht racing in the United States has been the most determinedly amateur of sports and, especially in the major classes, the most democratic: Full-blown ocean racing is open to absolutely everyone able to spare the $500,000 to $1 million a year it takes to build, outfit and maintain one of the 80-foot maxi boats. To keep the sport safe from the slightest taint of gainful endeavor, its American governing body, the United States Yacht Racing Union, has strict rules against professional racers and the awarding of prize money, and severely restricts commercial sponsorship of boats.

title: John Arthur Hedges Marries Janice L. Honigberg
description: Janice Lynn Honigberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel D. Honigberg of Highland Park, Ill., and Paris, was married yesterday to John Arthur Hedges, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hedges of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Harold Kudan performed the ceremony at the Northmoor Country Club in Highland Park.

title: TAX BILL AND JUDICIAL NOMINATIONS AWAIT CONGRESS
description: When Congress returns to work Monday after a three-week holiday, the lawmakers will be facing decisions that could have far-reaching effects on the nation's economic and judicial systems.

title: Boxer Is Best
description: Ch. Turo's Cachet, a 4-year-old boxer owned by Leonard and Susan Magowitz of New York, today led a field of 2,856 dogs at the 69th Westchester Kennel Club show on the grounds of Lyndhurst, a national landmark.

title: 3 KEY INGREDIENTS IN A BUYOUT RECIPE
description: The trick to a successful buyout is getting the right proportions in its financial structure.

title: CABBY SEIZED IN SHOOTING OF 2
description: A gypsy-cab driver shot and wounded two men who were in a crowd that stopped him when he ran a red light and almost hit them in upper Manhattan early yesterday, the police said.

title: REDSKINS ROUT EAGLES IN RYAN'S DEBUT
description: The Washington Redskins today introduced a new player, Kelvin Bryant, who promises to do wonders for their offense. The running back from the United States Football League scored two touchdowns as the Redskins routed the Philadelphia Eagles, 41-14, before the usual capacity crowd of 53,982, the 150th consecutive sellout at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: About the Weather
description: Starting today, The Times is publishing a new weather report, with map and expanded forecasts from the meteorology department of Pennsylvania State University. Page B10.

title: CAMPEAU'S GOAL: RETAIL REAL ESTATE
description: Robert Campeau, who, through his Campeau Corporation, is pursuing the Allied Stores Corporation in a $3.11 billion offer, lacks neither luck nor ambition.

title: The Editorial Notebook; First Flower, a Hundred Flowers
description: The impulse burst through the New England wilderness with surprising speed. The first settlers had barely ''provided necessaries,'' John Eliot wrote in 1643, cabins and churches before they longed ''to advance Learning and perpetuate to Posterity. . . . It pleased God to stir up the heart of one Mr. Harvard to give the one-half of his estate . . . towards the erecting of a College, and all his Library.''

title: Chelsea Isn't Overjoyed As Postman Rings Again
description: Snow, rain, heat and gloom of night are nothing compared with Chelsea residents when it comes to staying the postal authorities from the swift completion of their building plans.

title: Is India Dodging Nuclear Controls?
description: Do controls on nuclear exports really work? Or are they just a veil behind which nations buy and sell the means to make atomic bombs? India is now forcing these questions on the world. India has either diverted nuclear material from international inspection or imported it secretly from China and is using it to increase dramatically its ability to build a nuclear arsenal.

title: Syria Chief Repeats Demand For a U.N.-Sponsored Parley
description: President Hafez al-Assad stressed Syria's demand for an international Middle East peace conference today when he met with a senior United States official, Syria's official news agency reported.

title: Washington Watch; Jamaica Rejects Devaluation
description: Jamaica badly wants a new loan from the International Monetary Fund, but Prime Minister Edward Seaga has decided to reject one of the I.M.F.'s main conditions - a new devaluation of the Jamaican dollar.

title: IN CONNECTICUT PRIMARY, HOPES FOR G.O.P. STRENGTH
description: Connecticut Republicans, who have elected only one governor in the past 32 years, are counting on a three-way gubernatorial primary election Tuesday to improve their chances against the incumbent Democrat, Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: LONG LEGAL ORDEAL FORECAST FOR REPORTER IF U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD EMERGES
description: A leading expert on the Soviet legal system said today that the American journalist accused of espionage in the Soviet Union may face a long ordeal if the United States and the Soviet Union do not make political arrangements to free him.

title: LURE OF LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: As if he did not have enough to read already, Brian F. Wruble now has Chicago's two daily newspapers delivered to his Manhattan home every morning. The reason: The Equitable Capital Management Corporation, which he runs, has invested $50 million in a $145 million leveraged buyout of The Chicago Sun-Times, and he wants to keep a close eye on his investment, as well as its competitor, The Chicago Tribune.

title: A RENAISSANCE ROMP IN MERRIE OLDE KANSAS
description: What ho! What manner of apparition is this, rising over yon plain of parked cars? What castles, what battlemented walls and turrets rising over the dells, against darkening skies?

title: CBS SAYS IT DIDN'T SEEK BIDS
description: The management of CBS Inc., in a struggle with the largest CBS stockholder for control of the company, last night denied reports that it had spoken with Philip Morris Inc. and Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc. about buying CBS.

title: BROOKLYN MAN DROWNS MAKING RESCUE ATTEMPT
description: While trying to rescue a stranger who was apparently committing suicide, a 27-year-old man dived into the Hudson River at West 10th Street on Saturday night and drowned, the police said.

title: Architectural Split At Cooper Eckstut
description: The partners in Cooper Eckstut Associates, whose master plans for projects such as Battery Park City and the redevelopment of Times Square made their firm one of the most visible in planning and architecture, have split their practice.

title: HELPING TEEN-AGERS IN TROUBLE
description: IT'S past 10 P.M. when a police officer arrives at the door to inform you that your 15-year-old son is in custody for a vandalism spree that left dozens of store windows smashed.

title: Spy Agency Damaged In West German Blast
description: A powerful bomb exploded early today outside a building housing West Germany's counterespionage agency, heavily damaging the building and slightly wounding a passer-by, the police said.

title: RAHAL EDGES UNSER IN INDY-TYPE EVENT
description: Bobby Rahal beat Al Unser Jr. today for his second straight victory, winning the Molson Indy race at Sanair Super Speedway after Unser was knocked out of the lead by a penalty.

title: RIGHTS CURTAILED
description: Gunmen tried unsuccessfuly to kill President Augusto Pinochet tonight in an attack that left five members of his police and military escort dead, according to Government officials.

title: Ban Upheld on Stores' Renting Screening Rooms
description: Video stores may not rent private screening rooms to customers because the practice is unfair to movie studios, a Federal Court of Appeals has ruled.

title: In Pakistan, It's Time To Let Democracy In
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaped Murderer Held After Chance Encounter
description: A fugitive convicted of murdering a 10-year-old girl by burying her alive in an ice chest was captured when he went to use a public telephone beside a plain-clothes deputy.

title: FOR YOUNG EYES: THE HOLOCAUST'S CHILDREN
description: This is a time when almost any topic - from rape and incest to nuclear war - is considered suitable in books written for increasingly younger children. One of the most graphic picture books published in recent years is Chana Byers Abells's ''The Children We Remember,'' a book of photographs about the children of the Holocaust that has just been published by Greenwillow Books.

title: Name That Candidate
description: Nobody reads the publications of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee more closely in an election year than staff members over at the rival National Republican Congressional Committee - and vice versa.

title: O'CONNER BACKS A CURB ON DISSENTING SPEAKERS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor defended yesterday a directive by his Vicar General that parish speakers be screened according to their beliefs, saying it was ''common sense'' not to invite people who would ''attack the church'' to appear before Roman Catholic audiences.

title: Have a Nice Stay. At the Airport.
description: It's 6 P.M. Thursday in Boston, and you've joined the sweaty mob for the 6:15 flight to Denver after a tense struggle for a parking spot. Alas, no need to hurry. There's a thunderstorm near Hartford; the 45-minute delay now routine for rush-hour departures will be much longer. You'll be lucky to leave by 8:30.

title: SHARON SETS OFF A STORM IN ISRAEL, BLAMING PERES POLICY FOR KILLINGS
description: The massacre of Jews in Istanbul Saturday set off a political storm in Israel today, when Prime Minister Shimon Peres refused to hold the weekly Cabinet meeting until Ariel Sharon apologized for accusations that the killings were a result of peace overtures by Mr. Peres and his supporters in the Government.

title: ENDING THE COCAINE HABIT: EXPERTS DIFFER ON METHODS
description: The treatment of cocaine addiction is a fledgling field, with diverse methods being tried but too little scientific evidence of which ones work best, in the view of leading experts.

title: JETS DEFEAT BILLS, 28-24
description: A marvelous fourth-quarter mano a mano passing duel between two quarterbacks who waited three years to meet ended today with the Jets hanging on for a 28-24 victory over the Bills in the season's opener.

title: Yugoslav Captain Arrested
description: Capt. Seman Franko, the master of the Yugoslav freighter Jablanica, was arrested this morning in Sault Ste.

title: AUSTRALIAN FILMS SEEK U.S. DOLLARS
description: Hal McElroy has been one of the pioneering producers in the new Australian cinema. Along with his brother, Jim McElroy, he produced Peter Weir's early films ''Picnic at Hanging Rock'' and ''The Last Wave.'' But like many Australian film makers including Mr. Weir, Mr. McElroy is now branching out to produce both films and television programs financed at least in part by American companies.
