This move is signaled by Mr. McElroy's next project, ''The Last Frontier,'' a four-hour mini-series for CBS that stars Linda Evans and Jason Robards along with Australian actors Jack Thompson and Judy Morris. The program, which will be shown Oct. 5 and 7, is the first network mini-series ever filmed in Australia.

title: BEAR BAIT, BIG PLANTS, TIDY BAGS
description: This is the land of the great outdoors, where newspaper advertisements invite unguided horseback moose hunts and wilderness river float trips, and one outdoor store's offer attraction is free moose-call instruction.

title: Japan Officer Sets Meeting
description: Japan's Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa is expected to hold a press conference later today, after his return from talks with Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d in San Francisco, a Finance Ministry spokesman said.

title: DEBATE OVER UNION AT 'MACNEIL/LEHRER'
description: The staff of public television's ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' is grappling with an internal dispute over a drive by some of the program's writers, reporters and producers to join a union, an effort being stoutly resisted by the program's management.

title: Soviet Says U.S. Conducted Secret Nuclear Test in Desert
description: The Soviet Union said today that the United States held a secret nuclear test last week in the Nevada desert.

title: VIOLIN: ELLIOT ROSOFF RECITAL
description: THE highlight of Elliot Rosoff's violin recital at Merkin Concert Hall yesterday afternoon was the New York premiere of Karen Khachaturian's Sonata No. 3 in G minor.

title: Outdoors: City Trails
description: IF you have returned to New York City from a vacation in the country and sometimes yearn for what you left behind, you might soften the transition by visiting the natural areas within the 26,000 acres of parklands embraced by the five boroughs.

title: 'EUGENE O'NEILL,' CHANNEL 13 PROFILE
description: EUGENE O'NEILL once said that in order to know him, you had to go back to his beginnings. And even then, he warned, ''the answers seem to contradict each other.'' O'Neill remains the towering figure in the history of American theater. His output of 51 plays was prodigious. His experiments were courageous. His honesty and passion are unwavering. It is little wonder that he is the only American playwright to win the Nobel Prize for Literature.

title: PRIMARIES AND CANDIDATES
description: Following are the candidates in the contested races in tomorrow's primary elections in New York. Incumbents are marked with asterisks. Write-in candidates are marked with stars. DEMOCRATS

title: Vicki Match, Architect, Married to Stuart Suna
description: Vicki Ann Match and Stuart Mark Suna were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens, by Rabbi Joseph Sternstein.

title: AIDES SAY U.S. SENT FORCE TO PAKISTAN
description: A United States Army counterterrorism team was sent to the scene of the hijacking in Pakistan on Friday, but it failed to get there before the incident ended in bloodshed, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW MANHATTAN ARTS SCHOOL PLANNED
description: In a proposed exchange of property development for cultural development, the city would get a new educational arts center and the builders next door would get a skyscraper on the Avenue of the Americas about one-third larger than zoning rules allow.

title: Tunis Opens Inquiry On Ex-Prime Minister
description: Authorities have opened an inquiry into the disappearance of the former Prime Minister, Mohammed Mzali, official sources said today.

title: RED SOX TROUNCE TWINS
description: Jim Rice hit his second grand slam in three days to power the Boston Red Sox to their eighth straight triumph, a 9-0 rout today of the Minnesota Twins.

title: One Tough Quarterback
description: JIM KELLY is worth the $8 million. He can throw.

title: It's Carmel, Not Clint-ville
description: Storekeepers are not making Mayor Clint Eastwood's day when they sell bumper stickers and T-shirts bearing his name.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 8, 1986: MONDAY Bristol-Myers Dayco Corp Interco Inc TUESDAY Fleetwood Enterprises Intl Flavors&Fragrances Fluor Corp Lomas Mtg Corp Handleman Co Pillsbury Co WEDNESDAY Federal Co So NE Telecommunications Heinz (H.J.) Co Times Mirror Nicor Inc Transco Energy Quaker Oats Co THURSDAY Adams Express Petroleum & Resources Colgate-Palmolive Service Corp Intl Dow Chemical Trinity Industries Hallwood Group Inc Universal Foods Idaho Power FRIDAY Abbott Labs Dennison Mfg Big Three Indus Hazleton Labs

title: THE TIMES BEGINS NEW WEATHER REPORT
description: Beginning today, The New York Times is publishing a new weather report, with expanded coverage of conditions and increased forecasts and records.

title: THAT LOOKS GOOD ENOUGH TO TAX
description: Taxpayers, often vexed by their run-ins with the Internal Revenue Service, now have company within the Government itself.

title: RASMUSSEN SHAKY AS YANKS LOSE, 7-2
description: Lou Piniella was not prepared to offer a concession speech. There were still too many games to play, he said. Yet even as he spoke, the words carried a distinct message: The Yankees need some kind of miracle.

title: Blacks for Congress
description: The number of blacks now serving in the House, 21, is almost certain to increase with the November elections, though hardly dramatically. Black representation in the 435-member House has never approached the black share of the population, now about 12 percent, in the century since Reconstruction.

title: MUSIC: ORCHESTRA FROM SEOUL
description: DAVID W. YUN bit off a little more than his orchestra, from Seoul National University, could comfortably chew in their program at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night. The conductor is spirited and apparently able, but the young players left the impression that more rehearsal time devoted to a less demanding program might have showed them to better advantage.

title: DICKERSON GAINS 193 YARDS AS RAMS DEFEAT CARDINALS, 16-10
description: Eric Dickerson ran for 193 yards and two touchdowns today, leading the Los Angeles Rams to a 16-10 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: PAKISTAN TO TRY HIJACKERS, ZIA SAYS; NO LINK TO ANY GOVERNMENT FOUND
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet on Friday was carried out by four ''highly volatile'' young Palestinians with no apparent connection to any government, and that they would be prosecuted in Pakistan and not transferred to any other country.

title: FLUTIE TO SPEND SEASON AS FAN
description: More than 100 of his former United States Football League cohorts were suiting up in their new National Football League uniforms yesterday, but for Doug Flutie, the former star quarterback for Boston College and the U.S.F.L. Generals, the opening of the N.F.L. season brought no need for jersey, helmet or shoulder pads.

title: Blast at TV Filming Injures 5 in Chicago
description: An explosion set off by a television crew went awry and toppled a wall onto customers in a crowded restaurant, injuring two diners and three other people.

title: White Sox Drop Foster
description: George Foster, signed by the Chicago White Sox in August as a free agent, was released by the team following today's game.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How successful a pro career did Alan (The Horse) Ameche have after winning the Heisman Trophy as the outstanding player in college football?

title: MARYLAND VOTE MAY SEE ACTIVISM AS BIG WINNER
description: The Maryland primary election Tuesday could mark the emergence of a more activist political era in this state because the styles of the two Democrats considered front-runners for the Senate and the Governor's seat differ sharply from those they seek to replace.

title: COLORADO SENATE CONTEST OFFERS STARK DIFFERENCE
description: The Colorado politicians with national names -Senator Gary Hart, Gov. Dick Lamm, Representative Patricia Schroeder -are liberal Democratic products of the early 1970's, of the days when the state was swept by opposition to the Vietnam War and by concern for the environment.

title: 43 LEGISLATIVE CONTESTS ARE ON PRIMARY BALLOTS
description: The state's political parties will choose 43 candidates for the State Legislature in primary voting tomorrow, with many of the contests reflecting local battles for control of the party apparatus.

title: Philippine I.M.F. Credit
description: The International Monetary Fund is expected to approve next month the Philippines' request for a $508 million standby credit, The Manila Bulletin said on Saturday. It quoted Jose Concepcion, Minister of Trade and Industry, as saying he expected I.M.F. managing director Jacques de Larosiere to endorse the request on Sept. 15 and that the fund's executive board would take up the standby arrangement next month. The credit is necessary as a prelude to negotiations with creditor banks on $26 billion of foreign debt.

title: METS ARE BASKING IN HARD-EARNED GLORY
description: FROM the stacks of mail in the players' lockers to the stacks of money in the till, the magnitude of success is everywhere these days as the Mets rush toward the most pressurized and profitable championship in baseball history.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: CANDIDATES SEEK VOTES ON SUNDAY STROLLS
description: Many of the candidates in Tuesday's Democratic primary took to the streets yesterday, shaking hands, working their way through crowded festivals and generally trying to increase voter turnout in the neighborhoods they are counting on for support.

title: OFFICIALS SAY SPY CHARGE ALSO SERVES TO WARN REPORTERS ON FRIENDSHIPS
description: Although American officials and experts are convinced that an American correspondent in Moscow has been charged with espionage primarily to apply leverage for obtaining the release of an Russian being held on spying charges in New York, the choice of a journalist as the pawn seemed to these experts to serve a second purpose as well.

title: On the Other Hand . . .
description: A good speechwriter is nothing if not flexible. John L. Sherman, one of the best on Capitol Hill, is a case in point.

title: REPORTER'S CASE TERMED SERIOUS BY WHITE HOUSE
description: The Reagan Administration, stepping up its warnings to the Soviet Union, said today that the filing of espionage charges against an American reporter in Moscow was ''a matter of utmost seriousness'' for the United States.

title: TUTU IS INSTALLED IN ARCHBISHOP'S POST
description: In daylong ceremonies blending traditional Anglican pomp, modern African syncopation and the politics of apartheid, Desmond M. Tutu was installed today as the first black to lead the Anglican Church in southern Africa.

title: ONE DEAD, 5 INJURED AS CAB MOUNTS CURB AT DISCO IN CHELSEA
description: One woman was killed and five other people were injured last night when a taxicab collided with another car, spun out of control and crashed into the front of the Limelight discotheque in Chelsea, the police said.

title: POPE SAYS HOPE TURNS TO ANGUISH
description: From an Alpine peak near Mont Blanc, Pope John Paul II said today that terrorist attacks on a jetliner in Pakistan and a synagogue in Turkey had turned hopes for peace into anguish.

title: EXPERTS SAY MOSCOW CHARGE WILL HURT RELATIONS
description: High Government officials and some outside experts said today that the Soviet decision to charge an American correspondent with espionage had caused Soviet-American relations to take what one called ''a very ugly turn.''

title: Loving Ladies' Mile
description: ''All America goes to New York for its shopping, when it can. . . .'' reads an 1893 handbook. ''The brightness of Broadway, the vivacity of lower Fifth Avenue, the sparkle of 23rd Street, are made up of the splendid temptations of the shop windows, and the groups of charming people who linger about them spell bound. . . . What are the Paris boulevards, or even Regent Street, to this magnificent panorama of mercantile display?''

title: What Gorbachev Risks
description: A great opportunity is at hand -historic is not too strong a word - to ease relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. But the opportunity may be lost if the Soviet leadership does not quickly correct a gross misstep. That is the detention of Nicholas Daniloff, Moscow correspondent of U.S. News & World Report.

title: R. D. Kraus Wed To Dana Frankel
description: The marriage of Dana Ellen Frankel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving E. Frankel of New York and Sharon, Conn., to Robert David Kraus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Kraus of Great Neck, L.I., took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony.

title: GROUPS IN LEBANON WARY OF REPRISAL
description: Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Moslem fundamentalists went on alert today at their camps in Lebanon in anticipation of possible Israeli retaliation to the massacre at a synagogue in Istanbul.

title: Christine A. Leuthold Weds Dean H. Eisner
description: Christine Ann Leuthold, a daughter of Dolph Leuthold of New York and Annette Leuthold of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Dean Harris Eisner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Eisner of Pittsfield, Mass. The Rev. Charles Smith, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at the Stonehenge restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: The Short, Unhappy Life of Captive Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: Flip a Switch Now
description: To the Editor:

title: MECIR BEATEN IN THREE SETS
description: There was no talk of mental exhaustion after the match. Ivan Lendl did not say he was about to embark on a six-month vacation on an uninhabited Caribbean island to escape the burden of being the No. 1 tennis player in the world. He has invested too much time and effort in the pursuit of excellence to carry his ranking like a ball and chain around the court. Lendl will take a few days off to enjoy his latest achievement, he said, and then it will be back to work again. After all, someone may be gaining on him.

title: GOODEN WINS 14TH IN SWEEP OF PADRES
description: The Mets took a couple of giant bounds toward their first division title in 13 years yesterday when they swept a doubleheader from the San Diego Padres and also swept away any lingering doubt about the state of Dwight Gooden's art.

title: Paying Dues
description: It will be at least 1998 before he gets out of prison, and he'll probably be too old then to resume his boxing career. But Tony Ayala, the former junior-middleweight contender who was convicted of raping a neighbor in 1983, has a new occupation to pursue.

title: RESEARCH SPONSORSHIP SOARING AT UNIVERSITIES
description: Federal sponsorship of basic scientific research at universities has soared in the first six years of the Reagan Administration, in a revival that appears unmatched since the post-Sputnik era of the early 1960's.

title: Independent or Fleet Driver, a Cabby Is Always Misunderstood
description: To the Editor:

title: Catching Up
description: * Because crowds had become so persistently loud that receivers were often missing checkoff signals at the line of scrimmage, the National Football League experimented during the exhibition season last year with a helmet-to-helmet radio hookup between quarterbacks and the wide-outs. When the quarterbacks complained that the radio equipment was pinching their heads, the manufacturer, Telex Communications of Minneapolis, said the problem would be easy enough to remedy.

title: The Body's Value Has Gone Up
description: Until recently, it was possible to joke that the value of the body, based on its chemical constituents, was about $1.98. Now, its value exceeds $200,000 and is rising. Tissue is being harvested for transplantation, research and diagnostic and therapeutic products. In 1985, nearly 8,000 kidneys and 20,000 corneas were transplanted; heart transplants are being performed at the rate of 1,200 per year.

title: TOWN'S INDUSTRIAL REBIRTH MIRED IN LABOR DISPUTE
description: On a vast rolling slope on the outskirts of this tiny town, the earth-moving machines of the Ohbayashi Corporation have already cleared several million tons of rock and soil to make way for a new Toyota automobile assembly plant.

title: Fehr First By 2 Shots
description: Rick Fehr shot a two-under-par 69 today to win the $400,000 B.C. Open golf tournament by two strokes.

title: RED, WHITE AND PROUD
description: HIGH in Section 342, during the long wait between the women's and the men's finals yesterday, a young woman was wearing a red skirt and a white sweater.

title: 'JAPAN'S GRAND KABUKI' ON CHANNEL 31
description: ''JAPAN'S GRAND KABUKI IN AMERICA,'' to be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 31, follows one of Japan's greatest theatrical troupes during its visit to New York, Washington and Los Angeles in 1985. But it is more than a record of a tour. The half-hour documentary, produced by Milton Hoffman with Dick Cavett as host, serves as a fascinating introduction to a 400-year-old art.

title: DALLAS TRYING TUITION-INCENTIVE PLAN
description: A New York philanthropist who promised to send dozens of Harlem children to college has been invited to Dallas to help people there join his ''I Have a Dream Program'' to educate the disadvantaged. Dallas residents have already pledged enough to educate 1,000 youths.

title: REAGAN OPENS SENATE DRIVE WITH ATTACK ON CRANSTON IN CALIFORNIA
description: Starting his fall drive to keep Republican control of the Senate, President Reagan said today that November's ''make or break'' election will determine if his conservative course for the nation endures.

title: JET SURVIVORS SAY ARMY DIDN'T HELP
description: Survivors of the hijacking of a Pan American jumbo jet in Karachi said today that Pakistani commandos had played no role in the freeing of the plane after four terrorists hurled grenades and sprayed machine-gun bullets at the huddled passengers.

title: Nancy Helen Feinberg Married to John Tobin
description: Nancy Helen Feinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Feinberg of New York, was married yesterday to John Stephens Tobin, a son of Austin Tobin Jr. of Washington, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Stephens Tobin. Family Court Judge Michael Gage officiated at the Feinberg home.

title: Scott Elliot Lange Is Wed To Ann Limer in Westport
description: The marriage of Ann Beth Limer, a daughter of Claire Limer and Harry Limer, both of Providence, R.I., to Scott Elliott Lange, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lange of Westport, Conn., took place yesterday at the Long Shore Country Club in Westport. Rabbi Jonas Goldberg performed the ceremony.

title: A Standoff on Arms - Within the Capital
description: When the House of Representatives moved to pass a group of arms control amendments last month, Reagan Administration officials were conspicuous by their absence on Capitol Hill.

title: MORRIS BOYCOTTS PRACTICE FOR OPENER
description: Joe Morris stayed behind in his hotel room tonight while the Giants went through their final practice for Monday night's season opener against the Dallas Cowboys. The star running back is unhappy with negotiations for a new contract, and there was no indication whether he would play against the Cowboys.

title: Prime-Time Closed Captioning on the Networks
description: To the Editor:

title: 'MODERN' COWBOYS ARE BACK IN STRIDE
description: Whatever happened to the Dallas Cowboys?

title: Charles Robert Burrows, 76; A Former Envoy to Honduras
description: Charles Robert Burrows, United States Ambassador to Honduras from 1960 to 1965, died Saturday at a Washington hospital.

title: SPINKS LOOKS TO SERIES
description: Before his fight against Steffen Tangstad Saturday night, Michael Spinks decided his mustache was in need of a trim.

title: North Korea Says U.S. Plans Offshore Exercises
description: North Korea said today that the United States was planning large-scale naval exercises off the Korean Peninsula during the 1986 Asian Games, to be held in Seoul for 16 days beginning Sept. 20.

title: Miss Barrett Marries Stephen Lerner
description: Mary Ellin Barrett and Stephen Daedalus Lerner were married yesterday in Southampton, L.I., at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max Lerner. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: The 'Revenue Stream' At City Water Authority
description: When the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority talks about a ''revenue stream,'' it is talking billions of gallons.

title: CRITICISM GROWING IN INDIA OVER PAKISTAN'S HANDLING OF HIJACKING
description: Opposition political leaders and others here today joined Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in criticizing Pakistan's handling of Friday's hijacking at the Karachi airport, saying it could have been resolved without loss of life. There was also some criticism of President Reagan for his support of Pakistan's handling of the incident, in which 18 people died.

title: Campaign Funds
description: Excerpt from ''Can the Parties Regulate Campaign Financing?'' an article by Lloyd Cutler, a Washington lawyer, in the July 1986 issue of The Annals, published by the American Academy of Political and Social Science:

title: Ryder Is Introducing 2-Audience Campaign
description: Ryder Truck Rental, based in Miami, is starting a national advertising and promotion campaign with separate programs aimed at both consumer and commercial audiences.

title: Heart Surgery Halted At a Veterans' Hospital
description: Open-heart surgery has been halted at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Washington because of concerns over recent deaths of patients, a V.A. spokesman said Saturday.

title: Striking Faculty Faces A Threat of Dismissal
description: Striking faculty members at Fairleigh Dickinson University voted yesterday to continue their walkout for another day, but the university president threatened to dismiss professors who did not return to classrooms.

title: FOR THE HUNTS, A RISKY, AGGRESSIVE LEGAL STRATEGY
description: The Hunt brothers, members of one of the world's richest families, are pursuing a high-risk legal strategy that could buy them time to sort out their mounting financial woes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL EXPOS VS. METS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) DODGERS VS. BRAVES, at Los Angeles, 10:35 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) FOOTBALL GIANTS VS. COWBOYS, at Dallas, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio -WNEW, 1130, 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: Physician Is Wed To Alice A. Cohen
description: The marriage of Alice Anne Cohen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert George Cohen of New York; Danbury, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., to Dr. Albert Bruce Knapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Knapp of New York and Ridgefield, Conn., took place yesterday. Dr. David Seligson, rabbi emeritus of the Central Synagogue, officiated at the Hotel Pierre.

title: TOP CITY SCHOOL OFFICIALS STRESS UNITY
description: The city's Board of Education and the City Schools Chancellor, in a rare and sweeping statement of cooperation, said yesterday that the new school year would herald a ''fundamental change in perspective'' in which policies would be made for the sake of the classroom instead of the bureaucracy.

title: Groups Declare Boycott Of Bangladesh Elections
description: Two major Bangladeshi opposition groups today denounced next month's elections as a device to keep Gen. H. M. Ershad as President and said they would boycott the voting.

title: OPTIMISM ON TAX-EXEMPTS
description: Despite the dearth of new financings in the tax-exempt bond market, the market is far from moribund. Investment bankers are confident that investor demand will not be badly damaged under the proposed Federal tax bill and that new financings will be readily absorbed when activity rebounds later this year.

title: An Eye for an Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIPPINE CHURCH BLAST KILLS 8
description: Moslem rebels tossed a grenade inside a Roman Catholic church during a wedding mass today, killing 8 people and wounding 56, the military authorities said.

title: Washington State Seeks To Renew Exit Poll Ban
description: James Johnson, a Washington State senior assistant attorney general, has asked a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to reinstate the state ban on interviewing voters leaving the polls within 300 feet of a voting place.

title: Moscow's China Card
description: Every decade or so, China undergoes a political convulsion. In 1948-49, the Communists threw out the Kuomintang; in 1956, Mao's ''Great Leap Forward'' plunged the country into a depression; in 1966, the Cultural Revolution to purify the party brought on a new Dark Ages; in 1976-78, we saw Mao's would-be radical successors, the ''Gang of Four,'' replaced by pragmatic Deng Xiaoping.

title: Old Testament Law Doesn't Sanction Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: ALUMNI SAY THE C.C.C. EASED 30'S
description: Fifty years later, the Great Depression does not seem so depressing.

title: THIRD-WORLD GROUP FAULTS U.S. ON LIBYA
description: Leaders of the movement of nations professing nonalignment accused the United States today of ''state terrorism'' for its bombing of Libya last April and called for comprehensive mandatory sanctions against South Africa.

title: Dance Companies Awarded
description: The National Choreography Project has awarded $250,000 in grants to eight dance companies. The program, now in its third year, is designed to provide new opportunities to choreographers and to enrich the repertory of dance companies by supporting collaborations with choreographers not usually associated with the companies involved.

title: Lipton to Resume Sale Of Soup Mix in Jersey
description: Lipton will restock its instant soup mix in Camden area stores this week after thousands of packages were removed after the death of a man who ate cyanide-laced chicken noodle soup, a company spokesman said today.

title: Bruins to Receive Islanders' Boutilier
description: The Islanders must send Paul Boutilier, a defenseman, to the Boston Bruins in compensation for the Islanders' signing of Brian Curran, a former free agent who had played with the Bruins, an arbitrator ruled yesterday.

title: MOSCOW CHARGES NEWSMAN FROM U.S. WITH BEING A SPY
description: The Moscow correspondent for an American magazine, Nicholas S. Daniloff, was charged with espionage today, the Government-run television reported.

title: MCMAHON INJURED
description: Those expecting Super Bowl perfection from the Chicago Bears might have gone away disappointed today. The world champions were hardly the intimidating team they were last January, when they won the National Football League championship.

title: SUKOVA LOSES, 6-3, 6-2
description: If her last two weeks of tennis were a painting, the splashes of vivid color, shapes and form were applied on Saturday afternoon in a match that could not have been surpassed in excellence or intrigue. Yesterday, under cloudy skies at the National Tennis Center, Martina Navratilova signed the finished work.

title: Bridge: Von Zedtwitz Championship Runs Into Four-Week Delay
description: Slow play on a tennis court, leading to delay of the action and possible penalties, is measured in seconds. At the bridge table it is usually a matter of minutes, but last week at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, it was a matter of a month.

title: CRASH COURSE IN CHINA'S ARTS
description: On a steamy summer day in Hangzhou, China, a handful of Westerners are up at dawn, joining local Chinese in their morning exercises.

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIORS SEE NEW PAIN
description: Survivors of the Holocaust - brought together at the base of the Statue of Liberty by a paradoxical hope to recall yet heal their pain - had no choice yesterday but to face the reality that once again their brethren had been massacred just because they were Jewish.

title: PRICES LOWER AS SUPPLY STAYS LIGHT
description: Traders and investors in debt securities are confronted this week by prices that are sharply lower than a week ago, but still in the range that prevailed earlier this summer.

title: Thrift Unit's Officials Sued
description: Federal regulators are seeking $250 million in damages from the former officers and law firm of the failed Sunrise Savings and Loan Association of West Palm Beach, Fla., according to court documents released Friday.

title: BOOM IN DRUG TESTS EXPECTED
description: As the Federal Government and more and more large corporations consider adopting mandatory tests for drug use among job applicants and employees, the manufacturers of the tests are gearing up for what analysts see as potentially explosive growth.

title: Strike Period Slow One For USX Negotiator
description: J. Bruce Johnston, chief labor negotiator for the USX Corporation, is often described as a hard-nosed bargainer in dealings with steelworkers.

title: Paris Meeting Of Group of 5
description: Deputy finance ministers from the five leading non-Communist industrial nations met in Paris on Friday for talks to prepare for the International Monetary Fund's annual meeting in Washington later this month, the West German finance ministry said.

title: U.S., EUROPE TO SETTLE ON STEEL, CITRUS
description: The Reagan Administration will unblock a stalled agreement allowing United States imports of European steel after being assured that American citrus fruit growers will get better access to European markets, United States trade representative Clayton K. Yeutter announced here this weekend.

title: Market Place; Waste Control: Strong Outlook
description: WASTE management companies, several analysts say, have entered a time of unusually high predictability, growth and profit visibility, despite the nation's current general economic and corporate uncertainty.

title: Rise Seen in Oil Consumption
description: Oil consumption in the Western industrialized nations is likely to rise by 3.5 to 4.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 1986, compared with the same period last year, the International Energy Agency said today. In its latest monthly oil market report, the agency said 1986 oil consumption in the 24 countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development would be around 3 percent higher than in 1985, rising to 35 million barrels a day, from 33.9 million.

title: Air Crash's Victims Mourned
description: About 1,000 people gathered today for a memorial service honoring the dozens who died from the collision of a jetliner and a small airplane.

title: Washington Watch; Reagan's Plan On Oil Opposed
description: THE Administration, caught between its free-market principles and a desire to aid the American oil industry, seems to be making no one happy. Its plan to buy up to 35,000 barrels a day of domestic oil for the national stockpile, explicitly described as a support effort, is being ridiculed by the oil industry and is opposed by at least one member of the Senate Energy Committee.

title: German G.N.P. In Rebound
description: West Germany's economy, the strongest in Western Europe, has rebounded after a slow start this year, the Federal Statistics Office said Friday.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Playing to Win
description: Kevin Calderwood will have to play football a long time and against some pretty fierce opponents before he has a game as tough as the 1985 Northwestern team picture. It took two teammates holding him by the arms, while he leaned against the knees of a third, just to keep him erect. Even then, between shots he slumped over in pain and fatigue.

title: BUSNIESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1986
description: The Economy Congress is set to put the final touches on the tax legislation after returning today from a three-week recess. A vote is expected in the House next week and in the Senate later in the month. Approval is widely seen by lawmakers for the sweeping legislation, which would dramatically lower tax rates and eliminate or restrict many familiar deductions. [ Page D1. ] The Administration will unblock a stalled agreement allowing imports of European steel. The announcement was made after trade officials were assured that U.S. citrus fruit growers would get better access to European markets. [ D1. ] Companies CBS denied reports that it was seeking bids from Philip Morris and Westinghouse, but declined to say if it is was talking with other potential investors. A gloomy 1987 forecast for CBS is expected to be presented at a board meeting Wednesday. [ D1. ] Manufacturers of drug-detection tests are gearing up for what analysts see as potentially explosive growth. The Federal Government and an increasing number of large corporations are considering mandatory tests for job applicants and employees. Industry leaders include Syva and Hoffmann-La Roche. [ D1. ] International Dai-Ichi Kangyo has capitalized on the yen's appreciation and a huge pool of savings. It recently surpassed Citicorp to become the world's largest commercial bank in terms of assets. [ D20. ] Latin America's economic recession is persisting because of huge capital outflows to pay international debt and will not be reversed until the resource drain is sharply cut, the Inter-American Development Bank said.

title: FEW CLUES FOUND IN ISTANBUL ATTACK
description: The Turkish officials investigating the terrorist raid Saturday on Istanbul's largest synagogue said tonight that they believed the assailants were Arabs but that there were no definitive clues to explain the attack.

title: Debt Delay For Argentina
description: Argentina has postponed payment of $10 billion in foreign debt and will hold talks here in the near future with the International Monetary Fund on a rescheduling package, Treasury Secretary Mario Brodersohn told reporters today.

title: Departure at Newsweek
description: Morton Kondracke, the Washington bureau chief of Newsweek for the last 19 months, has resigned and is returning to the New Republic as a senior editor, according to Michael Kinsley, editor of the New Republic.

title: CLERICS AND LEADERS CONDEMN THE RAID
description: Government and religious leaders, while denouncing the attacks on a Pan American jetliner and a Turkish synagogue, called yesterday for a nonviolent response and greater negotiation in resolving conflicts in the Middle East.

title: ARCHITECT PUTS HIS MARK ON SKYLINE
description: In some ways, the Chicago architect Helmut Jahn is as colorful as his buildings. ''I hope you're not going to talk about my clothes,'' says Mr. Jahn, who recently appeared on the cover of Gentleman's Quarterly wearing an elegant hat. ''You're probably going to write about where we ate,'' he says during a lunch at Harry Cipriani's on Fifth Avenue. ''I'd prefer to talk about the issues, what we do in a project.''

title: ESPOSITO IS MOVING QUICKLY IN BID TO TAKE RANGERS TO TOP
description: PHIL ESPOSITO's nose showed. When he covered his face to think, his nose showed. He put down his hands and looked sad behind a glass of red wine with his knees tucked beneath the tray, a big sad bear stuffed into his plane seat.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The Senate Energy Committee is to consider tomorrow the nomination of Martha Hesse to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. She is scheduled to become chairman.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ROUND-TRIP FARE The one municipal transport that has seen a drastic decrease in fare is the Central Park Carousel, in the center of the park just south of the 65th Street transverse. The normal 50-cent fare for the three-minute spin has, since July, been reduced to a dime for all comers on Mondays.

title: NEW SNAG IN TOXIC CLEANUPS
description: In a development that industry and environmental officials see as a severe setback to toxic-waste cleanup efforts, most of the country's 400 big consulting engineering firms that do pollution control work are refusing to handle toxic-waste sites unless their clients protect them from lawsuits.

title: Caterpillar Restores Jobs
description: Caterpillar Inc. has recalled 1,100 more workers who had been laid off during a monthlong machinists' strike at a Joliet, Ill., components factory, leaving only 535 assembly workers still off the job. The manufacturer of earthmoving equipment said Friday the workers would return to their jobs beginning with Sunday's third shift. Caterpillar had laid off 1,935 workers at Illinois plants in Aurora, Decatur and East Peoria because of materials shortages caused by the August strike, a company spokesman, Brian Gareau, said.

title: ON FLIGHT 73: SOOTHING WORDS, MENACING ORDERS, THEN SHOTS
description: ''I am not going to hurt your babies,'' Zeba Hamid said gently, quoting a promise made by a bare-chested hijacker as he soothed her two sobbing children.

title: Vietnam-U.S. Talks On Refugees Fail
description: Vietnamese and United States negotiators failed to reach an agreement on an American request to be allowed to resume interviewing Vietnamese who want to settle in the United States, sources said today.

title: HOW SUMMER'S FILMS RANKED AT BOX OFFICE
description: The wild weeks of summer, when several new movies were flung into 1,500 theaters apiece each weekend, have ended. And the fall, a more cautious time for the movie industry, has begun.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Whether I like it or not, whether he likes it or not, as I have said before, P. W. Botha is my brother, and I must desire and pray for the best for him. Can you imagine what would happen in this land if we accepted this theological fact about ourselves -that whether we like it or not, we are members of one family?'' - Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu. [ A3:2. ]

title: Big Texas Bank Resuming Gifts
description: The First City Bancorp of Texas, one of that state's biggest bank holding companies, will again offer gifts to new depositors at its Dallas and Houston banks.

title: LONGO WINS 2D MEDAL
description: Jeannie Longo of France became the only winner of two individual gold medals at the world cycling championships today as she retained her title in the women's road race.

title: IN SOUTH SEA PARADISE, BIG-POWER REALITY INTRUDES
description: Prime Minister Walter Lini was late returning from a village festival on remote Ambrym island, and Terry Kerr, the pilot of his small chartered plane, had a problem.

title: THEATER: A MUSICAL, 'ANGRY HOUSEWIVES'
description: WHEN we first meet Bev, Wendy, Jetta and Carol, four suburban women who decide to form a hard-rock band in the new Off Broadway musical ''Angry Housewives,'' they are a typical cross section of friends one might find on a prime-time sitcom.

title: SOFTWARE FOR CHILDREN
description: EDUCATIONAL software that earns praise from parents and children alike is rare. To get the endorsement of parents, the programs must be instructive and challenging. To get the endorsement of children, they must be easy and fun to use.

title: HOW 43 AGENCIES KEEP SURVIVING THE REAGAN AX
description: Their proponents see them as flowers in an increasingly hostile desert on the Federal landscape. To the Reagan White House they are weeds that should be chopped and the sooner the better.

title: TUTU LEADS TOURS OF SQUATTER CAMP
description: Desmond M. Tutu, newly installed as the Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town, led Coretta Scott King and the Archbishop of Canterbury and others on brief tours of the Crossroads squatter camp today, prompting expressions of dismay from his guests.

title: Lots of Diamonds But Few Riches
description: If Don Fehr thinks he has a problem trying to safeguard free agency for his membership, he ought to be in Kyiochi Yamaguchi's shoes. In a burst of determination, Japanese ballplayers, who for years watched with mild envy as their well-organized American counterparts grew rich, have now turned their old, loosely knit guild into an officially sanctioned union, which Yamaguchi serves as full-time business adviser. But it will be a long time, if the day ever comes, before they enjoy American-size salaries or the mobility that the State-side players, at least until recently, have taken for granted.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ABC Carpet Co. has appointed David Landy president and chief executive.

title: A Poor Gift for Senator Laxalt
description: As a matter of courtesy, United States senators routinely accept legislation that affects only one or two states, and Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada hopes thus to secure a long-stalled water rights agreement between Nevada and California. But this agreement also affects Federal interests and the Paiute Indian Tribe, which was not consulted.

title: Film Editing on the Wing
description: People Express Flight 12, flying from San Francisco to Newark International Airport on Sunday, offered Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters'' - or at least most of it.

title: A Letterhead That Knows What's in a Name
description: Letterheads of nonprofit organizations sometimes include advisory boards whose well-known members take up half the space on the stationery but contribute a little less in day-to-day work.

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Promotion Expected At Kidder
description: Max C. Chapman Jr. has long been an avid rock climber and a frequent visitor to some of America's most challenging rock cliffs, where he is known for the determined manner in which he hauls his solid frame up the sheer faces.

title: G.M. ASKS U.S. TO EASE FUEL ECONOMY STANDARDS
description: The General Motors Corporation has asked the Federal Government to ease past and future Federal fuel economy standards for passenger cars so the company can avoid paying a $385 million penalty for failure to meet the standards.

title: EXPOS BATTER OJEDA
description: Contrary to the signs outside Shea Stadium, the Mets last night did not play baseball the way it ought to be played.

title: INSIDE
description: PRIMARY ELECTIONS TODAY New York Democrats will pick a candidate for the Senate, and Connecticut Republicans will designate a candidate for governor.

title: PARKING INQUIRY ASSIGNED IN '82, EX-OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Mayor Koch's first Investigation Commissioner said yesterday that in his final weeks on the job in 1982, he assigned staff members to question a city official who was warning of corruption at the Parking Violations Bureau.

title: SOVIET STILL SILENT ON ABM PROPOSAL
description: Administration officials said today that during two days of arms talks here that ended Saturday, the Soviet Union did not respond to a proposal by President Reagan for continued adherence to the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty.

title: WAR ON NARCOTICS EMERGING AS ISSUE IN FALL CAMPAIGNS
description: The surge of public concern about illegal drugs is energizing campaigns for state and Federal office around the country, according to political experts in both parties.

title: NAVRATILOVA, LLOYD FACING CHALLENGES
description: There was plenty of discussion during the United States Open concerning the ''gap,'' as the players call it, that has long separated the big two, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd, from the remainder of the field.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCIENTIFIC ADVANCES LEAD TO ERA OF FOOD SURPLUS AROUND WORLD
description: Scientific and technical advances in agriculture have yielded an era in which harvests are now outpacing population growth, resulting in unprecedented food abundance.

title: Michael Janofsky on Pro Football; SHULA ANALYZES TROUNCING
description: Over the last 24 years, Don Shula has coached 361 National Football League games, excluding those in the preseason. Only twice has an opponent scored as many as 50 points against him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1986
description: International

title: PLEA ACCORD IN WALKER CASE TO BE MAINTAINED, U.S. SAYS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would keep its plea bargaining agreement with John A. Walker Jr., despite recent lie detector results suggesting he is lying about some matters in his espionage case.

title: NEW PLASTIC SOLAR DESIGN PROMISES EFFICIENT POWER
description: In a quiet research laboratory here, an inventor is developing solar power devices designed to operate four or five times more efficiently than the best photovoltaic cells now in use, and at a small fraction of the cost.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Labor representatives of baseball's owners and players, whose dispute over the dismissal of their previous arbitrator hasn't been resolved, selected a new arbitrator yesterday. He is George Nicolau of New York, a career arbitrator.

title: CITY FIRE LIEUTENANT CHARGED IN RELEASE OF TEST INFORMATION
description: A 20-year veteran of the city's Fire Department was charged yesterday with revealing ''highly confidential information'' about the fire lieutenants' examination given in May.

title: THEATER TRAINING INSTITUTE IS ESTABLISHED AT HARVARD
description: Harvard University and its resident professional theater company, the American Repertory Theater, have announced the establishment of a new conservatory called the American Repertory Theater Institute for Advanced Theater Training at Harvard.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCULLS' ART TO BE SOLD AT AUCTION
description: Pop and Minimal art collected in the 1960's by Ethel Redner Scull and Robert C. Scull, the taxi tycoon, will be auctioned in separate sessions on Nov. 10 and 11, Sotheby's said yesterday. The Sculls were flamboyant in their collecting, buying art in a public way and entertaining lavishly. They amassed one of the first major collections of 1960's art.

title: Chlorine Leak in Mississippi
description: Poisonous chlorine gas spewing from derailed tank cars forced the evacuation of about 100 families and closed a 10-mile section of busy highway in southern Mississippi on Sunday. No one was injured when a 26-car Illinois Central Gulf train derailed near here, but a slow leak forced the evacuation of families within a five-mile radius of the accident.

title: Japan View of Baker Talks
description: Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said today that during a weekend meeting, the American Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, did not request interest rate cuts or other specific measures to stimulate Japan's economy.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: Taiwan registered a record trade surplus of $1.58 billion in August, surpassing the previous record of $1.43 billion set in July, a Government agency reported today. It said that for the first eight months of this year, Taiwan's trade surplus came to a record $9.86 billion, up 46 percent from the period last year. The agency attributed the surpluses to lower oil prices and increased exports, mainly to the United States and Japan.

title: The Jerusalem-Moscow Avenue to Mideast Peace
description: Although inconclusive in result, the Soviet-Israeli talks held last month in Helsinki may be the beginning of a long road back to normalization of relations between these two countries. Should this process unfold, it could be the key to breaking the deadlock now gripping the Middle East peace process. Without Soviet assent, there is little likelihood that any Arabs will be able or willing to negotiate directly with Israel in the foreseeable future.

title: EDISON CONTROL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COWBOYS DEFEAT GIANTS ON WALKER'S TOUCHDOWN
description: The game had a storybook ending, but not for the Giants. Herschel Walker, the heralded newcomer from the United States Football League, made his National Football league debut tonight for the Dallas Cowboys and scored the winning touchdown.

title: Weaver to Leave Orioles
description: Manager Earl Weaver said tonight that he would leave the Baltimore Orioles at the end of this season.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the losses in the latest periods include an inventory writedown of about $250,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday on the wedding of Mary Ellin Barrett and Stephen Daedalus Lerner was published in error. The couple are to be married next Sunday; the ceremony has not yet taken place.

title: CONTINUING CARE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax benefit of $8,000. The 1985 share earnings have been adjusted for a 1-for-4.9 reverse stock split in June 1985.

title: U.S. ASSAILED OVER DRUG FOR ARTHRITIS
description: A consumer group says the Food and Drug Administration shows a ''reckless disregard for the lives and health of older Americans'' by not requiring warnings against use of an arthritis drug by older people.

title: WEBSTER CLOTHES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Morris Signs Pact Worth $2.2 Million
description: Joe Morris returned to the Giants tonight, his contract problem resolved.

title: VIE DE FRANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Dinosaur Tracks Stolen in Texas
description: Three fossilized dinosaur tracks that survived 100 million years of floods and erosion have been stolen from a creekbed near here.

title: Newsweek Bureau Chief
description: Evan W. Thomas 3d, a 35-year-old associate editor of Time magazine, has been named Washington bureau chief of Newsweek. He is the son of Evan W. Thomas 2d, a literary editor in New York City, and the grandson of Norman Thomas, the longtime Socialist leader. Mr. Thomas succeeds Morton Kondracke, who announced his resignation yesterday to become a senior editor at The New Republic.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why are people over age 65 not allowed to donate blood? A.The American Red Cross normally accepts blood donations from people between the ages of 17 and 65, a spokesman said. Older people are more likely to suffer from physical ailments such as low blood pressure that would preclude them from giving blood, the spokesman said. However, the Red Cross will permit a person over age 65 to donate blood if he or she presents a letter from a physician indicating good health. The age limits were established to protect the donors as well as the recipients of the blood, she said. Q.Whatever happened to ''Russian sleep''? A.In the 1960's the Russians developed a technique for inducing sleep by placing electrodes over the eyelids. The device seemed to offer drug-free help for insomniacs, but there has never been a properly controlled study demonstrating that such devices work, according to Dr. Martin Reite, director of the Sleep Disorder Center at the University of Colorado School of Medicine. ''I know of no type of low-power electromagnetic impulses that can produce sleep,'' Dr. Reite said. Dr. Reite is currently testing a sleep inducing machine made in Switzerland. The electrodes of this machine are attached to the mouth, and the electromagnetic energy is radiated to the head. Test results will not be available for several months. Some researchers have speculated that the externally applied energy might influence the normal rhythms of the brain, thus inducing sleep. Q.What causes wood to rot and what determines how fast the rot spreads? A. Wood decay is caused by fungi, nonvascular plants without roots that feed on organic matter, according to Dr. Terry L. Amburgey, a professor of wood science and technology at Mississippi State University. Dr. Amburgey said fungi contain threadlike strands, or hyphae, that excrete enzymes that break down organic material into sugars, which the fungi consume.

title: TOP ISRAELI AIDES WON'T BE AT RITES
description: The Turkish Government has informed Israel that it would not welcome the presence of a high-ranking Israeli Government official at the funeral Wednesday of the 21 Jews slain in a terrorist attack on the largest synagogue in Istanbul, a senior Turkish official said today.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Rangers Clean House
description: With the opening of training camp a week away, the Rangers' general manager, Phil Esposito, was still cleaning house yesterday, trading Brian MacLellan, a left wing, to the Minnesota North Stars and signing a free agent collegiate defenseman, Norm Maciver, to a pro contract. MacLellan acquired from the Los Angeles Kings last season for Rollie Melanson, a goalie, and Grant Ledyard, a defenseman, was traded for a fourth-round draft pick in next year's entry draft.

title: DUTCH DANCERS ON BRAVO
description: JIRI KYLIAN, who directs the Netherlands Dance Theater, is widely regarded as one of today's most talented young choreographers. A look at the two ballets by Mr. Kylian that can be seen in ''Nederlands Dans Theater'' tonight at 10 on the Bravo cable network will reveal some of the reasons why. ''Symphony of Psalms,'' to Stravinsky, and ''La Cathedrale Engloutie,'' to Debussy, abound with the surges of movement that are among the exciting features of his choreography.

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS OPEN UNDER INTEGRATION PLAN
description: Last June, when classes in this city ended for the summer, Elementary School 25 on Warburton Avenue had a 94 percent minority enrollment and a standard instructional program.

title: Ex-G.E. Aide Cited by S.E.C.
description: Thomas M. Hartnett, a former General Electric Company executive, was charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with illegal insider trading in the stock of the RCA Corporation just days before G.E. announced a takeover.

title: Concerns on Surrogate Motherhoo
description: Most new techniques to enable infertile people to have babies are morally acceptable, but the practice of one woman's carrying another's fetus should be restricted, a medical ethics committee said today.

title: CONVEST ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the significant loss for the latest quarter and 6-month was due primarily to a writedown of $6,883,000 on the Partnership's oil and gas properties since the net cpaitalized cost as of June 30, 1986 exceeded the present value of estimated future net revenues.

title: TOKYO ACCORD BLAMED
description: The price of computer chips in the United States has skyrocketed in the last month, and major users of the chips - companies that make electronics equipment and computers -blame a trade agreement between the United States and Japan. The semiconductor accord is intended to protect American manufacturers from Japanese dumping - selling chips in this country below cost.

title: CITY STUDY URGES 'DRAMATIC' STEPS TO LIMIT TRAFFIC
description: New York City's Transportation Commissioner said yesterday that current methods of controlling traffic congestion had failed and ''dramatic'' steps were needed if the city was to meet Federal clean-air requirements.

title: Grant Thornton Settles Suit
description: Grant Thornton, the accounting firm for the bankrupt E.S.M. Government Securities, has reached a $22.5 million settlement of claims against it by the American Savings and Loan Association.

title: 2 Soviet Negotiators Recalled From Sweden
description: The Soviet Union has recalled its two top negotiators at the European Disarmament Conference for urgent consultations, Soviet delegates said today.

title: MUSIC: ISRAELI ORCHESTRA PLAYS BRAHMS AND HOLST
description: BIRTHDAY celebrations ought to be entirely happy occasions, but the 50th-anniversary concert given last night by the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra began on a somber note. Zubin Mehta, who not only acts as music director of the New York Philharmonic but also holds that title with the Israeli orchestra, announced before the program began that one of the evening's soloists, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, would play a piece in memory of the victims of the terrorist attack on an Istanbul synagogue. Mr. Ma then performed one of Bach's works for unaccompanied cello, the Sarabande from Suite No. 6, lavishing on it his usual ardor and pinpoint precision. Splendid though the performance was, one felt that a briefer, less virtuosic piece might have been more apt, so that the wholly inappropriate applause that followed might have been avoided.

title: TOPS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Year to June 28
description: The share earnings reflect the company's initial public offering in March.

title: Cancer Patients' Lobby
description: There are laws preventing job discrimination against people on the basis of race, sex, national origin or age, and many people who have survived cancer feel that they should have the same protection, contending that they frequently are denied employment unfairly because they have been ill.

title: China to Unearth More Ancient Statues
description: Archeologists plan to excavate 3,000 life-size terra-cotta warriors and horses near the northern city of Xian in the next two to three years, the official English-language newspaper China Daily reported today.

title: A NEW SEARCH BEGINS FOR AN AMERICAN STAR
description: Jimmy Connors, 34 years of age and fading fast, is the only American remaining in the top 10 computer rankings, clinging to No. 6. Among his more recent results was a first-round loss at Wimbledon and a third-round defeat at the United States Open. Connors has not won a tournament in 22 months.

title: HEINZ, HJ CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The 1985 share earnings is restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split of the company's common stock effective Sept. 23, 1985.

title: FISCAL CRISIS FORCES TEXAS LEGISLATORS TO RECONVENE
description: With one futile 30-day special session behind them, Texas legislators reconvened today for a second try at dealing with the state's fiscal crisis.

title: Japan Outlays Seen Easing
description: Capital spending by major Japanese corporations will slow down in the fiscal year 1986 ending next March, growing only 5.6 percent from the previous fiscal year, when it rose 7.6 percent, a survey released today shows.

title: YANKEES ARE OFFERED NEW PARKING IF LEASE IS EXTENDED, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The principal owner of the New York Yankees is considering a proposal to sign a lease extension at Yankee Stadium in exchange for a large new parking garage and improved access roads to the stadium, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Manute II
description: They call him Starvin' Marvin, and the joke is that he's so skinny, his uniform has just one pinstripe. At 6 feet 6 1/2 inches and only 190 pounds, he is baseball's own Manute Bol look-alike, and the Phillies are set to call him up this week, as soon as his Class AA team at Reading completes its season.

title: Attitude of Judges Needs Improvement to Make Divorce Fairer
description: To the Editor:

title: MCMAHON OUT FOR 3 WEEKS
description: An examination of Jim McMahon's right shoulder several hours after the Chicago Bears' victory over the Cleveland Browns Sunday showed that the injury was more serious than team doctors had first suspected.

title: ENDO-LASE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its prior year results are restated.

title: World Book's Market Debut
description: The World Book Finance Company made its capital market debut yesterday with a $120 million issue of 10-year notes.

title: LOOTERS IMPERIL UNKNOWN PEOPLE'S PAST
description: Mysterious archeological sites that Hmong and other tribal people have been finding for more than two years in the densely forested mountains of western Thailand are being irreparably damaged by their discoverers, according to Thai and international art experts.

title: Market Place; Mergers Seen In Utility Field
description: INVESTORS usually buy electric utility stocks for their dividend yields. But Henry M. Greenleaf is one money manager who has purchased a number of these issues on the rationale that the companies could become takeover targets.

title: 14TH GAME ADJOURNED IN CHESS MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, adjourned the 14th game of their title match today.

title: 10 Dead in Attack On Philippine Church
description: Military officials said today that Moslem rebels excluded from peace talks had attacked a Roman Catholic wedding ceremony, killing 10 people and wounding 96.

title: POLAND'S BISHOPS URGE FULL RIGHTS
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops called today for the release of all political prisoners and for constitutional guarantees that all political opposition figures may take part fully in national life.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Uneventful but Unforgettable Army Days
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS' MISTAKE: IGNORING WALKER
description: After a $2.2 million truce, Joe Morris participated in the Giants' 31-28 loss in their season opener here last night, but their uncertainty at running back might not have existed if they had chosen Herschel Walker in the National Football League's 1985 draft before the Dallas Cowboys did. The Giants' mistake, like that of other N.F.L. teams, was not checking the details of the 1982 Heisman Trophy winner's contract with Donald Trump.

title: MERCHANTSBANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $775,000, or 24 cents per share, for the latest quarter and $138,000, or 7 cents per share, for the year-ago period.

title: Manville Picks Chief Executive
description: W. T. Stephens, 43 years old, has been elected chief executive of the Manville Corporation, the company said yesterday. The move, which had been expected, completes the installation of a new management team in connection with the company's bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: Dart & Kraft Calls Spinoff 'Premark'
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. today announced the name of the corporation that it plans to spin off -Premark International Inc. - and said it would distribute the stock of the company in the fourth quarter.

title: Not a Spy, a Hostage
description: The formal charge of espionage against Nicholas Daniloff, an innocent American correspondent in Moscow, creates a grievous threat to Soviet-American relations. Pravda's claim notwithstanding, the rage that Americans feel is not being whipped up by opponents of arms control and other negotiations. It is an expression of widespread disgust that the Soviet Government would seize a legitimate journalist as hostage to force the release of one of its paid spies in the United States.

title: U.S. SEES ARREST OF DANILOFF AS STANDARD K.G.B. POLICY
description: The prevailing view inside the Reagan Administration is that the Soviet jailing of an American journalist was standard K.G.B. procedure. That procedure is to do whatever is necessary to get a Soviet agent out of jail and into Soviet hands and eventually to set up a trade to free the agent.

title: TIME'S FIGHT TO SAVE DISCOVER
description: Time Inc.'s ill-fated TV-Cable Week may have grabbed all the headlines a few years back with its $47 million in losses, but another Time publication, Discover, has been quietly chalking up disappointing numbers of its own. In the six years since it was introduced, losses from the monthly science magazine have mounted to an estimated $40 million.

title: ARRESTED IN FATAL CAR CRASH, OFFICER ENDS LIFE WITH A GUN
description: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and killed himself early today after being arrested on a charge of drunken driving in a fatal accident.

title: ROSAMOND GILDER, AN AUTHOR INFLUENTUAL IN WORLD THEATER
description: Rosamond Gilder, an influential theater figure in New York and overseas, died Friday at her home in Tyringham, Mass. She was 95 years old.

title: People
description: * Jay Durante has been elected a senior vice president at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: Survey Finds Backing For Breast Feeding
description: Almost three-quarters of adults believe breast-feeding is the best way to feed a baby, and more than half think employers should provide places for working mothers to pump out their milk for later use or to nurse their babies at work, according to a national survey made public today.

title: Newsletter Published On Music Marketing
description: Rolling Stone magazine's in-house creative department is publishing Marketing Through Music, a monthly newsletter geared for marketing, advertising and music executives.

title: Back to School
description: While St. John's ponders its next step in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's suspension of Marco Baldi, the 6-11 Italian-born star registered yesterday for his sophomore year. Baldi was suspended for the entire 1986-87 season and four games of the following season and ordered to repay $11,000 to Simac of Milan, which had paid some of his travel and high school expenses in the United States, an N.C.A.A violation that occurred before he entered St. John's.

title: TOLL BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NORTHWEST ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Johnson Foundation Chooses Staff Executive as President
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J., the country's largest philanthropy devoted exclusively to health care, has elected Dr. Leighton E. Cluff as president. He succeeds Dr. David E. Rogers, who is joining the faculty of the Cornell University Medical College in New York City.

title: NASA CHIEF SAYS FIFTH SPACE SHUTTLE IS NEEDED
description: THE head of the space agency said yesterday that NASA needed a fifth space shuttle to meet increased launching demands in the early 1990's, calling construction of a fifth spacecraft ''an absolute necessity.''

title: Rockwell to Buy Electronics Corp.
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said that its Allen-Bradley Company subsidiary had agreed to buy the Electronics Corporation of America for $52 a share, or $99 million.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $748,000 and $2,363,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, of income tax benefit from utilization of operating loss carryforward.

title: G.M.A.C. Offering Securities Abroad
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering the first issue of debt securities backed by car loan receivables specificially tailored for the Eurobond market.

title: U.S. DRUG TEST PLAN STUDIED BY AIDES
description: President Reagan's domestic policy advisers today considered legislation and an executive order that would permit drug testing of more than half of all Federal civilian workers.

title: George Gipe Is Dead at 53; A Film and Television Writer
description: George Gipe, a screenwriter who collaborated on such film comedies as Steve Martin's ''Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid'' and ''The Man With Two Brains,'' died Saturday shortly after being stung by a bee, according to the police. He was 53 years old and lived in Glendale.

title: French Denationalization
description: The insurance group AGF (Assurances Generales de France), the Saint-Gobain industrial group and the Paribas financial banking group will be the first concerns to be sold into private ownership in the French Government's sweeping denationalization program, the French state television reported tonight.

title: REAGAN SEES PERIL TO U.S.-SOVIET TIES IN REPORTER CASE
description: President Reagan today called the Soviet detention of of an American journalist an ''outrage'' and reiterated warnings that the episode was endangering United States-Soviet relations.

title: Would You Buy a Used Car From This Police Dept.?
description: Does the chance to pick up an antique Bentley motorcar at a police auction - for who knows how little money - sound too good to be true?

title: Phillips Petroleum To Buy Its Stock
description: In a continuing effort to reduce debt obligations, the Phillips Petroleum Company said that it might repurchase up to six million shares of its outstanding preferred stock. The company issued 12 million preferred shares in June 1985.

title: Hunts File Venue Plea
description: Lawyers for the three Hunt brothers of Texas asked a Federal appeals court today to block a judge's order transferring their bankruptcy cases from New Orleans to Dallas.

title: BEST SELLERS: BIG COATS, ALLIGATOR ACCENTS
description: The big flaring long coat is one of the first fashion successes of the fall season, according to the fashion coordinators of four New York stores.

title: HYDROMER INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FARM AID SPLITS U.S. AND FRANCE
description: The United States and France are sharply divided over the timing and extent of any subsidy cuts in agriculture as they prepare for multilateral negotiations next week on a new round of trade liberalization, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today.

title: 9 STATES CHOOSING CANDIDATES AT PRIMARIES TODAY
description: Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota faces a first hurdle Tuesday in his bid to keep his job for four more years.

title: U.S. Eagle Coin in Debut
description: The Government made a well-timed entry into the international gold coin market today by issuing the American Eagle, the first bullion coin to be minted in the United States in more than 50 years.

title: Pinochet Has Reaped What He Has Sown
description: The failed guerrilla attempt on the life of Gen. Augusto Pinochet on Sunday, almost 13 years to the day that he seized power in a bloody coup in Chile, marked a turning point in the history of my country.

title: MANY SCHOOLS CROWDED ON FIRST DAY
description: The 968 public schools in New York City opened yesterday, many overflowing with students and in need of serious repairs to walls and windows, and some experiencing their first encounters of the term with drugs.

title: A Star Is Born for the Democrats
description: President Reagan may be the biggest money-raising star on the political circuit, but for once the Democrats matched or maybe even topped him here last weekend, with a superstar of their own: Barbra Streisand, singing in public for the first time in six years.

title: POLL IN WEST BANK FINDS PALESTINIANS STRONGLY FAVOR ARAFAT
description: A poll published today by an Arabic newspaper here has found that a vast majority of West Bank Palestinians back Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, over King Hussein of Jordan, who has embarked on an Israeli-supported project to supplant the P.L.O.'s influence in the West Bank.

title: A PARISH BANS ASSEMBLYMAN FROM SPEAKING
description: Since his birth 46 years ago, Assemblyman John C. Dearie has been a member of St. Raymond's Roman Catholic parish in the Bronx, attending its school before going off to the University of Notre Dame and eventually watching his two children baptized in the parish.

title: SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $259,000 for the quarter and $467,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Muzak Sale Set
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had agreed to sell Muzak, a unit of its Group W Radio division, to the Field Corporation of Chicago. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MEMENTOES AT THE VIETNAM MEMORIAL
description: Thousands file past the Vietnam Memorial here every day, many studying it intently to find a familiar name among the 58,000 inscribed there, others pausing momentarily to run a finger along the black marble wall.

title: SUDDENLY, A HAVEN FOR BASQUES IS FULL OF HAZARDS
description: His name was Iker, he said, and in recent weeks he had been living on the run, sleeping in friends' houses and going out as little as possible.

title: Security, Esthetics and a Lost Road
description: Old-time Washingtonians like to reminisce about the days when security was not much of an issue at the White House. In fact, there was no fence and one could drive right up to the front door of the home of the President of the United States and leave a calling card.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COST OF SPIRALING Limited wall space along the half-mile of spiraling ramp that is the core of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (1071 Fifth Avenue, at 88th Street) has been causing a problem familiar to householders: Where to hang the pictures? A proposal to build an annex to Frank Lloyd Wright's 1959 home for the Guggenheim has touched off a spirited debate over design, and now the museum is taking advantage of its wall space to present its side of the question to visitors and other innocent bystanders.

title: Strike Stirs Debate on Armco Future
description: A strike by nearly 4,200 hourly workers at Armco Inc.'s major steelmaking operations has led steel industry analysts to debate whether the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker might be plunged into bankruptcy, as the company has contended.

title: Books: Ike in Command
description: EISENHOWER: AT WAR 1943-1945. By David Eisenhower. 977 pages.Random House. $29.95.

title: Alvin Heaps, 67, Dies; Retail Union President
description: Alvin E. Heaps, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union and a member of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive board, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Revamping Is Western Union Issue
description: This could be a critical week in the Western Union Corporation's 135-year history, according to some Wall Street analysts, as shareholders and bondholders vote on a complicated financial restructuring plan without which the company could end up in bankruptcy.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL EXPOS VS. METS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, at Toronto, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) BRAVES VS. DODGERS, at Los Angeles (Television - WTBS, 10:35 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: RED SOX WIN, 9-3, FOR NINTH IN A ROW
description: Bill Buckner doubled home the tiebreaking run in the 11th inning tonight to trigger a six-run explosion against Don Aase, and the Boston Red Sox beat the Orioles by 9-3 for their ninth straight victory.

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $8,146. c-After extraordinary gains of $30,376, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $95,569, or 5 cents a share, for the year. d-After an extraordinary gain of $9,179, or 1 cent a share.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Artists' Protection
description: That little c that appears on publications to protect the owner's copyright also has to appear on paintings and sculpture, which the artists frequently find esthetically unpleasing. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, has a plan to remove that intrusion and plans to include it in a bill he is introducing today.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIALS RESOLVE DISPUTE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres has accepted a written retraction from his Trade and Industry Minister, Ariel Sharon, who had charged that a terrorist attack against a synagogue in Turkey was a consequence of peace overtures by Mr. Peres.

title: BILL MOYERS AND CBS, THE STORY OF A BREAKUP
description: Bill Moyers and CBS News are parting ways, and the breaking up is bitter. Mr. Moyers, the commentator and documentarian who went to CBS five years ago to be the voice and conscience of CBS News, is convinced that network television, in the drive to survive commercially, no longer wants his kind of journalism.

title: FREE FARMERS' PAPER BINDS GEORGIANS
description: When his widowed mother, Clara, died at the age of 82, Hubert G. Holland, who was born along a dirt road in the country and is now is a city lawyer, sat down in his Marietta office and wrote a long letter to the Georgia Department of Agriculture, to the editor of its Farmers and Consumers Market Bulletin.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SOVIET INDICATES DANILOFF FACES WIDER CHARGES
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia indicated today that the Soviet authorities intended to link an imprisoned American journalist, Nicholas S. Daniloff, to an American diplomat who was expelled from the Soviet Union in June 1985 for what Moscow said was espionage.

title: Holocaust Museum
description: Alvin Rosenfeld, who has worked for eight years at the Smithsonian Institution, most recently as director of public affairs, began a new job yesterday.

title: It's in U.S. Interest to Support Iraq in Gulf War
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPARATE GROUPS BACKING BERING SEA OIL PACT
description: A rare agreement has been reached by oil companies, environmentalists, fishermen and Eskimos on which areas of the Bering Sea should be open to oil and gas exploration.

title: The Case Rehnquist Shouldn't Have Decided
description: To the Editor:

title: Dan Moore, 80, Dies; Governor and Justice
description: Former Gov. Dan K. Moore, an Associate Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court for nearly 10 years, died Sunday at Duke University Medical Center. He was 80 years old.

title: Now, Silicon Dating
description: The steady decay of naturally radioactive substances provides scientists with a set of useful gauges for determining the ages of things. Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., reports that it has added a new and important ''clock'' to the list: silicon 32, a mildly radioactive form of silicon, which can be used to measure the ages of silicon-bearing materials too recent for other forms of radioactive dating.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
LAW THWARTS EFFORT TO DONATE INFANTS' ORGANS
description: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, was told last week that one of her infants will die at birth because he is anencephalic - his brain has completely failed to develop. The woman wants to donate the organs of her doomed child when the twins are delivered 16 weeks from now, but she cannot. Using such infants as organ donors is illegal in the United States.

title: 117,000 Students Idle In 25 Teacher Strikes
description: Striking teachers reached agreement on new contracts in three school districts in Illinois, Michigan and Washington yesterday, while 117,000 students idled by strikes in 23 other districts nationwide and two colleges faced another week without school.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in September 1985 and a 15 percent stock dividend paid in May 1986.

title: 1 KILLED, 18 HURT IN PARIS EXPLOSION
description: An explosion apparently caused by a bomb ripped through the ground floor post office of City Hall tonight, killing one person and wounding 18 people, the police said.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,657,000. Revenue represents total revenue
