title: The Case Rehnquist Shouldn't Have Decided; A Touchy Subject
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATES INCREASE AGAIN
description: Interest rates rose yesterday for the fifth consecutive day as hopes for another Federal Reserve move to cut short-term rates waned and investors seemed wary of adding to their holdings of longer-term notes and bonds.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Year to June 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ''THE TARGET IS DESTROYED.'' What Really Happened to Flight 007 and What America Knew About It. By Seymour M. Hersh. Illustrated. 282 pages. Random House. $17.95. IN a positive sense, Seymour Hersh's highly anticipated book about the shooting down of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 is something of an anticlimax, if only because it fails to confirm any of the more extreme speculation about what might have happened in 1983 when a civilian airplane apparently flew into Soviet airspace over Sakhalin Island and was destroyed by a Soviet interceptor.

title: VICTIMS OF TERROR AT SYNAGOGUE
description: Following is a list of the worshipers killed and wounded in the attack on the Neve Shalom Synagogue on Saturday. The list was provided by Jewish leaders in Istanbul. DEAD ALHALEL, Jozef ANJEL, Salamon ATALAY, Yuda Levi BABAZADE, Mirva BAROKAS, Izak BARUH, Danyel Daryo BEHAR, David, a cantor CITTONE, Selim Salom ERESKENAZI, Binyamin ERGUN, Aser, a cantor ERGUN, Ibrahim GERSON, Izak HARA, Elyezer LEVI, Moiz LEVI, Rensiyon MATALON, Yakov MUSAOGLU, Leon Levi NESIM, Rafael OZFINS, Robert Israel SAUL, Moiz SENKAL, Sefanya Wounded ERESKENAZI, Avram GENC, Yasef Levi SAMRANO, Jak SITRAN, Moiz

title: CHILE'S ARMY, REACTING TO ATTACK, ARRESTS FOES AND SHUTS MAGAZINES
description: Hours after an unsuccessful assassination attempt against President Augusto Pinochet was reported, his military Government moved today to expand a state of siege, closing six opposition magazines and arresting a range of opponents.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 16
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $10,900,000 for the quarter and $10,877,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $230,000 for the quarter and $376,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago second quarter and 6 months results restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: FEARS OF U.S. COMPANIES RISE ON COST OF SOUTH AFRICA TIES
description: New pressures are increasing the burden on American companies operating in South Africa, prompting many to leave or consider doing so.

title: THE BOLSHEVIKS' PRISONER: NICHOLAS DANILOFF
description: In 1961, when Nicholas S. Daniloff told his father, the son of a czarist general, that he was going to cover the Soviet Union for United Press International, the elder Daniloff retorted: ''You think your American passport is going to save you from the Bolsheviks. You're wrong. They're going to send you to the salt mines.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of primary-election candidates in Metropolitan Report yesterday misidentified a Democratic candidate in the 30th Assembly District and failed to designate the incumbency of a Democratic candidate in the 32d Assembly District, both in Queens. Sheryl Ann Fetik is one of seven candidates in the 30th district; Edward Abramson is the incumbent in the 32d.

title: Desegregation Plan Begins in San Jose
description: Amid delays but no protests, thousands of pupils rode buses to the first day of classes yesterday in San Jose, Calif., as the city's schools opened under a court-ordered desegregation plan.

title: Bridge: A Lead Gave Away the Game In Von Zedtwitz Team Final
description: Some honor combinations, such as a doubleton J-10, represent very desirable opening leads because it is virtually certain that they will not give away a trick.

title: POLYDEX PHARMACEUTICALS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary profit of $768,043 on the sale of the company's Nova Scotia marine subsidiary for the quarter and 6 months.

title: PENTAGON INVESTIGATING WRITER AFTER SEARCH YIELDS CLASSIFIED PAPERS
description: A writer widely known in military and business circles for his reporting about antimissile defense plans is under investigation by the Pentagon after classified documents were seized in a search of his office.

title: CASE IS SEVERED FROM CITY CORRUPTION TRIAL
description: The judge presiding over the major Federal trial stemming from the city's municipal corruption scandal yesterday removed one of the defendants, David Leff, from the case after the prosecutors argued that including him might weaken their case.

title: RACE FOR HARD DISK HORSEPOWER HEATS UP
description: No sooner had hard disks established themselves as practical necessities in personal computing than manufacturers embarked upon a megabyte race very similar to the horsepower race Detroit began in the 50's, initiating its golden era of performance. As anyone familiar with that competition will attest, there's horsepower and then there's usable horsepower, the latter being dependent upon numerous factors ranging from transmissions to tires.

title: VOWS MORE PROTESTS
description: Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistan opposition leader, was released from prison tonight, three and a half weeks after her arrest in a Government crackdown on political dissidents. She immediately vowed to resume her drive to overthrow the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: MUSIC: 'VIENNA 1900,' SERIES AT MODERN MUSEUM
description: VIENNA in 1900 was in a boil and a lethargy, as if everything of the old century sensed the imminence of the cataclysms that would sweep it away, and it responded either with feverish activity or glum reiteration of old ideas. It was a time of intellectual ferment and vastly influential artistic pathbreaking, but neither in its visual arts nor in its music does one have much sense of joy. The music is being sampled in an extremely classy chamber series that began Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, where the Vienna 1900 exhibition is on display.

title: MUSIC: NAUMBURG GROUP PLAYS IN DAMROSCH PARK
description: IT seems only right that the Naumburg Orchestral Concerts should take place in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park. In an unsentimental city, where history is often shoveled under in the name of progress, it is satisfying to see these two great names in New York musical history prominently yoked together. Damrosch Park, a concrete garden west of the New York State Theater, is named for the Damrosch family: Leopold, the founder of the Oratorio Society and what later became the New York Philharmonic, and his sons Walter - a dedicated supporter of American music and a visionary in his use of the radio to instruct - and Frank, who founded the Institute of Musical Art, now the Juilliard School. The Naumburg family's contributions have also been extraordinary. Elkan Naumburg, who thought it important to encourage and stimulate the public's interest in symphonic and semiclassical music, founded a series of free concerts in 1905.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PAKISTANIS INVESTIGATE AID TO HIJACKERS
description: Police detectives visited this city's Arab communities and Palestinian hostels today, investigating whether the hijackers of a Pan American jumbo jet had local accomplices.

title: Impasse Reported on Site Of Third-World Meeting
description: The group of nations professing nonalignment, which ended a meeting here Sunday, said today that it could not agree on the site of its next meeting of heads of state, to be held in three years.

title: Mock Nuclear Disaster Stirs Public Alarm
description: More than a dozen frightened people called the police after hearing a political advertisement that simulated a news broadcast of a meltdown at the Seabrook nuclear power plant, the authorities said today.

title: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes utilization of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: DEMOCRATIC SENATE PRIMARY IN WISCONSIN TODAY SEEN AS TIGHT RACE
description: ''It's a dead heat,'' said the union leader, surprised.

title: CAR BOMB EXPLOSION IN COLOGNE
description: A powerful car bomb exploded early this morning outside the Cologne offices of West Germany's counterintelligence agency, slightly wounding a passing motorist and severely damaging the building's facade.

title: TV SERIES PUTS ENGLISH LANGUAGE IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: ABOUT 100 years ago Mark Twain published ''Huckleberry Finn,'' and it was an instant scandal. A book that was written in the vernacular and that made a hero of Nigger Jim, a runaway slave, was an assault on genteel minds. Except for a small but vocal minority, the English-speaking world has long since adopted Huck as a American linguistic and literary treasure.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I call upon the Soviet authorities to act responsibly and quickly so that our two countries can make progress on the many other issues on our agenda - solving existing problems instead of creating new ones.'' -President Reagan. [ A8:1. ]

title: DEMOCRATS IN NEW YORK FACE KEY RACES TODAY
description: New York State Democrats will nominate a candidate for the United States Senate and select nominees for many other public offices today in primary elections that also mark the first stage in an effort to modernize New York City's voting procedures and voter records.

title: G.O.P. Contests Top Connecticut Primary
description: Today's primary is largely a Democratic affair in New York, but in Connecticut it is a mostly Republican contest.

title: Multifoods Sets Restructuring
description: The International Multifoods Corporation said today that it plans to sell its consumer foods operations and several other groups. These segments, which account for 20 percent of the company's 1986 sales, should fetch more than $175 million, analysts said.

title: 'THE WIZARD' SERIES BEGINS TONIGHT ON CBS
description: THE HERO of ''The Wizard,'' a new hourlong series making its debut on CBS at 8 this evening, is a fantastically clever inventor who has a talent for solving supposedly unsolvable problems. Whether he will do anything for the network's ratings troubles remains to be seen, but Simon McKay, as he is called, winds up his first episode with a levitation illusion that reduces a gang of South American toughs to simpering idiots.

title: FIRST-RATE QUARTERBACKS TO TEST THE JETS
description: This should be a year to remember, not only for Jets fans, but for anyone who follows the American Football Conference East.

title: Alf Landon Turns 99 Today
description: ''I've got to see how my political predictions come out,'' Alf Landon says in explaining his new prediction that he will live to see his 100th birthday. Mr. Landon, the former Governor of Kansas who is the Grand Old Man of the Grand Old Party despite his landslide loss to Franklin Delano Roosevelt in the 1936 Presidential election, turns 99 Tuesday. ''I'm a little more optimistic than I was a year ago,'' said Mr. Landon, who now uses a cane and whose hearing and eyesight sometimes inhibit conversation. ''I think the country and the world are a little bit better off than they were on my 98th birthday.''

title: Hair Care Account To MG & Messina
description: MG & Messina International, a four-month-old agency, has been handling the United States advertising for five European companies. Now it has been assigned a new hair care system by B&R Manufacturing of Miami, which makes hair and skin care products for black consumers.

title: Notable Course Dropped
description: Last Friday, the Columbia University Office of Public Information announced that Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Representative from Queens and Vice Presidential candidate, had joined the faculty as ''adjunct professor of international and public affairs.''

title: KEY RATES
Two Plead Guilty
description: A Tulane student and another man pleaded guilty in a New Orleans Court yesterday to gambling charges arising from the point-shaving scandal that caused the university last year to end its basketball program.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $22.9 million for the quarter and $9.1 million for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.2 million for the quarter and $7 million for the year.

title: Today Is Primary Day. Vote!
description: As always, our most important recommendation on Primary Day is that voters vote. The absence of a vigorous two-party system in New York City is damaging enough without being made worse by apathy.

title: O'ROURKE FAULTS CUOMO FOR ATTACKS ON CHURCH BAN AGAINST DISSENTERS
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, yesterday criticized Governor Cuomo for taking issue with the policy of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York on dissident speakers, saying, ''If he doesn't want to be a Catholic, he shouldn't be one.''

title: VERMONT'S CHOICE: 2 FAMILIAR FACES
description: In a state where the election season is heralded by the appearance of the scarlet and yellow patches along the mountainsides, former Gov. Richard A. Snelling has an unusual problem: Too much good will.

title: Offer for Heck's Tops $130 Million
description: An investment group led by a private investor, Robert I. Toussie, and the New York brokerage Edward A. Viner & Company said that it had offered to acquire Heck's Inc. For each share, the offer consists of $13 in cash and securities estimated to be worth $3.25 a share. The offer totals more than $130 million.

title: Guam's Indicted Leader Wins
description: Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo, under indictment for alleged influence peddling, has easily won the territory's Democratic primary election.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FIXED MORTGAGE RATES DECLINE AS OTHERS RISE
description: Interest rates on fixed-rate mortgages continued to decline last month while rates on adjustable mortgages rose slightly, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Legal Aid Sues State On Shelter Referrals
description: The Legal Aid Society has sued New York State, charging it is allowing the city to send pregnant women, babies under 6 months of age and medically vulnerable people to group shelters. A state regulation forbids such referrals.

title: Talking Business with Gladstone of Arthur Young; In Accounting, Ties and Taxes
description: Last week's announcement that KMG Main Hurdman and Peat Marwick International intended to merge sent ripples, if not shock waves, through the accounting industry.

title: DRIVER CHARGED IN CRASH THAT KILLED ONE AT DISCO
description: A driver for a car service has been charged with running a red light after his vehicle collided with a taxicab that spun out of control, struck and killed a woman in front of the Limelight discotheque in Chelsea, the police said yesterday.

title: Bhopal Court Sets Deadline
description: The Union Carbide Corporation must reply within four weeks to the Indian Government's compensation claim on behalf of victims of the world's worst industrial accident, a Bhopal judge ruled today.

title: DIAGNOSTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONNECTICUT: BATTLEGROUND FOR A BASEBALL WAR
description: For years men have searched for the elusive line that divides Connecticut between Yankee and Red Sox dominance.

title: NBC Wins 15 Emmys In Technical Categories
description: NBC has won 15 Emmy Awards in behind-the-scenes categories, with ''St. Elsewhere,'' ''Amazing Stories'' and ''An Early Frost'' each taking three.

title: THE NAMES OF THE GAME
description: Seven guys on 1986 college rosters who were born to play football: STERLING QUASH linebacker, North Carolina State WILL RUSH defensive tackle, Columbia TOM QUICK wide receiver, Kansas STEVE HEAVYSIDE offensive lineman, Indiana REID LONG long-snapper, Colorado RICHARD BEAR defensive tackle, Arizona State SHAWN LIGHTNING fullback, Washington

title: Milan Wants Walker
description: With negotiations apparently at a standstill, Kenny (Sky) Walker, the 6-foot-8-inch forward out of Kentucky and the Knicks' top draft choice, is weighing the possibility of playing in Europe. Dan Peterson, the coach of Milan, arrived in New York yesterday to open discussions with Larry Fleisher, Walker's agent.

title: Blot on The Big Picture
description: This ancient city of tranquil gardens and shrines is a place to get a different perspective on the Big Picture. At least that was the idea in convoking the annual conference of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here. But events have their way of imposing unexpected distortions on the grand sweep of issues.

title: Malaysian Government Bans Rock Concerts
description: The Malaysian Government has banned all public rock concerts indefinitely, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-After tax credits of $690,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,890,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $2,018,000, or 59 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,978,000 for the 6 months.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: Boy Dies Alerting Others
description: A 4-year-old boy who died in a fire at his home is credited with giving the alert that saved the lives of three other people in the house, according to fire officials here.

title: Service for Ex-Editor of Post
description: A memorial service for Paul Sann, the former executive editor of The New York Post who died Friday, will be held at 5:45 P.M. tomorrow in the Mayer auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: WINERY STRIKES IN WEST MARRING INDUSTRY REVIVAL
description: A strike against California's wine industry is spreading just as the industry is experiencing a modest turnaround after four difficult years of slack sales, foreclosed vineyards and other problems.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A Washington dispatch by The Associated Press on Thursday reported that the National Archives had made public a tape recording of a 1974 conversation held by President Nixon.

title: FOR ONE JET, A FALSE ALARM
description: The sirens were going off. They sound inside people's heads each summer in professional football camps, where productive bodies are inevitably considered slightly less useful and where someone new and willing always comes along. Sometimes the sirens are false alarms, at least for the time being, and sometimes they are ignored until the very end, when the message is sent: The coach would like to see you, and don't forget the playbook.

title: Lorimar Buys MGM Facility
description: Lorimar-Telepictures said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire MGM/UA Entertainment Company's 44-acre production facility and Metrocolor Film Laboratory from Turner Broadcasting System Inc. for $160 million in cash and deferred obligations.

title: American on a Tour of Asia Is Found Dead in Pakistan
description: An American on a yearlong tour of Asia was found dead in his hotel room in Lahore over the weekend, United States diplomats said today.

title: Drug for River Blindness
description: A new drug may be an important breakthrough in the treatment of river blindness, a tropical disease that now impairs or destroys the sight of 40 million people in Africa and South America, scientists report. River blindness, or onchocerciasis, is caused by a parasite that is spread from person to person by blackflies that breed in rivers and streams.

title: DOW FALLS BY 11.11, TO 1,888.64
description: Profit taking sent stock prices to their second consecutive loss yesterday as investors again moved away from issues that were considered good bets in slow economic times.

title: Article 577586 -- No Title
description: IC Industries, the diversified railroad company, announced today that it would take a $520 million pretax charge as part of a restructuring of its transportation equipment and railroad operations.

title: 0-1, for Starters
description: Jerry Burns, after the Minnesota Vikings' loss to Detroit in his debut as head coach: ''You're not going to win every game, but I hate to prove it right off the bat.''

title: Nihilism in Istanbul
description: Hard in the wake of the Karachi hijacking, which left 19 dead, two gunmen crept into an Istanbul synagogue and opened fire on Sabbath worshipers, slaughtering 21 innocents. There is a common method in this madness, whose perpetrators leave no calling card except a heap of bodies. That is the signature associated with the infamous Abu Nidal, suspected plotter of the airport massacres in Vienna and Rome and of earlier attacks on European synagogues. Israelis suspect him as the mastermind in both Karachi and Istanbul.

title: MITSUBISHI TO ACQUIRE SILTEC
description: The Siltec Corporation, one of the two major American producers of silicon wafers used to make computer chips, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Mitsubishi Metal Corporation of Japan in a $32 million deal.

title: Chicago and Memphis Taxable-Bond Sources
description: Taxable-bond offerings by local government authorities are increasingly frequent and are touted by investment bankers as the financing of the future for many governments.

title: MAYORS PLAN DAY TO FOCUS ON DRUGS
description: The United States Conference of Mayors is planning a National Mayors' Day on drugs in cities across the nation this fall to emphasize in each locality the urgency of steps to curb drug abuse.

title: COCA-COLA TO SELL 51% OF BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it would sell 51 percent of its newly formed bottling company to the public in what could be the largest initial stock offering ever.

title: HEADED U.S. CHURCH COUNCIL
description: The Rev. Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg, former president of the National Council of Churches, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Orangewood Retirement Community, Phoenix. He was 93 years old.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AT P.S. 89 IN ELMHURST, EDUCATORS CAN JUGGLE, TOO
description: Arlene Kellner, a music teacher without a room to teach music in, copes with the overcrowding at Public School 89 in Queens by traveling from classroom to classroom with a small portable piano.

title: RED SOX TURNING EAST RACE INTO A ROUT
description: This was the day the Yankees were supposed to begin in earnest their part of the American League East race. At this juncture, though, the Yankees' chances of winning that race seem only slightly less remote than the Mets' chances of losing their race in the National League East.

title: I.M.F. Move on Mexico
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that its board had tentatively approved a $1.6 billion loan to Mexico. Disbursement of the funds, part of a $12 billion rescue package for Mexico, will not be made until a consortium of commercial banks reaches agreement on its part of the package, the I.M.F. said.

title: MAN WHO TOLD OF 300 KILLINGS GETS HEARING IN TEXAS SLAYING
description: A pretrial hearing began today for Henry Lee Lucas, accused of a 1983 ax slaying that was among the more than 300 killings he once admitted but later denied.

title: Moslem Factions Battle In 2 Beirut Suburbs
description: Rival Shiite Moslem militiamen fought street battles today in two southern suburbs of Beirut, and the police said two gunmen were killed.

title: Advertising; Campaign For DDB Needham
description: THE management of the recently created DDB Needham Worldwide Advertising, having decided on yesterday as its birthday, appropriately celebrated the event with some advertising both in newspapers and in the trade press.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt0

title: A CHICAGO THEATER RESCUED
description: The 12,000 light bulbs in the marquee of the Chicago Theater, which was nearly demolished four years ago, are shining again after a $3.5 million renovation.

title: Careers; Placing The Older Manager
description: TODAY, thousands of dismissed middle and senior managers are looking for jobs. One small, new step on their behalf is being taken by the Senior Career Planning and Placement Service, in New York, which recruits retired or dismissed older managers for specific jobs with foundations and small companies that cannot pay managers what they formerly received.

title: JUDGE BARS A DELAY IN MAFIA TRIAL OF 8
description: A defendant accused of being a Mafia boss acted as his own lawyer and requested a postponement yesterday as jury selection began in the trial of eight men charged with participating in a Mafia governing ''commission.''

title: FANNIE MAE CHOICE IS EX-CROCKER CHIEF
description: Frank V. Cahouet, former chairman, president and chief executive officer of Crocker National Bank in California, has been nominated to be president, chief operating officer and a director of the Federal National Mortgage Association in Washington.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: FALL'S ''new neutral'' grays, which blend so well with city asphalt and concrete, are popping up everywhere. But the new fashion season is hardly gray.

title: HOW TO USE SABER TEETH
description: SABER-TOOTHED cats, great predators of the last ice age, have long been a puzzle: The awesome saberlike teeth, extending well below the lower jaw, look murderous, but how were they actually used? On modern lions or tigers such teeth would be far too long to be useful.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the year-to-date net loss resulted from writedowns aggregating $71.25 million, or $57.6 million net of taxes, which were recognized during the second quarter in the carrying value of the company's oil and gas properties and certain other general properties.

title: US Magazine Acts To Woo Business
description: US magazine, owned jointly by Rolling Stone magazine and Lorimar-Telepictures, has enlisted three Hollywood stars to catch the eye of the business community.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1986
description: Companies

title: HAWAII VENTURE'S STELLAR CAST
description: In a marriage of spectacular expertise and connections, William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary who has become an investment Midas, has bought a stake in Hawaii's biggest savings and loan association and has hired Preston Martin to run it.

title: Not-So-Super Titles
description: To the Editor:

title: DEPRESSION TIED TO SOME EXCESSES IN YOUTH
description: WHAT draws young people to a flirtation with excess, risk, outrage and sometimes even evil?

title: LANDLORD RELEASED FROM RIKERS I.
description: J. Leonard Spodek, the landlord with thousands of building-code violations charged at 40 of his properties in Manhattan and in Brooklyn, was released late yesterday from the Correctional Institution for Men on Rikers Island after serving 45 days for some of the violations.

title: Dockworkers in 2 Cities Reach Tentative Agreement
description: Longshoremen in New York and Boston reached tentative agreement with four major employer groups on a new three-year contract.

title: NEBRASKA PLAYERS REGAIN ELIGIBILITY
description: The 60 Nebraska football players ordered suspended for at least one game by the N.C.A.A. last week had their eligibility restored yesterday by an appeals subcommittee.

title: PACKWOOD RULES OUT A TAX RISE
description: Zaking issue with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Senator Bob Packwood said today that following enactment of a new income tax system this year, tax rates would not be raised ''in the foreseeable future.''

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS CITES REHNQUIST MEMO ON RIGHTS
description: The debate over Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist flared up today as opponents of his nomination to be Chief Justice made public a memorandum he wrote as a Nixon Administration lawyer summarizing objections to the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: WOMEN'S SUCCESS: A DARKER SIDE
description: DURING the day, Mary is someone ambitious women could easily envy. At 37 years old, she is a highly paid hotel manager, divorced mother of a 10-year-old and 12-year-old, maker of homemade granola, community activist - in all, a ''pillar of the community,'' as she mockingly describes herself.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
What's 'Natural'
description: WE need a substitute for the word ''organic'' -another way to describe the nurturing, coddling and marketing that bring us the superior produce offered at superior prices by specialty stores and some farm stands.

title: Buell Mullen, Muralist And Painter on Metals
description: Buell Mullen, a mural painter, died Aug. 31 at a nursing home in Riverwoods, Ill. She was 85 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: India Arrests Suspect In Killing of General
description: The authorities said today that they had captured a man they suspect of assassinating Gen. Arun S. Vaidya, a former Indian army Commander in Chief.

title: President Resigns Post at Newsweek
description: Mark M. Edmiston resigned under pressure as president of Newsweek, yesterday, and Christopher M. Little, senior vice president and director of administration of the magazine, was named to succeed him.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAND IN GLOVE

title: Pact Set on Polish Debt
description: Polish authorities and Western bankers have signed an agreement for rescheduling more than $2 billion in debts due this year and next year.

title: Banks Signs Bulls Pact
description: The Chicago Bulls have signed Gene Banks, a 27-year-old forward, to a multiyear contract.

title: RECORD SAVE BY RIGHETTI HELPS YANKEES TO VICTORY
description: The Yankees, mathematically in the American League East race but realistically out of it, used the Dave Righetti formula tonight and further frustrated the Toronto Blue Jays' defense of their division title. Unfortunately for the Yankees, they have to have a lead for the Righetti formula to work.

title: PERSISTENT MINISTER CREDITS PREPARATION FOR VICTORY
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake took his two young sons into the polling booth at Public School 172 in Laurelton, Queens, yesterday morning and one of them Hasan, age 2, almost hit the lever for Representative Alton R. Waldon Jr., Mr. Flake's opponent in the Sixth Congressional District primary race.

title: CAPUS MILLER WAYNICK
description: Capus Miller Waynick, a retired ambassador, politician and newspaperman, died Sunday after a long illness.

title: Alcohol in the Tank
description: To the Editor:

title: 101 Percent Brushless: A Car Wash Saga
description: A sparkling Coupe de Ville sporting a fur-covered dashboard and chrome-spoked wheels rolled out of the car wash in Brooklyn. Dwayne Mayhew slipped behind the wheel and said he has the car professionally cleaned every week, ''because my girlfriend demands it.'' Sam Sherman thought that she must be a fine woman.

title: Quake Aftershock Registered
description: Scientists detected another aftershock today from the earthquake that shook the Palm Springs area in July, officials said. The aftershock, reported at 9:22 A.M., measured 3.7 on the Richter scale and was centered about nine miles north of here, said a spokesman for the seismology laboratory of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: ISSUE OF RADON: NEW FOCUS ON ECOLOGY
description: As if there were not enough problems with conventional air and water pollution and toxic substances, all at once the nation has had to start worrying about radon. The Environmental Protection

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
CHRONOLOGY OF ALLEGATIONS
description: Following is a chronology of the events surrounding one set of allegations of corruption that were first reported to the city's Department of Investigation in 1982:

title: THE SENATE RACE, COUNTY BY COUNTY
Pennsylvania Agency Makes First Loans to Reduce Radon
description: The Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency has approved the first loans under a $3 million program to help homeowners reduce indoor levels of radon gas, an agency spokesman said today.

title: Fannie Mae Yield at 8.91%
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday sold $200 million of 7 1/2 percent fixed-rate mortgage-backed securities at an average price of 93 14/32, for a bond equivalent yield of 8.91 percent.

title: Tests on Slain Woman Said to Find No Drugs
description: Jennifer Dawn Levin, the 18-year-old who was killed in Central Park on Aug. 26 by a young man she knew, was not intoxicated or under the influence of drugs that night, according to law-enforcement sources.

title: Four-Part Oxford Acceptance Issue
description: The Oxford Acceptance Corporation is offering $200 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: CITY TRYING TO MOVE 200 MORE HOMELESS FAMILIES INTO HOTELS
description: City officials said yesterday that they may move at least 200 more homeless families into two hotels in a midtown Manhattan area that already has the highest concentration of homeless families in the city.

title: MAKING LUNCHES TASTY AND SAFE
description: The return of children to the classroom is accompanied by a little noted but large gastronomical undertaking - the production of millions of brown-bag lunches. Food experts urge parents to remember safety, as well as flavor and nutrition, when making these meals.

title: The Lightweight Team
description: Here's the list of players under 170 pounds now on N.F.L. rosters:

title: PRUDENTIAL'S CHANGE AT THE TOP
description: In a surprise announcement, Robert A. Beck, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said yesterday that he would resign early next year. Mr. Beck, who will be 61 years old next month, will be succeeded on Feb. 5 by Robert C. Winters, 54, one of the two vice chairmen of the company, the nation's largest insurance concern.

title: Burlington Industries Names Chief Executive
description: Frank S. Greenberg will become chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries, the nation's largest textile manufacturer. Mr. Greenberg, currently president of the company, will assume that position on Sept. 30, when William A. Klopman resigns.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago period's results are pro forma.

title: GIANT DEFENSE GETS BRUNT OF CRITICISM
description: For years, through good days and bad, the defense has usually carried the Giants.

title: Advertising; MRB Group Getting Winona Research
description: Winona Research of Phoenix and Minneapolis, a 17-year-old firm whose 1985 sales volume was about $14.4 million, is to be acquired by the MRB Group, the JWT Group subsidiary that includes the Simmons Market Research Bureau. The deal will be for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Her mother carried her for nine months, and I am honored to give her part of me.'' - Senator Jake Garn, who is donating a kidney to his daughter. [ A13:2. ]

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Zykanthos, Greece, in Science Times on Sept. 2 about damage to sea-turtle nesting areas gave an incorrect location for the Ionian Sea. It is between Greece and Italy.

title: Holiest Season in Islamic Calendar Passes
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Maid Answers A Charge of Smuggling
description: Nancy Reagan's personal maid and two other people pleaded not guilty today to charges they conspired to smuggle ammunition to Paraguay.

title: A B C'S OF WINE: APPELLATION TO ZINFANDEL
description: PEOPLE whose knowledge of wines goes no further than the difference between white and red have much to learn. This year wine schools in New York City are trying to fill that void with a variety of classes, from single sessions to intensive semester courses suitable for beginners. Instructors' styles range from serious to irreverent. Many use blind tastings.

title: Other Energy Sources Will Cure U.S. Oil Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: GUNMEN KIDNAP AMERICAN IN LEBANON
description: Gunmen kidnapped the American director of a Lebanese school in Moslem West Beirut today, and an anonymous Arab-speaking caller purporting to speak for the shadowy Islamic Holy War organization said it had seized him.

title: Putnam Is Suing Former Executives
description: The Putnam Companies, one of the largest mutual fund managers, has sued a group of former executives, contending they conspired to steal business.

title: ARMY IMPOSES FLIGHT RESTRICTIONS ON 2 COPTER MODELS AFTER FAILURES
description: The Army has concluded it does not have to ground two aging helicopter models that have had a rare pattern of engine failure, but it has imposed special flight restrictions on them.

title: Corn
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SCREEN: 'BEDROOM EYES'
description: ''BEDROOM EYES,'' the neatly titled, sexy little mystery that opens today at the U.A. Twin, comes close to making up - with a sense of humor - for its want of other kinds of sense. It is about a young, swinging stockbroker named Harry Ross, whose nightly jogging leads him to peer into a room where a beautiful woman is removing her clothing in a most provocative way. The object of the provocation is a male companion, but it is Harry who succumbs.

title: SUMMERS ON THE SHORE
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Like Anna Quindlen [ ''Life in the 30's,'' Aug. 27 ] , I too, often think of summers at the shore. Summers, which conjure up memories of a 10-year-old heading straight to the sands, impatient to watch the wildness of the waves, to feel and take in the smells of the soft salt spray.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Wine Competitions
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: One Voter's Missing Card
description: A disenfranchised gadfly was about the last thing the executive director of the Board of Elections needed yesterday. But she got him anyway.

title: House Votes Medal for Copland
description: The House voted today to award a Congressional Gold Medal to the composer Aaron Copland for his ''uniquely American'' contributions to music.

title: Iran Plans to Execute 3 for Car-Bomb Blast
description: Three men blamed for a car-bomb explosion in the Iranian holy city of Qum last month will be executed next week, Iran's top internal-security official said in remarks published today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: LORAINE RICKARD-MARTIN was delighted to return to work as a secretary at the United Nations when her son was 4 months old because she could leave the baby at an inexpensive day-care facility there, enabling her to visit and nurse him during the work day. But she had not bargained for the hidden cost of this arrangement. In the first two months, she said, her baby had two bouts with bronchitis and an ear infection, and she ''worried about possible long-term health effects from so many infections.''

title: Salads and Pickpockets
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BELAGA PICKED BY REPUBLICANS IN CONNECTICUT
description: State Representative Julie D. Belaga, a political moderate making her first run for statewide office in Connecticut, last night won a three-way Republican gubernatorial primary election.

title: Cuomo Urges the U.S. To Adhere to SALT II
description: Governor Cuomo called on Washington last night to continue to adhere to the second strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: THE K.G.B.'S EVIDENCE IN DEVELOPING A CASE OF ESPIONAGE AGAINST DANILOFF
description: Following are excerpts from an article on Nicholas S. Daniloff in the Government newspaper Izvestia on Monday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet Government press agency:

title: Cetus Sues Amgen
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., said that it had filed suit in Federal District Court here against Amgen, a biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: L.I. Crash Victim Identified
description: The authorities today identified the woman who was killed in an accident while riding in a car with an off-duty New York City police officer here early Monday.

title: INSITUFORM GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results were converted into dollars at the rates of $1.53 equals 1 pound and $1.30 equals 1 pound at June 30, 1986, and June 30, 1985, respectively.

title: RABIN, AT NEW YORK RITE, CALLS SYNAGOGUE RAIDERS ANIMALS
description: Speaking at a memorial service in New York for the 21 Jews slain by Arab gunman in Istanbul last week, Israel's Defense Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, appealed yesterday to ''everyone who believes in the basic values that distinguish a human being from an animal'' to band together to fight terrorism.

title: LET MORE COME HERE
description: It is 1965. An East German family has bribed a guard to let them over the wall. They approach it apprehensively, but, sure enough, the guard turns his back. Home free, they think. They scramble to the top of the wall. To freedom? Not on your life. American M.P.'s waiting on the other side turn them back. The next day, the United States proudly announces that it has stopped the traffic in human lives. From now on, all refugees will be turned back.

title: FILM: 'STATIC,' A SATIRE ON AMERICAN FOIBLES
description: FOR a film about spiritual emptiness in America, Mark Romanek's ''Static'' is itself dangerously vacant. Its good looks, which are exceptional, only exacerbate the feeling of slightness. The screenplay is by Mr. Romanek and Keith Gordon, who stars as a would-be inventor named Ernie, and the dialogue tends to be flippant and thin. The images, meanwhile, have a good deal more staying power. The film begins and ends with a beautiful, barren desert vista, and certain key scenes take place in a diner that is shaped like a fish.

title: Fudging the Fiscal New Year
description: Fiscal 1987 starts in three weeks; it will be as full of empty new year's resolutions as the other kind. Despite all the hoopla about a strict new order in Federal budgeting, Congress still has no plan to cut the 1987 deficit to the target level. It hasn't even appropriated any funds yet.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
POLITICIANS URGING UNIFIED DRUG PLAN
description: House and Senate leaders and President Reagan called for bipartisan cooperation against drugs today while all sides continued to maneuver for the political spotlight on what is becoming a major issue of the 1986 campaign.

title: KEY RATES
Advertising; Fallon, McElligott Gets Brooks Shoe
description: Brooks Shoe Manufacturing of Rockford, Mich., has beaten a path to the door of Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis, bringing the client list there to 26 accounts with total annual billings of some $85 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Western Union Corporation's financial restructuring gave an incorrect affiliation for Harry Rosenthal, a Wall Street analyst who was quoted. He is with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: RAFTING DOWNSTREAM, DINING UPSCALE
description: IT'S happy hour on the Salmon River near here in the heart of one of the country's largest expanses of wilderness region. The trumpeting of a conch shell brings a rag-tag group of 10 couples from their makeshift campsites at the mouth of Ground Hog Creek to congregate around a fresh guacamole dip and chilled California chardonnay.

title: Cancer Resolution Passed
description: The House of Representatives passed a resolution today denouncing employment discrimination against cancer survivors.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Nutrition Booklet

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL EXPOS VS. METS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, at Toronto, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) BRAVES VS. PADRES, at San Diego, 10:05 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 10:00P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont, 1 P.M. (Television - SportChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: Professor Sues M.I.T. Over Refusal of Tenure
description: A professor of history filed suit today against the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, charging that the school denied him tenure because of his assertions that M.I.T. was increasingly dominated by industries and the military.

title: CAIRO GUNMAN SEIZES 4, GIVES UP
description: A former mental patient demanding $10,000 held the Italian consul and three consular workers at gunpoint in their embassy for two hours today before surrendering to the police.

title: Jury Deadlocks Over Suspect In Alaska Slaying of 8 Boaters
description: The seven-month trial of John Peel, a deckhand accused of killing eight people aboard a fishing boat in 1982, has ended with a deadlocked jury, and Judge Thomas Schultz has rejected a defense request to acquit him.

title: 3 Drown Trying to Save Boy
description: Tonya Denise Banks, 14 years old, Tommie Banks, 12, and Roosevelt Gibson Jr., 3, jumped from a pier into a lake Monday and drowned trying to rescue their 5-month-old brother, LaBobby Gibson, who survived the accident, the authorities said. The father, Roosevelt Gibson Sr., of Ensley, Ala., was in the water trying to save the children when rescue workers arrived.

title: U.S. to Expand Team Of Food-Sniffing Dogs
description: An experimental team of dogs that sniff out food in the luggage of returning foreign travelers has worked out so well that the unit is being expanded into a permanent patrol at some of the nation's major international airports, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said today.

title: Rev. J. S. Grauel, 68, A Supporter of Israel
description: The Rev. John Stanley Grauel, a Methodist minister who was an activist for the Jewish people and Israel, died Friday at his home in Roosevelt, N.J. He was 68 years old. For several decades Mr. Grauel was a speaker on Israel and the Holocaust at fund-raising events and programs sponsored by the United Jewish Appeal and Bonds for Israel.

title: Silver Trader Gets Big Fine
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said yesterday that Naji Robert Nahas, a Brazilian investor, had agreed to pay a $250,000 fine to settle charges that he and a group of others, including Nelson Bunker Hunt, illegally manipulated silver prices during the speculative debacle of the late 1970's.

title: WHERE THE FARE SERVED IS FANTASY
description: EVEN though visitors from out of town may spend a lot of time seeking out somewhere nice to eat, not all restaurants need to be sought. Some are just there, part of a great collective unconscious. Such restaurants are called tourist restaurants. Mamma Leone's, for example, is a tourist restaurant. Anyone who can name even one New York restaurant can name You Know Whose.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Challenge to Election
description: A Federal appeals court, in a decision written by the Supreme Court nominee Antonin Scalia, today dismissed a challenge to Representative Frank M. McCloskey's seat as the winner of one of the century's closest House elections.

title: Equal Treatment for Soviet Lawyers and P.L.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The effect of the acquisition cost over the fair value of the assets of Cabletech resulted in a charge to earnings of $220,304 during the latest second quarter.

title: Extra Points
description: If it seems that once again an inordinately high number of points were scored on the National Football League's opening weekend, that's because there were, 655 of them.

title: TRANS LEASING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
5 SOUTH AFRICAN PLAYS IN LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL
description: ''Life in South Africa,'' began Mbongeni Ngema, a South African playwright, ''is very complicated.''

title: DESPITE LAW, FAKE ID CARDS APPEAR EASY TO GET
description: Five months after Governor Cuomo signed a law regulating the sale or production of identification cards, many fraudulent ones are still being sold at Manhattan novelty shops, with many used by under-aged liquor buyers, according to a random survey of the stores and interviews with customers.

title: LIFE IN HOUSTON: BENEFITS OF HARDSHIP
description: When Houston's oil industry first began to erode, the event seemed remote to many here. The major companies tightened their belts a bit and the banks shuddered, but life went on for most, albeit a bit more slowly. Even many a native Houstonian chortled to see some of the town's bigger braggarts and quick-buck artists fall.

title: Teen-agers Don't Belong in Bars
description: Would stricter enforcement against under-age drinking have saved the life of Jennifer Dawn Levin, the 18-year-old slain in New York's Central Park after leaving an East Side bar? Possibly. Is it really important to prevent under-age drinking in New York City, where youthful drunken driving is not a major problem? Yes it is. Is Mayor Koch overreacting when he promises a crackdown on under-age drinking in the city? Absolutely not.

title: 2 GROUPS CLAIM RESPONSIBILITY FOR CITY HALL BOMBING IN PARIS
description: Two groups claimed responsibility today for the bomb explosion at City Hall on Monday that killed a post office employee and wounded 18 people.

title: Chip Makers' Indicator Dips
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator dropped for the fourth consecutive month, a trade group reported today, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported a slight decrease in orders and a slight increase in billings during August. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Bridge: The Bridge World Is Selling Back Issues at Bargain Rate
description: Buying magazine back issues in Manhattan is a dubious activity on 42d Street but a rewarding one, for bridge enthusiasts, on 94th Street.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago share earnings amounts restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split completed March 31.

title: Setback for Liberals: An Eviction Lockout
description: The troubled Liberal Party has enountered a new problem: it has been evicted from its state headquarters at 1560 Broadway overlooking Times Square for what its landlord said was nonpayment of rent.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise
description: After declining for five consecutive days, by a total of about 5 3/4 points, prices of Treasury bonds rebounded yesterday with the help of buying by Japanese investors in Tokyo and speculative purchases in the domestic market.

title: ELECTRONIC LEGACY IN BOSTON
description: ''BOSTON, you're my home!'' the Standells sang affectionately in their mid-60's hit ''Dirty Water,'' and ever since, a steady succession of rock bands have been proud to call Boston home. At present, such groups as as the Lyres, the Neats and the Del Fuegos carry on the garage-band tradition, a legacy of such 60's proto-punks as the Standells. Boston also has one of the East Coast's liveliest hard-core-punk scenes, and wildly original guitar bands such as Christmas, Volcano Suns, the Proletariat and the Wild Stares.

title: PERSICO WANTS JURORS TOLD MAFIA IS NOT CRIMINAL UNIT
description: Carmine Persico, accused of heading the Colombo crime family, suggested yesterday that the judge tell prospective jurors in the ''commission'' trial that the Mafia is not a criminal organization.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jayne Young has been appointed vice president and advertising director of The Atlantic magazine.

title: Climbing To the Top At Bates
description: FOR some time it has been known by top executives of Ted Bates Worldwide that the key to the highest levels would be international experience.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $461,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: Support for McCallum
description: Now that Napoleon McCallum is a full-time ensign as well as a pro football player, what do former military-football men have to say about it? Last Sunday, McCallum gained more than 100 yards on eight kickoff and punt returns for the Los Angeles Raiders. The Navy is breaking a long-standing precedent by allowing McCallum, who graduated from the Naval Academy earlier this year, to play professionally while completing his five-year active-duty obligation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: LIKE most meals in my home, a recent lunch for four was a matter of improvisation. The previous day I had prepared zucchini boats filled with chopped mushrooms and the flesh from the hollowed-out shells.

title: REAGAN STARS AT A RALLY FOR COLORADO CANDIDATE
description: ''I think of what it will mean to my grandchildren to see me photographed with the President of the United States,'' Jim Nicholson, a local land developer, said after he and his wife, Suzanne, emerged from behind blue curtains in a private area in an airline hangar here.

title: Advertising; A Top Executive Joins Revlon Beauty Group
description: Revlon is bringing in Arthur I. Cohen to be executive vice president, advertising, of the Revlon Beauty Group, to replace Sanford Buchsbaum, who left to become an agency biggie by forming Stevens & Buchsbaum.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WINE TALK
description: THE blush wine season is almost over. White wine we always have with us. So for anyone seriously interested in wine, it's time to think of some good, moderately priced reds to drink over the next few months. By moderately priced, I mean $10 or under.

title: The Uses Of Parchment
description: PARCHMENT paper is a handy item to have in your kitchen, for it has myriad uses such as wrapping, baking ''en papillote,'' lining cake pans and making paper cones for decorating sauces and pastries. This last application is particularly valuable if you want to add a last-minute finishing touch to a dish and don't have a professional pastry bag on hand.

title: College Coaches Find Peace In N.B.A.
description: After 27 years of college coaching, 19 as head coach at Transylvania, North Carolina-Charlotte, Purdue and South Florida, Lee Rose has left the college ranks to work as an assistant coach in the National Basketball Association. Rose's departure is part of a growing trend over the last several years in the shift from college to the pro ranks.

title: 'DRUG KNOT,' A CBS DRAMA WITH DAVID TOMA
description: THE man stands in a high-school gymnasium, a thatch of jet-black hair framing his heavily lined face, his pinky-ringed hand raised in the manner of a revival-tent preacher. He is mesmerizing an audience of parents and students as he rails against the evils of drugs and alcohol. He is David Toma, a former vice-squad detective from Newark (his exploits there were dramatized in the television series ''Toma'' and ''Baretta'') and now an antidrug crusader on the lecture circuit. ''The Drug Knot,'' on CBS at 8 o'clock tonight, is a fictionalized example of the situations Mr. Toma has found in his tours around the country.

title: ABZUG LEADING TEICHER
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, who two months ago lost a special election to represent the Sixth Congressional District in Queens, last night won the Democratic party's nomination for that seat by about 3,000 votes, defeating Alton R. Waldon Jr., who has represented the District in Washington for six weeks.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT THE CUBANS;
GO BEYOND EMBARGO
description: The real news about United States-Cuban relations these days is not the Administration's announcement that it will tighten the 26-year-old trade embargo against Cuba, but how little the Administration is willing to do in the face of Fidel Castro's provocation.

title: CAREY SUPPORTS BAN BY CHURCH AGAINST DISSENT
description: Saying ''this is not a time to separate from the church,'' former Gov. Hugh L. Carey yesterday expressed support for a directive by the Roman Catholic archdiocese of New York that prohibits those who disagree with church teaching from speaking at parish-supported events.

title: Weinberger Cites Hints On Group in Hijacking
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that there were indications that the radical Palestinian faction led by Abu Nidal was involved in the hijacking in Pakistan last week. But he said there was no proof of such a role.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MY favorite news story so far this year was the one saying that in England scientists are working on a way to allow men to have babies. I'd buy tickets to that. I'd be happy to stand next to any man I know in one of those labor rooms the size of a Volkswagen trunk and whisper ''No, dear, you don't really need the Demerol; just relax and do your second-stage breathing.'' It puts me in mind of an old angry feminist slogan: ''If men got pregnant, abortion would be a sacrament.'' I think this is specious. If men got pregnant, there would be safe, reliable methods of birth control. They'd be inexpensive, too.

title: Give Us More Talk
description: Ladies and gentlemen, the famous radio talk-show authority known as ''Lipp of the Airwaves, King of the Ether and Other Gases'' is here to answer your questions about the Daniloff affair.

title: New York City and State Should Eliminate Their Sales Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILEAN EDITOR AND TWO OTHERS ARE FOUND SLAIN
description: An editor of an opposition magazine banned under Chile's state of siege was found shot to death, the authorities said today. The editor's family said he had been taken from his home Sunday night by armed men in civilian clothes.

title: Suriname Troops Open A Drive Against Rebels
description: The Suriname Army announced today that it had opened an offensive against a guerrilla group seeking to overthrow the Government.

title: Trouble on Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Raid Reported In Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli planes attacked Palestinian bases on the outskirts of the southern port of Sidon at dawn today, the police said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers signed Chuck Sanders, a running back released recently by the San Diego Chargers. The Kansas City Chiefs signed Paul Coffman, a tight end cut by the Green Bay Packers before the season. . . . The St. Louis Blues signed Doug Gilmour, the center who was the leading scorer in the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, to a multiyear contract. . . . Maricica Puica, the Olympic 3,000-meter gold medalist from Rumania, will run in the Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue Saturday, according to the race's sponsors. . . . A mistake over registration deadlines will keep Nancy Lopez from playing in this week's Safeco Classic at the Meridian Valley Country Club in Kent. Wash. . . . Ken O'Brien, the Jets' quarterback, and Billy Ray Smith, the San Diego Chargers' linebacker, were named the National Football League's offensive and defensive players of the week, respectively.

title: BONN MAY REDUCE RATES, OFFICIALS SAY
description: West Germany's central bank may lower interest rates soon, possibly before the regular meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington later this month, according to senior West German banking and Government officials.

title: To Overcome Street Smarts About Crack
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubleday Talks Cited
description: There were reports yesterday of talks between Bertelsmann A.G., the West German publishing company, and Doubleday & Company about an acquisition of Doubleday's publishing operations, which include the Literary Guild book club.

title: INTERIOR SOLICITOR REFUSES TO APPEAR BEFORE PANEL
description: The Interior Department's top lawyer will not appear voluntarily to testify before a House subcommittee whose Democratic majority has been highly critical of what it called the ''miserable failure'' of the department's national strip-mine reclamation program.

title: NAIPAUL GETS ELIOT AWARD
description: V. S. Naipaul, the Trinidad-born novelist, has been named winner of the 1986 T. S. Eliot Award for creative writing. Andrew Lytle, former editor of the Sewanee Review, has been named winner of the Richard M. Weaver Award for scholarly letters.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-Includes gains on the sales of securities of 22 cents a share for the quarter and 28 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes gains on the sales of securities of 2 cents a share for the quarter and 12 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Signed a two-year working agreement with Toledo of the International League. Named Leon Roberts manager of Toledo.

title: A High School Soccer Player Is Shot During Team Practice
description: A Lancaster Senior High School soccer player was shot, apparently by a stray bullet, while at team practice behind the school, the police said today.

title: 3,200 TAXICABS FACE LOSS OF INSURANCE, OFFICIALS SAY
description: About one-quarter of the city's taxicabs could lose their insurance because the only company willing to insure them is in danger of financial collapse, state examiners said yesterday.

title: Ferraro and Santucci Talk About Zaccaro
description: Geraldine Ferraro, the former Vice Presidential candidate, met with the Queens District Attorney, John Santucci, and several of his aides within the last 10 days to talk about an investigation into bribery allegations against her husband, John A. Zaccaro, according to sources familiar with the matter.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE other evening, our friend the former frequent filmgoer went to his first movie in many moons - many more than he had realized.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CITY OPERA: REVIVAL OF GOUNOD'S 'FAUST
description: THE return to the repertory last evening of the New York City Opera's production of ''Faust'' should have been cause for good cheer. Reviled though the work generally is by those who know their Goethe in other form but Gounod's opera, ''Faust'' has never lost its hold on the audience's affection. Once heard, its melodies lodge themselves firmly in memory and can rattle around in one's head for hours after almost any performance. There are higher standards for operatic genius, but that is a fair one, for a start.

title: Gifford-Hill Accepts Offer
description: Gifford-Hill & Company, one of the nation's largest producers of cement and other construction materials, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by C. H. Beazer Holdings P.L.C. for $275 million, or $32 a share.

title: NEW JET LINE TO FACE PATRIOTS
description: When last seen against the New England Patriots, Ken O'Brien saw little. He was knocked unconscious and out of the game with a concussion on a sack by the redoubtable Andre Tippett.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
JOAN SUTHERLAND CANCELS CONCERT AT THE GARDEN
description: Dame Joan Sutherland, who was to appear with Luciano Pavarotti in a special ''anniversary concert'' next Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, has canceled the appearance on the advice of her doctor. Mr. Pavarotti plans to go ahead with the concert on his own, with some assistance from the young soprano Madelyn Renee.

title: Gerald Geddes Weds Annette Longnon
description: Annette Louise Longnon, a managing director of J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc., and Gerald Kip Geddes, a private investor in New York, were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Charles Amstein. The bride, who uses the original French spelling of her family name, is the daughter of the late Louis Lonyo 3d of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late Jane Edwards of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mr. Geddes is a son of the late Gerald Maxwell Geddes and the late Elizabeth Kip Geddes of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Mail Sorting in Queens Will Be Consolidated
description: The Postal Service announced yesterday that it would consolidate nine Queens offices into a station to be built on 36.8 acres in Maspeth along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, just north of the Kosciuszko Bridge.

title: PRESIDENT'S AIDE BAR RANGEL FROM SESSION ON DRUG POLICY
description: White House officials today rejected repeated attempts by Representative Charles B. Rangel to gain entry to a meeting on drug policy that President Reagan held with Congressional leaders.

title: NOUVELLE TOUCH TO 300-YEAR-OLD RECIPES
description: Right from the start, it wasn't easy for the Yates Street restaurant here when, as part of the city's tricentennial celebration, its owners decided to re-create a menu from 300 years ago. After all, what did people eat back then? Where do you get the recipes? How do you translate such measurements as ''poringerfull''? Besides which, does anybody really want to eat dishes from the 1600's?

title: Quarterback Penalized
description: Rickey Foggie, the quarterback who has twice been selected as the most valuable player on the University of Minnesota's football team, was declared ineligible by the school because the athletic department purchased an airline ticket for him, according to Dr. Robert Stein, chairman of the athletic board. Stein said that a second player, Don Pollard, a reserve linebacker, was declared ineligible for the same reason.

title: POLICE SAY USE OF CRACK IS MOVING TO SMALL TOWNS AND RURAL AREAS
description: To the alarm of local police agencies, crack, a highly addictive and inexpensive form of cocaine, is turning up with increasing frequency in small towns, from the rural South to the outlying areas of New York and Los Angeles.

title: ASTRADYNE COMPUTER INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $63,400, or 4 cents a share.

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $629,000 for the quarter and $658,000 for the year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $175,000 and $535,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and year results include net charges of $535,000 for estimated losses on the disposal of discontinued operations. The company said about $3,266,000, or $1.01 a share, of income for the latest year is attributable to the receipt of life insurance proceeds on Paul A. Johnston, who died Sept. 18, 1985, net of provision for retirement and related settlements. He was formerly chairman and chief executive of the company's textile subsidiary, Johnston Group Inc. Corrected from Wednesday, Sept. 3, editions.

title: JAPANESE AGREE TO 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH
description: Japan gave its long-awaited approval today to the Reagan Administration's space-based antimissile program, paving the way for possible involvement by Japanese industry and Government research agencies.

title: COMPAQ INTRODUCES MORE POWERFUL PC
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston yesterday introduced a new personal computer that the company says has the power and the quickness of a small miniframe computer, but costs many thousands of dollars less and is compatible with most forms of software.

title: BankAmerica in Talks
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had begun talks with Citicorp and others about selling parts of BankAmerica S.A., its 60-branch operation in Argentina. BankAmerica acquired it for $150 million in 1981.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The U.N. Today: Sept. 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.

title: Industries' Contributions
description: Ever since 1970, Environmental Action, a free-swinging political lobby, has identified a ''dirty dozen'' in each Congressional election campaign, saying the designated of candidates should be defeated because they tolerate pollution.

title: Three Killed in Crash of Plane Of Tennessee National Guard
description: A Tennessee Air National Guard C-130 Hercules transport plane crashed and burned today while making a practice landing here, killing three crew members and injuring two.

title: KETCHUP CLUE CRACKS CASE
description: A Queens man's yen for ketchup on his meatballs could cost him seven years in prison.

title: How Carolina Democrats Make 6 Votes Add Up
description: In the House of Representatives, the six Democrats from North Carolina make up one of the smaller delegations. But in the realm of impact, these quiet legislators carry a big stick that they have used successfully to defend the issue most important to them: tobacco.

title: ERIC ROHMER, FILM POET WITH AN EYE ON THE BUDGET
description: The definition of solitude is Paris in August. The city is empty, its streets eerily tranquil. The French plot and plan all year their summer exodus to the Cote d'Azur, to Brittany, to the Alps. It is hard to find a Parisian in town; the few who are left seem stranded.

title: TOWER PROPOSAL FOR WEST SIDE ROILS NEIGHBORS
description: The owner of a five-story, 94-year-old brick town house on West End Avenue at 85th Street has proposed building a 10-story glass-and-steel apartment building above the existing structure, and neighbors, preservationists and local elected officials are trying to block the plan.

title: JAPANESE ECONOMY IN REBOUND
description: Japan's economy bounced back in the nation's latest fiscal quarter, but even Government economists expressed doubt that the turnaround would be enough for Japan to overcome problems caused by the strong yen and achieve its 1986-87 growth forecast.

title: TRYING TO COLLECT IN HARD TIMES
description: For most of its 51 years, the Farmers Home Administration has existed deep in the bowels of the Agriculture Department's enormous building near the Washington Monument, quietly lending farmers down on their luck just enough to stay in business. In county offices around the country, the agency's supervisors saw as their primary mission preservation of the small American family farm, even if some loans went bad and some others were paid off too slowly.

title: Leaders of Union Pledge To Clean Up Its Cafeteria
description: On its current ''dirty restaurant'' list, the Health Department has cited the cafeteria operated by Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union in its headquarters at 310 West 43d Street.

title: FUNDS AND JOBS ARE PLEDGED TO BOSTON STUDENTS
description: Leading Boston businesses have organized a $6 million program that will guarantee financial aid to all graduates of the city's public high schools who get into college and then provide jobs for them when they finish their education.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the 1985 results have been restated to reflect the change to a Jan. 31 fiscal year-end closing, which went into effect this year. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split issued Jan. 6.

title: Rev. Richard Morford; Led U.S.-Soviet Group
description: The Rev. Richard Morford, retired executive director of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, died of pnuemonia Sunday while visiting his daughter in Madison, Wis. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Countersuit Against Perot
description: The developer William T. Criswell denied accusations of fraud made last week by H. Ross Perot, the wealthy businessman and chairman of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.

title: WARMTH, WHIMSY FOR FALL
description: 1. Big Sweaters Big sweaters will be popular for casual weekend outfits this fall. Indesign's Jacquard-weave Kandinsky pullover, made of soft British acrylic, is a bold blend of black, gray and white.

title: KEAN TRIES TO MEASURE HIS APPEAL
description: When Governor Kean travels to Cleveland on Oct. 16 to address a business organization, one of his closest political advisers will, for the first time, take an informal survey of the reaction out of state to the New Jersey Governor.

title: U.S. Expects Limited Help
description: Japanese participation in the research on an American anti-missile program may offer the Pentagon access to a host of technologies in leading-edge computer designs, semiconductors and artificial intelligence programming software that could speed the development of a space-based defense against nuclear attack, experts said yesterday.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FREY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 GROUPS SEE AUTO SAFETY EFFORTS AS WANING AFTER 20 YEARS OF GAIN
description: Two groups that seek to promote highway safety said today that tough Federal regulations had played a crucial role in reducing highway deaths and injuries over the last 20 years. Both also accused the Reagan Administration of slowing the pace of safety regulation and being overly influenced by the automobile industry.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $668,000 for the quarter and year which reflects a writeoff of insurance deposits by a subsidiary, the Washington Savings Bank, in connection with the May 1985 Maryland Savings and Loan crisis.

title: JAPAN'S EDUCATION CHIEF GETS LESSON IN DIPLOMACY
description: For nearly two months, Education Minister Masayuki Fujio unnerved his Government with a stacatto flow of comments considered insulting by South Koreans and Chinese.

title: OFFICER IN QUEENS USES GUN IN SUICIDE
description: A city police officer fatally shot himself early yesterday at his station house in Queens, officials said.

title: DELTA AND WESTERN AIRLINE MERGER AGREED TO IN A $860 MILLION DEAL
description: Delta Air Lines and Western Air Lines said yesterday that they would merge in an $860 million deal that would open major new markets in the West to the Atlanta-based Delta.

title: OCEANIC GROUP WITHDRAWS FROM SEAL RESCUE
description: Trying to rescue of dozens of seals and porpoises trapped by an Alaska glacier would be expensive, dangerous and futile, the Cousteau Society said Monday in announcing its withdrawal from the project.

title: AMERICARE HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Don't Make a Galileo Of Every Dissenter
description: To the Editor:

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $120,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $574,000.

title: New Chairman Named At Putnam Publishing
description: Peter Israel has been named chairman of the Putnam Publishing Group, of which he has been president for the last seven years. Phyllis Grann was named to succeed Mr. Israel as president. Mrs. Grann was formerly president of G. P. Putnam's Sons, a division of the group.

title: YOUNG MOTHERS SAID TO BE ON WELFARE LONGER
description: A new study says that young mothers stay on welfare rolls much longer than many people had thought.

title: MARK GREEN BEATS DYSON IN PRIMARY
description: Mark Green, the consumer advocate and frequent Congressional critic, defeated John S. Dyson for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate yesterday in the New York primary.

title: Popular Speaker
description: Few Washington rivalries are as keen as the one between the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers, competing both for dues-paying members and the attention of Congress and the White House. Longtime observers of this competition were interested to discover this week that the National Association of Manufacturers had listed the Administration's trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, as ''invited'' to speak at the first of its breakfast briefing series this morning but that Ambassador Yeutter had not accepted and was actually going to breakfast at that same time with the Chamber of Commerce.

title: GREAT BRAND NAMES IN CALIFORNIA WINES
description: AMERICA is entering a ''new stage'' in premium wines, in the opinion of 84-year-old Andre Tchelistcheff, who for nearly half a century has been celebrated as one of the nation's pre-eminent wine makers.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: All share earnings recognize the 5-for-4 stock split paid on Aug. 15.

title: New Soviet Bid on GATT
description: In an effort to bolster the Soviet Union's bid to join the multinational trade talks in Uruguay next week, a senior Soviet trade official pledged today that Moscow would adhere to rules of the 92-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: A Bank Loss Seen in Texas
description: Allied Bancshares Inc. of Houston said today that it expected to take a $110 million provision for possible loan losses in the third quarter. The bank holding company said the allowance would probably result in a $40 million operating loss for the quarter.

title: GARN TO GIVE KIDNEY TO DIABETIC DAUGHTER, 27
description: Senator Jake Garn of Utah entered Georgetown University Hospital today to donate a kidney to his 27-year-old daughter. The surgery will take place Wednesday.

title: Altman's Chief Guilty on Taxes
description: Anthony R. Conti, chairman and chief executive of B. Altman & Company, has pleaded guilty and will be sentenced Oct. 14 on charges of filing his 1982 Federal income tax return late. He faces a maximum of one year in prison and a $25,000 fine.

title: U.S. DELAYS MOVES IN DANILOFF CASE
description: State Department officials said today that in order to allow high-level diplomatic efforts to continue, the United States held off on taking measures against the Soviet Union for the detention of an American correspondent.

title: Advertising; Grey to Acquire Gross Townsend
description: Gross Townsend Frank Hoffman, an eight-year-old health-care advertising agency with $33 million in billings, is to be acquired by Grey Advertising, but will remain autonomous both from the parent company and Grey's subsidiary, Grey Medical.

title: Time for Change
description: If the big-time colleges ever do opt to de-emphasize athletics, those giving greatest thanks may well turn out to be the coaches. A recent survey undertaken by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution received responses from 205 Division I football and basketball coaches across the country, 62 percent of whom said they worked more than 80 hours a week during the season. Forty-six percent said they thought the demands would eventually drive them out of the profession, and 38 percent said they would not recommend the job to their children.

title: General Pinochet Declares 'War'
description: Chile is ''in a war,'' Gen. Augusto Pinochet declared after he survived an assassination attempt Sunday night. Who is the enemy? In his view, it is the vast majority of the Chilean people.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
