description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: MARYLAND VOTERS CHOOSE 2 WOMEN
description: Maryland voters set up the nation's only United States Senate race between women today, nominating Representative Barbara A. Mikulski, a Democrat, and Linda Chavez, a Republican.

title: CREDIT RISE LESS IN JULY
description: Americans took out $5.38 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in July, the smallest increase since April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Politics and the Alliance
description: During every American Presidential election since the last world war, Europe has asked the same nervous question: What will happen to the Alliance after Roosevelt, after Truman, after Eisenhower and so on. Now it asks: will it hold together after Reagan?

title: CORETTA KING CANCELS BOTHA TALK AFTER PRESSURE BY APARTHEID FOES
description: Coretta Scott King canceled a meeting today with the President of South Africa.

title: Charges at Kerr-McGee
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said it anticipates special non-cash charges of about $265 million after taxes in the third quarter of 1986. Frank A. McPherson, the company chairman, said the special charges would reduce stockholders' equity to $1.4 billion, from $1.7 billion.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 9
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $750,000 and $1,660,000 for the 12 weeks and 28 weeks, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $220,000 for the 12 weeks and $530,000 for the 28 weeks. The company said income before federal income taxes and extraordinary tax credit includes a LIFO inventory charge of $225,000 in 1986, and $345,000 in 1985 for the 12-week periods, and $525,000 in 1986, and $805,000 in 1985 for the 28-week periods.

title: WALKER HELPS TO BAIT A TRAP FOR GIANTS
description: If ever a play was obvious, this was it.

title: Chrysler Projects
description: The Chrysler Corporation will spend about $1.8 billion to renovate its Jefferson Avenue plant in Detroit and build a high-technology center in Oakland County in southeastern Michigan, Gov. James Blanchard said. The agreement, announced after Chrysler officials met with representatives of local governments and state and legislative leaders, will mean a state investment of about $150 million during the next five to six years, Governor Blanchard said.

title: MOSCOW BUILDS CASE AGAINST DANILOFF
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff, the indicted American correspondent, said today that he believed the Soviet authorities were trying to assemble an espionage case against him dating back five years.

title: Moses Sits Out Final in Rome
description: Edwin Moses won't compete in the Grand Prix track and field championship finals in Rome today, partly, he says, because he doesn't want to taint his record of supremacy and partly because he doesn't want to be party to an illicit financial arrangement that he says could have netted him $50,000.

title: EXPOS TOP METS WITH 19 HITS
description: Although the Mets allowed 19 hits, the most this season, and their relief pitching was ineffective, they want to assure their followers there is no need for alarm.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WALLACE STEVENS: The Early Years, 1879-1923. By Joan Richardson. Illustrated. 591 pages. Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow. $21.95. To readers of his shimmering, musical verse, Wallace Stevens appeared in a variety of antic disguises - he was Peter Quince or Crispin the Comedian or the Man with a Blue Guitar. To his fiancee, Elsie Moll, he was Pierrot or Tom Folio or her favorite jongleur - wearing ''cap and bells'' as he tossed epiphanies about brightly in the empty air. Yet the poet saw himself simply as ''a most inappropriate man/In a most unpropitious place'' - a ''thinking stone'' who garbed his insecurities in a luminous cloak of words.

title: MORE ANALYSIS WOULDN'T HURT
description: The seasons change. Leaves, people, even countries, come and go. But ''Monday Night Football'' rolls on.

title: INSIDE
description: Japan Backs 'Star Wars' Japan gave its long-awaited approval to Washington's space-based missile defense program, known as ''Star Wars.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1986
description: Companies

title: 14 Charged In Fraud Case
description: Fourteen people, including a stock promoter and three New Jersey stockbrokers, were charged today with conspiring to mislead consumers into investing in a bogus, publicly traded company that said it had created a self-chilling beverage can.

title: KARPOV RESIGNS 14TH GAME BEFORE PLAY RESUMES
description: Anatoly Karpov resigned the 14th game of the world championship chess match in Leningrad yesterday without resuming play, ceding a two-point lead to the 23-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov.

title: Advertising; Denaka Danish Vodka Plans $40 Million Drive
description: Whitbread, maker of Denaka Danish Vodka, will be introducing the brand to the United States with a $40 million five-year campaign beginning Monday in Chicago and Tampa-St.

title: U.N. Official Stripped Of Kenyan Citizenship
description: A United Nations relief official has been stripped of his Kenyan citizenship after the Government accused him of dissident activity, according to a report in The Kenya Gazette, published by the Government.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Red Raider Is Blue-Chipper
description: Kenny Gamble gained 300 yards for Colgate last Saturday, 225 by rushing, 60 returning kickoffs and 15 as a pass receiver. It was an impressive beginning for a football season, although not much was made of Gamble's performance at Colgate for a couple of reasons.

title: Charity's Loans to Aides Were 'Errors,' Panel Says
description: Loans that were made from charitable contributions to key executives of the United Way chapter here were ''errors in judgment'' but did not involve fraud or criminal activity, an independent panel says.

title: Tax Evasion in China
description: China's top court has sentenced 14 people to death for corruption, fraud and tax evasion and prosecuted 120 government officials, including some in high positions, The China Daily said today.

title: HAWKINS CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
100 Are Feared Dead In Nigeria Ship Collision
description: Two passenger ships have collided in the South Atlantic off the coast of Nigeria, and about 100 people are feared killed, a Government statement said today.

title: Nicaragua Asserts U.S. Maligns It on Terrorism
description: The Nicaraguan Government tonight rejected what it said were American attempts to link it to terrorism.

title: Allegheny Payout
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it was suspending quarterly dividend payments on preferred stock, a move that will save about $7 million. The heavily indebted consumer products and industrial specialty company had already suspended common stock dividends for the first and second quarters.

title: Retail Sales Spurt in City
description: Five of the metropolitan area's largest retailers registered average sales increases of 13.2 percent in New York City in August, compared with the period a year earlier. Their sales in the region rose by an average of 7.1 percent, a monthly spot-check found.

title: CONSOLIDATED HYDRO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began operations July 1, 1985.

title: TRADING SLOWS
description: With trading volume lightening, stock prices declined yesterday for the third consecutive session as investors continued to take profits in shares that went up substantially when Wall Street was worrying about a weak economy.

title: WITH KNIFE AND FORK, TOURISTS SEEK THE REAL NEW YORK
description: YOU can spot them immediately on the bustling streets of Manhattan, wearing sports clothes, ''sensible'' walking shoes and expressions of bewilderment. They are out-of-town tourists, visiting perhaps for the first time, in search of that gastronomic grail known as the ''cute little restaurant off the beaten track with cheerful owners, prompt service and delicious inexpensive meals.'' In New York City, one of the dining capitals of the world - there are more than 15,000 licensed restaurants of all nationalities in the five boroughs - one might suppose that finding a suitable place to eat would be a relatively easy task.

title: Indifference to Victories
description: Ivan Lendl and Martina Navratilova have received no lavish praise in Czechoslovak newspapers after winning the singles titles at the United States Open Tennis Championships last weekend. Lendl is a citizen of Czechoslovakia, who also has a home in Greenwich, Conn. Ms. Navratilova, who was born in Czechoslovakia, has become an American citizen.

title: DONOVAN TRIAL ENDS FIRST DAY OF PICKING JURY
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the larceny and fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, and the presiding judge said the trial could take three months.

title: College President Takes A Seat in the Classroom
description: In addition to being president of Hunter College and teaching a graduate course, Dr. Donna E. Shalala is now a student.

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes inventory adjustment of $570,000, or 10 cents a share. c-Net income

title: G.E. TO SELL ITS HOLDING IN RCA/ARIOLA RECORDS
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would sell its 75 percent stake in the RCA Corporation's RCA/Ariola record unit to Bertelsmann A.G., the West German concern that already owns the other 25 percent. The terms were not disclosed, but industry sources have valued General Electric's stake at $300 million.

title: RED SOX WIN 10TH IN ROW, 7-5
description: Dwight Evans hit two homers, and Marty Barrett's two-run double capped a three-run rally in the seventh inning tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7-5, extending their winning streak to 10 games.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
COSTA RICA GETS TOUGHER ON CONTRAS
description: President Oscar Arias says that despite the likelihood of increased fighting between the Nicaraguan Government and United States-backed rebels in the region he is determined to prevent this country from being used as a base for foreign military operations.

title: FEDERAL AUDIT FAULTS SOCIAL SECURITY PHONE SERVICE
description: People calling the Social Security Administration for help get busy signals, are disconnected or wait on hold for long periods more than a quarter of the time, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: CORRUPTION STUDY ASSAILS INQUIRIES INTO ALLEGATIONS
description: The City Department of Investigation received allegations of corruption and conflict of interest at the Parking Violations Bureau from three sources in 1982 and 1983, but repeatedly botched the investigations, a report to Mayor Koch concluded yesterday.

title: Taxable Bonds Offered By 2 Public Authorities
description: Attention in the corporate and municipal markets was focused yesterday on sales of taxable bonds by public authorities in Memphis and Chicago. Officials in both cities eschewed normal financings in the tax-exempt market, partly to avoid provisions in the Federal tax legislation now before Congress.

title: ROLE OF PARENT IS EMPHASIZED AS BABY SAFETY WEEK BEGINS
description: Federal regulators, industry officials and medical experts opened National Baby Safety Week today by stressing that the ultimate responsibility rested with parents.

title: Funds' Focus: Bankruptcies
description: THE stock market's plunge in July unnerved many money managers. But it spelled opportunity to Max L. Heine, founder and president of the Mutual Shares Corporation. ''We liked the type of merchandise that became available,'' he recalled in an interview.

title: AGE OF TERROR UNDERMINING TURKISH JEWS
description: To many Jews in Turkey, the synagogue massacre last weekend, which took the lives of 21 worshipers, represents more than a singular act of horror. It is widely seen as signaling the possible end of a long era of security.

title: SPANISH-LANGUAGE TV UNDERGOING GROWTH SPUR
description: With snappier computer graphics, more engaging plots in soap operas and colorfully flamboyant musicals and variety shows, Spanish-language television in the United States has begun to grow dramatically, advertisers and media analysts say.

title: Grand Central Area Gains
description: UNTIL recently the bustling neighborhood surrounding Grand Central Terminal, dominated by the Pan Am and Chrysler buildings and the Grand Hyatt Hotel, had not garnered the same attention from builders and prospective tenants as other business districts.

title: FINDING FLAWS: REPORT ON CORRUPTION INDICATES KOCH SHOULD HAVE KNOWN
description: From the start of the corruption scandal that has plagued his administration since January, Mayor Koch has sought to define its importance, or what he has suggested is its limited importance, in narrow terms.

title: JURY IN NEW YORK INDICTS A RUSSIAN OF SPYING COUNTS
description: A Soviet employee of the United Nations was indicted for espionage yesterday in a case that has become intertwined with the Kremlin's detention of an American journalist in Moscow.

title: Sponsored Free-for-All
description: ''The McLaughlin Group,''

title: White House Aide Leaving
description: Karna Small is leaving her White House post as deputy assistant to the President for National Security Council public affairs. Miss Small, a former broadcast journalist, has a farewell appointment with President Reagan on Thursday.

title: Vote Hits Snags At Western Union
description: A plan that would greatly alter the financial structure of the Western Union Corporation was dealt a blow yesterday when the holders of one group of preferred stock rejected the proposal and two other groups failed to get the quorum necessary to hold the vote.

title: Underground's Hidden Income
description: THE state of the American economy, with the stock and bond markets swinging back and forth in the last few weeks, has been baffling policy makers and investors. Is it on the verge of recession or is it gaining strength again? Are consumers so deeply in debt that they are bound to cut back their borrowing or spending or are a great many of them really loaded with more cash savings and other financial assets than the national-income accounts disclose?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1986
description: International A panel indicted a Soviet employee of the United Nations for espionage in a case that has become intwined with the Kremlin's detention of an American journalist in Moscow. The Soviet suspect, Gennadi F. Zakharov, was accused of three counts of spying by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn. Government officials say Mr. Zakharov was about to give $1,000 to an employee of an American military concern in exchange for three classified documents. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: The U.S.F.L. Factor
description: In the long season leading to Super Bowl XXI, the difference between making and missing the playoffs for many teams will be the U.S.F.L. Factor, the influence of players from the league that an antitrust jury put out in the cold, as the Giants and the Jets have already discovered.

title: SOVIET BARS VISA IN LEUKEMIA CASE
description: The Soviet visa agency has told a woman who wants to go to Israel to donate blood marrow to a brother dying of leukemia that she may go - but without her husband.

title: Policeman Is Held In Drug Purchase
description: An off-duty police officer who has been on sick leave for several months was arrested yesterday afternoon after he was observed buying a small quantity of heroin from a street dealer, the police said.

title: GOING LIKE 60 -ER, 100
description: By rushing for 102 yards Sunday against Denver, Marcus Allen set an N.F.L. record for most consecutive regular-season games of at least 100 yards on the ground. The longest such streaks in league history: Marcus Allen, L.A. Raiders, 1985-8610 Walter Payton, Chicago, 19859 O. J. Simpson, Buffalo, 1972-737 Earl Campbell, Houston, 19797 Jim Brown, Cleveland, 19586 Franco Harris, Pittsburgh, 19726 Earl Campbell, Houston, 19806 Walter Payton, Chicago, 19846 Eric Dickerson, L.A. Rams, 19846 James Wilder, Tampa Bay, 1984-856

title: A CITY TELLS BUILDERS: LET THE SUNSHINE IN
description: In a city covered by clouds three of every five days, owners of new homes are being guaranteed access to what sunshine there is.

title: G.M. British Unit
description: Bedford Commercial Vehicles, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said it was phasing out production of commercial trucks and bus undercarriages and eliminating 1,450 jobs by next year.

title: Federal Lawyer Agrees To Testify on Mining
description: Faced with a House subcommittee chairman's threat to subpoena his testimony on strip mining, the Interior Department's chief lawyer will appear voluntarily, the department said today.

title: German Talks On Doubleday
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the big German publishing company, is holding talks about acquiring the publishing operations of Doubleday & Company, industry sources here said today.

title: Stocks Post 4th Consecutive Loss
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday, giving the market its fourth straight loss as investors continued to sell issues that have risen sharply in the last few months.

title: THE FIGHT FOR OBJECTIVITY IN NEW CHINESE BRITANNICA
description: The Encyclopaedia Britannica said today that its new Chinese version preserved the reference work's objectivity despite disputes over Stalin, Taiwan and the Korean War.

title: STUDIES LINK TEEN-AGE SUICIDES, TV
description: TELEVISION news coverage of suicides and television dramas about the topic appear to cause a temporary increase in the number of teen-agers who take their own lives, according to two new studies.

title: Concrete for Wollman Rink
description: Yesterday there was a brief ceremonial pouring of concrete. But today, the concrete will be poured and poured and poured, as if to bury forever the ill-fated history of the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park.

title: CREATIVE IDEAS FOR TINY SPACES: REDESIGNING THE SMALL BATHROOM
description: FOR the owner of the small bathroom - that irksome five-by-seven-foot space devoured by tub, sink and toilet - mornings can be mean. Ordinarily serene couples wrangle over mirror time. Body movements are choreographed to avoid slips and collisions, while cotton balls tumble from packed medicine cabinets.

title: More Airline Mergers Seen
description: MERGER fever has struck the airline industry again and although nobody knows the identity of the next target carrier, Wall Street analysts believe that more consolidations are ahead.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN concrete or masonry cracks or crumbles - regardless of whether it occurs in stucco or concrete walks, steps or foundation walls - most homeowners pay little attention to the problem. If they do notice it, they do not think of it as a structural problem, but rather as a cosmetic one.

title: MAYOR COMMENDS D'AMATO AS BEING 'SUPERB SENATOR'
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had been ''a superb Senator,'' a better lawmmaker than his newly chosen Democratic opponent, Mark Green, would be.

title: TAXI METER COMPANY'S SUGGESTION ON INQUIRY UNANSWERED SINCE'82
description: A manufacturer of electronic taxicab meters suggested to the City Investigation Department in 1982 that there was corruption at the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Fed Backs 'Lifeline' Bank Programs
description: The Federal Reserve Board voted today to ask banks to offer low-cost checking and banking services to low- and moderate-income customers, noting that in recent years the fees charged for these services had increased significantly.

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis Strike in Lebanon Israeli planes struck at suspected Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon after Israel foiled an infiltration attempt by guerrillas.

title: When the Army Integrated Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Owners Are Briefed on U.S.F.L. Plea
description: Owners of United States Football League teams were given a final seminar yesterday on the league's appeal of a $3 damage award made by a jury in the league's antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: SALVAGED WOOD IN 'NAUGHTY PIECES'
description: IT seems reasonable to say that anyone exceptionally skilled at woodworking and finishing, with a knowledge of early furniture - how it was made and what type of tools were used at the time -would stand a fair chance of outwitting the wise with a forged antique. .

title: Woman Dies in Dumbwaiter
description: A woman who tried to climb into a moving dumbwaiter at a country club was crushed to death between the dumbwaiter and the shaft, the police said Wednesday.

title: McDonnell and Airbus Differ
description: Airbus Industrie said today that it had failed to reach an accord with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to build a long-range civilian airliner, although the two groups had not ruled out eventual longer-term cooperation in other areas. The Airbus president, Jean

title: ROOMS MIX PAST, PRESENT
description: SOME stores feature model rooms that forecast trends of the future.

title: Prices of Bonds Are Weaker
description: Bond prices weakened in lethargic trading yesterday with little demand from investors or speculators.

title: 2 Redmen Recruits Out
description: >What was to have been a banner recruiting year for St. John's, has taken a bad bounce with the loss of Moses Scurry and Jayson Williams. Scurry is a 6-foot-6-inch forward from Eli Whitney High School in Brooklyn, and Williams, 6-8, is from Christ the King High in Queens.

title: RASPBERRIES GROW FOR STRABWERRY
description: Up in Section 1, a few rows beneath the ascending airplanes above Shea Stadium, the hard-cores were savoring something new. Seats did not have to be saved hours before the first pitch. A cool playoff breeze was blowing. These people had never known a season like this.

title: Beacon Renter Finds Flaws in His Building
description: Sounding as would any old renter who had failed to conduct a thorough inspection of the premises before signing the lease, Olivier Coquelin held a news conference yesterday to talk about the dreadful condition of the building he is renting for ''not quite'' $1 million a year.

title: WILD-CARD REMATCH
description: Before the hurts heal, before they can revel in opening-day victories, the Jets and the Patriots find themselves in an important game tonight, barely 96 hours after the football season opened.

title: GUESS WHO WAS THERE DINING AT WHITE HOUSE
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil is in Washington for talks with President Reagan and other Administration officials on economics. Here is the list of people invited to the White House dinner tonight for the Sarneys. President and Mrs. Reagan President and Mrs. Sarney Minister of Foreign Affairs and Mrs. Roberto Costa de Abreu Sodre Adm. Henrique Saboya, Minister of the Navy Dilson Domingos Funaro, Minister of Finance Maj. Gen. Rubens Bayma Denys, Minister of the President's Military Household Joao Sayad, Minister of Planning Albano do Prado Pimentel Franco, Member of the Senate Milton Reis, Member of the Chamber of Deputies Ambassador Sergio Correa da Costa Maria Leonor Goncalves de Oliveira, wife of Governor of Brasilia Mr. and Mrs. Marcos Vinicios Rodrigues Vilaca, chairman of Brazilian Assistance Legion Foundation Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson of the Air Force, director, Strategic Defense Initiative Organization Elliott and Rachel Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs Licia Albanese and Joseph Gimma, former diva of Metropolitan Opera; senior vice president, Shearson Lehman Brothers Dwayne O. and Inez Andreas, chairman, Archer-Daniels-Midland Company Paul and Ann Anka, singer Michael J. and Alice Arlen, author Everett and Ann Ascher, president, Regent Recorded Music; president, Ann Ascher Inc.

title: SOLD! TRUMAN'S 'LITTLE WHITE HOUSE' BRINGS $17.25 MILLION BID
description: A Boston developer who once supported himself here for several months by diving for shells to sell to tourists, today bought the 100-acre historic Truman Annex from the Navy for $17.25 million.

title: Bridge: Choice of Spade Lead Made A Difference of 8,130 Points
description: There is, unfortunately, no Guinness Book of World Bridge Records. If there were, the diagramed deal would probably feature under the heading ''Biggest Swing on Opening Lead.''

title: DETROIT TV PRODUCER JAILED OVER REFUSAL TO SURRENDER VIDEOTAPES
description: A television producer was jailed today for refusing to give a grand jury videotapes of Detroit gang members sought in the panel's investigation of the murder of an off-duty Michigan state trooper.

title: SHIFT IN PRESIDENCY FOR MORGAN BANK
description: J. P. Morgan & Company and its subsidiary, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, announced yesterday that Robert V. Lindsay, president of both companies since 1980, intends to retire at the end of the year. Morgan said that Dennis Weatherstone, chairman of its executive committee, had been elected to succeed him.

title: BIG SHOW PAYOFFS AT BELMONT
description: Cagey Exuberance dueled heavily favored Bound into defeat and went on to score a 3 1/4-length victory in the $85,500 Astarita Stakes for 2-year-old fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Admarketer Campaign
description: Admarketer, a new monthly featuring nothing but ads, will be sent free to 10,000 marketing, advertising and communications professionals starting next month.

title: 2 Seized Fleeing to the West
description: Two people in a car tried to crash a barrier today at an East German border checkpoint to reach the West, but the barrier held and the two were arrested, the West Berlin police said. Witnesses said the car crashed into a barrier at a control point on the main highway connecting Potsdam in East Germany with West Berlin. The witnesses said a man and a woman jumped out of the car and tried to run to West Berlin, more than half a mile away.

title: Developments In Videotaping
description: THIRTY years ago the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences gave the Ampex Corporation of Redwood City, Calif., a special Emmy award for the invention of the first commercial videotaping system. That system was designed to replay live television performances at different times. Like early computers, the taping equipment was huge and unwieldy.

title: CHILE CLOSES A SECOND NEWS AGENCY IN CRACKDOWN
description: The Government continued its crackdown on the press today by closing an Italian news agency.

title: 140 Suspects Held In Jersey Sweep
description: About 140 suspected drug dealers were arrested today and 80 more were being sought in a three-county drug sweep.

title: CENTURY CLUB SAYS IT WILL ADMIT WOMEN IF CITY BIAS LAW IS UPHELD
description: The Century Association, one of several all-male clubs under pressure from the city to admit women, has agreed to open its membership if the constitutionality of the city's antidiscrimination law is upheld by the courts, according to city officials.

title: LIONS CLUB CHIEF-SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: The top official of the International Lions Club for Lebanon and Jordan was kidnapped today in predominantly Moslem West Beirut, one day after an American educator was abducted on his way to play golf.

title: GIVE McENROE A CHANCE TO PLAY
description: J. Randolph (Call Me Randy) Gregson has spent his two-year term as president of the United States Tennis Association sounding an alarm about the decline and fall of the United States as a tennis power. He has sounded a lot like the automobile industry, which had to do some soul-searching when those imports began multiplying on the interstates. In this instance, foreign models known as Becker, Lendl, Edberg, Graf and Sabatini are driving the U.S.T.A. to distraction.

title: A.C. Nielsen
description: The folks at A.C. Nielsen, the world's largest research company, have among their best known services an audit of a representative number of grocery retailers. So when they report through the pages of Progressive Grocer for September that there are 54,762 active branded grocery products wearing UPC codes in America, you would be wise to believe them. And as overwhelming as that number might be, it does not include 10,000 branded frozen products and another 6,000in the dairy section

title: Outline For Conrail Sale Set
description: Key House members involved in writing legislation for a public sale of the Government's stock in the Consolidated Rail Corporation have agreed on a basic outline that would set a minimum price of $2 billion, the chairman of the panel in charge of the legislation said today.

title: Accounts
description: * J. H. Harvey, a White Plains furnishings retailer, to Sklar-Lenett Associates in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: KEMP TO START
description: Jeff Kemp will start at quarterback Sunday for the 49ers in place of Joe Montana against the Rams, the 49ers' coach Bill Walsh, said yesterday. Kemp was acquired from the Rams in the offseason. Montana has lower back spasms and a minor left knee strain.

title: U.S. BANKS SWAP LATIN DEBT
description: When the Nissan Motor Company recently wanted to expand its Mexican subsidiary, it took a most unusual route.

title: TISCH: FROM AN INVESTOR TO AN INSIDER
description: Laurence A. Tisch has a reputation as a trustworthy insider. But, as Thomas H. Wyman, the departing chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc. has learned, Mr. Tisch also has strong business instincts and a willingness to act on them.

title: Valid Doubts About Justice Rehnquist
description: President Reagan has earned the right to try to shift the philosophy of the Supreme Court. But the Senate has an equal right to insist on high-quality appointments - particularly for Chief Justice, the noblest position in American law. The debate that begins today on the nomination of Justice William Rehnquist will properly turn on concerns beyond the mundanely partisan. The Senate's own investigation has raised valid questions about the nominee's credibility and convictions.

title: ALEXANDRIA: FABLED CITY
description: Alexandria, the site of the Israeli-Egyptian summit conference beginning today, is the chief port and second largest city in Egypt.

title: ISRAELI CABINET TO MEET BEFORE PERES TRIP
description: The Likud bloc demanded tonight that a Cabinet meeting be held on Thursday so that strict guidelines can be laid down for Prime Minister Shimon Peres's meeting with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Government sources said.

title: WESTCHESTER BOARD APPROVES INCREASES IN APARTMENT RENTS
description: The Westchester Rent Guidelines Board tonight approved rent increases of 3 percent on one-year leases and 5 percent on two-year leases for 50,000 apartments in 18 communities covered by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act.

title: WILLIAM E. BACHERT
description: William E. Bachert, a retired banking executive and former official of the United States Olympic Committee, died Sept. 4 at Montcalm Manor, a nursing home in Montclair, N.J. He was 85 years old and a longtime resident of Montclair.

title: CONGRESS MONITORS ITS MEDAL
description: In its early years, the Congressional gold medal, the highest award Congress can bestow, went most often to military leaders like George Washington.

title: LAG IN 'NICKLEBY' SALES MAY MEAN EARLY CLOSE
description: ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the highly acclaimed Royal Shakespeare Company production originally scheduled to run on Broadway until Nov. 16, is now expected to close on Sept. 28, because ticket sales have been so poor.

title: U.S. GROUP FOR LATVIA PARLEY IS PUT ON HOLD
description: One of several events that has been put in jeopardy as a result of the Soviet detention of an American journalist is a five-day ''town meeting'' in Latvia involving prominent Russians and Americans.

title: SHULTZ WON'T GO TO MIDEAST
description: American officials reacted with gratification today to the reports that Egypt and Israel had found a formula for submitting their border dispute to arbitration.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1986
description: Shake-Up at CBS

title: DEATH IN PARK: DIFFICULT QUESTIONS FOR PARENTS
description: For parents, educators and psychologists, the strangling of 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin and the arrest of 19-year-old Robert E. Chambers Jr. on a charge of murder have become more than a sensational and notorious criminal case.

title: Phil Berger on Boxing; Wait for Pryor Is Fruitless
description: The comeback of Aaron Pryor, the former junior-welterweight champion who last fought in March 1985, appears to have hit snags.

title: TRADE DEFICIT OF $36.02 BILLION
description: The United States suffered a $36.02 billion foreign trade deficit from April through June despite a dramatic plunge in the price of imported oil, the Government said today.

title: SUSPECT INDICTED IN CENTRAL PARK SLAYING
description: A 19-year-old graduate a an Ea Side preparatory school was indicted yesterday on charges of murdering 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin by asphyxiation in Central Park early on the morning of Aug. 26.

title: VAST YIDDISH DICTIONARY TAKING SHAPE, SLOWLY
description: The Yiddish language, which has amassed a cornucopia of wisdom and words in its thousand-year life, is nearly halfway inscribed in its own book of life, the Great Dictionary of the Yiddish Language, and this achievement in itself raises, as Yiddish so often does, a question.

title: PRIVATIZATION MOVE BY FRENCH
description: In an eagerly awaited announcement, Finance Minister Edouard Balladur today disclosed the first three companies that will be sold to shareholders under the new conservative Government's program to take 65 companies private.

title: PRESERVING THE STRIPED BASS
description: One of the organizations responsible for the growing awareness of the marine ecosystem's dependence on coastal regions is the 25-year-old American Littoral Society.

title: A LASER'S INVENTOR ENDING ARMS WORK
description: The young brilliant scientist who reluctantly invented the laser that helped inspire President Reagan's program for a defense against missiles has quit weapon research.

title: Couple From Polish Ship Seek Asylum in Cleveland
description: A Polish sailor and his new wife jumped ship in Cleveland today and were seeking political asylum, United States officials said.

title: 'AMERICAN GEISHA,' TALE SET IN KYOTO AND TOKYO
description: ALTHOUGH indulging in a great deal of talk about building bridges and mutual understanding between East and West, ''American Geisha,'' a television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight, ends up as just another show-and-tell exercise about how ne'er the twain shall meet - except perhaps through tourist agencies. The credits note that Judith Paige Mitchell's script is based ''in part'' on the 1982 book ''Geisha'' by Liza Dalby, an American who managed to penetrate Japan's still mysterious world of geishas.

title: LaRouche Turns To AIDS Politics
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and his political camp followers have taken up a new cause. They are out to make prejudice against AIDS victims respectable. If California voters approve a LaRouche-sponsored initiative that is to appear on the November ballot, doctors and public health authorities fear they will be forced to begin mass testing for AIDS and, worse yet, quarantine all Californians who have been exposed to AIDS.

title: THE KEY ISSUE: CHAMBER'S INTENT
description: The legal path that led to the indictment yesterday of Robert E. Chambers Jr. on two counts of second-degree murder is strewn with numerous potential legal options and tactics for the prosecution and defense that center on one key word: intent.

title: TWO WITH LINKS TO CRIME GROUP CHARGED BY U.S.
description: A man identified by the authorities as the acting boss of the Colombo crime family and another man described as a captain in the group were arrested yesterday and charged in Federal Court in Brooklyn with conspiring to receive hijacked goods.

title: British Telecom Net
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said today that earnings in its first quarter rose 20.6 percent, to $:304 million, or $465 million at the exchange rate at the end of the quarter, from $:252 million a year earlier.

title: SENATE VOTES AIDS DRUG FUND
description: The Senate agreed today to give the National Cancer Institute an extra $40 million to $50 million to provide the experimental drug AZT to 10,000 people dying of AIDS. The funds will be shifted from a $1.9 billion program that helps the poor pay heating bills.

title: GATT Talks' Stance of U.S.
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, contending that the future of world trade hinges on next week's 92-nation conference in Uruguay, today accused a small group of third world nations of seeking to sabotage those talks.

title: Jersey Prosecutor Asks Work-Gang Sentences
description: The Hudson County Prosecutor suggests that people convicted of minor crimes be sentenced to work gangs to make room in the county jail for prisoners guilty of more serious crimes.

title: Andries Retains Title in London
description: Dennis Andries of Britain retained his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title today when he stopped a countryman, Tony Sibson, in the ninth round of their scheduled 12-round bout.

title: ACCORD REACHED TO SELL 2 GIMBELS STORES IN CITY
description: The liquidation of the 146-year-old Gimbels department store chain was substantially completed yesterday when its owner reached an agreement to sell the two Manhattan stores and a Queens warehouse.

title: 'Tain't Funny, McReagan
description: President Reagan's ability to ad-lib a wisecrack in the middle of a prepared speech is generally recognized and applauded by his audiences, but there are exceptions.

title: Winners, Losers and Money
description: Americans love an underdog, and Mark Green was certainly that in his race for the Democratic Senate nomination in New York. Though he and John Dyson are both well equipped to serve, Mr. Dyson was far better supplied with prestige and money. He had the tacit support of Governor Cuomo and outspent Mr. Green, $6 million to $800,000. The Green triumph thus gratifies the spirit of never say die. What it should not do is ratify a wishful exaggeration.

title: DESIGNER OF LUXURY INTERIORS
description: Robin L. Jacobsen, a designer known for dramatic modern interiors, died Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 45 years old.

title: RESEARCH UNIT FOCUSES ON PROGRESS FOR BLACKS
description: For 16 years now the offices of the Joint Center for Political Studies has issued a steady outpouring of scholarly studies, books and newsletters on political and economic issues from a black perspective.

title: Rangers Sign DeBlois
description: Lucien DeBlois, who played last season with the Montreal Canadiens, but started his career as the first choice of the Rangers in the 1977 amateur draft was signed by the Rangers as a free agent yesterday. DeBlois, who was traded to the Colorado Rockies, now the Devils, in 1979 in the Barry Beck deal, played in 61 games for the Canadiens last season, getting 14 goals and 17 assists for 31 points, but was released by Montreal.

title: 'Junk Bond' Issue By First Brands
description: The First Brands Corporation, created earlier this year from the home and automotive products businesses of the Union Carbide Corporation, made its bond market debut yesterday with a $300 million offering of ''junk bonds.''

title: And Now Istanbul
description: Rome, Antwerp, Copenhagen, Paris, Vienna and now Istanbul: will there ever be an end to the shedding of Jewish blood? Will insane fanatics forever continue to murder Jews in Jewish places of worship? Are Jews destined to be in danger, always?

title: Espionage or Impropriety in the Daniloff Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: GOUNOD'S 'FAUST' AT THE STATE THEATER
description: THE return to the repertory Tuesday evening of the New York City Opera's production of ''Faust'' should have been cause for good cheer. Reviled though the work generally is by those who know their Goethe in other form than Gounod's opera, ''Faust'' has never lost its hold on the audience's affection. Once heard, its melodies lodge themselves firmly in memory and can rattle around in one's head for hours after almost any performance. There are higher standards for operatic genius, but that is a fair one, for a start.

title: T.W.A. Told to Reinstate Senior Flight Attendants
description: Trans World Airlines must reinstate hundreds of senior flight attendants who struck the airline.

title: PRIMARIES SHOW WOMEN EMERGING AS SEASONED POLITICAL CONTENDERS
description: The outcome of primaries Tuesday in nine states and the District of Columbia marked the advancement of women who have made a career of elective office, politicians and political consultants said yesterday.

title: WIDE BILL ON DRUGS PRESSED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives pressed ahead today toward approval of sweeping bipartisan drug legislation despite reservations about some controversial amendments, the bill's effectiveness, its cost and the haste with which it is being considered.

title: Chess Title Match Postponed by Kasparov
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, today called a timeout in his title match with the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, postponing the 15th game of the competition until Friday.

title: ISRAEL HITS SUSPECTED BASES IN LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force planes struck today at suspected Palestinian bases in southern Lebanon, one hour after the Israeli Navy reported it had foiled an attempt by the guerrillas to infiltrate into northern Israel by sea.

title: NEW VIGOR FOR AN OLD FRENCH POTTERY
description: THE last thing Paul and Sarah Janssens ever expected was that they would own a factory in France. Attracted to this picturesque town in southeastern Connecticut, they moved here 10 years ago and bought a home on Long Island Sound and a store on Water Street. ''We knew we wanted a business, but we didn't know which business,'' Mrs. Janssens said. ''We just knew we wanted to walk to work.''

title: 2 HASIDIC SECTS UNITED BY BROOKLYN WEDDING
description: Under a tiara of stars and street lights, two young Hasidic Jews were married last night in Brooklyn in a joyous traditional ceremony uniting two sects of the ultra-Orthodox movement that began in Eastern Europe.

title: PHILADELPHIA PAPERS RETOOL IN FACE OF CITY-SUBURBAN FLIP-FLOP
description: To some employees of The Philadelphia Daily News, especially those who came over from The Bulletin when it died in 1982, the news that their paper had lost $30 million in the last six years was unsettling to say the least.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 10
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $12,720,000 for the 12 weeks and $13,128,000 for the 28 weeks, and an extraordinary charge of $3 million from the extinguishment of debt for both periods. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,091,000 and $1,760,000 for the 12 weeks and 28 weeks, respectively. The company said the latest 28- week period results include a gain of $5,345,000 from settlement of accumulated benefits under a retirement plan and a gain of $2,817,000 from the sale of the Hot Sam Cos. division.

title: 'OUR HOUSE,' WITH WILFORD BRIMLEY
description: IF anybody can make still another lovable but crusty grandpa seem fresh and workable, Wilford Brimley is clearly the man. The new NBC series ''Our House'' is being given its premiere tonight at 8:30, immediately after a ''Cosby Show'' repeat and beginning in the slot normally reserved for ''Family Ties.'' As you might surmise, all three series fall into the category of ''family'' shows, this year's trendy trend following the smashing success of Mr. Cosby & Company. In its regular slot, the hourlong ''Our House'' will run on Sundays at 7 P.M., competing with CBS's long-entrenched ''60 Minutes.'' The prospect of tough Mike Wallace competing with sly Wilford Brimley is not without its ineffable charms.

title: PHILIPPINE DEFENSE CHIEF IS STIRRING ANXIETY
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile has stirred controversy with a statement that he might lose patience with his critics in Government and that ''when I lose my patience I am like Rambo.''

title: NORWAY TO REDUCE OIL EXPORTS
description: Norway said today that it would reduce its oil exports by 10 percent in November and December. This move by the North Sea producer helps buttress last month's OPEC agreement to curb production and bolster oil prices.

title: WYMAN FACED DOUBTS FROM START
description: When Thomas H. Wyman joined CBS as president and chief executive in June 1980, the corporation's third president in less than four years, some on Wall Street suggested that his biggest challenge would be to simply hold on to his job.

title: Echo Bay to Buy Tenneco Unit
description: Echo Bay Mines Ltd. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Tenneco Inc.'s gold mining properties for $130 million, with closing scheduled for November.

title: REAGAN WARNS BRAZIL CHIEF ON TRADE
description: In what Administration officials termed a clear expression of United States frustration, President Reagan warned Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, today that a greater effort must be made to open up that country's markets.

title: William L. Everitt, 86, Dies; Telecommunications Expert
description: Dr. William L. Everitt, a leader in telecommunications and dean emeritus of the College of Engineering at the University of Illinois in Urbana, died Friday at Carle Memorial Hospital in Urbana. He was 86 years old and a resident of Urbana.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT: KEY EVENTS
description: June 5, 1967 - Israel attacks Egypt after the Egyptians order United Nations troops out of Sharm el Sheik and close the Gulf of Aqaba to Israeli shipping. In the war, Israel retakes Sinai, captures the Golan Heights from Syria and seizes the West Bank from Jordan. Oct. 6, 1973 - Egypt and Syria attack Israel. By the end of the war Oct. 24, Egypt has a foothold in Sinai on the east bank of the Suez Canal, but the Egyptian forces are surrounded by Israeli troops on the west bank and in Sinai. Under the cease-fire, a United Nations peacekeeping force moves into Sinai.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: The 1985 results are reclassified for comparative purposes. The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective April 25, 1986.

title: 3 Surinamese Rebels Are Killed in Fighting
description: The army has destroyed a rebel base camp in the jungle near the French Guiana border and killed at least three insurgents in a two-day-old offensive, the Government said today.

title: HELMUT SCHMIDT'S VALEDICTORY: AS BITING AS EVER
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt gave his last speech today to the West German Parliament, a chamber he has graced with his oratorical power and acerbic wit for 33 years.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
JEWS TO TACKLE AUSTRIA ANTI-SEMITISM
description: With the backing of the Austrian Government, the American Jewish Committee is putting together educational and research programs in Austria intended to combat the anti-Semitism that emerged during Kurt Waldheim's successful campaign for the Austrian presidency.

title: A LONDON EXHIBIT OF DIVERSE DECORS 2,8.9,q>
description: A decade ago London's Victoria and Albert Museum presented an interior design exhibition of decorators' drawings entitled ''The Way We Live Now.'' Nearly everything on view was sleek, modern and minimal.

title: G.O.P. TO STRESS 'PRIDE' AGAINST O'NEILL
description: A day after winning Connecticut's three-way Republican gubernatorial primary election, Julie D. Belaga said today that she would campaign on a theme of bringing ''pride and performance'' to state government.

title: BABY M. TO STAY IN FATHER 'S CARE PENDING RULING
description: A state judge ruled today that the father of a baby born to a surrogate mother could retain custody of the 5 1/2-month-old girl until a final ruling this fall on the legality of the surrogate-motherhood contract.

title: SENATORS SAY '84 ARCHIVES LAW WAS VIOLATED
description: Two Democratic senators today accused the White House personnel director of violating the 1984 statute that made the National Archives independent by using political questions to screen candidates for archivist.

title: J. WAYNE WRIGHTSTONE
description: Dr. J. Wayne Wrightstone, a former assistant superintendent of the New York City school system, died Sunday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Summit.

title: Iraqis Hit Iranian Tanker And Raid an Oil Refinery
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked a large oil tanker off the Iranian coast today and raided a large oil refinery in a northern Iranian city, an Iraqi military spokesman reported.

title: Delta Strategy Change Seen in Western Deal
description: Delta Air Lines' proposed merger with Western Airlines is being seen in the industry as a belated admission by the Atlanta-based carrier that it can no longer rely on its conservative internal growth strategy to remain competitive.

title: Deadline for War Claims
description: The deadline for filing claims for art objects confiscated by the Nazis and now held by the Austrian Government is Sept. 30.

title: New Product List Tops Figure a Year Ago
description: Although the number of new products introduced for the grocery and drug store areas during August dropped during the ''traditional summer slump'' from the July figure, they were well ahead of the comparable month last year, according to Martin J. Friedman, pundit, and editor of DFS/ Dorland Worldwide's New Product The figure was 197, compared with 213 in July and 168 in 1985.

title: REPORT SAYS E.P.A. PAID TOO MUCH TO CONTRACTORS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's inspector general says he has found that ''excessive'' amounts were paid to private contractors working on the agency's program to meet toxic waste emergencies.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: EVENTS: HARVEST FESTIVAL AND CRAFTS FAIR
description: Harvest Festival, Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street, 212-757-0915.

title: 2 Jersey Politicians Charged in Bribery
description: The state today charged two Cape May political figures - including a member of the State Civil Service Commission - with taking a total of $110,000 in bribes in connection with the construction of a waste-water treatment plant in Ocean City.

title: STATE LIMITS CHARGE TO CUSTOMERS TO $4.16 BILLION FOR ATOM PLANT
description: The State Public Service Commission ruled today that customers of five utilities can be charged no more than $4.16 billion for the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant.

title: DOCTOR DISPUTES EFFECT OF VITAMIN C ON COLDS
description: Vitamin C appears to have ''no worthwhile'' value for preventing the common cold and may have only a small therapeutic effect in treating the sniffles, sneezing and other symptoms, an Australian researcher said today.

title: BUDGET CHIEF VOICES CONFIDENCE CONGRESS WILL MEET DEFEICT TARGET
description: Congress is now likely to meet its own deficit-reducing targets and avoid the need for spending cuts in the fiscal year beginning next month, the Federal budget director said today.

title: 19 Months of Upheaval
description: Since the start of 1985, CBS has been in a state of flux. In fending off takeovers, it has undergone a complicated recapitalization that has had severe financial consequences. Following is a chronology of key events leading up to the change in executives at the broadcast company: January 1985: Senator Jesse Helms helps to organize an effort by Fairness in Media, a group of conservative investors, to buy sufficient stock in CBS to change what the North Carolina Republican calls the ''liberal bias'' in coverage by CBS News of ''political events, personages and views.'' February 11, 1985: Fairness in Media confirms that it is considering a proxy battle to get one or two seats on the 13-member CBS board.

title: PALEY'S LATEST FEAT: HIS RETURN
description: Two weeks shy of his 85th birthday William S. Paley has once again become chairman of the company he founded and molded for more than 50 years.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LOST LANGUAGE OF CRANES. By David Leavitt. 319 pages. Knopf. $17.95. THE LOST LANGUAGE OF

title: MAN IS ACCUSED IN SLAYING OF DRIVER ON THE WEST SIDE
description: A Manhattan man who had been spotted in a stolen car with a sawed-off .44-caliber rifle was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of one of two livery drivers whose bodies had been found, 18 days apart, on the Henry Hudson Parkway, the police said. He is a suspect in the other killing.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Recalled Charlie Puleo, pitcher, from Richmond of the International League.

title: S.E.C. ACTS ON 'TRIPLE WITCHING'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today asked the New York Stock Exchange to experiment with a new procedure to reduce the volatility of stock prices on ''triple witching Fridays,'' when stock options, stock index options and stock index futures all expire.

title: BankAmerica's Italian Unit
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it had ''had expressions of interest regarding'' its Italian unit, and that ''those that are well thought out would naturally be considered.'' A spokesman said the Italian operation was ''well positioned and profitable.''

title: Stalag 20B Reunion
description: One is a surivor of the Nazi Holocaust. The other was imprisoned for five years in Nazi prisoner-of-war camps. And the second helped save the first.

title: COMBATIVE UNDERDOG AND ORATOR
description: On the morning after the Democratic primary election for United States Senator, Mark Green stood at an IRT subway stop on East 86th Street yesterday, shaking hands and just plain basking in the victory of what he calls his underfinanced ''march of dimes'' campaign.

title: 100 Bodies Recovered In Nigeria Ship Crash
description: About 100 bodies have been recovered after two ships carrying about 700 passengers collided three days ago off Port Harcourt, the police said today.

title: AT CBS NEWS, A FEELING OF RELIEF
description: At the end of the ''CBS Evening News'' last night, the CBS anchor Dan Rather looked into the camera and, ad libbing, said that the CBS chairman, Thomas H. Wyman, was ''out'' and that William S. Paley, the 86-year-old founder of CBS, was returning as temporary chairman.

title: Bias Case Official Loses
description: There was more fallout from the death of Len Bias in the Maryland Democratic primary Tuesday when Arthur Marshall, who led the grand jury inquiry into the death of the basketball player, was ousted as Prince George's County prosecutor. He had been accused of exploiting the case for his political benefit.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Stop Arguing; Rescue Junkies
description: For the last 6 of his 28 years, Herminio X. explains in an interview, he has been addicted to heroin, stealing auto parts to get the $70 to $150 the drug cost him every day. The life of a junkie and thief in New York City grows weary, however, and three years ago Herminio decided to go straight. Drug treatment programs seemed to promise help, yet the ones he approached welcomed him only with red tape.

title: Plea for Soviet Patients
description: Several members of the Senate, led by John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, have begun a campaign to persuade the Soviet Union to allow five Russians suffering from cancer to receive treatment in the United States, Canada and Israel.

title: LTV REPORTS LOSS OF $610.4 MILLION
description: The LTV Corporation, which in July filed for bankruptcy reorganization, reported today that it lost $610.4 million in the second quarter.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEMOCRATS' PROPOSAL TO SPUR U.S.
description: Senate Democrats, alarmed about threats to the American standard of living, offered a legislative blueprint today to overcome trade and other problems related to the nation's ability to compete.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 18 about two South African expatriates in New York misidentified the college attended by one of them, Rudzani Nemasetoni. It is Hunter, not New York University.

title: A Board In Turmoil
description: Until yesterday, the makeup of the CBS Inc. board was as follows: Thomas H. Wyman, age 56. Chairman of the board, president and chief executive. William S. Paley, 84.

title: 9th Week Of Declines
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell, for the ninth consecutive week, in the period ended yesterday.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Gallo Drops Time Inc. Ads
description: The E & J Gallo Winery, based in Modesto, Calif., said today that it was withdrawing all of its advertising from Time Inc. publications because of a cover article in the Sept. 1 issue of Fortune magazine. The winery said the article contained ''many vicious and damaging inaccuracies.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. One room in my house has pecan-chestnut wood paneling on the walls. This wood has been finished with shellac or varnish of some kind. How can I apply a ''pickled'' finish to this wood? A. Pickling is usually done by rubbing a thinned white or light colored paint over a darker wood finish, then wiping part of the white paint off so the color underneath shows through to some extent.

title: FILM BY ROHMER WINS TOP PRIZE IN VENICE
description: The top prize at the 43d Venice Film Festival was awarded today to ''Le Rayon Vert,'' Eric Rohmer's film about an unhappy secretary finding love on a summer vacation. It was released in the United States under the title ''Summer.''

title: PINIELLA DEFENDS HIS RECORD
description: Lou Piniella, whose job as manager of the Yankees seems to be in peril, said tonight that the speculation about his status has bothered him but that he plans to ignore it the rest of the season.

title: Debt-Equity Fund Proposal
description: The International Finance Corporation, an agency of the World Bank, is considering setting up a fund to convert some of the $97.3 billion of Mexico's foreign debt into shares in Mexican corporations, officials of the agency said today.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MEETING MISHA
description: Four years ago, Nicholas S. Daniloff, the correspondent of U.S. News & World Report, wandered into a restaurant in Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia, That evening in the Ala-Too restaurant Mr. Daniloff met a Russian who has been identified only as Misha. They began a friendship that ended 12 days ago when Mr. Daniloff was arrested in a Moscow park moments after Misha handed him a package that he said contained newspaper clippings. It was actually stuffed with what the Soviet authorities described as secret materials.

title: Dollar Bill
description: It may be petty cash for someone already earning $1.6 million a year, but Jim Kelly, the Bills' new quarterback, has made broadcast history in Buffalo by signing a radio contract that will bring him some $2,200 a week for 20 minutes' work.

title: P's and Q's at Pitt
description: One man taking no backseat to such efforts as the national high school federation's is Mike Gottfried, who, when he arrived at the University of Pittsburgh as the new football coach last spring, immediately detected what he considered to be a significant problem: not the team's size or speed, but its language. He thought the Panthers cursed too much.

title: Thompson Drops USAir
description: In order that it may attract a bigger advertiser in the airline industry, J. Walter Thompson, USA, has arranged for a mutual termination of its relationship with USAir of Arlington, Va.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1 million on early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,600,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the results for the latest quarter and 6 months include special charges of $510 million retroactively recorded to account for the financial effects of the company and its subsidiaries' Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, doubleheader at Toronto, 4:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770.) BRAVES VS.

title: Rorer Refinancing With Eurobonds
description: The Rorer Group Inc. plans to offer $250 million of convertible subordinated debt, up from $200 million, in the Eurobond market today to refinance debt incurred from the $690 million acquisition of Revlon's ethical pharmaceutical business early this year.

title: HEAD FOR SUMMIT
description: Egyptian and Israeli negotiators agreed tonight on a formula for settling a border dispute and salvaged a meeting Thursday between President Hosni Mubarak and Prime Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Participation Securities Offered by Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday offered $313.9 million of participation certificates backed by adjustable-rate mortgages, its second sale of such securities.

title: A FESTIVAL OF CULTURE FROM ISRAEL
description: Dance, music, drama, art, archeology, film, photography and literature - all originating in Israel - will be represented in a large concentration of cultural events in New York City this month. Some of the exhibitions and troupes will be here well into the fall and will travel to other American cities.

title: Soccer Brawlers Getting the Boot
description: Compared with football, say, soccer may seem like a gentlemanly game, but high school soccer players haven't always been behaving like gentlemen lately. Too often, they've been losing their tempers and hitting, kicking or otherwise attacking opponents, or using foul language to protest an official's call. Such behavior has always been defined as unsportsmanlike conduct, subjecting offenders to eviction from the game, but now the authorities say more drastic steps are in order.

title: Advertising; Saatchi Hit By P.&G. Shifts
description: AFTER plenty of time to think about it, Procter & Gamble reacted very firmly yesterday to the acquisition activities of its largest advertising company, Saatchi & Saatchi of London.

title: Queen to Visit China
description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip will pay a state visit to China from Oct. 12 to 18 at the invitation of President Li Xiannian, the Chinese Foreign Ministry announced today. The Queen's trip will be the first visit to China by a British sovereign.

title: Pakistani Government Frees More Opponents
description: Twelve more opposition politicians were reported freed from detention today, and the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto met with party activists to map strategy to topple President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq and press for new elections.

title: CHARGERS ADD A DIMENSION TO ATTACK
description: First came the wind, now comes the storm. That essentially characterizes the opening salvos of the Giants' 1986 campaign.

title: Conductor Is Appointed
description: Robert Black, a pianist and conductor, has been named music director and conductor of the Bronx Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Black, a graduate of Oberlin College and the Juilliard School, is currently conductor of the New Amsterdam Symphony Orchestra. The Bronx Symphony's first concert is scheduled for Oct. 26 at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts on the campus of Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: The Drug Bandwagon
description: An 11-year-old girl noticed a three-foot-tall marijuana plant growing in the backyard here this week and turned in her parents. Police are holding the girl in protective custody lest the parents speak sharply to her while an investigation continues.

title: Espionage or Impropriety in the Daniloff Case?; Talking to Shcharansky
description: To the Editor:

title: LOS ANGELES APPROVES 3D REDISTRICTING PLAN
description: Caught between the interests of its incumbents and a Federal demand for larger Hispanic representation, the Los Angeles City Council today approved a third redistricting plan in an effort to satisfy a Justice Department lawsuit.

title: When the Army Integrated Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: EVER FORCEFUL, ABZUG SURPRISES LEADERS OF PARTY
description: Bella S. Abzug, a former three-term United States Representative from Manhattan, upset conventional political wisdom Tuesday with a narrow victory in a four-way Democratic primary for a Westchester County Congressional seat.

title: THE GIFFORDS AND HILLS: FAMILY ERA NEARS END
description: When P. W. Gifford and John R. Hill formed Gifford-Hill & Company in 1926, they simply combined their own enterprises. Mr. Gifford owned a railroad construction and gravel concern; Mr. Hill headed an earthmoving and dirt contracting company.

title: CALL TO SERVE PUT FLAKE IN RACE
description: Even as a child in a black housing development outside Houston, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake knew he wanted to serve people through the ministry, he recalled yesterday after his upset victory in the bid for a House seat from Queeens.

title: AT U.N., IN THE BRONX, SPY SUSPECT BLENDED IN
description: Gennadi Fyodorovich Zakharov made no waves.

title: Quaker Oats Gets 4.8% Gerber Stake
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that it had acquired a 4.8 percent stake in Gerber Products Company, sparking takeover speculation and driving Gerber's stock price up $5.875 a share, to $52, in heavy trading.

title: FRANCE ACTS TO COUNTER INFLUENCE OF U.S. MUSIC
description: France is planning new measures to protect French culture against the onslaught of English and American pop music.

title: Energetic Prank
description: The office of Representative Bob Dornan, a California Republican, was alerted yesterday that a prankster was visiting all Congressional offices on Capitol Hill, dropping off a letter supposedly from Mr. Dornan and asking support for National Make Fun of Congress Week. To make matters worse, from a legislator's standpoint, the letter was not particularly humorous, asking, for example, ''In how many institutions do the members make long speeches to an empty room?''

title: NEWS UPSTAGES NEWLYWEDS' PARTY
description: Diane Sawyer, Don Hewitt, Morley Safer and 75 or so other colleagues and friends came to congratulate Mike Wallace and his new wife, Mary Yates, on their marriage, to have a drink and hors d'oeuvres and wish them well. The gathering at the Park Avenue apartment of Mollie Parnis was, as one guest noted, ''one of the best kissing parties of the year.''

title: European Air Travel
description: The Association of European Airlines, consisting of Europe's major air carriers, said today that it had revised downward its forecast for 1986 growth in intra-European passenger traffic to 3 percent from 5.2 percent. The association cited a weakening dollar and public fears about terrorism and the aftereffects of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1986
description: International

title: REHNQUIST'S CRITICS PRESS CHARGES THAT HE WAS UNETHICAL ON COURT
description: On the eve of Senate debate on confirmation of William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States, opponents today emphasized what they said was new evidence that he had acted unethically and was not candid in his Senate testimony in July.

title: JEWELER IS PAWNBROKER TO WASHINGTON'S RICH
description: Nestled in the city of power brokers is a pawnbroker who helps the rich turn their curios of history and wealth into quick no-questions-asked cash.

title: CORRECTION
description: A San Francisco dispatch last Thursday, on a ballot proposal to limit the salaries of California public employees, misidentified the organization headed by Paul Gann that is leading the effort. It is People's Advocate, not Public Advocates.

title: SHARING SOME MOMENTS FROM AN ARTISTIC LIFE
description: LAURENCE OLIVIER'S autobiography, ''Confessions of an Actor,'' provided some insight into the actor's personal life but was surprisingly reticent in dealing with the source of his creativity. In a new book, ''On Acting'' (published in London by Weidenfeld & Nicolson and scheduled to be published here Nov. 3 by Simon & Schuster), Lord Olivier, to a great extent, compensates for that initial oversight. This time, the actor as author makes no pretension of delivering a full-dress autobiographical performance. This is a conversational run-through of many of the most important moments in his artistic life. It is as if a tennis champion had just stepped off court after a thunderous ovation and is telling his public how he won the final tie-breaker. What the book may miss in quiet contemplation - not the Olivier style - it gains in immediacy.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: SEPT. 11, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Texas Inmate Granted Stay
description: A Federal district judge granted a stay of execution today for Antonio Bonham, who was to die Thursday for the rape, robbery and murder of a teacher. Judge Ross Sterling issued the stay less than 10 hours before Mr. Bonham, 26 years old, was to die by injection, for the 1981 murder of Marie McGowen, 62 years old, of Houston.

title: Action Grants Not Meant for Job Raiding
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY HALL, CIRCA 1956, FILLED WITH DESKS AND DISCIPLINE
description: LIKE many adults, I have done my share of walking through various prospective schools in which to install my children. But each time I step across another threshold, I am reminded that I am an architectural prisoner of my past. I am not looking for a new school but for a replica of the Dominican Convent in San Rafael, Calif., which I attended. For this reason, rambling, Victorian mansions with formal gardens inspire me. Low-slung buildings with asphalt playgrounds do not.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 27 about Marcel Friedmann, a retired textile executive who died when he fell through a basement opening on West 86th Street, gave his address incorrectly. He lived at 275 Central Park West, not 241.

title: Espionage or Impropriety in the Daniloff Case?; A Previous Incident
description: To the Editor:

title: ON 59TH STREET: GALA MARKS A CENTENNIAL
description: AS Mayor Koch dubbed the store ''a great city treasure,'' and Marvin Traub, chairman of the store, described the sight of two Bloomingdale's shopping bags at a foreign airport as ''matched luggage,'' Bloomingdale's fall promotion was off to an upbeat start as a storewide gala marked 100 years at the 59th Street location. In past years, Bloomingdale's has celebrated the wares of such countries as India, France, Japan, the Philippines and China. But this year, it has taken a different tack.

title: MICHIGAN ATOM PLANT CHARGED WITH LYING TO U.S.
description: The corporate owners and a former safety engineer of a Michigan nuclear power plant were indicted today on charges of lying to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in 1981 about compliance with Federal fire safety regulations.

title: HERS
description: I SET out to buy a chicken for dinner. The place was Tourrette-sur-Loup, a small village in the South of France; the time was one year ago, the beginning of our sabbatical abroad. ''I'll take that one,'' I said. The butcher weighed it. About $10 for a two-pound chicken. I blanched, and asked: ''What's the difference between that and the cheaper chicken you sell?'' ''The black one is a farm chicken.'' ''And the others are industrial?'' ''Oui, madame.'' With bravado, as if the rescue of French gastronomy from the jaws of industrialization rested on my shoulders, I told the butcher: ''One can't eat industrial food. Give me the black chicken.''

title: CABARET: 'SAY IT WITH MUSIC,' A REVUE
description: IF romantic love has been a dominant theme of Western culture for centuries, the image of the disenchanted sophisticate as presented to us by popular culture seems a relatively recent invention. At least that is the underlying premise of the superb cabaret revue, ''Say It With Music,'' featuring the singer Rita Gardner and the pianist Buddy Barnes, which opened on Tuesday at the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) for a two-week engagement.

title: National Endowment Withdraws From Film
description: The Federal Communications Commission granted the National Endowment for the Humanities permission today to remove its name from the list of contributors to an upcoming public television series, ''The Africans.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We cannot curse any one in a temple, even if the persons who deserve curses turned this temple into a chamber of massacre, the walls of which still carry the traces of the innocent blood that was spilled.'' - Jak Veissid, at the funeral in Istanbul for 21 terrorist victims. [ A8:1.

title: Moody's Lowers Australia Rating
description: Australia's triple-A long-term debt rating was reduced to Aa-1, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,285,000 for the quarter and $6,420,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month nets included a $27 million after-tax gain, or 34 cents a share, from additional proceeds and final settlement of the 1985 sale-leaseback of the company's Irvine complex, and the 9 months also included a $24.1 million, or 30 cents a share, after-tax gain from the sale of a 10 percent interest in the company's gold operation, St. Joe Gold. The year-ago quarter and 9-month nets included an after-tax gain of $55.7 million, or 70 cents a share, from the 1985 sale-leaseback of the company's Irvine complex.

title: Europe's Output Rises
description: Industrial production in the European Community rose by 2.3 percent in June from the period last year, a continuation of steady growth since 1982, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. Europe's gains contrasted with a leveling off of output in Japan and a slight decline in the United States.

title: EARL BARNES
description: Earl Barnes, a former chairman of the Ohio Republican Party, died Tuesday of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 65 years old.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Challenge to Election
description: A Federal appeals court, in a decision written by the Supreme Court nominee Antonin Scalia, on Tuesday dismissed a challenge to Representative Frank M. McCloskey's seat as the winner of one of the century's closest House elections.

title: ADMINISTRATION AIDES BACK TESTS OF FEDERAL EMPLOYEES FOR DRUGS
description: Top Administration officials generally agreed today on widespread drug testing of Federal employees but could not agree on whether to dismiss second offenders, officials said today.

title: Tribute to Aquino
description: A coalition of seven women's business groups and the National Women's Political Caucus will hold a reception this afternoon for President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines. The sponsoring organizations say her visit to Washington ''offers America's women economic leaders a rare opportunity to pay tribute to her leadership'' ''We applaud the increasing importance of women leaders worldwide and salute President Aquino for her courage,'' they said.

title: CUOMO AND THE CHURCH: SOME VEXING QUESTIONS
description: It is accepted political wisdom that there is little advantage for a public official to get into a fight with the church, particularly the Archdiocese of New York. It is not surprising then that Governor Cuomo has found preciously few allies among fellow Roman Catholic politicians in his confrontation with the archdiocese over a new church policy on parish speakers.

title: REAGAN TO APPOINT NEW VICE CHAIRMAN FOR RIGHTS AGENCY
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan would name Murray Friedman, an official with the American Jewish Committee, to fill a vacancy on the sharply divided United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: THEATER: AN ISRAELI 'KIDDUSH'
description: FROM the Second Avenue Yiddish theater up to Clifford Odets and his descendants, the Jewish family has been put through a lot over the years. It has been buffeted on stage not only by all the forces of assimilation but by most of the political, economic and social winds that swept America in the first half of this century. Now, to judge by ''Kiddush,'' a play from Israel being presented in the 92d Street Y's American Jewish Theater series, the Jewish family is in trouble in the Jewish homeland itself.

title: GARN'S DAUGHTER RECEIVES KIDNEY
description: Senator Jake Garn donated his left kidney today to his daughter, Susan Horne, in what doctors called ''an extremely successful'' operation.

title: 3 WHO GAVE CORRUPTION ALERT
description: Unlike the investigators who have spent months piecing together the corruption scandal at the New York City Parking Violations Bureau, the three men who first saw evidence of wrongdoing did not have to look very hard.

title: KEY RATES
SOUTH AFRICAN TROOPS LEAVE BLACK HIGH SCHOOL CAMPUSES
description: The security forces withdrew troops and police dogs from schoolgrounds in Soweto and other black townships today, ending three months of patrols that had set off student boycotts.

title: MCI to Offer Toll-Free Setup
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it plans to offer toll-free in-bound telephone service in the first quarter of 1987. The MCI service would represent the first major competition to the 800 toll-free system offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: A Sanctions Hook
description: Congress is at the point of passing sanctions legislation that would send a clear American message to South Africa. So it seemed - but now a problem has arisen. It threatens to cast a shadow over the whole purpose of the enterprise.

title: HEAVY AFGHAN FIGHTING REPORTED IN GUERRILLA OFFENSIVE NEAR KABUL
description: Reports reaching here today said that Moslem guerrillas in Afghanistan had opened their biggest assault in years on Kabul, the capital, and that Soviet and Government troops backed by jets and tanks were trying to push them back.

title: FERRARO VOICED ANGER IN SESSION WITH SANTUCCI
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro met with her former chief, Queens District Attorney John J. Santucci, to express her ''extreme dissatisfaction'' with the investigation of her husband, John A. Zaccaro, Mr. Zaccaro's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Tentative Pact Reported In Armco Steel Strike
description: A tentative agreement was reached tonight in a six-day strike by steel workers at Armco's Middletown Works, a union official said.

title: Mass Transit Legacy From Westway Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: O'ROURKE USED CARDBOARD CUTOUT OF CUOMO AS TARGET FOR TEASING
