description: Trying to revive what even Republicans have called a sagging campaign for governor, Andrew P. Rourke yesterday began a humorous television campaign that seeks to ridicule his opponent, Governor Cuomo, as a ''one-dimensional Governor.''

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,243,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $8,820,000 from discontinued operations for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $67,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,262,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $25,168,000 and $26,737,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: British Aerospace Net
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that its first-half profit after an extraordinary charge fell 80 percent, to $:12.5 million, or $18.8 million at current exchange rates, from $:62.1 million a year earlier.

title: CLEMENS WINS 22D AS RED SOX ROLL
description: Jim Rice went 4 for 5 and drove in three runs, and Roger Clemens gained his 22d victory tonight as the Boston Red Sox won their 11th straight game by beating the Baltimore Orioles, 9-4.

title: Omar Ali Saifuddin; Former Brunei Sultan
description: Gen. Sir Muda Omar Ali Saifuddin, the former Sultan of Brunei, who abdicated his throne in 1967, died Sunday. He was 71 years old.

title: 51 Fined for Brawl
description: A total of 26 players from the Chicago Bears and 25 from the St. Louis Cardinals have been fined by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for brawling in a National Football League preseason game. The fines, ranging from $400 to $2,300, came to $14,300 levied against the Bears and a significantly higher amount against the Cardinals, according to the Bears' general manager, Jerry Vainisi, who refused to name any players who were fined.

title: U.S. Grants to Promote Constitutional Studies
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities will provide matching grants of $500 to public libraries to help them set up ''Bicentennial Bookshelves'' of works about the Constitution, the agency said today.

title: ENVOYS' HOMES EVOKE SINGAPORE'S PAST
description: IN the condominium culture of this fast-paced little nation - a place of glittering ''Western'' shopping plazas, designer clothes, health clubs and air-conditioned cafes - who lives in the old houses with the leaky roofs and ceiling fans? The United States Ambassador and his British counterpart, representing the technological West.

title: Arguments Due In Hunts Hearing
description: Lawyers for the billionaire Hunt brothers and a group of banks will argue in Federal court Thursday over whether the Hunts should be forced to take their bankruptcy cases back to Texas. A three-judge panel of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit will hear the case in the morning and could rule later in the day.

title: South African Elected
description: Ray Moore, a former No. 1 player for his native South Africa and a current board member of the Association of Tennis Professionals, has been elected chairman of the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the worldwide governing body for official men's professional tennis. His election follows the resignation yesterday of the past chairman, Michael G. Davies.

title: SPENDING ON ARMS LINKED TO ACCORD
description: The chairman of a Senate committee drafting a military spending bill said today that he would seek $3 billion for a new space shuttle orbiter and would try to restore funds cut from research on missile defense if no arms control agreement was reached with the Soviet Union.

title: METS MOVE CLOSER TO TITLE
description: The Mets took advantage of Sergio Valdez, a pitcher making his major league debut, and got strong pitching from Ron Darling in defeating the Montreal Expos, 6-1, last night at Shea Stadium.

title: RESULTS OF BALLOTING IN NEW YORK AND CONNECTICUT
description: Following are the unofficial results in Tuesday's primary elections in New York and Connecticut. Incumbents are marked with an asterisk. Write-in candidates are marked with a star.

title: THE TREE DIED; THE QUESTION IS WHY?
description: A WEEK ago the most radiant plant in my garden in England was a 10-foot-high cream and green four-tiered wedding cake of a variegated Japanese dogwood. Everybody was drawn to this mouth-watering tree. It beckoned you down a shady path between larches and hollies like the light at the end of the tunnel. Today it is dead, and I don't know why.

title: Unidentified Plane Leads To Alert of Interceptors
description: A ''communications breakdown'' brought an order to two Air National Guard jets to intercept an unidentified aircraft off the coast of Oregon, the authorities said today.

title: SOVIET GIVEN NEW U.S. OFFER IN DANILOFF CASE
description: The United States, in a new proposal, has suggested that an American journalist in Moscow and a Soviet employee of the United Nations in New York who are being held on espionage charges be turned over to their respective ambassadors and that the American then be allowed to return to home without trial, Administration officials said today.

title: BRASS ACCENTS ADD TO ANTIQUE ICEBOX
description: ICEBOXES from the turn of the century, popular among collectors, are often found at flea markets and garage sales. Usually made of oak with brass fittings, they frequently need repair.

title: HEAD OF CBS QUITS UNDER PRESSURE; PALEY IN KEY ROLE
description: After a tense, lengthy board meeting yesterday, Thomas H. Wyman, the embattled chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc., resigned as head of the communications giant, the company announced last night.

title: SYNAGOGUE VICTIMS MOURNED AT RITES
description: In Neve Shalom Synagogue, which still bears the stains and scars of a massacre last Saturday, a funeral service was held today for its 21 victims. Afterward, in a semicircle of graves, 19 were buried at Istanbul's Jewish cemetery.

title: Biederman & Company Gets N.Y.U. Account
description: New York University's School of Continuing Education, which offers some 1,500 courses to adults and working professionals, has named Biederman & Company to handle its advertising, which Dorothy Durkin, an assistant dean, promises will have a budget ''in seven figures.''

title: German Told to Pay Fine In Smuggling of Tamils
description: The lawyer representing a freighter captain charged by the Canadian police in connection with transporting 155 Tamil refugees to Canada said today that he would advise his client to pay a $1,000 fine.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VINTAGE NICHOLSON Jack Nicholson, who has by no means reached the end of his line, has come of age, at least in retrospective terms. The Thalia Theater, 250 West 96th Street, today starts a 14-week Thursday series that will, by Dec. 11, have screened 29 of his films.

title: Ex-Councilman Admits Drug Sales
description: A former Manville councilman has pleaded guilty to charges stemming from his activities in a cocaine and marijuana sales ring but will not be sentenced until after he testifies against his co-defendant, a councilman, the authorities said.

title: WYMAN'S SUPPORT WANED DRAMATICALLY
description: The waning confidence of the CBS Inc. board in Thomas H. Wyman evaporated rapidly during the nine-hour board meeting Wednesday that ended with his resignation, sources close to the company said.

title: Dispute on Woman As Scout Den Chief
description: A Cub Scout pack plans to install a woman as leader of a Webelos den Oct. 1, in defiance of regulations, and national Scouting officials say they may deny affiliation to the pack.

title: Words at a Price
description: If you're interested in closed hearings the Senate held from 1824 to 1964, those for which transcripts have never before been published, the Congressional Information Service, a private company in Bethesda, Md., is prepared to sell you a transcript of every word of 7,300 of them, reproduced on microfiche. But you have to be really interested; the package costs $18,400.

title: REFUGEE FROM LAOS WINS $10 MILLION IN LOTTO
description: A 32-year-old refugee from Laos won $10 million in the state's Lotto game, lottery officials announced today.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-After tax credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $1,018,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: SHIITE GROUP DENIES SEIZING A U.S. EDUCATOR
description: A written statement issued here today by Islamic Holy War denied that the Shiite group had kidnapped Frank Herbert Reed, an American citizen, in Moslem West Beirut on Tuesday.

title: Gounod's 'Faust'
description: Gounod's ''Faust'' will be presented tomorrow night at 8 o'clock by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

title: ART: MARK KOSTABI SHOWS 20 WORKS
description: THOUGH it was born in 1981, the East Village ''art scene'' has long since subsided into middle age. Real estate giveth and real estate taketh away - in this case, the inexpensive spaces that make possible new artists and their galleries.

title: COURT REBUFFS HUNTS, SENDS CASE TO DALLAS
description: In the latest legal skirmish between the wealthy Hunt brothers and a Federal district judge in Dallas, three Federal appeals court judges today ordered the transfer of the Hunts' bankruptcy case from New Orleans to Dallas.

title: NICHOLS, S E INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2

description: Both the latest and year-ago quarters consisted of 13 weeks each but the latest 6 months had 27 weeks, compared with 26 weeks for the year- earlier period.

title: Japan Meets the World
description: Four days of intense talks at an international conference here showed that Japan with all its earnings not only feels itself in a box, it is in a box. In certain ways, the comparison often drawn with West Germany's emergence as the major economic power in Europe is accurate. But the biggest difference is that Germany belongs to a well-organized European and Atlantic club, while Japan both looms and cowers before a fragmented Asia.

title: DEFIANCE PRECISION PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Dr. Harry Shwachman Dead; Authority on Cystic Fibrosis
description: Dr. Harry Shwachman, an authority on cystic fibrosis, died Tuesday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He suffered a stroke a week ago.

title: GEORGE C. SCOTT IN 'LAST DAYS OF PATTON'
description: HAVING steadfastly refused to pick up his Oscar for the 1970 movie ''Patton,''

title: Manhattan College President Is Leaving Post After 12 Years
description: The president of Manhattan College, Brother J. Stephen Sullivan, has resigned, effective next June, the college announced this week.

title: 3 STORE EMPLOYEES ACCUSED OF SELLING FAKE IDENTIFICATION
description: As part of the city's effort to crack down on under-age drinking, three workers in Manhattan novelty stores were charged yesterday with selling forged college identification cards and birth and baptismal certificates to undercover investigators.

title: 'New Sounds' Concert
description: WNYC's ''New Sounds,'' a program of new and innovative music, will present and broadcast a live concert featuring the composer Michael Galasso, David Hykes and the Harmonic Choir, and the performer David Gilden at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

title: BRITISH WILL CONTROL ACID RAIN
description: After years of criticism as one of the worst polluters in Europe, Britain announced a $900 million program today to begin limited controls of sulfur emissions, which have contributed to the acid rain that has damaged forests, lakes and rivers in Scandinavia.

title: Dodge Truck in Pop-Up In Sports Illustrated
description: Sports Illustrated, on the heels of its sister publication Time, will be featuring a pop-up ad in its Sept. 22 issue. But while the Time ad displayed the skyline of San Francisco, courtesy of Transamerica, S.I. will have the new Dodge Dakota truck leaping from a six-page insert, courtesy of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: TISCH FACES TOUGH CHALLENGE
description: As he takes over as acting chief executive of CBS Inc., Laurence A. Tisch is facing a raft of nettlesome problems that have rocked the company for the last two years.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Peter Gordon and His Love of Life Orchestra, Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue and 13th Street (242-1664). The composer, reed player and bandleader mischieviously crosses over the conventional boundaries separating rock, jazz, pop, ''classical'' and avant-garde styles to create horn and synthesizer-oriented music that fuses all of the above into breezy cinematic set pieces. Mr. Gordon's compositions allude especially strongly to big band music, funk and film-noir melodrama. The common denominator of these musical kaleidoscopes is the composer's warmhearted sense of fun. Show time is Sunday at 9:15 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: Baghdad Area Struck By an Iranian Missile
description: An explosion rocked this city early today, apparently from an attack by an Iranian surface-to-surface missile.

title: LETTERS ON BAN BY PARISH
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie, a Bronx Democrat, said yesterday that he had received 610 letters and telephone calls in response to his being banned by his Roman Catholic parish, St. Raymond's, from speaking at parish functions because he voted to allow Medicaid funds to be used for abortions. Here is a sampling from some of the letters:

title: A LIGHTWEIGHT COPIER TO GO
description: It's a dead ringer for a sleek electric shaver - matte-black with nicely rounded corners. But the pocket-size unit is not a grooming implement - it's a portable machine that allows the user to make instant copies of printed material from magazines, books, menus and receipts.

title: COURT SAYS FEEDING MAY STOP FOR MAN IN A VEGETATIVE STATE
description: The highest court in Massachusetts ruled today that the family of a 49-year-old firefighter, who has been in a ''persistent vegetative state'' for three years, may have his feeding tube disconnected so he can die.

title: Chief Financial Officer To Resign From JWT
description: Glen A. Dell, who joined the JWT Group two years ago as executive vice president and chief financial officer, is going to resign, the company announced yesterday.

title: Conductor Is Arrested In '80 Subway Slaying
description: A man who worked as a subway conductor for the last year was arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting of a teen-ager during a 1980 confrontation on an F train, the transit police said.

title: DAM IN MICHIGAN BREAKS, FORCING HUNDREDS TO FLEE
description: An earthen hydroelectric dam weakened by days of torrential rain burst today, unleashing a torrent that washed away a highway bridge and forcing as many as 300 people to flee two towns, officials said.

Bridge: Player-Writer From Wales Makes a Stop in New York
description: Many of the 700 or so foreign players who are heading for the 1986 world championships, scheduled to begin in Miami Beach tomorrow, chose to make a stopover in New York. One of these was Patrick Jourdain, a British player-writer who edits the monthly Bulletin of the International Bridge Press Association from his home in Cardiff, Wales.

title: Leber Katz Retaining Its Style
description: QUITE counter to industry practice, Leber Katz Partners has never in its 33 years of existence solicited an account. It has participated in competitions with other agencies when invited to do so, but never a cold solicitation.

title: Carter Faults Reagan On Zimbabwe Aid Cut
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Reagan Administration was wrong to have cut off economic aid to Zimbabwe as a result of a diplomatic episode there July 4 that caused Mr. Carter to walk out of a reception.

title: LAST OF 6 RAIL UNIONS IN ACCORD
description: The railroad industry and a union representing 21,000 carmen reached a tentative agreement on a new contract today, ending the threat of a nationwide rail strike next Monday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JAPANESE FOLK SINGER Chikuzan, the folk singer, has spent most of his life wandering through the countryside of northern Japan, singing and playing his three-stringed banjo-like instrument called the tsugaru shamisen for appreciative audiences of farmers and villagers. In recent years, his reputation has spread to the country's major cities; some have compared him to a Japanese Leadbelly. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Chikuzan - now blind and nearly 80 years old - will perform at the Japan Society, 333 West 47th Street. Tickets are $15 for Japan Society members; $20 for nonmembers. Information: 832-1155.

title: ORIOLES WIN, 8-6, TO END RED SOX STREAK
description: Lee Lacy singled home the tiebreaking run in the eighth inning tonight and the Baltimore Orioles beat Boston, 8-6, ending an 11-game winning streak by the Red Sox.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Group, the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street (505-5660). The music that was called ''new music'' or ''free jazz'' in the 60's is no longer new, nor is it free in any meaningful sense. It's a method of improvising, primarily textural and thematic, that players like the five men in the Group have developed into a fine art. In the mid-60's, the Group's saxophonist, Marion Brown, was on John Coltrane's album ''Ascension''; the drummer, Andrew Cyrille, was with Cecil Taylor during the same period. The other players are newer voices, but all have proved themselves again and again. The Group is playing today and tomorrow at 9 and 11 P.M.; admission is $10 in advance, $12.50 at the door.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD IS REACHED BY ARMCO AND STEELWORKERS
description: A tentative contract was reached late Wednesday between Armco Inc. and striking steelworkers. It contains no wage cuts and restores money the workers lost when the company reduced pay scales without negotiating, the union said.

description: In the first test of a new national plan for setting up sites for disposal of radioactive nuclear wastes, a panel representing eight Southeastern states voted today to designate North Carolina as the repository for all the region's low-level refuse.

description: Herman Maril, a landscape artist and emeritus professor of painting at the University of Maryland, died of pneumonia last Saturday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. He was 77 years old and lived in Provincetown, Mass.

For the eighth year, Saks Fifth Avenue gave a black-tie party, called SFA/USA, honoring six American fashion designers and benefiting six of New York City's charitable or cultural organizations.

title: A FAIR FOR BOTH BIBLIOPHILES AND ADVENTUROUS BROWSERS
description: THE only leaves that were blowing in the brisk breeze that was heralding the fall season on Fifth Avenue were those of a pamphlet being thumbed by Weekend Walker. Walker, who makes every respectable New York scene, was getting the advance briefing about Sunday's New York Is Book Country, the event that proclaims the pre-eminence of Manhattan, and of Fifth Avenue in particular, as the dissemination center of books.

description: Marvin Schofer, executive vice president of ICM Artists Ltd., the classical-music management agency, left his position at the company yesterday. His attorney, Marc Glick, reported that Mr. Schofer was dismissed.

description: As Soviet and American leaders exchanged hostile words over spy charges, scientists in the two countries today held an unusual satellite teleconference urging cooperation on nuclear reactor safety and other issues.

title: Support for Swimmer
description: The United States Senate has passed a bill, sponsored by Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, to grant Peter Berndt, a 22-year-old East German swimmer, American citizenship four years early. Berndt was granted political asylum in the United States on Jan. 7, 1985, after he defected at an airport in Oklahoma City while he was traveling with the East German team.

This compared with $380,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year-ago quarter and $816,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year-earlier 9 months.

title: Rose Bird and Rehnquist
description: Right-wingers, who piously insist that no senator should vote against Justice William Rehnquist because of his political and constitutional views, have been conspicuously silent about the right-wing Republican effort to oust Chief Justice Rose Bird from the California Supreme Court because of her views.

title: Arbitrator's Dismissal By Owners Is Reversed
description: Labor representatives of baseball's club owners learned yesterday that they may not dismiss an arbitrator in the middle of a hearing, as they had done with the arbitrator hearing the players' grievance against the owners' alleged free-agent conspiracy.

title: Terminal's Shoeshine Men Get Marching Orders
description: Rain or shine, they always shine. Well-known to thousands of commuters who stream by daily, the five shoeshine men of Grand Central Terminal are one of the fixtures on 42d Street.

title: Lawrence C. Reehling; Designed Stage Scenery
description: Lawrence Clair Reehling, a scenic designer for theater and television, died of a heart attack last Friday at Lancaster (Pa.) General Hospital.

title: BEHIND THE REVOLT AT CBS, ISOLATION OF ITS CHAIRMAN
description: The shake-up at CBS Inc. has spurred conjecture - and concern - about the direction of a company that has set the standard for broadcasting for two generations. Here are questions about the company that have been raised most often during this turbulent week, and some answers. Q. What happened? A. Thomas H. Wyman was forced out of his job Wednesday as chairman and chief executive after he lost favor with his two largest shareholders: William S. Paley, the founder of CBS, and Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the Loews Corporation and a CBS board member. Mr. Wyman's resignation was followed yesterday by the departure of Van Gordon Sauter, president of CBS News. Q. Why did it happen now? A. Up until late last year, Mr. Wyman seemed securely at the top of CBS. His resignation came only after a series of setbacks and challenges, some personal, others corporate, had eroded his strength and isolated him from his board. Although Mr. Paley had handpicked him to run the company in 1980, Mr. Wyman, with the board's support, had squeezed Mr. Paley out of the chairman's seat and then generally ignored the advice the 84-year-old founder tried to offer from the sidelines, particularly about prime-time programming.

description: The Giants' defensive line received a vote of no confidence today from its coach.

Ferraro's Son Quits College
description: John A. Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine A. Ferraro, has quit school six months before graduation, a spokesman for Middlebury College said today. College officials refused to comment on whether the withdrawal of Mr. Zaccaro, who was arrested at his apartment Feb. 20 after he was alleged to have sold cocaine to an undercover officer, was linked to the drug case.

description: The city began a new effort yesterday to fight the spread of drugs in public housing projects, as a newly formed narcotics task force arrested 183 people in a 24-hour sweep at 53 projects.

title: MILITARY FORBIDS ACTIVE ROLE OF SOLDIERS IN 'HATE GROUPS'
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has given commanders new and explicit authority to prevent the active participation of servicemen in ''hate groups'' like the Ku Klux Klan, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Start at Ross Playground
description: Ground-breaking in New York sometimes presents problems. Such as what if there is no ground to break?

title: THEATER: SOUTH AFRICA'S 'ASINAMALI'
description: IN ''Asinamali!,'' the first offering of Lincoln Center's monthlong South African theater festival, five black men sing, dance and shout unceasingly for 90 frenetic minutes - almost as if they feared that to stand still might be to surrender or to die. And that may well be the overriding point of this stunningly performed tapestry of satire, tragedy and reportage from the land of apartheid. What can people do when denied their rights, their dignity, their families, their lives? The men of ''Asinamali!'' turn not only their harsh experience but also their voices and bodies, their every sound and gesture, into protest art. In this kinetic theatrical event, each rapid-fire breath is a volley of defiance against the repressive state.

title: PROBLEMS ECLIPSE NEW MEXICO RACE
description: A Federal district judge has released 1,200 pages of documents detailing for the first time the outlines of investigations of the finances of Gov. Toney Anaya by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Internal Revenue Service.

description: The Polish Government announced tonight that by Monday it would free all 225 prisoners being held for their political views and activities.

description: A Detroit television producer and a Detroit city official, both jailed for contempt of court Wednesday in unrelated cases, were freed today.

description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said that it had ended its offer for Jet America Airlines Inc. Delta said the decision had been based on its inability to reach agreement with Jet America's creditors regarding the restructuring of Jet America's lease and loan obligations. A Delta statement said the decision was not related to its proposed purchase of Western Air Lines Inc., announced this week.

Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein performed the ceremony at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York.

description: The New York City policeman who shot and killed himself after being arrested for drunken driving in a fatal auto crash was legally intoxicated and under the influence of cocaine, a medical examiner said today.

title: A JAZZ GROUP THAT TAKES CHANCES
description: MODERN jazz is a music created largely by individual players, who come together in shifting collaborations to make records and play club and concert dates. Yet a disproportionate number of the most influential and enduring modern jazz recordings have been made by working bands with stable personnel, from Charlie Parker's quintets to the Modern Jazz Quartet to the original Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane quartets. Another name can now be added to the short, select list of essential modern jazz bands, a quartet whose experienced members have devoted themselves to defining a group dynamic since the early 1980's. This band, called Sphere, is playing at the Village Vanguard through Sunday.

It was through this doorway, centered between the kitchen and living room of an otherwise unremarkable house, that one of the play's two characters planned to make an irreversible passage.

Thus was cleared the path for yesterday's meeting in Alexandria between Prime Minister Peres and President Mubarak, the first Israeli-Egyptian summit session in five years. It's been too long between drinks.

title: 30-Year Sentence In Jersey Slaying
description: A Louisiana man who spurned a plea bargain that would have allowed him to be released was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for his role in the slaying of the wife of a Toms River businessman.

title: THE TIME OF THE APPLE IS HERE AGAIN
description: Joy Crist stood in back of a large table in the Apple Ridge Orchard in Orange County, cutting a Jonamac and MacIntosh for novice apple-pickers. After a few minutes, the cut edge of the MacIntosh began to turn light brown while the Jonamac remained white.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DOME AND ITS BANKERS AT ODDS
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, and its bankers are staking out positions as they work toward a permanent resolution of the oil company's financial problems.

title: Hotel's Legacy
description: Oops!

title: I Was a Victim
description: Imprisonment is nothing compared to the psychological torment that Nicholas S. Daniloff and his family are suffering. The K.G.B. is up to its old games. Some authorities are cast as the nice guys, while others move in to crush hopes and play tough, with Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet spokesman, now playing the lead role.

title: First Chicago Deal
description: The American National Corporation, a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation, said it had agreed to acquire four suburban Chicago banks with combined assets of about $220 million. The banks are National Bank of North Evanston, the Elgin National Bank, First National Bank of Schiller Park and Merchants and Manufacturers State Bank.

title: THE ROAD WARRIORS ARE BACK
description: This is where the legend began, in the sterile, 21st-century bleakness of the Meadowlands, where the Road Warriors made their first strike last December.

title: The Aimless, Spineless Nonaligned
description: The Nonaligned Movement is too divided to pick its next meeting place, too aligned to condemn the Soviet occupation of a member state, too spineless even to expel a nation whose leader all but spat at the members. What happened at the movement's aimless conference in Zimbabwe recalls a famous remark by Marx - Groucho, that is - that he would never join a club so porous as to admit him. By trying to represent too much, the 99-nation club stands for nothing at all.

title: Monaghan Leads L.P.G.A. Event
description: Kris Monaghan, a Spokane native, shot a five-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the Ladies Professional Golf Association $200,000 Safeco Classic at Meridian Valley County Club.

title: Court Ruling on Manville
description: A ruling by a Federal appeals court could further delay the Manville Corporation's four-year-old bankruptcy proceedings.

title: A HARROWING DAY ON WALL ST.
description: One of the first things that Luis S. Mendez, co-head of stock trading at the First Boston Corporation, did when he saw the stock market tumbling yesterday morning was to cancel a trip to Bermuda scheduled for last night. Then he began to search the faces of his stock traders, looking for signs of panic that would suggest his people were paralyzed as one of the bloodiest days in Wall Street history unfolded.

title: U.S. BISHOPS URGE DIVESTMENT OVER APARTHEID
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops urged Roman Catholic dioceses and institutions yesterday to strip themselves of their holdings in companies operating in South Africa or persuade those companies through stockholder resolutions to withdraw business from that country.

title: JAMES THROWS JET DEFENSE FOR A LOSS
description: In these days of 45-man rosters, down four players from a couple of years ago, it's nice to know you have an extra quarterback if you ever need him.

title: Wilander to Rest
description: After losing the Swedish Open final last July, Mats Wilander hinted he would take a break from tennis to avoid burnout. Now he has confirmed that he will not play any Grand Prix events until early November.

title: POLICE CHARGE 7 WITH EXTORTION AT KOREAN BARS
description: Seven leaders and members of a ring accused of extorting money from Korean-American restaurant and bar operators in Manhattan and Queens and engaging in gambling conspiracies and other crimes have been arrested.

title: ...ZAKHAROV LIVES IN SUNLIT EASE
description: In contrast to the isolation of Nicholas S. Daniloff in Lefortovo Prison in Moscow, Gennadi F. Zakharov has been held for the last three weeks in relative comfort at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan.

title: ZONE SHIFT SPURS HOUSING ON EAST SIDE
description: Taking shape in the East 30's in Manhattan is a transformation set in motion by a series of zoning actions taken in the early 1980's.

title: Gimbels Investor a Risk-Taker
description: Others may have passed up the opportunity to bid on the Gimbels New York properties, but Melvin Simon has a history of finding opportunities overlooked by others.

title: JAILED MAN INDICTED IN SLAYING OF COUPLE LAST YEAR
description: A man already in jail on charges of murder and attempted murder was indicted yesterday in the fatal shooting of a couple in front of their West Side apartment building last year as the husband followed his nightly custom of meeting his wife's cab to see her safely home from work.

title: SENATORS HEAR FAMILIAR SPEECHES AS THE DEBATE ON REHNQUIST OPENS
description: The Senate opened debate today on the nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States.

title: TORO COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Violin and Harpsichord
description: The violinist Dora Schwarzberg and the harpsichordist Gerald Ranck will present a free concert of works by Handel and Bach at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Sunday at 3:30 P.M. Information: 662-2133.

title: Despite Objections, Golden Set for New Party Post
description: Despite the demands of State Attorney General Robert Abrams and other Democrats that party leaders not hold public office - a proposed reform that grew out of the Parking Violations Bureau and other scandals - the Democratic state committee is to elect Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden to the panel Monday.

title: Ortega in China for Talks
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua arrived in Peking today, beginning the first visit to China by a Central American head of state. He is expected to hold talks on military, trade and information matters, Chinese officials said. Diplomats said the talks may touch on Chinese aid to Nicaragua.

title: CABINET URGES RISE IN DRUG TESTING
description: President Reagan's Cabinet issued a unanimous call today for substantially increased drug testing of Federal workers and discussed the details of a nearly $1 billion program designed to reduce narcotics abuse, according to Administration officials.

title: HOW SHOO-IN ASBESTOS BILL FALTERED
description: When legislation first begins moving through Congress, it is sometimes difficult to see whose special interest is being gored. Some bills seem certain of speedy passage until the lobbying begins in ernest.

title: McAdoo to Play in Italy
description: It appears that Bob McAdoo's career, which included three National Basketball Association scoring championships, will end in Europe.

title: PAN AM SEES A TEXAS AIR AGREEMENT AS NEAR
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it was close to an agreement with the Texas Air Corporation on acquiring added landing and takeoff slots at three airports. The slots would enable Pan Am to start a more competitive shuttle service from La Guardia Airport next month.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OBBLIGATI: Essays in Criticism. By Anthony Hecht. 330 pages. Atheneum. $18.95.

title: TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ever So Humble
description: The 62 rookies reporting to the Rangers' training center in Rye yesterday were duly impressed by the plush dressing room that had been prepared for the veterans, who don't begin their workouts until next Thursday.

title: To the Winners Go the Spoils
description: Sometimes the boosterism accompanying athletic success gives rise to a fear that it's a school's academic side that pays the price. Take Clemson, whose emergence as a national power in the late 1970's engendered a lusty, years-long campus debate as to whether the growing emphasis on football - and subsequent alumni largesse to the athletic department -was affecting contributions to the university's general fund. A recent study by two Clemson economists suggests that it has, but in a manner that is distinctly positive.

title: GENZYME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the second quarter revenues and profit in fiscal 1985 included a one-time technology license fee of $400,000.

title: LOTS OF HOPE AS RANGER ROOKIES GATHER
description: In a spirit of mutual hope and shared anticipation, 62 Ranger rookies and the team's coaches hit the ice for the first time here today as the four-season sport of hockey got its late summer start.

title: F.D.I.C. TO REIMBURSE GOLDEN PACIFIC ACCOUNTS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the ''yellow certificates'' from the failed Golden Pacific National Bank in New York's Chinatown were insured deposits. As a result, according to attorneys working on the case, holders of the yellow certificates -savings accounts evidenced by yellow slips of paper - will be paid fully up to the $100,000-per-account insurance limit of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 12, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: JEWELMASTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
FILM: 'PARTISANS OF VILNA'
description: Look at the dozens of interviewees in ''Partisans of Vilna,'' which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse, and you'll know you are watching heroes. Their courage is visible and unmistakable as they let loose the flood of memories that is preserved here. This Holocaust documentary, unlike most others, concentrates on resistance as it describes the means by which the Jewish community of Vilna, Lithuania, once nearly 60,000 strong, was decimated. It chronicles and examines the extraordinary efforts of the few who survived.

title: Chilean Leader Rebukes Democratic Opposition
description: President Augusto Pinochet assailed the opposition today, accusing it of playing into the hands of Marxism-Leninism.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $146,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: WYMAN TALKS WITH COKE CITED
description: One ingredient in the ouster of Thomas H. Wyman as chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc. was that he tried to sell CBS to the Coca-Cola Company, sources close to CBS said yesterday.

title: No Detailed Report
description: Pakistan has not yet provided a detailed account of its interrogation of the terrorists who hijacked the Pan American World Airways aircraft in Karachi last week, according to Administration officials.

title: ART: AT THE GUGGENHEIM, WORKS BY RICHARD LONG
description: RICHARD LONG is a romantic figure. His art is based on journeys throughout Europe and the United States, and to the ends of the earth. He walks through Ireland and California, the Andes and the Himalayas, Bolivia and Iceland, Lapland and Japan. Periodically, he appears at a gallery - or now at the Guggenheim Museum - where he uses mud and stone to build lines and circles that mark his movements over the globe.

title: FILM: COMICAL STRIVINGS IN 'RESTLESS NATIVES'
description: ''RESTLESS NATIVES,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street 2, is a comedy that pushes whimsy to the breaking point.

title: VICTORIA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: STAGE: 'WORSTWARD HO,' A BECKETT MONOLOGUE
description: ''WORSTWARD HO,''

title: FROM HOCKNEY, NEW PERSPECTIVES IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: THE fall photography season has begun, and there are signs of a revival of interest in the medium's less-explored esthetic precincts. Some of the renewed momentum is being generated by well-known artists of the rank of David Hockney, who has become increasingly preoccupied by the issues of photographic perspective. The rest is coming from a younger generation of artist photographers, whose interests range from mapping the interior truths of everyday existence to creating ironic icons of popular culture. While some of their pictures may appear comfortably familiar in style and content, others are montaged, collaged, painted over, incorporated into sculpture or otherwise taken out of the realm of realism. ''Forget anything you may have heard about what a photograph can or should be,'' these images seem to say. ''This is the fall of 1986.''

title: Booth-by-Booth Guide to the Fifth Ave. Book Fair
description: Following is a booth-by-booth browser's guide to activities at the New York Is Book Country Fair. Author appearances are subject to change: 1. Rizzoli Publications: Flower theme; free sunflower seeds, posters. 2. William Morrow & Company:

title: HOUSE APPROVES USE OF MILITARY TO FIGHT DRUGS
description: In a mood to get tough on drugs, the House of Representatives tonight approved a bill that requires use of the military to curb the flow of narcotics into the United States and allows the death penalty for some drug-related crimes.

title: Why the Daniloff Arrest?
description: The case of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist arrested in Moscow on charges of spying, is not simply a human drama. It is also an affair of state. A summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, tentatively scheduled for later this year, is now in serious jeopardy. Powerful forces on both sides of the Iron Curtain would not be sorry to see the summit meeting scuttled. They may have found in the Daniloff case the means to do this. Suddenly a relatively minor incident is endangering the whole complex of superpower relations, including the control of nuclear weapons.

title: Harvest Time
description: Which teams came up with a bumper crop from the N.F.L. draft this year, and which found famine? The chart below shows number of picks and the number of those now under contract, as active players or on injured reserve.

title: Break-In Attempt Fails At Investigation Dept.
description: Two men attempting to jimmy an unmarked office door at 80 Maiden Lane in lower Manhattan discovered, too late to avoid quick arrest, that they were trying to break into the squad room of the city's Department of Investigation, authorities said yesterday.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Silver Rule
description: Al Davis, on how he molds young Raiders: ''Some say do unto others as you would have them do unto you. I say that's wrong. I say do unto others as they want to be done unto in a paramilitary situation.''

title: People
description: * Dean G. Schwartz has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor at Ketchum Advertising.

title: Diner's Journal
description: COUSCOUS, tagine, spicy lamb kebabs and other Middle Eastern specialties are featured at La Kasbah, an engaging new glatt kosher restaurant on West 71st Street off Columbus Avenue. The nine-week-old restaurant has two simply appointed peach-and-white dining rooms serving authentically prepared dishes at moderate prices. La Kasbah is owned by David Dery, who was born in Morocco and reared in Israel.

title: PROGRAM TRADERS GREASED THE SKIDS
description: Since early this summer, professionals in charge of program trading at major Wall Street investment houses have privately acknowledged that the day might come when their activities could help drive the Dow Jones industrial average down by 100 points or more.

description: An exhibition of the work of 13 New York-based Hispanic photographers opens on Sunday at the State Museum in Albany.

description: This year's corn harvest is producing large yields and should be the second-biggest crop on record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Service for Harriman
description: A memorial service will be held here next Tuesday at noon for W. Averell Harriman, the diplomat, governor and Presidential adviser who died on Sept. 16 at the age of 94. Those scheduled to speak at the service at the National Cathedral are Clark Clifford, former Secretary of Defense; Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts; Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian; and Cyrus R. Vance, former Secretary of State.

title: Standard Oil to Sell 2 Kennecott Units
description: The Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two major units of its copper mining subsidiary, the Kennecott Corporation, for about $220 million.

description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1 million on early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,600,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the results for the latest quarter and 6 months include special charges of $510 million retroactively recorded to account for the financial effects of the company and its subsidiaries' Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

title: COUPLE HELD IN MAIL-ORDER HEROIN SALES SCHEME
description: A research scientist at the National Institutes of Health and her husband, a Government engineer, were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of running a multimillion-dollar heroin-smuggling operation through the mail from a source in Pakistan.

title: Steven Crist on Horse Racing; MULTIPLE-CHOICE WEEKEND FOR OGYGIAN
description: Threatening weather and cautious handling continue to cloud Ogygian's plans and, with them, a weekend of major races as well.

title: Mediation Set For RKO Case
description: The Federal Communications Commission has appointed a Government mediator to try to end a 21-year tug-of-war over radio station licenses worth hundreds of millions of dollars held by Gencorp Inc.'s RKO General subsidiary.

title: GORBACHEV GETS VISA APPEAL
description: A Soviet woman has appealed to Mikhail S. Gorbachev to allow her family to emigrate to Israel, where she hopes to donate blood marrow to a brother who is dying of leukemia.

title: Dining Out Guide: Italian, West Side
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. FRANK'S, #431 West 14th Street (243-1349) - **(Feb. 3, 1984) An Italian steakhouse with sawdust on the floor, pressed-tin ceiling and friendly service, Frank's reflects a Manhattan that has almost disappeared. The best of the food is zesty and the portions are large. Tagliarini puttanesca achieves just the right balance, its tomato sauce spiked with capers, olives and anchovies; tilefish or snapper pescador is served with clams, shrimp, mussels and scallops in a spicy tomato sauce; and a recommended special is snapper in Livornaise sauce, with white wine, tomatoes, garlic, capers and black olives. Other options include veal chops, skirt steak, lamb chops and shell steak. Entrees $14 to $22. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.: closed Sundays. LATTANZI, #361 West 46th Street (315-0980) - *(Sept. 14, 1984) A simply decorated dining room with exposed brick walls and small hanging lights provides the backdrop for some hearty Roman food. You might start with carciofi alla Giudea, which are baby artichokes in olive oil and garlic, or a pasta available in appetizer portions of tortellini filled with veal and sausages in a zesty tomato sauce. Main dish options include chicken nuggets in a creamy spiced tomato sauce; veal with mushrooms and sage; osso buco, and shrimp sauteed in wine and garlic.

title: Redistricting Proposal Vetoed in Los Angeles
description: Mayor Tom Bradley today vetoed a redistricting plan approved by the City Council to increase Hispanic representation.

description: Aldo Gucci, the 81-year-old former head of the elegant Gucci Shops Inc., was sentenced to a year in prison yesterday for failing to pay $7 million in personal income taxes.

description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to a delegation of Americans sponsored by the Chautauqua Institution who are scheduled to take part in a ''town meeting'' next week in the Soviet Union. A tape recording was provided by a participant in the session.

title: REGAN SAYS ESTIMATE BOARD SHOULDN'T VOTE ON CONTRACTS
description: The Board of Estimate should be stripped of its power to approve city contracts as one step toward preventing a recurrence of one type of scandal that has rocked the Koch administration this year, the State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: Songs by Marlena Shaw
description: Marlena Shaw, a vocalist formerly with the Count Basie Orchestra, is appearing at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 68th Street) tonight and tomorrow. Show times are 9 P.M. and midnight; there is a $15 music charge and a $10 minimum. Reservations: 873-4100.

title: SAUTER QUITS AS HEAD OF CBS NEWS
description: Van Gordon Sauter, the president of CBS News, resigned yesterday, one day after the founder of CBS, William S. Paley, and Laurence A. Tisch, its largest shareholder, took control of the company.

title: FARM FORUM URGES INTERNATIONAL TALKS TO END RUINOUS TRADE WAR
description: An international forum of farmers and farm specialists today called for negotiations to end a trade war that they said was bringing ruin to growers around the world.

title: Phones Out in Puerto Rico
description: An overnight fire in the Santurce telephone substation knocked out all long-distance telephone service on the island and left 45,000 customers of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company without service today, officials said. There were no reports of injuries. Telephone company officials estimated that the fire caused at least $1 million damage.

title: Drug Crazed
description: What does America think it is doing about drugs? The House orders the military to halt drug traffic into the country within 45 days. Candidates challenge each other to submit to urinalysis and rush to endorse the death penalty for drug dealers. White House aides bicker over how many Federal workers should take drug tests. Congress suddenly wants to throw money at the drug problem. In bills hastily coopered together, House Democrats would commit $1.5 billion for enforcement, treatment and education; Senate Democrats would add $100 million more. No one knows what it will buy.

title: Spelling Stake Up
description: The Cincinnati-based American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have raised their stake in Aaron Spelling Productions to 10.2 percent, or 825,000 shares, from 7.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Lindner group did not amend its previous statement to the S.E.C. that it intends to review its investment in Spelling ''on a continuing basis.''

title: Campeau Rejected
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said its board had rejected a $58-a-share bid from the Campeau Corporation, saying the offer from the Canadian real estate developer was not in the best interests of Allied stockholders. Campeau, which made its offer last week, had given the retail chain until yesterday to respond. A spokesman for Campeau in New York said that the company had no comment on the Allied statement.

description: As one of the earliest Dutch settlements in the city, the Brooklyn neighborhood of Flatbush is the subject of a walking tour tomorrow sponsored by the Brooklyn Historical Society.

description: Hijacking Suspect Held Pakistan said it had arrested a Libyan as a suspect in the planning of the hijacking of a Pan American jetliner last Friday.

title: FILM: DE SICA'S 'CHILDREN,' FROM '42
description: IN 1942, four years before he made ''Shoeshine,'' his first neo-realist success, Vittorio De Sica directed ''The Children Are Watching Us'' (''I Bambini Ci Guardano''), based on a novel by Cesare Giulio Viola, who was also to contribute to ''Shoeshine.''

title: U.S. Troops in Bolivia To Stay Another Month
description: United States troops taking part in an anti-drug campaign aimed at destroying Bolivia's $600-million-a-year cocaine industry will remain for at least another month, the Interior Minister indicated Wednesday.

title: BROADWAY
description: THERE'S no date yet for ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' the Christopher Hampton dramatization of the Choderlos de Laclos novel, but, according to Elizabeth Ireland McCann, the associate producer, spring is the objective. The Royal Shakespeare Company production has been playing to sold-out houses at the Barbican Theater in London and moves to the West End next month.

title: Warner, Bicking Gets Message Unit's Account
description: Protocol Message Management Centers, a new United States subsidiary of Bell Canada set up last March in Reston, Va., has called on Warner, Bicking & Fenwick to handle its advertising budget, which exceeds a million dollars.

title: GUBERNATORIAL DEBATE IN ILLINOIS IS FIRST IN UNUSUAL AND BITTER RACE
description: Gov. James R. Thompson and Adlai E. Stevenson 3d met today in the first debate of a developing bitter campaign to govern the nation's fifth most-populous state.

title: Calling on Carter
description: The Democratic committee choosing a city for the the party's 1988 convention is taking a look at Atlanta this weekend, and one of the local hosts, appropriately enough, will be Jimmy Carter. Tomorrow morning the site-seekers will be get a tour of the former President's library and will be given a brunch there by Mr. Carter, the last Democratic occupant of the White House.

title: CBS MOVES DO NOT MEAN END OF HARD TIMES FOR NETWORKS
description: The departure of Thomas H. Wyman from CBS does not alter the difficult business environment confronting the company. Like its rivals at ABC and NBC, CBS is in for several more years of tough cost-cutting.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
CARDINAL ASSAILS CRITICS ON LIMITS FOR SPEAKERS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, asking ''how much further are the nonsensical allegations going to go on,'' yesterday condemned critics of an archiocesan policy that probibits those who disagree with church teachings from speaking at parish-sponsored events.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Cocaine Charges Stand
description: A motion to dismiss cocaine-selling charges against Tony Robinson, former University of Tennessee quarterback, and Kenneth (B. B.) Cooper was denied by a Tennessee judge in Knoxville. Defense attorneys had argued that the charges should be dropped because undercover agents delayed arresting Robinson and Cooper for two months, from November 1985 to January 1986 solely to gain a tactical advantage.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AUCTIONS of art, books, antiques and collectibles are being held these days virtually anywhere a crowd is inclined to gather. This season, there will be public sales at such unlikely sites as a Fifth Avenue department store, a public school on the Upper East Side, the Puck Building in SoHo and the Big Apple Circus tent at Lincoln Center.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOUSE AND SENATE REACH ACCORD ON MILITARY COMMAND STRUCTURE
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on compromise legislation that would change the command structure of the armed forces by strengthening officers who command joint operations and reducing the authority of the individual services.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1986
description: Markets

title: Litton-Navy Deal
description: The Ingalls Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries bested three competitors on Thursday to win a $402.5 million contract for a second Wasp-class amphibious assault carrier, the Navy announced. The contract also includes undisclosed fixed-price options for a third and fourth ship of the same class in fiscal 1988 and fiscal 1989, the Navy said. Ingalls received the contract for the lead ship in the class in February 1984 but had faced a spirited competition for the second because of a Navy decision to avoid sole-source contracts.

title: COURT ORDERS TUBE IMPLANTED TO FORCE-FEED INVALID PRIEST
description: A judge ordered a Bronx nursing home yesterday to implant surgically a feeding tube into the stomach of an 83-year-old Roman Catholic priest who has been refusing food and medication.

title: Officials Shut Bank in Tulsa
description: Rumors spread by a disgrunted employee apparently sparked a $15 million run on the Central Bank and Trust of Tulsa, forcing regulators to close the bank a day earlier than planned, the state banking commissioner, Robert Empie, said today.

title: Japanese Leader's Term Extended One Year
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's term in office was extended today by a year as the governing Liberal Democratic Party agreed to change rules that would have had him to step down late next month.

title: Santucci Says Talking To Ferraro Was Proper
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday that he had acted properly in meeting with Geraldine A. Ferraro last week to discuss his office's investigation of her husband.

title: SPENDING PLANS CUT BY INDUSTRY
description: United States businesses, bothered by a sluggish economy and tax-law uncertainty, have reduced their investment spending plans by 2.5 percent for this year, the biggest cut since 1982, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Fund Assets Increase
description: Assets of the nation's 363 money market mutual funds increased $2.1 billion, to $235.3 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY IS RULED LIABLE IN SUBWAY KILLING
description: New York's highest court ruled unanimously yesterday that a public transportation authority can be sued if its workers stand by and watch while a passenger is being attacked.

title: PRIMARY IN WASHINGTON COULD DECIDE FALL RACE
description: For Brock Adams, the day of reckoning may come sooner than for most candidates for the United States Senate.

title: The Politics of Race Grows Up
description: The Joint Center for Political Studies, a think tank on issues of concern to blacks, reports that the number of black elected officials in the nation rose to 6,424 last year, an increase of 6.1 percent from 1984.

title: Gerber Head Fights Quaker Oats Move
description: With the food industry undergoing a consolidation, William L. McKinley, chairman and chief executive of the Gerber Products Company, is finding it hard to convince people that what is good for the industry is not good for Gerber.

title: TUMON-FIGHTING CELLS FOUND
description: Scientists have discovered a powerful anticancer cell in the body that they say appears to be 100 times more potent than another used in a promising treatment that unleashes natural cancer-killing cells to attack tumors.

title: JOSEPH GODSON
description: Joseph Godson, a former Foreign Service officer and European coordinator of the Center for Strategic and International Studies at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., died of cancer last Friday at his home in London. He was 73 years old.

title: Tony Kraber Dead at Age 81; An Actor, Singer and Director
description: Tony Kraber, a retired actor, director and singer, died of emphysema Tuesday at his home in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: D.A.R. Reaches Accord With 2 on Racist Issue
description: The Daughters of the American Revolution said today that the organization was ending disciplinary proceedings against two members who had accused it of trying to adopt a racist membership policy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page gave an incorrect date for a businesswomen's reception for President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines. It is to be held Sept. 18; it was not held yesterday.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss The company said its year-ago quarter and 6-month losses were reduced by $27,700 and $56,400, respectively, as a result of the restatement of research and development expenses to reflect a change in accounting for software development costs.

title: US DESIGN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ex-Home Health Aide Seized In Deaths of 2 Bronx Women
description: A 28-year-old former home health care worker has been arrested in connection with the slayings of two Bronx women who had been her patients.

title: Economic Scene; Germans Hold The Rate Line
description: THE West German Government this week continued to resist the pressures of the United States, France and some other Western countries to cut interest rates and adopt other measures to stimulate domestic economic growth and help sustain world recovery. The failure of the Germans to cut rates is considered a key factor in the 86.61-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday.

title: SANDSPORT DATA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TEXSTYRENE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $580,000 for the quarter and $937,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income The company went public on Feb. 19, 1986.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
When He's Good
description: The Bobo Holloman Award: To Doug Cinnella, a right-hander from Seton Hall, who pitched two no-hit victories in his first three decisions for Newark of the New York-Penn League this year and ended the season with a record of 2-6.

title: 2 STARTERS FROM U.S.F.L. HELP CHIEFS TO IMPROVE THEIR LINE
description: The last time the Kansas City Chiefs won more games than they lost was in 1981. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year Joe Delaney, the late running back, set a club record by rushing for 1,121 yards.

title: VANGUARD TECHNOLOGIES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
INTEGRATED COMPUTER GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $43,750 for the latest quarter and $23,500 for the year- ago period.

title: Oxoco Bankruptcy
description: Oxoco Inc., an oil and gas production and exploration concern, said that it had filed in Houston for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: Panayotis Canellopoulos, 83; Was Toppled by Greek Coup
description: Panayotis Canellopoulos, a former Prime Minister who was ousted by a military coup in 1967, died here of a heart attack today. He was 83 years old.

title: Parker Loses Plea
description: A federal judge has refused for a second time to dismiss the breach-of-contract suit filed against Dave Parker by the new owner of the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: U.S. Finds More 'Spy Dust'
description: The State Department said today that Soviet attempts to spy on diplomats by use of a powder known as ''spy dust'' were more widespread than previously believed. The United States reported the discovery of the dust in August 1985, but an investigation last February showed that only five of 650 surfaces tested indicated traces of the dust. Now, in a retesting of 111 samples, 45 showed evidence of the chemical, the State Department said.

title: LIPOSOME CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tip's Namesake
description: For the benefit of those whose recollection of American baseball in the 1888 season has dimmed, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. explains how he got his nickname. In an interview that C-SPAN will broadcast Sunday, the Massachusetts Democrat says it goes back to Edward O'Neill, who played baseball for the St. Louis Browns that season, two dozen years before Mr. O'Neill was born.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss McDermott Inc. is a subsidiary of McDermott International, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NAN KEMPNER breezed into the salmon-colored parlor of Stephen and Jean Kennedy Smith's town house, blew kisses to friends and pronounced the social season a success - so far.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after net of $4,910 from discontinued operations.

title: U.N. CHIEF SAYS U.S. CUTS ARE CRIPPLING
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar accused the United States today of crippling the United Nations by withholding much of its financial contribution this fall.

title: Tax Bill Doesn't Get an A From Universities; Charitable Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: MAAZEL TO HEAD PITTSBURGH ORCHESTRA
description: Lorin Maazel has been appointed music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony, effective Sept. 1.

title: ACCORD IN CONGRESS ON SANCTIONS
description: House Democratic leaders agreed today to accept a Senate version of legislation that would impose tougher new economic sanctions against South Africa. The action means that the legislation could pass the House and reach President Reagan's desk as early as Friday.

title: 5 U.N. SOLDIERS HURT IN CROSSFIRE
description: Israeli troops backed by Lebanese Christian militiamen fought a pitched battle today in southern Lebanon with Shiite Moslem guerrillas. In the crossfire, five soldiers of the United Nations peacekeeping force were wounded.

title: TEST ON MISSILE DEFENSE IS HAILED BY THE MILITARY
description: An experiment in space last week was an elaborate test using several sensors, two rockets and a panoply of supporting equipment to investigate ways of intercepting ballistic missiles rising above the earth, Pentagon officials said today.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
CORETTA KING SEES APARTHEID FOE
description: On the last day of a trip to South Africa marked by political controversy, Coretta Scott King held an emotional hourlong meeting today with Winnie Mandela, one of the most prominent black campaigners against apartheid.

title: Ford Car Leads Design Survey
description: Automotive design enthusiasts have picked an American car, the Ford Taurus, as the one they most likely would buy, according to a survey conducted by Design News magazine.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Bella Abzug's victory in the Democratic primary for a House seat from Westchester County misstated the position of the Black Democrats of Westchester. The group endorsed Oren J. Teicher, not Ms. Abzug.

title: 2 HOMERS FOR KITTLE
description: This was a night of milestones for the Yankees. They did not win any kind of championship, as the Mets are poised to do Friday night, but Don Mattingly, Ron Kittle, Dave Righetti and Rickey Henderson each achieved something significant. For Kittle, the night was doubly significant.

title: Market Place; Stocks' Search For Leadership
description: AS the volatility that has existed in the stock market for some time turned into yesterday's record-smashing one-day drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, nervous investors and analysts searched for fundamental reasons.

title: Fannie Mae Issues
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday sold $200 million of stripped mortgage-backed securities to Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: WARNINGS PRECEDE START OF WORLD TRADE TALKS
description: The largest meeting of trade ministers in history will open in Uruguay on Monday to try to initiate the eighth major effort to liberalize trade since World War II.

title: U.S. APEALS COURT REVERSES CONVICTION IN MICHIGAN SLAYING
description: A Federal appeals court has reversed the conviction of a white foreman at an automobile plant in what prosecutors called the racially motivated slaying of an Asian-American.

title: TIDBIT ALLEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: There are no comparable sales figures for the year-ago periods since Tidbit began operations in September 1985.

title: MARIE B. HART
description: Marie B. Hart, a trustee of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y., died of cancer yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 57 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: ACA JOE EASTERN reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net income

title: Salvage and Archeology Can Share a Berth
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE ACTS TO HOLD SPACE STATION
description: The House voted today to prohibit the space agency from proceeding with development of the $8 billion space station until the agency makes certain design changes on the project.

title: Magazine Facelift
description: Roll Call, the Capitol Hill weekly that Arthur Levitt Jr. bought last April, has moved into its first phase of rejuvenation. The issue that appeared this week was, at 16 pages, twice as big as its predecessors, and used a new type face and four-column format, a ''listing'' feature of Congressional and neighborhood events on Capitol Hill, a book review page and a ''Board of Education'' column.

title: FOR MCNEIL, A SHORTENED YEAR AGAIN
description: The injuries have come with such frequency that Freeman McNeil, the 27-year-old Pro Bowl runner, has yet to complete a 16-game season for the Jets.

title: DANZIG CONNECTION UPSETS OGYGIAN
description: Ogygian's bubble burst suddenly tonight when the star 3-year-old finished a dull third, beaten four lengths by Danzig Connection and Broad Brush in the $300,000 Pegasus Handicap at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''Your Money'' column in Business Day last Saturday misstated the tax rate on gifts from grandparents to children below age 14 under the new tax bill. All of a child's unearned income beyond $1,000, regardless of the source, would be taxed at the maximum rate of the child's parents, according to the summary of the Congressional conference agreement.

title:
Patents;
Calculator Warns on Heat Stress
description: AN engineer with Research Associates of Washington was granted a patent this week for a heat stress calculator for use by weather forecasters, athletes and others.

title: Graphic Gift
description: Neighbors seeking takeout food, onlookers seeking involvement, skateboarders seeking thrills and strollers seeking fresh air congregated around a man on a ladder on the southeastern corner of Columbus Avenue and 70th Street on a recent evening.

title: BEENE AND KLEIN: RESORT WEAR TAKES ON A NEW DIMENSION
description: Calvin Klein and Geoffrey Beene are often seen as polar opposites in the world of expensive ready-to-wear American fashion. ''Simplicity is the ultimate luxury,'' says Mr. Klein. Mr. Beene is a creator of extravagant styles, which he describes as '' couture level.'' Thus, their holiday collections are as different as night and day. Yet both agree that the so-called ''holiday,'' ''resort'' or ''cruise'' season has taken on a new dimension, allowing them a freedom that tied-to-temperature fall and spring clothes cannot.

title: Squeri Leads Rout by Hofstra
description: Alan Squeri threw five touchdown passes, the longest for 77 yards to Chris Facas on the second play of the game, to lead Hofstra over Iona, 49-0, last night.

title: VOLUME CLIMBS TO A RECORD LEVEL; Wide Use of Computers to Set Trading Pattern Contributed to Slide
description: The stock market's plunge this week was as much a product of computer technology and Wall Street inventiveness as it was a reflection of new worries over the economy.

title:
Patents;
Safer Prison Utensil
description: The altering of forks, dinner knives and spoons to form sharp weapons is recognized as a problem in correctional institutions. Jim Mickelson and Barbara L. Winfield of Santa Fe, N.M., were awarded patent No. 4,610,087 this week for a plastic utensil with a slotted handle that is too weak to permit conversion to a weapon. The patent is assigned to the State of New Mexico.

title: KICKBACK BILL PASSED
description: The Senate passed without debate today legislation that would toughen statutes forbidding kickbacks by military contractors and other companies doing business with the Government.

title: DANCE: VANAVER CARAVAN
description: Are people more interesting because of the things that make them similar or because of the things that make them different? That question was prompted by the New York premiere of ''Full Circle,'' which the Vanaver Caravan offered Thursday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church as the first attraction of this season's Riverside Dance Festival.

title: ENRAGED CABBIE RUNS DOWN 9 NEAR A HOSPITAL
description: A gypsy-cab driver in Brooklyn, apparently angered by a fare dispute with his passengers, used his car as a ram yesterday and struck and injured nine people on the sidewalk outside the Kings County Hospital in Flatbush, the police said.

title: DANILOFF OUT OF JAIL: DRAWN BUT JUBILANT
description: Moments after his release from Lefortovo Prison this evening, Nicholas S. Daniloff clambered out of a United States Embassy car and danced for a moment in the street.

title: 15TH GAME IN MATCH IS A DRAW
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, agreed to a draw today after 29 moves in the 15th game of their title match.

title: Who May Speak to Catholics
description: Once again, New York's Governor Cuomo and John Cardinal O'Connor are locked in dubious battle. Ostensibly it concerns a directive that the parishes of the New York Archdiocese not invite speakers who disagree with church teachings. Actually, it is a renewal of their argument about how fervently Catholics in public office must oppose abortion.

title: Peru Rebels Kill 2 Policemen
description: A hit squad of a Maoist guerrilla group, the Shining Path, ambushed and fatally shot two policemen Thursday who were guarding power pylons on a hill overlooking Lima, the police said today. They said the rebels, hiding behind an embankment, opened fire at dusk. The police have accused the guerrillas of toppling more than 450 power pylons since 1982, blacking out the capital at least 15 times.

title: DALFORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the net income for the year-ago quarter and 6-month periods benefited by $4,150,000, or 41 cents a share, and $4,635,000, or 46 cents a share, respectively, from extraordinary income tax credits net of minority interests related to the net losses incurred by Braniff Inc. through Jan. 31, 1985.

title: Bond Prices End With Slight Gain
description: With wild price gyrations and heavy volume, tempestuous trading in the bond markets continued yesterday, ending with a modest gain in prices.

title: Farming Concessions Demanded by French
description: The French trade minister, Michel Noir, demanded far-reaching agricultural concessions today from the United States, Canada and other big farming nations.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $1,192.

title: WHITE SOX NIP ANGELS IN 10TH
description: Harold Baines's one-out, 10th-inning single over a drawn-in outfield scored Daryl Boston with the winning run tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 3-2 victory over the California Angels.

title: Age of Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JETS ARE UNDONE BY BIG PLAYS
description: Can hardened football players become demoralized when their teammates suffer injury?

title: INSPECTORS FIND 66 TAXI DRIVERS REFUSING TRIPS
description: Nearly one of five medallion taxicabs hailed in a recent undercover operation refused to take passengers from Manhattan to requested destinations around the city, the chairman of the city's taxi commission said yesterday.

title: GUNMEN SEIZE ANOTHER AMERICAN IN WEST BEIRUT
description: Another American, the second this week, was kidnapped at gunpoint in Moslem West Beirut today.

title: How Secret Should a Space Test Be?
description: In the capital, it seems, yesterday's secret information can become today's officially sanctioned news.

title: A COY ROBERTSON IS PIONEERING ERA OF SATELLITE POLITICS
description: Next Wednesday evening, in response to ''a personal letter'' from the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, thousands of evangelical Christians are expected to flow into hundreds of rental halls across America.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. The General Electric Company plans to sell 75 percent of its stake in the RCA Corporation's RCA/Ariola record unit to Bertelsmann A. G., a West German concern that owns the remaining 25 percent. The dog has been a symbol on phonograph records since 1901 when the Victor Talking Machine Company was founded. 2. After the first Egyptian-Israeli summit meeting in five years, President Hosni Mubarak announced that Egypt would return its Ambassador to Israel. Taba is a 700-yard stretch of beach on the border between Egypt and Israel 3. It is the second race between two women for a seat in the Senate. 4. Mayor Koch referred of any one of three informers who brought allegations of corruption at the Parking Violations Bureau to the City Department of Investigation in 1982 and 1983, which botched the investigations. 5. Mementos left at the Vietnam Memorial in Washington. 6. Pakistan. Poland. 7. Fifth. 8. Boston. Leading businesses have organized a $6 million program that will guarantee financial aid to all graduates of the city's public high schools who get into college and then provide them with jobs when they finish their education. 9. 240. 10. Mark Green, a consumer advocate and writer, was referring to his victory over John S. Dyson, who spent $6 million on the campaign for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate. The Mayor said he would not endorse Mr. Green. 11. The statue of Hadrian is being vacuumed for the opening of an upcoming exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 12.

title: G.M. PLANS 1987 PRICE RISE OF 2.6%
description: The General Motors Corporation will raise prices of its 1987 passenger cars by an average of 2.6 percent over this year's models, the company said today.

title: Twins Dismiss Miller
description: The Minnesota Twins dismissed Manager Ray Miller yesterday, one day after the club, last in the American League West, broke a five-game losing streak. The Twins appointed Tom Kelly, their third-base coach, as interim manager for the remaining weeks of the season.

title: IN ELECTION CAMPAIGNS, MONEY TALKS BUT IT ISN'T ALWAYS HEARD
description: At first glance, money did not talk as loudly as usual in Tuesday's Democratic primaries. But on closer examination, it has spoken and will continue to be heard in the general election campaign in New York in the next seven weeks.

title: REAGAN URGES ROLE FOR TEACHERS
description: Saying that ''education is too vital'' to be ''corrupted by drugs,'' President Reagan urged teachers today ''to take no drugs themselves and to do the best they can to keep all drugs out of schools.''

title: College Games at a Glance
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. LOCAL TEAMS Army (0-0) vs. Syracuse (0-1) First Syracuse trip to Army since 1970, when a brawl erupted. (TV - MSG). Fordham (0-0) vs. Worcester Tech (1-0) Larry Glueck begins his first season as coach of the Rams.

title: SALVAGE AND ARCHELOLOGY CAN SHARE A BERTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Adrift in Nicaragua
description: THE STARS AT NOON. By Denis Johnson. 181 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Nicaraguan Hears Charges in Spy Case
description: A Nicaraguan businessman has gone on trial charged with spying for the Central Intelligence Agency, the official newspaper Barricada said today.

title: Genentech Sued on Patent
description: Genentech Inc. said today that a suit had been filed against the company in Federal District Court here by the Hormone Research Foundation and its licensee, Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. of Nutley, N.J. The suit charges that Genentech's manufacture and sale of Protropin human growth hormone infringed a patent held by the foundation since 1974 and licensed to Hoffmann-La Roche in December 1982.

title:
CNSUMER SATURDAY;
GENTLER AEROBIC EXERCISES
description: AS fall approaches, for many people summer sports are giving way to running and aerobic dancing.
