That's fine for the lucky few who do not suffer from weak knees, ankles, a bad back or other problems that rule out running and jumping. For the estimated 70 to 80 percent of Americans who are not so lucky, there are gentler alternatives.

title: MORE FAMILIES SEEK CITY SHELTERS
description: The number of homeless families in the city's emergency shelters has grown by 53 percent in the last two and a half months, and city officials say they do not know why.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,887,000 for the quarter and $2,366,000 for the 6 months and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,764,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $582,000 for the quarter and $381,000 for the 6 months.

title: CITY AIDE OFFERS PLAN TO CONVERT S.R.O. HOUSING
description: The Koch administration has proposed allowing the conversion of the city's 52,053 single-room-occupancy hotel and rooming house apartments into luxury housing by charging developers a fee of $35,000 per unit.

title: Early Retirement Is Offered by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, moving to cut its expenses in the midst of a prolonged computer slump, yesterday doubled the number of its employees eligible for retirement.

title: 'QUEENIE PIE' OFFERS 'NEW' ELLINGTON
description: Duke Ellington called ''Queenie Pie,'' a music-theater work he composed between 1971 and 1974, a ''street opera.'' He died in 1974, leaving ''Queenie Pie'' unfinished, but a team of former Ellington collaborators has been working to complete it for a world premiere on Thursday at the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia.

title: Pizza Inn Pact
description: Pizza Inn Inc., said that it had signed a definitive merger agreement with a group headed by its chairman, president and major stockholder, F.J. Spillman. The investor group, which holds 34 percent of outstanding stock, is offering $12 a share in cash, or $26 million, for the stock it does not already control. It had originally offered $11 a share in July.

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,035,000 and $1,105,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,947,000 for the quarter and $2,748,000 for the year.

title: Small Investors And Dow's Fall
description: FOR small investors nervously watching the tumult on Wall Street over the last two days and wondering what, if anything, they can do to protect their holdings, the first advice from many strategists and brokers is: Don't panic.

title: Reversal by Steinbrenner
description: Increasingly disturbed by critical comments about his role in the Yankees' personnel moves this year, George Steinbrenner decided he would gather, by invitation only, a small group of reporters in his Yankee Stadium office yesterday to clear the air. Manager Lou Piniella and the front-office executives, Clyde King and Woody Woodward, would be present to acknowledge whose decisions prompted what player moves.

title: REHNQUIST OPPONENTS WARN THAT CONFIRMATION WOULD BE DIVISIVE
description: Senate opponents of the nomination of William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States warned today that his confirmation would divide the country and threaten progress on civil rights.

title: Solidarity Activist Freed In Government Amnesty
description: A leading Solidarity activist, Zbigniew Bujak, was freed from prison today under an amnesty for hundreds of political prisoners.

title: Cubs Put Cey on Block
description: As part of a major off-season shake-up designed to rid the Chicago Cubs of many of their older players, the team will attempt to trade Ron Cey, the 38-year-old third baseman, and if that fails, he will be given his release.

title: Indonesia Devalues 31%
description: Indonesia has devalued its currency by 31 percent, to 1,644 rupiahs per dollar, to prevent an economic collapse after the drop in the price of oil, the mainstay of the country's economy. Finance Minister Radius Prawiro, in a televised announcement today, said the step had been taken because ''we don't know when the oil prices will stop falling.''

title: Bargaining for Bodies With Moscow
description: Nicholas Daniloff remains a hostage in Moscow and the United States has been forced for the moment to equate his status with that of an accused Soviet spy in New York. Their simultaneous release from jail, under identical terms, so far ratifies an obvious Soviet extortion. But at least Mr. Daniloff is relieved of grueling daily interrogations and life in a tiny cell. This is not the end of an acceptable deal, but it is an acceptable beginning.

title: TRIO-TECH INTL reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $93,000 for the quarter and $303,000 for the year.

title: British Inflation Stable
description: Britain's annual inflation rate remained unchanged at 2.4 percent in August, according to official figures. It was the eighth consecutive month there had been no increase, and the annual rate is still at its lowest level for nearly 20 years.

title: KEY RATES
Learning to Get Along With the Nuclear Genie
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page, about a memorial service for W. Averell Harriman next Tuesday, misstated the date of his death. It was July 26.

title: BUCKNER DRIVES IN 4 AS RED SOX WIN
description: Life in a pennant race is treating the Boston Red Sox so well that they can afford to have a .350 hitter sacrifice. But then, the bunt by Wade Boggs was typical of the successful moves the Red Sox have made this season.

title: WIDESPREAD PHONE FAILURE DISRUPTS PUERTO RICAN LIFE
description: Puerto Rico remained cut off from virtually all telephone communications with the rest of the world today as technicians labored to replace vital equipment damaged by a fire in a key plant Wednesday night.

title: No Chain Saws to Nicaragua
description: Oxfam America, a private relief agency, was given permission last year to send seeds and agricultural implements to Nicaragua. This was possible because ''humanitarian'' aid is exempted from a United States trade embargo against the Sandinista regime. But last week, a similar application was rejected by the State Department because ''such transactions are inconsistent with current United States foreign policy.'' The deeper inconsistency is the Administration's double standard regarding the slippery word ''humanitarian.''

title: BEHIND SPY ARREST OF RUSSIAN, CONCERN OVER MISUSE OF U.N.
description: The espionage arrest of a Soviet employee of the United Nations was carried out for a number of reasons, including a decision to confront the Soviet Union over the use of the United Nations for spying, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RABBIS INVITE BISHOP TO ADDRESS CONGREGATION
description: Three Orthodox rabbis, praising Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe for his criticism of Governor Cuomo's stand on abortion, invited the bishop yesterday to speak before an Orthodox congregation on the subject of ''family values,'' including abortion.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes tax credits of $105,000 for the quarter and $153,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $200,000 and $951,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $403,000 for the quarter and $2,367,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also includes income from discontinued operations of $1,620,000.

title: Air Force Threatens Hughes
description: The Air Force is prepared to begin withholding monthly contract payments from the Hughes Aircraft Company because of continuing late deliveries of the Phoenix air-to-air missile, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Rehnquist's Civil Rights View Spurs Heckling at Indiana U.
description: Hecklers protesting Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist's stance on civil rights disrupted a speech by him Friday at Indiana University.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
description: The company said its year-ago first quarter results were reduced by $3,835,000, or 18 cents a share, because of expenses related to the company's discontinuation of a computer product line. The latest quarter included 12 weeks, compared with 13 weeks for the year-ago period.

title: DR. HENRY SMYTH, EX-MEMBER OF ATOM PANEL
description: Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth, a physicist who played an important role in the development of the atomic bomb and later served on the Atomic Energy Commission, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 88 years old.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: FIRE RUINED TERMINUS OF CABLE FROM FLORIDA
description: The telephone equipment damaged by fire in Puerto Rico this week includes the end of a large cable that runs from Jacksonville, Fla., to San Juan, associated electronic devices to regulate the signal, and power converters to supply the right kind of electricity.

title: Freeport Offer For Petro-Lewis
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc. said Kidder, Peabody & Company had completed firm arrangements for up to $600 million in financing on terms that would allow it to complete its tender offer for all of the Petro-Lewis Corporation and American Royalty Trust Securities and retire existing bank debt.

title: The Values At Maryland
description: Even though the grand jury investigating the death of Len Bias has not concluded its work, there is some related business at the University of Maryland that needs prompt attention: housecleaning in the athletic department.

title: Welcome for Women In Sanitation Dept.
description: Two women became sanitation workers yesterday, the first in the 105-year history of the department. After completing their training, the women - Anne Pabon, 30 years old, of Brooklyn, and Carlen Sanderson, 22, of Laurelton, Queens - were sworn in at a ceremony at Police Headquarters.

title: Presidential Author
description: It is not unknown for a head of government to be a noted writer (there was Winston Churchill, of course, and a Canadian Governor General, John Buchan, Lord Tweedsmuir, wrote ''The 39 Steps'' and other spy thrillers), but it is rare enough. So if President Jose Sarney of Brazil is seen scribbling on his visit to Washington, it may just as easily be pluses and minuses about his country's enormous debt as the backround notes for his next tale.

title: Irish Prepare to Open Against Michigan
description: Outside the brick walls of Notre Dame Stadium, the traffic crept along Juniper Road. Visitors returned to the campus, purchased their souvenir programs and headed toward the bookstore, continuing a ritual that has extended through many, many September Saturdays.

title: LAROUCHE ORDERED TO DISCLOSE FUNDS
description: A Federal district judge ordered the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. today to disclose ''who pays for the pork chop'' and the rest of his food, shelter, clothing and other expenses of daily life.

title: How to Improve Supreme Court Nominations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Flute Recital
description: The flutist Andrea Griminelli will make his New York recital debut tonight at 7:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: RUSSIAN PHYSICIST AND U.S. NEWSMAN FREED FROM JAIL
description: The United States and the Soviet Union today freed from jail a Soviet physicist in New York and an American journalist in Moscow to the custody of their respective embassies pending their trials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There can be no question of equating the cases of Mr. Daniloff and Zakharov. Mr. Daniloff is not a spy.

title: H.M.O. RATES FOR WOMEN ARE CHALLENGED
description: When a 35-year-old Minnesota piano teacher went to join a health maintenance organization this summer, she found the prepaid health plans a strain on her budget. But had she been a man, she said, she could have afforded any one of them easily. The cost would have been roughly a third less.

title: DECISION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Finance Aides Set Meeting
description: Finance ministers of the five leading industrial nations will meet Sept. 26 to formulate concrete measures for improving the coordination of their economic policies, United States and other monetary sources said totoday.

title: 14 Texas Air Slots Bought by Pan Am
description: The Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it had sold additional flight slots to Pan American World Airways for $9.8 million. The sale would make it possible for Pan Am to begin an East Coast shuttle service that would be competitive in frequency of flights with the Eastern Air Lines shuttle service.

title: A Rameau Ballet
description: Concert Royal, under the direction of James Richman and the New York Baroque Dance Company, led by the choreographers Catherine Turocy and Ann Jacoby, will present Rameau's ballet ''Les Fetes d'Hebe'' at the Hunter College Playhouse, on 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: Stop Presses
description: The Food and Drug Administration has done something that verges on the modestly spectacular. It has reduced the price of something, the FDA Consumer, a 10-times-a-year magazine it publishes for the general public.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: RETAIL SLAES UP BY 0.8%
description: Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest advance in four months, as strong sales at department stores and auto dealerships offset weakness elsewhere, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SUN SHINES AS MICHIGAN WATERS RISE
description: Swollen rivers and rampant flooding continued to disrupt life today in the small farm towns and resort villages along the Lake Michigan shore after three days of record rains.

title: PRESIDENT IS EXPECTED TO VETO BILL
description: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would impose new economic sanctions on South Africa, including a ban on all new American investment. The vote was 308 to 77. Since the Senate adopted an identical measure last month, the bill now goes directly to President Reagan's desk.

title: KOCH URGES CLERGY TO LOBBY ON DRUGS
description: In an attempt to foster what he called ''clergy pressure'' on the legislative process in the fight against drugs, Mayor Koch said today that he was inviting more than 1,000 leaders of New York City's religious community to Gracie Mansion on Sunday, Sept. 21, to urge them to lobby the Senate leadership.

title: F.A.A. REPORTS 13 OF 34 TOOK DRUGS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had found that 13 of 34 air traffic controllers under investigation had used drugs off duty. The agency said it had given them the choice of entering rehabilitation programs or being dismissed.

title: AFTER LONG LAPSE, GOODYEAR BIDS TO BUILD AIRSHIPS
description: With a familiar blimp moored in the background, officials of the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation said today that they would be bidding to get back into commercial airship production at this historic location.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. must perform additional research on its Tolrestat Diabetes Treatment before a Federal Food and Drug Administration Advisory Committee can recommend its approval, the committee said.

title: How Not to Protect Communications
description: The Senate should avoid repeating the mistake made by the House when it unanimously passed the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. Purportedly a benign updating of the 1968 Federal wiretap law designed to guarantee privacy in the electronic age, the bill actually promotes the cellular telephone industry at the expense of the public good.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. Nipper has a new master. Explain. 2. ''I think it is now time to send the Ambassador,'' said a participant after a meeting that was salvaged by an agreement on Taba. What meeting was it, who made the remark and what is Taba? 3. The race for the United States Senate seat in Maryland is only the second in American history with a distinguishing characteristic. Explain. 4. ''Had he brought those charges to me, you can be sure it would not have been an Inspector Clouseau operation.'' Who made this remark and to what was he referring? 5. Bracelets, hats and a dollar bill with an unsigned note - ''I've owed you this for years'' - are among the mementos that the Park Service is collecting. What mementos are they? 6. One foreign government released an opposition leader who had been imprisoned for three and a half weeks, and another foreign government said it would free all 225 prisoners being held for their political views and activities. What governments are they? 7. When Ivan Lendl, the men's singles tennis champion, appeared in the United States Open final, it was his (second/fifth/seventh) consecutive appearance in the championship. 8. ''This is an incentive for public school students from the inner city to go to college and stay in it,'' said a business executive. To what city and what incentive was he referring? 9.

title: ISRAEL RAIDS BOAT OFF LEBANON
description: Israeli fighter-bombers strafed a boat today off this southern port, and the police said four civilians were wounded. Israel's military command said the boat belonged to guerrillas.

title: STOCKS FALL ON FOREIGN EXCHANGES
description: Responding to Thursday's record-setting selloff on Wall Street, share prices fell sharply on stock exchanges around the world yesterday in a vivid demonstration of how interdependent global financial markets have become.

title: Foreclosures Up in Spring
description: Homeowners entered foreclosure proceedings at a slightly faster rate from April through June than they had during the first three months of the year, a trade association said.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL END TALKS AT ODDS
description: President Hosni Mubarak and Prime Minister Shimon Peres ended the first Egyptian-Israeli summit meeting in five years today without resolving their basic differences over the region's central issue, the Palestinian question.

title: 'ALL THE PEOPLE ARE WITH ME,' CHILEAN LEADER SAYS
description: President Augusto Pinochet, speaking in an interview less than a week after he survived an assassination attempt, asserted today that ''all the people are with me.''

title: China-Fiat Pact
description: The Iveco Company of the Italian Fiat Group and China's Nanking Automobile Plant have signed a contract to produce 60,000 light trucks in China using technology from Iveco, the official New China News Agency said.

title: Clashing Opinions On Failure Of Imports
description: The House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations is known for its aggressive questioning of witnesses.

title: BAGHDAD SAYS IRANIAN MISSILE KILLED 21 CIVILIANS
description: A long-range Iranian missile struck a residential area in downtown Baghdad early today, killing 21 civilians and wounding 81, 41 of them seriously, an official Iraqi statement said.

title: Synthesizer Concert
description: Isao Tomita, the Japanese avant-garde synthesizer player, will present a free concert, entitled ''Back to the Earth,'' at Battery Park tonight at 8 o'clock. The audio-visual effects will include a special three-dimensional ''sound cloud'' projected from boats and barges in the harbor and airborne helicopters in the vicinity. The rain date is tomorrow at the same time.

title: FARADYNE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
President to Leave Columbia Pictures
description: David Puttnam, who took over as chairman and chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures 12 days ago, today confirmed reports that Steve Sohmer, the president and chief operating officer, would be leaving the company. Mr. Puttnam also confirmed ''discussions'' with David Picker, a former top executive at United Artists and Paramount, who is almost certain to replace Mr. Sohmer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1986
description: International

title: CUOMO AND CARDINAL TRADE QUIPS
description: After a week of indirectly trading criticism, Governor Cuomo and John Cardinal O'Connor met face to face at a banquet last night, exchanging quips but failing to address the key differences between them.

title: Bo Jackson Batting .400
description: Bo Jackson is finally producing the kind of numbers that befit an athlete with enough confidence in his baseball ability to spurn a reported $7.6 million offer from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to play pro football. Opting instead for a reported three-year contract worth $1.06 million with the Kansas City Royals, the Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn at first had rough going with Memphis of the Class AA Southern League, batting only .089 after 45 times at bat as a professional.

title: Take Them Out to the Ball Game (With Helmets)
description: ''See that guy?'' said Edward McKechnie, pointing to a fellow Red Sox fan entering Yankee Stadium last night, a man looking rather like a walking Red Sox souvenir stand, with a pennant, baseball cap and T-shirt. ''He's history.'' Mr. McKechnie believes - ''absolutely!'' - in supporting his beloved Red Sox when they come to New York, but in a safe and sane manner. ''The problem,'' he said before his team's 7-2 victory, ''is that the Red Sox are big winners this year and these fans just coming out of the closet don't know they have to take precautions at Yankee Stadium. ''

title: Hostile Tender Offer Begun for Allied
description: The Campeau Corporation, rebuffed in its friendly offer to acquire the Allied Stores Corporation, began a hostile tender offer today at $58 a share.

title: MUSIC: ROBERTA RUST, PIANIST
description: Roberta Rust, a pianist from Long Island who played in concerts in South America earlier this year under the auspices of the United States Information Agency, gave a recital at Merkin Hall on Wednesday night. Her program consisted of works by Beethoven, Debussy, Berg, Bartok, Villa-Lobos and Almeida Prado.

title: Stake in Viacom Raised to 8.7%
description: An investment group, led by National Amusements Inc. and its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, has raised its stake in Viacom International Inc. to 8.7 percent, or about 3 million shares, from 6.4 percent. Viacom has been the subject of sporadic takeover speculation in the last year, and the New York-based cable company also survived a hostile bid from the New York investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the discovery of anticancer cells called tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes misstated a resulting action by the National Cancer Institute. It designated six medical centers to conduct human trials of a cancer treatment based on previously discovered anticancer cells, called lymphokine-activated killers.

title: BEI HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the latest quarter was primarily the result of one-time merger-related expenses and a previously reported $11.5 million writedown on the book value of certain real estate. The company also said it incurred a $1,731,000 of one-time merger-related expenses and a gain of $575,000 for the sale of its 55 percent ownership position in Bank Earnings Systems Inc.

title: Anthony M. Mazzucca Jr. Weds Cynthia Ann Bishop
description: Cynthia Ann Bishop, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bishop of Falmouth, Mass., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Anthony Michael Mazzucca Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mazzucca of Westfield and Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: FOR SHCHARANSKY IN PARIS, EMBRACES AND DOUBTS
description: Amid a round of Russian bear hugs, Anatoly Shcharansky met one night this week with a small group of French intellectuals and fellow former Soviet dissidents, some of whom he had not seen since his arrest in Moscow nine years ago.

title: CONTROL DATA UNIT GETS WEILL
description: After two unsuccessful campaigns to become the head of a major company, Sanford I. Weill, former president of the American Express Company, will become chairman and chief executive of one of the nation's biggest consumer finance companies under a tentative agreement announced yesterday.

title: SO WHAT IF IT'S MADE IN AMERICA
description: Bob Hope, Carol Channing, Sammy Davis Jr. and other celebrities have television spots in which they point with pride to products ''Made in the U.S.A.'' Here is an unabashed attempt to convince consumers to buy products made at home. The appeal is old-fashioned flag-waving. To my astonishment, there is evidence that it works. A summer survey found that 80 percent of the respondents said they had viewed the commercial, and one-third of these people went on to buy American-made garments.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: Among the most severe traffic trouble spots facing motorists this weekend in the metropolitan region, according to the city Department of Transportation, are these:

title: Troubled CBS Program Has a Surprise Visitor
description: David Corvo, the executive producer of the ''CBS Morning News,'' was sitting in the darkened control room during yesterday's program when someone came up from behind and tapped him on the shoulder. ''Hello,'' the visitor said, ''I'm Larry Tisch, it's nice to meet you.''

title: NAKASONE TO OFFER PLAN ON DOMESTIC SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone told Parliament today that he would soon submit a major spending program to stimulate Japan's lethargic economy and encourage greater domestic demand.

title: Thatcher Said To Back Oslo
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain wound up her official two-day visit to Norway today by tacitly approving Norway's preliminary 10 percent oil export cut for November and October, her host and colleague, Gro Harlem Brundtland, told reporters.

title: Salvador Rebels Arrive In Panama for Talks
description: Salvadoran rebel leaders arrived here today to meet with Salvadoran Government officials on an agenda for peace talks. The rebels predicted difficulty in reaching an agenda, and the Government urged the rebels to abandon their armed struggle.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revenue represents gross revenue.

title: GIANTS TEST ANOTHER KICKER
description: The Giants' kicking derby seems about to acquire a new member. Raul Allegre, who kicked for the Colts in Baltimore and Indianapolis the last three years, had a tryout with the Giants today and will probably kick for them Sunday against the San Diego Chargers in Giants Stadium.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENTT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Holiday's Defense Move
description: The Holiday Corporation adopted a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover provision today, but the company said the action had nothing to do with the recent purchase of some of its stock by the New York developer Donald Trump. A spokesman said the board began working on the stock plan before published reports that Mr. Trump planned to seek a controlling interest in Holiday.

title: MANILA WINS RULING IN JERSEY ON MARCOS ESTATE AND CASH
description: In the first court ruling on the disposition of property and funds amassed in the United States by Ferdinand E. Marcos, a superior court judge today ordered an estate valued at $1 million and $480,000 in cash turned over to the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: AIDE IN JUSTICE DEPT. HOLDS THAT BRENNAN HAS 'RADICAL' VIEWS
description: The Assistant Attorney General for civil rights today denounced an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, William J. Brennan Jr., on the ground that he was trying to achieve ''a radically egalitarian society.''

title: MOTHER OF 12 IS SENT TO JAIL OVER PROTEST
description: A peace activist packer her belongings and said goodbye to her 12 children today before heading to prison to begin serving an eight-year sentence for damaging missile equipment at an Air Force base.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER, 92
description: Jacques-Henri Lartigue, one of the most celebrated photographers of the century, died yesterday in a hospital in Nice, on the French Riviera, hospital officials said. He was 92 years old and had homes outside Nice and in Paris.

title: SOVIET NOT PREPARED TO CUT U.N. STAFF, ENVOY SAYS
description: The Soviet Union is not prepared to comply with a Reagan Administration order to reduce the size of its mission to the United Nations by the beginning of next month, the chief Soviet delegate said today.

title: TV: READING PROMOTED ON 'MR. HYDE'
description: Cackling and creating chaos, Mr. Hyde, that classic among weird creatures, enlists in a worthy cause -reading - today in the season premiere of ''ABC Weekend Specials,'' on Channel 7 in the half-hour beginning at noon.

title: Veto of Districting Plan In Los Angeles Upset
description: Mayor Tom Bradley vetoed the city's latest redistricting plan Thursday, but the City Council overrode his veto today by a vote of 11 to 3.

title: DYNATEM INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $10,000.

title: DELTA COMPUTEC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes the results of Computer Sales & Service Corp. acquired in May.

title: Rehnquist Is Given Ticket for Speeding
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court, nominated by President Reagan to be Chief Justice of the United States, was given a ticket for speeding and two other traffic violations last week, the police said today.

title: 2 SENATORS WELCOME HOUSE DRUG BILL
description: The Republican and Democratic leaders of the Senate today endorsed some of the most controversial elements of the $2 billion antidrug bill approved overwhelmingly in the House Thursday night.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Boston Celtics have signed Fred Roberts, a veteran free agent, to an offer sheet whose details were not announced.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM RUSSIA Edvard Radzinsky is a Russian playwright whose trilogy about intellectuals and their travails in society has been playing in Soviet theater repertory for a decade, and at last the final third of the work is being presented onstage in New York, at the Jean Cocteau Repertory's Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery, at Second Street (677-0060).

title: SOME SEIZED BY PRETORIA SENT TO 'YOUTH CENTERS'
description: Government officials said today that some young black detainees were being sent to special ''youth centers'' for ''reorientation'' before being released.

title: CBS Shifts Raise F.C.C. Issue
description: The appointment of the two largest CBS shareholders, Laurence A. Tisch and William S. Paley, to interim top management positions at the communications giant has raised the possibility of regulatory problems with the Federal Communications Commission.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
7 Sect Members Guilty In Death of Boy, 12
description: The leader of the House of Judah religious sect and six subordinates were convicted today of causing a boy's death.

title: SCIENCE INSPIRES HOCKNEY
description: David Hockney was talking about fractals - a new theory of geometry in which physical objects, like mountains or clouds, are conceived to be made of infinitely many smaller and smaller identical shapes.

title: Administration Sees No Reason to Be Concerned
description: Despite a record two-day plunge in stock prices, officials of the Reagan Administration said today that they saw no reason to be concerned.

title: T.W.A.-Ozark Merger Is Approved
description: The Department of Transportation today announced approval of the proposed merger of Ozark Airlines into Trans World Airlines, creating the nation's sixth largest commercial air carrier.

title: World Championship Play Gets Under Way in Florida
description: Some 1,700 players from 56 countries are converging on the Sheraton Hotel here eager to battle for the next 15 days in the world championships. The world mixed pair championship, a two-day event, begins Saturday and will be followed by the world team championship and the world open pair and women's pair championship.

title: The Color Purple in Vegetables
description: Americans constantly seek change. We are enthralled with the new, bored with the old, sometimes within a matter of months, even weeks. Now that we have discovered that tomatoes come in other colors besides red, that peppers are available in every rainbow color except blue, we are not satisfied with the traditional. And thanks to the specialty crop farmer, we don't have to be.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $45,594, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $104,147, or 13 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: INNOVATIVE ACCORD FOR MET OPERA ORCHESTRA
description: The Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra have reached a contract settlement that guarantees labor peace through the 1989-90 season and includes a significant and potentially influential change in the way pension eligibility is calculated.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 3:20 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 3:15 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 3:15 P.M.) METS VS. PHILLIES, at Philadelphia, 7:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7 P.M.) BRAVES VS. GIANTS, at San Francisco, 4:05 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) PADRES VS. ASTROS, at San Diego, 10:05 P.M. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 10:05 P.M.) FOOTBALL COLLEGES: California at Boston College (Television - Channel 11 and USA, noon); Mississippi State at Tennessee (Television - WTBS, 12:30 P.M.); Worcester Polytechnic Institute at Fordham (Radio -WFUV, 90.7; 1 P.M.); Rutgers at Kentucky (Radio - WCTC, 1450; WMCA, 570; WRSU, 88.7; 1:30 P.M.); Syracuse at Army (Television - MSG, 2 P.M., Radio - WNYE, 91.5; 2 P.M.); Ohio State at Washington (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.); Michigan at Notre Dame (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.). Night Games: Illinois at Southern Cal (Television - WTBS, 7 P.M.); Texas A&M at Louisiana State (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Michigan State at Arizona State (Television - WTBS, 10:15 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Bank of Boston Classic, Pleasant Valley Country Club, Sutton, Mass. LPGA TOUR: Safeco Classic, Meridian Valley Country Club, Seattle SENIOR PGA TOUR: United Virginia Bank Seniors, Heritage Country Club, Manakin-Sabot, Va.

title: Iraq Did Not Enter Willingly Into the Long Gulf War With Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Tardy Player Penalized
description: Derrick Fenner, the star North Carolina running back, missed the team plane and will not play in the Tar Heels' game at Kansas today.

title: PARIS BLAST, 2D IN A WEEK, WOUNDS 41
description: Forty-one people were wounded today, two of them seriously, when an explosion apparently caused by a bomb tore through a corner of a large, crowded cafeteria on the edge of Paris.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 26, 1986.

title: 6 KILLED IN SRI LANKA CLASH
description: Two policemen and four Tamil guerillas were killed Thursday in a clash in the eastern district of Batticaloa, a Government statement said today. It said nine policemen were also wounded when guerillas fighting for a separate Tamil state ambushed a police convoy.

title: HOW TO FUMIGATE MANHATTAN
description: For this week's big no-news story, how about the report that Manhattan is even more overcrowded with cars than the last time they counted?

title: INVESTORS ACT TO SAVE WESTERN UNION
description: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday that a group of investors had agreed to buy $250 million of the company's stock and debt, a move that analysts said would help to insure the company's survival.

title: Union Ratifies Hormel Pact
description: Striking meatpackers at Geo. A. Hormel & Company overwhelmingly approved a new contract to end a bitter, yearlong walkout that fractured the union, labor leaders announced Friday. The vote to end the strike at Hormel's flagship plant in Austin was 1,060 to 440, said Joseph T. Hansen, regional director of the United Food and Commercial Workers union.

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BIG FUNDS CAUGHT BY SURPRISE
description: Talk of an important correction in stock prices has been in the air for weeks, but a large number of institutions that manage equity portfolios worth billions of dollars were caught by surprise by this week's sudden, steep drop in stock prices.

title: NEW YORK RUNNER TRIES, TRIES AGAIN
description: Some runners dream of reaching the Olympics. Others thirst for world records.

title: 9 in U.S. Plead Guilty In Plot on Suriname
description: Nine of the 14 people accused of plotting to overthrow the military Government of Suriname have pleaded guilty to lesser charges.

title: ROCK: ELTON JOHN PERFORMS
description: Elton John's concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday might have been subtitled ''The Revisionist Elton John.'' It was not an attempt to pump up flagging record sales by performing new material.

title: Billy Cobham Band
description: Billy Cobham, the jazz-funk drummer and composer, is appearing with his band at Fat Tuesday's (190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street) this weekend.

title: INSIDE
description: 41 HURT IN PARIS BLAST An explosion apparently caused by a bomb ripped a cafeteria near Paris, wounding 41 people.

title: Helping Dropouts Climb In
description: Eugene Lang says it was an inspiration of the moment that led him in 1981 to promise college tuition to sixth-graders at Manhattan's Public School 121 if they would hang in and graduate from high school. Momentary or not, the way Mr. Lang has followed through on that inspiration turns out to be of even wider importance.

title: CROWN BOOKS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Guinness Head Holds the Reins
description: The head of the Guinness brewing company, Ernest Saunders, has been confirmed by stockholders as executive chairman of the merged Guinness-Distillers empire, thwarting a move to overthrow him.

title: IN BROOKLYN, DRIVE TO HELP DUTCH HOUSE
description: Forgotten by time, ravaged by weather and overwhelmed by weeds, abandoned tires and refrigerators, the 18th-century Christian Duryea House seems an unlikely symbol of what residents call the ''great potential'' of the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: 4 Poles Leave Ships; Seek Asylum in U.S.
description: Four Polish crewmen jumped from two fishing vessels at Coos Bay and sought political asylum, the Immigration and Naturalization Service reported today.

title: PHILLIES SPOIL METS' PARTY AND KNOCK OUT GOODEN
description: No, not even with Dwight Gooden pitching and six cases of champagne cooling, the Mets didn't do it tonight.

title: Insecurity on the Line
description: When was the last time you got a business call made by the person calling? Or answered by the person you were calling?

title:
Patents;
Method to Treat Atherosclerosis
description: Dr. Robert T. Gordon of Skokie, Ill., a cardiac surgeon who is a member of the University of Illinois faculty, received a patent this week broadening his method of treating atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tandon Job Cuts
description: The Tandon Corporation said today that it would lay off 135 of its 950 domestic workers for about one month and that it would cut executive salaries by 30 percent, as part of its plan to tighten its operations while starting its personal computer lines. The company, based in Chatsworth, Calif., also said it will resume production of its I.B.M.-compatible personal computers, which had been cut back six weeks ago to reduce inventories.

title: You Mean We Have a History?
description: Another academic year is under way, and as usual I am teaching a freshman survey course in United States history and counseling a group of college students.

title:
Patents;
A System to Prevent Collisions at Sea
description: A navigation warning system, designed to prevent collisions between ships or with underwater objects, was patented this week by Jerome H. Lemelson, president of the Licensing Management Corporation of New York, and Christian Grund, a graduate student at the University of Wisconsin in Madison.

title: A.B.A. PANEL REJECTS BID TO REWEIGH REHNQUIST ENDORSEMENT
description: An American Bar Association panel said in a letter made public today that recent allegations of unethical conduct by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court would not change its rating of him as ''well qualified'' to be Chief Justice.

title: COMPUTERS KEEP UP WITH ACTION
description: Because of sophisticated computerization, Wall Street had little difficulty in handling yesterday's record trading volume of 240.5 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange or the 237.6 million shares traded the previous day.

title: Typhoon on Vietnam's Coast Kills 400 and Injures 2,500
description: A typhoon killed nearly 400 people and injured more than 2,500 when it battered Vietnam's northern coastal provinces, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

title: FARMERS URGED TO SEEK CHANGE IN U.S. POLICY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson brought a throng of farmers to their feet cheering Thursday night with an emotional promise that rang across a convention hall: ''You are not alone.''

title: PRODUCER PRICE INDEX UP SLIGHT 0.3%
description: A key Government price gauge rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent in August, a smaller-than-expected increase that reassured many economists about prospects for avoiding a surge in inflation.

title: GROWTH IN HEROIN USE ENDING AS CITY USERS TURN TO CRACK
description: Heroin use, regarded for decades as the nation's most devastating drug problem, has stopped spreading in New York City and young people are spurning the drug, social scientists and drug-treatment centers say.

title: 47 HELD AT HUDSON CROSSINGS
description: A roadcheck of drivers bound for New Jersey over the George Washington Bridge and through the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels last night resulted in 47 arrests for drug- and alcohol-related violations and traffic delays on the West Side, the police said.

title: Bid by Pepsico
description: Pepsico Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement covering the previously announced purchase of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation from RJR Nabisco Inc. Pepsico said the price, based on Kentucky Fried Chicken's book value, was now estimated at $840 million, down from $850 million estimated when the tentative agreement had been announced. The company said the transition was expected to close in early fall pending final approval by directors of both companies.

title: The Shame - and Costs - of Illiteracy
description: It is estimated that nearly 23 million Americans are functionally illiterate: unable to read well enough to understand a job application, medicine label or a telephone directory. When those with marginal or limited skills are included in this group, the number increases dramatically. And illiteracy, which knows no prejudice, affects all segments of society - immigrants and native born, black and white, urban and rural, old and young. To survive or thrive in our complex society is for them an unending struggle. They are hardly free. Rather, they are hostages to a problem of frightening dimensions.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN MORTAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Taiwan-U.S. Trade Accord
description: Taiwan and the United States have resolved a trade dispute touched off by a prospective Toyota investment in Taiwan that Washington feared would lead to a surge of car exports to this country.

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its prior year results include a profit of $3,742,000 from a transaction in which the company acquired and then sold an interest in a property in New York City. The company said its latest year loss reflects the establishment of a loss reserve of $3,964,000 with respect to a mortgage and a property owned by the company, to reflect changes in economic factors and a diminution in value. It also said the latest year's loss reflects a reduction in the its equity in partnerships of $2,912,000, reflecting the reversal of equity in earnings recognized in prior years, and a provision of $1.1 million for possible losses and cost overruns in a project in which the company holds a 50 percent interest which had been under the management of the other partner. British Land added that the latest year's loss includes a provision of $300,000 for costs incurred during the year in connection with a proposed merger, Note Conversion and Warrant Exercise Program announced in June.

title: THE ALEXANDRIA DECLARATION
description: Following is the text of the joint statement read today at the end of the summit conference here between President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel:

title: ROLL-CALL IN THE HOUSE ON IMPOSING SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 308 to 77 by which the House of Representatives today agreed to accept the Senate version of a bill imposing economic sanctions against South Africa. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the Senate version. A ''no'' vote was against it. Voting ''yes'' were 218 Democrats and 90 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 4 Democrats and 73 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. ''Present'' denotes those who voted they were ''present'' at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 18
Envoy Choices
description: Arnold L. Raphel, a 43-year-old Foreign Service officer, has emerged as the leading State Department candidate to become the next Ambassador to Pakistan. The ambassadorship, now held by Dean Hinton, is especially important because of that country's close ties with the United States and its strategic location adjoining India, Afghanistan, Iran and China.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Woman Hurt in Ferry Leap
description: A 31-year-old Brooklyn woman was in critical condition last night after she leaped over the side of the Staten Island ferryboat Kennedy during an argument with another passenger, the police said. A spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said the woman, identified as Julia Ruffin, apparently suffered a heart attack just after she struck the water at 5:30 P.M.

title: RUSTY PELICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After a charge of $176,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change. c-Net income There were 17 weeks in the latest quarter and 53 weeks in the latest year, compared with 16 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: More Arrests Won't Win The War Against Crack
description: To The Editor:

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings for 1986 and 1985 periods are for both Class A and Class B common stock.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, some copies of Business Day yesterday carried a sports page in place of page D2. The omitted page included sections from an article on business capital spending, an article on Metromedia and the Economic Scene, Business People and Executive Changes columns. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: VOLUME CLIMBS TO A RECORD LEVEL; Dow Falls By 34.17 -- Interest Rates and the Economy Spur Worry
description: The stock market fell sharply again yesterday amid the heaviest trading in Wall Street history. Concerns about the health of the economy and the possibility of rising interest rates continued to discourage investors.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
IN L.I. HOSPITALS, 5 AFGHAN FIGHTERS FIND A CULTURE SHOCK THAT HEALS
description: When they were told they were being sent to hospitals on Long Island, in the United States of America, to be treated for crippling injuries suffered in the war against Soviet forces, the five young Afghan guerrillas were made to understand that they faced months of pain and struggle.

title: FILM: 'AVENGING FORCE,' WITH MICHAEL DUDIKOFF
description: In ''Avenging Force,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO National and other theaters, Michael Dudikoff and Steve James, who fought and defeated their evil enemies in ''American Ninja,'' pair up again to take on a vigilante group of extreme-right-wing psychopaths who happen to be experts in the martial arts.

title: PHILIPPINE SUPREME COURT OVERTURNS ACQUITTALS IN AQUINO SLAYING
description: The Philippine Supreme Court today overturned the acquittals last December of 26 men in the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. in 1983, calling the trial ''a sham'' orchestrated by Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: JUSTICE INVESTMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1986
description: Markets

title: New Format In P.S.A.L.
description: The battle for the Public Schools Athletic League football championship promises to be a fierce one this year. The Brooklyn squads have been restructured into two five-team divisions, and the increased interdivisional play that will count in the league standings should result in division races.

title: VMS SHORT TERM INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 IN SCANDAL MAY LOSE SEVERANCE PAY
description: The Koch administration, responding to objections from Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, has decided to withhold the severance pay of two former city officials charged with corruption in office.

title: WOMAN WHO ARRANGED SPOUSE'S DEATH IS FREED
description: A woman who admitted having hired the assassin who killed her abusive husband was spared prison by a judge who called the husband ''an animal'' whose treatment of his wife and their three daughters had been inhuman.

title: Shelley Fowle Is Married In Britain to a Classmate
description: Shelley Fowle and David Stokes, theology students at Trinity College in Bristol, England, were married yesterday at St. John's Anglican Church in Weymouth, Dorset, England.

title: Lee Vance Wed To Cynthia King
description: Cynthia Bayard King, the daughter of Canon and Mrs. Jonathan LeRoy King of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lee Gregory Vance, a son of Lee W. Vance of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and the late Mary Elizabeth Vance. The Rev. David R. King, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Richard B. Andersen, at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church, where the bride's father is a priest associate.

title: Has Piniella Done the Job For Yanks?
description: The following excerpts of letters from readers represent a sampling of the response to the above question. The overwhelming majority of letter writers favored retaining Piniella for another year.

title: ETHICAL CULTURE'S HEAD PURSUES JOURNEY OF LIFE
description: For the first time in its 110-year history, the Ethical Culture Society of New York has gone outside its own largely agnostic membership to choose a leader, selecting a man who until a few months ago served as a Methodist minister.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: OUT OF FASHION

title: Before and After the All-Star Break
description: Not including last night's game

title:
MEMORIES OF HENRY MOORE FROM MEN WHOSE LIVES HE TOUCHED;
THE COLLEAGUE: THE BONES
description: I met Henry Moore more than 20 years ago, at his home in Much Hadham. I just wanted to pay the man a visit and get to know him. I was amazed to find how easy it was to get to him. I had no plan in mind, and I didn't know what I wanted to ask of him, except to meet him. I went with my wife, and we had a marvelous time, talking about everything. He even took me to his garden to see his work. Then he said, ''It's chilly, isn't it? Let's have some tea.'' It seems like I've had more tea when visiting him than at any other time in my life.

title: ERNST HAAS, PHOTOJOURNALIST AND INNOVATOR, IS DEAD AT 65
description: Ernst Haas, a photographer known both for his photojournalism and for his innovative use of color, died Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 65 years old and lived in New York.

title: Mrs. King Delays Talk With Botha
description: Coretta Scott King, the American civil rights figure, was in South Africa last week to attend the installation of Desmond M. Tutu as Archbishop of Cape Town and, she said, to meet with other South Africans to discuss the suffering in their country. Those other Aficans were to include the white President, P.W. Botha, and the Zulu leader, Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, who is spurned by more militant blacks.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: HE WAS awake, but he didn't open his eyes, not right away. It felt good to lounge, to luxuriate under the quilt.

title: Miller Reflects
description: IT was Sept. 1 and, under major league rules, the Minnesota Twins could have recalled as many as 16 players from the minors to bring their roster to 40. But when the only players they brought up from their International League team in Toledo were the 34-year-old utility infielder, Ron Washington, and the 33-year-old utility outfielder, Alvis Woods, Ray Miller, then the Twins' manager, ''saw the writing on the wall.''

title: CHARACTERS DANGEROUSLY LIKE US
description: THE PROGRESS OF LOVE By Alice Munro. 309 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Why Lower Rates Wouldn't Hurt
description: THE recovery of the United States economy stopped 27 months ago. Since mid-1984, real gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 2.8 percent, only enough to keep unemployment at about 7 percent, while utilization of industrial capacity slipped from 82 percent to 79 percent. We have escaped outright recession so far, but we need not and should not settle for stagnation.

title: A CHANCE TO MAKE ELEPHANTS AND BREAK BUILDINGS
description: ''Can you make me an elephant?'' an excited 4-year-old at the Staten Island Children's Museum asked Louise Merola. ''Sure,'' said Ms. Merola, who then cut a headband from construction paper for the child and stapled on a long loose strip that ran over the nose and down the front of the T-shirt to the knees. The child went to the mirror and, unable to see around the trunk, held it up and stared. Sure enough, an elephant.

title: FISHERS OF MEN
description: THE NEW ENGLAND SOUL Preaching and Religious Culture in Colonial New England. By Harry S. Stout. 398 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: WESTPORT ROOSTERS MAKE ENEMIES
description: EIGHT-YEAR-OLD Charlene Marino of Hales Court in Westport loves her three prize-winning roosters. Some of her neighbors do not. She lives with her father, Charles, a Westport native, and they show the three-year-old roosters at state fairs, where the birds have won 12 blue ribbons.

title: Barbara Connolly to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Connolly of Floral Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jean Connolly to William Fenimore Comly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas Comly 2d of Lambertville, N.J. Miss Connolly is a registered nurse and a third-year student at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University. Her fiance is a financial consultant at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York. A November wedding is planned.

title: No Uncertain Trumpet
description: The Republicans, who now control the Senate by a margin of 53 to 47, are opening the fall election campaign with stout predictions that they will retain their majority and perhaps even increase it. Senator John Heinz, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, laid down the line last week: ''We will do no worse than 52-48, and the chances are better than even that we will wind up with 53 seats, perhaps as many as 56.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OF AUCTIONS, HONORS AND AWARDS
description: A remarkable collection of United States large cents will be sold at auction Sept. 30 and Oct. 1 in West Hollywood, Calif. The sale includes virtually every large cent variety known to collectors plus some that have not been listed previously in standard reference works.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE TOPS CALIFORNIA, 21-15
description: Jim Turner, a senior fullback, got his first career touchdown, a 1-yard run with 6 minutes 56 seconds remaining today, to give Boston College a 21-15 victory that spoiled California's season opener.

title: Robert Cox and Ann Hartenstein Wed
description: Ann Hartenstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hans Hartenstein of Syracuse, was married yesterday in her parents' home to Robert Hill Cox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell E. Cox of Brooklyn and Ashville, Me. The Rev. Thomas Halkett, an Episcopal priest who is the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: Amy Vorenberg and Paul Maggiotto, Assistant District Attorneys, Are Wed
description: Amy Vorenberg, a daughter of James Vorenberg of Cambridge, Mass., dean of the Harvard Law School, was married yesterday to Paul Anthony Maggiotto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Joseph Maggiotto of Buffalo. The bride's father, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Cronkite Graduate Center at Harvard University.

title: The Judiciary Sparks Some Heated Debate
description: The Reagan Adminstration's view of the appropriate course for the Federal judiciary prompted a testy battle last week. But in the Senate, where the nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States was debated, and elsewhere, as an assistant attorney general denounced a sitting Justice by name, both sides seemed to be fighting a future as well as apresent war.

title: David Winston Dies; Health Policy Expert
description: David A. Winston, a former unpaid adviser to the White House who coordinated the Reagan Administration's strategy on health policy, died of respiratory arrest caused by spinal cord injuries Thursday in San Francisco. He was 44 years old.

title: THE WILLOW THAT MAKES YOU WEEP
description: ALL right, Joyce Kilmer thought trees were lovelier than poems. But if you drive around Fairfield County, you'll see a lot of tree stumps making you think trees are not always quite that lovely.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of a recipe appearing in the Aug. 31 Food column should have read Open-Face Plum Cake.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET;
Meeting a Mate Amidst the Produce
description: FEW Washingtonians call the Georgetown Safeway by its proper name. The store, which is in one of the country's hottest singles spots, is usually called the ''Social Safeway.'' Cosmopolitan Magazine just listed it as one of the country's most likely places to meet eligible men.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE BEASTS OF HONOR
description: ''HOLY smoke!'' our son-in-law said as he walked into our kitchen one night and saw a raccoon staring at him through the sliding glass door. The size of a small bear, this ball of fur was one of several who periodically climb a flight of stairs to reach our deck to see what we're offering. It all began one night when I left the garbage out there for the man of the house to cart to its destination, and since then the racoons have lived in great expectation. David was awed by the enormity of the current visitor.

title: Lendl Withdraws
description: TENDINITIS in his knees and hip will force Ivan Lendl, who won the men's singles title at the United States Open one week ago, to withdraw from the $315,000 Volvo Tennis-Los Angeles tournament, scheduled for Sept. 15-21 at U.C.L.A. Jerry Solomon, Lendl's manager, said that the No. 1-ranked player in the world would not play competitive tennis for at least five weeks because of chronic tendinitis that has troubled his knees for most of this year. Lendl pulled out of a scheduled exhibition in Australia early last week. Solomon added that Lendl, in foresaking tennis for an extended period, is following the advice of doctors and will undergo treatment for the ailment.

title: O'Connor Defends Order on Speakers
description: The debate between Governor Cuomo and the Archdiocese of New York continued last week as John Cardinal O'Connor supported an order barring from parish events speakers who disagree with Catholic teachings.

title: LACK OF GRAIN HURTS NORTHWEST PORTS
description: Hard times have fallen on the publicly owned grain elevators at Pacific Northwest ports, such as here and on the Columbia River, because of declines in wheat and corn export markets and changes in patterns of trade.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: ENGLAND'S POET LAUREATE

title: MUSIC IN THE AMERICAN STYLE
description: A sampling of recent recordings of American music, most of it written for the concert hall, serves to illustrate the wide range of stylistic approaches and even the differences in basic musical language employed by this country's composers. If there is a common denominator here, it is perhaps to be found in the energy, enthusiasm and willingness to experiment on the part of men and women pursuing their craft in an atmosphere of freedom.

title: Classical Music
description: If you couldn't get, or didn't want, tickets to the Sutherland-Pavarotti bash at Madison Square Garden, but don't want to wait for the Met opening to start your fall opera season, here is an observer's speculative guide to the week at the New York City Opera.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Medley of Silences

title: A SAGA OF JEWS WHO FOUGHT BACK AGAINST NAZI OPPRESSION
description: On New Years's Eve, 1941, a young poet named Abba Kovner read aloud a manifesto, ''Let Us Not Be Led Like Sheep to the Slaughter,'' at a meeting in the Vilna Ghetto of Lithuania. This call for resistance to the Nazis led to the formation of the United Partisans Organization, which consolidated differing political parties into one Jewish underground.

title:
STAMPS;
FOLK ART BLOCK ACCENTS INDIAN BLANKETS
description: The United States Postal Service has issued a block of four stamps that display the artistry of the Navajo Indians. The stamps were issued Sept. 4 in Window Rock, Ariz. to coincide with the opening of the annual Navajo Nation Fair. Assistant Postmaster General Gordon C. Morison was the principal speaker.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: La Gran Scena Opera Company di New York Starring Vera Galupe-Borszkh, Philene Wannelle, Luis Russinyol, Sylvia Bills; directed by Ira Siff, 1985 Video Arts International 112 minutes. $59.95.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
THE WAR ON ILLEGAL ACCESSORY RENTALS
description: THERE are no clear-cut statistics on how many private houses on the Island harbor illegal apartments, but estimates are that there are many thousands.

title: DeFirmian Wins The Biggest Prize
description: The biggest individual first prize in United States history, $20,930, was won by Nick DeFirmian in the 14th annual World Open Tournament in Philadelphia. The 29-year-old San Francisco grandmaster won six games and drew three to score the winning 7 1/2-1 1/2 in the nine-round Swiss-system event sponsored by the Continental Chess Association.

title: WHEN THE BILL FOR THE MARVELS FALLS DUE
description: CADILLAC DESERT The American West and Its Disappearing Water. By Marc Reisner. Illustrated. 582 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: L.S.U. UPSETS TEXAS A&M; TENNESSEE FALLS TO MISS. STATE
description: A red-shirted freshman, Tom Hodson, completed 15 of 21 passes for 193 yards and two touchdowns in his first college start tonight, guiding Louisiana State to a 35-17 upset of seventh-ranked Texas A&M.

title: Planning to Supplement A Pension
description: THE proposed restructuring of the nation's tax system complicates retirement planning for people of all ages. ''Congress has put a lot of teeth in the current proposals,'' said Robert M. Siper, director of pension consulting services for the accounting firm of KMG Main Hurdman. The extensive changes ''will not simplify anything'' in retirement planning, he added.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANASTASIA HAS THE ANSWERS By Lois Lowry. 123 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: PAINTER MAKES ART FOR HISTORY'S SAKE
description: DESPITE living nearly 40 years in an old granite farmhouse surrounded by the quiet woods and rolling hills from which other painters might seldom stray, Woldemar Neufeld of New Preston still finds his greatest satisfaction in painting less natural landscapes.

title: Thomas R. Stapleton Wed To Barbara Jean De Haan
description: Barbara Jean De Haan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. De Haan of Forest Hills, Queens, was married there yesterday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church to Thomas Raymond Stapleton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stapleton of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Vincent Daly officiated. Mrs. Stapleton expects to join the Morse Shoe Company in Canton, Mass., next month; her husband is with the Bank of Boston. The bride's father is with Eastern Railroad Associates in Manhattan. Mr. Stapleton's father is The Daily News's Inquiring Photographer columnist.

title: INTO MEMORY, SLOWLY
description: ADIEU, VOLODYA By Simone Signoret. Translated by Stanley Hochman. 418 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: SYSIES: NOT QUITE YUPPIES
description: I HAVE nothing against young urban professionals, really, other than a slight jealousy over the enormous amount of publicity they have received over the last two years.

title: PUICA SETS MARK IN 5TH AVENUE RACE
description: Mary Decker Slaney ran her first race in nearly a year, but her long-awaited appearance yesterday in the Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue was quickly reduced to a subplot. Maricica Puica pulled away from a fast, aggressive field and sprinted to victory in 4 minutes 19.48 seconds, a record for the event.

title: ...And Some Low-Tech Brethren
description: The Washington area has more to offer investors than just high-tech Beltway Bandits. Some of their low-tech brethren, who serve the needs of the particularly affluent local community, have performed well for their shareholders.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Greensboro, N.C.;
A Second Try In City Center
description: TWO years ago, investors from this city's leading financial concerns announced plans to convert a collection of turn-of-the-century commercial buildings into a $20 million apartment and office complex in downtown Greensboro.

title: Linebacker Ineligible
description: JEFF BRASWELL, a 6-1, 224-pound senior linebacker who had been scheduled to start for Iowa State yesterday in its opening game at Iowa, was declared ineligible because of unspecified violations that were said to have occurred while he was being recruited in 1984. Iowa State said that after further investigation it would decide whether to ask the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eligibility Committee if Braswell can return to the team.

title: MEDIATION SPEEDS UTILITY RATE BIDS
description: It used to take 11 months for utilities in New York State to be granted rate increases. Now, it can take as little as three.

title: MOMENT YOU WEREN'T WAITING FOR
description: YOU can have a good time on vacation, or a mediocre time or a downright awful time but one thing is always the same - the re-entry blues.

title: Poland Grants Another Amnesty
description: Poland has granted amnesties before - notably to 650 Solidarity activists released in 1984 - only to rearrest many of the same people when they persisted in defying Gen. Wojceich Jaruzelski's orders to toe the line. So last week's amnesty for 225 prisoners accused or convicted of political offenses was greeted with only mitigated delight.

title: Robin Group Is Married
description: Robin Group, a daughter of Herbert Group and Ida Jean Group, both of New York, was married last night to Andrew Parker, a son of Carl Parker of Melville, L.I., and the late Iris Kurtz Parker. Rabbi Nathaniel Steinberg performed the ceremony at the Dix Hills (L.I.) Jewish Center. The bride graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo and the bridegroom from the Boston University School of Management.

title: AETNA PLANS EXHIBIT ON PHOTOJOURNALIST
description: AN exhibition of the photojournalism of Arthur B. Rickerby, including his work as a Life magazine photographer during the Kennedy presidency, opens Friday at the Aetna Institute and Gallery in Hartford.

title: HISTORIC SITES IN PINELANDS ENDANGERED
description: HISTORY in this pinelands village is made of tin roofs and cedar shakes, of packing houses and cranberry bogs and of ramshackle huts once home to generations of immigrant laborers.

title: CORPORATIONS BEGIN STUDYING WAYS OF CARING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: ELDERCARE, the word sometimes used to refer to the problems of caring for elderly relatives, has until recently been considered the domain of gerontologists, psychologists and sociologists. Now corporations, too, are expressing a growing concern with problems related to aging and how their work force might be affected. In the county, Pepsico recently announced a new employee program that addressed this issue and that company officials said they hoped would serve as a model for other companies.

title: COLLEGE SCOREBOARD
LEADERS EMERGING AT NEW ROCHELLE
description: Westchester's Conference A was so strong last season that four bowl contenders - Ossining, Roosevelt, Scarsdale and North Rockland - finished the regular season undefeated. But even though those teams didn't lose during the season, they all lost badly to graduation.

title: Mary Finn Becomes Bride Of S. L. Wood, Developer
description: Mary Finn and Steven Lee Wood were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ, Congregational, in Sharon, Conn., by the Rev. Terrence Ryan.

title: Lauri Levitt Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Lauri Levitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Levitt Jr. of New York and Westport, Conn., to Michael Lawrence Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Friedland of Hewlett, L.I., took place last evening at the Levitt home in Westport. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler performed the ceremony.

title: Elder Care Communities Catch On
description: WHEN Archie and Doris MacKinney first looked at Friendship Village of Schaumburg in 1977, they liked the idea that it not only offered attractive garden apartments but also guaranteed spots in a nursing home if they ever needed them.

title: To Rent or to Buy a Home
description: FOR those eager to own a piece of the American dream, buying a house has long been the investment of choice - it's safe and sure to appreciate, or so the conventional wisdom ran. But increasingly that wisdom is being called into question. In many parts of the country renters pay no more each month than homeowners, and they can put their capital to work more productively in other investments.

title: DUMP SITES SOUGHT FOR BULKY DEBRIS
description: A BUILDING boom has helped fill most of the state's ''bulky waste'' landfills with demolition materials and land-clearing debris, pushing disposal prices up and prompting some builders to turn to illegal dumping, state officials say.

title: 2 DIRECTORS BREW SURPRISE FROM TROUBLE
description: In a dim summer season that saw the instant demise of George Lucas's big-budget ''Howard the Duck,'' and in which David Cronenberg's lean, stripped-down remake of ''The Fly'' is possibly the most stylish American movie and Eric Rohmer's ''Summer'' the best foreign film, two unusually rewarding, low-budget productions by new film makers deserve attention before they're allowed to disappear. By coincidence, both are playing somewhere south of 14th Street - long a refuge for artists and ideas unable to survive in uptown Manhattan.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR
description: THE DAY before school opened last week, a business executive who has pledged to help 60 East Harlem students discovered that they did not know which junior high school they were supposed to attend. The executive, Dianne B. Sullivan, the president of Miraflores Designs, called the local school superintendent and solved the problem.

title: No Headline
description: EISENHOWER: AT WAR 1943-1945. By David Eisenhower. Illustrated. 977 pp. New York: Random House. $29.95.

title: ROSSINI IS THE REASON FOR A FESTIVAL IN ITALY
description: Luciano Pavarotti was sitting next to Riccardo Muti. A few rows back there was Bruce Crawford of the Metropolitan Opera. The invited audience also included political figures, social celebrities, and a number of distinguished scholars. The occasion was the dress rehearsal of ''Bianca e Falliero,'' an opera by Gioacchino Rossini, which had not been heard in public for well over a century, a work dismissed by most of the composer's biographers as a hastily-written pot-boiler of little intrinsic merit. Hardly the sort of thing you would expect to attract such a glamorous assembly.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET
description: RUNNING the nation's 31,000 supermarkets is no easy task these days. In New York City and some other urban areas, skyrocketing rents and competition from gourmet takeout places and other food sources are forcing some markets to close their doors. And in others, a leveling off of population growth has caused huge competitive battles for customers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A WOMAN'S PLACE. By Marita Golden. (Doubleday, $16.95.) ''A Woman's Place'' is a female coming-of-age-into-one's-own tale told through a smoked glass three-way mirror.

title: SYMPHONIES BY GOUNOD FROM THE MUSICAL HERITAGE SOCIETY
description: During the early and mid-19th century, France was no place for symphonists. As Camille Saint-Saens recalled in 1900, ''the beau monde [of the 1850s] thought of nothing but Italian music, while the bourgeous recognized no music besides opera and French comic opera . . .'' Idolaters of the virtuoso and the prima donna, French audiences generally equated symphonic writing with tonal algebra. Then along came Charles Gounod (1818-93).

title: A Nuclear Test At the Dump Site
description: A new national plan designed to keep closer to home the low-level radioactive wastes that are now shipped to three sites around the country got its first test last week. Not unexpectedly, the grade was mixed.

title: Miss Brockie Is Bride Of Karl Hill, Guitarist
description: Margaret Armstrong Brockie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Simmons Brockie Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and West Barnstable, Mass., was married yesterday to Karl Leland Hill, a son of Alice M. Sample and Leland R. Hill, both of Youngstown, Ohio. The Rev. Samuel Blenkin performed the ceremony in the West Parish Congregational Church in West Barnstable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1986
description: International A United Nations buildup campaign has been quietly started by the Reagan Administration, which has been a consistent critic of the organization, according to Administration officials. The attempt to strengthen the U.N. follows a wave of Congressional budget cuts that could severely hurt it. The Administration has now focused on the United Nations as a key for foreign policy interests and is asking Congress to restore at least some of the money. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Moscow made new spying charges against Nicholas S. Daniloff, an American reporter, and said the United States was holding East-West relations hostage in the case. The Soviet Union said it had ''irrefutable'' evidence that Mr. Daniloff, correspondent of U.S. News & World Report, had ''taken instructions'' from Murat Natirboff, an official who recently completed an assignment at the United States Embassy. The Soviet Government press agency Tass identified him as Moscow station chief of the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Daniloff said he would ''not dignify the charges by commenting on them.'' [ 1:4. ] Chernobyl radiation tainted reindeer in Lapland, where deer meat is a food staple. Herders reported that 97 percent of the 1,000 reindeer put to the annual fall slaughter have been measured in excess of permissible radiation levels and declared unfit for humans to eat. The Swedish Government is trying to protect the Lapps by buying and feeding contaminated deer meat to the region's mink and fox farms. [ 1:2. ] The 92-nation trade conference that starts tomorrow in Uruguay will deal only with a symptom of the weak world economy - growing world protectionism - and not with the strains of economic disorder that have caused it, international economists say.

title: Amichai in English
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. MAY DO WELL IN VOTE FOR HOUSE EXPERTS FORECAST
description: While national attention has focused on the elections that will determine which party controls the Senate, political leaders say the Republican Party, remarkably, is likely to avoid any serious losses in the House of Representatives this year.

title: 'THE AFRICANS' RENEWS A FUNDING FIGHT
description: ''The Africans'' marks a new battle in an old campaign. Should Federal funds be used for controversial documentaries? The Public Broadcasting Service says yes; ''The Africans,'' a nine-part series, is the jewel in this season's crown. The National Endowment for the Humanities says no; ''The Africans'' is an ''anti-Western diatribe,'' ''narrow and politically tendentious.'' Once again, the ramparts are mounted. On one side, the children of darkness; on the other, the children of light. Which side is which depends, of course, on how you face the ramparts, and the only sure thing is that when the particular battle is over, a new one will take its place. Disputes like this go with the territory. Their common denominator is that they are never resolved.

title: Hurricane Poses No Threat
description: Hurricane Earl was moving northward this afternoon toward a remote death in the mid-Atlantic, said officials of the National Hurricane Center. ''It's going to make a slow turn north, so we don't think it's ever going to affect land,'' said Gil Clark, a forecaster. The storm, with highest sustained winds of 85 miles an hour, was about 625 miles southeast of Bermuda this afternoon, the National Weather Service said.

title: Topics: NOBLE EXAMPLES; Per Aspera
