description: Having chided Senator Jake Garn for soliciting a ride aboard the space shuttle while overseeing NASA's budget, we are happy now to salute his decency and courage in donating a kidney to his daughter Susan.

title: SUFFOLK STUDYING CHANGES IN POLICE FORCE
description: A REPORT that found deficiencies in the management of the Suffolk County Police Department has led county officials to discuss steps to modernize the 2,559-member force, one of the nation's largest and best paid.

title: 4 SCHOOL DISTRICTS WAIT ON STATE AID
description: FOUR small-city school districts in Westchester began the new school year uncertain whether they would receive more than $3 million in extra state aid voted them by the Legislature last June.

title: END OF THE ERA FOR LAVISH ESTATES
description: PETER R. GIMBEL remembers growing up on his parents' 200-acre Greenwich estate as a time of exploration. He and his twin brother, David, would roam through the 26-room main house and ramble about the lawns and woods that spread out in all directions.

title: SEAFOOD COMES OF AGE
description: FIVE YEARS AGO, IF A RESTAURANT SERVED grilled tuna steak that was so pink and rare in the center that it resembled warm sushi, chances were that a diner would send back the dish in a huff. Something as pristine as tartare of raw salmon also would be greeted with astonishment, except perhaps in a sushi bar. Today, these two creations are among the most popular dishes in contemporary French and American restaurants.

title: Reading 'Vic Holyfield'
description: To the Editor:

title: Shifting Financial Gears
description: COLLINS SPENCER, a Hartford executive, is worried about how the expected new tax law will affect him.

title: Disability Coverage Needed
description: THREE years ago, the future looked bright for Edward Collins, a 28-year-old single accountant. He was young, had a secure job that paid well and had made several good investments.

title: Salzburg
description: To the Editor: May I add yet another name to Paul Hofmann's list of eating places in Salzburg (Travel, July 20), one likely to appeal to the less affluent traveler?

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
BBC EXAMINES WESTERN DOMINANCE
description: ''This is a series about ideas, not about events,'' the historian John Roberts said the other day. Yet he added that the ideas presented in ''The Triumph of the West,'' a 13-part BBC documentary beginning its American premiere Wednesday evening at 9 on Arts & Entertainment, may well be controversial.

title: Dance
description: Cynthia Gregory has gathered a chamber group of dancers around her to celebrate her 20 years as a principal dancer, first with the San Francisco Ballet and then with the American Ballet Theater. ''Cynthia Gregory and Company: The Celebration Tour'' thus opens both a national tour Saturday night at Lehman College and the fall season of the Lehman Center.

title: The Economy Signals 'Yes' To Investors
description: ALTHOUGH the long-predicted resurgence in the economy has been painfully slow to emerge - and may not be so robust as many still hope - most brokers, portfolio managers and ordinary householders appear to share a remarkable agreement about investment fundamentals.

title: TAMPERING BILLS SOUGHT
description: PROMPTED by recent incidents of food and drug tampering - and threats of tampering - the owner of a Belleville advertising agency specializing in package goods has created a group to press for protective legislation.

title: MEDICAL EMERGENCIES ABROAD
description: Before your next trip abroad, ponder this: The odds favor your returning home as healthy as when you left, but what happens if you are badly injured in an accident or become gravely ill? How will you find a physician you can trust, and one who speaks English too? If you are hospitalized, who will pay the bills, which could mount into thousands of dollars within days? If you cannot get adequate medical care where stricken, how can emergency evacuation be arranged?

title: DATA UPDATE: September 14, 1986
SERVICES -- THE STARS OF U.S. TRADE
description: ONCE America's export trade meant shiploads of cars from Detroit, bolts of cloth from Southern textile mills and farm machines from the Middle West. But, as America's traditional merchandise has been overtaken in the world marketplace, trade has emerged with a new look. Service exports - fees generated in Europe by Wall Street bankers and in the Middle East by American construction firms; royalties from overseas sales of Madonna records and McDonald's hamburgers - have become the new symbol of America's grandeur abroad. They are the bright spot in an otherwise bleak trade picture.

title: Tara Phelan Marries
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, N.Y., yesterday Tara Alexandra Phelan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Phelan of Kingston, was married to Robert Gray Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gray of Muskegon, Mich. The Rev. Jay Backes performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. Mrs. Gray graduated from Columbia College in Columbia, Mo. Her husband is a graduate of Michigan State University.

title: 90-CENT FARE ON THE BUSES IS IN DANGER NEXT YEAR
description: BUS riders got a break this month when the county canceled a planned 10-cent fare increase. But officials are not optimistic that the reprieve will last next year.

title: 4 Officers in Massachusetts Indicted on Cocaine Charges
description: Four experienced Chicopee police officers were indicted today on charges of possessing and distributing cocaine and marijuana, officials said.

title: DANILOFF IS TOPIC OF U.S. AND SOVIET LAWYERS
description: The case of Nicholas S. Daniloff surfaced today at the first joint symposium between Soviet and American lawyers in a classroom at Dartmouth College.

title: Albany Considering Minnewaska's Fate
description: SHOULD Lake Minnewaska, a 1,200-acre wilderness area in the Shawangunk Mountains near New Paltz, remain in private hands, its future mapped as a luxury resort? Or should it be acquired by New York State to become a preserve open to all?

title: KEY PLAY AT THE FIRST TRICK
description: It is customary to wax enthusiastic about the contestant, whether horse or bridge-player, who zooms past his rivals in the home stretch to snatch a thrilling victory. But spare a tear for the unfortunates who seem destined to be winners but then hit disaster.

title: Offensive Is a Success, Salvadoran Rebels Say
description: The rebel station Radio Venceremos said today that leftist guerrillas had killed or wounded 60 soldiers in attacks in Usulutan Province, marking the opening of a new military campaign.

title: MELBOURNE
description: Ask a Melbournian about Sydney and he will tell you it is flashy, aggressive, fast and superficial. Rather grudgingly he will concede that the harbor may be beautiful and the Opera House worth a visit. But who would want to live there?

title: HOLLYWOOD PROS AND LOCAL ICONOCLASTS PUT AMERICA'S STAMP ON THE FILM FESTIVAL
description: For inveterate film fans, the advent of fall means two things: no more movies with Roman numerals in their titles, until Christmas at least, and the arrival of the New York Film Festival. The festival, which begins on Friday, has been an irreplacable cultural constant in this city since its inception in 1963. If there is a particular character to the 1986 roster, it's in the unusually strong American presence. For the first time in the New York Film Festival's history, both the opening and closing night showcases have been reserved for American films - Jim Jarmusch's ''Down by Law'' as the inaugural event, and Francis Coppola's ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' for the finale.

title: Family Ties
description: IT WAS JOSH'S REACTION THAT HURT most. For several months, his mother and I had been quietly battling toward divorce.

title: Flip-Tax Notice
description: To the Editor:

title: TREKKING IN NEW ZEALAND
description: The Routeburn Track, a four-day trekking adventure in the South Island of New Zealand, takes the trekker through beech and lichen forests, native bush, river valleys and over a 4,160-foot mountain pass. It also crosses two of New Zealand's 10 national parks, Mount Aspiring and Fiordland. Although the Milford Track is a better known hiking route on the South Island, those who have taken both find Routeburn the more varied and interesting of the two.

title: OFFICE-BUILDING BUSTLES IN MID-HUDSON
description: MARKET STREET, running along high ground above the Hudson shoreline in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is uncharacteristically noisy these days. Jackhammers pound away at the rear and sides of the old Y.M.C.A. building, where a developer is preserving the classic facade to meld it later to a new 66,000-square-foot office building on the site.

title: L.I.R.R. Dispute Goes to Panel
description: President Reagan has signed an executive order establishing an emergency board to investigate a dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and its unionized employees, whose previous contract expired in December 1984.

title: Crowd at Penn State Protests Regan Appearance at Dinner
description: About 400 students, faculty members and local residents gathered to protest an appearance here tonight by the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, who spoke at a dinner opening a $200 million fund-raising campaign for Pennsylvania State University.

title: Salvaging Lives After Torture
description: I was heartened to read about the Toronto Torture Treatment Center (''Salvaging Lives After Torture,'' by Christopher S. Wren, Aug. 17).

title: Small Firms Gearing Up For Change
description: AS early as last July, the Donley Communications Corporation dropped its profit-sharing and pension plans in favor of increased salaries and bigger bonuses for its seven-member staff. The reason: Tax revision.

title: MUBARAK AND PERES PREPARE A WARM DIPLOMATIC SOUFFLE
description: ASSESSING last week's meeting between President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, a member of the Israeli delegation remarked that it was the diplomatic equivalent of a souffle - hard and tasty on the surface, but mostly air underneath.

title: Adam Meyerson Weds Nina Shea
description: Nina Hope Shea, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Shea of Yardley, Pa., and Kiawah Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Adam Meyerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Meyerson of Philadelphia. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg, performed the ceremony at the Stuart Country Day School of the Sacred Heart in Princeton, N.J., from which the bride graduated.

title: Attack on Haitian Protesters Leaves Two People Wounded
description: Men wearing civilian clothes and armed with clubs and machetes on Friday attacked about 400 people protesting the cost of food and lack of jobs.

title: CONTROLLERS' TAXING JOB: KEEPING AIR LANES SAFE
description: THE scene is not uncommon: A private, single-engine, piston-driven aircraft circles an airport in New Jersey, waiting to get into the traffic pattern to land.

title:
GARDENING;
PAWPAW TREE OFFERS FRUIT AND BEAUTY
description: uf9420>THE papaw is a little known and underused native fruit.

title: TRYING TO COMPUTE MADNESS OF CROWDS
description: THE stock market has long proven to be one of the most reliable predictors of the economic future. But at times it behaves no more rationally than a panic-stricken mob. In the wake of last week's sell-off, in which trading volume for much of Thursday and Friday was a million shares a minute, the question was whether this was one of those prescient markets or one that was mostly just tired and jumpy.

title: SWISS COALITION PRESENTS PETITION ON REFERENDUM TO END ARMY
description: A coalition of socialists, pacifists and religious groups has announced that it has met the requirements for a national referendum on abolishing the Swiss Army, and it presented a petition Friday bearing 113,000 signatures to the Government in Bern.

title: CUBANS ARE OUT IN FORCE AT THE 11TH TORONTO FILM FESTIVAL
description: From the smoke of their cigars to the rich bite of their dark rum, but particularly through the 23 films they brought from Havana, Cubans are a major presence at this year's Toronto Film Festival.

title:
ART;
LYRICAL VISIONS OF 10 WOMEN OFFER SOME JOY AT CASTLE GALLERY
description: THERE is so much sweetness and light in the written premise of the current exhibition at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle that you back away. Against a backdrop of nuclear annihilation and creeping computerization in our contemporary world are posited 10 female artists whose lyrical visions bring much-needed joy to the viewer.

title: JOHN CONNALLY'S TEXAS-SIZED TROUBLES
description: WHEN John Connally's Presidential ambitions were dashed in 1980, he decided, at age 63, that it was time to quit politics and to start making some real money.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 14, 1986
description: FICTION 1 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $3.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 2 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 3 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.50.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 4 ENTERPRISE: The First Adventure, by Vonda N. McIntyre. (Pocket, $3.95.) Under a young captain, the Star Trek craft faces unexpected challenges. 5 THE RED FOX, by Anthony Hyde. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A thriller in which a journalist journeys to Russia, seeking the father of a woman he loves. 6 AFTER THE REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Dell, $4.50.) The surprises that befell four Radcliffe women in the five years after their 20th reunion. 7 PALM BEACH, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A poor but beautiful woman finds her way in the town of the superrich. 8* THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 9 THE TRAIL TO CRAZY MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Three long Western stories that the author later turned into novels. 10 THE RIDER OF THE RUBY HILLS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Four frontier stories that were later expanded into novels. 11 SAN ANDREAS, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett, $4.50.) A British hospital ship with a deadly secret, adrift in the North Sea after a Luftwaffe attack. 12 LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The heiress of a crime lord versus the heiress of a shipping tycoon. 13 HELLFIRE, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.50.) Fury and vengeance pour out when a long-abandoned mill is reopened. 14 SWAN'S CHANCE, by Celeste De Blasis. (Bantam, $4.50.) The Civil War ordeals of the Falconers, a Maryland horse-raising and shipbuilding family. 15 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Bantam, $4.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. NONFICTION General 1 YEAGER, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $4.95.) The test pilot's autobiography. 2 ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Berkley, $4.50.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband and father. 3 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $4.95.) How the son of immigrants rose to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 4 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvin Kinder. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) Modern women's efforts to find good men. 6 LOVING EACH OTHER, by Leo F. Buscaglia. (Fawcett, $7.95.) Suggestions about priorities. ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 BLOOM COUNTY BABYLON, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) Five years of comic strips. 3 IT CAME FROM THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 4 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1986. 5* ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Help for victims of others' compulsive behavior. 6 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Revised edition of the handbook used in Scientology. 7 THE ONE MINUTE SALES PERSON, by Spencer Johnson with Larry Wilson. (Avon, $5.) How to increase selling skills. 8 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed Press, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1986 edition. 9 WHAT THEY DON'T TEACH YOU AT HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL, by Mark H. McCormack. (Bantam, $8.95.) ''Street-smart'' tips.

title: MUSEUM EXPANSION DEBATED
description: LAST January, the board of trustees of Huntington Town's Heckscher Museum and the town Supervisor, John J. O'Neil, jointly announced plans to expand the museum at a cost of almost $5 million.

title: PARIS BLASTS POSE A DILEMMA
description: It is a safe bet that until a few months ago only a small number of Government officials and journalists in France had heard of a 35-year-old Lebanese named Georges Ibrahim Abdallah.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET;
Hopping on the Fitness Bandwagon
description: SUPERMARKETS are jumping on the diet bandwagon.

title: Rebecca Murphy Becomes a Bride
description: At Grace Memorial Chapel in Menauhant, Mass., yesterday Rebecca Cort Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Murphy Jr. of Madison, N.J., and Menauhant, was married to Jeffrey Young Flynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Flynn Jr. of Baltimore and Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Seth W. Newton, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: AQUINO'S AMERICAN AGENDA
description: PRESIDENT Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines is to arrive in the United States tomorrow for nine days of pomp, sentimental visits and chances to improve her country's circumstances. From the first photo opportunity as she steps from a helicopter at the Washington Monument, the schedule is replete with opportunities to impress her hosts and the people back home watching on television.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY OFFICE DISPUTES G.A.O. AUDIT
description: The Social Security Administration took issue last week with a critical audit of its telephone answering services, particularly those provided to callers in the New York-New Jersey region.

title: I LOVE NEW YORK
description: To the Fans of New York:

title: HEARTS AND SLEEVES
description: MOSTLY TRUE CONFESSIONS Looking for Love in the Eighties. By Jean Gonick. 201 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95.

title: MARYLAND KICKS OFF A CONSTITUTIONAL 'CEREBRATION'
description: Two hundred years ago this weekend, this red brick Colonial capital played an unwilling role in the formation of a more perfect union, when delegates from other states met here to discuss the need for changes in the national government.

title: Radon Report Too Early
description: If it appeared to some that the Environmental Protection Agency was not altogether prepared for the barrage of interest in its recent ruling on acceptable levels of radioactive radon in inhabited areas, one reason may be that the disclosure was premature.

title: PARK IS TRYING TO KEEP BISON FROM ROAMING
description: A fence designed to keep bison from wandering out of their Yellowstone Park refuge and onto private land may bring an end to hunting of the animals.

title: Debt Ceiling Should Provide the Greatest Show in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Is There Too Much Football On TV?
description: Replies for publications should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
SHOULD REHNQUIST BE CONFIRMED?;
YES: HE HAS DEMONSTRATED HIS ABILITY
description: Every sitting Associate Justice enthusiastically and unreservedly supports the nomination of William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States. Since his appointment in 1971, he has participated in deciding thousands of cases. During these years, his colleagues have witnessed his judicial temperament, scholarship and understanding of fundamental constitutional precepts. Their personal knowledge of his talents, integrity and judicial performance make their ringing endorsement of the nomination exceptionally persuasive.

title: Q AND A
description: Changing Voting Rules Question: Our co-op has a nine-member board with staggered terms, and we elect three each year at the annual shareholders' meeting. The only restriction on director elections is a prohibition in the certificate of incorporation against cumulative voting (multiplying the number of votes by the number of directors to be elected). Shareholders have voted for one, two or three nominees in the past, but this year there was a surprise announcement by the board that we had to vote for three candidates or lose our vote; the incumbents won as a result of this last-minute change. Some shareholders feel we were denied the right of proper notice and the right to choose exactly which candidates we wanted. What can we do? . . . J. W., Garden City, L.I.

title: Virginia Wedding For Anne Stuntz
description: The marriage of Anne Grayson Stuntz, a vice president of the public finance division of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York, and J. Bradley Swanson, a Foreign Service officer assigned to the State Department in Washington, took place yesterday at the Vienna (Va.) Presbyterian Church.

title: All in the Family, Part 2
description: Senator Jake Garn of Utah and his daughter, Susan Horne, were doing just fine last week, and no doubt feeling a little closer, after doctors transplanted one of the Senator's kidneys into his 27-year-old daughter. The day after what doctors called ''an extremely successful'' six-hour operation, Mr. Garn was up and walking at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, said Dr. Baird Helfrich, who implanted the kidney in Mrs. Horne. The Senator's daughter, whose kidney failure resulted from the diabetes she has suffered since childhood, was ''doing about as good as we get,'' Dr. Helfrich added. Mr. Garn, who last year became the only senator to take a space shuttle flight, was expected out of the hospital in a week and back campaigning for re-election within a month.

title: ABZUG SAYS PARTY RALLIES AROUND HER FOR FALL BID
description: FORMER Representative Bella S. Abzug, fresh from a slender victory in the four-way Democratic primary for the 20th Congressional District race, said last week that she expected considerable support in the fall campaign from party officials who had originally opposed her running.

title: Photography
description: ''Remnants: The Last Jews of Poland'' is an exhibition of color photographs that records the remains of what once was a major religious, cultural and political force within Poland. There is, unfortunately, precious little left to show, but what there is has been conscientiously documented by Tomasz Tomaszewski, a young Polish photojournalist.

title: Ms. Greenough To Wed Editor
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Greenough of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Alice Greenough, to David Emmett Pitt, a son of James E. Pitt of New York and Harriett Philmus Pitt of Vieques, P.R. The wedding is planned for Sept. 28.

title: NEW RULES SOUGHT FOR TRIALS IN ABUSE OF CHILDREN
description: THE Legislature and State Supreme Court have begun to address a problem that is threatening the prosecution of those suspected of child abuse.

title: POSTINGS: Mixed-Use, at a Premium; Blending With the Boutiques
description: It was, perhaps, inevitable that the Mobil station at 90 Main Street in Westport, Conn., would be demolished. In a downtown commercial strip increasingly dominated by boutiques and other trendy establishments, the gas station was no longer considered by many real-estate investors to be the highest and best use of the land.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the ''Our Towns'' column last Sunday and a news summary of the column on page 47 misidentified the town where New Jersey has proposed a site to bury radium waste. The town is Vernon, N.J.

title: George Vetter 3d Weds Ms. Hirschhorn
description: Melanie Deborah Hirschhorn, a daughter of Drs. Kurt and Rochelle Hirschhorn of New York and Wellfleet, Mass., was married last evening to George Matthew Vetter 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vetter Jr. of Barrington, R.I. Judge Richard Owens of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the Lotos Club.

title: RED SOX CONFRONT FANS IN STANDS
description: The Boston Red Sox, who have swept through the American League East for the past four months, rushed into the stands in the eighth inning at Yankee Stadium yesterday, an incident that overshadowed their 11-6 loss to the Yankees on the field.

title: RYAN VS. DITKA: THEIR RIVALRY MOVES TO FIELD
description: TWO days after his finest hour, he was gone, off to Philadelphia to work his wonders on a team far less majestic than the one he was leaving.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
CLEAR DRUG-TESTING POLICY IS NEEDED
description: UNDER what conditions, if any, should your employer be permitted to test you for drug abuse?

title: POSTINGS: At Sheepshead Bay; Fair Winds
description: Although one part of the city's ambitious proposal to revive the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn has been derailed, the waterfront community is continuing to attract interest.

title: GOT $5 FOR A CUP OF COFFEE?
description: It is hard to discuss Tokyo prices these days without sounding like an alarmist, but hard-gulp reality is that the situation has become awful. The dollar's relentless decline, to a record low of about 150 yen to the dollar, has meant that prices for American travelers in Japan are about 60 percent higher than a year ago. And it is no secret that Japan was short on bargains to begin with.

title: MAJOR NEW FOUNDATION TO CONCENTRATE ON CITY
description: With a bequest from the late Aaron Diamond, a real-estate executive, a major foundation is being set up to focus almost exclusively on support of education for minority-group members, medical research and culture in the New York area.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL '86: Colonial League; A NEW CONFERENCE MAKES A STATEMENT
description: THE timing may be just right for the Colonial League, a new football confederation of six colleges that seeks to be a model along philosophical and pragmatic lines. ''Like my commencement speeches,'' one of its founding presidents said.

title: TURKOMAN RALLIES TO WIN MARLBORO
description: Turkoman, the strongest finisher in the country, rallied powerfully from last place to run down Precisionist and draw away to a 1 1/2-length victory in the $500,000 Marlboro Cup yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: WHAT EFFECT IS TV HAVING ON THE EVOLUTION OF ENGLISH?
description: Tomorrow evening at 9 on Channel 13, ''The Story of English'' will begin; the nine-part series, with Robert MacNeil as host, traces the history of the language from its beginnings to the present day. To one who has made a career in broadcast news, and a companion career in seeking to preserve the language in a reasonable state of health, it is encouraging that such a series should find its way onto television. It might also be taken as encouraging that the programs reflect the view that worry about the decline of English is unwarranted and misplaced. English, so Mr. MacNeil has concluded after three years of work on the series, is a mighty river that grows ever wider and richer.

title: PENTAGON EXTENDING ITS AIDS CURB TO R.O.T.C.'S
description: The Pentagon has decided that students enrolled in the service academies or college Reserve Officers' Training Corps programs must be discharged if tests show they have been exposed to the AIDS virus.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston; House Hunting By Computer
description: HOUSE hunters of the future may soon have a new way of finding their way to residential properties being offered for sale or rent if they have the right equipment: a computer and a modem.

title: 5 Touchdowns, 343 Yds.
description: Tony Jeffery rushed for 343 yards and five touchdowns on 15 carries today, best ever for a Southwest Conference back, leading Texas Christian University to a 48-31 victory over Tulane in the season opener for both teams.

title: FROM ROCKET TO RAZOR BLADE, DIAMOND-COATING ERA DAWNS
description: Scientists have discovered a way of coating objects with thin films of synthetic diamond, an achievement that they believe has opened a new era for electronics, optics, machine tools, chemical processing and military technology.

title: RISING CONCERN ON ASBESTOS
description: THE Long Beach Public Library last March packed up its 80,000 volumes, assorted periodicals, more than 3,000 records and all its furnishings and sent them to a storage warehouse in Manhattan.

title: HOSPITALS AND UNION BEGIN TALKS ON CONTRACT
description: Negotiators for 43 hospitals in New York City and the city's largest union of health-care workers have begun talks on a new contract by focusing on a 5 percent raise that was agreed to two years ago but never paid to the employees.

title: Randy Goldstein Wed To Andrew E. Suser
description: Randy Debra Goldstein, a daughter of Jean Goldstein of Manhattan and the late Hyman Goldstein, was married yesterday to Andrew Evans Suser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Lawrence Suser of Brooklyn. Rabbi Stanley Platok performed the ceremony at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: COSTA RICA'S IMAGE AS HAVEN FADING
description: The image of Costa Rica as a refuge for people with nowhere else to hide is quickly fading.

title: That Secret Desire
description: WE ALL READ with different eyes to satisfy unique needs.

title: IT IS NOT I BUT ME, AND I SAY: LEAVE AMERICAN ENGLISH ALONE
description: FOR a long time I have known that the English language was ''going to hell.'' I think I shared that belief as an article of faith, part of today's intellectual climate, with many people. We accepted it uncritically. To be pessimistic about what was happening to the language was a cultural marker. Everyone you knew believed there was a crisis of literacy.

title: THE CITY'S WATCHDOG HAD ITS EYES CLOSED
description: AT the height of the Watergate scandal, a two-part question came to crystallize the crisis for Richard M. Nixon. ''What did the President know?'' Senator Howard Baker demanded. ''And when did he know it?''

title: Exploring Choices Near And Far
description: AS important as money is to retirement planning, it is never the whole story. The life-style plan is a crucial part of the financial plan. Do we want to sell the condo and live aboard a houseboat? Or prepare for a post-retirement job?

title:
ANTIQUES;
LEARNING ABOUT VICTORIAN HOUSES
description: INTEREST among investors in acquiring and upgrading examples of Victorian residential architecture is helping to stabilize and revitalize primarily urban neighborhoods while contributing to the preservation of an important part of our design heritage.

title: CASHEN MADE THE MOST OF DOUBLEDAY'S DOLLARS
description: DAVE JOHNSON, a man on a mission, crossed the town square in Locust Valley on the North Shore of Long Island the other day, out where he and his coaches rent a house for the summer. His mission: ''A bottle of Dom Perignon. I'm taking it to Philadelphia. When we clinch, this one's for me, this is the one we pour in my office.''

title: Bush Delays Announcement On a Presidential Candidacy
description: Vice President Bush has pushed back the timing of a long-expected announcement that he will run for President until late summer or fall of 1987, according to his spokesman.

title: Panel Suggests Test for Boy With AIDS Who Bit Another
description: A committee has recommended that a 4-year-old boy with AIDS who bit a classmate must take a psychological test before returning to school.

title: FOR TWO SMUT SUSPECTS, THE BEST ALIBI OF ALL
description: Two dead men operate a major pornography ring out of Allentown, according to the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography and records kept by investigators in New York.

title: HISTORIC CHURCHES ADAPT TO CHANGE IN AREA
description: Scattered among the office buildings and stores of downtown Washington are a number of historic churches dating to a time when the center of the capital was a thriving residential area as well as a business district and seat of Government.

title: YUGOSLAVS, IN U.S. FORUM, CONCEDE PROBLEMS
description: Yugoslavia is in the midst of a crisis involving a 90 percent inflation rate, a $20 billion foreign debt and painful rivalries among its ethnic groupings, all of which has been freely acknowledged.

title: Charles H. Baker Wed To Susan M. Feldbau
description: Susan M. Feldbau, a daughter of Mrs. Abraham Best of Hollis, Queens, and the late Sidney Feldbau, was married last evening to Charles H. Baker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Baker of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Robert Orkand officiated at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Golf and Country Club.

title: IN DANBURY, PRISON IS JUST TOO INVITING
description: OFFICIALS at the Federal prison in Danbury knew there was a security problem when more than 100 ''No Trespassing'' signs were stolen in less than a month.

title: POSTINGS: Life Savers; Retaining A Tradition
description: If you think about it, there is simple justice in the fact that, to convert the former Life Savers Building in Port Chester, N.Y., into a condominium, the developers have to carve a hole in its center.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
The Future Arrives in Burlington County
description: LATE in the 1970's, a regional shopping center and a small office park went up in Burlington. Then commerce and industry apparently forgot the 14-square-mile township, where empty land is still plentiful and highway access is easy.

title: Make the Drivers Pay
description: Two statistics explain the weekday traffic jams in midtown Manhattan: In 1984, 30 percent fewer people came to the central business district daily than came in 1948, but 80 percent more came by auto. Unless the growth of auto use is checked, everyday traffic by 1990 will resemble the jams of the 1980 subway strike.

title: A ''LUCKY WOMAN'' HELPS YOUNG MUSICIANS HIT A HIGH NOTE
description: ''LIFE has been very good to me,'' said Phyllis Katz of Hewlett Neck. ''I have been a lucky woman, and this is my chance to pay my dues and to help others.''

title: IN LANDFILL 'CRISIS', RECYCLING RETURNS
description: AS more landfills around the state close or near their capacity, cities and towns are looking toward heavy-duty recycling as an answer to waste disposal.

title: 'SMALL WORLDS,' TIFFANY HOLIDAY DISPLAYS, AT QUAKER MUSEUM
description: ''ONE of the things we're pleased about is that this is an exhibition that will appeal to children as well as adults,'' said Pat McDermott, curator and director of education for the Scarsdale Historical Society. She was discussing the 13 dioramas, originally designed and constructed by the artist Robert Heitmann for the annual holiday windows at Tiffany & Company in New York City and currently on display at the society's 1828 Quaker Meeting House Museum.

title: Gallic Gall
description: Richard Bernstein's happy puncturing of Gallic linguistic pretensions (''Gallic Gall,'' On Language, Aug. 17) was marred by what has become a de rigueur genuflection at the beginning of any similar critical piece: describing the French language as one of ''precision'' and ''elegance.'' He contradicts his own description of ''precision'' when he tells us of his difficulties with the lack of a French distinction between ''like'' and ''love.'' I must presume that the use of plaire (to please) has disappeared except for s'il vous plait (a rather imprecise way of saying ''please,'' come to think of it).

title: DON QUIXOTE IN THE TRENCHES
description: CONFESSIONS OF A PARISH PRIEST An Autobiography. By Andrew M. Greeley. 507 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Islanders Open Camp
description: WITH Al Arbour's 13-season reign as coach of the New York Islanders at an end, Terry Simpson was in charge yesterday as 66 players reported to the opening of training camp in Hicksville, L.I. The new head coach, who spent the last 14 years guiding the Prince Albert team in the Western Hockey League, began his tenure by greeting 6 goaltenders, 10 centers, 15 right wings, 16 left wings and 19 defensemen at Cantigue Park. He will be assisted by Bob Nystrom, an Islander right wing for 14 seasons before suffering an eye injury last January that hastened his retirement.

title: TUGGLE'S FIGHT AGAINST TIME
description: ON a sultry Friday in August, John Tuggle, who made football history and became the Giants' fullback despite being selected last in the 1983 draft, hitched a trailer carrying his new powerboat to his truck and drove out to the San Joaquin delta to water-ski with two friends. Less than two weeks later, Tuggle, 25 years old, died in his sleep while undergoing treatments at a cancer clinic in Mexico. Because he never accepted the terminal nature of his illness, the friends didn't realize that the outing was Tuggle's last hurrah.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from West Chester, Pa., on Aug. 31 about Pennsylvania's Fifth Congressional District race misidentified the incumbent. He is Richard T. Schulze, not Robert.

title: Q&A
description: PANAMA CANAL Question:Which is the better way to travel through the Panama Canal, from east or west? What time of year is best for the trip, and what part of the ship is preferable? Any other suggestions for first-time cruise passengers? - G. J. D., Nutley, N.J. Answer:Travelers who have sailed on several trans-Panama Canal cruises say that more important than the direction is whether you want to fly out to the ship or fly home. All cruises through the canal are combined with - or require - a flight. For example, on a 15-day cruise in either direction between Fort Lauderdale and Los Angeles, the passenger flies to or from one of those two ports. People who live in Florida often prefer to sail from Los Angeles because then, when they disembark, perhaps carrying souvenirs, they can have someone meet them by car instead of having to get on a plane to go home. There is no significant difference, experienced cruisers say, in going through the locks one way or the other, and in either direction passage takes six to eight hours. But the Pacific side has strong tides, rising an average of about 12 1/2 feet; the Caribbean side's tidal range is less than a foot.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PARKINSON'S GROUP
description: Patients with Parkinson's disease, their families and community members concerned about the neurological condition are meeting 3 P.M. Tuesday in Room G41 of Building 7, the Wood Pavilion, of the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains.

title: NEPAL'S ENDURING ART
description: In Nepal, a land of Hindu-Buddhist gods where the triangle is a sacred figure and crimson-red the auspicious color, art surrounds the traveler.

title: MOISEYEV DANCES ARE CLASSICS NOW
description: The Moiseyev Dance Company has always been what its founder Igor Moiseyev said it was, a professional ballet company whose subject and style focus on folk material - itself always theatricalized for stage purposes.

title: Readings on Project Management
description: LAST week my uncle from Austria was visiting us and, as often happens during his stays, the conversation turned toward the cultural changes in our respective countries. No longer, for instance, is there an all-classical music station within the range of his radio, a range that includes such baroque bastions as Vienna and Salzburg. Here, it is not yet impossible to twiddle the FM dial and find, sandwiched between the machine music of rock purveyed by most broadcasters, a station firmly rooted in pre-1900's sonority.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET;
High Tech at the Check-Out Counter
description: SUPERMARKET managers are turning to technology to help them make their huge stores less intimidating.

title: BIAS REPORT DISPUTED
description: A new medical report, disputed by the state medical examiner, suggests that Len Bias, the Maryland basketball star, died as the result of swallowing cocaine, possibly in a drink, rather than sniffing or smoking it.

title: Back in Key West
description: Pritham Singh apparently liked what he saw of Key West, Fla., during the few months he spent there in the late 1960's hawking shells to the tourists. He was back last week when the Navy auctioned off the historic Truman Annex, and made the winning bid, $17.5 million.

title: MICHIGAN EDGES IRISH
description: He would stop pacing the sidelines whenever something went wrong, and a lot of things went wrong.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RIGHT TURN: The Decline of the Democrats and the Future of American Politics. By Thomas Ferguson and Joel Rogers. (Hill & Wang, $19.95.)

title: A MODERN WOMAN OUT OF OLD INDIA
description: A COPY OF A children's book, ''Bala, Child of India,'' published in the United States in 1968 and now out of print, was given to me by the authors, Luree Miller and Marilyn Silverstone. My grandson likes it because it has real pictures of real people in a real village in India. The story relates how Bala and her brother Padam went to the Republic Day parade in New Delhi on a bullock cart, leaving behind their sister, Shashi, weeping because she was not old enough to go.

title: MEN'S CLOTHES FOR WOMEN
description: AFTER CLAUDETTE COLBERT borrowed Clark Gable's pajamas in the movie ''It Happened One Night,'' she suddenly seemed fragile and kittenish. In return, she made men's pajamas chic. An oversize man's shirt similarly transformed Audrey Hepburn in ''Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' and in her case, too, the exchange was mutual.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MONUMENTAL THE sculptor Arden Scott refers to it as ''my gift to the community.'' And next Sunday afternoon at 2 her community, the Village of Greenport, will officially accept her present.

title: FIRST U.S. IRRADIATED FRUIT, PUERTO RICAN MANGOES, ON SALE IN MIAMI
description: For the first time, the Department of Agriculture has allowed onto the United States mainland fruit that has been subjected to radiation by gamma rays to eradicate insects and harmful bacteria.

title: PROTESTER TAKES TO THE PIGS
description: Thomas Hefele raised quite a stink in his neighborhood after the town zoning board turned down his request to build more homes on his property. He started a pig farm.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PACIFIC INDIAN EXHIBIT

title: For Giants, Hard Road Ahead
description: Before the National Football League's regular season began last weekend, many forecasters said the Giants would go to the Super Bowl. The path is still there, but it is not quite so smooth, especially because the Giants must play the explosive San Diego Chargers at 1 P.M. Sunday in Giants Stadium. The Giants are 3 1/2-point favorites.

title: CHAIRMAN PALEY RETURNS TO A DIFFERENT TV WORLD
description: THE TREMORS that have unnerved CBS for months became convulsions last week. When the place was finally still, William S. Paley, the man who founded the network in 1928, was back in control.

title: A RAW RECRUIT NAMED ANNA
description: GOD'S SNAKE By Irini Spanidou. 252 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: Miss Anderson, Lawyer, Is Wed To Larry Flood
description: The marriage of Rozlyn Lucille Anderson, the daughter of Dr. Russell Lloyd Anderson Jr. of Tallahassee, Fla., and Betty Douglas Anderson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., to Larry Flood, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Flood Jr. of Philadelphia, took place yesterday. The Rev. B. Daniel Clater, a Baptist minister and uncle of the bride, officiated at the Estherwood estate in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Bitter Poverty In New York
description: WHEN Governor Cuomo called upstate Essex County ''abject poor'' in his keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention in July 1984, some residents took offense. The Governor apologized.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRITY PORTRAIT SHOW

title: Alison Bell Holt Wed to C. M. Knight
description: Alison Bell Holt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Alan Holt of Darien, Conn., and Fairhope, Ala., was married yesterday to Christopher M. Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guyon H. Knight Jr. of Pinehurst, N.C. The Rev. Lawrence MacCall Horton performed the ceremony at the Talmadge Hill Community Church in Darien.

title: High Party Post Due For Maureen Reagan
description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the national chairman of the Republican Party, endorsed Maureen Reagan today for co-chairman of the party.

title: PHILHARMONIA SERIES AT 2 SITES
description: PHILHARMONIA VIRTUOSI, the county's pre-eminent professional chamber orchestra, is maintaining its split geographical personality this year by reinstating two parallel series: the popular ''Bach's Lunch'' cycle of (mostly) Baroque music resumes in Valhalla next Sunday at Westchester Community College, while the long-established concerts at the State University of New York at Purchase, this season dubbed ''The Connoisseur Series,'' begin a week later.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NOW my children are struggling to maintain our standard of living.

title: Renoir Film Festival Starts at the Regency
description: Two films by Jean Renoir, ''The River'' (1951), with Nora Swinburne, Esmond Knight and Patricia Walters, and ''The Rules of the Game'' (1939), with Marcel Dalio, Nora Gregor and Roland Toutain, will open a retrospective of the French director's work today at the Regency Theater, Broadway between 67th and 68th Streets.

title: NAVAJO WEAVINGS THAT SPIN A BRILLIANT WEB OF COLOR
description: Some extraordinary Navajo weavings - pulsing with color, boldly striped or splashed with diamonds, crosses, triangles and bolts of lightning - are on view in ''Historic Navajo Weaving 1800-1900,'' at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, at Rutgers University, through Nov. 11.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TO BE FREE! By Ron Martin. (Vanguard, $14.95.) In this novel about ''the bloody maw'' of the Vietnam War, the protagonist, Jack Ramsey, is a prisoner of war saturated in symbolism.

title: Delta and Western Hope to Form One Carrier
description: In the old days, before they were freed from their regulatory cages, airlines were about as competitive as the Postal Service or the old A.T. & T. The Civil Aeronautics Board told them where they could fly and what they could charge.

title: TIN ROOFS AMONG THE PEACH TREES
description: FOOLS And Other Stories. By Njabulo Ndebele. 280 pp. New York: Readers International/Persea Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: SHERIFF RACE KEY TO BOSTON IMAGE
description: The race for Suffolk County Sheriff has come down to a contest between a self-described ''conservative law and order man'' who threatens to ''kick in the brains'' of judges who delay trials and a bureaucrat who says, ''I carry a beeper, not a gun.''

title: Extending the S.R.O. Moratorium
description: PERHAPS no real-estate issue on the city's legislative agenda is potentially so significant for the city's physical evolution than the Koch administration's proposed long-term ban on the demolition or alteration of single-room-occupancy housing units by private owners.

title: DATA BANK: Sept.14, 1986
STRONG STYLE FAILS KARPOV IN 15TH GAME
description: Once again, in the 15th game of the world chess championship match in Leningrad on Friday, Gary Kasparov's Gruenfeld Defense stopped Anatoly Karpov cold.

title: Letter-Writer
description: One thing that irritates House members above all others is politicians outside Congress who tell them how to conduct their internal affairs. Thus, it seems unlikely that Gov. Bob Graham of Florida will enhance Representative Charles E. Bennett's chances of being elected chairman of the House Armed Services Committee in the next Congress through his effort of writing to all Democratic House members on behalf of his fellow Floridian.

title: Sorting Out Options In Life Insurance
description: HARDEN H. WIEDEMANN, who is 34 years old, married and the father of a three-year-old son, once considered cashing in his life insurance policies that combine elements of savings and insurance, then buying less costly term policies that provide only life insurance - but much more of it.

title: NIPPING A BOUNTIFUL MARIJUANA CROP
description: IN THE lush valleys north of San Francisco, wine makers in recent weeks have rushed to bottle a new vintage. And in the mountain ranges that rise just beyond the wine country, another harvest has been in full swing.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
PHILHARMONIC SPINOFF: CHAMBER PLAYERS
description: GERALD TARACK thinks the Long Island Philharmonic is the ''best freelance orchestra in New York.''

title: SALARY FUND UPSETS SCHOOLS
description: WESTCHESTER school administrators began the year faced with an unusual problem - how to deal with a state gift of $1.6 million that few local districts want.

title: SHARING THE THRONE AT BLACK ROCK
description: AT the end of CBS's dramatic nine hour board meeting last Wednesday, the company's two triumphant power brokers, William S. Paley and Laurence A. Tisch, seemed to be acting quite independently of each other. The 84-year-old Mr. Paley, once again chairman of the company he founded 58 years ago, sat smiling at the boardroom table of fine English walnut. He was clearly tired but his jacket was still on and he looked crisp and ready for action.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JOHN FORD: The Man and His Films. By Tag Gallagher. (University of California, $35.) This study of John Ford is an almost flawless blend of criticism and biography about one of America's greatest film directors.

title: Baby M.'s Father Wins Custody
description: Mary Beth Whitehead was in tears last week after a New Jersey court ruled that the baby she had been hired to bear would be allowed to stay, temporarily at least, with the father.

title: AFTER DELAYS, S.I. COMPLEX IS DEDICATED
description: Far from the spires of Manhattan, off a Staten Island country road well traveled by horseback riders, New York City's most futuristic office development was dedicated last week.

title: Buying a Town Dogged by Fire
description: AFTER living more than 20 years atop a spreading coal fire, the property owners of Centralia, Pa., considered a ''final'' state offer early this year: sell by Sept. 1 and relocate.

title: A FORMER MET ENJOYS CHANCE TO SPOIL PARTY
description: If he had regrets, Ronn Reynolds would not let them show tonight. He smiled brightly. He seemed to savor this victory as if it were different from others. He wanted it to be special.

title: STATE ACTS TO REDUCE OZONE POLLUTION
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is considering several steps that would significantly reduce the amount of ozone in the air, but officials concede that New Jersey still has a long way to go before it meets the health standard established by the Federal Clean Air Act.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston;
A $40 Million Place to Play
description: IT is Friday night at Fame City, one of the nation's first entertainment malls, and the good times are rolling. In Studio Circus, a discotheque on the second level of the 200,000-square-foot mall, hundreds of fashionably dressed teen-agers swing to the latest beat under throbbing strobe lights on a two-tier dance floor.

title: Jane Ellyn Stark Is Married
description: Jane Ellyn Stark, a daughter of Solomon Stark of New York and the late Charlotte Stark, was married last evening to Stuart A. Berger, a son of Mrs. Michael Mobile of Ocala, Fla., and a stepson of Mr. Mobile. Rabbi Mike Rosen performed the ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens. The bride is a vice president in charge of media and production at the Milton Samuels Advertising Agency in New York. Mr. Berger is a vice president of finance at Direct Mass Marketing in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: PROSPECTS
description: More Declines Ahead

title: FOR LINDA RONSTADT, THE PAST CONTINUES TO INSPIRE
description: ''The mythographer Joseph Campbell invented a wonderful phrase, 'following your bliss,' ''

title: Sports of The Times; The Mets And Their Catch-86
description: THE accents on the subway were more Queens Boulevard than Broad Street. There was a predominance of blue and orange T-shirts, and one somehow got the feeling the wearers had not come to town for the Judy Chicago exhibition at the Philadelphia Art Alliance.

title: GLASS AND STEEL GILD THE HEART OF HONG KONG
description: Even the sound of it is like a gong:

title: Ann Hotung Has Wedding
description: Ann Mary Hotung and Donald Charles Walkovik, both lawyers, were married in New York yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. The Rev. Laurence McGinley, president emeritus of Fordham University and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Against H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Grappling With Plans: 4 Profiles
description: An artist in Manhattan and a Kansas farmer. Two expatriates who teach on the island of Crete and dream of retiring to Florida. An executive from Colorado who quit the corporate life to start his own semiconductor company - all have struggled recently with some aspect of financial planning: how to hang on to present income, send the kids to college, make a business grow or supplement retirement income. These are problems almost everyone has to grapple with. What follows is a look at the financial plans being mapped by these individuals to solve those problems. WORRY AMID THE IDYLL LEE AND RICHARD HOWE live on the Greek island of Crete in the eastern Mediterranean, where they teach school at an American military base and have time to wind surf and to play tennis, bridge and racquetball. Their combined salaries total $65,000, and they enjoy free housing and shopping privileges at the military post exchange. Indeed, they say their basic living expenses come to only $4,000 a year - leaving them plenty of cash, even after paying the required United States taxes, to travel extensively during their three-month vacations, and to put money aside for the future.

title: Verbatim; Another Right to Die
description: 'In certain, thankfully rare circumstances, the burden of maintaining the corporeal existence degrades the very humanity it was meant to serve.

title: NO: HE HAS ADVOCATED SEGREGATION
description: Some senators apparently believe William H. Rehnquist when he states he has always believed racial discrimination is, and ought to be, unconstitutional. It is time to concede that his record speaks louder than his words. As Associate Justice, he has sought at every opportunity to minimize the constitutional and statutory protections against invidious discrimination.

title: A Boy On a Bike
description: Chuck Stevenson's About Men column (''Riding With the Pack,'' Aug. 17) should have been titled ''About a Boy.'' Mr. Stevenson's essay exudes not much more than adolescent cockiness, and I think we can do without that in such a column.

title: Ms. Payer Is Wed To David Thayer, A Legal Assistant
description: The marriage of Heather MacLeod Payer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen C. Payer of Old Lyme, Conn., to David Thayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart W. Thayer of New York, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme. The Rev. David Good performed the ceremony.

title: BARGAIN BURGERS: A SAVORY FIND
description: GOING out to dinner doesn't always mean going in style. But sometimes the informal, family style of dining out poses more problems than choosing an elegant place for special occasions.

title: Investing to Meet Objectives
description: INVESTING, financial planners say, should be thought of as a journey. And, before deciding on a mode of transportation, the traveler must determine his destination.

title: RECITAL SHOWCASES FOR SEVEN SOPRANOS
description: Eight new recorded recitals highlight the current vocal harvest. They range over three centuries of music -opera from Handel to Puccini, songs from Dowland to Debussy -and feature seven sopranos perched on various rungs of the celebrity ladder.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S as American as apple pie, baseball and the Rockettes. It was once called an automobile or ''the auto,'' and eventually it became known as a car. Then another generation came along and talked about ''wheels.'' Goodness only knows what name it goes under today; maybe it's called a car again.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW JAPANESE SPOT IN SCARSDALE
description: OPEN just eight weeks, Ginza, a restaurant and sushi bar, makes a welcome addition to the county's growing number of Japanese dining spots, and it is with good reason that reservations are a must, even on weeknights. First, the menu displays variety, listing several dishes rarely found in the county. Furthermore, the high quality of meats and especially of seafood deserves all the appreciation diners seem to be giving it. And, finally, the tempura - crisp, golden-battered and featherweight shrimp and vegetables - is superb.

title: ARMY OFFENSE KEY TO UPSET OF ORANGE
description: On one of those gorgeous days in the Hudson Valley, all was right with the world - Army's world that is.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Interstate Sanitation Commission has scuttled plans to hold hearings on water pollution from a Staten Island landfill.

title: DRIVE'S GOAL: BETTER MEDICAL AID FOR CHILDREN
description: Two years ago, Dr. Burton Brons-ther, a Long Island pediatric surgeon, visited a hospital in India and watched with dismay as 26 children crippled by polio crawled across the floor like crabs to greet him.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JEFFREY COUNTY. By Kathleen Ford. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Despite its contemporary setting, Kathleen Ford's first novel recalls at every turn what a harrowing thing it was, looking for love in the smug, oblivious 50's.

title: POP: MEL TORME AND TRIO
description: WHILE Mel Torme has long been recognized as a singer's singer, it is only in the last five years that he has ascended to the status of pop-jazz institution. Like Ella Fitzgerald, Mr. Torme exemplifies a serene pop-jazz classicism that balances the energy and inventiveness of be-bop with an abiding respect for the formal values of the well-made popular song. The years have yet to diminish Mr. Torme's extraordinary vocal endowment. Rather, the voice that used to be known as ''the velvet fog'' has thickened and deepened in a way that mutes its luscious romanticism to allow the assertion of a more pensive point of view.

title: FILM TRIAL WITNESS TELLS OF WORRIES
description: The first prosecution witness in the manslaughter trial of John Landis, director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' has testified that he and another defendant indicated they feared legal repercussions for filming children near explosives used for special effects.

title: THE RETURN OF CYNDI LAUPER
description: TONIGHT'S THE night - deadline night. Cyndi Lauper arrives at Sterling Sound in midtown Manhattan clutching a bottle of Dom Perignon champagne, to be opened when her long-awaited second album, ''True Colors,'' is completed.

title: STATE POOL LAW AFFECTS ISLAND
description: WHEN they received their tax bills last month, residents of the Village of East Hampton also got notices informing them that all swimming pools must be fenced in. The notices have caused many complaints about the apparent change in the regulations and the village's sudden hard-line stance.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Cambridge, Mass., dispatch last Sunday about a discussion of poverty conducted during Harvard University's observance of its 350th anniversary omitted part of a comment from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. He said, ''When we get the next depression -recession - we're going to get one -median income is likely to fall back.'' Mr. Moynihan's reference to a depression was a slip of the tongue, according to his spokesman, Paul J. Browne.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MORNING HAS BROKEN: A Biography of Eleanor Farjeon. By Annabel Farjeon. (Julia MacRae/Franklin Watts, $19.95.) When Eleanor Farjeon died in 1965 at the age of 84, she was one of the enduring names in children's writing.

title: 'Icebound' Once Before
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union does not want this trivial and secondary incident to interfere with the development of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.'' - Gennadi I. Gerasimov, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, on the Daniloff and Zakharov cases. [ 14:4. ]

title: RANGERS' 7 HOMERS DOWN TWINS
description: Texas hit a club-record seven home runs, including two each by Darrell Porter and Ruben Sierra, as the Rangers beat the Minnesota Twins, 14-1, today and snapped a six-game losing streak.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE FACE IN THE MIRROR
description: ''AS is her mother, so is her daughter.''

title: Article 056186 -- No Title
description: A retired Postal Service worker from West Springfield was identified Friday as the sole winner of $6,560,782 in the Massachusetts lottery. The winner, Albert M. Angelico, 70 years old, picked up the first of 20 annual checks for $246,029.00 at lottery headquarters, according to Brendan Sullivan, a spokesperson for the Megabucks lottery.

title:
GARDENING;
PAWPAW TREE OFFERS FRUIT AND BEAUTY
description: uf9420>THE papaw is a little known and underused native fruit.

title: REAGAN, IN SWITCH, WILL BOLSTER U.N. BY SEEKING FUNDS
description: After a wave of Congressional budget cuts that could severely hurt the United Nations, the Reagan Administration has quietly started a campaign to reverse that trend and bolster the organization, according to Administration officials.

title: Firecrackers Kill 20 on Bus
description: At least 20 people were killed and 22 badly burned when firecrackers exploded in a crowded bus, the official Shanghai Liberation Daily said. The paper, received in Peking today, said all 42 people on the bus were hurt in the explosion last Saturday on the road between Ganzhou and Xiamen in the southeastern province of Fujian.

title: ON THE BLODDY TRAIL OF SABRI AL-BANNA
description: THE MASTER TERRORIST The True Story of Abu Nidal. By Yossi Melman. Illustrated. 215 pp. New York: Adama Books. $16.95.

title: Rosanna Scotto, Reporter, Wed to Louis J. Ruggiero
description: Rosanna Scotto, a reporter for Channel 5 News in New York, was married yesterday to Louis John Ruggiero, an associate in the law firm of J. M. Furey & R. J. Furey in Hempstead, L.I. Msgr.

title: Perusing a 'Menu' Of Traffic Cures
description: New York City's traffic may soon be more than the law will allow. In a report last week, Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler warned that the city would have to get itself in gear if it is to comply with Federal clean-air requirements.

title: 'HAIR SHIRT' BUILDS MAGAZINE EMPIRE
description: D. Herbert Lipson's first magazine, which he acquired from his father 25 years ago, was called Philadelphia. It wasn't much of a magazine at first, but it gradually reflected countless images of Benjamin Franklin and cheese steak, urban blight and gentrification, Philadelphia jokes and media gossip and advice on where to get the best -whatever.

title: AUGUSTANA 37-0 STREAK ENDED
description: Augustana, the N.C.A.A. Division III champion the past three years, had its 37-game streak, the longest active winning string in collegiate football, broken today in a scoreless tie with Elmhurst College, Jim Heavey had two interceptions and a fumble recovery for Elmhurst.

title: SUMATRA UNTAMED
description: Most people first encounter Indonesia in the mysterious places. They get mired in mystical

title: CONNECTICUT DIRECTORS ON STAGE: FORUM OPENS THEATER YEAR
description: IN what has been called ''an unprecedented event in state theater history,'' the artistic directors of four of the state's foremost regional theaters will participate in a Connecticut Directors Forum, during which topics and issues concerning Connecticut theaters, theirs in particular, will be discussed.

title: Allison Dempsey Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Allison Dempsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Dempsey Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen B. Gruppo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno Gruppo of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. Stephen DeLuca performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: 1786 CALL FOR A CONVENTION
description: From the call for a constitutional convention adopted Sept. 14, 1786, at Annapolis by delegates of Delaware, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Virginia:

title: Getting Tickets:Pan Am Games
description: More than 6,500 athletes from 37 countries will meet in Indianapolis next Aug. 7 to 23 for the 10th Pan American Games, an event held only once before in the United States, in Chicago in 1959. Competition in 27 sports will include gymnastics, diving, cycling and track and field.

title: HOPPER AT STAMFORD WHITNEY: SCENES OF CALM AND MENACE
description: LURKING in the shadow cast by a house near railroad tracks is a small bluish form that could be a woman in a long dress. Otherwise, the 51 canvases, watercolors, drawings and etchings that make up the Stamford Whitney's Edward Hopper show are devoid of people.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
PORT JEFFERSON
description: TO people who live there, it is just Port Jeff. ''It's the only place on Long Island I know of whose residents think of it with such affection that they gave it a nickname,'' said John McKinney, the editor and publisher of The Port Jefferson Record, a weekly newspaper.

title: LAWYER IS CHARGED IN FAKE-MARRIAGE CONSPIRACY
description: A White Plains lawyer and five other people have been indicted on charges of arranging sham marriages for 19 Haitians, most of whom are believed to have been in the United States illegally, to help them gain permanent residential status.

title: Souci Upton Engaged To Wed Alger Rollins
description: Souci Bartlett Upton and Alger Rollins, 1981 graduates of the University of Vermont, plan to be married Oct. 11. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Gordon Upton of Bedford, N.H., and Darien, Conn., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mrs. Sherwood Rollins Jr. of Durham, N.H., and the late Mr. Rollins.

title: Mary Schneider Weds Classmate
description: Mary Schneider and Juan Enriquez-Cabot, who graduated cum laude and magna cum laude, respectively, with the class of '81 from Harvard College, were married yesterday at Emanuel Episcopal Church in Manchester, Mass. The Rev. Dr. George Hunter performed the ceremony.

title: FOILING THE FLOOD: HOW TO KEEP WATER AWAY FROM THE HOUSE
description: WET basements, flooding of foundation plantings and washouts of soil and lawns next to houses can be major problems.

title: TOPICS
description: MY niece, her husband and their three small children visited in Baldwin for a month. When I stayed with them in Ireland, they drove me along the glorious Antrim Coast Road and we climbed the Giant's Causeway.

title: LEHIGH LOSES OPENER
description: A new league, a new rivalry, two new coaches, new quarterbacks running offenses with half a dozen new starters each and a refurbished stadium were the elements of the Holy Cross-Lehigh game today at Fitton Field.

title: Increased Survival Reported For Children in Cancer Study
description: A new combination of five drugs increases the chances of survival for children stricken with the most common form of juvenile cancer, researchers have reported.

title: Miss Tennessee Wins Miss America Contest
description: Miss Tennessee, Kellye Cash, the grandniece of the country-music singer Johnny Cash, was selected Miss America 1987 here tonight.

title: Miss Luckhardt Marries in Maine
description: Mildred Corell Luckhardt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Luckhardt of Easton, Conn., was married yesterday in Southport, Maine, to Brenton Shaw Halsey Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey of Richmond. The Rev. Douglas J. Rumford of the First Presbyterian Church in Fairfield, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of All Saints-by-the-Sea.

title: EVEN FOR THE DEMOCRATS, REAGAN SEEMS TO BE A GIVEN
description: HERE he goes again: President Reagan, the master campaigner, jumped squarely into the middle of the 1986 Congressional elections last week. And once again, the crowds were behind him when he pleaded with the faithful to start paying attention to politics. ''It is a make-or-break election,'' he declared to supporters of Representative Ed Zschau, the California Republican who is challenging Senator Alan Cranston.

title: MUSIC: A FLUTE FESTIVAL
description: THE first installment of ''The Magic Flute: An International Festival,'' which took place at the 92d Street Y Thursday, went on far too long but offered some diverting moments along the way.

title: NEW WAVE JAPANESE ARCHITECTS
description: When I look at the buildings designed by the ''New Wave'' of architects, I once again wonder how long they will continue to ignore all of the social planning lessons of the 20th century in favor of ''immortalizing'' their own philosophical viewpoints in stone, steel or concrete.

title: DRUNKS ON ROAD FACING MORE FEES
description: DRUNKEN drivers would have to pay higher fees to the state and to their home counties under a bill passed by the Assembly and expected to be signed soon by Governor Kean.

title: Honduran Chief Affirms Ban On U.S. Trainers for Contras
description: President Jose Azcona Hoyo has said that ''not a single U.S. soldier'' will be allowed into Honduras to train rebels who seek to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: GROTON STUDIES SECESSION
description: GROTON, the only city in Connecticut with its own government while still part of another town, wants to shed its unique status and become just another municipality.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: VERMONT SKIIERS: A BAD BREAK

title: A GIANT ENSLAVED, A MIDGET MISPLACED
description: CARNIVAL FOR THE GODS By Gladys Swan. 229 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries/Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: Adventures of the Scrabble People in a Pumpkin Full of Nonsense Written by George Atkins Children's Video Library 30 minutes. $19.95

title: Paying For School Costs, No Easy Task
description: LAURENCE CLARFELD is only 14 months old. But his father, Robert, is already thinking about saving for Laurence's education.

title: FROM QUEENS, A PLEA TO MOSCOW TO RELEASE SONS
description: For six years, Riva Feldman has waited quietly for the authorities in the Soviet Union to keep their pledge to let her sons join her. Now this Soviet Jewish mother, a home attendant in Middle Village, Queens, believes her only hope is to appeal directly to the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: House Panel Sets A Price for Conrail
description: The House of Representatives is making progress in the search for a deal on Conrail. Last week members of a key subcommittee in the House, where the Senate-approved sale of the freight line to the Norfolk Southern Corporation met fatal resistance, agreed on a plan to sell the public the Government's stock for a minimum of $2 billion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 10 on the Isle of Jersey gave an incorrect date for the construction of Elizabeth Castle. It was built in 1594.

title: FOR NEW YORK PATIENTS, MORE ACCESS TO RECORDS
description: A long medical tradition that has given doctors and hospitals unquestioned control over the medical records of their patients will end in New York with a new state law that takes effect Jan. 1.

title:
GETTING THE MOST FROM YOUR ASSETS;
The Right Planner Can Help
description: IN personal finance, horror stories are a dime a dozen.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HONEYMOON. By Kathleen Spivack. (Graywolf, $7, Paper.) The title story of this slender volume is ironically named, for these honeymooners discover how little they have in common during a tour of Europe, when the man refuses to budge from his Paris hotel room, and his wife begins a lesbian relationship with an old college chum.

title: Robin Leavitt Is Wed To Eric David Melen
description: At St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford, Conn., yesterday Robin Leavitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scot Leavitt of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married to Eric David Melen, a son of William Melen and Joan Melen of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Robert M. Dresser performed the ceremony.

title: House Approves A Sanctions Bill
description: AFTER more than two years of debate on Capitol Hill and over the objections of President Reagan, the House of Representatives gave final legislative approval last week to a measure that would impose new economic sanctions on South Africa, including a ban on all new American investment.

title: FOR BELAGA, TWO MONTHS TO PRESENT HER CASE
description: AFTER months of preliminaries with intraparty fighting at state conventions and primary elections, the main bout finally began last week to elect a Governor of Connecticut on Nov. 4.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Saltwater Fishing Late in the Season
description: ALTHOUGH charter- and party-boat skippers from Cape Cod to New Jersey know that most of summer's casual anglers disappear after Labor Day, September and October and often a few weeks of November offer some of the best saltwater fishing of the year.

title: FOUNDATION HELPS BRING ENVIRONMENT TO PEOPLE
description: ''THE Indians knew best,'' said Samuel Sadove, reaching delicately into a patch of poison ivy and pulling out a sprig bearing small yellow flowers.

title: Article 045086 -- No Title
description: More than $100,000 in jewelry and watches was stolen from a Madison Avenue branch of Cartier early yesterday after thieves drilled through the door locks and smashed display cases, the police and store officials said.

title: Emily Sneath Has Wedding
description: Emily Bernice Sneath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath of Riverside, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt., was married in Riverside yesterday to John Spencer Jones Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title:
DIING OUT;
ON TAKING A GAMBLE IN PASSAIC
description: OPENING Bacchus, an intimate dining room and bar, in Passaic eight months ago was something of a gamble on the part of the owners, James Morrison and his son-in-law, Garry Klein. For who would think to offer a terrine of pike and salmon with a red pepper puree or medallions of lamb with woodland mushrooms and coriander on a back street in an industrial neighborhood that doesn't exactly sing of culinary promise.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A STEPMOTHER
description: LISA AND ALEX, AGES 6 AND 3, were standing in a fountain in the middle of the Santa Monica Mall. I insisted they get out. They refused. Again I insisted. Lisa put her arm around her brother and drew him closer to her.

title: Drug Buyer, Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PLAN TO AID L.I. WILDLIFE AND COASTS
description: A FEDERAL regulatory program aimed at protecting coastal fish and wildlife habitats from intensive condominium and recreational development will shield dozens of shoreline species in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for the first time when it is put into effect by Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer this fall.

title: FIRST LADY ASKED FOR TALK ON DRUGS
description: It began with a conversation several weeks ago at their mountaintop ranch near Santa Barbara.

title: ITS ONLY DEFENSE: INTELLIGENCE AND SPARKLE
description: THE essay? Thousands of pages of prose are published each month and not many of them are given to fiction. Perhaps most of the pages are information about the events of the day or the week and are not to be thought of as essays. What is this thunder and hail of newsprint felling the forests of the world? Journalism? Not quite, not nowadays. The knowing would not restrict the word ''journalism'' to mere information, if information can be thought of as mere. Nowadays journalism is a restless and predatory engagement, having established its imperial mandate under the phrase ''new journalism,'' established its claim with such occupying force that the phrase itself is no longer needed, no longer defining.

title: AMERICAN TRAVELERS STAYED CLOSER TO HOME
description: If not to Europe, where did Americans go last summer?

title: AQUINO IN TRUCE WITH 100 TRIBAL REBELS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino flew today to the Cordillera Mountains north of Manila, where her spokesmen said she joined an animist ritual and formed a truce with a small tribal insurgency led by a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FROM SAMOANS TO SEX TO SUMATRANS, AT THE MARGARET MEAD FILM FESTIVAL
description: IN 1925, Margaret Mead strode into a village on the Pacific island of Samoa with camera and notebook and asked teen-agers about their social and sexual lives.

title: The Theology He Teaches Is No Longer Catholic; The Life of Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEPHONE WORKERS IN CONNECTICUT GO ON STRIKE
description: More than 9,000 telephone workers for the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation went on strike yesterday, and management employees reported to work to keep essential services in operation throughout most of Connecticut.

title: ASK YOUR QUESTION AND DUCK
description: ME AND DIMAGGIO A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods. By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. 303 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Terence J. McLaughlin Is Wed to Sally J. Lewis
description: Sally Jeanne Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Adams Lewis Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Stratton, Vt., was married yesterday to Terence John McLaughlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas McLaughlin of Garden City and Jamesport, L.I. The Very Rev. Robert V. Wilshire, Dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, performed the service, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Gary O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Pop Music
description: The Smiths, the English rock quartet led by the singer-songwriter Morrissey, is an anomaly in the pleasure-oriented world of rock. Where the vast majority of rock songs talk about good times and being rowdy, Morrissey writes absorbing poetic meditations on having a bad time and feeling unable to act.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COLONIAL BLACKS

title: Travel Advisory; Fall in New England, Winter in Guatemala
description: Annual Blaze Of Leaves In Vermont Three train rides in Vermont offer leaf peepers unusual views of fall foliage.

title: LANDING UNUSUAL FISH FOR PROFIT
description: PECONIC BAY conch, Great South Bay eels, Long Island Sound porgies and Shinnecock squid are not yet standard items on most restaurant menus, but local fishermen have been concentrating more on species such as these because of the steady demand they enjoy among a variety of ethnic groups, as well as their growing acceptance among a bolder, seafood-eating public.

title: Grim Choices for Chairman Volcker
