description: IT is normally and naturally supposed that the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy is determined by the condition of the economy, the current and prospective inflation rate and the exchange value of the dollar. If these were the Fed's only concerns, then its policy would now be quite comfortably stimulative. The economy is growing only sluggishly, with considerable reserves of capacity and manpower. Inflation is as low as at any time in decades, even adjusted for the recent weakness of oil prices. The sharp fall of the dollar over the past 18 months has precipitated little rise in general import prices and no surge in demand for tradeable goods that threatens significant inflation.

title: Gail M. Schwat Is Bride Of Samuel G. Liss on L.I.
description: Gail Margo Schwat, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Schwat of Great Neck, L.I., was married at Temple Beth-El there last night to Samuel Gersten Liss, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Liss of Glen Rock, N.J. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: FOR FALL, UPDATING AN OLD FAVORITE
description: THE leaves may not be turning yet, but for the fashion-wise there is a definite feeling of fall in the air.

title: PLAYING THE MARKET IN POLLUTION RIGHTS
description: A PROPOSED plant that would generate electricity by burning old tires has many people angry in Rialto, a growing community 50 miles east of Los Angeles. Its sponsors say the plant would employ 240 people and save 545,000 barrels of oil a year; its critics point out that it would also create more haze in the San Bernardino Valley, which has some of the worst air pollution in the nation.

title: Satellite Chinatowns Burgeon Throughout New York
description: LIKE a stretching dragon awakening from a long slumber, Chinatown is bursting its traditional Chatham Square boundaries, spreading north in Manhattan and sprawling over the metropolitan area to spawn satellite neighborhoods in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and New Jersey. Indeed, it is not only Chinese who are expanding beyond what was in 1960 an ethnic enclave of a mere six square blocks, but other groups of Asians such as Koreans and Vietnamese whose increasing presence in New York is changing the countenance not only of Chinatown but also the rest of the city.

title: The Theology He Teaches Is No Longer Catholic; Policy of Undefiability
description: To the Editor:

title: Julia L. Willis Is Wed
description: At St. John's Episcopal Churh in Baltimore yesterday Julia Litchfield Willis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Norris Willis of Baltimore, was married to Daniel William O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bryan O'Connor of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Arthur R. Lillicropp performed the ceremony. The bride is an interior designer with the Peabody Company in Boston, where Mr. O'Connor is a senior management consultant for Touche, Ross & Company.

title: NEAR AIR COLLISION REPORTED ON COAST
description: An American Airlines twin-jet airplane took evasive action Thursday to avoid hitting a small plane about 35 miles east of where an Aeromexico jet and a single-engine Piper collided Aug. 31, Federal officials disclosed yesterday.

title: 3 SOVIET PEACE ACTIVISTS TO BE ALLOWED TO EMIGRATE
description: Exit visas have been approved for three founders of a Moscow peace group, including a man serving a three-year sentence on a hooliganism charge, sources here said today.

title: KOCH'S SMOKING BILL AND THE CITY'S BODY POLITIC
description: MAYOR Koch inched closer to his goal of restricting smoking in private offices and many enclosed public places when his bill to curb the practice was finally introduced in City Council last week.

title: FLORIO HAILS RAIL PLAN
description: IF THE Federal Government sells Conrail under the public stock-offering plan now gaining favor in Washington, adverse effects on New Jerseyans would be unlikely, according to Representative James J. Florio.

title: HOW TO PUT NEW LIFE INTO YESTERDAY'S RECORDS
description: After getting used to the exuberant dynamics of laser sound, listeners nowadays expect symphonic hurricanes to sweep through their homes in full force. Older LP recordings may seem tame in comparison.

title: WHEN CRITIC! IS A FOUR-LETTER WORD
description: Deep into ''Waiting for Godot,'' Vladimir and Estragon have an insult contest, and, having worked their way past ''Moron!,'' ''Vermin!'' and ''Sewer-rat!,'' there is only one remaining epithet. Estragon, ''with finality,'' devastates his friend with the single word, ''Crritic!'' Vladimir wilts at the charge and, speechless, turns away. Is there any worse insult than ''crritic''?

title: CLUES ON TERROR: FLUID TIES AND USE OF SURROGATES
description: Palestinian terrorist groups appear to be developing new methods of coordination and to be using surrogates to disguise their operations, according to Italian investigators and other officials looking into recent terrorist actions in Europe.

title: KODACHROME OFFERS A SPEEDIER FILM
description: WHEN Kodachrome film was introduced 50 years ago in 35-millimeter size, ''the miniature format,'' as it was then called, had yet to attain the dominant popularity it enjoys today. In effect, the two grew up together, 35-millimeter becoming by far the most popular format and Kodachrome becoming the most popular slide film.

title: Baba Heald Marries C. E. Deakins in Connecticut
description: The wedding ceremony of Elizabeth Blanchard Heald, a daughter of Mary Poe Maus Heald of New Canaan, Conn., and Robert Thayer Heald of Wayland, Mass., and Christopher Edward Deakins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Merritt Deakins of Somers, N.Y., formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. T. Guthrie Spears Jr. officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: THE N.C.A.A.'S VIEW OF COLLEGE SPORTS
description: INTERCOLLEGIATE athletics, including its high-visibility sports, football and basketball, have provided a wellspring of benefits for virtually all who are associated with it. The singular depressing aspect is that a handful, figuratively speaking, of those involved despoils the system with irresponsible behavior. In turn, these improper acts frequently receive disproportionate publicity that contributes to the perceived spoilage.

title: CHERNOBYL SHAKES REINDEER CULTURE OF LAPPS
description: In fright and confusion, the Lapp people have begun herding their radiation-laden reindeer down from the mountain feeding grounds to face one of the grimmest challenges yet to their ancient culture.

title: Giants Sign New Kicker
description: The Giants placed Bob Thomas, their place-kicker, on injured reserve toady and signed Joe Cooper to kick Sunday against the San Diego Chargers here.

title: VERMONT MAKES PRESERVATION A PRIVATE AFFAIR
description: On a black shale beach that curves in the shape of a quarter-moon, Lawrence Tudhope walked carefully, his eyes watching his feet. ''What's this?'' he asked, pointing to a plant.

title: Recent Sales
description: Butler $155,000 233 Bouton Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; renovated kitchen, pool; taxes $2,140. Maplewood $172,000 10 Cottage Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old Cape Cod; living room with fireplace, enclosed porch, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,180.

title: Wall Street Weak
description: It's tempting to interpret the stock market plunge as an omen. The drop was triggered by facts, by disturbing economic news that came at a time when many analysts are already worried about a recession. The Federal budget deficit and trade deficit still cast their towering twin shadows and there's no relief yet in sight.

title: All That Jazz
description: Is the good order of Communist Bohemia really threatened by Western jazz? The Czechoslovak Government of Gustav Husak apparently thinks so. Last week, it ordered the arrest of seven leading members of an unusual cultural organization called the Jazz Section.

title: MICHIGAN PREPARES FOR MORE FLOODING
description: Flood conditions worsened in nearly a dozen counties in central Michigan today as rain-soaked flatlands and swollen tributaries drained into already full rivers.

title: The Message From Milan
description: ALTHOUGH THE ITALIAN lira has risen in value against the dollar - making imports to the United States more expensive - furniture buyers, architects and interior designers are optimistic about the new products that will be shown at the Salone Internazionale del Mobile, the influential furniture fair that opens Wednesday in Milan.

title: HE DIDN'T LIKE US, BUT WE LIKE HIM: A BOOK COLLECTOR'S A.E. HOUSMAN
description: The letters, first editions, manuscripts and poems of A. E. Housman from the collection of Seymour Adelman will be displayed at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, beginning Tuesday through Nov. 9. Shortly before he died in April 1985, Seymour Adelman composed the following introduction for the exhibition catalog.

title: MURDER ON LONG ISLAND
description: THERE ARE THOSE WHO BELIEVE Cheryl Pierson and those who do not; those who contend she is a helpless victim and those who say she belongs in jail. Less than a year ago, Cheryl was a popular cheerleader at Newfield High School in Selden, L.I. She was studying to become a beautician. Today, at 17, a demure brunette, she is out on bail awaiting trial for murder - charged with having hired someone to kill her father, James Pierson, because, she says, he sexually abused her.

title: CAMEROON DISASTER: A U.S. TEAM SIFTS CAUSES
description: A team of scientists from the United States, in a preliminary report, has suggested four causes for the poisoning last month of more than 1,700 people who lived near a volcanic lake in northwestern Cameroon.

title: Where Friendship Is Fleeting
description: ''Seems like everyone's moving away,'' Beverly Funk said. In these outlying suburbs, where the housing is a little more affordable, the middle managers come and go.

title: FOR BROOKLYN DIOCESAN PAPER, A SHIFT
description: In the year that Ed Wilkinson has been editor of The Tablet, the weekly newspaper of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, he has shifted the newspaper's tone to reflect what he says are the theological views of the 1.3 million members of the diocese.

title: Comings and Goings
description: DAVID RIVERS, a 6-foot guard who was the leading scorer for the Notre Dame basketball team the last two seasons, was released on Friday from the university infirmary where he had been recuperating from a wound across his abdomen suffered in an automobile accident Aug. 24. Rivers said he hoped to begin exercising in about a week and to be on the basketball court with his teammates on Nov. 1. . . . Craig Bourgeois of New Orleans, who was tipped to bet on a fixed Tulane basketball game by a player who pleaded guilty to sports bribery, was placed on one-year of nonreporting probation and fined $250 Friday in New Orleans. Bourgeois, a friend of Bobby Thompson, the Tulane point guard, pleaded guilty Wednesday to a reduced charge of misdemeanor gambling after five counts of sports bribery and one count of conspiracy against him were dropped.

title: West Virginia Soot-Fall May Be From Plant Unit
description: A soot-like substance coated houses, cars and gardens today in an industrialized area, and the Union Carbide Corporation said it may have come from a fire at its plant in Institute, W.Va.

title: A BIBLIOPHILE'S PACT WITH GENIUS
description: Seymour Adelman, a private collector who died last year at 78, was an affectionate idealist of such self-effacing jauntiness, such sweetness and airiness and diffident wit, that you never expected to hear him brag about anything. With one celebrated exception: ''During the last 11 years,'' he once wrote, ''I have not been away from Philadelphia for 24 consecutive hours. And if my luck holds out, I look forward to another uninterrupted decade or two within the city limits.''

title: Lincoln Topples South Shore, 14-12
description: Lincoln upset South Shore yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League season opener. The Vikings, who lost to New Dorp in the Division A final last season by 1 point, had been expected to make a strong showing this year. They attempted a comeback in the fourth quarter after falling behind, 14-0, in the first half, but Lincoln's linebacker, James Rich, interecepted a pass and thwarted a 2-point conversion to preserve the 14-12 victory.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: What's Up, Tiger Lily? Created by Woody Allen, 1966 Vestron Video 80 minutes. $69.95.

title: Bali
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your recent articles on Bali (Travel, Aug. 17). Several years ago I spent about one month in various sections of the island.

title: BASQUE SEPARATISTS KILL A PARDONED FORMER LEADER
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A., sending a message to members tempted by a Government pardon program, has taken responsibility for the assassination of one of its pardoned former leaders.

title: Marilyn Lewis Weds Dr. R. H. Berman
description: Marilyn Judith Lewis, a daughter of Jeannette Lang Lewis of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Herman L. Lewis, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Hiram Berman, a son of the late Dr. Eleanor Davidson Berman and the late David Berman, both of New York. Village Justice Milton Lipson of Sea Cliff, L.I., the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at his residence in Sea Cliff.

title: THE QUESTION OF MARIO CUOMO
description: IN A SECOND-FLOOR CORRIDOR of the pompous old gray granite statehouse in Albany hang the portraits of New York's Governors.

title: PARTIAL TELEPHONE SERVICE RESTORED IN PUERTO RICO
description: Telephone links between Puerto Rico and the rest of the world were partly restored today, and technicians were hoping to return the fire-damaged system to full service by the opening of business Monday, officials of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company said.

title: 8 Tamil Rebels Killed in Boat
description: At least eight Tamil rebels were killed Friday when a navy vessel fired at a guerrilla boat off Sri Lanka's east coast, the Government said today.

title: Long Island Is Host To Match Racing
description: The United States Match Racing Championship, a yacht race that could be considered the chess match of sailing, will take place this year in Long Island Sound.

title: Janet Burke, John Connor Are Married
description: Janet Marie Burke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Churchill Burke of Watch Hill, R.I., Hobe Sound, Fla., and New York, was married yesterday to John Farrell Connor, a son of Mrs. Frank Philip Connor of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Connor. Msgr. James G. Wilders and the Rev. William O'Leary performed the the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: JEWISH DANCE VAULTS CENTURIES AND STYLES
description: When one ponders Jewish culture's contributions to the world, the historical images that arise tend to be earthbound and scholastic. There's the scholar, bent in solemn study over the great tomes; the devout, dark-garbed men swaying as they pray; or the gray lawmakers, who developed an early system of justice. For artists one might think of craftsmen, fashioning intricate candlesticks of silver or embroidering elaborate torah covers. Certainly the image of Jew as dancer, bounding and celebrating life, is not what immediately springs to mind.

title: SALVAGING LIVES AFTER TORTURE
description: The reluctance of the torture victims in Christopher S. Wren's article to seek help stems from such factors as their inability to understand their symptoms (nightmares, inability to sleep, anxiety), the inability of those close to them to believe and support them, and the lack of knowledge of sources of assistance in the community.

title: Alice E. Moyer Is the Bride of Dana H. Stewardson
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., yesterday Alice Eyre Moyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Stanton Moyer of Haverford, Pa., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married to Dana Haines Stewardson, the son of Mrs. Jeremiah Ford 3d of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late William Emlyn Stewardson. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: ATTRACTING THE VENTURE CAPITALISTS
description: SMALL new businesses seeking funds to expand try to interest venture capitalists in financing them. Venture capitalists, principally the professional investment firms that invest $2.5 billion a year in young companies, currently favor businesses in the high tech and health fields, according to Ira Polk, managing director of the Executive Venture Management Group, a White Plains consulting firm organized to help corporate executives become entrepreneurs.

title: HOSPITAL BUILDING CURBS ASKED
description: THE state's new Commissioner of Health has proposed regulations designed to keep hospitals from undertaking unneeded or fiscally unsound building projects and to prod underused institutions to close, merge or convert to other types of health-care facilities.

title: Edward L. Frost Jr. Is Wed To Wendy Jones, an Editor
description: The White Plains Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Wendy Neville Jones, a daughter of Louise Neville Jones of White Plains and the late J. Franklin Jones, to Edward Lawrence Frost Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frost of Arnold, Md.

title: COSTUME HUNTING AFTER THE WAREHOUSE FIRE
description: On opening night of the New York City Opera's production of Sigmund Romberg's operetta ''The New Moon,'' it was almost curtain time, and Leigh Munro's elaborate dress for the first scene was still down at the costume house where it was built, having more ruffles pinned on. When it did arrive, at two minutes to eight, it was missing the pannier underskirt that gives it its sofa-like size and shape, so the curtain was held for 10 minutes until the garment arrived and the singer could be put into it. In previous seasons, this would not have happened. ''Usually, everything is here by the piano dress rehearsal,'' says Joe Citarella, City Opera's resident costume designer. This year, however, the costume houses are overwhelmed with work. Instead of the usual 600 or so new costumes required for a season, this year City Opera needs about 2,600 just to get through 1986.

title: HUSKIES TROUNCE OHIO ST.
description: Chris Chandler passed 31 and 5 yards to Lonzell Hill for touchdowns, and Tony Zackery fell on a blocked punt in the end zone for another touchdown today as Washington shocked Ohio State, 40-7. Ohio State dropped to 0-2 for the first time since 1894.

title: DAY CARE FOR CAPITOL IS BACKED
description: THE solemn, stately halls of the State Capitol may, in a year or so, echo with the pitter-patter of little feet.

title: New Wave Japanese Architects
description: At the end of his very interesting article on Arata Isozaki (''Arata Isozaki: From Japan, a New Wave of International Architects,'' Aug. 17), Joseph Giovannini adds a rather unconvincing apology of the Tsukuba Center Building, north of Tokyo.

title: FOR EVERY TASTE, AND THEN SOME
description: PORT ORIENT sounds as if it belongs on the road to Mandalay, not on Queens Boulevard. But there it is, moored in Forest Hills, Queens, among the kosher delis and Chinese, American and Italian restaurants.

title: James A. Wollum Is Wed to Jill Hess
description: The marriage of Jill Hess, the daughter of Louise Dann of New York and Stamford, Conn., and Walter W. Hess Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., to James Arthur Wollum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wollum of York, Pa., took place yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. Walter Lawton, a leader of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony at the Bedford Court House.

title: ARE TODAY'S ARTISTS PROPHETS? YESTERDAY'S WEREN'T ALWAYS
description: We live at a time when the artist is ascendant.

title: Donovan's Trial Is Off to a Slow Start
description: Last week, two years after Raymond J. Donovan became the first Cabinet member indicted while in office, his fraud and larceny trial finally began in a Bronx courtroom.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
QUEEN ANNE'S LACE
description: (Wild carrot) Daucus carota Size: To four feet.

title: REGULATORS DECLARE TEXAS SAVINGS UNIT INSOLVENT
description: The Western Savings Association, one of the largest savings institutions in Texas, was declared insolvent late Friday by Federal regulators. Western, with $2 billion in assets, is the largest such unit to fail in Texas and the largest in the nation this year.

title: WALKING TOURS FOR SCULPTURE BUFFS
description: UNENCUMBERED by ''the look but don't touch'' prohibition of art works viewed in museums, people in New Haven have been using walking maps this summer to explore an unusual exhibition of 10 imposing pieces of sculpture placed in various sites around the city.

title:
GARDENING;
PAWPAW TREE OFFERS FRUIT AND BEAUTY
description: uf9420>THE papaw is a little known and underused native fruit.

title: Conferees Agree On Miltary Reform
description: With double-time dispatch, House and Senate negotiators agreed last week on a sweeping reorganization of the nation's military hierarchy that is designed to combat what the Pentagon's critics characterize as parochialism in the services.

title: TURNING 30 TAKES VERVE AND VITAMINS
description: TURNING 30 happens sometime between switching from Clearasil to Night Repair: When youthful blossoms are over and it is time to take care of the blemishes, when the gods of destruction are at work, breaking down cells instead of building them up,when growth processes go into reverse.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Catherine G. Leef Is Bride in Jersey Of Jeffrey Martin
description: Catherine Grace Leef, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Leef of Alpine, N.J., and Islamorada, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Scott Martin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Martin of West Hartford, Conn., and Key Largo, Fla. Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony at the Leef home in Alpine.

title: Lisa Borie Weds
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Lisa Stuart Borie, a daughter of Mrs. Robert M. Browning of Pomfret, Vt., and J. R. M. Borie of Flourtown, Pa., was married to William Radford Lovett 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Radford Dow Lovett of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Ross Wright, assisted by Bishop Frank Stanley Cerveny,performed the ceremony. The bride, was, until recently, an assistant treasurer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York. Mr. Lovell is general manager for the Lincoln Property Company in Jacksonville.

title: Margaret Bailey Wed in Princeton
description: At the Quaker Meeting House in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Margaret Buchanan Bailey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Scott Bailey of Princeton, was married to Daniel Victor Malloy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malloy Jr. of Little Silver, N.J. The ceremony was performed under the care of the Princeton Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.

title: ONE PLUS ONE EQUALS TWO ONES
description: LIFE IN WINDY WEATHER By Andrei Bitov. Edited by Priscilla Meyer. 371 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis Publishers. Cloth, $19.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: Seal and Porpoise Rescue Is Readied in Alaska
description: A Coast Guard cargo plane has arrived with volunteers, guides, tons of equipment and a portable base camp to rescue porpoises and seals stranded by a glacier.

title: 'Delicate Balance'
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGAL AID CELEBRATES 50 YEARS OF ''BREAD AND BUTTER'' DEFENSE
description: THEY don't get rich, they achieve little fame and they continually face suspicious clients who wonder if they are ''real lawyers.'' But for the last 50 years, attorneys for the Legal Aid Society of Westchester County have been defending the accused who cannot afford counsel or who need legal help in civil matters.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VICTORIANA
description: Victorian fashion ensembles, turn-of-the-century photographs of the county and a classical music group will be featured Friday at a cocktail party at Bloomingdale's in White Plains. The event, which begins at 6:30 P.M., celebrates the 100th birthday of the flagship store in Manhattan - and the 11th anniversary of the White Plains branch - and benefits two local organizations: the Westchester County Historical Society and the New Orchestra of Westchester. Tickets are $65 a couple; $32.50 a person; for information call, 592-4323 or 682-3707.

title: A Review: Computer Programs
description: TO take real control of your finances, turn to a personal computer. It can rapidly add up great columns of figures, and with new easy-to-use software, you can play ''what-if'' games, exploring various strategies in regard to taxes, investments, mortgage loans, insurance or retirement planning, for example.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DEMON BOX. By Ken Kesey. (Viking, $18.95.) In these articles and stories by Ken Kesey, novelist and Pied Piper to the LSD generation, the flamboyant energies of the author's 1960's novels and life flicker on into the colder, harder 80's.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLOOD LIBELS. By Clive Sinclair. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) Jewish guilt as a literary theme is now off the market. With ''Blood Libels,'' Clive Sinclair, the literary editor of London's Jewish Chronicle, wraps up Jewish guilt like a corned beef sandwich and takes it home - along with Jewish paranoia and Jewish self-torment.

title: ON PROTECTING THE WETLANDS
description: ASSEMBLYMAN John S. Penn, Republican of the 16th District (parts of Hunterdon, Morris and Somerset Counties), is doing everything he can to thwart the efforts of over 100 citizens' groups to protect the state's remaining fresh water wetlands. And he is doing it in the name of wetlands protection - the most dangerous kind of deception.

title: AS USUAL, THE K.G.B. HAS ITS KNUCKLES BARED
description: WHILE Mikhail S. Gorbachev is reform-minded on many issues, he showed no sign of softness when it came to letting the K.G.B. handle, with its customary hard-line efficiency, the arrest and indictment on espionage charges of Nicholas S. Daniloff, a correspondent of U.S. News & World Report.

title: Divorce and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TENANT MOVEMENT IN NEW YORK CITY, 1904-1984. Edited by Ronald Lawson with the assistance of Mark Naison. (Rutgers University, Cloth, $25.

title: CALLERS TRY K.G.B. VIA L.I. EXCHANGE
description: A Long Island caterer found himself swimming in the crosscurrents of superpower diplomacy yesterday, and he was not a happy man.

title: QUAKE IN GREECE KILLS AT LEAST 8
description: A powerful earthquake rattled through southern Greece today and a Cabinet minister said at least eight people had been killed in the port city of Kalamata.

title: The Entrepreneur's Game
description: THE first call I ever had from a broker caught me off guard. I was in the publishing business in Savannah, Ga., having joined four or five dozen other investors to start up a weekly newspaper, The Georgia Gazette. I was running it on behalf of the group.

title: DISPELLING SOME MYTHS ABOUT PERENNIALS
description: The romantic image of English cottage gardens, brimming with spikes of bellflowers and delphiniums, has been spurred by the comeback of perennials. Everyone seems to have jumped on the ''perennial bandwagon.'' To horticulturists, these plants have become standard vocabulary and big business.

title: FALL IN SHANGHAI: TIME FOR CRAB RUSH
description: Shanghai's annual crab rush begins with a frenzy in mid-September, continues unabated through October, and then subsides for another year. But during those six weeks virtually everyone in Shanghai, it seems, wants to eat nothing but the freshwater da zhai xie, or hairy crabs.

title: Delta and Western Also Plan a Merger
description: Delta and Western plan to merge in an $860 million deal that would make the new carrier a nationwide force. Delta, which operates mainly in the East and Middle West, has a reputation as a dependable and friendly carrier; Western, which flies mainly in the West, has been considered a takeover target for some time. It is not yet clear what offices in the new airline will be held by David C. Garrett Jr., Delta's chairman, and Gerald Grinstein, Western's chairman.

title: ACROSS THE AREA CODES: AS CHILDREN GROW UP
description: WHEN our oldest daughter announced her intention of spending her junior year in England, my uppermost worry was how we would get in touch with her if we needed to. We had always telephoned her on Sunday nights when she was in college in upstate New York. Notwithstanding the fact that our conversations would have never made the pages of The New Yorker, still it was comforting to hear her voice and to know that she was alive and well.

title: How Stars Tarnish
description: TODAY, A SPECIAL treat for film fans as this column answers your questions about the stars:

title: COAST QUAKE FEARS SHIFT TO LESSER FAULTS
description: Earthquake experts are beginning to pay more attention to the possibility of a major temblor in California at some point other than the San Andreas fault, and their initial findings are not likely to comfort residents here.

title: Cutting Costs Of Settling Your Estate
description: PLANNING your estate is much easier now than it once was, since only estates worth more than $500,000 are subject to Federal taxes. But do not be beguiled into thinking that estate planning can be avoided altogether. To be sure your heirs get what you want them to have with minimum expense and aggravation, a will is necessary. If you die without one, the state government will step in to provide for the administration of your estate - and your assets will probably not pass according to your wishes.

title: 'MOUSETRAP' CAPTURES AUDIENCES
description: DAME AGATHA CHRISTIE'S perpetually running play, ''The Mousetrap,'' has been playing in London for 34 years.

title: 'VIENNA: 1900' AND ITS CURATOR
description: One of the many informative aspects of ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture and Design'' is the insight it provides into the exhibition's director, Kirk Varnedoe. At the age of 40, Mr. Varnedoe is at the top of his profession. He is a professor of art history at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts, an adjunct curator at the Museum of Modern Art, and the likely heir to William Rubin as the museum's director of painting and sculpture; he is the recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship, a prestigious award that identifies and supports ''exceptionally talented individuals.'' Whatever insight the exhibition provides into the art historian hired by Mr. Rubin ''with an eye to the future'' therefore also suggests clues to the future of the museum and to the state of art history now.

title: A SMALL COMPANY WITH A CD PLANT
description: Hundreds of small, quirky classical-record companies exist all around the globe, but there are only a few compact-disk manufacturing plants in existence, and as far as can be determined there is only one company that is both small and quirky and owns a CD plant, and that is Nimbus Records, with headquarters in Monmouth, England. In fact, it owns two CD plants and has announced plans for a third.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
NEW CONCERT SERIES
description: TO the 2,500 arts organizations and events throughout the country and the world that are supported by the International Business Machines Corporation, a new one will be added this year. Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein, president of the State University of New York at Purchase, this week announced the establishment of the I.B.M./State University of New York at Purchase Concert Series, which will present world-renowned artists on the Purchase campus.

title: ORIOLES ARE IN DISARRAY, BUT THERE'S A SILVER LINING AHEAD
description: THE Baltimore Orioles are a disaster area. No amount of Federal aid from nearby Washington can salvage the season. The Orioles are perched precariously above last place, a location in which they never have finished a season.

title: The Theology He Teaches Is No Longer Catholic
description: To the Editor:

title: THAI-LAOTIAN REFUGEE NEGOTIATIONS REPORTED
description: The Thai Government is considering the forced return of a group of Laotian Hmong refugees in exchange for Thais detained in Laos, according to refugee officials.

title: CRIME
description: Can a Chicago sewer inspector make an attractive hero? He can in THE JUNKYARD DOG by Robert Campbell (Signet/New American Library, Paper, $2.95). James Flannery is his name. Not only is he on the municipal payroll, he also is a Democratic precinct chairman in a city run by the Democratic Party. He is something of a plodder, but he is honest and takes care of his people. He likes them, and they like him.

title: TWO CHEERS FOR CBS
description: One of the laments of this money-nutty age of Big Government, big corporations, big budgets and big deficits is that the individual is helpless in the face of overwhelming power. The latest struggle at CBS is a reminder that this is not necessarily so.

title: 2 Palestinians Are Arrested In Pan Am Hijacking Inquiry
description: Two Palestinians have been arrested for questioning in connection a hijacking in Pakistan, and two other Palestinians were questioned and released, intelligence officials said today.

title: CONGRESS'S MIND IS STILL MADE UP
description: SENATORS and representatives returned last week from three weeks at home saying they had heard almost nothing positive about the drastic changes in the tax law approved by a conference committee at the beginning of the recess.

title: THE RITZ: RISE, FALL AND RISE: IT'S ''110 IN THE SHADE''
description: THE Ritz Theatre, a landmark in this Camden County community, opened exactly 59 years and three days ago as a vaudeville and movie house.

title: Robots to Replace Farm Workers?
description: ENGINEERS at an academic conference in Tampa, Fla., reported in October 1983 that they hoped to develop robots to replace agricultural laborers. One robot, they said, might have a form of vision that could spot ripe oranges on trees and pick them.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 14, 1986
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 1 7 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 2 9 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 4 3 11 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 5 5 14 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 6 4 4 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two men, passion and power brokering in Washington. 7 6 28 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 8 12 2 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's coming of age in 18th-century England and France. 9 10 13 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 10 11 18 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 11* 9 16 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 12* 8 5 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 13 7 21 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 14 13 43 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 15* 14 21 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 19 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 27 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 4 18 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 4 3 14 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 5 5 21 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 6 6 12 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life written with his cooperation. 7 7 13 FORD: The Men and the Machine, by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 8 8 9 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation by the film director King Vidor of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 9* 10 24 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 10 11 9 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. M. Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 11 9 22 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 12 13 2 THE NIGHT LIVES ON, by Walter Lord. (Morrow, $15.95.) New discoveries and thoughts about the Titanic disaster. 13 4 THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by Barbara Branden. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of the author of ''The Fountainhead'' and founder of a cult. 14 14 2 STRANGER IN TWO WORLDS, by Jean Harris. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The recollections of a prep school headmistress who killed her lover and is now serving a prison term. 15* 12 174 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 17 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 2 56 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 3 64 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 5 9 MEDICAL MAKEOVER, by Robert M. Giller and Kathy Matthews. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) A ''no-willpower program for lifetime health.'' 5 4 42 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) SAINTS AND STRANGERS, by Angela Carter. (Viking, $13.95.) Eight stories in the unique voice of this master of so-called ''magic realism''; historically grounded characters (E. A. Poe, Lizzie Borden) inhabit fantasies in the guise of historical meditations. HIGH ART, by Rubem Fonseca. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) This detective story by one of Brazil's foremost fiction writers is a good-hearted parody of the genre, in which the protagonist is a dazzling narrator but a complete failure as a detective. THE FRENZY OF RENOWN: Fame & Its History, by Leo Braudy. (Oxford University, $27.50.) A heroically comprehensive inquiry into the concept of fame from Alexander the Great's time to ours, balancing the importance of individuals and their accomplishments with social and technological changes. ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) God and sex are again on the minds of Mr. Updike's characters, but this challenging, educative (and highly educated) novel adds science, mathematics, computers and a fierce bout with natural theology. THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Bizarre comedy, flat Middle Western facts and vigorous tragedy meet in the four women whose lives define Ms. Erdrich's second novel, set, like her first, ''Love Medicine,'' in North Dakota. THE FIFTIES: From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period, by Edmund Wilson. Edited by Leon Edel. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) There are puny and trivial thoughts as well as great ones on the mighty critic's mind from the age of 55 to 65, but it's a profoundly incurious reader who won't want to know them all. DOSTOEVSKY: The Stir of Liberation 1860-1865, by Joseph Frank. (Princeton University, $29.50.) The third installment (five are projected) of Mr. Frank's distinguished life of the great novelist.

title: GALLIC GAUL
description: In trying to learn French, I am reading comic books -''a great way to learn the spoken language,'' says my French professor. Having just finished my latest Mickey Mouse, and sympathizing with Richard Bernstein while reading his column, the proverbial light bulb went off. Hadn't I just read one in which Pluto was shaking his fist at a circus truck that had cut him off? ''Chauffards!'' he shouted, meaning ''speedster, hit-and-run driver,'' according to my pocket Larousse, and ''reckless driver, etc.'' according to Kettridge's dictionary. Why don't you try that, Mr. Bernstein, next time a Renault 5 tries to get away with something? JUDITH S. OCHS Riverdale, the Bronx

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: REDISCOVERING LOVE by Willard Gaylin, M.D. Viking. 288 pages. $15.95.

title: 'NO MORAL VICTORIES' FOR IRISH
description: IN the blue carpeted hallway leading to Lou Holtz's corner office across the campus from the Golden Dome, the wall is adorned with framed sketches of some of Notre Dame's most famous football coaches, including the revered Knute Rockne, Frank Leahy and Ara Parseghian as well as the hounded Gerry Faust, his departed predecessor. Every so often when the new coach walks by those sketches, he wonders what people someday will be saying when his framed sketch is up there.

title: Picking the 'Beltway Bandit' Winners
description: ROUTE 495, the 60-mile-long superhighway that encircles the District of Columbia - the infamous Beltway to motorists - is peppered with small, mainly high-technology, companies that feed off Government business.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS 'DESTRUCTIVE' SUBSIDIES
description: President Reagan said today that ''the mutually destructive practice of subsidizing agricultural exports'' had created an ''intolerable'' situation, especially for American farmers, and that ''we expect to have it corrected'' in trade talks next week.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: GIVE A BOY A GUN: A True Story of Law and Disorder in the American West, by Jack Olsen. (Dell, $3.95.) On Jan. 5, 1981, a trapper and ''mountain man'' named Claude Dallas Jr. shot and killed two game wardens in the Idaho desert, and two years later he was sentenced to 30 years in prison for manslaughter. Jack Olsen's is a ''compelling account,'' Bob Lancaster said in these pages earlier this year. ''In this fashionable genre, 'Give a Boy a Gun' is a superior entry,'' he said, although it would have been stronger if Mr. Olsen had been able to talk with the killer - who escaped from prison in April and at last report was still at large. ZUCKERMAN BOUND: A Trilogy and Epilogue, by Philip Roth. (Fawcett Crest, $5.95.) In a work combin-ing ''The Ghost Writer,'' ''Zuckerman Unbound,'' ''The

title:
FOCUS: Minneapolis;
Second Thoughts On Razing
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, nobody shed a tear when wrecking balls razed blocks of decrepit downtown boarding houses that once lodged thousands of migrant farm and railroad workers. On the rubble of those slums rose condominiums, office buildings and shops, the start of a building boom that rolled into the 1970's and 80's.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Headliners; All in the Family, Part 1
description: A few shoes here, a couple of bags there, it all adds up.

title: Victoria Lynch Wed to Jeffrey Connell
description: Victoria Clark Lynch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas C. Lynch of Scarborough, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey William Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Connell of Oxford Station, Ontario. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: INSIDE
description: CLOSE CALL IN THE AIR A near collision of two planes not far from Aeromexico disaster site added impetus to efforts to reduce hazards near congested airports.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Skills, Arts, Theories And 'Coping With Life'

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in a brief review of Jerry Bumpus's ''Heroes and Villians'' (Aug. 31), the title of a short story was given incorrectly. The story of a young woman who feels abused by her roommates is called ''Plenty of Time.''

title: SUPPLIER OF CONCRETE TO CITY HAD LINK TO A CRIME FIGURE
description: A top figure in the Gambino organized-crime family was a partner of a Staten Island concrete-supply company that has obtained more than $2 million in subcontracts on city and Transit Authority construction projects in the last two years, according to government records and construction company officials.

title: About Cars; CHEVY'S CAVALIER GETS SOME SIZZLE
description: From the beginning, Chevrolet knew that its subcompact Cavalier needed an infusion of horsepower. That was 1982, and the little car's 88 horses put the four-cylinder Cavalier squarely into the yawn category.

title: 6 Die When Their Car Hits Moving Train in Wisconsin
description: A car struck a moving freight train at a crossing without signal lights Friday night, crushing the car and killing all six of its occupants, the authorities said today.

title: NJ TRANSIT ADDS SOME BUS ROUTES, CUTS OTHERS
description: CHANGES in some of its northern and central New Jersey bus routes have been announced by NJ Transit.

title: From Sullen Stalemate in Poland
description: What a welcome surprise from Poland: By deciding to grant a general amnesty for all political prisoners, the Jaruzelski Government seems to have heeded the wise advice of Polish church and human-rights leaders. It has produced an important gesture for once free of pettiness and calculation.

title: A Vote For Hernandez
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EUROPE TRAVEL SEASON ENDS WITH LITTLE RECOVERY
description: Even before the latest outbreaks of terrorism in Karachi, Istanbul and Paris, the dismal 1986 peak travel season for Americans in Europe was ending only marginally better than it began, according to American travel-industry figures and the latest reports from foreign bureaus of The New York Times.

title:
ART;
THE MIXED MEDIA AND THE MESSAGE
description: ''PRESERVING the Landscape,'' the final exhibition of the season at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton, is both a celebration of the natural environment and a reminder that we can all too easily lose what we take for granted.

title: THE MAJESTIC TOMATO OFFERS A FESTIVAL OF TASTES
description: IN rural communities around the New York City area, strawberry festivals regularly dot the calendar in June. By midsummer there are clambakes and chicken barbecues galore, the yearly fund-raisers for fraternal and community organizations. What is surprising is that there do not seem to be tomato festivals on the seasonal schedule.

title: Dealing With Age Minimums
description: THOSE who choose to live in an age-restricted condominium complex must accept regulations on who can or cannot be permanent residents of their units. The intent is to allow older adults to live among their contemporaries without the noise and confusion of children.

title: DEMOCRATS PIN MUCH HOPE FOR SENATE CONTROL ON UPHILL RACE IN IDAHO
description: ''Ah, Idaho,'' said Peter D. Hart, a leading Washington pollster who works mostly for Democratic candidates. ''There isn't a state anywhere where it's any harder for the likes of us to win.''

title: A GENE FOR FLAWED COMPETENCE
description: ONLY THE LITTLE BONE By David Huddle. 217 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: Valerie Johnson Marries Stephen Dent
description: The marriage of Valerie Lynn Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald N. Johnson of Ormond Beach, Fla., to Stephen Gardner Dent, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Dent of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in Ormond Beach. The Rev. August Sorvillo performed the ceremony.

title: Singing and Flirting
description: For several years now, in addition to large-scale productions in the Kennedy Center Opera House, the Washington Opera has been presenting some works in the center's 400-seat Terrace Theater that are enjoyed best in a small setting. Some of the operas, by Handel, Rossini, Stravinski, Menotti and others, have done so well that the opera company will move them next year to the 1,200-seat Eisenhower Theater, a less intimate setting but still not an enormous one.

title: A Plan for the Single Parent
description: BEFORE her divorce early this year, Sheila Meyer of Spring Valley, N.Y., said, ''I had never made a financial decision in my life. I had left all the financial arrangements to my husband.'' Now, at age 44, she has to shoulder those responsibilities for herself and her two teen-age children. At the same time, her household income has dropped considerably from the time when she was married, and her husband brought home a six-figure salary.

title: A DIFFERENT WAR
description: FREEDOM A Documentary History of Emancipation, 1861-1867. Selected From the Holdings of the National Archives of the United States. Series I, Volume I: The Destruction of Slavery. Edited by Ira Berlin, Barbara J. Fields, Thavolia Glymph, Joseph P. Reidy and Leslie S. Rowland. Illustrated. 852 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $39.50.

title: MUSIC: 'FETES D'HEBE
description: RAMEAU'S ''Fetes d'Hebe'' at the Hunter College Playhouse Thursday night recalled the 18th century's yearning to civilize us all. In these three scenes of dance and song with their Classical themes of gods and men, human violence - whether in sound, thought or gesture - appeared to us at a distance, refined and filtered into a cool and gracious symmetry.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE 1. ANTIDRUG BILL: Vote on an amendment on a sweeping bipartisan antidrug bill that would require the President to deploy the armed forces necessary to significantly halt the transport of drugs into this country by ship or airplane. Approved 237 to 177, Sept. 11. 2. ANTIDRUG BILL: Vote on an amendment to a sweeping bipartisan antidrug bill that would permit the death penalty for a killing in a drug-related crime in the ''course of a continuing criminal enterprise,'' which is already defined in Federal law. Approved 296 to 122, Sept. 11.

title: TODAY'S SPORTS
description: Baseball Red Sox vs. Yankees At Yankee Stadium. Yanks, like virtually every other big-league team trying for second place, is closer to last than first. Time to start salvaging. Television Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio WABC 770, 1:30 P.M. Mets vs. Phillies At Philadelphia. It's all over but the pouting for N.L. East opponents as Mets continue to assault the record book. Television Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M. Braves vs. Giants At Atlanta. Giants were surprising for a while, but it's a day to watch the other Giants and the other San Francisco team (see football). Television TBS 4:05 P.M. Boxing Doubleheader at Harrah's Marina, Atlantic City. Mark Breland vs. Reggie Miller (10 rounds, welterweights) and Tyrell Biggs vs. Purcell Davis (10 rounds, heavyweights). Card begins at 8 P.M. Puffy made-for-TV bouts and made for Breland and Biggs to puff up their records. Television ESPN, 9 P.M. (live) Cycling Cititour Starts in Goshen, N.Y., Orange County, and ends at United Nations in Manhattan. Eric Heiden and Greg LeMond are featured in this event that encourages cyclists to run red lights. Football Chargers vs. Giants At Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J. Giants seemed to be facing an awesome foe, based upon Chargers' 50-28 opener over the Dolphins. But note: Chargers have won seven of their last eight openers, mostly by good margins, only to fall by wayside as season went on. Television Channel 4, 1PM Radio WNEW 1130, 1 P.M. 49ers vs.

title:
GARDENING;
PAWPAW TREE OFFERS FRUIT AND BEAUTY
description: uf9420>THE papaw is a little known and underused native fruit.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR A YONKERS HOUSING DREAM
description: TWO men have spent $384,000 for nine vacant lots in Yonkers and if they have their way ''affordable'' homes for dozens of families will be built on the sites in a construction program that will be only the beginning.

title: CONCERT: 'VIENNA 1900'
description: IT is an endless wonder to us all how, in the cycle of nature, the corruption of death serves to feed and fertilize the newly born. In this spirit, Wednesday's ''Vienna 1900'' concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art brought us four young composers from the turn of the century, each feasting hungrily on the death of Romanticism.

title: WHEN IS LIFE NOT WORTH LIVING?
description: THE RIGHT TO DIE Understanding Euthanasia. By Derek Humphry and Ann Wickett. 372 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: CERAMICS SHOW STRESSES FUNCTION
description: FUNCTION, a currently underplayed aspect of work in craft materials, is being celebrated in the ceramics exhibition now at the Perkins Center for the Arts here.

title: Nancy Axthelm and David Rosenberg Are Wed
description: Nancy Macrae Axthelm, a daughter of Marjorie Axthelm Scholly of Rockville Centre and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the late Ralph Axthelm, was married yesterday to David Rosenberg, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Moe Rosenberg of Brooklyn. Village Justice Frank Yanelli of Rockville Centre performed the ceremony at the Westhampton Beach home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Robert E. Scholly.

title: Katrina Heron Marries Christopher Hall Bartle
description: The marriage of Katrina Heron, a daughter of Mary T. Garry and Dawson C. Heron, both of Cambridge, Mass., to Christopher Hall Bartle, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Bartle of Harare, Zimbabwe, and Lee, Mass., took place yesterday in Stockbridge, Mass. The Revs.

title: A NAKED POWER GRAB
description: Franklin Roosevelt tried to ''pack'' the Supreme Court in the 1930's and suffered a Congressional defeat and much criticism for his pains. But his plan was less manipulative and more openly pursued, as a proposed constitutional amendment, than the naked political power grab now being staged by Republicans and right-wingers in California.

title: ATTEMPT TO KILL PINOCHET MAY SIGNAL A STRONGER LEFT
description: LAST week's attempt to kill President Augusto Pinochet and the recent discovery of hidden arsenals in the Chilean countryside suggest that this nation's violent left is more organized and determined than was previously thought.

title: DANCE: RAMZI EL-EDLIBI
description: THE Ramzi El-Edlibi Dance Company presented an amiably eclectic program Friday night at Marymount Manhattan Theater. Although the sources for Mr. Edlibi's choreography were traditional Middle Eastern dances, his arrangements often displayed a theatrical sense deriving from his studies of Western ballet and contemporary dance.

title: Seychelles Coup Plot Is Reported by Exile
description: The Seychelles Government has uncovered a plot to oust President Albert Rene, and the situation remains volatile, an exiled opposition leader said today.

title: Barbara Delaney And Neil Roman, Lawyers, Married
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Barbara Jean Delaney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Delaney of Louisville, Ky., and Neil Kenneth Roman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Roman Jr. of New York. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: ON THE ISLAND OF AUTOS, THE JOYS OF WALKING
description: ONE day I took advantage of a fine afternoon and walked home from Main Street - about a two-mile jaunt. I went a little out of my way and walked the side streets, which I had to myself except for a few dogs who watched me suspiciously.

title: IN THE MIDST OF DEATH, LESSONS IN CLOSENESS
description: WHEN my son Kevin was 5 years old, he was trying to put together what life was all about. He asked:

title: TRALKS ON WORLD TRADE TO FOCUS ON PROTECTIONISM
description: A 92-nation trade conference that starts Monday in Uruguay will deal only with a symptom of the weak world economy - growing world protectionism - and not with the strains of economic disorder that have caused it, international economists say.

title: WHAT PRICE FAME? OPERA AND THE SUPERSTAR BYL>By WILL CRUTCHFIELD
description: An ear injury has forced Joan Sutherland out of the Silver Jubilee concert she was to have shared with Luciano Pavarotti at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night. The tenor will bring his familiar solo stadium act to the Garden instead, and he will be in what has become his element. Dame Joan - who will be back for a run of fall performances at the Metropolitan Opera - might have been a fish out of water there anyway.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Aug. 24 about tuition increases at private day schools in New York City incorrectly described the Trinity School, on West 91st Street in Manhattan, and the makeup of the current kindergarten class. The school, which is 277 years old, was all-male until 1971, when it began admitting girls. In the current kindergarten, 87 boys and girls were admitted.

title: The Sullivan Code
description: To the Editor:

title: RELATIVES OF A PRIEST FIGHT PROVIDENCE DIOCESE OVER PLAN TO MOVE REMAINS
description: Near the top of a broad, gently sloping lawn overlooking the sparkle of Narragansett Bay here is the lonely grave of a Roman Catholic priest. It is surrounded by a freshly seeded area from which the bodies of 38 fellow priests and a bishop have in recent weeks been exhumed.

title: LAVI FIGHTER: A GRUMMAN-ISRAEL PARTNERSHIP WOULD BE GOOD FOR L.I.
description: THE Grumman Corporation has a historic opportunity to contribute to Israel's strength and America's security while at the same time bringing more jobs to Long Island and strengthening its position in the aerospace industry.

title: MAKING THE PUNISHMENT FIT THE HOUSE'S POLITICS
description: ''RIGHT NOW, you could put an amendment through to hang, draw and quarter,'' said Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, about the get-tough mood of the House of Representatives. ''That's what happens when you get on an emotional issue like this.''

title: NEW SLOGANS, OLD SHRINES IN SICHUAN
description: ''Have you seen the largest sitting Buddha in the world?'' Mrs. Guo asks during a dinner of spicy dishes in Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan Province. ''Maybe not - where is it?'' I respond, snaring a piece of chicken with peanuts, chili and shallots in my chopsticks.

title: THE STATEMENT BY DANILOFF
description: Following is the text of a statement by the American correspondent Nicholas S. Daniloff that was read by his wife, Ruth, and distributed at a news conference today at the United States Embassy:

title: Does Anyone Really Want Free Trade?
description: IN the annals of trade diplomacy, this promises to be a rough week.

title: FORDHAM COACH LOSES DEBUT
description: Mike Bucci, a freshman running back, made an auspicious debut for Worcester Poly, and in the process, spoiled Larry Glueck's coaching debut for Fordham as the Rams lost, 31-20, yesterday afternoon at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: Refinancing Makes Sense For Many
description: NOT since the frenzied home-building years following World War II has there been so huge a volume of mortgage activity as in the past year. Forty years ago the source of the mortgage madness was the vast army of veterans taking advantage of low-cost Government financing; much of the past year's crush of mortgage activity came from homeowners who are refinancing existing loans.

title: WORRIED CITIZENS ARE JOINING OFFICIALS AROUND U.S. TO FIGHT SPREAD OF CRACK
description: The rapid and continuing spread of crack, an inexpensive and extremely addictive form of cocaine, is igniting a groundswell of concern among law-enforcement agencies, rehabilitation workers, and urban residents and groups nationwide.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DISSENTERS: Voices From Contemporary America. By John Langston Gwaltney. (Random House, $19.95.) John Langston Gwaltney's interviews with nearly three dozen self-proclaimed ''principled dissenters'' span America's regions, classes, races and ethnic groups.

title: More Freed in Poland Under General Amnesty
description: The Government released more Solidarity union activists from prison today under a general amnesty.

title: Right to the Top
description: MANAGING JUST FINE

title: CURBS EFFECTIVE, SOUTH AFRICA SAYS
description: The Government said today that the three-month-old crackdown on unrest was ''working well'' despite some ''slightly troublesome'' areas where racial violence persisted.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The signal to us in the trenches is that we're going to do business as we once did it, in a classy and thoughtful way. Even if it's only symbolic, it's a very important symbol.'' - Morley Safer, ''60 Minutes'' correspondent, on the shake-up at CBS.

title: Betsy Eastman Married on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Merritt Eastman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Eastman of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married yesterday to William Charles Mahlan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mahlan of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: Canyon Consort: The Paul Winter Consort in the Grand Canyon Open Circle 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: Turning a Spare Room Into a Business
description: EIGHT months ago, Peggy and Michael Ackerman decided they could not afford a home large enough for themselves and their two children in New York. Instead, they bought a house near Lake Wallenpaupack, a recreational area in northeast Pennsylvania, and opened a bed-and-breakfast. While Mr. Ackerman commutes to a new job in Scranton, his wife tends the guests. ''They help pay the mortgage and besides, it's like being on vacation all the time,'' Mrs. Ackerman said.

title: THE DEBATE ON SANCTIONS GETS MORE INTENSE
description: WITH painful reluctance, foreign ministers of the European Community will gather in Brussels tomorrow and try to agree on something resembling sanctions against South Africa. If a quiet understanding between Bonn and London prevails, the measures will not cost President P. W. Botha of South Africa much sleep.

title: FOR SALE IN HAMDEN: 1 HUGE RM W/VU
description: LIVING in a water tank may not be for everyone, but nearly 100 people are interested in buying one from the South Central Connecticut Regional Water Authority. The tank, on Deepwood Drive in Hamden, is to be sold at a public auction Oct. 10, according to Otto Schaefer, director of land management for the water authority.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: Billy Crystal: 'A Comic's Line' Produced by Rocco Urbisci; directed by Bruce Gower, 1983 Paramount Home Video 59 minutes. $39.95.

title: Jacqueline Bikoff Is Engaged to Dr. Gregory Berk
description: A Nov. 29 wedding at the Pierre Hotel is planned by Jacqueline Shereen Bikoff and Dr. Gregory Ivan Berk. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Bikoff of Sands Point, L.I., and Manhattan, parents of the future bride.

title: FASHION'S LEADING EDGE
description: WHO WOULD HAVE thought that regal, haughty old Bergdorf Goodman would become the center of excitement in the fashion world of the 1980's. A few years ago, the store, like the carriage trade it served, seemed an anachronism, a stately reminder of times past. Now it is the place where a new breed of customers and designers want to be. Summing it up a few days ago, a New York career woman in her late 20's, hurrying over the beige carpet on Bergdorf's first floor, not pausing to glance at the crystal chandeliers over her head, said, ''When you want the newest belt, why waste time going anywhere else?''

title: Terrorist Violence Spreads Anew In Paris, Mideast
description: After five months of relative calm following the United States raid on Libya, international terrorism was back with a vengeance. As Western Governments struggled to identify the perpetrators of the Sept. 12 hijacking of a Pan American plane at Karachi airport and the massacre last weekend in an Istanbul synagogue, there were new - albeit less lethal - incidents in Paris and the Middle East.

title: Iraq Warplanes Attack Iran Oil-Pumping Sites
description: Iraq buried its dead today from an Iranian missile attack on its capital city and sent its warplanes to raid five Iranian oil-pumping stations.

title: DILEMMA OF A PRIEST IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: THREE PRIESTS had turned down the parish before the Rev. Rolando Nueva accepted it, and he says he can understand why they did.

title: Cheryl Christine Eppel Marries John D. Segar
description: At the First Congregational Church in West Tisbury, Mass., yesterday Cheryl Christine Eppel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Allen Eppel of Princeton, N.J., and West Tisbury, was married to John David Segar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Segar of Cambridge and Barnstable, Mass. The Rev. Eugene Goetchius, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. James Martin, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Travel article Aug. 31 on Moroccan cuisine failed to mention that the Hotel Mamounia in Marrakesh was closed for renovations and would reopen late in October.

title: Timothy Gerald Griffin Is Wed to Lauri Rohan
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lauri Ann Rohan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Rohan of Bronxville and Cotuit, Mass., to Timothy Gerald Griffin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Griffin of Bronxville and Ocean Ridge, Fla. The Rev. Robert Sweeney performed the ceremony.

title: Benefit From Your Benefits
description: MOST workers do not know very much about the employee benefits that come with their jobs.

title: Czechoslovakia's True Colors
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LATEST RACING FEATURE: FLASH OF CLOVEN HOOVES
description: The rousing strains of the ''Call to the Post'' filled the air, along with the rustle of racing silks, the starting bell, the furious pounding of hooves and the roar of the crowd. The race was close but the winner was clear: Seattle Slew by a snout.

title: Suspect in Texas Killing Is Freed by Technology
description: Modern security technology led to the jailing of Marvin Maurice Wells eight months ago in the slaying of a teen-ager in a convenience store and now it has proved him not guilty.

title: LATE FIELD GOAL TIES RUTGERS
description: The 16-16 tie today against Kentucky was like a loss for the Rutgers quarterback, Joe Gagliardi. And the feeling was mutual for the Kentucky running back, Mark Higgs.

title: THE STRUGGLE FOR A SUMMIT IS FAR FROM OVER
description: FOR most of last week, Soviet and American diplomats struggled to prevent relations from plunging out of control following the arrest in Moscow of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the correspondent of the magazine U.S. News & World Report. Some of the heat was drained from the controversy by the agreement Friday to release Mr. Daniloff and Gennadi F. Zakharov, the Soviet employee at the United Nations who was accused of spying, and to place them in the custody of their respective ambassadors.

title: SAUERS TAKES LEAD OVER STRANGE BY 1
description: Gene Sauers fired a seven-under-par 64 today to take a one-stroke lead over Curtis Strange after three rounds of the $450,000 Bank of Boston Classic.

title: Why Do New Yorkers Leave Auto Carcasses to Be Picked Clean?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Group to Attend Riga 'Town Meeting'
description: An American delegation left today for the Soviet Union after fears that its visit might be canceled because of Moscow's arrest of an American correspondent.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of a recipe appearing in the Aug. 31 Food column should have read Open-Face Plum Cake.

title: Studies Link TV To Early Suicide
description: Why does a teen-ager commit suicide? It is a question that a television reporter, like any other journalist, would try to answer while investigating a death. But television news stories as well as fictional accounts about teen-age suicides may themselves trigger an increase in the number of young people who kill themselves, according to two studies published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: WHERE, OH, WHERE TO EMPTY THE TRASH?
description: THE outskirts of Boulder, Colo., are usually quiet this time of year. But on one small, industrial lot, the silence of the Rocky Mountain morning is sporadically shattered by a loud, crunching noise. Eco-Cycle's shredding machine, familiarly called the 'bone crusher' by staff workers, is warming up.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GUN SHOP
description: IT stands on Central Avenue, between a dry-cleaning establishment and a podiatry office. The sign above the store is small, unobtrusive; yellow lettering on a black background. The cars that go by are often station wagons, filled with groceries from nearby supermarkets, or neat little compacts, driven by sedate looking folks on their way to or from work.

title: Health Plans: Complex Choices
description: FOUR summers ago, while on a train ride between Canton and Hong Kong, during a two-week vacation to China, Genevieve Mead suffered a minor stroke.

title: GALLIC GAUL
description: As a native French speaker, it is with tremendous pleasure that I read Richard Bernstein's article. Mr. Bernstein captured well the linguistic arrogance in which the French take so much pride. That arrogance, however, has formalized the language and created the need for Franglais.

title: EXPERIENCE KEEPS HEMPSTEAD IN FRONT
description: The Hempstead Tigers' most recent defeat came on opening day two seasons ago. They have since won two Nassau County Conference I championships, compiling a 17-0-2 record, and with several key two-year starters returning, they will be difficult to beat this season. Conference play begins Saturday.

title: PHILIPPINE COMMUNISTS ARE SPREAD WIDELY, BUT NOT THINLY
description: WHEN President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in 1972, one justification he cited was the three-year-old Communist insurgency, which was then estimated to involve 500 men. When he left office in February after 14 years of warfare, the insurgency had grown to an organized nationwide movement of 16,000 or more, whose expanding influence contributed to his downfall.

title: Real Estate Investments Can Still Pay
description: JUST about everyone agrees the approaching tax revolution will be bad news for real estate. With lower tax rates, the value of deductions for mortgage interest will slide. Depreciation schedules will be stretched out. And the preference given to capital gains would fade into history. Nevertheless, handsome returns of 20 percent or more are still available to astute investors in real estate, according to the experts. That - particularly given the volatility of the stock market and low interest rates in today's money market - makes real estate the investment of choice for many people.

title: SOVIET SAYS A C.I.A. STATION CHIEF PASSED ON INSTRUCTIONS TO DANILOFF
description: The Soviet Union presented new espionage charges against an American correspondent today and said the United States was holding East-West relations hostage to the case.

title: POSTINGS: New Condos; Neo-Classic On 72d St.
description: Over the years, the movie theater at 350 East 72d Street, once a Trans-Lux, aged into what the new owner of the site called a ''dilapidated form with an unappealing neon marquee,'' although it had a following in the neighborhood.

title: NEW CASSETTES: DANCERS AND COMICS
description: Baryshnikov: The Dancer and the Dance Kultur 84 minutes. $39.95.

title: HECTOR INHERITS BURDEN
description: The last Jet to rush for 100 yards is coming off the bench and going back to work.

title: PHILLIES DELAY METS' CLINCHER
description: Foiled again. And by the Philadelphia Phillies again. On the threshold of clinching their first National League East title in 13 years, the Mets stumbled again tonight.

title: PERSICO STARS IN 2 ROLES AT RACKETEERING TRIAL
description: A defendant playing a dual role has emerged as the early star of the racketeering trial of eight men accused of participating in a ruling ''commission'' of the Mafia.

title: Who Hits The Astros
Egypt Aide Briefs Jordan On Summit Meeting
description: Egypt briefed Jordan today on the results of the Egyptian-Israeli summit meeting that produced an agreement to prepare for an international Middle East peace conference.

title: HOUSE PANEL IS SETTING TERMS FOR DEBATE ON ALIENS
description: The House Rules Committee is preparing the way for the full House of Representatives to debate a comprehensive immigration bill that would prohibit employers from hiring illegal aliens.

title: Adding Up Westchester's Office Space
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY planners have made a survey of new office and commercial space, in some cases by using a tape measure and in some by looking at aerial photos, and have found that from 1980 to 1984, the county's supply grew by the equivalent of the two World Trade Center towers.

title: CAN JAZZ SURVIVE 'CLASSICAL' TREATMENT?
description: One of the more thought-provoking new ensembles in town is one that classical-music lovers may not at first be inclined to pay much attention to. But the new American Jazz Orchestra, which gave its debut concert at the Cooper Union on May 12 and is scheduled for its next appearance there Oct. 31, calls into question the very nature not only of jazz, but of classical music as well.

title: Social Events; Varied Causes and Parties
description: Party for Parsons Sept. 16 - The Parsons School of Design will benefit from a 6:30 P.M. cocktail party at Bonwit Teller, where 25 years of fashion illustrations by Jay Hyde Crawford, a 1949 graduate of Parsons, will be shown. Tickets, $50, from 212-764-4318. Twilight Cruise Sept. 18 - There will be cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and dancing aboard the side-wheeler Andrew Fletcher as she cruises leisurely around the Statute of Liberty and New York Harbor. Boarding will be at 6 P.M. at Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport. The Fletcher will cast off at 6:30 P.M. and return about 8:30 P.M. The hosts and beneficiaries are the New York City Friends of Thirteen, the public-television channel. Tickets, $75 or $40 in advance ($50 at the dock) for those under the age of 30, from 212-560-2800.

title:
ART;
11 EAST END PAINTERS ILLUSTRATE BOLD NEW TRENDS
description: THE dynamics and variety found in new painting trends show up very well in ''Eleven Painters,'' Guild Hall's current invitational exhibition highlighting East End artists whose work has not previously been featured at the museum.

title: CITY OUSTS 6 VOTED TO BOARD IN CHINATOWN HOUSING CLASH
description: City officials moved last week to expel the six new board members of a proposed $12 million Chinatown housing project, some of whom represent tongs or associations that officials have linked to organized crime.

title: BOSTON BUSINESSES GIVE A FUTURE TO THE YOUNG
description: Banks, law firms, real estate brokers and insurance concerns dominate a list of contributors to a program that meant to guarantee financial aid to all graduates of Boston's public high schools who are admitted to college and to provide them with jobs after graduation.

title: Florida St. Player Slain
description: A Florida State starting tackle was shot and killed after an argument early this morning on campus, the university police said.

title: The Good Nancy Mitford
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
HIGH IDEALS, LOW WAGES
description: Through history, nursing tasks have been mainly women's work, and their status correlated to society's value of women. The first nurses were female: religious, poor by birth or slaves.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of a recipe appearing in the Aug. 31 Food column should have read Open-Face Plum Cake.

title: The Theology He Teaches Is No Longer Catholic; Polls Are Irrelevant
description: To the Editor:

title: It Makes Sense to Keep Speed Limit at 55
description: To the Editor:

title: MINE KILLS FRENCH SOLDIER WITH U.N. IN LEBANON
description: A French soldier serving with a United Nations force was killed today and five others were wounded when a land mine exploded in southern Lebanon. The attack was part of a continuing campaign of harassment against the peacekeeping force.

title: A Few Voters and A Few Surprises In New York State
description: The New York State Democratic primary last week was marked by the lowest turnout on record and a high quotient of upsets.

title: REVERENCE, IGNORANCE AND BLAZING APATHY
description: A MACHINE THAT WOULD GO OF ITSELF The Constitution in American Culture. By Michael Kammen. Illustrated. 532 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: DECADENCE WAS ONLY SKIN-DEEP
description: FRANCE, FIN DE SIECLE By Eugen Weber. Illustrated. 294 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $20.

title: NEW RELEASES FROM THREE GUITARISTS
description: Eduardo Fernandez is a young Uraguayan guitarist who has won a handful of competitions in Latin America and in Europe, and whose New York recitals have been impressive displays of both personal style and dazzlingly precise technique. He has just released a pair of debut recordings - a set of works by 19th-century guitarist composers (London CD 414 160-2) and a collection of familiar Spanish display pieces (London CD 414 162-2; both also available on LP and cassette) -that confirm the strong impression he has made in the concert hall.

title: EXPERTS FIND ABUNDANT SPAWNING OYSTERS AT 10 COASTAL SITES
