description: STANDING knee-deep in Tom's Creek, a tidal stream in Madison, Timothy Visel peered at little dark spots on a shell he had scooped up from the creek bed.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of a recipe appearing in the Aug. 31 Food column should have read Open-Face Plum Cake.

title: The Present Tense
description: To the Editor:

title: DYING SOVIET OFFICER'S CRIES IGNORED BY APARTMENT DWELLERS
description: A young Soviet policeman, stabbed in the heart by a fleeing burglar, lay 15 minutes in the courtyard of a large apartment complex calling for help, but none of the residents who looked out from their balconies came to his aid, a Soviet newspaper reported Friday.

title:
MEMORIES OF HENRY MOORE FROM MEN WHOSE LIVES HE TOUCHED;
THE SPONSOR: GENTLE WARMTH
description: It was early on a cold Sunday morning that I drove from Heathrow to Henry Moore's home in Much Hadham, England. Hertfordshire was a fairyland glistening with the night's frost on every blade of grass and twig. Except for a telephone call to Henry Moore three days before, I had never talked with him. So it was with understandable apprehension that I drove up to his 16th-century house after a flight from New York.

title: WALL STREET SETS ITS SIGHTS ON THE NEWLY RICH
description: GIFFORD-HILL & Company, a cement and construction supply operation in Dallas, happily announced last week that it had agreed to be acquired by a British concern for $275 million, much of which would go into the pockets of some of its executives. Within hours, the executives' phones were ringing with calls from investment advisers whose specialty is catering to the rich. ''They do seem to descend on you pretty quickly,'' said Roy G. Turner, the chief financial officer.

title:
MEMORIES OF HENRY MOORE FROM MEN WHOSE LIVES HE TOUCHED;
THE CURATOR: HUMAN TOUCH
description: There was a wonderful spontaneity about Henry Moore in his human relationships. He loved taking people around the grounds at Much Hadham, to show them sculpture. When he couldn't walk so easily, he used a cane, and later on he'd drive. He was marvelously modest, extremely patient and he was absolutely perfect with kids. In fact, he really seemed more interested in them than the adults. Most curatorial types would get hysterical when children would climb all over his sculpture, but he really liked the idea. He didn't mind when people physically touched the work. He believed that sculpture was made by touch and should be appreciated by touch.

title: WHY STOCKS FELL SO QUICKLY: ANXIETY, WITH COMPUTER SPIN
description: The precipitous stock market decline last week, with record trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange, has confused and worried many investors. Here are some questions they have been asking, and some answers.

title: NARA OFFERS A BRIEF GLIMPSE OF TREASURES
description: Cups of Indian rhinoceros horn, cut-glass bowls from Persia, musical instruments made by artisans of Tang China, inlaid with mother-of-pearl from the South Seas and lapis lazuli from Turkey, boxes of persimmon and mulberry wood, crowns of silver and gold, burlap bags and silk brocades, tables and chests of drawers, tax records and population surveys - these are only a few of the many thousands of objects preserved in the Shosoin, the imperial treasure repository of the great temple Todaiji in Nara, Japan's first permanent capital.

title: A SHIFT ON ENDORSEMENT BAN
description: IN what could be a significant break with the Nassau County Republican organization, Long Island Conservative Party leaders have said they would be willing to violate the Republican ban on cross-endorsements.

title:
MEMORIES OF HENRY MOORE FROM MEN WHOSE LIVES HE TOUCHED;
THE COLLECTOR: HIS HANDS
description: For many years I had owned one of Henry Moore's sculptures, ''The Sheep Piece,'' and found it to be increasingly powerful and moving the longer I lived with it. I had been looking for a long time at other sculptures by him in exhibitions and collections and finally decided I had to meet him. When I did visit him in Much Hadham I was fascinated by what he said and how he explained his work. It was clear to me that I was meeting a wonderful human being. He had extraordinary dignity.

title: BIG TOURIST TRADE SPURS NORTHEAST LIQUOR BATTLE
description: Legislators in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts are fighting a battle of the bottle.

title: A PHYSICIAN LEARNS THE 'DOUBLE SPEAK' OF INSURANCE FORMS
description: AFTER 30 years as a physician, I am learning ''double speak.'' Not outright lies, mind you, but telling the truth ''on the slant,'' as Emily Dickinson described it.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CIRCUITS and WEDDING FEAST. By Michael Brodsky. (Guignol Books, Box 247, Rhinebeck, N.Y. 12572, $8.95 and $9.95, Paper.) Michael Brodsky writes philosophical fictions, using minimal plot and characterization and few surface details and metaphors.

title: New Look for Sports
description: Starting today, The Times is publishing a redesigned Sunday Sports section with more statistics and new features. Section 5.

title: FLAGGING FRIENDS ON COUNTRY ROADS
description: AT this point, I'm not sure if studies have already been done in this field.

title: JOURNALISTS MIXED ON ACCORD LINKING REPORTER TO RUSSIAN
description: American journalists have sharply different opinions about the wisdom of trading a Soviet physicist accused of spying for an American reporter who was detained in Moscow after the physicist was arrested in New York.

title: INQUIRY IN GEORGIA STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: What began earlier this year as an investigation into whether members of the Georgia State Patrol fixed traffic tickets has mushroomed into a bitter political controversy here, setting some of the state's top officials against one another and the city's newspapers.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 16 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 16 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: WATCHDOG OF U.S. TRADE
description: ASK AN AMERICAN to name the man who heads the Senate's powerful subcommittee on trade and you are likely to get a blank stare. Ask a Japanese and it's another story. In a recent survey, the Tokyo business journal Shukan Diamond rated Senator John C. Danforth - the 50-year-old Missouri Republican who has been a vocal, relentless critic of what he views as Japan's unfair trade policies - one of the 10 most influential foreigners. Last January, a Tokyo television reporter told Danforth, on camera, that the Japanese regard him as ''scary.''

title: GROWING OLD: CONSIDERING THE OPTIONS, IT'S GOT A LOT GOING FOR IT
description: ''Grow old along with me! The best is yet to be, the last of life, for which the first was made . . .'' - ROBERT BROWNING

title: NERD OF PARADISE
description: O-ZONE By Paul Theroux. 527 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Tax Overhaul Would Affect Everyone
description: FOR every American taxpayer, the Congressional blueprint for overhauling the Federal income tax system holds far-reaching implications. The monumental legislation would force people to reshape strategies for saving for retirement or a child's college education. The ban on consumer interest deductions would raise the cost of borrowing to finance a car, a boat, a new refrigerator or an around-the-world cruise.

title: ROLLING BACK THE LUST FRONTIER
description: RE-MAKING LOVE The Feminization of Sex. By Barbara Ehrenreich, Elizabeth Hess and Gloria Jacobs. 228 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $15.95.

title: ASIA THE SECOND TIME AROUND
description: The Asia I left in 1968 was a bit of a backwater (except, of course, in the strategic sense). I had lived in Saigon for three years, and during that time visited most of the countries of east and southeast Asia. Japan was exporting cameras, but not many cars; modern hotels were few and far between; tourism was just developing; international telephone and telex service was episodic or nonexistent. One felt far removed from the scene of the great decisions, political and economic, that were reshaping the world.

title: Thomas Schrum Wed To Mary Ann Mumma
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine's in Larchmont, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Ann Mumma and Thomas Bernard Schrum. The Rev. Joseph De Santos performed the ceremony.

title: STAGE: LOS TRIOS RINGBARKUS, 2 AUSTRALIAN CLOWNS
description: NEILL GLADWIN and Stephen Kearney, two clowns who bill themselves as Los Trios Ringbarkus, are representatives of Australian New Vaudeville, which is not to be confused with the American wave of the same name. Call them post-post-modernists - or call them insane - they specialize in attacking the audience as well as the principles of comic performance.

title: Brazil Tourism Account Given to Two Agencies
description: Ogilvy & Mather, an advertising agency, and Burson-Marsteller, a public relations firm, have been retained by a four-way joint venture to do an end-of-the-year tourism promotion for Brazil.

title: GOLDIN ASSERTS THE CITY NEEDS 15 NEW SCHOOLS
description: New York City will need to build 15 new schools at a cost of $262 million if the Board of Education intends to carry out plans for reducing class sizes and opening pre-kindergarten classes, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in a report released yesterday.

title: Nuclear Plants Fuel a Rural-Electric Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: METS AT LOSS FOR EXPLANATION
description: A wooden platform had been constructed at one end of the clubhouse, to be used as a stage for cameras hoping to capture a panoramic view of the celebrants. Large sheets of plastic had been rolled above the dressing stalls throughout the room, and attendants were prepared to drape them over players' clothes when the six cases of extra dry champagne were joyously opened and sprayed.

title: N.B.A. Referees Accept New Pact
description: Without the tumult that resulted in two work stoppages in the last nine years, the National Basketball Association and the union representing its referees reached a new three-year labor agreement.

title: 2 Sentenced to Jail In Oil Slick Scheme
description: Two tow-truck drivers convicted of pouring oil on a highway ramp and then offering to aid drivers of the vehicles they caused to crash have been sentenced to 364 days in jail and five years on probation.

title: STUDY SEES A DROP IN ANEMIA
description: The anemia rate among low-income children in health programs has dropped 62 percent in the last 10 years, according to a Federal study.

title: HOW EXPERTS SEE STOCK DIVE
description: What is going on in the stock market?

title: A SHIFT IN PERSPECTIVE ON RATES
description: After a year in which discussions of interest rates focused on how fast they would decline, the bond markets are in turmoil, as some analysts suggest that the downward trend is finished and the next move is toward higher rates.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS LEAVE PARLEY
description: Negotiators for the leftist rebels in El Salvador said tonight that they would not attend scheduled peace talks with the Salvadoran Government.

title: The Road to Yalta
description: The new Soviet equivalent of our National Security Council staff has just scored its first victory. In the Daniloff affair, Mr. Gorbachev went eyeball-to-eyeball with Mr. Reagan and it was the American who blinked.

title: NEW AGENCY IS FORMED FOR MUSIC MANAGEMENT
description: Classical Artists International, a new music management agency headed by some of the industry's more powerful professionals, opens for business today. The formation of the concern reflects the splintering of the concert management industry that began with the death of Sol Hurok in 1974 and continued after the death of Sheldon Gold of ICM Artists in 1985.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Tina Eve Brier Becomes Bride of David Shapiro
description: Tina Eve Brier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Brier of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to David Shapiro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Shapiro of Mineola, L.I., and Putnam Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis Ross performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: TEXAS COMMERCE SAID TO BE FOR SALE
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares, one of the largest banks in Texas, has put itself up for sale, and several large banks in New York and California have begun sifting through its books to determine what price, if any, they should offer, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Full Support In Funding
description: The members of the United Nations who have convened here this week for the opening of the General Assembly find the organization in a severe financial crisis.

title: BONN AND TOKYO INTEREST RATE CUT VIEWED AS LIKELY BY REAGAN AIDE
description: West Germany and Japan are soon likely to heed the Administration's ongoing appeals to cut their interest rates, one of President Reagan's senior economic policy officials said today.

title: A Standard for Appliances
description: Momentum is building rapidly for passage of legislation establishing national energy-efficiency standards for major home appliances. The change in prospects comes after 12 years of debate among appliance manufacturers, environmentalists, states and the Department of Energy.

title: BENGALS TOP BILLS IN OVERTIME, 36-33
description: Boomer Esiason sneaked 2 yards for the tying touchdown with 22 seconds left in the fourth quarter and Jim Breech kicked a 20-yard field goal in overtime today, giving the Cincinnati Bengals a 36-33 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: There's a Penalty for Being Unmarried in This Man's Army
description: To the Editor:

title: John Barrett Wed To Sarah Walzer
description: Sarah Esther Walzer and John Quin Barrett, 1986 graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. The service was performed by Judge Anne E. Thompson of the Federal District Court in Trenton, for whom the bride is a law clerk.

title: Jeffrey Rodman Is Married To Abby Vanessa Geduldig
description: The marriage of Abby Vanessa Geduldig, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Geduldig of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Shelter Harbor, R.I., to Jeffrey Scott Rodman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Rodman of Lexington, Mass., took place yesterday in Providence, R.I. Rabbi Meier Sendor performed the ceremony at the Roger Williams Park Casino.

title: FRONT AND CENTER IN THE HIT PARADE
description: NEITHER Wade Boggs nor Don Mattingly says he concentrates on trying to win the American League batting championship. ''If you worry about it, it's not going to happen,'' Boggs said. ''I just go out and do my job day after day and see what happens.'' ''I try to hit the ball hard every time up,'' Mattingly said. ''If at the end of the season you have the highest batting average, you win the batting title.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 15, 1986: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs Pay 'N Pac Stores Horizon Bancorp Rochester Tel Corp NBD Bancorp Thompson Medical PHH Group Inc TUESDAY Ames Dept Stores First Boston Inc Bankers Tr NY Corp Joy Mfg Co Brunswick Corp MONY Real Est Inv CPC Intl Natl Fuel Gas Federal Paper Board Upjohn Co WEDNESDAY American Info Tech Natl Serv Indus Amer Intl Group St Joseph Lt&Pwr Bell Atlantic Corp Savannah Elec & Pwr Carolina Pwr & Lt Stone & Webster Inc Flight Safety Intl Transamerica Corp Keystone Intl U S Shoe National Intergroup Vestaur Securities THURSDAY Air Products & Chem Kaiser Cement Arkansas Best Corp Nynex Corp Central Maine Pwr Ponderosa Inc Conagra Inc Southern Cal Edison Insilco Corp FRIDAY General Cinema Southeast Banking Corp General Electric SATURDAY Pueblo Intl Inc

title: A Taste of Texas
description: The Texas Commissioner of Agriculture, Jim Hightower, assures sensitive Washingtonians that tomorrow's tasting of Texas wine will not involve ''novelty bottlings of Chateau Bubba.''

title: See-Through Buildings Getting Good Reviews
description: Fashions in architecture, as in clothing, come and go, but recent evidence gathered at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan suggests that see-through buildings are here to stay.

title: FACING THE ST. LOUIS BLUES
description: ONWARD, onward, to the land of the White Rat, goes the mighty juggernaut. Thirty-six people in uniform, a few dozen journalists and camera crews and a credit chit for all the cases of champagne they did not open here.

title: An End To U.S. Narcissism
description: The overwhelming majority of United Nations members, whose 41st annual General Assembly opens this week, may well have been misguided in not voting with the United States on most issues over the past several years.

title: U.S. SCHOOLS PUT NEW STRESS ON TEACHING OF MORAL VALUES
description: Prodded in part by rising concern over drug use and teen-age pregnancy, public schools around the country are paying increased attention to the teaching of personal and social values.

title: Clement Stone Is Dead at 58; Head of World Financial Corp.
description: Clement Stone, chairman of the World Financial Corporation and son of the insurance magnate W. Clement Stone, has died of heart disease. He was 58 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Glum Forecast For Philippines
description: THE World Bank, finding that the economy of the Philippines is in significantly worse shape than its Government has publicly acknowledged, has concluded that the nation probably will not be able to repay debt projected to rise nearly 47 percent, to $38 billion, by 1995.

title: Boy Wounds 2 In Shooting Scare
description: A 13-year-old Oswego County boy wanted to scare his young cousin with a rifle but instead accidentally shot the boy and his brother, state police said today.

title: HOW A GOOD MOTHER EXPRESSES RAGE
description: THERE is a gun in Sue Miller's best-selling first novel, ''The Good Mother,'' about a divorced woman named Anna Dunlap and her legal fight to keep custody of her 4-year-old daughter, Molly. And that gun eventually gets fired, just as Chekhov would have insisted it must. But the circumstances under which its trigger finally gets pulled aroused such strong and ambivalent feelings in this reader that its report has continued to echo in my head with a volume that surpasses the dramatic power of Ms. Miller's story.

title: VELASQUEZ LOSES IN FAREWELL RACE
description: Jorge Velasquez was supposed to go out on a winning note at Belmont Park yesterday, but Richard Migliore would not let him and the fans would not forgive him. Velasquez's final ride in New York before leaving to ride in France for two years ended with boos from the crowd when Migliore and King's Swan outdueled Velasquez and Raja's Shark by a head to win the $75,000 Boojum Handicap.

title: Chilean Group Says It Killed 4 Leftists
description: A group calling itself the ''Sept. 11 Command'' has taken responsibility for the deaths last week of four leftists, saying they were killed to avenge the assassination attempt against Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean President.

title: GUESSING MARKET'S NEXT MOVE
description: When the stock market opens this morning, investors will begin to get a better idea of whether last week's record decline was largely a two-day aberration or the beginning of a prolonged slide in stock market prices.

title: WESTERN UNION BUYERS PLAN FINANCIAL SERVICES
description: An official of one of two investment concerns that agreed to purchase a controlling interest in the Western Union Corporation said yesterday that the investors were interested in developing a financial services business within the telecommunications and information systems company.

title: GIVING MOBILITY TO THE BLIND
description: As 18-year-old Anthony Vega of the Bronx approached the curb at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, tapping the ground with his ''long cane,'' as blind people call it, a young man took him by the elbow and asked if he could help. He could and did, escorting Mr. Vega to the nearby subway entrance.

title: Shamir Is Upset at Peres Over Bid for Peace
description: As Prime Minister Shimon Peres flew today to meet President Reagan in Washington, his coalition Government was torn over his agreement with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to work toward an international conference on Middle East peace.

title: A BRIDGE BETWEEN U.N. AND CAPITAL: PHYLLIS KAMINSKY
description: As the first American to direct the United Nations Information Center in Washington, Phyllis Kaminsky says the job has proved to be a bit of a diplomatic ''hot seat.''

title: Rescuers Free Boy, 17, Pinned by 20-Ton Rock
description: A teen-ager pinned under a 20-ton boulder for nearly 18 hours was freed today by rescuers who worked through the night in a cave on Pilot Knob Mountain, officials said.

title: Two New Commercials Promoting WPLJ-FM
description: The people behind the clever TV commercial that shows a radio station's janitor lip-syncing the programming as a way of promoting the contemporary-hits format of WPLJ-FM will today introduce the first of two 30-second TV commercials that will promote the featured players in its popular morning drive-time program, ''Jim Kerr and the Morning Crew.''

title: Metals Dealer Likes Platinum Action
description: Bruce L. Kaplan is happy whether platinum goes up or down, so long as it moves.

title: U.S. WEIGHS MOVES IN DANILOFF AFFAIR
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials, ruling out a direct exchange of an American journalist confined to Moscow for a Russian physicist restricted to New York, said today that they were discussing other formulas with Soviet officials to end the latest crisis in relations.

title: Who Should Drive Hasidic Schoolboys?
description: Jewish religious law prohibits male students who attend a Hasidic school in Orange County, New York, from riding buses driven by women. Women who drive the buses say they are therefore victims of sex discrimination - a violation of Federal law. Which law should rule? The secular one. The Orthodox Jewish sect prohibits men from virtually any contact with women outside of the home or family gatherings, and bars women from any business activity. Adherence to these teachings would provoke no dispute if New York law did not require public school districts to provide transportation to non-public-school students. Since it does, the Monroe-Woodbury public school district has been busing Hasidic students to the United Talmudic Academy.

title: Trade in Currency Isn't Like Trade in Goods
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Merchants Group Set At BBDO
description: YOU want to know about creating an image for a retail establishment? You certainly could not do much better than asking a person who has been helping to do it for dear old Bloomie's.

title: Jessica Elfenbein Is Married to Robert Feinstein
description: At the Lloyd Street Synagogue in Baltimore yesterday Jessica Ivy Elfenbein, a daughter of Dr. Iris M. Elfenfein of Washington and Richard Elfenbein of Pomona, N.Y., was married to Robert Daniel Feinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Feinstein of Albany. Rabbi Aaron Meckler performed the ceremony.

title: 'THE STORY OF ENGLISH,' NINE-HOUR SERIES ON 13
description: THERE is something audacious about ''The Story of English.'' Nine hours of television tracing the birth, growth and dissemination of a language is not everyday fare. Can Robert MacNeil and his colleagues pull this kind of thing off? Judging from the first episode, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, they do. The series promises to be rich and rewarding.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Los Angeles dispatch on Aug. 29 about President Reagan's approval of a 2 percent pay increase for Federal civilian employees, misstated the recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Federal Pay. It recommended an average pay increase of 4 percent, not 23.79. The 23.79 figure, in a companion report sent to the President, represented the difference in salaries between private and public employment for selected occupations.

title: BEARS EDGE EAGLES IN OVERTIME, 13-10
description: He conceived and developed the defense that gave Chicago its Super Bowl championship. He motivated players with darts that were often taken far more seriously than they should have been. In Buddy Ryan's line of work, sensitivity has not been listed as a job requirement.

title: 'L.A. LAW' SERIES TO BEGIN ON NBC
description: AS IT did with ''The Cosby Show'' and ''Golden Girls,''

title: Telephone Strike Continues
description: Both sides in a strike against Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation discussed a schedule today for resuming negotiations on a new three-year contract.

title: SAFETY OF LOS ANGELES BUS SYSTEM QUESTIONED
description: More than a dozen accidents on this city's sprawling bus-route system have killed one man and injured at least 137 other people since May. Critics are making charges of unsafe practices and drug abuse against the system and its 5,000 drivers.

title: Hepatitis Risk Found Among Sexually Active
description: A new study has found that white heterosexuals with many sexual partners have a high risk of contracting a serious liver infection that researchers are already studying because it is spread much as AIDS is believed to be spread.

title: U.S. ISSUES GUIDE URGING SCHOOLS TO 'GET TOUGH'
description: Declaring that ''because of drugs, children are failing, suffering and dying,'' Education Secretary William J. Bennett issued a handbook yesterday that prescribes a policy ''to get tough'' on the problem of drug use in the schools.

title: PERSUASION HELPED AT GOMPERS HIGH
description: When the cold weather came at Samuel Gompers Vocational-Technical High School in the South Bronx, Victor Herbert, the principal in those days, used to stand outside the school sending students home who were preening in new leather jackets.

title: Manion's Low Rating Normal Only Since '85
description: To the Editor:

title: For Street Photographs, Bad Day for Eddie Murphy
description: Don Johnson and Ronald Reagan stole the attention while Eddie Murphy languished on Columbus Avenue yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''One of the people placing these bombs will inevitably be caught and he will talk.

title: Iraqi Envoy Is Killed By Car Bomb in Pakistan
description: A senior Iraqi consular aide was killed today when an explosion, apparently caused by a bomb, ripped through his car while he was driving in a Karachi suburb.

title: Natalie Wexler Wed to James Feldman
description: Natalie Wexler, the daughter of Henrietta Wexler of Washington and Bernard Wexler of New York, was married yesterday to James A. Feldman, the son of Silva Feldman of Washington and Myer Feldman of Palm Beach, Fla., and Washingon. Rabbi Eugene Lipman performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Washington.

title: APARTMENT GLUT BRINGS CONCESSIONS TO RENTERS
description: A wave of apartment construction in Manhattan has led to an oversupply that is forcing landlords at the top of the market to give renters concessions that have not been seen in decades.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DANILOFF'S MEETING WITH THE PRESS
description: Following are excerpts from Nicholas S. Daniloff's news conference today in Moscow, which was also attended by his wife, Ruth, and Henry Trewhitt, deputy managing editor of U.S. News & World Report. OPENING STATEMENT

title: KOCH FAULTS G.O.P. CAMPAIGN
description: The Republicans have conducted ''such a miserable'' campaign for governor that they could get fewer votes than the Conservative and Right to Life Parties in the November election, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: IVY LEAGUE: FEW DOMINANT QUATERBACKS IN RACE
description: IF the polished and proven quarterbacks in the Ivy League this season were asked to stand and be counted, the total would come to only two.

title: SAUERS SINKS PUTT TO WIN IN PLAYOFF
description: Gene Sauers sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the third hole of a playoff today and won the $450,000 Bank of Boston Golf Classic.

title: ASSESSING WHAT VOTERS SAID BEFORE THEY SAY IT
description: It will be two months before the winners of the 1986 elections are known. But the groundwork for winning the interpretation of the elections is being laid now.

title: Cronies Are Reunited At Messner, Vetere
description: Another member of the old Tuesday Team, the specially formed agency that helped re-elect President Reagan, has joined three old cronies at Tuesday Team II.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Were the Hall of Fame pitchers Joe McGinnity, Christy Mathewson and Rube Marquard ever members of the same pitching staff with the New York Giants? If so, how did the Giants do in those seasons?

title: A Nominee No More
description: The White House has taken the unusual step of withdrawing the nomination of Helen Marie Taylor to the National Council on the Humanities, a step Congressional aides said resulted from a lack of enthusiasm for her among both Republican and Democratic senators.

title: BURRS PAY HOMAGE TO THEIR VILIFIED ANCESTOR
description: The minister stood by a grave, facing his ancestor's tombstone. ''Do we have the flag?'' he asked.

title: CASE OF DANILOFF CLOUDS RIGA TALKS
description: President Reagan's senior adviser on Soviet affairs, arriving here for a ''town meeting'' with Soviet officials and citizens, said today that the detention of an American correspondent in Moscow would ''cast a shadow on the conference.''

title: Jeffrey Meer Marries Stephanie R. Bradley
description: Stephanie Richelle Bradley, an assistant office manager of the Washington office of the New York law firm of Dewey Ballantine Bushby Palmer & Wood, was married in Greensboro, N.C., yesterday to Jeffrey Adam Meer, an assistant editor of Psychology Today magazine in Washington. The parents of the couple are the Rev. and Mrs. Paul Meredith Bradley Jr. of Greensboro and Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Ross Meer of Brooklyn.

title: FRIEDMAN IS ASKED TO ABANDON EFFORT TO KEEP PARTY POST
description: Several Bronx Democratic politicians and State Attorney General Robert Abrams yesterday called on Stanley M. Friedman, who is under indictment in the city's Parking Violations Bureau scandal, not to seek re-election this week as the county party chief.

title: FACING MIXED-AGE MARRIAGES
description: THE man who came to dinner was distinguished in virtually every way. He held a senior position with an investment banking firm, he was good-looking and charming, and he clearly loved their daughter.

title: CHARGERS DON'T PASS THE TEST
description: Just seven days ago, they had run up so many points (50) and yards (500) on the Miami Dolphins that some of their extremist fans were talking about the San Diego Chargers as the greatest offensive team in history.

title: INSIDE
description: Big Bank Sale Expected Texas Commerce Bancshares, one of the largest banks in the state, has put itself up for sale, banking sources said. Page D1.

title: Market Place; Actually a Few 52-Week Highs
description: WHILE stock prices were plunging last Thursday and Friday, a handful of Big Board issues moved counter to the trend and posted 52-week highs. There was no industrywide pattern evident. Rather, it was a case of individual issues responding either to rumors or to favorable news developments.

title: Romeo and Juliet
description: It's not quite like the steamy affairs on ''Dallas,'' but down in the Southwest Conference there's a real-life romance that has soap-opera potential. Tony Cherico, an all-conference junior nose guard for Arkansas, has been seeing a senior from archrival Texas.

title: Oldest Hummingbird Captured in Colorado
description: An 11-year-old hummingbird, the oldest known in North America, was captured last month at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Gothic, Colo., the National Geographic Society reported Saturday.

title: New York Whistleblowers Take Note
description: If only someone had told him, New York's Mayor Koch said the other day . . . If only one of those informants who complained of corruption in the Parking Violations Bureau had come directly to City Hall when his Department of Investigation botched the case. The picture is familiar: the Mayor presenting himself as ill served by aides whose duty it was to protect against corruption.

title: Rev. James J. Young, 46, Dies
description: The Rev. James J. Young, who is credited with founding the first American ministry group for separated, divorced and remarried Roman Catholics, died Friday at the age of 46.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Raises Its Stake in Multicom
description: At a gala cocktail party, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt last week entertained not only some local friends but also executives from its international operation who are in town for briefings, seminars and schmooze.

title: Minor Problems Delay Test of Voyager Plane
description: The final test flight of the experimental plane Voyager was canceled today because of ''minor but critical problems,'' a spokesman said.

title: HARD RUSH, HARD READ
description: IN the Giants' meeting room Saturday night at the Woodcliff Lake Hilton, where the team is lodged before home games, the defensive unit was watching a horror movie. With occasional voice-over by Bill Parcells, the defense was viewing films of Dan Fouts and the San Diego Chargers during a 50-28 rout of the Miami Dolphins in the season opener. But after having seen the Chargers' first four plays of the second half in that film, Jim Burt, the Giants' nose tackle, suddenly spoke up.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE ORIOLES VS. YANKEES, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS. CARDINALS, at St. Louis, 8:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) FOOTBALL DENVER BRONCOS VS. STEELERS, at Pittsburgh, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660, 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M. Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: QUAKE TOLL IN SOUTH GREECE RISES TO 17 DEAD AND 8 TO 12 MISSING
description: At least 17 people were reported dead today and 8 to 12 were missing in an earthquake that struck a southern port town on Saturday night. Thousands of people were left homeless.

title: NEWARK AIRPORT LEADS NATION AS FLIGHT DELAYS SHOW NEW RISE
description: It is a weekday morning at Newark International Airport and 62 planes are boarding passengers, all for scheduled departures from 8 to 9 A.M.

title: DISCIPLINE STRESSED IN PATERSON SCHOOL
description: Some of the older faculty members at Eastside High remember the violent days of blatant drug sales, assaults on teachers and administrators and gang fights in the hallways, some with boards and knives.

title: Topics; Global Gifts: The Norway Watch
description: The report's title is ''Human Rights in Developing Countries: 1986'' and it gives detailed factual accounts of the state of freedom in 10 countries. What's unusual is that this report, in English, is underwritten by the Norwegian Ministry of Development Aid.

title: FINDING A REFUGE OUTSIDE OF STOCKS
description: Investors who are now pulling out of the stock market following last week's record decline in the Dow Jones industrial average are faced with another big decision: where to put this money.

title: Eilene Appelbaum Marries Jerome Herszfeld in Jersey
description: Eilene Appelbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Appelbaum of Monsey, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jerome Herszfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Herszfeld of Brooklyn. Rabbi Moses D. Tendler officiated at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: Admire Brazil; Then Bargain
description: The visit of Brazil's President Jose Sarney to Washington last week followed all the formalities appropriate to a meeting between the New World's largest nations. But the visions they should share lost out to the nettlesome short-term questions of bilateral trade.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 'NEW' CUOMO TRIES A TOUCH OF CAMPAIGN HUMOR
description: Forget the image of Mario Cuomo as brooding, unforgiving, humorless. Here - for the next few weeks, at least - comes Mario Cuomo, the life of the party.

title: When The Law Works
description: Over the last two years U.S. Customs agents have been harassing Americans returning to this country after visits to Nicaragua. The agents have seized books, notes and personal letters. They have asked travelers intimidating questions about why they went to Nicaragua, and harangued them about bringing ''subversive'' ideas into the United States.

title: YANKS' 11-5 VICTORY KEEPS HOPE ALIVE
description: The Yankees, playing the role of those who profess to believe, gave themselves plenty of reason yesterday to profess their belief even more than they had been doing. They outslugged the Boston Red Sox for the second straight day, this time by a score of 11-5, and were only nine games out of first place.

title: A Passing Boater Rescues 2 Who Plunged Into East River
description: A man who fell or jumped 17 feet from a seawall into the East River and another man who tried to rescue him were both pulled from the water by a passing boater last night, the authorities said.

title: Ian E. Feldberg and Meredith Anne Schlow Wed
description: At the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations in New York yesterday, Meredith Anne Schlow, an editorial assistant for The Baltimore Evening Sun, and Ian Eric Feldberg, a computer graphics specialist at Johns Hopkins University, were married by Rabbi Joel Goor.

title: Bridge: California Couple Win Title At Mixed-Pair Tournament
description: The world mixed-pair championship was won here this afternoon by Jon and Pamela Wittes of Los Alamitos, Calif., continuing a string of American successes in this quadrennial event.

title: A Pro-Libyan Group Says It Seized 2 U.S. Men In Beirut
description: An apparently pro-Libyan group said in a statement published today that it was responsible for kidnapping two Americans in West Beirut last week.

title: Jihan Sadat Explains Why She Left Teaching
description: Jihan Sadat, the widow of the slain Egyptian President, who has been a visiting professor at the University of South Carolina for three semesters, says a lawsuit seeking to learn her salary prompted her to quit her position.

title: Buckle Up, Back There
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A roll-call supplied by The Associated Press Saturday of the vote in the House of Representatives on economic sanctions against South Africa incorrectly described the action taken by Representative Patrick L. Swindall, Republican of Georgia. He voted against the measure.

title: Global Gifts: Shrinking World
description: Many people first heard of World Airways when they read recently that the company was retreating to the charter and aircraft maintenance business.

title: BRIEFS
description: Ambassador General Partnership, which owns the hotel assets of the Tropicana Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, is offering $175 million of 12 percent first-mortgage notes due 1996 at 99.75 to yield 12.04 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: TISCH RULES OUT SELLING CBS PARTS
description: Laurence A. Tisch, acting chief executive of CBS Inc., said yesterday that units of the giant media company would not be sold to reduce the heavy debt incurred when it fought off an unfriendly takeover bid by Ted Turner, the Atlanta entrepreneur, in 1985.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT APPEARS ON SOVIET TELEVISION
description: Edward L. Howard, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer accused of severely damaging the American intelligence operation in Moscow, appeared on television today and described why he defected but said, ''I love my country.''

title: Pretoria, Citing Unrest, Closes 13 More Schools
description: The South African Government said today that it had closed 13 more black schools because of student boycotts and classroom disruption.

title: Bank Board Shuts Sunrise
description: The Sunrise Savings and Loan Association of Florida, a $1.5 billion thrift institution, was closed Friday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The board said it would reopen the Boynton Beach, Fla. thrift unit's offices today under a new name, the Beach Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1986
description: International

title: FRANCE TO REQUIRE VISAS FOR VISITORS TO COMBAT TERROR
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, speaking minutes after a fatal bomb explosion in Paris, announced measures tonight to combat a wave of terrorism, including a requirement that Americans and most other foreign visitors obtain visas.

title: DANILOFF DECLARES CHARGES OF SPYING ARE JUST POLITICAL
description: Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American correspondent charged with espionage, declared today that the charges against him were purely political and warned that any Western journalist in Moscow was a potential target for K.G.B. entrapment.

title: Scenes From South Africa
description: For some months now, reporters and photographers in South Africa have been severely limited by the Government there in what they can send out of the country.

title: Coal and the Military
description: Four years ago, the coal lobby won a major, though widely denounced, victory when Congress passed a law requiring the Defense Department to ship 300,000 tons of American anthracite to Europe each year to power military installations there.

title: U.S. REJECTS A EUROPEAN TRADE MOVE
description: The United States has rejected a ''common working platform'' proposed by the European Community to bridge key differences between Washington and third-world nations at a global trade conference here.

title: FOR THESE STUDENTS, COLLEGE CAN WAIT
description: Here it is the third week of September, and 18-year-old Lara Mendicino is enjoying a certain distance from the 770 freshmen of the class of 1990 who are hurrying to courses across the Columbia College campus in Manhattan. Actually, she's ''right back in high school again,'' Miss Mendicino said with a laugh.

title: 5,000 GREET FREED PRISONERS IN GDANSK
description: Five thousand cheering supporters turned out at a Gdansk church today to greet some of the Solidarity activists who were freed from prison this weekend under a sweeping amnesty.

title: BOOK FAIR ATTRACTS NOT JUST LITERATI
description: Thousands of book lovers and sun worshipers jammed nine blocks of midtown Manhattan yesterday at the eighth annual New York Is Book Country street fair. Decked out in everything from their Sunday best to beach attire, the festive crowd filled a balloon-bedecked Fifth Avenue from 48th to 57th Streets, transforming one of the city's major thoroughfares into a celebration of books and book-related games and activities.

title: Two Shootings, One Lesson: Gun Control
description: On Aug. 12, a 29-year-old student entered the campus of a college and went on a shooting spree that left one faculty member dead and six others injured.

title: FOR FINNISH WOMAN, STRUGGLE FOR A U.S. WELCOME
description: A year and a half ago, on a park bench in Federal Plaza in Manhattan, Leila Eways gathered her thoughts, took out a pad and pencil and tried to explain to the Immigration and Naturalization Service why she had joined the Communist Party eight years earlier, why she had quit shortly afterward and why the United States should therefore welcome her as a potential citizen.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Riddle of the Ring
description: Karen Stewart of Evansville, Ind., was thinking of ways to get her oldest son into art school when one day her eyes fell upon the 1961 World Series ring in her jewelry box. The ring had belonged to her father, Elmo Henson, a onetime scout for the Cincinnati Reds. It has Pete Whisenant's name on it and, Mrs. Stewart says, was given to Henson as a gift from Whisenant, a little-used outfielder and ultimately a coach for the '61 Reds, who lost the Series that year to the Yankees.

title: MUSIC: BERNSTEIN CONDUCTS ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC
description: OLD ways of freezing music in time and space have come under attack in our time.

title: John H. Trux Jr., 61, Founder of Company
description: John H. Trux Jr., founder and former president of Bang & Olufsen of America Inc., an Illinois-based audio specialty company, died of a stroke Wednesday in a hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 61 years old and lived in Glenview, Ill.

title: GIANTS' DEFENSE STIFLES CHARGERS
description: Six nights ago, in the Giants' opening game of the season, their heralded defense played lethargically. Today, against the most potent offense in the National Football League, that defense played with an intensity that frightened onlookers and seemed to frighten the San Diego Chargers.

title: Judith Avner Married To Stephen J. Eckert
description: The marriage of Judith I. Avner, director of the New York State Division for Women, to Stephen J. Eckert, manager of software systems and management information systems education for the Allied Signal Corporation in Sidney, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens. Cantor Dana Troupp performed the ceremony.

title: 3d WORLD STAKE AT TRADE TALKS
description: Disenchanted with past trade agreements and struggling with their own troubled economies, leading third world countries seem determined to make their voices heard at the 92-nation trade conference that opens Monday in Punta del Este, a beach resort in Uruguay.

title: For Wards I. Bridge, A Change of Colors
description: Several people have noticed, albeit a bit late, that the Wards Island Bridge is now another color.

title: Casino Workers Vote On Whether to Strike
description: About 13,000 casino hotel workers voted today on whether to strike Tuesday at eight gaming halls, and a union official said any effort to resume negotiations would be futile.

title: POLICE SUICIDE: ANSWERS ARE ELUSIVE
description: So far this year, seven New York City police officers - two in the last week - have turned the guns meant to protect society on themselves.

title: DIDIER CATCH HELPS REDSKINS WIN, 10-6
description: Clint Didier, a big tight end for Washington who specializes in crunching blocks and short pass receptions, surprised the Los Angeles Raiders' Stacey Toran today, streaking past the defensive back on a 59-yard pass that set up the only touchdown of the game in a 10-6 Redskins victory.

title: HIS CAREER THREATENED
description: Joe Montana, the quarterback who has guided the San Francisco 49ers to two Super Bowl victories, will miss the rest of the season with a ruptured disc and may never play again, a team doctor said today.

title: 5 DEAD, 36 HURT IN AN EXPLOSION AT SEOUL AIRPORT
description: An explosion apparently caused by a powerful bomb killed 5 people and wounded 36 others, 21 seriously, Sunday as they stood outside a terminal building at Kimpo International Airport here.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Coherent Communications Systems, a member of the Safeguard Scientifics Inc. group of high-technology companies, has appointed to its board George McKendrick, chairman of International Telecommuniciations Users Group.

title: COLUMBIA TRIES AGAIN TO BEAT LOSING HABIT
description: COLUMBIA will open its 96th football season against Harvard this Saturday. For most of the those seasons, Columbia has been to losing what Notre Dame and Oklahoma have been to winning. The Lions are currently on a 21-game losing streak (24 including ties) dating to 1983 - with no relief in sight. A year ago, Harvard pummeled Columbia in both teams' season opener, sending Columbia off to a 0-10 season and, more unfortunately, precipitating a scandal in the school's coaching ranks.

title: JETS' HAMILTON REGAINS SIGHT
description: Harry Hamilton could see again this morning. It was the first time since his horrifying accident Thursday night that sent shudders through his teammates.

title: MUSIC: CAROL WINCENC, MAGIC FLUTE FESTIVAL
description: FLUTE recitals sometimes suffer from a lack of variety.

title: BRELAND AND BIGGS EXTEND THEIR STREAKS
description: Mark Breland had a sore left hand tonight, so he used it sparingly. But there was nothing wrong with Breland's right.

title: INDIAN CENTER IN WEST CLOSED IN INQUIRY ON U.S. JOB FUNDS
description: The Los Angeles Indian Center, a 50-year-old community and education organization, has closed and is not likely to reopen soon.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH ON HALTING DRUG ABUSE
description: Following are excerpts from the speech given last night by President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: STRATEGIES FOR SMALL INVESTOR
description: For small investors who are willing to ride out the current storm on Wall Street and keep their money in the stock market, a variety of strategies are available. Brokers and investment advisers caution, however, that individuals who choose to remain in the market must be prepared for continued volatility in stock prices, even after the worst is over.

title: The Contrasts To 1929 Market
description: While some people are quick to draw parallels between today's stock market and the market of the 1929 crash at the beginning of the Depression, there are more dissimilarities than similarities.

title: Telstar Merger Accord
description: The Telstar Corporation of Los Angeles said last week that it had signed a preliminary agreement to merge with Golden West Television Productions Inc. and Resorts Broadcasting Inc. Under the agreement, Golden West and Resorts would become divisions of Telstar, forming a new multi-media company with interests in cable and satellite communications, radio broadcasting, radio and television production, distribution and home shopping service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1986
description: Markets

title: Catching Up
description: * Turner Gill, the former Nebraska quarterback who was forced by a series of concussions to quit Canadian football, has just finished his first season as a professional baseball player. Here's the bad news: a batting average of only .223 - albeit with 6 homers and 20 runs batted in - and 34 errors at shortstop in 53 games for Waterloo, the Cleveland affiliate in the Class A Midwest League.

title: QUARTERBACK SHIFTS AT BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Predicting the outcome of a Boston College football game has always been difficult ever since 1942, when an undefeated and untied team was surprised by Holy Cross, 55-12. Then there was the 1976 team, which defeated a highly favored Texas squad in the season opener, then lost to Villanova later that season.

title: FOR APPLE, REBOUND AND NEW COMPUTER
description: Only a year ago, the once high-flying Apple Computer Inc. seemed to have crashed to earth, its top executives feuding bitterly as their empire collapsed around them.

title: CYCLISTS FOLLOW A RURAL ROUTE
description: New York held its first professional international bicycle road race today under skies that couldn't have been bluer and conditions that couldn't have been more perfect.

title: No Havens Above
description: Given the far-reaching implications of the tax bill that is on its way to becoming law, it should give sports fans at least a perverse sense of pride to know that the linchpin of the entire vaunted enterprise is an obscure provision aimed directly at them, or some of them, anyway. While Congressional tax specialists say it will have virtually no impact on Federal revenues, they also say the provision has become critical in preserving the notion of reform and fairness in a bill that began as a crusade against the three-martini lunch by wealthy businessmen and is ending as a proposal that would cut their tax rates almost in half.

title: Hunt Legal Antagonists Play It Close to Vests
description: In contrast to the vocal and sometimes flamboyant style of the lawyers arguing for the Hunt brothers in their lawsuits against 23 banks, two of the lawyers heading the legal team representing the banks are notably reticent and cautious in their approach.

title: TREASURY'S FINANCING PLANS AWAITED
description: Participants in the Treasury market will begin looking ahead this week to a major financing next week. In the corporate and tax-exempt markets, however, the supply of new issues will remain light.

title: VISA POLICY IS SURPRISE IN THE U.S.
description: French and American officials in the United States and the airlines serving the two countries were caught by surprise yesterday by the French announcement of a visa requirement for United States citizens, effective today.

title: BLOOMINGDALE'S TO OPEN AIRPORT STORES
description: Bloomingdale's will open two small stores in late November at Kennedy International Airport in New York, in a test that could lead to stores at other airports in the United States and abroad.

title: A Stake in Fowler
description: The ideal people to run a political fund-raising function are politicians who stand to profit personally if the candidate for whom it is being given gets elected. They tend to sell more tickets.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A TOUCH OF AUTEUR The movie director who leaves a strong imprint on his work is still a director, but he is also elevated to the status of auteur. A new series at the Museum of Modern Art (11 West 53d Street, one Monday a month) is about directors, unpretentiously titled, ''The Directors Guild of America: 50th Anniversary Tribute.'' But the director it honors today is auteur caliber.

title: MONEY WOES IMPEDE BRADLEY IN CALIFORNIA RACE
description: California's gubernatorial race is settling into a war of economic attrition in which television is the principal weapon and the challenger, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, is facing what experts say is a serious financial disadvantage.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WE IRISH. Essays on Irish Literature and Society. By Denis Donoghue. 275 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. WHO speaks for Ireland? ''We Irish,'' the title

title: WARSAW'S HOPE: AMNESTY'S BENEFITS
description: As Poland's remaining political detainees left prison, Government officials made it clear that they are awaiting responses at home and abroad to the gesture, which they regard as a breakthrough after nearly five years of impasse that pitted the Roman Catholic Church and other major elements of society against the Government.

title: Taiwan-U.S. Trade Talks
description: Taiwan, under strong pressure from Washington to cut a huge trade surplus, will resume talks with the United States later this month to discuss its exports, a senior trade official said today.

title: MUSIC: CHIKUZAN, SINGER AND LUTANIST
description: FEW Western listeners have heard of the Tsugaru shamisen, a three-stringed lute played by itinerant folk musicians of northern Japan. But when the Japan Society announced that Takahashi Chikuzan, the instrument's most-celebrated player, would be giving two performances, both sold out. The heterogeneous crowd on Friday listened with a rapt intensity one rarely encounters at any sort of musical event. And for once, assertions in the program notes - that the music ''is said to penetrate directly the listener's soul,'' and ''to connect performer and listener with unseen natural forces'' - were not hyperbole.

title: Union Carbide's Disservice to Victims of Bhopal
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILLIES SEND METS WEST FOR CLINCHING
description: It may not count for much in the course of human history, or even in the course of baseball history, but the Mets did it again today: They lost to the Philadelphia Phillies for the third straight time, and failed to clinch the National League Eastern Division title for the third straight time.

title: AUTHOR OF 'AT HOME WITH THE BOMB' SETTLES IN CITY WHERE BOMB IS MADE
description: Amarilloans were perplexed when Grace Mojtabai came to town on a Greyhound bus four years ago and began hanging around the churches with a notebook and tape recorder, asking a lot of questions.

title: ASTROS BEATEN BY PADRES, 3-2
description: Carmelo Martinez, a pinch-hitter, had a two-run homer with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning today, lifting the San Diego Padres to a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: REAGANS ADVOCATE 'CRUSADE' ON DRUGS
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, in a rare joint address, called tonight for a ''national crusade'' against drug abuse.

title: Lobbying for More Readers
description: ''In Washington, the business of lawyering is the business of lobbying,'' Steven Brill said the other day, explaining why he had expanded the focus of The Legal Times, a weekly newspaper that he acquired recently, to cover both lobbying and legal affairs. His target is a nice juicy one: the 10,000 to 15,000 lawyers in Washington who work for trade or professional associations or for outright lobbying concerns. When asked to give an example of the kind of article that might result from the shift in focus, Mr. Brill cited an article out today noting that Leonard Garment, once President Nixon's lawyer, had lobbied for the Italian company Fiat, which was removed from the Pentagon's list of qualified bidders because of Libya's 15 percent interest in the company.

title: Jeanne T. Cohn, a Lawyer, Is Wed to John G. Connor
description: Jeanne Terry Cohn, an associate in the law firm of Cole & Deitz, and John Gregory Connor, an associate in the law firm of Owen & Fennell, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Hotel Thayer in West Point, N.Y. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey and the Rev. Howard Stowe, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: A CITY'S EFFORT TO SHARE THE BENEFITS OF PROGRESS
description: It is said here that when Anthony Cucci, a former schoolteacher, defeated the incumbent to become the city's mayor last year, no one was more surprised than Mr. Cucci himself.

title: McDonnell-Airbus Talks
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Airbus Industrie said over the weekend that they were still discussing a possible joint European-American effort that could rival the Beoing Company for dominance in the international airplane market. To date, however, their talks, which began five months ago, have been inconclusive, McDonnell Douglas said in a statement. The two airplane makers have been at odds over how best to build a long-range civilian airliner.

title: Briefcases
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission set a Nov. 10 deadline for comments on an application by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to offer a contract on the Australian dollar.

title: AMERICA, NO SCROOGE, BLESSES DICKENS COPIOUSLY
description: What larks, Pip! It turns out that the Americans are showing such a passion lately for Charles Dickens that Alan Watt from the Dickens Fellowship has returned from his American tour not only rereading ''Martin Chuzzlewit,'' of course, but resolved to adapt the latest recruiting methods for the English Dickens clubs.

title: U.S.'S 'FIX-IT' ANTITRUST POLICY
description: ON Aug. 26, the Federal Government rejected the proposed $675 million acquisition of Eastern Air Lines by the Texas Air Corporation, asserting that it would significantly reduce competition in the Northeast shuttle markets. But in rejecting a deal that would have created the nation's biggest airline, the Department of Transportation clearly signaled to the two carriers that there was a way to ''fix'' the merger to make it acceptable to the Reagan Administration.

title: Advertising; Theatrical Specialist Takes Position at Grey
description: Jeffrey Ash, a second-generation theatrical advertising specialist, has come to Grey Advertising's Grey Entertainment and Media as director of theatrical accounts.

title: MATTINGLY HOMER BRINGS 5-3 VICTORY
description: The fortunes of the American League's top two relief pitchers continued moving in opposite directions last night as the Yankees trimmed the Orioles, 5-3. Don Mattingly was primarily responsible for the latest developments in the late-inning lives of Dave Righetti and Don Aase.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a computer processing error, the Weather Report in some copies on Saturday repeated the previous day's listing of temperatures and forecasts for United States cities. Readers wishing a corrected list may write to the news desk, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Chairman Backs Spinoff Of Commercial Credit
description: In his spare time, Joseph D. Minutilli, chairman and chief executive of the Commercial Credit Company, renovates real estate properties. But he is best noted for the attempted restoration of the Control Data Corporation subsidiary.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Crack as a Scapegoat
description: The crack wars are far from over. The New York City police have seized some 30 cars belonging to alleged buyers. Mayors and governors have held conferences on the subject, and on Sunday the Reagans joined the fray, denouncing drug abuse on national television. Yet the reality in the streets remains the same: the crime rates continue their steady increase.

title: THE AUSTRIAN COALITION COLLAPSES OVER PARTY ELECTION OF A RIGHTIST
description: Austria's Government collapsed today after the junior party in the coalition, the Freedom Party, elected a far-right nationalist as party leader over the weekend.

title: CONFERENCE CALLS BENEFIT GIANTS
description: Last winter, Coach John Mackovic of the Kansas City Chiefs telephoned Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants. A few weeks later, Parcells telephoned Coach Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos.

title: More Surgery Scheduled For Mine Collapse Victim
description: More surgery is scheduled Tuesday for a teen-ager whose legs were crushed when he was pinned under 30 tons of rock for 18 hours in an abandoned iron mine.

title: G.O.P. CONSIDERS PLAN TO EXPAND DEATH PENALTY
description: Senate Republican leaders are considering introducing legislation to expand the use of the death penalty beyond drug-related Federal crimes, aides to the Republican leadership said today.

title: DIVI HOTELS NV reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a gain of $537,450 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONCERT: 'NEW SOUNDS'
description: New Sounds'' at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday afternoon was an aptly named event, being less about music than about the materials from which music is made.

title: Advertising; J. Walter Thompson Has New Division
description: J. Walter Thompson has set up a new department called Strategic Services, which will offer market and media research, market modeling and new product planning.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $588,000 from the sale of a plant in Germany, as well as related marketing operations. The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in July.

title: Brewing a Monopoly
description: Should beer companies have a right to set up exclusive distribution franchises that require supermarkets or bars in, say, New York City, to buy Budweiser from only a single source? Sensibly, the Supreme Court has decided that the answer depends on the facts of the specific case. Where the arrangement promotes competition, it is legal; where it inhibits competition, it isn't. But this ''rule of reason'' doesn't satisfy the beer wholesalers. They are trying to slip an outright exemption through Congress and it's up to the Senate to stop them.

title: Markets Steady Abroad
description: Stock prices steadied or rebounded on major exchanges around the world yesterday following Friday's sharp declines, although trading was generally thin and nervous.

title: LIBERAL PARTY CHIEFS FAULTED ON SELECTION OF SITE FOR MEETING
description: The leaders of the state's embattled Liberal Party have chosen Lockport, N.Y., about 20 miles from Canada, as the site of a party reorganization meeting tomorrow where they will face re-election to their posts.

title: PHILLIES WIN 4TH STRAIGHT
description: Don Carman pitched a four-hitter, John Russell drove in four runs with a double and triple, and Mike Schmidt hit a home run tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 5-0 for their fourth straight victory.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect subsequent stock dividends and splits.

title: SUIT CHARGES CONTRACTOR LIED TO ARMY ON INFANTRY VEHICLE
description: A recently discharged employee of the FMC Corporation, which makes the Bradley infantry fighting vehicle for the Army, has sued the company, saying it falsely asserted that the weapon system met the Army's specifications.

title: 5 From Chase Join Grenfell
description: Morgan Grenfell Capital Management said yesterday that it had hired five former executives from the Chase Manhattan Corporation to direct a major portion of Morgan Grenfell's United States portfolio management and new business development.

title: EX-PRISONERS OF CASTRO WARILY EMBRACE FREEDOM
description: Carmello Garcia Estevez stood in the blazing sun this morning, shy and a little edgy, finally free after 28 years in the Cuban prisons of Fidel Castro.

title: Smithsonian to Publish A New Journal of Art
description: The Smithsonian Institution has approved publication of a new journal on art by its National Museum of American Art.

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After a tax credit of $74,000. c-Net loss

title: Teachers Go on Strike In Two School Districts
description: Teachers in a school district in Michigan and one in Ohio went on strike yesterday over wages, bringing to nearly 84,000 the number of students in 20 districts nationwide who are facing another week without classes.

title: Life in Subsubbasement
description: Microscopic organisms have been found living as much as 700 feet below the earth's surface, despite proposals that life could not exist at such depths, according to Florida State University in Tallahassee. The organisms, including forms responsible for decay processes, were found in deposits in a study sponsored by the Department of Energy and its Savannah River Plant. Specialists had suspected that organisms found at shallow depths might be carried deep within the earth by water.

title: MONTANA GETS SURGERY FOR DISK
description: Joe Montana, who led the San Francisco 49ers to two Super Bowl victories, underwent back surgery yesterday to correct a ruptured disk that threatens his career.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $300,000 and $670,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After tax credits of $290,000 for the quarter and $779,000 for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago results reflect changes in accounting estimates.

title: Gamma Rays in Space
description: Efforts are being made to determine if the largest disposable component of the space shuttle, the huge external fuel tank, can be used in space. Recent studies have determined that the spent tanks, 154 feet long and 27 1/2 feet in diameter, could be carried into orbit rather than dropped into the sea just before the shuttle reaches space.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of vessels and aircraft of $2,389,000 for the quarter and $28,314,000 for the year. c-Includes a writedown of $1,758,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Phone Companies' Ratings Changed
description: Bond ratings for a dozen telephone companies were reduced slightly while ratings for another 11 telephone companies were increased, Fitch Investors Service said in a report published yesterday.

title: SOVIET IS 'THE PITS,' KOCH TELLS RUSSIAN CHILDREN
description: The little ceremony in the rotunda of City Hall yesterday started out like many others: Mayor Koch issuing a proclamation, this one to declare the week ''Peace Child Week.''

title: Data on Drug Use
description: So much attention has been focused lately on the drug problem by Congress and the White House that it is easy to fail to note that others have been working on the issue for a long time. The Parents Resource Institute for Drug Education, Pride, is one of these.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SCITEX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After share in losses of 50 percent owned companies of $869,000 for the quarter and $1,315,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: Choice for Tunisia
description: Robert H. Pelletreau Jr., a career foreign service officer now assigned by the State Department to a post at the Pentagon, is the State Department's leading candidate to be the next Ambassador to Tunisia.

title: ECONOMIC CRISIS PLANS, YES, BUT NOT ON PAPER, IT SEEMS
description: At the Pentagon, contingency planning is a way of life.

title: NOTES ON FASION
description: THIS season of what seems like a million parties began Tuesday night, when black-clad Manhattanites overflowed the opening of the fashion photographer Bruce Weber's new show at the Robert Miller Gallery on East 57th Strret and then poured downtown to a dinner at Amazonas on Broome Street. Enough beautiful faces were in attendance to fill several hefty September fashion magazines, beginning with the baseball-hatted Calvin Klein Girl, Jose Borain, who was checking names off a list at the door. Many of Mr. Weber's friends brought their friends in the hope that the photographer would discover them next. BLOOMINGDALE'S attracted more hordes Wednesday night at the opening of ''The World of Bloomingdale's'' promotion. Guests dined in the furniture department's model rooms, where one couple raised their glasses each time someone browsed by and, mimicking the store's slogan, announced, ''It's like no other world in the world.'' TINY violets used to be splashed on such things as hatboxes at Bonwit Teller in the 1930's and 1940's, according to Jay Hyde Crawford, an artist and fabric designer. In the 1960's, he grouped the violets into what he described as ''more with-it'' bouquets on Bonwit's shopping bags. Still in use after 25 years, his design for those bags is the point of a party honoring Mr. Crawford at the store tonight. In return, he recently gave a party in his East 50's town house. Guests trooped dutifully upstairs to admire Mr. Crawford's new granite bathroom while their host expressed his admiration for Bonwit Teller.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 6 months figures include a $1,597,000 charge related to the writedown of the book value of oil and gas properties.

title: PAKISTAN INQUIRY FINDING FEW CLUES
description: An investigation into the backgrounds of four men who attacked a Pan American World Airways jumbo jet here this month has failed to find evidence of a link with any foreign government, according to investigators and other Government sources.

title: FIVE TURBULENT YEARS FOR PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: April 30, 1981: Service begins with three planes based in Newark, offering trips to some smaller cities at fares discounted up to 60 percent. Loss for year is $9.2 million.

title: EUROPEANS DEADLOCK ON PRETORIA CURBS
description: Foreign Ministers of the 12 European Common Market nations appeared deadlocked tonight over proposals for a limited package of economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: PUTTING OFF THE AGE OF RETIREMENT
description: WITH corporate drug problems on the rise and mergers often causing dismissals, human resources managers now face still another problem: a changing attitude toward retirement. Many employees want to work longer.

title: STAGED PRODUCTIONS FOR THE CITY OPERA
description: Ronald Bentley, a stage director on the staff of the New York City Opera, died Thursday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan of cancer, according to his family. He was 48 years old.

title: Hyatt Hotel Sale
description: VMS Realty Partners said a limited partnership it heads had agreed to sell the Hyatt Regency Waikiki Hotel in Honolulu to the Azabu U.S.A. Corporation of Japan for $245 million. VMS bought the 1,234-room hotel for $113 million in September 1984.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Does the brain store information the way a computer does? A. Although our knowledge of the brain is incomplete, most scientists believe that, unlike computers, it generally has no specialized memory centers, said Dr. Larry Squire of Veterans Administration Medical Center in San Diego. There is evidence that information storage involves the synapses, the points at which information is transferred from cell to cell, said Dr. Robert Herndon of the University of Rochester, and synapses are modified in learning situations.

title: GLOBAL ROLE FOR LONDON EXCHANGE?
description: The London Stock Exchange plans to merge with a group of international securities dealers in a bold bid to form a central electronic marketplace for trading leading international stocks when their home markets are closed and to compete with those markets when they are open, according to sources close to the exchange.

title: NUCLEAR CRITICS CHARGE REACTORS' O RING SEALS POSE A THREAT TO SAFETY
description: THOUSANDS of O rings similar to the one that caused the space shuttle disaster are used as seals in nuclear power plants. Although the problem is not as severe in reactors, it is causing concern among nuclear critics, regulators and operators.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Von Hayes of the Phillies won his third National League Player of the Week Award by hitting .500, going 12 for 24 with five doubles, two home runs, five runs batted in, and 10 runs scored. Hayes beat out his teammate, Mike Schmidt, who hit .417 with four home runs and 12 r.b.i. . . . Bill Buckner, the Boston Red Sox first baseman who batted .438 with six home runs, 13 r.b.i. and 33 total bases, was named the American League player of the week. . . . Grete Waitz of Norway, seven-time winner and defending women's champion of the New York City Marathon, will compete in this year's event on Nov. 2, the race director, Fred Lebow, announced yesterday. . . . Dean Evason and Wayne Babych have signed multiyear contracts with the Hartford Whalers.

title: SMITHSONIAN DISCONTINUES PARKING SPACES FOR PUBLIC
description: The Smithsonian Institution, which draws 20 million people each year to its museums clustered around the Mall, announced today that it would discontinue all public parking because of security and financial reasons.

title: HEAD-TURNERS FROM SCAASI
description: Before his couture show at his Fifth Avenue salon yesterday afternoon, Arnold Scaasi professed to be a happy man. He had designed the kind of clothes he loved - extravagant styles with elaborate details shaped to show off the body. He certainly knows how to do this sort of dress. It has been his specialty since he started designing as an assistant to Charles James in the 1950's.

title: METS, IN SLUMP, LOSE ON A WALK
description: You can make of it what you will, but the Mets lost for the fourth straight time tonight and were shut out for the second straight time. And they were no closer to clinching the championship of the National League's East than they were four days ago.

title: 10-DAY CAR SALES SOAR ON RATE CUTS
description: A new round of low-interest-rate incentive plans pushed new-car sales to record highs in the first 10 days of September, the seven major manufacturers in the United States reported today.

title: THE TERROR DEMOLISHES SANG-FROID
description: Sirens wailed. The blue lights atop police vehicles flashed. And dozens of policemen and bomb experts descended today on the Air France terminal near the landmark Hotel des Invalides.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of New York Co. has elected Harold E. Sells as a director of the company and of its subsidiary, the Bank of New York, Mr. Sells is president and chief operating officer of F. W. Woolworth Co.

title: TRAFFIC TIE-UP FORECASTS GROWING MORE PRECISE
description: At precisely 5 P.M. on Nov. 26, there will be huge traffic tie-ups at the George Washington and Verrazano-Narrows Bridges. The trouble is more than 10 weeks off, but Samuel I. Schwartz says it is an absolutely sure bet.

title: Federal Judge Upholds Separation of Students
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday that a partition at a Brooklyn public school that separates Hasidic children taking remedial lessons and public school children did not constitute a violation of the principle of the separation of church and state.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $600,000 for the latest quarter and $508,000 for the year-ago period.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $206,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,235,000. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $44,000, an extraordinary gain of $202,000, and a loss due to change in an inventory accounting method of $1,103,000.

title: CUBANS ARRIVE IN NEWARK
description: Eight former prisoners who left Cuba at dawn today arrived this evening at Newark International Airport and were greeted by children, grandchildren and friends waving American flags and cheering.

title: Traditional Pattern Emerges In Matches for World Title
description: The world championships here appear to be continuing a traditional pattern. North America tends to win the pair events, and the rest of the world wins the team events.

title: MBI BUSINESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Moscow Sees No Gains At Nuclear Test Talks
description: The Soviet delegate at the nuclear test talks here said today that the two sides had been unable to narrow differences.

title: If Guardsmen Go to Honduras
description: Several Governors, including myself, have vetoed the deployment of state National Guard units in Honduras for what the Administration euphemistically describes as ''training.'' Now Congress, declaiming against the chaos of ''50 foreign policies,'' is rushing to strip governors of this power. It ought to think twice.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1985 results are restated to reflect the change for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 from the LIFO method of valuing inventories to the FIFO method.

title: NEW DISCOVERY BLOCKS DOORWAY FOR COLD VIRUS
description: VIRUSES of the common cold have been halted in their disease-producing attacks by a novel strategy that does not touch the viruses at all, but blocks their entrance into human cells.

title: ARC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $53,500 for the latest quarter and $28,500 for the year-ago period. The company said revenue figures aren't comparable because of a change in the nature of the company's business.

title: JERSEY SENATE BACKS MINIMUM 5-YEAR DRUG TERM
