description: Hard on the heels of the call by President and Mrs. Reagan for tougher action on drug abuse, the New Jersey Senate today approved a bill that would impose a minimum five-year prison term for selling hard drugs to minors or selling in the vicinity of a school.

title: A SOVIET MISSILE IS SAID TO MISFIRE AND HIT CHINA
description: An unarmed, submarine-launched Soviet missile misfired during a test last week and apparently landed in northeastern China, Defense Department and White House sources said today.

title: 'Nickleby' Extended
description: Because of an increase in ticket sales, the Royal Shakespeare Company will extend its production of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' through Oct. 12, according to Fred Nathan, a press spokesman. The play, at the Broadhurst Theater (235 West 44th Street), opened on Aug. 24 and was to have continued through Nov. 16. Slow ticket sales had prompted the producers to announce last week, however, that it would close on Sept. 28.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE ORIOLES VS. YANKEES, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS. CARDINALS, at St. Louis, 8:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.) BRAVES VS. LOS ANGELES DODGERS, at Atlanta, 7:40 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 1 P.M. and 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: Coke Limits Plans To Core Businesses
description: Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman of the Coca-Cola Company, told analysts that $1 billion of additional debt capacity resulting from the formation of a new bottling company would be considered for acquisitions only in Coca-Cola's three core business areas - soft drinks, food and entertainment - or for a stock buyback program.

title: ANALYZING THE INFLATION JITTERS
description: Inflation, or more precisely the fear of it, nudged itself back into the public consciousness last week, touching off a sharp rise in interest rates that set in motion the record plunge in the stock market.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,058,727 for the quarter and $3,144,802 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,015,241 for the quarter and $2,139,275 for the year. The 1985 results have been reclassified to conform to the 1986 presentation of continuing and discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Prison Population Swells to Record High
description: The nation's state and Federal prison population grew by more than 5 percent in the first half of 1986 to reach a record 528,945 inmates, a Justice Department agency said Sunday.

title: HOW 4 BOYS IN 'STAND BY ME' BECAME A FILM TEAM
description: The central characters in Rob Reiner's tender movie ''Stand By Me'' are 12-year-old boys, best friends who are lurching toward adolescence in a small Oregon town in 1959. Four boys in search of the body of a dead boy.

title: Bad Turnaround
description: The Twins' Bert Blyleven, back in the clubhouse after peering over his shoulder five times to watch five Texas homers that sailed over the Metrodome fences in his five and a third innings: ''I didn't ice my arm. I iced down my neck.''

title: ANXIETY ATTACK
description: Six cases of extra dry champagne were shipped with the Mets' bats and balls from Philadelphia, where the refreshment had lain iced and gloomily unopened in the clubhouse, to St. Louis, in anticipation of a division-clinching celebration. From the mighty theorizing surrounding the triple defeat in Philly, six cases of psychiatrists should also have accompanied the Mets West.

title: JULIUS S. GLASER
description: Julius S. Glaser, chairman of the board of Schocken Books, died Sept. 10 at White Plains Hospital of heart failure caused by hepatitis complicated by peritonitis. Mr. Glaser was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: JETS' WALKER DISPLAYS CAUTION
description: Wesley Walker did not gloat today when he watched the videotapes of the Chargers' opening-day aerial rout of the Dolphins.

title: RADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: NEW SUPERCALC OFFERED AS A RIVAL TO LOTUS
description: ONE would think software publishers might by now concede that there's no other spreadsheet besides Lotus 1-2-3. Entrenched as Lotus is in the public's mind and in users' computers, it's hard to remember when it was simply an improvement, albeit by an order of magnitude, on the original spreadsheet, VisiCalc.

title: Season of Hope Comes to Punta del Este
description: Punta del Este, a summer playground for South America's rich and famous, will be offering few of its usual distractions to the thousands of delegates attending this week's international trade talks. Spring in the Southern Hemisphere is still one week away, and the Uruguayan resort's windswept beaches are hardly beckoning.

title: Ideal Basic Nears Deal With Swiss
description: Ideal Basic Industries, as part of its continuing effort to avoid bankruptcy, said yesterday that it had substantially completed an agreement under which a unit of Holderbank Financiere Glarus A.G. of Switzerland would buy 67 percent of Ideal for $110 million.

title: BOMB RIPS OFFICE AT HEADQUARTERS OF POLICE IN PARIS
description: Less than 24 hours after the Government announced sweeping new measures to combat a wave of terrorism, a bomb exploded today inside the highly protected headquarters of the Paris police 100 yards from Notre Dame Cathedral. One person was reported killed and 51 wounded, two of them gravely.

title: F.C.C. FIGHTS ITS OWN POLICY ON BIAS
description: The Federal Communications Commission has asked a Federal appeals court to declare unconstitutional the agency's policies favoring women and racial minorities.

title: September Song
description: The left-field stands at Yankee Stadium on Saturday were the scene not only of Boston's expeditionary cap-recovery quest, but also of some unusually good-humored exchanges between Yankee and Red Sox fans.

title: Pay to Play at the U.N.
description: For too many of its 41 years, the United Nations has been in danger of drowning in its own swamp of paper. Ungainly and ill managed, the organization clearly needs a trimmer staff churning out fewer documents. So says a committee of the U.N.'s own experts, whose welcome if overdue report lies before the General Assembly that convenes today.

title: The Justice and the Radical
description: William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of protecting civil rights, has searched and found what he says imperils them most. ''Nothing threatens our civil rights and political liberties more,'' he said the other day, than Supreme Court Justice William Brennan Jr. and his vision of ''a radically egalitarian society.''

title: SOFTWARE SEEN AS OBSTACLE IN DEVELOPING 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan's proposed strategic defense against ballistic missiles has encountered a technical obstacle that will almost certainly limit its shape and performance - the prodigious difficulty of developing computer software to manage the course of a battle.

title: U.S. CONTINUES POLITICAL DISCUSSION WITH MOSCOW
description: The White House sought today to maintain a political discussion with the Soviet Union even as pressures mounted to cease conducting business until an American journalist under indictment in Moscow was allowed to return.

title: JULY INVENTORIES UP 0.4%, SALES 0.7%
description: Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July as a backlog of unsold cars mounted, but overall business sales posted a healthy increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Shift at Oklahoma Bank
description: John C. Dean has been named chairman, president and chief executive of First Interstate Bank of Oklahoma, replacing James G. Cairns Jr. First Interstate of Oklahoma is the successor to the First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, which was declared insolvent by Federal regulators July 14. It was subsequently bought by First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, which is the country's ninth-largest banking company.

title: MOTION ON REHNQUIST DEBATE MAKES VOTE LIKELY TOMORROW
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, moved tonight to cut off debate on the nomination of Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States.

title: Wendy Carter Wed To Gary Schonwald
description: Wendy Carter, a daughter of Arthur L. Carter of New York and Linda Gordon of Newfane, Vt., was married Sunday to Gary Schonwald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Schonwald of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Kenneth Hain performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: CENSORSHIP FOUND ON THE INCREASE
description: CENSORSHIP of books and public school curriculums has been increasing dramatically. In the last year, incidents have increased 35 percent; in the past four years they have more than doubled.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ruling Delays Trial Of General Dynamics
description: The trial of General Dynamics Corporation on charges that it and four of its top executives overcharged the Government by more than $7.5 million has been delayed because of a Federal district judge's ruling today.

title: SHULTZ MAY STOP IN SOUTH AFRICA IN A PUSH FOR TALKS ON APARTHEID
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has tentatively decided to visit South Africa next month to show the Administration's interest in a negotiated end to apartheid, State Department officials said today.

title: Pisani Starts Serving Federal Prison Term
description: Joseph R. Pisani, a former New York state senator, began serving a one-year term for tax evasion today at a minimum-security prison here.

title: Seoul Is Said to Hold Several Suspects in Blast
description: The police were reported tonight to be holding several suspects, including at least one foreigner, in an airport bombing that killed five people on Sunday.

title: LONG ISLAND GAMBLES ON A SCALLOP TRANSPLANT
description: At 4:32 P.M. today, a small plane landed here bearing some unusual and precious cargo: about 800,000 tiny bay scallops that scientists hope will mark the rebirth of Long Island's bay scallop industry, which has been virtually wiped out by a destructive algae bloom.

title: No Leak Seen By Baldrige
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that a spate of rumored leaks of sensitive economic data turned out to be nothing more than lucky guesses, and said investors who traded on such rumors were fools.

title: WESTERN PUBLISHING GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After a charge of $4,655,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Cut in Top Salaries Set at A.H. Robins
description: Ralph Mabey, the A.H. Robins Company's court-appointed examiner, said the company and a committee of its claimants had agreed on pay cuts for top officials that include forcing the company's chairman, E. Claiborne Robins, to agree to a token salary of $1 a year. The pay cuts were approved Friday by Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr.

title: SPECIES ARE LOST BEFORE THEY'RE FOUND
description: LEADING biologists, fearful that a significant share of living species will disappear before they are even discovered, are escalating their efforts to save tropical rain forests and other imperiled ecosystems.

title: DRUG TESTS GAIN PRECISION, BUT CAN BE INACCURATE
description: Advances in biotechnology have enabled doctors to test people for drug use with greater precision than ever before. But the tests are expensive, difficult and, if not done properly, can be highly inaccurate, experts say.

title: How Much Is Needed To Save the Thrifts?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of about $5 million for plant consolidation.

title: THE DANCE: DOUG VARONE
description: TIME flies. Doug Varone acknowledged that in his program called ''Dances by Doug Varone'' on Sunday night at Performance Space 122.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AIG Risk Management Inc., a subsidiary of American International Group Inc., said it and Salomon Brothers Inc. would jointly structure self-insurance programs for municipal clients.

title: OPERA: BELLINI'S 'NORMA'
description: YOUTH, enthusiasm and good health are qualities one likes to associate with the New York City Opera. They unfortunately do not solve the problems of ''Norma.'' Bellini's opera, as played Sunday night at the New York State Theater, showed once again that its title role is as wide in its demands as any in opera - asking size, brilliance and intelligent dramatic skill while in its exposed delicacies requiring the gentlest of touches and the finest of techniques.

title: ... and Reaching Out For a Future
description: Abraham Mohsin, 2 1/2 years old, also went back to school yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PERFUME: The Story of a Murderer. By Patrick Suskind. Translated from the German by John E. Woods. 255 pages. Knopf. $16.95. HOW can you help being intrigued by the title of this first novel, ''Perfume''; or by the subtitle, ''The Story of a Murderer''; or by the painting of the nude woman on the dust jacket, a detail from Watteau's ''Nymphe et Satyre''; or by the jovial yet ironic voice of the narrator? ''In eighteenth-century France,'' he begins, ''there lived a man who was one of the most gifted and abominable personages in an era that knew no lack of gifted and abominable personages.'' He continues, ''His story will be told here. His name was Jean-Baptiste Grenouille, and if his name . . . has been forgotten today, it is . . . because his gifts and his sole ambition were restricted to a domain that leaves no traces in history: to the fleeting realm of scent.''

title: Oil Rig Count Up Again
description: The number of working oil rigs in the country rose for the second consecutive week, to 740, an increase of 4 from last week's 736, Hughes Tool Company officials said. Last year at this time, the count was 1,912.

title: Clement Stone Is Dead at 58; Head of World Financial Corp.
description: Clement Stone, chairman of the World Financial Corporation and son of the insurance magnate W. Clement Stone, has died of heart disease. He was 58 years old.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DR. JOSEPH M. PETTIT, PRESIDENT OF GEORGIA TECH, IS DEAD AT 70
description: Joseph M. Pettit, who was credited with making the Georgia Institute of Technology a top-flight research institution during his 14-year tenure as its president, died today. He was 70 years old.

title: U.S.-FRENCH SPLIT OVER SUBSIDIES SEEMS TO NARROW AT GATT CONFERENCE
description: Formally opening a criticial trade conference here today, the President of Uruguay, Julio Maria Sanguinetti, called on the nations of the world to make a supreme effort to remove the danger of a ''suicidal trade war'' and embark on trade liberalization for the economic growth of all.

title: Park Ave. Water-Main Break Interrupts Supply on 2 Blocks
description: A water main broke early yesterday under Park Avenue, releasing thousands of gallons of water that buckled the pavement at East 78th Street and knocked out power to some buildings, city environmental officials said.

title: HORROR FILMS BOOST TEENS' SEX APPEAL
description: Teen-age men who can watch horror movies like the ''Friday the Thirteenth'' series without showing signs of distress are seen by their dates as more attractive because of their bravado, a new study has found. Teen-age women, however, are seen as more attractive by their dates when they react to the horror movies with squeamishness.

title: BLACK MUSLIMS, NEEDING MONEY, MAY SELL 6 SITES
description: The former followers of the late Elijah Muhammad and his Black Muslim movement are being pressed to sell a half-dozen properties the group owns to pay its debts and prevent foreclosure on the 116th Street mosque that is at once the symbol of the group's history in the city and the focal point of the religion.

title: PRETORIA APPOINTS A NONWHITE ENVOY
description: South Africa appointed a law professor of Indian descent to be its first nonwhite foreign ambassador today.

title: CATCHING UP
description: It's not often that you have a chance to catch up on an art exhibition that has long since come and gone. But a partial rerun of an exhibition that was a hit in 1883 is opening today at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street.

title: Allbritton Sets Investor Unit
description: The Allbritton Communications Company said yesterday that it had formed a new subsidiary that could spend up to $1 billion to acquire television stations affiliated with one of the three major networks.

title: Apple Price Cuts
description: Apple Computer Inc. said that it was lowering prices for its Macintosh computers and Laserwriter printer.

title: DRUG TESTS PROMOTE SAFETY, MANY SAY
description: ''Companies could get better production and fewer injuries in manufacturing jobs'' if workers were tested for use of illegal drugs, said Lee Moreau, 41 years old, a classified advertisement taker from Tampa, Fla. ''It would eliminate grogginess and improve concentration at office jobs.''

title: D. Harold Byrd Is Dead; A Texas Philanthropist
description: D. Harold Byrd, a philanthropist who made his fortune in Texas oilfields and helped finance the exploration of Antarctica, has died. He was 86 years old.

title: FRANK NELSON
description: Frank Nelson, an actor on Jack Benny's radio and television shows for 38 years and a former national president of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, died Friday of cancer at his home in Hollywood. He was 75 years old.

title: 2 of 600 Foods Tested Have Chernobyl Taint
description: Radioactive fallout from the Chernoybl nuclear accident on April 26 contaminated only two of some 600 food imports tested, the head of a Food and Drug Administration laboratory says.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
POP: STEVE WINWOOD
description: ALTHOUGH it has been nearly 20 years since he had his first hits, ''Gimme Some Lovin' '' and ''I'm a Man,'' with the Spencer Davis Group, Steve Winwood doesn't wear the predictable aura of a weather-beaten rock veteran. Indeed, the English pop-blues singer and multi-instrumentalist, who is a very young-looking 38 years old, is more popular today than in the late 1960's and early 70's, when he led the English folk-jazz-blues band Traffic. The spare textures and loosely blocked arrangements of his music today make only minor concessions to contemporary pop sounds as he continues to evoke an earlier, more romantic period in rock history.

title: Pacers Sign Person
description: Chuck Person, Auburn's career- leading scorer and the Indiana Pacers' ''fourth prize'' pick in the National Basketball Association lottery this year, has signed a multiyear pact with the Pacers. Terms of the contract were not disclosed but the 6-foot-8-inch Person joins a team already stocked with forwards, despite the fact that 6-7 Clark Kellogg remains questionable because of a recurring knee ailment that limited him to only 19 games last year.

title: DART GROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Baldwin-United Sells Thrift Unit
description: The Commercial Federal Savings and Loan Association, Nebraska's largest retail financial institution, said that it had acquired the Empire Savings and Loan Association of Denver from the bankrupt Baldwin-United Corporation for $45 million.

title: A HARRIED AQUINO FLIES TO THE U.S.
description: President Corazon C. Aquino left today for a nine-day visit to the United States in search of political and economic support, all at a time when she faces challenges at home both from within and outside her Government.

title: Howser Optimistic
description: Dick Howser, the Kansas City Royals' manager who is battling a malignant brain tumor, has faith that he'll be in Florida for spring training and will be managing the team April 6, 1987 when the Royals face the Chicago White Sox in a season opener. ''I know it's a day-to-day situation, but I'm optimistic.

title: It's a Breeze
description: Manager Whitey Herzog, when informed that his St. Louis Cardinals now had a team total of 48 homers for the season: ''We've got a chance for Maris's record if the wind's blowing out in Chicago.''

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Long-Shot Putt
description: Gary Player at the seniors tournament in Richmond, after sinking a 96-foot birdie putt that he described as the longest of his career: ''If it had gone any farther, it would have needed a passport.''

title: AT CBS NEWS, RUMORS AND CAMPAIGN EFFORTS
description: The vacancy in one of the most visible and volatile jobs in network television, the presidency of CBS News, has prompted intense speculation and some campaigning within the news division on behalf of individuals forming the list of candidates for the job.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $102,000. The company said the latest quarter loss is substantially attributable to costs of a pre-tax non-recurring expense of about $500,000 under a contractual obligation related to the recent termination of Ketchum's former president and chief operating officer who resigned in August.

title: Long Wharf Theater Wins $50,000 Award
description: The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is this year's recipient of the Jujamcyn Theaters Award, it was announced yesterday by Richard G. Wolff, president of Jujamcyn Theaters. The award, which consists of $50,000, is awarded annually to a ''regional theater organization that has made an outstanding contribution to the development of creative talent in the theater.''

title: LIST OF THOSE CUBA RELEASED
description: Following is a list released by the Immigration and Naturalization Service of political prisoners and their relatives aboard the ''Freedom Ride'' from Havana. The name of Antolin Diaz Espinosa, one of those who traveled to Newark after arriving in Miami, had been taken off the list, the agency said, because he had been denied an exit visa by Cuba. title: RICHARD L. SARNO
description: Richard L. Sarno, a news photographer who was for many years director of photography for the Hearst Newspapers, died Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: PERES, IN U.S., PLAYS DOWN CALL FOR CONFERENCE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel today played down his earlier endorsement of an international conference to pursue a Middle East peace.

title: WEINBERGER WARNING ON WALKER PLEA AGREEMENT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger suggested today that the Government might break its plea bargain with John A. Walker Jr. because of indications that the Navy veteran was lying about his Soviet spy ring.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The year-ago quarter and 9 months results include gains from property sales of $1.4 million, or 11 cents a share.

title: 3-POINT LEAD FOR KASPAROV
description: Gary Kasparov took a commanding 9 1/2-to-6 1/2 point lead over Anatoly Karpov today by winning the 16th game of the World Chess Championship.

title: Stop the Labor Day Pigeon Slaughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Sailor Shoots 3 Instructors
description: A Navy serviceman, apparently upset that he was being flunked from an electronics training course, opened fire on instructors today, killing one and wounding two, officials said. The gunman was captured and held by the Naval Investigative Service, said Bill Dermody, a spokesman for the Great Lakes Naval Training Center.

title: 45 Mexican Officials Linked to Drug Traffic
description: A newspaper quoting unidentified law enforcement officials reported today that at least 45 Mexican police and political figures, including the country's Defense Minister, had been linked to drug trafficking.

title: Value of Diet in Baseball
description: When the Boston Red Sox were in Baltimore recently to play the Orioles, their star pitcher, Roger Clemens, paid a visit to the White House and then won a game against the Orioles, which is as close to a home baseball team as Washington has. The next day, the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who is from Boston, gave a fried chicken lunch for three Red Sox players, Dwight Evans, Bill Buckner and Marty Barrett.

title: U.S. REPORTS DENY SOVIET IS PRESSED
description: American intelligence analysts have concluded that Soviet economic problems have had little effect in impelling Moscow to strike an arms control deal, according to newly declassified Congressional testimony.

title: Fixed Sentences for Young Offenders: From Bad to Much Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in SportsMonday this week with an article about Columbia University's football team misidentified its first coach. He was George Sanford.

title: Televideo Set To Buy Alpha
description: Televideo Systems Inc., a maker of computer terminals based in San Jose, Calif., said today that it had agreed to acquire Alpha Microsystems, a manufacturer of multi-user microcomputer systems based in Irvine, Calif. Under the proposed transaction, Televideo would acquire Alpha for $4 in cash and $4 in Televideo stock for each share, or a total of about $25 million.

title: THE SALVADORAN PARLEY IS OFF
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte pledged today to go alone to a site chosen for a new round of peace talks, even though leftist rebels said Sunday night that they refused to meet him there.

title: PASSING GAME REMAINS THE BIG GAINER
description: Passing yardage has exceeded rushing yardage in college football for the last three years and quarterbacks this season are continuing that trend. Division 1-A or major teams are throwing 188 yards a game while rushing 161.9 and Division 1-AA teams are passing 179 and rushing 150.7 each game.

title: SKY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING & EXLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain on debt restructuring of $3,343,000, a gain of $253,000 resulting from the release of guarantee of a limited partnership loan and a loss of $1,299,000 from the writedown of transferred assets, for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: TEXAS AIR BUYING PEOPLE EXPRESS FOR $125 MILLION
description: In a move that would have wide effects on the airline industry, the Texas Air Corporation will acquire People Express in a stock deal, the airlines announced yesterday.

title: Advertising; 'Barney Miller' Actress Gets Tri-Honda Spot
description: Florence Stanley, who played the part of Bernice, wife of Detective Fish on the ''Barney Miller'' TV series, has now gotten herself a gem of a starring role in a 30-second commercial for the Tri-Honda Advertising Association.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES STIFFER DRUG LAWS
description: President Reagan today formally proposed a $900 million program to combat drug abuse and ordered the heads of Federal agencies to establish a program of testing for evidence of drug use among a broad range of employees.

title: Ex-General to Join The Times
description: Lieut. Gen. Bernard E. Trainor, who retired from the Marine Corps in July 1985, will join The New York Times on Oct. 6 as its military correspondent. His appointment was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor.

title: HOW SENATE BILL ON LOBBYING FADED IN THE STRETCH
description: A bill that sails through a Senate committee on a vote of 17 to 1 can usually expect swift approval in the Senate chamber. Such a committee vote usually indicates widespread support and only minimal opposition.

title: CASINO WORKERS STAGE STRIKE AT EIGHT SITES IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Members of this resort's largest casino workers union struck 8 of the 11 gaming halls here shortly after midnight Monday in a dispute over wages and benefits, union officials said.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS IN PEPITONE CASE
description: Defense and prosecution lawyers presented their final arguments yesterday in the case involving drug and weapon charges against Joe Pepitone, the former first baseman for the Yankees.

title: Advertising
description: People

title: U.S. DRAFTS NEW IDEAS FOR GENEVA ARMS TALKS
description: The United States may propose a combined limit on long-range missiles and bombers in a new strategic arms pact to help bridge the gap between the American and Soviet positions, Administration officials said today.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
69 EX-POLITICAL PRISONERS IN CUBA FLY TO A JOYOUS WELCOME IN U.S.
description: With prayers of thanksgiving and deliverance, 69 former political prisoners from Cuba and about 40 members of their families arrived in the United States today.

title: RATES FALL SLIGHTLY; TRADING IS SLOWER
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities declined slightly yesterday in trading that was much less active than last week, when rates rose sharply for medium- and long-term issues.

title: POLL IN BOSTON PUTS KENNEDY AHEAD OF RIVALS
description: With support from the elderly, women and blue-collar voters, Joseph P. Kennedy 2d appears to hold a narrow lead over his closest opponent in Tuesday's primary for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives.

title: G.E. Plans to Sell Insurance Unit
description: The General Electric Company announced that it had entered into an agreement to sell the North American Company for Life and Health Insurance to a corporation formed by a group of investors headed by Harold S. Geneen, the former head of the ITT Corporation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: MANY JOURNALISTS ACCEPTING 'NO-STRINGS' OFFER BY DISNEY
description: Walt Disney World is giving a multi-million-dollar party for the nation's news organizations, and about 2,500 representatives of newspapers, magazines and radio and television stations have accepted the invitation to attend, with all expenses paid by Disney.

title: New Citgo Partner
description: The Southland Corporation said that it had signed a definitive agreement with the state-owned oil company of Venezuela to sell 50 percent of the stock of its Citgo Petroleum Corporation for $290 million.

title: Hands Across America
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Bank Workers Return
description: Most of Brazil's 750,000 bank workers returned to their jobs today after suspending a three-day strike for higher wages, union leaders said. In Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia the strike ended on Friday, but in the country's largest industrial center, Sao Paulo, and other cities bank employees stayed away from work until today, returning to their jobs under protest, they said.

title: Grand Jury Focusing On Krishna Activities
description: A Federal grand jury began an investigation today into the activities of the Hare Krishna religious group in West Virginia's Panhandle.

title: IN SMALL TOWNS OF MICHIGAN, A WAR WITH WATER AND WIND
description: Nearly a week after the first drops of a record downpour fell on central Michigan, small towns and villages were still struggling today to control rising flood waters as winds pushed currents up already-swollen rivers.

title: 18 Horses Enter Brown Jug Field
description: Barberry Spur, the winner of the Cane Pace and the Adios Pace, has drawn the pole position for Thursday's second division of the 41st Little Brown Jug pacing classic for 3-year-olds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1986
description: International

title: Broncos Win, 21-10
description: John Elway threw three touchdown passes tonight as the Denver Broncos held off a fourth-quarter Pittsburgh rally to defeat the Steelers, 21-10.

title: OILERS WORK TO TRADE EVERETT
description: The Houston Oilers, who picked Jim Everett of Purdue in the first round of the college draft but never signed him, have given another team permission to discuss a contract with him, Everett's agent said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1986
description: Companies

title: Garn Transplant Successful
description: Doctors today said the transplant of Senator Jake Garn's kidney to his diabetic daughter was a success. The Senator, a Utah Republican, is up and walking three miles a day and will be discharged on Wednesday, according to doctors at Georgetown University hospital.

title: Stop the Labor Day Pigeon Slaughter
description: To the Editor:

title: DALTON COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: HEARING ON IMPEACHMENT OF JUDGE GETS UNDER WAY IN SENATE PANEL
description: For the first time in 50 years, the Senate opened an impeachment proceeding today, to consider the removal of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas, who is serving a two-year prison term for tax evasion.

title: Mother and Son Killed In a Suspicious Blaze
description: A suspicious fire in a Brooklyn row house yesterday morning left a mother and one of her sons dead and another son injured, police and fire officials reported.

title: AT 90, JANIS STILL IN STEP WITH ART
description: The trombone wah-wahed a happy birthday, and Sidney Janis - with some help from assorted sons, grandsons, a great-grandaughter, world-famous artists, curators, critics and art collectors - blew out 90 candles on a cake last night at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Group Claims Abductions
description: A new claim of responsibility for the kidnappings of two Americans here has strengthened a theory that the abductions may be linked to the attack this month on the American airliner in Karachi.

title: CART Waves The Yellow Flag
description: Two months ago Rick Mears qualified his March-Cosworth for the Michigan 500 at 223.4 miles an hour. That is the fastest speed ever recorded by an automobile on a closed course, and Mears predicts that when the PPG Indy Car World Series returns to the high-banked, two-mile-long Michigan International Speedway later this month, the cooler weather may make possible a top lap 3 or 4 miles an hour faster. Mears claims that the blinding speed of today's Indy cars doesn't quite bother him, but he also admits that the record lap at Michigan ''really got my attention.''

title: Chief of Gimbels East Moving to Associated
description: Matthew D. Serra, president and chief executive of Gimbels East, is as sorry as anyone to see the demise of Gimbels. Mr. Serra has been in charge of the Gimbels stores in the Philadelphia and New York areas and now, with the closing of Gimbel, has taken a job in Rochester.

title: CONCERT: ENGLISH CHOIR
description: A VISIT from any of Britain's fine choirs is always a welcome reminder of that nation's finest musical tradition, and the choir of St. John's College, Cambridge, offered that reminder in an especially satisfying concert Sunday afternoon at St. Thomas Church.

title: An $85 Million Offering By County in Arizona
description: Maricopa County, Ariz., one of the few local governments scheduled to sell bonds this week, sold $85 million of tax-exempt general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Mystery Guest
description: No official announcement has been made, but the outward signs indicate that the special guest for next week's fund-raising dinner for the Reagan Scholarship Program at Eureka College will be the institution's favorite alumni and namesake of the scholarship fund.

title: TRUCE HALTS FIGHT OVER CONTROL OF BROKEN HILL
description: Australia's richest man, Robert Holmes a Court, agreed today to a truce that would halt, at least temporarily, his long-running battle for control of Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., the natural resources enterprise.

title: DISPUTE OVER THE DANILOFF AFFAIR ERUPTS AT THE RIGA TOWN MEETING
description: Soviet and American officials, meeting in public for the first time since an American correspondent was detained in Moscow, got into an argument about the case today at this Baltic beach resort outside Riga.

title: Williams in Capital
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., one of the members of Congress caught up in the Abscam political corruption case, made a triumphal if little publicized return to Washington the other day. It was his first visit to the capital since he entered prison in 1984 to serve what turned out to be 21 months for bribery and conspiracy.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $113,401 and inclusion of pre-tax income of $375,000 from Intercredit Corp. The company said the year-ago revenue includes $1,319,000 in revenue from Intercredit Corp. which was sold in April.

title: '86 Bond Issues Are Up Abroad
description: Gross borrowing in the international capital markets through bond issues is running at a record annual rate of around $223 billion this year, up about 38 percent from the comparable period last year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY OPENING WITH MONEY A TOP ITEM
description: When the General Assembly opens on Tuesday, it will scarcely resemble last year's gala, when a record number of world leaders descended on New York to mark the 40th anniversary of the United Nations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a dream. I never thought I would see it, but tonight I will see the moon over Miami.''

title: Market Place; Funds Keeping It in the Family
description: PROMPTED by the market's sharp decline, many mutual fund shareowners switched out of stock funds late last week and into money market funds that offer higher yields and far greater safety of principal. But industry sources asserted that outright liquidation of fund shares was virtually nonexistent.

title: Advertising; Posey and Quest Add Genova
description: FOUNDED in 1979 as Posey & Parry and then going to Posey, Parry & Quest and on to Posey & Quest, the Greenwich, Conn., agency has changed its name once again. This time it reflects the modernists' antipathy to ampersands: Posey Quest Genova.

title: Citicorp Unit Gets Fixed-Income Head
description: Citicorp Investment Management Inc. said yesterday that it had named Willard R. Phillips Jr. as director of fixed income.

title: Some Telephone Lines To Puerto Rico Restored
description: Special circuits have been established for emergency calls between the United States and Puerto Rico to help cope with a phone line failure, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today.

title: TEXAS AIR'S BOLD BARGAINING
description: Frank A. Lorenzo's complex bid to acquire People Express Inc. illustrates his penchant to act boldly and bargain hard when opportunities arise to build his Texas Air Corporation, analysts said today.

title: Choosing a Jury
description: Jury selection began yesterday in Riverhead, L.I., in the trial of the personal-injury suit brought by a photographer against Martina Navratilova. The tennis champion has filed a countersuit in the case stemming from an incident at the 1982 United States Open.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Although investors remained tentative after a steep two-day drop in the stock market, Wall Street posted its first gains in more than a week yesterday.

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
As Japan Moves Toward Economic Leadership; Share Is Overestimated
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach of Islanders Sees Job Openings
description: The training camp scrimmages have already been spirited this year, even the ones among the Islander veterans, and the players attribute this to a sense of job insecurity caused by the presence of a new coach, Terry Simpson.

title: GUNMAN INVADES A RESTAURANT SHOOTING 4 OWNERS, 2 FATALLY
description: A disgruntled former employee opened fire with a pistol yesterday in a closed fast-food restaurant near Union Square in Manhattan, shooting four of the owners, two fatally, the police said.

title: CATHOLIC CONNECTICUT YANKEE WHO HEADS THE KLAN
description: In the two weeks since he was elected the top Ku Klux Klansman in the nation, James Farrands, a tool-and-die machinist, has been bustling about, recruiting prospective members, ordering his new imperial wizard's robe, handling mail requests for Klan T-shirts, and granting interviews to reporters from all over the world.

title: Tales of Two Students: Recalling the Long Past ...
description: Mayer Susskind, 95 years old, went back to school yesterday.

title: FEARED RAIDER TO RETIRE AT UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
description: Harry J. Gray, one of the most widely feared executives of the 1970's and early 1980's because of his bold takeover attacks, announced yesterday that he would step down Dec. 31 as chairman of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Korea Has a Chance
description: A bomb explosion at the airport here on Sunday was obviously intended to tarnish the gloss South Korea expects from the coming Asian Games and the 1988 Olympics. It only serves to highlight the country's achievements, which President Chun Doo Hwan is trying to use to confound his critics.

title: Final Applause For William B. Williams
description: Frank Sinatra did something yesterday that he rarely does: take second billing. And at the Palace. The headliner was the late William B. Williams, a disk jockey at radio station WNEW for 42 years before his death Aug. 4 at the age of 62.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The U.N. Today: Sept. 16, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: HOUSE PANEL TO WEIGH RAISING TAX ON GASOLINE AS WAY TO CUT DEFICIT
description: The House and Ways Means Committee will consider raising the gasoline tax as much as 10 cents a gallon Tuesday as both the House and Senate work on legislative packages to reduce the 1987 budget deficit.

title: New Electronic Data Service
description: The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company, and Covidea, a partnership of several financial, communications and media companies, yesterday introduced an electronic information service intended for use by consumers in the New York area.

title: CREATED LIBERTY BROADCASTING
description: Gordon B. McClendon, a wealthy Texan who effectively used play-by-play sportscasts to build a radio empire, died of cancer Sunday at his ranch at Lake Dallas, Tex. He was 65 years old.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Books: Into the Wilds
description: SEVEN RIVERS WEST. By Edward Hoagland. 319 pages. Summit books. $18.95 If confirmation were needed of Edward Hoagland's distinction as a travel and nature writer, his new novel would provide it. ''Seven Rivers West'' is a virtuoso display of imagination grounded in affection and respect for the wild. The muscular prose penetrates the ways of the animals and plants, the rivers and mountains that confronted and confounded men moving west into the unknown toward the end of the 19th century. Unfortunately, the men are not as vividly realized as the forces of nature. They seem slight amid their awesome surroundings, and their desires seem transient and a little foolish compared to the basic responses they encounter. Perhaps that is what Mr. Hoagland wants to get across, but it works against his novel, his first in 20 years.

title: Tunisian Official Dismissed
description: President Habib Bourguiba dismissed Foreign Minister Beji Caid Essebsi today, the official Tunisian press agency reported. Mr. Caid Essebsi, who took office in 1981, was a protege of Mr. Bourguiba's wife, whom the 83-year-old President divorced a month ago. The new foreign minister will be Hedi Mabrouk, Tunisia's Ambassador to Paris, the press agency said. It said Mr. Caid Essebsi would get another post but did not say which one.

title: Venezuela Landslide Kills 2
description: Two people were killed and hundreds left homeless by a landslide this weekend in a shantytown in Caracas, Civil Defense officials said today. Rescue efforts continued in the western Caracas neighborhood of La Vega, more than 24 hours after the accident early Sunday that destroyed about 150 makeshift homes. Officials blamed heavy rains and an accumulation of sewage for the landslide.

title: COMING OF AGE ON THE OCEAN: A BAR MITZVAH ABOARD THE QE2
description: ''This is my first floating bar mitzvah,'' Rabbi Arthur Schneier of the Park East Synagogue was saying Sunday night as the Queen Elizabeth 2 steamed out of New York Harbor carrying 600 formally attired guests of Gerald and Linda Guterman whose 13-year-old son, Jason, was celebrating his coming of age on the high seas.

title: WISCONSIN SAVES A RURAL THEATER
description: On a farm south of downtown Spring Green, the American Players Theater can be found. It is winding down its seventh season, one that almost did not happen.

title: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid Sept. 5.

title: 2 WOMEN IN A CLOSE NEBRASKA RACE
description: Midway through a speech to rally the troops, Kay Orr, the Republican candidate for Governor, paused to acknowledge her spouse. ''And now I'd like to introduce a very important partner in all of this - Mr. Kay Orr,'' she said.

title: BERKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations in connection with the disposal of the company's film group of $730,000 and $129,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $515,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $264,000 for the 6 months. The company said the 1986 figures includes the results of B & E Sales Co. acquired in May 1985.

title: SQUEEZING MORE CHIPS ON A BOARD
description: IN computing, playing with a full deck of cards can be a disadvantage. Many computers are designed to accept a small number of plug-in cards, also called expansion boards, that allow the user to add functions and features to the computer as new needs become apparent or as one's budget allows. But these expansion slots fill up quickly with cards that control floppy or hard disk drives, provide color and graphics capabilities to video monitors, and add memory, parallel and serial ports, modems, mice, faster processors, network capability and other bells and whistles. Several companies even offer miniaturized 30-megabyte hard disk drives attached to a plug-in card.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9-month results include a writeoff of $375,000 to cover inventory writedowns and other costs related to the relocation of Applied Circuits's Certel unit, and its consolidation into the company's systems division.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Advertising; Out-of-town Agencies Plan Exhibition in City
description: Just in case New York ad agencies are beginning to forget the humiliation of losing so many creative-advertising awards to small out-of-town agencies, six of those agencies have decided to hold an exhibition of their work here as a reminder.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net loss Both year-ago periods' results are after a gain of $1,453,000 on the disposal of certain operating units.

title: THE FANS OF POLO STEP OUT FOR A STAR-STUDDED MATCH
description: ''I'm completely taken with polo,'' Eduardo Lluria said. ''It's a contact sport, like football.''

title: MAN, 33, KILLED AND 5 ARE HURT IN AN EXPLOSION
description: One man was killed and five other people were injured in an explosion and fire yesterday at a two-story duplex house in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, officials said.

title: HEARINGS START IN L.I. CONTRACT KILLING
description: ''I made you the promise I would find the person who killed your son,'' a Suffolk County homicide detective today recalled having told Cheryl Pierson's grandmother. That night he arrested Miss Pierson, a 17-year-old former high school cheerleader, who was accused of the contract-killing of her father last Feb. 5.

title: Egypt Raises Oil Price
description: Egypt today increased the price of all its exported crude oil by 60 cents a barrel for the Sept. 16-30 period. The top grade will be $13.10 a barrel. Egypt is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Retired Soldier to Head The Selective Service
description: President Reagan plans to nominate William A. Clinkscales, a retired soldier who has spent the last 15 years as a security specialist with the General Services Administration, to head the Selective Service System, the White House announced today.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a charge of $70,000. c-Net income and after a tax credit of $170,000. There were no share earnings for the year-ago 9 months because the net did not cover the preferred dividend requirements.

title: PERU'S PRISON MASSACRES: CAN THE FACTS COME OUT?
description: Doubts are being voiced here about whether the exact circumstances that led to last summer's prison blood bath will ever be made public.

title: COACHES FINE-TUNE SOCCER AT COLLEGES
description: Without an established professional league in the United States, college coaches have now become the guardians of the sport.

title: SAFETY SORTS OUT THE POSITIVE
description: Dave Duerson's remarkable season was almost over.

title: IT'S A GAME OF INCHES, AND OF DECIMAL PLACES
description: The pennant races may not be very exciting this September, but how about those batting races? Heading into last night's play, the best four hitters in the National League were within 10 points of one another, as were the best three in the American. A couple of them might even wind up on the list of the closest races for the batting title in modern major league history, which looks this way:

title: Air Controllers Taken Off Job
description: The Federal Aviation Administration placed four air traffic controllers on administrative duties today during an inquiry into allegations that they used drugs while off duty. F.A.A. policy is to ban such employees from certain jobs until it is satisfied there is no risk to public safety. The controllers worked at the Kansas City Air Route Traffic Control Center in Olathe, Kan.

title: As Japan Moves Toward Economic Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Urging Fight On Drugs in Workplace
description: Jesse Philips, founder and chairman of Philips Industries, today urged other businesses to join in a national campaign against drugs in the workplace. Mr. Philips announced at a news conference on Sept. 11 that he would adopt a program to ''obliterate drug abuse'' in all Philips facilities, Mr. Philips said in an interview today that he was offering $1 million to President Reagan to establish a National Alliance of Business Against Drug Abuse, and that he had asked the President to head the organization.

title: READING CAN BE LEARNED LATE IN LIFE
description: JOHN was out of work for three years, but the trouble was not lack of job skills. In his life he had been a farmer, a quarryman, a machine operator. The problem was that he could not read or write.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Restaurant Owners Slain A disgruntled ex-employee returned to a family-owned Manhattan restaurant and shot four of the owners, two fatally, the police said. Page B1. U.N. Ponders Its Bills When the General Assembly opens, the main item of discussion will be whether the United Nations can meet its payroll. page A6.

title: More Bang, Less Buck on Drugs
description: President and Mrs. Reagan deserve credit for focusing more national attention on drug abuse. Yet for all the buildup, the White House's touted antidrug program offers only louder language, fewer dollars and as many dead ends as the frenzied bill passed last week by the House.

title: Aftershocks Shake Southern Greece
description: Strong aftershocks rumbled through southern Greece today, and two more bodies were uncovered from the devastating earthquake of two days ago, raising the death toll to 19.

title: BONDS ALSO RECOVER
description: Wall Street steadied yesterday.

title: ABC'S 'JACK AND MIKE'
description: JACKIE SHEA and Mike Brennan are young professionals, trying to keep a marriage percolating while pursuing their separate careers. When Jackie is faced with a tough decision, Mike tells her she should trust her instincts because they're usually right. ''Thanks,'' says Jackie. ''What are buddies for?'' grins Mike. We are, obviously, in somebody's idea of yuppie heaven.

title: Thais Deny Report Of Population Exchange
description: A Government official has denied Thailand has plans to exchange Laotian Hmong refugees seeking asylum in this country for the Thais being held by the Vientiane Government.

title: Interstellar Voyage Weighed by NASA
description: The space agency is considering sending a spacecraft on a 50-year, 100 billion-mile voyage to try to determine the age of the universe and learn if a comet cloud surrounds the solar system.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $2,270,000 for the quarter and $2,635,000 for the 6 months. The 6 months also included a loss of $293,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $163,000 for the quarter and $86,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary gains of $1,509,000 and $4,278,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: AUTHOR OF 'LILIES OF THE FIELD'
description: William E. Barrett, the author of ''The Lilies of the Field'' and other novels of religious faith and social justice, died Sunday at his home in Denver. The author of more than 20 books and countless short stories, he had been in poor health since a recent heart attack. He was 85 years old.

title: Cambodia Reported Facing An Epidemic of Dengue Fever
description: Cambodia is facing a nationwide epidemic of dengue fever, according to a report from the Cambodian Government press agency.

title: METS EARN AT LEAST A TIE FOR TITLE BY ENDING SLIDE
description: The St. Louis Cardinals were batting in the home half of the sixth inning tonight when the Busch Stadium scoreboard flashed the word: ''The Phils beat the Pirates. There'll be no title clinching tonight.''

title: Bridge; 3 Famous Teams Are Upset In World-Champion Event
description: Three world-famous teams were upset Monday night in the world team championship here for the Rosenblum Cup.

title: Labor vs. Management
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Typhoid Cases Tied To McDonald's Salad
description: Four women who ate at the same McDonald's restaurant in the Washington suburbs have been diagnosed as having typhoid fever, health officials announced today.

title: Topics; Back in Balance: Code of Conduct
description: Members of the military do not shed their constitutional rights when they put on the uniform. But they do become subject to restrictions consistent with the mission of the armed forces.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A New Greenmarket The list of Greenmarkets operating in New York now includes one on the plaza of the State Office Building at 125th Street on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. This is the 20th addition to the network of open-air markets to which farmers truck their produce, and it has a special mandate - to encourage minority farmers from the Hudson Valley to participate in the program. The market's presence will also make it convenient for Harlem residents and employees working in the State Office Building to buy fresh produce at reasonable prices as at the farmers' markets in other parts of New York. The new Greenmarket will be open every Thursday until Christmas. The schedule may be extended if there is enough demand.

title: WINERY STRIKE SPREADS TO GALLO, LARGEST PRODUCER
description: The five-week strike against California's major wineries spread to the largest producer today as union employees at the E. & J. Gallo Winery walked out this morning, bringing the total number of strikers to over 2,200 and extending the walkout to all 12 members of the Winery Employers Association.

title: Memorial for Webber
description: A memorial service for F. Palmer Webber, a labor and civil rights activist who died Aug. 22 in Rochester, Minn., is to be held at 4 P.M. on Sept. 24 in the Tishman Auditorium of the New York University Law School, 40 Washington Square South in Manhattan. Norman Dorson, a member of the law school faculty and the president of the American Civil Liberties Union, will act as host. Others scheduled to appear include John Henry Faulk, the folklorist and broadcaster; Victor Navasky, the editor of The Nation magazine; Virginia Durr, the southern civil rights activist, and Pete Seeger, the folk singer.

title: New Fannie Mae Chief
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, said yesterday that it had named Frank V. Cahouet president and chief executive. The appointment of Mr. Cahouet, 54 years old, former chief executive of the Crocker National Bank, was expected. He succeeds Mark J. Reidy, who resigned.

title: AQUINO THANKS HER BACKERS IN U.S.
description: Corazon C. Aquino, President of the Philippines, thanked her supporters in the United States today for helping to bring about a ''successful, bloodless revolution'' in her homeland.

title: Sign the Sanctions
description: Now that Congress has overwhelmingly rejected President Reagan's advice and voted significant sanctions against South Africa, the President has three options. He can sign and finally subscribe wholeheartedly to a message made necessary by his failed policy of ''constructive engagement.'' He can let the bill become law without his signature, thereby reaffirming his doubts but letting America register its dismay. Or he can veto and bargain for a watering down, once again winking his tolerance for South Africa's disgraceful white-only regime. A veto could well become the worst decision of Mr. Reagan's Presidency.

title: DOW GAINS 10.96 TO END AT 1,778.54
description: Wall Street turned in a mixed performance yesterday as investors, still stung by the recent sharp drop in stock prices, continued to gravitate toward safer, blue-chip issues.

title: 154 OTHERS MISSING
description: A fire broke out in a South African gold mine today, killing at least 44 miners with toxic gas and leaving 154 men missing underground, according to the mine owners.

title: Conrail Stock Sale Advances
description: The long-stalled sale of Conrail moved forward today when a divided House Energy and Commerce subcommittee passed a bill calling for the sale of the Government-owned railroad in a public stock offering.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, misstated Henry Sheinkopf's relationship to Mr. Friedman. Mr. Sheinkopf is the spokesman for the Bronx Overall Development Corporation, not for Mr. Friedman.

title: EUROPE'S INDUSTRY COOL TO SANCTIONS
description: European industry officials voiced disgruntlement today over sanctions against South Africa but said it remained unclear what economic damage, if any, the measures would inflict in Europe.

title: IN DALLAS, THE GAME OF CHEF RUSTLING
description: As the Dallas Cowboys return to Texas Stadium and Bobby Ewing returns from the dead, celebrity chef stealing, as the other popular spectator sport is called, is in high gear.

title: U.S. News to Publish Edition in Chinese
description: U.S. News & World Report said yesterday that it would publish a Chinese-language version of the newsweekly in conjunction with United Daily News in Taiwan, which will translate the magazine's contents and print the Chinese edition.

title: Carole Baron Ending Tie to St. Martin's Press
description: Carole Baron and St. Martin's Press have called off previously announced plans for Mrs. Baron, formerly the publisher of the Dell Publishing Company, to start a new imprint at St. Martin's. Mrs. Baron joined St. Martin's on Aug. 25 and her departure was announced Monday.

title: BOND MARKET QUIET
description: With wary investors attracted mostly to safer, blue-chip stocks, Wall Street yesterday turned in a mixed performance.

title: DU PONT ENTERS THE G.O.P. RACE FOR PRESIDENT
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign formally began today as Pierre S. du Pont 4th, a former Governor of Delaware, announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination. He called for mandatory drug testing of all teen-agers and work programs to replace welfare.

title: Brazilian Troops Storm Prison to Crush Revolt
description: Hundreds of heavily armed riot troops stormed a penitentiary in southeastern Brazil today, crushing a rebellion that left eleven inmates dead and two seriously wounded, the police said.

title: TOKYO STOCKS IN RECORD FALL AGAIN
description: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted again Tuesday, marking a record decline for the second consecutive day of trading.

title: DEVIL SHIFTS INCLUDE NEW PRACTICE SITE
description: Sixty-eight players have been practicing with the Devils, some in hopes of making the team's fifth National Hockey League season in New Jersey more successful than the previous four, others in hopes just of making the team.

title: Inquiry to Be Dropped In Tamil Refugee Affair
description: The prosecutor investigating the West German ship captain suspected of smuggling 155 Tamil refugees to Canada plans to drop the case within the next few days, a spokesman said today.

title: Back in Balance: Some Bonanza
description: Finding one's name in a bank's advertisement of unclaimed deposits is not quite as happy an event as winning the New York Lottery. Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Frigand of Manhattan recently found the family name in an advertisement of the American Savings Bank. It notified them and a long list of other missing depositors that the sum of at least $150 was waiting for each of them at the bank.

title: John W. Riely Is Dead at 69; Headed Richmond Law Firm
description: John W. Riely, retired chairman of the executive board of the Richmond-based law firm of Hunton & Williams, died after a long illness Sunday at his home in Richmond. He was 69 years old.

title: Tire Tracks
description: Coach Ted Sator insists that he likes his practices to resemble game conditions as closely as possible, but one of the routines faced by the Ranger rookies on their first day at the Rye camp last week resembled no game ever seen in the National Hockey League.

title: Judge Picked in Hunts' Case
description: Federal Banckruptcy Judge Harold C. Abramson has been selected to preside over the bankruptcy proceeding of the Hunt brothers in Dallas. The assignment was done by random selection by the court clerk.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FROM THE REALM OF MORPHEUS. By Steven Millhauser. 370 pages. William Morrow. $17.95.

title: Advertisers' Chairman
description: G.F. (Pete) Tyrrell, vice president of advertising at Johnson & Johnson, has been elected vice chairman of the Association of National Advertisers, replacing Robert F. Lauterborn, who has resigned to assume the James L. Knight Professorship of Advertising at the School of Journalism at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

title: CELEBRATING THE GROWTH OF EXPERT FAMILY HELP
description: ''You're all heroes,'' said Bernice Weissbourd to her audience in the Grand Ballroom of the Palmer House hotel. ''We're all here proclaiming and heralding the advent of a new movement. The nation is talking about us - and we are being heard.''

title: DREXEL'S TIES TO PACIFIC ASSET
description: When Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. realized last week that the restructuring plan it had put together for the Western Union Corporation was likely to be turned down by stock and bond holders, it did not have to go far to find an alternative. In walked Pacific Asset Holdings L.P., a private company controlled by present and former Drexel officials, with $250 million and a proposal to take over control of the ailing telecommunications company.

title: For Mets' Aguilera, Hero Role, of Sorts
description: Rick Aguilera was deep into a postgame analysis when his teammates struck. Ron Darling and Bob Ojeda seemed to appear from nowhere, darting through a crowd of questioners and smearing two papers plates full of shaving cream into Aguilera's face. Finally, a celebration. Aguilera had taken the Mets there, beating the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and ensuring his team of at least a tie for the National League East title. The champagne remained corked, but the Mets did the next best thing: they pelted each other with shaving cream and talcum powder.

title: Pratt Makes Offer For Resorts Stock
description: The Pratt Hotel Corporation said it had offered to buy the 340,783 class B shares of Resorts International Inc. held by the estate of James M. Crosby for an undisclosed price. Mr. Crosby, the founder and chairman of Resorts, died April 10. Under the proposal, Pratt said that if the estate agrees to sell its shares, it would then be prepared to make a tender offer to all class B shareholders at the same price.

title: Shea's Hatches Battened Down
description: In 1969, Bob Mandt recalls, ''nobody ever dreamed what happened would happen.'' What happened, of course, was that the Mets, the butt of baseball jokes since their inception in 1962, clinched the Eastern Division title, captured the National League pennant and won the World Series -all in home games that sent their Shea Stadium followers into increasingly dizzy delirium. The culmination of the craziness came after the final Series victory over Baltimore, when the disoriented fans stormed the diamond by the thousands, scooped up clumps of the infield dirt and outfield grass, and carried them home as souvenirs, leaving the field a cratered wasteland.

title: Avrett Drops Cadillac
description: Avrett Free & Ginsberg said that it had resigned the $2 million Cadillac Tri-State Dealership account yesterday. The agency said the split was ''amicable'' and resulted from its decision to focus on packaged-goods clients.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CAPTAINS AND GENERALS The top officers in New York's commercial world are not generals but captains - captains of industry. Today at the New-York Historical Society, an exhibition titled ''Portraits of Power'' puts on view what amounts to a boardroom retrospective of the city's leaders in business, finance and trade.

title: 'TRIUMPH OF THE WEST,' A&E SERIES
description: ''T HE Triumph of the West,'' a 13-part series that begins on the Arts & Entertainment Network at 9 o'clock tonight, seems to be not so much about triumph as about defeat. The price paid for the ascension of Western civilization, apparently, was decline for everyone else. Credit the BBC series, at least in its opening episode, with being clear about its position.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about single-room-occupancy hotels misidentified the honorary chairman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing. She is Jane Benedict.

title: PACKWOOD MAKES TAX SUGGESTION
description: Senator Bob Packwood suggested today that if lawmakers need to raise additional revenue next year to reduce the Federal budget deficit, they might abolish more deductions and other tax preferences.

title: Down Memory Lane With the Steinways
description: On Sept. 16, 1853, the first American-made Steinway piano was sold to a local purchaser. Yesterday, John and Henry Steinway, great-grandsons of the founder of Steinways, celebrated the 133d anniversary and talked about their family's old and enduring links to Astoria, Queens, and to Steinway's 450 employees.

title: A Way for Hay-Fever Victims to Fight Back
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. WEIGHS CURB ON No. 1 HERBICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is considering whether to impose permanent restrictions on the use of alachlor, the nation's most widely used herbicide, agency officials said today.

title: DEFENSE OPENS ITS ARGUMENTS IN JUDGE'S IMPEACHMENT CASE
description: The prosecution rested today in the first judicial impeachment in half a century, and lawyers defending Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne began mounting testimony designed to show that the judge should not have been convicted of tax evasion in 1984 and should not be removed from office.

title: Back in Balance; School Spirit
description: Public schools in Yonkers, N.Y., have now been desegregated in relative tranquillity. After six years of complex litigation and testy negotiation, the achievement is welcome and much of the credit goes to Federal District Judge Leonard Sand.

title: POLITICS OF SHOREHAM PUSHES SUFFOLK CHIEF INTO RACE FOR JUDGESHIP
description: The Suffolk County Executive said yesterday that he would seek a State Supreme Court nomination, making it likely that the Shoreham nuclear plant - an issue in several Long Island elections - will now be a factor in the unlikely arena of a judicial election.

title: Ad Phobia At Movies Easing Up
description: EUROPEANS have long put up with it, and apparently even enjoy it. But advertising in movie theaters has always raised the hackles of many Americans, who become irritated or worse at the thought of paying up to $6 a head to see commercials along with a film.

title: ORTEGA TO SEE NICARAGUAN PRIMATE ON CHURCH-STATE RIFT ON SEPT. 27
description: The Government, trying to improve its relations with the Roman Catholic Church, announced today that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra will meet with Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo on Sept. 27.

title: SHARP TO SUBTLE: A SEASONING'S MANY FACES
description: As Americans have discovered the intricate richness of international and ethnic cuisines they have ventured outside the safe boundaries of rosemary, basil and thyme for the adventurous world of exotic spices. Yet many cooks are often thwarted by the complexities of these seasonings, generally because they do not know how to release their nuances.

title: BUILDING A GIANT AIRLINE: THE HURDLES FOR LORENZO
description: In seeking Federal approval of its acquisition of People Express Inc., the Texas Air Corporation plans to argue that the Newark-based carrier is in danger of failing, sources close to Texas Air said yesterday.

title: Analysts Stress Careful Buying
description: THE big stock market selloff last week left many investors so distressed that they are in no frame of mind to think about new equity purchases. Yet some analysts are convinced that this is the period for selective buying of stocks that have been battered recently and, now selling at attractive prices, appear to be poised for an upturn.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: GLEAMING BALTIC RESORT
description: This Baltic seaside community, the site of an unusual Soviet-American discussion forum this week, is about as close as the Soviet Union gets to a jet-set resort.

title: Japanese Studying Bond Investments
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry is in the last stages of a study that would allow Japanese banks to increase their holdings of foreign currencies needed for investment in foreign bonds, ministry sources said.

title: MOTION FILED IN A 1972 SUIT ON REHNQUIST
description: A major issue in the Senate debate on the nomination of Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States is whether he acted unethically when he refused to disqualify himself in a 1972 Supreme Court decision on Army surveillance of political groups, and whether he testified deceptively about it in July.

title: Video Show For Shoppers
description: Two Hollywood studios and the Horn & Hardart Company will join the fast-growing video shopping business, forming Value Television to produce a syndicated home shopping show for distribution to commercial stations. The Lorimar-Telepictures

title: CITY DELAYS CLOSING OF BRONX SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: City officials, in a reversal, said yesterday that the shelter for homeless families at Roberto Clemente State Park in the Bronx would remain open for now.

title:
CONTINUE COVERT AID TO ANGOLANS?;
Only If Congress Approves
description: The House of Representatives is expected to vote today on a provision of the Intelligence Authorization Act that would give Congress effective control over United States assistance to the anti-Communist guerrillas fighting the Government of Angola.

title: CAPTORS ISSUE WARNING ON LEBANON HOSTAGES
description: The underground terrorist group that calls itself Islamic Holy War said today that quick action was needed to insure what it called ''a happy ending'' for three American hostages in Lebanon.

title: World Trade Bancorp Stake
description: An investment group including former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon agreed yesterday to acquire a controlling interest in World Trade Bancorp, a California bank holding company.

title: Senate Rejects a House Plan To Limit Abortions in Capital
description: The Senate today rejected sharp restrictions on government payment for abortions in the District of Columbia, despite charges that the city has become ''the abortion capital of the world.''

title: Concepcion Concerned
description: The Big Red Machine is now down to its last three active members in Cincinnati. One of them, Dave Concepcion, the Reds' shortstop since 1970, is the latest player wondering about his future.

title: UNION SUES TO BLOCK REAGAN ORDER ON DRUG TESTS
description: A union representing 120,000 Federal employees sued in Federal District Court today to block President Reagan's executive order that would subject many Federal workers to mandatory drug testing.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
NOT JUST CALORIC
description: NUTS are a little like Ralph Branca, that respectable Brooklyn Dodger pitcher who despite a decent career and many other good points will forever be remembered as the man who served up a home run pitch to Bobby Thomson that gave the Giants the National League pennant in 1951. For all their flavor and textural and nutritional interest, nuts are best known for being fattening. Less than one ounce of roasted cashews (20 to 26 nuts) is 280 calories. An ounce of roasted, salted peanuts is 170 calories. And so on.

title: ASBURY PARK IS BUILDING FOR REVIVAL
description: The booming housing market appears poised to reawaken this blighted seashore city, with $150,000 town houses scheduled to rise near a boardwalk of shuttered shops and lifeless neon.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about impeachment proceedings against Federal Judge Harry E. Claiborne misidentified the President who was impeached in 1868. He was Andrew Johnson, not Andrew Jackson.

title: SUSPECT NAMED IN SLAYING OF 2 AT RESTAURANT
description: A 20-year-old Harlem man who was dismissed from his job at a Manhattan sandwich shop was being sought yesterday in the killing Tuesday of two of the shop's four owners, the police said.

title: Blast Damages Home Of White Supremacy Foe
description: A bomb exploded outside the home of a Roman Catholic priest who has been leading the opposition to white supremacists here, causing serious damage but no injuries, the police said.

title: U.S. Arrests a Witness In Drug Agent's Killing
description: A Mexican police official was arrested today as a material witness in the slaying of an American drug agent in Mexico, the Drug Enforcement Administration said.

title: Why Dismissed Air Controllers Won't Be Rehired
description: To the Editor:

title: STRIKE BRINGS EMERGENCY IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Law-enforcement officials declared a police emergency in Atlantic City last night, calling in all off-duty officers and requesting reinforcements from state police and other units as some 3,000 striking hotel casino workers and vandals roamed the streets, banging on cars, throwing stones and garbage and fighting with the police.

title: MEESE PLAYING CENTRAL ROLE IN DOMESTIC POLICY NOW
description: Who is shaping domestic policy in President Reagan's second term?

title: WESTERN EUROPEAN NATIONS IMPOSE WEAKENED SANCTIONS ON PRETORIA
description: Foreign Ministers of the 12 European Community countries agreed to impose limited new economic sanctions on South Africa today, saying the Pretoria Government had failed to respond to their appeals to dismantle apartheid.

title: Grand Jury to Get Data From Biaggi
description: A Government prosecutor said yesterday that Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx had agreed to turn over to investigators certain office records being sought for a current Federal grand jury inquiry.

title: VIACOM CHIEF LEADS GROUP'S BUYOUT BID
description: Viacom International - the diversified entertainment company that boasts among its holdings MTV Networks, Showtime/The Movie Channel, an array of cable systems serving 840,000 subscribers, and television and radio stations -said yesterday that a group led by its chief executive, Terrence A. Elkes, had offered $2.7 billion to buy the company.

title: Briton Dies in War Games
description: Two Canadian soldiers were injured in a helicopter crash today during North Atlantic Treaty Organization military exercises in Norway, and a British soldier died of injuries suffered in an accident six days ago. A NATO communique said the Canadians were hurt when their helicopter crashed near the city of Tromso. The Briton, whose death was the 11th in a month of exercises, had been unconscious in an Oslo hospital since falling down an embankment.

title: DETAINED CUBANS FAST A 9TH DAY
description: Fifty Cuban refugees yesterday entered the ninth day of a hunger strike to protest their indefinite detention at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service center in Manhattan.

title: Caracas Oil Dispute
description: The Venezuelan Congress has approved a Government plan to end a decade-old tax dispute with more than 30 international oil companies. Court cases brought against the companies for $1.1 billion in back taxes and other charges would be dropped by the Government in return for the oil companies' renunciation of claims to a $400 million deposit they had placed in Venezuela in 1976, according to the plan approved late Monday. The oil companies involved include Shell, Exxon, Texaco, Mobil, Gulf and many smaller concerns.

title: Home Loan Banks Offer $3.089 Billion in Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering $3.089 billion of new bonds to raise cash to finance lending to savings and loan associations, and to repay $1.825 billion of maturing debt.

title: Treasury Prices Are Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed with no large changes in quiet trading yesterday.

title: E.P.A. CRITICIZES PUERTO RICO ON SEWAGE TREATMENT EFFORT
description: The inspector general of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the agency had wasted hundreds of millions of dollars on sewage treatment plants in Puerto Rico.

title: Sikh Extremists Kill Leader Of a Militant Hindu Group
