description: Sikh extremists killed a leader of a militant Hindu organization today, ending a brief lull in separatist violence in the northern Punjab State.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 17, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PLAN FOR TOWER USES AIR RIGHTS OF RAIL STATION
description: A Wall Street investment company has filed plans to build the fourth-tallest building in Manhattan - a 74-story tower that would be a few feet taller than the Chrysler Building - on a Madison Avenue site zoned to accommodate a building less than half the size.

title: U.S. Court Orders Trial In 1973 Indian Uprising
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered a trial to determine whether members of the Nixon Administration illegally used the Army to quell an Indian uprising at the village of Wounded Knee in 1973.

title: ZAKHAROV CHARGES A 'SETUP' BY F.B.I.
description: Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet employee of the United Nations accused of espionage, said today that he was the victim of a setup by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: GYPSY SURVIVORS OF NAZIS HEAR PLEDGE ON AID
description: Gypsies who gathered here to remember family members annihilated in Nazi death camps were told by Representative Tom Lantos today that he would ask Congress to press both East Germany and West Germany to compensate gypsy survivors and their relatives.

title: U.S. WILL EXPLORE A SOVIET PROPOSAL TO CUT WAR RISK
description: In a reversal that may pave the way for the first major arms accord under his Administration, President Reagan has decided to explore a Soviet suggestion on how to verify an agreement for preventing accidental war, Administration officials said today.

title: Potential Danger Seen In Nuclear Plant Seals
description: Safety systems in many of the nation's nuclear power plants might be useless if a high-temperature accident was to damage their heat-sensitive rubber O rings, seals similar to those blamed in the space shuttle disaster, industry critics charged today.

title: KOCH DRAWS CRITICISM FROM TASS AND IZVESTIA
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass and the Government newspaper Izvestia criticized Mayor Koch yesterday for describing the Soviet Government as ''the pits.''

title: London Plans For Trading
description: The London Stock Exchange and a group of international securities dealers confirmed today that they had agreed to form a 24-hour electronic marketplace for stocks in a venture that would compete with other exchanges worldwide.

title: Officials Err on Replay
description: Denver Bronco players say that officials admitted that they had erred in nullifying a 79-yard touchdown pass during their 21-10 victory Monday night over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Kicker Still Critical
description: Gary Bounin, Purdue's freshman kicker, remained in critical condition yesterday in Indianapolis, where he is being treated for a stroke he suffered in his dormitory room at West Lafayette, Ind.

title: HESSEMAN IN 'HEAD OF THE CLASS'
description: HOWARD HESSEMAN has perfected the look of someone who has survived the assorted countercultures of the 1960's with a touch of pride and a hint of resignation to the dreariness of the present. On the former series ''WKRP in Cincinnati,'' his Johnny Fever, the spaced-out disk jockey in dark glasses, was still hung over from the days of Haight-Ashbury and Timothy Leary. In fact, way back then, Mr. Hesseman was a member of San Francisco's Committee, an improvisational theater group, and did indeed spin records, as the phrase went, on an underground rock station.

title: Israeli Officials to Investigate Rights Unit's Torture Report
description: Israeli Justice Ministry officials said today that they were investigating charges by Amnesty International that Israeli security forces had tortured Palestinian prisoners.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: TED BUNDY and I go back a long way, to a time when there was a series of unsolved murders in Washington State known only as the Ted murders. Like a lot of reporters, I'm something of a crime buff. But the Washington Ted murders - and the ones that followed in Utah, Colorado and finally in Florida, where Ted Bundy was convicted and sentenced to die - fascinated me because I could see myself as one of the victims. I looked at the studio photographs of young women with long hair, pierced ears, easy smiles, and I read the descriptions: polite, friendly, quick to help, eager to please. I thought about being approached by a handsome young man asking for help, and I knew if I had been in the wrong place at the wrong time I would have been a goner.

title: YOUNG GERMANS HEAR THE SANDINISTAS' DRUMMER
description: Four days before Christmas in 1983, an Aeroflot jet lifted off from Luxembourg carrying 150 young West Germans to Nicaragua to support the Sandinista revolution.

title: Turkish Measures Force Detour in Drug Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Major Changes Can Improve Filipino Life
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY IN DAKOTA ACTS TO IMPROVE ODDS FOR GAMBLING
description: A garish sign over a building startles many visitors entering the northwestern side of this city. ''Monte Carlo Casino,'' it says.

title: IRAQ REPORTS HEAVY RAID ON IRANIAN OIL TERMINAL
description: Iraq said today that its fighter-bombers struck an Iranian oil terminal in the northern end of the Persian Gulf three times in 45 minutes, inflicting damage on jetties and on antiaircraft defenses.

title: FROM SEA AND JUNGLE, FANCIES FOR THE SEASON
description: 1.Playing Sailor For the sailor who is daunted by the prospect of a long, cold winter ashore, help has arrived. It is the Sailor's Game by Sparkman & Stephens, the naval architects whose designs have included many America's Cup yachts. This board game takes players on a yacht race round the world. It comes with 360 game cards, each with six questions on topics such as basic and advanced seamanship, boating equipment, navigation and marine trivia. Each player ''sails'' with a two-inch-tall pewter yacht that resembles a Sparkman & Stephens design. The Sailor's Game costs $40. To order, call 800-835-2246, extension 61, or write to Sailor's Game, Box 20382 Cherokee Station, New York, N.Y. 10028 (add $2 for postage and handling). Or look for it at the South Street Seaport Museum, 209 Water Street, between Fulton and Beekman Streets. 2.Jungle Fashions Animal prints are rampant for fall. Here are jungle-inspired earrings covered with pony fur that has been printed to look like cheetah. The earrings, for pierced ears, are circled with rhinestones and have long tassles. For $55 at Savage, 267A Columbus Avenue, at 72d Street, and 59 West 8th Street. 3.Decorative Cards Here are decorative greeting cards for the Jewish New Year, which begins at sundown Oct. 3. They were printed in Israel and have a variety of colorful cover designs copied from paintings and old prayer books. Inside, the message is ''Best wishes for the New Year.'' They are available for $1.25 each at the Great Judaica Bookstore and Art Gallery, 56 East 11th Street, which also has a large selection of illustrated Jewish calendars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1986
description: Markets

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP IN AUGUST
description: Industrial output rose one-tenth of 1 percent in August as a moderate gain in manufacturing was largely offset by sharp declines for the nation's mines and utilities.

title: 22 Military Men Held In the Aquino Killing
description: Twenty military officers and enlisted men voluntarily surrendered today, officials said, as prosecutors reopened an investigation into the slaying in 1983 of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Mr. Aquino was the husband of President Corazon C. Aquino, who has blamed former President Ferdinand E. Marcos for the killing.

title: Accounts
description: * ITT Defense Space Group to Poppe Tyson for its Avionics and Gallium Arsenide Technology Center divisions.

title: EXPERTS ASSESS IMPACT OF TERRORISM SURGE
description: The State Department's new chief of counterterrorism held out only moderate hope today that the surge of terrorist attacks around the world in recent weeks would generate more international cooperation.

title: Officer Said to Steal From Crack Dealers
description: A suspended police officer, already charged with robbing a customer at a Bronx crack-buying site last April, has been indicted on charges of robbing three crack dealers in Manhattan, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Jury Selected In Gotti Trial
description: After 18 days of jury selection over a four-week period, a 12-member panel was selected yesterday for the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants.

title: I Spell It R-i-g-h-e-t-t-i
description: Dave Righetti, whose reassignment from the rotation to the bullpen caused an uproar in 1984, has since been more effective than any other major league reliever, by at least one gauge. According to the method that Rolaids uses to determine its annual Relief Man Award - 2 points for a victory, 2 for a save, minus 1 for a loss - these have been the best men out of the pen the last three seasons:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chad Peterson, a starting tight end for Northeast Louisiana University, has been dismissed from the team after his arrest on cocaine-distribution charges. . . . Lloyd Moore was dropped from the Rutgers basketball team because of his failure to conquer a continuing weight problem, the coach, Craig Littlepage, said yesterday. The 6-foot-9 center was listed in the media guide as weighing 280 pounds, but it is belived that Moore weighed more than that.

title: People's Employees Fear Loss of Status
description: For the 3,400 employees who run People Express Airlines Inc., the merger of the airline into the Texas Air Corporation could bring an end to the freedom and flexibility they enjoy under the carrier's employee-management system.

title: 'No More Minute' With the Mayor
description: Mayor Koch of New York is properly angry at the Soviet Government for equating its spying with American journalism. He's also upset that other Americans are not sufficiently angry at the Kremlin for additional reasons.

title: WEICKER IS FIRST G.O.P. SENATOR TO OPPOSE REHNQUIST NOMINATION
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today became the first Republican to oppose the confirmation of William H. Rehnquist as Chief Justice of the United States.

title: U.S. Troops Extending Drug Mission in Bolivia
description: A team of United States troops and helicopters is extending its anti-drug mission in Bolivia, where the special detachment has been taking part in a cocaine eradication drive since mid-July, the Pentagon reported today.

title: People
description: * Larry Vine has been appointed senior vice president, creative director at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: South Korea Closes 3 More Universities
description: The Government closed three universities in Seoul today, bringing to five the number of schools ordered to shut down during the 16-day Asian Games, which are to open here this weekend. Officials said more closings were possible.

title: Luring the Convention
description: New York City, which had been a more or less casual competitor for the 1988 Democratic National Convention, has decided to move into a full-court press to persuade the party's site selection committee to choose the Big Apple for the third time in four Presidential years.

title: California's Catholic Bishops Attack AIDS Ballot Proposal
description: California's 20 Roman Catholic bishops say a voter-initiated referendum that would impose controls on AIDS victims is an attack on civil rights that also threatens development of a cure for the fatal disease.

title: SAFFRON AND CURRY (AND EVERYTHING NICE)
description: FOR the average cook, a pinch of spice goes a long way. And although Americans may be using a wider range of spices and herbs than ever, they shouldn't be stockpiled like so many sale cans of imported tomatoes.

title: Yan Bratushchik Married To Riva Howard, Banker
description: The marriage of Riva Lynn Howard, a vice president of the Standard Chartered Bank in Manhattan, and Yan Bratushchik, an independent antiques dealer in Forest Hills, Queens, took place yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, assisted by Cantor Moshe Geffen, performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Howard of New York.

title: ONE COOK'S PERSONAL FAVORITES
description: ''A T one time or another, I use every one of the 80 or so spices in my bursting cupboard,'' says Madhur Jaffrey. ''Here are six that, after ingratiating themselves shamelessly by their amiability and adaptability, have found a hallowed permanent spot in a very accessible front row.''

title: PHILADELPHIA TO BE FOCUS ON CONSTITUTION EVENTS
description: To fife and drum, to 1930's swing played by ''Pershing's Own'' Army dance band, to the blandishments of Carol Channing and Mary Martin, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger tonight opened the first major exhibit of Philadelphia's celebration of the Constitution's 200th anniversary.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE ORIOLES VS. YANKEES, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) BRAVES VS. LOS ANGELES DODGERS, at Atlanta, 7:40 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. TENNIS: New York Stae Men's Championships, The Canyon Club, Armonk, N.Y. 2P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M., tape) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight, tape)

title: U.S. TO RELAX POLICY FOR ENTRY OF CUBAN DISSIDENTS
description: In a policy decision that emerged over the summer and was given greater impetus by the release of Cuban political prisoners Monday, the United States Government will ease the way for more long-term political prisoners to come to this country, a high State Department official said today.

title: Judge Bars Referendum On Chicago Elections
description: Mayor Harold Washington's re-election hopes got an apparent lift today when a judge barred from the Nov. 4 ballot a referendum that proposed changing the way the city elects its mayor.

title: Kick in the Head
description: Joe Cooper, the Giants' place-kicker, recalls being let go last year by Hugh Campbell, then the coach at Houston: ''He came up to me and said: 'I have good news and bad news for you. The bad news is you've been cut. The good news is we've gotten someone just as good as you.' ''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we can require vaccinations before kids go to school, we can require drug testing while they're in school.'' - Pierre S. du Pont 4th, announcing his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination. [ B10:1. ]

title: Addenda
description: * D.L. Blair Corporation will acquire Promotion and Merchandising in Atlanta.

title: ANALYZING GARLIC'S FIVE PERSONALITIES
description: HOME and professional cooks are using garlic more than ever, perhaps because of a renewed interest in Provencal food. Garlic, a member of the lily family, is indeed the mortar that binds the cuisine of southern France, indispensable in many soups, stews, roasts and sauces. In the hands of an experienced cook, garlic can be the most versatile and provocative of herbs; in the wrong hands, it is akin to a loaded gun.

title: Dynamics, U.S. Set Deal on Jets
description: The Air Force and the General Dynamics Corporation, after months of negotiation, have agreed on a second multiyear contract for F-16 jet fighters totaling $4.3 billion. The contract, announced late

title: CHEF AND SCULPTOR CREATE EDIBLE ART
description: JIM PETERSON said he was a bit skeptical when approached about taking part in the ''Artists and Cuisine'' dinner series at the French Culinary Institute in Soho.

title: IN THE GREAT SELTZER WAR, FIZZES WITH A FLAVOR
description: SELTZER isn't just seltzer anymore.

title: PERES DOUBTS SOVIET IS READY FOR ISRAELI TIES
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel expressed doubt today that the Soviet Union was close to restoring diplomatic relations with his country and repeated his longstanding position that such ties were a prerequisite to accepting Moscow as a participant in any Middle East peace conference.

title: MUSIC: ITZHAK PERLMAN WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: IF there is such a thing as a push-button concert program, Zubin Mehta conducted it last evening as the New York Philharmonic opened its 1986-87 season at Avery Fisher Hall. The benefit event, a traditional prelude to the first subscription concert, looked like a sure-fire success on paper and turned out exactly that way. Mr. Mehta, never a daredevil program planner, played this one very close to the vest. His soloist for the night was Itzhak Perlman, the world's most popular violinist - perhaps the best, too - playing three of the fiddling literature's most popular items: Ravel's ''Tzigane,'' Chausson's ''Poeme'' and Sarasate's ''Carmen'' Fantasy. If you have ever heard the prodigiously gifted Mr. Perlman make these virtuoso pieces sit up and speak, you probably can guess how much enthusiasm he stirred from this audience.

title: Chile Lifts Its Ban On Reports by Reuters
description: The military Government lifted an order today preventing Reuters from filing news and information from its Santiago bureau.

title: 2-Continent Hearing
description: For what is believed to be the first time in history, members of a Congressional committee will sit in a Capitol Hill hearing room today and hear live testimony from a group of Nigerian officials in Lagos, questioning them over an international satellite hookup provided by the United States Information Agency.

title: PARIS OFFERS REWARD IN TERROR INQUIRY
description: The Government offered a $150,000 reward tonight for information leading to the arrest of two brothers of a Lebanese prisoner in France or the apprehension of anyone responsible for the recent wave of bombings here.

title: O'ROURKE FINDS TEPID SUPPORT IN WASHINGTON
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, was in town today. He was lugging around the stand-up cardboard facsimile of Mario Cuomo that co-stars in his campaign commercials, a symbol of what the Westchester County Executive says is the Governor's refusal to debate him.

title: MATTINGLY DRIVES IN 3, PASSING 100
description: If he were in show business, his press agent would bill him as Mattingly the Magnificent or Mattingly the Magician. Lou Piniella, the Yankees' manager, doesn't care what anyone calls him, as long as they call him when it's his turn to bat.

title: Texas Health Aides Confirm 11 Sleeping Sickness Cases
description: Eleven cases of potentially lethal St. Louis encephalitis have been confirmed, Harris County health officials said Monday.

title: Greek Quake Toll at 20
description: Officials said today that a 65-year-old woman had died of injuries suffered in an earthquake three days ago, bringing the toll to 20. Rescue workers continued to clear rubble and inspect buildings. Authorities said 117 quake victims remained hospitalized.

title: Design Engineers Show Brash New Ideas
description: The design engineers have produced a plethora of brash new ideas on display at the National Design Engineering Conference, which opened yesterday morning and closes tomorrow afternoon at the Javits Center.

title: WINE TALK
description: LAST week, this space was given over to a selection of good red wines selling for $10 or less.

title: Gunman in Pakistan Slays a Soviet Attache
description: A gunman killed a Soviet military attache here today as the diplomat's wife and 11-year-old daughter watched. Officials said the assailant had a history of mental illness.

title: The Misjudged Judge
description: All discussion of William Rehnquist, Chief-Justice-to-be, starts with a bow to his ''brilliance.'' Even his most vigorous opponents are unable to start flailing away without first remarking that he is ''brilliant'' or conceding that his ''brilliance'' is undeniable.

title: MEL ARRIGHI, 52, PLAYWRIGHT
description: Mel Arrighi, a playwright and novelist, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: Yes: To Help Promote Peace
description: The House will make a serious mistake if it votes today to ban covert United States aid to the Angolan freedom fighters led by Jonas Savimbi. Such a ban would jeopardize our ability to restore peace to Angola, where Communist troops from around the world are fighting viciously to keep a Marxist Government in power.

title: Reebok in Accord to Buy Shoemaker
description: Reebok International Ltd., an athletic footwear maker known for its sneakers, took a step yesterday toward widening its markets by agreeing to acquire the Rockport Company for $118.5 million.

title: Getting to Roosevelt I.
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 'PLAN OF ACTION' ON DANILOFF Secretary of State George P. Shultz said a 'plan of action' was ready if the Soviet Union did not let an Amer-ican reporter leave soon.

title: The Well-Kept Artichoke
description: STEAMED artichoke hearts make a delightful - and slightly unusual - seasonal side dish, served with a drizzle of lemon juice and butter, or a hollandaise sauce.

title: An Unsung Live-Aid Challenge
description: It isn't a multimedia event, and there aren't any rock singers to rouse the troops. But a parliamentary struggle in Congress may determine how many children in the poorest nations will be saved next year from their most insidious enemies: measles, tetanus, whooping cough, polio, diphtheria and tuberculosis.

title: 35 Soviet Regional Officials Dismissed in Last Two Years
description: Thirty-five officials in the Soviet region of Volgograd have been dismissed in the last two years for corruption and other offenses, the regional Communist Party leader says.

title: TRYING TO FIND AN ENDING
description: As the moon was waxing gibbous, and the reporters were waxing eloquent and the nasty Cardinals were waxing their mustaches, the Mets finally got in their whacks, too.

title: MURDER IN THE PARK, PITCHES ON THE PHONE
description: The calls are pouring in now to Jack Litman, the attorney for Robert E. Chambers Jr., who is charged with the torrentially publicized murder of Jennifer Dawn Levin. ''This is great,'' the callers say. ''Just great.''

title: Angola Says Its Troops Killed 230 Rebels in Northern Area
description: Angolan Government troops killed 230 rebels and captured 15 in recent operations in Angola's two northern provinces of Uige and Zaire, the official Angolan news agency, Angop, said today.

title: REAGAN THREATENS VETO OF SPENDING BILLS FOR 1987
description: President Reagan will veto the spending bills the House and the Senate are now considering unless there are major changes, White House aides said today.

title: Money Talks
description: Jim Finks, general manager of the Saints (winners over Green Bay last weekend), sharing the dais at the New Orleans Quarterback Club with Chancellor James Wharton of L.S.U. (winner over Texas A&M) and Coach Mack Brown of Tulane (loser to Texas Christian): ''What this weekend shows is that we're the second-best team in the state of Louisiana.

title: THE ARTISTRY OF EARLY HANK WILLIAMS
description: HANK WILLIAMS would be celebrating his 63d birthday if he were alive today.

title: KASPAROV FEROCIOUS IN 16TH GAME
description: Gary Kasparov's ferociously complicated attacking play in the 16th game of the world chess championship match sent Anatoly Karpov down to defeat Monday in Leningrad.

title: First Chicago Ratings Raised
description: The First Chicago Corporation's debt ratings were raised slightly, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI IS MAIN EVENT AT GARDEN
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI swaggered onto the stage of Madison Square Garden last night like a conquering heavyweight, arms lifted high above his head, a 360-degree grin on his face. Television cameras whirred and diamonds flashed in the massive auditorium, which was more than half full. This was, by any standards, a major event - an event, however, that had very little to do with music.

title: JORDAN DISMISSES EGYPT TALKS
description: Jordanian officials today dismissed the results of the meeting in Alexandria, Egypt, last week between Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt as unlikely to make any breakthrough in reviving Middle East peace efforts.

title: VIEW OF 1930's PREJUDICE
description: The Mexican children were so deficient in English in 1930's California that their ''Anglo'' classmates were being taught at a slower rate. They caused health and sanitation problems, said school officials, and they came from homes where ignorance and poverty prevailed. Against that backdrop of cultural chauvinism the Lemon Grove School District in California secretly established a separate school for students of Mexican ancestry in the hope of ''Americanizing'' them. The segregation, a harbinger of other attempts in the Southwest to bar Mexican students from interacting with Anglo students, came despite the fact that most of them had been born in the United States and many spoke no Spanish.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Twistee Treat
description: The Twistee Treat Corporation said it had agreed with Metro Treat Inc. to develop up to 400 new Twistee Treat stores in the New York metropolitan area. Twistee Treat said it would receive $1 million as a nonrefundable performance deposit and 30 stores must be opened in the first year, followed by 50 a year for the next seven years in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Twistee Treat is an operator and franchiser of ice cream stores in Florida.

title: House Bank Bills Pushed
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee today announced a new strategy for passing banking legislation that has been stalled for months.

title: KEY RATES
How You Play the Game Still Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY CRACKS DOWN ON TAX CHEATS WHO CALL THEIR 2d HOUSES HOME
description: A judge, a television personality, corporate executives and government employees are among 145 New York City residents caught evading the city income tax by falsely claiming resort homes on Long Island as their primary residences, the authorities said yesterday.

title: 2 in Broadcast Industry Set to Buy TV Station
description: Lewis H. Erlicht and Robert M. Bennett are poised to buy television stations at what they believe is exactly the right time.

title: Hill, Holiday Wins Oppenheimer Account
description: Hill, Holiday, New York has won the $6 million Oppenheimer Fund account after a competition, which included the Omnicon group. A print and television umbrella campaign for the 19 mutual funds is to begin by the end of the year.

title: TAMPERING UNCOVERED AT AIDS RESEARCH LAB
description: Investigators at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta have found evidence that on at least five occasions in recent months research on the causes of AIDS and other viral diseases there may have been deliberately ruined, according to top scientists at the centers.

title: NEW PANEL GRADING FAT CONTENT OF MEAT
description: THE establishment of the Nutritional Effects Foundation was formally announced in Washington on Monday. The creation of the three-month-old nonprofit private research and education organization, set up to promote production of lean meat raised with a minimum of drugs and chemicals, marks a change in the meat industry's attitude toward consumer demands for a leaner, safer product.

title: OLD TECHNOLOGY BUT NOT YET OBSOLETE
description: In the 1960's they said that old Whites Ferry was already an anachronism, a rustic one-boat line across the Potomac that would not survive the suburbanization that was bound to be spread by a new highway around the outer edges of the capital, complete with a fancy bridge across the river.

title: Montana on the Mend
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback, who underwent back surgery Monday, was moved from the surgical intensive care unit to a regular hospital room yesterday to begin his convalesence.

title: FRIENDS HELP THEATER FOR NEW CITY TO MOVE
description: The Theater for the New City, known for its experimental works and its outdoor spectaculars, took to the streets again yesterday, but this time it wasn't a performance.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Monday about the marriage of Stefanie Richelle Bradley and Jeffrey Adam Meer misstated the location. The ceremony took place in the Finch Chapel at Greensboro College in Greensboro, N.C.

title: SHULTZ PROMISES U.S. ACTION IN THE DANILOFF AFFAIR
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had a ''plan of action'' against the Soviet Union that would be carried out if an American reporter confined to Moscow on espionage charges was not allowed to return to the United States soon.

title: Polaris Aircraft
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, said it intends to acquire 80 percent of the Polaris Aircraft Leasing Corporation, one of the nation's largest independent aircraft leasing companies. G.E. Credit said the acquisition of privately owned Polaris, which manages a $760 million portfolio of commercial jets leased to 15 airlines, would permit G.E. to enter the aircraft leasing business. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Burroughs-Sperry Deal Completed
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it had completed its $4.78 billion purchase of the Sperry Corporation with approval of the transaction by Sperry shareholders and the filing of legal documents.

title: MURRAY HAMILTON, A CHARACTER ACTOR FOR OVER 40 YEARS
description: Murray Hamilton, an actor who appeared in the made-for-television movie ''The Last Days of Patton,'' which was broadcast Sunday, died of lung cancer Sept. 1 at Beaufort County Hospital in Washington, N.C. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: India Rejects Trade Plan
description: The head of India's delegation to the global trade conference here, Finance Minister Vishwanath Pratap Singh, rejected today the demand by the developed countries that trade in services be included in a new bid to liberalize trade. He said such a move would give more business to multinational companies.

title: RED SOX TAKE PAIR; CLEMENS WINS 23D
description: Dwight Evans scored twice in a six-run eighth inning, including the tie-breaker on an error by a rookie shortstop, Edgar Diaz, as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 9-3, tonight for a sweep of a doubleheader.

title: 'FIGHTING TERRORISM'
description: HOW would the United States respond to a nuclear attack staged by terrorists?

title: JOSEPH KENNEDY WINS IN PRIMARY FOR SEAT HIS UNCLE ONCE OCCUPIED
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d won a sweeping victory in the Democratic primary today for the Congressional seat being vacated by Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House.

title: Daniloff T-Shirts
description: Colleagues and allies of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the reporter charged with espionage in Moscow, are expressing their support for him with T-shirts. A group of editors and writers at U.S. News & World Report ordered several hundred shirts, white with a blue logo of the magazine and blue letters reading ''Free Nick Daniloff.'' They are being sold for $8 each at the magazine's offices at 2400 N Street N.W. and a sales outpost in the office of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in the Russell Senate Office Building.

title: ESTROGEN PROVIDED IN NEW SKIN PATCH
description: MILLIONS of American women who are taking estrogen orally for hot flashes, sleep disorders, mood swings and other symptoms of menopause will be offered an alternative treatment by their doctors - an estrogen skin patch.

title: Crisis Simulation
description: An American plane carrying 126 passengers and a dangerous radioactive cargo has been hijacked by terrorists who object to United States policy in the Middle East, It sits on the runway at a NATO airfield in Sicily. What are the options for the United States to avoid an international nuclear clash?

title: LUGAR SAYS HE'D LEAD FIGHT TO OVERRIDE SANCTIONS VETO
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, warned key White House officials tonight that he would lead efforts to override any veto of legislation imposing additional sanctions against South Africa, a Congressional official said.

title: 'ME AND MY GIRL' CO-STAR IN HER OWN ROLE, AT LAST
description: Sleek and gleaming, the lone shoe is prominently displayed on a shelf in Maryann Plunkett's dressing room. An opening-night present from a fellow cast member, it is black patent leather, not Cinderella's glass slipper. But it might as well be.

title: Executive Moving To Hong Kong Job
description: Myron E. Ullman, an American department store executive in Dallas, has been named chief operating officer for a huge Hong Kong enterprise encompassing hotels, a department store, property, manufacturing, and warehouses and terminals.

title: Armstrong Rubber
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company said it had agreed to buy several automotive and industrial units of the Dayco Corporation for $185 million in cash.

title: 10 CHARGED IN COLLAPSE OF E.S.M.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Ohio financier Marvin L. Warner, nine other individuals and a Florida savings and loan association with fraud and other violations in the collapse last year of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IMMUNIZATION programs are typically directed toward children. Except for those who travel to countries that warrant vaccine protection, most adults consider ''shots'' and lollipops a thing of their past.

title: U.S. LITERACY CAMPAIGN
description: ''A CHANCE to Learn'' is earnest and sometimes it is unashamedly touching. At least 20 million people in the United States, it says, are functionally illiterate. What can be done to assist them? A number of things, the program says, and shows us, sympathetically, some of the people who are being helped. The message is that there is no moral stigma attached to illiteracy. The people we see look very much like everyone else.

title: Spaniard Turns Reporter
description: A former Spanish Communist Party leader, Santiago Carrillo, who lost his seat in Parliament last June, was accredited to Parliament today as a journalist for the popular magazine Interviu. A spokesman for the party said Mr. Carrillo, 71 years old, would also write for the Communist Party magazine Ahora. Mr. Carrillo was expelled from the party he led for 22 years after its election setback in 1982.

title: Trade Deficit at Quarterly Record
description: The deficit in the nation's broadest measure of foreign trade hit a record $34.7 billion during the April-June quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Clumsy Soviet Antics
description: Officials here are still concerned about the arrest of Nicholas Daniloff, not because of its sneaky trickery but because of its clumsy stupidity.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Hurricane Grows Weaker
description: A slowly weakening Hurricane Earl threatened shipping lanes today with winds of 85 miles an hour as it moved slowly over the Atlantic Ocean, meteorologists said. They said the hurricane, the fifth named storm of the 1986 Atlantic hurricane season, was about 985 miles east-southeast of Bermuda and would move east-southeast before turning northeast and dying later in the week.

title: HARRIMAN IS HONORED AS A PATRIOT AND MENTOR AT MEMORIAL SERVICE
description: Official Washington, which W. Averell Harriman served for four decades, remembered him today as a patriot, mentor and friend at a memorial service at the Washington Cathedral.

title: TENNIS BOOMS IN JAPAN, BUT LIKE NOWHERE ELSE
description: In the class for tennis beginners the students do not seek the net. The net is the place for aggressive play. And in the Japanese definition of tennis, that will not do. Easy ground strokes are better. Easy ground strokes with good form are best of all.

title: DOUR AND FESTIVE, THE U.N. SESSION STARTS
description: The festive atmosphere outside the United Nations today, where various groups staged a peace walk, a peace run and a minute of prayer for peace, contrasted sharply with the mood inside, where the opening of the three-month General Assembly session was dominated by talk of how to keep the organization solvent.

title: NEGOTIATIONS REPORTED ON DEAL FOR ALLEGHENY
description: Willard F. Rockwell Jr., the 72-year-old former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, said yesterday that he was part of an investor group attempting to buy Allegheny International Inc., maker of Sunbeam and Oster electrical appliances, for about $500 million in cash, or $25 a share.

title: CITY TO SEEK TEACHER-PAY AID
description: The Board of Education and Mayor Koch, in a reversal, have said they will seek $31 million offered by the state to increase salaries for New York City public school teachers.

title: Moffett Plans a Role As a TV Newscaster
description: Former Representative Toby Moffett, who ran unsuccessfully against Gov. William A. O'Neill for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, is becoming an anchor on the evening news here.

title: Alcan Aluminium
description: The state-owned pension fund for the province of Quebec, Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, said it had reduced its stake in Alcan Aluminium Ltd. to 6.7 percent, or 6.76 million shares, from 7.3 percent.

title: MOST CUBAN PRISONERS FOUGHT CASTRO, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Most of the Cuban prisoners released to the United States were members of the Cuban armed forces under President Fulgencio Batista and fought against Fidel Castro's revolutionary forces, the American official who interviewed them said today.

title: ONCE AGAIN, 1966 WORK IS BOOK CLUB'S SELECTION
description: A book published 20 years ago, and chosen as the December 1966 main selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club, again has been chosen as a main selection of the club - this time for November 1986.

title: DANILOFF AND THE SUMMIT: A NEW TEST FOR REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration is entangled in what could become its most protracted and complicated foreign policy test, and the view is widespread here among political leaders, policy experts and even Administration officials that the Reagan team may have put itself into a no-win situation. No matter which way

title: Brazil Importing Coffee
description: There used to be an awful lot of coffee in Brazil, but this year things have changed. The nation's trade and industry minister has confirmed that supplies are so short the world's biggest coffee producer must import beans. Brazil has been buying coffee to stabilize its own internal market and to allow export commitments to be met, the minister said.

title: UNIVERSAL PICTURES AIDE RESIGNS UNDER PRESSURE
description: A long-simmering battle between two top executives at Universal Pictures has ended with the resignation under pressure of Frank Price, chairman of Universal's movie division.

title: 6 Women Honored
description: Six athletes including Flo Hyman, the Olympic volleyball star who died this year, have been named to the Women's Sports Hall of Fame, according to the Women's Sports Foundation president, Carol Mann.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Thomas C. Fogarty, 82, Dies; Ex-Chief of Continental Can
description: Thomas C. Fogarty, a retired chief executive officer and a former chairman of the board of directors of the Continental Can Company, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: CITY INCENTIVES LURE INDUSTRY TO BRONX DEVELOPMENT
description: Reuben Mattus, the creator of Haagen-Dazs ice cream, started selling his mother's homemade cold confections to local candy stores in the South Bronx in the 1930's. His various ice cream companies have maintained a presence in the borough ever since.

title: STATES' AIDS DISCRIMINATION LAWS REJECT JUSTICE DEPARTMENT'S STAND
description: A majority of states, rejecting the approach of the Justice Department, have adopted policies prohibiting discrimination against people with AIDS.

title: Jury Gets Pepitone Case
description: A Brooklyn jury deliberated for about seven hours without reaching a verdict yesterday in the case involving drugs and weapons charges against Joe Pepitone and two other men.

title: SOME SCHOOL DRUG EFFORTS FAULTED
description: As the Federal Government urges schools across the country to adopt drug education programs from kindergarten through high school, many social scientists say that so far, few programs have worked.

title: 'Torch of Peace' Begins Its Journey
description: Diplomats, entertainers, and hundreds of children gathered in the garden of the United Nations yesterday to observe an International Day of Peace and to send a ''torch of peace'' on an 86-day global journey.

title: DETECTIVES TELL OF CONTRACT-KILLING CONFESSION
description: The youth accused of carrying out a contract killing of a Long Island man was in police custody for more than four hours during which he confessed and led police to the spot where he said he disposed of the murder weapon, detectives testified today in pretrial hearings.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I arrived in this country 47 years ago, the few kinds of pasta familiar to Americans were spaghetti, lasagna and macaroni (always with cheese, which I always assumed was an American invention). No longer. The numbers of pastas people cook with here have grown with the ranks of passionate pasta lovers.

title: More Stability In Postwar Era
description: LAST WEEK'S hurricane on Wall Street battered confidence about the economic outlook. Inevitably many people were asking, ''Is this another 1929?''

title: Ideal Fish for Young Anglers
description: If you have been planning to take a child fishing but haven't gotten around to it, September and most of October are prime months for snapper, or baby bluefish, from Cape Cod to New Jersey.

title: Greyhound Plans Stock Buyback
description: The Greyhound Corporation, the operator of the nation's largest intercity bus system, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 6 million shares, or more than 13 percent of the company's outstanding stock. The Phoenix-based company, which also owns consumer product companies and makes intercity buses, said it would be in and out of the market and would make purchases periodically ''when market conditions made it desirable to do so.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * BEI Holdings Ltd., Atlanta, a professional services firm serving financial institutions, has named Bruce W. Schnitzer vice chairman.

title: MATTHEW BESDINE
description: Matthew Besdine, a psychoanalyst and clinical professor emeritus of psychology at Adelphi University, died Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1986
description: International

title: BLASTS LINKED TO FRENCH FOREIGN ROLE
description: French officials increasingly view the devastating bomb attacks this month as the work of terrorists sponsored by groups trying to reduce or end France's role in the Middle East.

title: STRESS FRACTURES TO BE STUDIED
description: Thirty percent of the players in the National Basketball Association have suffered, or will suffer, stress fractures of the foot or lower leg.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $277,000 and $742,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and the quarter includes an extraordinary charge of $91,300. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: PRISM ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRUSSELS RESTORES ITS MASTERPIECES OF ART NOUVEAU
description: AFTER nearly three decades of neglect and abuse, Art Nouveau architecture in Brussels -one of the style's capitals - is undergoing a renaissance.

title: STUDY TIES STROKES TO SMOKING
description: Cigarette smokers are two to three times more likely than nonsmokers to suffer strokes but can reduce that risk by more than half by dropping the habit, Government researchers said today.

title: Lease Unit Sale By Greyhound
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Greyhound Capital Corporation, a computer-leasing concern owned by the Greyhound Corporation, for $140 million.

title: Robert L. Hallock, Inventor Of Disposable Vacuum Bag
description: Robert Lay Hallock, an inventor of household and industrial equipment, died Sept. 2 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 88 years old and lived in Needham, Mass.

title: Home-Field Edge
description: Manager Chuck Tanner, after his Braves beat the Dodgers with a bad-hop single on the football-scarred field of Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium: ''Bill Fralic has won three games this year, and the Falcons are only 2-0.''

title: Temporary Embassy
description: A coalition of environmental organizations, the Tropical Forest Action Group, was surprised to discover that its intention to picket the forthcoming annual meeting of the World Bank had been thwarted by the designation of the bank's headquarters and an uptown hotel as temporary foreign diplomatic missions.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CROSSING THE LINE: A Year in the Land of Apartheid. By William Finnegan. Illustrated with maps. 418 pages. Harper & Row. $22.95. EARLY in 1980, a young Californian named William Finnegan made his way from Sri Lanka to Cape Town, partly to escape the tropical rigors of traveling in South Asia and partly to pursue the surf and pizza parlors of a comparatively developed country. Intending to set out on a journey over the fabled ''Cape to Cairo'' route through East Africa, Mr. Finnegan found himself low on money and managed to finagle himself a job teaching in a high school for ''colored'' students on the Cape Flats outside Cape Town.

title: At Least Two Investors Report Stakes in Viacom
description: Several investors reported large stakes in Viacom International yesterday, a development that may impede a $2.7 billion buyout bid from a group led by the senior management of the diversified entertainment and communications concern.

title: BROADWAY GUIDE DUE IN DECEMBER
description: A new guide to what is happening on Broadway is to be published by the League of American Theaters and Producers, the league announced yesterday.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Accounts
description: * Department of the Treasury to Henry J. Kaufman & Associates, Washington, D.C., for U.S. Savings Bonds.

title: Navy Man Held in Shootings
description: A 30-year-old seaman has been charged with assault with a deadly weapon in the shooting of three Navy instructors, one fatally, at the Great Lakes Naval Training Center, officials say. The authorities said Tuesday that the charges will enable the Navy to hold the seaman, Arif M. Ameen, of Miami, for 90 days for investigation of the shootings. A senior electronics technician was killed and two chief technicians were injured in the shooting Monday.

title: VNU Adds Newspaper Researcher
description: VNU AMVEST, the American subsidiary of the largest publishing company in the Netherlands, has quietly assembled an impressive stable of marketing and media information companies in this country. Yesterday it added to those holdings by agreeing to acquire Scarborough Research, the newspaper research concern.

title: A Designer's Flair For the Natural
description: TO New Yorkers, he is known for his interior for Charivari 57, the clothing store. But for the first time, Shigeru Uchida, the 43-year-old head of Studio 80, a design group based in Tokyo, is showing his chairs, tables, lamps and wall units in New York.

title: Mrs. Aquino's Fair-Weather Friends
description: It was so easy to be a February friend to the Philippines. The exhilaration rang round the world as the brief election campaign and a disputed vote turned into a popular revolt. Nuns with flowers stopped tanks, and Cory Aquino, in her yellow dress, ended 25 years of Ferdinand Marcos. That, it turns out, was the easy part.

title: The Lost Season of Bobby Meacham
description: The dugout was still empty. Bobby Meacham seemed to find solitude there, a place where he could sit quietly and perhaps try again to sort out the confusion of the season. He had a bat and a glove and his thoughts. He was looking for something else.

title: Chesebrough Sells Division
description: The American Home Products Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the hospital products division of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. for $260 million.

title: TANNED GORBACHEV, FRESH FROM SEASIDE, CHATS WITH FARMERS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has been on vacation on the Black Sea, visited a farming region in southern Russia today and called on people to speak their minds and stop covering up failings.

title: Sons of Murdered Wife File Insurance Claim
description: The sons of an executive sentenced to death in the 1984 slaying of his wife have collected more than half the $1.5 million in insurance the husband took out before her death, a lawyer for the sons and the wife's estate said today.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Navratilova Accused
description: Tennis champion Martina Navratilova twisted a sports photographer's arm ''like a pretzel,'' ripped away his camera and exposed his film following her upset defeat in the quarterfinals of the 1982 United States Open, an attorney for the photographer told a civil court jury yesterday in Riverhead, L.I. The photographer, Arthur M. Seitz 3d, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is suing Ms. Navratilova, charging that he injured his left shoulder and elbow and was the target of a vendetta by Ms. Navratilova, whom he outweighs by 50 pounds and who is four inches shorter than the photographer. The photographer's attorney, Marvin M. Mitchelson, described Ms. Navratilova as ''a woman of exceptional strength.''

title: Fall Is a Season to Think of Summer, and Day Lilies to Come
description: IT'S chrysanthemum time in the garden, and the fields and roadsides out in the country are radiant with the purples and lavenders and whites of the scores of wild perennial asters. In my own garden, there's only one day lily in bloom, out of step with the season, but a sweet reminder of high summer, of late June through early August, when the day lily, or hemerocallis, rules my garden the way the Queen rules England - with dignity and splendor.

title: JURY DELIBERATES ON GANG LINKED TO TAIWANESE
description: A Federal jury began deliberating in Manhattan yesterday in the racketeering trial of 11 men accused of being members of an international Taiwan-based gang, the United Bamboo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1986
description: International

title: We Are Fam-i-lee
description: A knee injury that is expected to keep Yale's starting quarterback, Kelly Ryan, on the sideline for the season opener against Brown on Saturday is also postponing the debut of what may be a brotherly footnote to football history. Ryan's brother, Mike, a linebacker, calls Yale's defensive signals, and up around New Haven they're guessing that Kelly's return will mark the first time since the advent of the two-platoon game that brothers have called signals for both squads on the same team.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $960,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain of $564,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: PACIFIC ISLE BLOCKS NUCLEAR ACCORD WITH U.S.
description: A proposed compact that would have allowed the United States to bring in and store nuclear weapons in this Pacific island state was overturned today by a special tribunal here.

title: Bridge: Six Teams Remain Unbeaten In World Championship Play
description: Six teams remained unbeaten in knockout play after today's matches in world championship team play for the Rosenblum trophy.

title: Sorry for Dropping In, Reagan Tells Couple
description: Brett and Debbie Brumfield got a letter of apology from President Reagan, who dropped in uninvited on their wedding when his helicopter landed in a city park Aug. 30.

title: CURRY IN CONTROL OF HIS CAREER
description: When Donald Curry beat Milton McCrory last December to become the undisputed welterweight champion, he appeared ready to emerge as boxing's next hot commodity.

title: Horn & Hardart
description: The California investor Theodore H. Kruttschnitt raised his stake in the Horn & Hardart Company to about 10 percent, or 1.43 million shares, from 7.6 percent. Mr. Kruttschnitt reiterated a previous statement that he might seek control of the Las Vegas-based food-service and mail-order concern. Between Aug. 7 and Sept. 16, Mr. Kruttschnitt bought 349,700 shares for $11.88 to $14.88 a share.

title: Fulbright on Fulbrights
description: Admirers of J. W. Fulbright have been honoring the former Senator on the 40th anniversary of the Fulbright Exchange Program, which has allowed American and foreign scholars to study outside their countries. One group among the admirers is the National Federation of State Humanities Councils, which honored Mr. Fulbright at a lecture and reception in the Rayburn House Office Building.

title: OWNER OF HOTEL WON'T MAKE IT FAMILY SHELTER
description: The owner of the Collingwood Hotel in midtown Manhattan announced yesterday that he would not permit the city to house 200 homeless families in his hotel - a move that will place added pressure on the city's overburdened shelter system.

title: Curb on Guerrilla Training
description: Gov. James R. Thompson today signed into law a measure forbidding private guerrilla and paramilitary training in Illinois.

title: An Old Lineman Takes His Stance
description: Former athletes, who are widely seen as role models for the nation's youth, have also been much in demand to hawk beer on television, and generally eager to do so. Now a moral implication of such work has come home to one former athlete - or rather he came home to it.

title: Tylenol-Recall Liability Case
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, not its insurance carriers, is liable for the $100 million Tylenol recall that followed the deaths of seven people from cyanide-laced capsules in 1982.

title: 2 LEBANESE BROTHERS DENY ROLE IN WAVE OF PARIS BOMBINGS
description: Two Lebanese men whom French authorities are seeking for questioning in the Paris bombings convened a news conference here today to deny that they were involved in the attacks.

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT FINDING TELLTALE SIGN OF AGENT ORANGE
description: A group of Vietnam veterans, scientists and members of Congress today announced the results of a study they say may finally prove the deadly effects of the wartime herbicide Agent Orange.

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
WOLF, HOWARD B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHESAPEAKE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $860,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 24
description: The company was an operating business unit of General Mills Inc. prior to Nov. 1, 1985.

title: Shift by Penn Athletic
description: Penn Athletic Products, a tennis and racquetball maker in Phoenix, has sent $2 million to $3 million in billings to Fallon McElligott. The agency will develop a trade and consumer campaign, which it plans to break early next year. Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh was the previous agency.

title: The Chance New York City's Educational Option Schools Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghan Jets Kill 2 Refugees
description: Two Afghan refugees were killed and five people were wounded in bomb and rocket attacks by Afghan jets in northwestern Pakistan, the Government said today. It said it had lodged a strong protest with the Afghan charge d'affaires in Islamabad against the ''unprovoked attacks'' Tuesday in the Kurram tribal administrative agency near the border with Afghanistan.

title: OPERATING RATE DOWN FOR INDUSTRY IN AUGUST
description: The operating rate of United States industry dropped to 79 percent in August, the lowest level since 1983, as factories continued to be plagued by the trade deficit, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
An Even Simpler Way To Fight Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL NEWMAN'S CAMP FOR CHILDREN WITH LEUKEMIA
description: At a news conference today packed with enough photographers for a Cecil B. De Mille production, the actor Paul Newman outlined his vision for a rustic Western village - ''a turn-of-the-century lumber camp in Oregon'' -that is to rise from 300 acres of forest in northeastern Connecticut.

title: Point Four Data
description: The Point Four Data Corporation said it had terminated its offer for up to 49.9 percent of Alpha Microsystems' shares at $6 each. Point Four had intended to acquire remaining shares through an exchange of notes with a face value of $5.50 a share. Point Four said the offer had been ended because of a merger accord announced this week between Alpha and Televideo Systems Inc.

title: WEATHER SATELLITE LAUNCHED ATOP REBUILT ROCKET
description: On the 17th attempt, a $37.3 million weather satellite roared into orbit today atop a rebuilt 25-year-old rocket. It was the second successful launching in two weeks for the troubled American space program.

title: FRIEDMAN, 5 DAYS FROM TRIAL, RE-ELECTED TO POST
description: Five days before he was scheduled to go on trial on charges that he was involved in a bribery ring at the city's Parking Violation Bureau, Stanley M. Friedman last night was re-elected Bronx Democratic leader.

title: DOW FALLS 9.14 POINTS, TO 1,769.40
description: Caution prevailed on Wall Street again yesterday, as stock prices were mixed for the third straight session.

title: FIRST LADY ASSERTS ANTIDRUG EFFORT IS GAINING
description: In her first public appearance since her nationwide television address about drugs Sunday, Nancy Reagan visited a school for young drug abusers here today and declared the public had begun to react against drug use in America.

title: I.M.F. Report On Inflation
description: Inflationary pressure, for years an economic ingredient that undermined efforts at global recovery, has been conquered in industrial countries, the International Monetary Fund said today. The fund, in its annual report, said the reduction in these pressures has given monetary officials more freedom to influence economies without fear of re-igniting inflation.

title: DENIES LINK WITH DANILOFF AFFAIR
description: The United States said today that it had given Moscow a list of 25 members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations who must leave by Oct. 1.

title: DOUBTS RAISED ON PROGRAM TO AID BUSINESSES
description: Some of the nation's leading authorities on minority business asserted today that Federal, state and local programs that reserved contracts for employers who were black, Hispanic or women might be addressing the wrong problems, favoring the wrong groups and operating longer than required.

title: BEAUTICONTROL COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company went public March 13.

title: Officer Was Gunman In Slaying, Panel Finds
description: A slain police officer who officials say may have conducted a three-year vigilante campaign was apparently responsible for a 1982 slaying, a special panel of city investigators concluded.

title: Ecuador Calls Troops As Mass Strike Begins
description: The Ecuadorean Government called out troops today to keep order and guard public services as labor unions representing 700,000 workers went on strike for a higher minimum wage.

title: IMPEACHED JUDGE LOSES KEY RULING
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, defending himself against impeachment, cannot argue that Federal investigators sought to frame him on bribery charges, a Senate panel said today.

title: Fire at a Soviet Power Plant Crippled 2 Units Last Winter
description: A fire at a Soviet coal-burning power station in Kazakhstan crippled two units for months last winter and forced a diversion of energy that led to losses of valuable timber, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $416,100 for the quarter and $788,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: CITY TO EASE CAREER-SCHOOL ENTRY
description: The New York City Board of Education, for the first time asserting control over admissions to the city's high schools, voted yesterday to ease the entrance requirements for eight career-oriented schools and for more than 100 career programs at 52 other high schools.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Richard F. Shepard
description: CUBAN MUSICAL The Repertorio Espanol, Spanish Repertory Theater to those deficient in Castilian, draws from all the Spanish-speaking world for its plays and musicals, which are presented in their native tongue at the company's Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street (889-2850). The show that enters the repertory tonight at 8 P.M., however, requires no great gift of the language to be appreciated.

title: Woman Is Arraigned In Plot to Kill Spouse
description: A 23-year-old Bayside, Queens, woman was arraigned yesterday on charges she conspired with three teen-agers to kill her 31-year-old husband, who is a contractor and businessman.

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATS IN BRITAIN OFFER TAX PACKAGE TO WIN BACK VOTERS
description: The Social Democrats, part of a centrist grouping that expects to hold the balance of power in British politics after the next election, proposed a seemingly radical tax reform program today in an effort to win back ground lost to the Labor Party in recent months.

title: The Stupidity Factor
description: When an incident aggravates relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, there is a tendency to see it in conspiratorial terms. The ruthless Russians are plotting again. Intractable anti-Soviet elements are maneuvering the U.S. Administration.

title: DEWS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to April 30
Catholic Killed in Belfast
description: Four gunmen burst into an amusement arcade here today and killed a Roman Catholic businessman, the 50th victim of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland this year.

title: WALL STREET FIRMS HURT BY STOCK DIVE
description: The stock market's recent dive produced a wave of losses for major Wall Street firms, adding red ink to what was already proving a weak third quarter for stock trading departments, according to a number of senior traders.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,396,000 related to the redemption of debentures.

title: Appointment At Chase Bank
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday announced the appointment of Michael F. Dacey, 42 years old, as executive for the manufacturing component of its corporate industries sector.

title: Teachers Strike L.I. District
description: The 110 teachers here struck today for higher wages, officials said.

title: THE CARNAGE MAKES PARIS CITY OF FEAR
description: One of the news broadcasts tonight opened with an anchorwoman saying, ''It was the kind of night when we would prefer not to have had television news.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1986
description: The Economy

title: CALENDAR: POTTERY BAZAAR, COUNTRY FAIR
description: Pottery Bazaar, Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street between Bleecker and West 4th Streets, 212-242-4108.

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,437,000, a gain of $9,226,000 on the sale of discontinued operations, and a tax credit of $2,374,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $2,228,000 and a gain of $866,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: OLD DOMINION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After net of $50,493 for the quarter and $108,059 for the 9 months from a subsidiary which was sold prior to the 1986 fiscal year. c-Net income

title: RECITAL: PAMELA GORE
description: PAMELA GORE, a prominent Boston-based mezzo-soprano with lots of imagination and musicianship, broad and varied professional experience and a lively sense of adventure, gave a frustrating recital at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night. She left one pondering the circumstances in which so many fine qualities could yield so little that is satisfying.

title: A Divided Electorate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn-Tokyo Action Doubted
description: Prospects that central bankers in West Germany and Japan will reduce interest rates have faded, but that has not eliminated speculation in the credit markets that further declines in American rates are still possible.

title: PILOT IS KILLED AS 2 JETS COLLIDE
description: Two National Guard jets flying over a ridge in the Adirondacks collided and crashed yesterday 50 miles northwest of Albany, killing one pilot, National Guard officials said.

title: JIHAN SADAT DEPARTS, BUT PAY DEBATE GOES ON
description: Although Jihan el-Sadat, the best-known visiting professor at the University of South Carolina, quit her post because of a lawsuit seeking to find out how much she was being paid, that effort has not ended.

title: PRODUCTS WE CAN'T LIVE WITHOUT
description: LIFE without Baggies.

title: HURCO COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net income

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) BRAVES VS.

title: WATERS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: REAGAN IS LOOKING TO ARMS PROGRESS
description: President Reagan expressed hope today that the next round of the Geneva arms talks would offer ''a real chance'' to reduce the level of nuclear arms. He said the Americans would present ''new details'' in the negotiations.

title: HIRSCHFELD, IN SHIFT, BACKS CUOMO
description: Abraham Hirschfeld shifted fields again today, abandoning his promised support of the Republican gubernatorial candidate, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and instead endorsing Governor Cuomo.

title: Dealer Rules: Law Nearing
description: The Senate has passed a bill that would place all dealers in government securities under a regulatory structure to be determined by the Treasury.

title: COPTER VISITS L.I. RUSSIANS BY MISTAKE
description: From a couple of thousand feet up, one helicopter pad can look pretty much like the next, even to a pilot for one of the largest travel-related businesses in the world.

title: SOVIET WARNS 7 LATVIAN-AMERICANS AT FORUM
description: A Soviet security official told the American organizer of a Soviet-American discussion forum here today that the authorities could not guarantee the safety of seven Latvian-Americans taking part in the meeting.

title: Prospects for College
description: Some 8,000 city high school students, most of them seniors, turned up yesterday at Pier 90, 50th Street and the Hudson River, for the city's first Black College Fair Day.

title: 333 Los Angeles Bus Drivers Show Traces of Illegal Drugs
description: More than 11 percent of nearly 3,000 Rapid Transit District bus drivers showed traces of illegal drugs in the body in the first year of a testing program, officials said Tuesday.

title: GIANTS' HAJI-SHEIKH GIVEN HIS RELEASE
description: In 1983, as a Giants rookie, Ali Haji-Sheikh kicked 35 field goals, the highest one-season total in National Football League history. He played in the Pro Bowl. His future seemed limitless; that future is now limited.

title: A FINAL CONCERT IS SET FOR LIBERTY CENTENNIAL
description: If you thought the party for the Statue of Liberty Centennial was over, think again.

title: FARM POLICY IS BROKEN, WAYS TO FIX IT ARE MANY
description: Last December President Reagan reluctantly signed into law a new farm program that he and his leading leading agriculture policy-makers knew would be a risky experiment.

title: Hanoi Transfers Remains of Serviceman
description: Hanoi turned over to an American military delegation today what it said were the remains and personal effects of a United States serviceman missing in action since the Vietnam War.

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Wanamaker's Has Everything, Even Shopping
description: It is 11:15 on a weekday morning. The marble floor of John Wanamaker's flagship department store, a cubic city block in constant motion, is crowded. People are mailing letters at the store's post-office branch, hunting for tickets to ball games, getting watches or shoes repaired, having their hair done or their clothes cleaned, heading for an early lunch at one of the store's six restaurants -even shopping.

title: Putting a Tag On Microbes
description: AMONG the most important questions worrying the public and Federal regulators about using genetically engineered microbial pesticides in the field is this one: If the bugs survive, where will they go?

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
HOW CHICAGO SHAKES WALL ST.
description: Come the ''triple witching hour'' Friday afternoon, financial wizards will pay as much attention to the Chicago futures trading pits as to the stock exchanges in New York.

title: A Trying Time For Investors
description: THE selling that pounded the stock market late last week has left investors shocked and nervous. Their fragile confidence was tested anew yesterday after the Dow Jones industrial average reversed course in the last hour of trading to finish with its first loss of this week.

title: Boycott Threatened
description: ''We want everybody or we won't play,'' said the International Tennis Federation president, Philippe Chatrier, threatening to pull his sport out of the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, if the world's top players are banned from competing. ''We're returning to the Olympics after a 64-year absence and we want the best tournament possible,'' he said.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $3,262,000 from the repurchase of stock and the sale of a unit, and an extraordinary loss of $3,260,000 for the early retirement of debt for the quarter and the year includes extraordinary losses totaling $21,200,000. c-Net income

title: FRENCH CONSULATE SWAMPED BY VISA-SEEKERS
description: In the days since France announced that visas would be required as part of an effort to combat a wave of terrorism, the French Consulate in New York has had to cope with thousands of applicants.

title: THROUGH VIENNA'S GLASS, DARKLY
description: ''VIENNA 1900: A Festival of Music'' - now running its distinguished course at the Museum of Modern Art -makes much of relating sound to sight: Gustav Klimt held up to Schoenberg, Gustav Mahler as reflected in Kokoschka or Schiele.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Darold Knowles, the former Oakland relief pitcher who set a major league record by appearing in all seven games of the 1973 World Series victory over the Mets, was hit by a truck as he and another man stood on a street in Kansas City, Mo., early yesterday. The 44-year-old left-hander, who spent 16 years with seven teams in the majors, suffered a broken pelvis and was in fair condition at St. Luke's Hospital. . . . Appearing as a special contestant in a meet designed for Soviet youth 23 years old and under, 36-year-old Marina Stepanova became the first woman to break 53 seconds in the 400-meter hurdles yesterday, clocking 52.94.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
POLICE CRITICIZED
description: A violent one-day casino strike ended today following agreement on union pay increases for three years. At the same time the casinos denounced the city's police work as ''a disgrace'' that had intentionally permitted ''mob rule'' by marauding pickets.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net loss The latest second quarter and 6 months' earnings include a gain from the sale of real estate of $1,734,947, or $1.71 a share.

title: SENATE, 65 TO 33, VOTES TO CONFIRM REHNQUIST AS 16TH CHIEF JUSTICE
description: The Senate tonight confirmed William Hubbs Rehnquist as the 16th Chief Justice of the United States and Antonin Scalia to succeed him as an Associate Justice.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My mother always said: 'Sonny, it's not just how you play the game.

title: Arts Groups Get $21.5 Million in Grants
description: More than 60 arts organizations throughout the country, including 15 in New York State, are among the recipients of more than $21.5 million in challenge grants this year from the National Endowment for the Arts, the endowment announced this week. This is the ninth year for the grants, which have totaled more than $173 million; an additional $1.1 billion has been raised by participating arts groups.

title: MARK MOROZOV
description: Mark Morozov, a Soviet dissident, died Aug. 3 in prison, a dissident group supporting him said here Monday. He was 55 years old. Mr. Morozov was serving an eight-year term for distributing Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's books and for writing an article criticizing the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The results adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 7.

title: MODULAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $268,000 for the year.

title: POLICE KILL A MAN IN BROOKLYN WHO WOULDN'T DROP HIS GUN
description: An elderly man who lived and worked in a Brooklyn grocery store was fatally shot by a police officer Tuesday after he opened fire on a group of officers investigating a burglary report there, officials said.

title: ITT REPORTEDLY PLANS BIG LAYOFF IN NEW YORK
description: The ITT Corporation, which is in the process of reducing its involvement in telecommunications, will announce within a few weeks that it is trimming its New York headquarters staff by at least half, company sources said yesterday.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I FUND reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Moon of My Delight
description: A pop is occasionally taken in this space at parasitic nepotism. That is a virulent strain of favoritism in which spouses, siblings or offspring of the powerful or celebrated reap undeserved profits from their exploitation of closeness to famous names who wish only they would shut up.

title: SAN/BAR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,610,000 and includes a $2.8 million writeoff taken because the company discontinued making and selling its Vision 2000 electronic key telephone system. c-Net income and includes a $2,741,000 tax credit and an extraordinary credit of $8,903,000.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Airlines Inc., Seattle, said it had reached agreement with its pilots on a voluntary wage reduction of 8.63 percent.

title: PIANO: RUTH ANNE RICH PLAYS IN RECITAL
description: A WORTHY American composition was introduced Monday in Ruth Anne Rich's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall: an unpublished piano sonata written late in life by Arthur Farwell (1872-1952). Farwell was a publisher, educator and critic who championed the cause of American composition when that activity was still a matter of proving that Americans could write European music just as well as Europeans could. As a composer, despite his experiments with American Indian melodies, he did not have the power of invention and vision to break that mold, but works such as this ''new'' sonata prove that his musical voice was genuine and strong even though it was not especially original.

title: MEXICO GIVEN DEBT AID BY 'PARIS CLUB' NATIONS
description: Western governments agreed today to give Mexico more time to repay some $1.8 billion it owes them. The agreement followed all-night talks between the chief Mexican debt negotiator, Angel Gurria, and the so-called Paris Club of creditor nations.

title: AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: No Terrorist-Appeasement Road to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL CONSUMER BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said meaningful comparative figures for 1985 are unavailable inasmuch as the company began operations June 5, 1985. The company said that the 6-month figures includes restated results for the first quarter ended March 31, 1986 which reflect the inclusion of accruals previously omitted.

title: Shouting Into the Wind
description: Jacqueline G. Wexler, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, has urged the Senate to approve the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which has been pending since 1980.

title: NBD to Buy Omnibank
description: NBD Bancorp Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Omnibank Corporation for about $51 million. NBD would pay $66.50 a share in cash or the equivalent value in its own shares for each of the 773,218 shares outstanding. Omnibank owns Wyandotte Savings Bank in suburban Detroit.

title: A 13-YEAR-OLD QUEENS BOY IS CHARGED IN SALE OF CRACK
description: He is 4-foot-5, 100 pounds, looks younger than his 13 years and he now has the sad distinction, according to officials, of being one of the youngest people ever arrested in New York City for selling drugs.

title: Posner Nears A New Trial
description: Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier convicted of evading $1.2 million in income taxes, edged closer to winning a new trial today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture on the Washington Talk page yesterday with an article about the Justice Department was published in error. It showed Nancy J. Risque, a former White House aide now with the consulting firm of Russo, Watts & Rollins, not Becky Norton Dunlop, an aide to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: NAKASONE'S TEST: NATIONALIST REVIVAL
description: A week ago, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone abruptly dismissed his Education Minister, a man of strong right-wing views who seemed to go out of his way in public statements to offend Koreans, Chinese and other Asians.

title: GLASSWORK CLASSES: HOT, COLD AND NEON
