description: Beginning and advanced classes in glass blowing and neon sculpture are among courses in the fall schedule of the New York Experimental Glass Workshop in lower Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: We Have the Technology to Avoid Midair Collisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Fannie Mae Planning Securities Depository
description: The Federal National Mortgage Associaton yesterday announced plans to invest $10 million of ''seed'' money to develop a mortgage securities depository and clearing service for all kinds of mortgage-backed securities.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
Democrats in Alabama Ordered to Vote Again
description: A Federal district judge today ordered a new runoff in Alabama's disputed Democratic gubernatorial primary between Attorney General Charles Graddick and Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONFIRMATION VOTE FOR CHIEF JUSTICE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate confirmed the nomination tonight of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States: FOR CONFIRMATION - 65 Democrats - 16 Bentsen, Tex.; Boren, Okla.; Bumpers, Ark.; Chiles, Fla.; DeConcini, Ariz.; Dixon, Ill.; Ford, Ky.; Heflin, Ala.; Hollings, S.C.; Johnston, La.; Long, La.; Nunn, Ga.; Proxmire, Wis.; Pryor, Ark.; Stennis, Miss.; Zorinsky, Neb. Republicans - 49 Abdnor, S.D.; Andrews, N.D.; Armstrong, Colo.; Boschwitz, Minn.; Broyhill, N.C.; Chafee, R.I.; Cochran, Miss.; Cohen, Me.; D'Amato, N.Y.; Danforth, Mo.; Denton, Ala.; Dole, Kan.; Domenici, N.M.; Durenberger, Minn.; Evans, Wash.; Gorton, Wash.; Gramm, Tex.; Grassley, Iowa; Hatch, Utah; Hatfield, Ore.; Hawkins, Fla.; Hecht, Nev.; Heinz, Pa.; Helms, N.C.; Humphrey, N.H.; Kassebaum, Kan.; Kasten, Wis.; Laxalt, Nev.; Lugar, Ind.; Mattingly, Ga.; McClure, Idaho; McConnell, Ky.; Murkowski, Alaska; Nickles, Okla.; Packwood, Ore.; Pressler, S.D.; Quayle, Ind.; Roth, Del.; Rudman, N.H.; Simpson, Wyo.; Specter, Pa.; Stafford, Vt.; Stevens, Alaska.; Symms, Idaho; Thurmond, S.C.; Trible, Va.; Wallop, Wyo; Warner, Va.; Wilson, Calif.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
BOYD WINS 15TH FOR BOSTON
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd equaled a career best with his 15th victory and Don Baylor and Dwight Evans hit consecutive homers tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: HARDING REGAINS LIBERAL POWER ROLE
description: After a period of turmoil and infighting in the state's Liberal Party, Raymond B. Harding regained the party leadership tonight after a walkout by the incumbent leaders.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the opening of the United Nations General Assembly session misidentified a man talking with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. He was Diego Cordovez, Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs, not Rafeeuddin Ahmed.

title: California Judges Barred From Biased Clubs
description: Judges in California are subject to discipline if they belong to private clubs that discriminate on the basis of sex, race or religion, according to a new provision of the state's judicial code.

title: RESISTANCE HINTED ON RATE CUT
description: Manuel H. Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, raised the possibility today that the Fed will resist a further cut in interest rates until it can get a better reading of new inflationary signs in the economy.

title: DANILOFF TRIAL SEEN IN CONGRESS AS BAR TO SUMMIT
description: A hardening bipartisan sentiment appears to be emerging in Congress against any move toward a summit meeting with the Soviet Union until an American journalist under indictment on espionage charges there is allowed to return home.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes writedowns of $3.8 million on the value of oil and gas properties, and $1.8 million on the value of drilling rigs.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Technologies Deal
description: The United Technologies Corporation has agreed to sell its 26-story headquarters in downtown Hartford to Colonial Realty of Hartford for more than $100 million. United Technologies will continue to lease 25 percent of the 600,000-square-foot building from Colonial, a commercial and residential realty company.

title: Public-TV Nominations Are Held Up in Hearing
description: Nominations of the Republicans Sonia Landau and R. Kenneth Towery to return to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting were sidetracked today because no Democrat has been nominated.

title: FANS RIP UP FIELD
description: Shortly after the Mets clinched the National League East title last night, the grass at Shea Stadium looked as if it had been attacked by animals that had not grazed for ages.

title: Advice Across the Aisle
description: New York City's Councilman Noach Dear was on somewhat unfamiliar legislative turf yesterday. At the invitation of two Republican Senators, James A. McClure of Idaho and Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Mr. Dear, a Brooklyn Democrat, spent half an hour in closed session with the Senate Steering Committee, a caucus of conservative Republicans.

title: ROBERTSON SETS CONDITIONS FOR MAKING A RUN IN 1988
description: At a fervent coast-to-coast political rally bound together by television signal, the Rev. Pat Robertson promised tonight that he would seek the Republican nomination for President if three million of his followers signed petitions of support for him within a year.

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $3,006 charge from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and the year includes a tax credit of $187,494.

title: AA IMPORTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss

title: JET SECONDARY STRAINING
description: This is ''Miami Week,'' and that means life around the Jets is more intense.

title: RECITAL: ROGER ZAHAB, VIOLINIST
description: A SURPRISING amount of contemporary music has more in common with the spare, simple utterance of antiquity than with the knotty, angular qualities of traditional Modernism. Or so it seemed Monday night during the recital by the violinist and composer Roger Zahab at Christ and St. Stephen's Church.

title: WITH CHANGES IN SCHOOL BUS COMPANIES, PUPILS ARE ARRIVING LATE
description: Some of the children who ride buses to the city's public schools have been late to school and late getting home, their schedules disrupted by new bus companies.

title: KEY RATES
2 DISMISSALS OVERRULED BY WARD
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward has overturned a departmental ruling that urged the dismissal of two officers for beating a civilian.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 18, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Group Forms to Oppose Nuclear Dump Selection
description: Groups in 13 states opposed to the selection process for the nation's first high-level nuclear waste dump have joined forces as the National Nuclear Waste Task Force, an organizer said today.

title: Baker Talks on Drop in Dollar
description: With West Germany and Japan rejecting a cut in their interest rates, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said today that the dollar's value might need to decline further to help the nation's trade.

title: CONGRESS ENDORSES MILITARY OVERHAUL
description: The most sweeping reorganization of the military command structure in a generation passed Congress today and went to President Reagan, who the White House said was likely to sign it.

title: MEESE LINKS DRUGS AND ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that illegal immigration and drug trafficking from Mexico were closely linked and urged the House of Representatives to approve stiffer immigration controls.

title: 2.9% Growth Seen in 1987
description: The economy will grow by 2.9 percent in 1987, moderately faster than the 2.5 percent expansion now likely to be recorded this year, a diverse group of industrial and financial economists predicted today.

title: Surgery Needed
description: A Brazilian soccer star, Zico, announced in Rio de Janeiro that he would undergo knee surgery in the United States as a last recourse to ending his playing career. The 33-year-old midfielder of Rio's Flamengo club and the Brazilian national team will have the surgery in Columbus, Ga., where an orthopedic specialist, Dr. James Andrew will operate on damaged ligaments in Zico's left knee. Dr. Giuseppe Taranto, the Flamengo team physician, said that if Zico did not undergo surgery ''he could become a cripple.''

title: POP MUSIC: FRAN JEFFRIES AT FREDDY'S
description: THE pop-jazz singer Fran Jeffries has had an odd career whose twists and turns are reflected in her cabaret act. Ms. Jeffries once sang in a duo with Dick Haymes, to whom she was married, and she recorded with Count Basie. She has also appeared in movies with Elvis Presley and performed regularly in Las Vegas.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest quarter figures include the results of the LFE Corp. and Gulton Industries, neither of which were included in last year's first quarter. Gulton is included for the first time with the latest first quarter, and LFE was included as of the second quarter last year. The share earnings for the year-ago quarter and the shares outstanding for both periods have been restated to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid June 6.

title: NEW SUFFOLK ROAD SIGNS REMINDERS OF FATALITIES
description: The newest traffic sign in this Suffolk County community is a simple white circle with a large black dot in the center.

title: Shuwa to Buy ABC Building
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. has agreed to sell ABC's 21-year-old headquarters building on the Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street to the Shuwa Corporation of New York. The price was not disclosed, but real estate sources said the deal was worth $165 million.

title: BOOK LIST OF EASY READING FOR GARDENERS
description: This is a good time of year for gardeners to sharpen horticultural skills by studying some of the inexpensive booklets available on gardening matters. Many publications are available, and most cost less than $1. In addition, the expert writers, who have no commercial points to make, deliver information simply and helpfully.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THEATER: 'MINK SONATA'
description: THE family under observation in Allan Havis's ''Mink Sonata'' (opening the Fringe Series at the BACA Downtown theater in Brooklyn) has affluence and political influence - and, concomitant with both, comes a high quotient of emotional turmoil.

title: ON NORTH FORK, BATTLE TO DIRECT A STYLE OF LIFE
description: When Henry C. Weismann retired from his law practice in Smithtown in 1978, he decided he had had enough of suburban life. ''I'm a country boy and I wanted to be in the country,'' he said.

title: ARNOLD L. KATES
description: Arnold L. Kates, president of Mailographic Inc., a direct-mail advertising and printing concern, and former vice president of the Park Association of New York City, died of cancer yesterday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JOSEPH KENNEDY'S MARGIN MAKES HIM A FAVORITE
description: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d's victory margin in a Democratic Congressional primary Tuesday was much larger than expected, making him an overwhelming favorite to win the seat once occupied by his uncle, John F. Kennedy. The seat is now held by the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who is retiring.

title: 5 DEAD, 50 HURT AS BOMB IS HURLED ON A PARIS STREET
description: A bomb that the authorities said had been thrown from a passing car exploded in front of a crowded department store on the Left Bank today, killing at least 5 people and wounding about 50.

title: Knopf Will Publish H. L. Mencken Diaries
description: The board of the Enoch Pratt Free Library in Baltimore yesterday authorized publication of the private diaries of H. L. Mencken, written between 1930 and 1948.

title: Decline Eases a Bit
description: Yields on most certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell in the period ended yesterday. But there were signs that rate declines, which have now continued for 10 consecutive weeks, may be slackening.

title: ULSTER PARTY CHIEF SAYS TERROR IS NOT HIS FORTE
description: By the darkest tales of his enemies, Gerry Adams is the Machiavellian prince of Irish politics.

title: Pat Phoenix Is Dead at 62; Starred in British Soap Opera
description: Pat Phoenix, who became Britain's first television soap-opera star in ''Coronation Street,'' the country's longest-running television serial, died of lung cancer today at a hospital in Manchester. She was 62 years old.

title: Turkish Cypriot Chief, in U.S., Plans Campaign for Support
description: Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, said today that he was beginning a campaign for American support to counter official United States backing for the Greek side on Cyprus.

title: David Ben-Gurion Plaza
description: Asked if he would attend a rededication of part of East 43d Street to honor David Ben-Gurion, Mayor Koch responded in character: ''Only rabid dogs could keep me away.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Boehringer Ingelheim Corp., Ridgefield, Conn., a pharmaceutical company, has appointed Digby W. Barrios executive vice president.

title: INLAND VACUUM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said that net income for the latest periods include a $45,000 one-time charge to relocate corporate offices from Churchville, N.Y., to Saddle River, N.J.

title: LAX SAFETY CHARGED
description: A South African mining company said today that 177 people, most of them black miners, died Tuesday when a fire sent palls of toxic gas through underground shafts. It was the country's worst gold-mining disaster on record.

title: FOR RANGERS, A CHANGE IN ATMOSPHERE
description: A year ago, as the new Ranger coach, Ted Sator entered with all the clipboard-in-hand fanaticism of an assembly-line supervisor. There were charts and assessment meetings and productivity quotas and there were lists: lists of schedules and rules, lists handed out, lists on chalkboards, lists for players, reporters, administrative personnel, lists for just about anybody who wandered by.

title: KASPAROV'S LEAD NARROWS AS KARPOV WINS GAME 17
description: Anatoly Karpov outmaneuvered the world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, today to win the 17th game of their 24-game title match, keeping alive his chances of recapturing the chess crown.

title: CHILDREN GONE, PARENTS OPT TO REMODEL
description: IT has become something of a cliche in American family life:

title: COKE PLANS PRETORIA PULLOUT
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it will sell its remaining holdings in South Africa within nine months, with some of them going to black South African investors.

title: Director at Ernst To Head F.A.S.B.
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the accounting industry's chief rule-making body, said yesterday that it had named Dennis R. Beresford to a five-year term as chairman beginning Jan. 1.

title: HOW A BARN GREW UP TO BE A HOUSE WITH A VIEW
description: AS scheme succeeds scheme in a project's planning stages, architect and client may have a different solution in mind for the same problem. Ensuing design changes usually reflect fervent discussions, and in the case of a house in northern Westchester, can be a practical lesson in the give and take necessary between client and architect during the design period.

title: Michigan Utility In Pact With Dow
description: The Consumers Power Company, the financially troubled Michigan utility, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Dow Chemical Company for a joint effort to convert the idled Midland nuclear plant into a natural gas cogeneration plant. The agreement ends two years of uncertainty over the fate of the Midland plant.

title: HERS
description: NEW YEAR'S DAY 1985: Blustery, snow-swept and momentous. Leon and I walked to the drugstore for the results of the pregnancy test. The druggist says: ''Positive.'' I whoop, Leon grins, and we shake hands. Congratulations.

title: CML GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The 1985 results are restated to include Nordictrack, which was merged with CML during 1986.

title: How, and Where, to Lead the Schools
description: Our aim is to again make New York's schools a model for the nation, and our commitment is to see that they serve all of the city's children. Our mandate requires this. The city's future . . . demands it.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $102,000. The company said the latest quarter loss is substantially attributable to costs of a pre-tax non-recurring expense of about $500,000 under a contractual obilgation related to the recent resignation of Ketchum's former president and chief operating officer who resigned in August. Corrected from Tuesday's, Sept. 16, editions.

title: Drug Energy and Dubious Law
description: Impressed with the political electricity surging about the drug abuse issue, some lawmakers would use it to jolt old bills to life. Two such measures already approved by the House would relax the exclusionary rule in criminal courts and create a new death penalty offense. Wiring these dubious ideas into the drug bill doesn't make them smarter.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $307,000 to settle a lawsuit and a writedown of vacant land for the quarter and 39 weeks. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $574,000 on the sale of a store.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $77,000 for the both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Hong Kong Growth
description: Hong Kong's economy, as measured by its gross domestic product, is expected to grow by 5.6 percent this year, an upward revision from the Government's previous 4.5 percent estimate, the Financial Secretary said today. In a midyear economic report to the Hong Kong Society of Security Analysts, Financial Secretary Piers Jacobs attributed the revision to an unexpected rise in exports.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTRA AID IS SEEN HINDERING ACCORD
description: Congressional approval of $100 million in aid for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government has pushed further into the future any chance for a negotiated solution to the Central American conflict, according to Latin American diplomats and Reagan Administration officials here.

title: People
description: * James R. Wilson is joining the Newspaper Advertising Bureau as vice president, national advertising. He will also be named head of the national ad sales staff at the end of the year, succeeding Mac Morris, who will retire.

title: BENNETT WOULD WIDEN PUBLIC ROLE OF RELIGION
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett called today for an increased role for traditional Judeo-Christian religious values in public life but warned against any zealously sectarian view of America as a Christian nation.

title: Note Offering Set By New Zealand
description: New Zealand is offering 10-year and 30-year notes totaling $250 million through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: BLACK IN MICHIGAN GOVERNOR'S RACE URGES VOTERS TO MAKE HISTORY
description: ''Together we will make history,'' declares William Lucas in commercials that began appearing on television this week in support of his candidacy for Governor. Michigan voters, he goes on, will judge him on ''the strength of my character, not by the color of my skin.''

title: 2 KEY POSTS OFFERED BY KOCH REMAIN UNFILLED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had offered key jobs in his administration to two candidates, but one said no and the other is having difficulties working out a business complication.

title: A Door for Cats Only
description: THE problem pet owners usually have with pet doors is not that their cat or dog cannot find its way out, but that everybody else's cat or dog, as well as occasional raccoons or other intrepid small animals so inclined, can get in.

title: TEST RESULTS ARE DUE ON DRUG TO FIGHT AIDS
description: Physicians and Federal officials said yesterday that they expected an important announcement, probably on Friday, on the effectiveness of an experimental drug against AIDS.

title: A Benny Goodman Gift To Yale Music Library
description: The musical arrangements and recording masters of pieces played by the late Benny Goodman, the jazz clarinetist, have been bequeathed to the Yale University Music Library, the university announced today.

title: HARVARD'S ENDOWMENT LOSES FIRST PLACE TO TEXAS
description: The endowment managed by University of Texas System has passed Harvard's to become largest of any educational enterprise in the United States, according to an annual survey by the National Association of College and University Business Officers.

title: 6 Die in Pakistan Fighting
description: At least six people were killed and 60 wounded in two days of clashes between rival Moslem sects in Punjab province, the police said today. Two died today in Lahore, the provincial capital, in battles between Sunni and Shiite Moslems quarreling during Shiite rites marking the death 13 centuries ago of Mohammed's grandson Hussein.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI IS MAIN EVENT AT GARDEN
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI swaggered onto the stage of Madison Square Garden Tuesday night like a conquering heavyweight, arms lifted high above his head, a 360-degree grin on his face. Television cameras whirred and diamonds flashed in the huge auditorium, which was more than half full. This was, by any standards, a major event - an event, however, that had very little to do with music.

title: U.S. JURY SAYS 12 OFFICERS IN CHICAGO FACED BIAS
description: A Federal jury found today that 12 white Chicago police officers were discriminated against when they were transferred from an elite city investigative unit by an appointee of Mayor Harold Washington. The jury awarded the officers $4.29 million in damages, over $1 million more than had been sought.

title: AFTER THE SULTAN, IT'S SCHMIDT
description: Mike Schmidt, another home-run title all but in the bag, will officially break out of a tie when the season ends early next month and stand alone as history's runner-up in that category.

title: BI INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Cineplex Odeon
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of RKO Century Warner Theaters Inc. from MCA Inc. for $179 million in cash, stock and notes. RKO Century Warner operates 97 movie screens at 42 locations in the New York City area.

title: IRINI SPANIDOU, NOVELIST WITH ROOTS IN 2 CULTURES
description: The early fall publishing season is off to a lively start for new fiction writers with an acclaimed first novelist: Irini Spanidou, author of ''God's Snake.''

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net income

title: First Bank System Sees Write-Off
description: First Bank System Inc. said that, after a review of its investment and loan portfolio, it expects to add about $275 million to its loan-loss reserve and to charge off $275 million in loans during the third quarter.

title: Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation and Continental Airlines Inc. said that they had revised the terms of Texas Air's bid to acquire the shares of Continental that Texas Air does not already own. Under the proposed agreement, Continental common stock would be exchanged for $15.20 a share. The prior agreement called for each share to be exchanged for Texas air senior notes with a face value of $14.75.

title: MADONNA'S NEW BEAT IS A HIT, BUT SONG'S MESSAGE RANKLES
description: Madonna's new song ''Papa Don't Preach'' hit the top of the pop charts a few weeks ago and all around the city her voice is heard, singing of adolescent pregnancy. It drifted through Kathie Peters's headphones on a recent afternoon as she made her way to a pizza parlor in Queens, and the 18-year-old broke into a sidewalk boogie:

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Announced that John Tudor, pitcher, would miss the rest of the season because of a sore shoulder.

title: COURT REJECTS PLEA OF MIAMI JUDGE
description: The Judicial Conference of the United States may recommend to Congress that Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings of Miami be impeached, a court of appeals here decided today.

title: Bigger Prize to Winner Of Stephen Kelly Award
description: When it comes to advertising awards, the Stephen E. Kelly Award, presented by the Magazine Publishers Association for excellence in magazine advertising, has never been a biggie. The Andys attracted 5,000 entries last year.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EX-HOSTAGE STILL HAS HIS EYE ON MIDDLE EAST
description: Remember Allyn B. Conwell? He was the tall Texan who emerged as the spokesman for the hostages on the hijacked T.W.A. flight 847 last year in Beirut.

title: A PREVIEW OF NBC'S 'CRIME STORY'
description: IN its first ''sneak preview'' tonight at 9 o'clock on NBC, ''Crime Story'' wastes no time in revealing its intentions, which are somewhat less than honorable. During a robbery in progress at a flashy Chicago club, a customer is killed by a vicious thug, who then starts taking hostages. Rushing to the scene, a police lieutenant, Mike Torello, warns the murderer that if anyone else is hurt, ''I'm gonna kill whoever you love most - your mother, your father, your dog.''

title: AGENCY ORDERS REVIEW OF AIR TRAFFIC ENFORCEMENT
description: In the aftermath of the collision of a Mexican airliner and a small plane Aug. 31, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration has ordered an urgent internal review of the safety of restricted air traffic zones like the one in Los Angeles where data indicate that crash occurred, the agency said yesterday.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SPORTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
FINALLY, THE METS ACHIEVE THE INEVITABLE TITLE
description: Surrounded by a roaring crowd of 47,823 in Shea Stadium and by many ''amazing'' memories of the past, the Mets ended their six-month pursuit of a title in high style last night when Dwight Gooden pitched them to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs and to the championship of the National League East.

title: Iran Said to Shell Kuwaiti Supertanker
description: A Kuwaiti supertanker was ablaze off Saudi Arabia in the northern Persian Gulf today after being shelled by an Iranian gunboat, shipping sources in the region said.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
S.B.A. Offers Certificates
description: A $67 million issue of Small Business Administration 8 3/4 percent participation certificates, guaranteed by the United States Government, was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Illegal Aliens Are Not Entitled
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Reports Accord On Sudan Relief Flights
description: The United Nations has reached a tentative agreement with Sudanese rebels that could allow resumption of food aid flights into the beseiged city of Wau in the southern Sudan by the end of this week, United Nations officials said today.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
BELL BEATS YANKEES TO GAIN FIRST VICTORY
description: The Yankees, who have gone longer than any other baseball team in New York without winning a division title, crept closer to elimination from this season's race in their division last night, dropping an 8-3 decision to a flock of Rochester Red Wings who were disguised as Baltimore Orioles.

title: MEMPHIS STATE OUSTS KIRK
description: Dana Kirk, who coached Memphis State to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament in the last five years, was dismissed by the university today.

title: PEOPLE RIDESHARING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LUSKIN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $1,866,000 for discontinuing mail order marketing operations for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $550,000 for the latest year and $298,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $169,000. The company said the year-ago quarter net includes a gain of $213,000 on the sale of a Rochester, N. Y., manufacturing facility.

title: Study Critical On Layoffs
description: Most American workers caught in plant closings or layoffs get less than two weeks' notice, making it virtually impossible to provide them with timely help in finding or training for new jobs, a Congressional report said.

title: INSIDE
description: CAUTION RULES WALL STREET As investors remained nervous, stock prices were mixed for a third straight day.

title: West Side Story
description: With the teams dormant, there hasn't been much to cheer for in the United States Football League this fall. But for one group of U.S.F.L. cheerleaders, it's been business as usual - almost.

title: Understudy Plays a Role
description: The understudy who won the cheers and the hearts of the 47,823 fans in Shea Stadium last night was David Joseph Magadan, a 23-year-old infielder from Tampa, Fla., who said that he intended to report his rousing performance in a telephone call to his cousin - Lou Piniella, the manager of the Yankees.

title: We Have the Technology to Avoid Midair Collisions; Landing Parachutes
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Q. I recently had a new heating and air-conditioning system installed in the crawl space under my house. The insulation around the ducts in this crawl space seems to be sweating in places, and much of the foil is missing from the batts of insulation. Is this foil important and should the sweating be considered a problem?

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $430,000 and $172,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,409,000 for the quarter and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $13,463,000 for the 9 months, and a reversal of a tax credit of $441,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $6,629,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $1,298,000 and $2,214,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $296,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the credit markets incorrectly described the growth rates for the M-2 and M-3 measures of the nation's money supply. The 8.9 percent growth rate for M-2 and the 9.1 percent rate for M-3 represented the change from the average in the fourth quarter of 1985 through August.

title: KEY TO STRATEGY: THE POCKET VETO
description: As the final days of the 99th Congress approach, an old phrase is again buzzing through the corridors of the Capitol - ''pocket veto.''

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'LA CENERENTOLA' ON A&E
description: ROSSINI composed ''La Cenerentola,'' his setting of the Cinderella story, in 24 inspired days and nights. Although he wrote another 15 operas, this proved his final work in the opera buffa style. It is a splendid valediction - lively and tuneful, a mixture of giddy nonsense and genuine dramatic power.

title: Hyundai Canada
description: Hyundai Auto Canada Inc., a unit of the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea, said the plant it is building in Bromont, Quebec, will produce a new car model that is still in the planning stages. The company began construction of the plant this week. It is scheduled to start production in 1988 and produce 100,000 cars a year by 1991.

title: PEPITONE IS GUILTY OF LESSER CHARGES
description: Joe Pepitone, the Yankees' flamboyant first baseman of the 1960's, was convicted by a jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday of two drug charges, but was found not guilty of the four most serious charges against him, including one, for possession of cocaine, that carried a mandatory minimum sentence of 15 years in prison.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-After tax credits of $1,320,000 and $3,346,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary gain from extinguishment of debt received on disposal of minority interest of $3,501,000. c-After extraordinary gains from extinguishment of debt of $603,000 and $2,517,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax loss carryforward of $377,000 for both the quarter and year. d-Net loss The 1985 results are pro forma and reflect the spinoff of Intelogic Trace Inc.

title: Reporters Out, Judge In
description: The wheels of justice grind slowly but it looks as if they have finally caught up with the press room in Manhattan Criminal Court. To keep up with the backlog of trials, the state is transferring 20 Civil Court judges over to the criminal section.

title: THOUSANDS IN LEBANON MARCH TO BACK U.N. FORCE
description: Thousands of protesters marched through the streets of the port of Tyre in southern Lebanon today in support of the United Nations peacekeeping troops in the area.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
3 More Checked for Typhoid
description: Three more people, including two children, have come down with typhoid symptoms in an outbreak that has sickened a total of seven people who ate in a McDonald's restaurant last month, officials said today.

title: Polaris Aircraft Founder Shifts Company to G.E.
description: In law school at Harvard, Peter G. Pfendler had a good job in his final year: pilot for Eastern Air Lines flying 727's out of Boston's Logan International Airport.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: The company said the latest second quarter and 6 months' nets were reduced by 4 cents a share as a result of work stoppages and the cost of repositioning stores in its Atlanta division and by 5 cents a share for future store closings in the Atlanta division.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II FUND reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a non-recurring after-tax gain of about $600,000, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of a surplus manufacturing facility for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Budget Plan Is Offered For Improving Subways
description: The city's Transit Authority proposed a $6.5 billion capital improvement budget yesterday to be used in the next five years for buying new subway cars, overhauling others and continuing its rebuilding program.

title: Honeywell in Broad Swings
description: Trading in Honeywell Inc. stock fluctuated widely yesterday as Wall Street rumors persisted that the big producer of computers, controls and military systems might be on the verge of a significant announcement.

title: Officer Named in Death Of Handcuffed Suspect
description: A veteran police officer was charged today with killing a handcuffed drug suspect by firing two bullets into his head while the man lay face down on the ground.

title: 23 Have Surrendered In the Aquino Slaying
description: Two generals, 18 soldiers and a businessman charged in the killing in 1983 of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. surrendered today, bringing to 23 the number of men taken into custody in the case.

title: Chrysler-A.M.C.
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation plan to announce an agreement next week for A.M.C. to build cars for Chrysler at its Kenosha, Wis., plant, a Chrysler spokesman said. Joseph Cappy, president of A.M.C., had said in April that the companies were negotiating on assembly of the Chrysler Fifth Avenue, a rear-wheel-drive luxury sedan, and two related models, the Dodge Diplomat and Plymouth Gran Fury. Under the deal, Chrysler would move car production from one of its St. Louis assembly lines to make room for assembly there of a longer-wheelbase mini-van.

title: National Steel Raising Prices
description: The National Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would match price increases announced Tuesday by the LTV Corporation's steel unit.

title: ARCHITECTURE: PHOTOS OF CAPITOL IN ALBANY
description: WHEN buildings are professionally photographed, they are portrayed as handsome objects. Photographs are often taken on sunny days so that such architectural features as cornices and moldings are highlighted and seen against shadow. The photograph is flattering but objective.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOUSE BACKS COVERT AID TO REBELS IN ANGOLA
description: The House of Representatives today refused to cut off covert aid to rebels fighting the Soviet-backed Angolan Government. The vote was 229 to 186.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AT one time, many homes had at least one room paneled with plywood in a rich looking hardwood pattern. The popularity of those dark wood panels waned in recent years as homeowners began to prefer brighter, more colorful walls.

title: Harold M. Esty, 72, Is Dead; Backer of Broadway Shows
description: Harold M. Esty, a Buffalo businessman and a backer of Broadway shows, died Tuesday at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, Ohio. He was 72 years old and lived in Derby, N.Y., south of Buffalo.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the results include those from the Mr. Gatti's unit, which was sold early in the latest first quarter, and results from the Chattanooga, Tenn., Wendy's Restaurants, which were purchased in the first quarter a year ago.

title: RUSSIANS AT U.N. TO PROTEST ORDER
description: The Soviet Union will protest a Reagan Administration order to expel 25 members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, a Soviet official said today.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings results reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed in July. The company said the latest full- year figures include a third-quarter pre-tax charge of $11,791,000 related to certain plant closings.

title: BRAZIL PRISONERS FREE 20 HOSTAGES
description: Inmates exchanged 14 hostages they had held for a day and a half for three lawyers and three churchmen and fled their central Brazilian prison today. Later, they freed their six new hostages and eluded pursuing policemen.

title: BISHOPS AND VATICAN: U.S. PRELATES TREAD A FINE LINE
description: America's Roman Catholic bishops have largely been silent about the dramatic decision by the Vatican disciplining one of their colleagues, Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle, because they are caught in a dilemma involving their own authority. For many years now, America's 300 bishops, as a national conference living in a land of democratic values, have been gently, tactfully, but quite palpably, moving to upgrade their stature in relation to the Vatican.

title: Texas Prosecutor Is Arrested
description: The District Attorney for McLennan County was arrested today on Federal charges that he accepted bribes from lawyers to influence criminal cases, the authorities said. The prosecutor, Vic Feazell, 35 years old, was charged in a 12-count sealed indictment alleging violations of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act and mail fraud, said United States Attorney Helen Eversberg.

title: Response Sought On CBS Status
description: CBS Inc. was asked by the Federal Communications Commission today to respond formally to a complaint that control of the corporation and its broadcast licenses was transferred illegally.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $9 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 9 months. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the effect of the 2 percent common stock dividend paid April 18, 1986.

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES BILL TO SELL CONRAIL STOCK
description: A bill authorizing public sale of the Government's stock in the Consolidated Rail Corporation for at least $1.7 billion and imposing some reregulation upon the railroad industry was approved today by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. The measure was much weaker in its regulatory reach than one adopted Tuesday by a subcommitee of the House panel.

title: DSP TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said results include tax credits of $34,000 for the latest quarter and $58,000 for the 6-month period, and $18,000 and $43,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: CORRECTION
description: A transcript on July 23 of President Reagan's address about South Africa policy rendered a passage incorrectly in his appeal to President P. W. Botha. It should have read, ''As I urge Western nations to maintain communication and involvement in South Africa, I urge Mr. Botha not to retreat into the laager.'' His reference was to the Afrikaans word for a defensive circle of wagons.

title: Stake Seen In Lucky Store
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman has been accumulating shares in Lucky Stores Inc., Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Taft Stake Lifted
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have raised their stake in the Taft Broadcasting Company to 6.7 percent, or 619,400 shares, from 5 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Financial and Mr. Lindner said they had bought the shares for investment purposes only, but added that their intentions could change. Between Aug. 13 and Sept. 12, they bought 155,500 Taft common shares for $109.70 to $118.23 a share.

title: DUARTE ACCUSES GUERRILLAS OF SCUTTLING PEACE TALKS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte and other top Government officials assert that extreme demands by leftist rebels scuttled peace talks planned for this week.

title: GATEWAY MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $143,799. c-Net loss

title: FOR FLEET STREET, A NEW VOICE
description: To Andreas Whittam Smith, the recent history of Britain's newspaper industry, long identified with Fleet Street in London, has been characterized by ''bad management and degenerating journalistic standards.''

title: 'PINA BAUSCH,' PORTRAIT OF THE CHOREOGRAPHER
description: ONE of today's most controversial choreographers, Pina Bausch, is loved and loathed with equal ferocity for the productions she has created for West Germany's Wuppertal Dance Theater. ''Pina Bausch,'' offered tonight at 11 o'clock on the Bravo cable network, tries to show why she prompts such violent responses.

title: HOUSING CONSTRUCTION RISES BY 0.4%
description: Housing construction edged up four-tenths of 1 percent in August after three consecutive monthly declines, the Commerce Department reported today. But analysts said the pickup did not signal a return to boom times.

title: 2D SOVIET MISSILE FAILED IN A TEST, U.S. AIDES SAY
description: A new long-range Soviet missile exploded during a test flight last month, Reagan Administration experts said today.

title: OLD SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Year to June 28
description: b-After a pre-tax loss from the closing of a restaurant of $1,081,480. c-Net income

title: We Have the Technology to Avoid Midair Collisions; See and Be Seen
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'JUNK LOVE,' MODERN ROMANCE
description: ''JUNK LOVE'' is the theatrical equivalent of a home movie - self-involved and very sincere. Approaching the play on that level, one can feel a sympathetic concern for the two author-actresses, Robin Epstein and Dorothy Cantwell. Miss Epstein's character is a lesbian, Miss Cantwell's a heterosexual, and each in her own way is mired in an unrequited affair of the heart.

title: REAGAN OFFERS AQUINO WIDE SUPPORT
description: President Reagan held his first face-to-face meeting with President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines today and offered broad American support for her economic, political and military policies.

title: The Danger's Over
description: It's safe to look now, faint hearts.

title: BIG APPLE FIX-UP: RENOVATING HOMES
description: FINDING a place to live in New York City is in itself an accomplishment. But the real trick is making it feel like home. This weekend do-it-yourselfers can get advice at the Big Apple Fix-Up, the fifth annual home-improvement festival, which opens tomorrow at noon to run three days at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Farm Credit Shortfall Seen
description: According to the General Accounting Office, the $64 billion Government-regulated Farm Credit System, the nation's largest farm lender, probably will exhaust its financial reserves early next year and have to ask Congress for a bailout.

title: GUGGENHEIM NEIGHBORS OFFER ALTERNATIVE PLAN
description: A proposal to build an underground addition to the Guggenheim Museum of Art was offered yesterday by opponents of the museum's present plan to construct a cantilevered tower over a portion of the building.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $343,000 for a provision for loss on the disposal of engine remanufacturing operations. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $96,500 and $184,200 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary tax credit of $406,200 for the quarter and a tax credit of $940,500 for the 9 months. The company said the latest 9-month results include one month of operations for Tuneup Masters Inc., which Cardis acquired July 1.

title: SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
Destroy South Africa to Save It?
description: ''On television, you don't sense the daily squalor, the flies, the filth, the dehumanizing way people are just thrown together,'' said a stunned Archbishop of Canterbury, as he toured the Crossroads squatters camp near Cape Town. ''It's so much more dramatically squalid than I had expected.''

title: Addenda
description: * Venture magazine will increase its rate base 13 percent from 300,000, to 375,000 in January.

title: ALLISON'S PLACE reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
LAST-MINUTE TALK ON WAR-RISK PACT
description: With the East-West security conference here nearing its scheduled conclusion, negotiators from the NATO and Warsaw Pact countries were reported to be still deadlocked on key issues today.

title: FEDERAL STANDARDS FOR STATE LAWS
description: The Department of Transportation said in 1984 that if state laws were to be counted toward a rescinding of the automatic restraint rule for autmobiles, they had to meet these standards:

title: AUCTIONS
description: AFTER Gerrit Thomas Rietveld's innovative de Stijl furniture was sold for record prices at an Amsterdam auction by Christie's in May, an even larger group of the Dutch architect's work was assembled by Sotheby's for another sale scheduled in that city on Sept. 29 and 30. This time there will be 12 lots, comprising 26 Rietveld designs - twice the number auctioned in May.

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 31
Real-Estate Score
description: For a few hours every year, the tiny parcel that is most coveted by the giants of the real-estate industry is home plate of a Central Park softball field.

title: UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $275,000 for the quarter and $497,000 for the 6 months. The company went public Aug. 22.

title: SCREEN: ADVENTURE TALE, 'THE RIVE RUNS BLACK'
description: DESPITE its PG rating, which alerts parents to a glimpse of attractive flesh and a few moments of violence, ''Where the River Runs Black'' is strictly for the kids. Kids with patience, that is, for this movie, which opens today at Loews 84th Street Six, seems to be in slow motion even when it's not. Christopher Cain, the director, lets the story dawdle while the camera basks in the Brazilian sun streaming through trees or shutters or church windows.

title: The Trouble With a New York State Property Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: An Army of Snipers vs. Fair Taxes
description: Has the 99th Congress accomplished anything worthwhile? Yes: the monumental tax reform bill approved by a conference committee and now awaiting ratification by both houses. Yet with only days to go, a disturbing number of members say they don't find much public enthusiasm for the bill and aren't sure whether they'll vote for it. Even the House Democratic leadership says approval is not yet certain.

title: Post Office Tries to Improve
description: It was a tempting invitation from the postmaster in Manhattan, John M. Nolan.

title: A CORNUCOPIA OF CELEBRATIONS ALL AROUND TOWN
description: AS of Sunday, it's officially autumn, which means that the peak season for New York street fairs and festivals is drawing rapidly to a close. It's almost as if this weekend had been planned as a grand finale, for there will be no less than eight neighborhood celebrations tomorrow and Sunday - not only in Manhattan, but in Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island as well.

title: Grand Canyon Hearings Open in Fatal Crash
description: Efforts by helicopter operators to curtail noise on tours of the Grand Canyon may have played a part in the crash of two aircraft in which 25 people died June 18, a witness said at a a Federal hearing here today.

title: After the Shootdown
description: Exactly how and why Korean Air Lines Flight 007 was shot down over Sakhalin Island on the night of Aug. 31-Sept. 1, 1983, may never be known. But Seymour Hersh, in his new book, ''The Target Is Destroyed,'' tells us more, more persuasively, than anyone else has been able or willing to do.

title: Who Gains, Who Loses When Church Divests?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARK OF THE FANS
description: It was ravaged, with deep lines and stress marks that had not been there the night before. We are talking about Frank Cashen's face, not just the lawn at Shea Stadium.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS FIGHT OVER AFRICA BILL
description: Senators Bob Dole and Richard G. Lugar are both card-carrying kingpins on Capitol Hill, moderate conservatives with keen senses of practical reality and wide reputations for legislative acumen. Accordingly, Mr. Dole, the majority leader, and Mr. Lugar, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, work together on most issues facing the Senate.

title: 49ers Lose Everett Bid
description: The San Francisco 49ers suffered a major setback when they lost their quarterback, Joe Montana, for the rest of the season following back surgery Monday. The 49ers suffered another blow yesterday when they were outbid by the Los Angeles Rams, their National Football Conference West rivals, for the rookie Jim Everett, the Houston Oilers' first-round draft choice out of Purdue and a holdout this season.

title: Newsletters And the Plunge
description: WHICH investment newsletter made the most timely call in forecasting the sharp decline in stock prices that began earlier this month?

title: 'STUPIDITY' OF TAX ACCOUNTANT IS JUDGE'S DEFENSE AT HEARING
description: The defense in the impeachment hearing of Harry E. Claiborne contended today that the Federal district judge was a victim of ''stupidity'' by his tax accountant rather than being a willful criminal.

title: Atari Plans Stock Offering
description: The Atari Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said today that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 4.5 million common shares, to be priced from $11.50 to $13.50. The underwriter for the offering is Paine Webber Inc. Atari earned $12.4 million, or 56 cents a share, on sales of $105.6 million for the six months ended June 30. A year earlier it had a loss of $26.67 million on sales of $47.7 million.

title: FALL SEASON IN CAPITAL OPENS ON A FESTIVE NOTE
description: Congress and President Reagan are back in town, and Washingtonians have been making up for the doldrums of August with a series of evenings out: some elegant, some literary and some just plain fun.

title: ACCORD IS TENTATIVELY REACHED ON CUTTING DEFICIT
description: House and Senate leaders said today that they had reached a tentative agreement with the White House on the major elements of a package to cut the 1987 deficit by over $13 billion.

title: REHNQUIST SEEKS 'TO BE A GOOD CHIEF JUSTICE'
description: A smiling William H. Rehnquist, confirmed by the Senate Wednesday night as Chief Justice of the United States, said today, ''I'm looking forward to the future and to trying to be a good Chief Justice.''

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S pretty major, and very nice news. Mary Tyler Moore and Lynn Redgrave will be returning to Broadway as of Dec. 19. Miss Moore was last here in 1980 in ''Whose Life Is It, Anyway?'' and Miss Redgrave appeared in ''Aren't We All?'' last year. But what makes the project even more interesting is that the play in which they'll be co-starring, ''Sweet Sue,'' by A. R. Gurney Jr., has a format that is, to say the least, unusual. Miss Moore and Miss Redgrave will both play the title role, and if you think that's confusing, there will also be two actors, as yet uncast, playing the same male character. In other words, instead of a few actors taking on multiple roles, a not uncommon occurrence, this one will have four actors playing two characters.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after extraordinary tax credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $348,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE DANCE: REGNIER'S 'SCIENCE'
description: PATRICE M. REGNIER'S company, Rush Dance, has often explored music with popular elements that can be put to artistic use, and the new program now on view at the Marymount Manhattan Theater (221 East 71st Street) is no exception.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1986
description: International

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THIS story involves a rainy night, a Gothic cathedral, a pile of rotten wood and a bit of luck. The main characters are Dorothy and Henry Kraus, a husband and wife who roam Europe in search of great but overlooked medieval art, and who write books about the art that ordinary people can enjoy and understand.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: George Adams-Don Pullen Quartet, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). Charles Mingus brought together the saxophonist George Adams, the pianist Don Pullen and the drummer Dannie Richmond in his mid-1970's quintet, and after Mingus died in 1979 they decided to stay together. With the bassist Cameron Brown, they have followed Mingus's mandate - to merge the freedom of modern jazz with the verities of the blues. Mr. Adams's tenor saxophone can be lightly melodic, acerbic or incantatory; Mr. Pullen can toss off florid harmonies, modal vamps and splashy, expressive sweeps and clusters, above the precisely articulated cross-rhythms of Mr. Richmond and Mr. Brown. Their repertory can be sampled on an engaging new album ''Breakthrough'' (Blue Note) - recorded after their last Vanguard engagement - but the quartet's delicacy and volcanic power are best heard live. Tonight through Sunday, with sets at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: RJR Vice Chairman Gets a Broader Role
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that it had increased the responsibilities of Edward A. Horrigan Jr., the food and tobacco company's vice chairman.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: 'On Hold' Is Message Time At D'Amato Headquarters
description: Call (212) 714-9486 and a young woman may say: ''D'Amato for Senator headquarters. Can you hold please?''

title: SCREEN: 'BLUE VELVET,' COMEDY OF THE ECCENTRIC
description: OTHER directors labor long and hard to achieve the fevered perversity that comes so naturally to David Lynch, whose ''Blue Velvet'' is an instant cult classic. With ''Eraserhead,'' ''The Elephant Man'' and ''Dune'' to his credit, Mr. Lynch had already established his beachhead inside the realm of the bizarre, but this latest venture takes him a lot further. Kinkiness is its salient quality, but ''Blue Velvet'' has deadpan humor too, as well as a straight-arrow side that makes its eccentricity all the crazier. There's no mistaking the exhilarating fact that it's one of a kind.

title: MX Missile Passes 14th Test
description: An MX missile carrying six unarmed warheads of a new design today completed its 14th successful test shot in 14 launchings, with all the warheads hitting the target area 4,200 miles downrange in the Pacific, the Pentagon announced. The four-stage missile, which is to carry 10 warheads to make it the most powerful weapon in the United States arsenal, was launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif.

title: The Crisis That Wasn't
description: This is the crisis that wasn't. A senior British Government official noted recently that if London hadn't negotiated an agreement with Peking over the future of Hong Kong, it would be a major factor of international tension now. Because of alliance ties, that would strain delicate American relations with China. And that would make it easier for the Russians to push their current overtures to Peking and strengthen them in their haggle with the U.S.

title: KINNEBREW LEADS BENGALS TO VICTORY
description: Larry Kinnebrew, a fullback, ran for three touchdowns tonight, giving the Cincinnati Bengals a 30-13 victory over the Cleveland Browns.

title: YEARLONG DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR FAILS TO CUT U.S. TRADE DEFICIT
description: A year ago the five major industrial powers forged a historic compact to drive down the value of the dollar in hopes of easing a crushing trade imbalance.

title: Japan Economic Plan
description: Japan adopted an eight-point package designed to inrease domestic spending, Government officials said today. The package, the third in six months, calls for a $23 billion increase in construction spending, easier terms on loans from the government's Housing Corporation and greater spending by the electricity and gas industries, the officials said.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WHAT THE U.N. RULES SAY ABOUT EXPELLING DIPLOMATS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has challenged Washington's authority to expel 25 members of the Soviet Mission. Here are excerpts from the United Nations Headquarters Agreement, a 1947 accord that sets forth the privileges and immunities of the United Nations and its employees, as well as diplomats accredited to the world organization, in the United States. ARTICLE IV Section 11

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS CORIGLIANO WORK
description: IF pastiche is the only authentic musical style of our eclectic time, as some sage has alleged, John Corigliano's ''Fantasia on an Ostinato'' may be considered a mainstream work. The 14-minute piece, which was given its world premiere last night by the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta's direction, is a kind of thesaurus of contemporary styles. If any scholar of a future century should happen to unearth this piece, the musical story of the last half-century might be deduced from it.

title: FRENCH ATTACHE IS SLAIN BY GUNMAN IN BEIRUT
description: The French military attache in Lebanon was shot dead today by a gunman in the predominantly Christian sector of the capital.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sonny Sharrock, Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (203-357-1197). Sonny Sharrock's explosive electric-guitar forays of the mid-1960's opened up new areas for the instrument. His influence, if only at second or third hand, can be heard in many styles of music, from rock to funk to jazz. But as his recent solo album, ''Guitar,'' deftly demonstrates, Mr. Sharrock doesn't sound much like anyone else. He is a genre of music all by himself. The British bassist Percy Jones, playing with pre-recorded tapes, will provide an opening set tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $8.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday STAMP FESTIVAL '86 Stamp collectors and enthusiasts gather this weekend for Stamp Festival '86, a three-day showcase at Madison Square Garden. Sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers Association, the exposition offers an array of lectures, seminars and exhibits, with auctions at noon tomorrow and Sunday featuring more than 2,000 lots. The festival, which will be in the Garden's Exposition Rotunda, runs from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. today, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Daily admission is $3, with children under 14 admitted free if accompanied by an adult. Information: 564-4400. Saturday BLACK ROOTS IN NEW YORK Anyone with an interest in black culture or regional black history might want to stop in at ''African Roots in New York Soil: Black Culture in Colonial Westchester'' this weekend. The two-day program at Philipse Manor Hall in Yonkers begins Saturday night at 8 with a keynote address by Dr. Thomas J. Davis, whose lecture is entitled ''Black Culture in Colonial New York.'' Sunday's events begin at noon with a church service by the Rev. Darryl George of Yonkers Messiah Baptist Church, followed at 1 P.M. by the gospel soloist Tulivu-Donna Cumberbatch. The Olatunji Dance Troupe performs at 2 P.M., and at 3:45 there will be a dramatic piece based on an 18th-century slave narrative, delivered by Charles Dumas. At 4:30 P.M. comes the finale, a ''call and response'' gospel performance by the Brooks Family of Rockland County.

title: TREK OF 1,000 MILES FOR HOMELESS ENDS
description: It was a test of the body and mind, of idealism and faith. But after 51 days hundreds of people today came to the end of a thousand-mile walk to raise $1 million for the homeless.

title: ART: SELF-PORTRAITS AT CLAUDE BERNARD
description: GOOD timing is in evidence with ''Artists' Self-Portraits'' at the Claude Bernard Gallery, 33 East 74th Street. This is the beginning of the art season, and one is eager to see the lineup.

title: Officer Gives Up Post At Texas Instruments
description: When Texas Instruments formed Worldwide Memory Operations earlier this year, by consolidating its United States and Japan metal oxide semiconductor operating units, Tim B. Smith's job was eliminated. Mr. Smith, who was head of the American operation, was then moved to help incorporate artificial intelligence capabilities into the company's Houston plant.

title: TRANSFORM LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JAPAN TAKES NEW STEPS AGAINST PRETORIA
description: Japan announced this morning that it would impose new economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: HIGH SOVIET OFFICIAL WARNS U.S. ON TIES
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arriving here for two days of high-level talks, warned today that years of ''confrontation and dangerous contention'' might lie ahead if Washington and Moscow failed to make headway in the sessions.

title: STEVENSON, WORN BY HIS TROUBLED CAMPAIGN, PREDICTS A SURPRISE: VICTORY
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d says that he is going to make it, that he is going to surprise ''the big metro newspapers'' he accuses of ''pounding'' him, that his ''campaign for political rehabilitation'' will pay off and he will be elected Governor in November.

title: Virginia Gregg Is Dead at 70; Off-Screen Voice in 'Psycho'
description: Virginia Gregg, the versatile character actress who scared moviegoers as the chilling off-screen voice of the mummified mother in the three ''Psycho'' movies, died of lung cancer Monday in Encino Hospital. She was 70 years old.

title: ROME SAYS SUMMIT TENSIONS DELAY GORBACHEV VISIT TO ITALY
description: A senior Italian official said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, had put off a long-expected visit to Italy.

title: Iran Intercepts Ship Owned by West Germans
description: Iranian Navy units intercepted a West German-owned container ship in the Persian Gulf today and forced it to an Iranian port, shipping sources said.

title: EDGY WALL ST. AWAITS THE 'HOUR'
description: Today is the day when the stock market, still spooked by last week's dramatic drop in prices, just might rebound strongly. But it is equally likely that today's market, in its closing minutes, could produce another wrenching fall that would rattle the investing public even more.

title: REBUFF TO REAGAN
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a rebuff to President Reagan, said today that an American journalist restricted to Moscow was ''a spy caught red-handed.''

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 19, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RED SOX WIN, 7-1, LEAD BY 10 1/2 GAMES
description: Rich Gedman and Marty Barrett drove in two runs each with bases-loaded singles tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-1.

title: BATCH OF RITE AID ASPIRIN PILLS RECALLED IN SEARCH ON CYANIDE
description: Bottles of a store brand of aspirin were pulled from the shelves of Rite Aid drugstores in 20 states today after a woman returned three tablets laced with cyanide, officials said.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE
description: R: Revised. * Seasonally adjusted. ** Excluding acceptances. n.a.: Not available.

title: Chrysler to Extend Low Finance Rates
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was extending low interest rate sales incentives on some 1987 model cars because some dealers were nearly sold out of 1986 models.

title: AS WAR TAKES ITS TOLL, THE ANGOLAN MIRE DEEPENS
description: Many buildings in this gloomy capital city, their pastel colors overlaid with years of grime, are crumbling. Others have stood half-finished for a decade.

title: BRIDGE: THREE AMERICAN TEAMS ARE IN SEMIFINALS FOR WORLD TITLE
description: An American jinx seems likely to be broken here in the next three days.

title: TRANSTECTOR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Western Pacific
description: Western Pacific Industries said it had agreed to be acquired for $156.52 a share, or about $360 million, by a group led by the private investment firm of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen.

title: British Unemployment
description: The British Government took heart today from the latest unemployment figures, which showed the jobless rate virtually unchanged at 11.7 percent of the working population.

title: GOSSAGE AND PADRES REACH SETTLEMENT
description: Rich (Goose) Gossage, whose fiery criticism of the San Diego ownership resulted in his suspension, will be back with the Padres tonight in Houston. The Padres and Gossage reached agreement yesterday on a settlement of their dispute, which had been scheduled to be heard by an arbitrator today.

title: C Sharpe, Saxophonist
description: The alto saxophonist C Sharpe will lead his quartet tonight and tomorrow at at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly.

title: GIULIANI IS SILENT AS HE PREPARES TO PROSECUTE
description: For months, Rudolph W. Giuliani has been by far the most visible crime fighter in town. He held frequent press conferences. He was a regular on television talk shows and accepted countless luncheon invitations to talk about the importance of rooting graft and corruption from government.

title: PRETORIA LIFTS VEIL ON DISPUTED CAMP
description: The South African authorities offered reporters a limited look today at a ''re-orientation'' camp for former political detainees, one of a string of 13 such camps that anti-apartheid groups have termed sinister.

title: HONEYWELL HOLDS TALKS ON BUYING SPERRY UNIT
description: The Honeywell Corporation surprised Wall Street yesterday by announcing that it hopes to acquire more military technology operations and that it plans to sharply reduce its payroll in a companywide personnel cutback.

title: Changes At Times Approved
description: Shareholders of The New York Times Company yesterday approved several proposals expected to protect the independence of The New York Times by keeping control of the newspaper within the Sulzberger family.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: NOWHERE in the United States, nor anywhere else as far as I have seen, is there a dining room that crackles with the high-voltage energy of Le Cirque. There is indeed something magical about the fetes thrown twice a day by the suave Italian-born owner, Sirio Maccioni, that have the rich and famous from around the world clambering to squeeze into one of his elbow-to-elbow banquettes. While so many other chic restaurants blaze for a short time in the night then fade like a shooting star, Le Cirque has remained white-hot for most of its 12 years.

title: Arab League Crisis
description: The Arab League ended a two-day council session today, saying it would discuss its major financial crisis at a foreign ministers' meeting scheduled for Oct.

title: A Pretty Picture
description: In capturing his famous 1941 image of a defiant Winston Churchill, Yousuf Karsh resorted to an impish bit of spontaneous byplay. Just before he snapped the picture, the photographer snatched a cigar away from his subject, triggering the Churchillian glare that became the ultimate pictorial personification of the unyielding British resistance in World War II. ''He looked so belligerent,'' Karsh recalls, ''he could have devoured me.''

title: 2 Killed in Pakistan In Curfew Attacks
description: Security forces opened fire today on curfew violators attacking religious buildings here, killing 2 people and raising the death toll to 12 in two days of clashes between Moslem sects, the Government said.

title: MET OPERA BROADCASTS IN MUSEUM EXHIBITION
description: When ''Hansel und Gretel'' was performed by the Metropolitan Opera on Christmas Day 1931, Deems Taylor talked during much of it. Some people found the combination annoying; others were thrilled to hear it.

title: Sanitation-Worker Test Defeated Merit Ranking
description: To the Editor:

title: Speakeasy Anniversary
description: Speakeasy, the folk-music club at 107 Macdougal Street (598-9670), will celebrate its fifth anniversary tonight and tomorrow, with appearances by Tom Rush (tonight) and dozens of other performers, among them the songwriters Peter Stampfel and David Massengill. Admission is $10, with a two-drink minimum; advance reservations are recommended.

title: THE SCREEN: 'L'AMOUR PAR TERRE'
description: ''L'Amour par Terre'' was shown as part of the 1984 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 7, 1984. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Los Angeles Searches For Tainted Cheese
description: Health inspectors today searched for cheese made by unlicensed manufacturers after bacteria were found in one brand of illegally imported Mexican cheese.

title: 7 DIE IN SRI LANKA CAR-BOMBING
description: A car bomb went off in the port of Batticaloa today, killing at least seven people.

title: Burlington Air Chief
description: Robin H. H. Wilson, former president of Western Airlines, has been named president and chief executive of Burlington Air Express. Mr. Wilson, 50 years old, resigned last month from Western, which is being taken over by Delta Air Lines. Burlington's parent, the Pittston Company, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., said Mr. Wilson would succeed George B. Ryan, 64, who is retiring. Mr. Wilson joined Western in January 1985 after three years as president of the Long Island Rail Road and 17 years with Trans World Airlines.

title: High Society and Guest
description: The trio High Society, with the saxophonist Eddie Chamblee as guest, will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $7.50 minimum on Sunday.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $567,000 for the quarter and $761,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter and $87,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $32,000 and $94,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: SKI LTD reports earnings for Year to July 30
PERSICO ASKS JURY NOT TO BE DUPED BY MAFIA LABEL
description: In opening statements yesterday at the trial focusing on a Mafia commission, a prosecutor called the defendants crime leaders, defense lawyers conceded the Mafia's existence and a defendant warned that ''labels are a smoke screen.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SENATORS VS. REHNQUIST
description: In the end, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. said, it really came down to which side had to carry the burden.

title: CORITA KENT, ARTIST AND NUN, DESIGNED 'LOVE' STAMP ON 60'S
description: Corita Kent, who as a nun in the 1960's became famous for her silkscreen posters, and who designed the United States Post Office's ''Love'' stamp, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Boston. She was 67 years old.

title: Engelbert Brenner, 82, A Philharmonic Soloist
description: Engelbert Brenner, who played in the New York Philharmonic for 41 years, first as an oboist and later as the orchestra's English horn soloist, died Tuesday at his home in Atlantic Highlands, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: Uncle Sam Has to Get His Books in Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Press Curbs Widespread In Americas, Group Says
description: Freedom of the press in the Western Hemisphere is being assailed by dictatorships and democratic governments alike, the Inter-American Press Association said today.

title: PRIME MINISTER OF FRANCE PLEDGES 'CRUSHING' RESPONSE TO BOMBINGS
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac vowed today that France would deliver a ''crushing and unflinching'' response to the terrorists behind a wave of bombings if they could be caught and their guilt established.

title: FILM: JARMUSCH'S 'DOWN BY LAW'
description: JIM JARMUSCH is an American original. He's as singular as ''Bob'' Frost, Sam Shepard and Nicholas Ray, each of whom is evoked - in one way and another - by Mr. Jarmusch's darkly comic, lighter-than-air ''Down by Law,'' which provides the 24th New York Film Festival with a truly festive opening tonight at Lincoln Center.

title: BAVARO HAS SKILLS TO FIT MOWATT ROLE
description: When Zeke Mowatt, the Giants' excellent tight end, was injured in the final 1985 preseason game and lost for the year, the job, for better for worse, fell to Mark Bavaro, a rookie. So far, it has been for the better, much better than anyone had envisioned.

title: TRANSIT MISHAPS TIED TO DRUGS
description: The use of drugs or alcohol by transit workers has become the most common cause of accidents on the nation's bus, subway and rail systems, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: Seagoing Brass
description: The Dirty Dozen Brass Band from New Orleans will perform Sunday aboard a Seaport Line cruise that leaves the South Street Seaport at 6:30 P.M. Tickets are $15 in advance, $17.50 Sunday; information: 406-3434.

title: BARRY BLAU & PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DANCERS AND PERFORMERS RECEIVE BESSIE AWARDS
description: Dance Theater Workshop has presented its third annual New York Dance and Performance Awards for achievement in dance and performance art. The awards, selected by a panel of dancers, choreographers, critics and dance presenters, are familiarly known as the Bessies, in honor of Bessie Schonberg, a noted teacher of dance composition.

title: GUIDRY WANTS TO REMAIN A YANKEE
description: Ron Guidry was cleaning out his locker at Yankee Stadium the other day, throwing out, among other things, several stacks of picture postcards of himself in a Yankee uniform. Was he planning to move elsewhere and have picture postcards made in a new uniform?

title: Bethlehem Prices
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced price increases for sheet products effective Jan. 4, 1987, matching increases announced earlier this week by the LTV Corporation and the National Steel Corporation. Bethlehem is still studying price increases for its tin mill products.

title: Addendum
description: * Harcourt Brace Jovanovich has acquired the trade magazine Independent Restaurants.

title: Diner's Journal
description: MENAGE A TROIS, a London restaurant that claims to have originated the ''grazing'' concept of serving meals composed of many small portions, opened a warmly elegant branch in the Lexington Hotel on East 48th Street this week. Antony Worall-Thompson, a sandy-haired, bearded Briton with an impassioned commitment to light sauces and minimalist cooking, offers a seven-page menu of palate teasers that are highly refined, stunningly presented and judiciously balanced.

title: Revlon Amends Offer
description: The Revlon Group Inc. amended its tender offer yesterday for shares of Frigitronics Inc., saying that there has been a material deterioration in Frigitronics' business.

title: Robertson Denies Values Remarks
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson today denied making remarks that led to criticism from Secretary of Education William J. Bennett. The television evangelist said on ''The CBS Morning News'' that Mr. Bennett had ''picked up off an inaccurate news release - I had never said what I was quoted as saying.''

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $3.3 million from the sale of Symbolics Inc. common stock. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,322,000 for the quarter and $3,270,000 for the 6 months.

title: CBS Football Pact
