description: CBS Sports has signed a $60 million contract with the College Football Association to televise a minimum of 15 games a season from 1987 to 1990. The C.F.A., which consists of 63 Division I-A teams, has also renegotiated its four-year contract with ESPN, giving that cable network a dozen Saturday afternoon games each season from 1987 to 1990, in addition to the 15 night games already agreed to earlier this year. Chuck Neinas, executive director of the C.F.A., said the total package amounted to $130 million, meaning that ESPN is going to pay $70 million over four years for rights to 27 games a season.

title: Randy Wilson, Pianist
description: The pianist Randy Wilson is appearing tonight through Sunday at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street (675-7900). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: BELMORAL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Philip Glass Featured On 13's 'Creative Edge'
description: Of all the American composers not situated squarely in the pop field or involved with Broadway, the minimalist Philip Glass has been far and away the most successful at bringing his music - and himself - to the attention of the public and getting paid for it. He has written scores for a variety of uses up to and including opera and, since the late 1960's, has maintained the Philip Glass Ensemble, which tours annually.

title: FILM: 'AMERICAN JUSTICE'
description: ''AMERICAN JUSTICE,'' which opens today at the U.A. Twin and other theaters, is another movie with the plot and style of a third-rate television show. It has a standard, predictable plot, no surprises, stock villains played in the broadest of cliche styles, lots of tight head shots and, to liven things up, the usual barrage of butchery and blood.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; 82 WINNERS SHARE BIG PICK-SIX POOL
description: When New York's thoroughbred tracks introduced the Pick Six a year ago, the hope was that occasional huge carry-over jackpots would start a betting frenzy on the order of Lotto. That still has not happened, but yesterday was the closest it has come to doing so.

title: JERSEY RULING FOLLOWS SIMILAR DECISIONS ON GOVERNMENT DRUG TESTS
description: The ruling yesterday by a Federal judge in New Jersey, striking down what he described as ''mass, roundup urinalysis'' to determine if firefighters and police officers used illegal narcotics, was in line with several state and Federal court decisions involving the widespread drug testing of government employees.

title: TEXAS AIR'S EASTERN BID APPROVED
description: The Federal Government today approved a revised proposal by the Texas Air Corporation to acquire Eastern Air Lines for $676 million, a merger that would create the nation's largest airline.

title: Gibraltar Tells Britain Of Dismay on Border
description: Representatives of Gibraltar's 27,000 residents told Britain in a letter published today that they are dismayed by its latest move to ease tension with Spain. British officials, meanwhile, are preparing for a new round of talks in Madrid.

title: Baker Comments Spur Rates
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose for all maturities yesterday, partly in response to comments by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d warning that a further decline in the dollar would be needed if foreign central banks do not reduce their interest rates.

title: Battle Over Air Shuttle Has Begun
description: FOR the last 25 years, Eastern Airlines has offered shuttle service between New York, Washington and Boston without much competition. But about Oct. 1, Pan Am will start flying its shuttle, and the marketing battle is certain to be intense, even by the rough-and-tumble standards of the airline industry.

title: The Siege of Paris
description: Besides mourning the dead, Americans can show their sympathy for France by sparing it gratuitous advice on how to quell a savage burst of terrorism. Five explosions in 10 days have killed 8 and injured more than 170 Parisians. Wednesday's assault was the most despicable: a bomb was unloaded from a passing car outside a crowded department store favored by low-income customers, many of them Arab immigrants, at a time when children were out of school.

title: Say 'Yes'
description: Last Sunday in the White House television appeal on drugs, Nancy Reagan emphasized and re-emphasized the slogan: ''Just say no.'' A day later, some Washingtonians were startled to receive a mailing with the reverse appeal: ''Just say yes.'' It was advertising a trial subscription to Soviet Life, the English-language magazine the Russians circulate in this country to promote tourism and improve their image.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Saturday from Alexandria, Egypt, about the Egyptian-Israeli summit meeting, misidentified Abba Eban. He is a Member of Parliament in Israel, not a Minister Without Portfolio. Through an editing error, the misstatement also appeared in The Week in Review on Sunday.

title: Medals for Moynihan
description: Politics is sometimes not so much the art of the possible as the skill of satisfying simultaneously people who are on opposite sides of the same issue. Witness Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who received a medal from the Central Intelligence Agency one day last week for ''consistently adhering to the highest standards of personal and professional integrity in furtherance of the national security interests of the United States'' (i.e., not disclosing secret information as a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee). The next day the Senator got a gold medal and $15,000 from the Encyclopedia Britannica for ''excellence in the dissemination of knowledge for the benefit of mankind'' (i.e., spreading all other information.)

title: Country Fair Display
description: Chrysanthemums, pumpkins and antique farming tools will be on display beginning tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard at Bedford Park in the Bronx.

title: This Is Not the Time for a Four-Day Week
description: To the Editor:

title: Verdict Against Church Of Scientology Is Upheld
description: A judge refused today to overturn a $30 million verdict against the Church of Scientology of California.

title: LAW COSTS SEATTLE LUCRATIVE CRUISES
description: Port officials here say they are frustrated because a United States law is forcing cruise ships to operate out of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EDITED WEEKLY JESUIT JOURNAL
description: The Rev. Thurston N. Davis, former editor in chief of America, a weekly journal of opinion published by the Jesuits of the United States and Canada, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday at America House, the Jesuit residence and magazine headquarters at 106 West 56th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: Philharmonic Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic, under the direction of Zubin Mehta, will play music by Bartok, Brahms and John Corigliano at Avery Fisher Hall today at 2 P.M. and tomorrow at 8 P.M. Itzhak Perlman will be the soloist in Bartok's Violin Concerto No. 2. Tickets are $7.50 to $27.50. Information: 874-2424.

title: BankAmerica Urges Rumors Query
description: The BankAmerica Corporation called on Federal and foreign regulators today to investigate what the bank termed ''false and malicious'' rumors that have driven down the bank holding company's stock in the last few days.

title: KEY RATES
Rain Postpones Little Brown Jug
description: Heavy rain at the Delaware County Fairgrounds forced the cancellation of today's running of the 41st edition of the Little Brown Jug.

title: NBC NEWS TO REALIGN EXECUTIVES
description: NBC News plans a major realignment of its executives, putting Timothy J. Russert, the former political adviser hired two years ago to reshape NBC's public image, in charge of daily news programming, according to network officials.

title: CITY IMPROVED MANY SERVICES, MAYOR REPORTS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the municipal scandal had disrupted city government, and that even so, the delivery of many city services had improved in the last year.

title: HRE PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes gains of $31,627 and $92,145 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of real estate. c-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $28,101 for the quarter and $82,932 for the 9 months.

title: KILLER OF COUPLE IS CONVICTED
description: A 21-year-old man was found guilty yesterday of murdering an elderly St. Albans couple during a burglary in their home after he had taken crack.

title: EAST GERMANS TO HELP BONN STEM FLOOD OF THIRD-WORLD IMMIGRANTS
description: The East German Government, acceding to persistent demands by West Germany and its allies, agreed today to take measures to stem a continuing flow of people from the third world seeking asylum in West Germany.

title: REAGAN, ON STUMP IN SOUTH, PLEDGES TO RESIST A TAX RISE
description: Bringing the South a spirited partisan message, President Reagan said today that if Congress sought to raise taxes after lowering tax rates, it would be an ''intolerable breach of faith.''

title: Mets' Magic, and Mayhem
description: It's been a magical summer for the New York Mets, and the game that clinched the division title against the Cubs signaled a magical fall. When we found our seats at Shea Stadium, the air was nippy, the sky autumnal black and the moon a gleaming medallion.

title: Jet Crash Victim Identified
description: The pilot killed in the collision of two Air National Guard jets Wednesday was identified today as Major John Southrey, 32 years old, of Granby, Conn. The pilot of the other plane, Michael Kohut, 33, of Chicopee, Mass., was listed in fair condition at Albany Medical Center Hospital with a fracture of the lower back. A special board of inquiry will investigate the crash, which occurred in a wooded area near Wells, about 60 miles northwest of Albany.

title: Fiat Silent on Bid
description: Officials of Fiat S.p.A. remained silent about details of a new takeover bid for Alfa-Romeo, which is also being sought by the Ford Motor Company. A spokesman for Italy's largest auto maker and private employer also refused to give details about talks between the Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and Fiat's chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, held in Rome on Wednesday night. Mr. Agnelli reportedly sought support from the Government for taking over the state-controlled auto maker, for which Ford has made an offer for a 20 percent stake.

title: Old Questions, New Worries
description: World politics, this time in a particularly grim guise, is front and center again as a worry for the International Olympic Committee.

title: GIRLS PLAYING FOOTBALL, BUT NOT MANY
description: Playing touch football was Lina Garcia's favorite pastime last year in eighth grade. ''The boys insisted she play because she was one of the better athletes,'' said her gym teacher, Fred Blake. ''When she was pushed, she pushed back.''

title: Singer and Duo
description: The singer Jeanne Lee, the vibraphonist-bass clarinetist Gunter Hampel and the saxophonist-flutist Thomas Keyserling will perform tonight at 11 at the Alchemical Theater, 539 East 13th Street. Admission is $8; information, 477-1695.

title: U.S. READY TO CUT MISSILES IN EUROPE TO A TOKEN FORCE
description: The United States has told the Soviet Union that it is prepared to accept a Soviet suggestion that only token missile forces be kept in Europe under an agreement on medium-range arms, Administration officials said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Italian, East Side
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ALO ALO, #1030 Third Avenue, at 61st

title: Wanted: Speechwriter
description: Terry H. Eastland, director of public affairs at the Department of Justice, is back in the running for the long-vacant post of chief White House speechwriter. President Reagan's aides are talking about renewing their efforts to recruit Mr. Eastland, who declined the offer three months ago, and he has agreed that he will listen to the offer again.

title: PREMIERE OF 'ELLEN BURSTYN SHOW'
description: ELLEN BURSTYN is a remarkable woman. She was born in Detroit, originally named Edna Rae Gillhooly, and started out professionally as a model and as a regular on ''The Jackie Gleason Show.'' Over the years, she has won a Tony for her theater work in ''Same Time, Next Year'' and an Oscar for the leading role in the film ''Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore.'' She is the first woman to be elected president of the Actors' Equity Association. And in addition to being a gifted actress, she is a writer and lecturer, with two honorary doctoral degrees.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $519,000 for the quarter and $876,000 for the 9 months and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,898,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $145,000 for the quarter and $417,000 for the 9 months.

title: THERMAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split May 1, 1986.

title: Bach for Solo Violin
description: Richard Luby will play the complete sonatas and partitas for solo violin by J. S. Bach at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday night at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: THE DAY AFTER: PATCHWORK AT SHEA
description: On the day after 6,000 fans stormed across Shea Stadium and tore craters in its turf, the Mets patched together their playing field and their lineup yesterday and tried to prepare both for the National League playoff.

title: SYNCOPATIONS WITH FLAVOR FROM HAITI
description: FOR Tabou Combo de Petion-Ville, the world's best-known Haitian band, a Manhattan dance club is a minuscule place to perform. The group is more used to shows like the concert that drew 25,000 people in Paris last May or the one soon afterward for 35,000 people in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. At Haitian clubs in Brooklyn, the band can have thousands of people dancing until dawn. Yet tonight, Tabou Combo will return to the modest confines of Sounds of Brazil in its continuing campaign for hometown recognition.

title: Ex-Syracuse Mayor Testifies in Inquiry
description: Former Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse made a brief appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating his 16-year administration for possible corruption, his attorney said today.

title: Nina Darnton
description: IN ''Blue Velvet,'' which opens today (review on page C12), Dennis Hopper plays a cocaine-snorting psychopath who kidnaps a woman's husband and child to force her to obey his perverse sexual commands. Mr. Hopper won the prize for best actor at the Montreal Film Festival for his chilling performance - a plunge into the depths of sadistic lunacy that many actors would be reluctant to risk. But Mr. Hopper, who has admitted that he himself suffered the ravages of drug and alcohol addiction, is embracing a wide variety of parts with a productive frenzy unequaled in his career as an actor, writer and director. In the last year and a half, he has worked on eight films - more than half the number he made in the 17 years since ''Easy Rider'' catapulted him into the role of symbol and sometime spokesman for the 60's generation.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Are You Getting Cold, Or Is It Just Me?
description: Projected game-time and end-of-game wind-chill figures* for all of the Mets' scheduled postseason home dates:

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW TAX RULES WILL EXEMPT SOME NEW YORK INSTITUTIONS
description: The final tax revision bill exempts dozens of construction projects, companies and universities in New York State from some of the new rules.

title: Festivals and Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture. Today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Feast of San Gennaro, Mulberry Street, lower Manhattan. Food, games, entertainment. Today through Sunday, noon to midnight.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A headline in Sports People yester-day about the trial of Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee, said he had been found guilty of a lesser charge and had avoided a mandatory prison sentence.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The public interest in eliminating drugs in the workplace is substantial, but to invade the privacy of the innocent in order to discover the guilty establishes a dangerous precedent, one which our Constitution mandates be rejected.'' - Judge H. Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court in Newark. [ B2:2. ]

title: AT 2-DAY SYMPOSIUM, IT'S HAIL TO CHIEFS FOR PRATFALLS AND BELLY LAUGHS
description: ''Attending the Gerald R. Ford Symposium on 'Humor and the Presidency,' '' said the comedian Pat Paulsen, ''is sort of like attending the Ayatollah Khomeini Symposium on the sexual revolution.''

title: Knudsen Filing
description: The Knudsen Corporation has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws, just 16 months after acquiring Foremost Dairies of San Francisco to become the biggest dairy in the West. The filing, made in response to an involuntary bankruptcy action filed against Knudsen two months ago by three creditors, enables the company to continue operating while it struggles to repay its debts and resolve other problems. Knudsen is a subsidiary of Los Angeles-based Winn Enterprises.

title: Asia's Long Zithers
description: The Society for Asian Music will present a program devoted to ''The Long Zithers of East Asia'' Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Uris Auditorium.

title: ACID RAIN LAWSUIT REJECTED BY COURT
description: A lawsuit by seven Northeastern states seeking to cut air pollution coming from the Middle West was dismissed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: INSIDE
description: 'WITCHING HOUR' AWAITED Uncertainty surrounds today's ''triple witching hour'' on Wall Street, a quarterly phenomenon linked to wild swings in stock prices.

title: MARXIST CHRISTIANS IN A LEBANESE TOWN: A LINK TO TERROR BOMBING IN PARIS
description: An underground Lebanese group believed to be responsible for a wave of bomb attacks in Paris is made up of Marxist Maronite Christians, most of whom are from a village in northern Lebanon.

title: Soviet Acknowledges Explosion of a Missile
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman acknowledged today that a missile exploded during a test flight last month, but he gave no details other than that it ''did not clear the Soviet border.''

title: This Is Not the Time for a Four-Day Week; Another Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Gains
description: Sixth-seeded John McEnroe, trying to bounce back from his first-round elimination from the United States Open last month, topped Christo Steyn of South Africa, 7-5, 6-3, today in a second-round match of the $315,000 Volvo Tennis-Los Angeles tournament.

title: REAGAN'S VISIT LIFTS ALABAMA G.O.P.
description: President Reagan today sought to rally more than 6,000 listeners here to support Senator Jeremiah Denton. The Alabama Republican's re-election this fall is critical to the party's efforts to keep control of the Senate.

title: Ella Fitzgerald Home From Hospital
description: Ella Fitzgerald was recuperating at her Beverly Hills, Calif., home today after being released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where she had coronary-bypass surgery 15 days ago, a hospital official said.

title: LAWMAKERS HEAR AQUINO ON REBELS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she would continue negotiating with Communist insurgents in the Philippines, but would not hesitate to take up ''the sword of war'' if the talks failed.

title: FOR FRIEDMAN, A DAY OF JOY AND OF DREAD
description: For Stanley M. Friedman, yesterday was one of the bittersweet days: he spent his morning at Bronx Democratic headquarters, savoring his re-election Wednesday night to the post of Bronx Democratic leader, lining up the votes to insure that his candidates were selected in last night's judicial nominating convention, accepting telephone calls from well-wishers.

title: Long Policy of Deals May Have Backfired
description: Amid the fears and uncertainties unleashed by the current spate of bombings, some French people are wondering if their country's longstanding, unstated policy of striking deals with terrorists is coming back to haunt them.

title: People
description: * Jack W. Mascola has been named senior vice president, management supervisor at DFS Dorland/New York.

title: A Shake-Up At Bates?
description: Rumors swept Madison Avenue yesterday that the top three officers of Ted Bates Worldwide - Robert E. Jacoby, the chairman and chief executive; John R. Hoyne, the president, and John N. Nichols, president of Ted Bates/New York - would be dismissed by Bates's new corporate parent, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. A spokesman for Saatchi in

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Delsing, Byrum Post 65's to Lead
description: Jay Delsing eagled two consecutive holes and Tom Byrum made four birdies in succession as both second-year golf pros shot seven-under-par 65's to tie for the first-round lead today in the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Soviet Bid at GATT Talks
description: The Soviet Union's request to participate in a new round of trade liberalization talks was put forward by Czechoslovakia at a global trade conference here, but it is likely to be rebuffed, officials reported.

title: Massachusetts G.O.P. Victor Says He'll Keep Word to Yield
description: Gregory Hyatt, who won the Republican Party's primary election for Governor even though he had dropped out of the race, says he will be true to his word and allow George Kariotis to top the ticket in November.

title: 'OTHER' BACK MAY STEAL SHOW
description: The thought occurred to Gerald Riggs the other day that the best running back in Texas Stadium Sunday, when the Dallas Cowboys play the Atlanta Falcons, might not necessarily be Tony Dorsett or Herschel Walker of the Cowboys.

title: Mobil Oil Notes
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation is offering $100 million of 7 5/8 percent notes due in 1991, at a price of 100, to yield 7.625 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The five-year notes are not callable before maturity and are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: It might be called artistic justice.

title: YEMENITE TRADITIONS INSPIRED INBAL DANCERS
description: In 1948, the entire Jewish community of Yemen was flown from its old home in the southwest corner of the Arabian peninsula to the newly established state of Israel. The Yemenite Jews had lived in isolation from the rest of the Jewish world for 2,500 years. When they were relocated, their dance and music attracted the attention of an Israeli kindergarten teacher, who was so fascinated that in 1949 she formed Inbal, a company rooted in Yemenite folklore and now one of Israel's best-known dance troupes.

title: Mortgage Obligations
description: New issues of collateralized mortgage obligations continue to offer investors much higher yields than are available in the Treasury market or on other AAA-rated corporate securities.

title: Dollar Off After Baker Comments
description: The dollar dropped sharply against most foreign currencies yesterday after Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was quoted as saying that its value might have to come down to help reduce the nation's trade deficit.

title: Prudential P.L.C. To Buy Jackson
description: The Jackson National Life Insurance Company of Lansing, Mich., said it had agreed to be acquired by the Prudential Corporation P.L.C. of England for $51 a share, or about $608 million.

title: Smuggling of Aliens Laid To Air Force Family
description: An Air Force officer, his wife and two children were charged in a Federal indictment today with conspiring to smuggle illegal aliens from the Dominican Republic into the United States.

title: An Einstein Appeal
description: While Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union are meeting today, demonstrators from a half-dozen peace organizations will hold a rally a block away in front of a memorial to Albert Einstein outside the National Academy of Sciences. A poster for the event lists the theme as ''Test Peace, Not Bombs'' and quotes Einstein: ''You cannot simultaneously prepare for war and peace.''

title: ELDERS DEAL FOR BREWER
description: Elders IXL Ltd., an Australian brewing and trading company, said today that it had agreed to buy the Courage brewing unit of Hanson Trust P.L.C. of Britain for the equivalent of $2.07 billion.

title: Antibias Plans Said to Aid Cities
description: The United States Conference of Mayors said today that affirmative action programs had improved the efficiency and productivity of cities' work forces.

title: U.S. POLICY ON AIR BAGS WITHSTANDS A TEST IN FEDERAL COURT
description: A three-judge Federal panel said today that it was highly unlikely that a rule on passive restraints for automobiles would be rescinded.

title: ART: 2 DISPLAYS OF GAUGUIN, IN U.S. AND FRANCE
description: Not quite three weeks remain in which to see the great room of paintings by Paul Gauguin that is part of the exhibition of Impressionists and early modern paintings from the Soviet Union at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. Initially, perhaps these paintings were overshadowed by the rooms of Matisse and Picasso that bring the show to a close. The United States is rich, after all, in fine paintings by Gauguin but the ensembles of Matisse and Picasso in the show at the Met have no exact parallel (among paintings of their date) anywhere.

title: Dome Seeks Delay
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. has asked its lenders to agree to delay payment of their debts, rather than force the company into liquidation, which it characterized as the other alternative. Dome's proposal, as expected, also calls for lenders to accept new securities indexed to the price of crude oil. Talks with lenders will begin late this month and continue into October, Dome said.

title: F.S.L.I.C. SAYS FUNDS COULD FALL TO ALL-TIME LOW
description: The resources of the Government's agency that insures $844 billion in deposits at the nation's thrift institutions will fall to a dangerous all-time low of $1 billion by year-end unless legislation is passed to inject new money into the beleaguered fund, its chairman, Edwin J. Gray, said today.

title: LAWYER IS THE SURPRISE CHOICE TO FILL POST AT UNIVERSAL FILMS
description: To the surprise of the movie industry, an entertainment lawyer who has never produced a picture or worked as a studio executive was named chairman of MCA's Universal Motion Picture Group today.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Volatile Market Amid Stability
description: DESPITE the high volatility of the stock market, most economists consider the American economy far more stable today than it was before World War II. The new Commerce Department figures on gross national product, adjusted for inflation, appear to support the view that the critical problem facing the economy is not instability but sluggish or ''subnormal'' growth.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING NEW PRICING LAW
description: Pentagon auditors asked Congress today for new legal weapons in the fight against defective pricing, saying they had found overcharges in half the military contracts examined in 1985.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Thanks but No Thanks
description: Because Republican and conservative organizations tend to have more money to spend on fund-raising mailings than their Democratic and liberal counterparts, they send out more letters and more of them wind up in the mailboxes of ideological opponents. But sometimes it works the other way.

title: Burroughs Account Is Landed by Y.&R.
description: The Burroughs Corporation yesterday awarded its account to Young & Rubicam. Billings were estimated at $50 million, giving Y.&R. another big win in what has been the agency's hottest year ever for new business. Y.&R. has added $535 million in billings worldwide since the beginning of 1986.

title: EXPELLED RUSSIANS ARE TERMED SPIES
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the 25 members of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations who must leave by Oct. 1 are senior intelligence officers.

title: TOP DRUG AGENT CHIDES CONGRESS ON BORDER PLAN
description: The head of the Federal Government's main antidrug enforcement agency said yesterday that law enforcement alone would not solve the nation's drug problems and chided Congress for its recent proposals to use the military to stop drug smugglers at the borders.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: The share earnings reflect adjustment for a 2-for-1 stock split, effective July 10.

title: SOVIET EMBASSY WELCOMES KANSANS AND MESSAGE
description: Just before 9:30 o'clock this morning, the iron gates of the Soviet Embassy swung open to admit 11 Americans, not diplomats, not scholars, not experts in the tense play of relations between the superpowers, but just well-intentioned people from Lawrence, Kan., who wanted to deliver a simple message.

title: Photographer Testifies
description: Arthur Seitz, the freelance photographer who is suing Martina Navratilova, testified in State Supreme Court in Riverhead, L.I., yesterday that security guards stood by as he was assaulted by the tennis player and her friend Nancy Lieberman, the basketball player, after Ms. Navratilova was eliminated from the 1982 United States Open. The trial also encompasses a countersuit in which Ms. Navratilova charges the photographer invaded her privacy.

title: Comeback for Meyer?
description: Ray Meyer, the 72-year-old former basketball coach at DePaul, has said he would consider coaching again, preferably at a medium-sized school. In an interview with WMAQ-AM in Chicago, Meyer, who retired after the 1983-84 season with 724 vicories in 42 years, said he would listen to offers and ''it would have to be someone who has a program that they wanted to go upward with.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ST. LOUIS (NL) - Announced that John Tudor, pitcher, would miss the rest of the season because of a sore shoulder.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago Bulls have traded Kyle Macy, a veteran guard, to the Indiana Pacers for second-round draft choices in 1988 and either 1990 or 1992. ''With the Bulls backcourt of Michael Jordan, newly acquired Steve Colter and John Paxson, we felt we could afford to let Kyle go for future draft picks,'' said the team's vice president, Jerry Krause. . . . Akron's new football coach, Gerry Faust, learned yesterday that he had suffered a fractured left leg last Monday when he was knocked down accidentally during kickoff drills by Darryl Robinson, a linebacker, just five minutes after the former Notre Dame coach had reprimanded Robinson for failing to attend classes. . . . Jay Brophy returned to the Miami Dolphins just two and a half weeks after being let go. The Dolphins were forced to recall the linebacker because of the sudden retirement of another linebacker, Jack Squirek. . . . Mitchell Green, the heavyweight boxer, was arrested in the Bronx and charged with drunken driving early yesterday morning after his 1980 Lincoln struck another vehicle, the police said.

title: People Express Capital Raised
description: People Express Inc. said yesterday that under its acquisition agreement with the Texas Air Corporation, it would have working capital of up to $100 million to draw on until it becomes part of one of Texas Air's subsidiaries.

title: NEW GAMBIT IN ENDGAME AIDS KARPOV
description: An endgame nuance backed up with deadly skill brought Anatoly Karpov a victory in the 17th game of the world championship chess match Wednesday in Leningrad. But the 35-year-old former titleholder still trails in the contest, having 7 1/2 points to Gary Kasparov's 9 1/2.

title: SALLY CLARKE CARTY
description: Sally Clarke Carty, an editor and writer, died Tuesday at her home in Larchmont, N.Y. She was 59 years old and also maintained a residence on Nantucket.

title: FILM FESTIVAL VIBRATES WITH MUSICAL ACCENTS
description: WHEN the 1986 New York Film Festival is remembered, it may well be counted as a milestone in which movies began to take inspiration directly from the cutting edges of the rock and jazz worlds. In four of the festival's most eagerly awaited entries - ''Down by Law,'' ''Round Midnight,'' ''Sid and Nancy'' and ''True Stories'' - a bohemian musical sensibility saturates the very fabric of the film. Pop music, of course, is more crucial an ingredient than ever in mainstream movie making, but as often as not, its integration into Hollywood films amounts to a noisy, meretricious captioning of teen-age emotion. These four films, by contrast, are in their very different ways deeply inspirited by musical imagination.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The tumultuous decline in the stock market last week appears to have aided money market mutual funds. The assets of the nation's 363 money market mutual funds increased $3.9 billion, to $239.3 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; What 'Post-Feminism' Really Means
description: Among people who use the term ''post-feminism,'' there seem to be two schools of thought. The first holds that women went rampaging off to work only to discover that they were cheating home and family. The second holds that women went rampaging off to work only to discover that work wasn't so great after all.

title: New Chip From Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. stepped up its increasingly heated race with the Intel Corporation yesterday, introducing a new generation of microprocessors that it said could put the power of a mainframe computer on a single chip. The new chip, called the

title: PACT GIVES U.S. ACCESS TO DATA IN DRUG HAVEN
description: The United States signed an agreement today giving Federal prosecutors access to the once-secret bank records of drug smugglers who keep their money in a chain of eastern Caribbean islands.

title: Portraits of Israelis
description: Photographs of prominent Israeli archeologists, businessmen, journalists and sculptors taken by the American photographer Mariana Cook will be on display beginning Tuesday, at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street.

title: Northwest Air
description: Northwest Airlines is laying off nearly 800 employees and forcing hundreds more to relocate because of the carrier's merger with Republic Airlines, union officials say. Layoff notices have been sent to mechanics, baggage handlers and station agents, according to Guy Cook, president of the International Association of Machinists. A Northwest spokesman, William Wren, said there would be layoffs but would not specify a number.

title: Dow Up 4.78 Points, To 1,774.18
description: With Wall Street uncertain whether stock prices were going up or down, investors focused on things such as takeovers, hoping to make profits regardless of the overall market's direction.

title: UNION PACIFIC TO GO EAST BY BUYING OUT TRUCKER
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, the nation's third-largest railroad, announced yesterday that it was buying the Overnite Transportation Company, the nation's fifth-largest trucking company, for $1.2 billion in cash.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1986
description: Markets

title: CUOMO QUESTIONS DYSON SENATE BID
description: Governor Cuomo today urged John S. Dyson, who is running for the United States Senate on the Liberal line, to consider the results of a new poll that shows little support for Mr. Dyson in the three-way race.

title: Jarmusch's 'Paradise'
description: While Jim Jarmusch's new film ''Down by Law'' opens the New York Film Festival tonight, the director's earlier film ''Stranger Than Paradise'' will begin a one-week run at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street.

title: Nabisco Move Is Challenged
description: The Kellogg Company, the world's leading producer of ready-to-eat cereals, said yesterday that it had moved to protect its cereal secrets by obtaining a temporary restraining order against Nabisco Brands Inc. and a former employee.

title: L.I. Teachers Return to Work
description: After a one-day walkout, 110 teachers in the Cold Spring Harbor School District returned to classrooms this morning.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The 1985 share earnings have been restated to reflect the 4 percent stock dividend paid in June 1986.

title: PEPITONE RELIEVED, BITTER ABOUT TRIAL
description: A day after he was found not guilty of a drug charge that carried a penalty of at least 15 years in prison, Joe Pepitone was able to laugh at the prospect of growing old behind bars.

title: RENTAL BUILDING IN QUEENS SHOWS ADROIT USE OF SITE
description: Property susceptible to redevelopment is not easily come by in the Forest Hills section of Queens. But occasionally, even in locations zoned for midrise construction and almost fully built that way already, a relatively small ''infill'' plot goes on the market. Small builders take notice. Franklin Baharestani, who lives in Forest Hills, and his brother, George, took notice two years ago when the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind was trying to sell a single-family house it owned a block north of Queens Boulevard at the corner of 72d Avenue and 110th Street.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF CHIRAC REMARKS
description: Following is a transcript of a nationwide television address in Paris yesterday by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. It was simultaneously translated for CNN in Washington by Dr. Harris Coulter, a freelance interpreter.

title: G.N.P. RISE OF JUST 0.6% CONFIRMED
description: The nation's economy grew a mere six-tenths of 1 percent in the three months ended June 30 and 2.2 percent in the first half of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''IT'S amazing what they did in their times,'' said Iris Cantor, who was looking at an 8,000-year-old clay sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''But then again I guess they would say the same thing about us.''

title: Enough U.N.-Bashing
description: United Nations-bashing, an increasingly popular sport in the Administration, the Congress and a large segment of the public, has gotten out of hand. Unless all sides step back and rethink where they are going, crippling - perhaps fatal - damage will be inflicted on an organization that once was held as mankind's last best hope for peace.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHEN THE WAR WAS OVER: The Voices of Cambodia's Revolution and Its People. By Elizabeth Becker. Illustrated. 502 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Stopping Drug Abuse in a Pill-Popping Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: A LOOK AT 'TELEVISION'S IMPACT'
description: WE may as well admit it -one of the biggest influences on art in the last 25 years has been television. Artists have always been quick to join what they can't lick, and what they did more than a century ago with photography they are now doing with the electronic screen. They appropriate and alter its ready-made imagery, and get behind the camera to make their own. They do paintings and sculptures that incorporate both screen and set. And they invent new ways of working with television technology. In short, they have met the medium, and it is theirs.

title: DONALD ANDERSON
description: Donald H. Anderson, a professional trumpet player for 50 years who was a member of the original Spike Jones Band, died Wednesday.

title: Nigerian Cabinet Is Shuffled; Three New Ministers Named
description: Three new ministers were named today by Nigeria's military leader in a Cabinet shake-up involving six departments.

title: O'ROURKE, IN CAMPAIGN, FEATURES 3 KEY THEMES
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, took ''my friend Mario'' on commuter and subway trains and to a fund-raising event yesterday to dramatize the three major thrusts of his campaign in the six weeks before Election Day.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Imperial Chemical Consolidation
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, the giant British chemical company, said it planned to consolidate four of its chemical businesses into a new European group that would have sales of about $:3.5 billion, or $5.2 billion, a year.

title: STAGE: FROM SOUTH AFRICA, 'BOHPA!'
description: AT a time when each morning's front page intensifies one's sorrowful perception of the galloping tragedy of apartheid, it's hard to imagine how a play from black South Africa could leave a theatergoer cold. Such, however, is the sad case with ''Bopha!,'' the painfully sincere, yet just as painfully tedious, second entry in Lincoln Center's monthlong festival of South African drama. As the festival's previous offering, ''Asinamali!,'' proved only last week, theatrical vitality can impart new urgency to familiar battlecries of protest. ''Bopha!,'' by contrast, is a demonstration that wan agitprop drama can make even the most pressing and unassailable moral imperatives sound as numbing as a politician's empty slogans.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a charge of $4.3 million for the loss of investment tax credits resulting from anticipated tax law changes.

title: BERGDORF'S PARTY TOASTS PULITZER FOUNTAIN
description: Pomona, goddess of abundance, the sculpture that stands atop the once-cascading pools of the Pulitzer Fountain in Grand Army Plaza, is looking a little threadbare these days.

title: A.T.&T. Plan For Layoffs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it planned to reduce the number of lower- and middle-level managers by offering them money to quit.

title: MAN IS CLEARED IN FATAL SHOOTING OF YOUTH ON F TRAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: A grand jury in Brooklyn voted yesterday not to indict a man who was arrested a week ago in the fatal shooting of a teen-ager during a confrontation on subway train in 1980.

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS URINE DRUG TESTS
description: A Federal judge ruled today that mandatory urine testing of government employees to determine the presence of illegal drugs was an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.

title: On 'Campaign Economics'
description: During the next two months we will be treated to a brand of economics different from the normal varieties (Keynesian, monetarist, supply-side, etc.). It is called Campaign Economics. It is no more or less useful than the others, but it has one unique attribute. Its core ideas are universally popular. People who advocate them are sure to be admired, applauded, regarded as thoughtful and bold. They may even be elected to office.

title: JETS MUST OUTWIT A ROOKIE
description: The Miami Dolphins, a club historically top heavy with veterans, have a 22-year-old rookie from an obscure school calling the defensive signals.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 154 yen equals U.S. $1, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of July 31, 1986. The share earnings represent American Depositary Share and each A.D.S. represents one share of common stock.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY AQUINO BEFORE CONGRESS
description: Following are excerpts from an address by President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines to a joint meeting of Congress today:

title: U.S. REPORT SAYS HARLEM HOSPITAL FELL BELOW STANDARDS IN SIX AREAS
description: Harlem Hospital fails to meet Federal standards in emergency care, nursing, fire safety, cleanliness and other areas, according to the results of a federally commissioned investigation disclosed yesterday.

title: DEFENSE REORGANIZATION: NEW BILL CENTRALIZES AUTHORITY AT THE JOINT CHIEFS
description: The passage of the defense reorganization bill on Wednesday marks a major shift in the way the United States provides for the common defense. It is a victory for those who have argued that the Joint Chiefs of Staff system, which has existed in its current form since 1958, has hindered the efficient planning and conduct of joint military operations such as the aborted attempt to rescue the Iranian hostages in 1980 and the invasion of Grenada in 1983.

title: RUMORS PERSIST ON FLATLEY TRADE
description: This season, the Islanders have promised change. Rather than try to simulate the squad that captured four consecutive Stanley Cups between 1980 and 1983, the thought is to forget the past and build a contender - from scratch, if need be.

title: SCHEDULE AND TICKET AVAILABILITY
description: The 24th New York Film Festval opens tonight at Lincoln Center - with two screenings of ''Down by Law'' and a gala afterward at Tavern on the Green -and closes Oct. 5. All films, unless otherwise indicated, are at Alice Tully Hall. Opening and closing nights and some other screenings are sold out. Available tickets for performances, at $6 and $8, can be obtained at the Tully Hall box office (362-1911). Here is a schedule of the films: Tonight ''Down by Law'' (United States). Jim Jarmusch's tale of three men on the lam in the Louisiana bayou. Tully Hall, 7:45 P.M. Avery Fisher Hall, 9 P.M. Both shows sold out.

title: Perth Smuggling Sentences
description: A judge sentenced an American and two Swiss to seven and a half years' imprisonment for smuggling marijuana. The American, Langdon Wade Breur, and the Swiss, Bernhard Arnold Steck and Urs Alfred Peter, pleaded guilty to importing 3,913 pounds of marijuana.

title: Bedford to Meet Suns
description: William Bedford, the 7-foot center from Memphis State who was chosen sixth in the National Basketball Association draft, may become the highest-paid rookie in Phoenix Suns' history on Monday. Jerry Colangelo, the general manager, said the Suns had made flight reservations for Bedford from Chicago to Phoenix tomorrow in anticipation of a contract signing Monday.

title: U.S. EXPERT DOUBTS SOVIET ON CHERNOBYL'S EFFECTS
description: A Federal health expert said today that residents within 18 miles of the ruined Chernobyl nuclear plant in the Soviet Union could have more than four times the normal number of thyroid cancers because of excess radiation from the April 26 accident.

title: Bridge; Pakistani Team in Semifinals Along With Three From U.S.
description: Three American groups and a squad from Pakistan squared off here this afternoon in the semifinal of the world knockout team championship. The Pakistan team is headed by Zia Mahmood and includes Jan-e-Alam Fazli, Nisar Ahmed, Nishat Abedi and Mohamed Zakaris. All but Zakaris placed second in the 1981 world team championship.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1986
description: International The case of the American journalist detained in Moscow was discussed by President Reagan in an unscheduled meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, in which he expressed ''the strength of his feelings'' over the Soviet Union's refusal to allow Nicholas S. Daniloff to return to the United States, the White House said. There appeared to be no break in the case. Instead, the Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze surprised the American side by delivering a letter to Mr. Reagan containing the official response from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to Mr. Reagan's wide-ranging letter on arms control issues that was sent in late July. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Ministers of major nations agreed on a global undertaking to ease national restrictions on international trade in such services as banking, insurance and shipping. Procedural discussions at the trade meeting in Uruguay continued into the evening on a final accord to set the agenda for the postwar era's eighth round of trade liberalization, but most delegates expressed optimism that a final agreement would be reached by the 74 participating nations. [ 1:3. ] Cheers greeted Corazon C. Aquino on her visit to New York City. The cheers broke out in welcoming ceremonies at City Hall where the President of the Philippines was presented with a key to the city by Mayor Koch. The visit to City Hall was one of a number of major events on Mrs. Aquino's schedule. She delivered a speech at New York University, and was scheduled to address a meeting of the Philippine-American Chamber of Commerce.

title: AMERICAN DELTA TO FLY TO TOKYO
description: The Transportation Department today gave Delta Air Lines and American Airlines permission to fly to Tokyo and chose Portland, Ore., and Dallas/ Fort Worth as the two cities from which the carriers will offer service.

title: That Awesome Cloth
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, whose religion-and-business empire in Virginia is said to gross $230 million per annum, is itching to run for President.

title: HAWAII GIRDS FOR PIVOTAL VOTE TODAY
description: Beneath a tropical sun, scores of smiling, sign-waving Hawaiians shout at passing cars on the Kalanianaole Highway here nearly every morning. Elsewhere in town, Patsy T. Mink, a former United States Representative, waves at rush-hour commuters from another street corner, campaigning to become Hawaii's next Governor.

title: LILCO TO ASK $80 MILLION FOR SHOREHAM'S COSTS
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, seeking to recover costs for the Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant, will apply for a rate increase of approximately $80 million in November, a company spokesman said today.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ARCHITECTURE: DRAWINGS WITH A HINT OF VERSAILLES
description: The Bourbons, according to the French statesman Talleyrand, learned nothing and forgot nothing from the French Revolution. The drawings now on view at the Max Protetch Gallery, 37 West 57th Street, seem to show that, similarly, the Barcelona architect Ricardo Bofill and his office, Taller de Arquitectura, have learned and forgotten nothing from the Modernist revolution that overthrew the Classical regime this century. The drawings represent a kind of restoration - an architectural return to the style of Versailles.

title: BROTHER JONATHAN, PLAYWRIGHT
description: Jonathan Ringkamp, a Franciscan brother and a playwright, died yesterday of pneumonia in Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and was a member of the Franciscan Brothers of Brooklyn.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Woody Bennett, the eight-year fullback, walked out of the Miami Dolphins camp in what team officials said is a contract renegotiation dispute. Bennett, a 6-2, 225-pound eight-year veteran, is in the option year of his contract. . . . The World Boxing Council announced that it would vote to decide whether John Mugabi or Duane Thomas would hold the superwelterweight title left vacant by Thomas Hearns.

title: English Train Collision Leaves 2 Dead, 60 Hurt
description: Two high-speed trains filled with weekend commuters collided today in central England, and the police said 2 people were killed and 60 injured, 36 of them seriously.

title: Helping Put a Visitor In Fine Feather
description: A lot of odd birds have been seen on Lexington Avenue at 57th Street, but this was probably the first time anybody had sighted a wild American bittern on the sidewalks of midtown Manhattan.

title: STATE INCREASING EFFORT TO HALT SURGE IN FARMING OF MARIJUANA
description: The huge cornfields that flourish in this town of about 1,200 residents near the Vermont border have been yielding a bumper crop lately - marijuana plants.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 9 months includes a pre-tax writedown of oil and gas properties of $1,209,000.

title: THREE ARE SLAIN IN 'CRACK DEN' OWNED BY CITY
description: Two men and a woman were shot to death yesterday morning in a dispute over drugs in a run-down city-owned apartment building in Harlem known to the police as a ''crack den,'' the police said.

title: A REPORT OF POISONED ASPIRIN TURNS OUT TO BE ERRONEOUS
description: A report that three house-brand aspirin tablets sold by a Rite Aid drugstore had been laced with cyanide proved to be false, state health officials said today. Store officials immediately lifted all sales restrictions on the product.

title: In Haiti, Justice is Ramshackle and in Need of Money
description: The obstacles that Haiti must overcome to build a democracy seem overwhelming. After 29 years of an oppressive dictatorship, the country has been left with severe shortages of physical and human resources. It is true that several countries have increased their level of aid to Haiti since the overthrow of Jean-Claude Duvalier. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, for example, recently signed agreements designed to improve law enforcement (aimed largely at the drug trade), encourage private sector investment and help Haiti meet its balance of payment requirements.

title: ONE-WAY BRIDGE TOLL EXPERIMENT ENDS TODAY, BUT NOT CONTROVERSY
description: A six-month experiment creating one-way tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge ends today, with its future undecided and arguments continuing over its impact on bridge revenues and traffic in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: From Brazil, 'Malandro' Recalls 40's Hollywood
description: She's dressed like the schoolgirl Gigi, but she's singing a samba. The group of white-suited hoodlums (''Now the hood is back on the street prancing on tiptoe, that's his way...'') is supposed to be dancing in formation, but each moves in a slightly different direction. The gangster hero delivers one of his longer musical soliloquies in a men's room, sashaying past the row of urinals. No doubt about it: if the Brazilian film ''Malandro'' has the look of a '40's big-studio musical, it's also got more than a few idiosyncrasies.

title: A YEAR AFTER QUAKE, MEXICO CITY IS ON THE MEND
description: Amid tears and prayers and official speeches and ceremonies, Mexicans commemorated the pain and mourning wrought by the earthquake that shattered this city one year ago today.

title: Bond Prices Decline Sharply
description: Bond prices fell sharply early yesterday and hovered near those low levels for the remainder of the day. Traders said investor selling was unrelenting, with little buying appetite.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Harriman's Body Kept In Crypt as Plot Is Dug
description: Although a grave was dug and a funeral service held, the body of former Gov. W. Averell Harriman was not interred. It has instead been placed in a crypt while a grave is prepared on the family's property in Orange County.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Robertson Bio on Way
description: Ronald L. Goldfarb, a Washington lawyer who represents many literary clients, is auctioning a book on the life of the latest (perhaps) Presidential candidate, the Rev. Pat Robertson. It is an unauthorized biography being written by a freelancer, Lee Michael Katz, whose previous effort was ''My Name Is Geraldine Ferraro.''

title: PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREAT COUNTRY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: There are no share earnings for 1985 because the company converted from a mutual savings bank to a capital stock savings bank on Jan. 14, 1986, with the issuance of 2,185,000 shares of common stock.

title: Tennessee Fuel Unit Raises Safety Dispute
description: Representative Edward J. Markey says a nuclear fuel plant in Tennessee is endangering its workers through radioactive contamination. The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Vice Adm.

title: Kidder Shifts Management
description: As expected, Kidder, Peabody & Company, the investment banking subsidiary of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that it had formed a new holding company and made several management changes.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PETRY LEADS TIGERS AS YANKS LOSE, 8-3
description: There is no pretense now about miracle finishes. The Yankees will spend the final days of the 1986 season trying to avoid looking up to any team other than the Red Sox. And that may be more difficult than they envisioned.

title: ROBERT ALLEN BERGER
description: Robert Allen Berger, a dancer, choreographer and director of regional theater, died at his Manhattan home Friday of heart failure.

title: RALSTON IN NEGOTIATIONS FOR ANDERSON, CLAYTON
description: Anderson, Clayton, the Houston-based food and consumer products company, and the Ralston Purina Company disclosed today that they are negotiating for Ralston to acquire Anderson, Clayton.

title: 4 RAIDERS SAID TO BUY USX STOCK
description: Four of the shrewdest corporate raiders were said yesterday to be accumulating shares in the USX Corporation - the old United States Steel Corporation - sending the stock price up again in extremely heavy trading.

title:
PATENTS;
Boll Weevil Trap
description: A boll weevil trap that captures the tiny beetles that infest cotton plants has been invented for the Department of Agriculture by Willard A. Dickerson, an employee in Raleigh, N.C. Patent No. 4,611,425 was granted. The trap is a wire mesh funnel with a capture chamber. Licenses to manufacture it will be available from the department in Washington.

title: When Marlboro Men Go to Japan
description: In downtown Tokyo a pack of Marlboros sells for 280 yen, about $1.80. That was the price a year ago too, when 280 yen was worth only $1.40. Instead of boosting America's export sales, the declining dollar only boosts the profit margins of the American cigarette makers who hound Washington to punish Japan for import restrictions.

title:
PATENTS;
Antibodies Produced For Cancer Treatment
description: The production of monoclonal antibodies that aid in the diagnosis and treatment of human breast cancer was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Queens Man Killed in Blast At a Westchester Water Tank
description: A water tank exploded here this afternoon, killing one North Salem town employee and injuring two others as they painted the inside walls of the tank, the state police said.

title: TEXAS AIR TRANSFER OF SLOTS COMPLETED
description: The Texas Air Corporation said it had completed the previously announced transfer of 75 takeoff and landing slots at New York's La Guardia Airport and Washington's National Airport to the Pan Am Corporation for $60.7 million.

title: MARYLAND POLICE CATCH SUSPECT IN QUEENS RAPE
description: A suspect in a ''particularly vicious'' rape and stabbing of a woman in Far Rockaway, Queens, was arrested yesterday morning after an all-night manhunt by 200 Maryland police officers during which four officers were shot.

title: Triangle Industries
description: An investment group led by a New York businessman, George Soros, has purchased a 12.3 percent stake, or 738,500 shares, in Triangle Industries.

title: Prognosis for Balboni
description: Steve Balboni, the Kansas City Royals' first baseman who had been told Wednesday by the physician for the California Angels that he was suffering from two ruptured disks, has not been experiencing the usual symptoms of such a back problem, according to two team doctors.

title: CASA BLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $205,000 and $366,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $2,800,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: UNPAID PARKING TICKETS
description: THE sun is shining. The car is parked in a legal spot. And there have been no parking tickets on it since the last one was paid months ago. Life as a New York motorist seems pretty good.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $325,000.

title: O'Rourke Is to Release Tax Data for 22 Years
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, is preparing 22 years of past income-tax returns in an effort to satisfy Governor Cuomo's conditions for a debate, O'Rourke aides said yesterday. The 22 years represents his time in public life.

title: Homelessness in New York Isn't Inevitable
description: Those who busy themselves compiling lists of the best and worst aspects of our extraordinary city would have little difficulty designating the welfare hotel as a prime candidate for the negative list. Large-scale coverage in the media has ingrained an unforgettable image of thousands of homeless families packed into these dismal but expensive places.

title: METS RALLY IN 9TH BUT FALL TO PHILS
description: The Mets finished their most important task three nights ago, so it hardly matters that they stumbled at Shea Stadium last night and lost to the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-3. Consider that their lineup was generously filled with rookies and backups, many of whom are unlikely to be seen once the National League playoff begins next month.

title: COURT SAYS LAW DOESN'T REQUIRE BROADCASTING'S FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel ruled today that a key fairness policy governing the broadcast industry is not required by law.

title: GORBACHEV SEEKS A TREATY AT SUMMIT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev again specified the Soviet Union's conditions today for a summit conference, saying his second meeting with President Reagan would have to result in an arms treaty.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Shifts at State Dept.
description: Word from Foggy Bottom is that William Schneider Jr., who has developed a reputation as an effective negotiator with members of Congress, will be leaving his post in the State Department as Under Secretary for security assistance, science and technology. That post ranks No. 5 in the department, and Mr. Schneider is reported to be leaving it to take a position with a consulting company in New York.

title: M. Stanley Livingston; Atom-Smasher Builder
description: M. Stanley Livingston, a nuclear physicist who built the first working atom-smasher, died Aug. 25 in Santa Fe, N.M., where he had lived in recent years. He was 81 years old.

title: PHILIPPINE AID PLAN FACING UNCERTAINTY ON THE SENATE FLOOR
description: A new package of economic aid for the Philippines, which the House of Representatives approved Thursday within hours of President Corazon C. Aquino's visit, faces an uncertain future in the Senate.

title: Microfilm Is for Keeps
description: To the Editor:

title: Knudsen-Foremost Loan Bid Denied
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has denied Knudsen and Foremost Dairies operations a $5 million loan they termed essential to their continued operation. The companies, which are owned by Los Angeles-based Winn Enterprises, filed for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws on Wednesday.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $133,000.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net income The losses in the latest periods reflect an $18 million pre-tax writedown of certain restaurant properties.

title: Maurice Pialat's 'Police' With Gerard Depardieu
description: Character is even more truly action in Maurice Pialat's films than in most, since his central figures are so rarely given over to introspection. They are active and talkative, but they seldom stop to analyze. Nor does the director, and he also refrains from bringing any judgments to bear upon what these people do. The audience must watch and listen and think for itself about the lives of, say, an aimless, promiscuous teen-age girl from a combative family (Sandrine Bonnaire in ''A Nos Amours'') or a loutish, lady-killing scoundrel (Gerard Depardieu in ''Loulou'').

title: GOLDEN NUGGET KEEPS LICENSE, WITH CONDITIONS
description: The Casino Control Commission today renewed the Golden Nugget's license to operate a casino in Atlantic City, but imposed conditions intended to guard against the hiring of key employees with links to organized crime.

title: MARKET FALLS A BIT IN UNEVENTFUL DAY
description: The anticipation was worse than the event yesterday on Wall Street as stock prices declined, but not by a large amount, during the feared ''triple witching hour.''

title: CHEERS AND AID WELCOME AQUINO TO NEW YORK
description: President Corazon C. Aquino was triumphantly welcomed back yesterday to the city where she went to college, garnering tributes from Mayor Koch and drawing emotional cheers from enraptured New Yorkers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Sept. 2 about the Manhattan Borough President, David Dinkins, and an article on July 19 about the Board of Estimate's approval of an apartment tower proposed by Ian Bruce Eichner, gave an incorrect location for the 21-story building. It will be built on the west side of Broadway between 86th and 87th Street, not between 85th and 86th Street.

title: HANOVER COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain from tax loss carryforwards of $998,000.

title: Michigan a Disaster Area
description: President Reagan on Thursday declared Michigan a disaster area because of storms and flooding that killed five people and caused damage to 13,000 homes beginning on Sept. 10. The action was announced by the White House as the President was campaigning here. The Federal Emergency Management Agency immediately designated people in 22 Michigan counties eligible for Federal disaster aid and said application centers will be opened in the flood-damaged region within about four days.

title: Shuttle Loses Satellite Accord
description: Intelsat, the 112-nation communications cooperative that originally planned to launch a series of five huge satellites from the space shuttle, has decided to hire the European Ariane rocket to deploy the first three because future commercial shuttle missions are in doubt.

title: Ethnic America Day
description: The first Ethnic America Day is being marked tomorrow with 18 awards that celebrate the diversity of the nation, the recipients having been selected by various ethnic organizations.

title: Soviet Deserter Reported To Get 12-Year Sentence
description: A human-rights group said today that a Soviet soldier who deserted in Afghanistan, went to the United States and later decided to return home had been sentenced to 12 years in a labor camp.

title: Stun-Gun Allegations At Day Care Center
description: Ten children, including four babies, were punished with shocks from a 50,000-volt stun gun at a day care center here, the police said Friday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Chicago dispatch yesterday on the gubernatorial campaign of Adlai E. Stevenson 3d misstated his age. He will be 56 on Oct. 10.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Canandaigua Wine Co., Canandaigua, N.Y., said it had reached an understanding in principle with Monarch Wine Co. of New York to buy Monarch's wine business, including its Manischewitz brands. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch yesterday from Montgomery, Ala., on campaigning by President Reagan in Alabama and Louisiana, misstated the date of the Lousiana election. It is Sept. 27, not today.

title: MARK HIRAM HAWLEY, RADIO ANNOUNCER, DIES
description: Mark Hiram Hawley, who at age 19 became the announcer for Guy Lombardo's first New Year's Eve broadcast on CBS, died Sept. 5 of a heart attack in his home in San Jacinto, Calif. He was 76 years old. Mr. Hawley's career in broadcasting, from the late 1920's to the mid-1950's, spanned the heyday of radio and the development of network television. He came to New York in 1929 from station WMAK near Buffalo at the request of William S. Paley, the president of CBS. Mr. Paley hired Mr. Hawley to broadcast a New Year's Eve program from the Roosevelt Hotel featuring a Canadian band leader named Guy Lombardo and his band, the Royal Canadians.

title: Little Brown Jug To Barberry Spur
description: Barberry Spur captured the second jewel in pacing's triple crown today, winning the Little Brown Jug at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.

title: EAST AND WEST REPORTED NEAR ACCORD ON SECURITY
description: Diplomats from NATO and the Warsaw Pact said tonight that, after nearly three years of protracted negotiation, they were close to a historic new security agreement intended to prevent either of the two military alliances from launching a surprise attack in Europe.

title: Your Money; Fixed-Income Stock Play
description: NEW stock market-linked debt securities that give individual investors the assurance of a fixed income, along with the potential for capital appreciation, have made an appearance in the American financial markets.

title: HOUSE VOTES, 329 to 4, TO TOUGHEN ENVIRONMENTAL LAW ON PESTICIDES
description: The House of Representatives today voted, 329 to 4, to strengthen the law protecting public health and the environment from chemical pesticides.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Coopervision To Sell Unit
description: Coopervision Inc., a leading eye care company, said today that it had agreed to sell its Richards Medical Company orthopedics division to Smith & Nephew Associated Companies of London, a maker of medical and personal hygiene products, for about $284 million. The agreement is subject to Smith & Nephew shareholder approval and is expected to be completed by the end of October.

title: ARLINGTON REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN ORDERS ENERGY STUDY
description: President Reagan today ordered a high-level review of the nation's security in energy, but the action was regarded as essentially a device to improve the election chances of oil patch Republicans, various industry and political sources said.

title: Louise Parker Is Dead; An Operatic Contralto
description: Louise Parker, a contralto who sang with the New York City Opera and the New York Philharmonic, died Monday of respiratory failure in Philadephia. She was 60 years old and lived in Philadelphia and New York.

title: LaROUCHE TO PAY $250,000 TO NBC
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has paid more than $250,000 to settle a disputed judgment won by NBC, ending collection proceedings in which the political extremist faced a court order to disclose information about his own finances.

title: DORCHESTER MASTER LIMITED PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains from early extinguishment of debentures of $319,000 and $2,393,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: NORTH CAROLINA KILLER EXECUTED AFTER APPEAL FAILS
description: A white man who raped and slashed a white nurse and left her to bleed to death in a field was executed by injection today after the Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal based on race.

title: GATT PACT IS SEEN ON TRADE AGENDA
description: Representatives of major trading nations struck compromises on agriculture and the service industries early today, virtually assuring a new round of negotiations to strength the world economy through freer trade.

title: Layoffs at CBS
description: CBS Inc. has laid off 30 to 40 employees at the corporate level, a CBS spokesman said. The layoffs were part of a plan inaugurated under the company's former chairman, Thomas H. Wyman, to reduce corporate overhead. Sources close to CBS said it was likely there would be additional cuts, but did not indicate how extensive those would be.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 6
Vigil on Missing Soldiers Ends in Wisconsin
description: Veterans of three wars and their supporters today ended a 37-day vigil in a bamboo cage to call attention to American soldiers missing in action.

title: Math Flows Poorly From East to West
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AIDES SAY NEWS REPORTS IMPEDED INTELLIGENCE-SHARING
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that a close ally of the United States had slowed its sharing of information on terrorism because much of its intelligence data had appeared in reports by American news organizations.

title: Steinbrenner's Bottom Line
description: In the manager's office at Yankee Stadium a few days ago, Joe Altobelli, a coach for the Yankees, was telling Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, and assorted others, about his days as a car salesman in off-seasons in Rochester.

title: F.A.A. SEEKS TO REQUIRE AIRLINES TO INSTALL ANTI-COLLISION DEVICES
description: Spurred by the collision of a Mexican jetliner and a small plane in California, the Federal Aviation Administration announced today that it would seek to impose a rule requiring airlines to install anti-collision devices in their fleets.

title: Bottling Up Biological Warfare
description: Novel forms of warfare, once technically feasible, can rarely be constrained. Biological warfare promises to be an encouraging exception.

title: JAILED JUDGE, AT SENATE HEARING, ASSAILS INVESTIGATORS
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, the first member of the Federal bar to face a Senate impeachment trial in half a century, testified today in his own defense and accused the Government of ''putting the hammer to me'' to convict him of income tax evasion.

title: AIDS TEST DRUG PROLONGS LIVES IN SOME CASES
description: Federal health officials announced today that an experimental drug had markedly improved the health of a group of AIDS patients, adding months to the lives of some. They said thousands of victims of the deadly disease would soon be given access to the drug.

title: BankAmerica Stock
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it expected regulatory authorities to investigate rumors that have depressed the bank's stock in recent days.

title: Miami Judge Asked to Answer
description: A group of judges that sets policy for Federal courts asked Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami today to respond to a report urging his impeachment.

title: McDonald's Typhoid Tests
description: Preliminary test results on workers at the McDonald's restaurant in suburban Washington where seven customers are thought to have contracted typhoid fever turned up negative, health officials said Thursday. All the victims are thought to have eaten shrimp salad prepared at the fast-food restaurant in late August. The McDonald's reopened Wednesday after its walls, floors and utensils were sanitized.

title: U.S. BACKS BOSTON PLAN FOR DRUG TESTS OF POLICE
description: The Justice Department is supporting a Boston drug testing plan in a court case that could help determine the constitutionality of President Reagan's proposal to test thousands of Federal workers for drug abuse.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: PRINCIPAL IS ROBBED AT HARLEM SCHOOL
description: The principal of an East Harlem elementary school was robbed in her office by a razor-wielding intruder, and two students were stabbed, one seriously, in a dispute with another student in a Brooklyn high school yesterday, the police reported.

title: REAGAN REJECTS ZAMBIAN REQUEST
description: President Reagan has rejected an invitation from President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia to meet with leaders of black-governed nations near South Africa to discuss the Administration's policy in the region, White House officials said today.

title: FORD AND TOYOTA TO RAISE '87 PRICES
description: Preliminary price increases on the Ford Motor Company's 1987 cars range from 3.2 percent to 9 percent above prices at the end of the 1986 model year, the company said today.

title: AMERICAN CYTOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AN OLD SALT WONDERS WHY PEOPLE PAY $20 A FISH
description: ''Ticket please,'' chirped Sally Duffy, collecting tickets from tourists at the gangplank to the lightship Ambrose, an attraction at the South Street Seaport Museum. Edmund Francis Moran, ancient mariner, stared at her for a moment and then mumbled, ''But I live here.''

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary income of $704,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings represent class A shares.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. LOCAL TEAMS *Grambling (1-0) vs. N.C. Central (2-1) Grambling seeks Eddie Robinson's 331st victory, at Yankee Stadium. Merchant Marine (2-0) vs. C. W. Post (0-1) Mariners and Pioneers were first and second in 1985 Liberty Conference.

title: REPLACEMENT IS NAMED
description: Ted Bates Worldwide, which was acquired last month by Saatchi & Saatchi, the world's largest advertising company, has removed its chief executive officer, Robert E. Jacoby, and replaced him with Donald M. Zuckert.

title: TV: 'HEART OF THE CITY,' PILOT FOR AN ABC SERIES
description: Somewhere near the middle of tonight's 90-minute pilot for the new ABC series ''Heart of the City,'' Robert Disiderio and Dick Anthony Williams, talented actors, have a scene that seems unusually spontaneous. Following still another shootout in the police drama, Mr. Williams says, ''I don't suppose you learn anything from all this.'' Failing to keep a straight face, Mr. Disiderio laughingly replies, ''I'm trying my best not to.'' Anyone else connected with this relentlessly downbeat series, scheduled for Saturdays at 9 o'clock, must feel the same way.

title: YOM KIPPUR GAMES CRITICIZED
description: With two of the National League playoff games scheduled for Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish calendar, several hundred people have called and written to complain to the Mets, the commissioner of baseball and ABC, the television network that will broadcast the games.

title: 2 Men Killed in Plane Crash; Couldn't Land at 2 Airports
description: A light airplane, prevented by rain and heavy fog from landing at two central New York airports, crashed early today, killing the two men on board, the authorities said.

title: ROBERT CURTIS PARKER
description: Robert Curtis Parker, the principal of the Emma Willard School in Troy, N.Y., died Monday at his home on the school's campus, after a long illness. He was 58 years old. Mr. Parker became principal of Emma Willard, a preparatory school for young women, in 1979.
