title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its annual reserve for possible losses on loans and real estate totaled $38.9 million for the year ending June 30, 1986, compared to $8.4 million in the prior year.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Q&A: Sargent Shriver; Peace Corps at 25 a 'Proven Success'
description: When President Kennedy created the Peace Corps in 1961, he called upon his brother-in-law, Sargent Shriver, to serve as its first director. Mr. Shriver led the program through its infant years, leaving in 1966.

title: Film Makers Study Venture
description: Lorimar-Telepictures Inc. and Tri-Star Pictures have been considering the possibility of joining together to raise several hundred million dollars in equity and debt to produce motion pictures.

title: EDWARDS, A. G. & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: Barr Leads on 133
description: Dave Barr, taking advantage of soft greens and an afternoon starting time, shot an eight-under-par 64 today for a two-stroke lead after two rounds in the $400,000 Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart with an article about flavored seltzers in The Living Section on Wednesday omitted an explanation of how they had been ranked. No. 1 was the highest rank, No. 7 the lowest. Gimme Seltzer was No. 1 in all categories.

title: SUMMER LINGERS IN STREET MARKET
description: There are those who can't wait to put on the first sweater of the fall season, who probably love to jump in the leaves as they are being raked and who had all their pencils sharpened and lined up weeks before school began.

title: SENATE G.O.P. ADDS ITS OWN DRUG BILL
description: Senate Republicans proposed their own package of tougher drug laws today and included a provision that would impose the death penalty for certain drug offenses as well as such Federal crimes as treason, espionage and killing American hostages in a terrorist attack.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch yesterday from Grand Rapids, Mich., on a symposium on humor and the Presidency, misidentified the artist of a comic strip and the title of his strip. Berke Breathed draws Bloom County.

title: New Bentley Cars
description: Rolls-Royce Motors Inc., a unit of Vickers Ltd. in Britain, is starting a new line of Bentley cars in an effort to increase sales of its luxury cars, according to Robert Schwartz, president and chief executive. Mr. Schwartz indicated that the new Bentleys would be aimed at young, wealthy professionals who could afford the $90,000 price. The two models, the Bentley ''8'' and the Continental Convertible, will be available in mid-October.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 6
CHILDREN'S HAIRCUTS: STYLISH AND SENSIBLE
description: Dressed smartly in a pleated navy skirt and patterned white pullover, Baila Braunfeld sat silently, her large luminous eyes taking in all the activity around her. As her reddish-brown hair was being snipped, she accepted a book offered to her, preferring to leaf through it rather than engage in idle conversation. In less than half an hour, she was done, her shiny hair cut bluntly and carefully blown, looking just a smidgen shorter than before. She headed out of the Manhattan salon anxious to do two of her favorite things: ride escalators and go through revolving doors.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL ADDS
description: ILlinois Tool Works Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of Signode Industries, Glenview, Ill., for about $550 million. Signode, a maker of strapping, packaging and fastening systems, had been a private company since 1982, when its public stock was acquired in a leveraged buyout by management and outside investors.

title: ULTRA GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $172,586. c-Net loss

title: O'CONNOR ACCEPTS INVITATION FROM ISRAELI LEADER FOR VISIT
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, accepted an invitation yesterday to visit Israel from Prime Minister Shimon Peres.

title: 4 ARE CONVICTED AS RACKETEERS IN TAIWAN GANG
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan, clearly divided in its deliberations, brought in two partial verdicts yesterday that convicted four defendants and acquitted four accused of racketeering as members of the Taiwan-based international gang, the United Bamboo.

title: Sitter Held in Baby's Death
description: A baby sitter was charged in the beating death of a 10-month-old boy who had been left in his care early yesterday morning, the police said. The child, Kariyn Hill of 262 West 123d Street, was pronounced dead on arrival at Harlem Hospital at about 1 A.M. A half hour earlier, the police said, the baby had been left by his mother, Florence Hill, 19, at the home of the baby sitter, Jerome Seabrook, 27, of 70 West 128th Street. The baby had bruises on his chest and back, a police spokesman, Officer Joseph McConville, said. Mr. Seabrook was in custody yesterday, awaiting arraignment on a second-degree murder charge.

title: Study of William Wyler Includes Documentary
description: The career of William Wyler (1902-1981) is examined with affection and insight in the program to be seen today at 6 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall at the New York Film Festival. Making up the bill are a brand-new print of Wyler's screen version of ''Dodsworth'' (1936), based on Sidney Kingsley's impeccable stage adaptation of the Sinclair Lewis novel, and ''Directed by William Wyler,'' a 58-minute documentary that is both a tribute and a memoir.

title: KEY RATES
In a Fragile World, All Species Are Brothers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pep Talk From Hayes
description: Not since 1894 had an Ohio State football team lost its first two games until this year's Buckeyes matched that unenviable record. So Coach Earl Bruce, in an effort to revive his troops for today's home opener against Colorado, used his ultimate weapon this week: he invited Woody Hayes to address the team.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring, after- tax income of $656,000, or 11 cents a share, from a real estate tax settlement with the city of Binghamton, N.Y., covering the fiscal years 1982 through 1984, for the quarter and year.

title: CONCERT: CAMPBRIDGE PLAYERS OFFER A CHAMBER PROGRAM
description: One of the most satisfying chamber-music concerts this listener has heard for some time was presented at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night by the Cambridge Chamber Players and four guest performers. The Cambridge Players - Robert Stallman, flutist and artistic director; Chester Brezniak, clarinetist; Richard Sher, cellist, and David Deveau, pianist - have, for 10 summers now, been the core ensemble for the Marblehead (Mass.)

title: Reliance Bid Gets Approval
description: The Reliance Capital Group said yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission had approved its application to acquire control of John Blair & Company, the broadcasting and advertising concern. Separately, Reliance Group

title: Canadians in Vietnam
description: In the Vietnam War some Americans went to Canada to avoid being drafted. At the same time there was a little-noticed traffic in the opposite direction: Canadians who entered the United States to enlist in the armed services and fight in Vietnam.

title: Murder Charge Dropped In Death of Ill Wife
description: A stroke victim who helped his disabled wife end her life but then did not carry out his end of their double-suicide pact was cleared of a murder charge today and pleaded guilty to a lesser crime.

title: A Generation's Legacies: A Few Opinions
description: What is the best and worst legacies this generation will leave the next?

title: Iraq Says It Regained Positions From Iran
description: Iraq said today that its troops had regained border positions captured by Iran.

title: Buyout Set For Amstar
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company said yesterday that it would sell Amstar Holdings Inc., the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, in a leveraged buyout to a newly formed corporation organized by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. The equity in the new company will be owned by Merrill Lynch, its affiliates and senior management of Amstar Holdings.

title: NEW START OF RECORD PASSER
description: Earl Harvey says that, for all practical purposes, his first college football game in Yankee Stadium will be tonight, when North Carolina Central faces Grambling in the 16th Whitney M. Young Jr. Memorial Football Classic.

title: Best Argument for a New York Home Port Is National Security
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. CHIEF THREATENS TO PULL TROOP UNIT FROM LEBANON
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar threatened today to pull United Nations peacekeeping soldiers from southern Lebanon, blaming Israel for what he called the ''major crisis'' facing the nine-nation force.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. PHILADELPHIA PHILLIES, at Shea Stadium, 7:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7 P.M.; Radio - WHN, 1050; 7 P.M.) YANKEES VS. TIGERS, at Detroit, 3:20 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 3:15 P.M.; Radio - WABC, 770; 3:15 P.M.) BLUE JAYS VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Toronto, 3:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.). BRAVES VS. SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS, at Atlanta, 4:10 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) ASTROS VS, SAN DIEGO PADRES, at Houston, 8:35 P.M. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 8:35 P.M. ).

title: SCOFFLAW LIST HAS WRITERS OF TICKETS
description: Among the top 10 scofflaws in the city's Department of Transportation were four whose responsibilities were to write parking tickets, city officials said yesterday.

title: ELK ASSOCIATES FUNDING reports earnings for Year to June 30
Opening of ''Chess'' Off Until May 1988 at Least
description: ''Chess,'' the Tim Rice musical that was to have come to Broadway in the spring, will not arrive until May 1988 at the earliest, the Shubert Organization reported yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP 3.3% TO RECORD LEVEL
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RANGER PLAYERS SET FOR BLUNT ESPOSITO
description: ''In your face'' is usually basketball vernacular for ''I'm going to sink this shot with my elbows in your mouth.'' But to the Rangers last year, ''in your face'' came to be a player's way of saying that he had just come out of a meeting with Coach Ted Sator. Sometimes players left saying, ''He really gets in your face.''

title: In a Fragile World, All Species Are Brothers; What We Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Zed and Two Naughts'
description: Peter Greenaway's ''Zed and Two Noughts,'' which is a fancy way of spelling ''zoo,'' takes place partly in a zoo, partly outside a zoo and partly at some distance from a zoo. It opens when a white swan, perhaps in pursuit of a Leda, crashes into the windshield of a car driven by Alba Bewick (pronounced as if it were ''Buick''), played by Andrea Ferreol. As a result of the accident, Alba has one leg amputated by a mad doctor, called Van Meergeren (as in Hans Van Meergeren, the Vermeer art forger).

title: BANK DEREGULATION AND THE CONSUMER
description: What has happened since New York State and Federal officials lifted restrictions on what interest rates banks could charge and what rates they could pay for deposits? Consumer advocates say banks have raised basic checking fees, closed branches in some lower-income neighborhoods and made fewer loans to people and small businesses in those neighborhoods.

title: Marcos Broke U.S. Law By Coup-Attempt Role
description: To the Editor:

title: C. EDMONDS ALLEN
description: Claxton Edmonds Allen, a former executive of United Press International and former publisher of the Ocean Press Newspapers, died of pnuemonia Thursday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan.

title: INCOME AND SPENDING BOTH GREW IN AUGUST
description: Personal income in the United States climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in August while consumer spending, bolstered by a surge in car sales, rose by 1.1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: OWNERS OF SOUTH AFRICAN MINE ADMIT SAFETY LAPSES
description: The owners of a South African mine where 177 men died this week acknowledged today that there were flaws in their safety procedures.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST:SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1986
description: Companies

title: Next-Century Newark
description: If strength of will alone could raise a depressed city to prosperity, Newark would be well on the way. Since his election last spring, Mayor Sharpe James has relentlessly cultivated an upbeat atmosphere, a sense that good things are about to happen. Now an influential coalition of business, civic, religious and governmental groups has delivered a healthy reminder of how far New Jersey's largest city has to go and what it must do to get there. The analysis is not deflating but it is sobering.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'WITCHING' HOUR PASSES QUIETLY
description: Roughly 38 million shares, or about 25 percent of the day's market volume, changed hands in the last minute of trading yesterday, but Wall Street professionals and Federal regulators said yesterday's closely watched ''triple witching hour'' was pretty much a non-event.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE AVENUES

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: LEAHY NOW PERFECT AS JET PLACE-KICKER
description: Last Nov. 10, against the Miami Dolphins, Pat Leahy of the Jets missed three field goals. But he has been perfect since.

title: 3 Hitchhikers Complete Journey of 27,000 Miles
description: Three weary travelers who hitchhiked 27,000 miles from southernmost South America to Alaska claimed a world record today for what they called ''the most important experience'' of their lives.

title: A FAILURE LED TO DRUG AGAINST AIDS
description: AZT, the first drug that appears to curb the ravages of AIDS, was born of a bright idea that did not pan out.

title: Laughable Literati
description: GROUP SEX. By Ann Arensberg. 175 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Talks in Wine Strike Resume After 2 Weeks
description: Amid harvest-time strikes at California's largest wineries, labor and employer negotiators faced each other today for the first time in more than two weeks.

title: INSIDE
description: 9 SUSPECTS IN FRENCH BLASTS France has identified nine people, including four brothers of a suspected terrorist leader, as suspects in the recent bombing campaign.

title: Nelson W. Aldrich, Architect And Promoter of Arts, Dies
description: Nelson W. Aldrich, an architect who designed buildings at several New England colleges and was active in promoting contemporary art, has died. He was 75 years old.

title: REAGAN STRESSES THE DANILOFF CASE TO SOVIET MINISTER
description: President Reagan held an unscheduled meeting today with the Soviet Foreign Minister and conveyed to him ''the strength of his feelings'' over the Soviet Union's refusal to allow an American journalist to return to the United States, the White House said.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $621,763 gain from an accounting change.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Holiday Cheer A la Ritz
description: For thousands of New york's homebound elderly, Christmas dinner this year will be on the Hotel Ritz of Paris. Well, not the Ritz exactly, but on Mohamed Al-Fayed, the hotel's owner.

title: Cowley Pitches a No-Hitter
description: Joe Cowley, a right-hander who was so ineffective earlier this season that he was sent to the minor leagues, pitched the major leagues' first no-hitter in nearly two years tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 7-1 victory over the California Angels.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We could use a new meeting to reach an agreement on a stop to nuclear testing and on the scrapping of both Soviet and American medium-range missiles in Europe.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on the possibility of summit talks.

title: ECONOMIC SPURS SET BY JAPAN
description: Japan's Government adopted a variety of measures today designed to stimulate the nation's flagging economy.

title: Andover Offer
description: The Andover Group, an investment partnership in suburban Washington, D.C., has proposed to acquire HBO & Company for $15 a share, or a total of about $300 million.

title: FRANCE SEEKS 9 AS SUSPECTS IN BOMBINGS
description: The police said today that they would issue a list of nine suspects in the terrorist bombing campaign that has rocked Paris in the last two weeks.

title: Italy Signs a Formal Accord To Join 'Star Wars' Bidding
description: Italy signed a formal agreement with the United States today that would make it easier for Italian companies to bid on research projects for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program, the Defense Department announced.

title: Dollar Low Against Yen; Gold Hits a 3-Year High
description: In nervous, quiet trading, the dollar fell further against most foreign currencies yesterday, particularly against the Japanese yen.

title: Sri Lanka's Account of Blast Is Contradicted by Witnesses
description: The Government said today that 13 civilians had been killed in a car-bomb explosion in the eastern city of Batticaloa on Thursday, but residents said many of the victims were killed by security forces in reprisal for the bombing.

title: Financial Innovation and Global Linkage Have Made Markets Complex and Volatile
description: It has been more than 300 years since a craze sent prices of tulip bulbs soaring in the normally staid Netherlands. And half a century since a comparable craze sent stock prices soaring, and then crashing, in America, a harbinger of the Great Depression.

title: SENATE APPROVES $13.3 BILLION PLAN TO CUT '87 DEFICIT
description: The Republican-controlled Senate overwhelming approved legislation early this morning to reduce the 1987 budget deficit by $13.3 billion, a proposal one member dubbed ''a package of golden gimmicks.''

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the results of operations for the latest quarter and 9 months include a writedown of producing oil and gas properties of $600,000.

title: Time to Relocate Some Chicago Units
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it would move parts of its information systems group out of Chicago, which would result in a third-quarter charge of $50 million before taxes.

title: Newell Retires
description: Pete Newell, who compiled a winning percentage of .655 in 14 years as coach at San Francisco, Michigan State and California, has officially retired from basketball after four decades as a coach, administrator and scout.

title: LADY'S SECRET TO LEAD FIELD
description: Lady's Secret, who is widely regarded as the best filly of the decade, will shoulder a career-high 129 pounds in the Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park tomorrow.

title: GIANTS PLAN NO CHANGES FOR PLUNKETT
description: All week long, the Giants prepared for Sunday's game against the Raiders in Los Angeles in the belief that Marc Wilson would be the Raiders' quarterback.

title:
Patents;
Preventing Infections Of Bladder
description: DR. CHARLES L. FOX JR., professor of surgical microbiology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Shanta M. Modak, an associate research scientist, were granted a patent this week for a method of preparing infection-resisting coatings for wound covers and urinary catheters implanted in the body.

title: SALVADOR PEACE EFFORT A BOON TO TOWN
description: With a new coat of white paint, an infusion of state money and constant army patrols, the Salvadoran Government retook this war-weary village today.

title: FANNE WADE HEARST
description: Fanne Wade Hearst, widow of the late John Randolph Hearst, the son of William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, died Wednesday in her sleep at the home of her daughter, Deborah Hearst, in Southampton, L.I. She was 70 years old and lived in Southampton.

title: Reynolds Asks New Trial in Death
description: The Justice Department decided today that Ronald Ebens, who had been convicted on Federal charges of violation of civil rights, should face trial again in the murder of a Chinese-American. The department acted after the victim's mother, Lily Chin, made an emotional appeal for the Federal Government to go back to court.

title:
PATENTS;
Protecting a Satellite From an Intruder
description: A system to prevent an intruder from taking over control of a satellite was patented this week for the Hughes Aircraft Company of Los Angeles.

title: COMMISSION TRIAL ILLUSTRATES CHANGES IN ATTITUDE ON MAFIA
description: When ''The Godfather'' was being filmed on the streets of New York 15 years ago, the word ''Mafia'' was struck from the script at the request of an Italian-American group that felt the word was an ethnic slur.

title: STAGE: MURDER ON MENU IN 'RUTHERFORD HOUSE'
description: Murder mysteries have been staged on trains, on weekends at resort hotels and, currently, at dinner, with courses alternating with clues. The theory is that theatergoers might relish the idea of taking part in a ''crime'' and its solution. One such do-it-yourself dinner theater is in residence in a town house on lower Second Avenue with a show entitled ''Murder at Rutherford House.'' While the idea of a mystery-happening is tantalizing, the theatrical menu at Rutherford House is dubious.

title:
PATENTS;
Compounds' Colors Changed Electrically
description: Chemical compounds that show wide color changes in response to changing electric potential are being studied for use in television and computer display panels.

title: 18th CHESS TITLE GAME ADJOURNED ON 41st MOVE
description: The 18th game of the world chess championship was adjourned today after 40 moves and the defending champion, Gary Kasparov, sealed his 41st move.

title: Holding Highways Hostage to the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Bring New York Parents Into the Education Process
description: The first day of school is always a hopeful occasion. It's a fresh beginning for everyone - the children, teachers, parents and boards of education.

title: Tax Transition Rules Detailed
description: As the final version of the tax revision bill went to press today, many senators and representatives learned the fate of the special tax breaks they had requested on behalf of individual constituents.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Aaron Burr. 2. Only citizens of the 11 other countries of the European Community and Switzerland. 3. True. 4.

title: Toll-Free Information Line
description: The public Health Service has established a toll-free telephone line for physicians and AIDS patients seeking information about AZT. The number is (800) 843-9388 and will be answered seven days a week from 8 A.M. to midnight, Eastern time.

title: RAP MUSIC, DESPITE ADULT FIRE, BROADENS ITS TEEN-AGE BASE
description: Rap music, mostly popular among inner-city teen-agers since it began in the late 1970's, has broken out this year. Rap used to get major radio play only in the New York area, where it started, and in Washington, Philadelphia and other urban centers. But with the success of Run-DMC's latest single, ''Walk This Way,'' and album, ''Raising Hell'' (Profile 1217, LP and cassette), rap is being heard everywhere. Young disk jockeys are playing rap's popular scratch rhythms in rural Mississippi; skateboarding teen-agers are rapping to each other in California. And the promotional video for ''Walk This Way,'' which features both Run-DMC and the song's original authors from the rock group Aerosmith, is all over MTV.

title: Filling the Air At Grand Central
description: Such is the nature of New York City real estate that even the thin air above it can fetch a price if the location is right. For example, First Boston Corporation, the investment company, agreed a few years ago to pay $55 a foot for 1.5 million square feet of ''air rights'' over Grand Central Terminal.

title: Johnson Retains Light-Heavy Title
description: Marvin Johnson retained his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title tonight, stopping Jean-Marie Emebe in the 13th round.

title: Skagway
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from an extensive Alaskan trip, my husband and I were interested in Andree Brooks's article on Skagway (Travel, July 20). We would like to make a few additional comments.

title: French Isles
description: To the Editor: Christopher S. Wren's article on St. Pierre and Miquelon (Travel, July 27) brought back memories of my three-week stay in Miquelon last July as part of a seal-observing project run by animal psychologists from Memorial University in Newfoundland. We collected data about seal behavior by observing, videotaping and tagging the seals.

title: The March of Folly in the War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: REBELLION AT GRASSY PARK HIGH
description: CROSSING THE LINE A Year in the Land of Apartheid. By William Finnegan. 418 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: THE FRENCH SEEM UNABLE TO HALT A 'DIRTY WAR'
description: NOT since the Algerian War of independence in the late 1950's and early 1960's has Paris suffered such a bloody wave of terrorist attacks.

title: MUGGING OUR HEROES
description: SOMEWHERE in this region, a brave and mighty hunter is displaying a new trophy this weekend. One pictures him perched on a barstool in Hicksville or Bay Ridge or East Orange, holding up the trophy for his admiring pals to see.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NICE GUYS SLEEP ALONE: Dating in the Difficult Eighties. By Bruce Feirstein. Illustrations by Shary Flenniken. (Dell, Paper, $4.95.) Nice guys pick up women for dates.

title: A Sad Start for A Scallop Season
description: For as long as anyone can remember, September has marked the beginning of bay scallop season on Long Island. But last week, on what normally would have been opening day, the waters were empty of the baymen who have dredged for scallops for hundreds of years.

title: Heart Patient Better
description: Bernadette Chayrez, who twice received an artificial heart, continued to make progress Friday after surgery to eliminate an infection around the mechanical organ, hospital officials said. The patient, 40 years old, was listed in critical but stable condition, said Jan Rooney, a spokesman for University Medical Center. She underwent seven hours of surgery Monday for the infection.

title: TRAFFIC PLAN TO REMOVE AN ELM TREE DIVIDES RIDGEFIELD
description: THE elm tree on Main Street in Ridgefield would blend into the scenery with its leafy companions if it were not for the red, white and blue yarn tied around its circumference. The 75-foot tree is the focal point of a controversy involving residents, government and business in this Fairfield County town.

title: QUAKERS CRUISE IN OPENER
description: Fact, not fantasy, prevailed at Memorial Field today as Pennsylvania defeated Dartmouth, 21-7, in the opening Ivy League game for both schools. It was Penn's 15th victory in the last 16 games within the league.

title: AT SCHOOLS IN YONKERS, CONTRASTS EMERGE
description: TO Theresa Fiore, whose 9-year-old daughter Elizabeth left a predominantly white neighborhood school in Yonkers to attend a racially mixed program for gifted students on the opposite side of the city, the initial results are encouraging.

title: LATE RALLY SPARKS GRAMBLING
description: One of the interesting aspects of a hard-fought football game is that the turning point is often triggered by something that's completely unrelated to strategy. For the last week, Eddie Robinson, the Grambling head coach, had tried to devise a way to stop Earl Harvey, the highly regarded quarterback from North Carolina Central and Robert Clark, his favorite target.

title: South Africa and Sanctions
description: Juxtaposing the sober reflection of Helen Suzman's article with the raised fists and angry expressions in a photograph that accompanies it, one cannot help but share her dismay over the idea that one must endorse punitive intervention or advocate racism. She has made a strong case that black economic muscle must be the driver in the evolution of a nonracial (and, it is hoped, democratic) society.

title: Guard Adds Speed to Size
description: When opposing players look across the line of scrimmage and see Sheepshead Bay's imposing nose guard, Darrel Washington, looming large, it gives them a chill. But that's not the only reason the 6-foot-4, 285-pound senior has been nicknamed The Icebox by his coach and teammates.

title: Diane Strom Archer Married to Stephen Presser
description: Diane Strom Archer and Stephen Presser, both 1984 graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan by Rabbi Shira Stern. The parents of the couple are Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Archer of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Presser of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: Army Admirals, Navy Generals
description: When President Reagan decided to invade Grenada in 1983, the Pentagon could have sent in the Marines, who specialize in such operations. But that would have denied other services a piece of the action. So the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a horse-trading committee of service leaders, patched together an Army, Navy and Marine force which shambled to the inevitable victory.

title: SIMPLIFIED HOME SYSTEMS
description: Electronic home entertainment has grown ever more complex, especially in the last few years since combined audio-video systems have come into vogue. The gadgetry went on proliferating until the sheer number of knobs on the control panel would flummox a jet pilot.

title: Sri Lanka Imposes Curfew on Coast Town
description: The Government imposed an indefinite curfew on the east coast town of Batticaloa today.

title: Living Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: SEA-BOTTOM BACTERIA OFF STATE A POTENTIAL SOURCE OF ANTIBIOTICS
description: A RESEARCHER has isolated disease-destroying bacteria that grow deep in marine sediments off New Jersey and that one day may yield a new line of antibiotics.

title: A SPACE FOR ART
description: Like an actor who refuses to be typecast, the interior designer Mark Hampton says his rooms do not have one identifiable style. And although he is agile at juggling a large roster of clients for whom he creates Victorian visions as easily as he creates modern backdrops, Hampton's passion for quirky 19th-century objects arranged in a classic, tasteful manner has earned him special recognition in recent years.

title: A Suitable Brownout
description: A STORY HAS IT THAT A well-known New York socialite once took exception to a visitor's attire. ''Imagine,'' she was heard to say after her guest had gone, ''it was past 6 o'clock, and he wore brown shoes!''

title: Pat Robertson And 'Our America'
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's promise to seek the Republican Presidential nomination if three million followers signed petitions of support for him within a year has summoned up half-forgotten childhood memories. Like Mr. Robertson, I was reared in Virginia, and like many teen-agers of the early 1950's, I attended several Christian revival meetings with my friends.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Coeur d'Alene, Idaho; Wilderness Luxury
description: THE Idaho panhandle, a land of lyrically named lakes and thick Ponderosa pines, is in the midst of a dramatic change from a timber- and mining-based economy to one founded on tourism.

title: It's Not Castro's Nose, or His Face
description: No dictator anywhere is as unforgiving to political offenders as Cuba's Fidel Castro. Sentences are endless and treatment brutal for those who resist ''re-education.'' And no democratic leader anywhere should be gladder to offer refuge to such Castro foes than President Reagan. Yet after the Carter Administration negotiated the release of 1,500 prisoners the Reagan Administration refuses them refuge, even though it accepted 69 Cubans last week. It's a uselessly truculent policy and it cries out for revision.

title: Karl Barth and 'Roger's Version'
description: To the Editor:

title: ART WORKS AIM TO KEEP BOSTON'S MINDS OFF MUNDANE FACTS OF COMMUTING
description: When Dan Huck reached the narrow platform of the Park Street subway station's Red Line last Tuesday at the rush hour, he was greeted not only by the familiar construction noise from an $80 million modernization effort, but also by the mellifluous sounds of flutes, oboes and tympanies.

title: THE SCREEN: BOY TALK, IN 'THE MEN'S CLUB'
description: ''THE MEN'S CLUB,'' which opens today at the RKO National and other theaters, is male bonding's answer to sisterhood. If you thought today's women needed support systems, wait till you see the seven weak sisters brought together by Leonard Michaels' screenplay, from his 1982 novel. Having decided, for no better reason than as a pretext for a work of fiction, to become a club, these juveniles, who seem to range from the 30's to the 50's, meet at the Berkeley home of a pretty crazy psychotherapist (Richard Jordan) and take turns talking about their experiences with women.

title: McENROE, YES OR NO
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Diane McDevitt Becomes a Bride
description: Diane Helena McDevitt, a senior consultant in financial management at Peat Marwick in New York, was married yesterday to Christopher S. Eklund, head of the Philadelphia bureau of Business Week magazine. The Rev. Patrick Nowlan performed the ceremony at Our Mother of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1986
description: International

title: Producers Will Adapt
description: To the Editor:

title: VOCAL BURNOUT AT THE OPERA
description: THE METROPOLI-tan Opera has been criticized more for shortcomings in night-to-night operatic casting than for anything else in recent years, and the season that opens tomorrow night with ''Die Walkure'' can be expected to come under the same scrutiny. A remark overheard at one of last season's memorable failures, the opening night of ''Carmen,'' points directly to at least one of the problems. The speaker was a retired singer, a star of the Met in the 1930's and 40's, and this is what she said to a discouraged member of the Metropolitan board: ''You want to know what's the matter? I'll tell you: You have a Don Jose who forces his voice, a Micaela who forces, a Toreador who forces, and a Carmen who doesn't force, but doesn't sing!''

title: Nancy Thornton Wed to G. C. Reycraft
description: Nancy McCullough Thornton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., and Wainscott, L.I., was married yesterday to George Colville Reycraft, a son of Pamela Colville Reycraft of New York and George D. Reycraft of New York and Key Largo, Fla. Chief Judge Edward D. Re of the United States Court of International Trade performed the ceremony at the Thornton home in Wainscott.

title: TRAVAILS OF THE LONG ISLAND MAID
description: INEZ, who is from Ecuador, Yvonne, from Jamaica, and Martes, from Barbados, wait for the same 4 o'clock train on Friday afternoons at the Syosset railroad station. They are three of the thousands of live-in housekeepers who are dropped off at stations throughout Long Island every week to spend the weekend with their families in New York City.

title: ADDITIONAL VIEWS ABOUT INCEST
description: While I appreciate what was generally an accurate representation of my statements on incest in the article ''Incest Victims: Out of the Darkness'' on Aug. 31, I would like to refocus the following two points:

title: PEAY SEES CHANGE, NOT COMPROMISE
description: THE wind off Lake Michigan, Northwestern University's neighbor to the east, had not yet shown its cruel side. Classes had not yet begun, the football team had lost just one game, and the disappointment that has become an annual event for the Wildcats was weeks away.

title:
ART;
A TWIST ON BORIS CHALIAPIN IS OFFERED IN STAMFORD
description: MOST of us are familiar with Boris Chaliapin (1904-79) as a kind of highbrow Norman Rockwell, through his tightly drawn hyper-realistic Time magazine covers. Everyone from heads of state to movie stars became his subjects. Chaliapin was unusually faithful to their features, but he also added witty backgrounds that amplified them and became his trademark.

title: PRIZED PORCELAINS
description: There are moments in history when a yearning for simplicity sets in. At first, it appears in avant-garde creations, as it did with the advent of abstractionism or the Bauhaus style. When such a change does occur, our entire esthetic perception, including our way of seeing the art of the past, is altered.

title: Dr. Sally A. Rosenfeld Is Married in Portland
description: The marriage of Dr. Sally Ann Rosenfeld, a resident in internal medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, and Dr. Andrew Dorson Frank, an assistant attending physician at Montefiore, took place last evening in Portland, Ore. Rabbi Emanuel Rose performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Israel.

title: A QUEASY ECONOMY ADDLES THE MARKETS
description: The economy is in turmoil here and abroad, pulled to and fro by a multiplicity of seemingly conflicting factors. The current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, hit a record $34.7 billion in the second quarter despite the fall of the dollar that began a year ago. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said the dollar had to come down even further, and that statement alone sent the dollar even lower on world markets. It hit lows against the mark and yen, and gold soared to three-year highs.

title: POP: TAXXI CONNECTION
description: THE backup band was the star attraction Thursday at the Ritz, when the Taxxi Connection World Tour made its stop in New York. Taxxi is the production company headed by the drummer Sly Dunbar and the bassist Robbie Shakespeare, who have become the most prolific and best-known rhythm section in reggae. On a tour that will take them to Europe, Australia, India and Egypt, they lead a band that backs a triple bill of singers - Ini Kamoze, Yellowman and Half Pint - in an uninterrupted two-and-a-half-hour show.

title: THE SKY'S THE LIMIT IN PLAN FOR NEWARK
description: IT SHOULD come as no surprise that the man who wants to put up the tallest building in the world likes to read about potential real-estate opportunities in other parts of the solar system and beyond.

title: The Star Wars Spinoff
description: Malcolm W. Browne's article ''The Star Wars Spinoff'' (Aug. 24) recycles the classic ''something-for-everyone'' argument for pork-barrel defense programs: if you don't like the military applications, you'll love the accidental commercial offshoots. But Mr. Browne's quest for signs of his projected $5 trillion to $20 trillion in private-sector sales falls flat at the starting line.

title: MR. SHEVARDNADZE GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: THE delicate web of relations between the Soviet Union and the United States is easily torn, and a disruption in one spot can quickly lead to a widening rift. This is the danger now, amid a series of actions and retaliations surrounding the arrest of an American correspondent in Moscow, as officials on both sides work toward finding some common ground in the difficult area of arms control. Their immediate goal, undertaken as the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, conducted talks in Washington last week with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, is to reduce the obstacles to a meeting this year between Mr. Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Q AND A
description: Unregistered Parking Fee Question: I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment for four years. When I signed the lease I was assigned a parking space, for which I pay $30 a month. When I received my registration form this year from the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, I noticed that, while my rent was listed, the parking fee was not. Aren't these forms supposed to show everything that the tenant pays? . . . P. P., Staten Island Answer: No. According to Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the agency, landlords were required to include information on charges that were not included in the rent - such as maid service, parking spaces and recreational fees - only on the initial rent-registration forms, which were first sent to tenants in 1984.

title: Elise Kenyon Harrison Wed
description: Elise Kenyon Harrison, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Harrison of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to George Blackmore Lemmon Jr., the son of Ann Peterkin Lemmon of Villanova, Pa., and Mr. Lemmon of Haverford, Pa. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: DONOVAN'S PASSES HELP BEAT YALE
description: Yale, which lost its starting quarterback, Kelly Ryan, because of a knee injury a week ago, could ill afford to lose Ryan's backup, John Andrews, in today's opening Ivy League game against Brown.

title: LIVE FROM HARTFORD, A DAILY 9 A.M. MASS
description: THE Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford is evoking the Devil in a humorous advertising campaign with a serious objective.

title: INCAVIGLIA HAS PROVED HE WAS READY
description: PETE INCAVIGLIA won't win the rookie-of-the-year award in the American League; Jose Canseco or Wally Joyner most likely will. Incaviglia, though, is baseball's No. 1 rookie in the purest sense of the term. He not only is a major league rookie, but he also is a rookie as a professional and he has produced remarkable offensive numbers for one in his position. In fact, plenty of veteran major leaguers would gladly take his season for their own.

title: AN ART NOUVEAU INNOVATOR GETS HIS DUE
description: Siegfried Bing, a pioneering art dealer at the turn of the century, did more to advance Art Nouveau in Paris than any other person. The style's name derives from his shop, L'Art Nouveau, an artists' haunt that was ignored by the art establishment throughout its existence, from 1895 to 1904. Until now, however, Bing's role as a merchant, manufacturer and promoter of Art Nouveau has never been fully defined. Even his first name is usually misstated as Samuel.

title: The Potteries
description: To the Editor: From the Trent and Mersey canal one can get an excellent view of the Potteries (Travel, July 13) as they looked during the time they were in full production.

title: SCHOOL PROJECTS: BY WHOSE HAND?
description: Re the article ''School Prizes: Wrong Emphasis?'' [ Opinion Page, Aug. 10 ] :

title: Martha Hamilton-Phillips Is Married
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday, Martha Hamilton-Phillips, an art historian, and Robert Purks Maccubbin, an English professor, were married by the Rev. Dr. David H. C.Read.

title: THE REHNQUIST COURT STILL SEEMS AN APPOINTMENT AWAY
description: THE Constitution turned 199 Wednesday, the same day the Rehnquist Court became a certainty.

title: FIREFIGHTER CHARGES SEX BIAS IN HIRING
description: MARIE C. CAPRIA, a volunteer firefighter in Greenburgh, thinks she has the right stuff to become a paid firefighter.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Tibet By Elisabeth B. Booz. 208 pages. Passport Books, trade division of National Textbook Company. $9.95.

title: For the Waldorf, a Return to the Elegance of the 30's
description: THE red carpets are coming from Hong Kong, the chandelier glass from Czechoslovakia, the bathroom marble from Italy, the furniture fabrics from Thailand and the mahogany paneling from Honduras. It is the fulfillment of an interior decorator's wish list, and it will all wind up at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THUNDER IN AMERICA. By Bob Faw and Nancy Skelton. (Texas Monthly, $16.95.) For a political reporter nowadays, there probably is no public figure more difficult to write about objectively than Jesse Jackson. Bob Faw, a CBS news correspondent, and Nancy Skelton, who covered Mr. Jackson's 1984 Presidential campaign for The Los Angeles Times, haven't done it perfectly. But their book sheds more light on Mr. Jackson and his remarkable adventure in American politics than several other recent works, which seemed aimed at proving the entire affair was all sound and fury, signifying nothing. In conventional political terms, Mr. Jackson's impact probably was minimal; at best, it was ambiguous. As one N.A.A.C.P. official observed, revulsion for Ronald Reagan probably did more to boost black voter registration than Jesse Jackson did. What's more, black gains were more than offset by increases in white registration, the result of a backlash inspired by fear and hatred of Mr. Jackson. But the Jackson campaign never was conventional, not in style or purpose or measures of success. And the differences are traceable ultimately to the peculiar character of the candidate. The strength of this book is that Mr. Faw and Ms. Skelton appreciated this central fact. They seek not to debunk but to come to terms with Jesse Jackson and so are able to penetrate his character in a way others have not. Race and racism - his own and others' - are only one part of the puzzle.

title: Sunday Observer; ONE SACRIFICE TOO MANY
description: AFTER I STOPPED smoking I caught a cold that lasted a year and a half. Then I started getting fat. I had never been fat before, and didn't much like it, though it wasn't as bad as the 18-month cold.

title: Biggest Gainers in the Consumer Services Sector
description: (Media General Financial Services)

title: DIFFERENT USES AT 2 OTHER SITES
description: TUCKED deep in the Hudson Highlands across the river from West Point, the tiny village of Garrison's Landing is the proud home of two historic railroad stations. Both have been creatively adapted to new uses: one as offices for an illustrator and a graphics-design firm and the other as the theatrical home of The Hand to Mouth Players.

title: A QUICK MAN WITH A NIGHT STICK
description: THE HERO OF NEW YORK By T. Glen Coughlin. 320 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $14.95.

title: Support U.S. Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PAINTED LANDSCAPES Edward Nygren, a curator at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., says he believes that American landscape painting before 1830 has been neglected, overwhelmed by the rise of the Hudson River School in the second half of the 19th century. Earlier works by European and American painters, Mr. Nygren says, merit examination as precursors of the Hudson River School, and to support his thesis he has organized an exhibition that opens today at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, continuing through November.

title: AQUINO IS GIVEN DEGREE ON RETURNING TO BOSTON
description: President Corazon C. Aquino returned today to the city where she and her husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., lived in exile before his assassination. She received an honorary degree from Boston University and spoke at Harvard University.

title: TERRORISM IN PARIS: A NARROW PURPOSE OR A BROADER PLOT?
description: At the Interior Ministry at the Place Beauvau, ringed by metal fences and policemen in blue bullet-proof vests, the prevailing theory about the bombings that have brought terror to Paris is that France is caught in a Middle East vendetta.

title: BELIEVING THE WORST OF EACH OTHER
description: ''THE TARGET IS DESTROYED'' What Really Happened to Flight 007 and What America Knew About It. By Seymour M. Hersh. 282 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: A WAGNERIAN OPENING FOR THE METROPOLITAN OPERA SEASON
description: Metropolitan Opera opening nights are always special, even in this age of the deglamorization of opera. But tomorrow's opening night will be more special than most. It's not just a new production, which isn't always the case in the first place, but a new production of Wagner's massive opera, ''Die Walkure.'' And not just of ''Die Walkure,'' but the first in a complete new ''Ring des Nibelungen'' cycle at the Met. ''Das Rheingold'' (actually the first opera in the tetralogy) and ''Siegfried'' will follow next season, with ''Gotterdammerung'' the season after that and three complete cycles each planned for the springs of 1989 and 1990.

title: AMERICAN SCHOLARS ARE HONORED
description: As millions of students return to college classrooms this month, the United States honors two individuals who helped in the formative years of important American institutions of learning. On Sept. 3 a 56-cent Great Americans stamp was issued for John Harvard and on Tuesday a $1 Great Americans stamp will be released for Dr. Bernard Revel.

title: BATTLE CONTINUES OVER DUMPING IN LONG ISLAND SOUND
description: HOW much - and what kind of - dredged material can be dumped in Long Island Sound without endangering its ecosystem?

title: EMPLOYERS ARE TURNING TO DRUG TESTS
description: MORE and more jobseekers in Connecticut are finding that they have to pass drug tests before they can be hired.

title: Blacks on Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GOOD OLD BOYS CONFRONT SOME HARSH NEW REALITIES
description: A TEXTBOOK on Texas government used in colleges here describes the state's attitude toward taxes and economic growth as ''a complex set of semimystical, venerated beliefs.'' Antitax and antigovernment feelings may not quite be a matter of canon in Texas. But they are nearly enough so to explain the testy atmosphere that has prevailed over the last six weeks as the State Legislature has struggled in two special sessions to deal with Texas' worst fiscal crisis since the Great Depression.

title: An Impeachment Considered
description: Other than for certain limits on his physical mobility, Harry E. Claiborne, a Federal District Judge in Las Vegas who is also a Federal prison inmate, might as well be taking a two-year paid vacation. Congress moved a step closer to ending that situation last week when defenders and prosecutors presented arguments to a special committee of 12 senators conducting the first judicial impeachment proceeding since 1936.

title: A UNIVERSAL ESTHETIC?
description: AFRICAN AESTHETICS The Carlo Monzino Collection. By Susan Mullin Vogel. Photographs by Mario Carrieri. 224 pp. The Center for African Art, 54 East 68th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021. $39.

title: LIFE-AND-DEATH MATTERS ON THE FRONT PORCH
description: EACH spring, around Mother's Day, we hang a flowering fuchsia from a hook on our front porch. Within hours, without fail, a pair of purple finches take up residence, and in a day or two create a nest deep in the protected center of the plant.

title: 'A Walker' in His Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rancher and The Grizzly
description: The ''exiguousness,'' to quote rancher Ira Perkins, of livings made from the land seems to be a persistent problem of the American economy. It affects all agricultural sectors, and, on the whole, grizzlies have little to do with it.

title: DANCE: ALFARO-GONZALEZ
description: ACTORS and dancers never seem to tire of putting on plays and dances about actors and dancers struggling to put on plays and dances. That's hardly surprising, for performers always want to get jobs.

title: POLISH SEAMEN ARE FINDING ASYLUM IN CLEVELAND
description: This city, known for its steel mills and financial crises, has in recent months become an unlikely symbol of freedom for a small group of Polish seamen who jumped ship and sought political asylum in this country.

title: PIECE BY PIECE, THE BIG STORES REBUILD
description: ''MAKING a statement'' is one of the latest buzzwords in retailing, generally used to describe a designer's new line or a best-selling department. In the retailing business itself, however, it is the specialty stores - The Limited, Benetton, The Banana Republic, Crazy Eddie - that have made the most noticeable statements in recent years, while the giant department stores have generally plodded along.

title: A Detail Overlooked: No Luggage on Plane
description: The chartered airplane carrying vacationers to the Mediterranean had just reached cruising altitude when the 100 passengers got a startling message from the pilot.

title: GENERAL FAULTS ARMY RESERVES AND TRAINING
description: An Army general, in response to a request from his commanding officer, has submitted a scathing appraisal of the Army's reserve forces, its training of troops in the active forces and its operating procedures.

title: HOW TO MAKE A PICTURE BOOK
description: OF the 92 illustrations Sir John Tenniel drew for Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking-Glass,'' the author was only really happy with one. ''There is nothing quite as difficult to handle as an author with a wonderful manuscript and definite ideas about its illustration,'' Ursula Nordstrom said recently. The former publisher of Harper Junior Books and a leader in her field, Miss Nordstrom is one of a few people who believe that, despite the difficulties, a better book results when the author and illustrator have a good working relationship.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia; Rules to Curb Lender Abuses
description: AS mortgage-interest rates dropped dramatically last summer, banks and brokers across the country were overwhelmed with applications. There was also a flood of complaints. ''We received hundreds of phone calls and complaints by people who felt that they were being taken by brokers,'' said Robert Gentzel, the press secretary for Pennsylvania's Attorney General, Leroy S. Zimmerman.

title: BACKPACKING: AN UNLIKELY THRILL
description: DID you ever wonder why some people use their precious vacation time to haul groceries into the wilderness? Camping, in my mind, stands for reversion to primitive behavior. What were our ancestors here for anyway, if not to endow us with asphalt shingle roofs and multi-spray shower heads?

title: November Bridal For Miss Bartlett
description: Announcement has been made by Elizabeth E. Bartlett of New York and Peter B. Bartlett of Summit and Bay Head, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Kimberley Bartlett, to Gilbert Schaefer Kernan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Kernan Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich. A November wedding is planned.

title: EUROPE GRUMBLING ON DANILOFF CASE
description: The case of Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American correspondent charged with espionage in Moscow, has quickened European anxieties about the course of Soviet-American relations. It has also provoked criticism of the Reagan Administration's response from the right as well as the left.

title: SOUTHERN CAL UPSETS BAYLOR
description: With lightning cracking and rain pouring, Don Shafer made a 32-yard field goal on the final play today to give Southern Cal a 17-14 upset of Baylor.

title: Roman Ices
description: To the Editor: I read with pleasure the article by Louis Inturrisi on Rome's grattachecche (Travel, July 27). Having been a resident in the neighborhood of Testaccio in Rome for several years, let me make the following remarks.

title: REAL LIFE BUOYS 'THAT'S LIFE!'
description: ''That's Life!,'' Blake Edwards's new movie, takes place over the course of a weekend. A husband and wife, played by Jack Lemmon and Julie Andrews, are in crisis. He is an architect who is coming unglued because he's about to turn 60, he's scared he's impotent, and all his clients have mashed potatoes for brains. Wherever he looks, the dark is closing in. His trouble is in his head, or at least, his soul. His wife's trouble is different; she is waiting to hear from their doctor about whether or not she has a malignancy.

title: ISLANDER ROOKIES TRY TO MAKE MARK
description: Brent Sutter, awaiting the drop of the puck at center ice inside the Spectrum, looked to his right and saw an unfamiliar face, and the same thing happened when he glanced to his left, a position often frequented by his brother, Duane. What Sutter saw, in both cases, was a glimpse of the Islanders' future in a pair of their top draft prospects from 1985.

title: SYRACUSE NOW 0-3 AFTER LOSS TO VIRGINIA TECH
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 (AP) - Maurice Williams, a senior tailback, made two long touchdown runs and combined with Eddie Hunter to rush for 384 yards today to help Virginia Tech deal Syracuse its third consecutive loss, 26-17.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY SCHMIDT
description: Following are excerpts from the inaugural address today of Benno C. Schmidt Jr., president of Yale University:

title: Police Kill Escaped Convict In Brazil and Seize 3 Others
description: One of 14 convicts allowed to escape last Thursday in exchange for the release of 14 hostages, was killed by the police Friday and three others were recaptured, the police said today.

title: EXPERTS SEE RISK IN TROOP CARRIER
description: The Army's newest troop carrier would risk sinking if it tried to cross deep rivers in combat, according to weapon experts. The flaw, suggested by newly uncovered documents, could halt attacks across rivers in Europe, where the vehicle is deployed.

title: COLLEAGUES HONOR 90th BIRTHDAY OF VIRGIL THOMSON, FEISTY MAN OF MUSIC
description: TO some, like the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Ned Rorem, it is a tribute marking the 90th birthday of the man ''who put American music on the map.'' But to the man himself - Virgil Thomson, also a Pulitzer Prize winner - his birthday is only a coincidence at today's presentation of ''Americans in Paris'' at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: To The Rockies
description: A certain amount of loyal grumbling is audible on the staff of Senator Gary Hart as advisers for his 1988 Presidential campaign begin facing up to the reality of moving the operation to the Rockies in a few months. Mr. Hart, a Colorado Democrat, declined to seek re-election to the Senate to devote the next two years to a renewal and refinement of his 1984 campaign for the Democratic nomination. Apparently as part of an ''outsider'' strategy to divorce himself from Washington, he will put his headquarters near Denver, and some aides, used to the comforts of the capital, are assessing the political, social and cultural impact of this change.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHEN is a traffic sign not a traffic sign? When it is put up by a municipality or county without the authorization of the state's Department of Transportation and without a local ordinance.

title: Next Week; Should Pro Contracts Include Drug-Test Clauses?
description: Replies for publications should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Question of the Week, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Miss Franklin Wed to Derek Kirkland
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Ames Franklin, an associate in the investment banking division of Shearson Lehman Brothers, and Derek Granger Kirkland, an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company, took place yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Richard S. Spaulding performed the ceremony.

title: CYCLING THROUGH BRITAIN
description: Just as some countries are ideal for romance and others for relaxation, Britain is made for bicycling. This might seem a wildly eccentric thought to visitors who have found Britain to be often windy, chilly and rainy. Those who have traveled its country roads know that they often are hemmed in by hedges and in many areas plunge steeply into dells before shooting straight up the other side. In addition, most towns that draw visitors seem too compact or too well served by public transportation to make a bike useful, while London's geography and traffic are overwhelming.

title: THE RETURN OF BENAZIR BHUTTO: STRUGGLE IN PAKISTAN
description: THOUSANDS OF ROSE petals showered the path of Benazir Bhutto as she entered a packed auditorium in Karachi this summer. As the 33-year-old Pakistan opposition leader grinned and waved, the crowd stomped, clapped and chanted ''Benazir! Benazir!'' Miss Bhutto brushed the petals from her auburn hair and adjusted her chiffon scarf to keep it modestly covering her head. A rhythmic song blasted from the loudspeaker, half disco and half tribal beat from Baluchistan, sung in Urdu by a local pop music queen. Listen, all you holy warriors, Look at Benazir, the nation joins her, Long live Bhutto, long live Bhutto!

title: The Demand Side
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FAMILY SERVICE FETE
description: Five hundred multicolored, helium-filled balloons will rise into the early autumn sky Friday afternoon. Their release, scheduled for 5 o'clock in front of the heart-shaped sculpture at 123 Main Street in White Plains, marks the 75th anniversary of Family Service America and the 32d anniversary of its local branch, Family Service of Westchester.

title: 5 DIE IN JERSEY AUTO-TRUCK CRASH
description: Five members of a New Jersey family were killed yesterday morning when the car they were in was hit from behind and pushed into the path of a tractor-trailer on Route 45 in Mannington, N.J.

title: A MINING TRAGEDY, AND MORE PRESSURE FROM U.S. AND EUROPE
description: SOUTH AFRICA'S economy is powered by minerals, principally gold, diamonds and coal, taken from the earth by black migrant workers. Last week, in the country's worst gold-mining disaster on record, at least 177 people, all but five of them black mine workers, were killed by toxic fumes from a fire ignited by a welding torch in a tunnel at the Kinross mine, 60 miles east of Johannesburg.

title: TREASURES AMONG THE WILDFLOWERS
description: In a season when goldenrods and asters hold sway in fields and along roadsides, a shy yet regal couple hides at the edges of woods and in meadows.

title: SCHMIDT, INAUGURATED AT YALE, APPEALS FOR CAMPUS FREEDOM
description: Benno C. Schmidt Jr. was inaugurated today as the 20th president of Yale University in a traditional ceremony that he capped with a forceful appeal for new attention to freedom of expression on the nation's college campuses.

title: PREMIERE OF A LISZT WORK FOR 2 PIANOS
description: This year marks the centennial of the death of Franz Liszt, and there has been no shortage of celebration.

title: BOLTON FARM IS WHERE THE BUFFALO ROAM
description: SOME people keep poodles, others prefer tropical fish.

title: French Isles
description: To the Editor: My husband and I loved reading Christopher S. Wren's article on St. Pierre and Miquelon.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
BUYING MUTUAL FUNDS IN A SCARY MARKET
description: Many experts have suggested that investing in mutual funds is one of the best ways an individual can find some protection against a declining stock market. And when the Dow Jones industrial average cracked two weeks ago, plunging more than 120 points in two days, mutual fund managers apparently proved them right: During the worst part of the rout, the average equity mutual fund declined less than the overall market.

title: MYTHMAKING IN THE OLD WEST
description: ''T he West'' is a relative direction, implying an observer situated somewhere to the east (but not as far as ''the mysterious East'') ensconced in a central viewing position. Rarely straying from this vantage, ''The West of the Imagination,'' a documentary mini-series that begins tomorrow evening at 9 on most PBS stations (it is scheduled at 10 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13) takes the dislocation even further, going beyond geography as it attempts to explain what, in the days before National Geographic television specials, people who had never been to ''the West'' supposed it to be like, and how they got their impressions of it.

title: CASINOS MAP MARKETING PLANS
description: THIS city's 11 gambling casinos won $668.1 million over the summer, including $248.5 million in August alone, making it the best month the industry has ever had.

title: U.S. MAKES OFFER ON MID-RANGE ARMS
description: The United States has offered to the Soviet Union a new proposal on medium-range arms that would limit each side's weapons to 200 missile warheads, according to Administration and diplomatic sources.

title: Suzanne F. Clifton Becomes Bride of Peter Walsh
description: The Convent of the Sacred Heart Chapel in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Suzanne Frances Clifton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Clifton of Water Mill, L.I., and Peter Mallon Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Walsh of Manhattan. The Rev. Robert Kennedy and Msgr.

title: O.S.S. LIVES AGAIN AT SPIES' REUNION
description: Max Corvo, in town with 100 friends who are reliving the most exciting time of their lives, looked into a display case at one of the tools of his former trade. It was labeled ''Fairbairn/Sykes dagger.''

title: ASHEVILLE
description: It has been almost 100 years since the first train crossed the mountains and unloaded its cargo of tourists in what was then the small mountain town of Asheville, N.C. Asheville has boomed and busted several times since, but the astonishing thing is that it has gone almost unspoiled. The natural beauty of the Southern highlands has not only survived but also surmounted attempts to transform it. The folk musician, the clog dancer, the weaver, the bucket carver have all persisted.

title: Talking: Closings; Easing 11th-Hour Tensions
description: THE final hours leading up to a closing can be a highly emotional time. With the moving van at the door and major financial obligations already in place, any hint of a last-minute hitch can send both sides into paroxysms of anxiety or rage.

title: JANE FREILICHER CASTS HER LANDSCAPES IN A SPECIAL LIGHT
description: Of all the contemporary artists who have been working to sustain the traditions of still life and landscape painting, none may be more respected and influential than Jane Freilicher.

title: TRYING TO SHUT OFF THE TOXIC SPIGOT
description: SINCE the superfund law for cleaning up toxic waste expired a year ago, Congress has engaged in a game of ''Beat the Clock'' as it tries to keep the program alive with round after round of temporary funding.

title: Making Money and Being a Parent in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS MAY TEST FOR DRUGS
description: THE Old Saybrook Board of Education is considering a new policy on student drug abuse which would include urine-testing of students suspected of using illegal drugs. A vote on the proposal is expected next month.

title: Sandra Thornton, a Ph.D. Candidate, Weds Sheldon Whitehouse, a Lawyer
description: At the St. George's School Chapel in Newport, R.I., yesterday Sandra Christine Thornton, a daughter of Daphne Sellar Thornton of Newport and Henry H. M. Thornton of Sheffield, Mass., was married to Sheldon Whitehouse, a son of Charles S. Whitehouse of Marshall, Va., and the late Mary Rand Whitehouse. The Rev. John S. Rogers, the Episcopal chaplain of the school, performed the ceremony.

title: Another Attack
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Quincy, Mass.;
Waterfront Affordables
description: ALTHOUGH Massachusetts has 2,000 miles of coastline, life at the water's edge is expensive: Prices for shore condominiums and houses range from about $300,000 to $1 million, according to Dennis Ducsik, a spokesman for the state Coastal Zone Management Office.

title: INVITATIONAL IN ORANGE COUNTY FEATURES JOHNS, POUSETTE-DART
description: OFFICIALLY, it is the ''Mount Aramah Exhibition'' and, sponsored by Assemblywoman Mary McPhillips, it is part of the ''I Love New York Fall Festival,'' through Oct. 31. The setting, an especially lovable corner in the state, is the complex of pre-Civil War structures that once housed the Clove Furnace ironworks but is now the premises of the Orange County Historical Association, in Arden, N.Y., north of Suffern.

title: Wetlands
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE RIVER NIGER' AT THE CROSSROADS
description: IN THE last couple of decades, black drama has blazed forth with power and glory. Mostly, it has been nurtured by institutional theaters.

title: Arab Shot in Gaza Strip
description: A 21-year-old Arab was reportedly shot dead by Israeli troops who were quelling a riot this morning in Rafa, a Gaza Strip town on the Egyptian border.

title: H.G.WELLS: SOCIALIST, FEMINIST, POLYMATH, EDUCATOR AND HERO
description: The late summer and early autumn of 1986 mark major anniversaries for the protean literary figure H. G. Wells. As he was born 120 years ago this Sept. 21, and died 40 years ago on Aug. 14, Wellsians all over hehe world are reassessing his life. It is time, many feel, to reckon with H. G. Wells.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Custom Dressmaking And Ready-to-Wear Velda Design opened as a retail shop nearly a year ago on Route 22 in Bedford Village near the corner of Court Street after years of being a business-in-the-home. The shop does custom dressmaking, bridal parties and alterations for men's and women's clothing and custom handknitting of sweaters and design of coordinated skirts. It also has Indonesian ready-to-wear, Irish hand-knitted and hand-woven wares, Yugoslavian hand knits and modern and antique jewelry. All elderly people obtain a 10 percent discount.

title: Miss Otto Marries Marcus Christ Jr.
description: The marriage of Shelley Ann Otto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Otto of Durban, South Africa, to Marcus Hallsted Christ Jr., a son of Justice M. Hallsted Christ of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Christ of Oyster Bay, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Babos performed the ceremony.

title: THE ELECTORAL EVANGELISM OF PAT ROBERTSON
description: THIS past Wednesday evening, when the Rev. Pat Robertson announced on closed-circuit television from Constitution Hall that three million signatures on a petition would move him to seek the Republican Presidential nomination, the name heard most often was not his. It was God's.

title: Allison C. Blackfield Wed To Jeffrey Allan McKinnon
description: Allison Clark Blackfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy G. Blackfield Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Allan McKinnon, a son of June P. McKinnon of South Hadley, Mass., and Allan McKinnon of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. Robert Walker performed the ceremony at the Darien United Methodist Church.

title: Recent Sales
description: Farmingville $71,500 63 Columbus Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,100. Franklin Square $221,000 812 Morton Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath 35-year-old ranch; dining room, den, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,300.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT IN THE FALL FOR HEAD START ON SPRING
description: THE advantages of fall planting have long been stressed in this column. There are several advantages in planting at this time of year: The weather is usually more pleasant for working outdoors; the soil is less muddy than in the spring; nurseries, garden centers and landscapers are able to give you more attention, and getting plants established in the fall gives them a one-season headstart over those planted in the spring.

title: Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. $318,000 124 Wright Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old contemporary; swimming pool, pond, 7 acres; taxes $3,423. Clinton, Conn.

title: What Funeral in Istanbul Tells About Moslem-Jewish Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: SMOKELESS TOBACCO AND YOUTH STUDIED
description: CONCERN about possible health hazards of smokeless tobacco has prompted a professor at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington to undertake a study of its use by young people in the state.

title: STUDY FORESEES AN INCREASE IN THE CITY'S HOMELESS
description: While more than 4,360 families are now being housed temporarily by New York City in shelters and hotels, tens of thousands of additional families are in danger of becoming homeless, according to a study released yesterday by three advocacy groups.

title: Vast Police Layoffs Threatened in Chicago
description: Almost half of Chicago's police officers and firefighters will be laid off unless the City Council agrees to a $79.9 million property tax increase by Wednesday, city officials say.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: 3d STRAIGHT VICTORY FOR GUIDRY
description: The failure of the Yankee starting pitchers has only served to draw more attention to Ron Guidry's struggles this year. He had been a constant since 1977, a three-time 20-game winner on a staff often made up of remnants. Now, in the final days of what may be his most disappointing season, Guidry is pitching for respectability and a new contract.

title: A WINTER GARDEN
description: How tempting to ignore the garden in winter. Forgotten are summer's vibrant blooms and the russet hues of autumn. Yet, a frost-gray landscape lingers beyond the window.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SINGLETUSK. By Bjorn Kurten. (Pantheon, $14.95.) With ''Dance of the Tiger,'' the eminent paleontologist Bjorn Kurten turned to fiction so as to tell all ''that simply cannot be formulated in scientific reports.''

title: WOMAN GUILTY OF MANSLAUGHTER IN SHOOTING LOVER
description: A 25-year-old woman who testified that she killed her lover because he raped her and he threatened to harm their 7-month-old baby has been convicted of manslaughter.

title: SALE OF ISLAND WHERE WAR DEAD ARE BURIED STIRS A DISPUTE
description: Echoes of the War of 1812 are once again reverberating above the placid waters of Lake Champlain, 172 years after a famous battle there.

title: PRETORIA FOE MEETS 2 WESTERN OFFICIALS
description: The exiled leader of the main black political movement in South Africa, the African National Congress, held separate talks here today with an American official, Chester A. Crocker, and with the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe.

title: Field Trip to Venezuela's Andes
description: Why are trees so scarce in alpine regions of the equatorial zone, where other vegetation thrives? This question is the basis for two scientific expeditions to the Venezuelan Andes, Dec. 15 to 29 and Feb. 2 to 15. The trips, led by John King of the University of California at Davis, are part of a series conducted by the University Research Expeditions Program.

title: FORUM LETS SOVIET HEAR U.S. CRITICISM
description: American diplomats attending a Soviet-American conference here this week said they could not recall another occasion when such a sustained critique of Soviet policies was approved for domestic consumption.

title: THE HIGH COST OF GOING BACK IN TIME
description: LAST May, when a 1955 Split Second Wrist Chronogragh with Perpetual Calendar, made by Swiss watchmaker Patek Philippe, sold for $158,889 at Christie's auction in Geneva, history was made. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for a wristwatch.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Renovate weak lawns and plant seed or sod for new ones. . . . Water well any new plantings especially shrubs and perennials. . . . Finish pruning overgrown hedges. . . . Complete the peach harvest and start picking ripe apples. New Series The age of specialization is catching up with the garden world. Several series of books - on single topics -have made their debut. The individual books are good for in-depth study, at least, and they don't weigh as much as a full encyclopedia might. They certainly are easier to keep on the lap for an evening's reading.

title: Community Boards Gaining in Power
description: THE meeting has dissolved into pandemonium. Many members of the board are shouting. Others are talking among themselves. A few are trying to regain control of the session. After several minutes of gavel-pounding and trying to speak above the noise, the chairman calms the group and announces yet another roll-call vote.

title: W.A. Fraser Wed To Marian Frank
description: Marian Elizabeth Frank, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sam Hager Frank of Grymes Hill, Staten Island, was married yesterday to William Allen Fraser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Franklin Fraser of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. John Howard Walsted performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in New Brighton, S.I.

title: Out to Campaign
description: Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon has had a busy year. He faced a serious challenge for renomination in his state's Republican primary and since May has been running to retain his seat.

title: COMEDY: McLENNAN
description: THE young Scottish performance artist-comedian Oscar McLennan has a wonderful repertory of facial tics - a gapingly frightened stare, cheek muscles that seem to turn his cavernous face into a mass of quivering nerves, and a mouth whose corners twitch in four different directions at once. When Mr. McLennan revs himself into a state of high anxiety, he recalls Dudley Moore in the middle of one of his splenetic fits.

title: LOUISIANA ST. UPSET BY MIAMI OF OHIO
description: Terry Morris and Andy Schillinger combined on an 82-yard scoring pass play in the third quarter and a defense led by Bob Getz protected that lead as Miami of Ohio upset Louisiana State, 21-12, tonight.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SONG OF THE SILENT SNOW. By Hubert Selby Jr. (Marion Boyars, $16.95.) Hubert Selby Jr. has created more Harrys than any writer since Shakespeare. They turn up in all of his novels: as the loudmouthed union thug fatally attracted to drag queens in ''Last Exit to Brooklyn,'' as the imagined sadistic rapist in ''The Room,'' as the sexually obsessive hero of ''The Demon'' and as an addict in search of the big payoff in ''Requiem for a Dream.'' It comes as no surprise that in this collection of stories we meet many more Harrys. Among them: a loser trying to impress a date; a salesman on a lucky streak; a Bowery bum; a middle-class suburbanite recovering from a nervous breakdown. Though they often resemble each other, they are seldom the same Harry. Mr. Selby has taken the theme of the double and given it a modern twist - a character who metastasizes new identities in story after story. Though the dark shadow of Edgar Allan Poe hangs over these split egos, the dominant emotion is not so much horror as panic. For Mr. Selby, panic seems to be the prevailing emotion of contemporary life, the nexus of blurred identity and sexual violence. ''Song of the Silent Snow'' fails to find the narrative grooves that made ''Last Exit to Brooklyn'' so memorable. The tone of the collection is dated; a few of the stories were published before ''Last Exit'' and several others sound like early efforts. Mr. Selby himself seems conscious of a stilted style.

title: Who Reads 'Regrets Only'?
description: To the Editor:

title: HOPE AND HONEY
description: TWO YEARS AGO, I WAS ASKED TO write a kosher nouvelle cuisine cookbook. Why me? I protested. My knowledge of kosher cuisine was nil. I was French, raised in a convent. I knew nothing of Jewish tradition, possessed no childhood memories to help me conjure up recipes. The little I knew was that kosher cooking was often overdone, heavy, high in cholesterol and, above all, unimaginative. But, I was told, nowhere is it written that this should be so.
