I learned that there are a growing number of young people who, while not brought up in a kosher tradition, are now keeping a kosher home. Their taste is sophisticated; they are seeking a natural, light and varied cuisine in elegant recipes that bridge their past and their present commitment. This was a challenge I could not turn down.

title: Texas Air Takes Two Giant Steps
description: Frank Lorenzo said from the start that all he wanted for his little Texas Air Corporation was enough size to stand up to the competition in the deregulated skies. He got his wish last week, and maybe then some.

title: McENROE, YES OR NO
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT IN THE FALL FOR HEAD START ON SPRING
description: THE advantages of fall planting have long been stressed in this column. There are several advantages in planting at this time of year: The weather is usually more pleasant for working outdoors; the soil is less muddy than in the spring; nurseries, garden centers and landscapers are able to give you more attention, and getting plants established in the fall gives them a one-season headstart over those planted in the spring.

title: Topics: Political Performances; Serving All the Public
description: We have no opinion on whom the Queens Democratic organization should choose to succeed the late Donald Manes as its chairman. We have a strong opinion that it should not be Congressman Thomas Manton, City Councilman Morton Povman or any other elected official.

title: Miss Benenson Wed To Peter Amstel Land
description: Kimberly Benenson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Benenson of New York, was married last evening to Peter Amstel Land, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Land of New London, Conn., and New York. Rabbi Aaron Pearlstein performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: DO'S AND DON'TS FOR HIRING
description: EMPLOYMENT agencies, lawyers, housekeepers and Government officials offer the following advice for hiring a live-in housekeeper:

title: MUSIC SEASON: THE GROWTH CONTINUES
description: 9403>CONTINUING an astonishing growth begun a few years ago in both the number and quality of professional concerts, New Jersey will offer, in the 1986-87 season, musical programs in a broad variety of styles. Equally impressive is the enthusiasm of concertgoers: Many groups whose performing homes range from small churches to large concert halls play to capacity audiences.

title: IS THERE TOO MUCH FOOTBALL ON TV?
description: Yes, there is too much football on TV, but not on the dimension that the question implies. The problem is not the number of games, but the duration. Compounding the problem is the networks' misuse of their communication ability to keep the viewer informed about every other game in progress, plus, every other sporting event in the world. Not only does this take time, but it severely disrupts the continuity of the game. The endless stream of meaningless statistics and ''color'' commentary don't help the situation either. Perhaps the National Football League, College Football Association and the networks should take a lesson from the minimalists: Less is more.

title: Cable TV
description: Five years in the making from a 2,000-page script chronicling 63 years of Germany history, ''Heimat'' was a popular success in Europe before its United States premiere in 1985 at the New Directors/New Films Festival. Beginning Sunday night when its first two parts will be shown beginning at 8 P.M., the film - praised by Vincent Canby as ''immensely, easily watchable'' -will unfold on Bravo in eight installments presented during four nights.

title: TUTUS AND BEYOND
description: BALLET & MODERN DANCE A Concise History. By Jack Anderson. Illustrated. 243 pp. New Jersey: Princeton Book Company. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: BOND ISSUE BACKED
description: DESPITE widespread uncertainty over how much money Long Island would receive and the extent to which the Island's environmental problems would be met, government officials and local environmentalists are supporting the State Environmental Quality Bond Act that will be on the ballot Nov. 4.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UNHALLOWED GROUND. By Paul Guernsey. (Morrow, $16.95.) Wildcats howl, Grandpa Tarbox tells frightening tales, young men shoot at rusted cars in the eerie but life-giving swamp - you must constantly remind yourself that this first novel takes place somewhere between Hartford and Bridgeport, not Tallahassee and Jacksonville.

title: 12 Food Outlets Cited By New York Officials
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 12 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: David Huffine Exchanges Vows With Ellen Noble
description: The marriage of Ellen Noble and David K. Huffine took place yesterday at St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Jamestown, R.I. The Rev. Gregory Floyd performed the ceremony, assisted by the Revs. Peter Sidler and Andrew Jenks.

title: SUDAN WAR: STARVATION IS A WEAPON
description: With food supplies cut off for more than a month, hundreds of thousands of people are starving in the southern Sudan, and the death toll could reach two million, Western relief workers say.

title: STRAPPING ON A STYLE FOR ANY OCCASION
description: WALTER J. Jamieson Jr., a framing consultant for New York Museums, was decked out in full regalia at the opening party for the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center. He wore a tuxedo, a cummerbund, a black tie - and a plastic Swatch that probably cost $30. ''I'm perfectly comfortable wearing this,'' he said.

title: AGONY OF SUCCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: COCAINE USERS OVERWELMING STATE DRUG-TREATMENT CENTERS
description: ALREADY strained by cutbacks in funds, New Jersey's drug-treatment centers are being overwhelmed by users of crack, a highly addictive and relatively inexpensive form of cocaine.

title: LONG ISAND JOURNAL
description: THE GOOD SCOUT THE United Way's 1986-87 poster girl, a Girl Scout named Mary Linkowski, was to celebrate a birthday yesterday. ''She'll be 97,'' said Gordon Gibson, a United Way spokesman.

title: FINDING A NEW LIFE OUT EAST
description: OUR friends worried about us. They couldn't understand why ''at our age'' we would be eager to give up a beautiful home and a well-established life to move to East Hampton.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: TOURS OF DU PONT ESTATE

title: SHRINKING THE WORLD THROUGH ART
description: AFTER a rare opportunity to work with a group of ceramists from Eastern and Western Europe, Marion Weiss-Munk, an associate professor of visual arts at Middlesex County College here, has returned with a new zest for her teaching role.

title: PIQUANCY OF VIETNAM IN HARTFORD
description: VIETNAMESE cuisine is slowly making itself known in this country - and high time, too. Using many of the by now familiar ingredients of its Chinese neighbor, Vietnamese cooking has its own special distinction, a refreshingly sharp clarity that is unique.

title: DATA UPDATE: September 21, 1986
FAST-GROWING KENT TRIES TO SLOW DOWN
description: LEOLA DOTSON, the postmaster of Kent, got a shock recently when a staff shortage forced her to work at the sales window for a few days.

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE professional hole-in-one record of 47 set a year ago by Mancil Davis has been broken, according to the National Hole-In-One Association. It said Davis claimed the new record of 48 with an ace on the 155-yard eighth hole at the Pedernales Country Club in Spicewood, Tex., on Wednesday. . . . James Bell, a defensive back for the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League, suffered a serious spinal injury while making a tackle in a game Friday and is partially paralyzed, club officials said. . . . Rebecca Twig, who won a gold medal in cycling at the 1984 Olympics, and Davis Phinney, who won a bronze, have entered the Marine Midland Oyster Festival Cycling Classic at Oyster Bay, L.I., next Sunday.

title: PARING DOWN
description: In 1897, when Charles Scribner's Sons published a book called ''The Decoration of Houses,'' by Edith Wharton, then a relatively unknown writer, and the Boston architect Ogden Codman Jr., it was clear from the introduction that the authors had a mission: to rescue interior design from ''a superficial application of ornament.'' Elsie de Wolfe, the renowned decorator, joined the cause several years later when she preached suitability, simplicity and proportion. To her, a house in good taste meant decorating by ''process of elimination.'' Removing such Victorian trappings as potted palms, Oriental hangings and velvet portieres, she let light inside American homes for the first time in decades.

title: NEW TURNTABLES SERVE LP'S
description: It was a dim prognosis. According to the more fervent apostles of digital sound, the conventional LP was expected to turn moribund in an environment strongly permeated by the light of the laser and swiftly go the way of the Edison cylinder.

title: STUDENT ATHLETES GET EKG
description: NICHOLAS BATSIDIS, a junior at Paul D. Schreiber High School in Port Washington, received a little extra preparation for this year's varsity soccer season. Before starting play this month he had an electrocardiogram administered by the school nurse.

title: 50-YEAR-OLD UNION HAS LOST NONE OF ITS MILITANCY
description: In May the General Electric Company asked officers of Local 506 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, which represents workers at G.E.'s locomotive plant in Erie, Pa., to join company officials on a 10-day, expense-paid trip to Japan to observe manufacturing methods.

title: HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES: OUTLOOK FOR 1990
description: The article ''Colleges Try the Hard Sell'' reported that the State Education Department has projected that in 1990, 13,282 Long Island students will graduate from high school, compared with 18,557 this year.

title: Bumper Crop of Babies in '85
description: More babies were born in the United States in 1985 than in any year in the past two decades, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: FROM CONCILIATORY TALK TO A BITTER ACCUSATION
description: AT about this time last year, North and South Korea were swept up in a rare outbreak of civility. For months they had been meeting more or less regularly, discussing visits between members of war-torn families, possible economic cooperation and joint sports ventures. While no significant progress could be claimed, even mere talk was noteworthy, given four decades of hatred between them. If nothing else, the discussions offered a sliver of hope that both sides were ready to ease tensions on their heavily armed peninsula and that the North was finally trying to emerge from its thick shell of diplomatic isolation.

title: INQUIRY ENDS ON EX-BENEFITS COMMISSIONER
description: The Justice Department has cleared a former Social Security Commissioner of conflict-of-interest allegations stemming from the 1982 award of a computer contract to a concern where the official once worked.

title: Outdoors; Founding of Sporting Museum Proposed
description: DURING the past few decades, many Americans have become fascinated with antique waterfowl decoys, fine firearms both old and new, and rods, reels and lures of yesteryear, as well as the art and literature of hunting and fishing. With this in mind, it was probably inevitable that someone would propose a museum devoted to the venerable equestrian-hunting tradition.

title: 'INDEPENDENT FOCUS' AS A SHOWCASE FOR CONTROVERSIAL FILMS
description: To the Editor: As a feminist scholar, it was sad and laughable to see the otherwise articulate John Corry taken by surprise by his own gut reaction to the film ''Born in Flames,'' which he recently reviewed [ '' 'Born in Flames' Is 90 Minutes of Fizzle,'' Aug. 24 ] displacing that reaction with an attack on the artistic integrity of everyone, from Channel 13, the National Endowment for the Arts and independent film makers in general to Lizzie Borden, the ground-breaking auteur/director whose work he was obviously unfamiliar with.

title: Pop Music
description: Dr. John, whose splendid ''Gumbo'' album of New Orleans rhythm-and-blues classics was recently reissued by Alligator Records, and Allen Toussaint, the distinguished New Orleans pianist, producer, and songwriter, make a formidable team. Dr. John is a scrappy player with plenty of back-in-the-alley blues feeling. Mr. Toussaint is a visionary who frames riffs from the great blues pianist Professor Longhair in the style of a Chopin prelude. Together, they wail.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN WATCHES
description: THE watch industry has taken some unpredictable turns of late. Digitals, so hugely popular in the 1970's, have fallen into disfavor here. The Japanese, not the Swiss, are overall industry leaders, and now account for a 39 percent share of the 440 million watches sold internationally each year. And watches have become hot fashion items, to be changed as easily and readily as a scarf. Says Samuel Beizer, chairman of the jewelery design department of the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan: ''Watches are a very trendy business these days.''

title: Top Official of I.M.F. Is Said to Plan to Quit
description: Jacques de Larosiere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has told its executive board that he intends to resign at the end of this year or as early as possible next year, according to sources close to him.

title: THE PERILS OF REPORTING FROM MOSCOW
description: THE VOICE ON THE PHONE was familiar, a foreigner in Moscow with good Soviet sources. ''Nick Daniloff has been arrested and will be charged with espionage,'' he said.

title: Taken Aback
description: Washington has been boasting a lot lately about the increasing sophistication of its restaurant scene, and rightly so, considering some meals past.

title: MAKING ELECTRONIC EDITING EASIER
description: At summer's end, video fans by the thousands head homeward laden with taped mementos of holidays and travels. But when they finally run those cassettes through the VCR at home, the results are often disappointing. Splendid shots of one thing or another are interspersed with failed footage, and the scenes gathered randomly afield often lack dramatic progression or logical sequence. The net effect is best described in John Donne's despairing words as ''all coherence gone.'' What is needed, obviously, is a ruthless editing job.

title: Of Bathrooms And Scholarship
description: THE news article said Veterans High School in Warwick, R.I., was trying to improve students' grades by curbing their visits to the bathroom.

title: Classical Music
description: The Merkin Concert Hall, at the Hebrew Arts School, is one of our most elegant and attractive smaller auditoriums, and this week there are several good reasons to pay it a visit.

title: FABRICS: WEAVING A SUBTLE YARN
description: In an attempt to create what Henry James once described as ''a wilderness of faded chintz,'' fabric houses have been producing lavish floral designs emblazoned with ribbons and bows. While these patterns in the past have been the perfect answer for those decorators endeavoring to create the English country look, they are slowly being replaced this season by quieter, more subdued designs. The new emphasis is on textured fabrics such as Jacquards, damasks, sharkskin prints and chenille plaids.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MALDIVE MYSTERY. By Thor Heyerdahl. (Adler & Adler, $19.95.) The tireless seafaring detective Thor Heyerdahl is back on the case.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MILK DAY
description: The plastic containers of milk in the dairy section of supermarkets will mean a lot more to the children and adults who visited Muscoot Farm Park in Somers last Sunday afternoon on Milk Appreciation Day. The estimated 1,000 visitors saw a variety of exhibits including model cows of the major dairy breeds, a film on milk production from cows to store shelves and a demonstration of cows being milked. Visitors were also able to test their knowledge about milk at an electric ''Milk Quiz Board.''

title: Wayward Domicile Recovered in California
description: A two-bedroom house disappeared earlier this week from the lot where it was standing but has now turned up in another neighborhood 10 miles away, the authorities said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page Sept. 7, about the collection at the Folger Library, misidentifed the king to whom Anne of Cleves presented an illuminated prayer book. He was Henry VIII, not Henry VII.

title:
About Men;
The Geriatric Jump
description: THE JUMP PLANE WAS A Cessna 182. All the seats, except the pilot's, had been taken out, and we were sitting on the floor - the three beginning skydivers, ready for our first jump, and the jumpmaster.

title: A DEBATE ON ETHICS AND WORLD VIOLENCE
description: THE United States must take steps to thwart terrorism and develop a longterm policy founded on moral principles, a Connecticut expert on international terrorism says.

title: POSTPARTUM MANIA
description: MAUD GONE By Kathleen Rockwell Lawrence. 249 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: TICKET SALES LAGGING FOR THE ARTS
description: THE Long Island music season opens Thursday with a performance by the Festival of India at C. W. Post's Tilles Center. The season will include performances on the Island by such names as Yehudi Menuhin and the Chicago Symphony.

title: Gardner Isn't Homer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Helping Hand To Print Trades
description: FACED with the gradual loss of Manhattan's printing industry because of soaring rent and labor costs, the Koch administration offered to help in August 1985.

title: FRESH CORIANDER FINDS ITS WAY INTO THE AMERICAN CUISINE
description: FIRST it was sun-dried tomatoes and basil; now fresh coriander is cropping up all over. This herb has always been used to flavor Chinese, Latin American or Moroccan dishes, but recently it has become part of the new eclectic American cuisine.

title:
WINE;
RATINGS: HANDLE WITH CARE
description: PRESUMABLY as an aid to consumers, a number of area wine shops and restaurants display ratings given at tastings to bottles in stock. But the ratings are difficult for consumers to use to compare similar products from different outlets because there are a variety of methods to judge the esthetics of wine and not all local establishments use the same system.

title: PLAYING TO THE HOME FRONT
description: BOLD DRAGOON The Life of J. E. B. Stuart. By Emory M. Thomas. Illustrated. 354 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: House Endorses Aid to Angolans
description: President Reagan's supporters in the House argued successfully last week that the world is a ''tough'' place in which secret aid must be provided to rebels in countries such as Angola, Afghanistan and Ethiopia. A coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats voted down a proposal by the Intelligence Committee that would have restored the ban on covert aid to Angolan rebels, which Congress lifted last year.

title: DIOGUARDI TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO ABZUG
description: REPRESENTATIVE Joseph J. DioGuardi wasted little time moving into the most active phase of his re-election campaign this month. Even as the results of the Democratic primary were coming in on Sept. 9, radio and television stations were broadcasting the first DioGuardi campaign messages.

title: Producer Is Wed To Lydia Weaver
description: Lydia Weaver, the daughter of Fritz Weaver and Sylvia Short, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bruce Ostler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Bruce Ostler of Corte Madera, Calif. The Rev. Gayle Lehman-Becker, a Unitarian minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at the summer home of the bride's mother in Oak Beach, L.I.

title: THE DANCE: 'BALLROOM'
description: BALLROOM dancing need involve nothing more than people dancing together for their own amusement. They don't even have to be in a ballroom. Yet some ballroom dancers are more ambitious than that. Ballroom-dance organizations hold contests and award prizes, and a few performers put ballroom dance on stage to prove that it can be as satisfying to watch as the accepted theatrical forms of ballet and modern dance.

title: HARD QUESTIONS FOR MONTANA AND 49ers
description: NO football injury occurs in a vacuum, and when the victim has the stature of Joe Montana and the injury threatens his career, it becomes an event of more universal proportions. It also underscores the Big Question, in this case: Will Joe Montana, the quarterback and soul of the San Francisco 49ers, ever play football again?

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Adequacy of English Samuel Johnson's attitude toward the English language was like that of a loving but jealous husband. His criteria for correct usage are quoted in ''Johnson's Dictionary and the Language of Learning'' (University of North Carolina), by Robert DeMaria Jr.

title: RED SOX
description: Some statistics on the Red Sox, surprise leaders of the American League East. SERIES HISTORY After five straight victories, Boston has gone 67 years without tasting World Series champagne. 0 FOR 67 YEARS 1903 Defeated Pittsburgh, 5-3 Bill Dinneen and Cy Young each won two of the final four games in the first modern World Series.

title: Connecticut Water Improves
description: A state report issued today shows the state's water quality is improving, but persistent problems make only 68 percent of the state's 880 major river miles suitable for recreational use.

title: DIMMER SWITCHES SHEDDING LIGHT ON IMPROVING ILLUMINATION
description: DIMMER switches for lamps and lighting fixtures have become increasingly popular in recent years for several reasons.

title: REAGAN WAS A SUBJECT OF 60's SCREEN INQUIRY
description: A new book says that Ronald Reagan was investigated, and ultimately cleared, in a Federal criminal inquiry in the 1960's into allegations that the Hollywood entertainment conglomerate MCA had paid off officers of the Screen Actors Guild.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 21, 1986
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 2 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 2 8 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 3 10 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 4 4 12 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could affect the cold war. 5 8 3 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's coming of age in 18th-century England and France. 6 5 15 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 7 6 5 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two men, passion and power brokering in Washington. 8 12 6 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 9 1 ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers. 10* 7 29 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong. 11 14 44 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 12* 9 14 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 13 13 22 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 14 11 17 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their honeymoon. 15 10 19 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 16* 15 22 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 20 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 28 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 3 19 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 4 5 22 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 5 4 15 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 6 6 13 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life. 7 11 23 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 8 7 14 FORD: The Men and the Machine, by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 9 9 25 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 10 8 10 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation by the film director King Vidor of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 11 10 10 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. M. Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 12 14 3 STRANGER IN TWO WORLDS, by Jean Harris. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The recollections of a prep school headmistress who killed her lover and is now serving a prison term. 13* 13 5 THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by Barbara Branden. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of the author of ''The Fountainhead.'' 14 1 MAYFLOWER MADAME, by Sidney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's oldest profession. 15 9 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by James Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged - and is being stymied by diplomats and bureaucrats. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 1 18 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 2 57 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 3 65 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 1 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) Coping with overbearing men. 5 5 43 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) EISENHOWER: AT WAR. 1943-1945, by David Eisenhower. (Random House, $29.95.) Conceived as the first of three volumes on the author's grandfather, this thoughtful history argues that President Eisenhower's political acumen had been developed -and thoroughly - by the necessities of fighting a coalition war. THE PROGRESS OF LOVE, by Alice Munro. (Knopf, $16.95.) Mortality, self-delusion and the inexplicable ways of fate are the chief themes confronted by these 11 dark, dense short stories, most of them set in the Canadian author's home province, Ontario. A MACHINE THAT WOULD GO OF ITSELF: The Constitution in American Culture, by Michael Kammen. (Knopf, $29.95.) An authoritative and profoundly discouraging exploration of popular understanding of our fundamental political charter. ME AND DIMAGGIO: A Baseball Fan Goes in Search of His Gods, by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The author, a daily book reviewer for The Times, meets his heroes and takes us along on his eloquent, awe-filled pilgrimage. GOD'S SNAKE, by Irini Spanidou. (Norton, $15.95.) A fresh and vigorous contribution to the novel of childhood, in which a father's military rigidity helps form a girl into an artist. CADILLAC DESERT: The American West and Its Disappearing Water, by Marc Reisner. (Viking, $22.95.) Federal water development in the West has been highly productive, but its full costs have yet to be paid, this trenchant analysis contends. SAINTS AND STRANGERS, by Angela Carter. (Viking, $13.95.) Eight stories in the unique voice of this master of so-called ''magic realism''; historically grounded characters (E. A. Poe, Lizzie Borden) inhabit fantasies in the guise of historical meditations.

title: A SHORTAGE OF FOOTBALL PLAYERS
description: AS the county's high school football season opened yesterday, the thoughts occupying Frank Violante, coach of the team that has had the longest unbroken winning streak in its division in state high school football history, were unusually bleak.

title: Patricia Leigh Hosking Weds >R. B. >Pressman
description: Patricia Leigh Hosking, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hosking of New York and Forestburgh, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Bradford Pressman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pressman of Bryn Mawr, Pa. Rabbi Abraham Krantz performed the ceremony at the Hartwood Club in Forestburgh.

title: EAST-WEST TALKS KEEP INCHING TOWARD A PACT
description: Warsaw Pact and NATO negotiators continued to inch toward agreement today on a historic East-West security pact designed to reduce the risk of war in Europe.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Modesty is not Andrew M. Greeley's game in GOD GAME (Warner, $16.95). Early on, he draws some instructive analogies between his own work and the works of Gide, Proust, Joyce and Conrad. To be fair, he refers not to their use of language or psychological insights but to their sometimes testy relationships with their fictional alter egos. It is Father Greeley's point that all writers are less-than-omnipotent creators whose struggles to control their creations can teach us something about the theological concept of grace.

title: CAN PASSAIC MATCH ITS PAST
description: WHAT no one seems to recall in the millions of words written about the fire that devastated Passaic on Labor Day 1985 is that the site once before made the front pages of newspapers all across the country.

title: Rutgers Trounces Cincinnati, 48-28
description: Joe Gagliardi threw four touchdown passes, two to Brian Cobb, leading Rutgers to a 48-28 victory over the University of Cincinnati today before a homecoming crowd of 27,249 at Rutgers Stadium.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: A VOICE FROM THE PAST;
WHAT DRIVES GREAT MEN OF COMMERCE
description: (The name of Walter Bagehot, editor of The Economist magazine from 1861 to 1877, is recognized only dimly, if at all, by most Americans. Yet, this economist, writer and editor - whose name rhymes with gadget - wielded enormous influence in Victorian England through his deft commentaries on politics, history and economics. Over the last 20 years, Norman St. John-Stevas, a former British cabinet minister, has collected and edited Bagehot's prodigious life's work, which fills 15 volumes. It is published by The Economist and became available in the United States last week.

title: A Ray of Hope For AIDS Patients
description: A drug that was used unsuccessfully against cancer in the 1960's holds ''great promise for prolonging life for certain patients with AIDS,'' Federal health officials said last week. Scientists are so optimistic about the drug, called azidothymidine, that they are cutting short their tests on it and rushing to make it available in the next few months.

title: VALLEY STREAM LAKE SOURCE OF DISPUTE
description: VALLEY STREAM officials want to restore the lake in Hendrickson Memorial Park - little more than a 10-acre depression that fills only when heavy rains come. But a local citizens' group says the lake can be restored for perhaps one-tenth the proposed amount, and advocates a broader project.

title: RECENT RECORDINGS OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Ricky Nelson in Concert MCA Home Video 21 minutes. $19.95

title: Playing Lottery On Welfare
description: NOT long after California began its state lottery last October, public protests arose over some of the winners of the top $2 million prize.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
ROWAYTON
description: ONCE an oyster center, then a Victorian summer community, Rowayton has always had a special relationship with its waterfront. The shellfish are no longer so plentiful, but there are still five boat service operators in a community that has but one liquor store, one traffic light and one food market.

title: NIGHT SOUNDS OF THE DESERT
description: You go from amazed wondering to tentative naming, aware that, with flashlight in mouth and book in hand, you may be altering the experience even as it unfolds.

title: IN COLOGNE, 2 MUSEUMS UNDER 1 ROOF OFFER MASTERS OLD AND NEW
description: As of last Sunday, the great city of Cologne on the Rhine got itself an arts complex that could hardly have a more spectacular location, wedged as it is between the enormous cathedral and the no less enormous river. If the complex does not quite literally ''stand tall,'' it is doubtless because the cathedral is not a building to trifle with.

title: SHEVARDNADZE DECLARATION AFTER TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at his news conference last night at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, as translated by an interpreter and recorded by The New York Times:

title: How to Polish Yanks' Image
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hofstra Defeats Stony Brook by 13-3
description: Mike Codella made a 23-yard touchdown run between a pair of 37-yard field goals by Phil Kuzniar as undefeated Hofstra snapped Stony Brook's six-game two-season winning streak, 13-3, yesterday at Patriot Field, Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Topics: Political Performances; Distress Sale
description: The final manipulations on next year's budget, a senator admits, have been nothing more than ''fine-tuning the smoke and mirrors.'' To squeeze the estimated deficit down to the ceiling prescribed by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, Congress resorted to tricks like shifting a $680 million payment date by one day to move it out of fiscal 1987; accelerating $500 million of tax collection deposits into fiscal 1987, and raising user fees on everything in sight.

title: SCHOLARS WIN TIME TO THINK
description: PROFESSOR Harold I. Bloom of Yale was spending so much time on the lecture circuit, that, he recalls, ''I was beginning to have bizarre dreams'' about missing airplane flights. Now, relieved of the need to go on tour, Dr. Bloom can usually be found in his favorite chair at his New Haven office, where he has taken on the mammoth task of writing critical introductions to the whole of literature, a project that has grown to about 2,000 volumes.

title: Keeping a Rooming House 'As Is'
description: ROWS of neat, fully occupied brownstones, many with long-term roomers, line some of the sidestreets of central Harlem. These town houses were built early in the century by wealthy people from downtown; years later, many were divided into tiny rooms and rented out for income.

title: THE ART AND DESIGN OF THE MACHINE AGE
description: WHILE MUCH of Europe was in disarray at the end of the Great War in 1918, the United States was entering a period of extravagant development of the man-made environment: majestic skyscrapers challenging old records of height; light, airy suspension bridges ringing new urban landscapes. Streamlined locomotives appeared, as well as airplanes and automobiles, concrete highways, airports and service stations - all bringing news of modernity into rural and urban worlds. In the more remote sections, giant dams and their hidden turbines represented the transforming force of electricity.

title: A STOP-AND-GO FUTURE FOR REAL ESTATE
description: THE proposed tax revolution was meant to be rough on real estate - and most experts agree that the legislators succeeded. If the tax bill is enacted, as seems likely, accelerated depreciation would be replaced by the more conservative straight-line method. The 19-year depreciation period would lengthen to 27 1/2 years for residential real estate and 31 1/2 years for commercial buildings, reducing investors' annual deductions.

title: CORRECTION
description: An outdated photograph appeared with a report about Conrail in The Week in Review last week, creating an incorrect impression of the rail line's service. Although the pictured train was operated by Conrail when the photograph was made, the line has not offered passenger service since 1982.

title: CHEESE BLINTZES FOR BISHOP SHEEN
description: PRAYING FOR RAIN By Jerome Weidman. 422 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: LIBERIAN OPPOSITION POLITICIAN FLEES TO NEW YORK
description: Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, an opposition politician in Liberia who was cleared of charges of complicity in a coup attempt last year, said she fled to the United States this month after the chairman of the ruling party threatened her life.

title: STRATEGIES EMERGE IN DONOVAN TRIAL
description: For the prosecution, jury selection in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan is a search for people who will accept secret electronic eavesdropping as evidence and who have the patience to listen to droning testimony about construction contracts.

title: FOR AN OPERA COMPANY, REVIVALS COUNT
description: With the best will in the world, what are we to make of the Metropolitan Opera's schedule for the coming season? It offers the glimmerings of a new ''Ring'' but otherwise a depressingly stale menu, a virtually unrelieved diet of old favorites that shows little artistic enterprise or sense of operatic history. The casting shows a few bright spots, of course, but for yet another year we will have to wonder at the same proliferation of mediocre or worn-out singers and third-rate conductors.

title: A FAITHFUL, IF UNLIVELY, PORTRAIT OF WASHINGTON
description: The menacing crowd, demanding more American support for the burgeoning revolution in France, gathers outside a relatively modest home in Philadelphia. Inside, as a trusty butler reaches for his shotgun, George Washington and his family are apprehensive. Freeze frame. And so ends the initial half of ''George Washington: The Forging of a Nation,'' being broadcast on CBS at 8 this evening. When the story resumes tomorrow at 9, Washington appears alone at a window and, without saying a word, stares the rabble into submission. Looking sheepish in the face of such unquestionable dignity, the hooligans skulk away. It beats, I suppose, stories about chopping down cherry trees.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Builders Rush to Fill Adult-Housing Need
description: WHEN Donald Monti, a Plainview developer, bought a surplus elementary-school property in Plainview two years ago, his plan was to build a town-house-style complex where everything from gourmet meals to housekeeping services would be included among the amenities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: VENTURING An Introduction to Sailing. By Peter Burchard. Illustrated. 138 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: 'LIFE WHERE WE LEAST EXPECT IT'
description: THE MIRACLE OF INTERVALE AVENUE The Story of a Jewish Congregation in the South Bronx. By Jack Kugelmass. Illustrated. 231 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $17.95.

title: A CHRISTIANSEN VICTORY WITH STYLE
description: For the first time since 1979, the United States Open Championship did not have to be decided by a tie-break this year. The 87th running of the tournament, in Somerset, N.J., was won by Larry Christiansen, a 30-year-old Pasadena grandmaster, who tallied an unequaled 10-2.

title: GARDEN CITY HALFBACK PACES FIFTH CONSECUTIVE SHUTOUT
description: LONG ISLAND

title: SHEVARDNADZE ADDS WARMTH TO DIPLOMACY
description: The man who has been negotiating for the Russians in Washington in the last two days is a novice to foreign affairs and, although a Politburo member, is far from being a top policy maker.

title: PUMPING IRON, NOT CONCRETE
description: LONG before Arnold Schwarzenegger became a movie star and pumping iron a glamour business, weight lifting built the York Barbell Company into a strapping success. York Barbell, founded 54 years ago, put York on the map as Muscletown U.S.A., and still brings Olympic weight lifters here to train. The company still dominates the barbell business, with a 70 percent share of the market for cast-iron weights made in the United States.

title: DANCE: FOUR PREMIERES AT RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: THE five choreographers who spent the summer in residency with a group of dancers in the program run by The Yard in Chilmark, Martha's Vineyard, showed off the proverbial fruit of their labor Thursday night.

title: ROCK: DAVID THOMAS
description: DAVID THOMAS, who was at the Bottom Line on Friday, has pursued an intriguing course since the breakup of Pere Ubu, the trailblazing mid-70's rock band he co-founded and with which he sang. Pere Ubu was either ahead of its time or out of step altogether; the band's earliest music sounds as if it could have been recorded yesterday, and is likely to keep sounding that way for some time. Mr. Thomas, though, has been looking backward as well as forward for his inspiration - not back to the 60's or the 50's, as is fashionable now, but all the way back to his childhood.

title: Annabelle Catherine Cone Is Married
description: At the Community Chapel in South Woodstock, Vt., yesterday Annabelle Catherine Cone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney M. Cone 3d of Manhattan, was married to F. William Lipfert Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Lipfert of Northport, L.I. The Rev. Beverly M. Boke performed the Unitarian-Universalist ceremony.

title: Deborah Roby Is Married
description: Deborah E. Roby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vic Roby of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Joshua A. Boyce, the son of Prof. Lois Swirnoff of Brookline, Mass., and Los Angeles and the late Richard Boyce, were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Forcier, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed an interfaith ceremony at the Victorian Inn in Whitinsville, Mass. Mrs. Boyce is the senior analyst of the Massachusetts Health and Educational Facilities Authority in Boston. Her husband is a pediatric resident at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester.

title: Article 691386 -- No Title
description: The State of Connecticut is seeking a record $2.3 million penalty against the Upjohn Company for dumping poisonous chemicals into the Quinnipiac River in 1985, the State Attorney General's office said Friday.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinbrennerese Translated
description: AS the days dwindle down to a precious few for Lou Piniella as the Yankee manager, it's time for a refresher course in Steinbrennerese, speech patterns that always require translation. Through the years, linguists familiar with Steinbrennerese know that September often, but not always, is the time when the future of the Yankees' current interim manager is about to be decided. And when George Steinbrenner talked about Lou Piniella recently, linguists immediately understood what the principal owner really meant.

title: Karen A. Toner Becomes Bride of E. Brinton Coxe
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Karen A. Toner, a daughter of Margaret Reeves Maynard of Greenwich and Francis Laurence Toner 2d of New York, was married to E. Brinton Coxe, a son of Judith G. Kew of Greenwich and Eckley Brinton Coxe 4th of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Walter Wagner, assisted by Msgr. Andrew T. Cusack, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: A RIDE INTO THE PAST
description: FOR several summers now I have wanted to board a roller coaster. No big deal. Just another of those backward steps. Even in the jelly-roll period of middle age it seemed to be an amusement not yet out of reach.

title: EMPHASIS ON THE INTERNATIONAL
description: CONNECTICUT is an international playwrights festival.

title: POSTINGS: The New Suburbs; Minicondos In Orange
description: The increased cost of housing in New York City's suburbs has, in recent years, extended the traditional boundaries defining bedroom communities.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the municipal corruption scandal in The Week in Review last week misstated the number of people employed by New York City. It is 300,000.

title: Col. Samuel Watson 3d Weds Wendy Fibison
description: Wendy Janine Fibison and Col. Samuel Johnston Watson 3d, U.S.A., were married yesterday at Emanuel Episcopal Church in Geneva by the Rev. Jerome Moser.

title: SENATORIAL COURTESY CALLED AN OXYMORON
description: An oxymoron is a combination of words that conflict with each other, like ''married bachelor.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
A PERSONAL APPROACH TO COLLECTING
description: TWO longtime Americana collectors-turned-dealers have adapted into a successful and rewarding business the piece-by-piece selectivity that characterizes their personal approach to collecting.

title: FARMERS REAPING HIGHER CROP PRICES
description: THE Long Island farm harvest, now approaching its peak, is bringing much better prices than last year. But farmers and officials of farm agencies say that despite the return of better times, agriculture is an endangered way of life on the Island.

title: PLANTING TIME FOR GARLIC
description: The botanist would describe it as ''a bulb with several parts or cloves, all enclosed in a silky white or pink envelope or skin.'' Some cooks would call it the most flavorful, important condiment in the kitchen and have a braid of it present at all times. Gardeners just find it easy to grow. It is intriguing, almost addictive, revered in mythology and home medicine. It is garlic.

title: STEPS DETERMINING IF A HOME IS AFFECTED
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to test the radon level in their houses should take the following steps: (1) - Call the radon information line of the state's Department of Environmental Protection (1-800-648-0394) and request an information packet. The packet includes two brochures on radon and what to do about it, both published by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. It also includes a list of companies that do radon testing, although the department makes no recommendations about testers and has not begun certifying them yet. (2) - Call a testing service and request that your house be tested. The tests can cost from $12 to $400 and take from four days to three months or more. The service will either deliver the collection devices or send them to you. The devices are simple to use, but homeowners should follow directions about placement carefully. The devices must be returned to the service to be read. (3) - If the testing service reports that the radon in your house equals or exceeds the E.P.A. standard of four picocuries per liter, call the D.E.P. and request a confirmatory test. The first test is correct most of the time, but the D.E.P. will retest a house free of charge if the initial test showed a high level of radon. (4) - Once a radon problem has been confirmed, consult the E.P.A. brochures on how to reduce radon levels. The D.E.P. provides some basic assistance and has a list of contractors who do remediation work.

title: A TECHNICALITY SNAGS MEDICAL OFFICE FACILITY
description: A PROPOSAL to construct a medical office building in Woodmere for two physicians and a dentist is snagged on a technical point in the Hempstead Town zoning code.

title: BETTER SALARIES FOR BETTER TEACHERS
description: WINDFALLS to Connecticut towns from state coffers have led to justifications for raising teachers' salaries in the face of objections from some camps. These objections include arguments that teachers enjoy a reduced work schedule, that many are marginally or fully incompetent, that their work is not hard enough to warrant prestigious salaries, and that using a windfall to raise salaries will cost municipalities money they can ill afford if higher salary ceilings are to be mainained in coming years.

title: Celia Bumstead Becomes a Bride
description: The Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Celia Rochelle Bumstead, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Crane Bumstead of Rye, and William Wright Carroll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Carroll of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David Uhl performed the ceremony.

title: 'INDEPENDENT FOCUS' AS A SHOWCASE FOR CONTROVERSIAL FILMS
description: To the Editor:

title: RECENT RECORDINGS OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: The Soft Skin Starring Jean Desailly, Francoise Dorleac, Nelly Benedetti; directed by Francois Truffaut, 1964 Key Video 118 minutes. $59.98

title: J. W. McGovern And Miss Berns Exchange Vows
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Deborah Andrea Berns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony D. Berns of New York, was married to James Winslow McGovern, the son of Mrs. William B. Cutler of Stonington, Conn., and James McGovern of New York. The Rev. Susan C. Harriss performed the ceremony.

title: Social Events; In Clubs and Ballrooms
description: Champagne and Furs

title: ON CAMPUS AND OVER 60
description: In the course of a three-week trip to Australia early this year, 40 individuals aged 60-plus coalesced into a group resembling nothing so much as a bunch of sorority sisters and fraternity brothers. The transformation was effected by a Boston-based organization called Elderhostel, which specializes in study trips for adults 60 and over at colleges around the world. Participants in Elderhostel trips must be able to get around reasonably well and be willing to endure the sometimes Spartan life of college dormitory rooms with the bathroom down the hall and institutional food (always ample and usually tasty). They should also be socially adaptable and open to new experiences.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: MET ROOKIES GET INTO THE ACT
description: In the sixth inning last night, Stanley Jefferson emerged quickly from the dugout, removed his batting helmet and waved it above his head. In the eighth, John Gibbons did the same thing. Now the curtain calls belong to the rookies.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bloomingdale $170,000 19 Jeffrey Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; fireplace, central air-conditioning, laundry room; taxes, $2,224. Maplewood $315,625 94 Collinwood Road South 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 38-year-old Tudor; 2 fireplaces, deck, study; taxes, $6,025.

title: A STOREFRONT SAVES CULTURE FOR RED HOOK
description: When prosperous Dutch colonists built homes on Brooklyn Heights in the 17th century, their servants found living quarters in an unappealing neighborhood along the river called Red Hook.

title: O'Rourke Proposing Plan to Cut State Tax
description: The Republican candidate for Governor of New York, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said yesterday that, if elected, he would cut state taxes by $2.4 billion to offset an anticipated similar increase for New York in the Federal tax bill being considered by Congress.

title: ACROSS THE RIVER AND INTO THE TWILIGHT ZONE
description: RUBICON BEACH By Steve Erickson. 300 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DREAMS COME DUE: Government and Economics as If Freedom Mattered. By John Galt. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) At a time when libertarian ideas are attracting interest, this book - a guide to contemporary issues by a free-swinging free-marketeer - sounds promising.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT IN THE FALL FOR HEAD START ON SPRING
description: THE advantages of fall planting have long been stressed in this column. There are several advantages in planting at this time of year: The weather is usually more pleasant for working outdoors; the soil is less muddy than in the spring; nurseries, garden centers and landscapers are able to give you more attention, and getting plants established in the fall gives them a one-season headstart over those planted in the spring.

title: SELF-CONTROL KEEPS CHAOS AT BAY
description: SOME time ago, a student of mine asked me what I thought was the most necessary skill she should learn. I think now that she meant English, math or science. But at the time I answered her straight from my heart, and replied rather matter of factly: self-discipline.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
SERIES EXPLORES CONTEMPORARY COMPOSERS AND CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ''Most times, people enter a performing-arts event through some kind of grand front door,'' the producer-director Scott Fraser said the other day. ''Here, we let you in the back door.''

title: GROWERS SET UP GARDEN SHOW
description: WILTONI, a creeping juniper, commemorates the town of Wilton. Mother's Day, a red-flowered Belgian hybrid azalea, is one of the most famous grown. Brouwer's beauty, a pieris, is known for its red flower buds in winter. Although these woody landscape plants have fame, they have something more in common: all of them were introduced by Connecticut nurserymen.

title: Today's Sports
description: AUTO RACING Portuguese Grand Prix At Estoril, Portugal. Television ESPN, 5 P.M., delayed tape. BASEBALL Mets vs. Phillies At Shea Stadium.

title: STATE YIELDS, SELLING SUSSEX MOUNTAIN TO RESORT CORPORATIONS
description: A LARGE resort corporation here has won a complex legal struggle to acquire a recreational mountain that it now leases from the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: CRIME
description: Professionalism marks every page of TROPICAL HEAT by John Lutz (Holt, $14.95). This is a private eye novel very much in line with the new approach to the genre. The classic private eye school paid more attention to plotting and action than to Dr. Freud. The new school continues to provide action and, at the hands of its best practitioners, impeccable plotting. But considerable attention is also being paid to what people are and what makes them tick. This produces a lot of self-analysis, together with sympathy for the emotional predicaments in which people find themselves.

title: ADAPTING BECKETT'S PROSE FOR THE STAGE
description: At the same time that Samuel Beckett has been adamant about directors respecting every single line of dialogue and stage direction in his plays, he has allowed surprising latitude to those he trusts in adapting his prose pieces and radio plays into works of theater. In conversation, he has made the distinction clear. A play is meant to be performed exactly as the playwright wrote it, but a work not originally designed for the theater can be subject to the interpretation, the visual imagination of the adapter -should the author permit adaptation.

title: CARL SANDBURG'S BLUE RIDGE HOME
description: In 1945, when he was 67, and probably the most widely known literary figure in the United States, Carl Sandburg bought a home and 240 acres of land in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina at Flat Rock.

title: REAGAN'S TAX VIEWS SAID TO INFLUENCE DEFICIT PLAN
description: Two key Senate budget writers said today that President Reagan's determined opposition to tax increases had led to the deficit-reducing package approved early this morning that some members have called ''gimmicky.''

title:
DINING OUT;
A PUB WITH CAJUN DISHES, TOO
description: ON ROUTE 46 in Netcong is an Irish pub complete with piano player, Irish beer and a dining room. It is called Nellie Burke's, the name of the mother of the owner, Frank Burke.

title: Deciding to Make Wishes Come True
description: The regular monthly board meeting of the New Jersey chapter of the Make-A-Wish Foundation started at 7:30 P.M., with nine members present. First order of business was the need to improve the weekly wish reports from each county.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We are not interested in size for size's sake. What is important is the size of the profits.'' Frank Lorenzo, Texas Air chairman, on the huge new airline he is creating

title: GERMANY'S GOLIATH BANK
description: DEUTSCHE BANK officials bristle at the suggestion that West Germany's largest bank has ''control'' of major German companies. ''We view our active role in industry as a tradition we exercise in the interest of our clients, not contrary to their interests,'' says Alfred Herrhausen, Deutsche Bank's co-chairman.

title: NORTHEAST'S CONTINUOUS WEB, (POP. 43 MILLION)
description: The Northeastern Megalopolis as Jean Gottmann, a French geographer, described and analyzed it 25 years ago, is not a solid stretch of brick and concrete from Boston to Washington, as it has sometimes been mistakenly portrayed. Rather, it is a continuous web of 23 overlapping, interlocking metropolitan areas.

title: FOCUS: El Paso; A Bullish Attitude On Growth
description: ''THE local people are just sitting around with their mouths open,'' said Joe Rubio, this city's chief urban planner. ''Over the last 15 years, there's been this attitude of wait and see. Then all of a sudden Mel Simon starts to develop, and Trammell Crow starts to build and buy shopping centers. Indications are it's going to be bullish - Boom City.''

title: Housing Court
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GOOD-BYE, I LOVE YOU. By Carol Lynn Pearson. (Random House, $15.95.) Homosexuality was not something the author, a Utah-bred Mormon, understood when her fiance confessed to her that he'd had relationships with men.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Realistic Appeal By United Way

title: Coach Files Suit
description: THE way Virginia Tech sees it, college athletics have gotten so complicated that it is virtually impossible for one man to serve as both athletic director and football coach.

title: IN SALVADOR, AN UNEASY PEACE BETWEEN DUARTE AND THE ARMY
description: SALVADORAN Government officials and army officers made a strong showing of unity last week, standing together to blame leftist guerrillas for torpedoing scheduled peace talks. But despite the joint declaration against a common enemy, there have been signs that the army is beginning to take a more independent stance. After almost seven years of civil war and more than $600 million in United States assistance, the military is larger, better-armed and more politically savvy than ever, according to Western diplomats and military analysts. Thus bolstered, the military high command seems ready to press for its two main goals: to defeat the guerrillas and guarantee itself autonomy from excessive civilian control.

title: THE EMPTY LIFE OF BIN NO. 15
description: I like my rooms full of clutter. Lots of it. Bare tables supporting a single vase of calla lilies, spindly chairs devoid of cushions and stripped-to-the-glass windows hold no appeal for me. I want my rooms crowded, bustling with books and bibelots I have found or known all my life.

title: Miss Mennin Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Felicia Anne Mennin and C. Mark Barnard 3d took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. Msgr. George Bardes performed the ceremony.

title: WHO GETS TESTED? CITY HAS MANY ANSWERS
description: DURING a week in which the issue of testing public employees for illegal drug use reverberated from the White House to a New Jersey firehouse, New York City officials grappled with their own versions of the thorny questions and contradictory answers the subject invariably provokes.

title: MUSIC: ANTIDOGMA GROUP
description: THE Ensemble Antidogma Musica is a group of youngish composers and performers from Turin, Italy, who not only play new music by themselves and others but also present a wide-ranging new-music festival each fall; this year's will be the ninth annual installment. Thursday night,several members of the group opened the Experimental Intermedia Foundation season at Phill Niblock's funky but hospitable loft at 224 Centre Street. The earnest northern Italians had to contend with some raucous Southern Italian street noise from the San Gennaro Festival outside, but managed to present a serious, well-intended program, nonetheless.

title: GLORIA: MEMORIES OF A DARK AND STORMY DAY
description: MOSTLY, I'll remember the sounds of Gloria. That's not to say that her sights were not memorable: Who could forget just one year ago - Sept. 27 - the look of windows and houses plastered with that chopped-spinach look and boats tossed up onto backyard lawns, resting in place like some huge lawn ornaments?

title: A SCHOOL AGAIN
description: ELEMENTARY-SCHOOL children used to enter the Webb School in Hartsdale under a sign that read ''The Quest for Education Must Be an Endless One.''

title: THE ART OF QUIET DESIGN
description: Few visitors who step into the vestibule in the loft of David Vena and Carol Vena-Mondt in Los Angeles have ever been in an anechoic chamber. Few even know what one is. But as soon as the front door is closed, visitors are surprised to find themselves in complete silence - a silence amplified by the room's emptiness.

title: WALKER PLEA DEAL IS NOW UNCERTAIN
description: Senior military officers fear that John A. Walker Jr. is so deceptive that they will never be able to measure the damage caused by the Soviet spy ring he headed, according to Reagan Administration officials and others familiar with the case.

title: Stephanie Accas Weds
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Stephanie Diane Accas, the daughter of Sandra C. Sherrard of New York and Gene A. Accas of Los Angeles, was married to David Louis Armetta, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Armetta of Scarsdale. The Rev. William J. Winterrowd performed the ceremony. Mrs. Armetta is assistant to the controller at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. Her husband is head of the Armetta Studio, a graphic and industrial design concern in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: The Tax Rules That Ease the Pain
description: Few documents have been more eagerly sought after than the one legislators' aides and senior accountants are poring over this morning. The document, the final language of the comprehensive tax revision bill, was drafted only late last week and the text was released only late yesterday.

title: U.N. LEBANON UNIT REDEPLOYS FRENCH
description: French troops serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, who have been targets of frequent attacks by Moslem extremists, withdrew today from nine of their positions for security reasons, a spokesman for the force announced.

title: WHEN A RAILROAD STATION'S THE FINAL STOP
description: MAL SCHWARTZ and his wife, Janine Snow, owners of the advertising agency Graphic Harmony, have just installed two 1930 train cars next to their office in the newly renovated old Croton-North Station, a 93-year-old landmark. They call it ''office expansion.'' Historic preservationists call it ''adaptive use.'' But both phrases fall short of capturing the imagination, creativity and dogged determination involved in renovating old railroad stations.

title: THE POWER OF ARTIFICE
description: IT IS A MATTER OF NEW EMPHASIS ON AN OLD POINT. THE body may be clothed and reclothed, its shape and texture transmuted by the interventions of dress into a new thing each time, and any time.

title: Edward S. Mead Married in Erie To Su Ling Chan
description: Su Ling Chan and Edward Scott Mead were married yesterday in Erie, Pa., at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother and her husband, Samuel J. Roberts, the retired Chief Justice of Pennsylvania, who performed the ceremony.

title: TWO ANCIENT INNS CLAIM TO BE THE OLDEST
description: THEY both have worn stairs that creak, ceilings with fat beams, well-stoked fireplaces, and a system of ancient plumbing that sometimes ''talks back to you,'' as Chuck Baxter puts it.

title: U.S. Drug Agents Seize 4 Men With $553,295
description: Federal agents have arrested four suspected members of a foreign heroin ring and have seized $553,295 in cash, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration announced yesterday.

title: Verbatim; The Path of Peace
description: 'I must explore the path of peace to the utmost.

title: CAN A SECOND-TIER SCHOOL CRACK THE ELITE?
description: ACROSS the country, business schools are battening down the hatches. Fewer students are seeking admission, top professors are in tight supply, and corporations have stepped down recruiting.

title: THREE MANHATTAN BOARDS OPPOSE PLAN FOR TOWERS
description: Three community boards in Manhattan have disapproved plans for a double tower on the site of the New York Coliseum, saying it would be too tall and bulky and would be out of scale with the neighborhood surrounding Columbus Circle.

title: On Language; DON'T MAKE ME BLUSH
description: BLUSH - A WORD AS-sociated with maidenly modesty - is coming into vogue, long after women learned to redden with anger at being called modest maidens.

title: SEEDS OF RESISTANCE IN A FROZEN SOIL
description: UTOPIA IN POWER The History of the Soviet Union From 1917 to the Present. By Mikhail Heller and Aleksandr Nekrich. Translated by Phyllis B. Carlos. 877 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95.

title: Agent Orange and a Family's Ordeal
description: If American veterans are feeling the effects of Agent Orange, imagine what is going on in North Vietnam.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CHILDREN OF THE RUINS. By Thomas Wiseman. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) This novel, based on fact, relates the saga of a group of German juvenile delinquents, children of Ehrenfeld - a working-class suburb of Cologne - who during World War II became an anti-Nazi resistance gang dubbed ''The Wolf Children'' by the authorities.

title: SEEKING SHARPER PRINTS IN THE GRAIN
description: SOON after I started being curious about photography, I became addicted to detail. I loved looking into the nooks and crannies of pictures and finding unexpected, surprising things lurking there. Contact-printed albumen photographs from the 19th century were especially fascinating to me, their surfaces containing a wealth of historical information.

title: Klecko-Stephenson Key Duel
description: Joe Klecko knows there will be isolated replays, finely focused binoculars, fans leaning forward - everyone trying to see what may be the best matchup in pro football: Klecko vs. Stephenson, the heart of the Jets-Dolphins game today.

title: GERMAN DOCTORS AND THE FINAL SOLUTION
description: Before Auschwitz and the other death camps, the Nazis had established a policy of direct medical killing - killing arranged within medical channels, by means of medical decisions, and carried out by doctors and their assistants. The Nazis called this program ''euthanasia.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ REMARKS TO REPORTERS
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: IN BROOKLYN, AN EMOTIONAL REUNION
description: Divided by a war that killed many relatives and later isolated from each other by the demands of a modern society, six branches of a Jewish family were united in an emotional gathering in Coney Island yesterday.

title: Cranston Says All Americans Must Join War Against Drugs
description: Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, said today that without a long-term commitment by all Americans the war against drugs ''will be just another passing political fad.''

title: RETURNING TO WORK AFTER YEARS AT HOME
description: I HAVE been thinking of resumes lately - and of how we spend our lives. These thoughts were set off by a call I received from a friend. ''I've got to get a job,'' Clare told me, ''but I'm beginning to think it's hopeless.''

title: Honor to Correspondents
description: At least 200 American correspondents were killed in World War II and the wars since, and the tally no doubt would be even greater if older records could be found. Despite the toll, a humanitarian organization discovered that there was no national memorial to the reporters and photographers who had fallen in battle and set out to do something about it, an effort that will be culminated soon with a plaque at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: 175 at Football Game Injured Fleeing Fumes
description: About 175 fleeing spectators were injured Friday night when someone dropped a tear-gas grenade into the stands at a high school football game, the authorities said.

title: MAKING WAVES IN PHILADELPHIA POLICE
description: Day in, day out, for the last 20 or so years, a squad of police officers has guarded the city's ballot boxes, which are stored in a locked warehouse.

title: ON-TARGET BIDDING
description: The first world bridge championship with a good claim to be considered official took place in New York City half a century ago with nine players competing in a match between the United States and France. The latest is now more than half completed in Miami Beach and involves 1,700 players from 48 countries.

title: 3 HOUSE RACES GET NATIONAL ATTENTION
description: THE election of the state's 14 members of the House of Representatives heads the ballot on Nov. 4, and as the races begin in earnest, three campaigns have attracted the attention of the national Democratic and Republican Parties.

title: DATA BANK: September 21, 1986
SEEKING KEY ROLE FOR PARTY, RIGHT TO LIFE CANDIDATE TRIES TO MAKE ABORTION AN ISSUE
description: Virtually unnoticed so far, District Attorney Denis E. Dillon of Nassau County, the Right to Life candidate for governor of New York, is trying to make abortion an issue in the campaign and, at the same time, win enough votes to assure a line for the party on future ballots.

title: A SENSE OF ORDER
description: Amid stark white walls and highly polished oak floors, four Jacob chairs, an Egyptian Revival chaise and a large white cube appear like vignettes in a still life. These objects, though few in number, have been arranged with utmost precision.

title: Self Defense At a Mafia Trial
description: Carmine Persico was defendant and lawyer last week, giving his own opening statement to a jury, urging them not to be ''blinded by labels'' such as Mafia or Cosa Nostra, denying the racketeering charges against him, discrediting the prosecution witnesses in advance, pausing at one point to shuffle his notes and say, ''I'm a little nervous, too.''

title: Pinochet Risks Further Chaos
description: In response to an attempt on his life earlier this month, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is persecuting not just the violent left but also the moderates in the Chilean opposition - the very people who are best able to lessen the increasing risk of a blood bath in his country. By eliminating the middle, General Pinochet risks unleashing the chaos he claims to be preventing.

title: POSTINGS: Homage to Bogardus; Cast-Iron-Like Apartments
description: In the 1840's, when James Bogardus designed many of Lower Manhattan's Greek Revival buildings, he was a pioneer in the use of cast-iron facades. Now another architect, Christopher Barriscale, is paying homage to the innovator with his design for an 11-story condominium at 303 Greenwich Street in TriBeCa.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANT IN THE FALL FOR HEAD START ON SPRING
description: THE advantages of fall planting have long been stressed in this column. There are several advantages in planting at this time of year: The weather is usually more pleasant for working outdoors; the soil is less muddy than in the spring; nurseries, garden centers and landscapers are able to give you more attention, and getting plants established in the fall gives them a one-season headstart over those planted in the spring.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A WORLD OF VILLAGES. By Brian M. Schwartz. (Crown, $19.95.) What impels a 24-year-old American who graduated from Yale Law School at 22 to chuck his job as a clerk with a chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals and bum around Africa and Asia for six years? ''To find my fellow man, to learn other ways of life and perhaps, as an added bonus, to improve my own,'' Brian M. Schwartz reflects at the end of his journey through 50 countries.

title: LABOR DEPT. DATA SHOW A REVIVAL OF MAJOR STRIKES
description: Major strikes are on the rise again after years of decline, reflecting what union officials and some experts on labor say is renewed union militancy.

title: STATE PUTS CURBS ON NASSAU WATER SUPPLIERS
description: State officials have placed restrictions on Nassau County's 41 water suppliers in an attempt to avert what they fear will be a severe water shortage in the county by the year 2000.

title: NORTHEAST PROSPERS, BUT NEW OBSTACLES MAY RISE
description: The Northeast, its dominance of national and world affairs seriously challenged in the economic upheaval of the 1970's and early 1980's, has emerged from that painful period in some ways stronger and more influential than ever before, expert analysts say.

title: RISKING ALL FOR GOLD AND GRIZZLIES
description: SEVEN RIVERS WEST By Edward Hoagland. 319 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: MORATORIUM IN VALLEY STREAM
description: THE VAlley Stream Village Board has passed a six-month moratorium on the building of high-rise ranch homes and multifamily dwellings, condominium and cooperatives.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IT'S TIME TO LOOK ANEW AT MEDICARE
description: IN THE wealthiest nation in the world, it is a tragedy that many of our senior citizens must choose to go into poverty to obtain medical care when a catastrophic illness strikes.

title: ON THE F.I.T. CAMPUS, 2 CAMPS
description: THE academic year at the Fashion Institute of Technology is already a couple of weeks old, plenty of time for the students to settle in. So it seems appropriate now to visit F.I.T.'s Chelsea campus and see how things are going.

title: INQUIRY ON TRIAL IN FRIEDMAN CASE
description: The central allegation of New York City's corruption scandal - that control of its Parking Violations Bureau was seized by a small group of men who used it illicitly for their personal profit - will be tested beginning tomorrow in a Federal courtroom 70 miles away in New Haven.

title: AUSTRALIA'S 'CROCODILE' EYES U.S. WATERS
description: Paul Hogan was living in style on the second floor of a small, elegant hotel overlooking Washington's Lafayette Square, the sort of hotel where white-gloved doorman usher visitors into a lobby full of dark wood paneling, plush red upholstery and ornate detailing on the ceiling. Here, the man who, to millions of Australians, is known as ''our Hoges'' - television star, promoter of tourism and a national hero only a little less revered than a handful of the greatest cricketers and rugby players was receiving members of the American press to tell them about his first feature film. '' 'Crocodile' Dundee,'' is, Mr. Hogan says, ''a simple little film'' that has grossed nearly $18 million in Australia alone. Less than 13 weeks after opening, it edged out ''E.T.'' and that film's box-office earnings of $12.8 million as the country's top-grossing film ever.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR MOVES TO STOP NUCLEAR PLANT OPENING
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts said today that he would seek to prevent the opening of the nearly completed Seabrook nuclear reactor because of doubts about whether adequate preparations could be made for an emergency.

title: IS A WEAKER DOLLAR HELPING U.S. TRADE?  THE TRUTH WILL COME OUT IN THE WASH
description: As an American who has spent half his life in Japan, I am constantly struck dumb by the way we conveniently ignore the most critical factor in our trade relations with Japan. What is the missing ingredient? Surely it is the product itself. We never confront the issue of why so many American and Japanese consumers prefer Japanese products.

title: TWO FREE PIANO TRIOS AT NORWALK'S BURNDY LIBRARY
description: BETWEEN the ending of one concert cycle and the start of several others, the coming weekend is going to be a good one for chamber music in Connecticut.

title: Defense Asks Dismissal In Movie Deaths Case
description: Defense attorneys in the manslaughter case involving the film ''Twilight Zone'' have moved for dismissal of all chages, arguing that a ''stench of perjury'' permeates the case.

title: IN ROME, WHERE THOSE MATCHLESS POETS LIE
description: PLEASE do not caress, touch or molest the cats in the Cemetery.'' Forewarned by these guidelines written in three languages on water-damaged paper, you reach for a rope blackened by time and the tug of many hands. The resulting toll of a bell within the gates brings forth a squinting eye that peers through a peephole. ''Chi e?'' ''May we please see the cemetery?'' ''Chiuso!'' In Rome, most things at most times are ''chiuso'' (closed). No explanations, no pleading will make the eye relent nor urge a hand to open the 15-foot gate, above which appears the word ''Resurrecturis.''

title: IN CONNECTICUT, NEW FACE AND AN OLD PRO
description: WITH the victory 12 years ago of Ella T. Grasso, a Democrat, Connecticut became the first state to elect a woman Governor who had not succeeded her husband in office.

title: STIRRING UP ROMANTIC IRELAND
description: WE IRISH Essays on Irish Literature and Society. By Denis Donoghue. 275 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: MICHIGAN HOLDS OFF OREGON STATE, 31-12
description: Jim Harbaugh passed for two touchdowns and ran for another as third-ranked Michigan withstood Oregon State, a 40-point underdog, for a 31-12 victory today.

The Plaza Hotel Agreement of Sept. 22, 1985, was a turning point in United States economic policy. After four years of benign indifference to the rising dollar, the Reagan Administration - in cooperation with four other major industrial countries - embarked on a policy of depreciating the dollar. The main objective of this drastic shift was to reduce our widening trade deficit and to fend off protectionist pressures.

title: 'FEIFFER'S PEOPLE': HUMOR HITS HOME
description: JULES FEIFFER is a playwright perhaps best known as a cartoonist. His savvy political and social satires are weekly features in newspapers such as The Village Voice.

title: OHIO'S RHODES LOOKING FOR HIS BIGGEST UPSET YET
description: James A. Rhodes won his first election in 1938, and since then he has seldom been out of public office, serving as Mayor of Columbus for 12 years, as State Auditor for 10 and as Governor for 16.
