title: Elizabeth Mary Scullin Wed to W.M. Dolan 3d
description: Elizabeth Mary Scullin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bell Scullin of Woodbridge, Conn., and William Matthew Dolan 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dolan Jr. of North Smithfield, R.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Bernard Killeen performed the ceremony at Holy Infant Roman Catholic Church in Orange, Conn.

title: McEnroe, Edberg Gain Volvo Final
description: John McEnroe and top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden advanced today to the final of a Volvo tennis tournament.

title: POSTINGS: Hoboken in Transition; Fade Out, Fade In
description: When the old Fabian Theater, at Washington and Newark Streets in Hoboken, N.J., closed in 1965, the city's future seemed as dark as the big screen after the projector stopped running. The moviehouse and an adjacent row of five-story tenements were razed and replaced by a Shop-Rite supermarket and a parking lot.

title: C.A. Lennig Is Married To Christopher S. Hall
description: Constance Amelia Lennig, an advertising sales development manager for New York magazine, was married yesterday to Christopher Sumner Hall, an associate in the corporate finance division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The Quaker ceremony was performed at the Friends Meeting House in Sandy Spring, Md.

title: FILM: 'SHANGHAI SURPRISE'
description: THE nicest thing about ''Shanghai Surprise,'' the widely publicized washout starring Madonna and Sean Penn, is that you can watch it in near-total privacy. At the first show at Loew's State, where the film opened Friday, there were barely enough bystanders to make up a baseball team.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON TRADE
description: Following are excerpts from the declaration by ministers today at the conference here of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade:

title: VINEYARD REJECTS A COMPLEX
description: Plans for a $10 million shopping center on Martha's Vineyard were rejected at a packed Town Meeting because of fears the project might destroy the community's quaint village charm.

title: STORYTELLING AMONG THE ANTHROPOLOGISTS
description: WHEN it comes to the classics of ethnography, books about the ideas and practices of exotic peoples - Margaret Mead on Samoa, Bronislaw Malinowski on the Trobriand Islands, Gregory Bateson on New Guinea - reading about it is usually better than being there. That's not because of the mosquitoes, the heat or the dysentery. Despite the discomforts and inconveniences, some anthropologists actually have more fun away from home. The reason that reading about it is better than being there is less obvious than it seems.

title: THE U.S. WINS A ROUND ON GATT
description: THE world's merchant nations launched a major round of negotiations on freer trade here last week. The signatories of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -which is both a free trade charter and the institution that oversees world commerce - set their sights on lowering barriers to international banking, insurance, telecommunications and other services, a chief objective of the United States.

title: AGONY OF SUCCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: MANILA NOSES OUT LONG SHOT
description: Manila, the lone 3-year-old in an international field of grass specialists, outfinished Damister, a British long shot, to win the $705,250 Turf Classic by a nose yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Elizabeth Hufferd Married in Darien To Brian Mullen
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Elizabeth Kieron Hufferd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Beach Hufferd of Darien and Jupiter Island, Fla., was married to J. Brian Mullen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William James Mullen of Youngstown, Ohio. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Pierre A. Botton, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'MOTHER' AND 'OTELLO' PLAY DOWN TO US
description: Very early in the screen adaptation of Marsha Norman's '' 'night, Mother,'' as in the two-character Broadway play on which it is based, Jesse Cates (Sissy Spacek) announces that she's planning to kill herself that evening. For 10 years, she tells her mother, Thelma (Anne Bancroft), she's been thinking about suicide ''off and on'' and, for the last several months, ''mostly on.''

title: The Rancher And the Grizzly
description: The grizzly bear is a truly national resource (''A Town Divided by the Grizzly,'' by Jim Robbins, Aug. 31). Its extinction would impoverish all Americans.

title: HUDSON MUSEUM, FINANCIAL VISTAS IMPROVING, LOOKS FOR A NEW DIRECTOR
description: NINE months after the County Board of Legislators gave the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers only about half the aid it was seeking, the museum is in better financial shape than it has been in years. But once again it is looking for a new director.

title: TREATMENT NEEDS OF ALCOHOLIC WOMEN STUDIED
description: Women should be given different treatment for alcoholism than men because women become alcoholics at lower levels of consumption, are quicker to develop related diseases and drink for different reasons, a researcher says.

title: Katherine Meyers Marries a Banker
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Katherine Jane Meyers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Meyers of Greenwich, was married to Matthew Edward Gormly 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gormly Jr. of Encino, Calif., formerly of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Leo J. Gorman performed the ceremony.

title: THEY HAVE THE WORDS, SOMETIMES THE TUNE
description: AMERICAN MADE New Fiction From the Fiction Collective. Edited by Mark Leyner, Curtis White and Thomas Glynn. Introduction by Larry McCaffery. 214 pp. New York: Fiction Collective. $15.95.

title: Corruption Scandals: An Update
description: THE DEFENDANTS STANLEY M. FRIEDMAN

title: Elizabeth A. Mayer Wed To Alexander M. Carlisle
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Anne Mayer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Mayer of Newark, Del., and Alexander Macleod Carlisle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Carlisle of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Albert Neilson performed the ceremony.

title: HOW THE CURTAIN CAME DOWN ON THE DREAM OF 'RAGS'
description: Shortly after 10 P.M. on Aug. 21, amid the clatter of dishes in the glaring light of Sardi's kitchen, the producers of the Broadway musical ''Rags'' huddled grimly as Marvin A. Krauss, the show's general manager, read aloud the first devastating reviews.

title: BLUE JAYS DEFEAT RED SOX, 5-2
description: George Bell drove in two runs, setting a club record for most in a season, and Jesse Barfield became the third player in Blue Jay history to reach the 100-run-batted-in mark, as Toronto defeated the Boston Red Sox, 5-2, today.

title: BEHIND BARS
description: *as of June 30

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE DEMOCRATIC POLICY COMMISSION'S STATEMENT OF PRINCIPLES
description: Following are excerpts from the Democratic Policy Commission's statement of party principles: 1. Stronger Families

title: RESTRAINED GRANDEUR
description: Keith Irvine was among the first to bring the English look across the Atlantic. This was a direct result of his four-year apprenticeship to the late renowned English decorator John Fowler. Even during the minimal years of the late 1960's and early 70's, Irvine and his partner, Thomas Fleming, persisted in dressing windows with swags, loosely slipcovering upholstery in chintz and filling rooms with 18th- and 19th-century antiques.

title: 2 Soviet Missiles Go Up and Away In Test Failures
description: The Soviet Union's long-range missile program has apparently undergone some unilateral disarmament.

title: 4 Americans Among 5 Killed In an Airplane Crash in Brazil
description: Four Americans and a Brazilian died when a Brasilia commuter airplane crashed shortly after takeoff Friday near Sao Jose dos Campos, in Sao Paulo State, the air force reported today.

title: Typhoon Kills 13 in Taiwan
description: Typhoon Abby, downgraded to a tropical storm, headed toward Japan today after killing 13 people in Taiwan and causing about $80 million in damage. The police said six victims drowned, four were crushed by falling trees and three died in traffic accidents. More than 148,000 acres of rice paddies, fruit trees and other crops were damaged, the police said.

title: RESHAPED CARTER IMAGE TIED TO LIBRARY OPENING
description: On a wooded hillside overlooking downtown Atlanta, workers are putting the final touches on the Carter Presidential Center, the nation's eighth library complex dedicated to a former President.

title: 'DEMONIC FORCES NOW THREATEN TO TEAR US APART'
description: IN the grip of a harrowing ethnic conflict, the five-year-old separatist insurgency, Sri Lanka has learned to live in a blaze of unwelcome publicity.

title: A WOODCARVER'S ART IN TIJUANA
description: Old Tijuana hands will remember the Avenida Revolucion, the Baja California border city's main tourist drag, as an unholy mess, largely composed of strip joints and bars and largely populated by child entrepreneurs promoting a wide variety of illicit goods and services. But no more. The city's widely publicized cleanup of a few years ago seems to have stuck, and yet the Revolucion is still colorful - witness the vendors laboring under their enormous globes of multicolored paper flowers and the street photographers who will take your souvenir picture with a burro painted to look like a zebra.

title: Riddles of Equal Temperament
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Anne Cates Weds Damon H. Ball
description: Sara Anne Cates was married yesterday to Damon Howard Ball at the Bishop's School in La Jolla, Calif., by the Rev. Julian Lenz, an Episcopal priest.

title: Rachel Gelin Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Rachel Gelin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques B. Gelin of Rockville, Md., to Bartley James Breinin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Goodwin M. Breinin of New York and East Hampton, L.I., took place yesterday at the Cosmos Club in Washington. Rabbi Samuel Volkman performed the ceremony.

title: EASIER COMPUTING
description: Due in large part, no doubt, to the technophilia of its inventors and users, the computer and its lexicon have resisted simplification. Indeed, many practitioners of this modern ''dark science'' even prefer the phrase ''user-friendly'' to the more common word ''simple.'' Similarly, the machines themselves have been cloaked in such complexity that operating one can border sometimes on the mystical.

title: 'THE BLIND DIRECTOR,' FROM WEST GERMANY'S ALEXANDER KLUGE
description: BEGINNING in 1967, when it presented Alexander Kluge's ''Artists Under the Big Top; Perplexed,'' the New York Film Festival has presented three films by the German director. Today, at 2 P.M., the festival will show his latest work, ''The Blind Director,'' at Alice Tully Hall, where it will be seen again on Monday at 6:15 P.M. If nothing else, the showings testify to the festival's loyalty.

title: Ex-Upstate Aide Sentenced
description: The former chairman of the Sullivan County Board of Supervisors was sentenced today to three years in prison and fined $12,000 for stuffing an absentee ballot box and lying about a sewer-project contract. The former official, Brian Ingber, 40 years old, of South Fallsburg, N.Y., was sentenced in Federal District Court here. He was supervisor of the Town of Fallsburg from 1977 to 1985.

title: Surgery for Green
description: HE has been hobbled by a sore ankle for a year, and now Roy Green, the St. Louis Cardinals' outstanding wide receiver, is going to do something about it. He is scheduled to undergo surgery this week to remove a calcium deposit from his left ankle.

title: FOR A PRODUCER OF BOARD GAMES, WORK ISN'T CHILD'S PLAY
description: FOR some men, business is largely a game. For Joseph M. Cornacchia, games are largely his business.

title: How to Test for Drugs, and Why
description: One morning last May, Plainfield, N.J., officials locked the fire station doors, rousted firefighters out of bed and demanded instant urine samples - while testing agents watched. The tests revealed that 16 firefighters used illegal drugs, and they were fired. This week, a Federal judge reinstated them and threw out the test as unconstitutional.

title: LOVE, WITH KNOWLEDGE AFORETHOUGHT
description: A COMMON misconception among youngsters attending school is that their teachers were child prodigies.

title: BUILDING SPARENESS
description: For a long time, the common wisdom had it that the act of simplifying was the mission of the architect, and that the act of filling up was the mission of the decorator. Architects for much of this century believed that they were seeking basic truths, and decorators and interior designers, meanwhile, cared not a whit for truth but were much more interested in having a good time, and one rarely had a very good time in empty, or near-empty, rooms. Of course, it was never really so simple. The best architects and interior designers always shared a hesitancy to overindulge - they knew that even the most elaborate rooms are compromised by clutter. Historically, the modern movement led architects, at least for several decades in mid-century, to be strongly committed to austerity, to make interior space correctly crafted as much as they have been concerned with making interior space comfortable.

title: GOING THROUGH THEIR PETULANT MID-20'S
description: BOP By Maxine Chernoff. 126 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: PASSAIC OPPOSED ON RECOVERY PLAN
description: JUST one year ago, this city, struck by a fire on Labor Day that leveled nearly four blocks, began making plans to turn the disaster into an opportunity.

title: 4-H: MORE THAN JUST ANIMALS
description: NEW JERSEY'S many 4-H clubs are not, as popular image has it, only about farm animals and agriculture. In fact, say 4-H officials, the organization has provided a launching pad for a variety of career fields.

title: Susan Jennifer Stein is Bride of Jonathon G. Shore
description: The marriage of Susan Jennifer Stein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner A. Stein of Great Neck, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Jonathan Gideon Shore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gideon Schmukler of Haifa, Israel, took place last evening at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, where Rabbi Mordechai Waxman officiated.

title: WHERE GREAT BOOKS ARE THE TEACHERS
description: PARALLEL LINES strike out across the blackboard, perpendiculars drop, lines intersect, triangles close. And there, on the flat surface of the board, it's as if the icosahedron, the 20-sided figure that is the subject of this geometric proof, has blossomed into three dimensions. Lying flat in the pages of the text, it was just a welter of lines and vertices, a pick-up-sticks of geometric chaos. But now, built up line by line in chalk, a student explaining each step, it grows with the inevitability and grace of an Amish barn-raising.

title: A KILLER, HAUNTED BY SMELLS
description: PERFUME The Story of a Murderer. By Patrick Suskind. Translated by John E. Woods. 255 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Dr. Jacqueline E. Jones Weds John W. Gassett
description: Dr. Jacqueline Eleanor Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Farrell Jones of Port Washington, L.I., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to John Wilfred Gassett, a son of Meredith Gassett of Brockton, Mass., and the late Howard Gassett of Bonifay, Fla. The Rev. David Osborne performed the ceremony at the North Shore Unitarian-Universalist Society in Plandome, L.I.

title: PAKISTANI TEAM REACHES FINAL ROUND OF BRIDGE TOURNAMENT
description: A battling foursome from Pakistan reached the final of the world knockout team championship here today after one of the most memorable episodes in contract bridge history.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
PENN ST. BEATS BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Penn State reverted to its form of a year ago, relying on its defense for a 26-14 victory tonight over Boston College.

title: Bella Venezia
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Venice, I am filled with memories of a beautiful city. The canals do not smell and if indeed the city is sinking, never mind - enjoy its beauty and ambiance.

title: >This Way to the Egress
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Now? Now I am only drunk with happiness.'' - Adam Michnik, political analyst and historian, at party in Warsaw celebrating the release of political prisoners. [ 16:1. ]

title: PALMY DAYS AMONG THE CEYLONESE ARISTOCRACY
description: RELATIVE MERITS A Personal Memoir of the Bandaranaike Family of Sri Lanka. By Yasmine Gooneratne. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.50.

title: SOME EX-AIDES ADJUST WHILE OTHERS SCRAMBLE
description: New York City's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, has resumed running the family business while awaiting his trial.

title: Second Mistrial Is Declared In Weapons-Conspiracy Case
description: The case of a former Ghanaian official charged with conspiring to buy missiles and other weapons for shipment to his homeland ended Friday in a mistrial for the second time.

title: RECENT RECORDINGS OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Kyoto/Vivaldi: 'The Four Seasons' Featuring the Japanese Koto-Ensemble Designed, conceived and written by Rei Nakanishi; directed by Toshiya Iwasa, 1985 Sony Video Software 45 minutes. $29.95

title: Headliners; A Memorable Launching
description: Jason Guterman did not merely come of age last week, he arrived. For their son's bar mitzvah, Gerald and Linda Guterman hired the Queen Elizabeth 2, two orchestras, a string quartet and miscellaneous clowns and other entertainers, laid on a six-entree menu and invited 600 formally attired guests to enjoy it all on an overnight ocean cruise.

title: School Collapse in China
description: Eleven children were reported killed and 35 injured when their school collapsed in the central province of Henan. Henan Daily said a Communist Party secretary and another official had been arrested in connection with the collapse on Sept. 12 in the town of Dazheng. A preliminary investigation found school officials had ignored serious structural problems in the building, the paper said.

title: BUILT TO STAND THE HEAT ANYWHERE
description: Let's talk heat. It's only in the high 80's, but in these parts, where the summers drag on like a visit from an unwanted relative, the numbers aren't important. It's the feeling, the burning, that gets you sooner or later. Your scalp does a slow bake. Your sweat glands overflow.

title: Travel Advisory; Autumnal Colors in the Northeast and in Japan
description: Fall Rambles: West Point To Newport

title: A PITCH FOR THE CHRISTMAS SHOPPER
description: BUYING, or wearing, two or three watches at a time as though they were bangle bracelets does not come naturally to the average person. It is a trend that has been carefully cultivated by advertisements for watches.

title: THE K.G.B. IS WATCHING
description: ABIDING CITY By Laurence Halley. 252 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: THE NOBLE VIRGIN
description: THE NINE DAYS QUEEN A Portrait of Lady Jane Grey. By Mary Luke. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95. LADY JANE GREY AND THE HOUSE OF SUFFOLK By Alison Plowden. Illustrated. 201 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $15.95.

title: DEMOCRATS FASHION CENTRIST IMAGE IN NEW STATEMENT OF PARTY POLICY
description: The Democratic Policy Commission, seeking to create a new image of the party, has produced a statement of principles that includes strikingly tough criticism of the Soviet Union and strongly asserts the importance Democrats accord family life.

title: Alice Yaker Is Wed
description: At the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York last night Alice Yaker and Jerry H. Goldfeder, both lawyers in New York, were married by Rabbi Balfour Brickner. The bride, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is the daughter of Gertrude Yaker of Brooklyn and the late Philip Yaker. Mr. Goldfeder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldfeder of Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., is a Democratic Party district leader from the Upper West Side and chairman of the New Democratic Coalition.

title: WHEN MEN DANCERS PIONEERED
description: The weathervane atop the theater at Jacob's Pillow is in the shape of a dancing man. And now the man on the weathervane has written his life-story. Quite a tale, it can be found in ''Barton Mumaw, Dancer: From Denishawn to Jacob's Pillow and Beyond,'' by Jane Sherman and Barton Mumaw (Dance Horizons). The book casts light on three important institutions: Denishawn, the eclectic and influential school and company that Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn directed from 1915 to 1931; the Men Dancers, Shawn's all-male company that flourished between 1933 and 1940, and the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The book is also valuable because of what it reveals about some of the professional and personal problems dancers faced from the 1920's to the 50's - problems that still have not been entirely solved.

title: Laura Jeanne Akscin Weds Andrew Foord
description: Laura Jeanne Akscin, a lawyer in Seagirt Beach, Queens, was married yesterday to Andrew Duncan Foord, a construction manager for the West Bank Construction Company in Jersey City. The Rev. Mary Heyne, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony on Bear Mountain in Bear Mountain State Park, New York.

title: RIDER COLLEGE PLANS A MAJOR EXPANSION
description: GROUND is expected to be broken in January for a $6.5 million building to house Rider College's School of Business Administration. College officials hope it will be ready by February 1988.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Held
description: The police say they have arrested a man they believe committed 18 bank robberies in the San Fernando Valley northwest of downtown Los Angeles in the past two months. The suspect, Harold H. Ghaemmaghami, who is 33 years old, was arrested Friday by police officers and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as he drove through Van Nuys, the authorities said.

title: City Cracks Down On Commuters Who Aren't
description: A lot of New Yorkers have been lying about where they spend most of their nights, city and state tax auditors said last week.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DEBUT OF THE AMERICAN GOLD BULLION COINS
description: The United States Mint has started production of its new American Eagle gold bullion coins. The first examples should reach retail customers by early November, according to Mint Director Donna M. Pope.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: IT is lunch time at an apartment in the Bryant Gardens co-op complex. Chris has been out for a walk; now he settles himself into a chair near a window whose curtains billow in the warm Steptember breeze. Jack concentrates on a bowl of vegetable soup. David nods a greeting, then nods goodbye - his daughter-in-law is taking him out to a diner.

title: Czechs Firing at 2 Poles Kill a West German
description: A retired West German Army officer was killed this week by stray bullets fired by Czechoslovak border guards at two Poles trying to flee into West Germany, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE INHUMAN CONDITION. By Clive Barker. (Poseidon, $12.95.) Clive Barker is a young Englishman who writes short stories that regularly veer into the category of horror fiction.

title: Parisian Fourth
description: To the Editor: We'd like to share an interesting overseas sidelight to this year's celebration of the Fourth of July.

title: Nancy Krug Marries Deane Michael Dray
description: Nancy Joan Krug and Deane Michael Dray were married yesterday at the Plainview (L.I.) Reformed Church by the Rev. Harry Hall, the pastor, assisted by the Rev. Daniel Sheridan, a Roman Catholic priest. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Krug of Old Bethpage, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Dray of Deerfield, Mass.

title: COHALAN RACE SPELLS TURMOIL FOR SUFFOLK
description: WITH its two leading public officials seeking election to other posts, Suffolk County is confronted with a year of political turmoil and governmental instability.

title: A ROUSING POLISH PARTY CELEBRATES AN AMNESTY
description: ''There has never been a gathering like this, never!'' shouted Jacek Kuron as he hugged Zbigniew Bujak, the once-fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground who was freed last weekend along with Poland's last political prisoners.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 21, 1986
description: FICTION 1 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.50.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 2 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $3.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 3 THE RED FOX, by Anthony Hyde. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A thriller in which a journalist journeys to Russia, seeking the father of a woman he loves. 4 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 5 ENTERPRISE: The First Adventure, by Vonda N. McIntyre. (Pocket, $3.95.) Under a young captain, the Star Trek craft faces unexpected challenges. 6 AFTER THE REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Dell, $4.50.) The surprises that befell four Radcliffe women in the five years after their 20th reunion. 7 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 8 THE TRAIL TO CRAZY MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Three long Western stories that the author later turned into novels. 9 THE RIDER OF THE RUBY HILLS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Four frontier stories that were later expanded into novels. 10 SAN ANDREAS, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett, $4.50.) A British hospital ship with a deadly secret, adrift in the North Sea after a Luftwaffe attack. 11 SWAN'S CHANCE, by Celeste De Blasis. (Bantam, $4.50.) The Civil War ordeals of the Falconers, a Maryland horse-raising and shipbuilding family. 12 PALM BEACH, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A poor but beautiful woman finds her way in the town of the superrich. 13 LUCKY, by Jackie Collins. (Pocket, $4.95.) The heiress of a crime lord versus the heiress of a shipping tycoon. 14 HELLFIRE, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.50.) Fury and vengeance pour out when a long-abandoned mill is reopened. 15 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Bantam, $4.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. NONFICTION: GENERAL 1 YEAGER, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $4.95.) The test pilot's autobiography. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Berkley, $4.50.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband and father. 4 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $4.95.) How the son of immigrants rose to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 5 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvin Kinder. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) Modern women's efforts to find good men. 6 THE BRIDGE ACROSS FOREVER, by Richard Bach. (Dell, $3.95.) A search for a true love. NONFICTION: ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 BLOOM COUNTY BABYLON, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) Five years of comic strips. 3 IT CAME FROM THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) A collection of syndicated ''Far Side'' cartoons. 4 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1986. 5 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Help for victims of others' compulsive behavior. 6 THE ONE MINUTE SALES PERSON, by Spencer Johnson with Larry Wilson. (Avon, $5.) How to increase selling skills. 7 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Revised edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 8 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed Press, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1986 edition. 9 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $8.95.) Cartoons. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: CONGRESS STUDIES DEEP-POCKET POLITICS
description: CONGRESSIONAL concern over the growing influence of political action committees led the Senate last month to approve, 69 to 30, a proposal by Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, that would reduce from $5,000 to $3,000 the maximum amount any such committee could donate to a candidate and increase from $1,000 to $1,500 the maximum contribution for an individual. The measure would limit House candidates to a total of $100,000 in PAC contributions for primary and general elections. Depending on the size of the state, a Senate candidate could receive from $175,000 to $750,000 in such donations. Prospects for the measure are uncertain in the House, but Mr. Boren plans to introduce it again next year in the Senate, where it was strongly opposed by Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Minnesota Republican, among others. Senators Boren and Boschwitz discussed campaign financing with Martin Tolchin, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. Excerpts from those interviews follow. SENATOR BOREN CANDIDATES ARE ON THE AUCTION BLOCK

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: RAILROAD FESTIVAL Last year's Hoboken Terminal Festival drew 50,000 visitors, and this year's event - it features a 1928 steam locomotive and a train of 10 antique passenger cars - is expected to attract even more.

title: Candida S. Jones Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Candida Starr Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Starr Jones 2d of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Bradley Dean Landes took place yesterday at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Miller performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Edythe Martin Landes of New Haven and Gilbert Dean Landes of Stamford, Conn.

title: SIX OUTSIDERS PLOT A FUTURE FOR FORDHAM
description: John C. Burton Dean, Columbia Business School

title: THE RUSH TO HIRE L.A. LAWYERS
description: ANTHONY J. ONCIDI, a young associate at a Los Angeles law firm, received a tantalizing telephone call the other day. A ''headhunter'' asked if he was interested in moving four blocks to the rapidly expanding Los Angeles branch of a New York law firm, for a 50 percent pay increase to $90,000.

title: A CELEBRATION OF THE OYSTER
description: EVEN shellfish must have their day. And next weekend the mollusk will be celebrated at the annual Oyster Festival in Oyster Bay.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
California Builder Finds It Pays to Go East
description: AFTER studying the commercial real-estate market in New Jersey for the past two years, the Sammis Company, a major developing firm with headquarters in Irvine, Calif., has zeroed in on the rapidly expanding suburbs of Somerset and Morris Counties. The result is more than 1 million square feet of new commercial space that the company plans to develop in three large-scale projects.

title: 'STEADY GROWTH' AT ST. JOSEPH'S COLLEGE
description: I am the librarian at St. Joseph's College, Patchogue, and was very happy to note in the Long Island section on Aug. 31 an analysis of higher education and its projected future here on the Island [ ''Colleges Try the Hard Sell'' ] . But I was shocked and disappointed that we were completely omitted from the account.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: RETURN TRIPS, by Alice Adams. (Fawcett Crest, $3.95.) The protagonists in Alice Adams's third collection of short stories, mostly professional women, have ''a number of years and a good deal of experience behind them,'' Beverly Lowry said in The Book Review last year. Love and loss, travel and return, death and survival figure in many of the tales. ''How can one person know so much?'' Ms. Lowry asked. ''Like Colette's, Alice Adams's world is - praise be, these times - an altogether adult one. Long may she explore that world and make her swift reports.'' THE LIVELY AUDIENCE: A Social History of the Visual and Performing Arts in America, 1890-1950, by Russell Lynes. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) An excursion beginning with the Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago and ending with the Abstract Expressionists of the mid-20th century takes the reader through the worlds of music, theater, fine arts, movies and architecture. ''This is a charming book full of lovely touches,'' Richard Dougherty said in these pages in 1985. The author ''is superbly equipped to guide us on this amusing and informative journey over the goofy landscape of American artistic endeavor.'' THE BUS OF DREAMS, by Mary Morris. (Penguin, $6.95.) Transience and detachment are themes in many of these short stories, which are set in locales as disparate as Cape Canaveral, Peru, the Chicago suburbs and the Caribbean. They call to mind ''newspaper clippings or news flashes, bits of familiar this and that whizzing by,'' our reviewer, Eve Ottenberg, said in 1985.

title: Iceland Ends Dispute With U.S. Over Shipping
description: Foreign Minister Matthias Matthiesen announced an agreement with the United States today that promises to end a bitter two-year dispute over shipping to the United States Navy base at Keflavik, on the southwestern tip of the island.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''Bowling is the harmless sublimation of the terrible human instinct to throw things,'' H. Thomas Steele writes in his surprisingly entertaining book BOWL-O-RAMA: The Visual Arts of Bowling (Abbeville, $19.95). This lively pictorial history, which includes a fascinating account of bowling's origins, is mainly composed of beautifully reproduced color illustrations that celebrate the sport through the images and artifacts it has inspired.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: AT THE 'CLUB' Whenever and wherever Ray Johnson takes his ''performance art,'' the chances are that he will produce what one critic called ''a great deal of levity and wit, but also an air of deadly seriousness.'' Today the Locust Valley artist, who also works in the visual arts, takes ''The Jean Dubuffet Fan Club Meeting'' to the formal gardens of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art.

title: MORE DEBATE ON BASES SEEMS LIKELY IN MANILA
description: A commission preparing a new Philippine Constitution has defeated radical moves to dismantle American bases here and to ban nuclear weapons, but has adopted provisions that seem to guarantee divisive future debate over the bases.

title: INDEPENDENT BEFORE INDEPENDENCE
description: LIBERTY AND POWER 1600-1760. Volume One of ''Liberty in America: 1600 to the Present.'' By Oscar and Lilian Handlin. 280 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Lissa Lowenstein Weds
description: Lissa Lowenstein, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Lowenstein of New York and Clavarack, N.Y., was married last Sunday to Dr. Jonathan C. Florman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Florman of New York and Kent Cliffs, N.Y. Rabbi Jules Harlow officiated at the Lowenstein home in Clavarack. The bride is a counselor and teacher of special-needs children at the Manville School in Boston, where Dr. Florman is a resident in psychiatry at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: EXPANDING THE SHRINKING LABOR FORCE
description: ''HELP wanted, flexible hours.'' ''Seniors welcome! No experience required.'' The signs are everywhere. Employees are a scarce commodity, say Westchester labor analysts. The county posted an unemployment rate of 3.1 percent in July, the lowest in the state and far below the national average of 6.3, said Richard Kappus, the labor-market analyst who tracks employment trends in Westchester.

title: Convicted Slayer of 2 Will Not Seek Appeal
description: The lawyer for former New York stockbroker Murray Gold said Friday there will be no appeal of Mr. Gold's conviction and sentence for the murder of his former in-laws in 1974.

title: TAX BILL PROTECTS OLDER HOME LOANS
description: Millions of homeowners who borrowed heavily against their homes in recent years would be protected from tough new limits on interest deductions in the tax legislation, according to documents released today.

title: WHITE PLAINS HOTEL CANCELED BY BUILDER
description: WHITE PLAINS will not get the 19-story, $175-a-night hotel it had been expecting, the builder revealed last week.

title: In the Ballpark
description: On the theory that a significant number of Washington political professionals are also Redskin football fans, one of the numerous political consulting concerns in the capital, Nordlinger Associates, is running a less-than-subtle ad on the animated scoreboard in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium during home games. Its red, white and blue letters inform elected officials: ''When you're out of votes, you're out of here.'' Then the Capitol dome opens and ejects a defeated candidate, followed by the signature: ''Nordlinger Associates, the Political Communications and Research Company.''

title: CARNAL LANGUAGE
description: DAUGHTERS OF MEMORY By Peter Najarian. Illustrated. 157 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: City Miner Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: WORKING TO SAVE AN AGING LIGHTHOUSE
description: SALTWATER, wind, rain and ice have assaulted Long Island's lighthouses for years, but Federal budget cuts and automation now threaten to do away with them completely.

title: Barbara Cooke Wed To Lawrence Monks
description: The marriage of Barbara Cooke, the daughter of Col. Frederick James Cooke, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Cooke of Chestnut Hill, Mass., to Lawrence Edward Monks, the son of Mrs. Leo Edward Monks of Natick, Mass., and the late Mr. Monks, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. George L. Blackman and the Rev. James L. Monks, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: ANNUAL EXHIBIT IN GREENWICH HONORS AREA ARTISTS
description: THE annual members' juried exhibition, the most important event on the Greenwich Art Society's calendar, opened in the Hurlbutt Gallery at the Greenwich Library Thursday to run through Oct. 12.

title: BOSTON WATERFRONT: AT 25, A MODEL URBAN RENEWAL
description: The obvious anniversary in Boston last month was Quincy Market's 10th. But there was a larger, unsung anniversary - the 25th for renewal of the downtown Boston waterfront.

title: HOLY LAND'S TREASURES COME TO NEW YORK AT LAST
description: Though it's roughly two years behind schedule, thanks to the controversy that has swirled about it, ''Treasures of the Holy Land,'' a show of art and artifacts from the rich cultural terrain of Israel, will finally open to the public Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum. The largest and most important exhibition of ancient art from Israel ever to travel abroad, the show presents nearly 200 objects spanning 12,000 years, from carved bone animals of the Neolithic period to a mosaic synagogue floor made in the sixth century A.D. In its totality, the show is a moving expression of the spirit of the Holy Land, conveying a fascinating sense of the grand, prodigal, hodgepodge of people and cultures out of which emerged the basis for Judeo-Christian civilization. And in the objects themselves we seem to experience a haunting aura, an ancestral pull that lessens our remoteness in time and space from the land of the Bible.

title: Make It Legal
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa And Sanctions
description: I admire Helen Suzman's endeavors to speak out against apartheid while seeking a constructive means by which to implement change (''What America Should Do About South Africa,'' Aug. 3). I, nonetheless, disagree with her opposition to sanctions.

title: IS A WEAKER DOLLAR HELPING U.S. TRADE?  YES: IMAGINE IF THE DOLLAR HADN'T FALLEN
description: It is just a year since the Group of Five agreed on a plan to drive down the value of the dollar. Yet, largely because of the Plaza Agreement, as it has come to be called, the dollar has declined by about 40 percent against the Japanese yen and major European currencies, and about 30 percent against an average of all industrial countries.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Uptick in the C.P.I.

title: Danbury Mall Rents Out Before Opening
description: WITH the long-awaited opening of a regional shopping mall on the site of the old Danbury fairgrounds scheduled for Oct. 9, virtually all of the 210 stores have been rented - a exception for an industry accustomed to having less than half of a mall's space filled by opening day.

title: A DWINDLING SPECIES: THE FOOTBALL HERO
description: BEGINNING his second year as the varsity football coach at Old Saybrook High School, Bill Golden had reason to be optimistic in mid-August, just before preseason practice began.

title: AUTUMN IN NEW YORK
description: Traditionally, fall brings warmer, more intense colors in makeup. This autumn is no exception -except for the exceptions. Because following a prescribed palette for the eyes, cheeks and lips is a thing of the past, there is more variety in color and fewer rules about application.

title: POWER TO THE PROVINCES TO A POINT
description: THE rumor spread that the central Government was planning to close a television station here begun by the regional Basque government without Madrid's permission. Five vans of Basque police officers were immediately called to the station.

title: Before the Shootdown
description: In 1984 and 1985, several articles in this space raised questions about the Reagan Administration's insistence that on the night of Aug. 31-Sept. 1, 1983, Korean Air Lines Flight 007 accidentally entered the Soviet Union's airspace and was deliberately shot down by Soviet air defensemen who knew it was a civilian air-liner.

title: Appomattox
description: To the Editor: In Richard Halloran's excellent article about Appomattox (Travel, July 6) he identifies John Brown Gordon as a lieutenant general.

title: LASTING STYLE
description: While other interior designers are only beginning to discover the spare look, Albert Hadley never has strayed from this view. Instead, he has been refining his renowned disciplined approach.

title: Ellen Medearis Is Wed To Richard Superfine
description: The Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Ellen Sandford Medearis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Medearis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., to Richard Superfine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Superfine of Philadelphia. The Rev. Francis M. Geer, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Allen Press performed the interdenominational ceremony.

title: NEW SOUTH FORK VINEYARD OPPOSED
description: PLANS to start a new vineyard in Water Mill, which would be only the second wine-making operation on the South Fork, have run into opposition from local residents, Southampton Town officials and other vintners.

title: BRAZIL AND THE BOMB: QUESTIONS ARISE ANEW
description: After the mystery of a remote air force base with a hole deep enough to test an underground nuclear device, there came news that the navy was building a secret uranium enrichment plant that could provide fuel for a nuclear submarine. And with that, the controversy was on again.

title: MIGRANT WORKERS FIND AN EASIER ROW TO HOE
description: A CBS-TV network camera crew recently came to the East End of Long Island to shoot farm scenes for an update of Edward R. Murrow's famous documentary ''Harvest of Shame.''

title: GOETHE'S ITALIAN JOURNEY
description: A fugitive moon slipped among the clouds over the Rotonda, whose marble flanks were washed with spotlights. ''Viene Goethe,'' whispered citizens of Vicenza, seated on metal folding chairs arrayed on the lawn of Palladio's 16th-century architectural masterpiece. ''Goethe is coming.'' Like a password, the message rustled through the audience as the jingling clatter of the horse-drawn carriage grew louder and nearer -and then, a vision in the Italian night, there he was. This legendary German sojourner was once again on the spiritual quest that he first made in 1786 and that has been emulated by millions since.

title: LOSS LEAVES HOLTZ 0-2 AS NOTRE DAME COACH
description: The Lou Holtz era at Notre Dame is still looking for a victory as the Irish dropped their second game today. Michigan State's defense stymied Steve Beuerlein's passing attack and the Spartans won, 20-15.

title: TRAILS BY POINT IN TITLE MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov exploited a blunder by Gary Kasparov to win the 18th game of the world championship chess match yesterday in Leningrad. The 35-year-old former champion has now pulled to within a point of tying the contest, which began July 28.

title: INSIDE
description: TAX BILL AND HOME LOANS Tough limits on interest deductions in the tax bill would not apply to loans taken out against homes before Aug. 17, documents show.

title: THE RESULT OF FREE-AGENT INACTIVITY
description: MAJOR LEAGUE baseball owners and their officials have long and repeatedly asserted that their primary concern has been to preserve the integrity of, and maintain public confidence in, the game. Although the rhetoric has usually omitted definitions, it is clear that the references are to the honesty of the contests; that in all games, everyone involved must do all that is reasonable and proper to win.

title: TEETERING ON A THIN LINE BETWEENNREPUTATION AND RUINATION
description: AMERICA'S campaign against child abuse and molestation has unearthed many cases that might otherwise have remained buried.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THEY'RE small calamities, but that's not exactly how the people affected describe them. They'll accept the word calamity, but small? -never. The moment of happening is, according to those on the receiving end, the end of the world, absolute disaster, or a combination of both. Fortunately, the disasters under discussion are benign, the kind of ''I don't believe it's happening'' occurrence that, very shortly after, turns into humor, and then into a terrific dining out story.

title: Cuban Prisoners Are Free at Last
description: ''This is a dream,'' said Ramon Grau Alsina last week after his 90-mile flight to freedom. ''Tonight I will see the moon over Miami.''

title: ANCIENT TOWN OF MYTHOLOGY AND MOSAICS
description: It was one of the great cities of antiquity, and events of historic magnitude are known to have occurred there. Others are said to have taken place, but they cannot be proved or gainsaid. Early Christianity made it one of its vital centers. Mythology situates some of its most enduring legends in its precincts. Its mosaics, gathered in a provincial museum whose modesty belies the splendors of its contents, are second to none, not even Ravenna's or the Chora Monastery's in Istanbul.

title: SHAKEN BY TERROR, PARIS PERSEVERES
description: The Champs-Elysees, its outdoor cafes sparkling in late-summer sunshine, was a picture of Parisian life today, marred by the lurking fear of a terrorist attack.

title: RADON EXPERTS SEE NEED FOR TESTING
description: ALL New Jersey homeowners who live north of Trenton should have their houses tested for radon immediately, according to two of the state's leading public-health experts.

title: Officer Charged in Shooting
description: An off-duty city corrections officer was charged yesterday with shooting a man in the finger during a dispute in Brooklyn, authorities said. The officer, Atlas Garner, 39 years old, of Queens was charged with assault and reckless endangerment. The victim, a 33-year-old man whose name was not released, got into a dispute with Officer Garner about 2:30 A.M. He was treated at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn

title: SOWETO RESIDENTS SAY THE POLICE KILLED 5 PEOPLE AT A FUNERAL
description: Residents of Soweto, the sprawling black township outside Johannesburg, said today that black municipal policemen led by two whites shot five blacks to death during a funeral vigil before dawn, spraying a house and a tent for mourners with gunfire.

title: KINARD INTERCEPTS SOME RECOGNITION
description: This is Terry Kinard's fourth season in the National Football League, and the scouting report on the Giants' free safety is impressive.

title: POSTINGS: A Shul in Time; Modular Answer on S.I.
description: Members of the newly formed Congregation Shaarei Simcha in the New Springville section of Staten Island were aware that the High Holy Days were fast approaching and that the cellar the flock of Rabbi Nate Segal had been using for its synagogue just would not do. It was cramped and occasionally it flooded with several inches of water when the rains came.

title: CORNELL A WINNER IN OPENER
description: Maxie Baughan has already achieved what he failed to accomplish in his first three years as coach of Cornell.

title: ENHANCING THE PC'S COORDINATION
description: INTEGRATED software made its mark on personal computing with the immensely successful Lotus 1-2-3. That program arrived on the scene at a time when ''integration'' and ''multitasking'' were buzzwords in the industry, and its prosperity fostered many a dream of further megahits.

title: A Rousing Debut
description: Occasionally, life imitates corn and is no less glorious for it. One such scenario began to take shape at Shea Stadium last week when Keith Hernandez, the New York Mets' All-Star first baseman, did his part by catching a cold.

title: Q AND A
description: Camping Plans Question:My wife and I are hoping to tent camp in England and France next summer. We would like information on guidebooks on camping sites in England and the Paris region, and the feasibility and cost of transporting our camping equipment, including small tent, to Europe by air. - R. W. B., Grosse Pointe Park, Mich. Answer:For England, the country's Automobile Association issues a comprehensive book titled ''A.A. Camping and Caravaning in Britain,'' which lists sites all over the country and rates them with from one to five pennants. The information ranges from site rules and fees to local shops, and there are maps. The book is sold by the British Travel Bookshop (40 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-765-0898) for $10.50 and $1.95 for shipping.

title: A Kennedy Wins And a DuPont Plans Ahead
description: Though last week's primaries produced no great upsets, in general they reflected more Democratic than Republican strengths.

title: CORRECTION
description: The credit under a drawing that accompanied a Business Forum article on free trade last week misidentified the artist. He is P. E. Foster.

title: ILLEGAL TAKING OF CLAMS FROM TAINTED BAY RISES
description: The patrol boat cut through the murky waters of Jamaica Bay and veered toward the Brooklyn shore several hundred feet away. From the bow, Officer William Geeslin of the United States Park Police peered at four-foot-tall thickets of marsh grass rimming the shore.

title: Mets Call Up Lawyer
description: IN theory, at least, it is not the Mets, but two Met players who face felony assault charges in Houston, but with the prospect of a Mets-Astros showdown for the National League pennant, the Mets aren't taking any chances. The club has hired a lawyer of its own to help defend the players, Ron Darling and Tim Teufel, who so far have been represented by Dick DeGuerin. Darling and Teufel were arrested last July 20 at a popular Houston nightspot, Cooter's Executive Games and Burgers, and accused of assaulting a pair of Cooter's finest, two uniformed Houston police officers working as bouncers at the disco. In disclosing that the club had hired a lawyer, the Mets' director of public relations, Jay Horwitz, stressed that there was no dissatisfaction with the players' lawyer. ''We have hired counsel just to be in the background, just to be of help if there is a need,'' he said. There was some indication, however, that the Mets might like to arrange a quick plea bargain. The first pre-trial hearing has been scheduled for Oct. 30, four days after the last possible World Series game, and Horowitz indicated the Mets would like to have the matter out of the way even before the playoffs, which begin Oct. 8. DeGuerin has ruled out a plea bargain, vowed a vigorous trial defense and publicly denounced the arresting officers and the police department program that allows them to hire out to private businesses.

title: Agent Orange And a Family's Ordeal
description: Much has been written about the Vietnam War, but its ultimate tragedy has rarely been revealed more graphically than in ''Agent Orange and the Anguish of an American Family,'' the Aug. 24 story by Elmo Zumwalt Jr. and Elmo Zumwalt 3d, with John Pekkanen.

title: FOR 3d TIME, KLEIN CHALLENGES KENNELLY FOR FIRST DISTRICT SEAT
description: HERSCHEL A. KLEIN jokes that he once had a teacher who told him, ''If you don't do it right, you're going to keep doing it until you get it right.''

title: THE FLOWERING OF 13 GARDENERS
description: IT IS sunny, and the flowers are so vivid I don't know where to look first.

title: WHO LIVES FAR AWAY AND BRINGS PRESENTS?
description: THE NEW AMERICAN GRANDPARENT A Place in the Family, A Life Apart. By Andrew J. Cherlin and Frank F. Furstenberg Jr. 278 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: Dance
description: Want to join dancers in some celebrations? There are several opportunities to do so this week. The Erick Hawkins Dance Company is celebrating its 35th anniversary with a season opening Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: THE U.N.'S COMPLICATED BRAND OF OFFICE POLITICS
description: ACCORDING to the Russians, Gennadi F. Zakharov is an international civil servant who was trying to learn all he could for his job in an obscure scientific office of the United Nations. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he is a spy who bought classified information and should be tried and punished.

title: The Peace Corps
description: The Peace Corps celebrated its 25th anniversary here this month, reminding us that American foreign policy is not all missiles and Stealth bombers but has a gentler side.

title: Joanna Bendheim Marries Jules Bergman, an Editor
description: Joanna Lee Bendheim and Jules Bergman were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Bendheim, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis officiated.

title: FILM: NUCLEAR COMEDY
description: ''RADIOACTIVE DREAMS,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO National Twin and other theaters, was not heralded by any press screenings. This is no surprise. The film is so inane, and its plot so consistently defies logic, taste, and even clever commercialism, that the mystery is simply that it opened at all.

title: VENTURING BEYOND THE BURRITO
description: FOR Mexican food that is tastier and more interesting than the combination platters served at the elaborate chain restaurants opening across Long Island, try Amigos in Port Washington. Originally a small storefront, it has added a second storefront, doubling the size without diminishing quality.

title: Susan Sutherland, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Susan Jane Sutherland and Robert Booth Opatrny, graduates of the New York University School of Law who practice in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Church of Christ, Congregational, in Norfolk, Conn. The Rev. Bruce F. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title:
DINING OUT;
FAMILY-RUN ITALIAN IN TARRYTOWN
description: THE county's booming condominium projects have done much to increase the area's dining-out population. To meet the feeding demands of these new arrivals, often a 9-to-5 working couple, yuppy dining spots that once seemed confined to Manhattan appear to be following their constituency northward, opening in towns that not long ago were known for little more than a gas station and a diner.

title: AUTUMN IN PARIS
description: AFTER SEVERAL YEARS OF TOYING WITH VARI-ous ready-to-wear fancies - including Japanese shroudings; strict, minimalist separates; somberly erotic body dresses, and neo-New Wave tough gear - Parisian fashion designers and buyers are again enamored of the opulence that couture originally represented. The fashion world has embraced Paris for clothes, hairdos and makeup that evoke artifice, originality, audacity, a certain Baroque glamour and a naughty sense of humor that makes one smile, laugh and, finally, want to look the extravagant part. Suddenly it is not demode to dress and make up. Suddenly it is new-fashioned to look old-fashioned. Perhaps this new couture fever is a necessary change, since with it comes a breath of highly intoxicating fresh fashion air. If haute couture is rampant with seemingly impractical, improbable and clearly imaginative clothes, accessories, hairdos and makeup, it is on purpose. Evening fashion is swinging toward fantasy and embellishment. A simultaneous craving for arch elegance and frivolity is its newest fixation.

title: WORLD GROUP BACKS TALKS TO END CURBS ON FARM AND SERVICE TRADE
description: In an attempt to stimulate economic growth and halt a drift to protectionism, a global trade conference agreed early today on a far-reaching agenda for new talks on freer trade in goods and services.

title: JURY BEING PICKED IN RETRIAL OF GUYANA CULTIST
description: Nearly eight years after the event, the story of the mass suicide and murder in the jungle of Guyana that took the lives of more than 900 people, most of them cult members, is about to be told again in a Federal courtroom here.

title: The Recovery
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES H. GRAY, 70, PUBLISHER AND A FORMER SEGREGATIONIST
description: James H. Gray Sr., a Georgia publisher and former state Democratic chairman who drew wide attention two decades ago as he articulated a segregationist position in the tones of his native Massachusetts, died Friday of a heart attack at the New England Medical Center in Boston. A resident of Albany, Ga. since 1946, he was 70 years old.

title: HARTSDALE STUDENT WINS PRIZE FOR PLAY
description: ISA-JILL GORDON, 17 years old last week, would rather be an actress than a playwright; in fact, the hyphenated extension of her given name, Isa - after her late grandfather, Isaac - was her own invention, as she envisioned ''a pretty stage name in lights.'' That was in the seventh grade. ''I was kind of a precocious kid,'' she recalled.

title: Prosecutor Is Selected In Levin Slaying Case
description: Linda Fairstein, a veteran prosecutor in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, will head the prosecution of Robert E. Chambers Jr., who is charged with strangling 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin in Central Park on Aug. 26, according to a spokesman for the office.

title: SCHOOLS STEPPING UP CAMPAIGN AGAINST DRUGS
description: THE Lakeland School District is recruiting members for its newly formed Drug and Alcohol Abuse Council. The Byram Hills Parent-Teacher Association will have a former Newark police detective, David Toma, at its high school Sept. 30 to talk to students about the dangers of drug abuse. And Harrison school officials have scheduled a community seminar on drugs for next month.

title: WALL STREET RETHINKS ITS LATEST TRADING FAD
description: THE ''triple witching hour'' explosion that some had expected on the stock exchange Friday was a dud. But the controversy over program trading, the sophisticated investment strategy responsible for the upheavals that have sometimes marked ''witching'' Fridays, is far from over.

title: Cohen Ponders Man and Science
description: Senator William S. Cohen is one of the better known poets on Capitol Hill, writing about the disparate worlds of politics and the inner man. But his second volume of poetry, ''A Baker's Nickel,'' just published by William Morrow & Company, contains a poem, ''High Frontier,'' that touches on both.

title: ROAMING BACK ROADS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Whenever I leave home, which isn't often, I tend to go what we used to call ''the extra mile.'' I arrive at a quite unforeseen added destination to that which I set out for. These little add-ed journeys have, over the years, over-shadowed - overshone - the main trip. I find myself dwelling on them, on the accidents that caused them, on their durability as experiences.

title: SIGNS THAT MAY POINT TO TOUR-PACKAGE DEFAULT
description: If you dialed 800-338-2700 recently with questions about your planned vacation in the Caribbean, you would have been told that the number had been disconnected.

title: Short Search
description: THE search for a permanent replacement for Dana Kirk, who was dismissed as the Memphis State basketball coach last week, was apparently over before it really got started. Kirk's assistant, Larry Finch, who was named interim coach after Kirk's dismissal Wednesday, has been offered the job on a permanent basis and is expected to accept it, according to university officials.

title: LEARNING EXPERIENCE FOR A PRINCIPAL
description: I AM an elementary school principal. I am also a lifelong learner. In order to continue to grow, it is necessary for me to regularly take seminars, workshops and courses, much as a dancer continues to take classes throughout her career.

title: Sheila A. Heffron To Wed Dec. 20
description: Sheila Anne Heffron and Michael Louis Rankowitz plan to be married Dec. 20, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Heffron of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Westhampton, L.I., have announced. Mr. Rankowitz is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Rankowitz of Pawtucket, R.I.

title: PROGRESS IS CITED BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON SUMMIT MEETING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister said tonight that they had made progress in laying the groundwork for a summit meeting.

title: OPENING UP SOME ELITE CITY SCHOOLS
description: AT Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, a group of seniors sprawled comfortably on a hallway floor the other day, engrossed in animated discussion. Another student sat by herself, busily doing homework. It was a normal scene at Murrow, where students are given ''option time'' each day to do what they want: chatter, work, sit in the library, go to the cafeteria or do some service chore, such as answering the switchboard.

title: NEW START, OLD ENDING FOR COLUMBIA
description: The powers-that-be at Columbia University hired a new football coach. The coach chose a different metaphor. The Lions discovered a brand-new punter. They all endured a familiar result. In Larry McElreavy's first game as coach, the Columbia season began the same way the one last year under Jim Garrett had ended. Just a little more quietly. The Lions lost to Harvard, 34-0, this afternoon at Harvard Stadium. They extended their current losing streak, the longest in Division I-AA, to 22 games. They have not won since October 15, 1983, and they have just five victories in their last 74 games. The Lions have lost 26 times to the Crimson, with three victories and one tie, since 1956. They have not scored a touchdown in 16 quarters.

title: GENDER KEEPS CHANGING
description: WOMEN, FEMINISM AND BIOLOGY The Feminist Challenge. By Lynda Birke. 210 pp. New York: Methuen. Cloth, $25. Paper, $11.95.

title: Sara Lynn Chang Becomes a Bride
description: Sara Lynn Chang, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lennig W. Chang of Needham, Mass., and Meredith, N.H., was married yesterday to Kevin McCammon Guthrie, a son of Gen. John R. Guthrie, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Guthrie of Annandale, Va. The ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Borsch, an Episcopal priest and the dean of the chapel.

title: Young Couple Gather Allies To Bend Rules
description: The nation's capital has long been a destination for the aggrieved who hope that a journey here will promote a cause, block an injustice or untangle the red tape of the Federal bureaucracy. Such was the goal this week of a young couple from California who are trying to stay together in the face of a Government agency's ruling.

title: MY HANDSOME, COSMOPOLITAN FRIEND
description: A SPECIAL DESTINY By Seymour Epstein. 329 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: Why Don't They Sign Social Security Letters?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE controversial Pelican Cove condominium and marina development in Brick Township, currently in the appeal process, has been put on hold while the developer and the state's Department of Environmental Protection negotiate an acceptable water-quality management plan.

title:
ART;
IN SEARCH OF THE DEEPER MEANING
description: IN MANY cultures, art is closely linked to religious and social practice and the artist's role is to celebrate the significance of those beliefs and customs.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SOURCE OF SUCCESS Sal Fradella, a seventh-grade social studies teacher in Mohegan, is also a writer and lecturer. At 8 P.M. Tuesday in the New Rochelle Public Library, he will narrate a slide show on his book about Jack Johnson, the black prizefighter who broke the color barrier in the ring.

title: ACHIEVEMENTS OF A LIFELONG GUEST
description: A RINGING GLASS The Life of Rainer Maria Rilke. By Donald Prater. Illustrated. 472 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50. THE SONNETS TO ORPHEUS By Rainer Maria Rilke. Translated by Stephen Mitchell. 183 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $13.95 Paper, $6.95.

title: No Class for 61,000 Pupils, But 3 Teacher Walkouts End
description: Salary disputes that led teachers to the picket lines have ended in one Pennsylvania and two Michigan districts, but more than 61,000 pupils remain without classes nationwide.

title:
RECORDINGS;
GENIUS OF CULT FIGURE?: 10 CD'S REVEAL A CONDUCTOR
description: Consider the case of Carlos Paita. Well-heeled conductors in the past - Serge Koussevitzky and Leopold Stokowski, to name two -have founded their own symphony orchestras to advance their careers or causes. Others have paid to get up in front of existing orchestras. Mr. Paita presents yet another scenario: a conductor whose admirers, seeking to make an indifferent world listen, have created an orchestra and record company for him.

title: ARMY UPSET BY WILDCATS
description: He spoke of pride and of aggressiveness before the seemingly sure defeat, but Northwestern's interim head coach, Francis Peay, knew his team's game today against Army would come down to a single factor: the Wildcats' ability to stop the Cadets' wishbone offense.

title: CITY PLANS TO FINISH 63d STREET SUBWAY LINE BY '91
description: The 63d Street subway line - begun more than 15 years ago as a new link between Manhattan and Queens -would finally be finished under the $6.5 billion capital improvement plan proposed last week by the president of the city's Transit Authority.

title: 'MARLENE,' MAXIMILIAN SCHELL'S DOCUMENTARY ABOUT DIETRICH
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK, who never took kindly to suggestions from actors in his employ, once said of Marlene Dietrich: ''She's a professional.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TIGERS IN THE WOOD. By Rebecca Kavaler. (University of Illinois, $11.95.) These seven stories have the density and texture of miniature novels; each is at once a finely calibrated character study, an oblique essay on the ritual failings of the American family and, most ambitiously, an ironic investigation of memory.

title: WHEN THE MOVIES WERE FUN
description: IN the days when movie theaters had names like Central, Capitol and Lincoln, going to the movies was fun.

title: SUMMIT PATH: CLEARER NOW?
description: After months of sharp disputes, the United States and the Soviet Union seem suddenly on the road to both a summit meeting and conclusion of a major arms control agreement.

title: LADY'S SECRET SETS RECORD IN RUFFIAN
description: Any doubts that Lady's Secret is among the best fillies ever to race were erased yesterday when the daughter of Secretariat carried 129 pounds to an eight-length victory while winning the $230,400 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park in stakes-record time.

title: FOR AQUINO, A DAY FULL OF MEMORIES
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines received an honorary degree and two medals from three colleges, in a day full of memories she shared yesterday with private friends and crowds of cheering strangers.

title: Ohio Knife to Shut Plant
description: The Ohio Knife Company, a manufacturer of industrial cutting equipment, is shutting down its Cincinnati plant and reviewing operations of an Indiana plant. Company officials said imported products from competitors helped force the plant out of business.

title: Journalists Add To Bangladesh Strikes
description: Strikes have shut Bangladesh's newspapers, hospitals and universities and raised fears that violence may disrupt the presidential elections scheduled for next month.

title: Amy R. Benenson Weds C. H. Aronson
description: At the Pierre Hotel in New York yesterday Amy Roberta Benenson, the daughter of Edward H. Benenson of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and East Hampton, L.I., and Mrs. Richard Lewisohn of New York and Holmes, N.Y., was married to Clifford H. Aronson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Aronson of Marina Del Rey, Calif. Rabbi Shira Stern and Presiding Justice Milton Mollen of New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, officiated.

title: Use of Public Transit In Midtown Is Urged
description: Because of today's ceremonial opening of the United Nations General Assembly, City Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler yesterday urged those traveling to midtown to use public transportation.

title: Nancy A. Burger Marries W. J. Dougherty, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Nancy Ann Burger, area manager in Albany for the Treasury Department's Savings Bonds Division, to William James Dougherty, a partner in the New York law firm of Solomon & Rosenbaum, Drechsler & Leff and special counsel to State Senator Warren M. Anderson, took place yesterday at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Bolton Landing, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Young officiated.

title: Repression Is Undoing Work of Vatican II
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Sell Democracy Short
description: There will be an effort in the Senate this week to kill off the National Endowment for Democracy, the private agency that administers this country's modest efforts to promote democratic movements around the world. This should not be allowed to happen.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1986
description: International

title: Philadelphia Orchestra In Wagner Programs
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra will continue its three-year-old series of full operas in concert version with three performances of Wagner's opera ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' on Oct. 9, 11 and 14.

title: Bridge: Americans Lead Pakistanis In World Team Title Event
description: An American team held a commanding lead as play neared an end in the final of the World Knockout Team Championship here tonight.

title: A Bevy of Birdies
description: Gary Grossman, a 45-year-old certified public accountant, has what he calls ''a unique brand of mentality.'' That means he likes to keep records and make lists. As a boy, he studied the telephone directory to extract the 50 most common first names. He used to record his bowling scores. He still lists all the operas he attends, making careful note of places and performers, and, as a golf buff, he can cite from memory every winner of the Masters and the United States Open.

title: PUSH BY BSN STIRS UP SPORTING GOODS INDUSTRY
description: Less than 15 years ago, Michael J. Blumenfeld, a one-time minor league outfielder, broke into the sporting goods business by selling tennis court nets ''door to door'' to Memphis country clubs.

title: SENIOR'S SCORES ON TESTS FOR COLLEGE SHOW SOME SIGNS OF IMPROVEMENT
description: High school students showed some signs of improvement this year on standardized college admission tests.

title: DANCE: A GALA TRIBUTE TO SOKOLOW
description: THE achievements of a distinguished American modern-dance choreographer and teacher were celebrated Saturday night in ''A Gala Benefit Performance Honoring Anna Sokolow'' at the Joyce Theater. It was the opening event of ''Jews and Judaism in Dance: Reflections and Celebrations,'' an international conference and festival sponsored by the National Foundation for Jewish Culture. The conference will also include lectures and symposiums today and tomorrow at the 92d Street Y. A member of Martha Graham's company in the 1930's, Ms. Sokolow has since choreographed both dances of social protest and dances of poignant lyricism, and her best-known creations include works expressing the loneliness of big cities and choreographic treatments of Jewish themes. A teacher much in demand throughout the world, she has often taught in Israel, where she has encouraged Inbal, a company rooted in Yemenite Jewish traditions.

title: A Busy Week for U.S. Financings
description: The Treasury has scheduled securities auctions every day this week, except Friday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: GATT TALKS FACING TOUGH OBSTACLES
description: A new attempt to liberalize world trade is expected to be the most difficult such effort in the postwar period. There are a rising number of key players in the trading system, the United States Congress remains at odds with the President over protectionism and the easiest measures to foster more-balanced trade are already in place.

title: A Rehnquist Ruling On Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 From Polish Freighter Crew Left BehMnd in Duluth, Minn.
description: A Polish freighter left the Duluth Harbor Saturday, leaving behind three crew members who are apparently seeking asylum in the United States.

title: Linda Chin Is Wed To David Krawitz
description: Linda Chin and David Krawitz were married yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Acting Justice Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated in the room named after the late Eleanor Belmont, the bridegroom's godmother.

title: ON RIVERSIDE DRIVE, 2 VAST CRATERS
description: Apparently undermined by a leaking water main, two large sections of Riverside Drive near 156th Street in northern Manhattan collapsed like sinkholes over the weekend, cutting off water supplies to thousands of residents in the area Saturday night and yesterday.

title: Barbara Lippert Is Wed
description: Barbara Elyse Lippert, a columnist for Adweek and weekly advertising commentator on the CBS Morning News, was married yesterday to Michael David Singer, a painter. Rabbi Elyse Frishman officiated at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan. Mrs. Singer, a cum laude graduate of Mount Holyoke College, is a daughter of Lenore Lippert of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Michael Lippert. Mr. Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Singer of Dallas, graduated from the Parsons School of Design

title: Picture That
description: Washington sidewalk photographers have done well for several years now by posing tourists alongside a lifesize cardboard cutout of President Reagan or sometimes both the President and Nancy Reagan. Today, a new magazine, Fed Fortnightly, is celebrating its coming-out with a reception at The Palm, and the most prominent figure there, in all probability, will be a 6-foot, 8-inch cardboard figure of the principal protagonist of the magazine's area of interest, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Volcker has been invited to the party and may thus be able to pose beside himself.

title: Mobile Phone Sale Set
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation said Friday that it would complete the previously announced purchase of a cellular mobile telephone system licensed to serve the Washington-Baltimore market. Southwestern Bell, which already owned most of the Washington-Baltimore system, said it would spend $74.1 million to buy out the minority partners - 20 percent from the Washington Post Company, 14.5 percent from Metrocall Inc. and slightly less than 1 percent from a private investor.

title: METS LOSE
description: The celebrating ended days ago, but the hangover remains. In the post-game rampage that followed the clinching of the division championship by the Mets last week, there was an apparent victim: the pitcher Rick Aguilera, who was knocked to the ground by an exuberant Shea Stadium patron and suffered a severely bruised left shoulder.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 22, 1986: MONDAY American Express General Mills Esterline Corp Primark Corp Federal Mogul TUESDAY Hydraulic Co Public Serv Co Colo Metropolitan Finl Corp Roper Corp Park Electrochemical USAir Group WEDNESDAY EG&G Inc Medtronic Inc Harper & Row Ocean Drill&Exploration House of Fabrics Raytheon Co Hunt Mfg Washington DC Gas Lt Iowa Resources THURSDAY Boston Edison Research-Cottrell Campbell Soup (US) Viacom Intl Combustion Engineering Wyle Labs Commonwealth Energy FRIDAY Burroughs Corp Pacific Telesis Group CP National Ralston Purina Central Hudson G&E Rexham Corp Homestake Mining Sierra Pacific Res Lowe's Cos Southwestern Bell Corp

title: Pavin Wins in Playoff
description: Corey Pavin sank a 10-foot birdie putt on the fourth playoff hole today to defeat Dave Barr of Canada and win the $72,000 first prize in the Greater Milwaukee Open.

title: IMPACT ON JAPANESE IS WIDE; AMERICAN HOPES UNFULFILLED
description: When Japan's central bankers agreed a year ago to join an international effort to bring down the value of the dollar, they hardly dreamed that their efforts would be met with such spectacular results.

title: ON BRIBERY TRIAL'S EVE, YAWNS IN NEW HAVEN
description: Fifteen years ago, when Bobby Seale and other leaders of the Black Panther Party went on trial here for murder, tight security ringed the courthouse, rallies thronged the historic Green and New Haven winced in the glare of a national spotlight.

title: Coseka Oil Write-Down
description: Coseka Resources Ltd. said Friday that it would write down the value of oil and gas assets by about $195 million, after tax, to reflect current energy price levels and an accounting change. A company spokesman said the charge would be taken in the third quarter ended Sept. 30. Coseka calculated the write-down under new oil and gas accounting guidelines from the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, it said.

title: NICARAGUA FAMILY SAGA (CONT.): A WAR, A WEDDING
description: When Claudia Chamorro Barrios is married in Mexico on Tuesday, many members of her illustrious Nicaraguan family will be present to wish her well.

title: New Ted Bates Chief An Acquisition Expert
description: Donald M. Zuckert, the new chairman and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, was deeply involved in the company's acquisition program that helped his predecessor, Robert E. Jacoby, increase billings from about $400 million a year to $3 billion and make Bates worth $450 million to Saatchi & Saatchi of London.

title: THE OPERA: 'BUTTERFLY'
