description: WHAT promised to be a routine ''Madama Butterfly'' at the New York City Opera Saturday afternoon turned into an excellent opportunity for Edith Davis, an impressive young soprano who made her debut as Liu in last year's ''Turandot'' at the house. There are so many nice things to say about Miss Davis one scarcely knows where to begin.

title: CLEMENS GETS 24TH, WINS 7TH STRAIGHT
description: Roger Clemens recorded his seventh consecutive victory, and Dave Sax, Rich Gedman and Dwight Evans hit homers as the Boston Red Sox scored a 3-2 victory today over the Blue Jays.

title: Hesburgh Checks Out After Night in Hospital
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president of the University of Notre Dame, checked himself out of Yale-New Haven Hospital yesterday after fainting Saturday evening and spending the night under observation in the coronary care unit, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Transit Authority Needs More Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEWS OF WEST IN ART
description: ''THE WEST OF THE IMAGINATION'' is, in fact and on television, romantic territory.

title: Trade Deficit Understated
description: The severity of the trade deficit in June and July was understated as a result of a one-time purchase by Japan of nearly $3 billion worth of United States gold, a Congressional committee reported today.

title: Rescuers Fail in 2 Efforts To Free Alaska Porpoises
description: Porpoises trapped in Russell Lake let would-be rescuers herd them toward nets in a shallow cove twice today, but slipped away at the last moment, officials of the rescue effort said.

title: A Travelers Account
description: Another account in almost the same billings area is Travelers Mortgage Services of Cherry Hill, N.J., a subsidiary of the Travelers, which has dropped its account at Grey Advertising. The former agency as Morgan, Cohen & Naish of Philadelphia.

title: LONG TRAIL IS PLANNED IN MISSOURI
description: If Gov. John Ashcroft has his way, and the chances are he will, despite a bit of a ruckus over the matter, Missouri bikers and hikers will soon have one of the country's longest and most historic nature trails.

title: A Shoe Manufacturer Chooses Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day of the West and East Coasts has become the ad agency for the Rockport Company, the Boston manufacturer of walking and casual shoes.

title: EUROPEANS MAY PROP THE DOLLAR
description: The 12 nations of the European Community have agreed to a joint effort, starting Monday, to buttress the value of the dollar against the West German mark, the Reuters news service reported today.

title: PRETORIA TO SEND BLACK POLICE UNIT TO TROUBLE SITES
description: South Africa's national police force is hiring 1,000 blacks and sending them to patrol black townships with guns and full police powers after three weeks of training, according to news reports here today.

title: RAIDERS, AT 0-3, PUZZLED BY POOR START
description: The room had an eerieness about it, an uncomfortable stillness. On so many other Sunday afternoons, the Los Angeles Raiders' dressing quarters in the Coliseum had been a scene of monkey business and mirth. Not today. Today the Raiders' strange odyssey of 1986 continued.

title: Inroads by Women
description: One of the last stubborn centers of resistance to the women's rights movement has been the House of Representatives, run historically by and for men and staffed on the floor almost exclusively by men. The number of women who are House members remains small, 23 out of 435, with material change unlikely in the November elections.

title: Foundation Job for Svahn
description: John A. Svahn, the President's domestic policy adviser, has left the White House for a senior fellowship at the Heritage Foundation.

title: Lucy Commoner Marries a Lawyer
description: Lucy Alison Commoner, the daughter of Gloria Gordon of St. Louis and Dr. Barry Commoner of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Richard Sander Berry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman L. Berry of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Sharon, Conn.

title: Commercial's Target: Fathers on the Run
description: David McCall (mentioned above) is working with Louis McCagg, executive director of Child Find of America, on a public service advertising campaign for the organization, dedicated to locating missing children.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: PRESERVING CHURCHES: A QUANDARY
description: Struggling to keep a rich architectural heritage and an active religious ministry, the Episcopal Church in New York is divided over the city landmarks law. The Episcopal Diocese and St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue are challenging the law itself, while other church leaders are seeking ways to exist within its confines.

title: DOCTORS FORM PANEL ON JEWS IN SOVIET PRISONS
description: A doctor at Northwestern University has formed an international committee of physicians to help monitor the medical condition of Jewish political prisoners in the Soviet Union.

title: PHILADELPHIA EXERTS ITSELF FOR ITS GARMENT INDUSTRY
description: In the Great Court of Drexel University's main building, the dinner-dance tables were set. In an adjacent auditorium, models twirled, whirled and glided their way through a high-spirited show of Philadelphia-born clothing fashions from the 1920's till now, for the enlightenment and pleasure of women in gowns and men in dinner jackets.

title: HOWARD KLEIN TO LEAVE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
description: Howard Klein, who has overseen the arts programs at the Rockefeller Foundation since 1973, has decided to take early retirement and will leave the organization Oct. 1. In his 19 years with the foundation, Mr. Klein, who is 55 years old, is recognized as one of this country's most innovative and influential patrons of the contemporary creative artist.

title: 4 Lebanese, Sought by Paris, Say They Fear Assassination
description: Four Lebanese brothers wanted by France in connection with terrorist bombings in Paris said today that they were keeping a 24-hour vigil at their home here in northern Lebanon because they feared French agents would try to kill them.

title: Topics: Studies in Management; Asleep at the Wheel
description: Rundown buses provide rundown service, and New Yorkers shouldn't tolerate either. Yet a recent survey of the Transit Authority's 20 bus repair garages found that the system's 2,000 mechanics typically start work 17 minutes late and end work 20 minutes early.

title: Wonscription in Drug War
description: In the current campaign to obliterate drug use and commerce, the House has proposed a new crime that the Senate may want to take a second look at. House legislation approved by a 392-to-16 vote last week provides, among a large number of things, that a customs officer making an arrest, search or seizure as part of a drug operation may ''demand the assistance of any person.''

title: CAMPUS AND NATIONAL ISSUE: LIMITS ON FREE SPEECH
description: In his appeal for a new affirmation of freedom of expression on the nation's college campuses, the newly inaugurated Yale University president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., has raised an issue that has begun to attract increased interest across American higher education.

title: BACK IN THE CLUBHOUSE
description: HAVING escaped the good, the bad and the ugly out there in public, the Mets observed the champagne ritual in their clubhouse after clinching their division title Wednesday night.

title: Environmental Group Lauds Cuomo for Help
description: A statewide coalition of environmental groups has praised Governor Cuomo for helping to pass key environmental legislation last session, but called on him to ''intensify his efforts to address the complex environmental issues that New York faces.''

title: U.N. CHIEF SAYS HE MIGHT STEP DOWN AT END OF TERM
description: In the face of the worst financial crisis in the 41-year history of the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar says he is not certain he will seek a second five-year term this fall.

title: Downhome Chili Lovers Under Midtown's Towers
description: It was an unlikely setting for a chili cookoff - amid high-rises and traffic noise - but that did not dampen the boisterous spirits of hundreds of connoisseurs and fans gathered in the yard of Public School 183 on East 67th Street yesterday for the New York State Chili Championship, sponsored by the International Chili Society, a group of chili lovers.

title: NBC DOMINATES EMMY AWARDS
description: ''Cagney & Lacey,'' CBS's series about two tough but sensitive women cops, eclipsed ABC's top-nominated ''Moonlighting,'' winning best drama series, actress and supporting actor tonight at the 38th Emmy Awards.

title: IN SOHO, 2 NEW BOUTIQUES
description: Time was when people went to SoHo for avant-garde clothes and art. Then success struck, forcing many designers and artists into the East Village. In their place came uptown names such as Benetton, Rizzoli and Dianne B. Now Dianne B. has opened another shop in SoHo, and Norma Kamali has brought her individuality to the downtown scene. SoHo is getting to be like Madison Avenue.

title: FOR AGING ANGELS, LITTLE SERENITY AMID SUCCESS
description: IF this were a Gene Autry western from the 1940's, there would be tumbleweed drifting across the California plains, a lonely coyote howling in the distance, the sun beginning to set behind a majestic mountainside. Ten shadowy figures would ride slowly across the giant screen, then fade into the distance. The credits would roll.

title: Uruguay Official Exercises His Diplomatic Skills
description: In the old neighborhood in Montevideo they still remember him as the delivery boy from his parents' grocery store.

title: Overnite's Chairman, 73, Staying On Despite Sale
description: Harwood Cochrane recalls that he started the Overnite Transportation Company in 1935 with two trucks -''one big one and one little one.''

title: Religious Leaders Meet Koch in Antidrug Bid
description: More than 300 religious leaders from throughout the city gathered yesterday afternoon with Mayor Koch and members of the state's Congressional delegation at Gracie Mansion to discuss the role of the clergy in fighting drugs.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: OPERA: 'PECHEURS' CHANGES
description: BIZET'S ''Pecheurs de Perles'' is a work of wildly uneven quality, containing pages that rank among the composer's most noble, and a substantial amount of filler. The New York City Opera's current production has come in for a fair amount of criticism since it was unveiled in 1980, but seems rather appropriate to me, its Maxfield Parrish-like castles and turquoises suiting the gentle, naive Orientalism of the libretto.

title: Opposition From Bankers
description: The House Banking Committee chairman, Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat from Rhode Island, is learning that even after compromise he cannot please everyone.

title: Nancy F. Bookbinder Marries D. D. Nossiter
description: The marriage of Nancy Freda Bookbinder, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence Bookbinder of Burlington, N.J., to Daniel Debs Nossiter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Daniel Nossiter of New York, took place yesterday in Philadelphia. Rabbi David W. Silverman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Zion-Beth Israel.

title: Western Union Satellite
description: Western Union and China have signed a letter of intent for China to launch a Western Union satellite, the official China News Service said.

title: DISCORD OVER DOLLAR
description: A year after Japan, West Germany, Britain and France joined with the United States to lower the value of the dollar, sharp frictions have surfaced.

title: Family Gains $1.65 Million
description: The family of a woman who was trapped in her burning car after a plane rented by the Federal Bureau of Investigation crashed into it, killing all six people aboard the craft, has been awarded $1.65 million from the Federal Government. A Federal district judgeon Friday awarded the 55-year-old woman, Phyllis Neyer, $1.4 million and her husband, Donald, $250,000.

title: COMECON COURTING WESTERN EUROPE
description: A European Community official recently received a telephone call from a Soviet diplomat who wanted to know whether the Common Market would be interested in buying some barley from Moscow. After a few minutes of cordial discussion in Russian, the community official promised to give a formal response as soon as possible.

title: U.N. GUEST: SYMBOL OF THE NEW SPAIN
description: When Juan Carlos de Borbon y Borbon was crowned King of Spain 11 years ago, many Spaniards looked on him as inept. He would would go down in history, they said, as Juan Carlos the Brief.

title: DANCE: CYNTHIA GREGORY AT LEHMAN
description: ''CYNTHIA GREGORY AND COMPANY: THE CELEBRATION TOUR,'' to give its full title, is the latest chamber group headed by a ballet star now willing to embark on the one-night stands that dancers had supposedly once hoped to see banished from the earth.

title: Diana Jane Robinson Weds David S. Plants
description: Diana Jane Robinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Robinson of Stonington, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Sinclair Plants, a son of Marjorie Souders Plants of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Kenneth Jack Plants. The Revs.

title: UNCERTAIN TIME FOR TIGERS' MORRIS
description: JACK MORRIS chose his words as carefully as he would his pitches with the bases loaded and Don Mattingly at bat. For the first time in his career, Morris is wondering whether the uniform hanging in his locker will be the one he wears next season. After nine years with the Tigers, the prospect of becoming a free agent is exciting, but also a bit unsettling.

title: LUCILLE BALL RETURNS IN ABC COMEDY SERIES
description: TWO children are squealing happily that Grandma is coming. The door opens and, as the studio audience cheers warmly, Lucille Ball bursts in, lugging a large plant, its big green leaves smartly setting off the star's bright orange hair. Explaining that the plant is sick, she promptly screws her face into an impersonation of a dreaded spider mite.

title: SHULTZ SEES HOPE IN SOVIET COMMENT ON DANILOFF CASE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was encouraged at a suggestion by the Soviet Foreign Minister that they might be able to resolve at meetings in New York this week the case of the American journalist held in Moscow on espionage charges.

title: WOMEN, MEN AND HUMOR
description: AMONG the panoply of senses -sense of touch, sense of sight, common sense - the sense of humor stands as a distinguishing feature between the sexes: men have one, women don't. Or so the stereotype goes.

title: VICTIM SAFE IN BUNGLED FLORIDA KIDNAP PLOT
description: A 9-year-old girl was kidnapped in an elaborate scheme but was found safe late Saturday in a cardboard box in a wooded area, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said here today.

title: FALCONS TOPPLE COWBOYS
description: Mick Luckhurst kicked an 18-yard field goal with 20 seconds left today to give the Atlanta Falcons a 37-35 victory over the Dallas Cowboys. The triumph was the Falcons' first over the Cowboys since 1976 and their third straight without a loss this season. Dallas is 2-1.

title: Midland-Ross Posts Added by FL Chief
description: Being discharged after a buyout can be the best thing to happen to someone, says Richard W. Vieser, who has been let go in the past because of a buyout and who was responsible for the reduction last week in the corporate staff of the Midland-Ross Corporation in Cleveland.

title: Is There No Respect?
description: The United States Department of Justice over its long history has had a relationship with the Supreme Court of particular respect and confidence. Even in the 1930's, when a conservative majority was striking down New Deal laws, the Justice Department officials who lost those cases would not conceivably have made a personal attack on a justice.

title: JETS AND O'BRIEN OUTDUEL MARINO AND DOLPINS, 51-45
description: The Jets and the Dolphins stretched football to the breaking point today, and when it seemed nothing zanier or more dramatic could happen, it did.

title: Gasoline Prices Down
description: Gasoline prices fell slightly in the last two weeks, reversing an August increase and reflecting the end of the summer driving season, Trilby Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, said today.

title: World Bank Sees Easing of Trade Woes
description: The dollar's decline and hopes that it will lead to a reduction in America's punishing trade deficit may lead to a cooling of protectionist pressures, the World Bank said today.

title: CHEVROLET SPRINT TOPS ECONOMY LIST
description: The Chevrolet Sprint ER still gets the best gasoline mileage of any car on the highway, but it is slightly worse than last year in a market that appears to de-emphasize economy.

title: Out-of-Court Programs Called Success in Study
description: Pilot projects in three cities that direct minor legal disputes to out-of-court arbitration, save taxpayers' money and reduce court caseloads, a Justice Department study reported today.

title: COST OF MAMMOGRAPHY IS A MAJOR DETERRENT
description: She feels perfectly well, she has no evidence of a lump or other changes in the breast and she experiences no discomfort. Why, then, should she spend $100 or more to have a mammogram every year or two after the age of 40 and annually after 50?

title: ACTIVISTS IN POLAND REAFFIRM IDEALS AT A RALLY
description: Forty-five thousand workers from all over Poland gathered at a Roman Catholic shrine here today to join in a reaffirmation of the democratic ideals of the Solidarity labor movement.

title: Yanks Lose, 3-1; Mattingly 2 for 4
description: Today's game between the Tigers and Yankees was not quite as meaningless as it may have first appeared.

title: S.E.C. Gains British Help
description: A major policy thrust of the Securities and Exchange Commission in recent months has been to persuade foreign governments that it is in their best interest to help apprehend those who violate American securities laws and try to hide outside the United States. Cooperative agreements for surveillance and investigation have been reached with Switzerland, Japan and the Cayman Islands.

title: Administration to Drop Rule Requiring Advice on Abortion
description: The Reagan Administration is dropping a requirement that federally financed family planning clinics list abortion among the options for dealing with an unintended pregnancy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adirondack Chair Co., a supplier and distributor of institutional furniture, has elected Arnold Siegel president and chief executive officer.

title: Market Place; A Long-Term Focus Is Urged
description: UNDAUNTED by the 120.78-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average on Sept. 11 and 12, investment professionals have begun reassuring small investors that they can still make money in the stock market.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1986
description: International

title: SEAHAWKS GO TO 3-0 BY BEATING PATRIOTS
description: Dave Krieg's 67-yard touchdown pass to Ray Butler with 1 minute 14 seconds to play capped a 17-point explosion in the final three minutes and gave the unbeaten Seattle Seahawks a 38-31 victory over the New England Patriots today.

title: Principals Can Learn, but Must Be Able to Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Choir in Concert
description: The Vatican's Sistine Chapel Choir will make its first visit to the United States this month, to perform in 17 cities before appearing at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 6.

title: AFTER 6 YEARS, IRAN-IRAQ WAR IS DEADLOCKED AS TACTICS SHIFT
description: When illumination flares begin popping and shells falling along the 733-mile border Monday morning, Iraq and Iran will have been at war for six years.

title: OUTDOORS: CHARTING A SAFE COURSE
description: BOATING has been compared to driving on the world's biggest and busiest parking lot, with everyone heading in a different direction at a different speed. No one is licensed, no one has brakes, and if you run out of gas, you can't walk home.

title: One-Hitter In Debut
description: Jimmy Jones pitched a one-hitter in his major-league debut today as the San Diego Padres beat the Houston Astros, 5-0.

title: Not Quite Bankrupt
description: The three Hunt brothers of Dallas have suffered another legal defeat in the attempt to save Placid Oil, the cornerstone of their empire, and been forced to transfer their bankruptcy court filings from New Orleans to Dallas. But even defeat buys delay, and time for oil price rises to lift the Hunts' oil businesses off the rocks.

title: DEBATE BREWS ON BELL UNIT RESTRICTIONS
description: Industry discord and Congressional ambivalence have combined to weaken the prospects of Congress enacting legislation in the near future that could expand competition in the telecommunications industry, according to lawmakers and industry and legislative analysts. The legislation is aimed at ending court-imposed restrictions on the business activities of the seven regional Bell Telephone holding companies.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF DOCUMENT AT STOCKHOLM MEETING ON SECURITY
description: Following are key sections of the final document of the Stockholm Conference on Confidence- and Security-Building Measures and Disarmament in Europe. I. Prior Notification

title: Judge Offers Amnesty To Hormel Strikers
description: A judge has offered to drop criminal charges against more than 200 meatpackers arrested in the bitter yearlong labor dispute at Geo. A. Hormel & Company in return for community service.

title: Thank You, Ken O'Brien
description: WALKING to the sideline with only 4 minutes 8 seconds remaining, Wesley Walker thought he had lost the game.

title: GREEN'S POSITIONS: VARIATIONS ON A LIBERAL THEME
description: Mark Green, the Democratic nominee for the Senate, supports continued United States adherence to the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty, increased Federal support of public housing, cuts in defense spending and broader Federal involvement in cleaning up hazardous wastes.

title: CAMPUSES PRESS EFFORTS ON AWARENESS OF AIDS
description: College administrators on campuses around the country this autumn are gearing up special programs aimed at educating their students about the risks from AIDS and how to reduce them. But they say the process is painfully slow.

title: No, Thanks
description: The executive board of the International Olympic Committee last week ratified a proposal by its eligibility commission that would throw open the Games' hockey competition to all professionals. But even if the I.O.C.'s full membership gives final approval at its meeting next month, the change is unlikely to have much impact at Calgary little more than a year from now.

title: South Assesses Damage From Summer Drought
description: Increased rainfall since early August has raised crop yields and cut drought damage in the Southeast, but officials with the United States Department of Agriculture say losses may still surpass $1 billion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STILLS The 300 photographs of the 1986 Scholastic/Kodak Photography Awards National Exhibition, on view through Sept. 30 in the Atrium at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street, frequently tell us as much about the generational changes in youngsters' attitudes as any individual picture can.

title: Slaughtering Whales for 'Science'
description: Great progress has been made in protecting whales, but more needs to be done. Iceland and South Korea continue to slaughter several species by pretending to do research. Others will follow their example if not stopped.

title: GLOBAL STUDY OF CHANGES IN EARTH'S LIVABILITY SET
description: The world's leading scientific academies have approved a global effort to learn what changes in the habitability of the earth are likely in coming decades.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FUMBLE: Bear Bryant, Wally Butts, and the Great College Football Scandal. By James Kirby. Illustrated. 248 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95. IT still seems a little crazy, at least to someone old enough to recall the incident, which occurred nearly a quarter of a century ago. As Prof. James Kirby reconstructs it in his lucid and absorbing ''Fumble: Bear Bryant, Wally Butts, and the Great College Football Scandal'': on the morning of Thursday, Sept. 13, 1962, an Atlanta businessman named George Burnett tried to telephone one of his partners. Through some electronic mix-up, he suddenly found himself eavesdropping on a conversation between Paul (Bear) Bryant and Wally Butts, respectively the University of Alabama football coach and the athletic director at the University of Georgia.

title: Ms. Schiffman Is the Bride Of Gary R. Cohen on L.I.
description: Barbara Schiffman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schiffman of Syosset, L.I., and Gary Ronald Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry L. Cohen of Tenafly, N.J., were married yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Myron Fenster.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Chief Unsure of Future Javier Perez de Cuellar is unsure about a second term, saying he sees no reason ''why I should preside over'' the U.N.'s collapse.

title: If Family Farms Are to Survive
description: Thoughout America's heartland, another bumper harvest aggravates the severity of the Reagan farm crisis years and underscores the need for the Administration to end its ''free market'' agricultural policy.

title: Barbara Cohen Marries
description: Barbara Nancy Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Cohen of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Louis Michael Aronica, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Aronica of East Northport, L.I. Rabbi Emily Korzenik officiated at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. The bride, a cum laude graduate of Smith College, is the production manager of book design at Bantam Books. Mr. Aronica, a summa cum laude graduate of Dowling College, is the publishing director of Spectra Books, an imprint he established at Bantam.

title: ON BENCHES IN YONKERS, FRIENDSHIP
description: The apartment complex, two six-story brick buildings on a cliff overlooking Central Park Avenue, is called Jeffrey Park. But here, on the urban edge of suburbia, there is no park, only a small swimming pool and, practically unnoticed by all but the regulars, the benches.

title: JUDGE GIVEN SENATE PANEL DEFENSE IN OLD WEST STYLE
description: With the best wishes of Frank Sinatra, who contributed to his legal defense, Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne is finishing with a frontier flourish another effort in his struggle against Federal law officials.

title: ON PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE, A RESTORATION WITH WIT
description: Most restorations of venerable buildings fall into one of two categories: They are either attempts to recreate as faithfully as possible what once was, or they are inventive interpretations that use the original architecture as a jumping-off point.

title: McCaffrey & McCall's Job Change
description: BRUCE McCALL, one of the Canadian McCalls, has been named executive vice president and creative director of McCaffrey & McCall, a distinguished but not gigantic New York advertising agency owned by Saatchi & Saatchi of London.

title: Family Musical 'Narnia' Will Have 2-Week Run
description: Four precocious schoolchildren, several mythical creatures, witches and a heroic lion are the characters caught up in a struggle between good and evil in the musical ''Narnia,'' a work for family audiences that will have a two-week engagement at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, from Sept. 29 through Oct. 11.

title: Warning Is Issued On French Hostages
description: An Iraqi opposition group said today that French hostages in Lebanon would suffer if two Iraqis deported from France in February were not allowed to return to Paris soon.

title: SURPRISES ARE FOUND IN TAX BILL
description: Tax accountants and lawyers today found a number of surprises embedded in the final version of the tax revision bill, which comes up for a vote this week in the House, including a smaller standard deduction for next year than originally announced.

title: ISRAEL SAYS IRANIANS TRAIN GUERILLAS IN LEBANON
description: Iranian troops in the central Lebanese town of Baalbek have been training Shiite guerrillas to undertake a systematic and semi-conventional war against the Israeli-backed militia known as the South Lebanon Army, Israeli military sources said today.

title: Mets Set Ticket Plan
description: The Mets announced yesterday that a limited number of tickets for the coming National League playoff would be made available for public sale beginning next Sunday through Teletron, the Ticketron telephone ordering service.

title: Shasta Names Bloom
description: The Bloom Agency of Dallas and New York has become the agency for Shasta Beverages, a division of the National Beverage Company.

title: McEnroe Defeats Edberg in Final
description: Playing almost flawlessly, John McEnroe swept past top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3, today in the final of the $315,000 Volvo tournament.

title: Chief Retiring At Robertson
description: James L. Davis, the 59-year-old president and chief executive officer of the H. H. Robertson Company, has elected to take early retirement, effective immediately. Robert Lauterbach, 68, a

title: Venezuela Debt Proposal
description: Jorge Marcano, Venezuela's Public Finance Director, has returned to Caracas from New York, where he proposed to creditors a new repayment schedule for $21.2 billion of foreign debt.

title: New York Should Save St. Paul and St. Andrew
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA HAD SOLUTION TO KEY FLAW IN ROCKET WHEN SHUTTLE EXPLODED
description: The key solution proposed by the space agency to the problem that caused the Challenger explosion was devised years before the disaster and was being systematically applied to the entire space shuttle fleet, interviews, documents and testimony show.

title: Lorrie Beth Panzer Weds
description: Lorrie Beth Panzer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Panzer of Millburn, N.J., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Rudin, the son of Claire Rudin of Englewood, N.J., and Martin Rudin of North Miami, Fla. Rabbi Victor Mirelaman performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Israel. The bride is manager of corporate compensation for American Express in New York. Mr. Rudin is a political reporter and assistant to the political director of ABC News in Washington.

title: Amy Lynn Benenson Is Married to Peter Lynfield
description: Amy Lynn Benenson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Osler Benenson of Flushing, Queens, and Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Julian Sidney Lynfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Geoffrey Lynfield of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at the Benenson home in Weston.

title: Carbide India Official Resigns
description: Keshub Mahindra, a prominent Indian industrialist, resigned Friday as chairman of Union Carbide India Ltd., which faces a multimillion-dollar lawsuit for the 1984 Bhopal gas leak that killed more than 2,000 people.

title: 'TOGETHER WE STAND' AND 'ALF'
description: IN a television world where, for the moment, ''The Cosby Show'' solidly tops the ratings, the rush to churn out reasonable facsimiles is almost delightfully shameless. It's the season of family sitcoms, featuring hordes of adorable little ones. One of the better, simply because it's kind of cute and a bit offbeat, is ''ALF,'' making its debut on NBC at 8 this evening. One of the more exasperating, because it is such an obvious carbon copy of the Cosby formula, is ''Together We Stand,'' which is having a premiere on CBS tonight at 8:30 before eventually settling into its regular period of Wednesdays at 8.

title: GIANTS STOP RAIDERS
description: Good football teams usually find a way to win. The Giants found a way today -much skill, much determination and a little luck - and scored a significant 14-9 victory over the Raiders.

title: EASING ADMISSION TO CAREER SCHOOLS
description: Over the past decade, eight career-oriented New York City high schools and about 100 career programs at 52 other high schools have flourished as popular places of learning. Alongside the career schools and programs, another set of schools that tested and interviewed students before admitting them also gained reputations for achieving academic goals.

title: Why U.S. Textile Industry May Go the Way of Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST-WEST ACCORD REACHED ON A PLAN TO CUT RISK OF WAR
description: Negotiators from NATO and the Warsaw Pact finally agreed today on a major new security package designed to lessen the risk of war in Europe.

title: NAKASONE IS CONTRITE ON VISIT TO SOUTH KOREA
description: This was a weekend of rare contrition and humility for the normally self-assured Prime Minister of Japan, Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: MUSIC: 'QUEENIE PIE,' AN ELLINGTON PREMIERE
description: Duke Ellington worked on his musical ''Queenie Pie'' up to the time of his death in 1974, but he did not finish it. And since it was announced that a completed version would have its world premiere at the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia this month, Ellington admirers have been wondering: would the team of specialists assembled to complete the work and bring it to the stage be able to put together a substantial and coherent evening from the materials at its disposal? And would it be a work worthy of Duke Ellington's name and reputation?

title: Mack Truck Staff Trims
description: Mack Trucks Inc., the No. 2 maker of heavy-duty trucks, said Friday that 700 white-collar employees have agreed to take early retirement under an offer made by the company as part of a cost-cutting plan. Mack said it hopes to save more than $20 million this year through layoffs and early retirements.

title: U.S. IS APPLYING PRESSURE, BUT EUROPEANS STELL BALKING
description: A year after Britain, France and West Germany joined with Japan to help the United States devalue the dollar to improve its trade performance, America's persistent payments deficit is again souring relations between Washington and its principal European allies.

title: RANGERS AND FLYERS SLUG IT OUT AGAIN
description: Six minutes 56 seconds after the Flyers and the Rangers began their exhibition season this evening, Tony Feltrin punched Daryl Stanley. Stanley punched Feltrin. Don Maloney and Rick Tocchet punched each other. Lucien DeBlois and Glen Seabrooke wrestled.

title: Debra Ann Boulanger Weds Neal Goldsmith
description: The marriage of Debra Ann Boulanger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Boulanger of Warren, N.J., to Neal Marshall Goldsmith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Goldsmith of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., took place yesterday in Stamford, Conn. Justice of the Peace Marie K. Patterson performed the ceremony at the Inn at Mill River.

title: Latins May Dig In Heels
description: THE annual conclave of the International Monetary Fund and its sister institution, the World Bank, begins late this week, and it looks as if the hard-pressed Latin debtors are preparing to give their creditors in the industrial world fresh earfuls of sobering news.

title: Fellow Citizens of the World:
description: The following speech draft was filched from a White House burnbag; it will not be delivered by President Reagan today in his welcome to the U.N. delegates. My fellow citizens of the world: We gather today at what many of us thought would be the opening of the Third Era of Detente. Instead, in response to the prospect of a visit to Moscow by the leader of China, the Soviet Union has placed world Communist unity ahead of superpower agreement and has turned 1986 into ''The Year of Reciprocity.''

title: Trains Collide in Nebraska
description: Two Burlington Northern freight trains collided Saturday and burst into flames, but the eight crewmen escaped injury by jumping to safety moments before impact, authorities said. The impact demolished the engines, a sand car and a freight car, and spewed diesel fuel into a nearby creek, according to Doug Wells, the district fire chief. Railroad representatives said damage could run as high as $4 million.

title: Founder of Jackson Life Calls Deal a Compliment
description: After World War II, Athanase (Tony) Pasant married his high school sweetheart, enrolled at Michigan State University and lived in a 14-foot house trailer. After Army service in the South Pacific, where he contracted malaria, he took a part-time job selling insurance.

title: CIVILIANS FERRY NAVY ATOM ARMS
description: At least two cargo ships sailed by civilian crews are used by the Navy to transport nuclear missiles across the Atlantic, according to public documents and various sources.

title: BEHIND-THE-SCENES RACE FOR SPEAKER IN ALBANY
description: One of the state's most important political contests, whose outcome will touch the lives of all New Yorkers, will be decided soon not by the voters but by politicians meeting in a closed room.

title: AUSTIN STRUGGLING TO REMAIN AFLOAT AS TEXAS ECONOMY SINKS
description: In the boom years, John Lloyd's smooth good looks, easy charm and penchant for pulling off big deals helped make him one of a handful of young real estate developers here who became local celebrities.

title: Other Markets, Steeped in Tradition, Face Challenges
description: For centuries, London has also been the home of several other international markets, including ship charters, insurance, gold bullion, diamonds and metals. At first glance, these traditional markets, many of which had their beginings in 17th century coffee houses, would seem exempt from the tumult now shaking London securities markets.

title: Ellen J. Fischer Is Wed To Samuel Dawidowicz
description: The marriage of Ellen Jane Fischer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harris E. Fischer of New York, to Samuel Dawidowicz took place yesterday at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., where Rabbi Haskell Lookstein performed the ceremony.

title: PATENT OFFICE AUTOMATION TEST
description: With a bevy of critics looking on, a controversial automation project at the Patent and Trademark Office will get its first test starting Oct. 1.

title: Another Bank In Texas Fails
description: The Texas Bank and Trust in Lubbock was closed Friday by the state banking commissioner, the 18th Texas bank and the 102d bank nationally to fail this year.

title: Trust Consumers to Shop for Credit
description: The director of New York State's Consumer Protection Board, Richard Kessel, thinks credit card interest rates are a rip-off and vows to sponsor re-regulation next year unless rates come down. Similar rumblings can be heard elsewhere, including in Congress. Mr. Kessel may have a point. Other borrowing rates have fallen sharply while most credit card interest has barely budged. But consumer savvy is a far more attractive remedy than regulation.

title: UNDERDOG WINS HAWAII DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY
description: Lieut. Gov. John Waihee's upset victory in the Democratic primary for the governorship keeps leadership of the party in the Democratic faction that has controlled Hawaii since 1962.

title: Judge Kaufman Celebrates 25 Years of Appeals
description: In June 1961, Judge Learned Hand, a retired chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, wrote to President John F. Kennedy, urging him to name Federal District Court Judge Irving R. Kaufman to one of three openings on the Second Circuit bench. ''He is a man of most exceptional capacity,'' Judge Hand told the President.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of the Rush Dance company in Weekend on Friday misstated the name of the designer responsible for the slides in ''Popular Science.'' He is Bruce Morozko.

title: WASHINGTON SURPRISES AGAIN
description: Brigham Young has been posting such big scores during the last decade with its excellent passers that it came as something of a shock to the Cougars and their fans Saturday when Washington trounced B.Y.U., 52-21, in Seattle.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's remarkable how much NASA knew and how little they did about it.

title: LONDON RECLAIMS A HERITAGE
description: West Germany's Deutsche Bank has moved the base of its international bond business here because ''it's the crossroads of global finance,'' said Ronald Lemke, director of the bank's capital markets group.

title: Who's He Doing It To?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chalek Name Returns As a New Shop Opens
description: Chalek & Dreyer was long a fixture on the New York ad agency scene until it was sold to the Creamer agency more than five years ago.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What was Bob Lemon's record as manager of the Yankees in 1978 when they overtook the Boston Red Sox and won the division title in a playoff game? How does that winning percentage compare with the best ever by a manager for one season?

title: JAMAICAN LEADER, A U.S. ALLY, HARD-PRESSED BY LEFTIST FOE
description: President Reagan's closest ally in the Caribbean, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga of Jamaica, is in serious political trouble and an old rival, who has embraced Cuba and criticized United States policy in Central America, is striving to replace him.

title: Lessons on Terrorism
description: The degree of success individual European nations have had in fighting terrorism has been recognized for some time by their leaders as having serious economic and political consequences in the United States, and they are beginning to send emissaries to Washington to explain to the American public, rather than merely the State Department, how they have succeeded and the problems posed by their failures.

title: DRUG PLAY TO REFLECT A NEW ERA
description: In 1968, when heroin was New York's menace of the moment and cocaine a little-known plaything for the rich, a group of former drug addicts re-enacted their histories in an Off Broadway play called ''The Concept.'' None were professional actors; all were residents of the Daytop Village rehabilitation program.

title: Mexico Is Protesting Article on Drug Traffic
description: The Mexican Embassy has made public a formal diplomatic protest to be delivered to the United States Government this week over a newspaper article that linked Mexico's Defense Minister to drug trafficking.

title: FED IS EXPECTED TO HOLD ITS COURSE
description: Federal Reserve Board officials in charge of setting monetary policy are widely expected to vote for no change in policy and stable short-term interest rates at tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, many analysts said.

title: 383 Madison Is the Wrong Address
description: Kohn Pedersen Fox, architects, have designed a beautiful building for 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. A partnership including the First Boston Corporation wants to build it. Its 1.4 million square feet of floor space would provide jobs for about 5,600, with underground access to Grand Central Terminal. Its owners would pay about $16.5 million a year in property tax. There's only one thing wrong with it. It's far too big for its site.

title: THE OTHER SHOE DROPS
description: When you push Senator Jesse Helms, he pushes back.

title: Dutch Demonstrate Over NATO Warships
description: About 1,000 demonstrators daubed cars and buildings with paint today as they marched to Amsterdam harbor to protest the presence of 22 NATO warships, witnesses said.

title: LAWYERS, CITING FINANCIAL LOSSES, SHUN DEATH ROW APPEALS
description: As the pace of executions in the United States quickens, death row inmates across the country are finding it harder and harder to obtain lawyers willing to handle their final appeals.

title: PIANO: HAMMOND IN RECITAL
description: GARY HAMMOND'S piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Saturday night was the work of a secure technique, an ear for pleasing yet clearly defined sound and a lot of intelligent thought. The last attribute worked both for and against him.

title: Letter of the Law
description: Sidney Prince was the kind of student that high school principals dream about, especially those who double as football coach. A crack linebacker, Prince was also a top scholar, one whose 3.4 grade point average was good enough to make him the salutatorian in a class of 28 seniors at Fox High School in rural Oklahoma last spring.

title: New Ways of Seeing At First Vision Expo
description: What do Sophia Loren and Martina Navratilova have in common with Vice President Bush, Governor Cuomo, Lee Iacocca, Elton John, Woody Allen, Sammy Davis Jr., Liz Claiborne, Gloria Steinem and Diane Keaton?

title: Bank Inquiry By Argentina
description: Argentina's central bank began an internal investigation Friday into the swindling of $110 million in official funds by the country's main cooperative bank, central bank sources said.

title: TRAIN TUNNEL FIRE DELAYS THOUSANDS
description: A smoky fire in a railroad control room beneath Park Avenue last night disrupted train service from Grand Central Terminal and delayed thousands of passengers heading home after a day in Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: ESTES TAKES ON CHALLENGE OF WOTAN WITH VERVE
description: Near the beginning of the final act of Richard Wagner's ''Walkure,'' opening tonight in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera, Simon Estes is at his most majestic. He appears on stage, a brooding, commanding figure robed in greenish-gray folds of leather and faux-metal armor as the angry, vengeful god Wotan, who, with a voice that rumbles like thunder, has come to punish his daughter Brunnhilde.

title: POPULAR COOKBOOK CELEBRATES DOWN-HOME FARE
description: The way to cook Aunt Rosie Deaton's All-American Slum-Gullion, according to the most surprising cookbook to come along in a month of Sundays, is to ''Simmer til you can't stand it any more, then take it off the fire and dive in.''

title: Claudia Rabin Is Bride Of Dr. Mark Manning
description: The marriage of Claudia Lynn Rabin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rabin of Valley Stream, L.I., and Dr. Mark Royce Manning, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jasper I. Manning of Brooklyn, took place yesterday. Rabbi Jacob I. Hack officiated at the Homowack Resort in Spring Glen, N.Y.

title: Jet Pass Defenders Have No Easy Day
description: Some homecoming. Jerry Holmes sat dejected, as if his Jets had lost to the Dolphins today. Instead, they had won a spectacular 51-45 victory. But Holmes, in his first start since he left the Jets after the 1983 season for the United States Football League, could not forget the passes that Dan Marino threw.

title: Ricoh Appoints Head Of Its 2 U.S. Divisions
description: Ricoh Company Ltd., the Japanese automated office machine manufacturer, yesterday named Keiji Endoh chairman of its American subsidiaries, the Ricoh Corporation and Ricoh Electronics Inc.

title: Nabisco Brands Shifts Top-Level Executives
description: Nabisco Brands Inc., a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., announced yesterday that it had named a new president and chief operating officer, Charles J. Chapman, who has been president of Nabisco Brands U.S.A.

title: Philadelphia Gas Bonds Are Priced
description: An $86 million issue of Philadelphia gas works revenue bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with yields ranging from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 6.80 percent in 1986 and 7.25 percent in 2001 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THE OTHER QUARTERBACK WINS
description: Ken O'Brien may be the best unknown quarterback in pro football - smart, accurate, plodding.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-After a gain of $321,000 for the quarter and a loss of $308,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,536,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $245,000 for the quarter and $1,214,000 for the 6 months. All shares outstanding and share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective for shareholders of record on Aug. 1, 1986. Results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the department stores segment which was sold during the 13 weeks ended Aug. 2, 1986. The periods ended Aug. 3, 1985 include a pre-tax gain on the sale of surplus real estate of $1,200, or 2 cents a share, after taxes.

title: TROPICAL WEATHER MAY INFLUENCE ICEBERG BEHAVIOR
description: WHILE daily predictions of iceberg conditions have been of vital concern to ships ever since the Titanic hit one and sank off Newfoundland in 1912, the offshore-oil industry is seeking seasonal forecasts to help plan activity on Grand Banks.

title: FRIENDS AND DAUGHTER PAY TRIBUTE TO MINNELI
description: There is a line in Vincente Minnelli's movie ''Lust for Life'' in which Vincent van Gogh (Kirk Douglas) chastises Paul Gauguin (Anthony Quinn) about the way he views art. ''You look too fast,'' van Gogh says. At a tribute yesterday to Mr. Minnelli, who died July 25 at the age of 83, Martin Scorsese, the film director, recalled the comment.

title: CHURCH COUNCIL SHUNS JERSEY HOTEL WITH SOUTH AFRICA LINKS
description: The National Council of Churches has canceled reservations for 300 rooms at the Hyatt Regency in New Brunswick, N.J., and moved its fall governing-board meeting to Chicago because of the New Jersey hotel's ties to South Africa.

title: AQUINO REBUKES U.N., SAYING IT FAILED THE FILIPINOS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino, delivering her first speech at the United Nations on the same podium where Imelda Marcos stood a year ago, criticized the organization today for not supporting the Filipino struggle to oust Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Players Honored
description: Kent Tekulve, the Philadelphia Phillies' reliever, and Vince Coleman, the St. Louis Cardinals' outfielder, have been named the National League players of the week for Sept. 15-21.

title: RADICALLY NEW TELESCOPE HERALDS GREAT SHARPNESS
description: TWO giant concrete spheres on railroad tracks, open to the sky to collect starlight in two mirrors more than 40 feet apart, forms the heart of an unconventional observatory that is overcoming longstanding limits on the sharpness of telescope images.

title: Pope to Visit Asian Nations
description: Pope John Paul II will visit six countries in Asia and Oceania on his 32d overseas tour, his longest so far, which begins Nov. 18, Vatican officials said today. The Pope will visit Bangladesh, Singapore, Fiji, New Zealand, Australia and the Seychelles during the trip, returning to Rome on Dec. 1.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
ISRAEL TELLS U.N. IT WON'T QUIT SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israel told the Security Council today that it would not dismantle its ''security zone'' inside Lebanon as demanded by the United Nations.

title: Ad Campaign Begun By Allied-Signal
description: Allied-Signal Inc., the result of the merger of the Allied Corporation and the Signal Companies and their acquisition of Bendix, today breaks its first corporate advertising campaign in about a year. Its primary raison d'etre is to let the financial community know just what Allied-Signal is and just what it does.

title: China's Hazy Reform
description: The Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee meeting this week has been prepared to mark a new step in the process of fundamental but carefully controlled reform.

title: REPORT SAYS MALPRACTICE INSURANCE IS A SMALL PART OF MEDICAL COSTS
description: While the cost of medical malpractice insurance for hospitals and doctors is increasing at a rapid rate, it still represents a relatively small part of the cost of operating hospitals or doctors' offices, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Why We Should Keep Life Tenure for Federal Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE BACKS WIDER PROTECTION FOR WHISTLE BLOWERS IN CIVIL SERVICE
description: The House of Representatives voted unanimously today to give added protection to Federal employees who ''blow the whistle'' on mismanagement or corruption in their agencies.

title: Talking Business with Joe C. Morris of the Savings Industry; Thrift Units: A Diagnosis
description: THE savings industry is in an upheaval again.

title: NEW EAST-WEST ARMS PARLEY IS OPENING TODAY IN VIENNA
description: Western diplomats said here today that they intended to use a new conference opening Tuesday in Vienna to continue to press the Warsaw Pact for information about its force deployments in Europe.

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Robertshaw Controls Company, which makes residential and commercial thermostats, home appliance valves and other electrical equipment, agreed to be acquired by Siebe P.L.C. of Britain yesterday for $85 a share in cash, or about $468.8 million.

title: RECOLLECTIONS: NORELL IN KANSAS CITY...
description: When the gallery of art at the University of Missouri-Kansas City decided to open its 10th anniversary year with an exhibition of clothes by Norman Norell, it sent ripples of excitement through the fashion community.

title: LOS ANGELES VOTING PROPOSAL PUTS END TO FEDERAL BIAS SUIT
description: After three tries by the City Council here to devise a politically acceptable redistricting solution, a Federal judge today accepted the latest plan and dismissed a Justice Department lawsuit accusing the city of depriving Hispanic residents of representation.

title: Blowing Hot and Cold With Moscow; First, Free Daniloff and Remove the Chill
description: President Reagan put first things first in his tough but highly constructive message to the Soviet leaders yesterday, setting relations in a perspective that most Americans can support. He pressed for the speedy release of Nicholas Daniloff while holding open the door for a step-by-step return to nuclear arms control.

title: I.M.F. PARLEY TO TEST BAKER'S COORDINATION POLICY
description: The summerlong drama over interest rates, the dollar and the course of the world economy shifts this week to Washington, where promises that countries would devise a better way to run the economy are now in doubt.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,675,000 for the quarter and $3,632,000 for the 9 months.

title: Robertson, Citing Demands Of Politics, Quits as TV Host
description: The television evangelist Pat Robertson said today that he would no longer be host of ''The 700 Club'' because of the demands of his political travels.

title: GREEN WILL VOTE AGAINST THE BILL TO REVISE TAXES
description: Representative Bill Green of Manhattan announced yesterday that he would vote against the Federal tax overhaul bill, which he called ''harmful to New Yorkers and bad for the city.''

title: U.S. JOURNALISTIC GROUPS SEEK TALKS ON DANILOFF
description: Leaders of organizations representing newspapers, magazines and broadcasting announced today that they wanted to go to Moscow to seek the release of an American journalist charged with espionage.

title: D'Agostino Names Chief
description: D'Agostino Supermarkets Inc. said yesterday that it had named Nicholas D'Agostino Jr., chairman and chief executive. Mr. D'Agostino, 47 years old, a son of the founder, has served eight years as president.

title: MATTINGLY AT .351
description: At this time of year, Willie Randolph was saying after the Yankees defeated the Baltimore Orioles by 4-2 tonight, ''it helps to have something to motivate you.''

title: House Panel Approves A New Fee on Imports
description: The House tax panel agreed today on $3.6 billion more in revenue-raising proposals, including a fee on imported goods, that will become part of a $15.5 billion package of deficit-cutting measures the full House of Representatives is due to consider later this week.

title: Japan's Car Output Off
description: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses declined in August for the first time in three months, dropping 3.1 percent from a year earlier, to 772,128 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHALING DOWNTOWN Back in 1696, when New Yorkers wanted to build the church that would become Trinity, at Wall Street and Broadway, the problem was one that continues to beset the most modern of builders today: money. The authorities of the British colony gave the congregation a patent that would give them revenue from all whales that drifted ashore in the colony.

title: Overt Praise for Spies
description: Spies don't usually get the credit due them, Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern observed yesterday at ceremonies marking the 210th anniversary of the execution of Nathan Hale.

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOR POLICE, A QUIET DAY ON DUTY AT THE U.N.
description: Frankly, the police officers said, President Reagan's visit to the United Nations was downright boring - if pleasantly so.

title: Rosy Outlook
description: Gerome Singleterry and Lynn Robinson were in sad shape at this time last year. Singleterry, a commercial painter, had run out of houses to paint in his home town of Calera, Ala., and was praying for help. Robinson, who lives in nearby Clanton, was trying to make a living as a traveling salesman but was so strapped for money he was sleeping in his beat-up Chevette (mileage: 200,000).

title: FREDA CORP reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
Service for Dr. Rainwater
description: A memorial service for Dr. James Rainwater, the Michael I. Pupin Professor Emeritus of Physics at Columbia University, who died May 31 at the age of 68, will be held at 4 P.M. today in St. Paul's Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 117th Street. Three Nobel laureates are scheduled to speak: Val L. Fitch, a Columbia graduate who was a co-winner of the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1980; Dr. T. D. Lee, University Professor, who received the physics prize in 1957, and Dr. I. I. Rabi, University Professor Emeritus, who won the 1944 physics prize.

title: HOW THE NEW ADMIRAL AT THE WHITE HOUSE FARES
description: Most weekdays at 8 A.M., Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, leads a senior staff meeting in the Roosevelt Room. He sits at one end of the large rectangular mahagony table, and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the national security adviser, sits at the other end. That placement of the 50-year-old admiral, who is also one of the few people permitted to see President Reagan alone, marks him as the second most powerful staff member in the complex at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Allstate Insurance Names Chairman
description: Richard J. Haayen, president and chief operating officer of the Allstate Insurance Company, has been named chairman and chief executive of the company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: RANGERS AND FLYERS CONTINUE BRAWLING
description: It was the same sheepish smile Don Maloney wore a year ago, the same smile he wore a year before that, probably the same smile that many others have been smiling for some time. Fans might not know it, but there are many hockey players out there who are actually embarrassed by all the fighting.

title: 2 SOVIET HIJACKERS ARE SLAIN IN SHOOTOUT
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass said today that two armed drug addicts had tried to hijack an airliner on the ground in the city of Ufa, in the Urals, killing two policemen and two passengers before the hijackers themselves were slain.

title: FRIEDMAN TRIAL OPENS AS JUDGE ADVISES JURORS
description: The Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and four other defendants opened here today with the judge telling potential jurors that there was ''not going to be much dispute that there was corruption in the Parking Violations Bureau.''

title: No Honorable Solution in 1978 Soviet Case of U.S. Businessman; A Detained Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEAKERS AT U.N CITE NEEDS OF THIRD WORLD
description: Peru's Foreign Minister, addressing the opening of the 41st session of the General Assembly, today denounced what he called the ''increasingly technical confrontation'' between the world's powers.

title: ARABS FEARFUL OF A BREAKOUT BY IRAN ARMY
description: Centrist Arab Governments that support Iraq in its war with Iran are becoming increasingly apprehensive about the possibility of a major new Iranian offensive, according to Western and Arab sources in Egypt, Jordan and the Persian Gulf.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury securities fell slightly in quiet trading yesterday, reversing part of the increases that occurred in last week's trading.

title: Mozambique Needs Food to Avert Famine
description: The Government appealed today for urgent food aid to feed nearly four million people, almost a third of this southern African nation's population, who are facing famine.

title: Navratilova Testifies
description: Martina Navratilova testified today that she lost her composure and grabbed a camera from a photographer who took pictures of her after she asked him to stop following a tennis match in September 1982.

title: NASA PRESSING SHUTTLE CHANGE AMID CONCERNS
description: The space agency is moving forward on modifications of the shuttle's booster rockets amid rising concerns that it may be discarding more reliable designs in an effort to save time and hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: DOW SURGES BY 30.80 AS INTEREST RATES DIP
description: With its ''witching hour'' problems over and interest rates dipping a bit, Wall Street yesterday staged its most potent rally in more than two weeks.

title: DOLLAR RISES SHARPLY
description: The stock market and the dollar both had their best day in weeks yesterday.

title: JUDGE WON'T DISMISS CHARGES IN DEATHS AT MOVIE LOCATION
description: A judge today refused to dismiss charges against five movie makers who are accused of involuntary manslaughter for three deaths that occurred during the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone.''

title: To Human Vision, A Stained-Glass Salute
description: It's big and mostly red and has been clearly visible on Fifth Avenue at 40th Street since early summer. But only yesterday did it get official recognition.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: Required Reading
description: Keeping Learning Alive Excerpt from ''Once More, a Plea for History,'' the Alf Landon address by William J. Bennett, Secretary of Education, at the University of Kansas, Sept. 9:

title: Deacons at Michigan Church Vote to End a Ban on Blacks
description: Deacons at one of the state's largest Christian congregations have voted to end a 60-year-old policy of banning blacks from joining their church.

title: DANCE: SPOKE THE HUB
description: THERE was much to attract the eye in the works by Elise Long that were offered Sunday night at the Washington Square Church by Spoke the Hub Dancing, a dance company in residence at the Gowanus Arts Exchange in Brooklyn. Nevertheless, watching these dances resembled paging through a book containing striking illustrations but garbled captions.

title: REACTOR FALLOUT IS SAID TO MATCH PAST WORLD TOTAL
description: The nuclear disaster at Chernobyl emitted as much long-term radiation into the world's air, topsoil and water as all the nuclear tests and bombs ever exploded, according to a new study of the April 26 Soviet accident.

title: WALKER RELIVES PAST SUCCESS
description: Once the most dangerous receiver in the National Football League, Wesley Walker reflected today that it seemed like old times.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Long Island Trust
description: The Bank of New York Company said it had agreed to acquire the Long Island Trust Company for $300 million from Banca Commerciale Italiana.

title: OPEC Called Within Quota
description: OPEC has kept its oil output below the target it set in last month's Geneva agreement, despite apparent cheating by three members, a trade weekly reported today.

title: C.F.L. Injury
description: James Bell, a defensive halfback with the Edmonton Eskimos, has only partial movement in his limbs after suffering a pinched spinal cord in a Canadian Football League game against the British Columbia Lions. Bell, 27, a native of Albuquerque, N.M., was in stable condition in the intensive care ward of the spinal-cord injury unit at a Vancouver hospital. Bell played college football at New Mexico and was with the San Antonio Gunslingers of the United States Football League.

title: Chris-Craft Discloses Stock Plan
description: Chris-Craft Industries announced a recapitalization plan yesterday that would allow it to issue additional common stock with minimal effect on voting control of the company.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: b-After gains of $3,600,000 and $10,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of the Manning Paper Co. division and from the settlement of an insurance claim, and also after charges of $21,300,000 for the quarter and $21,337,000 for the 9 months from the cost of defending against an unsolicited tender offer and negotiating a merger agreement with International Paper Co. c-Net income

title: Careers; Economic Developers In Demand
description: IN a world where managers increasingly want to use letters like M.B.A. or C.P.A. after their names, there's a relatively new designation: C.I.D./C.E.D. It stands for Certified Industrial and Economic Developer.

title: 'CACTUS,' AUSTRALIAN ROMANCE
description: DIALOGUE is to the movie ''Cactus'' what rain is to the plant; seasons pass without much of it. But the director, Paul Cox, who helped write the screenplay, keeps the theater filled with sound. There are the attention-exciting bird calls of the Australian bush, particularly a cry like whiiiiip that whips out to startling effect the first couple of times, and lovely church music for soprano and countertenor. When the dialogue does start up, we miss them. ''It's not goodbye, it's a new kind of hello,'' says the hero to the heroine. Bring on the birds.

title: PARIS REJECTS TERROR ALIBIS ISSUED IN LEBANON
description: The police are still leaning toward a theory that relatives and friends of a suspected terrorist being held in France are responsible for a recent wave of terrorist attacks here.

title: Manuel Too Elusive for Raiders' Hayes
description: A day after helping the Giants to their victory over the Raiders in Los Angeles, Lionel Manuel, the third-year wide receiver, sauntered through the locker room like an explorer just back from a glorious expedition.

title: 1,140 TREASURE HUNTERS SOON TO GET THEIR LOOT
description: On the second floor of an old Navy warehouse here a computer goes about the workaday business of matching precious items of recovered Spanish treasure with more than 1,000 investors who backed Mel Fisher's 16-year search for it.

title: MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Ex-Im Bank Bill Advances
description: The House voted today to extend the authority of the United States Export-Import Bank for six years, but it barred any financing for export sales to Marxist-Leninist countries or to Angola.

title: House Approves Water Bill
description: A bill creating a national program to reduce groundwater contamination was passed by the House on a voice vote today. The bill, sponsored by Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, would require the United States Geological Survey to establish a groundwater research program and information service.

title: Flooding Hits Wisconsin
description: Heavy thunderstorms that caused the deaths of two men in Minnesota moved east into central Wisconsin yesterday and covered some roads with three feet of water. In Fond du Lac County, Wis., flood waters closed State Highway 41 and in Clark County, State Highway 10 was under three feet of water. Many secondary roads in the region were closed or washed out by the rain.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Continental Air Agency
description: It looks as if Continental Airlines is heading for N.W. Ayer, a former Pan Am agency, although the agency would only offer a ''no comment.''

title: Image Bank Research On Photo Transmitting
description: Down at the Image Bank at 111 Fifth Avenue, research is going on that is producing a piece of electronic hardware that will allow art directors to select photographs at their desks. The wedding of videodisk and a computer will put the vast resources of Image Bank at the fingertips of the people who need it most, eliminating the trip to the bank's research facility or the need for the bank to send 35-millimeter transparencies to the art directors by messenger.

title: 2 Connecticut Agencies Planning to Merge
description: There's no reason Connecticut can't share in agency mergermania even though they could hardly be on the same mega scale as the New York joinings.

title: Dime-Wise About Philippine Democracy
description: This year of Gramm-Rudman-Hollings sure isn't the best time to vote for more foreign aid. And yes, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, a Republican, has reason to be annoyed with the Democratic House. Just after hearing President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines last Thursday, the House voted an extra $200 million for her country - what Mr. Dole scorns as a ''$200 million honorarium'' for a speech. He's getting even by sending the matter to die in the Senate Appropriations Committee.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1986
description: Markets

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Respect for human rights is not social work, it is not merely an act of compassion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1986
description: International

title: Books; First Safety Net
description: FDR: THE NEW DEAL YEARS 1933-1937. By Kenneth S. Davis. 756 pages. Random House. $29.95. WITH the third volume of his biography of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, ''FDR: The New Deal Years 1933-1937,'' Kenneth S. Davis arrives at the White House and the period of Roosevelt's great domestic achievements. Taking office at a time of nationwide suffering, the Roosevelt Administration set about the task, energetically if somewhat disjointedly, of aiding farmers and protecting workers, bringing jobs to the young and security to the aged, and establishing controls over financial institutions. In fits and starts, the New Deal began to put together what a half-century later would be accepted even by conservatives as a necessary safety net for the down and out.

title: How About a Capital Accumulation Tax?
description: While the country is focused on tax reform, we might begin thinking about a modest tax on the accumulated capital of the American family that could dramatically reduce the deficit and begin a painless, gradual redistribution of wealth in the United States.

title: Ozone Depletion
description: An analysis of the potential reduction in the ozone layer by manmade gases has found that resulting ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth would cause 1.4 million extra skin cancers in the United States over the next 40 years.

title: NEW EVIDENCE BROUGHT BEFORE IMPEACHMENT PANEL
description: A tax preparer produced a paper late today showing, he said, that Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne disclosed to him the 1980 income that the judge was convicted of willfully concealing.

title: Sculptor in Village Reindicted In the 1985 Death of His Wife
description: Carl Andre, a sculptor, has been reindicted on charges that he murdered his wife, Ana Mendieta, also a sculptor, by having ''forced her'' out of a window of the couple's 34th-story apartment in Greenwich Village a year ago, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: A MATTER OF MIRACLES
description: On a day in which both the Giant and Jet quarterbacks were engaged in miracles of sorts - Phil Simms had thrown a go-ahead touchdown pass that bounced off two defenders and into the arms of Lionel Manuel, and Ken O'Brien had rifled a touchdown pass to give the Jets an overtime victory - the most venerable miracle-worker of all was summoned to do his stuff, too.

title: TREND STUDIED AS FEWER BLACKS CHOOSE SCIENCES
description: The proportion of black college freshmen who choose to major in science decreased to 5 percent from 10 percent in the last 10 years and is continuing to drop, educators say.

title: Platinum in Australia
description: Reserves of platinum have been discovered in Australia's Kakadu National Park. The energy minister, Gareth Evans, said today that geological tests showed a ''significant new platinum province'' exceeding one million ounces.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $768,750 from the writedown of an asset. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $400,000 from the settlement of litigation.

title: RUSSIAN'S TRIAL DATE COULD BE SET TODAY IN A BROOKLYN COURT
description: A trial date for Gennadi F. Zakharov, the Soviet physicist accused of spying while working for the United Nations, is expected to be set today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, officials said yesterday.

title: McCarthy-Muskie Team
description: What may be the first novel ever written by two women who were married to Senators is officially appearing in two weeks. The authors, Abigail McCarthy, former wife of Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota, and Jane Muskie, wife of Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, were talking up their joint effort, ''One Woman Lost,'' at the Women's National Democratic Club yesterday.

title: Heart Victims Do Better on Streets Than at Homes
description: The chances of surviving a heart attack are twice as good if the seizure occurs on the street rather than at home, according to a study of Seattle heart attack victims.

title: BEARS BEAT PACKERS TO GO 3-0
description: Steve McMichael was credited with a safety in the fourth quarter and Kevin Butler kicked three field goals in the game as the Chicago Bears won a hard-fought 25-12 victory tonight over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Nassau, Under Order, Tries to Reduce Inmates
description: Nassau County officials, under a Federal court order to reduce the number of prisoners at the county jail by Wednesday, asked a Federal appeals court today for a 30-day extension to comply.

title: First Chicago Jobs
description: The First Chicago Corporation said it would reduce its work force by 350 employees, or about 2.4 percent, as a result of a previously announced restructuring.

title: Market Place; A Cooling Off For New Issues
description: THE sharp decline in stock prices has cast a decided chill over the formerly ''hot'' new-issue market. As a result, initial public offerings of companies have often been reduced in size or, in numerous cases, even postponed. Price levels commanded by these newcomers, too, have become decidedly more restrained.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been restated for the 15 percent stock dividend distributed in January 1986.

title: DRUG INQUIRY FOCUS IS ON FLIGHT CREWS
description: A Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh is investigating allegations of drug abuse by members of USAir flight crews, including a pilot who nearly died of a cocaine overdose, lawyers said yesterday.

title: MET OPERA'S OPENING COUNTDOWN
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened both a new season and a new ''Ring'' cycle last night. Its performance of ''Die Walkure'' - the second opera of Wagner's great tetralogy, but the first installment in the Met's new version - compelled glittering first-night patrons to take an early buffet instead of the traditional patrons' dinner, to accommodate the unprecedented 6:30 P.M. curtain. More important, the faithfully pictorial settings for the opera, by the same designer-director team that produced the house's romantic ''Tannhauser'' a decade ago, announced the Met's commitment to traditionalist Wagner staging for the forseeable future.

title: BETTER SCHOOLS: ISSUES OF POWER
description: WHEN the nation's governors joined the school reform movement at their annual convention last month, they stepped into a hornet's nest. Like other school reformers, they found that efforts to restructure the schools run into fierce opposition from the existing power structure.

title: Don't Ban Reading Material for New York State Prison Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLEMENT AVERTS KEY TRIAL IN DEATHS TIED TO POLLUTION
description: Eight families, who charged that water pollution by W. R. Grace & Company had resulted in the death from leukemia of five children and an adult, announced a settlement with the company today.

title: ANALYSTS OFFER VIEWS ON WHAT USX IS WORTH
description: The USX Corporation could raise between $25 and $40 a share if it sold its varied holdings individually, Wall Street analysts estimated today.

title: GRAND CENTRAL BLAZE DAMAGE TO MEAN DELAYS TILL WEEKEND
description: Trains going in and out of Grand Central Terminal will have delays at least through Friday because of an electrical fire that destroyed a main switching room and left railroad officials searching for alternative ways to provide service.

title: CHAMBERS GIVES NOT GUILTY PLEA IN PARK SLAYING
description: In a barely audible voice, Robert E. Chambers Jr. pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to a two-count indictment charging him with strangling Jennifer Dawn Levin in Central Park early Aug. 26.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE SPEECH BY KING JUAN CARLOS OF SPAIN
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by King Juan Carlos of Spain to the General Assembly:

title: BEHIND PEOPLE EXPRESS'S FALL: AN OFFBEAT MANAGERIAL STYLE
description: From day one, People Express Inc. was a highly unorthodox outfit. Every new employee had to buy its stock. Every worker was dubbed a ''manager'' and everyone performed a variety of tasks. Even senior executives took their turn as flight attendants.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MINERS' RITES DISRUPTED
description: Hundreds of militant black mine workers, waving sticks and chanting slogans, disrupted a memorial service today for 177 miners who were killed in a South African gold-mine disaster last week.

title: VALENZUELA GETS HIS 20TH FOR FIRST TIME
description: Fernando Valenzuela became the first 20-game winner in the National League, pitching a two-hitter tonight to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 9-2 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: NO SWINE FEVER LINK TO AIDS SEEN
description: Scientists at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta today said that a series of blood tests conducted in July and August indicated that a deadly disease in swine was not related to the spread of AIDS in humans.

title: SUN SETS ON A RINK WITH A HEART
description: Since the early days of Levittown, a boy or girl with nothing definite going on for Friday night has been known to head straight for the roller rink. ''The hottest guys are here,'' said 16-year-old Michelle Miller.
