title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, announced that George T. Farrell, vice chairman of Mellon National Corp. had resigned from its board.

title: Jones F. Devlin Jr., 87, Dies; A Former Shipping Executive
description: Jones F. Devlin Jr., a former executive of the United States Lines, the shipping concern, died Wednesday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: 12 PROTESTERS ARE ARRESTED IN YALE SIT-IN
description: Twelve demonstrators were arrested today after they occupied Yale University's investment office to demand that the school sell all of its holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: INSIDE
description: 6 Die in Soviet Hijacking Two drug addicts tried to hijack a plane in the city of Ufa, killing two policemen and two passengers before being killed themselves.

title: Not Much Will Help In Easing the Delays
description: Metro-North Commuter Railroad passengers traveling in and out of Grand Central Terminal on the Hudson, Harlem or New Haven lines today can expect delays of between 5 and 20 minutes.

title: TRANSFERS PLANNED FOR 2 OFFICIALS NAMED IN PARKING BUREAU REPORT
description: Two senior officials of the city's Department of Investigation will be reassigned because they must be ''held accountable'' for their roles in what has been called a mishandling of inquiries into corruption at the Parking Violations Bureau in 1982 and 1983, the Koch administration announced yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Texas Tech Inquiry
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has notified Lauro Cavazos, president of Texas Tech, that the university is under investigation, charging it committed recruiting violations from 1982 to 1984.

title: MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Georgetown U. Will Sell Off South Africa-Related Assets
description: Georgetown University's board of directors has voted to divest itself of all holdings in companies doing business in South Africa, officials said today.

title: Navy Eases Litton Curb
description: The Navy today lifted its suspension on doing business with Litton Industries except for one subsidiary.

title: ANDREW CUOMO'S PROPOSAL FOR SHELTER RUNS INTO SNAGS
description: Construction on a city-state plan to build housing for the homeless, initiated and directed by Governor Cuomo's son, Andrew, is months behind schedule, and officials cannot say when it will get under way.

title: McKesson Sells Chemical Unit
description: The McKesson Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its chemical distribution concern, the McKesson Chemical Company, for $76 million to Pakhoed U.S.A. Inc., a subsidiary of the Dutch company Pakhoed Holding N.V. McKesson said it does not expect a significant gain or loss from the transaction.

title: Merrill Discloses Anderson Holding
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased a 5.2 percent stake in Anderson, Clayton & Company, the Houston-based food company, ''in the ordinary course of its risk-arbitrage business.''

title: TONY DANZA IN 'DOING LIFE,' ON NBC
description: IN the land of television entertainment, the words ''real'' and ''true'' are just about meaningless. The latest example is ''Doing Life,'' a television movie on NBC at 9 tonight. Stephen Bello's script is based on his book of the same title. Even the book, which tells the ''true story'' of Jerry Rosenberg, described as ''America's greatest jailhouse lawyer,'' uses fudging techniques. It contains composite characters and identities that have been changed ''for legal reasons.'' But the movie, billed as being ''inspired by'' a true story, goes even further, twisting facts solely for the purposes of easy dramatics. What's left is a decent enough vehicle for Tony Danza, taking a brief respite from the ABC sitcom ''Who's the Boss?'' to make his debut as a ''serious'' actor, but any resemblance to a true story is almost entirely coincidental.

title: Farm Loan to Tunisia
description: The World Bank announced today that it would make a loan of $150 million to help make farming more efficient in Tunisia.

title: PROTECTED U.S. WITNESS COMMITS NEW CRIMES
description: Henry Hill, the mobster turned government informer whose life story was the subject of a recent best-selling book, has been convicted six times during the last two years while in the Federal Witness Protection Program.

title: ATOMIC TEST PLAN HAS NEW ELEMENTS
description: President Reagan's address to the United Nations today marks a significant shift in the United States position on nuclear testing, American officials said.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S SPEECH TO THE U.N. GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech today to the United Nations General Assembly, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HUMAN RIGHTS AND THE MEDIA
description: WHAT are the responsibilities of journalists in the coverage of human rights? ''The Media and Human Rights,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, tries to provide an answer. It doesn't succceed, although, presumably, it doesn't expect to. The question has too many layers.

title: DR. ALLAN H. BONNELL
description: Dr. Allan H. Bonnell, a New York patent lawyer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: GEORGE E. PROBST
description: George E. Probst, a historian, broadcaster and educator, died of cancer Sept. 9 at his home in Spencertown, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: People
description: * James H. Hammon has joined I. Goldberg & Partners as senior vice president.

title: Test of Ultralight Plane
description: An experimental ultralight airplane that looks like a toy magnified thousands of times flew into clear skies today in its final test before a globe-hugging, nonrefueled flight around the world.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $200,000 provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: National Fuel Issue to Kidder
description: The National Fuel Gas Company is offering $100 million of 9 7/8 percent debentures due in 2006 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Whirlpool-Philips
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said it was entering discussions with Philips N.V. of the Netherlands about possible joint production of appliances.

title: U.N. ENTHUSIAST AT ASSEMBLY HELM: HUMAYAN RASHEED CHOUDHURY
description: Humayan Choudhury, who presided today as the new President of the General Assembly, says his country sought the largely ceremonial post because it cares about the United Nations. Mr. Choudhury, who is

title: Nations' Steel Output
description: Crude steel production in the non-Communist world fell 7.8 percent in August, to 31.32 million metric tons, from 33.99 million tons a year before, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today. The decline was steepest in the United States, where production fell 22 percent, to 5.05 million tons from 6.47 million tons.

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TIGHT RACE FOR GOVERNOR LOOMING IN KANSAS
description: Michael Hayden, a man who normally smiles quickly, grips hands vigorously and claps shoulders easily, glanced briefly at his opponent and peered sternly out across his lectern at his audience.

title: US CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Suns Sign Bedford
description: Ever since they lost the coin flip and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to the Milwaukee Bucks in 1969 and settled for the second choice, Neal Walk, the Phoenix Suns have been looking for a center who could turn the franchise around.

title: 15 Die in South Africa In Zulu Factional Fight
description: Rival Zulu factions battled with guns in a remote mountain valley of Natal province, killing 15 fighters, the police said today.

title: NEW BUDGET LAW BEING PUT TO TEST
description: The House and the Senate have left the major budget decisions of the year to the last few weeks of the election-year session, and legislators are openly questioning whether the deficit-reducing law has worked.

title: Advertising; General Foods Cuts Ted Bates
description: TED BATES WORLDWIDE, the most recent addition to the General Foods agency roster, was dropped from it yesterday. The three brands it has been handling have been assigned to two longtime General Foods agencies.

title: METS ARE WINNERS ON GOODEN 2-HITTER
description: Where had Dwight Gooden been all summer? There were theories, but none of them really mattered last night. The gifted Met pitcher, who endured a confusing stretch and some uncharacteristic hard times, has apparently returned.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL METS VS. ST. LOUIS CARDINALS, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: PRESIDENT, AT U.N., VOICES NEW 'HOPE' ON ARMS CONTROL
description: President Reagan said today that recent arms-control exchanges between the United States and the Soviet Union might mark ''the beginning of a serious, productive negotiation on arms reduction.''

title: Montana Out of Hospital
description: Joe Montana went home from the hospital today, and his doctor said the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback should be sufficiently recovered from back surgery to play again late this season.

title: POLICE OFFICIAL NAMED TO HEAD THE CITY'S JAILS
description: Richard J. Koehler, the Police Department's Chief of Personnel, was named the city's Correction Commissioner yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Toll the Bell for Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A New Bard, Custom-Made
description: Visitors to Central Park may have wondered why the statue of Shakespeare at the southeast end of the mall seemed to wear white and then black leggings that, day by day, grew upward to envelop his face.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FISHER KING. By Anthony Powell. 256 pages. W. W. Norton. $15.95.

title: Pressure Ahead For Debi Thomas
description: At the age of 19, Debi Thomas has won the United States and world women's figure-skating championships, is in her second year of pre-medical studies at Stanford and is aiming for a gold medal at the Winter Olympics at Calgary, Alberta, in 1988.

title: JERSEY CITY HAILS START ON TOWER
description: Ground was broken today for a 30-story tower that is being billed as the tallest office building in the state.

title: TEXAS LOOKS INTO REPORTS OF VOTE FRAUD
description: The Texas Attorney General is investigating allegations that a number of discrepancies found in the computerized voting records of several recent Dallas elections might have resulted from fraud.

title: Nuclear Debris in Space
description: Collisions in space involving nuclear debris from worn-out Soviet satellites could allow radioactive pieces to fall back to Earth, an expert in debris in space said today.

title: Hammer Deal's Familiar Name
description: Armand Hammer, the industrialist, will soon own a piece of Arm & Hammer, the baking soda brand.

title: PIER I INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $422,000 and an extraordinary charge of $129,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $5,187,000 and an extraordinary credit of $82,000. The year-ago figures were restated to reflect discontinued operations. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1986.

title: PSYCHIATRY: FIRST GUIDE TO THERAPY IS FIERCELY OPPOSED
description: AMID intense controversy, psychiatrists are moving to publish an official manual of recommended treatments for mental disorders, the first since their discipline emerged close to a century ago.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE fashion world's concern over AIDS is leading to further fund-raising efforts. Robert Molnar has organized a group of his fellow designers, including Betsey Johnson, Michael Kors, Isabel Toledo, Diane Pernet, David Norbury, Miguel Osuna, Mary McFadden, Alexander Julian, Marc Jacobs and Willi Smith, to create a collection of silk-screened T-shirts and donate the proceeds to AIDS research. They will be available nationally in February under the New Alliance label.

title: DOLLER UP 2% AGAINST THE MARK
description: The dollar pulled itself up and soared against the West German mark yesterday, just one day after European Community leaders were said to have agreed on a plan to bolster the American currency.

title: No Honorable Solution in 1978 Soviet Case of U.S. Businessman
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF IS NAMED TO HEAD OFFICE OF F.B.I. IN CITY
description: The director of the F.B.I.'s inspection division in Washington, Thomas L. Sheer, was named yesterday by the agency's Director, William H. Webster, to head the F.B.I.'s flagship New York City office.

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes unusual charges of $1.6 million for the quarter and $3,393,000 for the year.

title: Mortgage Securities Set With Floating Interest
description: Securities dealers continue to introduce new wrinkles to the mortgage securities market, a trend they expect to continue.

title: MIXING TEXT AND ART: A NEW ERA OF OBFUSCATION?
description: TEN years ago, when psychedelic art was sizzling the eyeballs and everything from telephone directories to party napkins sported zooming stars and a cornucopia of effusive color, word processing via personal computer was no more than a dream. There were a few prophets, among them Ted Nelson, author of the outrageous futuristic volume ''Computer Lib,'' who foresaw the coming mass marketing of electronically processed words.

title: LOTUS PRODUCT
description: The Lotus Development Corporation will introduce a computer system today that combines financial data bases and analysis software.

title: ADMINISTRATION UNVEILS PLAN FOR MANAGING FORESTS
description: The Agriculture Department today unveiled a proposal to nearly double the timber harvest from the national forests by the year 2030.

title: THAILAND'S NEW ENVOY SAYS HE SEES ISOLATIONISM IN U.S.
description: Thailand is sending a new Ambassador to Washington next week in hopes he can do something to ease his Government's worries about isolationist and protectionist trends in the United States.

title: ...BALENCIAGA IN NEW YORK AT F.I.T.
description: Cristobal Balenciaga is back in the fashion news. Designers here and abroad are paying attention to the expert technique and pure lines of this master of the couture, the son of a Basque fisherman, who died in 1973 at the age of 77.

title: Double Execution in Florida Is Put Off By Justice Powell
description: Two Florida convicts who were scheduled to be electrocuted at 7 A.M. Tuesday were tonight granted temporary stays of execution until 3 P.M. Tuesday by Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. Lawyers for the two, Kenneth Wayne Hardwick, 37 years old, and Allen Davis, 42, had asked for the stays so they could file requests for reviews with the Supreme Court. Mr. Hardwick was sentenced for the Dec. 24, 1980, slaying of a 72-year-old widow.Mr. Davis was condemned to die for beating a pregnant Jacksonville woman to death and killing her two young daughters on May 11, 1982.

title: Bridge: American Team Is Winner Of World Knockout Final
description: An American team led by Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., scored a convincing victory here Sunday night in the final of the World Knockout Team Championship for the Rosenblum Cup.

title: AIDS RESEARCH RIVALS SHARE A MAJOR AWARD
description: TWO scientific rivals, each playing a central role in finding the virus that causes AIDS and then becoming involved in an international legal dispute over the research, were among those named yesterday as winners of the Albert Lasker Medical Research Awards, an honor that has often gone to people who later won the Nobel Prize.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How do antihistamines work?

title: Blowing Hot and Cold With Moscow; Then Bring Welcome Warmth to Arms Control
description: From the day he took office, President Reagan has been barreling down a road of rearmament that could lead in two very different directions. The result could be an open-ended arms race or, because of that threat, an intensive new effort to restrain new military technologies. Now, heading into the final lap of his Presidency, Mr. Reagan seems to be earnestly seeking negotiated controls.

title: OPERA: A NEW 'WALKURE' OPENS THE MET SEASON
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Die Walkure,'' the first installment in its projected ''Ring,'' takes a feasible approach to this second work in Wagner's four-evening cycle. Feasible, but on the whole so far from being satisfactory in both large and small matters that the success of the cycle may already be in jeopardy. Otto Schenk's staging is a schizoid affair, with naturalistic, 19th-century scenery bumping up against naturalistic acting in a 20th-century style.

title: SLIGHT GAIN SEEN ON COLLEGE TESTS
description: High school students showed some signs of improvement this year on standardized college admission tests.

title: CLINI-THERM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 COACHES LEARN TO GET OUT OF WAY
description: Coaching became a physically hazardous profession for a couple of Ohio natives last week as Gerry Faust, Akron's head coach, suffered a broken left leg in practice on Tuesday and Dick Crum, North Carolina's head coach, came away from the game at Florida State Saturday with two things he didn't want - a 10-10 tie and a broken right leg.

title: 'TIME TO LIVE' RECOUNTS STORY OF TAIWAN FAMILY
description: THE Taiwanese film ''A Time to Live and a Time to Die'' is slow and muted, but it has an attractive plainness. It's a film in which even the most momentous events in the life of the hero are presented with a matter-of-factness that amounts to understatement. The director, Hou Hsiao-hsien, revisits his own childhood in this autobiographical film, telling of a family's adjusting to Taiwanese life after emigrating from mainland China in the late 1940's. Almost all of the action is confined to the small village where the family settles, and much of it is domestic drama.

title: THEATER: LUDLAN'S 'ARTIFICIAL JUNGLE'
description: IT'S a jungle out there, all right. In ''The Artificial Jungle,'' Charles Ludlam's self-proclaimed ''masterpiece of suspense'' at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, a bored wife wants to bump off her pet-store owner of a husband, the greedy husband uses ventriloquism to sell a mute parrot to an unsuspecting cop, and the piranhas are forever rattling their aquarium. As if this weren't sleazy activity enough, a mysterious drifter named Zachary Slade responds to a help-wanted sign and soon starts to insinuate himself into the pet shop's live-in household. The wife, Roxanne Nurdiger (Black-Eyed Susan), develops a thing for Zachary (Everett Quinton). ''Kiss me until I bleed!'' she instructs, while conspiring to buy her husband a fat new insurance policy.

title: New York's Sloppy Contract Routine
description: A trial just beginning will determine whether Stanley Friedman, Donald Manes and other Democratic Party leaders conspired to convert New York City's parking agency into a criminal enterprise. But the corruption and confusion in the city's contracting practices are abundantly clear. The latest evidence comes from Edward Regan, the State Comptroller.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,342,000 on the termination of a capital lease of one of its Irvine facilities. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,362,000 and $3,938,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: EVERETT TRADE SHOWS FANCY MANEUVERS
description: The big trade last week involving Jim Everett, whom the Houston Oilers failed to sign after making him the third pick in the 1986 draft, reflects the lengths to which teams will go to obtain a highly regarded young quarterback - or to get the most in return for one.

title: GLOVE PADDING AT ISSUE AS TESTIMONY BEGINS
description: Billy Collins Sr., whose son Billy Jr. was defeated by Luis Resto in a June 1983 fight at Madison Square Garden, testified yesterday that when he shook hands with the winner after the bout, he felt that padding had been removed from Resto's gloves.

title: Dayton-Hudson In Note Offering
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation is offering $150 million of 8 3/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.60 to yield 8.435 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: EXCERPTS FROM AQUINO'S SPEECH TO U.N.  UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines to the General Assembly:

title: TWO ON MOB TRIAL TAPE SAY TO KILL DRUG SELLERS
description: Mafia members who deal in drugs ''gotta be killed'' because they attract too much attention from the authorities, a defendant accused of being a mob boss said in a secretly taped conversation played yesterday in a Manhattan courtroom.

title: York Wins Judicial Primary
description: After a completed count of absentee ballots, Louis B. York is the winner of the Democratic nomination for Civil Court in Manhattan by 138 votes, the Board of Elections announced yesterday. Mr. York defeated Dorothy Chin Brandt, who appeared to be the winner on primary night. Ms. Brandt is challenging the final count in State Supreme Court.

title: A National Attack On Addiction Is Long Overdue
description: The Congressional leadership and the Reagan Administration discovered this summer what the Harlem Representative Charles B. Rangel and every urban cop and street-smart teen-ager from Brooklyn to East Los Angeles have known for more than a decade: addiction is America's No. 1 crime problem.

title: Sympathetic Foe
description: After his Los Angeles Rams pounded the Colts, 24-7, at Indianapolis on Sunday, Coach John Robinson commiserated with the Colts, whose regular quarterback, Gary Hogeboom, was sidelined with a dislocated shoulder.

title: Strike Over G.M. Car Project
description: About 250 members of Local 160 of the United Automobile Workers struck the General Motors Corporation's Technical Center in Warren, Mich., today, saying they were shut out of working on a secret new car project. The union said G.M. was violating its labor contract by not allowing union members to work on Project Trilby, a $90 million program expected to draw on the electronics technology of Hughes Aircraft, which General Motors bought last year.

title: ENERGY ASSETS INTERNAIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed its revenue and earnings decline to the withholding of financing commitments, the sharp drop in oil and gas prices and a $66,000 writedown of leases associated with the company's prospect generation activity.

title: Wisconsin Hoedown
description: Elsewhere on the Washington cultural scene, Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, has cut an album of bluegrass, folk and country music that will be released today at a party at the Democratic National Committee headquarters. By way of explanation, Mr. Obey is running for re-election, against Kevin Hermening, a Republican who is a former hostage in Iran. Mr. Obey plays the harmonica and is backed by a band of friends and his sons Craig and Douglas. The album is called ''Capitol Offenses.''

title: 2,000 Winery Workers Vote on Contract Offer
description: More than 2,000 striking winery workers voted today on a proposal to end their walkout, which entered its sixth week against some of the $5.5 billion California wine industry's biggest producers.

title: Owens-Corning Outlines Changes
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation outlined its new operational structure yesterday, the result of a reorganization plan announced last month.

title: JUROR MISCONDUCT CITED
description: Victor Posner was granted a new trial today on his conviction for income tax evasion, but the millionaire industrialist expressed doubts that he would ever receive a fair hearing because of the complexity of the case.

title: Poor Means You Can't Buy Your Own Apartment
description: To the Editor:

title: Beneficiaries of Oil Spils
description: Environmentalists have long considered pollution of the seas by oil and other hydrocarbons to be among the most dangerous threats faced by marine animals and plants. But Lawrence Livermore Laboratory reports that, although hydrocarbons are poison for most organisms, they are meat for some.

title: USX TAKES STEPS TO LIFT STOCK VALUE
description: The USX Corporation, the old United States Steel Corporation, gave stockholders a clear signal yesterday that it was working on a plan to raise the value of its stock.

title: Office Growth
description: Even amid mandatory budget cutbacks and the Administration's emphasis on reducing the size of Government, Washington's white-collar work force is growing apace.

title: Congolese Official Apologizes For Likening Israel to Nazis
description: Foreign Minister Antoine Ndinga-Oba of Congo has apologized to Israel on behalf of his president for a comparison of Israel and Nazi Germany in a United Nations speech Mr. Ndinga made last week, Israeli officials said today.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 24
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,200,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $800,000. Prior year results have been restated to reflect discontinued furniture operations separately. The company said yesterday the board of directors declared a 2-for-1 stock split to stockholders of record on Oct. 10.

title: MAKER DENIES PROBLEMS WITH TROOP CARRIER
description: The FMC Corporation yesterday denied assertions that it had not properly tested the ability of the Bradley infantry vehicle to swim across rivers and streams. It said it was ''examining legal recourse against'' a company engineer who made the allegations in a lawsuit.

title: High Court Ceremony Friday
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist will be sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States and Judge Antonin Scalia will be sworn in as an Associate Justice Friday in a joint ceremony at the Supreme Court, the Court announced today. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will administer the oath to Justice Rehnquist, who in turn will administer the oath to Judge Scalia. The ceremony, expected to last about 20 minutes, will begin at 2 P.M. in the courtroom.

title: Liberian Leader Ends Ban on Rival's Party
description: The Liberian Government lifted a ban today on the United People's Party of former Foreign Minister Gabriel Baccus Matthews.

title: Prosecutor Ends Case In Georgia Murder Trial
description: The prosecutor in the murder trial of a nurse accused of killing six patients with injections of potassium chloride concluded his case today without calling nearly 60 scheduled witnesses.

title: New Apple: Advantages Of Mac and II
description: APPLE will soon begin selling a new computer, a hybrid that plucks some of the best features from both the model II series and the flashier Macintosh. The new machine, called the IIgs, is being aimed at home and school users who are tired of the aging technology of the model II but are not ready, willing or able to buy Apple's top-of-the-line Macintosh.

title: 2 NEW SERIES, 'MATLOCK' AND 'SLEDGE HAMMER'
description: THE ''law and order'' formula continues to be milked, sometimes in wondrous ways. NBC's ''Matlock,'' having its premiere at 8 o'clock this evening, stars Andy Griffth as an Atlanta lawyer who plays detective on his own cases. That's pretty standard stuff. Meanwhile, on ABC at 8:30, a ''preview'' of ''Sledge Hammer!'' (which begins its regular run this Friday at 9:30) offers a trigger-happy police detective whose cartoon-like antics include firing warning shots at jaywalkers. Square-jawed Sledge is supposed to be a sendup of Rambo, Dirty Harry and other current icons. Actually, the parody is curiously affectionate.

title: A DISPUTED SLICE OF SINAI IS TAKING IT ALL IN STRIDE
description: In 1906 a battalion of Ottoman soldiers from the nearby Jordanian port of Aqaba tried to occupy this 700-yard-long stretch of sand.

title: American Catfish
description: Templeton Inc. of Farmington, Conn., the consultant who is running the agency search for the American Catfish Institute, has announced the names of the two finalists in the competition: the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, and the Richard Group of Dallas. Both will be sending teams down to see the Catfish board of directors next month in their headquarters in Belzoni, Miss. The recently formed institute is for people who raise catfish and their suppliers.

title: IRAN MARCH MARKS SIX YEARS OF WAR
description: The Iranian press agency said today that soldiers marked the sixth anniversary of the start of the war against Iraq today by marching in Teheran past throngs chanting ''Death to the U.S.''

title: New Proposal On Rail Merger
description: The Santa Fe-Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it had entered into an agreement that should overcome Federal antitrust concerns about the merger between the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railways.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After special charges of $269,000 and $9,442,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After a special gain of $388,000 for the quarter and a special charge of $39,451,000 for the year. The 1985 results are restated to reflect the sale of Inverness Petroleum.

title: U.S. Is Told To Pay Iran
description: Under a recent ruling of the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague, the United States must return more than $500 million to Iran, money that came from excessive interest payments made by Iran.

title: MUSIC: CECILY REEVES, MEZZO
description: HALF concealed within Cecily Reeves's present singing apparatus is a voice of some warmth and musicality. Miss Reeves, a mezzo-soprano from Detroit with an opera and teaching background in Georgia, gave her first New York recital at CAMI Hall Sunday afternoon, singing Handel, Berlioz, Verdi, Wolf and Ginastera.

title: Man Hunted in Missouri In 3-State Crime Spree
description: A fugitive who painted his face silver and black and vowed he would never be taken alive killed two people, abducted at least five others, wounded a police officer and stole seven vehicles in a three-state crime spree today, the authorities said.

title: A WORKABLE ORGAN-DONOR SYSTEM
description: On June 10, Jesse Sepulveda and Deana Binkley appeared on the Phil Donahue show to plead for a heart for their dying infant, Jesse.

title: Sabonis Stays Put
description: Arvidas Sabonis, the 7-foot-3-inch star of the Soviet Union's basketball team drafted on the first round by the Trail Blazers, will not play for Portland - or for any other team besides his current one, for that matter. Sabonis's coach, Vladas Garastas, also said there have been other untruths and farfetched speculation surrounding the big center, including rumors that he is in poor health.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: D'Amato Is Endorsed By Some Democrats
description: About three dozen New York Democrats, including three Assemblymen, three former Congressmen and a top aide to Mayor Koch, endorsed Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, yesterday for re-election.

title: SCANDAL STILL MARS BUREAU
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau is still recovering from the bribery and extortion scandal that racked it, according to the new management team brought in to run the agency.

title: Tremblay Retires
description: The Montreal Canadiens have announced the retirement of Mario Tremblay, the veteran forward and a member of five Stanley Cup winning teams in his 12 seasons with the team. Tremblay, who turned 30 on Sept. 2, suffered a severe shoulder injury last season and played in only 56 games.

title: Scanlon Beaten In First Round
description: John Letts defeated Bill Scanlon, 6-4, 6-2, today in opening-round action at the TransAmerica Tennis Open.

title: Timeout for Kasparov After 18th Chess Game
description: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, took his third and final time out today in his title match with Anatoly Karpov. The action postponed their 19th game until Wednesday.

title: Shcharansky Endorses Council Bill on Soviet
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, speaking by telephone from London with a New York City Council subcommittee, yesterday endorsed a bill that would bar municipal contracts with companies that sell goods directly to certain agencies of the Soviet Government and city deposits in banks that lend money to the Soviet Union.

title: Perez Honored
description: Tony Perez, one of the last great Cuban baseball players to come out of that country since the Fidel Castro regime took over, was honored Sunday by the Cincinnati Reds. Among the presents he got from the team and his teammates were a new car and a vacation in Spain.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS IN 2 MOVES
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation, which owns Almaden wines, Windsor Supreme whisky, Old Grand-Dad bourbon and DeKuyper liqueurs, said yesterday that it would put its wine and spirits operations up for sale to concentrate on chemicals and energy.

title: 2 Trade Blocs Open Talks
description: Europe's two main trading groups, the European Community and the Soviet-led Comecon, opened talks today, resuming a dialogue broken off more than five years ago.

title: Of the Rose
description: By this afternoon, if all goes as expected on Capitol Hill, America will for the first time have a national flower, the rose.

title: SAYS THEY AGREED TO CONSIDER TIES
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Prime Minister Shimon Peres met for more than an hour today, and Mr. Peres said they had agreed to consider normalizing relations between the Soviet Union and Israel.

title: U.S. GAIN IN FACSIMILE MARKET
description: Over the past decade a half-million American offices bought facsimile machines to send graphs and documents over telephone lines, and Japanese manufacturers, who gradually took over the market for those machines, garnered most of the profits.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After net of $288,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2.7 million for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $720,000 for the quarter and $2,525,000 for the year.

title: Polish Conscripts Reported to Shun Oath
description: The Warsaw Government has jailed dozens of conscripts for refusing to take an oath obliging them to fight alongside the Soviet Army, an outlawed pacifist group said today.

title: Older Jurors Excel In Life Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBYA'S FIAT STAKE SOLD FOR $3 BILLION
description: Libya has sold all of its 14 percent share in Fiat S.p.A. for about $3 billion, the automobile maker said today.

title: The Difficulty of Donating Infant Organs
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAMIR, AFTER A RAID ON LEBANON, SAYS ISRAEL DOESN'T PLAN INVASION
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, said today that Israel had no plans for a new invasion of Lebanon.

title: A FAMILY ORIGINAL
description: ''THE best apple pie in New York is made right here in this kitchen,'' says Cousin Ruth, who, at 82, is neither immodest nor charitable in her opinion of other people's pies. ''That's pie?'' she said after tasting one. As for store-bought pies, ''They have gelatin and God knows what else.''

title: Islanders Lose to Flyers
description: They are skating in jerseys with numbers, but not names, affixed to their backs, a situation that emphasizes the unsettled nature of the Islanders' roster this season. That touch of anonymity is apparently intended to show all 56 Islanders left here in training camp that no jobs have been secured yet.

title: A Versatile Decision-Maker
description: ''Sports is the key to my life,'' says Matthew (Pop) Shortell of Ansonia, Conn., who has apparently logged more time umpiring and refereeing than seems humanly possible. According to records he has kept since 1940, Shortell has worked 15,381 basketball games and 15,067 baseball and softball games, some with such major leaguers-to-be as Walt Dropo, Bobby Valentine, Steve Balboni and Mike Flanagan.

title: RAIN SUSPENDS MET GOLF
description: The host pros stole the show today just before a thunderstorm forced suspension of the opening round of the 60th championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association. Tom Joyce, head professional of The Glen Oaks Club, was four under par after 14 holes and Don Reese, one of his assistants, was two under after 16.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER'S SPEECH AT THE U.N.
description: Following are key sections of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's speech today to the General Assembly, as distributed in translation by the Soviet Mission:

title: After Four Years, the Gavel Falls on Columbus
description: A longtime source of debate has finally been removed from the General Assembly's agenda: the issue of how the United Nations should observe the quincentenary of the 1492 discovery of America.

title: Ease in Babyland
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: High Court Ceremony Friday
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist will be sworn in as Chief Justice of the United States and Judge Antonin Scalia will be sworn in as an Associate Justice on Friday in a joint ceremony at the Supreme Court, the Court announced Monday. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will administer the oath to Justice Rehnquist, who in turn will administer the oath to Judge Scalia. The ceremony, expected to last about 20 minutes, will begin at 2 P.M. in the courtroom.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Green of Dolphins Out for 10 Weeks
description: Hugh Green, the Miami Dolphins' linebacker and defensive captain, who fractured his right kneecap in Sunday's 51-45 overtime loss to the Jets, underwent surgery today and is expected to be out of action for 10 weeks.

title: LINDENAUER WILL BE WITNESS NEXT WEEK IN FRIEDMAN'S TRIAL
description: Opening statements in the Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and four other defendants were set today for next Tuesday, and the Government said it would call Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, as its second witness.

title: Arms and the Men
description: The 39-year-old right-handed reliever is the leader among active pitchers. The top 10, with seasons in parentheses:

title: A CAT CRISIS? JERSEY TOWN WEIGHS LIMIT
description: The history of small towns might one day be written as the history of two great opposing forces - those who love domestic animals and those who do not.

title: Fallout At Bates Deplored
description: JUDGING from conversations with a few of the top executives in the largest advertising agencies, the entire industry is feeling the pain of the instability of Ted Bates Worldwide. The fallout from the top of its personnel list and client list is causing ripples of concern that are rolling out from its Times Square headquarters.

title: AN IRAQI CITY FEELS THE SIX-YEAR WAR UP CLOSE
description: Inside a place here called the Museum of the Martyrs of the Iranian Aggression, the walls are lined with hundreds of passport-size photographs of the war dead.

title: Democrats Bring Out New Mode
description: Meet the new Democratic Party. For the past year it has been listening. Now, it is ready to talk.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CUBS, at Chicago, 2:20 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 2:15 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 2:15 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Out With Organic
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MARINE DEAL TO BUY FIRST PENNSYLVANIA
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. yesterday announced an agreement to acquire the First Pennsylvania Corporation, one of the oldest banks in America and one of the biggest financial institutions in Pennsylvania.

title: Nonalcoholic Tax
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
City Hall Adjunct Forced to Close
description: For more than three decades, Jimmy Meehan presided over a 19th-century corner of lower Manhattan. Behind a 35-foot serpentine mahogany bar at Suerken's Restaurant at Park Place and Church Street, Jimmy - it is almost impossible to think of him as Mr. Meehan - got to know the restlessly changing cast of City Hall regulars, from the highest-ranking officials to the hardest-working bureaucrats.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A PRIMER FOR APPLE PIE PURISTS: FINDING THE CITY'S BEST SLICE
description: WHILE Moms who bake apple pie have become scarce, Mom's homebaked-style apple pie has not, more than holding its own beside its Continental shelf mates, the French apple tart and German kuchen.

title: Citicorp's Auction
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper rose a bit. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper yesterday at an average 5.739 percent, up from 5.721 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average 5.72 percent, up from 5.69 percent.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Bridge: 2 Ex-Champions in the Lead In Play for World Pairs Title
description: The quarter-final stage of the world pair championships ended here Monday night with two former world champions in the lead. Jeff Meckstroth of Columbus, Ohio, and Eric Rodwell of West Lafayette, Ind., who were members of the winning Bermuda Bowl team in Stockholm in 1983, headed the standings, with pairs from France, Brazil and Italy in pursuit.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE package of Sunshine Peanut Butter Wafers proudly declares that it is ''baked with 100 percent vegetable shortening.'' To a health-conscious consumer, that sounds tempting, until one reads the fine print of the ingredients list. There ''vegetable shortening'' means ''one or more of the following partially hydrogenated oils: soybean, cottonseed, palm, peanut, palm kernel and coconut oil.''

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The year-ago quarter figures reflect a change in accounting for pensions.

title: Risky Business
description: The undefeated Washington Redskins have rallied from deficits in all three of their victories. Says Coach Joe Gibbs, not completely pleased with his team's style of winning: ''You like to be a good come-from-behind team, but you don't like having so much practice at it.''

title: IN CAPITAL DOGFIGHT, NEW YORK BATTLES TO SAVE THE T-46A
description: The troops from Long Island have been working here since Monday, 10 men bearing attache cases loaded with bound, printed booklets that explain all the reasons why Congress should retain funds for the T-46A, a trainer aircraft built by them and their colleagues at the Fairchild Republic Company's plant in Farmingdale.

title: SUMMIT PROSPECT CALLED 'REALISTIC' BY SHEVARDNADZE
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union said today that despite major differences with the United States, a summit meeting was now ''a realistic possibility.''

title: POLICE CORRUPTION: A LOOK AT HISTORY
description: 1896: An investigating committee headed by State Senator Clarence Lexow hears testimony that police officers took bribes from brothel owners and gambling-house operators. The initial fee for opening a brothel ran from $300 to $500; officers collected a monthly fee of $50 to $100. 1930: A state investigating commission headed by Judge Samuel Seabury hears testimony that an informer, Chile Mapocha Acuna, and 28 vice squad policemen had extorted money from prostitutes. 1954: Harry Gross, a Brooklyn bookmaker, testifies that he paid $1 million a year for police protection for his $20-million-a-year gambling operation. A five-year special inquiry into Police Department corruption headed by Julius Helfand, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, led to 300 resignations, 22 indictments and 10 convictions. Ultimately, Mayor William O'Dwyer, himself a former policeman, resigned, as did Police Commissioner William O'Brien and Chief Inspector August Flath. 1968: Nineteen officers are indicted following an investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan into police payoffs. Ten others were dismissed for refusing to sign waivers of immunity to testify before a grand jury. Investigators traced a pattern of cash bribes paid to policemen by gamblers for warning of impending police raids. 1972: The Knapp Commission, after a two-year investigation, calls corruption an ''extensive departmentwide phenomenon, indulged in to some degree by a sizable majority of those on the force.''

title: Knudsen Foods' Operating Funds
description: Financially troubled Knudsen Foods Inc., the West Coast's largest dairy operation, said its lenders had agreed to provide enough money to keep operating through Wednesday pending the outcome of talks to sell the company.

title: DESIGNER VEGGIES: HOME ON THE RANGE
description: SITTING in a trendy Manhattan restaurant over a $20 plate of designer vegetables - purple peppers, yellow tomatoes and blue potatoes no larger than a walnut - a diner may not realize how his meal has helped turn a debt-ridden farm into a profitable one.

title: JAMAICANS REPORT KILLINGS BY POLICE
description: A high-ranking Jamaican official says that in each of the last seven years, the police in the Caribbean nation have killed an average of 200 civilians.

title: TAINTING OF FISH FEARED AFTER MICHIGAN FLOODS
description: Industrial solvents that escaped a flooded Dow Chemical Company plant may have contaminated fish and other life in two rivers and the Saginaw Bay, state officials said today.

title: CONGRESS NEARS APPROVAL OF NEW STUDENT AID BILL
description: A bill nearing approval in Congress that would set the terms of grants and loans to college students for five more years offers some increases in aid but imposes tougher eligibility standards.

title: British Tanker Attacked
description: An Iranian helicopter gunship attacked the 122,000-ton British-flag tanker Pawnee in the Persian Gulf today, marine salvage executives reported. They said that the tanker, bound for Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, was attacked 25 miles east of Bu Musa, an island where Iran has a military base. The crew escaped harm and the Pawnee proceeded under its own power to Dubai in the United Arab Emirates for repairs, the sources said.

title: Rumbles From Olympus
description: One of the lesser known facts about the United States Olympic Committee is that it has the sole legal right to the word ''Olympic,'' under the 1978 Amateur Sports Act, which strengthened a 1950 act of Congress.

title: Impasse at Coffee Talks
description: Negotiations over market shares at a conference of the International Coffee Organization remained deadlocked today. The talks, which opened Sept. 15, are scheduled to end on Friday.

title: THE DANCE: HAWKINS IN 'AHAB'
description: ''MOBY DICK'' transformed into an American Noh play - this is''Ahab,'' Erick Hawkins's new piece of dance theater. Yeats, who tried his own hand at Noh forms, would have liked it as poetic drama.

title: Western Pacific
description: The Western Pacific Corporation said that the Danaher Corporation had offered to acquire Western for more than $165 a share in cash.

title: LAWMAKERS JOCKEYING ON TAX BILL
description: Congressional leaders basically agreed today that the comprehensive tax revision bill was likely to be passed by the House of Representatives this week, but the lawmakers continued to angle for political advantage.

title: U.S. SETS NEW INTERROGATION OF MEMBER OF SPY RING
description: The Justice Department has scheduled a new interrogation of Arthur J. Walker, convicted of spying for the Soviet Union, after reports that his brother lied about the family's espionage ring, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: 7 ASTRONAUTS' SURVIVORS OPEN $1 MILLION FOUNDATION DRIVE
description: The surviving families of the astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger said Monday that they had begun a campaign to raise $1 million to establish programs in space sciences education and training for teachers and students.

title: Vatican Issues Rebuke To European Educator
description: The Vatican today issued a public rebuke of the Rev. Edward Schillebeeckx, a writer and teacher at a Dutch university, in the latest action against prominent theologians found at odds with Roman Catholic doctrine.

title: Carpaccio From the Sea
description: NOT long ago the term carpaccio automatically meant the Italian dish of thinly pounded raw beef drizzled with olive oil and garnished with Parmesan cheese and perhaps some fresh herbs. Today, however, all sorts of seafood carpaccios are in vogue, no doubt spurred by the influence of Japanese cuisine. Raw salmon, tuna, bass and even swordfish have become popular carpaccios in New York restaurants.

title: Tobacco Ads' Effect On Young Minimized
description: The International Advertising Association has published a booklet on the results of a study on why juveniles smoke that was sponsored by the International Tobacco Information Center in Brussels. It found, believe it or not, that ''advertising plays a minuscule role in the initiation of smoking by the young.''

title: Sheaffer's New Chief 'Passionate About Pens'
description: When Murray R. Eisner was being interviewed 10 years ago for a marketing job at the Sheaffer Eaton division of Textron Inc., he used a ballpoint pen to take notes at a luncheon. He was immediately chastised by a Textron executive for not using a Sheaffer pen. Mr. Eisner tried to give the pen to a waitress, then the Textron executive told him to ''get it out of circulation.'' He threw it away.

title: President Is Chosen At Arthur D. Little
description: Arthur D. Little Inc., the consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday that it had named Charles R. Lamantia president and chief operating officer.

title: BIGOTRY ISSUE IN CAROLINA CAMPAIGN
description: On the surface, the gubernatorial campaign in South Carolina presents a picture of a maturing two-party system in a state that has elected only one Republican Governor in this century, James B. Edwards in 1975.

title: Aide Reappointed Despite Objections
description: The City Council approved the reappointment of Mary E. Mann to the Tax Commission yesterday, over the objections of five Hispanic and black Council members who complained that the seven-member commission has no minority representation.

title: HEAD OF AGENCY WARNS CONGRESS ON TOXIC WASTE CLEANUP PROJECTS
description: Time is running out to save the huge spending program for cleaning up toxic waste dumps, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency has warned Congress.

title: People Express Status Report
description: The Texas Air Corporation, which is seeking quick regulatory approval of its proposed takeover of People Express Inc., has told the Transportation Department that People Express is in danger of going bankrupt soon, an airline industry source said.

title: Frigitronics Offer
description: Frigitronics Inc., an eyewear and vision diagnostic equipment company, recommended to its shareholders yesterday that they reject an amended offer from the Revlon Group Inc. Revlon last week reduced its offer for Frigitronics to $29.50 a share from $35.50, citing a material deterioration in Frigitronics' business.

title: WINE TALK
description: A 1976 wine tasting in Paris, at which a relatively unknown California wine bested some of France's most famous names, has become a kind of watershed event in the modern history of American wine. Last week, the same tasting was re-created in New York. This time, two California wines came out on top.

title: Kennedy Center Search
description: The board of trustees of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has begun a search for a new chief operating officer for the center, someone to assume some of the administrative load carried by Roger L. Stevens, chairman and chief executive officer since 1961. The new officer might eventually succeed Mr. Stevens when he decides to retire.

title: PITT'S NEW WAYS FOR A COMEBACK
description: Mike Gottfried abandoned the thought of being a priest in the fifth grade. But he never forgot the traditional working-class values of family, faith and hard work he learned as a youth in Crestline, Ohio.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about Presi-dent Corazon C. Aquino's appearances on Sunday at three colleges incorrectly described her alma mater, the College of Mount St. Vincent in New York. The college, which admitted only women when Mrs. Aquino studied there, is now coeducational.

title: Astros' Deshaies Fans First 8 for Record
description: In his previous three starts, Jim Deshaies of the Houston Astros looked nothing like the rookie left-hander who impressed the National League with a 9-2 record through Aug. 24.

title: Let's Consider Before Rushing Into Drug Testing; Questioning a Survey
description: To the Editor:

title: Moody's Reduces USX Debt Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service reduced its debt ratings for the USX Corporation yesterday.

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $76,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,458,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and an estimated loss of $11,904,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $670,000 for the quarter and $4,616,000 for the year. The 1985 figures have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: 'FIRING LINE' DISCUSSION ON 'HARVEST OF DEPRESSION'
description: IGNORE the title; ''The Media and 'Harvest of Despair' '' is misleading. Ignore the clumsy format, too. Concentrate on ''Harvest of Despair,'' the 55-minute documentary that is the centerpiece of the two-hour ''Firing Line'' special on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. It is harrowing. More to the point, it is true. The documentary says the Soviet Union systematically, purposefully, starved seven million Ukrainians to death in 1932 and '33. In fact, the figure of seven million is extrapolated from unreliable Soviet census data, and other estimates say the number of Ukrainian dead was higher. Two things, however, are indisputable: a state-sponsored cataclysm struck the Ukraine; the world either chose to ignore, or did not know, what happened.

title: Globetrotters File Labor Complaint
description: The union representing players on the Harlem Globetrotters has filed an unfair labor practice charge against the management, Edward Bell and Seymour Floyd, who represent the United Basketball Players Association, said today. The charge accuses Harlem Globetrotters Inc. of failing to bargain in good faith.

title: THEATER: 'NIGHTINGALE'
description: EXCEPT for a brief appearance as an actor during the Off Broadway engagement of his play ''Small Craft Warnings,'' Tennessee Williams was not a public performer, but in interviews and private relationships -and in his ''Memoirs'' - he was often given to self-revelation. It was impossible for him not to talk about himself, which he did with ebullience and even abandon, although his artistic life remained a closely guarded confidence between himself and his muse.

title: DOW ADDS 4.36 AND RISES TO 1,797.81
description: The increase was not as impressive as Monday's, but Wall Street managed to record its second consecutive gain yesterday as nervous investors became a little more aggressive.

title: POLICE ARREST HUNDREDS IN SWEEP OF SUBWAYS
description: Plainclothes transit police officers staged a nine-hour sweep of 27 subway stations in midtown and in lower Manhattan last night, arresting fare-cheats, smokers and other suspected violators of transit laws, officials said.

title: Pump Up Trade, Not the Dollar
description: Is the dollar still overvalued? Treasury Secretary Baker thinks so, pointing to the huge U.S. trade deficit. His European and Japanese counterparts think not, citing the dollar's 40 percent drop against the mark and yen since February 1985. Last weekend, the disagreement turned nasty. Angered by Secretary Baker's attempt to ''talk down'' the dollar, the European Community vowed to defend its value in the currency markets.

title: FILM: MEDIEVAL MYSTERY IN 'NAME OF THE ROSE'
description: IT'S possible that nobody could have been more surprised than Umberto Eco, the Italian journalist, critic and professor of semiotics, when, in 1983, his first novel, ''The Name of the Rose,'' became a best seller in this country as it had earlier been in Europe.

title: THOUGHTS OF SPRING AND A NEW YEAR
description: 1.A Garden Box

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,574,000 from a patent licensing agreement which included proceeds from the recovery of patent infringement.

title: I.B.M. ACTS TO BOLSTER SALES FORCE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced a reorganization of its marketing operations that will put about 2,800 more employees into the company's sales offices, the latest in a series of moves to pump up slow-growing revenues.

title: The Difficulty of Donating Infant Organs
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Eleanor Roosevelt Plaque
description: A new brass plaque on the wall of the weathered-brick 17-story building at 29 Washington Square West says:

title: New York State's Insanity Defense and a Balancing of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene is a Fifth Avenue bus. Across from Carolyn Klein an adorable baby is nestled in her mother's backpack. ''Here, Annie, have some bran muffin,'' the mother says, reaching over her shoulder and handing the child a piece of muffin. Then she turns to her other daughter, who is sitting beside her, and starts reading aloud from a storybook.

title: 2 Banking Bills in Texas
description: Gov. Mark White Jr. signed two banking bills today. One permits branch banking in Texas, and it becomes law Jan. 1.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK QUEENS LEADER IN VOTE TONIGHT
description: A new Queens Democratic leader will be chosen tonight, and his first task will be to restore the financial and political health of an organization still reeling from the city corruption scandal.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1986
description: International A U.S.-Soviet summit meeting is now ''a realistic possibility'' despite major differences with the United States, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said. Addressing the United Nations General Assembly, he said that ''encouraging outlines of meaningful agreements have been emerging lately.'' An American spokesman said a further meeting between Mr. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State George P. Shultz had failed to resolve the case of an American journalist in Moscow who faces trial on espionage charges. The case has been viewed by the United States as the main obstacle blocking a summit meeting. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: KEY RATES
MANDATORY FARM CONTROL POLICIES PROPOSED
description: A group of Democratic legislators from farm states today introduced a bill in Congress that is based, in part, on national farm policies first tried in the Great Depression.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHEN I was 19 years old, the temporary female caretaker of four younger siblings and a split-level house on a corner plot in the suburbs and desperate to get back to college, I put an advertisement in the local paper. It read: HOUSEKEEPER to cook and clean for five chil dren. Own room. References required.

title: Fraud-Inquiry Pact Reached
description: Two Federal regulatory agencies announced today that they had reached an agreement with Britain under which both nations will help each other in the investigation of securities fraud cases.

title: LANDLORDS GRANTED INJUCTION BLOCKING CITY DATA DEMANDS
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens issued a temporary injunction yesterday barring the city from forcing landlords to file statements of their incomes and expenses. The city says it needs the statements to determine whether the landlords' properties are under-assessed.

title: Change of Scene
description: It was his very first White House invitation, and he was just a bit apprehensive about the procedures and protocol. But once he discovered that Presidents are just folks, Clyde Drexler, the basketball player, says he felt right at home at the dinner President and Mrs. Reagan held a while back in honor of the visiting president of Brazil, Jose Sarney.

title: STUDY URGES CANADA TO STRENGTHEN PUBLIC TV
description: A federal task force has recommended increasing the quantity and quality of Canadian television programs, partly by creating a new public television channel.

title: DANCE: ISRAELI TROUPE IN 'WOMEN OF YEMEN'
description: THE Yemenite Jewish heritage has always been the basis of the repertory of the Inbal Dance Theater of Israel on previous visits. There was a familiar ring, then, to the title of the company's program, ''Women of Yemen, Interpretations in Theatrical Dance,'' presented Sunday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Knick Tickets To Go on Sale
description: Individual tickets for all 41 Knick regular-season games and the two exhibition doubleheaders will go on sale tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Madison Square Garden box office and all Ticketron outlets. The Knicks open their regular season at home on Nov. 1 against the Chicago Bulls.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1986
description: Companies

title: THE DANCE: A GALA BENEFIT
description: THE audience at Harkness House on Monday night both watched with pleasure and viewed with alarm. The pleasure was provided by the dancers who appeared at a gala benefit performance for the Danse Coalition.

title: MISSOURI OFFICERS SEEK EX-CONVICT IN CRIME SPREE
description: Law-enforcement officers with dogs and helicopters searched a farm town today for a former convict and mental patient accused of killing at least two people and wounding a policeman on a three-state crime spree.

title: Donn Rosen, Key Researcher In Ichthyology, Is Dead at 57
description: Donn E. Rosen, a former chairman of the department of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, died Monday at his home in Closter, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: Preprandial Toast
description: When distinguished foreign officials visit Washington and are entertained at diplomatic dinners, the exchange of toasts between the senior American official and the guest of honor sometimes provides the highlight of the evening, casting light on current relations between the United States and the country involved and the personalities of the leaders. By tradition, these salutes with the raised glass are given after dinner, but that may be changing.

title: Louisiana Sells Taxable Bonds
description: The Louisiana Agricultural Finance Authority, in its second sale of taxable bonds in less than a month, is offering $150 million of 8.80 percent bonds due in 1996 at par through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title:
PRESS THE KREMLIN ON HUMAN RIGHTS;
A Letter To Delegates In Vienna
description: Gentlemen:

title: SOPHIA LOREN IN 'COURAGE' AS INFORMANT IN DRUG CASE
description: THE film opens on a warm gathering around the family table. Toasts are being made with wine. Suddenly, the kitchen door swings open and Mama enters, announcing that she has more pasta. But hold on. This is no ordinary mama. This is Sophia Loren, playing Marianna Miraldo in the three-hour television movie titled ''Courage'' at 8 tonight on CBS. Miss Loren can still command attention simply sitting still and letting the light play over those fabulous cheekbones. But after some 30 years as a star, she clearly wants to keep on expanding her employment opportunities. She does just that very impressively in ''Courage'' with a performance that is beautifully restrained and yet fiercely passionate.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain, a two-time winner of the Masters and the British Open, is planning to move into the business of designing golf courses. Ballesteros said he would help design a championship course at Cumberland, Scotland, near Glasgow, that should be completed by 1989. . . . Nick Buoniconti, whose son, Marc Buoniconti, was paralyzed from a football injury suffered during a college game, has organized a golf tournament at Panama City, Fla., Friday and Saturday to benefit research for paralysis victims. Among the expected guests: Bobby Hull, Gale Sayers, Johnny Unitas, Ernie Banks, Willie McCovey, Bob Cousy and John Havlicek.

title: BOC Yachtsman Reports Mishap
description: Richard McBride of New Zealand, a leading contender in the BOC single-handed yacht race around the world, reported by radio from sea yesterday that the mast on his 60-foot sailboat had snapped and that he was heading to shore.

title: Turning Off the Juice For Power Lunches
description: For years some top officials and staff members at the Federal Communications Commission were wined and dined by representatives of the entertainment and communications industries they regulated. No more. The agency has imposed a tough new policy: No free lunch. Or supper. Or breakfast. And no free tickets.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS OF BUDGET VETO OVER ARMS CURB
description: Promising a veto, President Reagan sharply criticized the House of Representatives today for provisions on arms control it has added to bills involving funds for the military.

title: Sick Children
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS LIMITS ON CIVIL RACKETEER SUITS
description: Congress is being urged to act this week on an overhaul of a major antiracketeering law despite charges that the proposed revisions would eliminate important consumer protections.

title:
PRESS THE KREMLIN ON HUMAN RIGHTS;
At Vienna, A Time to Use Leverage
description: The talks covening this week in Vienna to prepare the agenda for the Helsinki review conference in November are likely to see a basic shift in Kremlin strategy. The Soviet delegates can be expected to drop their fierce resistance to talk about their country's compliance with the human rights provisions of the Helsinki accord.

title: Time Inc. Is Merging Two Research Firms
description: Time Inc., which acquired Burke Marketing Services, a research firm, last May, has now merged it with its Selling Areas-Marketing, also in research, to form SAMI/Burke.

title: LEADING ARCHBISHOP CHALLENGES VATICAN ON SILENCING DISSENT
description: One of the nation's most influential Roman Catholic bishops, Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee, has strongly questioned the Vatican's efforts to impose a stricter orthodoxy on the American church by disciplining leaders who dissent.

title: SCREEN: MEMORIES OF FREUD IN 'NINETEEN NINETEEN'
description: ''NINETEEN NINETEEN,'' which opens today at the Film Forum 1, is an ambitious and fascinating film about Sophie Rubin and Alexander Scherbatov, supposedly the last surviving patients of Sigmund Freud. Hugh Brody, who is the film's director and co-writer, and Michael Ignatieff created characters based on two of Freud's case histories, invented names for them and set them in Vienna in 1970.

title: SCHOOL CHIEF TO ASK MANDATORY SEX EDUCATION
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that he would ask the Board of Education to mandate a sex-education curriculum in all elementary and junior high schools.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Pheasants on Sale

title: Gains Forecast For Truckers
description: LAST week, when the Union Pacific Corporation agreed to buy the Overnite Transportation Company for a substantial premium over its market price, investors began to wonder if more takeovers of trucking companies were likely.

title: Smelter Closing
description: Alusuisse, the Swiss aluminum company, said it was abandoning its smelting activities in the United States as part of a streamlining operation to cut continuing losses. Hans Jucker, Alusuisse's chief executive, told a news conference that the company had sold its 66 percent stake in the Ormet Corporation, which operates a processing plant in Louisianna and smelter in Ohio, to an investor group that includes company employees, and will shut down a smelter in New Johnsonville, Tenn., by December.

title: STAGE: 'SOCRATES: THEATER OF LIFE' FROM SOVIET TRILOGY
description: WITH ''Socrates: Theater of Life'' the Jean Cocteau Repertory completes its staging of a trilogy by the Soviet playwright Edvard Radzinsky that it began to present in 1984. Actually, the Cocteau has done them in reverse order. In them Mr. Radzinsky examines relationships between the individual and the state through the lives of the Athenian philosopher, a Russian intellectual murdered in prison for his part in the Decembrist uprising of 1825 (''Lunin: Theater of Death'') and the philosopher-playwright Seneca, who committed suicide on orders of the emperor-playwright Nero (''Theater in the Time of Nero and Seneca'').

title: 'Sills & Co.' to Close
description: ''Sills & Company,'' the improvisational revue directed by Paul Sills, will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Actors' Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South, at Sheridan Square. The show will have run for 118 regular performances and 24 previews.

title: Sale by Pickens Of USX Is Seen
description: T. Boone Pickens, one of four corporate raiders reported to have major stakes in the USX Corporation, no longer has any stock in the big oil and steel company, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Judge Orders Dearborn To Open 2 Parks to All
description: A judge today struck down an ordinance barring nonresidents from two parks in Dearborn but upheld the ordinance's application to 35 other parks in the Detroit suburb.

title: CARPENTERS OFFICIAL CHARGED IN 'TRASHING' OF RESTAURANT
description: A carpenters union official who was shot in a murder attempt last May was charged yesterday with heavily damaging a restaurant being built in lower Manhattan to coerce its operators to use union carpenters.

title: BRITISH LIBERALS BAR LEADERS' NUCLEAR POLICY
description: The allied Liberal and Social Democratic Parties appeared to have been thrown into disarray today when the Liberals repudiated by a narrow vote a stand on nuclear weapons by the leaders of the two parties.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOVIE TALK The Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, has gone Hollywood in a big way, with its big exhibition ''Hollywood: Legend and Reality.'' It surveys the reel art form in a display of 400 items including photographs, the original piano from ''Casablanca,'' Rudolf Valentino's matador garb from ''Blood and Sand,'' a Red Grooms sculpture inspired by D. W. Griffith's ''Way Down East'' and other pertinent paraphernalia.

title: SHIITES' RAIDS GOAD ISRAEL TO RESPOND
description: Israeli military analysts said today that pressure was building on the Israeli Army to attack an Iranian-backed Shiite militia that has been involved in an increasing number of attacks on Israeli, United Nations and Christian militia forces in southern Lebanon.

title: S.R.O. POLICY ELUDES COUNCIL AND DISPUTE IS LEFT FOR THE COURTS
description: City officials failed to forge a new policy on single-room-occupancy hotels for adoption at yesterday's City Council meeting and now the battleground on the issue will shift to the courts.

title: Letter: On Deinstitutionalization; Better Care for the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach Has Surgery
description: Fred Dunlap, the football coach and athletic director at Colgate University, who experienced chest pains while jogging Sunday morning, has undergone double-bypass heart surgery and will most likely miss the rest of the season.

title: COMMUTER-TRAIN DELAYS LESSEN AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: Both railroads that use Grand Central Terminal reported sharply reduced train delays yesterday as investigators tentatively concluded that an electrical failure had knocked out a key underground switching center.

title: Warriors Giving Ford Another Chance
description: Phil Ford, the college player of the year at the University of North Carolina and the National Basketball Association's 1978 rookie of the year, is 30 years old. The memories and the effects of the left-eye injury he suffered on Feb. 22, 1981, when he caught World B. Free's thumb in the eye, still linger.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
More Air Time for Koch
description: New Yorkers can look forward to hearing yet more from their Mayor.

title: Bad King George Again
description: In a speech at the University of Richmond the other day, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reached back to the Declaration of Independence for historical evidence that the Framers of the Constitution were concerned about one of Mr. Meese's favorite topics: Usurpation by the Federal judiciary of the powers of the executive and legislative branches.

title: Rate on Salomon Paper Varies With Currencies
description: Salomon Brothers announced a new program yesterday: It will sell commercial paper with an interest rate that may change as foreign currencies fluctuate.

title: ENTREPRENEURS ON THE PROWL OUTSIDE THE OPERA
description: Monty is uncomfortable with the word ''scalper,'' finding it a rather indelicate description for the service he provides habitues of the opera.

title: UNLIKELY COMMUTER ROUTE: 125TH ST.
description: For the second day in a row suburban commuters streamed down the steps from the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station at 125th Street and Park Avenue yesterday, bringing to a stretch of Harlem's main thoroughfare more heterogeneity and attache cases than it has seen in a long time.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID PALESTINIANS NEAR BEIRUT
description: Israeli jets bombed Palestinian positions in the mountains overlooking the capital today.

title: HIGHWAY PROGRAM NEARS SENATE VOTE
description: The Senate tonight moved closer toward final action on a $64.8 billion, four-year program for highways, bridges and mass transit after adopting an amendment to let states raise the speed limit on some rural highways.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $299,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $598,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months, from adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement 87 regarding accounting for pension expense. The latest periods' figures include the results of both LFE Corp. and Gulton Industries, which were acquired by Mark IV, effective June 1, 1985, and March 1, 1986, respectively. The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 6.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 5-Nation Trip for Weinberger
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will visit China, India, Pakistan, Italy and Britain next month on a 19-day trip, it was announced today. The four-day visit to China will include meetings with Deng Xiaoping, the foremost Chinese leader, the Defense Department said.

title: OPERA: 'WALKURE' OPENS MET SEASON
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Die Walkure,'' the first installment in its projected ''Ring,'' takes a feasible approach to this second work in Wagner's four-evening cycle. Feasible, but on the whole so far from being satisfactory in both large and small matters that the success of the cycle may already be in jeopardy. Otto Schenk's staging is a schizoid affair, with naturalistic, 19th-century scenery bumping up against naturalistic acting in a 20th-century style.

title: A NATIONAL FLOWER: ROSE IS VICTOR
description: The House of Representatives voted today to make the rose America's national flower.

title: Hawaiian in Congress To Serve for 10 Days
description: A Hawaiian Democrat was sworn in today as the newest member of the House, but his tenure here will be brief because while he won one election on Saturday he lost another the same day.

title: PLAN TO BAN SALE OF COLD BEER IN UTAH UPSETS DISTRIBUTORS
description: A proposal to ban sales of cold beer in Utah as a way to prevent accidents involving drunken drivers has upset distributors and retailers.

title: Intel Move in Special Chips Is Seen
description: The Intel Corporation is expected to announce soon an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation that will help propel Intel into the fast-growing business of making semi-customized computer chips, according to industry sources.

title: IN ANISE OR APRICOT, PINEAPPLE OR PEAR, SCHNAPPS IS PEACHY
description: IN 1906, on Manhattan's Lower East Side, immigrants often celebrated by filling glasses and saying to friends in Yiddish, ''Lomir machen a schnapps'' - ''Let us 'make' a schnapps.''

title: Fruit, Fish and Gamma Rays
description: Insects, bacteria and mold are the enemies of fresh food. All can be arrested by energetic radiation - typically a zap of gamma rays. The Food and Drug Administration recently approved the sale of irradiated fruit and may soon allow that of fish and poultry too. Is that hasty? Irradiated food sounds unappetizing. Is it also unsafe?

title:
FOOD AND FITNESS;
YOGURT'S 'COUSIN'
description: IT sounds unfamiliar, this kefir.

title: 2 PAPERS QUOTE JAPANESE LEADER ON ABILITIES OF MINORITIES IN U.S.
description: Two Japanese newspapers quoted Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone on Tuesday as having said that because of the presence of ethnic minorities in the United States, that country's ''level is lower'' than Japan's.

title: RARE BOOK OF GOSPELS ON DISPLAY
description: The earliest lavishly illustrated book of Gospels that is known to exist, a sixth-century manuscript that has left Italy only once before in its history, will be shown at the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan for two weeks beginning today, the museum announced yesterday.

title: Sculpture Park to Open With Works by Moore
description: Three monumental bronze works by Henry Moore have been installed in the first permanent outdoor sculpture reserve in the United States.

title: Unwanted Player
description: ''I've wanted to come back for two years, but the Twins don't want me,'' said Jim Eisenreich, whose major league career was cut short by a nervous disorder.
