Eisenreich, a 27-year-old outfielder who played 48 games for the Twins from 1982 through 1984, has asked that his name be removed from the Minnesota voluntarily retired list so he can become a free agent.

title: Rates Continue Downward
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday for the second consecutive day, though many analysts said investors were still wary of long-term notes and bonds.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Comarco Inc., Anaheim, Calif., has elected to its board Burrell W. Hays, recently retired as technical director for the Naval Weapons Center at China Lake, Calif.

title: MCA Inc. Seeking A Stake in Mets
description: Preliminary negotiations for the sale of a part interest in the New York Mets to MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company, are under way.

title: SPEAKERS AT U.N. URGE ACTION AGAINST TERRORISM
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, urged the General Assembly today to combat ''the scourge of international terrorism.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: Murray Friedman; Hunting For Peace On The Rights Panel With Mixed Impact
description: Murray Friedman says he had been in his new post as vice chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission for only five minutes when he was asked to resign by two of the seven other commissioners.

title: THE BLUE MESSIAHS RAISE A RUCKUS
description: ''IT came out of nowhere, just like lightning hitting a plane,'' Bill Carter sings on the Screaming Blue Messiahs' debut album, ''Gun-Shy'' (Elektra). That might describe the band itself, which will perform Saturday at the Ritz (119 East 11th Street), as well as ''Gun-Shy,'' one of the year's most powerful - and raucous - major-label albums, blunt and muscular and implacable. With twanging, squealing guitars and walloping drums, ''Gun-Shy'' comes on like a pickup truck full of Furies.

title: Therapists Disputed
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NEWSPAPER CHAIN SWITCHING LAWYERS IN LAXALT LIBEL CASE
description: McClatchy Newspapers, the Sacramento-based chain that faces a $250 million libel action by Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, has retained Robert Warren of Los Angeles as chief counsel in place of James Brosnahan of San Francisco.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo to Aug 31
CHRYSLER TO EXPORT TO EUROPE
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation is planning to export American-made cars and mini-vans for sale in Europe to take advantage of the decline in the dollar's value, company officials said today.

title: LOUIS BEACHNER
description: Louis Beachner, a New York actor who recently completed his 13th season as a member of the Williamstown Theater Festival, died of cancer Friday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BOLIVIA'S COCA GROWERS: BITTERNESS OVER LOST CROP
description: Now there would be no money for food, the woman said, and none to put in the outstretched hands of her children each morning when school classes resumed the following week.

title: Landlord Pays $216,000 to City
description: A landlord who completed a 45-day jail sentence earlier this month for failing to comply with a court order to repair a building paid the city more than $216,000 in back taxes yesterday to prevent foreclosure on three other buildings.

title: House Bars a Set Retirement Age
description: The House of Representatives today passed a bill eliminating mandatory retirement at any age. The bill also requires continued health coverage by employers for workers 70 years old and above.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS PLAN A NEW UNION
description: After several false starts by other groups, scores of air traffic controllers convened here today to found a new nationwide union.

title: EX-MOB LEADER TELLS OF SLAYING FATHER'S KILLER
description: Dramatic stories about revenge killings, secret initiations and life in a crime family were told yesterday by a former Mafia leader testifying at the ''commission'' trial in Manhattan.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net loss of $2,243,000 for the quarter and net income of $8,820,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations and an extraordinary reduction in income tax benefit of $67,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary income tax benefit of $3,262,000 for the year, arising from utilization of prior year's operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss d-Includes net loss from discontinued operations of $25,168,000 for the quarter and $26,737,000 for the year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A SUMMONS TO MEMPHIS. By Peter Taylor. 209 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. THE world delineated in Peter

title: TEAM WARNED DEFENSE DEPT. BEFORE MARINE BARRACKS BLAST
description: More than four months before a truck bomb destroyed the United States Marine garrison in Beirut, a team of military experts warned of serious failings in American intelligence in Lebanon, according to a member of the team.

title: L.I. THEATER IS CONVERTED INTO 3-LEVEL FASHION MALL
description: Conventional retail wisdom might question a plan to bring 25 more shops to a small town of 7,000 residents that already has more than a dozen boutiques selling high-fashion clothing, shoes and gifts.

title: POLICE SUSPEND 13 OVER DRUG INQUIRY IN BROOKLYN UNIT
description: Thirteen police officers from a Brooklyn precinct were suspended yesterday afternoon, pending a grand jury investigation, after police and state investigators charged that they had extorted money and drugs from narcotics dealers, law-enforcement officials said.

title: FLIGHT DELAYS: AIRLINES AND F.A.A. FAULTING EACH OTHER
description: Delayed airplanes are bunching up again on the tarmacs of the nation's busiest airports, with Government and airline representatives faulting one another and the consequences falling on the hapless traveler.

title: Israeli President Meets New Egyptian Envoy
description: Egypt's new Ambassador to Israel, Mohammed Bassiouny, who had served as charge d'affaires since the former Egyptian Ambassador was withdrawn in 1982, presented his credentials to President Chaim Herzog today.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Amounts are in millions of dollars; fiscal years run from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Improvising on 5th Ave.
description: Dr. Gerard R. Wolfe, professor and avid traveler to the jungles of the Amazon and Guatemala, faced his most demanding stretch of terrain in Manhattan yesterday, along the Ladies Mile Historic District.

title: TRIAL IS DELAYED IN ZAKHAROV CASE
description: A Federal judge in New York appointed a security officer yesterday to safeguard secret Government papers that would figure in a trial of Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet spy suspect.

title: ROBERT RUSHMORE
description: Robert Rushmore, an author best known for ''The Singing Voice,'' a history of vocal music and its great exponents from earliest recorded times to the present, died Saturday in Poughkeepsie. He was 60 years old and lived in Highland, N.Y.

title: The Big Stakes In Allies' Clash
description: THE harmony reached just one year ago at the Plaza Hotel in New York among the Group of Five major industrial countries on the need to work together to realign exchange rates has degenerated into cacophony on the eve of this year's meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Transfer Rejected
description: The 14 American League baseball team owners voted yesterday in Newport Beach, Calif., to reject the transfer of ownership of the Texas Rangers to a broadcasting company, Bobby Brown, president of the American League, said.

title: 4 Escape From East Germany
description: Two East German workers escaped into West Germany while being shot at by Czech border guards, and two East German guards also fled to the West, the police said today. A Bavarian border police spokesman said the two workers, both 22 years old, fled late Monday across the Czech-West German border. At about the same time, the two soldiers, both armed with machine guns, escaped in uniform into Bavaria across the East-West German border, the police said.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 are adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split paid in February 1986. Shares outstanding for 1986 reflects the pro rata effect of the issuance of 1.35 million shares in public offering in August 1986.

title: INSIDE
description: FISH CONTAMINATION FEARED Solvents that escaped a flooded plant of the Dow Chemical Company in Michigan may have contaminated fish, officials said. Page A15.

title: 'CHARLOTTE AND LULU'
description: THE 13-year-old heroine of Claude Miller's ''Charlotte and Lulu'' lives with her father and a housekeeper who is her de facto stepmother, in a setting that is provincial and drab. She has a rocky but close friendship with Lulu, a much younger girl who is sickly, neglected, innately comical and a perfect foil. She also has a daydream, which Mr. Miller represents as only slightly unreal. She dreams of becoming the helpmate and darling of an exquisite little pianist, a famous prodigy who is her own age.

title: S.E.C. STUDIES CURBS ON COMPUTERIZED TRADES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is studying further regulatory responses to the explosion on Wall Street in computerized trading in stocks, stock index options and index futures, officials at the commission said today.

title: AS THE SMALL FARM FINDS PROSPERITY, CONSUMERS PROFIT
description: DESPITE the continuing crisis in American agriculture, there are promising signs across the country that innovative programs - all on a local level - are helping to keep the family farm alive. The result is a boon to consumers.

title: Suzanne C. Urban-Stern Dies; Held Chanel Executive Post
description: Suzanne C. Urban-Stern, executive director of public relations for Chanel Inc., the fashion, fragrance and cosmetic house, died Sunday night after a fall from a stalled elevator.

title: Metzenbaum's Wife Gains
description: The condition of Shirley Metzenbaum, wife of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, has been upgraded to fair condition after she suffered serious head injuries in a bicycle accident near George Washington's Mount Vernon estate, officials said today.

title: Lin Broadcasting To Sell 10 Stations
description: Lin Broadcasting, the New York-based media company, is putting its 10 radio stations up for sale. Lin Broadcasting also owns seven televison stations and has extensive interests in the cellular radio business and a small speciality publishing operation.

title: PLAY IS HARD WORK FOR CLUB MED STAFF
description: The cry ricochets around the reception area, and a group of two dozen people dressed in bathing suits, shorts, tank tops and flowered sarongs quickly forms as a tour bus pulls to a stop. Pop music starts blaring from a loudspeaker; the group, all smiles, claps to the beat and waves a greeting to the new guests, who spill off the bus with looks of bewilderment on their faces.

title: Southerner Is Needed In '88, Carter Asserts
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Democrats can recapture the White House in 1988 only if they nominate a Southerner.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 23
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $779,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: Chile Holds 3 Suspects In Assassination Attempt
description: Security agents have arrested three people for questioning in the attempted assassination of President Augusto Pinochet this month in which five of his bodyguards were killed, a prosecutor announced today.

title: Borg-Warner Restructuring
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that it would repurchase up to 15 million shares, or 17 percent, of its common stock, as part of a restructuring.

title: Let's Consider Before Rushing Into Drug Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday by Joseph A. Califano Jr., ''A National Attack on Addiction Is Long Overdue,'' misstated the number of Americans who have tried cocaine or crack at least once. It is 20 million.

title: Double Execution Stayed by High Court
description: The Supreme Court granted stays today for two condemned killers scheduled to die in the electric chair Wednesday morning in what would have been the nation's first double execution in more than a decade.

title: DOLLAR CLIMBS AGAIN; BONN REPORTS ARE CITED
description: The dollar moved higher against the West German mark again yesterday in brisk, nervous trading on the foreign exchange markets.

title: RIGHETTI FAILS TO SAVE, BUT WINS INSTEAD
description: Cal Ripken jolted Dave Righetti out of his dream of perfection tonight with a game-tying, save-squandering home run in the ninth inning. Righetti, though, rebounded and helped the Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles, 5-3, in 10 innings.

title: California Girl's Parents Ask for Drug Counseling
description: The parents of a 13-year-old girl who inspired a nationwide debate when she turned them in to the police pleaded not guilty today to charges of cocaine possession and asked for counseling.

title: OJEDA RETURNS, STOPS CARDINALS
description: The afternoon seemed to follow a well-written script, just like so many other days and nights at Shea Stadium this season. The pitching was precise, the offense timely, the defense flawed but occasionally spectacular.

title: FRANCE REPORTED IN TERRORIST DEAL
description: A French weekly newspaper says that the Government negotiated directly this year with a Lebanese group believed responsible for the recent bomb attacks in Paris.

title: ACCUSED JUDGE SAYS IMPEACHMENT IMPERILS JUDICIARY'S INDEPENDENCE
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne told a special Senate impeachment committee today that he was the innocent victim of ''brutal errors'' by his accountants.

title: Malaysia Plans To Toughen Drug Law
description: The Government of Malaysia, which has enacted some of the world's toughest anti-narcotics laws, is planning additional legislation that would allow officials to seize the assets of traffickers.

title: Rangers Re-sign Huber
description: The Rangers and the Devils each moved yesterday to solidify their rosters, with the Rangers re-signing Willie Huber and the Devils making several cuts.

title: TALKS ARE BEGUN ON VIENNA AGENDA
description: A two-week meeting opened here today to prepare an agenda for a new 35-nation European security conference that is to open in November.

title: A TASTE OF THE PAST
description: THE cultivation of apples probably goes back to the Stone Age. Pie crust, in some primitive form, was likely to have been made as early as humans baked dough. Two-crust pies were eaten by the early Greeks and Romans, but are associated with the English, who used their fingers to eat them in the Middle Ages.

title: Christian Bros. Brandy Ads Set
description: Whether it's been successful or not, creating an easy way of ordering a beverage has certainly become a popular ploy.

title: SUSPENSIONS STIR ACCOUNTABILITY ISSUE
description: Allegations that 13 police officers in a Brooklyn precinct extorted cash and drugs from narcotics dealers have highlighted what many police commanders have been warning for months: that drugs and the money they generate pose the key threat to the integrity of the force.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: CERTAIN incredibly delicious foods were never intended to be the principals of a meal, but rather supplements to give greater glory to the main dish.

title: An Ex-Prime Minister Is Acquitted in Turkey
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit was acquitted by an Ankara court today of violating a ban imposed by the former military Government on his involvement in party politics.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5.2 million for the quarter and a tax credit of $2.2 million for the year and an extraordinary credit of $1.1 million related to reorganization proceedings for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After tax credits of $3,547,000 for the quarter and $9,544,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $5,029,000 related to reorganization proceedings for the quarter and year. The latest period results reflect the acquisition of Harris Graphics Corp. in June 1986.

title: DURABLES ORDERS DOWN 2.6%
description: Orders for durable goods, hurt by a steep decline in demand for military equipment, fell 2.6 percent in August for the biggest setback in five months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HARSH WORDS FOR SHOREHAM AT A FEDERAL HEARING
description: Nora Bredes of St. James held out a picture of her 2 1/2-year-old son, Nathan, to three Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission officials who presided at a public hearing today on an emergency evacuation plan for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Yanks' Broadcasts Disappoint
description: The pattern is familiar. During the winter, changes are made in the Yankee team amid promises of improved performance. By the end of the season, the performance is tired, the promise is broken.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $2,162,000.

title: New Rules Limit Lead In Water Supply Pipes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced new limits on the use of lead in piping systems for public drinking water supplies.

title: ABOUT THOSE RECIPES RIGHT OFF THE BOX
description: INSATIABLE recipe collectors are rarely content with a comprehensive library of cookbooks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Chernobyl was a tragic error of man working with the peaceful atom.

title: AIDS DRUG DECISION IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: As thousands of AIDS patients anxiously wait, officials expect to decide today whether to provide a promising drug to more AIDS victims than they had originally planned.

title: Give Central Brooklyn a Boost
description: Despite the gentrification of nearby neighborhoods, Brooklyn's Atlantic Terminal district has for nearly 20 years remained the home of rundown bars and fast-food joints, a hangout for prostitutes and low-lifes. A revival plan goes before the Board of Estimate this week and it deserves enthusiastic support.

title: ST. BART'S MEMBERS APPROVE 47-STORY TOWER
description: The rector and vestry of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church were given a clear mandate yesterday by their congregation to continue their six-year battle to build a high-rise office tower on the Park Avenue grounds of the church.

title: Ryan Sought By NVHomes
description: NVHomes L.P., a Virginia-based partnership that builds and sells family homes and condominiums, said today that it plans a $45-a-share tender offer for Ryan Homes Inc.

title: Navratilova Testifies
description: Martina Navratilova testified yesterday that she ''did my part with the media'' after a loss to Pam Shriver in the United States Open in September 1982 and had a right to tell a photographer, Arthur M. Seitz 3d, to stop taking more pictures of her.

title: Thinner Alphabet Soup
description: Purists who have been resisting the advance of the acronym through the Federal vocabulary may take comfort from developments at the Occupational Health and Safety Administration.

title: Kuwaitis to Try Five Iraqis
description: The state security court is to try five Iraqis accused of trying to assassinate the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, in May 1985, the Kuwait News Agency reported today.

title: REAGAN PLANS TO VETO SANCTIONS BILL
description: A White House spokesman said today that President Reagan intends to veto a bill imposing strict economic sanctions against South Africa, and that Administration officials were trying to gather support on Capitol Hill to sustain that veto.

title: Monsters Thrive Best
description: Here is a press release announcing a new musical that will tell the story of ''Little Red Riding Hood'' from the wolf's point of view. ''A revisionist version'' is promised, ''told from the viewpoint of the much-maligned wolf.''

title: Reagan's Ticking Clock
description: President Reagan is twisting and turning these days in his relations with the Soviet Union, to the irritation of both Pravda and The Wall Street Journal, so maybe he's edging in the right direction.

title: Allen on Fitness Gap
description: According to George Allen, television and junk food are the likely causes of the fitness gap he sees between American kids and their counterparts in the Soviet Union. Allen, the former coach of the Washington Redskins who is chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness, made the observation at a news conference yesterday in Moscow.

title: New Combat Reported Around Afghan Capital
description: Western diplomats said today that new fighting had flared around Kabul, the Afghan capital, and as many as 15 Afghan soldiers were being killed each day.

title: TAKING STOCK IN PRETORIA: BOTHA TALK LEAVES MANY QUESTIONS UNANSWERED
description: Within the sometimes inscrutable world of South Africa's white politics, this is the season when the nation's elite consolidates itself for the new challenges ahead. Yet, when President

title: ACTOR ON STAGE, SCREEN AND TV
description: John C. Becher, an actor who appeared on the Broadway stage, in movies and on television for nearly four decades, died of cancer Sept. 20 at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Cummins Engine Retirement Offer
description: The Cummins Engine Company has announced an early retirement incentive program for most of its United States employees as part of an overall cost-reduction program.

title: SUIT CHARGES ARMY MISPLACED A VIRUS
description: A former scientist at one of the Army's principal biological research centers charged in a lawsuit filed today in Federal District Court here that security procedures at the center were lax. The suit said the Army had never properly accounted for containers lost five years ago containing a ''vaccine and the infectious virus used to produce it.''

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August as another food price spurt was roughly offset by continued drops for energy, the Labor Department said today.

title: SIGNS OF TRAFFIC IN CADAVERS SEEN, RAISING ETHICAL ISSUES
description: The discovery of five human heads in a parcel being shipped from here to Denver is one of several recent indications that an underground market may be developing for human organs and cadavers, some medical and legal authorities say.

title: Righetti Gets His 42d Save
description: The Yankees held their ''magic number'' at three tonight and Dave Righetti lowered his to three.

title: Privacy of Cellular Telephones Can Be Protected
description: To the Editor:

title: KREMLIN EASES RULE ON TRADE
description: The Soviet Union has announced ambitious measures to decentralize and enhance its foreign trade, giving almost 100 ministries and enterprises the right to make deals directly with foreign partners.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
KEY SECTIONS OF CHIRAC'S U.N. TALK
description: Following are key sections of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's speech today to the General Assembly, as distributed in translation by the French Mission:

title: Hunts' Plea Against Judge
description: Companies owned by the Hunt brothers asked a Federal appeals court today to remove District Judge Barefoot Sanders of Dallas from all proceedings involved with their bankruptcy case.

title: I.M.F. FILLING A KEY POST
description: Jacob A. Frenkel, a leading international economist who has taught for the last 13 years at the University of Chicago, will become research chief at the International Monetary Fund, succeeding William C. Hood, a former deputy finance minister of Canada, who is retiring.

title: PLASTOMEDICAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After deducting an extraordinary non-recurring item of $100,000.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,417,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The latest 9 months' results include a $1.6 million pre-tax provision for a loss on the sale of its Canadian subsidiary. The year-earlier 9 months includes a $6.6 million provision for a loss on the closing of production facilities.

title: BALLET AS PICASSO SAW IT
description: THE new Musee Picasso in Paris does more than offer a retrospective survey of works by one of the 20th century's greatest painters in a tastefully remodeled, 17th-century mansion. It also contains much of specific interest to dance lovers, as I discovered on a recent visit.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Green moss grows on the hand-split shingles on my house, primarily in shady areas. Rubbing with a stiff wire brush parallel to the grain removes the moss and some of the black spots. I use the brush dry, but am concerned about the moss coming back. The shingles have no finish. Should I use a solution of bleach and water, one to four, with the brush, and would a clear wood preservative inhibit growth? A.Definitely use a bleach solution in scrubbing, to help remove the growth and help prevent regrowth. I suggest a stiff bristle brush, not wire. Protect eyes with goggles. Scrub the solution on, let it dry on the surface and rinse off with lots of plain water. When the wood is completely dry, applying a good preservative that contains a water repellent will help discourage moss and mildew. Q.Our books got wet from a leaky roof, and they smell of mildew. The odor pervades the room, particularly in damp weather. Airing the room helps temporarily. Do you have any suggestions? A.A most effective cure is to open the books outside in direct sunlight. Turn the pages several times a day, for several days if possible. Sprinkling cornstarch between the pages may help. Air out other objects in the room, too - mildew odor may come from such things as the shelves that held the books. Have upholstered furniture cleaned; clean rugs and hangings, and wipe wood surfaces with rubbing alcohol. Q.The return duct in our air-conditioning system is noisy.

title: Trade Triumph, Trade Challenge
description: It took four years just to negotiate agreement for a new round of world trade negotiations. But 74 nations have now agreed to a broader sweep of bargaining than ever attempted before. The time is ripe. Last weekend's initiative in Punta del Este, Uruguay, was promising - if President Reagan can persuade Congress to go along.

title: Treasury Bonds Rise Again
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds improved for the third consecutive day, spurred by reports of good demand for new four-year Treasury notes and weaker-than-expected car sales in mid-September.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said the Justice Department had told it and Triangle Industries that it did not object to the previously announced sale of American Can's packaging business to Triangle.

title: Reese Leads by 4 In Met Tournament
description: Don Reese, one of the host pros, shot a five-under-par 67 today to take a four-stroke lead after the second round of the 60th Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship.

title: Why Imperil U.N. Reform?
description: The United Nations is facing a crisis. The question is: what kind of crisis?

title: Goetz Lawyers Request Removal of Prosecutor
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz, who shot four youths on a subway train in 1984, have asked that a prosecutor be taken off the case because they intend to call him as a witness.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AT LEAST 3 MYSTERY WITNESSES TO BE HEARD AT FRIEDMAN TRIAL
description: The Government has at least three mystery witnesses in its corruption case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and four co-defendants.

title: HOME BEAT
description: WHITE-PAINTED wicker furniture speaks of summer, but natural wicker is year-round, especially to devotees.

title: BID FOR MONEY BEGINS IN PLAN TO KEEP REBUILDING SUBWAYS
description: Seeking to continue rebuilding the subways, transit officials have begun a campaign to win financing this fall for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $8.3 billion, five-year proposed capital program.

title: HAITIANS' NEXT UPHILL BATTLE: WINNING THE TOURISTS
description: Some people were drifting in the shallow waters of the quiet, sun-splashed bay on air mattresses. Others were snorkeling. A few were pedaling around on gawky, bright yellow floating tricycles.

title: Students Must Be Forgiven for Their Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 6
JAZZ: TONY WILLIAMS BAND
description: TONY WILLIAMS was still in his teens when he first made a splash in New York jazz circles. But already his work was superbly integrated. Mr. Williams's thunderous but poetic drumming, which dealt in shifting planes of rhythm and color, abrupt dynamic changes and an almost atomized brand of swing, was expanded upon in his compositions, especially the tunes he contributed to several of Miles Davis's mid-60's albums and to his own disks for Blue Note.

title: Too Hot
description: A letter in the new issue of The New England Journal of Medicine from three Cincinnati physicians, Robert J. Toltzis, David J. Morton and Myron C. Gerson, describing an exotic hazard of a common treadmill heart test in which the patient is first injected with the radioisotope thallium-201.

title: Federal Agency Selects Adviser on Asset Sales
description: Federal agencies that expect to sell assets next year to help reduce the Federal budget deficit have begun selecting financial advisers for those sales.

title: TESTIMONY ON BRIBERY IS TO WIDEN
description: A key figure in the bribery trial of New York City officials and in the continuing investigation of similar municipal graft in Chicago has agreed to testify against others accused in the New York case.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Robert Neuman, a senior vice president, has been made a creative director at Ogilvy & Mather, New York.

title: BankAmerica Ends Oregon Bank Deal
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had ended its agreement to buy the Oregon Bank, Oregon's third largest, for $57 million.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Gannett Foundation to Give Fellowships to 12 Reporters
description: A $1 million program to assist newspaper and broadcast correspondents newly assigned to Washington was announced today by the Gannett Foundation.

title: NEW YORKERS AMONG THE MAGNOLIAS
description: There were a lot of things Carole Brown didn't like about Atlanta when she and her husband Floyd moved here last year from Brooklyn. The pizza wasn't crispy enough, it was hard to find a bakery open on Sunday morning and the shopping was, well, it was all retail.

title: James Conlon Named To Cologne Opera Post
description: James Conlon has been appointed the chief conductor of the Cologne Opera for four years, beginning with the 1989-90 season, the opera said today.

title: Sweet Thoughts
description: When Coach Dan Henning of the Falcons got to his office Tuesday morning, magnificent visions of Atlanta's come-from-behind 37-35 victory over Dallas still quite fresh, he found a 10-pound box of candy and a bouquet of flowers. From whom? The Washington Redskins, that's whom.

title: Knudsen to Sell Parts of Unit
description: Knudsen Foods Inc., the troubled company that is the West Coast's largest dairy products concern, said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell many of its western division operations in California and Nevada to Kraft Inc. and Hughes Markets Inc.

title: High Yen Cuts Toyota's Profit
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its earnings fell 14.9 percent in the latest year as a result of the yen's surge in value.

title: GORBACHEV HAILS THE STOCKHOLM PACT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today hailed the Stockholm agreement on European security as a ''major step'' that paves the way for reducing international tension. He said it showed how detente must be built in the future.

title: Propping Up Uranium, With Tax Dollars
description: It sounds like an impossible dream: to organize a worldwide uranium cartel so well disciplined it could raise energy prices - and then get the U.S. Department of Energy to enforce it. Too crude and too obvious? Maybe, but it's not impossible. Thanks to slick maneuvering by Senator Pete Domenici, Republican from uranium-producing New Mexico, there's a real chance such a cartel plan will become law. It's up to the Senate to stop it.

title: HERS
description: I ALWAYS wanted to marry a prince. And she did it. Some would have hated her for it, but I am happily obsessed with Diana, Princess of Wales. I, who would be mortified to be caught reading a fashion magazine, am a moth to a flame when Diana is featured. Waiting in supermarket checkout lines has lost its tedium, because there's sure to be something about Di on the rack beside the register. I devour it; my favorite outfits are the old-fashioned Scarlett O'Hara gowns, all tiny waist and ruffles. If I were a princess, that's what I would wear.

title: Chemical Raises Stake in Horizon
description: The Chemical New York Corporation has raised its stake in the Horizon Bancorp to 24.99 percent, or 2.42 million shares, from 17 percent.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for 12wks to Sept 7
Advertising; Quaker Oats Assigns Golden Grains Brands
description: The Quaker Oats Company announced yesterday that it was assigning two big-billing brands from its recently acquired Golden Grain Macaroni Company to Chiat/Day, San Francisco. At the same time it is sending its Quaker Puffed Wheat and Puffed Rice brands and a couple of new products to Geers, Gross Advertising in New York.

title: Senate Orders a Study Of Panama Drug Trade
description: The Senate voted 53 to 46 today to direct the Central Intelligence Agency to report on whether the military forces of Panama traffic in drugs and arms and abuse human rights.

title: Kaiser Cement Considers Sale
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation said today that it was considering the sale of all or parts of the company and that it had retained the First Boston Corporation as an adviser.

title: 19TH GAME ADJOURNED IN CHESS TITLE MATCH
description: Anatoly Karpov kept up his strong comeback in the world chess championship today, threatening to even the score against the champion, Gary Kasparov.

title: Jury Selected for Trial Of Donovan in Bronx
description: Jury selection was completed yesterday in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: 'OUR WORLD' RECALLS '69
description: ''OUR WORLD'' is a retrospective. What did things look like in, say, the summer of 1969? More accurately, what did things look like on television? ''Our World,'' the new ABC magazine program at 8 o'clock tonight, uses old film to show us. There are worse ways to spend an hour than in watching.

title: COLORFUL SWITCH PLATES
description: THERE is a new look in switch plates. Instead of the traditional square shape, with screw holes above and below the switch, the new one is dome-shaped and does not need screws.

title: Tandon Executive Quits
description: The Tandon Corporation, which makes personal computers and disk drives, said that H. L. Sparks, senior vice president of sales and marketing, had resigned for personal reasons. No successor has been named to replace Mr. Sparks, who was hired last November to introduce Tandon's new lines of microcomputers to domestic dealers.

title: CBS AND F.C.C. MEET ON CHANGE OF CONTROL ISSUE
description: Representatives of CBS Inc. met today with officials of the Federal Communications Commission and a key member of Congress who have raised questions about whether the recent management shake-up at CBS constituted a transfer of control of ownership of the company.

title: Pacific Stereo Deal Collapses
description: The Pacific Stereo Corporation, once the world's largest retailer of brand-name stereo equipment, said today that plans for the company's reorganization by the U.S. Electronic Group had fallen through. As a result, Pacific said liquidation of remaining furniture, fixtures and leases would begin around Oct. 1.

title: Indications Of Upturn
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds, which had been declining for the last 10 weeks, showed signs of a turnaround in the week ended yesterday.

title: TOGO REPORTS ROUTING AN ATTACK BY 50 DISSIDENTS
description: About 50 dissidents attacked a military barracks that serves as the residence of the President of this West African nation, military officials said today. The officials said the attackers had been routed by security forces.

title: Go West, Democrats
description: Though the courting season by Presidential hopefuls is about to begin in earnest, it's not too early for Democratic Party strategists to decide which states should receive the bulk of the millions of campaign dollars for television commercials, staff and get-out-the-vote drives. Strategists must plan how the candidate who emerges from the Democratic National Convention can win at least 270 electoral votes.

title: REAGAN STUMPS FOR 2 GUBERNATORIAL CANDIDATES IN THE MIDDLE WEST
description: Attempting to bolster the gubernatorial campaigns of a black man in Michigan and a white woman in Nebraska, President Reagan said today that the Republican Party was the ''true party'' of opportunity and ''the party of all Americans.''

title: Access to Reading
description: Americans for Constitutional Freedom has commissioned a survey of American attitudes toward access to reading material, and it says the results are ''a pleasant surprise.''

title: Judge Orders Payments On Waste Site on Coast
description: The owners of the Stringfellow Acid Pits and many of the companies that used them as a dump for hazardous waste should pay to clean the area and stop leaks into nearby water supplies, a court-appointed overseer has ruled.

title: When Harry Hopkins Was a Presidential Aide
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Missionary Dies; Detained by Kenyans
description: An American missionary detained on security charges died today at the headquarters of Kenya's Criminal Investigation Department, security sources said. The United States Embassy confirmed an American death.

title: Chief Faces New Era At First Pennsylvania
description: George A. Butler has been with the First Pennsylvania Bank through thick and thin. The thick came in the days of heady expansion in the early 1970's, as First Pennsylvania moved from a commercial bank doing business locally in Philadelphia to become the 20th-largest commercial bank in the nation. The thin came after the expansion unwound in the late 1970's and the bank survived its mistakes with a $1.5 billion Federal bailout.

title: INSIDE
description: LITERACY HIGH BUT LIMITED Americans have a high basic literacy rate, a national study said, but many young adults have a limited ability to use reading in daily life.

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The tragic events in Istanbul, Karachi and Paris prove once again that terrorism has become the systematic weapon of a war that knows no borders or seldom has a face.'' -Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France. [ A10:5. ]

title: U.S. STUDY ON ADULT LITERACY FINDS THE RESULTS ARE MIXED
description: Ninety-five out of a hundred young adults can read as well as the average fourth-grader, the level educators call basic literacy, a national survey has found. But the literacy skills of many of them are extremely limited, the independent experts who conducted the survey said today.

title: A ROOKIE STOPS METS AGAIN
description: Come see the showboat Mets, see the big, brass team from New York dance and hug and outmug and overpower everyone in the way. Ball parks are filled and bristling when the Mets are in town. That's the popular thinking because the Mets have had more than 100 such days and they will have more. But first. . . .

title: May to Sell Horne

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES RISE 1.7%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 1.7 percent in mid-September from record levels last year, the nation's biggest manufacturers reported here today. Aggressive consumer incentive programs, in the form of below-market-rate financing, propelled the sales this year and in 1985.

title: Now on Tour: Eastern League
description: It's a national sport of China and not totally unknown in the United States, so there's not much surprise that a group of young Chinese athletes would be invited to this country for a series of games against American youngsters. For the first game, in New York today, the home team may be at something of a disadvantage. The New York players, a five-borough team of 11- and 12-year-olds assembled by the Police Athletic League, have had only one practice together, while the visitors have been hard at it for the last two months.

title: OIL CAN'S RETURN
description: ''Watch it, 'Can,'' called Jim Rice, the Boston outfielder. The damp T-shirt he had just pulled off and tossed in the Red Sox clubhouse was about to land, not in the laundry bin, but on the head of Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, who with eyes lowered, had walked by and intersected the plane of the flying T-shirt.

title: Shanghai Stock Market?
description: Shanghai is studying the possibility of opening a stock market for the growing number of enterprises raising funds by offering shares, the official New China News Agency said today. Since last year, 749 factories in Shanghai have issued stock, the report said.

title: GOTTI'S COURTROOM FOE: Diane Frances Giacalone
description: John Gotti and Diane F. Giacalone both have ties to Ozone Park in Queens. There the similarity ends.

title: WHEN THERE'S A GAP IN THE SILVERWARE, IT OFTEN CAN BE FILLED
description: EVEN in the best-run households silverware can disappear - into the trash with the leftovers, perhaps, or down the garbage disposal and mangled beyond repair. Finding a duplicate may not be difficult if a retailer is willing to sell a single knife, fork, spoon or serving piece from stock. It is harder to find a replacement when the missing piece is no longer being made.

description: Louise Bushnell, a retired executive and volunteer worker, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

Her award consists of a gold medal, $12,000 in cash, a Carnegie Hall debut, a debut recording on the Vox Cum Laude label, a contract with a European manager and more than 70 concert and recital engagements.

title: POLL FINDS 40% OF YOUNG DOCTORS ADMIT DRUG USE
description: Nearly 40 percent of physicians under the age of 40 admitted in a survey that they had used marijuana or cocaine with friends, and a quarter of doctors of all ages said they had recently treated themselves with mind-affecting drugs.

title: HOUSE, 309 TO 106, VOTES PLAN TO CUT DEFICIT $15 BILLION
description: Fashioning its own hodgepodge of budget ''gimmickry,'' the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a package intended to reduce the 1987 deficit by $15.1 billion.

title: Coach Suspended
description: Cedrick Hardman, a former all-pro lineman, has been suspended from his position as coach at Laguna Beach (Calif.) High School after being arrested on charges of cocaine possession.

description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $2,640,000 for the quarter and $2,394,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary tax credit of $1.2 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $523,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 9 months.

description: After a jetliner on its way to Madrid made an emergency landing at the Miami airport, the 20-year-old son of a Nicaraguan official and a Cuban family of three asked for political asylum today.

title: DUARTE TO SEEK MORE U.S. AID
description: Faced with a perception that he has lost ground politically, President Jose Napoleon Duarte says he will visit Washington next month to lobby members of Congress for support.

title: PALESTINIAN RESURGENCE SEEN IN SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: An air raid Tuesday by Israeli jets has pointed up the fact that Palestinian guerrillas have moved their positions closer to Beirut and the main coastal highway linking the capital with southern Lebanon.

title: OFFICIALS SAY ASPIN ASKED ABOUT BROTHER'S MILITARY CONTRACT, FIND NO FAULT
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee has approached both Pentagon and New York State officials in behalf of his brother, a military contractor, according to Federal and state officials.

description: Representative Thomas J. Manton was elected chairman of the Queens Democratic Party last night, a post held for 12 years by the late Donald R. Manes, who resigned last January after being implicated in the city corruption scandal.

title: En Garde for Moiseyev

title: Bridge: Brazilian Star Making a Bid For Second World Pair Title
description: A Brazilian star who won the world pair championship in 1978 was making a strong bid to become the first player ever to win that title twice when play resumed here this afternoon.

title: Japan Credit For Mexico
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan has agreed to extend Mexico $1 billion worth of credit for three major industrial projects, Mexico's Finance Minister, Gustavo Petrocioli, said today.

title: RECIPE FOR APPLE PIE
description: Following is the corrected version of a recipe for apple pie published in The Living Section yesterday. Cousin Ruth's Pie The dough: 1 stick unsalted butter #1 to 1 1/2 cups sifted flour, approximately #1 teaspoon vanilla 1/4 cup ice water, approximately.

title: SABOTEURS DISRUPT COMMUTING IN TOKYO
description: Saboteurs cut cables and communication lines of the Japan National Railways, disrupting train service during the morning rush hour and inconveniencing an estimated one million Tokyo commuters.

title: HEINZ ALBERT PINNER
description: Heinz Albert Pinner, a lawyer who fled Nazi Germany and helped win restitution for Hitler's victims, died here of cancer on Sept. 17. He was 93 years old.

description: b-Net income

title: 7 DRUG RING SUSPECTS SEIZED
description: Federal agents seized $3.5 million in cash and 10 pounds of cocaine and arrested seven Colombian nationals who they said were responsible for a large part of the cocaine traffic in the metropolitan area, authorities said yesterday.

The Morning Line on the Bench, as Revised
description: The Supreme Court's internal chemistry will doubtless be affected by the changes in membership that the Senate has approved, scholars agree, but its ideological balance is unlikely to shift dramatically unless another aging member steps down.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IN DRUG-WRACKED 77th PRECINCT, POLICE SUSPENSIONS DRAW VARIED REACTIONS
description: Brooklyn's 77th Precinct would seem to encompass two distinct worlds.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev signaled a shift in the Soviet position on the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty in a letter to President Reagan last week, Administration officials said today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: YEARS ago, when few homes had insulation in their outside walls, no one worried about vapor barriers - there was no need for them. But now homes are better insulated, making it necessary to install a vapor barrier wherever there is insulation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table on Sept. 18 with an article about universities with the largest endowments described the figures incorrectly. The endowment totals were in millions of dollars.

title: Tax Increase in Chicago Averts Threat of Layoffs
description: The Chicago City Council, facing a budget deficit that Mayor Harold Washington said would force him to lay off 11,000 city workers, today approved an $80 million property tax increase.

title: LEGAL AID SOCIETY TO SEEK BAN ON ADMITTING NEW JAIL INMATES
description: With New York City's jails crowded by hundreds of prisoners above their capacity, the Legal Aid Society said yesterday that it would draft a request for a court injunction to block all new admissions.

title: EXILES FROM TAIWAN OPPOSITION
description: Three Taiwan exiles here said today that they were forming a political party to oppose the Taiwan Government.

title: JUDGE ORDERS LONGSHOREMEN TO PAY $8 MILLION
description: A longshoremen's union that refused to service ships carrying Russian-made goods in protest against the movement of Soviet troops into Afghanistan must pay more than $8 million in damages to an importing company, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: McAuliffe Named a Trustee
description: The husband of the teacher-astronaut Christa C. McAuliffe was named a state university trustee today, replacing the controversial nomination of Max Hugel, a race track owner. Gov. John H. Sununu's selection of Steven McAuliffe, a lawyer, was unanimously approved by the Executive Council.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AGENCY IS FAULTED ON ITS CUBA POLICY
description: A top State Department official joined members of Congress today in criticizing the Immigration and Naturalization Service over its policy toward immigration from Cuba.

title: POLICE PUSH HUNT FOR SLAYING SUSPECT
description: More than 100 police officers and Federal agents searched woodlands and homes today for a murder suspect who they believe may have been wounded in a gun battle.

title: Replay the Replay
description: In a major concession to technology and fairness, professional football agreed this year to let instant-replay cameras second-guess the referees on the field. Three weeks into the season, the new system seems to be adding confusion without contributing much fairness.

title: 2 SIDES WRAP UP ARGUMENTS OVER TEXTBOOKS IN TENNESSEE
description: Arguments ended today in a lawsuit that pits seven fundamentalist families against their school board and the state over the content of textbooks.

title: ROSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1986
description: The Economy

title: A FIRST FOR SPORTS? 3 FOOTBALL BOOKS MAKE THE BEST-SELLER LIST
description: Few books about football have become best sellers, but this Sunday, the first Sunday of autumn, three football books will appear on The New York Times nonfiction best seller list - apparently the first time three books about any sport have ever been simultaneous best sellers.

title: Soviet Team Gains in Title Volleyball
description: The Soviet Union, winner of six of the last 10 world championships, defeated Taiwan today in straight sets to open the 11th men's world volleyball championships.

title: A G.O.P. EFFORT TO BLOCK TAX BILL IS FRUSTRATED
description: A last-ditch effort by a band of Republicans to block the tax revision bill when it comes up for a final vote in the House of Representatives on Thursday was apparently blunted today by the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel.

title: Bills Emerge That Aren't for Passing
description: The end of a Congressional session is a strange season, when normal rules of legislative behavior do not always apply. Bills can be brought up for a whole range of reasons, and passing them is not always the main goal.

title: Marine Corps Hero
description: They gathered in the hospital dining hall. An employee played the national anthem on a piano. An invocation was given and words of praise expressed.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. Chairman Sees Harm in Mega-Mergers
description: ''Outside of the fact that the largest merger in the world seems to be falling apart before our eyes, both internally and externally, the whole megamerger idea has demeaned and hurt our business,'' said Edward N. Ney, chairman of Young & Rubicam, which has been the largest single American agency and got there with the help of quite a number of acquisitions. He made his remarks in a speech yesterday to the San Francisco Advertising Club.

title: J.P. STEVENS BUYBACK
description: J.P. Stevens & Company said it would begin a cash tender offer for up to 2.5 million of its common shares for prices between $34 and $38 a share. The company said it would select a price to enable it to buy up to one million shares and added that it might buy as much as 2.5 million shares. The tender offer will expire Oct. 22 unless extended.

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $396,000 for the quarter and 9 months, relating to the early extinguishment of debt.

description: Tears came to Officer Steven McDonald's eyes as he received the telephone call in the Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday morning from President Reagan.

description: INTO the prime-time world of ruthless vintners, resurrected oil tycoons, ardent young doctors and big-city lawyers, at long last the decorators have come.

title: Screen the Housing, Not the Children, for Lead Poisoning
description: To the Editor:

title: THOUGHTS ON THE ROSE AS NATIONAL FLOWER
description: THE rose is in the news right now, it seems, although interest in roses goes back to the very earliest days of gardening. It is one of the oldest flowers in cultivation, starting in China some 5,000 years ago. In medieval Europe it was the symbol of Divine Grace, made visible in the rose windows of Chartres. One kind of rose or another is already the official flower of the District of Columbia and the states of Georgia, Iowa, North Carolina, North Dakota and New York.

title: LINK IN PARIS BOMBINGS
description: The French police said today that they had found evidence linking bombings here to a brother of the terrorists' suspected leader.

title: Snohomish County Refunding
description: The Snohomish County, Wash., Public Utility District is offering $311.5 million of electric revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 8.18 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: INCREASES IN POTENCY OF MARIJUANA PROMPT NEW WARNINGS FOR YOUTHS
description: Parent groups and drug counselors are cautioning that marijuana, the nation's most widely used illegal drug, is now two to seven times more potent than it was in the early 1970's, and that a teen-ager's first brush with it today may be a far more powerful experience than it was a generation ago.

title: 4 Gold Medals Won by Chinese
description: Li Ning of China became the first quadruple gold medalist in the 10th Asian Games today, winning the men's floor exercises and rings, as his compatriots collected seven other gymnastics medals.

title: ANTI-COLLISION DEVICES: FINDING AN END TO DELAYS
description: Many hurdles must still be surmounted before airline fleets carry anti-collision devices, and political and legal problems might cause more delay than any remaining technical snags, most experts agree.

title: Talks Planned in Peking On Chinese-Soviet Ties
description: A ninth round of talks aimed at improving relations between China and the Soviet Union will begin in Peking next month, the first formal discussions between the Communist powers since Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, called for better relations in July, Chinese officials said today.

title: TOO-PERFECT HOUSEWIFE IN 'DANCING IN THE DARK'
description: TO all outward appearances, Edna Cormick (Martha Henry) is the perfect housewife. In her own mind she's not yet perfect, though she's working on it. As if living in a fantasy world where perfection is possible, Edna moves serenely around her spotless house, making sure that the corners of the mirrors are as free of smudges as the centers and that not a tuft of offending lint hides under the bed she shares with Harry.

title: ROCK: BOB SEGER CONCERT
description: ROCK-AND-ROLL concerts rarely evoke the sense of homey togetherness that Bob Seger, the 41-year-old singer and songwriter from Detroit, elicited at his Madison Square Garden concert on Tuesday evening. At a time when rock music is being attacked from many sides as a demonic force in American society, Mr. Seger stands as a reassuring reminder that the music can also be as wholesome as apple pie without seeming wishy-washy.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an apple pie recipe in The Living Section yesterday omitted an ingredient. A corrected version appears today on page C11.

title: Fed Approves Underwriting
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved an unusual structure that would allow a subsidiary of a commercial bank holding company to participate in a public securities underwriting.

title: SPOTLIGHT ON LOANS FOR MEXICO
description: New loans for Mexico have developed as one of the principal issues facing the conferences among world finance ministers that begin here Thursday, participating officials said.

title: Iowa Farm Value Off
description: The value of Iowa farmland dropped 7.9 percent in the last six months, but the decline was not as steep as in the period a year ago, according to the Iowa Realtors Land Institute. According to the survey, the average value of an acre of several types of farmland in Iowa ranged from $583 to $1,056.

title: Technology; Long-Distance Phone Access
description: ALLEN J. PORTNOY picked up the phone Tuesday in Huntsville, Ala., and dialed Ross Spicer, an executive vice president for Southwestern Bell, at the telephone company's headquarters in St. Louis. Nothing too special about that. People have been making telephone calls ever since Alexander Graham Bell spoke to Thomas A. Watson on March 10, 1876. But Tuesday's call nevertheless prompted one Southwestern Bell spokesman, Timothy E. Clark, to say: ''It was a Watson-Bell type thing.''

title: GLUM NEWS FOR U.S. APPAREL
description: The annual gathering of the garment and textile industry, called the Bobbin Show, brought nearly 30,000 delegates to Atlanta this week, hoping dearly for the success of American-made apparel.

title: DYSON PLEDGES HE WILL WAGE VIGOROUS RACE
description: John S. Dyson, who lost the Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination two weeks ago, declared yesterday that he would wage an active campaign as the Liberal Party candidate and as a ''mainstream'' Democrat.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS SENATE SEATE IN LOUISIANA SATURDAY
description: Representative W. Henson Moore wants voters to see the lever next to his name on the voting machine as a sword of righteousness.

title: House Panel Clears An Immigration Bill But a Fight Looms
description: The House Rules Committee voted today to send to the House floor a long-delayed bill seeking major changes in immigration law, paving the way for a fight over whether it will even be considered.

title: KEY RATES
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PUPPETS Janie Geiser's Jottay Theater, an unusual puppet company from Atlanta, opens tonight at that special center for unusual avant-garde and experimental performance arts, the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street (924-0077).

title: Suffolk County Chief Vetoes Drug Test Ban
description: The Suffolk County Executive vetoed a bill today that would have banned mandatory drug testing for employees of the county and private companies.

title: Woman Drops Request For Test of Ex-Husband
description: A woman who opposes allowing her two daughters to make overnight visits to their divorced father, who is homosexual, today dropped her request that a court order him to take an AIDS test.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A SYRACUSE GATHERING FOR BLACK ALUMNI
description: IN MANY respects, it was a typical, mid-September weekend on the Syracuse University campus. The air had begun to take on the invigorating crispness of fall, and there was the bustle of activity through the main quadrangle as students hurried to class or made plans for the weekend.

title: LOGIMETRICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on debt restructuring of $471,242 and a tax credit of $145,820. c-Net loss

title: RECITAL: LUIGI TAGLIAVINI, ORGANIST
description: LUIGI FERDINANDO TAGLIAVINI may not be as well known to the general public as some other organists; that's a process that takes place almost exclusively these days through extensive recordings. But the Italian organist is well known to his peers: he teaches at the University of Fribourg in Switzerland, in Bologna, where he lives, and at special organ academies here and there; he prepares scholarly editions, and he performs widely in Europe and North America. Last year he was the winner of the annual International Performer of the Year award given by the New York City chapter of the American Guild of Organists, and Monday night the chapter presented him in recital at St. Michael's Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street.

title: SECOND BID IS REJECTED BY ALLIED
description: The directors of the Allied Stores Corporation yesterday rejected a tender offer of $58 a share from the Campeau Corporation, a Canadian real estate developer, and said they would consider a possible restructuring and the sale of all or parts of the company. Some analysts said they thought that Allied would buy back stock.

title: Discontents
description: For some time now there has been subdued but growing evidence that all is not well in the Foreign Service. For the most part, dissatisfaction has been limited to hallway mutterings and an occasional internal memo.

title: House Liability Insurance Bill
description: Under pressure of rapidly rising liability insurance costs, the House on Tuesday approved an expansion of the rights of business, government and professional organizations to save money by forming groups for self-insurance or to buy insurance.

title: IN PRISTINE PARK, CHORUS OF NAYS TO DEVELOPMENT
description: Much of what is now the 70,000-acre Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area remains as pristine as it was when the Lenni Lenape Indians knew it centuries ago.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include a $2.4 million provision on a foreign claim taken as a result of economic measures imposed by the Venezuelan Government on July 18.

title: N.C.A.A. WILL IMPLEMENT POSTSEASON DRUG TESTING
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today disclosed that some athletes will be selected for drug testing on the basis of performance in 74 postseason championships and 19 football bowl games.

title: FINANCING THE QUEST FOR A BETTER MUG
description: ''UNTIL now, I thought I was on a lunatic fringe,'' says Keith Baxter of Wauwatosa, Wis., a lawyer by day and inventor on his own time who has just received an Innovative Design Fund Grant for his thermal-dynamic coffee cup insulated with beeswax. ''I.D.F. gave me credibility by putting their check behind my idea,'' says Mr. Baxter, whose design is based on principles borrowed from solar-heated housing.

title: From the Sideline
description: Dissatisfied with the new ''Monday Night Football'' duo of Al Michaels and Frank Gifford? So was a guy who dropped by the Jets' camp yesterday.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LUCKY GETS OFFER FROM EDELMAN
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, offered yesterday to acquire Lucky Stores Inc., a California-based retail and specialty chain, for about $1.79 billion, the company said.

title: GRAND MET IN TALKS TO SELL LIGGETT
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the Liggett Group Inc., the ailing United States tobacco concern that markets the L&M, Lark and Eve brands and is a major seller of generic cigarettes.

title: U.S.-Japan Air Talks
description: Japanese and American negotiators began talks today to revise a 34-year-old civil air transport agreement, an American Embassy official said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said Patricia Shontz Longe, a professor of business administration at the University of Michigan and a member of seven other company boards, would resign as a director to reduce her board participations.

title: Nixon's Advice
description: With relations with the Soviet Union at a critical juncture amid talk of a summit meeting and the matter of Nicholas S. Daniloff, President Reagan is quietly seeking the counsel of a man even many Democrats concede probably knows more about the Soviet mind than most other living Americans: former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: U.S. NOW SEEKING DANILOFF TRADE INVOLVING SOME SOVIET DISSIDENTS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing a possible arrangement that would allow Nicholas S. Daniloff, an American journalist charged with espionage in Moscow, to return home, Administration officials said today.

title: FLORIDA EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $53,000 and $502,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $895,000 for the quarter and $1,110,000 for the year. The company said its results for the latest fourth quarter included about $1 million in non-recurring costs related to unusually high engine and engine- component overhaul costs and maintenance tied to four aircraft, the start- up of a maintenance base away from Orlando, Fla., and the expansion and training of pilot and maintenance personnel in anticipation of an increase of the jet fleet to 15 from 11.

title: Team Abandons Effort To Rescue Porpoises
description: A team that has been trying to rescue porpoises from an ocean inlet dammed by a glacier began breaking camp today, vowing to return next spring to see if any of the sea mammals survived.

title: U.S. Accepts Answer Of Japan on Minorities
description: The United States Government said today that it accepted Japan's explanation that remarks by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that outraged some members of American minorities were taken out of context in two newspapers and not intended as a racial slur.

title: Students Must Be Forgiven for Their Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1986.

title: BOOKS FOR THE TIMES
description: THE NAZI DOCTORS: Medical Killing and the Psychology of Genocide. By Robert Jay Lifton. 561 pages. Basic. $19.95.

title: CHIRAC SEES NO STATE ROLE IN BOMBINGS
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France said today that France had no proof that any government was behind the recent wave of terrorist bombings in Paris.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 8
description: b-Includes a loss of $126,500 for the quarter and net of $79,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company restated its latest second quarter and 6-month net income figures.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: JUDGE SAYS HE IS 'INCLINED' TO GRANT BAIL FOR CHAMBERS
description: A Manhattan judge said yesterday that he was ''inclined'' to set bail for Robert E. Chambers Jr. but put off a decision until Monday to allow the prosecution time to interview some of the 40 people who wrote to the court in the defendant's behalf.

title: Inman Will Head Electronics Venture
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman said yesterday that he would become chairman of a new holding company that would acquire military electronics companies and develop ''leading-edge technology.''

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Hey, Yogi!
description: Manager George Bamberger of the Brewers, on Boston's drive to clinch the division title: ''I hope they don't win it in Milwaukee. That means we lost.''

title: Pretoria Says Never
description: With all that Americans have learned of South Africa in the last few years, I suspect that the reality of life there still escapes us. Because we live in an open society protected by law, and because South Africans seem like us, we cannot altogether imagine the cruelty, the lawlessness employed to maintain the power of the white minority.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HOSTILE OFFER DROPPED FOR ANDERSON, CLAYTON
description: The battle for Anderson, Clayton & Company apparently ended today as a hostile bidding team withdrew its $697 million tender offer.

title: A PREVIEW OF THE OPERA 'X'
description: ANTHONY DAVIS'S ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X)'' will receive its first staged production this weekend at the New York City Opera. Those who would like an advance television preview might wish to tune in the first in the Arts & Entertainment Network's ''Guggenheim: Works and Process'' series, which will be shown tonight at 9:30.

title: BERES INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Which Welfare Mothers?
description: Is welfare a virtue, a temporary humane bridge between poverty and self-sufficiency? Yes. Is welfare a vice, a dispiriting instrument of long-term dependency? Also yes. The danger is that by generalizing about the vice, Congress will now jeopardize the virtue. But it's not too late in the session for action on welfare that can save families, dignity and money.

title: EFFORTS TO REVISE NEW YORK'S TAXES ARE FACING UNEXPECTED PROBLEMS
description: Efforts to revise New York State's tax code to conform with proposed Federal tax changes have encountered unforeseen political and economic problems that present some of the state's most difficult financial decisions since the state and city fiscal crisis of a decade ago.

title: NEW BILL PUSHES DRUG FIGHT
description: The Department of Agriculture is seeking legislation to give agents of the United States Forest Service wider authority to combat the growing of marijuana in national forests, a department official said tonight.

title: U.S. REPORTER CLEARED IN ITALY
description: An Italian criminal court acquitted an American journalist today on charges of aiding and abetting an official who purportedly provided her with a secret document that formed the basis of an article in The New York Times in 1984.

title: GIRL, 11, FOUND STRANGLED NEAR SCHOOL IN NORWALK
description: An 11-year-old girl was found strangled early this morning on the wooded grounds of the school she attended, the police said.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for 13wks to July 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-2 stock split paid May 2.

title: ENERGY OPTICS INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day yesterday, about the dedication of a plaque on a Greenwich Village apartment house where Eleanor Roosevelt once lived, carried an incorrect identification - issued by the building's owner, New York University - for a Roosevelt biographer. The author is Joseph P. Lash, not his wife, Trude. The university also misstated the building's size; it has 16 stories, including the penthouse.

title: Linda F. Gering Is Married To Advertising Executive
description: Linda Fern Gering, the special events coordinator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and Neil Ivan Kreisberg, an executive vice president of Grey Advertising Inc., were married last evening at the Carlyle Hotel in New York by Rabbi Debra Zecher.

title: EX-MOB CHIEF DENIES DRUG CHARGES IN MAFIA TRIAL
description: A major Mafia informer denied on the witness stand yesterday that he was guilty of drug charges that had put him in prison with a life sentence.

title: ENCHANTED VILLAGE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Low-Car-Rate Extension Seen
description: Sweeping sales incentives on automobiles will continue as long as the General Motors Corporation produces more cars than it can sell without the incentives, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today.

title: Japan Reports Export Decline
description: Japan's exports are slowing because of the yen's growing strength, and that is putting a drag on production and the economy in general, a Government report said today.

title: PROBLEM OF DEBT IS STRESSED AT U.N.
description: The President of Mexico told the General Assembly today that industrial nations must realize that global security depends upon their ''flexibility toward the demands of the weak.''

title: GENESEE COMPUTER CENTER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GASTINEAU UNHAPPY WITH SACK TOTAL
description: Mark Gastineau has been churlish lately. When he isn't sacking people, he is moody and even refuses some interviews.

title: Lorimar Plans Separate Unit
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the diversified entertainment and communications concern, said today that it planned to make its entertainment arm a separate affiliate in a partial restructuring.

title: Federal Home Loan Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering $650 million of 8.65 percent subordinated debentures due in 1996 at a price of 99.734, to yield 8.69 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Poll Sees Rise In Pessimism
description: A growing number of Americans believe that the economic recovery will sputter by the end of 1987, although more people still predict continued growth, according to a Gallup Poll to be released today.

title: Gorilla Is Dead at 47; Central Park Favorite
description: Carolyn, a 47-year-old gorilla who was a prime attraction at the Central Park Zoo for nearly four decades, died of natural causes at the Bronx Zoo yesterday.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $449,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: U.S. SAID TO SEEK SECOND DELAY ON SENTENCING SPY
description: The Justice Department has decided to seek another delay in the sentencing of John A. Walker Jr. because of concern that the Navy veteran may have lied about his Soviet espionage ring, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: COSTA RICA CLOSES AIRSTRIP NEAR NICARAGUA BORDER
description: Costa Rican officials said today that they have closed a military-size airstrip near the Nicaraguan border because they suspect it may have been used by Nicaraguan rebels or drug traffickers.

title: RYAN HELPS ASTROS CLINCH TIE
description: Nolan Ryan, the Houston Astros and a crowd of 37,611 fans ventured inside the Astrodome tonight expecting a celebration. Yet the one they experienced was not the one they envisioned.

title: ICAHN FORECASTS PROFIT FOR T.W.A. IN 3D PERIOD
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that the airline would have a profit of about $70 million in the third quarter and that it would have a substantial profit in the fourth quarter.

title: Decision on Who Will Receive Drug for AIDS Is Postponed
description: Federal health officials and representatives of the Burroughs Wellcome Company did not reach a final decision yesterday on which AIDS patients will have immediate access to azidothymidine, or AZT, a promising experimental drug.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 25, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INTERFERENCE CONTROL TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SEA GALLEY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 7
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $73,000. Sea Galley said the third quarter results include $1,745,000 of writeoffs related to its investment in Flakey Jake's Inc.

title: OPERA: MARTINA ARROYO IN 'AIDA' AT THE MET
description: THE second night of the Metropolitan Opera's new season brought the return of John Dexter's 1976 production of ''Aida.'' James Levine once said this opera was nearly impossible to cast these days, but now the Met gives it all the time. There are three possible explanations for this paradox: that Mr. Levine's standards have slipped, that the public loves this opera so much it will purchase tickets for any level of mediocrity or that we've entered a new golden age of vocalism.

title: Carbide Payment
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said holders of special distribution rights would receive a second payment of $3.22 for each right on Oct. 14.

title: Reliance Is Said To Cut Offering
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., the holding company headed by Saul P. Steinberg, has for the second time reduced the price and number of shares in its initial public offering, Wall Street sources said yesterday. The price of each Reliance share has dropped to $10, from $12 and $13, according to the underwriters of the offering - Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the First Boston Corporation, and Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Under the Rose
description: The House of Representatives, after two minutes of discussion and by unrecorded vote, approved a bill passed by the Senate after a century of debate making the rose our ''national floral emblem.''

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SERVICE RECORDS OF THE OFFICERS SUSPENDED IN 77th PRECINCT
description: The 13 officers in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn who were suspended Tuesday are a mixture of veterans and rookies.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEPAL U.N. SOLDIER SHOT AND WOUNDED IN LEBANON'S SOUTH
description: Gunmen in southern Lebanon today shot and seriously wounded a Nepalese soldier serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force.

title: ANIMALS RESPOND TO EXPERIMENTAL AIDS VACCINE
description: An experimental vaccine against the AIDS virus produces two important kinds of immune reaction in animals, according to a new research report.

title: CAMPAIGN IN TEXTILE BELT FOCUSING ON TRADE
description: Here in textile country, the nation's trade policy is not a matter of philosophical debate. It is widely viewed as a simple question of jobs.

title: Buyout at Carrols
description: The Carrols Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by a company formed by the president of Carrols, David J. Connor, and other senior managers, along with Morgan Ventures III, whose principals are Alan Vituli and Peter Weidhorn.

title: U.S. SETS TERMS ON A-SITE VISIT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to permit Soviet scientific experts to investigate potential seismic montoring sites near the installation where the United States tests its nuclear weapons, officials disclosed today.

title: Advertising; Arch Gives Insurer A Theme
description: IN three quite different markets, the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company has begun testing the communication ability of a new, very striking commercial.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
