Senate Asks Deep Cuts In Soviet's U.N. Mission
description: The Senate voted today to order even deeper cuts in the personnel of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in New York, going beyond reductions already demanded by President Reagan.

title: TRIANGLE MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Tamils Killed 4 Soldiers, Sri Lanka Military Says
description: Tamil guerrillas killed four soldiers and wounded 11 in separate attacks on a patrol and a district capital, the military reported today.

title: The First Lady
description: Buddy Ryan, the coach with a propensity for identifying his players by number instead of name, responding to a Veterans Stadium banner that asked whether he treated his wife the same way: ''Sure I do. She's a 10.''

title: GOTTI TRIAL OPENING STATEMENTS TODAY
description: After six weeks of jury selection and six months of pretrial legal maneuvers, opening statements are to start today in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti, reputed boss of the nation's most powerful organized-crime family, and six co-defendants.

title: ON CBS 'KAY O'BRIEN'
description: PROBABLY the last thing prime-time television needs right now is another hospital-doctors show. Just about every emergency and heartwarming angle to be found on that particular scene is being exploited each week in NBC's ''St. Elsewhere,'' the kind of middlebrow soap opera that wins Emmy Awards (while virtually acing out ABC's ''Moonlighting,'' a far more original and offbeat romp). Nevertheless, CBS is bringing on, tonight at 10, ''Kay O'Brien,'' a series set in a New York hospital where everybody seems to speak in exclamations: ''We need more blood!'' ''C'mon, let's go!'' ''Do it!'' It is the practice of medicine seen as a football game.

title: IN MILAN, A SHOW STARS BOLD, WITTY FURNITURE
description: Shapes from the spare and minimal to the frankly Baroque, inventive and unexpected uses of materials and an engaging wit dominated the designs presented at this year's Salone Internazionale del Mobile. The international furniture fair, the most influential event of its kind, ended here Monday. Some of the designs, whose prices range from the inexpensive to the stratospheric, will be available in the United States as early as November.

title: ART'S-WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Convergent Sees Loss in 3d Period
description: Faced with lower-than-expected sales to major customers, Convergent Technologies expects to report a loss for the third quarter, ending Sept. 30, the company said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1986
description: International

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HOUSE PASSES EDUCATION BILL TIGHTENING AID REGULATIONS
description: The House of Representatives today voted 385 to 25 to pass a compromise bill on higher education that tightens the requirements for financial aid while extending the help to part-time, nontraditional students.

title: Packer Will Retire
description: Doctors have told Tim Lewis that he cannot risk another blow like the one he took against the Bears on Monday night so the Green Bay Packers cornerback will be placed on injured reserve for the rest of the year and will then retire. The 24-year-old Lewis, a fourth-year player out of Pitt, suffered a jammed neck when he butted heads with Willie Gault, a wide receiver.

title: Market Place; Seeking Curbs On Volatility
description: STILL stunned by the stock market debacle of Sept. 11 and 12 that was caused in part by program trading of stock index futures and options, traders in New York and Chicago, where most futures and options contracts are traded, are divided about what can or should be done to avoid a repeat of the impact.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $87,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $107,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Driesell Talks Reported
description: Edward Bennett Williams, the attorney for Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell, has reportedly discussed with the chancellor of the University of Maryland conditions under which the basketball coach may leave his job in the wake of the controversy over the death of Len Bias. Williams, told the chancellor, Dr. John Slaughter, about three weeks ago that the coach wants to keep his job but might leave in return for a sizable financial settlement, according to The Baltimore Sun.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: The 1985 share earnings are restated for a 6-for-5 stock split paid May 1986.

title: New Trophy Set For No. 1 Team
description: United Press International and the American Football Coaches Association, who have been collaborating since 1950 on weekly rankings of the nation's top-20 college teams, will join with the family of the late Edward J. Gerrits, a Florida construction company executive, to award an annual trophy to U.P.I.'s national championship team.

title: EVENTS: HOME AND NEIGHBORHOOD TOURS
description: Indoor Antiques Show, Human Resources Center, I. U. Willets Road at Searingtown Road (a half mile south of Exit 36 on the Long Island Expressway), Albertson, L.I., 516-747-5400.

title: Aquino Flies Home; U.S. Trip Called Success
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines returned from the United States today, saying that she had established personal rapport with President Reagan and warning against ''holding our breath'' for foreign economic help.

title: Fleet Financial
description: The Fleet Financial Group, already among the top five mortgage agencies in the nation, reached agreement to buy the Security Pacific Mortgage Corporation, based in Denver. J. Terrence Murray, Fleet's chairman and president, said the purchase would increase the Providence bank's mortgage servicing portfolio by $2.5 billion, to $17 billion, making Fleet the nation's third-largest mortgage banking company.

title: BRENDLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
DUARTE IN THE FIRST ROUND OF COMEBACK
description: In the midst of a thriving pro career, Frankie Duarte, a ranked bantamweight from West Los Angeles, became an alcoholic.

title: OPERETTA: 'FORTUNE TELLER'
description: VICTOR HERBERT'S ''Fortune Teller'' is sweet, exuberant, naive, tuneful Americana - none the less so for its Hungarian setting. Those with a fondness for either the score or the genre might wish to investigate the Light Opera of Manhattan's production, which is playing through Sunday at the Cherry Lane Theater (38 Commerce Street) in Greenwich Village.

title: Everett-Ram Accord
description: The Los Angeles Rams plan to announce the signing of Jim Everett at a news conference today. The former Purdue quarterback, according to a source familiar with the negotiations, has agreed to a four-year contract that could be worth up to $3 million, including base salary and bonuses.

title: AIDE'S HOME IS HIT IN JOHANNESBURG
description: An explosion in Johannesburg today rocked the home of a white official responsible for housing policies in Soweto, the city's huge black township. The policies have led to the eviction of blacks refusing to pay rents as part of a widening protest against township conditions.

title: '87 Gain Seen In Chip Sales
description: Sales of semiconductors should rise about 22 percent in the United States and 20 percent worldwide next year, according to an annual survey of industry executives.

title: AIDS and Restaurants: Rule of Reason Urged
description: Citing scientific evidence, the Secretary of Health and Human Services told restaurant owners today that they should ordinarily let employees with AIDS keep working in the kitchen.

title: Henry P. deVries, a Lawyer And Professor at Columbia
description: Henry P. deVries, a lawyer and professor emeritus at the Columbia Law School, died Tuesday at his office in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Fairfield, Conn.

title: HONEYWELL RETREAT FROM COMPUTERS
description: The Honeywell Corporation conceded yesterday what many in the computer industry have said for years: It cannot compete with I.B.M.

title: ASTRO ROOKIE MAKES MARK
description: Alan Ashby, who catches for the Houston Astros, was suddenly in the mood to drop a few names. ''I started with some of the old-timers,'' he said. ''Walter Johnson, Cy Young. Then I moved on to guys like Koufax, Ryan and Seaver. But he just sat there, dead-panned and straight-faced. I don't know if he was listening to me or not.''

title: THE STAGE: 'HITLER'S CHILDHOOD'
description: WHAT a terrible childhood Adolf Hitler had - really. Oddly, ''Hitler's Childhood,'' by the Swedish poet Niklas Raadstrom, being presented by Northern Lights Productions at the Irish Arts Center, makes it seem utterly surreal.

title: MUSIC: SINGERS OFFER COUNTRY FARE
description: GARY MORRIS and Nancy Griffith, Texas singer-songwriters who come respectively from Fort Worth and Austin, represent in very different ways a new cosmopolitan breed of musician that is busily reshaping the sound of contemporary country music.

title: STAGE: YOUNG PLAYWRIGHTS FESTIVAL
description: THE Fifth Annual Young Playwrights Festival, in residence at Playwrights Horizons with an evening of three short plays, offers further validation of the festival's purpose - to nurture incipient creative talent. As usual, the plays benefit from productions of a high professional caliber.

title: 13 POLICE SUSPENSIONS: LESSONS OF '68
description: It has been 18 years since two frustrated New York City policemen, David Durk and Frank Serpico, went to newspapers with allegations of widespread police corruption after being all but ignored by their superior officers.

title: ELIZABETH RIEFSTAHL
description: Elizabeth Riefstahl, an Egyptologist and author who helped build the Brooklyn Museum's library of Egyptology to international recognition, died Sept. 15 at Providence Hospital in Southfield, Mich. She was 97 years old.

title: AGE FOR DRINKING RAISED IN CAPITAL
description: The District of Columbia, under pressure from Congress and neighboring states, has acted to raise the legal age for drinking beer and wine to 21.

title: TALKS IN SEOUL ON CHARTER AT IMPASSE
description: For the last few months, South Korea's political parties have tried to achieve something rare for this fractious country - agreement, through debate, on a new way to select the national leader.

title: COLLINS MAY REPLACE INJURED PATTERSON
description: Elvis Patterson, the Giants' starting left cornerback, likes to say he always gives 110 percent effort. But his strained left groin muscle has left him at less than 110 or even 100 percent, and Mark Collins, a rookie, may replace him in Sunday's game here against the New Orleans Saints.

title: DOW ADVANCES 5.48 POINTS TO 1,803.29
description: A moderate increase in stock prices yesterday gave Wall Street its third consecutive gain, but trading volume remained weak and investor nervousness was evident in a sharp and unexplained selloff of some highly regarded technology stocks.

title: FLYERS, IN OVERTIME, DEFEAT RANGERS, 3-2
description: The Rangers lost again to the Flyers, but this time it happened calmly because the teams resorted to playing hockey with only a modicum of their renowned fisticuffs.

title: Sudan Rebels to Admit A U.N. Relief Plane
description: A United Nations official said today that Sudanese rebels had agreed not to fire on a plane carrying relief supplies as long as the plane stopped first at a town held by the rebels.

title: DOLLAR LOW ENOUGH FOR VOLCKER
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the dollar had probably dropped enough in relation to the currencies of other industrial countries and that policy makers should rely on other tools to redress imbalances in the world economy.

title: SENATE VOTES 99-0 FOR A $64 BILLION HIGHWAY BILL
description: The Senate today unanimously adopted legislation setting a ceiling of $64.8 billion over the next four years on Federal spending on highway, bridge and mass transit programs and allowing the states to raise the speed limit on some rural highways. The vote was 99 to 0.

title: Detroit Papers' Proposal Delayed a Second Time
description: The Justice Department, frustrating the hopes of Detroit's two newspapers for early approval of their request to merge some of their operations, extended the period for public comment on the proposal.

title: POLL SEES CHILDREN'S PROBLEMS AS SEVERE
description: Three out of four American adults believe that the problems facing today's children are more severe than when they were growing up, and even more are willing to pay higher taxes for better schools, drug treatment programs and other services for youths, according to a recent survey by Louis Harris.

title: Tenneco to Buy Steiger Tractor
description: Steiger Tractor Inc., a farm equipment maker that has been operating under bankruptcy-law protection since June, said that Tenneco Inc. had agreed to buy the company in a deal worth $75 million.

title: KNICKS ARE EYEING MULLIN OF WARRIORS
description: The Knicks want Chris Mullin, but the Golden State Warriors' demands plus salary cap restrictions, have put major stumbling blocks in front of the trade that the two teams have been discussing since June.

title: 2 BROOKLYN OFFICERS SAID TO SUGGEST EXTORTION TO 13
description: The investigation that led to the suspension of 13 police officers Tuesday developed rapidly this year after two other officers, working undercover, approached their colleagues about joining them in ''ripping off'' drug dealers, officials said yesterday.

title: The Apollo Stompers
description: The pianist-saxophonist Jaki Byard will lead the Apollo Stompers big band tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; admission is $8, or $5 for students and the elderly.

title: KEY RATES
SWEEPING TAX BILL APPROVED IN HOUSE BY 292-136 MARGIN
description: With a majority of both parties in support, the House of Representatives gave its final approval today to legislation creating a new Federal income tax system.

title: IRAQI MINISTER SAYS IRANIAN OFFENSIVE MIGHT INCLUDE A FEINT TO DRAW UNITS
description: The Iraqi Defense Minister says an expected Iranian offensive will probably begin with a feint intended to draw Iraq's strategic reserve forces away from the area of the main attack.

title: Notes and Bonds Dip Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly yesterday, as dealers said there was no clear-cut trend in investor activity to provide direction to the credit markets.

title: DRUG TALKS BEGUN WITH LATIN LANDS
description: The Reagan Administration has begun discussions with Colombia, Ecuador and Peru about sending American military troops to aid in drug eradication there, Justice Department officials said today.

title: FILM: 'CROCODILE DUNDEE'
description: THE Australian import ''Crocodile Dundee'' deals with the stuff myths are made of - Australian myths. The movie is about a man, Michael J. (Crocodile) Dundee, but he's not just any ordinary mortal. He lives in a small dusty town in the wild untamed Australian outback. He was raised by a local aborigine tribe and knows how to hunt crocodiles, kill poisonous snakes with his bare hands and tame wild buffalo just by staring them straight in the eyes. He also runs a small safari business for tourists. Its motto is ''If you don't go out with us, you probably won't come back.''

title: VIKINGS' DEFENSE MIXES OLD AND NEW
description: In an era of the ''46,'' fancy blitzing schemes and daring man-to-man coverages, here's a new defense to think about.

title: Wang Discounts
description: Wang Laboratories said it would offer discounts of 6 percent to 30 percent for large users of desktop computer systems and certain work stations. The policy is intended to strengthen the long-term relationships with large accounts and provide discounts for the entire desktop product line, Wang officials said.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar U.S. From Chess Olympiad
description: Two members of the United States Chess Federation have filed a lawsuit here seeking an injunction to stop the group from participating in the 1986 Chess Olympiad, at which Israelis will be banned by the host Arab nation.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO MAKE NASA SEEK EXTRA ROCKET MAKERS
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would require the space agency to seek proposals from additional manufacturers to build booster rockets for the space shuttle.

title: Berbick Settles
description: The Canadian Professional Boxing Federation has discontinued its legal action to recover the heavyweight title belt from Trevor Berbick, now the World Boxing Council champion.

title: WITHDRAWAL OF BOOK ROILS DALLAS RACIAL FEELINGS
description: When Jim Schutze, a local newspaper columnist, started working on a book about race relations in Dallas, some of those he was writing about had a skeptical view of his book's prospects.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Ashford and Simpson and El DeBarge, Radio City Music Hall (757-3100). Besides having written at least a dozen pop-soul standards, from ''Ain't No Mountain High Enough'' to ''Solid,'' Nick Ashford and Valerie Simpson have developed an act that fuses music, choreography and gilt-edged production values into a high-spirited, sophisticated expression of connubial understanding. El DeBarge, who opens the show, is Motown's brightest candidate to fill Michael Jackson's shoes. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tomorrow's show is sold out; tickets for tonight are $20 and are available through Ticket Master outlets and at the Radio City Music Hall box office.

title: ISRAEL RAID: NEW TACTIC
description: The bombing today by Israeli jets of suspected Palestinian guerrilla positions near Sidon fits an unusual pattern of Israeli military behavior that has developed over the last two years. Under the pattern, Shiite Moslem groups in southern Lebanon attack Israeli and Israeli-allied militia bases in Israel's self-proclaimed ''security zone'' along the border, and the Israelis retaliate by striking Palestinian camps farther north.

title: City Votes to Forgive Falwell Tax Bill
description: The Lynchburg City Council agreed tonight night to forgive a $1.4 million tax bill owed by the enterprises of the Rev. Jerry Falwell, who had threatened to move his organization from the city because of the dispute.

title: FILM: 'LAST RESORT,' A VACATION GONE AWRY
description: ''LAST RESORT'' is one of those movies for which it is hard to find one redeeming feature, except that it does, ultimately, come to an end. It's a comedy that confuses humor with confusion, wit with noise and eccentricity with absurdity. It opens today at the U. A. Twin and other theaters.

title: Pulitzer Option Will Be Sold
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the Detroit entrepreneur and real estate developer, has agreed to sell back his investment in the Pulitzer Publishing Company to the Quesada family, a group of dissident shareholders who tried to engineer the sale of the entire company.

title: A ROUND OF DUCAL FETES TO FIGHT LEUKEMIA
description: ''I do get tired,'' Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor, the Sixth Duke of Westminster, was saying Wednesday. ''You never sit down. When the adrenaline settles, it will be like having taken 100 sleeping pills and waking with a hangover.''

title: Student Killed in Peru Clash
description: One student was killed and 15 were injured in clashes between rival political groups over the results of a campus election at the University of the Center here, the university authorities said today.

title: CHILDREN'S TURN FOR DIPLOMACY
description: The adults had their sessions earlier in the week at the United Nations General Assembly. Now it was the children's turn to practice their own form of international diplomacy.

title: CITY JUVENILE CENTER 'REMADE' IN BRONX
description: In the 1960's and 70's, the Spofford Juvenile Center, a city-run detention center in the Bronx, had a notorious record of drug-dealing on premises, sex offenses, suicides and assaults of children and staff members.

title: Spurs Sign Gilmore
description: Artis Gilmore, a free agent, has signed a contract with the San Antonio Spurs, the team for which he played the last four seasons.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $432,000 and $675,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $475,000 for the quarter and $830,000 for the 9 months.

title: METS TIE CLUB MARK WITH 100TH VICTORY
description: Dirt stained the front of his uniform and obscured his Number 12. A film of dirt lined his brow. The pitcher said he was not happy. But he was happy. On a hot day at Wrigley Field that was another landmark day for his team, Ron Darling came away from another gritty performance today with neither a victory nor a loss as the Mets defeated the Cubs, 6-5.

title: State Psychiatrist Held In Sex Abuse of Girl, 4
description: A supervising psychiatrist at the state's Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing a 4-year-old neighbor girl at his home.

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS COMPANY
description: THE dances of Erick Hawkins, whose company performs through Sunday at the Joyce Theater (Eighth Avenue at 19th Street), clear the mind and, yes, refresh the eye.

title: A New Hedging Product
description: J. Aron & Company, the foreign exchange and commodity trading arm of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has created a product that will allow pension funds and other institutions with large international portfolios to hedge against changes in foreign exchange rates, as well as fluctuations in the prices of stocks or bonds.

title: 14 Accused of Selling Drugs at Mail Centers
description: Fourteen postal workers have been charged with selling heroin, cocaine and a variety of other drugs at mail distribution centers, the Federal authorities announced today.

title: ANXIETY INVADES A MISSOURI TOWN AFTER SHOOTING
description: The steeples of five churches stand over this town of 1,200 people, looking, as the Rev. Werner Strick puts it, like shepherds watching over their flocks.

title: THE SCREEN: 'LIGHTSHIP,' WITH DUVALL
description: IF Robert Duvall and Klaus Maria Brandauer weren't the stars of ''The Lightship,'' you might suspect that the film had been salvaged from the hold of the Andrea Doria.

title: SHUTTING DOWN GIMBELS STORES
description: The final curtain will fall on Gimbels' two Manhattan department stores tomorrow night.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $720,000. c-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE
description: * American Electric Power, Columbus, Ohio, has elected to its board Richard M. Ringoen, chairman, president and chief executive of Ball Corp. in Muncie, Ind.

title: Cheaper Milk for the Rest of Us, Too
description: Farmland Dairies, a New Jersey company, already operates in Staten Island, where its low prices have driven down the cost of milk by 40 cents a gallon. Why doesn't Farmland sell milk in the rest of New York City? Because under the state's Depression-era regulation, distributors must obtain a license to sell milk, county by county. And local dairies have long been able to shut out new vendors by claiming it would create ''destructive competition.''

title: U.S. ANTI-COLLISION PLAN IS CALLED TIMID BY PILOTS
description: The main airline pilots' union and the companies most of the pilots work for took opposing positions today on the Government's plan to seek a rule requiring the airlines to equip their fleets with anti-collision devices.

title: PROSECUTOR IN GOTTI CASE TELLS TALE OF AMBITION AND MURDER
description: A Federal prosecutor charged yesterday that ''killing was one way to climb the ladder of success'' in the Gambino crime family and that John Gotti, while in his 30's, helped kill a man to win a ''place of favor'' in the organization.

title: Reagan's Historic Opportunity
description: President Reagan is worried about his place in history. He has one eye on Geneva and another on Managua as places where he might leave his mark, but he and his advisers are missing an angle - an important opportunity to propel his reputation into the next millennium.

title: Restructuring For Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company yesterday announced a restructuring that puts its oil and gas assets directly under the control of the parent company and makes three divisions into subsidiaries. In response, Pennzoil stock soared $4.25, to $63.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday with an article about the Mets misidentified a player. He was Wally Backman, not Kevin Elster.

title: STAGE: 'ASAZI' AND 'GANGSTERS'
description: ''ASINAMALI!'' and ''Bopha!,'' the first two plays in the ''Woza Afrika'' festival at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, were ensemble performance pieces in which actors, shifting among roles, presented a cumulative portrait of the grief of their nation. The third evening - two one-act plays of individual authorship, ''Children of Asazi'' and ''Gangsters'' - is more personalized. For the first time in the festival, the work deals directly with the suffering of black women in South Africa.

title: NESTOR INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid on Jan. 2, 1986.

title: Sirica to Retire at 82; Watergate Trial Judge
description: Twelve years after the start of the trial that made him the best-known judge in America, John J. Sirica is hanging up his black robe for good.

title: CUOMO URGES INTERIM TAX CHANGES
description: Governor Cuomo proposed yesterday that extensive revision of the state's tax code be postponed and that, for now, a more limited interim plan be devised to reimburse New Yorkers for the sharp rise in their state taxes stemming from changes in the Federal tax code.

title: FROM KNICKS HERO TO JOBS SPOKESMAN
description: Walt Frazier, who knew a few things about teamwork as a guard for the New York Knicks basketball team, has taken his game to a new arena, but his emphasis on teamwork has not changed.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
description: b-After a gain of $3,706,000, or 17 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The 1985 share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Dec. 9, 1985, effected in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend.

title: Sale to Wintershall
description: The International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation said it had signed an agreement to sell its oil and gas businesses in the United States to the Denver-based Wintershall Corporation. International Minerals said that the sale of the oil and gas division was part of its plan to reduce its exposure to the cyclical nature of commodity businesses. The sale, which includes a gas pipeline network in Louisiana, is expected to be completed by November.

title: Avoid Lincoln Tunnel, Officials Warn Drivers
description: Motorists should avoid the Lincoln Tunnel this weekend because repair work on an access road leading to major highways on the New Jersey side could cause long delays, backing traffic up into Manhattan, transportation officials warned yesterday.

title: Sri Lanka Blasts Darken A Strike-Bound City
description: Suspected Tamil guerrillas blew up two power transformers today in eastern Sri Lanka, the authorities said. The blasts cut off electricity to Batticaloa, a provincial capital paralyzed by strikes and rebel attacks.

title: Union Pacific Speeds Shift
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would accelerate its previously announced management transition, making Drew Lewis president and chief operating officer of the parent company on Nov. 1, five months ahead of schedule.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Gminski, the Nets' center, required 11 stitches after cutting his right hand while working out with several teammates in North Bergen, N.J. He is expected to be ready when the Nets open training camp next Friday at Princeton University. . . . Larry Finch, a former Memphis State All-American, was named head basketball coach for the school yesterday. Finch, 35 years old, had been an assistant for seven years to Dana Kirk, who was dismissed last week.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 364 money market mutual funds decreased $210 million, to $239.1 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 87 institutional funds were down $813.9 million, to $68.86 billion. Assets of the 187 general purpose funds were down $54.1 million, to $65.57 billion, and the 90 broker-dealer funds rose $658 million, to $104.67 billion.

title: Fate of Soft Drinks Could Await Beer
description: To the Editor:

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
The U.N. Today: Sept. 26, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: MONACO, not the principality but a new nightclub, opened officially Tuesday night at 41 East 58th Street. To attract the sophisticated set it aspires to, the management hired George-Paul Rosell, the professional party giver; Ludovic Autet, president of the Junior International Club, and Christine Biddle. Their guests for a seated dinner of vegetable pate and chicken piccata included Baron and Baroness Roger de Cabrol, Steve and Maria Burton Carson, Cornelia Guest, and Kimberly and Jonathan Farkas.

title: LITERACY IN AMERICA: BEYOND THE BASICS
description: The latest report on the state of literacy in the United States was a good news/bad news document that reinforced the conclusion of other recent research that the American educational system faces serious problems.

title: FROM THE CITY TO L.I., A FLOOD OF STREET FESTIVALS
description: With a harvest of fresh seafood and the mesmerizing click of tapping feet, the streets of New York will enliven the senses this weekend in a flood of outdoor festivals. In Brooklyn, a bounty of ethnic arts and food will line Atlantic Avenue. On the North Shore of Long Island, a hamlet will pay homage to a local icon of sorts -the oyster. And three festivals, each with a different flavor, will transform Manhattan into one continuous party.

title: The Cops Caught the Crooked Cops
description: New York City's government, beset by scandal, must cringe at the news of extortion and drug dealing in the Police Department. Yet the suspension of 13 officers in Brooklyn's 77th Precinct has a reassuring aspect. Without flinching, the department is bringing its own wrongdoers to justice. That is largely because of a man named John Guido.

title: OPEC to Seek Lasting Pact
description: OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman, said the organization would try to reach a lasting oil production arrangement at its meeting in Geneva on Oct. 6, the OPEC News Agency reported today.

title: ALLEGRE IS SIGNED AS GIANTS' KICKER
description: Just when the Giants' kicking derby seemed to have run out of twists, it took a new one today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IMPOSING NEW CURBS ON FLOW OF NEWS ABOUT VIOLENCE
description: The South African authorities announced further restrictions today on the flow of information about the state of emergency in force since June 12.

title: 2 Brokerages Are Censured
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Shearson Lehman Brothers and Stein Roe & Farnham for what it described as a failure to supervise four employees who are charged with defrauding customers.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THEATER: AT CIRCLE REP, 'IN THIS FALLEN CITY'
description: THE unnamed fallen city of Bryan Williams's play ''In This Fallen City'' could be anywhere in the country today. It's a place where ethnic neighborhoods can fractionalize into armed camps, where thugs can escape punishment on technicalities, where latter-day liberals can find themselves rooting for ''law and order.'' But if the complex issues raised by Mr. Williams are as up-to-date as the Bernhard Goetz case, his play's theatrical method might lead one to believe that time has stood still for 50 years or so. ''In This Fallen City'' is a work in which characters withhold secrets for no other reason than to build suspense, in which every theme is announced in advance of its dramatization, and in which exposition is cued by questions like ''What was she like, your wife?'' and ''Would you tell me what happened that night?''

title: CALIFORNIA WINERY WORKERS REJECT LATEST CONTRACT OFFER
description: Workers striking 11 of California's largest wineries have overwhelmingly rejected the latest contract offer and both sides predict a long, bitter strike. The union called today for a statewide boycott of the products of the struck wineries.

title: BLACKS AND OTHERS ATTACKING WASHINGTON POST'S COVERAGE
description: The first issue of The Washington Post's new Sunday magazine has drawn angry protests from some of the city's black leaders, and there is now a much larger coordinated protest by church and union groups aimed at the newspaper's overall coverage.

title: ISLANDER ROOKIE HAS A TOUGH NIGHT
description: He wears green pads and a green blocker, and he was called in from the bench for goaltending duty for the third night in a row with 20 minutes left in a regulation 60-minute game.

title: People
description: * George Jaccoma and R. B. (Bo) Mitchell have joined Martin Sturtevant Silverman & Marshall as partners.

title: GROUP SUES TO BAR PLACING HOMELESS IN MIDTOWN
description: Charging that the city has ''dumped'' thousands of homeless people in their neighborhood, a coalition of midtown Manhattan merchants and residents filed suit yesterday to stop further placements of homeless families in an area of midtown.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a passage on Wednesday in the excerpts from Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's speech to the United Nations General Assembly was printed out of sequence, and the transposition altered its meaning. A corrected version of the section appears today on page A10.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. DETROIT TIGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Haiti Opposition Group Urges Regime to Quit
description: A coalition of opposition politicians appealed today to the ruling National Council of Government to resign and hand power to a new council headed by a former Justice Minister.

title: 10 TRUCKS AND A CAR CRASH IN A BIG PILEUP ON OIL-SLICKED I-95
description: Ten tractor-trailers and a car skidded on a slick of diesel fuel and plowed into each other in a massive chain-collision pile-up on the New England Thruway in New Rochelle, N.Y., early yesterday morning, injuring five truck drivers and the car's driver and closing the northbound lanes for eight hours.

title: ENVOY CALLED FOCUS OF U.S. INVESTIGATION ON EMBASSY FUNDS
description: Federal officials are investigating charges that Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the United States Ambassador to Switzerland, misspent money raised from private donors that was intended for entertaining Swiss citizens, a Reagan Administration offical said tonight.

title: A Drug Christmas Tree
description: Congress rushes forward with a new narcotics bill that, like crack, creates its own temptation. More and more lawmakers use the drug bill like an appropriations bill, as a vehicle for stalled pet projects.

title: Why Made in the U.S.A. Is Good; Exporting Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: PESTICIDE WITH DDT BANNED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today banned the sale and distribution of a pesticide that has been found to contain DDT, the powerful insecticide that was banned in 1972.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE SOUND OF COLORS The Indian word sarangi means ''instrument of a thousand colors,'' and prominent Indian musicians will explore the aural dimension of those colors in a concert tonight as the Festival of India continues. Ustad Sultan Khan, an exponent of north Indian music and the sarangi (a bowed string instrument), will be joined by Ustad Alla Rakha and Zakir Hussain on the tabla, or drums. The festival, presented by the World Music Institute, features the trio in concert tonight at 8 o'clock at the Triplex Theater at 199 Chambers Street. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Triplex, Sitara Devi, in her first United States appearance since a 1976 performance at Carnegie Hall, will dance the kathak - intricate, stamping ritual dances of northern India, while Mr. Hussain accompanies her on the tabla. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: 618-1980. (Chargit: 944-9300.) On Sunday, the choreographer Martha Graham and Charles Reinhart, the director of the American Dance Festival, will be among those paying tribute to the late T. Balasaraswati, the Indian classical dancer. The program is from 2 to 5 P.M. at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, and includes a screening of Satyajit Ray's documentary ''Bala'' (as the dancer was known). Lakshmi, the daughter of Balasaraswati, will dance the Bharata Natyam, the dance style of southern India made famous by her mother. Limited tickets are available for $20 to the public, $18 for society members. Information: 517-8508.

title: Doubleday Sale Plans Expected
description: Doubleday & Company is expected to announce the sale of its publishing businesses to Bertelsmann, the German publisher, as early as today, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: 2 CITY INQUIRIES OF 'PUBLIC IMPORTANCE' DISCLOSED BY JUDGE IN FRIEDMAN TRIAL By RICHARD J. MEISLIN
description: The Government is conducting two investigations of ''tremendous public importance'' in New York City, a significant phase of which will end within a month, Federal Judge Whitman Knapp disclosed today.

title: Bridge: U.S. Players Dominating Events in World Tourney
description: Players from the United States continued to dominate the world championships and may well sweep all the four major titles in the two-week tournament. They have already won the mixed pairs and knockout team titles.

title: 10 AGENCIES WIN GRANTS FOR INNOVATIVE PROJECTS
description: Sandy Steiner is a circuit-riding engineer who travels 17 counties for the State of North Carolina designing personalized mechanical devices that enable severely handicapped people to hold jobs.

title: HPECIAL TASKS IN CAPITAL FOR CITICORP EXECUTIVE
description: Citicorp's man in Washington is Thomas C. Gaspard, whose job is to take a once-failing savings and loan institution there and turn it into a slick Citicorp consumer operation.

title: DRUG ROLE SOUGHT FOR FOREST AGENCY
description: The Department of Agriculture is pressing for legislation to give agents of the United States Forest Service wider authority to combat the growing of marijuana in national forests, a department official said Wednesday.

title: ERLAND JOSEPHSON STARS IN TARKOVSKY'S 'SACRIFICE'
description: ''THE SACRIFICE'' is a stunningly beautiful film that holds your attention even while you feel slightly stunned, in a less welcome way, by what is actually going on.

title: Gencorp's Plan On Station Sale
description: A Federal Communications Commission official said today that Gencorp Inc., parent of RKO General, had indicated it did not want to retain ownership in any of its 13 broadcast stations that the F.C.C. wants sold.

title: Festivals and Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture. Today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Ninth Greenwich Village Crab Fest, Avenue of the Americas at Bleecker Street, Our Lady of Pompeii Church; sponsored by the Village Visiting Neighbors organization, today, 6 to 9 P.M. Entertainment; hot steamed crabs. Tomorrow Village Schoolmart, P.S. 41, Greenwich Avenue, west of the intersection of Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Street. Antiques, jewelry, clothing, records, books. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Antique, Flea and Farmers Market, P.S. 183, East 66th Street, First and York Avenues. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Street Fair, East 78th Street, between York Avenue and the East River, tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Entertainment, vendors, clothing, memorabilia, antiques, homemade food. Rain date: Sunday. Sponsored by the City and Suburban Tenants'

title: AIM TELEPHONES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $33,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $65,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $16,000 for the quarter and $32,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months. The company said revenue includes those of Precision Communications Inc. as of July 26, 1985; Business Communications Systems Inc. as of Jan. 1, 1986; Phoenix Communications Inc. as of June 13, 1986; and PBX Systems Services Inc., as of July 25, 1986.

title: FRANCE ARRESTS 9 IN PARIS BOMBINGS
description: The French police have arrested nine people, including five ultra-leftist French activists, in connection with the series of bombing attacks that took place here this month.

title: Saturday Review Is for Sale Again
description: The Saturday Review, the 62-year-old magazine of literature and the arts, is up for sale again. The Manhattan Media Corporation is selling the Washington-based magazine, which changed hands in 1982 and again in 1984, for about $3.5 million.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: b-After tax credits of $9,450 for the quarter and $181,700 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $19,200 for the quarter and $112,700 for the 9 months.

title: Celtics' Offer Matched
description: Rather than allow Boston, the defending National Basketball Association champion, to beef up its roster at its expense, Utah has decided to match the Celtics' offer sheet of $315,000 for two years to Fred Roberts, a forward who earned $100,000 last season. ''We feel Fred is a fine player and rather than give him up for nothing, we felt we should bring him in and hope he fights hard for a spot on the roster,'' said David Checketts, president of the Jazz.

title: Dining Out Guide: Indian
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AKBAR, #475 Park Avenue, near 58th

title: The Giants' Kicking Derby
description: 1985 Aug. 15: Ali Haji-Sheikh injures left hamstring in practice.

title: 4 MONTHS AFTER PACT, CONTRAS' LEADERS CLASH
description: In spite of a formal agreement to work together, top Nicaraguan guerrilla leaders continue to have serious political differences, according to senior American and rebel officials.

title: Quake Off Mexico's Coast
description: An earth tremor measuring 5 on the open-ended Richter scale was recorded early today off the Pacific coast near the Mexican resort of Mazatlan, the National Autonomous University of Mexico said. No damage or injuries were reported

title: HEWLETT SAYS SPECTRUM FACES HALF-YEAR DELAY
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that software problems would force it to delay shipments of its new Spectrum minicomputer by about half a year.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Reese Earns 2d Met Title
description: Don Reese today won his second consecutive championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association. The victory strengthened his resolve to recapture his playing card on the PGA Tour, which he relinquished in 1982.

title: HOLY LAND'S ANCIENT ART AT THE MET
description: BENEATH the calm surface of ''Treasures of the Holy Land: Ancient Art From the Israel Museum'' lies a complex, if not stormy, show. It is thoughtful and sometimes inspired in its consideration and installation of objects from a very special part of the world, where religion is like oxygen and archeology is a way of life. But its desire to avoid controversy creates an atmosphere in which the intensity and passion of the Holy Land struggle to breathe.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE STORY OF ENGLISH. By Robert McCrum, William Cran and Robert MacNeil. Illustrated. 384 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 9
description: The company said the latest 40- week results includes gains realized on the sale of restaurant leases amounting to $1,373,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: CHARGES TRADED AT VIENNA TALKS
description: Talks in Vienna on reducing the number of troops in Central Europe resumed on a sour note today, as officials from NATO and Warsaw Pact nations accused each other of standing in the way of progress.

title: Citicorp Notes
description: Citicorp is offering $250 million of extendible notes due in 1998, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes carry an initial interest rate of 6 7/8 percent and were offered at 99.80 to yield 6.963 percent to April 1, 1989. At that time, investors may redeem their notes at par, or accept new terms.

title: Onward Burger
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will doff his robes today after his successor, William H. Rehnquist, has been sworn in. But his active promotion of professional excellence is not likely to decline with this retirement.

title: DOLE KILLS LEGISLATION TO CURB LAWSUITS ON PRODUCT LIABILITY
description: A hotly debated bill to curb product liability lawsuits was killed in the Senate Wednesday when Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, removed it from the legislative agenda.

title: Cuba Expels 2 Newsmen Over Rights Interview
description: Cuba expelled the Havana correspondents of Reuters and Agence France-Presse today after telling them that publication of an interview with a human rights activist was an ''unfriendly act.''

title: Hassan Urges Peace Prayers To Group Including Israelis
description: King Hassan II urged an international group of Moroccan-born Jews, including four Israeli legislators, to pray for peace between Jews and Arabs, the official Moroccan news agency said today.

title: Glenz a Winner In Jersey Golf
description: David Glenz, head professional at the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station, today completed an unprecendented sweep of four major local golf championships in one season.

title: GROUP URGES BAN OF A PAINKILLER, CITING REPORTS OF KIDNEY DAMAGE
description: A private group that monitors the drug industry charged today that Suprol, a non-narcotic painkiller approved for sale last December, caused kidney damage and asked that it be taken off the market.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-end figures reflect a restatement of its results for the first quarter ended Sept. 30, 1985, due to an accounting change.

title: Bates President Leaves Agency
description: John N. Nichols recently promoted president of Ted Bates Advertising, New York, has left the agency. An agency spokesman last evening was not sure whether he had resigned or was dismissed.

title: Thiokol Quiet On Accident
description: Handling bad news in an annual report has always been a problem for corporations. But Morton Thiokol Inc., which made the solid-fuel rockets whose failure led to the space shuttle explosion, found a simple solution this year: It scarcely mentioned its role in the tragedy.

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10,000 for the quarter, and the year is net from discontinued operations of $608,000 and a gain on sale of discontinued operations of $8,137,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $282,000 and $1,358,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PHILIPPINE PEACE HOPES DIMMING, REBEL ENVOY SAYS
description: A Communist negotiator says chances are narrowing for a peaceful settlement of the country's 17-year-old insurgency, amid indications that hard-line military leaders are gaining the ear of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AMID the clamorous backdrop of the West Village, Fukuda is a serene nook where you can enjoy bright fresh sushi and sashimi along with an array of Oriental tidbits at moderate prices. Run by a solitary chef who whirls at 78 r.p.m. behind the sushi bar and a service team of two, this unassuming little spot -about 30 seats including 8 at the bar - has a family feeling to it, which perhaps explains its possessive and cliquish following.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ISRAELI JETS AGAIN ATTACK PALESTINIANS IN LEBANON
description: Israeli Air Force planes struck suspected Palestinian guerrilla targets in Lebanon today for the second time in three days. The attacks today were against targets in the southern port of Sidon.

title: Koch, as in Cox
description: As recounted in the Scouting column Wednesday, Clyde Drexler of the Portland Trail Blazers had a thrilling time at the recent White House dinner for President Jose Sarney of Brazil, and no one disputes that Drexler enjoyed the food, the entertainment and the company. One element of his account, however, did raise an eyebrow or two: his report that a wise-cracking Mayor Koch kept the guests at Drexler's table in stitches.

title: CONBOY REVEALS AN INQUIRY OF DRUG USE AT CITY AGENCY
description: The City Investigation Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, disclosed last night that his department was investigating ''systematic drug use'' in a city agency other than the Police Department.

title: WERNER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * British Petroleum Co., London, said it was taking a 40 percent stake in a new $520 million refinery in Seosan, South Korea.

title: CONCERT: GOLIARD CHORALE
description: ON paper, the Goliard Chorale and Chamber Orchestra's Wednesday night performance at Merkin Concert Hall seemed an odd mix: a choral motet by J. S. Bach, chamber music by Poulenc, a concert aria by Schubert and Stravinsky's Mass.

title: PRIME CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALNY INC reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 12
Cotton Prices Plunge; Hogs Also Off Sharply
description: Cotton futures fell sharply today after a long rally, as the market prepared to deal with a glut of cotton. Traders said they expected the Agriculture Department to begin issuing large amounts of certificates that could be redeemed for cotton from reserves as part of their farm support payments to farmers.

title: Ms. Fahimian, Accountant, And Barry S. Gould Marry
description: Diana Ruth Elizabeth Fahimian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Baroukh Fahimian of London, and Barry Steven Gould, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maxwell M. Gould of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., were married yesterday.

title: MEXICO AND CREDITORS PUSH FOR LOAN ACCORD
description: Mexico and its creditor banks struggled again yesterday to reach agreement on terms of a new $6 billion loan. Although progress was made and negotiators expressed optimism that an accord could be reached before a deadline on Monday, they said important issues remained unresolved.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: WHEN Randa Haines was signed to direct Mark Medoff's Tony Award-winning play ''Children of a Lesser God'' two years ago, she said she worried immediately about how to handle the fact that the film's central character never speaks. The movie, which will open next Friday, is about Sarah, a deaf woman who refuses to learn to speak or to read lips. She meets James, played by William Hurt, who is a teacher in a school for the deaf where she works as a janitor. The two fall in love but the communication barriers between them threaten their relationship.

title: QUAKER OATS JOINS ANDERSON BIDDING
description: The Quaker Oats Company emerged yesterday as a surprise new bidder for Anderson, Clayton & Company.

title: First Place in Value, Too
description: In the 25 seasons since they joined the National League, the Mets have dramatically demonstrated the soaring value of a baseball franchise, especially one in New York.

title: Reggae Concert
description: Yellowman, Half Pint and Ini Kamoze will be accompanied by the Taxi Gang, led by the drummer Sly Dunbar and the bassist Robbie Shakespeare, in a reggae concert tonight at 7:30 at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of the Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South. Tickets are $10; information, 598-2027.

title: Electrical Problem in Queens Stalls Commuters on L.I.R.R.
description: Commuters on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Rail Road were delayed, some by as much as an hour and a half, during the evening rush yesterday because of electrical problems.

title: 14 YEARS OF WOMEN AS FEDERAL AGENTS
description: When Joann Kocher went on her first stake-out as a law-enforcement agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, she heard shooting and rushed in.

title: MAFIA DISPUTE IS MEDIATED ON 'COMMISSION' TRIAL TAPE
description: A jury heard a tape yesterday of Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, a defendant accused of being a Mafia boss, declaring that the ''commission'' would settle a dispute over mob control in Buffalo.

title: Black and White
description: Washingtonian magazine undertook ''the most extensive area-wide polling of black and white racial attitudes to date'' this summer and found that black and white residents of the capital and its suburbs had roughly similar views on a number of issues. But the sample of 1,070 divided sharply along racial lines on certain questions, and the figures indicate how widely beliefs can differ.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ONE question restaurant critics are asked often is: ''Do you ever come across an inconspicuous little gem that you want to keep secret for yourself?'' Yes, on occasion, but I have invariably given in to professional duty and blown its cover, at times turning a serene nook of serendipity into something resembling halftime at a Shea Stadium hot-dog stand. At the risk of performing such a dubious favor for my latest hangout, I am passing along the name Azzurro, a pint-sized, family-run Sicilian restaurant that turns out some terrific pastas, salad and regional seafood.

title: Rebel Sabotage Causes Chile Power Blackout
description: Leftist guerrillas blacked out half of Chile tonight by blowing up two major power pylons in what a guerrilla spokesman called the beginning of an offensive against the state of siege in effect in this country.

title: Falconbridge Stake Set for Public Sale
description: The Canada Development Corporation said it had agreed to sell its 10.5 million common shares, or 20 percent, of Falconbridge Ltd. to underwriters for resale to the public.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $394,000 loss resulting from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. c-Net income and includes a $236,000 credit from a dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock. c-Net income

title: 3 Share the Lead In Abilene Golf
description: D.A. Weibring birdied his last two holes today for a six-under-par 66 that lifted him into a three-way tie for the lead in the first round of the Southwest Golf Classic.

title: CONCERT: PREMIERE OF HUSA
description: KAREL HUSA'S Concerto for Orchestra, which was given its first performance last night by the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta's direction, is a large-scale work whose name and intention inevitably call to mind Bartok's masterpiece by the same title. Since Bartok wrote his piece in 1943 a whole genre of such showpieces has developed, their primary aim being to show off the orchestra's virtuosity and challenge its members, both individually and communally. Mr. Husa's work, a Philharmonic commission, succeeded in that elementary purpose, but did not manage to go much further, in spite of some fits and starts along its 38-minute way when the orchestral busywork threatened fleetingly to turn into memorable, meaningful music.

title: BARTON VALVE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $448,000 for both the quarter and 9 months representing a writedown of assets held for sale and a provision of $229,598 for bad debt. c-After a gain of $375,000 from litigation settlement.

title: NOVUS PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART: WHITNEY DISPLAYS SOME NEW ACQUISITIONS
description: THE Whitney Museum has been in business for 56 years, but the consensus among its critics seems to be that it has yet to come of age. A great irritant has been the museum's now-you-see-it-now-you-don't handling of the permanent collection. This seems to have been more the result of insufficient space than curatorial policy - a museum that has no room to display its holdings being as anomalous as a convention center without a parking lot - but by how much won't be known until the Whitney's premises on Madison Avenue and 75th Street are enlarged.

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING S.A. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All amounts are in U.S. currency.

title: Keep Your Hands Off the 14th Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: KLEVER: ALWAYS PREPARED
description: The current depth chart of the Jets does not reflect that Rocky Klever will be prepared to play running back this Sunday in Indianapolis because of injuries to other backs.

title: RIGHTS PANEL, EXPECTING BIG CUT, IS GEARING DOWN
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has begun steps to reduce its staff by more than three-fourths and close seven of its 10 regional offices to comply with an expected cut in financing.

title: GEORGIA FARM DESPAIR STOKES ANGER AT G.O.P.
description: Here in the old Cotton Belt, where farmers and farm business people talk about the future with tears in their eyes, the hard feelings are turning political in a way that Republican candidates may not like.

title: SHELLY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Year to June 30
G.M. Plans to End Chevette in 1987
description: The General Motors Corporation will stop building its subcompact Chevrolet Chevette next year and will shift production of the full-size Chevrolet Caprice from Detroit to the Chevette plant in Lakewood, Ga.

title: Japanese-Americans Join Nakasone Critics
description: Japanese-Americans joined black, Hispanic and other leaders today in demanding an apology from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone for remarks he was reported to have made about the intellectual levels of minorities in the United States.

title: VARITRONIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $382,000 for the quarter and $996,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Arthur Blythe Quartet
description: The alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe is leading his quartet tonight through Sunday at Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $15 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Robertshaw Stake
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky has lowered his stake in the Robertshaw Controls Company to less than 1 percent, from 5.7 percent. Robertshaw, a maker of temperature control equipment, has accepted an offer of $85 a share, or $466 million, from the British company Siebe P.L.C. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Boesky said that the sales, on Monday and Tuesday, were for $84 to $84.12 a share.

title: Elf Aquitaine Stock
description: The French Finance Ministry said it had fixed a price of 305 francs a share, or the equivalent of about $45.54, for the sale of a 14 percent stake in Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine. The shares closed yesterday at 339 francs. The state-owned Entreprise de Recherches et d'Activites Petrolieres owns 64.4 percent of Elf Aquitaine.

title: OKLAHOMA-MIAMI GAME IS A PASSIONATE SUBJECT
description: No sense mincing words.

title: FRANCE SENDING FORCES TO TOGO IN WAKE OF ATTACK
description: The Defense Ministry said today that it was sending warplanes and troops to Togo after an outbreak of shooting today in Lome, capital of the West African country, following an attempted coup there on Tuesday.

title: Fraud and Fantasy in Congress
description: Truly, triply fantastic: that's about the only way to describe the way the 99th Congress is coming up to the finish line. With adjournment only days away, it has not yet passed the fiscal measures needed to run the Government.

title: Death of AIDS Victim Weighed as Act of Mercy
description: Edward Lebowitz, an AIDS victim for whom a man posing as his doctor prescribed a change in his medication over the telephone, died Wednesday, officials said.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bamberger Retires
description: George Bamberger made it official yesterday, announcing his second retirement as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers and saying he was ''just being realistic'' after 41 years in baseball. ''I said, 'What am I doing here? I should be back in Florida,' '' said the 61-year-old manager.

title: CHAMPIONS WAGE A WAR OF WORDS
description: Two champions have been working up a grudge against one another this week at the Boxing of the Americas Gym, a converted warehouse in the northwest section of the city.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 16wks to July 19
FILM: 'FOREIGN BODY,' COMEDY FROM BRITAIN
description: THE ''Foreign Body'' of the British movie that opens today at the U. A. Gemini and other theaters is Ram Das, a young Indian with an eye or two for the girls, who bribes his way from Calcutta to London. As played by Victor Banerjee (who gave vivid life to Dr. Aziz in ''A Passage to India''), Ram is full of beans, ready for anything and everything. With the help of lucky accidents, a remarkable vibrating couch and a worldly wise Indian named I. Q. who works as an attendant in a men's toilet (a bravura performance by Warren Mitchell), the young fellow shortly becomes a much sought after Harley Street practitioner.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Philadelphia yesterday, about problems in obtaining human organs and cadavers for research, misstated the number of patients awaiting certain transplants. According to the American Council on Transplantation, 400 are awaiting livers and 300 are awaiting hearts.

title: HIGUERA GETS 20TH IN 9-3 BREWER VICTORY
description: Robin Yount had a two-run homer, Paul Molitor drove in three runs and Teddy Higuera posted his 20th victory of the season tonight as Milwaukee defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 9-3, in George Bamberger's final game as manager of the Brewers.

title: DONOVAN CO-DEFENDANT ASKS JUDGE FOR EARLY MURDER TRIAL
description: A co-defendant in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan asked yesterday for permission to be tried simultaneously on a murder charge in the same Bronx courthouse.

title: Surprising Antiunionism at 'MacNeil/Lehrer'
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Aid Program Approved by Congress
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation that would permit as much as $10.2 billion for college student grants and loans in the fiscal year 1987.

title: WIDER POLICE CORRUPTION INQUIRY IS SEEN
description: More police officers are likely to be disciplined in the Brooklyn precinct where 13 officers accused of stealing from drug dealers were suspended Tuesday, senior law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The officials said they could not estimate how many other officers might be involved.

title: G.M. to Lay Off 1,250 in Canada
description: The General Motors Corporation plant in the Toronto suburb of Scarborough is laying off half its 2,500 workers because of a drop in North American sales of large vans, according to a union spokesman.

title: THE SCREEN: 'VASECTOMY'
description: THERE is a scissors in the logo for ''Vasectomy: A Delicate Matter,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters. In terms of taste, that pretty much says it all.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM N' POPS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
DAYS INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,702,000 for the quarter and $6,746,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,702,000 and $3,600,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Shares outstanding and share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 28, 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1986
description: The Economy

title: AUCTIONS
description: CHRISTIE'S first auction of modern American designs, presenting 200 works dating from 1920 to 1960 by many of the period's most important architects and industrial designers, is being held this weekend. The sale is filled with many designs that are the same as or similar to those seen last year at the Whitney Museum of American Art in ''High Styles: 20th-Century American Design'' and those that will be included in the Brooklyn Museum's ''Machine Age in America, 1918-1941,'' which opens Oct. 17. The auction items are by such notables as Norman Bel Geddes, Walter Dorwin Teague, Gilbert Rohde, Charles Eames, Eero Saarinen and Florence Knoll.

title: BROADWAY
description: NEVER mind Broadway at the moment: the dates aren't even definite in San Diego, where there probably will be a six-week run, but the new James Lapine-Stephen Sondheim musical, ''Into the Woods,'' seems to be progressing nicely. A melange of several children's stories, from Cinderella and Rapunzel to Little Red Riding Hood and Jack and the Beanstalk, the musical had a reading at Playwrights Horizons last spring and negotiations are under way for a Dec. 4 opening at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego. Mr. Lapine, who collaborated with Mr. Sondheim on ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' will also direct this one, and Barbara Bryne, B. J. Ward, Joy Franz and Danielle Ferland are likely performers.

title: BROOKLYN'S BROWNSTONES THRIVE AMID RESTORATION
description: One by one, over the last several years, the once-derelict brownstones within the designated historic district of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn have made their way back to the market. An integrated middle-income community has expanded as small builders have seized the opportunity for restoration, helped by Federal tax incentives that make it possible to attract investment capital.

title: What's to Undercut?
description: One day President Reagan tells the United Nations General Assembly that he is ''ready now to take two important steps toward limiting nuclear testing.'' The next day he tells Congress he'll veto some House-approved arms control provisions, including a one-year moratorium on all but the smallest nuclear tests.

title: HUGE SPENDING BILL APPROVED IN HOUSE DESPITE VETO PERIL
description: The House of Representatives voted today, 201 to 200, to approve a $562 billion overall appropriation bill for 1987 despite the strong threat of a veto from President Reagan.

title: Newspaper Carrier Is Killed By Man Who Feared Vandals
description: A man guarding his house from vandals fatally shot a teen-age newspaper carrier making a predawn delivery today.

title: Accounts
description: * Heritage Health Plan of Southeastern Pennsylvania, Norristown, Pa., to McKinney Advertising, Philadelphia.

title: Jazz Trios
description: The pianist Cedar Walton, the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Billy Higgins are playing jazz trios tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japan Is Positive On Space Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Soprano in New Work
description: The soprano Marie Grippo will sing a program of works by Mozart, Schoenberg, Faure and Marc Blitzstein and will perform the world premiere of ''Six Songs of God and Man,'' by James Norton, at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow night at 8:30. Tickets are $8; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 362-8719.

title: CORRECTED SECTION OF SHEVARDNADZE'S SPEECH
description: A passage on Wednesday in the excerpts from Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's speech to the United Nations General Assembly was printed out of sequence. Here is a corrected version of the section.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
O'ROURKE VIES FOR TV DEBATE
description: Trying to pressure Governor Cuomo to debate him, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, announced yesterday that he had purchased a half hour of television time for a debate with the Democratic incumbent on Sunday, Oct. 5.

title: EUROPEANS ACTING TO DISRUPT TERRORISTS
description: Meeting in an emergency session in response to the bombings in Paris, European officials with responsibility for internal security resolved today to intensify their efforts to ''harry and disrupt'' suspected terrorist networks.

title: Robert Gordy Is Dead at 52; Artist With a Whimsical Style
description: Robert Gordy, an artist known for whimsical paintings with repeated patterns and abstract studies of human heads, died Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

title: FOR 17 SNOW LEOPARDS, A BIT OF TIBET IN BRONX
description: Nuptse the snow leopard still seems suspicious, sniffing and poking gingerly at the unfamiliar rocks and water around him. But starting today when it is dedicated, the just-completed Himalayan Highlands habitat at the Bronx Zoo will officially be the new home for him and the zoo's 16 other snow leopards.

title: ASTROS CLINCH WITH PIZAZZ ON NO-HITTER BY SCOTT
description: The Houston Astros wrapped up an improbable season with an improbable ending today as Mike Scott pitched a no-hitter that clinched their first division championship in six years.

title: A SURVEY OF PARENTS' VIEWS
description: A new survey of American parents shows that the majority believe they are better parents than their own were, and they are more affectionate with their children than their mothers and fathers were with them. Two-thirds of those surveyed said they were spanked by their own parents, but only half of the respondents spank their own children as often as they were spanked.

title: AN INNOVATOR OF THE 60'S RETURNS
description: TONY WILLIAMS, one of the finest drummers to emerge in the 1960's, has returned to straight-ahead jazz with the quintet he's leading this weekend at the Village Vanguard. Through the 1970's, Mr. Williams delved into jazz-rock, rock and funk; he maintained his jazz credentials by performing with the pianist Herbie Hancock and the bassist Ron Carter in the group V.S.O.P. Before forming his current quintet, he led his last full-time band in 1980; in between, he spent most of his time studying composition in California, although he still showed up occasionally in New York with V.S.O.P. On record, meanwhile, he has recently worked with Johnny Rotten's Public Image Ltd. and with Yoko Ono.

title: GISH BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Drug-Free' California Plan
description: In an executive order signed Wednesday, Gov. George Deukmejian directed the State Department of Personnel Administration and the State Personnel Board to develop a plan ''to achieve a drug-free state workplace.'' The plan is to include testing for use of illegal drugs by people among the state's 230,000 employees in ''sensitive positions'' and provision for their removal.

title: Market Place; Lucky Stores Vs. Edelman
description: THE Fruehauf Corporation makes trucks.

title: IRAQI, IN U.N., ASKS END TO IRAN WAR
description: The Iraqi Foreign Minister appealed today to the United Nations to find a way to negotiate an end to the six-year-old Iran-Iraq war.

title: ADOBE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DRUG INFLUX A STRAIN ON THE BEAT
description: On the city's street corners, in alleyways, even in precinct house storerooms, drugs are ever present, and so, police officers said yesterday, is the temptation.

title: EX-I.B.M. OFFICIAL CHOSEN BY FRENCH
description: With a bow toward American business techniques, the French Government has named a former I.B.M. executive to be its new Director General of Industry, charged with making French industry more competitive.

title: KARPOV TIES TITLE MATCH IN 19TH GAME
description: Anatoly Karpov continued his amazing comeback by taking the 19th game of the world chess championship and tying the match at 9 1/2 yesterday in Leningrad.

title: Plant Security Concern Is Indicted for Lying
description: The company responsible for the security of the Limerick nuclear plant was charged today with lying and falsifying documents in 1984 to cover up defective training of its guards.

title: Nurse Is Not Guilty In Deaths of 6 Patients
description: A nurse accused of injecting six patients with fatal doses of potassium chloride was acquitted of murder today by a jury that found her guilty but mentally ill on one count of aggravated assault.

title: Japanese Official's Airplane Is Delayed by a Bomb Threat
description: A plane carrying Japan's Foreign Minister, Tadashi Kuranari, was delayed for three hours at John F. Kennedy International Airport yesterday after a bomb threat, a Japan Air Lines spokesman said.

title: IS BOBBY BACK? IF SO, HOW? 'DALLAS' DOES IT AGAIN
description: Was that handsome man in Pam's shower really Bobby James Ewing, Daddy's favorite son and the good guy on ''Dallas?'' But how could that be? Bobby died. Or did he?

title: BONN RATE REMAINING UNCHANGED
description: West Germany's central bank again refused to give in to pressure from Washington today, saying it would leave its benchmark discount rate unchanged.

title: 17.6% Gelco Stake Held
description: The investment group of Gollust, Tierney & Oliver, principals of Coniston Partners, said yesterday that it and other investors had bought 17.6 percent of the Gelco Corporation and was prepared to pay at least $22.50 for the rest of the company, a total of at least $293 million.

title: DOW DROPS 34.73 POINTS, TO 1,768.56
description: A steep drop in stock prices on Wall Street yesterday, prompted partly by West Germany's unwillingness to cut interest rates, nearly nullified the previous three-day advance.

title: Classical Guitar
description: The guitarist Dennis Koster will play works by Bach, Tarrega, Paca de Lucia and Mozart at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn Sunday afternoon at 1. Tickets are $8; $6 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 891-9054.

title: 3 in Britain Face Drug Trial In Official's Daughter's Death
description: Magistrates ordered a Guinness heir and two other people today to stand trial on charges of supplying heroin to a Cabinet minister's daughter who died of an overdose at Oxford University.

title: Proposition 22
description: Say what you will about the Columbia football team - after 22 straight losses the Lions have already heard it all anyway - but spirit apparently continues to stir on Morningside Heights.

title: MARKS POLARIZED CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Company benefited from proceeds received on settlement of litigation and from tax credits totaling $286,343.

title: SHULTZ MEETS WITH SHEVARDNADZE ON DANILOFF A 3D TIME THIS WEEK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met tonight with the Soviet Foreign Minister as they stepped up efforts to resolve the cases of an American reporter in Moscow and a Russian in New York, both accused of espionage.

title: Glenmore Distillers Has Video in Campaign
description: Glenmore Distillers, which last December produced ''Mr. Boston's Official Video Bartenders Guide,'' now has a new video from the same producer but with an entirely different mission.

title: CUOMO CHARGES PRESIDENT LACKS ECONOMIC VISION
description: Governor Cuomo charged last night that there was a ''lack of coherent economic vision'' in Federal policy and called on President Reagan to appoint a bipartisan commission to address the nation's economic ills.

title: Killer Who Is Retarded Is Granted a Stay
description: The Supreme Court has granted a stay of execution for a mentally retarded man who killed his aunt and her boyfriend and was to die in the state's electric chair early Friday.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding represent both primary and fully diluted.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 Recitals in Church
description: The organist Harrison Oxley will play music by Bach, Durufle, Vierne, Janacek and others at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, Sunday afternoon at 2:30. Admission is by contribution; suggested offering, $3. A carillon recital by James Lawson will precede the organ program at 2 P.M. Information: 222-5900, extension 218.

title: 3 SHOT, ONE FATALLY, IN BRONX
description: One man was shot to death and two other men were wounded, one critically, in two separate but related incidents at known drug-sale locations in the University Heights section of the Bronx early this morning, the police said.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After non-recurring severance and transition costs of $639,000 resulting from the company's recently announced major reorganization. c-Net income d-After net of $736,000 from the recognition of a previously deferred non-recurring gain from a 1983 sale of stock. Micropro said its latest year results were also adversely affected by its third quarter decision to reserve the entire $1.4 million due from First Software, a major software distributor, that filed for bankruptcy.

title: SKETCHES OF TRIAL JURORS
description: Following is a list of the jurors chosen today to serve in the Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman and four co-defendants, who are accused of corruption involving New York City's Parking Violations Bureau. The information was taken from questionnaires submitted by the jurors during the selection process.

title: F.D.A. TO GET PROPOSAL FOR USE OF TEST AIDS DRUG
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company said yesterday that it was submitting to the Food and Drug Administration its proposed criteria for selecting AIDS patients to receive immediate distribution of a promising drug.

title: HANA BIOLOGICS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $14,000 income tax benefit of operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $191,000 from discontinued operations.

title: REGIONAL CONFLICTS: U.N. HEARS DELEGATES CALL FOR END TO DISPUTES AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Foreign Minister of Sweden told the General Assembly today that United States help for armed groups fighting the Government of Nicaragua was a ''violation of international law obstructing efforts to bring about peace'' in Central America.

title: Horse Racing Notebook
