description: So far this year, the strength of the nation's 2-year-olds can be summed up in a name: Gulch.

title: USX: PONDERING THE OPTIONS
description: As the latest target of the corporate raider fraternity, USX, the energy and steel company, is under pressure to find ways to maintain shareholders' loyalty.

title: DON'T INVITE 'EM
description: A complete list of the most unwanted guests at current big-league stadiums:

title: PHYSIO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: VOTE IN SENATE SUPPORTS HELMS ON C.I.A. CURB
description: The Senate passed secret legislation Wednesday that legislators and Administration officials say undercuts the authority of the Central Intelligence Agency to manage its own affairs.

title: DOUBLEDAY AND PRESIDENT OF METS TO BUY BALL CLUB FROM PUBLISHER
description: Nelson Doubleday Jr. said yesterday that he and Fred Wilpon would retain control of the Mets by buying the baseball team from Doubleday & Company, the publishing concern that he heads.

title: Games Called: Not Rain, Politics
description: A California baseball tour arranged by West Coast peace activists for the Nicaraguan national team has been delayed and foreshortened because of a tug-of-war between Washington and Managua over a visa for a Sandinista official.

title: Chrysler, A.M.C. In Production Pact
description: The American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation signed a contract, as expected, to produce some of Chrysler's full-size models at the Kenosha A.M.C. plant.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1986
description: International

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Honolulu last Saturday, on the primary election in Hawaii, misidentified the state's largest newspaper. It is The Honolulu Star-Bulletin, not The Advertiser.

title: Time to Reduce New York State and City Individual Income Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THAT'S LIFE!' BY BLAKE EDWARDS
description: WHEN one considers ''personal'' films, one usually envisions something small and low-budget, photographed in a black and white that is solemn, self-effacing and artistic. Not Blake Edwards. He hasn't lived most of his life in and around the southern California movie community without coming to share many of its gaudy values, which he also enthusiastically ridicules.

title: Another Hundred Flowers
description: Foreigners are startled that once again China's leadership is urging that ''a hundred flowers bloom'' and is expecting a bright response from its artists. That was the slogan of a Mao Zedong campaign a generation ago, encouraging people and especially intellectuals to speak up. Those who responded were harshly punished. The short spring brought a long freeze.

title: 7 Aliens Held in Washington As Big Smugglers of Heroin
description: Seven Nigerian nationals have been arrested in connection with a ring that smuggled heroin into the United States in wooden statues, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Wednesday.

title: MTV, Message Television
description: Not so long ago, groups eager to get the attention of legislators or the press sent telegrams rather than letters. Then this became ordinary, and many groups shifted to air express or something resembling it.

title: Advertising; Magazine Getting a New Look
description: AT 56 years of age, Norman Raben has been getting his exercise by publishing magazines for people who want to stay fit.

title: MAKEUP OF KEY FED PANEL IS UPHELD
description: A Federal district court today dismissed a suit challenging the makeup of the Federal Reserve body that holds prime responsibility for setting the nation's monetary policy.

title: ART: 31 WORKS BY WALTER MURCH BEING SHOWN
description: WALTER MURCH (1907-1967) kept a rocking chair with extra-long rockers in his studio. When he moved forward, he could paint details; when he leaned back, he could appraise his progress.

title: INSIDE
description: IRAQI EXPECTS IRANIAN FEINT The Iraqi Defense Minister says an expected Iranian offensive will probably begin with a feint to lure Iraq's strategic reserve forces.

title: Kenyan Says a Heart Attack Caused Death of Missionary
description: An autopsy on an American missionary who died at the headquarters of Kenya's Criminal Investigation Department showed that a heart attack was the cause of death, Kenya's Police Commissioner said today.

title: REMARKS BY PREMIER HIGHLIGHT JAPAN'S ATTITUDES ON MINORITIES
description: Whatever Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone meant by his remarks about minorities in the United States, some intellectuals and members of minority groups here say, he was reflecting a widespread assumption among Japanese that their homogeneity breeds strength while diversity in other societies can mean weakness.

title: Pat Robertson Group Says It's Disbanding
description: The Freedom Council, a tax-exempt organization that critics charge has been financing the Presidential ambitions of the Rev. Pat Robertson, said today that it would disband Oct. 1.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Why Made in the U.S.A. Is Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The choice today is not between this bill and a perfect bill; the choice is between this bill and the death of tax reform.

title: The Free-Trade Myth Is Ruining Us
description: America faces an economic crisis caused by the Administration's infatuation with the long dead theory of ''free trade.'' To deal with that crisis, the Senate must act quickly on trade reform legislation passed last May by the House.

title: A MARTIAL-ARTS WHIZ IN ABC'S 'SIDEKICKS'
description: TAKING a predictable cue from the success of the ''Karate Kid'' movies, television has come up with ''Sidekicks,'' starring Ernie Reyes Jr., a 14-year-old, 4 1/2-foot-tall expert in the martial arts. Created by Dan Gordon, the show began as a presentation called ''The Last Electric Knight'' on ABC's ''Disney Sunday Movie.'' Now, produced by Ric Rondell for Disney Television and Motown Productions, the spinoff weekly series is having its premiere on the same network tonight at 8:30 (its regular slot will be Fridays at 9:30, which is a bit late for what is obviously a series for young viewers).

title: Chinese Official Executed
description: A Communist Party official was executed today for leading a group that obtained more than $50,000 from fraud and bribery, the Peking radio reported. It said Huang Yuhui, deputy party secretary of He County in the southern Guangxi region, had been sentenced to death by the Guangxi Supreme Court.

title: Timely Exit
description: Ivan Lendl went for a spin with Paul Newman Tuesday, but, fortunately for the world's No. 1 male tennis player, it was not the same spin that caused the motion picture star and racing driver to whirl out of control and crash against a barrier on the race track at Lime Rock Park in Lime Rock, Conn. Newman escaped without injury.

title: Northwest Pilots
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. said that the Air Line Pilots Association had tentatively agreed to a proposal under which Northwest will not lay off any pilots for at least a year. Northwest also said it would rescind the layoffs of 24 former pilots of its recently acquired Republic Airlines.

title: USX to Raise Prices
description: The USX Corporation said that it would raise prices on all tin mill products an average of $15 a short ton, effective with shipments of Jan. 4. The move follows similar price increases announced by other steel companies.

title: SCREEN: 'PRIVATE PRACTICES'
description: THE first thing to be said about ''Private Practices'' is that it treats in remarkably straightforward fashion a subject that has a way of bringing out clinical pretentiousness or juvenile snickers. Kirby Dick's documentary, which opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema after having been shown at the Margaret Mead Film Festival at the American Museum of Natural History, is subtitled ''The Story of a Sex Surrogate.''

title: How Tax Bill Breezed Past, Despite Wide Doubts
description: Representative George E. Brown Jr. pulled out a copy of a speech he was about to deliver on the tax bill. But he was not happy with it.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUESE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 292 to 136 by which the House of Representatives today approved the compromise tax overhaul legislation. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the bill. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 176 Democrats and 116 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 74 Democrats and 62 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes.

title: 5.5% Stake in Allied Acquired by Briton
description: Alan Clore, a British investor, disclosed yesterday that he had acquired a 5.5 percent stake, or 2.6 million shares, in the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: Catholic Hospital Employees Will Receive 5 Percent Raise
description: Some 4,000 workers at four hospitals operated by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will get a 5 percent wage increase retroactive to 1984, according to a announcement issued yesterday by John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, and Georgianna Johnson, the president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union.

title: Communist and Officer Are Killed in Punjab
description: Sikh terrorists shot and killed a popular Communist leader, and two unidentified attackers killed a senior police official in Punjab State, an Indian news agency reported today.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Wind and Thunder Presents ''Yoruba Proverbs,'' Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway (864-5400). Bill Cole, the jazz writer, educator and sometime musician, has come up with an evening of music built around the wisdom of the Yoruba, who created an enduring West African civilization and have had a profound impact on the cultures of the Americas. The music is to be performed by an octet featuring some outstanding musicians - the saxophonist Julius Hemphill, the trumpeter Olu Dara and the cellist Abdul Wadud among them. The concert is tonight at 8; tickets are $10.

title: SPECIAL EXEMPTIONS IN THE TAX BILL, AS DISCLOSED BY THE SENATE
description: A list released tonight by the Senate Finance Committee identified the hundreds of corporations, private organizations and civic projects that received special exemptions in the tax revision bill passed by the House.

title: Piano, Bass and Drums
description: The pianist Kirk Lightsey, the bassist Santi DeBriano and the drummer Eddie Gladden are playing trios tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Jupiter, 228 West 10th Street (924-9292). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $5 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Economic Scene; Volcker-Baker Currency Gap
description: A STRANGE gap appears to have opened up between Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d just as the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are getting under way in Washington.

title: FIAT'S NOVEL GLOBAL OFFERING
description: When the Agnelli family and an investment bank underwriting syndicate bought back Libya's stake in Fiat, the Italian auto maker, for $3.15 billion on Tuesday, they set in motion a securities offering that breaks new ground in the emergence of a global market for corporate equities.

title: CITY OF ST. FRANCIS PREPARES FOR HIS MODERN HEIRS
description: In September and October the afternoon sky is limpid and at sunset the gray stones of Assisi turn rose colored, according to Mayor Pietro Profumi and many poets and painters before him.

title: Home Resales Up by 7%
description: Sales of existing homes jumped 7 percent in August to an annual rate of 3.69 million units, the fastest sales pace of this decade, a real estate trade group said today.

title: JAPANESE BUYING BOOM STIRS CONCERN IN HAWAII
description: A Japanese company paid $245 million last week for a Hyatt hotel near Honolulu's famous Waikiki Beach. That the same hotel sold only two years ago for $108 million did not seem to surprise many people here: Japanese investors are scooping up hotels, restaurants, buildings, golf courses and just about every other kind of tangible asset in Hawaii at record prices.

title: 'TWIST AND SHOUT,' FROM DENMARK
description: THE extremely likable Danish film ''Twist and Shout,'' directed by Bille August, is a sequel to ''Zappa,'' another film of Mr. August's that was a high point of the New Directors/New Films series in 1984. Both films center on a schoolboy named Bjorn, and both are lightly comic in tone. But they draw their strength from the portrait of an arid, conventional Danish society that Mr. August uses as these stories' implicit backdrop.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Gillespie the Immortal
description: To its collection of great American artifacts, the Smithsonian Institution is about to add the trumpet that Dizzy Gillespie played from 1972 to 1985, a silver instrument with an upturned bell. On Oct 16, he will make the formal presentation in the Presidential Reception Suite of the National Museum of American History, as seems only fitting. He may even be persuaded to play a few bars.

title: MTV Names 2 to Top Posts
description: MTV Networks, the cable television company, named two executives yesterday to replace Robert W. Pittman, the president and chief executive who is leaving to form an entertainment and communications company financed by MCA Inc.

title: Rangers Said to Seek Messier
description: The Rangers need to reshape their defense, and as always they need a scorer. Phil Esposito has reponded to both needs in probably the only manner he could.

title: NOT QUITE A MASTER OF THE ART
description: This is how to perfect the art of skateboarding in four easy steps:

title: AFP IMAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $116,155.

title: Lakers Waive Lucas
description: Maurice Lucas, a veteran power forward for 10 seasons, was waived by the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Invitation to Wiesel
description: In what is considered a significant gesture, the Soviet Union has invited Elie Wiesel, chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, to meet with Soviet scholars next month to investigate the fate of millions of eastern Europeans, Russian soldiers and others who killed in Nazi concentration camps in World War II.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
HEALTHWAYS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mr. Reagan's Veto, Not America's
description: As Congress has already made plain with its lopsided votes, the President who yesterday vetoed its angry, calibrated sanctions against South Africa does not speak for the American people. There will be time to weigh the President's arguments against Congress overriding his veto. But his continued resistance makes him appear apartheid's virtual defender. The repugnant symbolism of his veto calls for instant protest.

title: 'DECLINE,' A COMDEY BY FRENCH-CANADIANS
description: Denys Arcand's ''Decline of the American Empire'' isn't easy to know at first. It's like finding yourself at a dinner party where you're the only stranger among intimate friends. They're a tight little band. In one way and another, all of the characters in this new French-Canadian film are attached to the university's history department, either as professors or instructors, or as wives, mistresses or lovers of same.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1986
description: Companies Doubleday's publishing unit will be sold to Bertelsmann. The deal, which had been expected, will make the German book publisher the second largest in the U.S. after Simon & Schuster. The price, $475 million in cash plus some other proceeds, exceeded estimates by analysts. Bertelsmann, which already owns Bantam Books, will gain the Literary Guild, one of the nation's two leading book clubs. Doubleday said that the sale of the New York Mets baseball team had not been completed. [ Page 37. ] Ralston Purina has gained the upper hand over Quaker Oats in the takeover battle for Anderson, Clayton, Wall Street professionals said. Some experts said that Ralston might have already gained control of more than half of Anderson, Clayton's stock. Meanwhile, Quaker Oats filed a Federal suit charging that a Ralston-Anderson merger would lessen competition in the pet food business. [ 37. ] A move to insure an LTV pension fund's annual payment was made by Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The Federal agency seeks control of the fund, but the action raises the possibility that it will become responsible for all $2.5 billion of the unfunded pension liabilities in LTV Steel, the nation's No. 2 producer. [ 37. ] Allied Supermarkets and Vons agreed to merge. The two large retail food companies valued the deal at $660 million, including the assumption of about $440 million in debt. [ 38. ] CBS may cut 400 to 500 staff positions, sources at the communications giant said. [ 38. ] The Economy The Senate's final debate on tax revision began, with no doubt that the bill will be approved by a comfortable margin.

title: U.S. INDICTS 22 AT EASTERN AIR ON DRUG COUNTS
description: Twenty-two cargo and baggage handlers for Eastern Airlines were indicted on drug smuggling charges today by a Federal grand jury in Miami.

title: ARLEY MERCHANDISE reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The net income represents net investment income.

title: Therapists and Sex Survey
description: About one in five psychotherapists in Wisconsin has reported treating people who had harmful sexual encounters with previous therapists. The Wisconsin Psychological Association said today that 20 percent in a survey of 1,559 therapists reported having patients who had been involved in a sexual relationship with a previous counselor.

title:
Patents;
A Method to Synthesize Opium Derivatives
description: A method of synthesizing opium derivatives, which are used as pain-killers and narcotic antidotes, has been invented for the Department of Health and Human Services. Kenner C. Rice, a research chemist in the National Institutes of Health, was granted patent No. 4,613,668 this week.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. DETROIT TIGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) METS VS. PIRATES, at Pittsburgh, 7:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M.; Radio - WHN, 1050; 7 P.M.) RED SOX VS. TORONTO BLUE JAYS, at Boston (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.). HOUSTON ASTROS VS. BRAVES, at Atlanta, 4:10 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) PADRES VS. CINCINNATI REDS, at San Diego (Radio - WCBS, 880; 10:05 P.M.).

title: BOND PRICES INCREASE SLIGHTLY
description: Bond prices inched cautiously higher in very light trading yesterday.

title: SPOTLIGHT BECKONS AT LAST
description: Injuries - the overriding X factor in pro football - have suddenly made leading men of two Jets who usually perform in plodding roles.

title: Rehnquist Can Find Comfort in Hughes's Ordeal
description: William H. Rehnquist, who was sworn in yesterday, can take comfort in the fact that he is by no means the first Chief Justice of the United States to win confirmation from a divided Senate after vehement debate. An illustrious predecessor, Charles Evans Hughes, had to run a similar gantlet, albeit on different issues, and was confirmed by almost the same proportion of Senate votes - about 2 to 1 - as Chief Justice Rehnquist.

title: GAGLIARDI AND MCPHERSON IN A MATCHUP
description: For Joe Gagliardi the season has been a delight so far, and for Don McPherson it has been little more than a disaster. Both are quarterbacks.

title: Compliance With Election Law Tests a Candidate's Competence
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE TAKES UP DRUG BILL WITH SESSION WANING
description: In a race against adjournment, the Senate opened debate today on a sweeping package of proposals aimed at choking off the supply of dangerous drugs and the demand for them.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PROGRAMS UNLIMITED reports earnings for Year to June 30
SEA CONTAINERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes foreign exchange losses of $1,002,000 for the quarter and $989,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and includes foreign exchange gains of $200,000 for the quarter and foreign exchange losses of $956,000 for the 6 months.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RADICAL MAGAZINE REMOVES EDITOR, SETTING OFF A WIDENING POLITICAL DEBATE
description: Mother Jones, the radical magazine that says it is the nation's largest political monthly, has removed its editor, who has filed a $2 million lawsuit. The situation prompted a bitter debate in the columns of other publications with similar views.

title: E.P.A. Is Found Losing Waste Cleanup Funds
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is losing millions of dollars in potential waste cleanup money because it has not been aggressive in collecting from those responsible for dumping toxic wastes, an audit released today showed.

title: CONTROL OF LTV FUND SOUGHT
description: In order to prevent one of the pension funds of the LTV Corporation from missing its annual payment, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said today that it was seeking to take control of the fund.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR ELDERLY: A NEW OPTION
description: When John During had a stroke two years ago at the age of 79 and entered the De Kalb County Nursing Home, west of Chicago, his wife did not have to worry that they would go bankrupt paying $18,000 a year in nursing home expenses.

title: BLAST WOUNDS 3 IN JOHANNESBURG TAVERN
description: An explosion apparently caused by a bomb wounded three people today in a downtown bar here, the police said.

title: ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dow Edges Up 1.13 As Trading Is Light
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday in lighter trading. Traders continued to focus on the course of interest rates and doubts about the economy.

title: VIDEO GAMES, ONCE ZAPPED, IN COMEBACK
description: Don't look now, but here comes Pac-Man. Again. Video games, the entertainment craze blamed for everything from sore thumbs to the decline of the nation's youth, are making a comeback.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The company said electric operating revenues include revenues subject to refund of $179,377,000 for the 12 months ended Aug. 31, 1986 pursuant to the May 16, 1986 order of the Circuit Court of Cook County, Ill.

title: CABARET: JULIE WILSON SINGS
description: Since ending an eight-year semiretirement from the nightclub stage two and a half years ago, Julie Wilson has rebuilt her career by applying her extraordinary talents as a mature singing actress to individual programs devoted to the songs of Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim, Rodgers and Hart, the Gershwins, Noel Coward, Kurt Weill and Irving Berlin. Last Tuesday, Ms. Wilson and her longtime accompanist, William Roy, returned to what has become their regular fall home, the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, with a tribute to the songs of Harold Arlen.

title: GASTINEAU DOUBTFUL; BUT HALFBACK MIGHT PLAY
description: The Giants reported today that Joe Morris, their main running back, was hospitalized with an undisclosed ailment. Although there were indications that the problem was not serious, Coach Bill Parcells listed Morris as questionable for Sunday's game here against the New Orleans Saints, which meant he was given a 50-50 chance to play.

title: U.S. ARMS AGENCY: BATTLEGROUND IN FIGHTS OVER DISARMAMENT
description: On Sept. 26, 1961, President Kennedy signed a law creating a semiautonomous body called the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Its very name symbolized the passing of an era, the transition from the visionary goal of total disarmament to more modest thinking about arms control.

title: STAGE: SISTERS CLASH IN 'NOT SHOWING'
description: James Ryan's corrosive comedy, ''Not Showing,'' in which two sisters and their husbands gather in a backwoods cabin to arrange their grandfather's funeral, portrays a thoroughly disharmonious quartet of warped libidos.

title: CENTRAL PARK TREE: 5TMS, NO FEE, GREAT BREEZE
description: ''This is New York,'' Frank Serpe, city official, said with a shrug. ''People live in the trees.'' This is something those in other parts of the country have long suspected.

title: The Thonic Boom
description: ''Thons'' are spreading. The Times of Sept. 12 announced a ''nonstop 100-hour reading'' of Shakespeare's complete works. It was called a ''Bard-a-thon.''

title: WHITE COMPRESSOR UNIT
description: White Consolidated Industries has formed a new division tomake and market compressors and motors for other appliance companies, White said today. The company combines the Americold Compressor Company and the Athens Products Comapany.

title: ATOMIC POWER SFETY STEPS APPROVED
description: Member nations of the International Atomic Energy Agency approved two international conventions today requiring countries to inform each other immediately about nuclear accidents and to help countries where such accidents take place.

title: CBS Is Said To Plan Cuts
description: CBS Inc. may cut 400 to 500 staff positions, sources at the broadcasting company said yesterday. The move would be part of the company's efforts to cut costs in the face of a heavy debt load and a disappointing earnings outlook.

title: 2 Soldiers in Ulster Convicted of Killing Man
description: Two soldiers were convicted of murder today and sentenced to life in prison for the slaying of a Roman Catholic civilian 18 months ago.

title: NAKASONE APOLOGIZES FOR COMMENTS THAT OFFENDED U.S. MINORITIES
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone apologized today for remarks about ethnic minorities in the United States.

title:
Patents;
Antenna Reflector Aids Space Communications
description: A spacecraft antenna reflector was patented this week by Roger A. Stonier of San Jose, Calif., for the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation of Detroit.

title: U.N. Project in Trouble
description: A secret report prepared for the State Department that suggests the Soviet Union has used the United Nations Environmental Project as a cover for spying may have scuttled a United States appropriation to support the project.

title: Pat Robertson Group Says It's Disbanding
description: The Freedom Council, a tax-exempt organization that critics charge has been financing the Presidential ambitions of the Rev. Pat Robertson, said Thursday that it would disband Oct. 1.

title: Marathon Reading of Complete Shakespeare
description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company will conduct a 5-day, 100-hour reading of Shakespeare's complete works next month to open its 10th season as New York City's only resident Shakespeare company. The readings - by professional actors, including cast members from the Broadway production of ''Nicholas Nickelby'' -will begin on Tuesday, Oct. 14, at 7 P.M. and will end on Saturday, Oct. 18, at 11 P.M., at the Shakespeare Center, 165 West 86th Street.

title: JOHN H. GARY
description: John H. Gary, the motions clerk of the New York Court of Appeals for at least 20 years, died last Saturday at the Albany Medical Center Hospital after a brief illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Wyantskill, N.Y.

title: SCANDALE! PET CEMETERY BY THE SEINE UNDER SIEGE
description: Rin Tin Tin is buried here. So is Poilu, whose tombstone tells visitors of the ovation he received for his performance in the 1929 production in Paris of ''A Priest Among the Rich.''

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL'S RAIDERS
description: Two days before the most significant regular-season game in the history of the football program at the University of Miami, the team's halfback was in court asking for a postponement of a trial on a charge of petty theft, and the athletic director held a meeting with campus police to discuss a growing animosity between players and security guards that had existed for at least two months.

title: 200 French Paratroopers Take Up Guard in Togo
description: About 200 French paratroopers took positions in Lome today, and a French Navy minesweeper steamed offshore in support of Togo's Government after a coup attempt.

title: U.S. CIVIL RIGHTS COMMISSION APPROVES EXTENSIVE CUTBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -

title: Meese Disputes Report About Antidrug Troops
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today denied that the United States had held discussions with Colombia, Ecuador or Peru regarding the possibility of sending American military troops to help with drug eradication.

title: U.S. ASSAILED AGAIN ON CURBING CUBAN IMMIGRANTS
description: The Reagan Administration's policy toward immigration from Cuba, already under attack in the House Foreign Affairs Committee, came under strong bipartisan criticism today at a hearing of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: ANGELS CAPTURE TITLE
description: Brian Downing knocked in five runs with two homers as the California Angels clinched their third divisional title in eight seasons tonight with an 8-3 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Blowin' in the Winds
description: The Metropolitan Soloists Wind Octet, under the artistic direction of Christine Soder, will present a free concert of works by Mozart and Gounod at the Fort Washington Branch Library, 535 West 179th Street, this afternoon at 2. Information: 221-7676.

title: U.S. BACKA BROAD ELLIS I. PLAN
description: A key Federal committee today endorsed the conversion of more than two dozen deteriorated buildings on Ellis Island into a privately financed conference center.

title: Boxer Arrested
description: Reggie Gross, the heavyweight knocked out by Mike Tyson in the first round last June 13 at Madison Square Garden, has been arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the slaying two weeks ago of a man shot execution-style, the police in Baltimore reported yesterday.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS LIFTING SANCTIONS ON WARSAW
description: A high-ranking State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration was ''actively examining'' whether the United States should lift the remaining economic sanctions against Poland in response to the recent release of Polish political prisoners.

title: Karpov Takes Time Out For Final Delay in Match
description: Anatoly Karpov called his final timeout today in the world chess championship, postponing his 20th game against Gary Kasparov, the champion, until Monday.

title: Nicaraguan Supreme Court Rejects Newspaper's Appeal
description: The Nicaraguan Supreme Court has rejected an appeal by the opposition newspaper La Prensa against its closing by the Government three months ago.

title: HOMELESS SHIFTED TO NEWARK MOTEL
description: New York City, faced with increasing numbers of people without homes and a dwindling number of places to house them, began referring homeless families to a motel in Newark last night, according to officials.

title: MICHIGAN DIVERSIFYING ITS ECONOMY
description: In the early 1980's Michigan led the nation in unemployment as the recession and surge of imported cars crippled the state's automobile-dominated economy. Now, though, unemployment is falling more rapidly than in other nearby industrial states, indicating that Michigan is succeeding in its effort to diversify its economic base.

title: China Grain Near Peak
description: China's 1986 grain harvest will be the second highest on record, the Ministry of Agriculture said today. The New China News Agency quoted a ministry spokesman as saying the rise was due to increased acreage and measures to combat droughts in the south and flooding in the north.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: REHNQUIST AND SCALIA TAKE THEIR PLACES ON COURT
description: Turning a page of history, William Hubbs Rehnquist took his oath today as the 16th Chief Justice of the United States, and Antonin Scalia took his as the newest Associate Justice.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,345,000, or $3.79 a share, related to damages awarded in a breach of contract action.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: COMMTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company went public July 8.

title: POLICE INQUIRY MAY LEAD TO PERJURY ACCUSATIONS
description: A grand jury investigation into allegations of police corruption in the 77th Precinct, where 13 officers accused of stealing from drug dealers have been suspended, may result in perjury or other charges against more officers, police officials said yesterday.

title: CALSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $154,000 and $151,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Thursday of Henry P. deVries, a lawyer and emeritus professor at Columbia Law School, misstated his Army rank with the Office of Strategic Services in World War II. He was a lieutenant colonel.

title: Italy Announces Sanctions
description: The Italian Government said today that it was banning the import of scrap iron and steel products from South Africa as part of a joint European effort to press that country to abolish apartheid.

title: Vons and Allied Set Food Chain Merger
description: The Vons Companies and Allied Supermarkets Inc., two big retail food market companies, have agreed to merge, the companies announced today.

title: This Is a Way to Treat a 14-Year-Old Pupil?
description: One hears much these days of students who have, as they say, fallen through the cracks of the educational system, usually in some spectacular and tragic manner. This implies that there is a catwalk up there somewhere, a clearly defined pathway that, provided everyone does his job, leads the youth of New York City to a lifetime of literacy and good citizenship. The experience of my daughter suggests otherwise.

title: Eddy Kirkland, Guitar
description: The blues guitarist Eddy Kirkland will make his first New York appearance in five years tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: JUMPING-JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NU HORIZONS ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CLARK (J.L.) MANUFACTURING CO (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BASQUE VOTE SET AFER SCHISM
description: The Basque regional government today called early elections amid political turmoil that officials in Madrid said had complicated the fight against Basque separatist terrorists.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income

title: No Basis for Nuclear-Controls Charges Against India
description: To the Editor:

title: T.I.M.E.-DC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $250,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $283,000.

title: TALKS ON 1987 PENTAGON BILL STALL OVER TRAINING PLANE MADE ON L.I.
description: Senate and House negotiators on the 1987 military programs bill recessed discussions today after they hit a snag over the future of the T-46A training plane, manufactured by the Fairchild Republic Company on Long Island.

title: Singing the Blues
description: The blues singer Johnny Littlejohn will appear tonight at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908), with the solo blues singer John Campbell opening. Shows are about 9 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Don't Punish Aliens With Death by Illness
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
A Guide for Placing Catheter in the Brain
description: A guide invented by Dr. Jamshid B. G. Ghajar, a neurosurgeon at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, helps surgeons place more precisely a catheter through a hole in the cranium into the ventricular section of the brain.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch from Washington yesterday, on a proposal to remove a non-narcotic painkiller from the market, incorrectly described another drug, Selacryn, that was banned in 1980. Selacryn is a diuretic used to treat hypertension, not a painkiller.

title: Don't Punish Aliens With Death by Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes discount benefits of $296,451 for the quarter and $217,397 for the 6 months received in the reported periods resulting from quantity purchases made in earlier periods.

title: Society Must Live By Values It Wants Taught
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: NEW WORKS IN 'SHOWCASE I'
description: Four choreographers presented works Wednesday night in ''Choreo Showcase I,'' the first of a series of programs by young choreographers scheduled this fall at the Theater of the Riverside Church. It was a choreographic grab bag.

title: Hilde-Marie Dunker Weds Peter Munson
description: Hilde-Marie Dunker, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hans-Joachim Dunker of Rio de Janeiro, was married yesterday to Peter Countcil Munson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund G. Munson Jr. of Utica, N.Y. The Rev. Max Preilipper performed the ceremony at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Portugal Is Selected for Vatican Post
description: President Reagan will nominate Frank Shakespeare, the current Ambassador to Portugal, to be Ambassador to the Vatican, the White House announced today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 11 about the Democratic primary election in New York misidentified Carole A. DeSaram, an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic state committee. She says she is not an ally of Mayor Koch.

title: Senate Debates Tax Bill; Wide Approval Is Predicted
description: With no doubt that the bill will be approved by a comfortable margin, the Senate began its final debate on tax revision legislation today.

title: Unjam New York's Housing
description: While New York City agonizes over complex housing problems, City Hall's own statistics show that it has not kept up with the capital spending and commitment rates in other realms. While city agencies generally have allocated 98 percent of their capital funds, the Housing Department has allocated only 65 percent. Housing strategies need close study and weighty changes.

title:
American Industry Heads Into Outer Space;
2. Subsidies are Needed
description: President Reagan's decision to limit shuttle launchings primarily to military and research functions, with a few civilian launchings, and to look to the private sector for launching commercial payloads is wise. It is a step toward solving the problem of finding reliable, less costly and more efficient systems for putting payloads into orbit for both military and civilian operations. But subsequent White House policy that no subsidies will be provided to encourage the development of commercial launching services is unrealistic and counterproductive. The 200 commercial satellites expected to be launched in the next decade are too few to create or sustain a market economy for exorbitantly expensive space launchers. Subsidies in the initial commercialization phase are essential to challenge and spur the private sector, just as mail subsidies sustained commercial aviation in its infancy.

title: Malaysia Ousts 2 Writers Of Financial Newspaper
description: Two correspondents of The Asian Wall Street Journal were ordered to leave Malaysia today, and sales of the newspaper were banned for three months.

title: SOVIET SPOKESMAN SEES PROGRESS ON A MEDIUM-RANGE MISSLE ACCORD
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the Kremlin believes progress has been made toward a superpower agreement on medium-range nuclear missiles, and that obstacles to a new summit meeting can be resolved.

title: Bridge; Leaders in Open Pairs Title Are Overtaken in 3d Session
description: When the world championships resumed here this afternoon, it seemed likely that, for the first time, a world title would go ''Down Under.'' But if it turns out that way, there may some argument about whether Australia actually deserves the victory.

title: CITING APARTHEID, JERSEY WITHDRAWS $1.5 BILLION
description: In the first year of one of the nation's most far-reaching divestment programs, New Jersey has withdrawn $1.5 billion in pension fund investments from companies doing business in South Africa and has raised its total planned divestiture to $4.3 billion, from $2.7 billion.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Reagan and Columnist Have Oval Office Chat
description: President Reagan and the syndicated columnist George Will, his sometime confidant and recent critic, chatted for more than half an hour at the Oval Office Thursday.

title: New Foreign Institute At Brown University
description: Brown University opened a $15 million Institute for International Studies this week with two days of speeches and discussions.

title: Stephanie M. Nebehay Weds Nicolas C. Ulmer
description: Stephanie Marie Nebehay, a daughter of Mrs. Wolfgang G. Nebehay of Euclid, Ohio, and the late Dr. Nebehay, was married yesterday to Nicolas Courtland Ulmer, a son of Doris Bridges Ulmer of New York and Alfred C. Ulmer Jr. of Devonshire, Bermuda. The Rev. Judith T. Baumer performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Knicks Make Offer For Bulls' Oldham
description: The Knicks, the second worst shot-blocking team in the National Basketball Association last season, have tried to remedy the problem with an offer sheet to Jawann Oldham, the Chicago Bulls' 7-foot free-agent center.

title: Speakes Belittles News Parley
description: The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, suggested today that Presidential news conferences had ''outgrown their usefulness'' and defended the Reagan Administration's tight controls on information to the news media.

title: European Bid to Stabilize Currencies
description: Europeans attending a secrecy-shrouded five-nation meeting here today of top economic officials said they would be appealing to all the countries to try to stabilize the exchange rates of their currencies at current levels until they get a better sense of where the world economy is headed.

title: AN INQUIRY OR A TRAP?
description: When members of Congress became the targets of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam inquiry, the issue of entrapment was raised almost immediately. The same thing happened when judges and lawyers in Chicago became subjects of a Federal undercover investigation into corruption in the Cook County Circuit Court and when John Z. DeLorean was charged with cocaine trafficking.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I pray that God will grant me the patience, the wisdom and the fortitude to worthily follow in the footsteps of my illustrious predecessors in discharging the responsibilities of this high office.'' - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. [ 8:5. ]

title: Make Sex Education Mandatory
description: Should sex education be taught in New York City's schools? The annual teen-age pregnancy total - 35,000 - argues cogently that it should. Yet the subject continues to stir powerful controversy.

title:
Patents;
Underwater Flow Generates Electricity
description: An underwater generator of electricity, which is to be tested by the New York Power Authority in the East River in the next six months, was patented this week by Dean R. Corren, a New York University research scientist, and Gabriel Miller, a professor of applied science at the university.

title: JACK BODI, DESIGNER AND PHOTOGRAPHER OF FRENCH COUTURE
description: Jack Bodi, a fashion photographer who had a second career as a knitwear designer, died of a stroke Sunday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue, L.I. He was 68 years old and had suffered from lymphoma for two years.

title: MATTINGLY KEEPS HIS STREAK ALIVE
description: The crowds have become sparse, but Don Mattingly is still playing as if the Stadium were full and a division championship was at stake. The Yankees moved one step closer to elimination from the American League East race last night, losing by a 3-2 margin to the Detroit Tigers, but Mattingly kept alive the streak that matters: he had one hit in four times at bat and now has hit successfully in 24 consecutive games.

title: FED VOTED TO EASE POLICY IN AUGUST
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board voted to ease monetary policy further at an August meeting the day before the Fed cut the discount rate, according to minutes of the closed-door session released today.

title: HOUSE REFUSES TO CONSIDER BROAD BILL ON IMMIGRATION
description: The House of Representatives today refused to consider a comprehensive immigration bill, and supporters of the legislation said it was dead.

title: Prosecutor Halts Bridge Roadblocks
description: The Bergen County Prosecutor has canceled drug and alcohol checks at the George Washington Bridge.

title: Cleon Jones Sentenced
description: A judge in Mobile, Ala., told Cleon Jones he was letting him off easy in handing the former Met outfielder a 10-year suspended sentence on guilty pleas to first-degree assault charges.

title: MILK PANEL SEEKS END TO AD RULE
description: In 1973 the American Dairy Association agreed to demands by the Federal Trade Commission that it not make dietary claims for milk without including in its advertisements the number of calories and the amount of calories that come from fat.

title: Waiting for Walesa
description: Lech Walesa, the Polish dissident and Nobel Peace Prize recipient, may come to the United States next month if an influential group of members of Congress have their way. Mr. Walesa has been selected for the 1986 International Integrity Award by the John-Roger Foundation of Los Angeles, which has enlisted senators and representative to press the State Department and the Polish Government to clear the way for him to come to this country for an award ceremony Oct. 24.

title: DENEUVE IN 'SCENE OF THE CRIME'
description: Andre Techine's elegant thriller ''Scene of the Crime'' is alive with danger and sexual possibility, in a manner reminiscent of Claude Chabrol. Though its setting is rural, it is never bucolic, not for a moment. The film begins as a young boy takes a bicycle ride, and no sooner has he stopped to pick a flower - a sprig of oleander, which is poisonous - than he is accosted by a stranger. The man has no money, and he orders the boy to get him some and return with it by nightfall. The boy is too frightened not to do as he is told.

title: SPEAKERS AT U.N. ASSAIL TERRORISM
description: The Foreign Ministers of India and Sri Lanka called today for greater international cooperation to fight terrorism in a day of speeches that touched on subjects ranging from Afghanistan to drug trafficking.

title: PROFILES OF SEVEN FINANCE OFFICIALS MEETING IN WASHINGTON
description: Britain

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1986
description: International President Reagan vetoed legislation imposing economic sanctions against South Africa, calling punitive measures ''the wrong course to follow.'' Setting the stage for a rare foreign policy battle with Congress and Senate Republicans, he said that the United States ''must stay and build, not cut and run.'' [ Page 1, Col. 6. ] Spies are to be rooted out and punished severely by the Reagan Administration, President Reagan promised. He said the Administration would not tolerate the arrest of innocent Americans ''in retaliation for protecting ourselves from espionage.'' Speaking at the National Security Agency, the code-breaking and electronic intelligence organization, Mr. Reagan did not specifically mention the case of Nicholas S. Daniloff. But his remarks were clearly intended to send a tough message about the Daniloff case. [ 1:4. ] A British journalist told of escaping kidnappers in the Moslem Shiite southern suburbs of Beirut. David Hirst, Middle East correspondent of The Guardian told colleagues that he had escaped from three armed men who had forced him into a car. [ 3:3. ] A suspected terrorist in France whose release is being demanded by a group of bombers in Paris will probably stand trial within months, the Minister of Justice said. The Minister, Albin Chalandon, said he had ordered prosecutors to demand that Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, the reputed had of a terrorist group called the Lebanese Armed Revolutionary Faction, be brought to trial on charges related to the deaths in Paris of two diplomats, an Israeli and an American, in 1982.

title: MAY RACE IN 1987
description: Ogygian, the star-crossed 3-year-old who finished a dull third as the heavy favorite in the Pegasus Handicap 15 days ago, will be sent home to Tartan Farm in Ocala, Fla., tomorrow for the rest of the year but may race again next season.

title: DOUBLEDAY BOOK UNITS TO BE SOLD
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the big German publisher, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the publishing operations of Doubleday & Company for $475 million. If completed, the deal would make Bertelsmann the second- largest book publisher in the United States, after Simon & Schuster.

title: INSIDE
description: Immigration Bill Dies The House refused to consider a comprehensive immigration bill, and supporters of the legislation said that it was dead. Page 8.

title: Randy Weston, Piano
description: The pianist Randy Weston is appearing tonight and tomorrow at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street (675-7900). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: Fugitive's Wounds Thought to Be Serious
description: Tests conducted today on a bullet-riddled stolen car that a fugitive was driving when last seen indicate he may be seriously wounded.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES BILL FOR SANCTIONS AGAINST PRETORIA
description: President Reagan, calling punitive economic measures ''the wrong course to follow,'' tonight vetoed legislation imposing economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: TV: NEW POLICE DRAMA, 'DOWNTOWN,' ON CBS
description: Described by CBS as a ''one-hour police drama with humor,'' ''Downtown,'' making its debut at 8 o'clock this evening, offers still another television collection of misfits posing as crimebusters. Those viewers who find ''The A-Team'' hilarious might, with some effort, work up a tiny snicker for ''Downtown.''

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Norse Restake Claim
description: Under unexpectedly sunny skies, a small Viking-style ship sailed into New York Harbor yesterday to begin celebrations marking the 1,000th anniversary of the discovery of North America - an event that is bound to reopen the ancient debate over which explorers did what.

title: New Savings Deposits
description: New deposits at federally insured savings and loan institutions exceeded withdrawals by $1.5 billion in August, half the increase of the month before, the Government reported. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said on Thursday that deposits had exceeded withdrawals by $3 billion in July, the second-biggest increase of the year. Mortgage lending in August remained at a high level with $25.4 billion in loans closed, 43.8 percent higher than a year ago.

title: GASTINEAU DOUBTFUL; ONE OF MANY INJURED JETS
description: What started as a week in which Coach Joe Walton of the Jets was concerned about his team's enthusiasm for the game Sunday in Indianapolis has wound up with real worries about the club's health.

title: THE VATICAN AND DISSENT IN AMERICA
description: Within the Vatican's large and loosely articulated bureaucracy several recent efforts to discipline American Catholics are described as separate initiatives, each driven by different institutional imperatives.

title: THE OPERA: 'MANON LESCAUT'
description: Puccini's ''Manon Lescaut'' features a libretto strewn with dramatic craters - gaps in plot over which its story line jumps with only great difficulty. But, as the Metropolitan Opera reminded us Wednesday night, it contains music of considerable beauty, particularly in its use of chorus.

title: Ohio Fumes Hospitalize 89
description: A chemical reaction released irritating fumes inside a plastics plant Thursday, sending 89 workers to hospitals for treatment, officials said. The fumes at the Budd Company plant were caused by a chemical reaction between adhesives and structural foam inside five-gallon containers that had been placed in a waste bin, a company spokesman said. The plant was closed for three hours while the air was ventilated, officials said.

title: Burroughs Pact
description: The Burroughs Corporation will receive up to $29 million to build as many as 44 letter-sorting machines, the Postal Service said.

title: 10 Die as Soviet Bridge Falls
description: Ten people were killed and 14 were admitted to hospitals last weekend after a bridge collapsed at a hydroelectric power station in Latvia, a Communist Party newspaper said this week.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., said that effective Jan. 4 it would raise the price of its tin mill products by $15 a ton, matching increases announced by competitors.

title: Mother Frees Son From Alligator's Grip
description: A 12-year-old boy who was snorkeling in a creek was bitten on the head by an alligator then chased to shore, where his mother yanked him from the gator's grip.

title: LOWELL C. WADMOND, LAWYER AND PATRON OF ARTS, DIES AT 90
description: Lowell C. Wadmond, for 50 years a prominent Wall Street attorney, Republican Party activist and patron of the arts, died Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., after a heart attack. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
American Industry Heads Into Outer Space; 1. It Can Do the Job
description: President Reagan's decision to build another space shuttle and to shift responsibility for launching communications satellites to private industry marks a turning point in the space program.

title: TERROR SUSPECT TO STAND TRIAL IN PARIS
description: The French Minister of Justice said today that a terrorist suspect whose release from prison was being demanded by a group responsible for recent bombings here would probably stand trial within months.

title: FIRST AMERICAN HEALTH CONEPTS reports earnings for Year to July 31
SWEET VICTORY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.B.I. Assisting Inquiry Into Slaying of Girl, 11
description: The Federal Bureau Investigation has joined the investigation of the strangulation and sexual assault of an 11-year-old girl as she walked from school to her home.

title: MUSIC: 'VIENNA 1900' SERIES
description: The Wednesday evening concert in the ''Vienna 1900: A Festival of Music'' series at the Museum of Modern Art - the fourth of the eight programs -stuck soberly to the central trinity of the Second Viennese School, Schoenberg and his two prize pupils, Berg and Webern, and more narrowly still to mostly string-quartet music composed between 1907 and 1910.

title: KEY RATES

PATENTS;
Millionth Patent by Computer
description: THE one millionth patent produced by a computerized printing system first used in 1970 was granted this week. Patent No. 4,613,269, assigned to Object Recognition Systems Inc. of Princeton, N.J., covers a method of guiding robots in handling materials.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Wayne Babych will undergo surgery today for torn ligaments in his right knee and should be lost to the Hartford Whalers for at least six months, the team announced yesterday. The right wing was hurt Wednesday in Hartford's 3-2 exhibition loss to the Quebec Nordiques. . . . Two drivers, Kyle Petty and Ricky Rudd, have been fined by Nascar following a review of their driving in last Sunday's Goody's 500 at Martinsville, Va.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net income

title: MEXICO'S LOAN TALKS SNAGGGED
description: The Mexican debt talks stalled again today over the question of interest rates, and bankers said they were no longer confident that an accord on a $6 billion loan to Mexico could be reached before a Monday deadline.

title: NEW TESTIMONY IS SET IN DONOVAN FRAUD TRIAL
description: A former special Federal prosecutor who investigated Raymond J. Donovan will testify Monday in a dispute over evidence in Mr. Donovan's fraud trial, a judge said yesterday.

title: REAGAN PROMISES TO ROOT OUT SPIES, RESIST RETALIATION
description: President Reagan promised today that his Administration would root out and severely punish spies and would not tolerate arrests of innocent Americans ''in retaliation for protecting ourselves from espionage.''

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
A Legend Lives On
description: Fiorello H. La Guardia had a pretty good sense of timing, it has often been noted. But even posthumously?

title: REAGAN VETOES AID FOR TRIBES
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have extended programs that provide grants to Indian tribes and organizations, native Alaskan villages and corporations, and native Hawaiian communities and organizations.

title: LABARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $18,570,781 and $20,969,816 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $799,877 for the quarter and $12,561,965 for the year. The company said the 1985 figures reflect results for the year ended Dec. 31, 1984 because it subsequently changed from a calendar year to a fiscal year ended June 30. It did not provide directly comparable figures for the latest year and the prior year.

title: Flutie Getting Release
description: Bob Woolf, Doug Flutie's attorney, said yesterday that he had a verbal agreement with Donald Trump, owner of the New Jersey Generals, to release the quarterback from his contract in the hope that Flutie could play in the National Football League this season.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Mothers' Appeal
description: Slight and frail at the age of 81, Kitzia Ratner said:

title: BRITISH REPORTER IN BEIRUT SAYS HE ESCAPED ABDUCTORS
description: A British journalist said today that he had foiled an attempt to kidnap him in the predominantly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs of the capital.

title: Lawmakers in Texas To Grapple With Deficit
description: The Texas Legislature, nearly three weeks into its second straight special session, appears ready to gain control of one of the largest deficits in state history.

title: Italians Convict Filipino Of Weapons Possession
description: A former Philippine Ambassador to the Vatican was found guilty in an Italian court today of illegal possession of weapons and was sentenced to a three-year jail term.

title: Suspect Accused of Bribery
description: An 18-year-old man, arrested in an assault case, was charged with second-degree bribery yesterday after he offered the arresting officer $1,580 in cash to set him free. The suspect, Cleve Abbot, offered the bribe to Officer Stephen Fitzpatrick, the police said. The officer is assigned to the 77th precinct in Brooklyn, where 13 officers accused of stealing from drug dealers have been suspended.

title: PIZZA'S HOME-DELIVERY WAR
description: It is already being called the Pizza Wars.

title: TAKEOVER EDGE SEEN OF RALSTON
description: The takeover battle for Anderson, Clayton & Company, the big Houston based food producer, has tilted strongly in favor of the Ralston Purina Company, Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

title: Shearson Group Bids for Vernitron
description: An investment group, led by the New York brokerage firm Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said it had offered to acquire a controlling interest in the Vernitron Corporation, an electromechanical concern, for $12.50 a share in cash, or about $30 million. A spokesman for Vernitron, based in Lake Success, L.I., said the company had no comment.

title: MONTANA IS HIT BY HEAVY RAINS, CAUSING WORST FLOODS IN 30 YEARS
description: North-central Montana, drenched by 18 hours of heavy rains, has been hit by the worst flooding in 30 years, officials said.

title: College Games at a Glance
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. LOCAL TEAMS Army (1-1) vs. Wake Forest (2-1) Jolted by Northwestern, Cadets now meet team averaging 30 points a game. Columbia (0-1) vs. Lafayette (1-1) Columbia's losing streak can be easily extended to 23. (TV - Channel 13).

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: Among the most severe traffic trouble spots this weekend in the New York metropolitan region, according to the City Transportation Department, are these:

title: YOUR MONEY
description: MANY purchasers of Ginnie Mae mutual funds are understandably confused these days about the wide range of yields that funds disclose to the public. Because of this confusion - which some securities executives believe is caused by misleading advertising - the Securities and Exchange Commission is considering the promulgation of rules governing such advertising.

title: BELGIAN WRITER HELD AT NEWARK AIRPORT AS A SUSPECTED COMMUNIST
description: A correspondent for a Socialist newspaper in Belgium was detained overnight Thursday after immigration officials found Communist documents in his baggage when he arrived at Newark on a flight from Brussels.

title: SCOTTO AS 'BUTTERFLY,' ALSO RUNS THE SHOW
description: ''Before, I always saw Pinkerton as, you know, my tenor.'' The speaker is Renata Scotto, who returns to the Metropolitan Opera as a veteran and a debutante tonight when she becomes the first woman to direct and star in an opera - ''Madama Butterfly'' -at the house. At those last two words her expressive face is suffused with a smile at once humorously apologetic and distinctly possessive. Butterfly may not get her man in the opera, but one somehow senses that Vasile Moldoveanu will not be the first Lieutenant Pinkerton whose interpretation Miss Scotto has directed in one way or another. ''Now,'' she continues, ''I want to see the American funny guy, who wants to have an adventure in Japan like maybe he had at the last harbor.''

title: No Exit From South Lebanon
description: Lebanon's murderous, multisided civil war has baffled and defeated all outsiders who have tried either to end or exploit it. The contestants have included Syria, Israel, France, the United States, the Vatican and Unifil, the nine-country United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon. This record of failure has to be the starting point of any analysis of the newest flare-up in southern Lebanon, which finds Israelis again attacking Palestinian positions while a pro-Iranian Shiite militia, the Party of God, hunts down the mostly defenseless Unifil peacekeepers.

title: 700 BOMB THREATS, 1 SUSPECT
description: A 42-year-old mail sorter known to the police for months only by his ''poor brogue'' was arrested yesterday as the anonymous caller who has plagued midtown Manhattan for nearly a year with false bomb warnings in the name of the Irish Republican Army.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RELOCATION

title: Delays in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Maureen O'Brien Becomes a Bride
description: Maureen Catherine O'Brien, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett O'Brien of Smoke Rise, N.J., and Longboat Key, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Richard Neven Hurley, the son of Mrs. Robert Richmond Hurley of Howell, Mich., and the late Mr. Hurley. Justice Hortense W. Gabel of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the justice's chambers at the Supreme Court Building.

title: COMPROMISE OFFERED ON HIGHER SPEED LIMIT
description: The principal Congressional opponent of a higher speed limit offered today to end his opposition if tough conditions were placed on the states to assure the use of seat belts and compliance with the higher limit.

title: TIMES COMPANY NAMES TOPPING TO POST WITH ITS REGIONAL PAPERS
description: Seymour Topping, managing editor of The New York Times, has been appointed to the new position of director of editorial development for the Times Company's 32 regional newspapers.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AT U.N. ASSEMBLY: MAGIC, DOVES AND DEBATE
description: Just before he was to make his speech on Monday, President Reagan got stuck in an overloaded elevator for nearly a minute before a security guard employed by the United Nations pried the door open.

title: NCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a tax benefit of $118,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: ROSARIO SURPRISES BRAMBLE FOR TITLE
description: Edwin Rosario, considered an over-the-hill fighter only a few months ago, won the World Boxing Association lightweight title in a shocking upset tonight when he knocked out the champion, Livingstone Bramble, at 2:28 of the second round.

title: EQUIPMENT BLAMED IN FATAL MINE FIRE
description: An air compressor with two inoperable safety devices caused a coal mine fire that killed 27 people in 1984, Federal investigators said today. They said they were not certain why the equipment malfunctioned.

title: Gelco to Meey On Coniston Bid
description: The Gelco Corporation said it had scheduled a special meeting on Tuesday for its directors to review a takeover offer valued at more than $250 million from an investor group led by Coniston Partners, a New York-based investment partnership.

title: Paternity Verified In Surrogate Case
description: Medical tests have shown that a child born to a surrogate mother was not fathered by her husband. A judge ruled today that the woman who contracted for the surrogate birth does not have to take a fertility test or surrender medical records in a dispute that began when Mary Beth Whitehead, the woman who bore the child, decided to fight for custody.

title: SLANT/FIN CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
Dashed Dreams
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR. By Richard Yates. 182 pages. Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
FERNANDEZ GOES 8 TO GET 16TH VICTORY
description: Manager Davey Johnson proclaimed his pitching staff ready for the National League Championship Series tonight after Sid Fernandez defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-1, for a record 101st victory for the Mets.

title: PRACTICAL PRICES FOR PRACTICE FOOD
description: If Broadway shows charge preview prices while the cast is in dress rehearsal, why should restaurants charge full price when their dining room and kitchen staffs are still practicing? Every time I visit a restaurant in its shake-down phase and find the service and food less than professional, I wonder why I have allowed myself to be practiced on for full price.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OFTEN OUTGUNNED, POLICE ARE BOLSTERING FIREPOWER
description: With some criminals these days using more sophisticated weapons, some police departments in the New York area are turning to new weapons that give them more firepower.

title: BUILDINGS CHIEF, IN DRUG INQUIRY, DISMISSES THREE AIDES AS FIVE QUIT
description: An assistant commissioner at the City Buildings Department had parties in his office at which he and his staff used marijuana and cocaine, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: No Basis for Nuclear-Controls Charges Against India
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHMARK DEAL
description: The Southmark Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Realty World from Thomson McKinnon Inc. for an undisclosed price. Realty World, with headquarters in Fairfax Va., is a rel estate brokerage franchise concern with 1,500 offices and 14,000 sales associates throughtout the United States and Canada.

title: REGENTS REJECT PRESSURE FOR LIST OF POOR SCHOOLS
description: The Board of Regents today rejected an attempt to force the Commissioner of Education to release a new list of the state's lowest-performing schools.

title: A.M.C. to Raise '87 Model Prices
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would raise its 1987 car and Jeep prices an average of 1.9 percent to 4 percent from prices at the end of the current model year. The price of the average equipped Renault Alliance would be raised by 1.9 percent, or $170, the company said.

title: Guitar Improvisations
description: The guitarist Derek Bailey will play improvised music tomorrow at 9 P.M. at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street in TriBeCa (219-8242). Tickets are $5.

title: CONGRESS CONSIDERS CUTBACKS IN INTELLIGENCE BUDGET
description: A dispute between the Central Intelligence Agency and the Senate over the annual bill for intelligence programs comes as Congress is weighing sharp reductions in President Reagan's proposed budget for the C.I.A. and other agencies.

title: EXCERPTS FROM VETO MESSAGE ON SANCTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's message tonight announcing his veto of legislation imposing economic sanctions on South Africa:

title: SECRET WITNESS SAID TO BE TIED TO LINDENAUER
description: Dr. Jerome Driesen, a psychiatrist close to Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, is one of the secret witnesses in the Government's corruption case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, according to people familiar with the case.

title: DAVID L. BERMAN
description: David L. Berman, a senior human resource officer of Citicorp, died Wednesday in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Ken Harrelson Resigns
description: Ken Harrelson, admitting he had made mistakes, has resigned his post as executive vice president of the Chicago White Sox, effective immediately.

title: CP National Rejects Utility Bid
description: The CP National Corporation, a telecommunications and energy company based in Walnut Creek, Calif., said it had rejected as inadequate a merger proposal from PacificCorp, a utility based in Portland, Ore.

title: Thorny Status Issue Slows Air Fund
description: The world's finance ministers, central bank governors and private bankers are descending upon Washington for their annual get-together about the global economy.

title: Hofstra Wins
description: Alan Squeri passed for two touchdowns and Phil Kuzniar made three field goals to lead Hofstra (3-0) to a 31-0 rout of C. W. Post (0-3) tonight at Hofstra Stadium. Squeri passed for a 30-yard score to James Scully and for a 3-yard score to Chris Facas. Kuzniar, in making kicks of 32, 22 and 20 yards, brought his total to a school-record 22.

title: California Prohibits Smoking in High Schools
description: California has banned smoking by students at all its high schools, reversing a nine-year-old policy that had permitted the local authorities to decide whether the students could smoke.

title: Running
description: THE BEST ADVICE I got about the New York Marathon came from Bill Evans, a friend who had run it twice before. The advice was to walk home after the race. So instead of treating my weary legs to a taxi, I slung the commemorative Mylar blanket over my shoulders and headed out of Central Park and up Columbus Avenue.

title: CAMPAIGNING FOR THE I.M.F.'S TOP POST
description: THE chatter in New York's Dutch community last week centered on Netherlands Finance Minister H. Onno Ruding, who was in town on his way to the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Washington. It seems that Mr. Ruding's wife convinced him to take a break from his conferences in New York to attend a performance of ''Arsenic and Old Lace.'' Shortly after settling into his theater seat, Mr. Ruding dozed off.

title: THE LESSONS OF AUTUMN
description: THE sun still feels warm at my back, but beneath the surface the soil is cold as I till the garden bed this late fall afternoon. The air chills each evening now. Few good days remain before frost.

title: CABLE TV OPERATORS UNITE TO FIGHT THEFT OF THEIR SERVICES
description: THE state's cable television operators have banded together to fight theft of their services and equipment, in what organizers say is the first statewide effort in the nation to eliminate cable piracy.

title: Honeyghan Stuns Curry, Captures Title
description: Donald Curry, who was regarded as the heir apparent to Marvelous Marvin Hagler as the best fighter, pound for pound, in boxing, is due for reassessment. The reason is Lloyd Honeyghan. Honeyghan, a 26-year-old Jamaican now living in London, staged a shocking upset tonight when he beat Curry to become the undisputed world welterweight champion. Their scheduled 12-round bout was stopped after six rounds with Curry seated on his stool, bleeding profusely from a deep cut over the left eye.

title: U.S. Civil Rights Commission Votes To Slash Its Staff
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission, which as recently as three years ago looked to Congress for protection after President Reagan dismissed members who had criticized his policies, expects no such rescue now.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COLORADO SPRINGS;
Safe Bets On the Future
description: FRANK ARIES has developed the uncanny knack of buying up huge tracts of land around growing metropolises at just the right time. This time he may have struck it particularly big.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. STILL FIGHTING 1976 PRIVACY SUIT
description: The Justice Department is still fighting a citizens' damage claim that was filed 10 years ago against five Federal agents whom a jury found in 1981 to have illegally wiretapped and harassed a group of Washington area blacks and Vietnam peace activists in the late 1960's.

title: BRONX DEMOCRATS, FEELING THE HEAT, STILL RUN THE KITCHEN
description: THE telephone has been quiet lately at Bronx Democratic Headquarters. ''You're the first call in three days -they're afraid the phone is tapped,'' said a nervous Murray Lewinter, secretary of the organization, as his leader, Stanley M. Friedman, went on trial in Federal District Court in New Haven last week.

title: Looking for European Package Bargains
description: For travelers who have not given up on Europe, attractive bargains exist for this fall and winter. Trans-Atlantic airlines, hotels and the government tourist authorities are striving to overcome the deep financial losses of much of 1986, when hundreds of thousands of Americans who had been expected to visit Europe decided to stay away.

title: On Culbertson
description: To the Editor:

title: On Culbertson
description: To the Editor:

title: 'UNCLE BOB' MARKS 50 YEARS ON THE RADIO
description: LOOKING down from his office on the 19th floor of the ''Gold Building'' in downtown Hartford, Bob Steele points in the direction of the spot on Asylum Street where he first set foot in Hartford on May 10, 1936.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Klaus-Jurgen Sembach argues in STYLE 1930: Elegance and Sophistication in Architecture, Design, Fashion, Graphics, and Photography (Universe, $14.95) that by the mid-20th century, artistic modernism had ceased to refer to that which was new and avant-garde, and had ossified into a definitive style. Its slogan and ethos might have been borrowed from Pierre Masseau's 1931 poster for the French state railways; a study in geometric formalism, the poster makes the point with a single word: ''Exactitude.''

title: Linda Beth Sinofsky Wed To Daniel Edward DiTolla
description: Linda Beth Sinofsky and Daniel Edward DiTolla, both graduates of Rutgers University, were married yesterday at the Wayne (N.J.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Dale Sims performed the ceremony.

title: THE DEFICIT IS A DRUG, TOO
description: After years of indifference, Congress and the President have hijacked the antidrug bandwagon. You'd have to be greener than Kermit the Frog not to grasp the relationship between Washington's new-found zeal for fighting drugs and the fact that Election Day is only six weeks away.

title: Bomb Wounds 15 At Bangladesh Rally
description: A bomb exploded at an opposition political rally today, wounding at least 15 people, the police said.

title: THE ARMS RACE HAS NO QUICK FIX
description: Congress threatens to impose on the White House the constraint Mikhail Gorbachev has long sought - a moratorium on testing nuclear weapons. Its motives are wholly different but the result would be the same: a severe weakening of the President's bargaining power and of national security.

title: I.L.A. Ordered To Pay for Boycott
description: For years, the International Longshoremen's Association used the boycott as a weapon against foreign governments of which the union's leadership disapproved, occasionally to the discomfort of the Administration in Washington. Last week, the tactic produced considerable discomfort for the union.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: FULFILLING THE 'PENSION PROMISE;
WITHOUT REVERSION, BUSINESS WON'T PLAY
description: IMAGINE your reaction if you received the following letter from the Internal Revenue Service: Dear Taxpayer: Last year you prudently withheld from your wages more money than was necessary to pay your tax bill. Nonetheless, we have now changed the law and decided not to send you your tax refund. Sincerely, Uncle Sam. Employers who too-prudently fund their pension plans will get a similar message if some self-proclaimed champions of employees and retirees, and their supporters in Congress, get their way. These groups are advocating the reversal of a nearly half-century-old policy that permits an employer to reclaim excess pension assets that are not needed to pay benefits promised in the company's pension plan.

title: DOLLAR GETS BUFFETED BY MIXED SIGNALS
description: The dollar was tugged and pulled by conflicting international signals and statements from American leaders. It had fallen sharply the previous week when Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d had said it would have to come down further. But it rose on a report that European nations, jittery that the dollar was too low against their own currencies, had agreed on a concerted effort to bolster the dollar. The rise accelerated last week when the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said the dollar has fallen enough, and needs to be stronger to stimulate growth, lower interest rates worldwide and ease the American trade deficit.

title: POP: BY CUBAN COMPOSERS
description: ''HABANA, ANTOLOGIA MUSICAL,'' the Repertorio Espanol's handsomely staged revue of pre-Castro-era Cuban popular songs, is a colorful reminder of the not insignificant role Cuban composers have played in the evolution of an international pop style that, despite the rock upsurge, continues to flourish across Europe and Latin America.

title: Recent Sales
description: Livingston $355,000 2 Pittsfield Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; dining room, central air-conditioning, skylight in master bedroom, 2-car garage; taxes $4,583.
