Maplewood $271,000 9 Morse Drive 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 25-year-old Tudor; living room with fireplace, den, oak floors, terraced yard, family room; taxes $5,031.

title: Tunnel Delays Eased As Rain Halts Repairs
description: Foul weather dampened attempts by construction crews to make repairs on an access road leading from New Jersey to the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday, avoiding the long delays that were predicted because of the work.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN WOMEN IN TRANSITION. By Suzanne M. Bianchi and Daphne Spain. (Russell Sage Foundation, Cloth, $32.50. Paper, $14.95.) Most of us have heard or read about the influx of women into the work place, the high divorce rate in America, the problems of single parents and a myriad of other difficulties plaguing women of the 1980's.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC GAMES
description: FIVE years ago, the craze for video games seemed unstoppable. There were electronic space invaders and little yellow Pac-Men who ate bigger blue monsters as well as the lion's share of teen-agers' allowances. Pinball, a favorite since the 1940's, was virtually abandoned. Suppliers of coin-operated equipment began to ignore cigarette machines and jukeboxes in their frenzy to cash in on the video boom.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BONN IS REVIEWING ASYLUM FOR EAST-BLOC REFUGEES
description: As part of a clampdown on immigration, West Germany intends to review its practice of not obliging refugees to return to the Soviet bloc, a Government minister has announced.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Doughnuts, Cider, Squash and More About eight miles north of White Plains on Old Route 22 the Schultz family has been selling its own cider for 35 years, plus local vegetables and fruit, with trucked-in supplements seasonally, except for the month of June.

title: MANY HURDLES STILL LITTER THE COURSE FOR CONGRESS
description: THE 99th Congress heads into the homestretch this week, hoping to complete its work and leave town by Friday. But the pressure of the schedule and the threat of President Reagan's vetoes could well move the finishing post down the track.

title: Reagan Veto Sends Pretoria Sanctions Back to Congress
description: Ronald Reagan, by dint of enormous personal popularity and adeptness at mixing Presidential power with politic flexibility, has almost always had his way in Congress. Last week, however, Mr. Reagan vetoed legislation to impose punitive sanctions on South Africa; White House aides and Republicans in Congress said it would be hard to prevent an override, the first of his Presidency.

title: Elizabeth R. Schlosser Marries in Larchmont
description: Elizabeth Rachel Schlosser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Schlosser of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Albert Birkbeck Vanderhoof 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderhoof Jr. of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. George Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Living In a Silent World
description: I question the implicit message that Lou Ann Walker's experiences were fundamentally different from others simply because her parents are deaf. For example, my grandmother, who raised me, was a native Italian living in a non-Italian section of New York.

title: POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEES PROMOTE DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The (Monster?) of Silver Lake

title: Should the Government Save Vital Enterprises?
description: SINCE 1970, when Congress for the first time underwrote an ailing private enterprise, the Penn Central Transporation Co., with a multibillion dollar loan guarantee, there has been debate over the appropriateness of Federal bailouts in a free-market system. Congress may soon be voting on another rescue, perhaps its most expensive, that of the $66 billion Farm Credit System, the network of small cooperative lending institutions that holds a third of the nation's $214 billion farm debt. The General Accounting Office said earlier this month that because of huge losses from defaults the system's remaining reserves will be all but wiped out this year by a record $2.9 billion loss. Most experts believe it is not a question of whether, but when the farm credit banks come to Congress for an injection of money. With the theory and practice of bailouts still in dispute, Nathaniel C. Nash, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, talked with two Senators with strongly opposed views, John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, and William Proxmire, Democrat of Montana. Excerpts of the interviews follow. JOHN MELCHER ACT IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST WILLIAM PROXMIRE THE PRINCIPLE IS A BAD ONE

title: AN AIR OF CHANGE MAY HELP YONKERS GET A SECOND WIND
description: THIS could be called The City Where Nothing Comes Easily. But lately, its municipal penchant for strife seems to be yielding positive results.

title: CAN THE COW MAKE A COMEBACK
description: IN a top-secret room at the Excel Corporation's huge plant here, where 5,000 head of cattle are slaughtered a day, the beef packer is carrying out an experiment that it hopes will swell its coffers and help reverse the beef industry's sagging fortunes. Inside the room a few dozen workers are cutting beef into consumer-sized portions that will be shipped to supermarkets and sold under the Excel label, making Excel the first large beef packer to market brand-named beef in a big way.

title: SAMPLING TRAINS AROUND EUROPE
description: The taxi inched along in the honking, engine-racing, rush-hour traffic of a humid Barcelona Friday morning.

title: THE ROVER BOYS PASSED THE TORCH
description: THE SECRET OF THE STRATEMEYER SYNDICATE Nancy Drew, the Hardy Boys, and the Million Dollar Fiction Factory. By Carol Billman. Illustrated. 187 pp. New York: The Ungar Publishing Company. $14.95.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Colombians Accused Of 'Dirty War Tactics'
description: Government and guerrilla forces in Colombia are using ''dirty war tactics'' in their fight against each other, according to a group that monitors human rights violations in the Western Hemisphere.

title: HOW YOU HANDLE MONEY: THE VAST CHANGE TO COME
description: Life in America is likely to change in hundreds of ways under the new tax law, shifting the way people spend, save, borrow and invest their money.

title: Living In a Silent World
description: Lou Ann Walker is perceptive about her deaf parents but, nevertheless, perpetuates myths that are all too common in articles about the deaf (''Outsider in a Silent World,'' Aug. 31). The troublesome thing about Ms. Walker's article is the pain it must have given to parents of young deaf children who are struggling with a very difficult problem.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DIALOGUES
description: RABBI LUDVIG NADELMANN isn't quite sure what theme he will choose for Rosh ha-Shanah. He might mark the Jewish New Year, which begins Friday at sundown, with a discussion of God as an expression of the human spirit. Or he may address the issue of man's moral judgment in, as he puts it, a world ''polarized'' by extremism on the political and religious right and left. Or he may expand on his belief that ''memory is the stuff of which human consciousness is made'' - a concept he finds particularly appropriate for the period of the High Holy Days, which begin with Rosh ha-Shanah, also known as the Day of Rememberance, and end 10 days later with Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement.

title: SOCIALIST VIES FOR A CRUCIAL SEAT IN TOULOUSE
description: For Lionel Jospin, first secretary of the Socialist Party, the campaign outing should have been a breeze.

title: Joke Jeopardy
description: MY NAME'S JACK Jakes. I'm a sergeant in the joke squad. It's mostly night work.

title: Jill Alison Runcie Marries Lee Lorenz
description: Jill Alison Runcie, a vice president of Decker, Decker & Freas, a marketing communications firm in New York, was married yesterday to Lee Sharp Lorenz, the art editor and a cartoonist for The New Yorker magazine. The Rev. Merton Rymph performed the Congregational ceremony at the Homestead Inn in Greenwich, Conn.

title: AN AMERICAN WHOSE JAPANESE ART WON PRAISE IN TOKYO
description: For several months last summer, the Tokyo National Museum exhibited a collection of ancient Japanese art that was lauded by Japan's art critics and scholars as a collection of ''masterpieces'' and ''treasures.'' The show, however, had not been culled from the museum's storerooms but was a selection of works on loan from the private collection of an American, Mary Burke. Many Japanese were surprised to learn that this New Yorker and her husband, Jackson Burke, had amassed one of the most important collections of Japanese painting, sculpture and ceramics in the world, most of which had been acquired during a seven-year period in the late 1960's and early 70's.

title: SEA VIEWS AND SOLITUDE IN MENDOCINO
description: A buoy moans softly in the distance.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TALKING HEADS. By Jerome Davis. (Vintage, $6.95.) Biographies of rock-and-roll bands are rarely read by anyone but fans. Presumably, however, this one is intended for a wider audience, since Talking Heads is an unusually cerebral band whose influence goes beyond the world of pop music.

title: Fondly Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON THE TAX BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today gave final Congressional approval for tax revision: FOR TAX REVISION - 74 Democrats - 33 Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Bradley, N.J. Bumpers, Ark.

title: 10 Hurt in Chemical Mishap
description: An ammonia pipeline at a margarine plant split open while a repair crew was trying to cap it Friday. Ten people who inhaled caustic fumes from the chemical were injured, three critically.

title: Michaela Ann McElroy Wed to George E. Beitzel
description: At St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday Michaela Ann McElroy and George Elliott Beitzel were married by the Rev. Herbert McElroy, who is the bride's uncle, assisted by the Rev. Charles Wilcox, a Methodist minister. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. McElroy of Spring Lake and Stuart, Fla.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 28, 1986
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 3 IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 2 2 9 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 3 11 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 4 5 4 THROUGH A GLASS DARKLY, by Karleen Koen. (Random House, $19.95.) Romance, family conflict, power and greed mark a young woman's coming of age in 18th-century England and France. 5 4 13 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 6 6 16 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 7 9 2 ROGER'S VERSION, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A fiftyish professor wrestles with God, sex, science, technology, mathematics and computers. 8 7 6 REGRETS ONLY, by Sally Quinn. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Two women, two men, passion and power brokering in Washington. 9 8 7 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 10 10 30 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 11 15 20 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 12 13 23 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 13* 11 45 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla's adventures in the prehistoric world; the sequel to ''The Valley of Horses.'' 14 * 12 15 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 15 1 THE BEET QUEEN, by Louise Erdrich. (Holt, $16.95.) Forty years of life in a small North Dakota town near an Indian reservation. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 21 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 2 29 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 3 20 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 4 1 MCMAHON! by Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The autobiography of the quarterback for the Chicago Bears. 5 4 23 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 6 14 2 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Arbor House, $17.95.) A member of one of America's oldest families tells of the world's oldest profession. 7 7 24 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 8 5 16 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 9 6 14 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life. 10 1 SNAKE, by Ken Stabler and Berry Stainback. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The experiences of the retired Oakland Raider quarterback. 11 * 10 11 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation by the film director King Vidor of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 12 * 8 15 FORD: The Men and the Machine, by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 13 * 9 26 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 14 175 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 15 * 1 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.) Observations on football by the television commentator and former Oakland Raider coach. Weeks This Last On Week Week List ADVICE, HOW-TO AND MISCELLANEOUS 1 4 2 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) Coping with overbearing men. 2 1 19 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 3 2 58 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 4 3 66 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 1 UNLIMITED POWER, by Anthony Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Directions for achieving ''super success in personal and professional affairs.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) SEVEN RIVERS WEST, by Edward Hoagland. (Summit, $18.95.) An adventurer sets forth to possess the West - in the form of grizzly bears - in Mr. Hoagland's first novel for 20 years, a historical tall tale of cracked mountain folk and unblemished landscape, related with documentary exactness. ''THE TARGET IS DESTROYED'': What Really Happened to Flight 007 and What America Knew About It, by Seymour M. Hersh. (Random House, $17.95.) No conspiracies emerge from Mr. Hersh's scrupulous investigation of the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner in 1983, but both American and Russian offials are thoroughly indicted for leaping before looking. PERFUME: The Story of a Murderer, by Patrick Suskind. (Knopf, $16.95.) An 18th-century Parisian perfumer, an olfactory vampire who kills people to steal their scents, is the hero of this strangely immediate historical novel, its German author's first. CROSSING THE LINE: A Year in the Land of Apartheid, by William Finnegan. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) Mr. Finnegan spent his year teaching in a high school for ''colored'' children; his account is thoughtful, instructive and - for those reasons - discouraging. BOP, by Maxine Chernoff. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) A first collection of short stories whose main strength is their deflationary humor; most concern offspring of the counterculture. RUBICON BEACH, by Steve Erickson. (Poseidon Press, $15.95.) Imagery counts for more than plot in this vigorous novel, part science fiction, part surrealist love story, part political fable. EISENHOWER: AT WAR, 1943-1945, by David Eisenhower. (Random House, $29.95.) Conceived as the first volume of three, this thoughtful history argues that President Eisenhower's political acumen was learned by commanding a coalition war.

title: NOT WITH A BANG BUT A DOLLAR
description: THE DEFENSE GAME An Insider Explores the Astonishing Realities of America's Defense Establishment. By Richard A. Stubbing with Richard A. Mendel. 445 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $21.50.

title: STATE'S ORCHESTRAS TO HAVE BUSY SEASON
description: NEW JERSEY has more than 30 orchestras, from chamber groups with as few as 25 members to full 100-member symphonies.

title: Aerobics
description: TWO YEARS AGO, WHEN I assumed the job of professional eater for The Times, one of my primary concerns was how to avoid resembling the Michelin tire man. Until that time I had been a dedicated - although never fanatical nor competitive - runner. Surely my new vocation, which involves dining out more than 450 times a year, would call for a more disciplined and rigorous routine.

title: Freshman Learns The Hard Way
description: THIS is about coming of age, a popular theme in Hollywood these days. Any thick-necked, crusty football coach will tell you it is an old story, played out time and time again over the years on brightly splashed autumn Saturdays, when the victory march can be heard echoing in the background as the team jogs triumphantly off the field.

title: Libya Sells Its Stake in Fiat
description: Libya's partial ownership of the multinational conglomerate Fiat S.p.A has been an embarrassment to the company, as well as a political thorn in Italy's side. Early this year, for instance, the manager of the Rome office of Lafico, the Libyan state enterprise that held 14 percent of Fiat's shares, was expelled with other diplomats and businessmen in an Italian protest over Tripoli's role in terrorist activities.

title: SHAPIRO'S RACE STILL DOGGED BY KEAN
description: JUST when he thought it was safe to go back into the political waters, Peter Shapiro finds Governor Kean still following him.

title: Los Angeles Bias Suit Dismissed
description: It took six months of wrangling and conflict, but the Los Angeles City Council finally devised a redistricting plan that led a Federal judge to dismiss last week a Reagan Administration suit charging that the city had intentionally diluted the voting power of its Hispanic residents.

title: Classical Reviews To Be Mainstay of New Monthly
description: An unusual and potentially very useful music magazine will make its first appearance in February of 1987. Within the 150 pages of the first edition of Music Review Monthly, to be published in Berkeley, Calif., the reader will find every classical music review printed by 11 major newspapers across the country within the previous month. In addition, there will be articles from correspondents in Europe and Japan, a feature story by a critic or musician, and a comprehensive index, with crosslisting.

title: Set Up for the Big Fall
description: The Jets' recent history has several examples of big victories followed by disappointing losses

title: Looking Back at Vienna's Workshop of Artistic Wonders
description: Austrian 20th-century modern - the compelling classicism of Josef Hoffmann and Koloman Moser, the arresting graphics of Berthold Loffler and Oskar Kokoschka, and the Baroque fantasies of Dagobert Peche and Susi Singer - are explored in ''Viennese Design and the Wiener Werkstatte,'' an exhibition on view at the Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, through Nov. 8.

title: NICARAGUAN PRELATE CONFERS WITH ORTEGA
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra met today with the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, to discuss the deep conflicts between the church and the Sandinista Government.

title: SENATE REJECTS USING MILITARY TO FIGHT DRUG TRAFFIC
description: The Senate tonight rejected an amendment that would have permitted the military to pursue and arrest drug smugglers trying to enter the country.

title:
INVESTING;
THE BLOODLETTING IN CUT-RATE ELECTRONICS
description: RETAIL chains that specialize in discounted consumer electronics products have started going nose-to-nose in many big markets.

title: POLISH POLICY ON DISSIDENTS TWO-PRONGED
description: While Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has welcomed recently released political prisoners to what he called ''responsible'' public life, the Polish Communist Party has called for the administrative detention, without trial, of dissidents deemed harmful by the authorities.

title: A SHOW IN BRITTANY ILLUMINATES GAUGUIN'S TRANSFORMATION OF ART
description: Exactly when did modern art begin? A good question, much disputed. Some veterans of the subject put it as far back as 1793, when Jacques-Louis David put the Ancien Regime behind him once and for all with ''The Death of Marat.'' So blunt and so bald a portrait in high art of a contemporary murder would have been hard to imagine any earlier.

title: Israeli Planes Hit P.L.O. in Lebanon
description: Lebanon, as is often the case, was the center of considerable violence last week.

title: A FAMILIAR ISSUE: ADULTS IN TRANSITION
description: THE new director of the Sarah Lawrence Center for Continuing Education, Alice K. Olson, understands a lot about the center's major constituency - adults in transition. In her own background, she has been - in addition to wife and mother - at various times teacher, lawyer, political candidate, feminist activist, community worker, student and business manager.

title: Miss Litvack, a Teacher, To Wed Thomas Pereles
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Litvack of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Beth Litvack, to Thomas Pereles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pereles of Potomac, Md.

title: Sonja A. Gora Becomes the Bride of W.J. Maroni
description: Sonja A. Gora, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin K. Gora of Providence, R.I., was married there yesterday to William J. Maroni, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Maroni of North Providence, R.I. The Rev. Adrian Dabash, the chaplain of Providence College, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Ochre Court Chapel of Salve Regina College. He was assisted by Msgr.

title: Man Talk
description: A PRIEST RANG MY DOOR-bell not long ago. I do not know any priests, but I always notice them. I have always assumed that priests know great secrets bestowed from Above. I sensed that this one was about to deliver a portentous message and, as I opened the door, I shooed my curious 5-year-old son back into the depths of our home.

title: DUBLIN JOHNNY'S SONS
description: ONE LAST WALTZ By Ethan Mordden. 196 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95.

title: Peripatetic Sculpture
description: A MONUMENTAL sculpture by Henry Moore became a wanderer last May, and the public was asked to suggest a home for it.

title: PORTRAIT OF ISAAC SINGER IN NOSTALGIC DOUBLE BILL
description: ''WHAT a wicked place!'' thought Isaac Bashevis Singer, upon visiting his first American-style cafeteria in the 1930's and trying vainly to attract someone with a tray. ''So many waiters, and no one pays attention to me!'' The venerable Mr. Singer has lively, colorful memories of this and many other such incidents. He recounts an hour's worth of them in ''Isaac in America,'' a warmhearted, anecdotal portrait of the author by Amram Nowak.

title: MORE GUNS, LEGAL AND ILLEGAL, ON ISLAND
description: THE number of people obtaining handgun permits and the number of registered handguns have been steadily increasing on Long Island in recent years, experts say.

title: Green Tide
description: WARM temperatures and a lack of wind off the Jersey Shore last summer contributed to two conditions that seemed to threaten shellfish: lowered oxygen levels in bottom waters and so-called green tide - a bloom of microscopic algae.

title: In Kyoto, Everyday Elegance
description: The word ''crafts'' bears heavy overtones of cunningly contrived, cute but useless objects, admired in a shop or at a fair, taken home and stashed away in a closet never to be seen again. In Japan, the expression ''kogei,'' loosely translated as crafts or sometimes as decorative arts, is fraught with other associations as well - those of folk art and the traditional decorative arts. Kyoto, for many centuries the center of many of Japan's traditional arts, has a reputation for conservatism in the arts as well as in customs, but fosters contemporary design in the decorative arts as well.

title: A 'FOURTH WAY' FOR THE THIRD WORLD
description: PATHS TO PROGRESS Bread and Freedom in Developing Societies. By William McCord with Arline McCord. 352 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the next-to-last sentence of Joyce Carol Oates's review of ''The Progress of Love'' by Alice Munro on Sept. 14 was incorrectly printed. It should have read: '' 'The Progress of Love' is a volume of unflinching honesty, uncompromising in its dissection of the ways we deceive ourselves in the name of love; the bleakness of its vision is enriched by the author's exquisite eye and ear for detail.''

title: OPERA: NEW 'FIGARO' CAST
description: IT was once said of Samuel Johnson that his genius sprang not from any inherent natural superiority to his fellow man, but rather from a heightened empathy; that he was like everybody else, only more so. The same might be said of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' which was presented with a subtantially altered cast Thursday night at the New York City Opera.

title: Filipino Rebels to Offer Peace Plan to Aquino
description: Communist rebels, who rejected a Government cease-fire earlier this month, said today that they planned to offer President Corazon C. Aquino their own proposal for ending the fighting.

title: TOWN SHIFTS ON RENTING OF CONDOMINIUMS
description: SMITHTOWN officials are preparing to amend the town condominium zoning ordinance to allow condominium owners to rent out their units.

title: WORKOUT CLOTHES: FROM THE GYM TO THE STREET, A RELAXED STYLE OF DRESSING
description: EXERCISE CLOTHES SEEM TO be everywhere. Sneakers, sweatpants, leggings and tank tops - gear that is meant to be worn in the gym - have become a standard part of everyday dressing for exerciser and nonexerciser alike. Now the influence of this comfortable, colorful, high-spirited clothing is spreading into the realm of designer fashion. The fall collections of Donna Karan, Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein and Norma Kamali, among others, include clothes that display a definite connection with exercise.

title: A SAMPLING OF LECTURE TOPICS FOR FALL
description: ''I CANNOT see that lectures can do so much good as reading the books from which the lectures are taken,'' Samuel Johnson said, according to his biographer, Boswell. Residents of the county may have ample opportunity to test that assertion in the coming months, as the county lecture season moves into high gear.

title: Texas A&M Wins
description: Kevin Murray passed 22 yards for a touchdown to Rod Bernstine, and Scott Slater made three field goals as Texas A&M (2-1) defeated Southern Mississippi (2-2), 16-7, tonight. The game was scoreless at halftime.

title: THE PROBLEMS FACED BY PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: The article ''Back to School: Times Get Tougher - New Standards to Test Pupils,'' on Aug. 31, expounded on the many problems facing the local public school systems; aside from the long overdue and more stringent requirements in educational achievements, the statements concerning the increases in public school costs that exceed the rise in the general cost of living rates by a factor of 300 to 400 percent require some explanation.

title: 'REPRODUCTIVE RIGHTS' IS FOCUS OF DAYLONG, OCT. 24 WORKSHOP
description: ON Oct. 24, Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers will conduct a daylong workshop to update men and women on threats to ''reproductive rights'' and strategies for action.

title: Elizabeth Booker Wed To Donald M. Bond Jr.
description: Elizabeth Carter Booker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Armistead Page Booker of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday to Donald Matthew Bond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bond of Great River, N.Y. The Rev. Benjamin Campbell performed the Episcopal ceremony at the chapel of the University of Virginia, of which the bride is an alumna.

title: NAMELESS LOVERS CHASED THROUGH HELL
description: THE STARS AT NOON By Denis Johnson. 181 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Giant Kicking Teams Special
description: In their first three games of the season, the Giants lost to the Dallas Cowboys and beat the San Diego Chargers and the Los Angeles Raiders. Now they start a three-game stretch against supposedly softer opponents - the New Orleans Saints (1-2), the St. Louis Cardinals (0-3) and the Philadelphia Eagles (0-3).

title: INSIDE
description: A JUDGE'S WINNING HAND Two spades, bid and made, helped Amalya L. Kearse, the Federal judge, and Jacqui Mitchell win the world women's pair bridge title.

title: YES, THE ROSE - BUT WHICH ONE?
description: After almost a century of floral fussing, Congress has finally voted us the rose as our national flower. The wait was long but the choice was wise, for there is no flower more lovely or more widely loved.

title: 'Biblical Scoreboard'
description: Concerned that ''most of our government offices'' are ''in the hands of amoral or immoral leaders,'' two church-related groups, Chrisian Voice and the Biblical News Service, have published a ''Biblical Scoreboard'' to help voters select candidates for Congress and some state offices in November.

title: AUXILLIARY STATE POLICE: PERIL WITHOUT PAY
description: EARLIER this month, Ken Anderson traveled from the state police barracks in Westbrook to Colchester to turn in an old cruiser and pick up a new one.

title: FITNESS: IS IT GOOD FOR YOU?
description: FITNESS IS MORE THAN A FAD. IT'S A flourishing way of life, a national obsession - an addiction, some would say - and the foundation of a multibillion dollar industry that equips, dresses, feeds and trains its practitioners. As a modern-day fountain of youth that has been shown to slow and even reverse much of the deterioration associated with aging, fitness is being pursued by millions of people who realize that their medical fate lies more in their own than in their physicians' hands.

title: Gulf Nations to Meet
description: The seventh summit conference of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council has been scheduled for Nov. 2-4, officials said today. The group includes Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates.

title: AIDS DRUG IS RAISING HOST OF THORNY ISSUES
description: The advent of a drug that shows promise against AIDS has paradoxically raised a host of thorny new ethical and practical problems for researchers developing treatments for the deadly disorder.

title: Standing Tall In Jersey City
description: The ground breaking was unusual - a nicely turned-out brass quintet played beneath a power shovel - but the project seemed to call for something catchy. The 30-story tower going up just across the river from the World Trade Center is to be the tallest office building in New Jersey, and when the ceremonial gold shovels came out last week, Mayor Anthony Cucci said, ''It's a fantastic day for Jersey City.''

title: Islanders Defeat Sabres 2-0
description: Helped by desultory play from the competition, the Islanders won their second straight exhibition game tonight. But the 2-0 victory over the Buffalo Sabres was a plodding affair and unhelpful in terms of revealing fresh rookie talent.

title: Morris's Status: Doubtful
description: Joe Morris, the Giants' ailing running back, was discharged this morning from Pascack Valley Hospital in nearby Westwood after spending two nights there. However, the Giants downgraded his status to doubtful for Sunday's game here against the New Orleans Saints.

title: A ROYAL DUTCH OPENING FOR AMSTERDAM OPERA HOUSE
description: At long last - at very long last - the Netherlands has an opera house. When Het Muziektheater - the Music Theater - opened last Tuesday it was not only the first such structure in Amsterdam but also the first one in the history of a country that has produced a Rembrandt, a Spinoza and a Mengelberg and his great Concertgebouw Orchestra.

title: Sri Lanka Extends Measures
description: Sri Lanka extended a state of emergency for another month Friday night, one day after a West German engineer was killed in the island's ethnic war. The engineer, Ulrich Heberling of West Germany's overseas broadcasting service, was killed Thursday in crossfire between troops and guerrillas fighting for a separate Tamil state. A Government statement said Mr. Heberling had been walking home from a relay station of the radio station Deutsche Welle, at Trincomalee, 150 miles from Colombo, when he was hit by a splinter from a mortar bomb.

title: CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: WHERE SHOULD IT BE CARTED?
description: WESTCHESTER'S contractors turned to the county last week, and county legislators and officials turned to the state, to seek a solution to a growing problem: how to dispose of 110,000 tons a year of construction debris that used to be dumped at the Croton Point Sanitary Landfill.

title: GROOMING FOR FIT SKIN, STRONG HAIR
description: Vigorous exercise may strengthen and tone muscles, but it is not as kind to skin and hair. Still, most people want exercise to improve their appearance, and want to look good in the process. That is where grooming comes in. ''To look healthy,'' said Trish McEvoy, a facialist and makeup expert in New York, ''you have to pay attention to your skin as well as your muscles. As well as your hair and nails. A healthy person is totally healthy, from head to toe, on the inside as well as the outside.''

title: HOW A SKEPTICAL MUSCOVITE MIGHT VIEW THE DANILOFF AFFAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: Portuguese Hero
description: As a result of a plea from 80 members of Congress, the Government of Portugal has agreed to clear the name of a Portuguese diplomat summoned home in disgrace in World War II for defying his Government by ''improperly'' issuing visas to people fleeing the Nazis.

title: L.I. RONALD MCDONALD HOUSE TO OPEN
description: THE first Ronald McDonald House on Long Island - a facility that will allow parents to live with children undergoing treatment for cancer and other serious illnesses - will be opened tomorrow.

title: Novelists in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PERSHING: General of the Armies. By Donald Smythe. (Indiana University, $27.50.) This is Donald Smythe's second and final volume of the life of Gen. John J. Pershing, commander in chief of the American Expeditionary Forces during World War I. The first volume, ''Guerilla Warrior: The Early Life of John J. Pershing,'' was published more than a decade ago.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: MASTERS IN VERMONT

title: Harry H. Handler Marries Cindy Schweich, an Editor
description: The marriage of Cindy Schweich, an editor at RCA Records, in Manhattan, and Harry H. Handler, a vice president of futures at Dean Witter Reynolds in Manhattan, took place last evening at the Vista International Hotel in Manhattan.

title: THEY SAY IT BETTER IN THE MOVIES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GOLDEN CUP. By Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $17.95.) What can you say about a novel that tells us on the first page, ''When she was very old she would still marvel, as do we all, over the randomness of things, for if she had not happened to turn just that corner, in just that hour, her whole life would have been different''? Its stock characters are mildly likable; its couplings are wind-swept yet proper; its plot is well paced but predictable.

title: A PLEA TO RESTORE READING AS A SPOKEN ACTIVITY
description: ANYONE seeking to better understand why so many of our brightest young people are turned off by reading and turn instead to the immediate and more basic sensory gratification offered by rock videos and inane films about college dormitory food fights, need only attend a church service where both young and old take turns at reading. It is rare indeed to find anyone under 40 who can deliver the words accurately or with a semblance of intelligibility.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FLOATING RESTAURANT
description: A FORMER passenger ferryboat that reportedly served as the setting for elaborate dinner parties given by a well-known Washington hostess is to be converted into a floating restaurant in Yonkers.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S time to be purely selfish - absolutely no high thoughts or nobility. Let's pretend.

title: A Night to Remember
description: To the Sports Editor: Met management naturally bemoans the destructive behavior of some of their fans. True, they did try a last-minute, frantic - and futile - mass appeal to reason and public pride.

title: Paramus Strength
description: While the office market remains sluggish in some suburban areas, demand is still strong in parts of Bergen County, N.J., including Paramus.

title: On Culbertson
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome Synagogue
description: To the Editor: Deborah Gimelson's article called ''The Ghetto at the Tiber's Edge'' (Travel, Aug. 17), reminded me of a college semester I spent in Rome.

title: CUTTING INTO NATIONAL FORESTS
description: THE people of Puerto Rico know the 30,000-acre Caribbean National Forest as el Yunque, the Anvil. It is the only tropical rain forest in the national forest system, and environmentalists and scientists have protested angrily against a recently unveiled Forest Service plan calling for more than one-fifth of its acreage to be harvested for timber over the next 45 years.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PUSHCART PRIZE XI: Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Henderson. Poetry edited by Philip Levine and David Wojahn. (Pushcart Press, $26.) ''Think you know what's happening in literature today? Maybe you've been missing something,'' wrote Bill Henderson to his first ''Pushcart Prize'' readers more than a decade ago. Many discoveries later, the anthology continues to scour the literary countryside for talent. What it has come up with this year, however, is something of a puzzle. Many of the writers included have firmly established reputations in the mainstream of commercial publishing, and those newer recipients seem to be mostly aspiring versions of the former. That's not to say there isn't some fine writing here. Paul Auster's ''In the Country of Last Things'' is a haunting postapocalypse fantasy. Mona Simpson's ''Lawns'' movingly recounts a young girl's incestuous involvement with her father. ''Communist,'' a story by Richard Ford, is as well crafted as his novels. And Li-Young Lee's poem ''Eating Together'' captures the sense of loss that comes with the death of a parent. Nonfiction includes Wendell Berry's powerful critique of American nuclear defense policy, ''Property, Patriotism and National Defense,'' and Donald Barthelme's ''Not-Knowing,'' a clever, often hilarious essay on the apparent randomness of the creative process. But in general the collection seems less adventurous than it might have been, less indicative of what, under the best of circumstances, distinguishes the smaller press from the large: it provides a haven in which writers can - and often do - take risks.

title: About Missing Donald
description: AS my wife and my accountant will attest, I know nothing about taxes. It is a personal failing, but the reams of copy about the emerging tax law do nothing but give me a migraine.

title: Amy Chan Bride Of Tony Downer
description: Amy Ka Ling Chan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bit Yui Chan of Stamford, Conn., and John Ashton Downer, a son of Jannett Tucker Downer of New York and Joseph Platt Downer of Glen Cove, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Carol Gilbert performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Stamford.

title: An Officer Is Unhurt By Nearby Gunman
description: A man suspected of attempted robbery near the corner of Broadway and 95th Street pointed a handgun at a police officer yesterday and squeezed the trigger four times.

title: HUNTING THE THIEF OF IDENTITY
description: MY AMPUTATIONS By Clarence Major. 205 pp. New York: Fiction Collective. $15.95.

title: GREECE IS RECONSIDERING THE PRICE OF TOURISM
description: Tourism and its effects on the environment are causing the Government to re-examine longstanding policies to encourage vacationers at almost any price.

title: Dr. Petersmeyer Weds Dr. C. J. Damm
description: Dr. Nancy Quayle Petersmeyer, an assistant attending psychiatrist at Presbyterian Hospital and an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher John Damm, an intern at Mount Sinai Hospital. The Rev. Lynne Kochtitzky performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: POP: SONGS BY BROOK BENTON
description: AN interesting transitional figure in the evolution of contemporary pop-soul singing, Brook Benton continues to bring to ballads the same singular blend of gentility and unexpected roughness that characterized his earliest hits in the late 1950's.

title: A Night to Remember
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Unbeaten Rutgers Tops Syracuse
description: Joe Gagliardi tossed a 24-yard touchdown pass to Matt Prescott late in the third period today and Doug Giesler added a fourth-quarter field goal to give undefeated Rutgers a 16-10 comeback victory over Syracuse, which has lost its first four games.

title: SYNDICATED SHOWS ARE NO LONGER LAST SEASON'S LEFTOVERS
description: All this month, amid little or no fanfare, a cavalcade of new shows has been creeping onto the television screen. To name a few, there are ''Throb,'' a situation comedy starring Diana Canova as a 30-ish single mother working for a very hip recording company; ''Oprah Winfrey,'' a morning talk show with the actress from ''The Color Purple'' as host; ''You Write the Songs,'' a talent showcase for songwriters, and ''Rambo,'' a children's action cartoon. There are more than a score of other new shows - and not one of them is on network or cable television.

title: TEEN-AGE DRINKING INCREASES SHARPLY IN FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: FROM time to time in recent years, dances at some high schools in Fairfield County have been suspended because large numbers of students turned up intoxicated.

title: Books From The Times
description: TAKE MY WORD FOR IT. By William Safire. (Times Books, $22.50.)

title: Reagan Assails Spending Bill
description: President Reagan today accused Congress of an inability to control Federal spending as he vowed anew to veto a spending bill to run the Government.

title: Getting Ready For Holy Days
description: WHEN Moses Weiser tapped his cane last July on the vaulted ceiling of Chasam Sopher, a 134-year-old synagogue on the Lower East Side, plaster floated down in a white powder.

title: Jackson's Late Rally Defeats Clinton
description: Clinton (2-1) was helped last week by Far Rockaway's errant punt late in the game in a 13-12 come-from-behind victory. Yesterday, the tables were turned.

title: A SOAP STAR DIRECTS MARK TWAIN
description: WHEN an accomplished character actress of the legitimate theater has both an established soap opera and a new - and recently renewed - television series going for her, she might, understandably, say ''no'' to the call of community theater.

title: G. S. Diddel Wed To Miss Michaud
description: Suzanne Marie Michaud, the daughter of Anna G. Michaud of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Clarence L. Michaud, was married in New York yesterday to Gregory Scott Diddel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Diddel of New York and West Falmouth, Mass. Bishop Edwin B. Broderick performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral, assisted by Msgr.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1986
description: International Street battles in Beirut marked the worst day of violence in the Lebanese capital this year. The fighting between rival Lebanese factions in Christian East Beirut was followed by large-scale artillery exchanges. The Christians said that during the battles their forces drove off a Syrian-sponsored attack from the Moslem side of the so-called Green Line that divides Beirut into Christian and Moslem sections. If Christian claims are true, this would be the first time that a large-scale military thrust into East Beirut has been attempted. [ Page 1, Column 3. ] Detainees are treated harshly and sometimes tortured under South Africa's emergency decree, according to civil rights monitoring groups, former detainees and physicians who have examined detainees after their release. Physicians say many of them display symptoms of the disorder known as post-traumatic stress syndrome. [ 1:2. ] Nicaragua's President held talks with the Roman Catholic Archbiship of Managua, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, to discuss deep conflicts between the church and the Sandinista Government. It was the first time they had met for discussions in almost two years. Church leaders said before the session began that the Government had given no indication that it was planning any substantial concessions. [ 3:4. ] National A new Federal income tax system received final Congressional approval. The Senate, voting 74 to 23, passed a tax bill that provides the most comprehensive changes in the income tax system since World War II. Tax overhaul, which President Reagan made the top priority of his second term, will affect almost every household and business in the nation.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MARS PROJECT: Journeys Beyond the Cold War. By Spark M. Matsunaga. (Hill & Wang, $17.95.) This is a lively, engaging book by a 25-year Congressional veteran who scorns the drift toward war in space and makes a persuasive case for international cooperation in the heavens.

title: Updike and Hawthorne
description: To the Editor:

title: SAD SONG OF THE CITY
description: Autumn in New York: Why does it seem so inviting?. . . Glittering crowds and shimmering clouds in canyons of steel / They're making me feel / I'm home. This season, in this city, should glow with the warmth that Sarah Vaughan brought to the old ballad. As a new autumn begins, the song of the city in fact sounds more like Lou Reed: Take a walk on the wild side.

title: YALE SEEKS PATIENTS FOR DIABETES STUDY
description: THE Yale University School of Medicine is recruiting insulin-dependent diabetics to spend the next seven years helping doctors answer an important question. Can the rigorous control of blood sugar help prevent complications associated with the disease, including blindness, kidney failure and heart disease?

title: TRIAL IN FILM DEATHS HEARS MOTHER OF A VICTIM
description: A Vietnamese immigrant whose 7-year-old son was killed in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' has testified that she was never told the fatal scene would involve a low-flying helicopter and explosions used for special effects.

title: SEEING THE METS LARGER AND SMALLER THAN LIFE
description: DURING the summer my hometown, Port Washington, is invaded by a number of Mets baseball players.

title: TRAFFIC GETS WORSE AND WORSE AND...
description: ''Long Island Expressway traffic at a crawl from the Cross Island to the Clearview . . . Westbound traffic faces a 30-minute wait to the Midtown Tunnel . . . Heavy in both directions on the Southern State . . . Right lane closed because of resurfacing on the Northern State in the Wantagh vicinity . . . Long Island Expressway still sluggish around the Jericho area.'' - Radio station advisories.

title: The Smoking Letter
description: Eternal vigilance is one key to a successful lobbying effort, and few are better at it than the tobacco industry. When Dan Rostenkowski, the Chicago Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, suggested not long ago that raising tobacco taxes might be one way to increase revenue, it caused scarcely a ripple on Capitol Hill.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 6 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of six food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Budget-Minded
description: Members of Congress, like prophets, are sometimes held in higher respect in the capital than in their homes. When a Washington woman was chatting with a South Carolina man in the TKTS discount theater ticket line in New York the other day, she spotted Representative Butler Derrick, Democrat of South Carolina, in the line and pointed him out. ''Well,'' the man responded, eying the Congressman, ''when it comes to his own money, I see he doesn't spend it.''

title: Blacks And the Fortune 500
description: When Jackie Robinson entered professional baseball, the sports world was never the same again (''No More Zero-Sum Game,'' by Arthur Ashe, About Men, Aug. 31). When Arthur Ashe and his 39- to 45-year-old black professional buddies entered their particular occupations, the world was never the same.

title: PENNSYLVANIA CHIEF IN DRUG CASES QUITS
description: Eighteen days after he was installed as head of criminal and narcotics investigations in the Pennsylvania Attorney General's Office, Richard L. Guida resigned amid allegations that he had used cocaine.

title: THE GOOD NEWS ABOUT NEW YORK CITY
description: NEW YORK CITY holds a fascination for many people - especially for people who don't live there. I am aware of this because I am a New Yorker who travels a lot. Over the years, I have practiced law, been a senior officer of the Dreyfus Mutual Funds and a general partner of the banking firm of Lazard Freres. I am now president of a broadcasting and publishing company. These positions have taken me to Hong Kong, Moscow, Paris and, lately, on a regular basis to some two dozen United States cities where our company owns facilities.

title: Wedding Planned By Betsy Karmin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Monroe W. Karmin of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Karmin, to Emanuel David Strauss, the son of Mrs. Joseph S. Strauss of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Strauss. A Nov. 22 wedding is planned.

title: WESTPORT FOR CONN-MEX
description: THE state has a handful of Mexican restaurants, and Westport, with three, seems to have cornered the market. The third arrival, La Sierra, is in a long, softly (one might say dimly) lighted room with a bar or cantina in a room beyond in a Post Road shopping complex.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO REASON ON EARTH. By Katharine Haake. (Dragon Gate, 508 Lincoln Street, Port Townsend, Wash. 98368. $16.) Theo, one of the many drifters and searchers in Katharine Haake's accomplished first collection of stories, is a runaway at 16, flower child, war protester, lover of other women as well as men.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN UNDISCOVERED GEM IN MADISON
description: AN EXTRAORDINARY small museum, housed in a magnificent stone and stained-glass former library in the heart of downtown Madison, has attracted visitors from as far away as Canada, England and Colombia in recent weeks.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC GAMES;
BRINGING TOGETHERNESS INTO ARCADES
description: A WOMAN manipulating the character of Questor the elf was face to face with the shrouded figure of death. She - or, more accurately, Questor - was saved by Merlin the wizard, handled by the young man next to her.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
LEADERSHIP FORUM
description: A group of internationally known speakers will be on the rostrum this year to participate in the 1986-1987 President's Leadership Forum at the State University College of New York at Purchase.

title: Jane Madden Sullivan Weds David Gutierrez
description: The marriage of Jane Madden Sullivan, a doctoral candidate in neuroscience at Rockefeller University, and David Gregory Gutierrez, an assistant professor of history and ethnic studies at the University of Utah, took place yesterday in Erwinna, Pa. The Rev. John Mathison performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Evermay-on-the-Delaware, a country inn.

title: Michigan Intercepts Florida State, 20-18
description: Pat Moons broke a tie late in the third quarter with a 32-yard field goal today, and a beleaguered Michigan defense limited Chip Ferguson to 73 yards passing for a 20-18 triumph over Florida State.

title: SUBMARINE LAB IS PLANNED
description: TWO scientists want the Marine Sciences Institute of the University of Connecticut to acquire a decommissioned Navy submarine for use as a laboratory.

title: Two Gestures of Faith In Religious Landmarks of a Community
description: The intensity of real-estate pressure in Manhattan is too great, really, for any person or institution to resist. There is simply too much money to be made. Even the legal protection of the city's landmarks preservation laws is not enough today - not in an age when the congregation of one of the city's greatest churches, St. Bartholomew's, seeks to sue the city to overturn its landmark designation and erect an office tower on the site of its community house, and the owners of several other landmark buildings, including the great Metropolitan Club on Fifth Avenue at 60th Street, are in negotiation with real-estate developers to erect profitable towers above or beside their structures.

title: TOWNIES' ANCESTRAL PASTIME: HALFBALL
description: Fighting a raw, damp chill, Robert (Peanuts) Griffin swung his broomstick and watched the ball rocket across the street. It caromed high off the wall of a boarded-up warehouse before landing safely beyond a lunging opponent's frantic reach for a home run.

title: OPERA: JUDITH MALAFRONTE IN HANDEL'S 'ARIODANTE'
description: ONE of the enduring problems of opera is music's propensity -through repetition and elongation of phrase - to slow human action on stage very nearly to a halt. Dramatic credibility, in other words, asks the body to respond as if its words were spoken. Singing these same words reduces the actor to an agonizing slow motion, or else freezes audience perception into one static frame.

title: Blacks and the Fortune 500
description: There has been much talk that since the 1960's and 70's, blacks in America have lost their ''national agenda.'' Jesse Jackson added some sparkle in his Presidential bid, but I submit that Arthur Ashe has hit on a true objective when he says, ''I now look forward to the first black C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company.'' MICHAEL B. HARRIS Stone Mountain, Ga.

title: Division Winners Boast Best-of-the-Best Pitchers
description: BASED on performances during the season, pitchers should dominate the league championship series that begin next week. The Mets and Houston in the National League and Boston and California in the American League have a collection of pitchers who are the best or among the best in the majors.

title: WHEN AMERICA ENTERED THE 20th CENTURY
description: FDR The New Deal Years. 1933-1937. A History. By Kenneth S. Davis. 756 pp. New York: Random House. $29.95.

title: BARYSHNIKOV: STAYING IN TOP CONDITION
description: SEVEN THOUSAND PEOPLE filled the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles one night last year to see Mikhail Baryshnikov dance ''Giselle'' with the American Ballet Theater. Peter Marshall, the physical therapist for the company, was watching backstage. Baryshnikov made an exit in the first act, grabbed Marshall's arm and his own left foot and said, ''My foot - I can't put weight on it, I can't point it.''

title: Carson's Former Wife Reports Theft of $65,000 in Jewelry
description: Joanna Carson, the former wife of the television entertainer Johnny Carson, told the police Friday night that $65,000 in jewelry had been stolen from her suite in the Pierre Hotel.

title: Operatic Tenors
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco
description: Anniversaries are on the minds of San Franciscans as autumn, perhaps their most pleasant season, approaches. The City, as they like to call their town as if it were the only one, is about to commemorate the 50th birthdays of the two great bridges that grace its skyline, while the San Francisco Symphony, reinvigorated under Herbert Blomstedt, in his second year as conductor, has opened its 75th anniversary season.

title: LEBANON FACTIONS BATTLE AFTER RAID INTO EAST BEIRUT
description: In the worst day of violence in the Lebanese capital this year, heavy street fighting broke out today between rival Lebanese factions in Christian East Beirut. It was followed by large-scale artillery exchanges.

title: POLAND SEEKS EASING OF ECONOMIC STRICTURES
description: THE Polish diplomatic and political mazurka is becoming lively again. Following the release of political prisoners two weeks ago, the Government, the Party, the Church and some elements in the opposition are all whirling separately about the floor, apparently considering how far they should go in coordinating their movements.

title: Women and Change
description: Excerpt from the introduction to ''Feminism in America: 1848-1986,'' a section in The Wilson Quarterly, published by the Woodrow Wilson International Center at the Smithsonian:

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of a listing that accompanied a Sept. 21 Travel article about Goethe, incorrect names and telephone numbers were given for some hotels and restaurants in Italy.

title: Miss Stringfellow Weds
description: Kathleen Rogerson Stringfellow, a marketing manager at Institutional Investor, a financial publication in New York, and Mitchell Alan Orfuss, an executive vice president of Grey Direct in New York, the direct marketing subsidiary of Grey Advertising, were married yesterday in Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. George Kloster performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hargrave Stringfellow of Greensboro and Mr. and Mrs. Irving Orfuss of New York.

title: Bettie Bair Marries
description: Bettie Suzanne Bair and Reynolds Pomeroy 2d, 1980 graduates of William Smith and Hobart Colleges, respectively, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Chapel of the Transfiguration in Moose, Wyo. The Rev. Lester Thrasher, assisted by the Rev. David F. Gearhart, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rippel Bair of Baltimore and Mr. and Mrs. Burdette Pomeroy of New York.

title: Alaskans to Get $556.26 Each
description: Every man, woman and child in Alaska is to receive a check for $556.26 by Christmas, thanks to the state's annual share-the-wealth program.

title: UCONN PLAYS HOST TO A CASCADE OF FINE CONCERTS
description: THE first of three major concert cycles to be given at the University of Connecticut's Jorgensen Auditorium this year will open Thursday at 8 P.M. with the Alexander String Quartet.

title: POSTINGS: 71 for Norwalk; Landmark Rehab
description: Officials of the Delta Corporation have decided to convert a landmark building in Norwalk, Conn., into a condominium apartment house and have it blend in with urban renewal efforts in the old mill town. Their plans involve the R & G corset factory, a waterfront fixture for a century with brick walls up to a foot thick.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SAY THEY WERE ABUSED IN PRISONS
description: Civil rights monitoring groups, former detainees and doctors who have examined detainees after their release assert that South Africa's emergency decree has led to harsh conditions and sometimes torture for those held under its provisions.

title: Wilson and Hemingway
description: To the Editor:

title: AN INFLATION SCENARIO
description: Signs of reviving inflation are abundant, as are skeptics who read each rise in inflationary barometers as an aberration. Marc Perkins, president of a Tampa, Fla., investment banking firm, Perkins, Smith Inc., said he was ''on the fence'' until a few weeks ago.

title: Cable TV
description: Besides Lafayette and the Statue of Liberty, France has exported to the United States a multitude of splendid films. And Bravo is unreeling a great deal of these riches in the form of a three-month festival titled ''Comedie Francaise,'' starting this week.

title: STUDY SLIGHTS RISK OF FORMALDEHYDE
description: A new study by the Federal Government indicates that the 1.6 million workers exposed to formaldehyde do not have a higher risk of cancer than the general population.

title: A SKILL USEFUL THROUGHOUT LIFE
description: How unfortunate that the retired English teacher John Weiner finds that ''going to the library can be a humiliating experience.'' Is he troubled by an unfortunate experience in his own past, or is he simply unhappy with the notion that books must be returned to the library - where they are circulated and shared by many other library patrons?

title: STAGE: GYPSY TROUPE FROM MOSCOW
description: YOU don't have to know Russian or Romany, the gypsy language, to understand that the exuberant entertainers of Moscow's Romen Gypsy Theater are singing and dancing about sadness or joy.

title: President Aquino, King Juan Carlos Tell It to the U.N.
description: At the opening of the United Nations General Assembly session a year ago, the speaker from the Philippines was Imelda Marcos, the wife of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. She passionately denounced ''injustice, intolerance, greed and domination by the strong.'' Last week, President Corazon Aquino took the same podium and criticized the United Nations for not supporting the revolt that ousted Mr. Marcos and put her in his place.

title: 2 RABBIS SHARE PULPIT AND HOME
description: WHEN the rabbis begin the High Holy Day services next Friday night at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, there will be something unusual in the proceedings. The rabbis are husband and wife.

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: Pas de Deux Recorded at the 1984 Los Angeles International Ballet Festival; directed by Ted Lin Video Arts International 81 minutes. $49.95

title: Discovering Fronsac
description: FOR AT LEAST TWO DEC-ades, wine people have been predicting a great future for Fronsac.

title: The New School Germanized?
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIDING RETIREMENT FUNDS IS PIRACY
description: TEMPTED by overflowing returns on stocks in their pension plans, more than 1,000 companies have recently siphoned off $12 billion in pension fund assets meant for workers and retirees. The corporations then used the funds to fuel scores of ventures completely unrelated to the employees on whose behalf the plan was established.

title: Charles Ludlam And the Importance of Being Ridiculous
description: During his 20-year career as artistic director, playwright and star of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, Charles Ludlam has created an extensive and chimerical body of work - more than two dozen comedies, all written and performed in the Ridiculous manner. Heightened into hilarity, the genre is a step beyond Theater of the Absurd. Mr. Ludlam has himself defined the style as ''ensemble playing which synthesizes wit, parody, vaudeville farce, melodrama and satire, giving reckless immediacy to classical stagecraft.'' ''Reckless immediacy'' is, in fact, a signature of his theater, beginning with ''Bluebeard,'' the bizarre comedy that first brought him to prominence in 1970, right up to his mirthful new show, ''The Artificial Jungle.''

title: Blacks in the Fortune 500
description: Although I'm female, as a black I identify with Arthur Ashe's article in its entirety. His final sentence is beautiful and says much about the author. I have a daughter who may be that first black C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company. DOROTHY N. ROWN Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: DOMESTICITY, DEAD AND ALIVE
description: TUXEDO PARK By Laura Furman. 352 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: MORRIS COUNTY is beginning a $208,000 study of storm-water management in the flood-prone Upper Rockaway River Watershed as part of its effort to develop a countywide management plan.

title: ALBANY BECOMES A SEAT OF PORTRAITURE
description: Visitors to the Capitol here might wonder why there are blank spaces on the walls of the Hall of Governors, where painted portraits of DeWitt Clinton, Theodore Roosevelt, Martin Van Buren and many others normally hang.

title: WITH TRUST AS COLLATERAL, KOREANS GET HEAD START
description: The meeting was modern but the arrangements for it, in a way, go back a thousand years.

title: PLANE PACT IS SEEN FOR LOCKHEED
description: Congressional investigators asserted today that the Air Force was proceeding toward awarding a final $2.2 billion contract to the Lockheed-Georgia Company for C-5B cargo planes despite the company's refusal to prepare a new bid and evidence of significant overpricing.

title: For Dennis Conner, There's a New Race to Win
description: THERE was a time when Dennis Conner chided himself for losing the America's Cup, not in doleful tones, but with the sense that fate had dealt him the wrong card. Yet he appears to have come to grips with that, and he still considers himself the man to beat.

title: Housing Costs Soar in New York Area
description: WHILE the New York-Northeastern New Jersey region has always been an expensive place to live, Government figures show that it is now the inflation capital of the country, especially when it comes to housing.

title: A GUIDE TO MASSAGE
description: IT RELAXES AND INVIGORATES. IT can aid circulation, soothe sore muscles and alleviate the pain of athletic injuries. But even so, massage still gets a skeptical response.

title: MUSIC TODAY- MORE THAN JUST ANOTHER SERIES
description: ''WE didn't want to put together just one more new music series presided over by composers,'' Gerard Schwarz said in a recent interview. ''Instead, we wanted to present concerts in which composers didn't conduct, didn't perform, didn't sit on the board of directors, and we could choose the pieces we wanted to play for musical rather than political reasons. Don't get me wrong. This is not to say that if Peter Maxwell Davies starts a group to play his music or if Steve Reich starts a group to play his music, that it somehow isn't valid. It's very valid indeed. But we had something different in mind.''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: SHUTTLE service between Princeton Airport in Montgomery Township and Newark International Airport began Sept. 2 and, according to the operator, the Princeton Air Link Corporation, business has been picking up steadily.

title: HOSPITALS PRESSING ADVERTISING
description: NEW JERSEY'S health-care institutions are increasing their advertising to try to stem the loss of tens of thousands of patients a year to out-of-state hospitals.

title: A VOW TO BUILD DISPUTED MALL
description: DESPITE the Brookhaven Planning Board's rejection last week of the site plan for a large mall in Yaphank, the developer, Harry Grant, said he still intends to build the mall.

title: Olivia Hatch Has Wedding
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., yesterday Olivia Hatch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Whiting Hatch of Beverly Farms, was married to John Farr 2d, a son of C. Sims Farr of New York and the late Mary Randolph Rue Farr. Bishop John B. Coburn, who is retired from the Diocese of Massachusetts, performed the ceremony.

title: RUNOFF SET IN LOUISIANA SENATE RACE
description: Representatives W. Henson Moore and John B. Breaux will meet in a runoff Nov. 4 as Mr. Moore fell short in his bid Saturday to be the first Republican from Louisiana to serve in the United States Senate in more than a century.

title: France Aids Togo After an Attack
description: When the Goverment of the West African nation of Togo reported last week that it had put down an attempted coup, France quickly sent 250 soldiers and a navy minesweeper to its former colony. By week's end, as quiet returned to Lome, Togo's capital, Zaire said it was sending troops, 350 men, as a further gesture of solidarity.

title: NEW MALL, NO NEW PARKING
description: THE signs on the borders read, ''Welcome to Cedarhurst -a Unique Shopping Village.''

title: Polish Navy Winner in Cowdin Stakes
description: Polish Navy sailed through the slop at Belmont Park yesterday to win the $183,600 Cowdin Stakes and join Gulch and Bet Twice as undefeated leaders of the nation's 2-year-olds.

title: AN ELECTRIFYING BILL, SUDDENLY OVERDUE
description: BY almost any standard, the lending record of the Rural Electrification Administration has been one a banker would envy. At the end of the last fiscal year, the Federal agency reported that in the previous half century it had collected more than $12.5 billion in principal and interest on loans made to the co-ops that provide electricity for about 20 million people in the nation's hinterlands. During that period, it lost only $44,478.

title: MAKING THE RIGHT CONNECTIONS
description: ONE of the ''givens'' in project management is that the job being overseen never proceeds as planned. A large project may well require repeated recalculation to compensate for changes due to delays in the delivery of materials, worker absenteeism or any of the myriad variables that can affect the venture. In this respect project management resembles the machinations of spreadsheeting, except that in the case of project management one is not asking the by now familiar ''What if?'' questions, but rather ''What now?''

title: SOFTENING UP SOFTWARE PUBLISHERS
description: IN 1984, Gloria Molina, of Los Angeles bought an Apple Lisa personal computer to automate her office mailings. To her dismay, she found that the software that the dealer had said would do the job was never released. Worse yet, Ms. Molina found that there was little that she could do to get her money back.

title: MISSING BOOKS LISTS SPEAK VOLUMES
description: New York, a city of writers and readers, is a literate place and, as such, it is sometimes possible to take its measure in its public reading rooms.

title: FALCONS WIN RESPECT, FANS
description: HERE'S what happens when a team starts the season 3-0 for only the second time in 21 years:

title: Swimming
description: I ALMOST DROWNED when I was 3 years old. One of the family stories concerns my blond curls floating like meringue down the creek while my mother, much the stronger swimmer, cried out to my father to save me. Yet I have no fear of the water. At the beach, I am always the one farthest out beyond the breakers, my head bobbing trustingly among the waves.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in this section on Aug. 17 with an article on newspaper chains misidentified the newspapers purchased by Morris Communications in 1982. They were The Florida Times-Union and The Jacksonville Journal.

title: RIGHT TO LIFE SLATE: ALL L.I.
description: THE State Right to Life Party has often been criticized as a one-issue party, concentrating only on abortion. But now it also has a narrow geographic base - Long Island - in a year when the party is fighting for its survival.

title: Q AND A
description: Sale of a Time Share Question: We are interested in selling our time share in Hawaii. How can we find out what the current market is for time shares there? If we decide to sell, how do we go about it? . . . K. H., Brooklyn Answer: The best way is to contact a brokerage company that specializes in time-share resales. Susan Alexander, a spokesman for the National Time Share Council, a trade association that serves developers, lenders, marketing companies and interior designers, referred to ''Helpful Hints for Time Share Consumers,'' a pamphlet published by her organization that includes the names of 10 time-share resale companies throughout the country. The booklet costs $1 and is available by mail; send a self-addressed, stamped envelope to National Time-Share Council, 1220 L Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20005.

title: On Culbertson
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara Ann Ettorre Wed To Kostas Skordelis, Artist
description: Barbara Ann Ettorre, a freelance writer from New York, and Konstantinos Demetrios Skordelis, an iconographic artist and portrait painter from the island of Lesvos in Greece, were married yesterday at the Church of St. John in the village of Kalloni on Lesvos.

title: WOMEN BISHOPS CONSIDERED
description: Bishops of the United States Episcopal Church have reaffirmed their intent to name women as bishops but acknowledged a need for caution lest worldwide Anglican unity be endangered, a church spokesman said today.

title: A JUDGE FROM NEW YORK WINS WORLD BRIDGE TITLE
description: In the end, it was nolo contendere as Judge Amalya L. Kearse, a Federal appeals judge from Manhattan, and her partner, Jacqui Mitchell, led throughout the two days of final play to win the World Women's Pair Championship here.

title: BUDDHA SNATCHERS
description: THE NEXT BEST THING By John Ralston Saul. 241 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: U.S.C. Stuns Washington
description: Ken Henry caught two touchdown passes, including a 13-yarder from Rodney Peete in the fourth quarter, as Southern Cal (3-0) rallied to upset Washington (2-1), 20-10, in their Pacific-10 Conference opener today.

title: Marjorie Seaman Weds
description: Marjorie Seaman, a manager of the East Williamsburg Industrial Development Corporation in Brooklyn, and Max C. Rosin, a financial valuation expert at the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company in Manhattan, were married last night at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated.

title: Honors for Two Distinguished Americans
description: The United States honored T. S. Eliot and Dr. Paul Dudley White this month. T. S. Eliot, poet and dramatist, was recognized last Friday on a Literary Arts commemorative. Dr. Paul Dudley White, the late cardiologist, is shown on a Sept. 15 issue that is part of the Great Americans regular series.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: KALEIDOSCOPIC VIEW The Adult School of Montclair has commissioned six of the top people in diverse fields - art, literature, terrorism, dictatorships, health care and symphony music - to share their expertise in the club's Special Lecture Series, ''Fall Kaleidoscope: View From the Inside,'' which opens Tuesday at Montclair High School.

title: Laura Roulet, Grants Manager, Weds Rafael Hernandez Mayoral, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Laura Roulet, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman L. Roulet of Shaker Heights, Ohio, to Rafael Hernandez Mayoral, a son of Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico, and Mrs. Hernandez of San Juan and Ponce, took place yesterday. The Rev. Nicholas White performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: IN JAPAN, MICKEY-SAN IS RIGHT AT HOME
description: When it comes to Mickey Mouse in Japan, Joe Louis had it right: You can run, but you can't hide.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ESTATES OF GRACE In observance of New York State's Architectural Heritage Year, the Rye Historical Society and the Rye Landmarks Advisory Committee have arranged a tour from 1:30 to 5:30 this afternoon of the city's ''Estates of Grace,'' five important religious institutions. Most are situated on ''Church Row'' between Milton Road and the Boston Post Road, and the tour route is easily walkable, but transportation will be available.

title: OH, TO BE A DESIGNATED SPENDER
description: ''THE rich are different from us,'' my father has often said.

title: Manning on Campus
description: HE led Ole Miss to three bowl games between 1968 and 1971 and then had a 14-year pro football career with the New Orleans Saints, the Houston Oilers and the Minnesota Vikings but, according to Archie Manning, it won't be long before his fame fades. ''I know that in time it's going to decrease,'' said Manning, now an investment counselor in New Orleans, ''but it doesn't bother me.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TALES OF A GAMBLING GRANDMA Written and illustrated by Dayal Kaur Khalsa. Illustrated. 32 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $11.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: TWO KINDS OF NATIONALISM
description: APARTHEID IN CRISIS Edited by Mark A. Uhlig. 335 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: PRESSURE ON SPECTER INTENSIFYING IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania is well ahead in the polls. He has raised far more money than his Democratic opponent, Representative Bob Edgar. And the Republicans have won every senatorial contest in this state since 1962.

title: IBERIA'S WHITE HILL TOWNS
description: The white hill towns of Iberia, those whitewashed villages perched along high ridges, still exist in their own very private world. With their walls as clean as the air itself, flowers everywhere and traditional blue and white tiles, they cling to a neatness and serenity that has endured for centuries.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: WHEN the first shimmer of blue flickered through the pines, the frog began his kick. By the last quarter-mile, he was moving at world-class pace.

title: MARK GREEN SEEKS INQUIRIES INTO D'AMATO CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, called on Federal and state prosecutors yesterday to investigate possible illegal contributions to his Republican opponent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and whether those donations influenced the Senator's actions on legislation.

title: SECRETS AND SURPRISES IN A DURABLE WORLD
description: THE LOVER OF HORSES And Other Stories. By Tess Gallagher. 184 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: 'BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIRS': YOUNG SIMON
description: NOT only has the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst opened its fall season with Neil Simon's ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' but as the Studio's new producer, Jerry Zaback, explained in a lengthy curtain speech, it has been taken over by the Broadhollow Theater and is now known as the New Studio Theater.

title:
