RECORDINGS;
French Music For Piano Works Its Charms
description: When one thinks of French piano music, several names immediately spring to mind, not the least of which are represented in recent performances on disk. Called the ''master of charms'' by Debussy (who compared the ''play of fleeting curves that is the essence of [his] music. . .to the movements of a beautiful woman without either suffering from the comparison''), Faure (1845-1924) developed a musical idiom that formed the Procrustean bed of Impressionism, while maintaining the cool linear clarity traditionally a feature of the French school. Nonetheless, despite the respect he earned as organist and teacher, Faure's popularity as a composer was on the whole posthumous.

title: ON MONITORING BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: IN AN Aug. 24 Opinion Page article (''Genetic Engineering Must Be Regulated''), State Senator John H. Dorsey presented his case for S. 1123. a bill to ''regulate the release of genetically engineered microorganisms.''

title:
GARDENING;
LEARNING FROM ENGLISH COUNTRY ESTATES
description: ENGLAND has long been called ''the mother of gardens.'' Many of the plants we accept as commonplace had their origin in England.

title: Marvin Miller Is 'Off Base'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Russians Seem to shift Into a Conciliatory Gear
description: THE back and forth over the case of Nicholas S. Daniloff and the related controversies diverted attention last week from the main development in Secretary of State George P. Shultz's talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. As became evident last weekend, the Soviet Union has apparently decided to go for a summit meeting.

title: INVESTING IN MINORITY BUSINESS
description: IN Summit, N.J., Dr. Lemuel Leeper, a black biochemist and the inventor of a special shaving cream, needs money to manufacture and distribute his product. In Atlanta, a Vietnamese-Chinese proprietor of the Mayleese Chinese Fast Food Service needs money to expand his two successful stores into a chain. In Puyallup, Wash., Earl Reubel, the black owner of a helicopter service company, needs money for a new business opportunity to make up for the disappearance of his prime customers: the oil exploratory companies. In Tulsa, Okla., the black owner of a trucking company, buffeted by forces beyond its control, needs money to turn the company around and get it out of bankruptcy.

title: Constance Laibe Marries John A. Hays
description: Constance M. Laibe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Laibe of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to John A. Hays, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hays of Greenwich, at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester, a Methodist minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Peter Dora, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Richard H. Stearns, a Presbyterian minister.

title: A HARD DAY'S WORK, ON A MAFIA TRIAL TAPE
description: Even men who are supposed to be Mafia bosses can have a hard day at the office and feel like quitting.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Koval Wed To Robert Peak

title: Bernstein Triumphant
description: Having been one of the orchestral students fortunate enough to play under Leonard Bernstein at Tanglewood in the 1970's, I can truly appreciate John Rockwell's apt descriptions (''Bernstein Triumphant,'' Aug. 31).

title: L.I. Assemblyman Dies After Jogging at School
description: State Assemblyman John J. Flanagan, who represented the Huntington area for 14 years, died today when he collapsed after jogging.

title: PEPSICO INSTALLS 3 TOTEM POLES IN ITS SCULPTURE GARDENS
description: THE way the addition of three new pieces of sculpture to the Donald M. Kendall Sculpture Gardens at Pepsico in Purchase was dedicated recently may have been a ''first'' in the annals of corporate celebrations.

title: Miss Brooks Wed To G. H. Love 2d
description: Susan Byrd Brooks, a daughter of Mrs. Ernest Action Brooks 2d of St. Louis and the late Mr. Brooks, was married yesterday to George Hutchinson Love 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Love of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Jack L. Adams performed the ceremony at the Salem in Ladue United Methodist Church in Ladue, Mo.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC GAMES;
BEAMS OF LIGHT THAT 'KILL' THE ENEMY
description: EERIE synthesizer music floated through the dim, foggy room as about 20 youths wearing bulky helmets with flashing lights and cumbersome battery-pack belts sneaked around corners, up ramps and through narrow corriders shooting each other with ''phasers.'' They had each paid about $3 for a six-and-a-half-minute jaunt through Planet Photon, and they seemed to be getting their money's worth.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Of Medals, Meetings, Coins and Shows
description: Israel has unveiled an unusual new medal whose design includes a multi-colored lithograph. It is thought to be the first such medal ever commissioned and issued by any government mint.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Five Series to Bow on USA Network
description: Can game shows and sitcoms build a better USA?

title: PARENTS PRAISING GROCERY-CART BELTS
description: ''THEY are wonderful,'' said Kathleen Nertney of Peekskill, wheeling her small daughter around a supermarket.

title: SPA FOODS
description: LET'S FACE IT, WHEN YOU'RE used to cream, butter and salt, food doesn't taste good without them,'' says Seppi Renggli, chef at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. Like many top chefs, Mr. Renggli doubted that low-calorie, low-fat, low-salt and high-fiber food could be as flavorful and as sophisticated as more classically prepared dishes. But a few chefs - Mr. Renggli included - were so successful at creating light, healthful cuisine that many of the leading restaurants have added these foods to their menus. Today, ''spa'' food is likely to include the latest variations on regional American cooking. And recipes for spa meals are making their way into books for the home cook.

title: A RETURN VISIT TO GLISTENING SPETSAI
description: The Greek island of Spetsai is a small, wooded rock that rises gently out of the Argolic Gulf some 90 miles southwest of Athens. Although it lies just off the Spartan shore, the symmetry of Spetsai is an Attic symmetry: harmonious and pure; land, sea and sky. When the sun shines upon its white houses, its white churches and the white sails of its fishing boats, the island gleams.

title: BALLET: EGLEVSKY TROUP IN A NEW 'CINDERELLA'
description: THE EGLEVSKY BALLET presented the first performance of a new production of ''Cinderella'' on Thursday night at the Half Hollow Hills Concert Theater in Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Smoked Meat
description: To the Editor: For connoisseurs of smoked meat (Travel, Aug. 17) there is an alternative to Bundnerfleisch and jerky, which is closer to home for most readers than the Grisons or Texas.

title: The Mix of Art and Commerce
description: The first thing to be said about the exhibition ''Art and Advertising: Commercial Photography by Artists,'' now at the International Center of Photography (1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, through Nov. 9), is that its title joins two apparently disparate realms with a simple conjunction. This is rather presumptuous, since art, which purports to deal with the esthetic, and advertising, which trades in the creation of desire, are normally considered antithetical. It is also simplistic, since in practice - as well as in theory - their relationship is quite complex.

title:
GARDENING;
LEARNING FROM ENGLISH COUNTRY ESTATES
description: ENGLAND has long been called ''the mother of gardens.'' Many of the plants we accept as commonplace had their origin in England.

title: THE NEW RULES FOR PREGNANCY
description: THERE SEEMED TO BE mirrors everywhere, and there we stood, reflected over and over, great black bumblebees in our leotards, pregnant women exercising. We stretched our necks and shoulders, worked our thighs, pulled in the long-suffering abdominal muscles that had so much to hold. ''Hug your baby,'' said the instructor as we tried in vain to flatten our stomachs. The classes were held in a racquetball club, and I remember the morning when two men in tennis whites stumbled in upon us by mistake. Ashen, they backed out, mumbling excuses; we were the ones who laughed as we continued our leg lifts.

title: CONCERT: STEVIE WONDER
description: STEVIE WONDER, who played at Madison Square Garden on Friday, has been pop's unquenchable optimist for nearly a generation. In the records he has made over the past 23 years, seldom is heard a discouraging word; his love songs aim to capture ecstasy, unafraid of voicing cliches, while his character studies are models of positive thinking. At some points, he comes close to drowning in treacly sentiment - but most of the time he pulls back with an unpredictable vocal line, a surprising chord change, or simply his own unforced sincerity.

title: SERVING MANY NEEDS
description: Actively Concerned

title: THE YANKS MUSCLE IN ON THE CITY
description: WHEN Robert Maxwell, the British newspaper baron and stock wheeler-dealer, unloaded a huge portfolio 10 days ago, he did not take the usual route of asking British brokers to peddle the stocks bit by bit. Instead, he invited three foreign investment houses to bid on the whole package, finally selling it to Goldman, Sachs International, the London arm of the American investment house, for nearly $300 million.

title: Columbia Rally Fails as Lafayette Wins
description: Columbia scored three touchdowns yesterday but still suffered another loss, this time a 26-21 setback to Lafayette, at Lawrence A. Wien Stadium.

title: Virginia T. Thumm Is Wed
description: Virginia Thayer Thumm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Linwood Armfield Thumm of Norfolk, Va., was married in New York yesterday to Thomas John Robotham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Robotham of Richmondtown, S.I. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The bride is development coordinator of the Third Street Music School Settlement. Mr. Robotham is a special projects editor with Esquire magazine.

title: HOSPITALS SEE RISE IN USE OF CRACK
description: THE use of crack is spreading steadily in Connecticut, and doctors and other health authorities say they are beginning to see evidence of it in emergency rooms and treatment centers.

title: U.S. Judge Charges V.A. Destroyed Papers in Suit
description: Federal District Judge Marilyn Hall Patel says that the Veterans Administration has destroyed documents that could have been used as evidence in a suit filed on behalf of veterans who were exposed to radiation from atomic bombs.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This bill makes political sense. There's enough glory and gain to go around for Republicans and Democrats.'' Representative Guy Vander Jagt, Republican of Michigan, on the tax bill.

title: The Angels
description: * Has made $200,000 in bonuses, and can make $100,000 more.

title: MAJOR FIGURE IN HORTICULTURE
description: Thomas H. Everett, one of the pre-eminent horticulturists in the world and former director of horticulture at the New York Botanical Garden, died Friday of complications after undergoing surgery for ulcerative colitis in June. He was 83 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: UP ON THE FLAT RMOF: HOW TO MAKE REPAIRS TO ASPHALT ROLLS
description: FLAT roofs are much easier to repair than shingle roofs. Replacing or patching a damaged shingle is trickier than patching asphalt-roll roofing, the material normally used on flat roofs. Flat roofs also are much safer to work on. In addition, a leak is much easier to locate in a flat roof because it is more likely to be directly above the trouble spot inside; on a sloping roof the leak may actually be much higher up on the roof or even off to one side of where it occurs inside.

title: PLAN TO SELL WATERSHED SCRUTINIZED BY OFFICIALS
description: A PROPOSAL by a Bridgeport water company to sell more than 2,000 acres of watershed in 14 Fairfield County towns is being scrutinized by state and local officials.

title: SURVEY OF LAND FINDS 27 PERCENT REMAINS GREEN
description: DESPITE the growth of office parks, shopping centers, condominiums and networks of highways, 27 percent of Westchester's land is still open, as parkland, watershed land, golf courses and farms, according to a new survey by the Westchester County Department of Planning.

title: Grace Settles A Pollution Case
description: Using what seems to be a favored tactic in ''toxic tort'' cases, W.R. Grace & Company last week settled a suit brought by eight families in Woburn, Mass., who charged that Grace had contaminated two local wells with chemicals that caused leukemia, killing five children and one adult.

title: BOSTON WAITS WORD ON POLICE DRUG TEST SUIT
description: In the five months since the Boston Police Commissioner, Francis M. Roache, announced his proposal to conduct random drug tests of all department employees, the plan has drawn fire from civil liberties groups, a lawsuit from a police union and now approval from the Justice Department.

title: Pamela Constable Weds a Professor
description: Pamela Groome Constable, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Cheston Constable of Essex, Conn., was married yesterday to Arturo Arms Valenzuela, a son of Bishop and Mrs. Raymond Arms Valenzuela of Santiago, Chile. The Rev. Joseph Eldridge performed the ceremony at the Dumbarton United Methodist Church in Washington.

title: THE PEOPLE WHO WERE PATCO
description: THE change in speeds is what amuses David Livingston. All those years, the big airplanes flying at hundreds of miles an hour depended on him to get in and out of airports. Now commuter trains in Philadelphia follow his instructions. To him, they barely seem to move. ''One of the controllers from Newark who's doing this too said that it's like going from Star Wars to stagecoaches,'' Mr. Livingston chuckled. ''That's about what it's like.'' It was Mr. Livingston's day off, and he was having coffee with his wife at the Ritz diner in Philadelphia, where he lives. He is a sturdy, solemn-eyed, genial man of 38. He laughed some -a good, hearty laugh - even though his life over the last five years hasn't been a great deal of fun.

title: EGGPLANT FINDS DOZENS OF USES, FROM BEGINNINGS TO ENDS
description: EGGPLANT is nearly as versatile as the egg itself. The glossy, deep purple vegetable (which also comes in white - hence, they say, an explanation for its name) can be used in dozens of dishes from appetizer or hors d'oeuvres to soup to main course to side dish. Eggplant dip, eggplant with pasta, curried eggplant, baked eggplant, stuffed eggplant, eggplant Parmesan, eggplant salad, pickled eggplant, Chinese eggplant with a jolt of hot pepper, grilled eggplant, fried eggplant sticks and eggplant slices decorating and flavoring a pizza are just the beginning.

title: Holding the Line
description: 'In contrast to the situation 18 months ago, and assuming growing markets are open to us, my sense is that we are for now reasonably close to an appropriate adjustment. I'm not sure a further adjustment is necessary.' Paul A. Volcker chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, telling Congress that in his opinion the value of the dollar has dropped enough.

title: CONFESSIONS OF AN EQUIPMENT FANATIC
description: I CAN PINPOINT THE MO-ment when I realized I had slipped out of the American mainstream. One night five years ago as I watched a television commercial I was made aware of two embarrassing gaps in my life: I did not have a favorite pain reliever, and I did not jog. Since I didn't even have a favorite pain there was nothing I could do about the first deficiency, but why not jog?

title: Princeton Stymied By Northwestern
description: Princeton's first offensive play against Northwestern at Palmer Stadium today set the tone for the first game in 33 years between an Ivy League team and a Big 10 team.

title: HEALTH FACTS: A BAKER'S DOZEN
description: 1. Weight vs. Fat For years, weight tables were considered the best gauge for judging fatness. Now, there is a better way: measuring body fat. Body-fat norms, according to the American Heart Association, are 10 to 14 percent for men and 20 to 25 percent for women. Looks can be deceiving. At 6 feet 5 inches and 280 pounds, Mark Gastineau, the Jets defensive lineman, might seem too heavy. But his body fat is only 4 percent. Body fat is deterneneby calipers, in which a person's skin folds are measured, or by hydrostatic bath, in which the amount of water displaced by a person's body is measured. 2. On Foot Workers in several jobs were clocked for daily mileage.

title:
ART;
EXPLORING 25 DIRECTIONS IN PRINTS
description: THE subtitle of ''Graphic Images,'' the current exhibition at the East End Arts and Humanities Council in Riverhead, is ''Personal Impressions: Choices and Directions.''

title: POLITICS IN SUDAN IS DELAYING RELIEF
description: A planned relief operation for famine victims in the war-ravaged southern Sudan appears to be caught in a tangle of opposing political considerations.

title: Dogs Used in Search For Missouri Fugitive
description: A bloodhound and other dogs were used today in a search for Michael Wayne Jackson, a suspect in three killings, but the dogs did not pick up the scent, the authorities said.

title: HER HUSBAND ISN'T
description: BREAK IT DOWN By Lydia Davis. 177 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Incisive Tactics Bring In The Point
description: New York State, which has staged consecutive championships since 1878, surely tops all other states. This year, the 108th running of the event resulted in a tie among the defending champion, Joel Benjamin, a Brooklyn international master: Walter Shipman, a New York international master, and Tony Renna of New York.

title: ACTION IS URGED TO SAVE SPECIES
description: Scientists and conservationists are urgently calling for worldwide action to slow the accelerating mass extinction of animal and plant species.

title: A Night to Remember
description: To the Sports Editor: The prize at next year's Mets Fan Appreciation Day should be two blades of Astroturf and three empty beer cans. DANIEL McCRACKEN Manhattan

title: THE SELECTION OF A LENS
description: AT one time or another, all photographers who take their work seriously ask themselves: what lens do I need to make my pictures better? This is especially a quandary for those who are just starting with a single-lens-reflex camera and have never experienced the joys of interchangeable lenses. For them, going beyond the 50-millimeter ''normal'' lens that comes with most cameras is a momentous step.

title: TESTING HIMSELF
description: IF YOU ARE MEET-ing Paul Newman for the first time, he will have on his sunglasses. As he gets to know you, he will peek over the rims occasionally. As he gets to trust you, he will let the sunglasses hang from his left ear. The next time you meet, he will take them off.

title: HIJACKING IS A BLOW TO INDIA-PAKISTAN TALKS
description: The faltering effort to improve relations between India and Pakistan has been further damaged by the hijacking of an American jetliner in Karachi this month, according to diplomats.

title: Elizabeth Walsh Wed To Joseph Lovering 3d
description: Elizabeth Marshall Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Walsh of New York and Edgartown, Mass., was married in Edgartown yesterday to Joseph Sears Lovering 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lovering Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va. Msgr. John F. Corr and the Rev. George Almeida performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 'YANKEES', HIT OF OLD, IS REVISITED IN MILLBURN
description: SOMETHING supercharged is going on at the Paper Mill Playhouse, where a spiffy revival of ''Damn Yankees'' is running through Oct. 26.

title: John S. Sheldon Wed in Plainfield To Gigi Guenther
description: uf812>Mary Margaret Guenther and John Stevens Sheldon were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's grandmother Mrs. John P. Stevens Jr. in Plainfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roger W. Paine, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: Challengers and Defenders Are Ready to Sail
description: The following descriptions of America's Cup contenders were prepared and written by Barbara Lloyd. UNITED STATES Syndicate: The America II Challenge Boat: America II Sponsor: New York Yacht Club Skipper: John Kolius Budget: $15 million Headquarters: Newport, R.I.

title: France's Visa Procedure, New England River Voyages
description: New Rules: Getting a Visa For France

title: Music
description: Among the varied musical offerings coming up this week, two that are decidedly off the beaten path pique the curiosity of the adventurous listener.

title: UP ON THE FLAT ROOF: HOW TO MAKE REPAIRS TO ASPHALT ROLLS
description: FLAT roofs are much easier to repair than shingle roofs. Replacing or patching a damaged shingle is trickier than patching asphalt-roll roofing, the material normally used on flat roofs. Flat roofs also are much safer to work on. In addition, a leak is much easier to locate in a flat roof because it is more likely to be directly above the trouble spot inside; on a sloping roof the leak may actually be much higher up on the roof or even off to one side of where it occurs inside.

title: TUTU SAYS HISTORY WILL JUDGE REAGAN'S VETO
description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu said today that President Reagan would be judged harshly by history for vetoing a bill for economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: Electronic Monitoring Of Helms Talks Alleged
description: An aide to Senator Jesse Helms said Friday night that there were growing indications that the Central Intelligence Agency had obtained electronic surveillance information on conversations between the North Carolina Republican and President Augusto Pinochet of Chile.

title: MINORITIES IN MALAYSIA SEEK MORE LIBERAL POLICIES
description: In August, a few days after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was returned to office by a large majority, Tan Seng Giaw, a Member of Parliament, was invited by students at the National University of Malaysia to take part in a forum on the election.

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: Donizetti's 'Lucia di Lammermoor' A Metropolitan Opera House production, featuring Joan Sutherland, Alfredo Kraus, Paul Plishka, with the orchestra conducted by Richard Bonynge; 1982 Paramount Home Video 128 minutes. $59.95

title: TOPIC
description: I WILL be 40 in just a few months, taking my place next to the myriad ''baby boomers'' who have crossed over the bridge (or over the hill) before me.

title: Who Are Baseball's M.V.P.'s?
description: Replies for publications should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Riverfront Condos
description: Jeffrey Glick, the developer who sold out Manhattan Place on East 36th Street and First Avenue a year before the condominium was built, said he is now preparing a $2 million sales office for a new condominium across the street.

title: LONG-TERM WOES SEEN FOR CALIFORNIA ECONOMY
description: The diversified California economy, long the envy of many other states, is losing ground to foreign competitors virtually across the board and faces deepening long-term problems, according to a yearlong study of the state's future.

title: Mets Will Walk, But Not Very Far
description: It can be unsettling for a ball club to be up for sale during one of its best seasons yet, but last week the New York Mets discovered that they would just be going from one Doubleday pocket to another. Nelson Doubleday Jr., chairman of the Mets, said he and Fred Wilpon, the club president, would buy the baseball team from Doubleday & Company, the publishing concern Mr. Doubleday also heads. Mr. Wilpon, a real estate developer, has a 5 percent stake in the team; Doubleday & Company owns the rest.

title: Jackson Quiet as Angels Celebrate
description: With champagne squirting all over, players scampered about, eyes burning and playful smiles everywhere, the California Angels celebrated the American League Western Division title they won Friday night with an 8-3 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: PUTTING ON THE DOGS With 1,675 purebred specimens on hand there will be variety in abundance when the Westbury Kennel Association holds its 64th All Breed and Obedience Dog Show today at the C. W. Post Center in Brookville.

title: Patricia Brandy, A Lawyer, Wed To F. T. Connor
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Ogdensburg, N.Y., yesterday Patricia Ann Brandy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Brandy 3d of Ogdensburg, was married to Francis Thomas Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Connor of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Garry Giroux, assisted by Msgr.

title: VIRTUE IN DISSENSUS
description: RECONSTRUCTING AMERICAN LITERARY HISTORY Edited by Sacvan Bercovitch. 351 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.

title: Kary Mertz Wed To Brian Clancy
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Kary Elizabeth Mertz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mertz of Princeton, was married to Brian Joseph Clancy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cummin Clancy of Garden City, L.I., and Windham, N.Y. The Rev. Jean Smith performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Keane, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Cathy Mahoney Weds John B. Morris
description: Cathleen M. Mahoney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Mahoney of Arlington Heights, Ill., was married in Chicago yesterday to John B. Morris Jr., a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Morris of Atlanta. Judge James B. Moran of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, for whom the bride served as a law clerk, performed the ceremony at the Mansion in the City, a property of the Chicago City Day School.

title: Chile Lets Italian Agency Resume News Reporting
description: The military Government has authorized the Italian news agency ANSA to resume reporting from Chile after a 16-day suspension. It also released a prominent dissident who was detained two weeks ago after an attempt to assassinate Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the President, on Sept. 7.

title: DETROIT KILLING MARS 'NO CRIME DAY'
description: After a wave of summer shootings, Detroit today was observing ''No Crime Day'' at the urging of officials who had pleaded for residents to put away their pistols and refrain from crime for at least 24 hours. But, as an official parade was forming, a police officer responding to a call was killed early this afternoon.

title: Changing of the Guard
description: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia (left) poses with the former Chief Justice, Warren E. Burger, and the new Chief Justice, William H. Rehnquist, outside the Supreme Court building after Justices Scalia and Rehnquist were sworn in last week. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)

title: A BLACKSMITH BECOMES VILLAGE CAUSE CELEBRE
description: SIX days a week, 89-year-old Paul Nossolik trudges from the small house overlooking Greenport Harbor, where he has lived for 60 years, to a tumbledown wooden structure behind the new boutiques of Front Street.

title: A SWISS TOWN WITH ROOTS IN IRELAND
description: When Empress Eugenie, the beautiful consort of Napoleon III, wanted a new lace gown some 130 years ago, 36 seamstresses stitched for 18 months. The low-cut dress can be admired in a glass case in the Museum of Arts and Trades of St. Gall (in German, St. Gallen), the embroidery capital of Europe where now computers govern the machine needlework in busy factories. Yet, embroidering is also still a cottage industry in and around the old town in eastern Switzerland, and some St. Gall women who work in their homes take orders from private customers.

title: Looking Over NASA's Shoulder
description: Since the nation's first manned space flight in 1961, engineers who design spacecraft have argued about margins of safety, weighing cost and time against risk to human life. But it was always a quiet debate, behind closed doors, and almost never framed in life-or-death terms.

title: Anne E. Corroon Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Anne Eileen Corroon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Francis Corroon of Rye, N.Y., to Stephen Deacon Grubbs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Okla Gatewood Grubbs of Darien, Conn., took place yesterday in the chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. Edwin J. Duffy, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. Stephen V. Duffy, also an uncle of the bride.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Montclair Renewal Plan in Homestretch
description: MORE than two decades ago, Montclair officials started a campaign to turn a blighted area in the southern half of the township into a bustling commercial and residential hub.

title: GLOBAL NUCLEAR BAN TO BE DEBATED IN PRINCETON
description: FEDERAL Government officials, clergymen and high school students are among those expected to debate the possibility of a global nuclear-weapons ban at a conference here today.

title: Amy Ziebarth Is Bride Of William Fleming Jr.
description: Amy Miles Ziebarth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Ziebarth of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Troxell Fleming Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fleming of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Calvin Jackson performed the ceremony at The Presbyterian Church.

title: WIDEST REVISIONS IN 40 YEARS CUT RATES, CURB DEDUCTIONS
description: Ending one of the most tortuous legislative odysseys in years, the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to the most comprehensive changes in the Federal income tax system since World War II.

title: Walking
description: I USED TO PLAY ONE-WALL handball growing up in New York City. I remember a red-headed kid; he was the handball philosopher. I used to like to listen to him. We'd go for a walk after four or five hours of handball. We walked for miles around the neighborhood. Years later when I was in the Army Air Corps, I did a lot of walking. I have always done a lot of walking. When I had the heart attack in l966, I think I beat the mortality rate because I was in pretty good condition. I was 45 and working on

title: The New Shape of Denim in Jackets and Dresses
description: DENIM is nothing if not ambitious.

title: HOW I SPENT MY AEROBIC VACATION
description: RESPECTING PHYSICAL FIT-ness, I am plagued by two concerns. The first is universally experienced: the fear of (and esthetic distaste for) biological atrophy. About that there isn't, really, much to be said: everyone knows that the human body needs limbering. The second concern is less widely shared. It comes to me at two levels. The first of these has to do with the dislike I feel for physical exertion. It is one thing to play tennis, ride a horse, ski, sail a boat; quite another to jog, on and on, or to push weights (up and down) or for that matter to dig a hole in the ground or to climb steep mountains. These last activities constitute, for those of us who find it most comfortable to spend one's life lying down, or sitting in a chair, effort: the equivalent of required ingestions of medicine when one is sick. Those of us who aren't Christian Scientists will take medicine to get well, and by the same token, exercise to stay well. The key to acceptable physical-fitness programs, as far as we are concerned, is brevity. There are those who get highs from prolonged exercise. You cannot take jogging away from those who ''cross the 30-to-35-minute level,'' writes Jack H. Wilmore, professor of physical and health education at the University of Texas. Well, bless them. But most of us have no intention of devoting 10 percent of our day to physical exercise, so the search for economy in exercise-time is a concern.

title: PROFESSORS BACK YALE STUDENT ON FREE SPEECH
description: Last May the governing executive committee of Yale University put a sophomore on two years' probation for drawing and distributing a poster that satirized Yale's annual Gay and Lesbian Awareness Days.

title: 29 YEARS WATCHING THE WORLD GO BY...
description: HAD I known in 1957, when I so eagerly anticipated riding the train into New York every day, that I was about to spend the next 30 years of my life on the Long Island Rail Road, I might have reconsidered.

title: CHARLEY AND MAEROSE: THE EARLY YEARS
description: PRIZZI'S FAMILY By Richard Condon. 284 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: NEWSMAN REPORTS WORK CURB
description: A white South African journalist who was freed this month after 83 days in detention says he has been served with official restriction orders that effectively prevent him from carrying out his profession.

title: POP: DEFUNKT HEADS BILL
description: DEFUNKT, the hard-nosed New York band that emerged at the turn of the 1980's, then disappeared, has made a comeback - and Thursday at the Lone Star it was as tough, eccentric and danceable as ever.

title: A Couple Loses Out as Jersey Upgrades Police
description: Before heading out on afternoon patrol, Sgt. Florence Garrison waved goodbye to the head of the Police Department - her husband, Owen, really -and then climbed into one of the three town police cars.

title:
GARDENING;
LEARNING FROM ENGLISH COUNTRY ESTATES
description: ENGLAND has long been called ''the mother of gardens.'' Many of the plants we accept as commonplace had their origin in England.

title: Network News: In a Time of Change, Old Problems Persist
description: It is a time to reassess. Network news as we know it is either dead, dying or carrying on in the great tradition of Edward R. Murrow. The bottom line, drawn by accountants, eviscerates news coverage. There is no evisceration, someone replies, only a healthy tightening of the belt. Entertainment values take over, obliterating journalistic standards; nonsense, standards are cherished as always. Meanwhile, morale at CBS News rises, falls or skitters, and one night Dan Rather concludes his broadcast by saying not ''Good night'' but ''Courage.'' On the one hand this, on the other hand that, and the only sure thing is that in the last year or so television news has become one of its own best stories.

title: WOULD-BE CONTENDERS LIVE LIFE IN THE RING
description: Joseph (The Champ) Liranzo, 11 years old and 85 pounds, stood in front of a mirror imitating the jabs, punches and footwork of his hero, the lightweight champion Hector (Macho) Camacho.

title: 7 FINANCE CHIEFS REACH NO ACCORD
description: The finance ministers of seven leading industrial countries failed today to resolve their disputes over interest rates and the dollar that have unsettled the financial markets for months.

title: Losers
description: The news flowing from this year's Miss America show didn't end with the crowning of Kellye Cash, of Tennessee's Johnny Cash clan. There wasn't anything as embarrassing this time as the disclosure that Miss America '84 had been photographed in the nude.

title: 'To Sleep,' From Japan, Recalls Detective Serials
description: ''TO Sleep So As to Dream,'' a not-quite silent not-quite mystery in black and white, may be taken as a tribute to, or overextended joke about, those movie buffs who dream of a magical world where reality and illusion merge, where the show goes on forever. This Japanese work, which will be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 4 P.M. and tomorrow at 9:30 P.M., begins with the climactic scene of a 50-year-old serial called ''The Eternal Mystery.'' It is being watched by an elderly woman, and the reel breaks off abruptly just as the hero, The Black Mask, is about to reveal his identity.

title: TERROR IN SPAIN: IS CIVIL GUARD FIGHTING BACK?
description: Iosu Pascual, a 32-year-old town councilor in this Basque town near San Sebastian, said he was returning home one night when a group of men whom he could not identify seized him at his doorstep.

title: Mayor's Cup Sailing
description: THE schooner Victoria, owned by Merrick Pratt of Highlands, N.J., won the Mayor's Cup yesterday with the best corrected time in the 20th annual schooner race, which covered a 15-mile loop between the Battery and a point south of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. The winner of the trophy for the best elapsed time was Brilliant, an entry of the Mystic Seaport Museum in Connecticut.

title: MALCOLM X- HERO TO SOME, RACIST TO OTHERS- IS NOW THE STUFF OF OPERA
description: The impact, let alone success, of any new opera can never be predicted in advance of its premiere. Even the initial response, positive or negative, may not correspond with the judgment of posterity. That said, the opera receiving its world premiere tonight by the New York City Opera, Anthony Davis's ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X),'' is full of fascinating points of interest. There may well be those who wind up not liking it, for all sorts of reasons, but tonight's premiere will still be a genuine event.

title: Astoria Expands On Its Movie Heritage
description: Giant klieg lights peer down from the 30-foot ceiling, and a melange of assorted props, unused set walls, scrim and a tangle of wires surround two sets - a spartan basement apartment and a plush suburban bedroom - at opposite ends of Kaufman Astoria Studios' stage H. The tattered linoleum floor is strewn with boxes, and a bare lightbulb hangs from rusting pipes in the apartment of Brantley Foster, a Kansas boy who has come to New York to make his fortune. Foster - played by Michael J. Fox - works in a mail room but has duped his unwitting company into thinking he is an executive, all the while juggling two romances. Mr. Fox, and the rest of the cast and crew of the new Herbert Ross comedy, ''The Secret of My Success,'' are finishing their last day of shooting at Astoria.

title: LEAGUE CLARIFIES DATA ON PARTY LEVER
description: With reference to the article on the League of Women Voters of Connecticut that appeared on Aug. 24 [ ''New Image Is Sought by Voters' League'' ] , we would like to clarify a few points.

title: READ IT IF YOU CAN
description: There have been two comments in recent days on the level of American education, the first by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan, for which he has apologized; and the second a report on literacy by the National Assessment of Educational Progress that was commissioned by the U.S. Department of Education.

title: VERA'S PATH TO TRUTH
description: LEAVE OF ABSENCE By Ralph McInerny. 210 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: 'UNPOPULAR STAND' WINS SUPPORT
description: ''A Shift on Endorsement Ban,'' by Frank Lynn [ Sept. 14 ] , reports that the Conservative Party has declined to back the re-election of Nassau County Court Judge John Thorp on the ground that he opposed the death penalty as an assemblyman.

title: FRECKLES FOR THE AGES
description: NORMAN ROCKWELL A Definitive Catalogue. Volume One and Volume Two. By Laurie Norton Moffat. Introduction by David H. Wood. Illustrated. 1,152 pp. Hanover, N.H.: The Norman Rockwell Museum at Stockbridge/ The University Press of New England. $170; $195 after Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Hurricane Passer Prevails
description: BY nature, they are enemies. The bull and the matador. The mongoose and the cobra. The linebacker and the quarterback, especially Brian Bosworth and Vinny Testaverde.

title: Anne Van Munching Is Wed in Darien
description: ds2>Anne Van Munching, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Brown Ardery, the son of the late Grace Brown Ardery and the late Edmund Francis Ardery, also of Darien. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien.

title: In New Seas Across the World, the Race Begins
description: LIFE isn't the same anymore at the New York Yacht Club. With the loss of the America's Cup to the Australians in 1983, the West 44th Street club also lost control over an event that had been its showcase for nearly 132 years. The shift was abrupt; it was as if the club had found itself ousted overnight from the dugout of Newport, R.I., to the bleachers of Fremantle, Western Australia.

title: Siobhan O'Duffy Wed To Pressley Millen 3d
description: Siobhan Therese O'Duffy and Pressley McAuley Millen 3d, who recently graduated from the Duke University Law School and are associates in New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Stan Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: A TOUCH OF HOME IN THE CAPITAL
description: sINCE moving to Washington from New Jersey last year, Bob Legrand says, he hasn't been able to find a decent deli sandwich. And Mike Nardolilli says he misses the Jersey City neighborhood where he grew up.

title:
Focus: Newport, R.I.;
Carving Mansions Into Condos
description: ALTHOUGH ''The Great Gatsby'' was filmed at another mansion here, the 28-room Harbour Court - where members of Rhode Island's eminent Brown family have summered for decades - is worth a movie of its own. Sotheby's International Realty says it also is worth $4.5 million.

title: Living in a Silent World
description: Lou Ann Walker's article highlights the need to provide deaf and hearing-impaired people with the same opportunities as the non-hearing-impaired have.

title: FINDING THE RIGHT HEALTH CLUB
description: FINDING A HEALTH CLUB today is easy. What can be difficult is finding a club that is right for you, whether it is a full-service club with swimming pools, tennis courts, running tracks, exercise classes and weight rooms; an urban country club with restaurants and conference rooms or one of the more specialized one-on-one training facilities, cardiovascular fitness centers and body building gyms.

title: STOCKHOLM PACT IS ' A BLOW FOR PEACE' AND REAGAN'S FREINDS
description: THERE was an ambivalent mood of elation and anxiety in some European capitals last week.

title: DISCOUNT CLUBS PLANNED FOR ISLAND
description: WAREHOUSE clubs, which offer huge discounts on merchandise to members only, are coming to Long Island.

title: A FATHER'S GREAT EXPECTATION
description: EXPECTANT father. I find myself acting with the anticipation of going on a first date. The first official date.

title: Jets Hope to Stay in High Gear
description: The Jets' history - of losing the game they expected to win, of falling flat the week after a big, emotional victory - faces another test on Sunday when they meet the 0-3 Colts in the Hoosier Dome.

title: AID FOR BOATERS OF THE CONNECTICUT
description: WHEN Albert Einstein rented a boat and sailed down the Connecticut River while vacationing in Lyme in 1935, the tricky current, sandbars and tides completely befuddled the brilliant scientist; A headline in The New London Day read: ''Einstein's Miscalculation Leaves Him Stuck on Bar of Lower Connecticut River.''

title: CHICAGO TAX FIGHT VICTORY FOR MAYOR
description: Mayor Harold Washington and his opponents within the Democratic Party have moved to a new level of political brinkmanship.

title: Nora S. Goodhue Connecticut Bride
description: St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nora Steed Goodhue, the daughter of Stephen V. R. Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y., and Mrs. Charles W. Smith of Wilton, Conn., to Nicholas Michael Barton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace E. Barton of Milford, Conn. The Rev. James O. Cravens performed the ceremony.

title: HASTINGS CENTER TO MOVE TO BRIARCLIFF
description: THE Hastings Center, which for 17 years has helped lead the public discussion of some of the nation's most difficult ethical issues from its home in Hastings-on-Hudson, has announced plans to move to the Briarcliff campus of Pace University. The center's staff of 25 will move into Tead Hall, a two-story white stucco building that once served as the library of the former Briarcliff College.

title: Today's Sports
description: Auto Racing Nascar Holly Farms 400 At North Wilkesboro, N.C. Television ESPN, 1 P.M. Michigan 250 At Brooklyn, Mich. Television ESPN 4 P.M. Baseball Yankees vs.

title: JUST HOW LONG IS A TRILLION SECONDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: SEASON QUICKENS AS FALL ARRIVES
description: UPCOUNTY or down, the music season in Westchester is gradually coming back to life. In Peekskill, for instance, 7:30 tonight is the time to hear Orpheus, the superb, conductorless chamber orchestra, in the first of its three concerts at the Paramount Center for the Arts. We are promised works of Schubert, Schonberg and Richard Strauss today, other delights on Dec. 14 and April 26.

title: LILCO STRUGGLE HEATS UP AGAIN
description: AFTER a brief interval of calm, the struggle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant intensified again last week.

title: DANCE SEASONS SET, DESPITE SETBACKS
description: DESPITE significant losses in dancers and artistic staff, the state's three major ballet companies are confidently planning the coming season.

title: CONVICTION UPSET IN PRISON MURDER
description: Fifteen years after a gun battle at San Quentin Prison in which three guards and three inmates died, the only person found guilty of murder in the incident has won the overturning of his conviction.

title: Heismans At Oklahoma
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RIDING DAREDEVIL BICYCLE BALLET TO FAME
description: IN the last 14 months, Eddie Fiola has performed in all 48 contiguous states. In that time, he has also shown his wares in China, Japan, England, Switzerland, West and East Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden, France, the Caribbean and Hawaii.

title: Manzanilla
description: To the Editor: The Spanish sherry manzanilla may have the reputation for not traveling well (Travel, July 13), but Emily Dickinson knew about it in her New England town of Amherst more than a hundred years ago.

title: Senate Opposes Summit Talk Before Daniloff Is Returned
description: The Senate voted tonight to urge President Reagan not to hold a summit meeting with the Russians until Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist accused by Moscow of spying, was allowed to leave the Soviet Union.

title: PRESIDENTIAL RACE OF '88 COULD BE A LOT LIKE 1960
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD HEALTH
description: THESE DAYS, THE word healthy has many implications - being in good physical condition, eating right, avoiding stress, being knowledgeable about proper medical care. Good health -feeling good - is no longer viewed as a matter of mere good luck.

title: GAPS ARE CITED IN SHOREHAM EVACUATION PLAN
description: A Long Island Lighting Company emergency evacuation plan for its Shoreham nuclear power plant does not include provisions for sheltering evacuees, Long Island officials have told the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Ex-Caddie Leading by 5
description: Mark Calcavecchia, an occasional caddie at the start of the season, shot a six-under-par 66 and took a five-shot lead today after three rounds of the $400,000 Southwest Classic.

title: DATA BANK September 28, 1986
Comings and Goings
description: IF the Louisiana State University athletic council and the school's board of supervisors give their approval to a contract proposal by the athletic director, Bob Brodhead, L.S.U.'s basketball coach, Dale Brown, will become the highest paid coach in the Southeastern Conference with a guaranteed income of $165,000. . . . Zico, the Brazilian soccer star who returned home yesterday after undergoing knee surgery in the United States, said he expected to rejoin his Flamengo team within nine months.

title: Mets Score 2 on Error in 11th, Top Pirates by 4-2
description: Nothing apparently is sacred, not even when it involves the No. 1 pitcher on the No. 1 team in the National League's Eastern Division. For the first time in his professional career, Dwight Gooden was hit by a pitch in what he firmly believed was a retaliatory gesture by Bob Kipper, Pittsburgh's starting pitcher.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RECOLLECTIONS OF THE GOLDEN TRIANGLE. By Alain Robbe-Grillet. Translated by J. A. Underwood. (Grove, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $6.95.) This latest of Alain Robbe-Grillet's works to become available in English could be read as the French New Novelist's tribute to the vibrant Latin American fiction that his own early works helped to inspire.

title: 2 RESIDENTIAL AREAS ASK HISTORIC STATUS
description: BUILT at the turn-of-the-century, Rochelle Park and Rochelle Heights in New Rochelle were among the first planned residential communities in the county. They were designed with wide streets, park-like settings and a rich variety of architectural designs.

title: 4-Bedroom Walk-Ups
description: Four-bedroom apartments are a rarity in New York. But in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, where 80 percent of the residents are Orthodox Jews and families tend to be big, five neighboring four-story walk-ups are being rebuilt into condominiums as large as four bedrooms.

title: Scoring Changes In Duplicate Play
description: The first changes in bridge scoring in almost 40 years were approved in Miami Beach this month by the World Bridge Federation's Laws Commission, subject to expected ratification by the federation's Executive Council.

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: The Bad Seed Starring Patty McCormack, Nancy Kelly, Henry Jones, Eileen Heckart; directed by Mervyn LeRoy, 1956 Warner Home Video 129 minutes. $59.95

title: Israeli Man Stabbed to Death As He Shops in Gaza Market
description: An Israeli man was stabbed to death in Gaza early today while shopping in an Arab market, the radio said.

title: Hail ot the C.E.O.
description: THE MOST PAINFUL ad of the year appeared in business pages recently, headed ''One Clarification of Motorola's Management Succession Announcement.''

title: COLD WAR ON CAMPUS
description: NO IVORY TOWER McCarthyism and the Universities. By Ellen W. Schrecker. 437 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $20.95.

title: Peggy Davison, a Teacher, Wed to David B. Stephens
description: Margaret Rae Davison, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Henry Davison of Bluff Point, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Brockman Stephens, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wade Carroll Stephens of Lawrenceville, N.J. The Rev. Richard Kesel performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the North Chapel in Keuka Park, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. Dr. H. Dana Fearon.

title: CELLIST, 16, TO OPEN SUBSCRIPTION SERIES IN BRIDGEPORT
description: WHEN she was 9 years old, Allison Eldredge of New Canaan decided she just couldn't handle the competition from all the concert pianists in her family.

title: Free University Courses Offered Farm Families
description: Starting in the winter, students whose families are financially distressed can attend classes free, on a part-time basis, at Minnesota's seven state unversities.

title: ROWLAND AND COHEN: AT ODDS ON MOST ISSUES
description: VOTERS sometimes complain that modern-day Democrats and Republicans are too much alike, and that campaigns turn on style points instead of clear differences on the issues.

title: State Bar Association Backs Ban on Tobacco Advertising
description: The New York State Bar Association voted today in favor of a national ban on all tobacco advertising.

title: A CRIME WAVE IS HAITI'S LATEST WOE
description: Michele Leconte, a 60-year-old widow, has stopped going to early-morning mass. Some days, she says, she does not venture into the streets at all.

title: NICARAGUA'S U.N. VOICE
description: SHE HADN'T BEEN EXPECTED TO AT-tend the reception, but it was her first invitation from the United States Mission to the United Nations, and as Nicaragua's chief delegate, Nora Astorga accepted. When she shook hands with her somewhat bemused American host, Vernon A. Walters, the chief United States delegate, he told her, in impeccable Spanish, how pleased he was that she had come. She complimented him on how well he spoke her native tongue.

title: Sportmanship Becomes Lendl
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STATE COMPETES WITH TORONTO AREA FOR CANADIAN MALL PROJECT
description: New York State, seeking to bring new life to this honeymoon capital fallen on hard times, has offered a Canadian developer $400 million in economic incentives to build a vast entertainment and retail complex within sight of the famous falls.

title: SO, WAS IT REALLY BOBBY?
description: In case you didn't tune in, it was all a just a bad dream.

title: Reagan Tells Federal Workers To Use Seat Belts on the Job
description: President Reagan has ordered all Federal employees and military personnel to wear seat belts while driving on official business.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S not every day that you go to the movies and start out by taking a walking tour of Post Avenue in Westbury.

title: Creating Marketplace Images
description: WHEN it comes to imprecise science, naming a new car is right up there on the Olympus of inexactitude.

title: A Natural Buy
description: Henry Ford can say, ''Yes, my company built that car,'' and Donald Trump can say, ''Sure, that's my tower.''

title: Lisa Ann Rosenberg Is Bride of Dr. D.W. Meade
description: Lisa Ann Rosenberg, a daughter of Mrs. Robert L. Beir of New York and Elberon, N.J., and the late Henry C. Rosenberg, was married in New York last night to Dr. Dennis W. Meade, a son of Justice and Mrs. Robert C. Meade of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Charles B. Lippman and the Rev. Russell Abata, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Harmonie Club.

title: Prospect Lefferts Gardens
description: HIDDEN away in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn is a tightly knit and ethnically diverse neighborhood known as Prospect Lefferts Gardens, which has been described by the Landmarks Preservation Commission as ''one of the finest enclaves of 19th and early 20th century housing in New York City.''

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: Reading Rainbow: 'Arthur's Eyes' Children's Video Library 30 minutes. $14.95

title: THE MAN WHO SHAPES UP THE ARMY
description: ON THE SAME BUCOLIC CAM-pus in Carlisle, Pa., where Jim Thorpe once eluded opposing tacklers, middle-aged men today jog peacefully over hill and across stream. Then it was the Carlisle Indian School. Now it is the Army War College, where each year some 250 carefully selected senior officers take a leave from military duties to engage in study. These officers also work out, under the direction of Col. Frederick R. Drews, head of the Army's Physical Fitness Research Institute. Colonel Drews, 56 years old, has the look of a military man - with his trim torso, erect posture and close-cropped hair - but does not always think like one. In the five years since he was summoned from academia to overhaul the Army's fitness procedures and policies, he has often clashed with the standard grit-your-teeth military conditioning theories of yore.

title: NURSE ARRESTED IN CALIFORNIA HOSPITAL DEATH
description: A private nurse who cared for an AIDS patient who died Wednesday has been arrested on murder and other charges, with the authorities saying that he had posed as a physician and ordered insulin injections for the patient.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: CHANGES AT U.S. NETWORK STIR CONCERN ABOUT NEWS IN SPANISH
description: Changes at the Spanish International Network are arousing concern, among its news staff and in Hispanic quarters in general, that the Mexican Government is increasing its influence on the 17 million Spanish-speaking television viewers in the United States.

title: A School That Trains The Public's Lawyers
description: IN 1982, when Charles R. Halpern was named founding dean of the City University Law School at Queens College, critics said the metropolitan area, which already had more than a dozen law schools, was hardly in need of more lawyers. Others expressed skepticism about a school established expressly to train lawyers for public service. Now the school has not only held its first graduation, but also gained national recognition, winning praise from Warren E. Burger, when he was Chief Justice, for its innovative curriculum. Mr. Halpern, who had previously taught law at Stanford and Georgetown universities, recently started his last year as dean, having announced plans to write a book about his experience and to resume teaching. He recently discussed the shaping of the law school with Samuel Weiss, an editor at The New York Times News Service. Excerpts follow.

title: CHALLENGING THE ANNUAL PHYSICAL
description: THE ANNUAL PHYSICAL, an American medical tradition since the turn of the century, has become the focus of a continuing controversy. A growing number of experts say that annual physicals are often useless and can even be harmful. ''It may be an unnecessary expenditure of resources and provide false assurance to patients,'' said Dr. Robert S. Lawrence, chairman of the United States Preventive Services Task Force, a federally-appointed group that will soon release official recommendations on yearly examinations. The task force will propose that annual physical examinations be banished in favor of periodic health assessments.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN OLD STANDBY IN THE IRONBOUND
description: ROBUST portions of shrimp with garlic, colorful paella and the shellfish stew called mariscada are mainstays at just about every Spanish-Portuguese restaurant in the Ironbound, Newark's Portuguese area. In fact, the moderately priced menus of the score or so of establishments that dot the square-mile neighborhood are practically interchangeable.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide (section 2A) name an incorrect theater for the opening of ''Menage'' on Friday. It will be at Cinema Studio I, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: A Too-Familiar Face
description: It isn't exactly against the law to look like Woody Allen, but Phil Boroff, an actor, found that his resemblance to the comedian could become a matter for lawyers and courts under certain circumstances. Two years ago, after Mr. Boroff's Allen-like face was used in an ad for a chain of video stores, Mr. Allen sued his look-alike; the actor's agent, Ron Smith's Celebrity Look Alikes, and National Video Inc. Mr. Allen's lawyers contended that the defendants had caused him ''irreparable harm'' in ''usurping'' his right to control his name.

title: Mary Catherine Vespa Weds James Hillard Cole
description: Mary Catherine Vespa, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Vespa of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to James Hillard Cole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Cole of Newton Center, Mass. Justice Beatrice S. Burstein of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Players Club in New York.

title: Dance
description: Balasaraswati was one of India's greatest dancers, and she was one of the great dancers of the world. A well-known fellow artist, who paid homage to this venerated exponent of Indian classical dance before she died in February 1984, has been the director Satyajit Ray in his film ''Bala.''

title: 'That's Life!' Has Fun With Mortality
description: In John Updike's new novel, ''Roger's Version,'' a fiftyish theologian gives his nubile young niece a lecture on William Cullen Bryant's poem ''Thanatopsis,'' the title of which means ''view of death.'' ''He wrote this when he was younger than you,'' he tells her, discussing the poem's morbid imagery. ''Bryant was so young, you see, he could say it; an older poet's hand would have frozen with terror trying to write those lines.''

title: MERRILL LYNCH'S LONDON BLITZ
description: For the American brokerage giant Merrill Lynch & Company, the Big Bang has meant recruiting a large team for the assault on the British stock and government-bond markets.

title: Miss McKendry Is Wed in Wilton To R.S. Anderson
description: Elizabeth Phillips McKendry, a daughter of Elizabeth Phillips of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and George McKendry of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Sanford Anderson, a son of Senator Warren M. Anderson, majority leader of the New York State Senate, and Mrs. Anderson of Binghamton. The Rev. Carl Becker performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Wilton.

title: 7 Filipinos Are Named For Fellowships in U.S.
description: Seven leaders in the public and private sector of Philippine society are beginning an eight-week tour of the United States today as Eisenhower Fellows based in Philadelphia.

title: TALKING HEADS ALBUM STIRS FEET, NOT BRAIN
description: Dance parties have already discovered ''True Stories'' by the Talking Heads (Sire LP 25512-1, cassette 25512-4, CD 25512-2), an album that couldn't be more crisp or playful or benevolent. Opening with a laugh from David Byrne, the band's singer and songwriter, the album kicks and chugs through nine songs; half a dozen of them are danceable, just the thing to put the Talking Heads back on Top 40 playlists. But for all its spunk and momentum, ''True Stories'' is also a major letdown. Among the nine Talking Heads albums, plus the three David Byrne projects outside the band, ''True Stories'' is by far the shallowest set of songs.

title: Miss Terminelle Weds
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York yesterday Christina Marie Terminelle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Thomas Terminelle of New York and New Fairfield, Conn., was married to Paul Thomas Harley, the son of Barbara Harley of Matunuck Beach, R.I., and Indian Harbour Beach, Fla., and the late Col. George E. Harley Jr., U.S.A., retired. The Rev. John B. Clermont performed the ceremony.

title: Should Pro Contracts Include Drug-Test Clauses?
description: Clauses that call for indiscriminate drug testing should not be in sports contracts for several reasons. First, indiscriminate drug testing violates the presumption of innocence by assuming that everyone is guilty of illegal drug use unless proven otherwise. Second, the drug-testing procedure represents a significant invasion of privacy. Third, the most commonly administered drug test is inherently unreliable. Moreover, it cannot measure impairment of someone's ability to function on the job.

title: CRIME
description: We have had from Stephen Dobyns ''Saratoga Headhunter,'' ''Saratoga Swimmer'' and ''Saratoga Longshot.'' Now comes SARATOGA SNAPPER (Viking, $15.95), and the book continues the adventures of Charlie Bradshaw. Not that Bradshaw is on the lookout for adventure. He wants nothing more than to be left alone. He is not big, strong or in any way a hero. In fact, he is unambitious and something of a slob.

title: A Storm Over Bias
description: One thing the Japanese Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, did not clarify last week was whether it is customary for a Japanese politician to remove his shoes before putting his foot in his mouth. Mr. Nakasone raised a storm of criticism in the United States when he was quoted in Tokyo newspapers as saying that America lagged behind Japan because the presence of ''a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans'' meant ''the level is lower.'' The press first said Mr. Nakasone had been referring to America's intellectual level, and the Black and Hispanic Congresssional Caucuses, among others, took no small umbrage.

title: WHAT STRANGERS? WHAT GATES?
description: ARAB AND JEW Wounded Spirits in a Promised Land. By David K. Shipler. 596 pp. New York: Times Books. $22.50.

title: A PLAN FOR BROOKLYN RISES AT ATLANTIC TERMINAL
description: A complex of office towers, stores and condominiums will rise on the site of the Long Island Rail Road's old Atlantic Terminal, a dusty, largely vacant piece of downtown Brooklyn, if the Board of Estimate approves next week.

title: 2 BISHOPS WEIGH VATICAN TRIP ON TURMOIL IN WEST
description: Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen and the Auxiliary Bishop assigned to take over many of his duties said Friday that they were willing to go to Rome to tell the Vatican that church members were upset at having two leaders.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT GROUP HOMES FOR THE RETARDED
description: MANY people object to having group homes for mentally retarded adults in their community. But I believe the real reason people have misgivings is that they don't know what kind of people live there, or what to expect from them.

title: The New Allure of Tahitian Vanilla
description: NO FLAVOR IS MORE ROMANTIC THAN THAT OF vanilla - sweet, floral, intoxicating, poetically right for the fruit of a tropical orchid whose pale primrose-colored flowers must be hand-pollinated within a few hours of their opening. Fittingly, few stories are more romantic than that of the meteoric rise of Tahitian vanilla, a botanically distinct variant that is both more delicate and more fragrant than the far more common vanilla from Madagascar.

title: VIRUSES: STILL A MYSTERY AFTER ALL THESE YEARS
description: AFTER EXAMINING A PATIENT, THE DOC-tor makes a diagnosis, a common one: ''You've got a virus - the bug that's going around.'' The advice is just as familiar: ''Rest and drink plenty of liquids. You'll feel like yourself in no time.''

title: Miss Fairchild Becomes Bride
description: The Episcopal Church of the Ascension in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jill Fairchild, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Burr Fairchild of New York, and Klosters, Switzerland, to Peter Allan Buhl Melhado, a son of Frederick A. Melhado and Mrs. William H. Mann, both of New York. The Rev. Donald R. Goodness performed the ceremony.

title: Yale Loses, 17-12, To Connecticut
description: Connecticut scored touchdowns on its first two possessions today and went on to beat Yale, 17-12, in a nonconference game before 25,175 fans at the Yale Bowl.

title: Bernstein Triumphant
description: I guess you might say it all started when I read his biography in the eighth grade. I began sitting a little straighter at my piano, as if the Maestro were watching me practice.

title: NEW MANAGEMENT IN SOUTHAMPTON
description: THE precipitous decline that began affecting the venerable Herb McCarthy's Bowden Square in Southampton a decade or so ago has been arrested, and not a moment too soon.

title: Malta, Where Suleiman Laid Siege
description: At sundown, Maltese flock to the town square. They gaze at their church, decorated with strands of multicolored light bulbs. They sing the folk songs played by local musicians who stroll through the square and down the narrow streets. Young women in sundresses push strollers; their husbands buy ice cream and kinnie, a cold, bittersweet Maltese drink. Teen-agers hold hands, discreetly, in a corner of the square. Children wave town flags while young boys lock arms and twirl round and round to the music until they become dizzy.

title: SQUARELY FACING THE CAMERA
description: AUGUST SANDER: CITIZENS OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY Portrait Photographs 1892-1952. Edited by Gunther Sander. Text by Ulrich Keller. Translated by Linda Keller. Illustrated. 431 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $55.

title: SOUTH JERSEY IS GOING TO SOHO
description: THE first auction for the benefit of the Creative Glass Center of America in Millville will take place next Sunday at the Heller Gallery in New York City's SoHo.

title: AMID DEBATE ON SANCTIONS, A DISASTER IS DIVISIVE
description: ELSEWHERE, a mining accident might unite a nation in grief. Here, the impact of great loss seems only to deepen division and hatred. The death of 172 blacks and 5 whites Sept. 16 in the worst mining disaster in the century since gold was discovered in South Africa was transformed last week into one more sad depiction of a polarized land. At a memorial service 70 miles east of Johannesburg, some blacks characterized the causes of the catastrophe as white greed for wealth and power; no whites attended the memorial service organized by a black labor union in a segregated township. Earlier, militant black mine workers, saying they would not pray alongside whites, disrupted a service organized by the mine owners.

title:
ART;
30 YEARS OF WINSLOW HOMER ON VIEW AT YALE
description: ALL the necessary rationale for seeing the exhibition of watercolors by Winslow Homer at the Yale Art Gallery in New Haven is contained in the opening sentence of the exhibition's catalogue: ''Winslow Homer's watercolors have, almost from the time they were made, been ranked among the greatest achievements in American art.''

title: THE HAVES CAN HELP THE HAVE-NOTS
description: When world finance ministers gathered in recent years for the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, there was much anticipation of the strong measures they might adopt to straighten out growing financial and development problems involving both the industrialized and the poor countries. But these meetings, held at various locations around the globe, were usually distinguished by little more than partying and perorations.

title: MERTENS FESTIVAL TO HONOR LEONARD BERNSTEIN
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN will become the 16th American composer to be honored at the Andre and Clara Mertens Contemporary Composers Festival when the festival is held at the University of Bridgeport Oct. 6, 7 and 8.

title: FOR MUNICIPALITIES, A ONE-TIME-ONLY WINDFALL
description: IN New Haven, some of the funds are to pay for shelter for the homeless. In Cheshire, roads are to be resurfaced.

title: Exporting The Homeless - Temporarily
description: It would seem that Newark has enough troubles of its own, but last week New York City's Human Resources Administration announced that homeless families were overflowing city facilities to such an extent that 20 of them were being sent to a Newark motel.

title: OF LITCHFIELD, RAGGIES AND THE GAS PIPELINE
description: I tremble as I take pen in hand to question the essay by renowned Taconic correspondent Harrison E. Salisbury on Aug. 31 (''In Litchfield, No Change and No Pipeline'').

title: U.S. WEIGHING WIDER DRUG TESTS FOR AIRLINES' OPERATIONAL WORKERS
description: The Department of Transportation, increasingly concerned about drug abuse in aviation, is quietly exploring ways to expand the drug testing of airline employees who are involved in flight operations.

title: AMERICA'S PROFILE SHIFTS
description: AT THE TIME of the 1980 census, the center of population in the United States was in a forest a mile west of the small town of De Soto, Mo., and 40 miles southwest of the Gateway Arch in downtown St. Louis.

title: FAMILY AND ETHICS ARE BYWORDS IN '86 RACES
description: Candidates around the country and national strategists of both parties, appealing to the personal concerns of voters this fall, are putting a greater stress on moral issues and family values.

title: 'APPLE DAY' SET IN PRINCETON
description: WHAT started as a family reunion 10 years ago at Gary and Pam Mount's apple farm has grown into a festive two-day homage to the fruit.

title: COURT RULES AGAINST HOSPITAL ON WHITE PLAINS DEVELOPMENT
description: NEW YORK HOSPITAL lost its appeal last week in its suit against the White Plains Common Council, which had refused to consider its proposal for a $500 million development with Robert Martin Company on hospital land.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in the Food column in the Aug. 31 issue of the magazine omitted dill from the list of ingredients for salmon steaks. The recipe calls for four or five sprigs of fresh dill, finely chopped, about two tablespoonfuls, as a garnish for the cooked salmon.

title: Carol Ann Phethean Wed to Peter Samuel Yawitz
description: Carol Ann Phethean, who will become an associate Oct. 20 in the New York office of Dorsey & Whitney, a Minneapolis-based law firm, and Peter Samuel Yawitz, an associate at Jones Lang Wootton realty advisers in New York, were married yesterday at the Lords Valley (Pa.) Country Club.

title: VYING FOR POLITICAL HAY IN A DEPRESSED HEARTLAND
description: MILTON NOWKA, a corn and soybean farmer in Trumbull, Neb., has taken a beating in the last four years, but he is not sure where to place the blame. On the one hand, the strong dollar during the Reagan years helped devastate grain exports and prices. But high inflation during the Carter years led to high interest rates, which still plague Mr. Nowka as he seeks to repay his farm debts.

title: Newport Bandits Sought
description: Patricia and Philip Archer Thomas, the owners of Malbone, an 18th-century mansion ransacked by armed bandits, have posted a $5,000 reward for information leading to their arrest. The bandits invaded the mansion this week, overpowered the caretaker and took an undetermined amount of valuables from the Gothic Revival-style building. The Thomases, who bought Malbone from the Newport Preservation Society in 1980, were in Europe at the time, the police said.

title: BIG INCREASE EXPECTED IN RADON POLLUTION SUITS
description: Not long after Dr. Joel Nobel and his family moved into their striking new home in the forested hills of the Main Line Philadelphia suburb of Gladwyne, they undertook a screening of the house to find out whether its air was free of such contaminants as formaldehyde.

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: New Wave Comedy Produced and directed by Mitchell Kreigman, 1985 Vestron Video 60 minutes. $59.95

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'GILDED AGE' ON STAGE John Houseman's Acting Company of New York is collaborating on a production for the first time. The Hartford Stage Company will provide the facilities and the director, Mark Lamos, while the cast will be supplied by the Acting Company.

title: Counting Lunt and Fontanne
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT ARE DAKOTA AND MONTANA DOING IN NEW YORK?
description: THE new apartments may be much alike, with little to distinguish one from another except the color of the marble in the bathrooms. But the one sure way a developer can separate his new building from the crowd of others now rising in Manhattan is to give it a distinctive name. That is an old game in New York, and each new wave of luxury construction in Manhattan seems to tax the vocabulary of apartment-marketers even more than the last.

title: ARGENTINA AGONIZES OVER 'DIRTY WAR' TRIALS
description: THE agony that was called the ''dirty war'' intruded again into the Argentine conscience last week. In a wood-paneled courtroom, six civilian judges began the trial of Ramon Camps, a retired Army general and former Buenos Aires metropolitan police chief, and six others.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LOS ANGELES;
Scaling Back After the Bust
description: AT the height of the luxury condominium craze that swept Westwood a few years ago, an ambitious developer began erecting what was to be a 31-story tower in the so-called ''condo corridor'' along Wilshire Boulevard, with units at prices ranging from $900,000 to well into the millions.

title: LATE WORD ON THE LIFE AND TIMES OF THE CAST OF THE ORIGINAL 'NICKLEBY'
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' has done many things in its six-year history. It has shown that a play can be as long as it needs to be, it has loosened up the British theater - and it has set several careers going in new directions. Talk to actors from the original, 42-member-strong New York company of 1981-82 and you discover a lot about the power of ''Nickleby'' to act as a personal launching pad.

title: American Bishop Offers the Vatican Some Advice
description: The Catholic Herald of Milwaukee was perhaps not the most conspicuous forum, and Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland's columns did not name names, but his message was pointed. The Archbishop, known as a liberal and a scholar, said the Vatican's pursuit of orthodoxy in the American church must not engender ''fanaticism and small-mindedness.''

title: A WORD ABOUT BOOKS, READERS, LIBRARIES
description: John Weiner certainly must have had a terrible experience to state that ''libraries are just a pain in the neck,'' and going to one was ''a humiliating experience,'' [ ''Helping the Homeless,'' Westchester Journal, Aug. 24 ] . I cannot quarrel with the motivation behind his book tables; collecting money for the homeless is important, and his idea a novel one (no pun intended).

title: Out of the Past Comes Vital Novelty
description: Officially, the new dance season has already begun. Unofficially, the season has been ambling in. Dancers and their managers were kind enough to give audiences, and especially critics, a breather by slowing down in August. Dance Theater Workshop, the Joyce, Riverside Dance Festival and Danspace are already presenting their annual series, but the full-scale dance onslaught is still to come. Taking advantage of what is only an illusory respite, one might want to consider some thoughts on the shape of seasons in general and the inclusion of revivals in particular.

title: Literacy: Stuck On the Basics
description: Nearly all young adults in the United States can read, according to a report on literacy issued last week, but very few can read very well, and four out of five cannot make sense of a bus schedule or fill out a catalogue order form correctly.

title: UP THE COAST TO WILDERNESS
description: The Point of Kings. La Punta de los Reyes. Named in 1603 by a Spanish sailor once shipwrecked there, Point Reyes rises from the Pacific plate along the San Andreas fault, about 40 miles north of San Francisco. But for the foibles of plate tectonics, the Point Reyes peninsula might well be a suburb of Los Angeles, much as that thought distresses northern Californians. Over perhaps 30 million years, the Point has made its way north along the fault, and still moves north as much as two inches a year.

title: Clinton Runner Is First at Meet
description: The Public Schools Athletic League opened its cross-country season yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx with its annual Group Run.

title: On Culbertson
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 HOMELESS CITY FAMILIES REMAIN IN NEWARK
description: Twenty homeless families continued to stay at a Newark motel last night after officials were unable to find shelter for them in New York City.

title: A FRIENDSHIP WITH REAGAN DRAWS CLOSE TO DISCOMFORT
description: A RECENT political cartoon depicted President Reagan teaching an infant Brian Mulroney to walk by holding his hands and chanting, ''Onesy. . . twosey. . . threesey. . . .'' The cartoon, in The Globe and Mail of Toronto, lampooned a Vancouver speech in which Prime Minister Mulroney had promised significant legislation on narcotics, child abuse and tax reform by the end of his Progressive Conservative Government's term. His critics promptly accused Mr. Mulroney of parroting President Reagan.

title: A NEW LIFE STYLE IN A NEW HOMETOWN
description: AFTER 16 moves to seven states in 22 years, this summer I moved to Connecticut.

title: Safety Group Finds Task is Tougher These Days
description: A few months ago, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration began investigating motorists' reports of erratic acceleration in Nissan automobiles but did not publicize it, news of the investigation was announced by a private consumer action group here.

title: Pitt's Long Passes Rout West Virginia
description: John Congemi threw for three touchdowns, including a 66-yarder to Bill Osborn, and Osborn passed for another on a halfback-option play as Pitt routed rival West Virginia, 48-16, today.

title:
