SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
HERO? RARELY: BUDDY? WELL...HOW ABOUT EXPENSIVE PEST?
description: THE little kid from down the block came over with his new puppy and set it in my lap for me to admire. Thirty seconds later, my striped pants also had spots.

title: A DEADLY REMINDER TO CYCLISTS
description: IT happened again. Someone died on a motorcycle. The accident was just down the road - less than a mile away.

title: AT HOME ON THE RIVER, AT SEA OVER ISSUES
description: WHILE boating enthusiasts across the Northeast are preparing their crafts for storage, a handful along the Hudson River near Indian Point are preparing instead for another winter on the river.

title: Flowers and Foliage Accent The Sturdy Kalanchoes
description: Kalanchoes provide the best of all worlds. They are succulent. They tolerate dry indoor conditions. They are incredibly endurant if there is an occasional lapse of attention with the watering pot - as long as you do not make a habit of neglecting their thirst. But soggy roots are to be avoided.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last week, about the new production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the Metropolitan Opera, described the Met's previous ''Ring'' incorrectly. All four operas were produced, and three complete cycles were presented in 1975.

title: GIVING THE CONCRETE CITY A SOFTER EDGE
description: ''THE city is a tough place,''

title: On When a Child Stays Home From Camp
description: I was surprised when reading the first paragraph of Ms. [ Anne F. ] Glauber's article [ ''Experience Is Rich When a Child Stays Home From Camp,'' Opinion Page, Aug. 24 ] . It seems to me if this is the first summer her 4-year-old daughter did not go to day camp, the child must have started at less than 2 years of age! Perhaps I am old fashioned, but sending children under 4 years of age to a full-day camp program after probably attending nursery school all year could cause serious problems later on in the child's life.

title: Staten Island's Surge in Building
description: NORTH from central Staten Island's major growth area of New Springville, the path of residential development has swept through the barren fields of Bull's Head and Graniteville in the last two years. Small, low-overhead home builders are in action, providing low-rise housing to meet a vigorous demand.

title: Injuries Are Complex, So Are Solutions
description: ''FOOTBALL is getting too dangerous and we'd better do something about it!'' That is the cry raised every time more than three prominent professional players are simultaneously injured. The facts are that a good deal has been done to make football less dangerous. As a result, it has become progressively safer during the past 20 years.

title: Marcelline Thomson Wed to David Duffy
description: The marriage of Marcelline Eugenie Thomson and David Livingstone Duffy took place yesterday at the New York home of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Philip T. Zabriskie, where Dr. Zabriskie performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
LEARNING FROM ENGLISH COUNTRY ESTATES
description: ENGLAND has long been called ''the mother of gardens.'' Many of the plants we accept as commonplace had their origin in England.

title: Jazz
description: The saxophonist-clarinetist-flutist Eric Dolphy died in 1964, when his fleet, angular, deliberately dissonant music was still under-appreciated. His close associate, the trumpet player Booker Little, died in 1961 at the age of 23.

title: S.I. AND ITS FERRY STAR IN A NEW FILM
description: THE Staten Island ferry, which New York City's Department of Cultural Affairs already considers a source of borough pride, has became a floating entertainment center for commuters and tourists.

title: AND OFFERING LUXURIES, TOO
description: IN AN effort to fill their beds, more and more hospitals not only are advertising, but also are turning to other marketing techniques, including some borrowed from hotels and airlines.

title: In a Quest for Human Speed, the Lab Has Two Wheels
description: TO reach 65 miles an hour, a bicycle rider has to pass through five varieties of breeze and four varieties of gale and enter what wind experts officially call ''storm.'' Little wonder, then, that the future of cycling is converging with the future of aerodynamics.

title: Miss Parker Has Wedding
description: Nancy Gray Parker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Parker of Bedminster, N.J., and Portsmouth, R.I., was married yesterday to William Fisher Wilson, a son of Mrs. Robert P. Wilson of Woburn, Mass., and the late Colonel Wilson, U.S.A., retired. The Rev. Gordon Stenning performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Portsmouth.

title: DO UNTO OTHERS -- AND DO IT FIRST
description: HENRY FLAGLER The Astonishing Life and Times of the Visionary Robber Baron Who Founded Florida. By David Leon Chandler. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $22.50.

title: ...TAKING THE 7:40 TO UNREALITY
description: THE music was playing on the radio - something classical, I think -and it awakened me with not so much a start as a gentle nudge. I shook my head to get the blood circulating to my brain and arose from what seemed like the longest slumber of my life.

title: TIME TAKES A TOLL ON 'SOUTH PACIFIC'
description: ''SOUTH PACIFIC'' must be the ultimate romantic musical. Go to the Darien Dinner Theater for reaffirmation, but be forewarned: You may be in for a disenchanted evening.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SANTA MARIA DEL MONTE: The Presence of the Past in a Spanish Village. By Ruth Behar (Princeton University, $30.) Ruth Behar, assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Michigan, notes that many students of rural life and culture have either relegated the past to a promptly forgotten introductory chapter or reduced it to a static body of ''timeless'' usages, little more than quaint anachronisms.

title: Lisa Barlow Wed To Alan Towbin
description: Elizabeth Ewing Barlow, the daughter of Elizabeth Barlow Rogers and Edward L. Barlow, both of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Alan Lamar Towbin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Towbin of Scarborough, N.Y. The Rev. Fred Davie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at Mr. Barlow's home in East Hampton.

title: Holdout Backfires
description: HE is in the option year of a contract that would pay him a reported $165,000 this season, but the way Brad McCrimmon, a Philadelphia Flyers defenseman sees it, that isn't enough for a seven-year veteran who played in all 80 games last season. In an attempt to force the Flyers to renegotiate the contract and put his salary on a par with those of his ''peers'' in the league, the 27-year-old hockey player refused to play in preseason games after appearing in the exhibition opener against the Islanders.

title: WELCOME TO THE AGE OF GREED
description: LIFESTYLE By Peter Warner. 215 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: EAST HARLEM GIRL SLAIN ON WAY TO VISIT FATHER
description: A 14-year-old girl who managed to reach her father's East Harlem apartment early yesterday after having been attacked and stabbed on her way there, died on his living room floor, the police said.

title: Miss Paddon Is Bride Of W. R. Petricone Jr.
description: The marriage of Katherine French Paddon, a daughter of Richard Paddon of Berkeley Heights, N.J., and the late Lydia Babbott Paddon, to William Richard Petricone Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Petricone of Torrington, Conn., took place yesterday in Bernardsville, N.J. Canon Charles Shreve, the bride's godfather, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain, assisted by the Rev. Alfred Niese.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MEMOIRS OF THE LATE MR. ASHLEY: An American Comedy. By Marianne Hauser. (Sun and Moon, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $11.95.) The initial joke in this darkly satiric chronicle of a modern marriage and its alternatives is that the narrator, Drew Ashley, begins his memoirs only after he has died.

title: Elizabeth Uhl Is Wed To Stephen A. Kowal
description: The Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Ross Uhl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Uhl of Pelham Manor, to Stephen Alexander Kowal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kowal also of Pelham Manor. The Rev. Don G. Morse, assisted by the Rev. Susan P. Trucksess, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Inherited Traditions
description: UNLIKE THE VIEWS FROM MOST CITY apartments, those facing Gramercy Park are just as they were around the turn of the century.

title: BRINGING LIFE TO THE GAGS OF YESTERYEAR
description: A long time ago - a very long time ago - I was one of the collaborators on a Broadway musical starring Charles Butterworth. You may not recall Mr. Butterworth today, but he became fairly famous after delivering Robert Benchley's comic monologue, ''The Treasurer's Report,'' in some revue or other. After that, he spent time chasing Jeanette MacDonald - to no avail -through films starring Maurice Chevalier. He looked like the accumulated drip on a melted wax candle. He was the accumulated drip on a melted wax candle.

title: EARLY AMERICANA IN HARTFORD
description: THE annual Connecticut Antiques Show returns to the State Armory in Hartford for three days starting Friday, with a vast display of Americana offered by 88 dealers from 15 states.

title: A BITTERSWEET FINALE FOR GIMBELS
description: Everyone, it is said, loves a sale. So when a store slashes its prices 40, 60 and, in some cases, 80 percent, one could expect to see a lot of euphoric faces rummaging through the racks.

title: McEnroe Rolls
description: JOHN McENROE, bidding for a second straight tournament title, defeated the defending champion, Stefan Edberg, 7-6, 6-2, last night as he advanced to a showdown in today's final with Jimmy Connors in the Transamerica Open tournament in San Francisco. Connors, seeded second, won the other semifinal when Anders Jarryd retired in the third set with a knee injury.

title: New Cassettes: A 50's Thriller, New Wave Humor
description: The Mothership Connection Live From Houston Featuring Parliament-Funkadelic, with George Clinton Sony Video 30 minutes. $19.95

title:
DINING OUT;
EXPERIMENTATION IN CHAPPEQUA
description: WITH its timely name, Cafe Liberte (erstwhile The Ordinary) made its bow earlier this year, appropriately in time for New York's special July 4 birthday celebration. Represented wittily on the cover of the menu, Liberty's arm holds, instead of a torch, a whisk. But the associations with the name go further than that. Menu notes suggest that the restaurant's new name respresents the liberties this extremely personal kitchen takes with both French and American cuisine. Results are not always harmonious. Innovation is welcome only when it works.

title: Valenzuela Loses, 8-3
description: Bob Melvin and Chili Davis hit home runs for the San Francisco Giants, backing Vida Blue to his first victory since Aug. 12, an 8-3 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers and Fernando Valenzuela.

title: Mr. Wilson, Say Hello to Richard Wagner
description: I am addicted. I freely admit it, though with a sense of shame at my weakness. Much as I would like to overcome the habit, I cannot resist devouring those interviews in which celebrated theater directors who find themselves mysteriously drawn to opera try to explain why. I cherish, for instance, and preserve in my files an analytical colloquy with Andrei Serban, who was then wrestling with what might seem to the casual observer an insurmountable problem: before taking up the challenge of directing opera he had rarely seen an opera and, to tell the truth, hated the stuff. Mr. Serban overcame his esthetic scruples, however, and staged, as New York City Opera devotees know, a bizarrely anti-Handelian ''Alcina'' and a ''Norma'' that bent Bellini's romantic triangle into the shape of a pretzel.

title: GETTING IT STRAIGHT
description: The last two Presidents have been former governors, which is worth remembering now that former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware has become the first honest man in the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: DARIEN GETS 'SOUTH PACIFIC' HALF RIGHT
description: ''SOUTH PACIFIC'' must be the ultimate romantic musical. Go to the Darien Dinner Theater for reaffirmation, but be forewarned: You may be in for a disenchanted evening.

title: Senate, 74-23, Votes Tax Bill; Widest Revisions in 40 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27  Ending one of the most tortuous legislative odysseys in years, the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to the most comprehensive changes in the Federal income tax system since World War II.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC GAMES;
AN OLD STANDBY IS BACK IN PLAY
description: ''I DON'T like video,'' said Jon Martel, 15, as he leaned and jabbed at the flippers on a glossy pinball machine at the Broadway Arcade. ''With pinball you can work the machine, you have more control.''

title: FLOODS CONTINUE TO IMPERIL TOWNS IN MONTANA
description: Floodwaters that killed one person and hundreds of head of livestock rolled eastward in the Milk River Valley today as residents of this tiny farming town braced for the river's flood crest.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HEAR US O LORD FROM HEAVEN THY DWELLING PLACE, by Malcolm Lowry. (Carroll & Graf, $9.95). First published four years after Malcolm Lowry's death, this collection includes stories that are ''enormously funny,'' as well as ''two absolutely first-class pieces of work,'' Elizabeth Janeway said in The Book Review in 1961. She called one of them, ''Through the Panama,'' a ''tour de force of violence'' and the other, ''The Forest Path to the Spring,'' a ''true version of Paradise, as real as the hell he also knew.'' The same publisher has reissued Lowry's novel ULTRAMARINE ($7.95), the story of a Liverpool youth who ships out as a messboy on a freighter bound for the Orient. In 1962 our reviewer, Ernest Buckler, found the work, originally published 30 years earlier, ''still as green and vivid as the sea itself.'' PHILIPPE HALSMAN'S JUMP BOOK. (Abrams, $12.95.) The photographer Philippe Halsman first asked a subject to jump for him in 1953, and over the next five years he asked most of his illustrious subjects to jump before their sittings, finding that it relaxed them and that the ''jump'' photos were often more revealing than the formal portraits. The ''Jump Book,'' first published in 1959, includes text by the author and 191 gravity-defying photos of stage and screen stars, politicians, Nobel laureates and royalty. Gene Thornton said in The Times last spring that jumping ''added a bit of humanness to celebrityhood without upsetting the fundamental idea that celebrities were a breed apart.''

title: COURT BACKS RULING TO SUPPRESS TAPES IN DEVELOPER'S DEATH
description: A millionaire who was slain violated the state's wiretap law when he secretly recorded conversations between his wife and her young lover, making the tapes inadmissible in court, a Superior Court panel has ruled.

title: LOVERS, ENEMIES AND OTHER DEDICATEES
description: WRITING a book is often sheer pain and drudgery, but writing the dedication is a moment most authors savor, a chance to pay back old debts, even the score or give one's spouse (or former spouse) a reward for putting up with all those nights of writers' angst. Dedications are sometimes as original, humorous and witty as the books they precede. And a few are as banal.

title: Officers Suspended In City Drug Case
description: New York City's latest disappointment in itself began quietly gestating in 1985, when the Police Department's Internal Affairs Division set a criminal to catch some policemen. The case exploded into headlines last week with the suspension of 13 Brooklyn police officers charged with extorting money and drugs from narcotics dealers.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Drift of the Dollar Has the dollar's 36 percent decline since early 1985 been enough? The debate between Fed Chairman Paul A. Volcker (Yes) and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d (No, unless America's trading partners spur their growth) may be a hollow one. A weaker dollar may be inevitable, says Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Court Upholds X-Ray Search Of Passenger Bags by Airline
description: Once airline passengers place their hand luggage on an X-ray conveyor belt for inspection they have given their implied consent to a hand search of their bags, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: 22 at Airline Indicted by U.S.
description: What with the year's labor disputes and its near bankruptcy, Eastern Airlines is one of those carriers that does not need more trouble. And last week it took the position that it had rid itself of some.

title: N.C. State Surprises Maryland
description: Erik Kramer passed for two touchdowns and ran for another, and Mal Crite scored twice as North Carolina State, with 21 fourth-quarter points, upset Maryland, 28-16, tonight. That ended Maryland's 17-game Atlantic Coast Conference winning streak.

title: SUPPORT GROUPS FILL EMOTIONAL GAPS
description: DONNA OETTINGER was only 8 years old when dark, ugly lesions began to cover her body, but it was not until she was 17 that she learned she had neurofibromatosis, or Elephant Man's disease, a hereditary disorder that produces benign tumors and growths on and beneath the skin. (The Elephant Man was Joseph Merrick, a hideously disfigured 19th-century Englishman who was exhibited at carnivals and freak shows.) ''I felt like a freak,'' recalled the 34-year-old Miss Oettinger, a New Milford medical assistant who has undergone 13 operations in the last 15 years. ''Kids at school made fun of me. No one I knew had anything remotely related to what I had, and I could find very little in the medical literature.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ASHEVILLE, N.C.;
A Pei Tower Is Revived
description: FIVE years ago, when the New York architect I. M. Pei completed his modest glass office tower here in the Blue Ridge Mountains, he did not expect it to become a monument. But neither did he expect it to sit vacant.

title:
ART;
'12 IN FOCUS': OUT OF THE DARKROOM, INTO THE GALLERY
description: ANYONE who still needs to be convinced that photography warrants a full measure of attention as an art form would do well to see ''12 in Focus,'' at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove. This well-balanced show is quite likely the richest and best exhibition on the subject that has been mounted in the area. Its strengths include attention to a wide range of approaches, sympathy for independent investigation and serious experimentation, and an adequate overview for each of the 12 Long Islanders represented.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Taxes are about more than money and about more than economics.

title: Closely Knit
description: A FASHION ILLUSTRATION from the late 1930's portrays a young man in a handsome wool sport coat. A dinner plate is balanced in each of his hands, and nipping at their contents is an unruly terrier. But even the athletic pup scarcely ruffles this fellow's composure. Or, for that matter, the lines of his jacket, which is cut from a pliant, tweedlike knit. A woven garment, the scene suggests, might not have weathered the canine assault so gracefully.

title: Joanne Bloom Is Wed To Michael R. Toplyn
description: Joanne Barbara Bloom and Michael Richard Toplyn, doctoral candidates in anthropology at Bryn Mawr College and Harvard University respectively, were married last evening at the Warwick Hotel in New York. Rabbi Gordon Richards and the Rev. Michael Sehler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Geneva Delegates Agree To Limit Biological Arms
description: After a three-week conference, delegates from 55 nations have agreed to try to strengthen a 14-year-old treaty banning the production, storage and use of biological weapons.

title: YANKEE CHICANERY
description: THE WINES OF PENTAGOET By John Gould. 219 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $14.95.

title: OFFICIAL FAULTED IN SCANDAL CALLS TRANSFER 'A RAW DEAL'
description: Kenneth Litwack says he that did his job exactly the way he should have, and that now he is being made to take a fall for those who did not.

title: WHAT PAC MONEY BUYS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. IN MASSACHUSETTS SEES SINGLE RAY OF HOPE
description: In a year of political mishaps for Republicans in Massachusetts, their party is finding some hope in the contest for the state treasurer's seat.

title: MOROCCO REPORTEDLY FOILS SYNAGOGUE ATTACK
description: Morocco recently arrested a team of Palestinian terrorists who were preparing to bomb a synagogue in Casablanca on the Jewish New Year next weekend, according to Administration officials.

title: Fordham Wins
description: John Kennedy kicked a 37-yard field goal with 7 minutes 41 seconds to play to give Fordham a 20-19 upset over previously undefeated Merchant Marine Academy in a Liberty Conference game yesterday afternoon at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: 10-Year Decline Cited For the Poorer Nations
description: A group representing the poorest countries of the world said today that their standards of living had deteriorated to levels below those of 10 years ago. To help revive their economic growth, they called for higher prices of rubber, tin, copra, copper, oil and other international commodity prices.

title: Patricia A. Rubin Weds D. L. Sacks
description: Patricia Ann Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Rubin of Stamford, Conn., and Douglas Lowell Sacks, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Sacks of New Haven and West Brattleboro, Vt., were married yesterday. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York.

title: Praise for Koreans
description: THE 27-nation Asian Games being held in Seoul, South Korea, have been serving as a preview of sorts for the 1988 Summer Olympics, also scheduled for Seoul, and as the 16-day event reached its halfway point yesterday, the head of the Asian Olympic Council said the games augured well for Olympic effort. ''Our friends in Korea have given an example to the whole world that they will be capable of holding a 1988 international games which will be one of the best in the world,'' said Sheikh Fahad Al Ahmad Sabah, a sports official from Kuwait who was elected Thursday to a second four-year term as president of the Asian council.

title: St. Bart's Rector Wins a Mandate
description: Should a church be constrained by a landmarks law when - as J. Stuart Wetmore, the Suffragan Bishop of New York's Episcopal Diocese, put it recently - it must ask itself ''do we feed the hungry or repair the facade''? Is it in fact constitutional to apply such laws to churches, when the First Amendment says that ''Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof''?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HENRY AND JUNE: From the Unexpurgated Diary of Anais Nin. By Anais Nin. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) For those familiar with Anais Nin's monumental journals (there were 150 volumes preserved in a vault when she died), this pared-down version of a previously published volume covering the years 1931-1934 may be somewhat disappointing.

title: NEW TRICKS OF THE AUTO DEALER'S TRADE
description: ''WHEN you buy a car, you should have that great feeling of making a major purchase,'' said Jeffrey B. Hirsch, a Los Angeles marketing consultant who recently bought a Honda Accord. Instead, he said, ''I walked away with a queasy feeling.''

title: Miss Garrity Wed To E.R. Heilbron
description: Deirdre Anne Garrity, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lawrence Garrity of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward R. Heilbron, the son of Josephine K. Heilbron of Lancaster, Pa., and the late Robert S. Heilbron. Msgr. Joseph A. DeAndrea, adviser to the Holy See Mission to the United Nations, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in Manhattan.

title: Loft Conciliation
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FOOTSTOOL IN HEAVEN. By Brett Singer. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) Brett Singer's second novel is hip and corny, sentimental and vulgar all at once.

title: Bernstein Triumphant
description: Leonard Bernstein misses the point in discussing his decision to return to Austria to conduct the Vienna Philharmonic orchestra.

title: MAKING CONNECTIONS
description: THE SPRINGHOUSE By Norman Dubie. 56 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95. THE BEAUTY OF THE WEAPONS Selected Poems 1972-82. By Robert Bringhurst. 159 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Copper Canyon Press. Paper, $10. VESPER SPARROWS By Deborah Digges. 51 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $15. Paper, $8.95.

title: A Night to Remember
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE AGONY OF ELIJAH BLACK HORSE
description: THAT DAY IN GORDON By Raymond H. Abbott. 229 pp. New York: Vanguard Press. $15.95.

title: RELIEVING STRESS: MIND OVER MUSCLE
description: YOU ARE SITTING AT YOUR DESK finishing an important report. You have been working on it for two months, and it is due in 30 minutes. You feel that you need at least another week to finish. Your boss is screaming in the next office; he is already in a foul mood. ''This is it,'' you say to yourself, ''I can't take it anymore. I'll run away and live in Tahiti. Or maybe I'll just look for another job.''

title: Buying Top Stereo With Bottom Dollars
description: My neighbor's daughter Laura voiced a complaint. ''All the stuff you write about is too expensive,'' she told me reproachfully, and explained how she arrived at that opinion. She had saved $400 from her summer job as a baby sitter to buy a stereo system to take back to school, only to find that most of the items I had mentioned in print were out of her reach.

title: Costa Rica Closes A Border Airport
description: Somebody informed the Costa Rican Government that planes had been heard near a supposedly unused military-size airfield hidden in a valley 20 miles miles from the Nicaraguan border. The reports raised suspicions, and last week the Public Security Minister, Hernan Garron Salazar, said the field had been closed.

title: RED SOX CLINCH A TIE FOR EAST TITLE
description: The shouts of joy and excitement in the Red Sox clubhouse seemed appropriate, coming, as they did, right after Boston had beaten Toronto, 2-0, today to assure itself of at least a tie for its first American League East title in 11 years. Yet there was something strange going on. The exclamations came from just one area of the clubhouse, the one in front of the television set. No, the players weren't watching a replay of Bruce Hurst's game-ending strikeout of Jesse Barfield or of the homer by Dwight Evans that broke a scoreless tie in the fifth inning. Nor were they tuned to a sports show reporting that the Boston victory and a Yankee loss to Detroit had eliminated the rivals from New York.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HELLO, MA BELL TUESDAY is T-day for Richard and Di Anne Solberg and their two children. That's the day the Solbergs, who moved to Long Island from Spokane, Wash., about seven weeks ago, are scheduled to finally get a telephone installed in their home in Centereach.

title: MIAMI WINS BATTLE FOR NO. 1
description: Vinny Testaverde, the once-forgotten quarterback who considered leaving the University of Miami in search of a chance to play, today turned an angry confrontation of the two most highly ranked college football teams into his stage.

title: Caroline T. Mitchell Marries
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan yesterday Caroline Thorn Mitchell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Lindsay Mitchell of New York, was married to James Roy Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Clark of Cary, Ill. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: NEW CLUES MAY HELP PILOTS AVERT WIND SHIFTS
description: Plunging columns of torrential rain have been found to cause wind gusts that are a major factor in air crashes in humid climates. A new study shows that these rains may explain at least two major air disasters in the United States in which 277 people were killed.

title: NEW STUDY OFFERS PLAN TO RESCUE LATIN ECONOMIES
description: Economists in Washington, Mexico City and Rio de Janeiro have drafted an ambitious blueprint for renewed economic growth in Latin America that they say represents a growing consensus in the hemisphere on economic policy.

title: David Hoffman Wed To Carla Nathanson
description: Carla Gimbel Nathanson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Nathanson of New York and Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to David Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Hoffman of Glen Rock, N.J., and Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin officiated at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sept. 7 incorrectly stated that the new president of Yale University, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., would not teach at the university this year.

title: VETERAN FIGHTER OF POLICE CORRUPTION EMBARKS ON HIS FINAL INVESTIGATION
description: He is the solitary figure in blue who darts quietly from the room the moment police promotion ceremonies are over, not stopping to press the flesh like the rest of the brass. He shuns department parties in favor of steamed fish with close friends in Chinatown.

title: Q AND A
description: Culebra Question:My family is planning to rent a house on Culebra, P.R. Can you provide information about this island, including beaches and what to wear? - M. L. W., Needham, Mass. Answer:Culebra, 7 miles long and 2 miles wide, and 20 miles east of the main island, pleases visitors who want a casual vacation and are not bothered by the absence of golf, tennis, casinos and boutiques. Travelers accustomed to the amenities of San Juan may describe the island as almost barren and lacking a plentiful water supply, which is true; but its admirers point to deserted sandy beaches, excellent scuba diving and friendly bars.

title: A Night to Remember
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART;
SUMMIT: 'CONSTRUCTED IN JERSEY CITY'
description: THE title of the current exhibition at the Summit Art Center, ''Constructed in Jersey City,'' has a muscle-flexing tone to it, one similar to the slogan ''Trenton Makes, the World Takes.''

title: DATA UPDATE: September 28, 1986
PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 21, 1986
description: FICTION 1 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $4.50.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 2 THE RED FOX, by Anthony Hyde. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A thriller in which a journalist journeys to Russia, seeking the father of a woman he loves. 3 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Penguin, $3.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 4 LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. 5 ENTERPRISE: The First Adventure, by Vonda N. McIntyre. (Pocket, $3.95.) Under a young captain, the Star Trek craft faces unexpected challenges. 6 AFTER THE REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Dell, $4.50.) The surprises that befell four Radcliffe women in the five years after their 20th reunion. 7 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 8 ILLINOIS! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) The ''Wagons West'' series reaches Chicago at the time of the 1871 fire. 9 THE TRAIL TO CRAZY MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Three long Western stories that the author later turned into novels. 10 * SAN ANDREAS, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett, $4.50.) A British hospital ship with a deadly secret, adrift in the North Sea after a Luftwaffe attack. 11 THE RIDER OF THE RUBY HILLS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $2.95.) Four frontier stories that were later expanded into novels. 12 THE FRATERNITY OF THE STONE, by David Morrell. (Fawcett, $4.50.) After spending six years in a monastery, a hit man must face his past. 13 SWAN'S CHANCE, by Celeste De Blasis. (Bantam, $4.50.) The Civil War ordeals of the Falconers, a Maryland horse-raising and shipbuilding family. 14 THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, by John Irving. (Bantam, $4.95.) Life in a Maine orphanage earlier in this century. 15 PALM BEACH, by Pat Booth. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A poor but beautiful woman finds her way in the town of the superrich. NONFICTION: General 1 YEAGER, by Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $4.95.) The test pilot's autobiography. 2 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Berkley, $4.50.) The rock legend as friend, mentor, lover, husband and father. 4 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $4.95.) How the son of immigrants rose to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 5 SMART WOMEN, FOOLISH CHOICES, by Connell Cowan and Melvin Kinder. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) Modern women's efforts to find good men. 6 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles Kuralt. (Fawcett, $4.50.) The television reporter tells of Americans he's encountered. NONFICTION: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 BLOOM COUNTY BABYLON, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $12.95.) Five years of comic strips. 3 IT CAME FROM THE FAB SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) Cartoons. 4 THE ONE MINUTE SALES PERSON, by Spencer Johnson with Larry Wilson. (Avon, $5.) How to increase selling skills. 5 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1986. 6 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Help for victims of others' compulsive behavior. 7 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Revised edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 8 WHAT COLOR IS YOUR PARACHUTE? by Richard Nelson Bolles. (Ten Speed Press, $8.95.) Job and career advice; 1986 edition. 9 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $8.95.) Cartoons.

title: GOLD COAST NEEDS HOUSES, NOT OFFICES
description: THE Gold Coast cannot go on this way forever. Traffic on Interstate 95 and the Merritt Parkway clogs more and more every month, housing prices continue to escalate at a destructive rate, and office construction races ahead unabated.

title: MATTINGLY STREAK ENDS; YANKEES ELIMINATED
description: The chase ended yesterday. So did the hitting streak.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: High Priestess of the Humble

title: Dodging Debate
description: Four years ago, an underdog candidate named Mario Cuomo was elected Governor of New York after scoring against opponents in a series of well-publicized debates. Now Mr. Cuomo is ducking invitations to debate this year's underdog, Republican Westchester County Executive Andrew O'Rourke.

title: Texas House Approves Cuts and Tax Increase
description: The Texas House of Representatives today approved $582 million in spending cuts and an $869.2 million temporary tax. Both measures are intended to pare down a projected $2.8 billion deficit as Texas copes with the oil slump.

title: Montana Eyeing Return This Year
description: Joe Montana said today that he would try to come back before the end of the 1986 season.

title: Susan Epstein Is Married To Michael S. Shulklapper
description: The marriage of Susan Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Epstein of New Rochelle, N.Y., to Michael Steven Shulklapper took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Shulklapper, also of New Rochelle.

title: CUT-RATE AUTO LOANS HURT USED-CAR DEALERS
description: Detroit's high-stakes bid to spur car sales with low-interest financing has helped dealers sharply pare swollen inventories. But the cut-rate loans have attracted many thousands of drivers who otherwise would have bought used cars and that segment of the industry is now in a slump, with sales off as much as 30 percent in some parts of the country.

title: ROHATYN ASSAILING 'CYNICISM'
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said yesterday that he felt ''profound disappointment and depression'' at what he described as the lack of interest in ending municipal corruption.

title: Ice Dam Reported Close to Breaking Open
description: The Hubbard Glacier ice dam, which cut off porpoises from the Pacific and apparently doomed them to a fresh-water death, is on the verge of breaking open naturally, the United States Forest Service reported Saturday.

title: EGYPT'S NEW ISLAMIC SCHOOLS: SETTING AN EXAMPLE
description: ''Islam is growing stronger,'' chanted the tiny girl with the microphone, a fifth grader in pigtails and a green school uniform.

title: John Flanagan Dies; G.O.P. Assemblyman
description: John J. Flanagan, a New York State Assemblyman who represented the Huntington, L.I., area for 14 years, died of a heart attack Saturday, after collapsing while jogging in a neighborhood schoolyard. He was 50 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: A COMMITTED CROWD SUPPORTS PREMIERE OF 'X'
description: Among the 2,800 people, including standees, at the world premiere yesterday of ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X)'' were many who attended because they felt such an opera presented not only music and song but what they called ''a statement.''

title: Walesa Says Solidarity Wants To Act Legally After Amnesty
description: Lech Walesa, speaking to hundreds of supporters celebrating his birthday in Gdansk, said today that his outlawed Solidarity trade union movement wanted to act legally after the recent Government amnesty for political prisoners.

title: The Political Narcotic
description: The spectacle of the month in Washington has been the Gadarene rush of politicians to the drug issue. Democrats in the House of Representatives vied with President Reagan and his followers for the most ferocious posture in the crusade against drugs.

title: Wed at the Tip Of Manhattan
description: They were both outdoor people and determined to have an open-air wedding in Manhattan.

title: BAKER FINDS DEALING WITH ALLIES TOUGHER THAN TAX CAMPAIGN
description: These are days of triumph and days of disappointment for the President's master political strategist and Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d.

title: Soviet Minister Ousted After Ship Disaster
description: The Soviet Minister of Merchant Marine has been removed from his post less than a month after a cruise liner sank in the Black Sea with the loss of almost 400 people, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: No Sweat
description: It should not come as a shock to anyone who hasn't been confined to a cave these last few years, but there is new statistical evidence that the man you passed on the street wearing multi-ply, super-reinforced long-distance running shoes may actually be out for just a short stroll. And the woman in the tennis dress may have been nowhere near the courts all day.

title: EAGLES WIN TO GIVE RYAN FIRST VICTORY
description: Ron Jaworski's three touchdown passes and a defense that stopped Eric Dickerson carried the Philadelphia Eagles to a 34-20 upset of the previously unbeaten Los Angeles Rams today. It was the Eagles' first victory under Buddy Ryan, their new head coach.

title: Washington Watch; Banking Group's New Leader
description: The Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based organization representing the world's commercial bankers, is getting a new managing director and expects to play a broader role in the international debt crisis.

title: ACTOR MOVES INTO FOREGROUND AT 81
description: After 60 years of playing bit parts, Feodor Chaliapin Jr. has had plenty of practice in adding atmospheric touches in films. Now, however, the 81-year-old actor has a key role in a serious movie. His name is currently appearing in the title credits of ''The Name of the Rose'' with the likes of Sean Connery and F. Murray Abraham.

title: POLITICS; GETTING THE YOUNG WHERE THEY LIVE
description: Later this fall, rock music radio stations in about a dozen states will start running some unusual commercials. Instead of promoting a certain brand of beer or blue jeans, these commercials will be pushing a particular brand of politician, Republican, to be exact.

title: NELSON DOUBLEDAY'S SUCCESS WITH THE METS IS ONE FOR THE BOOK
description: ''WHEN the dugout telephone rings,'' Ron Darling was saying the other day in Shea Stadium, ''you never imagine it's Nelson Doubleday. It isn't, and it never could be.''

title: Boeing Up for Contract
description: The Boeing Company and the General Electric Company of Britain are the only remaining contenders to build a future airborne early warning system in Britain, it was announced Friday. The two contenders have until early November to come up with final offers before a decision is made by the end of the year. The British eliminated five other contenders, including the Grumman Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation.

title: Nuclear Policy After 1988
description: It is none too soon for each 1988 Presidential aspirant, regardless of party, to begin shaping what should be the centerpiece of his 1989 Inaugural Address - a frank exposition of the nuclear threat and of the first steps he will take to defuse it. That shock treatment is essential if the world is to break out of its torpor and reverse the advancing risk of nuclear war.

title: THE CROWDED COSMETIC ARENA
description: Behind the rosy glow of rouge and the scent of perfume on any department store cosmetics floor, some not-so-pretty fights are taking place. Many cosmetic companies are locked in vicious battles for better retail locations and more space.

title: TAPPIANO WINS MATRON
description: If Personal Ensign had run in the eighth instead of the sixth race at Belmont Park yesterday, she probably would have won a Grade I stakes race in her first career start. Instead, the 2-year-old filly scored a 12 3/4-length victory in a $22,000 maiden race while running faster and more impressively than Tappiano, who won the $120,000 Matron Stakes an hour later.

title: 1 of 4 Maryland Policemen Dies 10 Days After Shooting
description: One of four police officers whom officials say were shot four days ago by a New York fugitive has died.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1986
description: International

title: CHRISTIAN MILITIA FOILS BEIRUT RAID
description: Christian militiamen, reportedly backed by units of the Lebanese Army, have foiled an attempt by pro-Syrian militiamen to seize control of the predominantly Christian sector of Beirut.

title: Montana Continues To Battle Flood Waters
description: Residents of this small farming and ranching town stood guard behind sandbags and dikes today as a major creek steadily rose. More than 300 people have been evacuated from flooded towns along the Milk River.

title: Sloan Bromberg Becomes Bride of Morri Berman
description: Sloan Bromberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Bromberg of Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday to Morri Berman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Berman of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at One Main on Fulton Landing in Brooklyn.

title: Competing For Charlie Business
description: NOW Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has won the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States corporate account. Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopolus's New York office has landed Revlon's Charlie. And Grey Advertising has retained the joint recruiting program of the Defense Department, while Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt has gotten the Department's National Guard Bureau's recruiting assignment. None of these has anything to do with Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: 2 KILLED, 3 WOUNDED IN SHOOTINGS AT EAST HARLEM CHRISTENING PARTY
description: A heated argument among revelers at a christening celebration party in an East Harlem school gymnasium erupted into a shootout early yesterday that left two men dead and three other men wounded.

title: Thousands of Trees Die Along Jersey Turnpike
description: More than half of the 20,000 seedlings planted this spring along the New Jersey Turnpike as part of a beautification plan have died over the summer, according to the program's director.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR GAINS ON CHALLENGER
description: With the Texas economy reeling from the collapse of the oil industry, Gov. Mark White, a Democrat, has been the underdog in his race for re-election against the former Governor, Bill Clements, a Republican.

title: Dr. Sorokin Wed To James R. Goff
description: Dr. Rachel Bernice Sorokin, an internist and rheumatologist at Philadelphia Health Associates, was married yesterday to James Richard Goff, a computer consultant in Philadelphia for the textile and apparel industry. Rabbi Robert E. Goldberg performed the ceremony at Troutbeck, an inn in Amenia, N.Y.

title: EXPERTS TRY NEW LOOK AT DOLLAR'S FALL
description: The dollar has not fallen by anywhere near as much as Government officials have claimed, according to a number of economists who have been compiling new indexes intended to better measure how price-competitive American goods have become.

title: Kiyoshi Tanimoto Dies; Led Hiroshima Victims
description: The Rev. Kiyoshi Tanimoto, an American-educated Methodist minister who survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and then led a movement on behalf if its victims, died today of pneumonia complicated by kidney failure, relatives reported. He was 77 years old.

title: WEST SIDE SURPRISE: IF THAT'S MAIL, THIS CAN'T BE SUNDAY
description: A strange thing happened on Manhattan's Upper West Side yesterday. They delivered the mail.

title: New Group of 10 Head
description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, was elected chairman of the Group of 10 nations at a meeting here, the group said in a communique today.

title: COMPUTER USE FOR NEWS RAISES LEGAL QUESTIONS
description: Computers that have changed the way reporters write the news are changing the way they gather it as well. The technology has been a boon to journalists, but its use has raised questions, even among reporters and editors, about privacy, access to public information and the limits of the First Amendment.

title: RED SOX CLINCH EAST DIVISION TITLE
description: The magic number for the Boston Red Sox is zero.

title: David E. Pitt Married To Martha Greenough
description: Martha Alice Greenough and David Emmett Pitt were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York by the Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, a Unitarian minister.

title: GIANTS RALLY TO BEAT SAINTS, 20-17
description: At the beginning today, the Giants were in deep trouble. Midway through the second quarter, they trailed the New Orleans Saints, 17-0, and that was only part of it.

title: USE OF COCAINE, BUT NOT OTHER DRUGS, SEEN RISING
description: As the nation debates ways to counter drug abuse, the extent of the problem appears mixed, with statistics showing a significant increase in cocaine use but a leveling-off or decline of other illicit drugs.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
America's Team
description: During the nine years in which Gene Corrigan was athletic director at Virginia, the Cavalier football team made it to network television exactly once, in a regional appearance against V.M.I. Before that, the Cavs had gone 19 years without a TV spot, and so Corrigan felt justifiably miffed that the Notre Dames and Alabamas seemed to be hogging the tube every time he tuned in. Now, as the athletic director at Notre Dame, he's grazing the green on the other side of the fence.

title: BAKER BIDS TO LOWER DOLLAR RATE
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, after an open rift with West Germany and Japan over currency and interest rate policies, today resumed his efforts to encourage a lower rate for the dollar.

title: UPSET LOSSES SLOW BOXERS' PROGRESS
description: Both Donald Curry, the undisputed welterweight champion, and Livingstone Bramble, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, had been expected to use their title defenses last weekend as steps toward more lucrative bouts.

title: REUNION TAPS A WELL OF MEMORY
description: The little wooden synagogue has burned to the ground, and the boarders who dubbed this village the poor man's answer to the Catskills long ago stopped spending their summers here. The skinny cows, the creamery and the kosher butcher who slaughtered the chickens have all been gone for almost half a century.

title: SERENE OUTING IN MAINE
description: A PAIR of loons wailed to each other across the smooth, night-shrouded surface of Parmachenee Lake as we sat silently - as if in a great cathedral - in our old Rangely boat, and we could see only two sets of lights, one from our camp, which was close by, the other from the western shore two miles away.

title: BRIEFING; Return of LeBaron
description: Eddie LeBaron is coming back to Washington. The former Washington Redskins quarterback, most recently executive vice president of the Atlanta Falcons, is joining the Washington office of the Atlanta law firm Powell, Goldstein, Frazer & Murphy in an ''of counsel'' capacity. Mr. LeBaron also formerly played with the Dallas Cowboys and practiced law in Texas and Nevada.

title: BRIEFING; Nixon Library's Request
description: ''Please make it clear,'' the former President wrote, ''that the Richard Nixon Presidential Library will not be a monument to one man but rather a place where people will be able to recall the events that occurred while I served as President and make their own judgments about the successes or failures of our Administration.'' A copy of this letter accompanied a mailed appeal by William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury, for contributions to the Nixon library, which brought in more than $100,000 this summer.

title: MUSIC: 'SLOW FIRE,' IN PHILADELPHIA FESTIVAL
description: ''Slow Fire,'' a merger of music, monologue and assorted manic shenanigans, came to New York's attention at one of the Philharmonic's Horizons '86 concerts last June. At Philadelphia's American Music Theater Festival tonight, it accumulated a second act and reportedly will end up with a third.

title: A DANCER, ACTOR AND DIRECTOR
description: Sir Robert Helpmann, an Australian dancer who became an international ballet star and choreographer as well as a noted actor and director, died yesterday in Sydney after a long illness. He was 77 years old. A grand mimic with a flamboyant sense of theatricality, Sir Robert moved from ballet to stage to films with an ease and flair that both confounded and delighted his friends and colleagues, who included Vivien Leigh, Dame Margot Fonteyn and Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: 'REALISTS' GAIN AT THE CONGRESS OF GREEN PARTY IN NUREMBERG
description: Four months before national elections, the anti-establishment Green Party concluded a chaotic congress today with something resembling a victory of its pragmatic wing over its utopian and Marxist-Leninist factions.

title: SOVIET TAKES WESTERN REPORTERS TO ATOM-TEST SITE
description: The Government took a small group of Western journalists on a tour of a Soviet underground nuclear test site in Central Asia this weekend. It was believed to be the first time Westerners were allowed to inspect the site.

title: SPIRITUAL CONCEPTS DRAWING A DIFFERENT BREED OF ADHERENT
description: Representatives of some of the nation's largest corporations, including I.B.M., A.T.&T. and General Motors, met in New Mexico in July to discuss how metaphysics, the occult and Hindu mysticism might help executives compete in the world marketplace.

title: NIKOLAI SEMYONOV, WINNER OF 1956 NOBEL IN CHEMISTRY
description: Nikolai N. Semyonov, a pioneering Soviet scientist who was awarded the 1956 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work in exploring chemical chain reactions, has died, the official press agency Tass said today. He was 90 years old.

title: Teamwork Unsnarls Busy West Side Street
description: Traffic can be heavy at times on West 62d Street. Very heavy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1986
description: International

title: Michael Andretti Is Edged by Rahal
description: Bobby Rahal took advantage of a late caution flag to edge out Michael Andretti and win the Pepsi-Cola 250 Indy car race today at Michigan International Speedway.

title: AMERICANS REPORTEDLY SUPERVISED AIRSTRIP PROJECT NEAR NICARAGUA
description: Two Americans and the local police commander supervised the building of a military-size airstrip near Costa Rica's border with Nicaragua, according to local residents, including some who say they worked on the project.

title: OPERA: ANTHONY DAVIS'S 'X (THE LIFE AND TIMES OF MALCOLM X)'
description: OPERA means many different things to many different people. One meaning with a long history is opera as musically accompanied declamation, which is how ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X)'' struck this reviewer in its formal world premiere last night at the New York City Opera. The scenario amounts to an authorized, romanticized biography of the black separatist leader whose assassination in 1965 made him a legend and, to some, a hero. At the heart of the story, as set to music by Anthony Davis, is a power struggle between Malcolm X and his mentor, Elijah Muhammad, for control of the Black Muslim movement. Of such confrontations has many an opera been made, of course.

title: THE STORY 'ADAM' CONTINUES
description: AS a sequel to ''Adam,'' NBC's ''Adam: His Song Continues'' picks up the story on the very day, Oct. 10, 1983, that the first film was broadcast. That's about as close as the new material ever gets to the powerful original. ''Adam'' told the true story of John and Reve Walsh, whose young son suddenly disappeared in a shopping center. The parents were horrified to learn that law-enforcement authorities, locally and nationally, had few or no mechanisms for finding missing children. Adam was eventually discovered murdered, but publicity generated by the Walshes helped gain widespread awareness of the problem. In addition, photos of missing children shown at the end of the movie led to more than a dozen of them being located.

title: COMPTROLLER SWIMMING AGAINST A POLITICAL TIDE
description: Edward V. Regan has said he has made a career of swimming against Democratic tides since he began running as a Republican for office in Buffalo and Erie County. And, he says, he will continue to do so as he seeks a third term as State Comptroller.

title: Ecuador Fires Finance Chief
description: The opposition-controlled Congress fired the nation's Finance Minister early Saturday, charging his free-market, pro-business economic policies had hurt Ecuador's many poor.

title: Unwise Wall in Williamsburg
description: May Orthodox Jewish schoolgirls receive federally assisted remedial instruction? Yes, they are entitled to it. The question inflaming Hispanics and Jews in Brooklyn is where. A local school superintendent has decided it in a way that seems needlessly provocative, no matter that it has been approved by a Federal judge.

title: PEKING PARLEY BACKS ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee held a rare meeting today and reaffirmed China's commitment to economic modernization, while warning against corruption and other evils.

title: Protection Never Dull To Head of Borg Unit
description: When Charles R. Schneider hears of bombs exploding, robberies, terrorist attacks or hijackings, he says his first reaction is the same outrage of any citizen, but his second is: ''How can we help?''

title: Famous Fugitive Captured in Paris
description: A prisoner who made a spectacular escape by helicopter from a Paris penitentiary last spring has been seriously wounded and captured in a shootout while trying to rob a bank, the police said.

title: HOUSE VOTE COULD COME SOON ON REAGAN VETO OF SANCTIONS
description: The House of Representatives could act as early as Monday to override President Reagan's veto of a bill imposing economic sanctions on South Africa, a Congressional aide said today.

title: MEETINGS RESUME BETWEEN SHULTZ AND SHEVARDNADZE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister met for nearly three hours last night trying to find a formula for the release of an American journalist in Moscow and to resolve other issues holding up the setting of a date for a summit meeting.

title: 'DESIGNING WOMEN,' A CBS COMEDY
description: HAVING allowed ''Dallas'' to inform its fans, in what has to be the most arrogant plot development ever, that all of last season was merely Victoria Principal's dream, CBS is now turning its attention to imitations. Like NBC's ''Golden Girls,'' the new series ''Designing Women,'' tonight at 9:30, features four women with wisecracks to spare. Although they don't live together in Florida, these women spend most of their time working together in a Victorian-type house in Atlanta. They are in the business of interior decorating.

title: VIEWS SPLIT OVER EFFECT OF TAX BILL
description: Politicians and economists disagree over whether the changes in economic behavior to be brought about by the landmark tax-revision legislation that cleared Congress Saturday will be good or bad for the nation's overall economy.

title: HOLY CROSS HAS TWO-WAY PLAYER
description: Gordon Lockbaum's astonishing contributions to the unbeaten Holy Cross football team continue. They are astonishing in that Lockbaum does it all for the Crusaders.

title: Gorman Newsletter
description: The Gorman Publishing Company of Chicago has bought the DFS Dorland Worldwide New Product Newsletter, which Martin Friedman has been publishing for 22 years. He will continue to edit it from Miami. Gorman's other publications are Bakery Production and Marketing, Dairy Foods and Grocery Marketing.

title: REPORT OF TERROR CALLS U.S. UNREADY
description: The United States has no effective strategy to cope with the increasing threat of terrorism and guerrilla warfare, a Pentagon study has concluded.

title: AUTOPSY RULES OUT MEDICINE IN THE DEATH OF AIDS PATIENT
description: A patient suffering from AIDS died of complications related to the disease, not from a change of medication that was said to have been ordered by a registered nurse who is suspected of stealing more than $10,000 from him, according to autopsy results made public today.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYERS CHASE DOWN SUSPECT IN BROOKLYN ROBBERY
description: A robber was chased, tackled and captured yesterday by a sandlot football team moments after he took $1,795 from a 72-year-old Brooklyn church trustee who was depositing the Sunday collection, the police said.

title: Let Sports Fans Own Their Teams
description: The New York Mets are sold again. The new owners say they will keep the team in Queens. Why do we give them the power to make that decision? Why do we allow others to own and control hometown sports teams - to buy, sell and move them like so much furniture? Our community pride should not be for sale. Let the fans own their teams.

title: WHEREIN AN IDEA THAT WORKS COLLIDES WITH CHANGING TIMES
description: It may not happen often, but at least once in a while, Congress passes a law that demonstrably works. Such a law was the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit, adopted in 1974 at the height of the energy crisis with the goal of reducing gasoline consumption.

title: Medical Students Go Deeper In Debt to Pay for Schooling
description: Medical school graduates are getting deeper in debt, with the average burden, $30,000, nearly double what it was in 1980, according to an American Medical Association survey.

title: Signet Paperback Job Shifts to David Deutsch
description: David Deutsch Associates has become an agency of New American Library and will do advertising largely for its Signet line of paperbacks.

title: Market Place; The Prospects Of Food Issues
description: SHARES of food-processing companies - a top-performing group for the last four years - tumbled by 20 percent from their record highs during the market's sharp selloff this month. And some Wall Streeters now are betting on a switch from disinflation beneficiaries such as the foods to more cyclical sectors that would respond to an economic recovery.

title: 3 ARAB MAYORS NAMED IN WEST BANK
description: Israeli military authorities appointed three Arab mayors today to head towns in the occupied West Bank that were previously controlled by Israeli officers.

title: PAYING HOMAGE TO HISTORIC ROLE OF THE SANTA FE TRAIL
description: On Sept. 1, 1821, William Becknell, an American trader, left Arrow Rock, Mo., with a band of men and pack animals. Two months and nearly 1,000 miles later the caravan arrived in Santa Fe.

title: STOCK EXCHANGES TURBULENT IN QUARTER
description: For stock markets around the world, the third quarter was filled with a lot of memorable moments but little profit. Yet, while share prices were buffeted by concerns about interest rates, the economy and the like, the markets were, at least, giving investors the thrill of participating in one of the bumpiest rides ever.

title: The Truth About Frank
description: Transcripts of wiretaps ordered by courts and directed at suspected leaders of organized crime help us cross the bridge from fiction to fact.

title: Dollar Drops Briefly but Levels Off
description: The dollar dropped steeply, but briefly, before leveling off yesterday as some banks and other institutions in New York and overseas sent in skeleton crews to respond to the meeting of finance ministers of the major industrial nations.

title: BEARS ROLL BEHIND MCMAHON
description: Jim McMahon, making his first start since suffering a separated shoulder three weeks ago, threw three touchdown passes today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 44-7 rout of the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Bridge: 4 World Champion Events Swept by American Teams
description: The world championships that ended here Saturday produced an unprecedented American sweep of the four major events.

title: Ad Pages Off in August
description: The troubled magazine industry, suffering from advertiser pullbacks in important categories, showed a 4.3 percent drop in ad pages last month from August 1985. The figure, 9,688 pages, was supplied by the Publishers Information Bureau from its own membership. Their estimate of ad revenues for the month was $307.7 million, up six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 29, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Party Unity in New York ... and in Georgia
description: New York politics is commanding more attention than usual in Washington this year, primarily because one of the capital city's favorite pastimes these days is Cuomo-watching.

title: Merger Near In Oklahoma
description: The talk along the part of Madison Avenue that runs through Oklahoma is about the pending merger of the 47-year-old Ackerman & McQueen Advertising of Oklahoma City with the 16-year-old Hood, Hope Advertising of Tulsa to form Ackerman, Hood & McQueen, with 160 people, 35 accounts and $70 million in billings.

title: PARTY KEEPS ASSEMBLY LEAD
description: The conservative party of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac won a substantial number of new seats in the French Senate today and maintained its narrow majority in the National Assembly, the more powerful lower house.

title: DOWD IS IDENTIFIED AS FIRST TO TESTIFY IN FRIEDMAN TRIAL
description: Michael G. Dowd, who first implicated Donald R. Manes in New York City's corruption scandal, will be the Government's first witness in the major Federal corruption trial in New Haven and will take the stand there as soon as opening arguments end, people familiar with the Government's case said yesterday.

title: Oregon City Shows How It Became 'Livable'
description: Speaking on what some call the Portland Miracle, the architect Robert Frasca had some advice for the City of New York.

title: OPERA: NEW HALL'S FIRST WEEK
description: The first week of the Music Theater - the new, $73 million home of the Netherlands Opera and the Dutch National Ballet, and the country's first opera house - ended with repeats of two operatic presentations. Those were ''Ithaka,'' a one-act, hour-and-a-half-long opera by Otto Ketting, which had its world premiere at the theater's opening last Tuesday, and a new production of Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' which had been presented on Wednesday.

title: Benefit Concert Set For Carnegie Reopening
description: Frank Sinatra, Marilyn Horne, Liza Minnelli, Isaac Stern, Benita Valente and the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Zubin Mehta will be the stars of a benefit concert in December that reopens Carnegie Hall after a seven-month shutdown for renovation.

title: Erica Hanson Is Wed On Governors Island
description: Erica Hanson, a daughter of Vice Adm. Thor Hanson, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Hanson of New York, was married yesterday to Joshua Elbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Elbaum of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Robert Nunn, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Officers' Club on Governors Island.

title: TIME RUNNING OUT IN BALLOT DISPUTE IN ALABAMA
description: With a little more than five weeks left until Nov. 4, the question of who will succeed Gov. George C. Wallace as the Alabama Democratic Party's gubernatorial nominee is still the subject of hot dispute here.

title: The Trade-Deficit Route to Recession Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Steinberg Is the Bride Of J. A. Lebovitz in Boston
description: Margot Steinberg, who will join the law firm of Drinker Biddle & Reath next month, and James Allen Lebovitz, an associate in the law firm of Ballard, Spahr, Andrews & Ingersoll, both in Philadelphia, were married yesterday. Rabbi Herman Blumberg officiated at the Ritz Carlton in Boston.

title: No Academic Freedom At Issue in Curran Case
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: QUIET RAGE. Bernie Goetz in a Time of Madness. By Lillian B. Rubin. 247 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: QUAKER SET TO BUY ANDERSON
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy Anderson, Clayton & Company for about $800 million, apparently bringing to an end a bidding war centered around the company's pet food business.

title: Rambling To All-Pro
description: AMONG his Giants' teammates, he's known as ''Rambo,'' and it fits. Mark Bavaro plays tight end without a headband, but at 6 feet 4 inches and 245 pounds, it's as if he were wearing bandoleers across his bare chest and waving a machine gun. Early in yesterday's 20-17 victory over the New Orleans Saints, he suddenly had a cracked upper tooth. But he returned to finish with seven receptions for 110 yards, including a 19-yard touchdown. In the Giants' 3-1 start, he's now caught 25 passes for 393 yards. He might be the All-Pro tight end this season. And at his locker now, pro football's Rambo even sounded a little like Sylvester Stallone. ''I got to go for an X-ray,'' he mumbled. ''How's your tooth?'' somebody asked. ''I got to go for an X-ray. I'll tell you tomorrow.'' ''How did your tooth get hurt?'' ''I got to go for an X-ray,'' he repeated. He meant a dental X-ray to determine the damage to his tooth. During the game the Giants had feared a fractured jaw; those X-rays were negative. But none of his teammates seemed to know how his tooth had been cracked.

title: CITY AND UNION LEADERS MEET FOR INFORMAL TALKS
description: New York City officials and leaders of the municipal unions, in an unusual approach to airing their differences, came 170 miles to a conference center here this weekend for informal talks.

title: Hollywood Treatment For Yogurt Milkshake
description: Goody Two Shakes is about to enter the booming yogurt market.

title: DANCE: KATHAK, AN INDIAN CLASSIC
description: KATHAK, the classic dance of northern India, is more frequently associated with male than female performers. But Sitara Devi, India's most celebrated female Kathak dancer, has proved that a true classical art form has no gender.

title: Colorburst Drive Starts
description: Zazu Colorburst and Colorwash, L'Oreal's latest hair-coloring products, will be introduced in a four-page ad in the Oct. 6 issue of People magazine. McCann-Erickson is the agency. Colorburst comes in 10 shades, including Tootoo Pink and Join the Navy, while Colorwash is available in Grapevine and Golden Blaze.

title: Naomi Oreskes Is Wed To Dr. Kenneth Belitz
description: The marriage of Naomi Oreskes, a doctoral student in geology at Stanford University, to Dr. Kenneth Belitz, a hydrogeologist of the United States Geologic Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Don McGlone. Justice Eli Wager of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: To Control Aliens, Control Partisans
description: There's much in the blow that the House has just dealt to immigration reform to be sad about, even angry. It may well sink eight years of education, thought and political struggle. But the saddest loss is of bipartisanship, of the recognition that immigration reform is not a conservative or liberal issue but a national need.

title: Search Finds No Trace Of Fugitive in Slayings
description: Police officers searched a vacant trailer home today but found no trace of a former mental patient suspected of killing three people, the authorities reported.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS CONNORS BY 7-6, 6-3
description: John McEnroe, playing his best tennis since coming back from a layoff of more than six months, won a superb match against Jimmy Connors, 7-6, 6-3, tonight in the final of the Transamerica Open tennis tournament.

title: SUDAN FAMINE-RELIEF FLIGHTS SET
description: International sponsors of a planned relief operation for hundreds of thousands of famine victims in the war-devastated southern Sudan announced today that they would begin this week to fly food and other aid to starving civilians in two Government-held towns in the region.

title: PRISONERS LEARN HOW TO BE GOOD FATHERS
description: ''Oh, this is fun; I miss my daddy, so it's nice to be here,'' said a 9-year-old girl who had come to the Taconic State Correctional Facility in Bedford Hills, N.Y., to visit her father on a sunny Saturday afternoon. But she readily conceded, ''I would rather have him home.''

title: OUT OF NOWHERE, A DIVISION TITLE
description: JOHN McNAMARA, with two pieces of white tape flapping from the sleeve of his blue Red Sox windbreaker and a stiff lineup card in his hand, entered the Boston dugout one day recently from the passageway leading from the clubhouse.

title: Bonn Says It Foiled Bid To Rush in Refugees
description: West Germany has apparently thwarted an attempt to rush 27,000 third world refugees into West Berlin on a roundabout route through Eastern Europe, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Ellin Gail Sanger Is the Bride of Mortimer Agress
description: Ellin Gail Sanger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Sanger of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mortimer S. Agress, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Agress of Brooklyn. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael performed the ceremony at the Wampus Inn in Armonk.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Can a starting pitcher be credited with a perfect game if a teammate commits an error, or does the feat merely become a no-hitter?

title: INSIDE
description: American Role at Airstrip Local residents say two Americans helped in the building of a military-size airstrip near Costa Rica's border with Nicaragua.

title: MESSAGE FROM OLDER WOMEN
description: Across the country, older women are busy sewing a surprise for Congress for next Mother's Day. They are turning out colorful banners focused on the theme ''Health Care Is a Right, Not a Privilege,'' and their handiwork was shown in a sneak preview recently when about 450 members of the Older Women's League met here for their third national convention. A Particular Concern

title: Washington Watch; Why Banks Really Failed
description: IT is not uncommon for banking regulators to identify bad real estate loans as a cause for the failure of a bank or thrift institution. But generally there is an unspoken element behind that statement implying more than just a lot of vacant office buildings. Often the root cause consists of highly inflated values for real estate carried on the bank's books.

title: METS WIN ON HOMER IN 11TH
description: This has been an unforgettable season for the Mets. It has been unforgettable for Darryl Strawberry, too, but unlike the Mets generally, what Strawberry won't forget are the negative aspects.

title: Books; Law of the Land
description: A MACHINE THAT WOULD GO OF ITSELF: The Constitution in American Culture. By Michael Kammen. Illustrated. 532 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Sept. 29, 1986: MONDAY Ameron Inc Unocal Corp Ampco Pittsburgh Corp TUESDAY Cascade Nat Gas Harsco Corp Delmarva Pwr & Lt WEDNESDAY Acme Cleveland Corp Houston Indus Amer Water Works Murphy Oil Carolina Freight Nevada Pwr Carter Hawley Hale Sun Co Inc Hi-Shear Indus THURSDAY Gencorp Inc Grace (WR) & Co General Dynamics Tultex Corp FRIDAY Lomas & Nettleton Fin US West Inc Travelers Corp

title: O'ROURKE CRITICIZES CUOMO FOR DELAYING STATE TAX DECISIONS
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, accused Governor Cuomo yesterday of delaying politically difficult decisions on state tax cuts until after Election Day and of misleading the public about his position.

title:
TALKING POLITICS;
Party Unity in New York... and in Georgia
description: Down in Georgia, meanwhile, Senator Sam Nunn, another Democrat who has shown some symptons of Presidential fever, has overcome his early reluctance to take an active role in his state's Senate campaign.

title: A COLORFUL START TO FALL IN CITY STREET FESTIVALS
description: They sashayed across 42d, thundered up Third, strolled 52d and ambled down Atlantic.

title: U.S.C. THRIVING ON INTENSITY
description: Coach Ted Tollner of Southern California had hoped for a hard-fought, down-to-the-wire game against Washington because he believed that would offer the Trojans' their best chance against the Huskies.

title:
TALKING POLITICS;
Taking Off the Gloves
description: Strategists for Representative Ed Zschau, the Republican Senate nominee in California, were particularly proud of a radio spot they had come up with that hit Senator Alan Cranston, the Democratic incumbent, on the tax issue.

title: Continental Grain Case
description: The Continental Grain Company, a co-defendant with the Hunt brothers in a suit brought by a Peruvian agency charging conspiracy to corner the silver market in 1979, settled out of court last week for what mining sources here said was more than $5 million.

title: 300 WAR BRIDES GO HOME, TO TEA AND TEARS
description: It had all the makings of a first-rate 40-year reunion, with big band music, a lavish garden party and tears. But for many, it was the weekend they never dreamed would occur.

title: Boy, 15, Shot in Lefrak City; Two Girls Are Being Sought
description: A 15-year-old boy, identified by the police as Rogean Williams Haywood, was found shot in his bedroom in his family's apartment in Lefrak City in Queens yesterday afternoon. The police were looking for two teen-age girls as suspects.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: SHAMIR DENIES ISRAELIS' RAID NEAR BEIRUT WAS RETALIATORY
description: Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli Foreign Minister, denied yesterday tha Israel bombed Palestinian sites near Beirut to retaliate for the terrorist bombing of an Istanbul synagogue.

title: Required Reading
description: A Hero's Protest Excerpts from remarks made by Representative Robert J. Mrazek, Democrat of Nassau County, on the House floor Sept. 23:

title: BRIEFING; Billboards' Plea
description: The humble billboard, long a medium for domestic politics, is being used by international protest movements trying to gain attention in Washington. As part of a campaign to investigate purported human rights violations in Sri Lanka, Amnesty International has installed 11 billboards around Washington with red and black letters reading ''Sri Lanka - Stop Torture'' and giving the organization's local telephone number. A spokesman said the group was trying to arouse concern in government leaders and influential citizens over hundreds of ''disappearances'' of people seized by security forces in Sri Lanka in two years.

title: Rates and the U.S. Economy
description: In the absence of a coordinated reduction in interest rates by large industrialized countries, analysts will look to the health of the domestic economy for clues to future changes in American interest rates and Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: AREA LAWMAKERS DISCUSS THEIR VOTES ON TAX BILL
description: As he studied the reams of pages detailing legislation to overhaul the tax system, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, a Democrat, said he thought about the people of New Haven, a city in his district and one that ranks as the seventh poorest in the nation. And then he decided to vote ''yes.''

title: Karen Mandel Is Married to Michael O. Adelman
description: Karen Mandel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mandel of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Ochs Adelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Adelman of New York and Hancock Point, Me. Rabbi Aaron Pearl performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: PRIVATE SURVEY IS SENT TO BLACKS BY STATE AGENCY
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation distributed a private group's survey among its black employees, asking them, among other things, whether they would vote for Governor Cuomo.

title: Ogilvy Has New Unit
description: The Sage (for strategic assets group enterprises) Group is the latest subsidiary of the Ogilvy Group, which is also the parent of Ogilvy & Mather. Spencer L. Hapoienu will be managing director of Sage. It is intended to help manufacturers, retailers and service organizations ''to create fully integrated marketing and merchandising stragegies.''

title: LOUISIANA VOTE FORCES A RUNOFF IN SENATE RACE
description: Representative W. Henson Moore, a Republican, fell well short of a majority in the Louisiana primary Saturday, forcing a runoff in November and heartening national Democratic leaders in their drive to take control of the Senate.

title: Accounts
description: * Heritage Health Plan of Southeastern Pennsylvania, Norristown, Pa., to McKinney Advertising, Philadelphia.

title: U.S. Financings Smaller Than Usual
description: A light supply of new debt issues is scheduled for sale in the Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt markets this week.

title: MATTINGLY GETS 3 HITS FOR .350 AVERAGE
description: Their conversation had taken place a week ago in Detroit. Bob Tewksbury did not want to make much of it yesterday, except that his talk with Don Mattingly had given him a significant mental lift. He wanted to convey that thought.

title: 3 South Africans Hurt In Nightclub Attack
description: A hand grenade was hurled at a nightclub open to all races today, and the blast wounded three people and caused extensive damage, the Bureau for Information said.

title: THE RED SOX BANISH CALVIN'S GHOST
