description: When the score reached 10-2 in favor of the Red Sox over the Toronto Blue Jays in the fourth inning this afternoon, a fan unfolded a banner that read, ''The fat lady is singing.''

title: Bid to Lucky Stores Challenge for Chief
description: John M. Lillie has been chief executive of Lucky Stores Inc. for only a little more than a year, but he is already contending with what may prove the major challenge of his tenure.

title: DAVID DODGE BOYDEN
description: David Dodge Boyden, an American musicologist best known for his books ''A History of Violin Playing From Its Origins to 1761'' and ''An Introduction to Music,'' died of a heart attack Sept. 18 in Berkeley, Calif.

title: FRED WILPON'S ROLE IS CERTAIN TO GROW
description: AS the ownership of the Mets prepares to realign its business batting order, one thing seems certain at Shea Stadium these days: Fred Wilpon, the president of the club, who owns 5 percent of the stock, is going to own and say a great deal more.

title: People
description: * Terron Schaefer will join Bloomingdale's as vice president, marketing.

title: Debt
description: * Burlington Northern Railroad Co. is offering $275 million of 9 1/4 percent consolidated mortgage bonds, due 2006, at a price of 99 7/8, to yield 9.264 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They were different, and so polite. They opened doors for you, which English boys didn't do.

title: Ashley Leeds Married to C. M. Harland
description: The marriage of Ashley Leeds, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence C. Leeds Jr. of New York, Stamford, Conn., and Tel Aviv, to Christopher M. Harland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Bruce Harland of New York and Aukland, New Zealand, took place yesterday. Rabbi Michael Gelber officiated at the Leeds home in Stamford, assisted by the Rev. Harold Barrett, rector of Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: No Progress on Peru, Mexico Debts
description: Peru and its creditor banks have failed to make any meaningful progress toward resolving a bitter, 14-month dispute over the country's $14 billion foreign debt, creditors were informed over the weekend.

title: OPERA: SCOTTO DOUBLES IN ''BUTTERFLY''
description: RENATA SCOTTO secured herself a distinctive place in the Metropolitan Opera annals on Saturday evening by not only singing the title part in ''Madama Butterfly'' but also functioning as the production's stage director. Her vocal performance as Puccini's cruelly mistreated heroine followed a pattern we have come to expect from the soprano in the late years of a long career: ardently and shrewdly acted, though erratically and sometimes painfully sung. She was in her best current voice on this red-letter occasion, however, which means she produced acceptably pleasing tones when the voice's extremely wide tremolo could be held under control in light lyric passages. When put under dramatic pressure, it turned hard and at times nasty, as at the fortissimo conclusion of Cio-Cio-San's ''Un bel di, vedremo.'' Like many a canny veteran, she knew how to direct one's attention to dramatic niceties rather than pure vocalism.

title: HIGH-TECH UNIT FUSED BY ALLIED
description: Continuing its recent emphasis on high-technology operations, Allied-Signal Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its aerospace and electronics businesses in a single unit. The company also announced that Robert L. Kirk, currently president and chief operating officer of the LTV Corporation, would head the new enterprise as president and chief executive.

title: ASTROS PITCH ANOTHER SHUTOUT
description: Jim Deshaies, Aurelio Lopez, Charlie Kerfeld and Dave Smith combined on Houston's fifth shutout in six games yesterday to lead the Astros to a 2-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: DISPUTE REKINDLED BY PLAN TO RAISE PENALTIES FOR SELLING CRACK
description: Faced with a public outcry for action to reduce the use of the drug crack, Governor Cuomo is pressing for penalties of up to life in prison for those convicted of selling even a small amount - three vials, or about $50 worth.

title: JETS OVERPOWER BUMBLING COLTS BY 26-7
description: Aided by the stumbling, fumbling Colts, the Jets produced an inelegant but conclusive 26-7 victory today as Pat Leahy kicked four field goals to extend his streak to 19 without a miss.

title: WOMEN DISCUSS THEIR FUTURE IN CORPORATE OFFICES
description: Are women leaving excellent career opportunities with corporations because they believe sexual discrimination bars them from senior positions?

title: Islanders Reduce
description: The Islanders reassigned 19 players today and announced the retirement of a 23-year-old left wing, Dan Brennan, to reduce their roster to 36.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. TORONTO BLUE JAYS, at Yankee Stadium (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) FOOTBALL DALLAS VS. CARDINALS, at St. Louis (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M.; Radio -WNBC 660; 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: at Roosevelt, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: at Belmont, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 & 11:15 P.M.); at Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight) TENNIS: Virginia Slims of New Orleans VOLLEYBALL: World Mens Champs, France

title: ISSUE OF FINANCING THE KEY OBSTACLE FOR ANTIDRUG PLAN
description: The Senate ended hours of debate early today on a measure to combat drug abuse after voting in support of the death penalty for major traffickers who commit a murder while they conduct their trade.

title: Screaming Eagles
description: All right, so maybe Erk Russell has never been a licensed social worker or drug counselor. But when the coach of Georgia Southern's defending Division I-AA football champions preaches an anti-cocaine sermon to his charges, he doesn't have to do it twice.

title: STUDY SAYS ABUSE OF COCAINE MAY CAUSE SEIZURES
description: The anesthetic effect of cocaine can sensitize the brain to potentially fatal seizures induced by small amounts of the drug, according to results of tests performed on animals.

title: Now What if We Stopped Barking at Russians?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spreading Grass Fire
description: When the first news report appeared charging that the Rev. Pat Robertson had used his father's political influence to avoid combat duty in the Korean War, the television evangelist reportedly viewed it as a political grass fire that could be quickly stomped out with a simple denial.

title: BRONCOS OVERCOME PATRIOTS AND GO TO 4-0
description: The Denver Broncos scored on four of their five possessions in the second half today and rallied to beat the New England Patriots, 27-20. It was the fourth victory without a loss for the Broncos, who trailed by 13-3 at halftime. The Patriots fell to 2-2.

title: PALMER GETS EAGLE TO WIN BY 3 SHOTS
description: Arnold Palmer shot an eagle on the par-5 16th hole today and went on to his first tournament victory since June, a three-stroke triumph in the Union Mutual Seniors Golf Classic.

title: WHEN A CHILD GOES AWAY
description: THE week that his daughter, Catie, now 19 years old, left home for Sarah Lawrence College was a difficult time for Tom Fuld, who has had custody of his only child since his divorce five years ago.

title: Waltrip a Winner
description: Darrell Waltrip grabbed the lead from Geoff Bodine with 11 laps left in the Holly Farms 400 today and won his first Nascar race at North Wilkesboro Speedway since 1984.

title: Seller's Market
description: To the Editor:

title: BERTELSMANN EXPANSION FACES TOUGH CHALLENGES
description: Talking to reporters about a year ago, Mark Woessner, the youthful-looking 47-year-old chief executive of Bertelsmann A.G., the big German publisher, predicted that the company was entering ''a brand new phase of expansion.''

title: VIETNAMESE FIND ALLY IN TEXAS: TIME
description: Efrain Martinez remembers well the stormy spring evening in 1980 that he locked Gene Fisher and Nguyen Van Nam together in a room at the Holiday Inn in Seabrook, Tex.

title: REDSKINS (4-0) BEAT SEAHAWKS BY 19-14
description: They seem rather odd, these Washington Redskins. They use three tight ends, sometimes one as a wide receiver. They run a one-back offense, which sometimes shifts to a no-back offense. They even have two kickers.

title: Diane Adler Wed To a Bank Officer
description: The marriage of Diane Paula Adler, director of development and publicity for the Hudson Guild, a settlement house in New York, and Shawn Joseph Harrington, an assistant treasurer in the real-estate division of the Seamen's Bank for Savings in New York, took place yesterday. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House in New York.

title: The Graying Veterans
description: In studying the phenomenon of the graying of America, the House Select Committee on Aging turned up something startling: By the year 2000, just 14 years hence, two of every three American men over 65 years of age will be military veterans.

title: CBS Trading Examined
description: The investigative staff of the Chicago Board Options Exchange has examined on four occasions during the past year unusual activity in the trading of options in CBS Inc. stock, a spokesman for the exchange said today.

title: MACHINE TOOLS OFF 9.3%
description: New orders for American machine tools dropped 9.3 percent in August from July's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Washington Watch; Close Look at Sumitomo Deal
description: The $500 million investment by Japan's Sumitomo Bank in Wall Street's Goldman, Sachs & Company is creating a lot of soul-searching at the Federal Reserve Board. The central bank is holding a public hearing Oct. 10 on pros and cons of the proposed transaction.

title: People Who Live Somewhere Meet People Who Live Nowhere
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOWCASE The Paine Webber Gallery has been developing as a grand, main-floor showcase in midtown for the artworks of smaller museums, art galleries and similar institutions situated elsewhere in the city. The 4,000-square-foot gallery is divided between two sides of the big Paine Webber lobby at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street.

title: Now Simplify the State Tax
description: It's not a trick. The new Federal tax law will reduce the amount most New Yorkers owe Washington for earnings in 1987 and beyond. But there is a catch. Unless the state income tax system is also revised, the Federal reform would sharply increase payments due to Albany. Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have promised to change the law to eliminate the state's inadvertent windfall. The $2 billion question is how.

title: PEOPLE WHO LIVE SOMEWHERE MEET PEOPLE WHO LIVE NOWHERE
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Deregulation Has Not Worked as Promised
description: To the Editor:

title: 20TH GAME FOR CHESS TITLE IS DRAWN AFTER 21ST MOVE
description: Gary Kasparov, the defending world chess champion, and Anatoly Karpov agreed today to a draw after 21 moves in the 20th game of their title match.

title: SUIT SEEKS REMOVAL OF CROSS AT MARINE BASE
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and 15 individuals of various religious faiths have filed suit in Federal District Court seeking to force the Marine Corps to remove a huge cross from the military base here. The case is expected to go to trial in Honolulu in November.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include a one-time pre-tax charge of $151,000 for the settlement of a lawsuit and a one-time pre-tax gain of $448,000 from the sale of a Canadian business. Results for the year-ago periods include a charge of $98,000 for the quarter and a one-time charge of $128,000 for the year, both from the disposition of warehouses and the discontinuance of certain products.

title: YANKEES WIN, BUT MATTINGLY GOES 0 FOR 3
description: When Don Mattingly was walked intentionally in the seventh inning last night, Yankee Stadium fans booed lustily. When Dave Winfield, the next batter, bounced a single into center field, they cheered just as lustily.

title: 76ers in Trade
description: The Philadelphia 76ers yesterday sent a center, Clemon Johnson, and a No. 1 draft pick to the Seattle SuperSonics for a center, Tim McCormick, and a forward, Danny Vranes. . . . The Indiana Pacers placed Dwayne McClain on waivers yesterday. McClain, a 6-6 guard, was a second-round draft pick out of Villanova in 1985.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FEDERAL PANEL ISSUES PLAN FOR REVAMPING
description: A special commission today issued a 200-page draft report designed to end sentencing practices that have resulted in wide disparities in the length of prison terms for Federal offenders.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL ON SANCTIONS
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 313 to 83 by which the House voted today to override President Reagan's veto of Congressional sanctions against the South African Government. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to override the veto. Voting ''yes'' were 232 Democrats and 81 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 4 Democrats and 79 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. ''Present'' denotes those who voted they were present at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There are 3 vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Ralston Loss on Anderson
description: The Ralston Purina Company will lose about $7 million on its unsuccessful battle for Anderson, Clayton & Company, sources close to Ralston said in St. Louis yesterday.

title: 'UNHELPFUL' ALLEGATIONS ON TAXIS DISMISSED IN '82
description: A few months after becoming City Investigation Commissioner in 1982, Patrick W. McGinley dismissed as ''unhelpful, to say the least'' allegations of corruption at the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: COMSAT, CONTEL PLAN TO MERGE
description: Comsat, struggling to recover the growth rates it grew accustomed to in the early days of communications satellites, said yesterday that it would merge with the Contel Corporation in an exchange of stock worth about $2.4 billion.

title: SUDAN REBELS WON'T ACCEPT NEW PLAN FOR AIRLIFT OF FOOD
description: The Sudanese rebels said today that they would not provide safe passage to an emergency airlift of relief aid to Government-held areas of the southern Sudan and they repeated an order to their commanders to shoot down unauthorized planes.

title: FIRST CABLE TV INDICTMENT RETURNED BY QUEENS JURY
description: A Queens grand jury returned the first indictment yesterday in a months-long investigation into allegations of bribery in the awarding of cable television franchises in the borough.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes after-tax gains of $7.4 million from the sale of securities and $1.2 million from the settlement of litigation. c-Net loss

title: EUROPEAN SOCIALISTS PREPARE FOR EFFORT TO REORIENT NATO
description: In a novel undertaking, the Socialist parties of Western Europe have started to coordinate their policies toward the Atlantic alliance and are challenging some of NATO's central tenets and watershed decisions.

title: McCONKEY REACQUIRED BY GIANTS
description: The Giants learned today that Lionel Manuel, their best wide receiver, would be lost for at least several weeks with a sprained left knee. They found a replacement by trading with the Green Bay Packers for Phil McConkey, a wide receiver and punt returner the Giants cut in training camp.

title: JACOB B. AGUS
description: Rabbi Jacob B. Agus, who promoted dialogue between Christians and Jews and wrote about Jewish history and philosophy, died Friday at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore. He was 74 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: JERSEYANS TO CONSIDER BOND ON CLEANUP OF TOXIC WASTE
description: New Jersey voters will be asked to approve a $200 million bond issue for hazardous-waste cleanup in the Nov. 4 election. Governor Kean announced today that he had signed the bill calling for the referendum.

title: 'MURDER IN THREE ACTS'
description: WITH tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, ''Agatha Christie's 'Murder in Three Acts,' '' Peter Ustinov will have played the Belgian detective Hercule Poirot five times on film. With each succeeding impersonation, however, Mr. Ustinov seems to have become more superficial, relying on assorted tics and mannerisms designed, it seems, to amuse himself as much as the audience. In this latest Poirot caper, Mr. Ustinov's performance is one unrelieved ''shtick'' from beginning to end.

title: Ex-Litton Aide Pleads Guilty
description: A former executive of Litton Systems Inc. pleaded guilty today to masterminding a $6.3 million plot to cheat the United States Government through inflated defense contracts.

title: HIGH HONDURAN OFFICERS OUSTED
description: Honduran officials said today that three high military officers had been dismissed on charges of plotting to oust the chief of the armed forces.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $115,714 and $230,523 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: MUSIC: SONG CYCLES OF 20'S AND 30'S
description: WE are a nation surprisingly oblivious to our own musical history. So a Sunday afternoon program called ''American Song Cycles of the 1920's and 1930's,'' presented at the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church by an organization called the Alliance for American Song, would have deserved support even if it had been much less rewarding than it was.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $510,000 for an inventory adjustment and a charge of $345,000 from an adjustment to the allowance for possible losses.

title: PRESIDENTS TO HEAR PROPOSALS
description: Proposals calling for major changes in the rules governing college sports, including shorter seasons and fewer athletic scholarships, are to be put before a group of college presidents this week.

title: MICHAELS, J INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boycott Threatened On Seoul Charter Plan
description: Opposition leaders warned today that they would boycott sessions of a committee formed to revise South Korea's Constitution unless President Chun Doo Hwan met with them.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Includes income of $59,575, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $119,150, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months, due to early compliance with Financial Accounting Standard No. 87, the ''Employers Accounting for Pensions.'' c-Net income and includes extraordinary tax credits of $58,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 6 months.

title: Article 990586 -- No Title
description: A Manhattan judge set $150,000 bail yesterday for Robert E. Chambers Jr. despite a written plea from the family of the young woman Mr. Chambers is accused of murdering last month in Central Park that bail be denied.

title: Webb Sale Set
description: The British Printing and Communication Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Webb Company, a Minnesota-based printing and publishing group, for $117 million.

title: A Farewell to Russia, With a Russian Poem
description: As Nicholas S. Daniloff left Moscow, he read a poem by Mikhail Lermontov.

title: Royal Is Bought Out
description: The Kansas City Royals have chosen to exercise a $300,000 buyout on the next year of Dennis Leonard's contract. But they will invite the 35-year-old right-hander, who has injury-plagued knees, to spring training next year for a look.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPT. CRITICIZED OVER CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Civil rights and equal employment at the Agriculture Department are sometimes given ''insufficient attention'' until there are formal complaints, according to an internal report.

title: HEALTH-CARE SERIES ON 13
description: MODERN medicine raises legions of moral, social and legal issues; ''Managing Our Miracles: Health Care in America'' examines them. The new 10-part series, beginning on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, joins experts and other interested parties in discussion. In terms of television, the best parts may be where they disagree.

title: Flooding Abates in West; 4 Towns Face Threat
description: North Montana's worst flooding in 34 years, which forced at least 350 people from their homes and drowned hundreds of cattle, slowly subsided at the hardest hit areas today but threatened four other small towns.

title: Empty House Searched; Fugitive Still at Large
description: Searchers surrounded a house where a fugitive was believed to be hiding today but found no trace of the murder suspect in a raid at dawn, prompting a scaling down of the manhunt.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. EXPOS, at Montreal, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: SPANIARDS FEAR AN INFLUX OF ARAB TERRORISTS
description: The crackdown in France on Arab-related terrorism has raised fears in Spain that many suspected Arab terrorists are shifting their bases here, Spanish officials said.

title: Sibling Rivalry
description: Greg Maddux gave his older brother a pitching lesson in Philadelphia last night as he and the Chicago Cubs beat Mike Maddux and the Phillies, 8-3. It was the first time two brothers faced each other as starters in the major leagues since Joe and Phil Niekro met as members of the Houston Astros and Atlanta Braves on Sept. 13, 1982.

title: THE ORIGIN OF 'PURSUIT': ONE IMAGE
description: In the beginning there was only a vision in the playwright's mind. ''I had this image of a gramophone in a room at Cambridge, and these people listening to music,'' says Simon Gray. ''It had haunted me for years. I kept thinking about following their lives through the years, these people who were all blissfully unaware of what I had in store for them.''

title: Aquino Autobiography Set by Random House
description: The autobiography of President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines, will be published by Random House, the company announced yesterday.

title: THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CONABLE'S CAUTIOUS APPROACH
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., who for the last three months has headed the World Bank, faces his first annual meeting Tuesday of the bank's stockholders -151 governments representing most of mankind.

title: New Soviet Envoy to Syria
description: Aleksandr S. Dzasokhov, first deputy chairman of the Asian-African Solidarity Committee, has been appointed Ambassador to Syria. He replaces Feliks N. Fedotov, a career diplomat, who has been in the Damascus post for two years.

title: Increase in Oil Rigs
description: The number of working oil rigs in the country rose for the fourth week in a row, to 806, an increase of 42 from the previous week's 764, Hughes Tool Company officials said today. Last year at this time, the count was 1,935. In the previous week, the rig count had increased by 25.

title: PANEL URGES RELAXATION IN GENETIC SPLICING RULES
description: The Government's most prestigious advisory panel on genetic engineering proposed today a change in national safety guidelines that would remove from special scrutiny experiments of a kind that have produced major controversies in recent years.

title: Pilot Dies in Crash Near Chicago Airport
description: A twin-engine propeller plane carrying copies of the national edition of The New York Times crashed and burned in a residential neighborhood here Sunday night shortly after takeoff from Midway Airport.

title: MINORCO MINERALS & REOURCES CORP LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Marine Midland
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. said that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board planned to begin an administrative proceeding to challenge Marine Midland's acquisition of the Westchester Financial Services Corporation, which took effect at midnight Sunday. The two banks have disputed the board's authority to put conditions on their $106 million merger. A spokesman for the bank board in Washington declined to comment.

title: NO TRADE IS MADE, PRESIDENT ASSERTS
description: White House officials, seeking to deflect speculation of possible concessions in gaining freedom for Nicholas S. Daniloff, said today that no conditions had been attached to his release.

title: George R. Cooley Dies at 90; Established Professorships
description: George R. Cooley, an Albany securities broker who established one of the country's first professorships in peace studies at Colgate University in 1972, died Saturday at his home in Rensselaerville, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: EARLY NEGOTIATIONS CAN BENEFIT PLAYERS
description: It is now a fairly common practice in the National Football League for players to begin negotiating their next contract with a year or more remaining on their current contract. What happened to Tim Lewis, the Green Bay Packers' cornerback who was forced to retire after injuring his neck last Monday night, illustrates why doing so is in a player's best interest.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Hard Labors: Bridge Delays
description: Add the Third Street Bridge over Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal to the list of New York City's public construction disappointments.

title: KEVIN CLUESS
description: Kevin Cluess, a former St. John's University basketball star, died Sunday at Sloane Kettering Memorial Hospital of leukemia. He was 33 years old.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The net income represents net investment income.

title: DOW OFF 14.49 ON ALLIES' RATE STAND
description: Wall Street's disappointment over the inability of the United States and its major trading partners to agree on further interest rate reductions caused stock prices to decline moderately yesterday.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL CHECKING T.V.A. ON TENNESSEE REACTOR'S SAFETY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating the actions of top nuclear power officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority after concluding that one of them made ''false statements'' about the safety and readiness of one of its nuclear reactors, according to a commission memorandum.

title: Lockheed Rebuffs U.S.
description: The Lockheed Corporation today formally challenged Air Force claims that the company overcharged the Government by as much as $500 million for its C-5B cargo aircraft.

title: Sugar Ray Redux
description: It's been seven months since he was booted out of the National Basketball Association for repeated cocaine use, and now Micheal Ray Richardson has finally entered a treatment center: Regent Hospital on East 61st Street, where he underwent several weeks of the same kind of care three years ago. Why so long before Richardson sought help? ''The reality of it takes some time to sink in,'' says Charles Grantham, his confidant and former agent.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is there a link between aluminum and Alzheimer's disease? A.Scientists have found heavy concentrations of aluminum in the brains of people who died of Alzheimer's disease, but there is no conclusive evidence so far of a direct link between the two, according to Dr. David Wekstein of the Sanders-Brown Research Center on Aging at the University of Kentucky. Alzheimer's disease is a degenerative brain condition that causes memory loss and affects mainly the elderly. Some studies have found no traces of aluminum in the brains of Alzheimer's patients; others have revealed other substances such as bromine, mercury and silicon, Dr. Wekstein said. This has led scientists to believe that the disease may break down the barrier that normally prevents metals from reaching the brain. People consume aluminum every day in their drinking water, canned food and food cooked in aluminum pans, Dr. Wekstein said, adding that there is no reason to avoid it. Q.Could an individual ant be expected to survive if it was removed from its colony and placed in a foreign one of the same species? A.The ant would probably be killed or chased away from the foreign colony, according to Dr. David Inouye, professor of zoology at the Unversity of Maryland. Among social insects such as ants and bees, he said, each individual colony has a specific odor produced by pheromones, substances secreted by the insects to convey information and to produce certain responses.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WORLD WILDLIFE FUND BEGINS A 'NEW ALLIANCE'
description: The World Wildlife Fund proclaimed ''a new and powerful alliance'' today between conservation groups and religious organizations as its 25th anniversary celebrations ended with an interfaith ceremony conducted by leaders of five major religions.

title: Global Investors Honed Their Skills at Du Pont
description: David Marvin, who was vice president and manager of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's $10 billion pension fund, and Stanley Palmer, who was in charge of its international equity management, have formed their own investment company to specialize in global equity investment.

title: PROSECUTION STALLED IN GOTTI CASE
description: The plans of Federal prosecutors to open their case against John Gotti and six co-defendants with dramatic testimony from a witness who last year helped convict a state judge of bribe-taking ran into an unexpected snag yesterday.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for 12mo to Aug 31
BADILLO IN UPHILL RACE FOR COMPTROLLER
description: ''Because I was a whiz kid,'' Herman Badillo laughed in an interview at his sparsely furnished midtown campaign office, ''everybody thinks I died a long time ago, or that I'm 90 years old.''

title: MERRILL LYNCH SET TO QUIT REAL ESTATE
description: Pulling back from its commitment to run a financial supermarket with a diverse array of businesses, Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had decided to sell its large real estate services operations to focus more on its basic securities businesses, particularly in the international arena.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $12,651,947 from discontinued operations.

title: Careers; Downtrend In Bonuses Indicated
description: SLOW inflation, the tax bill, and the emphasis on cost control have all combined to encourage companies to take a new look at their pay and perquisites.

title: KEY RATES
Boxer May Leave Series
description: Butch Lewis is going to try to withdraw Michael Spinks from the HBO heavyweight championship unification series, Don King, Lewis's promotion partner in the series, said yesterday. Lewis has called a news conference for tomorrow in New York.

title: Toeholds In the Record Books
description: Pat Leahy isn't the only kicker who's zeroing in on the N.F.L. record for consecutive successful field-goal attempts.

title: LOS ANGELES BREAKS GROUND IN METRO RAIL PROJECT
description: Symbolic shovels of dirt were raised today as ground was broken for a long-discussed subway project, Metro Rail, designed to bring back rapid transit to Los Angeles after a quarter of a century.

title: Chief Operating Officer Is Promoted at Armco
description: Armco Inc., the steel company, announced yesterday that its board had named Robert L. Purdum president. Mr. Purdum, 51 years old, succeeds Robert E. Boni, 58, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: CUOMO CRITICIZES D'AMATO'S RECORD
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday criticized the record of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, saying he had cast votes that were ''bad for us'' as New Yorkers.

title: 'SHOOT TO KILL' ULSTER ISSUE: RIGHTS GROUP FAULTS BRITISH
description: Amnesty International accused the British Government today of having failed to conduct a proper investigation into charges that the Northern Irish police deliberately killed unarmed civilians suspected of being members of the Irish Republican Army.

title: ISRAEL INDICTS MAN IN TREBLINKA CASE
description: Israel today formally charged John Demjanjuk, a retired American auto worker, with crimes against humanity for what it said was his role in torturing Jews on their way to the gas chambers at the Treblinka death camp.

title: IN OIL-POOR OKLAHOMA, ANGRY VOTERS LOOK FOR SCAPEGOATS AND FOR SAVIORS
description: Alexander Holmes, an economist at the University of Oklahoma, invokes the words of the country singer Kris Kristofferson to sum up the attitude here these days: ''The goin' up,'' the ballad proclaims, ''weren't worth the comin' down.''

title: SWEET VICTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Viacom Studies Sale of Stations
description: Viacom International, the diversified media company that is seeking to go private through a leveraged buyout, said today that it was considering selling its broadcasting stations to help finance its $2.7 billion bid.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BancOklahoma President Quits
description: The BancOklahoma Corporation said that Samuel B. Hayes 3d had resigned as president and chief operating officer of the troubled bank holding company and its Tulsa, Okla., unit, effective Oct. 1.

title: NOT A TRADE, PRESIDENT SAYS
description: The Soviet Union yesterday freed Nicholas S. Daniloff, the American journalist who had been confined to Moscow for the last month on spying charges.

title: ROBERTSON'S CAMP HOPES TO CAPTURE VAST TV EVANGELICAL VOTE IN NATION
description: Bound by a common theology and the spreading sensation that their number is great and their time and leader have come, the Rev. Pat Robertson's brother Pentecostal and charismatic evangelists are stirring to his still-unannounced quest for the Republican nomination for the Presidency.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLAY IT AGAIN, YOGI World Series time, 1952. A subway series. The Dodgers, the Brooklyn Dodgers, to be sure, are one game up on the Yankees in their bid for a championship. The sixth and seventh games are swept by those unbeatable Yankees, and Brooklyn has to wait until 1955 to capture baseball's crown. You missed this sports thrill as it unfolded at Ebbets Field? Thanks to the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street (752-4690), you now have a chance to catch up.

title: OPERA: ANTHONY DAVIS'S 'X' IN PREMIERE
description: OPERA means many different things to many different people. One meaning with a long history is opera as musically accompanied declamation, which is how ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X)'' struck this reviewer in its formal world premiere Sunday night at the New York City Opera. The scenario amounts to an authorized, romanticized biography of the black separatist leader whose assassination in 1965 made him a legend and, to some, a hero. At the heart of the story, as set to music by Anthony Davis, is a power struggle between Malcolm X and his mentor, Elijah Muhammad, for control of the Black Muslim movement. Of such confrontations has many an opera been made, of course.

title: Retton Retires
description: At an age when most people are embarking on their careers, 18-year-old Mary Lou Retton announced yesterday she was retiring and would concentrate on school. ''My decision to retire was based on my feeling that I have achieved the goals as a gymnast that I set out for myself several years ago,'' said Miss Retton, who vaulted to fame, fortune and a picture on Wheaties boxes in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Bridge: Attack on Communications Makes for Interesting Play
description: Some of the prettiest plays in the game, for both the declarer and the defenders, concern an attack on communications. An example is the diagramed deal noted recently by Simon Klein of Halesite, L.I.

title: JOURNALISTS SEE A DECLINE IN PRESS FREEDOM IN ASIA
description: Malaysia's three-month ban on distribution of The Asian Wall Street Journal and the expulsion of the newspaper's two reporters are part of a disquieting trend toward diminished press freedom in several parts of Asia, according to journalists and experts on the region.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,377,000. The company said earnings for the latest second quarter and 6 months were reduced by 2 cents a share and 4 cents a share, respectively, because of a change in the method of valuating inventory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1986
description: Markets

title: NEW RESORT WEAR, FANCIFUL AND WEARABLE
description: An artfully draped, stretchy bathing suit by Donna Karan becomes an evening dress when a crinoline and a bouffant skirt are added. A crisply tailored white silk jacket is gaily sprinkled with red bows and a sultry black sweater glows with gold stars - both are by Perry Ellis. Gently flowing wraps are based on kimonos, by Louis Dell'Olio for Anne Klein; shirtdresses are striped like candy canes and bare-shouldered silk sundresses are cheerfully patterned in madras plaids by Ralph Lauren.

title: Whose Foreign Policy?
description: Stung by Congress on foreign issues twice in a week, President Reagan has twice threatened to shoot back, and has already done so once. Yet this week he may suffer startling defeat as Congress votes to override. Who's in charge here?

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a charge of $545,000 for the writedown of excess and obsolete inventories.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I have something of a news announcement I would like to make.

title: RUSSIANS IGNORE REAGAN'S OFFER TO SELL WHEAT
description: President Reagan's offer to sell 3.85 million metric tons of subsidized American wheat to the Soviet Union expires on Tuesday, and Moscow has shown no interest.

title: The Real Danger in Seoul
description: South Korea is threatened by Communist armies of the North and by a protectionism that could suffocate its export economy. Yet its rulers focus on what they seem to regard an even larger threat: a democratic election. Their preventing one may be the greatest danger.

title: U.N. SPEAKERS TACKLE DRUGS, TERROR AND WAR
description: The Foreign Minister of Pakistan said today that a million Afghans had died since the Soviet Union swept into Afghanistan nearly seven years ago.

title: JACKSON PURSUES PERSONAL STYLE OF FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson led 50 people on a protest march outside the Japanese Embassy on Friday. They were demanding an apology for Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's suggestion that blacks and other minority groups had held back educational progress in the United States, compared with Japan. They got what they came for.

title: Government Announces Plan To Explode a Nuclear Device
description: The Department of Energy announced Sunday that it would set off a large atomic test explosion 2,000 feet below ground Tuesday. Tenants in high-rise buildings were warned to expect some swaying.

title: Aircraft Contractor Pays Fine
description: The Air Force lifted a suspension against an Alabama aircraft maintenance contractor today after executives agreed to pay more than $2 million in fines, damages and restitution.

title: THEATER: 'HEARTBREAK HOUSE' AT YALE
description: ''Heartbreak House'' is Shaw's melancholic contemplation of the decline of England and the death of heroism. A play conceived in the Chekhovian manner, it has been regarded as Shaw's ''Cherry Orchard,'' as an old social order finds itself swept aside by world disorder. ''Heartbreak House'' is ''a house without foundations,'' a ship of state - and a ship of stage -that is sinking.

title: SNORING LINKED TO IMPAIRED THINKING
description: Although most people who snore have nothing to worry about, except the annoyance they may cause their bed companions, a University of Florida medical researcher reported last week that in some people this noisy behavior may be associated with impaired thinking.

title: Series Tickets on Sale
description: The Mets, who sold their small public allotment of playoff tickets within five hours Sunday, said yesterday that they would sell ''a limited number of reserved seats'' for the World Series by telephone, starting Thursday at 7 P.M.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writedowns of oil and gas properties of $56 million for the quarter and $388 million for the year. The latest year also included a gain of $8,837,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-After an extraordinary charge of $2,345,000 from early repayment of debt for the quarter and year.

title: T I M E-DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $250,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $283,000.

title: ROOM FOR DARWIN AND THE BIBLE
description: The argument over whether (or how) the scientific theory of evolution should be taught in our public schools, as against the religious doctrine of ''creationism,'' generates high passions. The consequence, alas, is that the debate has become a dogmatic crusade on both sides, and our educators, school administrators and textbook publishers find themselves trapped in the middle.

title: How Can It Be Worse for South African Blacks?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SEES DANGERS IN CHIP LAG
description: The Federal Government is growing increasingly concerned that a rapid deterioration of the American microelectronics industry will leave the United States dependent on other nations for computer chips.

title: ONE OF MATH'S MAJOR PROBLEMS REPORTED SOLVED
description: TWO mathematicians in England and Portugal have announced that they have proved one of the most important, longstanding problems in mathematics, the Poincare conjecture - setting off a heated and sometimes emotional flurry of talks, seminar sessions and analysis that will occupy many of their colleagues for months to come.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $337,000 and $873,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: End Warehousing
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH BAGELS, WINE AND FANFARE, PAN AM SHUTTLE TAKES ON EASTERN
description: After six weeks of furious construction on a still-unfinished terminal at La Guardia Airport, the new Pan Am Shuttle is to begin challenging the prototype Eastern Air Lines Air-Shuttle tomorrow for a major share of the 4 million passengers who fly annually between New York City, Washington and Boston.

title: Blyleven Sets Homer Mark
description: Bert Blyleven of the Minnesota Twins set a major-league record tonight for most home runs allowed in a season when he yielded his 47th homer pitching against the Cleveland Indians.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Hard Labors: Brown in the Bronx
description: A shiny apple to Paul Lipson, a Brown University senior who mobilized a dozen students this summer to transform a garbage-strewn lot in the South Bronx into a neighborhood park. The terraced gardens, vegetable beds and picnic areas demonstrate a spirit of community service Mr. Lipson, with family roots in the Bronx, was inspired by former President Carter's housing restoration work with Habitat for Humanity on the Lower East Side.

title: COWBOYS ROUT CARDINALS, 31-7
description: Danny White passed for 223 yards and three touchdowns to lead the Dallas Cowboys to a 31-7 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: How Can It Be Worse for South African Blacks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Robins Postpones Filing Its Plan
description: The A. H. Robins Company has postponed the filing of its proposed reorganization plan. At a hearing in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Richmond, a judge extended until Feb. 5 the date in which Robins has the exclusive right to propose a reorganization plan.

title: NMS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The latest loss was attributed to development costs for its over-the- counter consumer product line, a $236,100 writedown of unprofitable assets and losses from development of subsidiaries.

title: Colt Linebacker Out
description: Barry Krauss, the Indianapolis Colts' linebacker and leading tackler this season, suffered ligament and cartilage damage to his right knee in Sunday's loss to the Jets and will be out for the rest of the season, Coach Rod Dowhower said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alabama Federal Savings and Loan Association, Birmingham, has accepted the resignation of James H. Gamill as president, chief operating officer and director.

title: Fairness in Media Makes CBS Filing
description: Fairness in Media, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, has cited news accounts of recent executive changes at CBS Inc. to support its assertions that control of the giant network had changed without approval of the regulatory agency.

title: POLICIES OF U.S. ETHICS AGENCY ARE HOTLY DEBATED AT CAPITOL
description: The Office of Government Ethics came under scathing Congressional criticism today and was described as ''a toothless terrier on Valium,'' but the agency's director said he preferred to work quietly to make sure that Federal officials maintained high ethical standards.

title: Uncharted Adventures
description: This World War II capital of China during the Japanese occupation once again has a special role to play. It is the largest of the ''experimental cities,'' indeed the largest city in China, with 14 million compared with Shanghai's 12 million. And it is expected to demonstrate that urban reform can transform the industrial cities the way agricultural reform has changed the countryside.

title: JUDGE VOIDS WHITE SUBURB'S LAW RESTRICTING PARKS
description: A judge today struck down Dearborn's law barring nonresidents from parks, which had been challenged by civil rights groups who said it was enacted to keep blacks out of the virtually all-white suburb.

title: Wal-Mart Venture
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Cullum Companies said they planned to build a series of large combination food and general merchandise stores, as a joint venture. The stores, which will be known as Wal-Mart Super Centers, will cover 150,000 square feet each, and their opening is scheduled for late next year.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Moscow Reports Restart Of a Chernobyl Reactor
description: One of the four reactors at the Chernobyl nuclear plant was restarted today for the first time since the disaster in the No. 4 reactor five months ago, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported.

title: INDUSTRIES, IN SHIFT, AREN'T LETTING STRIKES STOP THEM
description: More and more employers, under pressure to reduce costs, are hiring permanent replacements at lower wages to fill the jobs of union members who strike or are locked out in strikes.

title: 4TH BUILDINGS AIDE DISMISSED
description: The city's Buildings Commissioner, Charles M. Smith Jr., said yesterday that he had dismissed another employee in his department in connection with the use of marijuana and cocaine at after-hours office parties.

title: Minnesota County Sets Refund Issue
description: Hennepin County, Minnesota, is offering $134.5 million of bonds to refund revenue notes for solid-waste resource recovery, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Where Winning Isn't Anything
description: One of the zaniest phenomena in all of sports is simply a matter of routine on the Nascar circuit, where the driver who wins the greatest number of races, grabs most of the headlines and is thus the focus of fan attention frequently winds up losing the season title. Last year, for instance, Bill Elliott exercised all but total domination of the Winston Cup series, winning better than a third of the 28 races on the schedule, yet finished second in the standing to Darrell Waltrip, who won only three times. ''What the fans notice,'' says Steve Waid, executive editor of the weekly stock-car newspaper Grand National Scene, ''is that Bill Elliott won 11 races and $2 million, and he's not the champion.''

title: CHANNEL 31 TO ADD POWER AND SHOWS
description: When its fall programming season begins Wednesday, Channel 31 will offer viewers in the New York metropolitan region a stronger, clearer signal from a new $2.8 million transmitter atop the World Trade Center and a somewhat different public-television schedule that is an ambitious mix of original programming, repackaged drama and documentary series and new acquisitions from producers around the world.

title: FEW LEGISLATORS READY TO COMMENT ON RELEASE
description: Members of Congress, as much in the dark as the rest of the public about the release of Nicholas S. Daniloff, for the most part withheld comment today.

title: LANDMARK WILL ADD A MUSEUM
description: Officials gathered on the steps of the Federal Hall National Memorial at 26 Wall Street yesterday to announce plans for its restoration and for the creation within its historic walls of a computer-based museum devoted to the Constitution.

title: INFORMER CALLS PERSICO COLOMBO BOSS
description: A key Mafia informer testified yesterday that Carmine Persico was the ''real boss'' of the Colombo crime family, even when he was in prison.

title: Closing Inquiry Door
description: At a time when the Economic Regulatory Administration of the Department of Energy is swamped with reports of oil industry overcharges of buyers, including the Federal Government, legislators friendly to the oil industry have managed to slip a cutoff date for bringing action into a pending bill to reconcile the budget.

title: HOUSE, 313 TO 83, AFFIRMS SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The House of Representatives brushed aside a new proposal by President Reagan today and voted decisively to override his veto of a bill imposing stiff economic sanctions on the South African Government.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column of the Travel section on Sunday omitted a step of the procedure for applying for visas to visit France and its territories. A traveler applying in person to a French consulate must fill out an application form, available from a travel agent or at the consulate, and supply a current passport, a color photograph of passport size (2 inches by 2 inches) and cash or a money order for the visa. A three-month visa is $9, a one-year visa is $15 and a 72-hour transit visa is $3.

title: Mobay Corp. Disc Resin
description: The Mobay Corporation has begun production of a high-purity polycarbonate resin for use in the manufacture of compact audio discs and digital storage memories, and will build a compact disc research laboratory in Pittsburgh, the company said today. Mobay, a subsidiary of Bayer USA Inc. and Bayer A.G. of Leverkusen, West Germany, added that the resin, Makrolon CD-2000, is being made at its plant in Baytown, Tex. It said the plant can produce up to 50 million pounds annually.

title: INSIDE
description: War-Crime Charge in Israel Israel charged John Demjanjuk, a retired American auto worker, for what it said was his role in torturing Jews in World War II.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debtuf812>

title: JUDGE TO OPEN RECORD OF GRAFT-TRIAL HEARING
description: Judge Whitman Knapp, who is presiding over the Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman and four co-defendants, has decided to release an edited version of the transcripts of closed hearings between defense and prosecution lawyers last week, the judge's law clerk said today.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest year includes non-recurring gains of $1,750,000 from technology access fees. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Guarding the Titanic
description: In a few days, President Reagan is expected to sign a bill designed to control the taking of artifacts or other activities that could ruin archeological and historical studies of the sunken Titanic.

title: FOR CITY PEOPLE, AN AUTUMNAL DAY IN THE ORCHARD
description: Oh, the City People are coming! This time of year, some primeval force stirs deep within them, moving the City People to get into their cars on Sunday mornings and drive north, for a day in the country. They will look at leaves, pay to pick apples, and then they will go back to where they came from, feeling whole again.

title: Close the Book on Judge Claiborne
description: If a Federal judge already convicted and imprisoned for tax-dodging should not be removed from office, who should? Thus defined, the Senate's choice in the case of Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada ought to be simple.

title: Hitachi Cuts Pay
description: Hitachi Ltd. has announced a six-month plan to slash its executives' salaries by 5 percent to 10 percent to offset the yen's sharp rise, which has reduced profitability. Hitachi's pay cuts will affect about 6,800 employees, including members of the board, whose salaries will be cut by 10 percent. Officials refused to say how much the company expected to save.

title: Gift for Fresh Air Fund
description: When business affairs call a wealthy Egyptian, Mohamed al-Fayed, to New York, he usually manages to crowd in some time for another interest - philanthropy. Last month, a visit led to a $100,000 contribution to the city's Meals-on-Wheels program to buy holiday dinners for the elderly.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Red Tape 0, Love 1
description: As a result of a waiver of a visa requirement, a young Israeli will now be permitted to stay in this country with her husband and apply for permanent residence.

title: SYNDICATE IN FIAT SALE FACES LOSS
description: Investment bankers participating in one of the largest offerings of equity securities ever undertaken in the world's capital markets said yesterday they expect their underwriting syndicate to suffer losses of between $100 million to $200 million on the deal. The offering is of $2.1 billion worth of shares in Fiat S.p.A. They are part of the stake in the Italian automobile maker sold by Libya last week and purchased by the Agnelli family and the underwriting group.

title: It's Past Time to Crush The Terrorist Monster
description: I believe that the pogrom in Istanbul, in which Arab terrorists with automatic weapons mowed down 21 elderly Jews praying in a synagogue, was the gravest incident in Jewish history since the founding of Israel in 1948 - a prime example of the boundless brutality of Palestinian-Arab terrorism. Perhaps for the first time, the shock felt by world public opinion matched Israel's own sense of outrage. But outrage is not enough.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its prior year results reflect the operations of Omega Enterprises Inc. for 12 months and the operations of Gaming & Technology for 6 months. Gaming acquired Omega Jan. 1, 1985, but it said it treated the acquisition for accounting purposes as if it had been bought by Omega.

title: CLEARING OF DONOVAN IN '82 INQUIRY IS DENIED
description: A former special Federal prosecutor rejected suggestions by a defense lawyer yesterday that he had cleared former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan of wrongdoing four years ago.

title: BOMBS ROCK IDAHO CITY TORN BY STRIFE OVER RACISTS
description: Three bomb blasts rocked downtown buildings here today, including one housing a Federal Bureau of Investigation office, and the Federal authorities began an intensive investigation.

title: VOLCKER-BAKER 'RIFT' CLOUDS POLICY
description: The apparent rift between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve is making it harder for other countries to fathom American policy and is perhaps reducing the chances of agreement for coordinated action on world trade imbalances, various foreign officials and private bankers indicated today.

title: Ex-Turkish Premier Surges in an Election
description: A former Turkish Prime Minister, Suleyman Demirel, who was toppled in 1980 by a military junta, received an unexpectedly strong show of support today in results from by-elections held Sunday. A political party that he supported won 24 percent of the votes, the returns showed.

title: ISRAELI LAWYERS IN A DISPUTE: MINISTRY VS. SECURITY AGENCY
description: A dispute between lawyers in the Justice Ministry and the security agency Shin Beth is hindering the Government's ability to sustain punishments imposed on suspected terrorists or security offenders, according to Justice Ministry sources.

title: SILENCE ABOUT SHUTTLE FLAW ATTRIBUTED TO PITFALLS OF PRIDE
description: PRIDE, self-deception and institutional loyalty were some of the factors that aerospace experts say kept the space agency from sounding alarm bells years ago when it discovered the flaw that would cause the Challenger disaster and embarked on sweeping efforts to fix it.

title: TENOR IN 'X' TALKS OF DEBUT AND OF BLACKS IN OPERA
description: The cast of Anthony Davis's new opera ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X)'' includes 33 singers making New York City Opera debuts, 31 of them blacks. Praise has been widespread, but perhaps the most striking performance of all is by the 40-year-old Thomas Young as Street, the hustler who leads the young Malcolm into crime, and then later as Elijah Muhammad.

title: FIELDS OF JETS SIDELINED
description: The Jets lost their General today, perhaps for as many as three games.

title: ON FLIGHT FROM MOSCOW, REFLECTIONS ON FREEDOM
description: Moments before the Lufthansa jumbo jet took off from the Moscow Airport in an unseasonable snow squall, Nicholas S. Daniloff lifted a glass of French champagne and toasted his imminent departure with his wife, Ruth.

title: China Oil Sales Resume
description: China has resumed spot market sales of its Taching crude oil after an eight-month break, sources in negotiations with the Chinese said today.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DYA;
Classes With Ginsberg
description: The publication in 1956 of his poem ''Howl'' shocked the literary establishment and made him an enfant terrible of American letters. But times change and tastes do, too, and yesterday Allen Ginsberg was appointed one of five new Distinguished Professors at the City University.

title: Candidate for H.R.A. Turns Down Position
description: Mayor Koch's latest choice to head the Human Resources Administration will not take the job because it would be too great a financial sacrifice for him, the Mayor said yesterday.

title: HUMANITIES PEER REVIEW IS FAULTED
description: When an article appears in a scholarly journal it is widely viewed with respect. After all, it comes with what might be called the Good Scholarship Seal of Approval: It has passed the muster of peer review or critical appraisal by a learned and objective jury of experts. The general impression, even in the academic world, is that these experts constantly demand scholarship that explores new intellectual ground.

title: 55 Miles an Hour
description: Every year, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration compiles data on how states are enforcing a speed limit of 55 miles an hour, a regulation that is under pressure in Congress. These figures show the percentage of auto traffic in each state found in 1985 to be moving faster than that.

title: Southland Financial Studies Asset Sale
description: The Southland Financial Corporation, a real estate development company, disclosed today that it was considering selling its assets, including a huge corporate headquarters center in Dallas. The company also said that its chairman and chief executive, Ben H. Carpenter, 62 years old, would step down at the end of the year for health reasons.

title: STATE OFFICIAL TO TESTIFY IN FILM DEATHS TRIAL
description: Testimony about waivers of state regulations on the hiring of children in the motion picture industry will be permitted in the trial of John Landis, who directed ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' a judge ruled today.

title: Wineries Give Deadline To Striking Workers
description: The Winery Employers Association, which represents some of California's largest wineries, today warned members of two striking unions to return to work by next Monday or be dismissed.

title: O'Neill's Boswell
description: When Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill completes his final term in the House this year, he will close a chapter of Congressional history. And future scholars of the O'Neill years will be greatly helped by a young staff aide to the Rules Committee, Eric Schwartz, who has compiled a record of the Massachusetts Democrat's thoughts and comments over six years.

title: DEXTER GORDON STARS IN ''ROUND MIDNIGHT'
description: NO actor could do what the great jazz saxophonist Dexter Gordon does in '' 'Round Midnight,'' Bertrand Tavernier's glowing tribute to the golden age of be-bop. Mr. Gordon, who stars in the film as an expatriate American named Dale Turner, becomes the very embodiment of the music itself. It's in his heavy-lidded eyes, in his hoarse, smoky voice, in the way his long, graceful fingers seem to be playing silent accompaniment to his conversation. It's even in the way he habitually calls anyone or anything ''Lady,'' as in ''Well, Lady Sweets, are you ready for tonight?'' In that instance, he's addressing his saxophone.

title: ARMY OFFICER IS SLAIN BY BEIRUT GUNMEN
description: A senior army officer was slain in East Beirut today as tension grew between Christian militiamen and troops loyal to President Amin Gemayel.

title: CANADIAN PARK FOR ECOLOGY AND SOVEREIGNTY
description: The scene is the banks of a frozen fiord less than 600 miles from the exact top of the world. The distance to the nearest tree is farther than the drive from Manhattan to Miami. Most days, the closest human is well over 100 miles away.

title: 5 Die in a Fire in Zagorsk
description: A fire swept through buildings at Zagorsk, a Russian Orthodox complex near Moscow, and caused ''loss of life,'' the Government press agency, Tass, said today.

title: LABORITES ACCUSE WEINBERGER OF 'INTERFERING'
description: The opposition Labor Party accused the Secretary of Defense, Casper W. Weinberger, today of ''interfering'' in British politics but sought to play down the significance of his warning against its ''nonnuclear'' defense policy.

title: Panel Divided On Conrail
description: A House-Senate conference committee, struggling to reach agreement on a compromise measure to sell Conrail, remained divided today on some major issues. But the panel plans to continue discussing the legislation today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American City Business Journals, Kansas City, Mo., said it and Business Journal Publications of St. Louis would merge by Nov. 15. Shareholders of Business Journal Publications will receive about $40 million, an official at American City Business said.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Fund Report In Ryan Bid
description: NVHomes L.P., the Virginia- based home builder, said that the Maryland National Investment Banking Corporation had raised $170 million of the $360 million it needs to finance the $45-a-share bid for Ryan Homes Inc.

title: FEAR OF LOWER DOLLAR IS CITED
description: Treasury note and bond prices declined yesterday as traders worried that demand from foreign investors would diminish if the value of the dollar continued to fall.

title: Newmont Mining
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it has adopted a plan to recapitalize its Magma Copper Company unit.

title: DISMISSED STUDENT IS SUING STANFORD FOR LIBEL
description: A former student who was expelled from a Stanford University doctoral program on grounds of illegal and unethical conduct in a research project filed a civil lawsuit today charging the university with seriously damaging his professional reputation.

title: Moroccan Aide Denies Report Of Arrests in Synagogue Plot
description: A Government spokesman today denied a report that Morocco recently arrested a team of Palestinian terrorists planning to blow up a synagogue during Jewish New Year celebrations.

title: CANADIANS IN UPROAR OVER SRI LANKA'S ENVOY
description: The appointment of Gen. Tissa Indraka Weeratunga as Sri Lanka's envoy to Canada has touched off a furor here that has embarrassed both Sri Lanka and Canada. It has also strained the two nations' normally warm relations as members of the Commonwealth.

title: BEFORE DINOSAURS, ANOTHER CATASTROPHE
description: THREATENED with bombardment by boulders from above and inundation by 57-foot tides in the Bay of Fundy, researchers here are excavating fossils that they believe prove that a catastrophic extinction occurred 125 million years before the disappearance of the dinosaurs.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: IT seemed like old times at the Chelsea Hotel last week, where Sally Kirkland, a former Andy Warhol actress, was again filming a low-budget movie. ''Anna'' is a ''Star Is Born'' story of a Czech actress (Miss Kirkland) and her protegee, played by the Czech-born swimsuit and fashion model Paulina Porizkova in her first film role.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES Qtr to Aug 31 reports earnings for 1986
Buyout Offer For Mayflower
description: Mayflower Group Inc., the nation's fourth-largest household moving company, said today that a group led by senior management was trying to take the company private in a leveraged buyout.

title: Students Arrested in Protest
description: Fifteen students who defied a court order and erected a protest shanty on the Johns Hopkins University campus were arrested today and school officials used a dump truck to destroy the plywood structure.

title: Advertising; New Peril: The TV Flipper
description: ''TELEVISION is getting weaker as an advertising medium, but it's still the strongest thing we have,'' said Bertram Metter, chairman of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., whose recent discovery of cable television set some wheels in motion at the agency. It also led to the discovery of the flipper, who is partly responsible for the weakening.

title: FIXED-RATE IDEA INCHES FORWARD
description: The Reagan Administration's notion that countries collaborate in managing their economies has run into difficulty here. Instead, some diplomats are talking of reverting to the inflexible arrangements of the decades from World War II until the early 1970's.

title: PRAXIS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POWERFUL SOFTWARE DEALS WITH STATISTICS
description: ONE of my favorite books in college was a slim volume entitled ''How to Lie with Statistics.'' Though it was intended as a cautionary guide to the more easily introduced errors and hoodwinks encountered in numerical manipulation, I liked it because it supported my belief - or lack thereof - in the field.

title: National-Security Argument for a New York Home Port Sinks
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE ACTS AGAINST ALIENS' SHAM MARRIAGES
description: The House of Representatives voted today to stiffen Federal penalties for immigrants who use sham marriages with Americans to gain entry into the United States.

title: GROVE PRESS AND FOUNDER SETTLE DISPUTE
description: Grove Press announced today that it has settled its dispute with Barney Rosset, founder of the avant-garde publishing house and its president until he was removed from the position five months ago.

title: PLAN FOR SCHOOL DRUG TESTING DIVIDES TEXAS TOWN
description: Mary Dages, who teaches 12th-grade English, has a concerned but firm manner and an air of quiet authority that has made her one of the most respected teachers at Central High School here.

title: 600 LEAVE BMT AFTER A BLAZE
description: More than 600 people were led off stranded BMT trains in Manhattan yesterday when a fire interrupted service for two hours, the authorities said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1986
description: International

title: National Licensing Bill On Truckers Endorsed
description: The Senate has tentatively endorsed a proposal to establish nationwide licensing requirements for truck drivers and to crack down on drunken driving by commercial drivers.

title: Stroke Victim on Probation For Helping in Wife's Suicide
description: A stroke victim who pleaded guilty to helping his wife commit suicide was sentenced today to three years probation.

title: KIESLOWSKI'S 'NO END,' FROM POLAND
description: ''NO END,'' Krzysztof Kieslowski's 1984 Polish film that's only recently been made available abroad, is a dour, deadly serious contemplation of the effects of martial law on post-Solidarity Poland. Like some of Andrzej Wajda's work, it's also the sort of movie that can only be fully understood by someone with an initmate knowledge of the various twists and turns in recent Polish political history.

title: BIG POOLS, LOCAL BEER AND COCOA
description: The biggest news on the island of Kauai these days is that a developer is about to build what local officials call the world's biggest swimming pool.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writeoff of $1,330,000 of accounts receivable from a major distributor which ceased doing business in July 1986, and additional legal costs associated with this distributor's demise. c-Increased by out-of-court settlements of warranty and other claims, and were partially offset by the expense related to voluntary early retirements.

title: DIOGUARDI AND ABZUG PRESSING RACE FOR CONGRESS
description: Long before Bella S. Abzug beat three other Democrats in the primary earlier this month for Westchester's 20th Congressional District seat, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, the Republican incumbent, said he hoped she would win because it would draw national attention to the race.

title: 'Raining' Rings of Saturn
description: Saturn's rings may be raining and this ''ring rain'' may be responsible for cleaning parts of Saturn's atmosphere, affording scientists a better look at the planet, according to a theory advanced by a researcher at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md.

title: Grenada Invasion Was a Military, Political Success
description: To the Editor:

title: P.O.W.'S ALIVE IN VIETNAM, REPORT CONCLUDES
description: A Pentagon panel, after a five-month review of intelligence files, has concluded that American prisoners of war are still alive in Southeast Asia.

title: U.S. Aides Discuss Joint Space Venture
description: Representatives of NASA, the White House and the Departments of State and Defense traveled to the Soviet Union earlier this month to discuss possible future cooperation in space science, the space agency said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LIFE OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Vol. I: 1902-1941. I, Too, Sing America. By Arnold Rampersad. 468 pages. Illustrated. Oxford. $22.95.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS TO END ELECTRONIC MAIL SERVICE
description: The Federal Express Corporation said yesterday that it would end its electronic mail service known as Zapmail, as well as its plans to sell and lease facsimile equipment. The moves will result in a $340 million pretax write-off, the company said.

title: A PROGRAM FOR READING FASTER, BETTER
description: THE ''must read'' pile of books next to the desk now reaches halfway to the ceiling. The daily reading of newspapers, magazines, mail, memorandums and reports required for the job has become a full-time job in itself. The idea of killing a few hours with a trashy novel seems impossibly decadent.

title: MET TO RELABEL 2 OF ITS 'REMBRANDTS'
description: Last month, the two paintings were by Rembrandt van Rijn. Within days, the world will know them as ''from the workshop of Rembrandt.'' They will still be hanging, relabeled, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: ON E. 57TH, CHANEL'S AT NO. 5
description: Chanel's new boutique - its fifth free-standing shop in the United States - opened Sept. 18 at 5 East 57th Street. ''The number 5 has the magic touch for us,'' Kitty D'Alessio, president of Chanel Inc., said yesterday, meaning, of course, the enduring popularity of Chanel No. 5, the perfume introduced by Coco Chanel in 1921.

title: MUSIC: STRAUSS AT 92D ST. Y
description: THE Y Chamber Symphony, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, presented a characteristically bracing program at the 92d Street Y Saturday night - an all but unknown large orchestral work by Richard Strauss, the Divertimento (Op. 86); a clarinet concerto fashioned by Aaron Copland for Benny Goodman, and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 3 (''Scottish'').

title: Market Place; TV Shopper's 'Fifth Network'
description: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK INC., which has captivated bargain-hungry consumers by offering discount merchandise through cable television, has gone on its own shopping spree.

title: INQUIRY URGED ON SCHLUMBERGER'S CONTRACT BIDS
description: Two Democratic Congressmen today called for the Reagan Administration to investigate whether Schlumberger Ltd., the giant oilfield services company, has tried to win contracts from Arab or Moslem countries by agreeing not to do business with Israel.

title: Boston Student-Aid Plan Will Pay a Health Bonus
description: To the Editor:

title: Business and the Law; A Liquor Issue: Warning Label
description: EVERY single product-liability lawsuit against tobacco companies, seeking damages for injuries related to smoking, has failed. Nonetheless, some lawyers are now gearing up for similar cases against liquor companies.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS CUTS FARES
description: People Express Inc., in an effort to strengthen its cash flow during its slow travel season, yesterday began a three-day sale during which most of its domestic fares can be bought for half price.

title: Alcan Aluminium Names President
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., the Montreal-based aluminum giant, announced yesterday that it had named David Morton president and chief operating officer effective Jan. 1.

title: The Daniloff Affair: 4 Tense Weeks
description: Aug. 30 Nicholas S. Daniloff, correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, is detained in Moscow after being handed a package by a Soviet acquaintance containing two maps marked ''top secret.'' The arrest follows by one week the arrest in New York of Gennadi F. Zakharov, a Soviet employee of the United Nations, on charges of espionage.

title: Arnell/Bickford Gets Green Stamps Account
description: Arnell/Bickford, up to now a fashion specialty agency, has come out as the winner of a two-month competition for the $1.5 million S&H Green Stamps account of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company.

title: DOLPHINS' DEFENSE STUNG BY CRITICISM
description: By the time the Orange Bowl clock reached the final seconds, Mike Charles, the nose tackle who had just returned from a suspension, was gone from the Miami Dolphins' bench with a knee injury. Hugh Green, the linebacker who was going to spend his first full season as a Dolphin, was in the early stages of a long recovery from a fractured kneecap. John Offerdahl, the rookie inside linebacker and defensive signal caller, was on the bench, hunched forward with a back injury.

title: Encore Contract
description: The Encore Computer Corporation said it had been awarded a contract to develop a powerful parallel-processing computer architecture for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. It said the contract is worth $10.7 million over three years and calls for a prototype computer system that can execute one billion instructions a second.

title: POIGNANT WELCOME IN POLAND FOR JEWISH SCHOLARS
description: Simply put, what happened here on Tuesday was that Moshe Altbauer, who received his doctorate from Jagiellonian University 50 years ago, came here from Israel and took part in a conference on Jewish life in medieval and Renaissance Poland.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS RECORD ON FARMS
description: President Reagan, campaigning for Republicans in tight Senate races in Missouri and South Dakota, acknowledged today that farmers were still suffering but asserted that sending Democrats to Washington was not the answer.

title: Pitching In in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Spirit might be called a mixture of individualism, pragmatism and just plain neighborliness.

title: Chip Company Picks President
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., one of the world's largest semiconductor companies, said yesterday that Anthony Holbrook, chief operating officer, was given the additional title of president.

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income and the 6 months' net includes income of $74,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: The U.N. Today: Sept. 30, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.

title: FLORIDA RUNOFFS MAY SET THE STAGE FOR A CLOSE CONTEST FOR GOVERNOR
description: Runoff elections in Florida will decide the two parties' nominees for governor Tuesday and set the stage in November for what may be the Republicans' best chance to capture the statehouse in 20 years.

title: G.M.A.C. Obligations Offer Monthly Payment
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $400 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through First Boston Corporation with several unusual features, including monthly payments of principal and interest.

title: 75 Police and Guards on L.I. Search for a Missing Person
description: Searching for an 18-year-old student who has been listed as a missing person since Sunday, 75 police officers and college security guards swept across the C.W. Post College campus yesterday, the Nassau County police said.

title: What Crack Hysteria Distracts Us From
description: To the Editor:

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Net income

title: Perrier Switches From Waring to Riney
description: ''I could not wish to have done better work nor to do better for a client,'' said Saul Waring, president of Waring & LaRosa, who yesterday was wondering why he had lost the Perrier mineral water account to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco.

title: MEXICO AND BANKS MISS I.M.F. DEADLINE ON DEBT
description: Mexico and its bankers failed to meet a deadline today for agreement on a $6 billion loan for the country. But banking sources said that an agreement reached later this week would be just as good.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Petro-Lewis Weighs Moves
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation today reported a loss of $415.6 million for the fiscal year ended June 30 and said that, if an ongoing tender offer was not successful, the Denver-based oil company would seek reorganization in Bankruptcy Court.

title: SENATORS REJECT $200 MILLION RISE IN PHILIPPINE AID
description: The Senate voted 51 to 43 today against $200 million in increased economic aid to the Government of the Philippines.

title: NPS TECHNOLOGIES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hugh Franklin, 70, an Actor On Stage, Film and Television
description: Hugh Franklin, a retired stage, screen and television actor whose career spanned several decades, died of cancer Friday at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Goshen, Conn.

title: DOLLAR OFF AS ALLIES' TALKS FAIL
description: The dollar dropped in skittish trading yesterday after the major industrial nations failed to agree on coordinating economic policies.

title: FOR BANKERS, PARTIES RATE TRIPLE A
description: Picture this, if you can: The ballroom of the Sheraton Washington Hotel filled with 5,000 bankers and finance ministers from around the world sipping drinks and talking in a babble of tongues about G-3, G-5, G-7, G-10 (which is really G-11), G-24, G-77, M-1, M-2, M-3, 6 percent LIBOR, 5 percent T-bills, 2 percent spread and millions and billions and trillions.

title: OLIVER'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Albert Sabin Hospitalized With Heart Ailment
description: Albert Sabin, developer of the oral polio vaccine, was hospitalized today with a heart ailment.

title: CONGOLESE LEADER DENIES HIS AIDE EQUATED ISRAEL AND NAZI GERMANY
description: The President of Congo denied today that his Foreign Minister had equated the Government of Israel with that of Nazi Germany.

title: Sun Will Sell Trucking Unit
description: The Sun Company said it had sold its subsidiary Sun Carriers Inc. for $180 million to a group that includes Kidder, Peabody & Company; the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, and Riordan Freeman & Spogli, a Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm.

title: 2 Die as Car Rams Hotel
description: A car struck the wall of the Hotel Lake Merrit today, killing two people, and the police were seeking to find out if the car had been racing with another.

title: McAUTHOR: VERY AUDIBLE
description: Most authors promote their books by appearing on television talk shows. Others do radio interviews.

title: CAMPEAU RAISES BID FOR ALLIED
description: The Campeau Corporation yesterday raised its offer to acquire the Allied Stores Corporation by $8 a share, to $66. The amended bid, which is in cash and preferred stock, increases the proposed purchase price to $2.68 billion, from $2.47 billion.

title: G.M. STUDIES CUTS
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was reviewing the operations of the Fisher Guide division's nine American plants as part of the company's drive to reduce business costs. The unit's 28,000 employees were told that the review was being made but that G.M. had ''made no decision yet about where to reduce capacity or how much it must be reduced.'' Fisher Guide makes auto lighting, door systems, bumper systems and hardware components in plants in Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Indiana and Louisiana and in Mexico, Spain and Northern Ireland.

title: DELAY IS GRANTED IN SPY SENTENCING
description: A Federal district judge in Baltimore agreed today to delay the sentencing of John A. Walker Jr. for more than a month while prosecutors try to determine if the Navy veteran is lying about the extent and origin of his family's Soviet spy ring.

title: GODFREY COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
Anne Frank House Scene of Bomb Scare
description: A bomb scare forced a two-hour evacuation of the Anne Frank House today as the former Soviet dissident Anatoly Shcharansky was due to visit the museum, the police said.

title: Invalid, 64, Among 3 Slain In a Dallas Suburb
description: A 64-year old blind invalid, her niece and a friend were found hacked to death today with a small ax at their remote, tree-shaded house today in what the Police Chief termed a ''crime of passion or rage.''

title: One-Man Band
description: Coach Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz, on why he enrolled at a California fat farm where he lost 30 of his 300 pounds in one month: ''It's hard to be fit as a fiddle when you're shaped like a cello.''

title: AN AFRICAN VILLAGE STAGGERS UNDER THE ASSAULT OF AIDS
description: THE funeral of Mirina Nakalawa was just beginning in the compound tucked away among the matooke trees and coffee bushes. Her body had been wrapped in bark-cloth, according to local tradition, and was laid out on a bed in a small room. Beside her, the women in her family were keening softly. Outside, the men sat in the shade of a tree, some of them getting quietly drunk though it was only midmorning.
